title: News Analysis
description: The announcement by Columbia College that it will begin admitting wo men as undergraduates in the fall of 1983 not only signifies the en d of an era but also points up the sharp differences that have em erged at men's and women's colleges in attitudes toward segregatingth e sexes in education.

title: INQUIRY PRESSED INTO KILLING OF 4 LINKED TO DRUGS
description: Federal and city law-enforcement officials yesterday questioned dozens of possible witnesses and sifted large caches of drugs, weapons and money in a widening investigation of the execution-style murders of a Colombian couple and their two infant children in Queens on Saturday.

title: Armco Closing
description: Armco Inc., the nation's seventhlargest steelmaker, said it was closing its coke plant in New Miami, Ohio, on May 1, in a move that will cost 250 jobs. The closing is part of a ''comprehensive survival plan'' announced earlier last week that aims to reduce a projected loss of $20 million this year, a spokesman said. The plant is being closed because of high operating costs and a bleak outlook for coke sales, the company said.

title: Rally Protests Weapons Lab
description: A group of antinuclear protesters who plan to form a blockade at Lawrence Livermore Laboratory tomorrow began their two-day, 45-mile trek to the weapons laboratory with a rally in Berkeley.

title: Delmed Inc. Appoints A President and Chief
description: Peter P. Phildius, 51, has been named president and chief operating officer at Delmed Inc., a manufacturer and distributor of plastic disposable products for hospitals and in-home patients and systems for collecting and processing blood. He succeeds Amin J. Khoury, 42, who continues as chairman and chief executive of the publicly owned company based in Canton, Mass.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1982
description: International P oles fought with the police in Gdansk in vio lent clashes in which more than 200 people were arrested and 14 inj ured, the Warsaw radio said. The fighting broke out despite official appeals for calm on theeve of new food price increases. The governin g military council ordered a stricter curfew in Gdansk aimed at clearing the streets from 10 P.M. to 5 A.M. It also suspended all public entertainment andsports and banned private cars from the roads . (Page A1, Column 6.) U.S. military aid to Egypt and Israel would be increased by the Reagan Administration. Congress will be asked to increase Egypt's allotment by $400 million and Israel's by $300 million in the next fiscal year, Administration and diplomatic sources said. (A1:4.)

title: Delayed Flight
description: Half a dozen of the American jumpers who competed this weekend at Lake Placid, N.Y., to qualify for the United States ski team that will compete in the 70- and 90-meter world championships on Feb. 28 in Yugoslavia received an exotic form of training assistance last week in Buffalo.

title: ISRAEL DICKHOLTZ
description: Israel Dickholtz, who operated the Dick Coffee Company at 414 West 42d Street for almost 45 years, died Saturday at the Parkway General Hospital in North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: ROSENBAU M, 'A ROCKEFELLER REPUBLICAN,' SEEKING GOVERNORSHIP
description: The lights gleamed on Richard M. Rosenbaum at the Republican Party's 1976 national convention, where he was the focus of conservative hostility. He was Nelson A. Rockefeller's New York State party chairman - personally picked - a leader in the successful fight to deny the party's Presidential nomination to Ronald Reagan.

title: Bus Accident Injures 29 Skiers
description: Twenty-nine persons were injured when a bus carrying a load of skiers from New York City overturned in this Delaware County village, the state police said.

title: News Analysis
description: The debate over President Reagan's ''new federalism initiative'' has quickly shifted from the lofty realm of political philosophy to a more mundane concern over money. Although Reagan Administration officials said there would be ''no winners or losers,'' mayors and governors said they feared they would lose millions of dollars when programs were ''swapped'' and ''turned back'' by the Federal Government.

title: Reagan to Get Medal for 'Courageous Leadership'
description: Since it was first given in 1965 to recognize ''courageous leadership in governmental, civic and humanitarian affairs,'' the Charles Evans Hughes Gold Medal of the National Conference of Christians and Jews has been awarded to two Supreme Court Justices, two Secretaries of State and three former Presidents, but never to an incumbent President.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
From Pins to Pin-Ups
description: Although it sometimes is strangely loath to admit it, the Ladies Professional Golf Association has something to attract spectators that the men's golf tour does not: many of the young ladies on the L.P.G.A. tour are nice to look at. Some of them are even sexy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm not going to be a designated assassin who just comes off the bench to fight.'' - Paul Mulvey, Los Angeles Kings player who refused to enter a hockey brawl as ordered by coach. (C1:1.)

title: Baker International
description: Baker International, an American oil company, is raising a 10-year, zero-coupon Eurobond for a nominal $225 million, one of the lead managers, the Goldman Sachs International Corporation, said Friday. Priced at 24.70 percent, the bond yields 15.01 percent annually, it added.

title: PAYOFF FOR REPRESSION
description: The U.S. Government last week decided in secret to pay $70 million a month to American banks unable to collect loans to Poland, despite rules of the Commodity Credit Corporation that require the debtor first be declared in default.

title: PROFITS FALL OVER BROAD SPECTRUM
description: The nation's sagging economy, high interest rates, and a strong dollar depressed earnings for a broad range of American companies during the fourth quarter of 1981, according to year-end reports issued so far.

title: Bridge: Alvin Roth Rejoins Action After 3 Years on Sidelines
description: One of the world's greatest players plans to return to competition this year, which is good news for the kibitzers but bad news for his opponents.

title: No Headline
description: GEORGETOWN ROUTS ST. JOHN'S

title: No Headline
description: Lendl, in Four Sets, Defeats McNamara

title: SOVIET SAID TO SEEK PAYMENT DELAY
description: The Soviet Union, in a strong indication that it faces a shortage of hard currency reserves, has asked several West German and Japanese companies in recent weeks for permission to stretch out payments for goods that have already been shipped, it was reported today.

title: Chargers' Choice Going to Packers
description: The Green Bay Packers confirmed today that they will get the San Diego Chargers' first-round choice in this spring's draft as part of the deal last fall for the wide receiver John Jefferson.

title: Hartford Ending A Jobless Program
description: HARTFORD (AP) - State officials say that, starting Tuesday, it will become harder to match unemployed people with jobs, because Federal budget cuts are making it necessary to disconnect a computerized job-placement system.

title: MORE ALLIANCE TROUBLE?
description: President Reagan's budget message will disclose his decision to go ahead with a new family of weapons that have a curious feature. They cannot be deployed in the theater for which they are intended.

title: Eileen Kiel Joins Grey Lyon & King
description: Eileen Kiel has joined Grey Lyon & King, a subsidiary of Grey Advertising, as management supervisor of its new book publishing division.

title: Craig Parker Dies at Age 55; Popular Vermont Announcer
description: Craig (Rusty) Parker, for decades one of Vermont's most popular radio personalities, died today, two days after suffering a heart attack while broadcasting a news report.

title: UNCERTAIN REACTION AWAITS NEW ISSUES
description: This is an exceptionally full week for the credit markets, and uncertainty surrounding short-term interest rates and Federal Reserve monetary policy has increased the perceived risk of buying and distributing the $20 billion of Treasury bills, notes and bonds due out this week.

title: Armed Veteran Takes Nurse Hostage in Protest
description: A Vietnam-era veteran protesting the treatment of his comrades at Veterans Administration hospitals stormed into an emergency room with a shotgun and held a nurse hostage for more than two hours today.

title: Mary T. Meagher Excels in Butterfly
description: Mary T. Meagher of Louisville, Ky., stood alone in her specialty, the butterfly, and Birgit Meinecke of East Germany dominated other events as the three-day Swedish International Swim Games came to a close tonight.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Le Anne Schreiber A BIGAMIST'S DAUGHTER. By Alice Mc- Dermott. 282 pages. Random House. $13.50.

title: ISRAEL AGREES TO ROLE IN SINAI FORCE FOR UNITS OF 4 EUROPEAN COUNTRIES
description: Israel agreed today to accept military units of four European countries in a Sinai peacekeeping force. The decision by the Cabinet ended weeks of debate over the terms under which Britain, France, Italy and the Netherlands would participate. It also marked a successful diplomatic effort by the United States to create a broadly based force outside United Nations auspices.

title: THE PENALTY FOR NOT FIGHTING
description: A week ago, Paul Mulvey, a journeyman forward for the Los Angeles Kings, refused his coach's order to leave the bench and get into a general fight between the Kings and the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Renault Output to Rise
description: Renault, the French state-owned auto maker, plans to produce 2.5 million vehicles a year by 1985, compared with 1.81 million in 1981, its new chairman, Bernard Hanon, told a news conference Friday.

title: Menuhin Plays Bach W ith the Philharmonia
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia spent a good part of Saturday night looking at Bach as the 20th century has seen him. The rest of this concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music went to Ernest Bloch's Violin Concerto, with Yehudi Menuhin as soloist, and Bach's Concerto for Two Violins, with Mr. Menuhin and Edna Michell.

title: GAMBIA ENTERS UNION WITH SENEGAL ON WARY NOTE
description: The talk in the cafes and plazas of Dakar these days is mostly about the recently completed Paris-to-Dakar motor rally or the recently completed movie by the Senegalese film maker Ousmane Sembene.

title: Avalanche in Austria Kills 11 in Ski Group
description: An avalanche on a mountain slope near here buried a West German school group on a ski tour today, killing 11 people and leaving one missing, the police said.

title: Advertising; Policy Shift Results In A Windfall
description: house ad agency among the top advertisers, is stripping that agency of all of the advertising functions except media buying. That means that five American Home ad agencies will enjoy a multimillion-dollar windfall.

title: M.T.A. FEARS A RISE IN NEW YORK FARES
description: New Federal budget cuts expected to be announced next Monday have raised the possibility that New York's 75-cent subway and bus fare may be raised a nickel or more by this summer, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Pabst Slates Change To Garner Votes
description: The two sides in the battle for control of the financially ailing Pabst Brewing Company added to their lineups last week in efforts to sway stockholder votes at the company's annual meeting in April.

title: JAZZ: SARAH VAUGHAN AND ZOOT SIMS
description: SARAH VAUGHAN began her concert at the Beacon Theater on Friday evening, the first of two that she gave there over the weekend, by going directly into a swinging bit of scat singing, the sort of thing she might normally do later in her program. It was the kind of attention-getting device, a quick audience grabber, that an opening number should be.

title: Play on Vietnam War To Open at Westside
description: ''How I Got That Story,'' a play by Amlin Gray about a reporter covering the Vietnam War, will begin previews Feb. 10 and open Feb. 17 at the Westside Arts Theater, 407 West 43d Street.

title: Sharp Shooting, Tight Defense Help Iowa to Lead Big Ten
description: Michigan State and Ohio State were not supposed to give the top basketball teams in the Big Ten Conference too much trouble this season. But Iowa, the conference leader, has had so much difficulty with that pair in recent seasons that the 57-56 victory at Michigan State last Thursday and the 76-66 victory last Saturday over Ohio State at Iowa were major successes for Coach Lute Olson.

title: GARMENT DISTRICT BEGINS A PROGRAM TO CUT THEFTS
description: Thefts in New York City's garment district, home of a multibillion-dollar industry, soared 22.6 percent last year, and the industry has started a self-help security program led by the city's former top uniformed police commander.

title: Idil Biret, Pianist, Plays Boulez and Liszt
description: Idil Biret is apparently one of those pianists who are capable of memorizing and playing almost anything. The demonstration of her prowess at the Abraham Goodman House on Tuesday centered on Pierre Boulez's Sonata No. 2, a formidable post-Webern composition dating from 1948 that, even now, only a handful of pianists will attempt to play with the notes before them.

title: Setzer and Miss Adezio In Violin-Piano Recital
description: The first part of the recital given by the violinist Philip Setzer and the pianist Antonia Adezio in Carnegie Recital Hall last Tuesday had a curiously uninspired quality. But that was partly in contrast with the unmistakably inspired performance of Prokofieff's First Sonata in the second half of the program.

title: Porsche Drivers First at Daytona
description: The team of Rolf Stommelen of West Germany and John Paul and John Paul Jr. of Lawrenceville, Ga., won the Daytona 24-Hour Pepsi Challenge in record time today, continuing the domination of American sports car racing in recent years by the Porsche Turbo 935's. The German- built 935's have won six straight 24-hour races at Daytona, with Stommelen co-driving in three of those triumphs.

title: ITALIAN TELLS HOW DOZIER WAS FREED
description: The head of the provincial government in Verona, which is conducting the inquiry into the abduction of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, said Saturday that the police were not certain before the rescue that that the general was being detained in the apartment from which he was freed on Thursday.

title: 'PLAYING GOD'
description: In general, Americans have a positive attitude toward technology. A study recently published by the National Science Foundation reports that the use of science is favored to increase life expectancy, discover intelligent beings in outer space, modify weather, and even detect criminal tendencies in young children. But when it comes to genetic engineering, many people still take a deep breath.

title: COAST GUARD ACADEMY FACING CUTS
description: By sixth grade, Andrew J. Connolly knew he wanted to attend the United States Coast Guard Academy here. He grew up imagining the Coast Guard band performing, the cutters sliding down the Thames River on training maneuvers and the cadets marching in procession.

title: A TALK WITH MUBARAK
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt that was conducted in Cairo on Jan. 20. Parts of this interview were broadcast that day by NBC News, which provided the transcript.

title: CHANGE IN THE TAX LAW: THE BENEFITS ARE BROAD
description: This year there is a special incentive to get out pencil and calculator and figure one's taxes early. Because of the 1981 tax law, as well as legislation that was passed in 1980, many people will owe less Federal income tax than before. Many may wind up with refunds, instead of owing money to the Government on April 15. The newest legislation, the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, provides for a dramatic cut in income tax rates over a four-year period. The first phase, which took effect Oct. 1, reduced individual tax rates by 5 percent across the board. This reduction for the final quarter of 1981 has been translated into a tax credit of 1.25 percent that is built into the tax tables accompanying one's return for the whole year. The result will be modest, trimming taxes by only a few hundred dollars, at most, for people in the upper brackets.

title: Erika Hess Takes Ski Event
description: On a sloppy slalom course that was chemically treated to harden the rain-soaked snow, Erika Hess, Perrine Pelen and Christin Cooper claimed the first medals today at the world Alpine skiing championships.

title: Benitez Shows New Maturity in Victory
description: The Roberto Duran saga has ended, but the greening of Wilfred Benitez may be just beginning. Only hours after the 30-year-old Duran had been beaten by a younger, taller, stronger, and fitter rival, Carlos Eleta, his manager and mentor, said: ''I think I will retire him. The time has come.''

title: Oilers Beat Flyers
description: Wayne Gretzky, moving closer to another National Hockey League record, scored three goals and assisted on two others tonight as he led the Edmonton Oilers to a 7-4 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: 3 ROOKIES ENJOY ALL-STAR ROLE
description: Buck Williams, the voracious rebounding forward of the host Nets, was thinking of completing his junior season at Maryland. And Isiah Thomas, the affable playmaker, was a sophomore beginning to help Indiana surge toward the national collegiate title.

title: Flood, and Leak, at the Pen tagon
description: The reason for the recent lie-detector tizzy at the Pentagon was that someone dared to whisper the true cost of the Administration's undiscriminating military strategy: not the staggering $1.5 trillion already budgeted for the next five years, but perhaps $2.2 trillion. Defense Secretary Weinberger scoffed at the leaked ''wish list'' of his generals and admirals. To the Joint Chiefs, however, the arms and forces they seek are ''requirements'' if the President will not redefine their military mission.

title: 2 REAGAN AIDES BACK FED ACTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration moved today to ease tensions with the Federal Reserve Board over the conduct of monetary policy when two Cabinet officers praised Fed actions as having contributed to cutting the inflation rate by a quarter last year.

title: Roslyn Reiser Is Married to Cantor Paul Zimelman
description: Roslyn Reiser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Reiser of Forest Hills, Queens, and Paul Zimelman, son of Mrs. Samuel Zimelman of New York, were married yesterday afternoon at the Park Avenue Synagogue. Rabbi Sidney Zimelman and Cantor Sol Zim, the bridegroom's brothers, performed the ceremony.

title: India and Pakistan Agree To Set Up Panel on Ties
description: Foreign Minister Agha Shahi of Pakistan accepted an Indian proposal today to establish a joint commission on relations between the two countries, an Indian Government spokesman said.

title: Magazine Quits Auditing Body
description: Scientific American magazine has resigned from membership in the Audit Bureau of Circulation, one of the most important organizations in the print advertising field. Even the two publishers who have been the magazine's supporters consider it a bad move.

title: EAST TOPS WEST, 120-118, AS CELTIC PLAYERS EXCEL
description: The National Basketball Association All-Star Game took on a different look today. In addition to the usual East-West confrontation, the Celtic connection beat the Laker connection, 120-118, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Leak Curtails Nigeria's Oil
description: Nigeria's oil production has been cut 20 percent because part of the main pipeline to the export terminal at Forcados has been shut down to repair a leak found early last week, a spokesman for Shell International said, adding that it would take ''a couple of weeks'' to fix the line.

title: Miller Wins by One After Nicklaus's 64
description: It was Johnny Miller's tournament, but it was Jack Nicklaus's show. Miller, for 12 years one of the outstanding players on the tour, halted a challenge from Nicklaus today to win the San Diego Open by one stroke.

title: PITCHING CAMP FOR SUMMER IN A BASEMENT GYM IN JANUARY
description: In the name of summer's fresh air and the great outdoors, 3,000 children and parents jammed into a stuffy basement gymnasium yesterday, milling among almost 100 cubicles to see and hear the sales pitches of summer camps as close as the nearest park or as far away as China.

title: HARBOR CONTROL PLAN TO END BECAUSE OF U.S. BUDGET CUTS
description: Because of Federal budget restraints, a Coast Guard vessel-control plan heralded in 1976 as a way to bring New York harbor ''into the computer age by 1978'' is facing a shutdown without ever having gone into full operation.

title: THE COLD GIVES A LIFT TO DOWN PRODUCTS
description: The down business is up. Thanks to the bitter Canadian winter weather blowing south to the United States, Canada's makers of down winterwear, major suppliers for the American market, are reporting surprisingly good sales despite the recession and record high world prices for the little puffs of feathers.

title: Swap? Or Swindle?
description: The salesmen for President Reagan's new fed eralism need a refreshercourse in politics. Messrs. Meese and Stockma n say poor people have amassed such political power, particularly in the South, that they shouldn't fear state takeover of welfare and food stamps. Are they kidding?

title: Carolyn Friedman Married To Michael F. Paltrowitz
description: Carolyn Friedman, corporate marketing manager of Faberge Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to Michael Francis Paltrowitz, president of the Renee division of Shalom International, a jewelry company in New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David Kahane at the Sutton Place Synagogue.

title: TO JOIN THE CAR RACE
description: Volkswagen of Wolfsburg, West G ermany, is whizzing past General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler of D etroit in the race to develop the world's next generation of f uelefficient automobiles.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ARTISTS ON PARADE

title: Robbers Kill Man On the West Side
description: The 45-year-old superintendent of an Upper West Side apartment house was shot to death Saturday night by two men in an attempted robbery, the police said.

title: Terrorist Sentenced in Israel
description: An Israeli military court sentenced a Palestinian terrorist to life imprisonment today for murdering three West Bank Arabs and throwing a grenade at an Israeli bus, a military spokesman said.

title: DANCE JAZZY 'THIN ICE' BY ANDREW deGROAT
description: A CONCERT by Andrew deGroat and Dancers on Friday began in disarray and ended in disappointment. But what came between was worth the rest.

title: PAINTING AND 'LIFE REVIEW' PROCESS
description: P ICTURES that Desid er Lustig, 81 years old, paints usually contain the image of a violin. Pat Annunziato, who wa s born in 1911, depicts boats in his work. Mollie Collins, 94, paints in abstract symbols the extended family of her youth, including f ifth cousins.

title: ADMINISTRATION TRYING TO RECONCILE SCIENTIFIC AND SECURITY INTERESTS
description: Intensive efforts are being made here to reach a compromise under which American technical and scientific data that are unclassified but of potential military and industrial value can be kept from the Soviet Union and other foreign nations without destroying freedom of communication in scientific research.

title: FALLING IN LOVE WITH SLED DOG RACING
description: dog racer, although it verges on being an impossible dream. The urge was triggered by observing the ALPO International Sled Dog races held here over the weekend. At the close, Peter Norberg of Tuktoyaktuk, Northwest Territories, had won the unlimited event (seven dogs or more), Doug McRae of Rhinelander, Wis., the seven-dog competition, and Dan Larkin of Buena Vista, Colo., the five-dog.

title: 11th Man Out
description: Chuck Studley had vowed not to look at the films until July. But last Thursday, curiosity got the better of him and, at his home, he flipped on the projector and counted noses in the Super Bowl.

title: Fires and Arson Plague Poor Area of Baltimore
description: Seventeen fire deaths in 18 days and the burning of more than 20 vacant buildings in less than a week have exhausted the city's firefighters, caused a run on smoke detectors and created a new fear among the poor, mostly black residents of west Baltimore.

title: Meharry Medical School Finds Its 8th President
description: After a yearlong search, Meharry Medical College in Nashville has found a new president. He is Dr. David Satcher, who has been serving as chairman of the department of community medicine and family practice at the medical school of Morehouse College in Atlanta.

title: PHILHARMONIC: FROM VIENNA OF THE 1930's
description: ORCHESTRAL programs devoted to Viennese music have never been much of a rarity. Indeed, they are almost impossible to do without, especially when one considers the extent to which audiences are devoted to Viennese music. But a program centered on the music of that other Vienna -not the Vienna of Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert, or of Brahms, Bruckner and Mahler, but the Vienna of Schoenberg, Webern and Be rg - really is a rarity. For one thing, audiences aren'tso devoted to the second Viennese school as they are to the traditionthat went bef ore it; for another, many musicians aren't either.

title: Commodities; Eurodollar Acceptance Spreading
description: FEW new futures contracts have captured the interest of hedgers and traders in so short a time as Eurodollar futures. Since they started trading Dec. 10, the open interest has climbed to more than 2,400 contracts of 90 days, $1 million face value each, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's International Monetary Market. The open interest in any commodity is, in effect, the number of contracts entered into for trading.

title: Rangers Top Kings On 4-Goal 2d Period
description: Admonished by Coach Herb Brooks that they should not be lulled into a vacation mood because of the sunny weather, the Rangers worked assiduously tonight, and the result was a 6-3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings at the Forum.

title: TV: NED BEATTY IN ROLE OF BROADCAST EVANGELIST
description: ''PRAY TV'' begins with a very sly, gently satirical version of a religious variety show. ''The Freddy Stone Hour'' has an imitation stained-glass set, a saccharine-sounding chorus and an 800 number you can dial toll-free (''Call the number you see on the screen and we'll pray with you,'' an announcer declares). The show also has Freddy Stone (Ned Beatty), an enormously successful evangelist who controls the Divinity Broadcast Corporation, satellite dishes and all.

title: DON'T DOWNGRADE ART IF YOU'D UPGRADE LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: 200 AT JERSEY SCHOOL ARE SCREENED FOR MENINGITIS AFTER TEACHER DIES
description: More than 200 pupils and staff members at an elementary school in this Bergen County community were screened over the weekend for signs of bacterial meningitis after a teacher suspected of having the disease died early Saturday.

title: Bloom Gets More Libby
description: The Bloom Agency in Dallas, which already has assignments from Libby, McNeil & Libby, is getting a few more million in billings as the Chicago company removes all of its assignments from Tatham-Laird & Kudner in its home town. The new business is for beverages, pumpkin, produce products and new products.

title: CHINESE EASE TAIWAN ARMS STANCE A BIT
description: China acknowledged today that it was willing to discuss a time limit with the United States f or ending American military sales to Taiwan.

title: COAST GUARD CLIENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'STRANGE SNOW,' ECHO OF VIETNAM
description: STEVE METCALFE'S ''Strange Snow'' at the Man hattan Theater Club begins and en ds unconvincingly, and raises issues that it is unwilling to resolve, but it has a middle that bears watching. It also offers c enter stage to Dann Florek, a very talented young actor,who, as he de monstrated as the spiritualist Edgar Cayce in ''The Freak,'' can make the oddest people both believable and sympathetic.

title: Miss Friedman, Student, Married
description: Deborah Lynne Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Friedman of Atlantic Beach, L. I., was married yesterday to Mark Lawrence Cooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Cooper of Lawrence, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Sol Roth and Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A quarterback in a National Football League game crosses the line of scrimmage with the ball and then laterals back to a teammate, who is still behind the line. Is it legal for that player to throw a forward pass?

title: Lockheed Sales
description: Algeria has purchased six advancedmodel C-130H Hercules transport aircraft from the Lockheed-Georgia Company, the company announced.

title: A PIECE OF JAPAN'S CHIP MARKET
description: By the look of it, a slice of California's Silicon Valley has been transplanted here, 40 miles northeast of Tokyo. The modernistic low-slung building, the chest-high beige partitions that divide office space inside, even the landscaping, are similar to the Santa Clara, Calif., headquarters of the Intel Corporation, a leading United States semiconductor maker.

title: Britt Burns Given $1.65 Million Pact
description: Britt Burns, a 22-year-old left-hander who won 25 games in two seasons, has agreed to a three-year contract that would make him the highest-paid pitcher in Chicago White Sox history.

title: SALVAGE CREW LIFTS WRECKAGE OF JET OUT OF BOSTON HARBOR
description: A salvage crew used three mammoth cranes, big winches and heavy cables to lift the body of a World Airways DC-10 jet out of the muck of Boston Harbor today, eight days after it plunged off the end of a Logan International Airport runway.

title: Gustafsson Wins In Speed Skating
description: Tomas Gustafsson of Sweden, a 22-year-old student, won the gold medal in the European speed skating championships today with a world record of 14 minutes 23.59 seconds in the 10,000-meter event

title: WHEN IT'S A MATTER OF INTERPRETATION
description: They are the cream of the linguists, the State Department's corps of 22 diplomatic interpreters, traveling the world at the side of Presidents, ambassadors and special envoys, listening to words that make history, then delivering them instantly in another language with all the subtleties intact.

title: CELEBRATION FOR JOYCE CENTENARY
description: Following are some major events planned in the metropolitan area, Boston and Washington to mark the centenary of James Joyce's birth on Feb. 2, 1882. (Space for some is limited; all are free unless otherwise noted.) New York Tuesday. Donnell Library Center, New York Public Library, 21 West 53d Street. ''Passages from Finnegans Wake,'' 1967 film by Mary Ellen Bute. Noon. Tuesday. James Joyce Society quarterly meeting, Gotham Book Mart Gallery, 41 West 47 Street. At 8 P.M. (space limited). Tuesday. Muhlenberg Branch, New York Public Library, 209 West 23d Street. Excerpts from Virginia Woolf and Joyce read by Irene Worth (in conjunction with the Woolf-Joyce exhibition in the Berg Collection, Room 318, of the main building at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, open during library hours through June 30). At 7:30 P.M. Tuesday. Ridiculous Theatrical Company, 1 Sheridan Square. Seventh chapter of ''Finnegans Wake'' read by Bill Vehr. At 8:30 P.M. Feb. 15-21. Center for the Arts, State University campus at Purchase. Weeklong Joyce festival (subscription for all events, $20), with a talk by Leslie Fiedler, reading by Colleen Dewhurst, films, plays, songs, danc e. Reservations: (914) 253-5900. Feb. 17-April 17. Grolier Club, 47 East 60 Street. Exhibition of Joyce manus cripts, first editions, portraits. Closed Sundays and holidays.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Britt Burns to a three-year contract for an estimated $1.65 million that would make him the highest paid pitcher in the club's history.; FOOTBALL GREEN BAY (NFC) - Announced the acquisition of the San Diego Chargers' first-round choice in the N.F.L. draft for obtai ning John Jefferson, wide receiver, in a trade last fall.; HOCKEY HARTFORD (NHL) - Recalled Michel Galarneau, center, from Bingamton of the American League to replace Ron Francis, an injured center.; COLLEGE
description: Named Fred Samara men's field-events coach in track.

title: Adviser Cited At U.C.L.A.
description: Sam Gilbert, an adviser to U.C.L.A. athletes for 15 years, arranged and paid for abortions for the players' friends and helped athletes get discounts on cars, stereos and airline tickets, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: A 'Second Fiddle' Gets to Do Some Solos
description: Learning to play second fiddle to a newborn sibling is a familiar peril of childhood, but few youngsters have to face what 5-year-old Richard Francisco Thomas did last August, when his mother gave birth to triplet daughters.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 1, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ninth Emerg ency Special Session of the General A ssembly - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TANK CAR BURNS IN OHIO TOWN
description: A tank car of a derailed freight train exploded and burned today, forcing most residents of this village to briefly evacuate their homes, the authorities said. No serious injuries were reported.

title: Shutdowns Begin On Flushing IRT
description: The early-morning shutdown of the Flushing IRT subway line in Manhattan began yesterday to permit workers to upgrade the 75-yearold tunnel that takes the line under the East River into Queens.

title: France Signs a Contract To Advance Saudi Navy
description: France and Saudi Arabia signed a contract today to modernize the Saudi Navy as part of the Saudi-led buildup of Arab forces in the Persian Gulf.

title: Dances for Year of the Dog
description: Chinatown was jammed Saturday night with 165,000 revelers dancing and parading to usher in the Year of the Dog.

title: MUSIC: TRIBUTE TO MARIAN ANDERSON
description: THE Fourth of July may have its fireworks, but for Marian Anderson's birthday there were Grace Bumbry and Shirley Verrett. It was Miss Anderson's 80th; and as she sat - regal but a little frail - in her box at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, two of opera's most important sopranos sang duets and arias. A packed house roared its approval and admiration.

title: Miss Oliveros's Works Involve Her Audience
description: Pauline Oliveros's evening of music at the Paula Cooper Gallery Friday was many private internal concerts rather than a single large one. Composers in the traditional sense create musical objects and then direct the listener's attention toward them.

title: IS THAT OLD HOLLYWOOD TRADITION-THE SNEAK PREVIEW-FADING OUT?
description: By Aljean Harmetz Hollywood, Jan. 25 - For the last 50 years, sneak previews have been an important part of the process of making films. Studios have shown their not-quite-finished movies to one or two paying audiences and then used the audience's reaction to fine tune the films. But the system is now on the verge of a radical change. ''You can s till have a sneak preview on an ordinary film, but you can't do it o n any film to which attention will be paid,'' said BarryDiller, chair man of Paramount. ''Today, movies being sneaked are no longer consid ered works in progress. Judgements are made and those judgments tur n up in the press the next day.''

title: Hamilton in Top Form at Skating Championships
description: Scott Hamilton of Denver earned his second straight gold medal in men's competition at the national figure skating championships Saturday night and said it probably was his best performance in a while.

title: CHILDHOOD CANCER: HOW IT AFFECTS FAMILIES
description: Cancer in a child was once considered an almost automatic death sentence. But now that the survival rates for cancer have dramatically improved, the young survivors and their families often face a whole new set of problems -including the constant fear that the cancer will recur, marital discord of parents, the resentment of siblings and the loss of friends.

title: Studies of 25 Americans Of Letters Coming Out
description: ''American Men and Women of Letters'' will be published by Chelsea House on Washington's Birthday. The general editor of the work is Daniel Aaron, professor of English and American literature at Harvard University.

title: U.S. MARKETS NEED PROTECTION, NOT FREE TRADE
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Amity Is Urged
description: Calls for trade protectionist measures ''are louder and more shrill than they have been in 50 years,'' said Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, in a speech prepared for delivery Monday.

title: MCENROE CONQUERS CONNORS IN PRO FINAL
description: Jimmy Connors didn't have to look hard to find a reason for his 6-3, 6-3, 6-1 loss to John McEnroe today in the final of the United States Pro Indoor tennis championship. ''Flat,'' w as the way Connors described his performance. There was n o argument from his opponent. ''He was sluggish,'' McEnroe said. With the vi ctory, McEnroe thwar ted Connors's efforts to win this tournament for the fifth time and he cut Connors's lead to 9-8 in their head-to-head series.

title: POTATO CHIPS ARE NOT A JUNK FOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: JARVIS WILCOX WEDS JANE VAND ERPOEL
description: Jane Stuart VanderPoel of Oxford, Md., a sculptor and owner of The Register Mark, a greeting card company in New York, was married yesterday to Jarvis Geer Wilcox, president of the Circle Drilling Company in Lake Charles, La. The Rev. Milton H. Keene, pastor of the United Methodist Church in Oxford, Md., performed the ceremony at Coomsberry, the residence of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Lockhart in Oxford, Md. Mr. Lockhart is the bride's godfather.

title: POTVIN'S SEASON OF DESPAIR
description: THE Islanders were in Boston Garden for an afternoon game last Nov. 28, looking for their fourth victory in a row. They were in first place and felt secure. The score was tied at 1-1 late in the first period and New York was on a power-play attack.

title: Tokyo Marathon To Soviet Runner
description: Vadim Sidorov of the Soviet Union outfinished Britain's Hugh Jones in the final 600 meters and won the second Tokyo Marathon today. Bill Rodgers of the United States, running his second marathon in a week, finished 37th.

title: JOURNALISTS AND POLITICAL ADVISERS TRADE CRITICISMS ON CAMPAIGNING
description: In a rare encounter, executives and news reporters from the three television networks, politicians, academics and image-makers met at Harvard University this weekend to appraise their roles in Presidential elections, from the early primaries to election eve.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1982; International
description: The Administration agreed to repay $71 million in Polish debt without requiring that American banks declare Poland in default. Washington and the lenders feared that such a declaration would provoke Warsaw into refusing to pay much larger debts. (Page A1.)

title: 2 Killed as Cars Collide in Bronx
description: Two persons were killed early yesterday on the New England Thruway when their car collided with a second auto near Steenwick Avenue in the Eastchester section of the Bronx.

title: CO-AUTHOR OF 'MIDDLETOWN'
description: Helen Merrell Lynd, co-author of the pioneering sociological works ''Middletown'' and ''Middletown in Transition,'' died Saturday in Warren, Ohio. She was 85 years old and had lived in Manhattan until last year.

title: People
description: * Robert Neuman and F. Paul Pracilio have been elected senior vice presidents of Backer & Spielvogel Inc.

title: MARCH OF DIMES BIRTHDAY BALL CELEBRATES F.D.R.
description: The establishment, government and social, didn't turn out, and the beautiful people stayed away in droves, but the 400 men and women who did show up managed to keep a stiff upper lip. One would have thought that the absence of the movers and shakers wasn't even noticed. It might well have been interesting to hear what was said in the privacy of their bedrooms once the guests got home Saturday night, but in the Mayflower Hotel Grand Ballroom, they said nothing. Zilch.

title: Black Youths Clash With Police in England
description: Violent clashes broke out between the police and young blacks Saturday night in a Bristol suburb that was the scene of serious riots two years ago.

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN IN TV SHOW ON CRISIS IN POLA

title: SOVIET HOSPITAL SAYS PENTECOSTALIST IS TAKING FOOD
description: Soviet officials said today that a Pentecostalist hunger striker who was removed from the United States Embassy to a Moscow hospital after a monthlong hunger strike had eaten some food and was slowly regaining her strength.

title: Maple Leafs 5 Black Hawks 2
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Rick Vaive's three goals and two assists paced Toronto as Chicago's string without a victory was extended to 10 games and the Leafs moved ahead of the Hawks into fourth place in the Norris Division.

title: MORE STATES TESTING TEACHERS IN RESPONSE TO SCHOOL CRITICS
description: A growing number of states are beginning to test teachers before letting them into the classroom, in an effort to produce better teachers and counter increasing dissatisfaction with the nation's public schools.

title: GOVERNOR'S HEAD HAILS REAGAN PLAN
description: The chairman of the National Governors Association, Richard A. Snelling of Vermont, today hailed President Reagan's plan to transfer more than 40 Federal programs to state control but added that the Administration should establish a ''humane minimum standard'' of aid before turning over major welfare responsibilities.

title: Buying for Pabst Units To McCann-Erickson
description: McCann-Erickson U.S.A., which already was handling Pabst Blue Ribbon and Furstenberg beers on a full-service basis for the Pabst Brewing Company, has been assigned all broadcast time-buying for the company's other beer brands that are being handled by Ogilvy & Mather, San Francisco.

title: Washington Watch; Chip Challenge From Japan
description: WASHINGTON AS recently as three years ago, the United States was the world's leading producer of the tiny chips that are t he building blocks of computers.

title: JOB ODDS ARE AGAINST YOUNG PHILADE LPHIA BLACKS
description: It was a day like hundreds that had gone before in the young life of Debra Adams. Along snow-banked streets, she tramped from door to door, from store to store, seeking the elusive warmth of a smile and two words that she had not heard for more than two years: ''You're hired.''

title: Fatal Fire Linked To Oxygen Leak
description: A man and his son were killed in a flash fire that was triggered by oxygen leaking from a tank, authorities said.

title: THE CITY
description: The proprietor of a used-clothing store on the Lower East Side was shot in the head by two robbers - a man and a woman, the police said.

title: H ead Named At Associated Madison Cos.
description: Joseph Fafian Jr., 42 years old, president of the National Benefit Life Insurance Company, has been elected to the additional post of president and chief operating officer of Associated Madison Companies, National Benefit's parent and owner of two other insurance companies.

title: Market Place; Lease Problem For Outlet
description: TRADERS fearing that the Outlet Company will not be included in the Coca-Cola purchase of Columbia Pictures Industries hammered the stock mercilessly last week.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK SAYS SHE HEARS 'WHISPERS' OVER U.S. JEWS AT U.N.
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick says she has heard ''whispers'' from other delegations voicing ''concern about Jewish influence'' within the mission she heads here.

title: Storm Kills 3 in Fiji
description: Three people were reported dead today in the aftermath of a storm that brought serious flooding and galeforce winds to the islands. Two men were swept away in floods and drowned, and an electricity worker was electrocuted while repairing a line brought down by the winds, officials said.

title: BRIEFING
description: A FTER 10 years of doing battle with the Government's Environmental Protection Agency, lawyers and scientists at the Natural Resources Defense Council have suddenly taken mercy on their adversaries and published an ''open letter'' to E.P.A. staff members with the message: ''Don't Give Up.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * ABKO Properties Inc., Wichita, Kan., has appointed Corliss J. Nelson president, and S.H. Cammett Jr. executive vice president-real estate operations.

title: PERILED ETHIOPIANS CAN STILL STAY HERE
description: To the Editor:

title: 205 HELD, 14 HURT IN POLISH PROTEST ON PRICE INCREASES
description: More than 200 people were arrested and 14 were injured in violent weekend clashes with the police in Gdansk, the Warsaw radio said today. There have been repeated calls in the last week for strikes and pr otests against higher food prices scheduled to take effect Monday fr om underground resistance groups, particularly in Gdansk, the bi rthplace of the Solidarity union.

title: SALVADOR TROOPS ARE LINKED TO THE KILLING OF 19 CIVILIANS
description: Armed men in uniforms routed 19 civilians from their homes in a San Salvador suburb early today, then shot them to death, according to relatives, who identified the assailants as Government troops.

title: REAGAN TO OFFER ISRAEL AND EGYPT MORE MILITARY AID
description: The Reagan Administration plans to ask Congress to increase military aid to Egypt by $400 million and to Israel by $300 million in the next fiscal year, Administration officials and diplomatic sources said today.

title: Miss Stacy Wins Playoff
description: Hollis Stacy sank a 6-foot birdie putt on the fifth hole of a sudden-death playoff today to defeat JoAnne Carner and win the $125,000 Championship of Deer Creek.

title: JAMES T. CASSERLY
description: James T. Casserly, corporate secretary of Merrill Lynch & Company, died Saturday at his home in Fanwood, N.J. He was 60 years old. Mr. Casserly, who was also a vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, was with the brokerage concern for more than 20 years.

title: 4 BIG DAYS ARRIVE FOR TREASURY
description: The Treasury dominates this week's calendar of new debt securities, with auctions every day but Friday. Besides $10 billion of new three- and six-month Treasury bills, there are sales of $5 billion of three-year notes, $2.5 billion of ten-year notes and $2.5 billion of 14 percent bonds due in 2011.

title: ATLANTA TRIAL PROSECUTION LIKELY TO STRESS FIBERS AND BLOODSTAINS
description: Prosecutors, beginning what may be the last week of their double murder case against Wayne B. Williams, are expected to use analyses of fibers and bloodstains to forge the final links between the defendant and 10 other victims among Atlanta's 28 missing and murdered young blacks.

title: 3 Seized in Yonkers Slaying
description: Three Yonkers teen-agers were arrested over the weekend and charged with murder in the stabbing death Friday of the son of a Yonkers police officer. The suspects, John Maida, 17 years old, Ronsdell Washington, 18, and Jessie Stinson, 16, were charged with second-degree murder in the slaying of Gregory Vance, 24, the police said.

title: NEEDED: A LEADER FOR THE JOINT CHIEFS
description: The subtle, intricate maneuvering in what a senior military officer calls ''the most sensitive of all ballgames in this town'' has the rumor circuits overheating here. The prize: Appointment as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the top milit ary officer in the nation. The incumbent, Gen. David C. Jones of the Air Force, must retire in June when he will have served two terms of two years. Under the law, he cannot succeed himself.

title: The 'Key Stuff' on China From an Expert
description: Few Americans have experienced as much of China as Sidney Rittenberg, who remained there for 34 years after leaving the Army in World War II.

title: HOW A LONDON THEATER CHEATED THE WRECKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Montana Calling
description: On Super Bowl Sunday, John Miller paid for one of the most expensive personal messages of all time. The president of Waterford Crystal took a full page advertisement in The New York Times Sunday magazine, displaying one of its crystal bowls filled with roses. Beneath the ad, Mr. Miller requested that the winning quarterback in the Super Bowl call to claim the Victory Bowl of Roses. A California telephone number was listed.

title: Condition of RFH Mine Shocks Kentucky Official
description: The coal mine where seven men died in an explosion Jan. 20 was in such bad shape that ''I could hardly believe my eyes,'' according to Willard Stanley, the Kentucky Mines and Minerals Commissioner. He said that his tour of the RFH Coal Company mine near Craynor indicated that its owners and workers had ignored safety precautions.

title: Lambert Explains Court Absence
description: Jack Lambert, the Pittsburgh Steelers' all-pro middle linebacker, has issued a published statement denying that he shirked his duty by failing to appear to testify in a murder trial.

title: Marian McPartland Sets Concert With Pro Arte
description: Marian McPartland, the jazz pianist, will play her own compositions with the New York Pro Arte Chamber Orchestra on Feb. 16 at 8 P.M. at the Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street.

title: Aide Says Iran Will Continue Rationing of Essential Goods
description: Iran will continue to ration essential goods, including food and fuel, in order to save hard currency, Iran's Minister of State for Executive Affairs said today.

title: What Price College Sports?
description: It's getting a little ridiculous: A Federal judge enjoins the University of Minnesota from barring its leading scorer from the basketball team because of bad grades. The judge rules that the young man was recruited for athletic, not academic, prowess.

title: Regrouping for the Drug War
description: Attorney General William French Smith deserves credit for abandoning plans to merge the Drug Enforcement Administration with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He will keep the two agencies separate but give William Webster, the F.B.I. Director, authority over both.

title: Cierpinski Victor
description: Waldemar Cierpinski of East Germany scored an easy victory in the first Manila International Marathon today. Cierpinski, the favorite, completed the 26-mile-385-yard race in 2 hours 14 minutes 27 seconds.

title: G.O.P. FAVORING CALIFORNIA VOTE TO RECALL JUDGE
description: The California Republican Convention adopted a resolution today that moved it a step closer to a recall drive against Chief Justice Rose Bird of the California Supreme Court.

title: MUSIC: NED ROREM IS PIANIST IN PROGRAM OF HIS SONGS AT Y
description: LIKE the paintings of Andrew Wyeth, the songs of Ned Rorem deal with familiar images in a distinctive and sometimes disturbing way, combining intensity and accessibility in a way that can leave a vivid imprint on the imagination. Many of the songs achieve their point with surprising simplicity of means, which often adds to their impact. All are models of craft and construction, thanks to Mr. Rorem's remarkable sense for the turning points in the poems he sets and his ability to evoke a rising tide of emotion in the way he sets them.

title: Miss Pollack Bride of Dr. L. E. Maliver
description: Deborah Sarah Pollack and Dr. Leonard Eric Maliver were married yesterday at the Forest Hills Jewish Center. Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik performed the ceremony.

title: Egyptian Oil Discovery
description: Egypt's oil minister, Ahmed Ezzedin Hilal, has announced an oil discovery in the Western Desert made by Shell Winning, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Shell Oil Company. Industry sources reported the well, in the Badreddin concession, 220 miles west of Cairo, was producing 6,000 barrels a day.

title: A CHICKEN AND A BIRD
description: Star Game, the players never seem to be sweating. They do, of course, but mostly, they appear to be doing a sneaker commercial. And yesterday at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the only all-star wearing green sneakers, Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics, needed only one take - the last 6 minutes and 48 seconds.

title: West Virginia Gas Explosion
description: An explosion destroyed a printshop and damaged 100 other buildings today.

title: Berkey Hires Mann For All Its Business
description: The Berkey Marketing Companies, a subsidiary of Berkey Photo that sells imported Japanese and German photographic equipment, has hired David H. Mann to do the all of the advertising that was previously being handled by four agencies.

title: News Analysis; RECESSION IS NEW CENTRAL AMERICAN PERIL
description: The world recession has created potentially greater obstacles for political stability in Central America than the extremist violence affecting much of the region, according to many experts on the area.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline in the sports section of some editions of Saturday's paper incorrectly identified the postion to which the Giants had named Ron Erhardt. He will be the team's offensive coordinator.

title: HOUSE IS STARTING HEARINGS ON C.I.A.
description: The House Intelligence Committee will begin closed hearings Tuesday on the Central Intelligence Agency's investigation of its possible links to two former agents who sold their services to Libya.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: A DEBATE IN BLOSSOM
description: Shades of Everett McKinley Dirksen! The great flower debate is on again in Congress. Unlike years past, the debate so far has been somewhat low-key. The sole candidates for designation as the national flower are the sunflower, the marigold and the Shasta daisy.

title: Developing Profit from Ko dak
description: A new amateur camera line from the Eastman Kodak Company, a development that periodically sweeps across the photograhy industry like a monsoon rain hitting Asia, is due to be introduced on Wednesday, just about on schedule.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in some editions on Saturday incorrectly described the circum- stances of Franklin D. Roosevelt's election as Governor of New York in 1928. He won a two-year term in a regularly scheduled election.

title: LOWERY'S KICK LIFTS A.F.C. TO VICTORY
description: Nick Lowery of Kansas City kicked a 23-yard field goal with three seconds remaining today to give the American Football Conference a 16-13 Pro Bowl victory over the National Conference.

title: 10 Seized on L.I.  In Betting Case
description: Ten persons have been arrested in connection with a betting ring that operated in three Long Island communities, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Sports World Specials; Always a Big Hit
description: At tonight's second annual Thurman Munson Award Dinner, sponsored by the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, it is appropriate that among those receiving awards will be at least one former catcher who hit the long ball when he played more than 60 years ago.

title: ISLANDERS' FATHER FIGURE
description: BECAUSE he is the biggest man on the New York Islanders, Clark Gillies sometimes feels the pressure to be an enforcer. The pressure comes mostly from the fans, who expect the 6-foot-3-inch, 215-pound man with the dark beard to keep order with his hands and elbows.

title: BLUES SINGER AND GUITARIST
description: Sam (Lightnin') Hopkins, one of the great country blues singers and perhaps the greatest single influence on rock guitar players, died Saturday in Houston, where he made his home. He would have been 70 years old next month.

title: DEFAULT AVOIDED
description: The Administration has decided to repay $71 million that Poland owes to American banks. But the Government, which had guaranteed the loans, did not require the banks to declare Poland in default.

title: CAPITAL-BUDGETING
description: The Government must turn its attention to the national infrastructure - highways, sewers, ports, bridges, water systems - if the economy is to expand.

title: SOLARZ'S PRESCRIPTION FROM DR. JOHNSON
description: To the Editor:

title: States' Justices Oppose Curb on Federal Courts
description: The chief judges of the highest state courts in the country have voted to oppose pending Federal legislation that would strip the Federal courts of jurisdiction over a number of issues and give exclusive jurisdiction to the state courts.

title: INJURY CASTS SHADOW OVER MELNYK'S GOLFING CAREER
description: Deep in concentration, Steve Melnyk stepped off the practice green of the Phoenix Country Club onto the smoothly paved border. His spiked shoes slid out from under him and he fell heavily, fracturing his right elbow.

title: WHAT'S 'AMID' ISRAEL?
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $662,000 tax credit...C-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday on the marriage of Roslyn Reiser to Paul Zimelman incorrectly identified the bridegroom's professional affiliation. He is a concert tenor known professional ly as Paul Zim and former ca ntor of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in New York.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr ot Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $2 million, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of part of the company's investment in Extel Corp; C-After a $9.4 million writedown in the book value of Book Digest Magazine

title: GOVERNOR KOCH-IN SPITE OF HISTORICAL ODDS
description: To the Editor:

title: CASTLE & COOKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
St. Regis Unit Sets Newspapers Sale
description: The St. Regis Paper Company said that its British subsidiary, St. Regis International Ltd., had agreed to sell its newspaper operation to Reed International Ltd. for about $13.3 million.

title: More on Slayton's Retirement
description: A follow-up: The forthcoming retirement from the space program of Donald K. (Deke) Slayton, announced last week, may not be entirely voluntary.

title: PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: The Japan External Trade Organization, in another move to ease trade friction with the West, today established a committee to deal with foreigners' complaints about impediments to trade with Japan.

title: PRESS CURBS URGED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A system for licensing journalists in South Africa was proposed today by an official commission that said it was necessary to thwart a Soviet campaign of ''disinformation'' for ''the political and moral subversion of the white man.''

title: 3D MAJOR SNOWSTORM STUNS MIDDLE WEST
description: The third major storm of the season stunned the long-suffering Middle West yesterday before plodding across western Pennsylvania and New York into New England, leaving behind paralyzing snow drifts, darkened homes, closed schools, eerily empty business districts, icy flood waters and death.

title: EARNINGS;
description: The Lockheed Corporation said yesterday that it lost $360.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1981, mainly because it took a $412 million accounting loss for discontinuing its uprofitable commercial aircraft business.

title: MAINE PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wheelabrator
description: Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. said it had bought 390 coal cars and a coal unloading terminal at Southwestern Public Service Company's new Tolk power station in Muleshoe, Tex., in a transaction valued at about $47 million. Wheelabrator also owns and operates the coal handling systems at two other Texas power plants, a company official said.

title: Carolyn Adams Leaving Paul Taylor Dancers
description: Carolyn Adams, one of the best-known interpreters of the work of Paul Taylor, will retire from the Paul Taylor Dance Company after its spring season at the City Center-55th Street Theater.

title: U.S. Steel Lists Marathon Cost
description: The United States Steel Corp oration said the cost of its planned takeover of the Marathon Oil Company amounts to an estimated $3.77 billion.

title: S.A.S. TAKES OFF THE GLOVES
description: Last year, every employee of the Scandinavian Airlines System was given a 50-page booklet with a bold red cover, printed in large type and illustrated with cartoons. At first glance, it looked like a comic book, or a perhaps a child's coloring book.

title: DELUXE CHECK PRINTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
E.P.A. ASKING A VOLUNTARY CLEANUP OF CHEMICALS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would give those responsible for abandoned hazardous waste dumps an opportunity to clean them up voluntarily before the agency undertook Federal remedial action.

title: ALLIED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEMOCRATS STAGE A ROOSEVELT RALLY
description: The Democratic National Committee assembled several hundred Democrats, including most of those considered Presidential contenders for 1984, here last night to celebrate the centennial of Franklin Delano Roosevelt's birth by denouncing the Republicans, and especially President Reagan.

title: Victims' Relatives Fear Reprisals in Salvador
description: Relatives of the 19 people reportedly killed by army troops in a San Salvador slum Sunday refused to press charges today against the soldiers for fear of Government reprisals, judicial authorities said.

title: TV: STORY BY VONNEGUT AND A ROB REINER FILM
description: IN ''Who Am I This Time?'' a premise - and not a terribly inventive one, at that - masquerades as an hourlong drama. That's the plight of many television dramas, but in this case it's particularly unfortunate because so much talent is dissipated on materia l that can't support the weight of the efforts.

title: PACCAR INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock divd declared in Dec 1981

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * E.F. Hutton Credit Corporation said that it had signed a $30 million revolving credit facility with a syndicate of international banks headed by S.G. Warburg & Company.

title: Subsidy Plan Is Rejected
description: The White House has rejected plans to grant Government subsidies for production of four materials critical to the defense industry, the budget director, David A. Stockman, said today.

title: Repeat Ads Said to Get As Much Readership
description: It may not be a conclusion you would come to about print advertising if you were just sitting there trying to analyze it, but research shows that the same ad repeated in the same publication, ''on average,'' gets just as much readership the second time around.

title: A 7TH -GRADE CLASS IS A STAGE FOR ONE-AC T PLAY BY O'NEILL
description: Raising their hands hesitantly, fewer than a third of the seventh graders indicated they had ever heard of Eugene O'Neill when the two-hour class began at the O. Henry School in lower Manhattan.

title: Industry Assailed Over Acid Rain
description: Power companies have the technology to eliminate most acid rain but are not doing anything about it, a researcher says.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Cardox Corp. subsidiary to a unit of Liquid Air Corp. for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: A listing yesterday of events for the James Joyce centenary gave an incorrect date for a reading by Irene Worth at the Muhlenberg branch of the New York Public Library. It took place last night.

title: RAYCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $6.8 million British tax credit; yr-ago results reflect changes in accounting for foreign currency translations and compensated absences

title: COMMONWEALTH TELEPHONE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
City Investing Net Rises 8.3%
description: The City Investing Company reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 increased 8.3 percent, to $23.6 million, or 64 cents a share, from $21.8 million, or 59 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues increased 7.2 percent, to $1.49 billion, from $1.39 billion.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After pretax foreign exchange losses of $3.4 million for the qr and $21.6 forthe yr...C-After pretax foreign exchange losses of $2.1 for the qr and $3.9 forthe yr; 1981 net income is after a $14 million pretax provision for losses fromthe decision to discontinue the unprofitable adhesive tape business and certaincomponents of the company's footwear operations

title: GATX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Briton Indicted In Weapons Case
description: A 27-year-old British citizen, Paul John Arthur, was indicted on weapons charges in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: CURIOUSER AND CURIOUSER
description: Last Friday, the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board - a mayoral body whose purpose is to spark development in areas where economic activity is moribund - held a meeting at which it once again seemed determined to demonstrate that whoever it represents, it is someone other than the taxpayer.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Saudi Imports A t $32 Billion
description: Saudi Arabia, which has a population of about 8 million, imported goods valued at $32.2 billion in the last Islamic calendar year, the Saudi Ministry of Finance and National Economy reported today.

title: CHOOSING FILING STATUS: THE KEY TO TAX RATE
description: Your Taxes A Guide to Preparing 1982 Returns Second of 12 articles. By DEBORAH RANKIN

title: ADIOS, ROBERTO
description: AT a festival in Panama once, Roberto Duran was strutting around, as he always did, with the sneer of a buccaneer. All he needed was a bandana around his black hair and a knife between his teeth. He always seemed to be daring the world to challenge him. And that day somebody did.

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including nonrecurring expenses in excess of $1.5 million incurred by prior management for a proxy contest; C-Net income

title: Chopping Off Census Fingers
description: Civics Question 1: Which level of government should handle welfare, (a) the national Government or (b) the states?

title: WYNN'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $140,000 for the qr and $104,000 for the yr; 1980 results reflect revised standards for reporting foreign currency transactions

title: ALLIED TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results reflect a gain from an insurance settlement of $242,000

title: AMERICAN STANDARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: SWEDLOW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The U.N. Today; Feb. 2, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ninth Emergency Special Session of the General Assembly - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A FEDERAL COURT REVERSES RULING ON MURDER CASE
description: A Federal appeals court has reversed a ruling that Justice Burton B. Roberts improperly instructed the jury in a murder case in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Advertising; Campaign On Hotel Face Lift
description: TOMORROW, the beloved Barclay Hotel, following a $30 million facelift, will become the Hotel Inter-Continental New York to the muted drum beating of advertising supplied by Doyle Dane Bernbach and Smith/Greenland.

title: SEGREGATED ACADEMIES LOOK TO CONGRESS FOR TAX RELIEF
description: Private, all-white schools like Sumter Academy here sprang up by the hundreds across the South a decade ago, fed by the anger of white parents dead set against having their youngsters attend public school with blacks.

title: COUTURIERS ZERO IN ON THEIR STRENGTHS
description: The haute couture has left play clothes and casual wear to the ready-to-wear branch of the business. Except for a couple of pairs of very brief shorts at Christian Dior, which were more for evening than for the beach, and some Bermudas at Givenchy and a few other houses, worn with high heels, tailored jackets and hats, the emphasis was on formal day and evening clothes.

title: F.B.I. FIBER EXPERT LINKS HAIRS TO WAYNE WILLIAMS
description: A fiber expert for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that the fibers and dog hairs found on nine murdered black youths can be traced to the home or automobile of Wayne B. Williams.

title: Transit Report
description: L.I.R.R.: Of the 134 morning rush-hour trains, 25 were late and one was canceled. The longest delay, 32 minutes, occurred on the 6:22 from Speonk because of equipment trouble.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Seoul Urges North Korea To Open Its Border
description: South Korea urged North Korea today to open its border to reunite 10 million people with their families, start extensive cultural exchanges and share resources.

title: REAGAN TAX EXEMPTION BILL ASSAILED
description: The prospects of President Reagan's bill to deny tax exemptions to segregationist private schools were described as ''uncertain'' today by Senate Republicans and Democrats.

title: Steel Production Up
description: Steel production rose to 1.79 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a gain of 6.2 percent from the previous week's 1.686 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Dow Jones Net Increases 20.7%
description: Dow Jones & Company Inc., which owns The Wa ll Street Journal, Barron's and other financial news operations, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 20.7 percent f rom a year earlier.

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $33,643,000 from sale of tax benefits

title: OMNICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net income and shr earnings have been included after pro forma adjustments to reflect the net additional costs of operations as a separate entity for all periods prior to Omnicare's initial public offering in July 1981

title: Ford Shuts a Plant
description: The Ford Motor Comp any, citing a decline inauto sales, closed its St. Paul production pl ant for at least one week. About 1,400 workers were laid off in th e closing, the seventh of its kind since January 1981. Ford official s will decide later thisweek whether to reopen the plant next Monday, a company spokesman said.

title: DRAFT OF ORDER ON PRESS DISCLOSURES IS STUDIED BY WHITE HOUSE AIDES
description: A ''working draft'' of a directive that would place significant new restrictions on contacts between Government officials and news reporters on the subject of foreign policy is circulating within the Reagan Administration, White House officials said today.

title: Thomasville Furniture Promotes Two Officers
description: Frederick B. Starr, 49, has been appointed president of Thomasville Furniture Industries, one of the nation's largest wood furniture manufacturers, with $220 million in sales last year. He succeeds Lawrence E. Bish, 57, who became executive vice president and a director of Armstrong World Industries, the parent corporation.

title: Texas A & M 95
description: Claude Riley scored 38 points and grabbed 18 rebounds for Texas A & M in a Southwest Conference game.

title: Five Agencies Seek Sears Apparel Account
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has announced t he names of the five agencies that will be considered for its $30 million consolidated apparel adver tising account. They are Foote, Cone & Belding, which had one-third of the apparel business, as well as the automotive and recreation bu siness; the Leo Burnett Company, which has Sears's Allstate Insu rance; N.W. Ayer; Needham, Harper & Steers, and Tatham-Laird & Kudner.

title: REPUBLIC GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $533,000 for the qr and $787,000for the 6 mos

title: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: for the quarter and $1.9 million for the year; C-After a $1.6 million loss fromdiscontinued operations

title: PECULIAR SOVIET CLAIM TO POLISH FRIENDSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: Golden West Unit Sets Acquisition
description: World Savings and Loan Association, a unit of the Golden West Financial Corporation, announced a tentative agreement to acquire First Savings and Loan Shares Inc., a $1.3 billion savings and loan holding company that owns two ailing thrift institutions in Colorado and Kansas, in a transaction valued at about $18 million.

title: Mishaps Eliminate 3 Top Slalom Racers
description: Falls and a ski that strayed on the wrong side of a gate-flag removed three leading slalom racers from the Alpine combined event of the world ski championships today. The event had already been diminished by the absence of Phil Mahre, Ingemar Stenmark and some of the world's top downhill racers.

title: INDIA AND THE U.S.
description: Of all the major countries, India is the one whose relations with the United States have been the most baffling. The story since 1947, when India became independent, is one of mutual irritation and missed opportunities.

title: HALL, FRANK B, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated for pooling of interests and adoption of a new method of accounting for foreign currency translations

title: 2 CONNECTICUT BANKS IN $85.5 MILLION LINK
description: In a bid to maintain its position as the largest banking institution in Connecticut, the CBT Corporation, holding company of the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, announced today that it had concluded an agreement to acquire the State National Bancorp, holding company of the state's fifth-largest bank. The deal was valued at about $85.8 million.

title: FEDERAL SCREW WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including accounting gains of $288,000, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter and $405,000, or 36 cents a share, for the 6 months

title: Chamberlain Says No
description: It is not because he is 45 years old and therefore too old to return to the National Basketball Association. Instead, it is because he does not want to create any friction on the team.

title: NATIONAL DATA COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income; the revs for both 1980 periods have been restated to reflect an accounting change in calculating sales revs of equipment

title: NO VIOLATION FOUND IN D'AMATO LOANS
description: The Justice Department said today that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato had not violated Federal laws in obtaining $130,000 in loans for his 1980 campaign and that it had closed its investigation of the New York Republican.

title: Suit Planned on Young
description: Hoping to prevent its sports columnist, Dick Young, from joining the staff of The New York Post in a similar capacity, The Daily News announced it would take legal action to keep him. ''Under the contract, he is clearly barred from writing for the Post,'' said Michael J. O'Neill, editor and executive vice pres ident of The Daily News, adding that Young's contract with the p aper runs to 1984.

title: U.S. VOWS TO SEEK POLISH REPAYMENT
description: The State Department said today that the United States would ''make every effort'' to collect on the debt that Poland owes United States banks.

title: Power and the Money
description: Three years ago, the British novelist Graham Greene began delving into the underworld of Nice, 12 miles from his home in Antibes and the haunt, he says, of the most powerful criminals in the south of France.

title: MUSIC: VIOLIN CONCERTO OF PICKER HAS PREMIERE
description: ONE of the most serious problems facing any composer, young or old, is how to convey something of his own individuality in his work. Hordes of people seem to be able to turn out scholastically correct, faceless music; in fact, it seems to write itself. When a musical idiom has been around for a while, it develops an inexplicable defense mechanism that operates to enforce conformity with its dogmas and conventions. But significant composers somehow learn to defeat this mechanism and reveal themselves in their music, even if it means bending or breaking every rule they learned at their composition teacher's knee.

title: HAVEN FOR THE STRANDED
description: They drank coffee, talked, played cards, slept, watched television and did ''anything to keep busy.'' But the main occupation for the snowbound travelers here today was waiting for word that they could continue on to see their friends or families or to vacation in such distant states as California, Oklahoma and Nevada.

title: Oil Concerns Leave Alsands
description: Chevron Standard Ltd. and Amoco Canada Petroleum Company said yesterday that they have withdrawn from the Alsands Project Group in Alberta because they no longer believe that the $13 billion plant will ever produce a worthwhile return in its attempt to recover oil from tar sands.

title: CHINA FINDS SAVING GRACE IN A NO-FRILLS WEDDING
description: Three dozen blushing brides descended the staircase with their new husbands through a blizzard of colored confetti. The occasion could hardly be called intimate, but the young couples had waived their individuality and, answering the Communist Party's call, had agreed to a more frugal mass wedding ceremony.

title: HOLLYMATIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange

title: Law Banning Sale of Pistols Takes Effect in Illinois Town
description: Three residents here surrendered a total of five weapons to the police today as the nation's only law banning sale or possession of pistols took effect.

title: T.W.A. Cuts Fare to Coast
description: In an effort to fill up more seats in the coach section of its planes flying the transcontinental routes, Trans World Airlines said it had lowered fares and relaxed some of its restrictions on its Super Saver fares.

title: WILLIAMS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits

title: DEPUTY MINISTER IS STILL IN DERBY PICTURE
description: Deputy Minister, whose chances of fulfilling his role as the winter-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby seemed slim after his injury last Wednesday, could still be in the starting gate at Churchill Downs on May 1. John Tammaro, who trains last year's 2-year-old champion, is more optimistic now that additional X-rays have confirmed that Deputy Minister sustained a wrenched ankle and bruises instead of the hairline fracture that was initially feared after he finished fifth in the Bahamas Stakes.

title: VICTORIA STATION INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Jan 3
description: B-Includes $215,000 tax refund...C-Net losses after $2.2 million charge for the 16 and 40 weeks from the disposition of certain restaurant properties and $585,000 charge from an accounting change

title: KANSAS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hershey Oil Sets Investment Pact
