description: The Hershey Oil Corporation of Los Angeles, a producer of crude oil and natural gas, said that two Transamerica Corporation units, the Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company and the Transamerica Insurance Company, had agreed in principle to make a $10 million equity investment in Hershey.

title: ANDREW CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter include a gain of $165,000 from the sale of facility

title: News Analysis
description: Foreign companies must test Japan's new measures intended to eliminate import barriers before they know whether the Tokyo Government's actions do in fact open the Japanese market to their products.

title: RADIATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VOLCKER - AND REAGAN - ARE ON THE RIGHT TRACK
description: To the Editor:

title: Wells Fargo
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the San Francisco-based bank holding company, said it had received approval from the Canadian banking authorities to open a nationally chartered bank in Canada. The new bank, to be called the Wells Fargo Bank Canada, will have its headquarters in Calgary, Alberta. It will provide wholesale lending services to the middle market and foreign exchange services as well as international banking services, the company said.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING FELL BY 1% IN DECEMBER
description: Spending on new construction fell 1 percent in December compared with November, making 1981 the worst year for builders since 1975, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: China to Issue New Bonds
description: China will issue $2.4 billion in Treasury bonds this year to raise funds for economic development and encourage saving, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: B Y yesterday the Big Cold, as it is called by the Chinese, seemed to have loosened its grip on New York, which couldn't have made the city's retailers happier. After suffering extremely weak sales in November and December, many leading retailers hoped that post-Christmas business would impove. But it did not and many of them blame the weather.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Broadcasting Companies has appointed Richard L. Intrator to the newly created position of vice president, new business planning and development in the Strategic Planning Department.

title: PROPERTY-TAX ASSESSMENTS IN CITY ROSE BY $2.5 BILLION
description: The assessed value of taxable property in New York City increased more than $2.5 billion last year, to $44.9 billion, according to tentative figures released yesterday by the Department of Finance.

title: TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JERSEY WOMAN SEIZED AT KENNEDY AS BAGS YIELD 37 POUNDS OF HEROIN
description: A Customs official making a routine luggage check at Kennedy International Airport discovered 37 pounds of heroin hidden in the suitcases of a New Jersey woman, authorities announced yesterday.

title: TRADERS GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $526,000 writedown from the company's factoring subsidiary...C-After $1,866,000 loss from discontinued international operations; the company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto Stock Exchanges

title: Farm Aid Funds Said To Be Low
description: The Agriculture Department will soon be unable to make support payments to farmers or to pay off guaranteed export loans held by banks unless Congress replenishes the funds of the Commodity Credit Corporation, officials said today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: GREEDONOMICS
description: The Reagan Administration continues to propose the dismantling of Federal programs designed to help poor people. It also continues to resist proposals to reduce tax breaks that benefit mostly rich people. Meanwhile, any reasonably observant adult can see what is going on in the economy: things are fine at the top, but rough below.

title: TELLABS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EGYPT AND LIBYA REOPEN FRONTIER
description: Two border crossings in the Western Desert separating Egypt and Libya were reopened today to allow Egyptians working in Libya easier access for home visits.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1982; Markets
description: Citibank raised its prime lending rate by three-quarters of a point, to 16 1/2 percent, reversing a downward trend that began last July. It cited the rising interest rates it is paying for its own funds. Except for Crocker National in San Francisco, most major banks refrained from following Citibank's lead, partly from concern that increasing rates would be too heavy a burden for some of their customers and partly from concern that the the Reagan Administration would be critical. Senior managements of major banks were said to be divided on the issue of how to deal with rising interest rates. (Page A1.)

title: Cellist on the Sidelines
description: Because of a slip on the ice that injured his right thumb, the cellist Nathaniel Rosen, winner of the 1978 Tchaikovsky Competition, has had to cancel all engagements for at least six weeks - ''including, worst of all,'' he said yesterday, ''my Carnegie Hall recital debut March 4.'' While in Anchorage, Alaska, for the Sitka F estival last week, Mr. Rosen took time off to go cross-country skiin g with his wife.

title: CHEMICAL LEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $111,952; C-Incluing income from discontinued operations of $245,797, a loss of $465,806 from thecumulative effect of an accounting change and an extraordinary credit of $2,234,865; D-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $4,800,240 and income from discontinued operations of $248,030

title: TV: SERIES ON BLACKS BEGINS WITH POET
description: A HAPPIER choice could not have been made to launch ''Conversations in Black,'' WNET-TV's February series in observance of Black History Month, than the one to be seen at 10 o'clock tonight, a wonderful hourlong chat with Sterling A. Brown.

title: Drop at Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc., citing competitive pressures in its semiconductor business, said today that its fourthquarter profit fell 31.9 percent from a year earlier.

title: Comprom ised Justice
description: How would you like to be on trial for murder and have one of the jurors, throughout the trial, trying to get a job in the prosecutor's office? And to learn about it only afterwards, because the prosecutors kept it secret?

title: THE T.A.'S CONDITIONAL BELIEF IN SWIFT JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE OF SCHOLARS WIITHOUT SCHOOLS
description: LEO MILLER has published more than 30 articles on the poet John Milton and tracked down manuscripts relevant to Milton studies that had gone unexamined for nearly 300 years. He is now completing a study of the poet's political writings that, according to Albert Labriola, secretary of the Milton Society of America, will ''cause us to revise our understanding of Milton's life, at times significantly.''

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in December as well as assumed conversion of outstanding convertible bonds issued in April

title: BRIEFING
description: I T was billed as an event of some significance yesterday morning within the elaborate Corinthian columns of the Supreme Court. On the ground floor, inside the entrance portico, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger was expected to unveil a bronze statue of John Marshall, the nation's fourth Chief Justice and a pivotal figure who established the principle of judicial review.

title: UNITED NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-The company changed its fiscal yr ended on Feb 28 and thus there are no comparable yr-ago results

title: Pentecostalist in Soviet In Satisfactory Condition
description: Soviet doctors said that Lidiya Vashchenko, the hunger striker, was in satisfactory condition and eating today, but they refused to let United States Embassy officials see her.

title: CHAMBER: KREMER AT THE Y
description: born violinist, was the featured participant in a program of chamber music at the 92d Street Y Sunday evening, a program that marked his debut at the facility as well as his first New York appearance in a chamber setting.

title: FLIP OF COIN DECIDES JAIL TERM IN A MANH ATTAN CRIMINAL CASE
description: A toss of a coin was used by a New York City Criminal Court judge to determine the length of a prison sentence in a misdemeanor case. District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan, who said yesterday that he knew of the sentencing shortly after it happened last Tuesday in Criminal Court in Manhattan, described the actions by the judge, Alan I. Friess, as ''ridiculous and outrageous.''

title: DeLorean Aid Wins Support
description: Michael Foot, the leader of Britain's opposition Labor Party, said today that the Government should provide enough money to help save the financially troubled DeLorean Motor Company in Northern Ireland.

title: BEHIND THE BOTTOM LINE: HOW EMHART ADDS UP ITS YEAR'S WORK
description: On the second floor of the low-slung world headquarters of the Emhart Corporation, the consolidation department fanned out behind mustard-colored partitions. Fluorescent tubes gleamed. Men and women huddled over Formica desks, wearing down pencils. The desks were laden with spread sheets and computer printouts, enough paper to start a mill.

title: UNION CARBIDE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JUDGE TO WEIGH INQUIRY DISPUTE IN STOUFFER FIRE
description: A Westchester County judge presiding over the case of Luis Marin, who is charged with arson and murder in the 1980 fire at Stouffer's Inn, today ordered a preliminary hearing into allegations that a prosecutor improperly suppressed an expert's conclusion that the fire was an accident.

title: BRADY'S GOAT GAP CHILI IS POSITIVELY THERAPEUTIC
description: Ten months after he was critically wounded in an assassination attempt on President Reagan, James S. Brady, Mr. Reagan's press secretary, is again enjoying two of his favorite activities, cooking and dining out. In fact, said Dr. Arthur Kobrine, his neurosurgeon, cooking is playing an important role in Mr. Brady's physical therapy.

title: American Airlines Spots Retain Original Theme
description: If you are waiting to see the act that Bozell & Jacobs Southwest will come up with to replace Doyle Dane Bernbach on the American Airlines account, you do not have long to wait.

title: Market Place; Soothsaying On Wall St.
description: THIS is one of those confusing periods when stock market investors could use a Delphic oracle. Meanwhile, Wall Street has its own portents to watch in hopes of reading the future.

title: Brunswick Acts on Pay
description: Officials of the Brunswick Corporation, the object of a takeover bid by the Whittaker Corporation, acknowledge d yesterday that Brunswick's directors had made takeover-relat ed changes in the employment contracts of the company's chairma n and chief executive officer, K. Brooks Abernathy, and its preside nt, Jack F. Reichert. But the officials declared that the defensive steps, which began in mid-December, were not based on prior knowled ge that a specific bid was imminent.

G.M. POSTS PROFIT FOR 1981 AS SLUMP IN SALES PERSISTS
description: Despite the continuing slump in car and truck sales, the General Motors Corporation today reported a small profit of $97 million for the fourth quarter of 1981 and $333 million for the entire year - a profit it attributed largely to cost-cutting.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOLOCAUST MEMORIAL SOUGHT FOR CITY
description: Survivors of the Nazi Ho locaust proposed to a mayoral task force yesterday that a memorial and learning center be created in New York City in honor of the six million Jews who did not survive.

title: GAINS REPORTED IN INDIA-PAKISTAN TALKS
description: The foreign ministers of India and Pakistan ended four days of discussions on a nonaggression treaty today with a joint statement saying that the ''air had been sufficiently cleared to facilitate specific consideration of the elements which could constitute the substance of such an agreement.''

title: Price Support Rate Up
description: The interest rate on Government price support loans was set today at 14 percent for February, the Commodity Credit Corporation announced, up from January's 12 1/4 percent. This is what the corporation pays the Treasury Department for the money it uses to make price support loans.

title: TRACOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1981; 1980 results restated to include the acquisition of Flight Systems Inc on a pooling of interest basis as of August 1981

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1982
description: International Tightened security overseas has been imposed by United States intelligence-gathering officials because of the loss of sensitive documents in the 1979 seizure of the American Embassy in Teheran, according to senior intelligence officials. They said that the activities abroad were increasingly being conducted under the cover of private commercial organizations rather than official United States diplomatic missions. (Page A1, Column 6.) Reports that a major massacre of civilians took place in a Salvadoran village in December were disputed by the Reagan Administration as it announced it was about to send $55 million in emergency military aid to that country. The grant does not require Congressional approval. (A1:3-5.)

title: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sally Stanford, Madam Who Became a Mayor
description: Sally Stanford, the former San Francisco madam who went on to become Mayor of Sausalito and see her life turned into a television movie, died in Marin General Hospital today apparently of heart failure. She was 78 years old.

title: ART: PACESETTING DE STIJL, INFLUENCE ON AVANT-GARDE ART AND DESIGN
description: MINNEAPOLIS ONE of the most important art movements of the 20th century - De Stijl, which originated in the Netherlands during the darkest period of World War I and has wielded a considerable influence on avantgarde art and design ever since - is the subject of a major new exhibition at the Walker Art Center. Organized by Mildred Friedman, the curator of design at the Walker, the exhibition - called ''De Stijl: 1917-31, Visions of Utopia'' - will remain on view in Minneapolis through March 28, and will then travel to the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington (April 20-June 27) and to museums in Amsterdam and Otterloo, the Netherlands (Aug. 8-Oct.3). It will not be seen in New York.

description: B-Including a $5.6 million special gain on the sale of a subsidiary; Year-ago net income has been restated; The company is also listed on the Montreal, Torontoand Vancouver stock exchanges

title: On TV and Courts
description: Proceedings of the United States Supreme Court may one day be televised, but it will not be soon, according to Potter Stewart, who retired from the Court as an Associate Justice last year.

title: U.S. TO RETURN TO SEA PARLEY AT U.N.
description: After a prolonged review, President Reagan has said that the United States will return to the Law of the Sea Conference and will seek to relax the proposed curbs on mining the oceans' mineral wealth.

title: CIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After special charges of $3,620,000 for the quarter and $5,170,000 for the year; C-After a special charge of $729,000 for the quarter and year

title: Jets Raise Ticket Prices
description: The New York Jets announced yesterday that they have raised the price of their tickets for the 1982 season. The $11 seats will go to $13, the cost of box seats will increase by $1, to $14, and the temporary field reserved seats are going up by $1, to $10. It is the second price rise in two years.

title: Crew of Fishing Trawler Hunted by Coast Guard
description: The Coast Guard was searching an area 21 miles southeast of Portland Harbor tonight for the crew of a fishing trawler believed to have sunk.

title: Required Reading The Promised Land
description: Excerpt from ''Rickover: Controversy and Genius,'' by Norman Polmar and Thomas B. Allen: ''Our eyes beheld the promised land,'' an immigrant wrote of that moment when his ship passed through the Narrows and into the New York Harbor. There stood the Statue of Liberty, and just ahead lay Ellis Island.

title: NEW BUSES: NEW HOPE TO DISABLED
description: Ellen Nuzzi of Brooklyn Heights rode Transit Authority buses back and forth to work and to shop 40 times in October, 54 times in November and 60 times in December.

title: Topics; Bigger Bang, and Buck; Bad Bullets, Bad Policy
description: Another deadly refinement has become available to the owners of handguns. It is the KTW, a Teflon-coated bullet that fits most guns and can penetrate even automobile engines and bulletproof vests.

title: ADAC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hydro-Quebec Loans
description: Hydro-Quebec's borrowings this year will rise to about $2.3 billion (Canadian currency) from $2.2 billion in 1981, Georges Lafond, finance vice president, said in an interview today. Mr. Lafond said that with continuing work on the James Bay Hydroelectric Power Project in northern Quebec and construction of an interconnection with New England, Hydro-Quebec's 1982 capital spending should rise to $2.75 billion, up from the $2.6 billion spent in 1981. He said the provincially owned utility had already completed about 25 percent, or $575 million, of its 1982 borrowing program.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Two children died in a fire at 1:30 P.M. at 88-58 240th Street in the Bellerose section of Queens. The children's mother, Cheryll Thenier, 23 years old, tried unsuccessfully to rescue the children, Paul Michael, 1, and Mark Anthony, 3, from the second floor.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''New York has a heart. We know that because here we found a home.

title: Spain Says It Has Captured Prominent French Gangster
description: Spanish authorities said today they had detained Francois Besse, a French gangster regarded by the French police as their most wanted criminal.

title: C.I.A. CHANGES SPY OPERATIONS TO ADD SECURITY
description: United States intelligence-gathering activities are increasingly being conducted under the cover of private commercial organizations rather than diplomatic missions, according to senior intelligence officials.

title: U.S. Chief Named At Triumph-Adler
description: Triumph-Adler, the West German-based international business equipment manufacturer, has established Triumph-Adler North America to bring together its American units under one umbrella and has named Robert R. Hagy president and chief executive officer. Among the components in the American operation -with temporary headquarters in Hartford, but moving next month to nearby Windsor - are Royal Business Machines, the Pertec Computer Corporation and McBee Loose Leaf Binders.

title: VALMAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $890,000 extraordinary gain

title: WILLIAMS RETURN EXPECTED TO BE SOON
description: The lawyer for Sly Williams, the Knick forward who was suspended indefinitely last Saturday, met yesterday with Knicks officials and said afterward that he hoped for a quick resolution of the dispute.

description: B-Includes $4,688,000 extraordinary credit...C-After $10,192,00 extraordinary charge

description: Prospects of moving the financially troubled Colorado Rockies of the National Hockey League from Denver to Ottawa received a setback yesterday when a special study done for Mayor Ben Franklin of suburban Nepe an recommended against having the team play in that town's local arena.

description: The Mitsubishi Corporation said today that it had agreed with Fisomex of Mexico and NV DSM of the Netherlands to join a $500 million project to build a caprolactum and ammonium sulfate plant in Mexico.

description: Share earnings figures are fully deluted

title: HE PROMISES TO FIGHT FOR DEMOCRACY
description: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit was released from prison today, and he pledged to continue to struggle for the restoration of ''true democracy'' in Turkey.

title: NIKOLAIS WINS CAPEZIO PRIZE FOR CREATIVITY
description: Alwin Nikolais has been selected as the recipient of the 1982 Capezio Dance Award. The award will be presented on April 26 in a private ceremony at the Juilliard School.

description: Earnings in 1981 benefited from a $43 million foreign currency translation gaincompared with a $17 million loss in 1980

description: The Directors Guild of America has won a resounding victory in an antitrust suit brought against it by Home Box Office, a wholly owned subsidiary of Time Inc.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The San Diego Chargers acquired David Lewis, a 6-4, 245-pound linebacker, from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers for future draft choices. ... The Detroit Tigers' general manager, Jim Campbell, will undergo open heart surgery today. Campbell, 57 years old, was admitted to Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit on Friday after complaining of chest pains. ... Eric Floyd, a Georgetown guard who had 18 points each game in victories over Villanova and St. John's, was named the player of the week by the Big East Conference. ... Vitas Gerulaitis has informed the Men's International Professional Tennis Council that he will not appeal $15,000 in fines assessed him as a result of incidents at the United States Open and the Melbourne, Australia, Indoor tournament last year.

title: SPARTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
10 L.I.R.R. Trains Out for Rail Repair
description: The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that 10 trains, five in each direction, would be canceled today, tomorrow and Thursday for the repair of rails.

title: METHADONE LINKED TO ADDICT DEATHS
description: Take-home doses of methadone dispensed as a substitute for heroin in drug-treatment programs may be contributing to overdoses and deaths through illegal resales to addicts, a state commission said today.

MURIEL GOLDBERG
description: Muriel Goldberg, who founded such diversified businesses as coinoperated laundromats, poultry stores, a spice-distributing company and a precious-metal recovery concern, died Saturday at her home in Hawthorne, N.J. She was 60 years old.

title: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Defense Unit Bars Circuits
description: Some micro-circuits made by the National Semiconductor Corporation are to be removed from the list of items approved for sale to defense contractors, Pentagon officials said.

title: U.S. DISPUTES REPORT OF 926 KILLED IN EL SALVADOR
description: The Administration today disputed reports that a major massacre of civilians took place in a Salvadoran village in December. It also announced that it was about to send emergency assistance to El Salvador.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: IN advocating the ''new federalism,'' the Reagan Administration has been telling state and local school administrators that it will free them from regulations and domination by bureaucrats in Washington.

title: Auto Workers and Ford Start New Talks on Concessions
description: The United Auto Workers and the Ford Motor Company today began a new round of talks on concessions aimed at helping Ford compete with foreign manufacture rs.

title: WILLIAMHOUSE-REGENCY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RANGERS PLEASED WITH JANUARY SHOWING
description: Craig Patrick looked around the dressing room at the team he had restructured. ''I'm very pleased,'' said the vice president and general manager, after the Rangers defeated the Los Angeles Kings, 6-3, Sunday night. The victory had done several things for the Rangers. In addition to loosening Patrick's tongue, slightly, it meant that the team had won the first three games of an eight-game trip; that the Rangers held third place in the Patrick Division (named after the general manager's grandfather, Lester) by a comfortable 5-point margin over the Pittsburgh Penguins; that, for the first time, they were only 5 points behind the secondplace Philadelphia Flyers, and that they were four games above .500 (24-20-7) by having made January their best month of the season (9-3-2).

title: HOUSING A HOME
description: As part of a nationwide trend, the State of New Jersey is moving 4,000 mentally retarded people out of institutions into residential neighborhoods.

title: Shapiro Will Run
description: Peter Shapiro, who had been considered a possible candidate for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat held by Harrison A. Williams Jr., said that he seek re-election as Essex County Executive.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES RISE SHARPLY
description: Short-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday and caused securities dealers to revise upward the yields that will be needed to attract buyers for three- , 10- and 30-year Treasury issues scheduled for auction this week.

title: Chess: Alekhine's Spirit Lives On In the Games of Kasparov
description: With defense supposedly dominant these days , it is remarkable how many games Gari Kasparov wins by mating-attac k combinations. The extraordinary 18-year-old Soviet grandmaster can be seen imbuing the spirit of Alekhine into his encounter with Vi taly Zeshkovsky, anothergrandmaster, in the U.S.S.R. championship in Frunze.

title: TV Program on Poland Is Criticized by Many
description: ''Let Poland Be Poland,'' a 90-minute television show sponsored by the United States Government, was criticized today in both East and West.

title: ITALIAN POLICE FIND MORO'S'PRISON' WITH AID OF DOZIER'S KIDNAPPERS
description: Policemen acting on information obtained from the kidnappers of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier were able today to find the ''prison'' where former Prime Minister Aldo Moro was kept by his Red Brigades captors before they executed him.

title: TIMEX TO MARKET NIMSLO 3-D CAMERA
description: The Timex Corporation and Nimslo International Ltd., a British company that plans to market a camera that takes three-dimensional pictures, have agreed in principle for Timex to purchase and distribute 800,000 of the cameras, valued at $125 million, over the next two years, Nimslo said yesterday.

title: KATHERINE BACON
description: Katherine Bacon, a British-born concert pianist who taught at the Juilliard School for 30 years, died Saturday in a New York nursing home.

title: THEORY EXPLAINS HOW CRUCIAL STEP IN DEFENSE AGAINST DISEASE BEGINS
description: ANEW theory to explain how the body begins the process through which protective antibodies are made has been proposed by scientists of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine.

title: City Ballet Premiere Set For 'Gershwin Concerto'
description: The New York City Ballet will present the premiere of ''The Gershwin Concerto,'' a ballet by Jerome Robbins, Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

description: B-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge from writeoff of operation rights of $2,564,601 for qr and yr...C-After an extraordinary credit of $1,180,000

title: MARVIN MILKES
description: Marvin Milkes, a former baseball and soccer executive, has died of an apparent heart attack, his sister said Sunday night. Mr. Milkes was 58 years old.

title: Inner City Broadcasting Plans to Buy the Apollo
description: The Inner City Broadcasting Company, which, with the Unity Broadcasting Company has just been given a cable-television franchise in New York, plans to purchase Harlem's Apollo Theater and make it into a production studio.

title: STAGE: BREAD AND PUPPET
description: IN ''The Story of One Who Set Out to Study Fear,'' the Bread and Puppet Theater has taken a fanciful Grimm fairy tale and turned it into a parable about the apocalypse. The Grimm story ends with a brave young man's marrying a princess. The Bread and Puppet adaptation ends with a countdown and a warning, ''He who has ears let him hear.'' The stage is filled with a chorus of ears - drawn on large cards and held by actors - listening for the sound of devastation. Despite the air of fatalism, the work is filled with Bread and Puppet ingenuousness and imagination.

title: ARMSTRONG RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $375,000, or 19 cents a share

title: ONCE, LONG AGO, THERE WAS A MOUSE
description: SHE was the greatest of all great grandmothers. By now her ''grandchildren'' may number in the billions. She was a mouse, the single ancestress of at least nine varieties of inbred mice used for research all over the world today.

description: B-Including tax credits of $115 million for the quarter and $123 million for the year; C-Net loss including a tax credit of $385 million

title: CITIBANK, REVERSING TREND, RAISES PRIME RATE AND STOCK PRICES DROP
description: Citibank, the nation's second-largest bank, raised its prime lending rate yesterday by three-quarters of a percentage point, to 16 1/2 percent. The action reversed a downward trend that began last July.

description: * Split rate, 15.75-16.50. ** Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Loewe Group Appoints U .S. Division President
description: Neal J. Fox, 46, a retailer whose career has included top positions at some of the country's best-known stores, has joined Loewe Inc. as president. The new company is a division of the Loewe Group, a big Spanish leather-goods manufacturer and retailer founded in Madrid in 1846 that operates shops around the world.

title: WHITE HOUSE ORDERS RESIGNATION OF CHIEF OF BUSINESS AGENCY
description: The White House has asked for the resignation of Michael Cardenas, the head of the Small Business Administration and President Reagan's top-ranking Hispanic appointee.

title: No Headline
description: CONNECTICUT DEFEATS PROVIDENCE IN OVERTIME, 47-45

A Day in Prince's Life
description: It was not, ''blessedly,'' he said, a typical day in the life of Harold Prince, the Broadway director .

title: D.D.B. Acquires Fletcher/Mayo
description: Fletcher/Mayo Associates in St. Joseph, Mo., the country's largest ad agency specializing in agribusiness, has been acquired by Doyle Dane Bernbach International through an exchange of stock.

title: O.E.C.D. WARNS FRENCH POLICY MAY LEAD TO PROTECTIONISM
description: France will face ''a great temptation'' to take protectionist measures because the Socialist Government's attempt to stimulate demand is likely to bring disappointing results, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned in its first report on President Francois Mitterrand's economic policies.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What is the definition of wind chill factor, and what formula do meteorologists use to calculate it?

description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Panel Sets Inspection Review
description: The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission told a House subcommittee yesterday that the commission would review its inspection requirements for steam-generator t ubes.

title: Fraternity at Amherst Disbanded by Officials
description: Amherst College has disbanded the Delta Upsilon Delta fraternity after officials discovered a headless skeleton, two stuffed roosters and a motorcycle in the fraternity house and a 6-foot-high phallic ice sculpture on the lawn.

title: ATHLETIC DONATIONS RISE
description: A national survey shows that donations to college athletic programs have grown rapidly in recent years, despite the poor economy, and that the competition for funds is getting more competitive.

title: ROSENBAUM DECLARES HE'S RUNNING FOR GOVERNOR
description: Attempting to make an unusual transition from party leader to candidate, Richard M. Rosenbaum announced his candidacy for the Republican gubernatorial nomination yesterday in his home city of Rochester.

title: Track Conditions Force Aqueduct to Cancel Card
description: Poor track conditions caused by unseasonably mild weather and heavy rain forced cancellation of yesterday's racing card at Aqueduct, track officials said.

title: Naked at the Microphone
description: The Reagan Administration has come perilously close to confessing that all its fulminating about Poland is bluster. While demanding in television propaganda that the Kremlin ''Let Poland Be Poland,'' it has devoted its real energies to letting Warsaw and Moscow avoid the penalties of Polish bankruptcy. Furtively, the Administration has paid off a Polish debt of $70 million to American banks and thus set the stage for paying $400 million more in 1982. The threats of credit squeeze, by which the President wanted to stiffen the bargaining power of Poland's Solidarity union and Catholic Church, are thus evaporating into hot air.

title: SHELL CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOCIAL SCIENTISTS SAYS U.S. CRIME HAS LEVELED
description: OFF By PHILIP M. BOFFEY

title: 170 ARRESTED AS NUCLEAR PROTESTERS TRY TO BLOCK LABORATORY ON COAST
description: Misdemeanor charges were placed today against 170 persons arrested when members of the Livermore Action Group tried to block the gates at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in protest of the nuclear weapons design work done there.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: MANY diseases seem to have distinct cycles, some quite unusual, and doctors often chat informally over dinner or cocktails about the disappearance of this or that disease, or the resurgence of another.

title: KROY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rebels in Mozambique Reportedly Attack Town
description: Rebels fighting the Marxist government of Mozambique attacked the town of Inhaminga in that southern African country, killing two people, looting shops and demolishing a train, reports from Mozambique said today.

title: BURGESS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago net loss restated to reflect losses in foreign currency translations

Times Square Sign For Social Security
description: A worker in the neighborhood was struck by the fact that the Spectacolor sign overlooking Times Square was running an ad for Social Security. He wondered whether everything he had been reading led him to believe that the Government was trying trim the sails of that agency.

title: MANY SEEKING WORK IN WEST WITHOUT LUCK
description: West of downtown, just past a set of noname wareho uses of gun-metal gray and hard against a concrete freeway abutm ent, men gather daily to stare into a campfire and tell tales of home , of Michigan and Pennsylvania and Oregon and Washingtonand Illinois and Indiana.

title: IOWA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Talking Businesswith Sharkey of Steel Service Group Stress on Need To Cut Costs
description: Steel shipments by American manufacturers decline d dramatically in the last half of 1981, foreign imports surged and the embattled domestic producers are expecting dismal profi ts in this year's first quarter. Steel service centers, which are to steel mills what lumber yards are to forest products companies, are a lso beginning to feel the effects of the recession.

title: SITUATION IN GDANSK UNCERTAIN AFTER STREET CLASHES
description: Aside from editorial condemnation of street demonstrations Saturday in Gdansk, there was no word today on the situation in the Baltic coast city, a stronghold of anti-Government feeling where the Solidarity union was formed 18 months ago.

title: MATRIX SCIENCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Farmland or Wasteland: A Time to Choose By R. Neil Sampson. 422 pages. Rodale Press, Emmaus, Pa. $16.95. Between the so-called living spaces of towns and cities and the wild areas of parks, deserts, mountains and lakes, there are about 1.5 billion acres of farmland in the United States, and it provides much of the basis for our national wealth and the strength of our economic system. But unless we change the way we exploit it, the nation will lose not only much of this economic power but also the ability to feed itself, the author states in this comprehensive and well-researched book.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Sunday about the clos- ing of three shelters of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals incorrectly reported the ad- dress of the Brooklyn shelter. The shel- ter, open 24 hours a day, is at 2336 Lin- den Boulevard. The only other 24-hour shelter in the city is at 441 East 92d Street in Manhattan.

title: ILLINOIS POWER CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
AROUND THE WORLD
description: The White House withdrew the nomination of a longtime supporter of President Reagan, William R. Van Cleave, as chairman of the General Advisory Committee of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency today.

title: T.W.U. CHIEF ASKS INCREASE IN SECURITY ON SUBWAY LINES
description: The president of the city's Transport Workers Union, reacting to a weekend during which 149 felonies were reported on the transit system, called yesterday for greater protection for subway personnel and passengers.

title: L.I.R.R., Conrail Later Than Usual
description: After a steady period of improvement, on-time peformance on the Long Island Rail Road and Conrail fell sharply last month to the lowest levels in years.

title: ALTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
BIBB CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MULVEY INQUIRY STARTED
description: John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, opened an inquiry yesterday into the case of Paul Mulvey, who apparently has lost his job on the Los Angeles Kings after refusing his coach's order to leave the bench and join a team fight.

title: Music Hall 50th Jubilee Will Begin March 19
description: The golden jubilee year for Radio City Music Hall will be celebrated with ''Encore,'' beginning with previews March 19.

title: WALCO NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales to the latest period include for the first time the acquisition of five operating companies of Standard Alliance Industries which was formally merged into Walco National on Dec 9, 1981

title: Equal Rights Proposal Is Set Back in Virginia
description: The House of Delegates dealt a severe blow today to ratification of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment in Virginia, rejecting, 62 to 35, a rule change designed to pry the proposal from a hostile committee.

title: RIBLET PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Warwick, R.I., Teachers Strike School System
description: A union representing 1,100 teachers struck today, setting up picket lines and forcing the cancellation of classes for the city's 13,500 public school students.

title: AGNES TURNBULL, NOVELIST, 93, DIES
description: Agnes Sligh Turnbull, a popular and prolific novelist and shortstory writer, died Sunday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. She was 93 years old and had lived in Maplewood, N.J., for 60 years.

title: DOW DROPS 19.41 ON RATE JUMP
description: Rising interest rates sent stock prices tumbling yesterday after last week's impressive market advance. The Dow Jones industrial average, in the minus column throughout the session, finished down 19.41 points, at 851.69. It was the biggest decline for the average since Aug.24, when it fell 20.46 points, also because of apprehension over rising interest rates.

title: Prisoners in the Parks
description: To ease jail crowding, corrections experts say, reserve cells for dangerous convicts who really need to be removed from society - and find ways to deal with the others in the community. The idea is noble, but unfortunately, most communities aren't.

title: British-French Perfume Venture
description: Two British companies and a French concern announced in New York that they planned to merge into what would be one of the world's largest fragrance and flavor producers, with annual sales of $200 million.

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW CLASS OF DRUGS REVOLUTIONIZES THERAP Y FOR HEART DISEASE
description: FEW drugs have had as great an impact on medicine as the beta blockers. Since the first of this cl ass of synthetic drugs was marketed in 1 965, doctors have prescribed them for a wide variety of conditions, r anging from heart disease, the nation's leading killer, to such seemi ngly minor but potentially incapacitating disorders as stage fright.

title: Breweries Honor Roosevelt
description: Workers at three breweries here enjoyed a paid holiday today to celebrate the birthday of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the man credited with making their work legal. After he assu med the Presidency in 1933, one of his first proposals to Congress w as to repeal Prohibition -to again allow the legal manufacture a nd sale of alcoholic beverages. Workers at the Hudepohl,Schoenling an d Wiedemann breweries had the birthday put into their contract as a paid holiday about 15 years ago.

title: 12 Die in Philippine Floods
description: Twelve people were killed in floods in the southern Philippines, including six who drowned in a bus when the driver tried to cross a creek, the state press agency reported today. It said most of the deaths occurred Saturday.

title: REAGAN WILL SEEK GOVERNORS' VIEWS ON TRANSFER PLAN
description: President Reagan pledged to several Governors today that he would be flexible in devising the details of his proposed ''new federalism'' program and would consider their suggestions for ways to help some states pay for new responsibilities.

title: BATTERED IRISH ECONOMY IS BATTLEGROUND IN ELECTION CAMPAIGN
description: The parliamentary election campaign here has opened with both sides claiming to have the solution to Ireland's serious economic problems.

title: DEMOCRATIC LAWYERS FINDING INTERIOR COLD
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt and his political aides seem to be trying to expand the endangered species list to include lawyers and lobbyists who are tainted by service in past Democratic administrations, according to complaints rumbling through this city's legal and environmental circles.

title: THE NEWS STATES' RIGHTS
description: President Reagan proposes to make the states responsible by 1988 for welfare, food stamps and more than 40 other Federal programs - so responsible, in fact, that the states can kill any or all of these programs, beginning in 1984, if any or all of the states decide to. And some probably will.

title: BRIDGESTONE TIRE CO. MAY GET FIRESTONE PLANT
description: The Bridgestone Tire Company, Japan's largest tire maker, is holding talks with the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company on the purchase of a Firestone plant in Nashville.

title: Fish Spear Fishermen
description: The men who spear fish at night from small canoes in the coastal waters off Papua New Guinea have discovered that the ocean can spear back at them.

title: Pornographic Film Star Faces Coast Murder Trial
description: John Holmes, a pornographic film star, was ordered today to stand trial for murder in the bludgeoning deaths of four Laurel Canyon residents last July.

title: Treatment for Backache
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Jane Brody's articles on backache (''Care and Treatment of Your Aching Back,'' Jan. 12 and 13) were very informative with respect to methods of treating back pain and maintaining a healthy back.

title: French Joblessness Up
description: France's unemployment rose again last month despite the Socialist Government's efforts to create new jobs, but the rate of increase slowed.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the 15 most popular television programs of the last week (Monday, Jan. 25, to Sunday, Jan. 31), according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating refers to the percentage of households with sets tuned to a specific program. Rating Program Network 1 29.3 60 Minutes CBS 2 28.4 Dallas CBS 3 24.5 Magnum, P.I. title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO CUT SPENDING FOR THE ARTS
description: President Reagan's budget message next week is expected to call for substantial cuts in Federal spending for the arts and humanities, according to Congressional aides who have discussed the matter with Administration officials.

title: Bernadette Devlin to Run For Parliament in Dublin
description: Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, a champion for Roman Catholic civil rights in Northern Ireland, announced today that she would run for election in Ireland.

title: TV: 'DAVID LETTERMAN'
description: AS one of the first segments on ''Late Night With David Letterman,'' the new one-hour talk and variety show that made its debut on NBC- TV at 12:30 A.M. yesterday, Mr. Letterman conducted a guided tour o f the show's set. Wandering into what is commonly calledthe ''Green R oom'' - the room in which a show's guests sit and await their appearances - he found himself instead in a greenhou se, a veritable tropical garden filled with lush green flowering plants.

title: TEXT OF LETTER ON EXEMPTIONS
description: Following is the text of the letter protesting the Reagan Administration's legal conclusions on tax exemptions to private schools, which was signed by more than 200 lawyers and others in the Justice Department's civil rights division:

title: HOUSE PAPERS TERMED ALTERED
description: The lawyer representing President Reagan in the sale of his house in Los Angeles informed local and Federal prosecutors today that a document on the home had been altered to appear as if he had signed it when he had not.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Financial Corp. increased its share of Wheeling-Pittsburg Steel Corp. to 14.7 percent of the outstanding common stock, or 580,232 shares, including 48,200 shares purchased for $1,449,700.

title: A Man Who Knows About Foundations
description: When it came time to find a new president, the Council on Foundations quite naturally thought it would be a good idea to get someone with a lot of foundation experience.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN PROPOSAL ATTACKED AS A 'BLUEPRINT FOR PRESS CONTROL'
description: The English-language press today assailed a proposal that journalists be registered by a body with the power to bar them from writing articles for any publications in South Africa.

title: A Gift for White Sox
description: The Chicago White Sox made the first selection from the pool of players set up to compensate a team for the loss of a free agent.

title: NEW STATE RULES ON TOXIC WASTE DUE ON MARCH 9
description: A decision permitting a corporation to file a civil-rights suit charging racial discrimination has been handed down by the Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

title: F.T.C. IS ASKED TO VOID GAS ADDITIVE PRICE RULE
description: Representatives of companies accused of violating antitrust law by signaling price changes to each other argued before the Federal Trade Commission today that to alter their methods would be to change one of the most common practices in American business.

title: BOSSES OF MIGRANTS SENTENCED FOR SLAVERY
description: Three migrant crew chiefs convicted of kidnapping, s lavery and holding farm workers in involuntary servitude rec eived long prison sentences today in Federal District Court. Judge W. Earl Britt, said that he wanted ''to let others knowthat, in the Eastern District of North Carolina at least, you don't commit this k ind of an offense and walk out of a courtroom.''

title: BRIEFING
description: C ONGRESSIONAL Democrats have revamped their campaign methods for the fall and say that never before have they been so well prepared to do district-by-district battle with Republicans. Their immediate problem is that the final battle lines have not been drawn by slow-moving reapportionment mappers in such key states as New York, Florida and Pennsylvania.

title: WORKERS ENTER GINNA ATOM PLANT
description: Workers continued to vent the damaged generator at the disabled Ginna nuclear power plant here Tuesday as technicians prepared to enter the radioactive generator chamber.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 65-year-old woman who had been staying at a city shelte r in Flushing, Queens, was found dead, apparently beaten to death, about noon yesterday in an alley near the shelter. The woman, Justina Miranda, had been seen cashing a public-assis tance check near the Flushing Armory shelter at 137-58 Northern Bo ulevard.

title: California Gets Measure For Thumbless Gloves
description: The California Legislature was asked today to require thumbless boxing gloves in all professional and amateur boxing and sparring matches.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: An American jet accidentally launched a nonnuclear Sidewinder missile in the Black Forest, and the United States and West German authorities were searching for the missile today, a United States Air Force spokesman said.

title: FOUR MORE SMALL MOONS OF SATURN ARE DETECTED IN VOYAGER 2 PHOTO
description: Four and possibly six more small moons of Saturn were discovered in a new analysis of Voyager 2 photographs, scientists at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory reported yesterday. This would bring to 21 or 23 the number of known Saturnian satellites.

title: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Jane Brody's article failed to mention one of the most revolutionary breakthroughs in the management of chronic low back pain, the technique of Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (Tens).
description: Tens Therapy is noninvasive, non-narcotic, nonaddicting and eliminates or reduces pain medication and thus improves the quality of life.

title: CALIFORNIA GOVERNOR RACE TIGHTER
description: The race for Governor of California has drawn closer, according to voter opinion surveys released today by Mervin D. Field, director of the California Poll.

title: JUDGE WILL NOT COMMENT ON WISDOM OF COIN TOSS
description: Judge Alan I. Friess, declaring that judges are public figures, said yesterday that they ''should be made accountable'' for what they do. But he refused to comment on whether he had been wrong last week to use a flip of a coin to determine a prison sentence in a misdemeanor case.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: MANY of the so-called ''family'' restaurants (and others, too, that make a point of appealing to tight budgets) have exposed virtually everybody to mechanically tenderized meat, although few diners realize it. What is done to an inexpensive cut of beef, which would ordinarily be too tough to eat, is that it is assaulted by a machine with thin, long, prong-like blades. They repeatedly pierce the meat, breaking its sinews before it is broiled.

title: AS STUDENTS SUFFER
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing A Concern For I.O.C.
description: The decision to house Olympic athletes at two large local universities for the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics instead of at one self-contained village drew expressions of concern from members of the International Olympic Committee's executive board today.

title: Converse Sale Set
description: The Allied Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell its Converse divi sion, a maker of athletic footwear, to an investor group that in cludes current management. The price was not disclosed. Trade sources estimate Converse's sales at about $150 million yearly.

title: Fordham 64, Fairfield 59
description: David Maxwell, a junior guard, scored 17 points to pace Fordham. Fordham (12-7) led by 32-25 at halftime behind Dud Tongal's 10 points and Maxwell's 8.

title: MILITARY BUDGET FOR '83 REPORTED $10 BILLION BIGGER THAN EXPECTED
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger informed Congress today that the Reagan Administration planned to ask for a 1983 military budget of nearly $260 billion in appropriations, or $10 billion more than previously expected, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: AMBIANCE OF EATING: WHAT IS ITS ROLE?
description: THERE seems to be no limit to the number of ways and places in which Americans take their meals: in bed, at coffee-shop counters, while sandwiched between other passengers on commuter trains, from brown bags at their desk. They eat chili to the twang of country and Western music and hamburgers that are served by waitresses on roller skates. They dine at drive-ins where plastic trays are fixed to their car windows and in restaurants where the lights are so dim that flashlights are needed to read the menu. At home, meals often turn into a sort of relay race, the freezer's treasures being consumed in front of the television set by one family member at a time.

title: NEW HOME SALES RISE IN MONTH, OFF FOR YEAR
description: Sales of newly built single-family houses gained a solid 10.9 percent in December, the third consecutive month of increases of 10 percent or more, the Government reported today.

title: COSMOS SET BACK MANIC, 7-5
description: The Cosmos built leads of 4-1 and 6-2, then withstood a late rally by the Montreal Manic for a 7-5 victory before 5,827 fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: KINGS DEMOTE PLAYER WHO DIDN'T FIGHT
description: Paul Mulvey of the Los Angeles Kings, who refused to leave the bench and join in a team fight last month, was not claimed by any of the 20 other clubs in the National Hockey League yesterday as the 72-hour waiver period passed and was sent to the minor leagues.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard BEYOND THE PALE. By William Trevor. 256 pages. Viking. $12.95.

title:
OBSERVER;
SPEAKING OF HOGS
description: BakerA Democrat denouncing a budget deficit is like a hog with wings. When you see one you know either nature has gone crazy or somebody thinks you were born yesterday.

title: Quintuplets Born in Belgium
description: Quintuplets were delivered by Caesarean section in the Academic Hospital today, a university spokesman said.

title: SKETCHES OF MAJOR APPOINTEES TO KEAN'S CABINET
description: Governor Kean has named 13 persons to Cabinet positions, all of whom require confirmation by a majority vote of the State Senate. Under a new law, the Governor may set the salary for each Cabinet member, within a range of $56,000 to $70,000 a year. Here are sketches of his major Cabinet appointees to date: Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman of Short Hills has been in all three branches of government. The 51-year-old lawyer served in the State Assembly in 1964 and 1965 and as a Superior Court judge from 1971 to 1976, when he resigned to return to private practice.

title: Williams, Holzman to Meet
description: Sly Williams is scheduled to meet today in Los Angeles with Red Holzman, the coach of the Knicks, in a step that could lead to the lifting of the player's suspension.

title: NOT-SO-VITAL STATISTICS ABOUT BYRD
description: For Senate-watchers and collectors of Senatorial trivia, here are some insights into Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who is the Senate minority leader:

title: Careers; Financing E ngineers' Education
description: A ''2 PERCENT solution '' to the shortage of engineers will be considered ne xt week by many of the 110 companies that make Route 128 outside B oston one of the most famous thoroughfares in technology.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT has long been my contention and that of most chefs I know that good food is not necessarily seasonal. And by that I mean that cold poached salmon should not be invariably relegated to summer meals and fine hots soups to those of winter.

title: EVIDENCE GAINED BY HYPNOSIS ON STOUFFER 'S FIRE IS WEIGHED
description: A businessman who survived the fatal Stouffer's Inn fire in 1980 gave two dramatic accounts of his escape today, first from the witness stand and then through a tape-recorded session with a hypnotist.

title: DETERMINING INCOME AND TAX EXEMPTIONS
description: The Internal Revenue Service takes an expansive view of income, and requires that just about everything from bartered goods, salary and wages to lottery prizes and even kickbacks be reported on a tax return. But new provisions in the law double the amount of di vidend income that i nvestors can exclude on their 1981 returns, and allow people to she lter their interest income in two new ways. The general rule is that taxpayers must include all payments for services rendered, including such items as severance pay, union strike benefits and under-the-t able commissio ns. Gambling victories must be reported (losses can be deducted as a n itemized deduction, but only up to the amount of winnings), and s o must illegal income such as embezzled funds. Alimony and separate maintenance payments are considered income, but child support paym ents are not.

title: THE TENANTS' GRIEVANCES IN THE CASE OF AN EMPTIED BUILDING
description: To the Edit or: As an S.R.O . tenant organizer, formerly with Project FIND, I feel it necessary to comment on Donald Crown's letter of Jan. 5, which responds to S ydney Schanberg's columns ''Trashing Old People.'' Over the past year I have spoken with dozens of Mr. Crown's tenants, many of whom made their home in the Hutton Hall, including Alberto Arroyo and Emma D'Ar tuniaga, the subjects of Mr. Schanberg's articles.

title: Yale True Blue to Ivies
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced yesterday that 39 of the former 137 major college football teams, including seven of the eight Ivy League teams, had lost their status as major teams and been dropped from Division I-A to Division I-AA. But Yale, the only Ivy team that meets the new Division I-A criteria, announced immediately that it would voluntarily move to Division I-AA in order to remain with the other Ivy League schools.

title: NEW POISON GAS IS A MUST FOR AMERICA'S ARSENAL
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSERVATIVES BEARD REAGAN ON REAGANITES
description: For the 13 months since President Reagan took office, tensions have been building between his Administration and the conservative activists who, as they see it, were with him in the wilderness.

title: Judge Sonia Morgan, 54, Dies; S at in Jersey's Superior Court
description: Judge Sonia Morgan of the Appellate Division of Superior Court of New Jersey died Sunday at her home in the Llewellyn Park section of West Orange, N.J., after a long illness.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Interest rates declined yesterday, reducing the yield at the Treasury's auction of new three-year notes to 14.63 percent, well below the 14.9 percent yield that was estimated a day earlier.

title: MELANCHOLY, NOT MILITANCY, ENVELOPS SINAI'S SOUTH
description: Occupied Sinai -With less than three months to go until Israel's withdrawal from the final third of Sinai, an eerie feeling of half-abandonment has come over the three oases of civilization that lie along the rugged coast of the Gulf of Aqaba.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Thursday about the reassignment of judges to Criminal Court incorrectly described the status of Judge Irving Lang. He is serving temporarily in Criminal Court and will be eligible to return to the Supreme Court as an act- ing justice on Jan. 1, 1985.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I am not about to lay out a litany of actions that may or may not take place.

title: 200 IN U.S. AGENCY CRITICIZE DECISION ON TAX EXEMPTIONS
description: More than 200 lawyers and others in the Justice Department's civil rights division have signed a letter expressing ''serious concerns'' about the Reagan Administration's decision that racially discriminatory private schools are entitled to tax exemptions under current law, Justice Department sources said today.

title: STANDARDIZED TESTS DEFENDED BY PANEL
description: The standardized ability tests widely used to screen applicants for schools and jobs are generally valid and not in themselves unfair to blacks and other minority people, a panel formed by the National Academy of Sciences concluded today after four years of study.

title: 90 NOMINEES PICKED FOR AMERICAN BOOK AWARDS
description: Novels by John Updike, John Irving, Robert Stone and William Wharton, as well as stories by Mark Helprin, are the fiction nominees for the third American Book Awards, The awards, to be announced April 22, are for books written or translated by Americans and published in the United States last year.

title: No Headline
description: Canadiens 5, Flames 3

title: DOZIER TELLS OF 42 DAYS IN A PUP TENT
description: Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier spent his 42 days of captivity in the hands of Red Brigades terrorists constantly chained to a steel cot in a pup tent under the never-extinguished glare of an electric bulb.

title: China Charges That Vietnam Is Provoking Border Conflict
description: China accused Vietnam today of committing 44 military provocations along their border during the 10-day lunar New Year period despite Hanoi's call for a cease-fire over the holiday.

title: Ruling Against Arum
description: A Federal judge yesterday issued an injunction against the boxing promoter Bob Arum and his Top Rank Inc. that prevents Arum from interfering with the career of Johnny Bumphus. Judge Richard Lee Price ruled in New York Supreme Court that Bumphus, who is unbeaten and holds the United States Boxing Association junior welterweight title, can fight for any promoter and on any television network. Bumphus and two other fighters, Tony Ayala and Alex Ramos, have sued Arum, claiming he violated their contracts by assigning their television rights to NBC without their consent.

title: CHEVY'S NEW HEAD PREPARES TO REFOCUS AFTER EUROPE STINT
description: Only 17 months ago the General Motors Corporation sent Robert C. Stempel to West Germany, hoping he could bring some life to the auto maker's ailing Adam Opel subsidiary, which lost $227 million in 1980.

title: Trade Authority Voted
description: A House trade subcommittee voted unanimously today to authorize the President to negotiate tariff-cutting agreements with foreign countries over the next two years.

title: Fire Drives Many From Mall
description: A smoky fire in an electrical vault in a delivery tunnel forced hundreds of shoppers and employees out of stores at the Menlo Park Mall today, authorities said.

title: Israelis Rout Militants Demonstrating in Sinai
description: Israeli troops today used force for the first time in routing militants who were trying to prevent the evacuation of Sinai.

title: C.I.A. DENIES LINK TO FORMER AGENTS
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, told the House Select Committee on Intelligence today that the C.I.A. had tentatively concluded that the agency had no official involvement in the Libyan activities of two former agents, Edwin P. Wilson and Frank E. Terpil, according to Congressional sources.

title: I, THE NORTH WIND I, the North Wind, am blowing snow into people's faces, making kids fall and making jackets come off.  They thought it was annoying.  I thought it was pleasant.  I was blowing at 70 degrees below zero.  People were so chilled that they got frostbite.
description: I was blowing from 81st Street. I got bored there. So I decided to move on to 65th Street. There I tried to stop people from getting to work - 65th Street is so much fun. When I blow so hard, people can't get out of their lobbies.

title: ON THE ATTACK WITH SALVADOR REBELS: BATTLE STARTS EARLY AND LASTS ALL DAY
description: With the stars providing the only light, the rebels remained within touching distance of one another as they moved cautiously for three hours up and down rocky mountain trails and across streams.

title: THE MANY GUISES OF THE HUMBLE APRON
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paula Deitz is co-editor of The Hudson Review. By PAULA DEITZ

title: A.T. & T.'S NET IS WORLD RECORD
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that its net income for the year rose 13.7 percent, to $6.89 billion, or $8.55 a share, the highest profit ever reported by any company in the world.

title: Economic Scene; The Growing Money Muddle
description: THESE are jittery days. The stock market is behaving like a manic depressive, elated one day, plunged into despair the next. Inflation slows but interest rates soar. Is the world out of joint? What is the explanation?

title: A Fatter Japan Is a Safer Japan
description: Japan's Minister of International Trade, Shintaro Abe, listened with apparent sympathy in Florida last month to the complaints of his American and European counterparts. Yes, he agreed, Japan's enormous trade surplus with the West during this recession is a serious strain on the alliance. And yes, Japan could do more to welcome imports.

title: Er ika Hess Captures Her 2d Alpine Ski Title
description: Erika Hess of Switzerland gained her second gold medal at the world Alpine skiing championships today by winning the giant slalom title. Miss Hess, 19 years old, won the combined championship Sunday.

title: Power Agency Names Chief
description: The board of trustees of the Power Authority of the State of New York has named Leroy W. Sinclair president and chief operating officer. Mr. Sinclair, who is 39 years old, has been senior vice president and chief financial officer of the agency. He succeeds George T. Berry, who retired.

title: Kashmir Landslide Kills 23
description: Twenty-three people were feared killed in a landslide today in northern Kashmir, the Press Trust of India, a news agency, said. The report said six houses and several cattle sheds had been destroyed in the slide, which followed heavy rains.

title: Notre Dame 75 San Francisco 66
description: Mike Mitchell scored 19 points as Notre Dame upset San Francisco.

title: HERTZ: 'RIGHT PARENT' IS SOUGHT
description: When the RCA Corporation put its Hertz subsidiary up for sale last week investment bankers speculated that the prospective buyer would have to be of one extreme or another: either very reckless or very sophisticated.

title: Malone Scores 53 for Rockets
description: Moses Malone, the Houston center, scored a career-high 53 points and grabbed 23 rebounds as the Rockets defeated the San Diego Clippers tonight, 122-106.

title: Pabst Plans to Buy Pittsburgh Brewing
description: The Pabst Brewing Company, which is engaged in a battle to prevent Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis financier, from taking control of the company, announced yesterday that it has reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Pittsburgh Brewing Company, a small but profitable regional brewer.

title: Dow Edges Up 0.86, to 852.55
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday, benefiting from a slight decline in interest rates, in a quiet session that followed Monday's retreat.

title: Egypt's Oil Prices Reported Lowered
description: Egypt cut its price for top-grade oil by $3.75 a barrel, to $32.25, and lowered its other major crude oil by $2.50, to $28.50 effective this past Monday, Platt's Oilgram Price Report, a New York-based trade publication, said yesterday.

title: David F. Smith Is Dead at 84;
description: Chemist and Research Chief

title: CAREY AIDE WILL URGE CUTS IN INCOME TAX IN NEW YORK
description: The State Commerce Commissioner has urged Governor Carey to call for substantial cuts in the state's personal income-tax rate and will make his position public in a speech on Wednesday.

title: Sir John Foster Dead; On Eisenhower's Staff
description: Sir John Galway Foster, a prominent British lawyer, Government official and longtime Conservative Member of Parliament, died Monday in London after a brief illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Inquiry Set on Steel Petitions
description: There is enough merit in most of the unfair trade suits filed by American steelmakers against 11 foreign steel producers to warrant a formal investigation, the Administration has concluded.

title: CLEVER SOVIET ATTACK ON ITALIAN
description: COMMUNISTSTo the Editor:

title: Jury Declines to Indict Henderson for Theft
description: A Dallas County grand jury today declined to indict the former Dallas Cowboys linebacker, Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson, on a felony charge of stealing an $800 typewriter from the Richardson Police Department.

title: AVON FALLS 24.1%
description: Dart & Kraft Inc. reported yesterday that the divestiture of a subsidiary as well as foreign exchange translation losses caused net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 to plunge 88.1 percent as sales increased 7.8 percent.

title: FACTORY ORDERS RISE 0.2%
description: New factory orders increased by a scant two-tenths of 1 percent in December, the Government reported today. However, the increase was seen as encouraging in light of separate reports that showed sales of newly built houses in December rose 10.9 percent, the third straight monthly gain, and that the value of new construction in December was up 21 percent from November, the low point of 1981. (Page D12.)

title: Charles D. LaFollette, 82 Dies; Retired Corning Glass Official
description: Charles D. LaFollette, a former vice president and a director emeritus of the Corning Glass Works, died Tuesday at the Corning (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Former Reagan Aide Picked to Head SIPC
description: James G. Stearns, a former member of President Reagan's Cabinet when he was Governor of California, has been selected as chairman of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, the nonprofit organization that provides up to $500,000 in insurance for each stockholder's investment held at brokerage firms.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Recently, I read of a meal served to Randolph Churchill aboard a British ocean liner in the 1950's. He breakfasted on Champagne, a stack of cakes and deviled bones. I know of such English peculiarities as pickled walnuts and bubble and squeak. But what, pray, are deviled bones?

title: HAIG PLEDGES U.S. WILL ACT TO BLOCK SALVADOR REBELS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. declared today that the United States, in cooperation with its allies in Latin America, would do ''whatever is necessary'' to prevent the overthrow of the Salvadoran Government by guerrillas he said were backed by Cuba and Nicaragua.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: A.P.S. Finance Co., a subsidiary of Arizona Public Service Co., has completed arrangments for the offering of $75 million of 16 1/4 percent guaranteed debentures due in 1989 in the international capital market. The lead manager of the issue is Credit Suisse First Bosto n Ltd.

title: PROSECUTION AND DEFENSE OUTLINE VON BULOW CASES
description: The jury in Claus von Bulow's trial on charges of attempted murder heard for the first time today the opposing versions of how Martha von Bulow sank into the irreversible coma in which she has been for 13 months.

title: TRANSIT REPORT
description: CONRAIL: On the Hudson Division, 10 of the 29 scheduled morning rush-hour trains were up to 14 minutes late and one was 36 minutes late. The longest delay occurred on the 7:20 from Croton-Harmon, due at Grand Central Terminal at 8:07, as a result of equipment trouble.

title: LIMOUSINE COMPANY TO OFFER CHALLENGE TO MEDALLION TAXIS
description: A private limousine company today will introduce the first of what it says will be 6,000 radio-dispatched cars operating at rates competitive with those of New York City's medallion taxis.

title: Nijinsky Play to Open At Wonderhorse Feb. 15
description: ''Clownmaker,'' a play by Richard Crane about Nijinsky, Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes, will have its New York premiere Feb. 15 at the Wonderhorse Theater, 83 East Fourth Street.

title: CITY BALLET: BART COOK'S DEBUT AS FAUN
description: provoking debut in Jerome Robbins's ''Afternoon of a Faun'' Sunday afternoon at the State Theater.

title: Mets, Allen in Accord
description: The Mets reported progress on two talent fronts yesterday. Frank Cashen, the general manager, said that the club had reached agreement with the relief pitcher Neil Allen on a new contract and that the salary-arbitration case he filed would be withdrawn.

title: Dinnertime
description: Tonight's W hite House dinner in honor of President Hosni Mubarak ofEgypt is shap ing up as a historic event.

title: WHEN BASQUE MEN FEEL AN URGE TO COOK
description: In this most dogmatically masculine of countries, a married man would no sooner don an apron and prepare a meal than he would enroll in a knitting class. Even in this liberated age, such an act, under less than dire circumstances, would be considered unseemly. The children might see it.

title: Schoolgirl Is Reaching Heights
description: ''You know what Lew Alcindor did for men's basketball? Well, that's what Cheryl Miller is going to do for women's basketball.'' That prophecy came from Judy Holland, the former women's basketball coach at U.C.L.A. and now the school's women's athletic director. College recruiters for schools around the country are pursuing Miss Miller, an 18-year-old senior at Riverside (Calif.) Poly High School, as persistently as they did Alcindor, now known as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, when he was a senior at Power Memorial High School in Manhattan in 1965.

title: Cleveland Bank Settles $15 Million Bias Suit
description: The Reagan Administration and the National City Bank of Cleveland reached an out-of-court settlement of a $15 million job discrimination suit, the Labor Department disclosed today.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration seems at times to be at war with its own self-image of toughness in foreign affairs. One result is that officials sometimes have to defend decisions that do not measure up to their strong statements.

title: Why Laetrile Lived So Long
description: Laetrile, the alleged cancer cure made from apricot pits, may at long last be dead. A definitive new study, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, concludes that it ''is a toxic drug that is not effective as a cancer treatment.'' After many premature announcements, this should prove to be Laetrile's obituary.

title: Jack Fitzpatrick, Reporter; Covered Denver Statehouse
description: Jack Fitzpatrick, a veteran Statehouse broadcast reporter who was declared a state landmark, died early today. He was 81 years old.

title: FORD WIDENS REBATES AFTER G.M. MOVE
description: The Ford Motor Company today announced a broadened two-month rebate campaign as a quick stimulus to lagging sales and to counter a similar promotion announced last week by the General Motors Corporation.

title: TRUDEAU CRITICIZED
description: The premiers of most of Canada's 10 provinces criticized Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today for pursuing an economic policy that keeps Canada's interest rates in step with high United States rates.

title: Massachusetts Official Convicted of Conspiracy
description: Barry M. Locke, the suspended Massachusetts Transportation Secretary, was found guilty today on all five counts of conspiracy to commit bribery and larceny.

title: Topics Intemperate; Term Toss
description: One of the most enduring human illusions is that man is master of his fate. But there comes a time in every life when reality intervenes.

title: ART: PRIMITIVE WORKS FROM DIVERSE WORLDS
description: THE new Michael C. Rockefeller Wing at the Metropolitan Museum is in itself a most remarkable spectacle. Quite apart from that, it would be a very difficult visitor who did not find in it something to please and astonish him.

title: NEW POISON GAS IS A MUST FOR AMERICA'S ARSENAL
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: THE goal of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin, the world's most renowned wine society, is to have fun drinking great Burgundy wines and dining on fine Burgundian fare, so it was not surprising that food, drink and revelry were the focal points at its annual feast the other night at the Hotel Pierre.

title: TO THE LIVING SECTION
description: I was pleased to see Jane Brody's article and delighted with several of the suggestions in ''Care and Treatment''.

title: Work-Plan Inmate Flees and Is Seized
description: While taking part in a program in which Rikers Island inmates are released for part of the day to clean Parks Department facilities, a prisoner walked into the men's room of a Brooklyn recreational center and ran out a back door. He was recaptured later in the day.

title: NUGGETS TOP KNICKS, 128-117
description: The four days rest that most of the Knicks received for the All-Star Game break was supposed to help the struggling cl ub.

title: Air Florida Jetliner Is Hijacked to Cuba
description: A man described as a ''homesick Cuban'' hijacked a jetliner with 77 persons aboard to Havana today by telling the crew that he had a bottle filled with gasoline, the authorities said. It was the first successful hijacking in the United States in more than six months.

title: FILM PREMIERE FOR HURWITZ
description: ''Dialogue With a Woman Departed,'' a film written, produced and directed by Leo Hurwitz, will have its American premiere F eb. 19 at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. The screening wi ll follow athree-day retrospective of the director's work.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 3, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ninth Emergency Session of the General Assembly- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Msgr. John C. Dougherty, 84, Retired Vicar in Westchester
description: Msgr. John C . Dougherty, the retired episcopal vicar of WestchesterCounty, died Sunday at the rectory of St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Yon kers, where he had been assisting his nephew, the Rev. Donald W. Hen dricks, the pastor.

title: THE CC RATTLES ALONG AN UNLIKELY PATH
description: The CC train is the longest line in the New York City subway system, running 32.39 miles from Bedford Park in the Bronx to the Rockaway Peninsula, and passing through -or, in most cases, beneath - a number of the city's best-known neighborhoods and landmarks.

title: Inco Reports Loss in Quarter
description: Inco Ltd. reported an operating loss in the fourth quarter of $45.2 million, compared with income from continuing operations of $48.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1980.

title: Canada Dry Sold To Dr Pepper Co.
description: Norton Simon Inc. said it had completed the sale of its worldwide Canada Dry business to the Dr Pepper Company for $143 million in cash and seven-year subordinated notes.

title: British Reserves Drop
description: Britain's gold and foreign currency reserves fell by $122 million last month, to a total of $23.23 billion, from $23.35 billion in December and $28.39 billion in January 1981, the Treasury said today.

title: Reagan Sends Congress B angladesh Nuclear Pact
description: President Reagan today sent Congress a proposed agreement for peaceful nuclear cooperation with Bangladesh, the White House announced.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.75-16.50. ** Maximum rate payable by savings institutionsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four rose $2.26 to a record high of $109.59 during the reporting period of Jan. 18 to Jan. 29, according to the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs. This was the largest two-week increase in the last 12 months. Shoppers paid $7.87 more for the 41-item market basket than in the corresponding period last year.

title: Experts on Bloodstains Testify in Atlanta Trial
