description: Bloodstains found in the back seat of a car driven by Wayne B. Williams matched the blood of two slain young blacks, witnesses testified today at Mr. Williams's murder trial.

title: Weinberger to Visit Mideast
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will leave Thursday for a visit to Saudi Arabia, Oman and Jordan, the Pentagon said today. Mr. Weinberger will be discussing military cooperation.

title: IRANIANS FREE BRITISH BUSINESSMAN HELD WITHOUT CHARGE 17 MONTHS
description: Iran has released a British businessman after holding him without charges for 17 months, the British Foreign Office announced today.

title: ISLANDERS WIN SIXTH IN ROW, 7-6
description: ''It wasn't pretty,'' said Bill Smith, ''but we got the 2 points. What more do you want?'' Smith was summoned off the Islanders' bench in the second period tonight to take over the goaltending duties from the rookie Roland Melanson, and New York managed to outlast the Washington Capitals for a 7-6 victory at Nassau Colisetm.

title: Brazil Soybeans Lack Rain
description: The new soybean crop in Brazil, America's chief competitor in world soybean markets, continues to suffer from inadequate rain, the United States Government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said today.

title: Boston Cracking Down On Its Ticket Scofflaws
description: Somebody owes the city of Boston $6,000 for hundreds of unpaid parking tickets, and soon everyone will know who it is.

title: Teamster Aide Convicted
description: An official of Local 830 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters was convicted Monday of covering up a kickback scheme that netted a former union leader $70,000 in three years. Vincent Improto, 52 years old, of Norristown, was found guilty of filing a false report to the United States Department of Labor about money listed as expense funds for business agents but that was actually paid as a salary to a former union official, Gordon Grubb, 60, of Philadelphia.

title: Ritchie-Calder Dead; British Science Writer
description: Lord Ritchie-Calder, an explorer, professor and former journalist who is credited with developing science reporting in Britain, died Sunday at the age of 75.

title: A NEW BOON FOR THE CAREFUL SHOPPER: TALKING CASH REGISTERS
description: When computerized scanning systems began replacing manual cash registers in supermarkets several years ago, food store owners praised the new technology as being faster and more accurate than even the most nimble-fingered check-out clerk. While that may have been true, some consumers complained that the lightning-fast scanners, which read coded labels and tallied prices automatically, were too quick to follow.

title: Egypt Says Its Border With Libya Is Still Closed
description: Egypt said today that it would keep its border with Libya closed and that the crossing of the frontier Monday by 27 Egyptians and their families was an exception to the policy.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REFURBISHED

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: TAX MOVE ON INTEREST WEAKENS
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, in a surprise remark, said today that President Reagan is ''lukewarm'' about his own proposal to have the Federal Government withhold income tax on dividends and interest.

title: Brooklyn 78, John Jay 69
description: Rich Micallef scored 22 points to pace Brooklyn Colle ge, which improved its record in the City University Co nference to 8-1. Ron Phillips and Keith Williams added 14 points a piece for the Kingsmen, 11-5 over all. John Jay (13-5 and 6-3) was le d by Curtis White, who had 20 points.

title: CAREY WILL SEEK TO ASSUME THE FOOD STAMP OPERATION
description: Governor Carey said today that the state would ask for permission to take over the administration of the Federal food s tamp program.

title: A REPLACEMENT FOR CANS AND BOTTLES
description: A Massachusetts marketing cooperative says it has found an answer to the problem of disposable bottles and cans. It has begun packing fruit juices and juice drinks in airtight laminated containers of paper, plastic and foil that need no refrigeration or freezing at any stage, from packing plant to consumer.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: A follow-up: To cash in on Pope John II's visit to Britain in May, the first visit by a reigning Pope since the 16th century, the Roman Catholic Church last July hired the Cleveland-based International Management Group, headed by Mark McCormack, to handle the licensing of authorized souvenirs.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Davey Moore of New York won the World Boxing Association junior middleweight championship with a sixth-round knockout of Tadashi Mihara of Japan in Tokyo. Referee Carlos Berrocal of Panama stopped the scheduled 15-round bout after Moore knock down Mihara three times in the sixth.

title: Advertising; Ayer News Show on Business
description: WITH its longtime client the American Telephone and Telegraph Company as sponsor, N.W. Ayer Inc., will begin testing a business news show on Warner-Amex's Qube interactive cable TV system in Columbus, Ohio, on Feb. 17.

title: Reynolds Raises Cigarette Prices
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's largest cigarette producer, said it will raise the wholesale price for all of its domestic cigarette brands and its Winchester little cigars by $1 per thousand, effective next Tuesday.

title: 3 ARE INVESTIGATED IN THEFT OF EXAMS
description: The Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service is studying the arres ts of three pers ons and the seizure of stolen college admissions tests that they bel ieve are part of a Taiwan-based ring dealing in English-language examinations used by Taiwanese to get into American schools.

title: Prosecutor Named For Transit Crime
description: Responding to what he called an ''upsurge in subway crime,'' District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan yesterday announced the appointment of a prosecutor to act as a ''special coordinator for transit crime'' in his office.

title: Shadow of a Doubt
description: It was Groundhog Day yesterday, and, as usual, the people who interpret the groundhogs' actions were in dispute as to whether they had forecast six weeks more of winter weather or an early spring.

title: MOST BANKS MATCH RISE TO 16 1/2 FOR PRIME RATE
description: Most of the nation's major banks yesterday followed the lead set by Citibank o n Monday and raised their prime lending rates to 16 1/2 percent from 15 3/4 percent.

title: INTEMPERATE; Gutter Politics
description: Nature drops snow, the city sprinkles salt, and at most major intersections slush collects in pools, a half foot (or a full ankle) deep.

title: Corrections
description: An article in SportsMonday on Jan. 18 and a question in the weekly news quiz of Jan. 23 incorrectly explained the origin of the Cleveland Browns nickname. The name Brown Bombers - after the boxer Joe Louis - was chosen in 1946, and soon was shortened to Browns.

title: SOVIET PENTECOSTAL IS VISITED IN HOSPITAL
description: American officials today were allowed to visit the Pentecostal who was hospitalized after a hunger strike at the United States Embassy. They said she had resumed eating solid foods and appeared in good spirits and health.

title: First Farwest Corp.  Appoints President
description: Darrell E. Lindquist, 48, has been appointed president of the First Farwest Corporation, a diversified company with holdings in health, life and disability insurance, and heavy-duty transportation distribution. He succeeds Forrest W. Simmons, 57, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Portland, Ore.

title: Valve Cited in Fatal Blast
description: A valve blamed in part for a school explosion that killed eight persons was installed improperly and in violation of national standards, a manufacturer's representative said Monday. Joseph F. Keegan, sales vice president of the Watts Regulator Company, maker of the valve, said its installation in a water heater at the Star Elementary School did not meet national standards and plumbing codes.

title: TESTIMONY BY HAIG AT CAPITOL
description: Let me begin by commenting on East-West relations and my meeting last week with Soviet Foreign Minister Gromyko. Ever since taking office, the President has stressed our desire for a constructive and mutually beneficial relationship with the Soviet Union. At the same time, we have made clear to Moscow that such a relationship must be based on greater Soviet restraint, especially in the use of force or the threat of violence. The Soviet role in Poland and elsewhere, specifically Moscow's lack of restraint, was therefore uppermost in my discussions with Mr. Gromyko.

title: AUCTIONEER FOR HEUBLEIN
description: Heublein has announced that Reeder Butterfield has been retained to be the auctioneer at its annual auction of rare wines on May 27 at the Park Plaza Hotel in Boston.

title: JUDICIAL ACTIVISM
description: WeinrebCAMB RIDGE, Mass. - Some legal scholars and observers of our political processes have applauded Attorney General William French Smith's call for a more restrained Federal judiciary, even if they do not favor legislation pending in Congress that would amputate part of the courts' jurisdiction. They agree with him in deploring ''managerial'' interventions in the daily operations of public institutions like jails and prisons, hospitals and facilities for the mentally ill or incompetent, and schools. Such interventions, they assert, usurp legislative and executive powers and diminish the place of law - as opposed to politics or policy - in society. They ask judges to recall an older and nobler conception of law as a restraining influence on shifting views of the moment.

title: ZERO-COUPON EUROBONDS A HIT
description: The international bond market is being swamped by a rash of American company issues that pay no interest but are sold at a steep discount. The zero-coupon Eurobonds, as such foreign issues are known, are modeled on a similar bond that first appeared in the United States last fall and became an immediate success.

title: CONSTRUCTION REBOUNDS 21% IN MONTH
description: The value of new construction in December rebounded from a yearlong decline, advancing 21 percent from November, which was the low point for the year, to $11.6 billion, after seasonal adjustment, the F.W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill reported yesterday.

title: Michael Sorkin Weds Joa n K. Copjec, Editor
description: Joan Karen Copjec, associate editor of October magazine, a quarterly published by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies in New York, was married yesterday to Michael Sorkin, an architect and writer.

title: 2 NEW QUEENS KILLINGS TIED TO COLOMBIAN DRUG TRAFFIC
description: The bodies of two men who had been shot to death were found in a Queens apartment yesterday by authorities investigating the execution-style murders of a Colombian family in Queens on Saturday.

title: ARGERICH RECITAL CANCELED
description: A Piano recital by Martha Argerich scheduled for Friday at Avery Fisher Hall has been postponed from Jan. 24. Refunds may b e obtained from the box office. Patrons who charged tickets through C enter Charge will receive a credit.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ROCK and roll has had more than its share of unsung heroes - performers who made important breakthroughs, created styles or influenced subsequent development - who, for a variety of reasons, didn't receive much credit. Before there was rock and roll, there was rocking music that had the same sort of rhythmic excitement. And before that, there were entertainers with what we would recognize today as rock-and-roll attitudes. Most of them weren't aware that they were rock pioneers. Some would have been horrified if they'd been given a glimpse of what was to come. But they all contributed, in one way or another.

title: S.& P. Cuts A .M.C. Rating
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said that it had lowered its rating on the American Motors Corporation's 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 1988 to Triple-C from Single-B.

title: An Die Musik to Play Local Debut of a Haydn
description: An die Musik, the chamber-music group, will give the New York premiere of Haydn's Quartet for Oboe and Strings in B flat (Hob. IIB:4) at the third and final concert of its series at the Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street. The concert will be March 14 at 4 P.M.

title: REAGAN OFFICIALS WEIGH PLAN TO BAR STATES FROM CUTTING RELIEF AID
description: Federal officials, working out the details of President Reagan's ''new federalism initiative,'' are seriously considering a proposal that would require states to continue total spending on welfare and food stamps at current levels for several years.

title: ON HIS CENTENARY, DUBLIN HONORS THE JOYCE IT ONCE SCORNED
description: The Irish nation, which shunned and often vilified James Joyce throughout his lifetime, celebrated his 100th birthday today with a joyful exuberance that would have tickled even Leopold Bloom.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Clothes for the Tiny Parents of premature infants sometimes have difficulty finding clothes for their offspring to wear once they leave the hospital since most infant sizes are too large. Now there's a group of garments made especially for the baby as small as three pounds. The line includes a cotton flannel sleeper with feet ($9), a knit top ($4) that ties on over knit pants ($5) and a flower-sprigged quilted bag the baby can wear in a crib or pram ($21). You'll find the clothes in the infants' department on the second floor of Bloomingdale's.

title: BILLIONS FOR WAR, NOT DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: A TALK WITH MITTERRAND
description: President Mitterrand of France is not happy with the state of the Atlantic alliance these days, but unlike many others in this part of the world, he is cautiously optimistic about the future of the Western world. There will always be crises, he says, but we should not confuse crises with decline.

title: New Snowstorm Hits S outhern Plains Area
description: Winter's latest storm bludgeoned the southern Plains yesterday with more than a foot of snow that caused automobile accidents, closed schools and was blown into hip-deep drifts, then took another swipe at the Great Lakes states.

title: No Headline
description: Nets Win; Ray Williams Hurt

title: News Analysis
description: In the Assembly chamber here, at his first news conference after being certified as winner of the race for Governor, Thomas H. Kean was asked if he intended to name any Democrats to his Cabinet. Before he could answer, someone from the gallery boomed: ''Hell, no!''

title: LESS PAY FOR NEW LAWYERS URGED
description: Scarcely a month after leaving the Wall Street law firm that helped to send legal salaries skyrocketing, the New York City Corporation Counsel, Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., has called on private firms to stop paying their new lawyers so much.

title: TERKEL DEFENDS BOOK AFTER A PROTEST
description: Studs Terkel, author of several best-selling books, came here today to defend one of his works against a bookbanning movement and captured a school. But he ran into more opposition when he returned in the evening to meet with parents.

title: Bridge: Trend to Use of Specialists In Sports May Go Further
description: The trend toward increasing specialization, long obvious in the academic world, is also clear-cut in baseball, football and other sports.

title: Report of Romance
description: It is not normally in the nature of the Pentagon to bother to deny reports speculating on the personal lives of its officials. But yesterday, Henry Catto, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, took the trouble to comment on a published report about his boss, Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Defense.

title: MOBIL DROPS BID FOR U.S. STEEL SHARES
description: The Mobil Corporation, which had said that it might buy up to 25 percent of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that it had dropped any plans to add to its current holding of nearly 1 percent of the nation's largest steel company.

title: Market Place; Foreigners' C autious View
description: LAST Friday morning, the day after the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 21 1/2 points, Alan Ackerman thought that foreign investors, who had recently been reluctant to buy, might show a spark of enthusiasm. ''But the follow-through from abroad was disappointing,'' said Herzfeld & Stern's director of foreign research. ''We saw only scattered buying. International Business Machines is still the longterm favorite of overseas investors.''

title: A RARE VISIT BY GIRARDET, THE SWISS 3-STAR CHEF
description: FOR about a hundred of his admirers in New York, the visit this week of Fredy Girardet and three of his assistant chefs is the gastronomic event of the season. Mr. Girardet, whose three-star restaurant in Crissier, Switzerland, has been called the greatest in the world by several of France's chefs, is here to prepare three byinvitation-only meals at Manhattan's Le Cirque restaurant.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1982
description: International Support for El Salvador was reaffirmed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. He said that Washington would do ''whatever is necessary'' to prevent the overthrow of the Salvadoran Government by guerrillas he said were backed by Cuba and Nicaragua. Under questioning by a Senate committee, Mr. Haig again refused to say whether the pledge included the possible use of American combat troops. (Page A1, Column 6.) A burst in Salvadoran rebel attacks was reported in the eastern part of the country. Military sources said that 500 guerrillas had stormedand occupied a town 75 miles northeast of San Salvador, killing about100 people. ( A6:3-6.)

title: BRICK OR STONE STRIKES BUSH'S CAR, CAUSING ANXIETY ABOUT SECURITY
description: A ''big bang'' on the roof of an armored limousine carrying Vice President Bush to work this morning caused a rush of anxiety among Secret Service agents, who reacted as if the motorcade had been attacked. The authorities said later, however, that the car had been struck by a brick or a stone.

title: People
description: * Curtis R. Troeger and Wesley E. Truesdell have been elected executive vice presidents of Doremus & Company.

title: Iona Tops Manhattan, 69-65
description: Gary Springer hit five free throws in the last 39 seconds as Iona defeated Manhattan, 69-65, last night to move into first place in the Metro Atlantic Conference. Steve Burtt led the Gaels (15-6 and 5-1) with 26 points, and Springer had 19.

title: U.C.L.A. Case Under Review
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is reviewing its recent case against U.C.L.A. that led to the imposition of two years of probation for the school's basketball program. But David Berst, director of enforcement for the N.C.A.A., said yesterday that this action did not mean the U.C.L.A. case would be officially reopened at this time.

title: STAVROPOULOS'S ENDURING EVENING WEAR
description: GEORGE STAVROPOULOS made the quantum leap from couturier in his native Athens to dress designer in New York 20 years ago - and many of his first clients are still with him.

title: DEPORTED TO SALVADOR
description: Kiehne 36,2For many people in the United States, the violence in El Salvador is a nasty business that we would just as soon forget. Yet thousands of Salvadoran refugees who cannot forget are making their way across the border into the United States only to be told that they are not welcome here.

title: Sports People; Jan Stephenson Hurt
description: Jan Stephenson, a three-time winner on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour last year, has informed the association she broke a small bone in her right foot and will miss at least a month of tournaments. Miss Stephenson told the association that the injury occurred in an exercise class.

title: SCOTT PAPER, HAMMERMILL UP
description: Two major Pennsylvania-based paper companies - the Scott Paper Company of Philadelphia and the Hammermill Paper Company of Erie - reported higher sales and earnings in the last quarter of 1981 and for the year compared with 1980 results. Scott Paper

title: REAGAN ISSUES NEW RULES ON CLASSIFIED DOCUMENTS
description: President Reagan, moving again to curb disclosures of sensitive foreign policy material, today imposed new regulations on the handling of National Security Council documents containing classified information.

title: Strategic Arms Talks Urged by U.N. Chief
description: Javier Perez de Cuellar, the United Nations Secretary General, called on the United States and the Soviet Union today to resume their negotiation on limiting strategic nuclear weapons.

title: Tenneco's Net Rises by 30%
description: Tenneco Inc., the nation's 11th-largest oil company, said today that earnings for the fourth quarter rose 30 percent, from $200 million, or $1.56 a share, to $260 million, or $1.91 a share.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Natural Resources Co., Detroit, elected Edward A. Wiegner to the new post of senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Vermont 89, F.D.U. 82
description: Mike Evelti scored 27 points to lead Vermont. Vermont (9-9) took a 53-46 halftime lead, but Fairleigh Dickenson rallied to lead by 1 point - 74-73 - with seven minutes remaining.

title: Kroehler Names A New Chairman
description: Robert Rittmaster, the 56-year-old chairman and president of a recently acquired subsidiary of the troubled Kroehler Manufacturing Company, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the parent company, a major furniture manufacturer based in Naperville, Ill.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THOUGH we all know that you cannot judge a book by its cover, when it comes to judging other people, most of us do just that. We say that people look young, look happy, look tired, look intelligent, and we are often content to be deceived by appearances.

title: C.W. Post 65 U.S.  Merchant Marine 63
description: Nick Jenkins and Gene Higgins scored 14 points apiece as C.W. Post (11-5) won its seventh straight game. Jenkins, a junior forward, preserved the victory by blocking a layup attempt by Scott Brueggeman of the Merchant Marine Academy (7-10) with one second left. The Mariners were led by Bob McNamee, who had 19 points.

title: I.B.M. WILL RENT TIME ON ITS UNITS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced its re-entry into the remote computer services business. Under the new service, customers will be able to rent time on I.B.M. computers in Tampa, Fla., and have the use of more than 100 programs stored on those units.

title: N.F.L. Is Denied a Shift Of Antitrust Trial Site
description: A Federal judge denied today the National Football League's motion for a change of venue in the antitrust suit of the Los Angeles Coliseum and the Oakland Raiders against the N.F.L.

title: 'EMBARRASSMENT' OF F.D.R. RICHES ON VIEW
description: Famous sons come and go at places like Groton and Harvard, often leaving little behind them but their names on the alumni rolls. They come and go in Washington, too, though from time to time a sel ect few leave their names carved in stone or on legislation.

title: Sports of The Times; James Bozeman's Problem'
description: JAMES BOZEMAN was willing to disappear quietly from the Florida State basketball team last December. He was prepared to take his damaged knee and his damaged ankle to his own doctor, rather than take the drugs he says the basketball office was pushing at him.

title: News Analysis
description: The economic difficulties in Poland and other Eastern European countries have presented Western bankers with a dilemma at least partly of their own making.

title: Roy Eaton's Music Agency
description: Roy Eaton, 51-year-old pioneer in the field of ad agency music direction, is leaving Benton & Bowles after 22 years to pioneer once again. Roy Eaton Music, which will be at 595 Main Street, Roosevelt Island, is to be a music production company that coordinates ad agencies' sometimes chaotic search for music.

title: FOREIGN INVESTORS TAKE A LOOK BEYOND NEW YORK
description: Mix a little myth with a little reality, add a few crucial questions that no one can answer, and New York City looks like a mecca for foreign individuals and institutions who want to invest in real estate.

title: Meningitis Tests Prove Negative
description: Tests have proved negative on cultures taken from 200 people who may have come into contact late last week with a third-grade teacher who died of meningitis last Saturday, Lyndhurst Township officials said.

title: Price in Hall of Fame
description: Eddie Price, a star fullback for Tulane who went on to set rushing records for the Giants, was among four players named to the College Hall of Fame of the National Football Foundation. Three others also honored posthumously were John Orsi, a Colgate end; Bernie Shively, an Illinois guard, and Lloyd Yoder, a tackle from Carnegie Tech. Price twice won all-pro recognition with the Giants.

title: Methadone at Home
description: Methadone is an opium derivative that acts more slowly than heroin and with less debilitating effect. It is thus widely used to treat drug addicts, permitting them to lead normal lives.

title: 'No' From Jack Ford
description: There may be a Ford in California's political future, but not in the present. That is the word, at least, from former President Gerald R. Ford's son, Jack Ford.

title: RANGERS SET BACK CANUCKS
description: For the 20th time this season, the Rangers took a lead into the third period, as they led the Vancouver Canucks, 3-0, tonight after the first 40 minutes of play. New York won, 4-3, but only after the Canuc ks fought back with three third-period goals, threatening to brea k the Rangers' nocollapse record - they had won the 19 previ ous games in which they led going into the last period.

title: No Headline
description: ATTACKS BY GUERRILLAS BURST ACROSS THE EASTERN PART OF EL SALVADOR

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan is ''lukewarm'' about his own plan for the Government to withhold taxes on dividends and interest payments, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told the National Press Club. The proposal is one of several Mr. Reagan is scheduled to submit to Congress next week in his budget for fiscal year 1983. (Page D1.) New orders for manufactured goods rose just 0.2 percent in December, to a seasonally adjusted $160.3 billon, the Commerce Department re ported. Officials also said manufacturers' inventories were down las t month, a sign that stockpiles of unsold goods are being reduced . (D1.) The value of new construction rose 21 percent inDecember, to a seasonally adjusted $11.6 billion, the F.W. Dodge division of M cGraw-Hill reported. (D12.)

title: TV: BETTE DAVIS AS ELDERLY 'MRS. CIMINO'
description: ''SENILITY! That's a word they use in the medical profession when they don't want to do anything, and they certainly don't want to do anything for anyone over 65.'' So declares a character in ''A Piano for Mrs. Cimino,'' a television movie that approaches the subject in an unusually helpful way. In addition to its instructive merits, this film also features Bette Davis in the title role, and Miss Davis gives the most forthright, affecting performance she has offered in years. ''A Piano for Mrs. Cimino'' will be shown tonight at 9 P.M. on CBS.

title: ARCHITECTURE: PRIMITIVES IN SPACE
description: IT is not at all uncommon to see a piece of pre-Columbian or African art set against the background of a white wall in a sleek An Appraisal Manhattan apartment. It is often the only nonabstract piece of art there, and it seems placed in deliberate juxtaposition to the starkness of its setting, as if it were believed to offer a kind of humanizing influence.

title: Warriors 119, Lakers 117
description: J. B. Carroll hit two free throws with no time remaining for Golden State, which rallied from a 10-point fourth-quarter deficit. Carroll was fouled at the buzzer by Jim Brewer.

title: HERS
10 Policemen Killed in Brazil
description: A box of dynamite exploded in a state police barracks today, killing 10 troopers and a civilian. The police said the explosion, described as accidental, took place in a remote jungle outpost near this city in western Brazil.

title: NEW PROCESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LASER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $54,000 extraordinary charge; C-After $147,100 tax loss carryforward credit

title: HARD-LINERS IN POLAND CALL FOR PURGES
description: A strong conservative faction has emerged among Poland's rulers that opposes political reform, the revival of Solidarity as an independent union and the holding of negotiations with Lech Walesa, Polish sources said today.

title: SALVADORANS RAISE BATTLE DEATH TOLL
description: The Government today increased the number of civilians that it said had been killed by guerrillas in an attack Sunday on a town northeast of here.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Spanish Navy Officer Wounded in Basque Area

title: A Deadline on Sirens Met by Jersey Utility
description: T he Public Service Electric and G as Company said today that it had met the deadline for installing sir ens in a new emergency notification system for residents within 10 miles of its Salem Nuclear Generating Station.

title: TRUCE BROKEN, ISRAEL CHARGES
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said today that there had been more than 60 Arab violation of the cease-fire agreement last July between Israel and the Palestinian forces in Lebanon.

title: SOLVING THE QUANDARY OF GUEST-ROOM SPACE
description: THE economy is rocky and the price of hotel rooms is beyond many budgets, but New York continues to be a magnet for the rest of the country and, indeed, the world. To an increasing number of visitors the solution is simple: stay with a friend.

title: Williams Loses Move To Bar Senate Action
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Senate could proceed with consideration of a resolution to expel Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, the only Senator convicted in an Abscam bribery case.

title: KODAK SHOWS NEW DISK CAMERAS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday introduced a line of cameras that use a film disk instead of conventional roll film. The new products are intended to secure the company's position as the dominant force in amateur photography for the rest of the decade.

title: FOSSILS MAY BELONG TO FIRST LEAF-EATING MAMMAL
description: Two scientists have found fossil evidence on the plains of Wyoming of a previously unknown creature that is believed to have been the first leaf-eating mammal to exist on earth. The chipmunk-like animal may have played a vital role in the spread of flowers around the world, the sc ientists believe.

title: COMBINED COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1980 period results restated

title: Scott Layoffs
description: The Scott Paper Company said it would dismantle three of 10 paper-making machines at its Chester, Pa., plant and lay off 350 employees.

title: ANN WEAVER NORTON, THE CREATOR OF 'MEGALITH' SCULPTURES, IS DEAD
description: Ann Weaver Norton, a sculptor whose work had begun to receive wide art-world recognition in the last few years, died yesterday at a hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. Although she refused to give her precise age, Mrs. Norton acknowledged in an interview in 1978 that she was in her 60's.

title: AND THE HOSTS
description: Patricia Sullivan, administra- tor, Natural Resources De- fense Council:

title: Topics Saving Time, Saving Grace
description: Falling Back

title: MUBARAK, MEETING WITH REAGAN, ASKS PALESTINIAN 'NATIONAL ENTITY'
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt told President Reagan today that solving the Palestinian problem was the ''key to peace'' in the Middle East. He said the Palestinians could not be denied ''the right to self-determination'' and formation of ''a national entity.''

title: Shipwrecked Canoeists Found Near San Juan
description: Two shipwrecked young men, one of them dead, were found early today in a rubber life raft at sea 20 miles north of here.

title: CAREY WILL ASK SALES-TAX RISE TO AID SCHOOLS
description: Governor Carey plans to ask the Legislature to increase the state's sales tax to provide more money for education, top aides to the Governor said today.

title: SOME SOURCES FOR SUMMER JOBS
description: Students 19 years or older looking for work as camp counselors can register with the placement services of the American Camping Association, 225 Park Avenue South (at 18th Street) New York, N.Y. 10033, 212-677-8200; the Association of Independent Camps, 157 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019, 212-582-3540, or Camper Consulting Services, 14 Wesley Court North, Huntington, N.Y. 11743, 516-549-3902.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Oklahoma Energies Corp. said it was withdrawing its registration statement for a previously announced $12.8 million exchange offer for partnership interests in four limited partnerships.

title: LIGHTS MAKE ANY CORNER A GARDEN SPOT
description: ''ANY kind of light is O.K. for plants, so long as there is enough of it,'' according to Jack Golding, a former national president of the Indoor Light Gardening Society of America. This means that what he calls the ''ugly purple bulb'' associated with many plant growth lamps is not mandatory after all.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SAYS DISSIDENTS 'ARE WELCOME TO LEAVE' JOBS
description: The top spokesmen of the White House and Justice Department suggested today that Government employees who objected to Reagan Administration policies were free to resign.

title: MARSHALL FIELD FACES TAKEOVER
description: Marshall Field & Company, the diversified retailer based in Chicago, yesterday faced the thre at of a pote ntial takeover by a group including the Icahn Capital Corporation , an affiliate concern and a Netherlands Antilles company, which now holds 14.3 percent of Marshall Field's stock.

title: NETS DEFEAT HAWKS BY 112-103
description: Ray Williams, listed as a doubtful starter because he had sprained his right ankle Tuesday night, and Albert King, a rookie, helped the Nets win respect from their former coach and a game tonight. Williams no t only started, but he also scored 18 of his 34 points in the first quarter. King had 22 points as the Nets scored a 112-103victory over the Atlanta Hawks at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Rescuer Honored
description: Len nie Skutnik, the Federal employee who ju mped into the Potomac and rescued a survivor after the crash of an Air Florida jetliner last month, got another accolade yesterday.

title: SMD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec26
description: B-Includes $12,066 gain for the quarter from discontinued operations and $546,415 loss for the 9 months from discontinued operations

title: Racing Board Refuses To Hear Andretti's Plea
description: As far as the governing body of auto racing is concerned, Bobby Unser is officially the winner of last May's Indianapolis 500, whose outcome was one of the most controversial in the event's 65-year history.

title: EXECUTIVE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a net gain of $4,680,000 on disposition of property, plant and equipment; C-Net loss

title: Pretoria's License to Muzzle
description: The dubious proposals advanced in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to license journalists have so far survived the repeated denunciation of Western editors. But now they face a m ore formidable threat: embrace, by imitation, from SouthAfrica.

title: No Headline
description: Cavaliers 108, Pacers 104

title: RIFT ON SALVADOR GROWS IN CONGRESS
description: Congress appears to be increasingly divided over the decision to send more aid to El Salvador, but for the moment the Administration seems to have majority support for its policy of trying to prevent the overthrow of the Salvadoran Government.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Business Day article in some edi- tions yesterday incorrectly quoted Treasury Secr etary Donald T. Regan on natural ga s deregulation. Mr. Regan said, ' 'At the current moment the President is not going to propose deregulation of n atural gas or a wind- fall profits tax.''

title: GOLDWATER IN BOOK SUIT
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, and Harcourt Brace Jovanovich are waging a court battle in Manhattan about a book of the Senator's memoirs.

title: AMERICAN MICROSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HARVARD DROPS FOGG ADDITION
description: Harvard Universi ty has canceled plans toconstruct a long-awaited $7.8 million additio n to the Fogg Art Museum, university officials confirmed this e vening.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The exercise of the right to self-determination cannot be denied to the Palestinian people.

title: A Del Monte Corp. Shift For Its Frozen Foods
description: From San Francisco has come the announcement that the Del Monte Corporation is moving its frozen foods business to Young & Rubicam, Chicago, from Advertising to Women, New York.

title: GANNETT COINC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
DEBATE ON TV IN SENATE: NOT FOR PRIME TIME
description: The United States Senate, which frequently bills itself as the World's Greatest Deliberative Body, is seized this week with the momentous question of whether to consider legislation that would permit televising of its proceedings. So far, at least, there has been more dead air than live debate.

title: 8 GUILTY IN A 10 POKER CASE
description: Eight retired men, ranging in age from 63 to 70, were found guilty today of violating Florida's gambling law by playing nickle-and-dime poker at their mobile home village in nearby Largo.

title: DANCE: THE HARLEM HAILS LENA HORNE
description: THE Dance Theater of Harle m was in a festiv e mood Sunday night, when it presented its Emergence Award to Lena Horne. In on-stage ceremonies at the City Center-55th Street The ater, Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook, the company's directors, mad e brief speeches. Then, as the orchestra struck up ''Stormy Weather,' ' Miss Horne entered, and the audience gave her a standing ovation.

title: VEECO INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest quarter reflect the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 forthe translation of foreign currency

title: Steel Losses Are Cited
description: The domestic steel industry has lost $1 billion a year in gross revenues and shipped two million tons a year less than it might have because of subsidized competition from European steelmakers, a leading economist testified today.

title: Chicago Board Head Backs Changes
description: Leslie Rosenthal, chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, today proposed dividing the exchange into four subsidiary exchanges to trade the various futures contracts now listed with the board.

title: 2 DIE IN 2D BLAZE
description: A fire attributed to arson killed seven residents of a Brooklyn tenement early yesterday and injured 27 persons, 14 of them firemen. Fire Department officials said that the blaze, at 258 Albany Avenue in the Crown Heights section, had been set and that they had no suspects.

title: REAGAN MAY BACK JOINT RESOLUTION ON TAX EXEMPTIONS
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today there were ''preliminary indications'' that the White House would accept a joint resolution of Congress, rather than new legislation, opposing tax exemptions for private schools that practice racial discrimination.

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MIME: COLUCCI DEMONSTRATES PHYSICALITY
description: STEVEN COLUCCI, a young mime who appeared last Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, brings an extra physicality to the art form. Short and with the compact muscles of a dancer, he adds elements of classical ballet and acrobatics to his mime.

title: Zapata's Profit Rises
description: The Zapata Corporation, active in energyrelated fields, today said its profit in the fiscal first quarter, ended Dec. 31, rose 56.6 percent, to $22.7 million, or $1.06 a share, from $14.5 million, or 68 cents a share, a year before. Revenues climbed to $121.3 million, from $94.4 million.

title: IT'S THE TIME TO THINK OF SUMMER JOBS
description: TO those students thinking about summer jobs this year - and now is a good time to begin - the big question concerns job availability. What are the chances o f landing a decent summ er job in a recession market? The answer, according to economists a nd labor specialists, isthat conditions are uncertain.

title: SHORT ON RESOURCES, STUDENTS STILL DONATE TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: Many young people who are college students or have been among the unemployed after having attended college manage to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund despite limited resources.

title: Giant Slalom to Steve Mahre
description: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden trained all winter in an effort to retain his title in the giant slalom at the world Alpine championships. He said he would rather fall out of the race than relinquish the championship he won two years ago at the Lake Placid Olympic Games.

title: WITNESSES SOUGHT IN KILLING AT COLUMBIA CAMPUS
description: It was the early morning of Jan. 5, and 22-year-old Salvatore Calandruccio was saying good night to Lucy Vanegas, 17, at the inner entrance door of her apartment building across from the southern edge of the Columbia University campus.

title: GINO'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the 1980 earnings were restated for an accounting change

title: Bonn Predicts Rise in G.N.P.
description: West Germany's gross national product is expected to grow by 1.5 percent in 1982, after having dropped by three-tenths of 1 percent in 1981, the Government said today in its annual economic report. The relatively optimistic forecast is based on expectations of a revival in world trade.

title: FIRST LADY'S CHINA MAKES ITS DEBUT
description: Nancy Reagan's new set of formal chinaware was unveiled at the White House today in preparation for a state dinner for President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.

title: HOME BEAT
description: ONE might wonder why a group of house cleaners comes all the way to the East Coast from Hawaii. One might also register surprise at the rates.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1982
description: International A major policy split on Poland's debts was reported in the Reagan Administration. High Pentagon officials said that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger intended to keep pressing to have Poland declared in default of its debts to the West and to prod Western European nations to halt their natural gas pipeline deal with Moscow. (Page A1, Column 6.) A group of hard-liners in Warsaw has emerged among Poland's rulers, Polish sources said. The strong conservative faction, they said, opposes any political reform, a revival of Solidarity as an independent union and any talks with Lech Walesa. (A3:1-3.)

title: CZECH MUSIC: 'THE DIARY' BY JANACEK
description: JANACEK'S ''The Diary of One Who Vanished'' is a marvelous curio that defies pigeonholing. It is more than a song cycle and less than an opera. It consists of 23 intensely emotional poems, one a ''silent song'' consisting of nothing but dashes in the score, meant to suggest that something steamy happens at that point.

title: Plucknett Files Suit
description: Ben Plucknett, the discus thrower who was suspended for life last year but later reinstated, is suing The Athletics Congress, a part of the International Amateur Athletics Federation, in an attempt to return to competition immediately. Plucknett, from San Jose, Calif., set two world records in the discus throw las t year, but they have not been recognized because of allegations th at Plucknett used anabolic steroids.

title: Signal Net Up 2%
description: The Signal Companies today reported that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 2 percent, to $52.1 million, or 72 cents a sh are, from $51.1 million, or 70 cents, in the same periodof 1980.

title: SAFE, INVI TING I.R.A.' S
description: To the Editor:

title: CHESAPEAKE CORP OF VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RUG WORKSHOPS AT COOPER-HEWITT
description: THE Cooper-Hewitt Museum, which is the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, has assembled a series of four how-to crafts workshops, ''Rugs and Floor Coverings,'' and a decorative arts repair clinic, ''Hand-Woven Rug Restoration.''

title: A MIDEAST WITHOUT PEACE
description: The United States may have to learn to live without Middle East peace.

title: COMPUTING CAPITAL GAIN: RATE CUT AIDS AFFLUENT
description: For wealthy investors who managed to outsmart the market and sell their stocks or bonds at a profit last year, one of the biggest breaks of the new tax law is the retroactive cut in the top capital gains rate. The law slashed to 20 percent from 28 percent the maximum tax on net long-term capital gains, effective for transactions that took place after June 9, 1981. But this dramatic rate cut benefits only those affluent individuals whose tax brackets exceed 50 percent.

title: KOCH POLL TESTS CHANCE IN THE RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: The political advisers of Mayor Koch have taken a statewide poll to test his chances in a gubernatorial campaign. Though it is has long been his practice to take frequent polls on a variety of subjects, the decision to conduct the survey is the first concrete indication that Mr. Koch may be giving more than idle consideration to running for Governor.

title: Power Loss Stops East Side IRT
description: Subway service throughout much of the East Side was halted for more than an hour last night when power was lost on the Lexington Avenue IRT tracks between Grand Central Terminal and 125th Street.

title: Muskie at Center of Clash Born of Good Intentions
description: The City Council in Portland, Me., has renamed the Portland International Jetport for Edmund S. Muskie, but the gesture has caused some embarrassment for the former Maine Senator and Secretary of State.

title: Mrs. King May Retire
description: Billie Jean King, in the twilight of her tennis career, may decide to call it quits for good. Mrs. King walked out in the middle of her first-round Avon tournament match Tuesday night against Ann Kiyomura in Detroit.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HOSE hard-working Congressmen: The House of Representatives officially set a meeting at 3 P.M. yesterday, with the timetable reading: ''Program for Wednesday. No legislative business is scheduled.''

title: LANECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 19
Judge Denies Brunswick Motion
description: A Federal judge has denied the Brunswick Corporation's motion to extend th e proration date and withdrawal dateof the Whittaker Corporation's $320 million t ender offer for Brunswick common stock.

title: U.S. Silver Output Up
description: The United States and Canada increased silver production last year by 15 percent and 13 percent, respectively, but Mexico, the world's top producer, suffered its first decline in five years, Handy & Harman, a major New York metals broker, said yesterday. Production in the United States rose to 36 million ounces, while Canada's output climbed to 38.7 million ounces. Mexican production fell 6 percent, to 45.2 million ounces, the lowest since 1976.

title: CELLIST: DAVID LOW IN LATE-ROMANTIC STYLE
description: PERFORMERS can often be classified according to historical style; one temperament may be peculiarly Baroque, another Classical, still another Expressionist in quality. The cellist David Low, for example, seemed a late-Romantic personality Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: THE NEW FRENCH ENVOY FACES A BIT OF A PROBLEM
description: Bernard Vernier-Palliez, the new French Ambassador, has never been a big party-goer. ''What I despise are futile parties,'' he said the other day, ''where people stand around and don't have anything to say to each other.''

title: LONDON THEFT: $1 MILLION BRUEGEL
description: Thieves took a painting by Pieter Bruegel, the Elder, valued at more than $1 million from a London museum Tuesday, and today museum officials blamed Government spending cuts for the incident.

title: Luigi Rossini, Tenor, Dead; Founder of Opera Workshop
description: Luigi Rossini, a tenor who was a great-grandnephew of the composer Gioacchino Rossini, died Tuesday in his New York apartment. He was 84 years old.

title: FUEL DEALER LEGISLATION THAT IS BOUND TO HURT THE MOTORIST
description: To the Editor:

title: Wedded Bliss
description: She was 18, he was 23, and it did no't take them long to decide they were meant for each other. The second time they met, he proposed, she said ''yes'' and they were married the next day.

title: Miss de Mille Immersed in Tax Work; Tedious Job
description: For a woman who had just won a major award, Agnes de Mille was not in much of a celebratory mood yesterday. ''For the last two months, I've been doing my income taxes,'' said the choreographer, who has been named the recipient of the 1982 Elizabeth Blackwell Award, given by Hobart and William Smith Colleges of Geneva, N.Y., to outstanding women.

title: FORD AND UNION BEGIN TALKS ON WAGE GUARANTEE
description: Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the Unite d Automobile Workers began detailed discussions today on a company offer of a ''guaranteed income stream'' to protect production wo rkers who have been on the job more than 15 years, even if laid off i ndefinitely.

title: WEINBERGER SEEKS TO DECLARE POLES IN DEFAULT ON DEBT
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger reportedly intends to keep pressing to have Poland declared in default of its debts to the West and to have Western European nations halt their natural gas pipeline deal with Moscow.

title: F.T.C. Judge Drops General Foods Case
description: A Federal Trade Commission judge has dismissed charges that the General Foods Corporation used unfair practices and tried to monopolize the coffee market with its Maxwell House brand, the F.T.C. announced today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENTS
description: WHEN refinishing furniture or wood paneling or finishing a raw piece of furniture, a wood stain is usually required to modify the tone or color of the natural wood.

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Net income for the latest year includes an extraordinary tax credit equal to 12cents a share

title: PEIDMONT AVIATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; Ad Agencies' Stock Outlook
description: ADVERTISING agencies may appear as homespun enterprises to the American public, but they contain a strong international streak. In fact, ''International'' is literally the last word in the name of such publicly owned companies as Ogilvy & Mather, BBDO and Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: ZAPATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $867,000 loss from discontinued operations; C-Includes $1,117,000 gain from discontinued operations

title: WHAT PLEASES GUESTS...
description: Charles Moore, architect, Los Angeles:

title: ACTION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,229,100 for the quarter and $5,765,200 for the 6 months; C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $248,900 for the quarter and $423,000 for the 6 months; results for the latest 6 months and the year-ago quarter and 6 months have been restated to reflect discontinuance of the company's retail business during the second quarter of fiscal 1982

title: Hearings Set on Plane Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board announced today that it would convene a public hearing March 1 on the Air Florida jetliner crash that killed 78 persons here on Jan. 13. The board plans to call about 30 witnesses, including survivors, witnesses, rescue personnel and aviation safety experts.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
STAGE: 'ARTICULATED MAN' AT LA MAMA
description: PING CHONG turns dreams into visions and creates a theater of illusion. In his new work, ''A.M./A.M. - The Articulated Man,'' at La Mama Annex, he welcomes us to the atrium of his phantasmagoric imagination. Intellectually, the new piece is difficult to penetrate, at least without the help of exegesis from the author-director, but the images - visual, aural, choreographic, photographic and cinematic - are as ineluctable as they are beautiful. In its stunning procession of stage pictures, the play reminds one somewhat of the work of Robert Wilson, but Mr. Chong has his own distinctive touch.

title: FRANCE, IN A FUEL SUPPLY SHIFT, TO PAY ALGERIA MORE FOR GAS
description: The Government announced today that France would pay substantially higher prices for imports of natural gas from Algeria.

title: AMBASSADOR GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CITY LIBRARY OFFICIALS SAY U.S. AID HAS BEEN CUT BY OVER 50%
description: Federal funds for New York City public libraries have been cut by more than 50 percent this year, library officials said yesterday. As a result, a number of programs will be severely curtailed, including job-search services that are used by more than 200 people a day and a literacy program that has a waiting list of 300 people.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Libya Says U.S. Fighter s Buzzed a Jetliner

title: TIN MINING MAGNATE AND FORMER ENVOY
description: Antenor Patino, a businessman and diplomat who made a fortune in the tin-mining business, died Tuesday at New York Hospital, a spokesman for the Bolivian Consulate said yesterday. He was 85 years old.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 4, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Ex-Citibank Chief Gets Venture Post
description: At the age of 76, when most retired executives are little involved in day-to-day business decisions, George S. Moore is taking a fresh approach. Mr. Moore, a former chairman and chief executive officer of Citicorp and Citibank, has just been named chairman of Ingram Worldwide Investments, a new venture-capital concern established by the Ingram Group, an energy-oriented international business organization.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
JAMES, FRED S, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upstate Crash Fatal to Pilot
description: A 24-year-old man died today of injuries suffered in the crash of a twin-engine airplane Tuesday night.

title: BREZHNEV OFFERS DEEP ARMS CUTS IN EUROPE BY '90
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev today proposed a two-thirds cut in United States and Soviet arsenals of medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe by 1990.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams Drug Co. announced the retirement of Samuel Salmanson as chairman and secretary of the company. He will continue as director. Charles Salmanson, vice chairman and treasurer, was named chairman and treasurer. Jerrold Salmanson was named secretary.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: FOR the accommodation of guests in his New York studio, the artist Richard Lowell Neas installed a Murphy bed in an armoire (see page C6).

title: Young & Rubicam Gets Gannett's USA Today
description: In addition to Del Monte, Young & Rubicam, which has been serving the Gannett Company as corporate ad agency for two years, has also been named to do advertising for USA Today, Gannett's proposed national newspaper scheduled for publication in the autumn.

title: SCHMIDT SEEKS VOTE OF CONFIDENCE OVER ECONOMY
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who has threatened to resign if he fails to receive support for a new program of employment stimulants, called on Parliament today for a vote of confidence on Friday, the first such vote in West Germany since 1972.

title: Venezuela Oil Price Cut
description: Venezuela lowered its export prices for high-sulfur-content residual fuels by between 25 cents and 94 cents a barrel, an official from the state oil monopoly, Petroleos de Venezuela, said today.

title: The Rumanian Touch
description: The Rumanian couple who coached Nadia Comaneci to a gymnastics gold medal at the 1976 Olympics are planning to move to Texas and train young Americans for the Games, according to officials at Sam Houston State University in Huntsville. The univers it y said that the coaches,Bela and Marta Karolyi, who defected to the U nited States last June and settled in Norman, Okla., were expected t o begin teaching physical education at Sam Houston in August a nd to become part-ownersin an athletic club in Houston where they hop e to train future Olympians. In Norman, the Karolyis have been lecturers and consultants at the University of Oklahoma.

title: O'NEILL PROPOSES A $3.1 BILLION BUDGET
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed a $3.17 billion budget today that calls for a 7.3 percent increase in spending with no new taxes. Most of the new spending for the fiscal year beginning in July would be in areas over which the Governor has no discretion.

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including income of $630,000, or 9 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change

title: MANHATTAN NEWSSTAND SELLS 2D MULTIMILLION-DOLLAR LOTTO TICKET
description: In defiance of astronomical odds, a Queens plumber yesterday won $3.35 million on a state Lotto ticket bought from the same midtown newsstand that issued the winning ticket for last November's record $5 million jackpot.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Grant Is Made to Save R.K.O. Keith in Queens
description: In an effort to save the interior of the R.K.O. Keith Theater, the New York Landmarks Conservancy has been awarded a $3,000 matching grant from the National Trust for Historic Preservation to sponsor an economic and architectural analysis of a plan to retain the theater as a landmark.

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pinter to Attend 'Hothouse' Rehearsals; Pinter Will Attend ' Hothouse' Rehearsals
description: Harold Pinter, the British playwright, will arrive in Providence, R.I., on Monday to spend a week at rehearsals of the Americ an premiere of his play ''The Hothouse'' at the Trinity Square RepertoryCompany. The drama, which is being staged by Adrian Hall, the director of Trinity Square, will begin perfor mances March 5.

title: Knicks Triumph; Williams Returns
description: Sly Williams was lounging during the afternoon in the corner of the lobby at the hotel where the Knicks were staying, dressed in a gold and velvety sweatsuit, when Maurice Lucas approached with an outstretched hand and a smile.

title: TRAGICOMEDY: ACT II
description: As he raises the curtain on the second year of his Presidential performance, Ronald Reagan's benign image partly masks but doesn't wholly conceal his deeply cynical role.

title: SPEAKING IN TONGUES
description: There are countries in the world where language is the most d ivisive political issue. Belgium and Canada are racked by the a rgument, which reflects real rivalry for economic and social b enefits.

title: NEWPORT DEFENSE CHALLENGES FAMILY
description: Martha von Bulow's son, Alexander von Auersperg, testified today that he and his sister and grandmother had paid ''somewhere in the neighborhood of $100,000'' in an attempt to determine why Mrs. von Bulow fell into a coma at her mansion here on Dec. 21, 1980.

title: ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 Chained to a Barge To Protest Dumping
description: Three environmentalists protesting the dumping of acid waste last night chained themselves to the anchor chain of a barge used in the dumping for six hours, but were cut free by Coast Guardsmen and returned to their ship anchored nearby off Staten Island.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: CRAFTS
description: Arts Program at Teachers College, Co- lumbia University, 525 West 120th Street.

title: Outlet No Snag To Columbia Deal
description: The Coca-Cola Company said that its proposed acquisition of Columbia Pictures Industries would not be affected by its review of its proposed acquisition of the Outlet Company.

title: THE EXCUSES THAT KEEP THEM AWAY
description: ''OH, we'd love to have you but, uh, the apartment is being painted that week.'' That's the answer. The question was: ''Can we stay with you when we come to New York?''

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $311,000 for the quarter and $849,000 for the year; C-Including a tax credit of $1,330,000 and a gain of $1,561,000 from the extinguishment of bank debt

title: Stan Getz's 55th
description: If he keeps it up, it's just possible that someday Stan Getz will master the tenor saxophone. But after 40 years, the most his fans can apparently hope for is that he continues his public quest for perfection.

title: Soviet Streak in Pairs Ended by East Germans
description: A 17-year Soviet domination of the pairs competition in the European Figure Skating Championships ended tonight when Sabine Baess and Tassilo Thierbach of East Germany took the title.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE TRUANTS. Adventures Among the In- tellectuals. By William Barrett. 270 pages. Anchor/Doubleday. $15.95.

title: SNOWSTORMS ALSO BRINGING FINANCIAL CHILL TO CITIES WITH DWINDLING DOLLARS
description: In addition to dumping ice, snow and misery on millions of people, the violent storms that have plowed across the country in the last month have brought added financial troubles to many cash-starved cities whose budgets have been sharply trimmed in the face of reduced Federal aid and dwindling local revenue.

title: ATLANTANS WAIT AS TRIAL TURNS TO QUESTIONS OF MOTIVE
description: For more than a year, the mysterious deaths and disappearances of young blacks here ignited imaginations and filled conversations with wonder and speculations about the bizarre.

title: IMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $4.7 million loss on sale of investment in Pop Shoppes Intl; companyis listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: Mexican Oil Plan Reported
description: The Mexican Petroleum Institute has recommended that Mexico elimi nate its ceiling s on exports of crude oil and natural gas so that funds can be rais ed for industrial development, Petroleum Information Internatio nal reported today in its latest edition.

title: MUSIC CRITICS HAVE FEELINGS, TOO
description: BEFORE I added the words ''music critic'' after my name, no one ever asked my opinion about anything. Now, for a few people at least, my word seems to carry some weight - even though I know just about as much (or as little) now as I did then. The title is not granted by license, so why are music critics assumed to possess certain powers and why are they expected to operate in mental states that don't apply to other people?

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Richard G. Shapiro, the 57-year-old president of the specialty store division of W.R. Grace & Company, has resigned ''to pursue other business interests.'' The company did not elaborate on Mr. Shapiro's resignation, and the executive was not in his office yesterday.

title: Source of Rashes in Lupus, Incurable Disease, Is Traced
description: Rashes suffered by victims of lupus, an incurable, life-threatening disease, are caused by a substance coded to attack the skin, a group of researchers has reported.

title: QUESTIONS IN PHOTO SESSIONS IRK STAFF OF THE WHITE HOUSE
description: The White House is once again irked by questions posed during photo sessions.

title: People
description: * Victor L. Olesen has joined Kenyon & Eckhardt as executive vice president in charge of its new Western division.

title: TOLEDO TRUSTCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
S.& P. to Begin Rating Tax-Exempt Notes
description: The growing use by state and local governments of short-term taxexempt notes has prompted the Standard & Poor's Corporation to extend its ratings to include those issues as well as tax-exempt issues of bonds and commercial paper that it already rates.

title: UREA-FORMALDEHYDE INSULATION BAN ADVISED
description: The technical staff of the Consumer Product Safety Commission advised the five-member Federal panel today to ban urea-formaldehyde insulation in homes and commercial buildings as a health hazard.

title: WHAT WE NEED IS TAX INDEXING
description: To the Editor:

title: Kidnapper Given New Term
description: Kenneth Parnell, already sentenced to seven years in prison for kidnapping, was sentenced today to 20 more months for another kidnapping. Mr. Parnell, 50 years old, was convicted last month with Ervin Murphy of kidnapping and conspiring to kidnap 7-year-old Steven Stayner, who was taken from a Merced, Calif., street on Dec. 4, 1972, and lived like a son with Mr. Parnell for seven years. Mr. Parnell was sentenced earlier for the 1980 kidnap of Timmy White of Ukiah.

title: An App raisal
description: There is an Upper West Side of brownstones and old apartment buildings and tenements and shoemakers and greengrocers, and there is another Upper West Side of new high-rise apartment towers and sleek sidewalk cafes and fancy ice-cream shops. At this moment in the history of Manhattan, the first West Side is rapidly giving way to the second.

title: Swimmer, 15, Dies
description: A 15-year-old high school swimmer died today after having become ill at team practice Tuesday. An autopsy was scheduled on the body of Anthony Martino of Eggertsville, a sophomore at St. Joseph's Collegiate Institute in the Buffalo suburb of Tonawanda.

title: Cincinnati Section Votes To Resume Liquor Sales
description: Residents in a mostly working-class section of Cincinnati who voted three months ago to ban the local sale of beer and liquor thronged to the polls in a special election Tuesday to approve emergency legisation restoring such sales.

title: PLANT PATHOLOGIST TO RECIEVE AWARD
description: The first Gold Medal of Horticulture has been awarded to Dr. Pascal P. Pirone, a noted plant pathologist, by the New York State Nurserymen's Association. Dr. Pirone recently retired after having been the plant pathologist at the New York Botanical Garden since 1947.

title: ST JOHN'S SUBDUES BOSTON COLLEGE, 71-70
description: In the end, Bob Kelly, the junior point guard for St. John's, could smile at the thought that he had helped the basketball reach Billy Goodwin for the twisting eight-foot jumper with four seconds left that beat Boston College tonight, 71-70.

title: Wooden Remembers Booster
description: John Wooden said today that he had been aware of the closeness between the players on his championship U.C.L.A. basketball teams and Sam Gilbert, a wealthy Los Angeles businessman.

title: People Express Tries TV Spoof
description: When the year-old People Express Airlines began its cut-rate, nofrills service here in the East, its advertising pitch could be purely price since the competition wasn't into that yet. Now they are, so Peoplexpress (as its logo reads) will make fun of the other guys' deals.

title: Florida State Inquiry
description: At Florida State University, the chairman of an investigating committee said that the charges made by James Bozeman, a former basketball player for the school, would be looked at ''very seriously.'' Bozeman has accused the university of helping athletes cheat on exams, paying money to him and giving him drugs so he could play while injured.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reagan Is Challenged By Maryknoll Leaders
description: Leaders of the Maryknoll missionary orders have challenged President Reagan's decision to certify that the human rights situation in El Salvador has improved. In a statement issued Tuesday, the Rev. James Noonan, superior ge neral of the Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers, and Sister Regina Mc Evoy, vice president of the Maryknoll Sisters, said increased mi litary aid to El Salvador ''will serve only to further the violencedo ne by the security forces of El Salvador against their own pe ople.''

title: KOCH LIVES UP TO HIS FORM
description: Bill Koch, who went from being America's most famous skier to possibly its most infamous and then back again, is eye-catching. Against the white snow of the mountains, Cokie, as friends call him, is seen wearing a yellow-and-black-striped bumblebee knit cap, distinctive from the standard solid blue or red tuque of the United States ski team.

title: A ROLE FOR PARENTS IN VIDEO GAMES
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN BUSINESS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Belle Smith Spafford, Mormon Relief Official
description: Belle Smith Spafford, leader of the Mormon Church's Relief Society for nearly 30 years until her retirement in 1974, died Tuesday after a lingering illness. She was 86 years old.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 4 cents a share gain from real estate gains; sales andnet income for the first quarter of 1981 have been restated to include ZynolyteProducts Co which was acquired in November 1981 in a pooling of interest transaction

title: Nuclear Waste Disposal Issue
description: HOW should we dispose of nuclear waste? A lot of people think that the question is not a technical one. Their point of view was expressed succinctly by a South Carolina Congressman, Butler Derrick, last November. "We have the technology to do it," he said. "The problem is politics. No state wants it. No state will take it."

title: Florida Bank Seeks Merger
description: In a move that could thwart a thrust into Florida by the Chemical Bank, the Sou theast Banking Corporation announced yesterday that it had obtained an option to buy one-third of the shares outstanding of the Florida N ational Banks of Florida Inc.

title: AFRIKANERS SHUN A CLERIC WHO PRAYS WITH BLACKS
description: Until about a year and a half ago, Beyers Naude worshiped on Sunday mornings at the Dutch Reformed Church in a white suburb of Johannesburg called Parkhurst.

title: A.M.C. Rebates
description: The American Motors Corporation, following the lead of the nation's two biggest auto makers, said it would expand its current rebate program through March 31. The rebates on 1981 and 1982 American Motors cars and most Jeep vehicles have been increased to between $400 and $1,000 from the previous range of $300 to $600, the company said.

title: Study Blames Industry For New-Drug Delays
description: A Congressional study released today blames the pharmaceutical industry, not the Government regulatory process, for significant delays in bringing new drugs to market.

title: PHYSICIAN'S TAPES RULED IRRELEVANT IN INVESTIGATION OF ATTACK ON AIDE
description: A Bronx judge ruled yesterday that two tape recordings made by a surgeon at the Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center were not ''relevant to the investigation'' into an attempt to murder the physician's assistant.

title: By Sports of The Times; A Player's Right Not To Fight
description: PERHAPS there is hope for the National Hockey League now that some of the players are influencing it for the better. Hockey's best-known player, Wayne Gretzky, has been proving that skill is more entertaining than kill. And one of its least-known players, Paul Mulvey, suddenly is a defender of the right not to fight and a disciple of the teachings of that now-reformed ruffian, Dave Schultz.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Home Ra tes Decline
description: The average interest rate for new mortgages dropped to 17.33 percent in January, the third consecutive monthly decline, the Government said today. The continuing fall in those rates ''appare ntly reflected a delayed response to the substantial decline i n market interest rates in November,'' the Federal Home Loan Bank Boa rd said in a new report.

title: VIETNAM AND CHINA ENGAGING IN RENEWED VERBAL HOSTILITIES
description: A series of border incidents during the Lunar New Year holiday last month has prompted new recriminations between China and Vietnam, which have been on hostile terms since their border war three years since their border war th ree years ago.

title: FLEMING COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $862,000 for the quarter and year; the results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of the McLain Grocery Co on a pooling-of-interests basis in December 981; the 1980 results restated for an accounting change

title: No Headline
description: RECRUITER SUSPECT IN 'SLAVE' CASE IS ARRESTED

title: NORTHWEST ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV: HOPKINS AS THE HUNCHBACK OF NOTRE DAME
description: ONE of the most powerful scenes in the ''Hallmark Hall of Fame's'' excellent new production tonight of ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' (CBS-TV, 9 P.M.) takes place when Anthony Hopkins, playing the hunchback Quasimodo, confronts the beautiful gypsy Esmeralda (Lesley-Anne Down) in the church bell tower after rescuing her from certain death.

title: Soviet Finds Debt Costlier
description: The Soviet Union and its allies are finding it more expensive to borrow money from Western banks since the military takeover in Poland, banking sources said here today.

title: SAVING TIME, SAVING GRACE; Honorifics
description: Scene I: a Manhattan bus stop on a Saturday afternoon. Characters: middle-aged man in Irish tweed hat and Burberry coat. Very tall, disheveled young man, in once-white sneakers, buttonless old polo coat fastened with a big safety pin, red woolen cap.

title: WALKER, HIRAN, RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $5.2 million foreign currency loss; C-Includes $11.5 million foreign currency gain

title: Soviet Pentecostal Cites Threat of Force-Feeding
description: A Pentecostal who ended a monthlong hunger strike after she had been moved from the United States Embassy to a Moscow hospital indicated today that she had given up the protest because of threats that she would be force-fed.

title: KEY RATESKEY RATES
description: In percent Yesterday Previous Day Year Ago PRIME RATE * 16.50 16.50 19.50 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 15.38 15.34 16.33 3-MO. TREAS.

title: No Headline
description: VIRGINIA SETS BACK NORTH CAROLINA, 74-58

title: CONCERT: ROREM PREMIERE AT JUILLIARD
description: THE Juilliard School's mid-winter enthusiasm for 20th-century music is not yet over, what with the performances of Roger Sessions's opera ''Montezuma'' scheduled for Feb. 19-23. But last Friday at Alice Tully Hall marked the end of the school's annual Festival of Contemporary Music, with the sixth concert of the series, and the third orchestral concert.

title: Reagan Picks Businessman
description: President Reagan nominated James Winchester on Tuesday to be associate administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Mr. Winchester, 65 years old, of Pass Christian, Miss., has been a consultant and owner of Business and Engineering Consultants Inc. since 1977. He would succeed George Benton.

title: Virginia Dooms Equal Rights
description: A committee of the Virginia General Assembly today effectively doomed the proposed Federal equal rights amendment in the state by tabling it indefinitely.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The entrance doors to our house each have a button to ring the central chime - a single tone for the side door and a double tone for the front door. The chime is powered by a 10-volt transformer in the basement. We cannot hear the chime in the back of the house, or in the basement when the television is on. Would the chime be louder if we installed a 16-volt transformer, or can I install a buzzer in the basement (that will sound when the front button is pressed) without running wires all the way to the button and the chimes? - M.E.A., Whitestone, N.Y.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DELTA PLANS TO MATCH OTHERS' LOW FARES
description: In an attempt to put pressure on competitors to limit fare discounting, Delta Air Li nes announced yesterday that it would match, with s ome restrictions, the lowest fare of any major airline on any of its domestic routes.

title: Ward Gets Mobil Funds
description: The ailing Montgomery Ward & Company retailing unit of the Mobil Corporation said yesterday that its corporate parent had contributed another $220 million in December to finance its operations.

title: Bard Implants' Officer Promoted to President
description: Daniel M. Mulvena, 33, has been appointed president of Bard Implants, a Billerica, Mass., company that manufactures devices and implants for use in surgery. Previously Mr. Mulvena was vice president and general manager of the rapidly developing division of C.R. Bard Inc.

title: PULLMAN'S OWNER TO STOP PRODUCING PASSENGER CAR
description: Wheelabrator-Frye Inc., which acquired the Pullman Corporation two years ago, said yesterday that it would halt production of Pullman's railroad passenger cars. Pullman was the last American-owned company to produce the cars.

title: MERIT BADGE FOR TYRANTS
description: Having certified the good behavior of the El S alvador junta, President Reagan is ready for the next logical step. U nless there is a last-minute change of mind, he will shortly c ertify that Chile's dictatorship and its torturers are making ' 'significant progress'' in respect for human rights.

title: ALASKA AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a pretax gain of $1,626,000 from the sale of property and equipment; C-Including a pretax gain of $1,616,000 from the sale of property and equipment and a tax credit of $1,246,000

title: MORE FLIGHTS PERMITTED AT 14 AIRPORTS IN U.S.
description: Beginning in April, the Federal Aviation Administration will increase the number of flights permitted at 14 of the nation's 22 largest airports, a spokesman for the agency said today.

title: Allen Signs 2-Year Mets Pact for $800,000
description: Neil Allen signed a two-year contract for nearly $800,000 yesterday that made him the highest-paid relief pitcher in the history of the Mets, and then agreed not to contest any decision by the team to switch him to the starting rotation.

title: Macchiarola Gets A Raise of $16,000
description: Frank J. Macchiarola, the city's Schools Chancellor, received a raise of $16,000 from the Board of Education yesterday, increasing his annual salary to $85,000.

title: IC Industries' Net
description: IC Industries, a diversified transportation, consumer products and heavy manufacturing concern, said today that fourth-quarter earnings of $44.8 million were unchanged from the same 1980 period, while revenues fell 2.7 percent, to $1.09 billion, from $1.12 billion.

title: COMMUNISTS OPEN MEETING IN FRANCE
description: The French Communist Party, battered in its own country and out of step with its sister parties in Western Europe, opened its first congress in three years today.

title: VALLE'S STEAK HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Canadiens 6, Oilers 3
