description: Mark Napier scored two goals in the first three minutes of the third period to help Montreal win its seventh straight.

title: Stockman Is Criticized
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and the Budget, is largely to blame for a recession that is ravaging the nation's economy and threatening to scuttle Reaganomics, Paul Craig Roberts, a former Reagan Administration official, said yesterday in an article to appear in Fortune magazine.

title: EISENHOWER'S TRY AT NEW FEDERALISM
description: To the Editor:

title: IOWA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOVIET SAID TO STOP DEPLOYING NEW SS-20'S AGAINST EUROPE
description: A West German legislator said today that a member of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party had told him that the Soviet Union had stopped deploying SS-20 missiles targeted on Western Europe.

title: POLISH PRICE RISES HURT FAMILY BUDGETS
description: The price increases in food, fuels and electricity that took effect on Monday come at a time when, according to official figures, the cost of living for the 18 million workers in the socialized sector has risen by 25 percent over the last year.

title: A.T.&T.'S NEW CHALLENGES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Co. settlement with the Justice Department will provide grist for business school case histories for years to come. It is a nearly perfect case - one that raises many issues, is filled with uncertainties and for which there are no clear-cut answers.

title: HANNA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Saudi Oil Flow Is Said to Dip
description: Saudi Arabia's oil output slipped last month to just under 8 million barrels a day from an average ceiling of 8.5 million in force since November, oil industry sources said here today. Saudi Arabian officials were not available for comment.

title: BOTANIC GARDEN TO OFFER SEMINARS
description: ACCORDING to Donald E. Moore, president of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, winter is as good a time as any to teach nature to city dwellers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON CAMPUS

title: TUCKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: Grant Mulvey Scores 5 Goals

title: IN NOVEL CUSTODY SETUP, PARENTS ALTERNATE CARE
description: INTERLOCHEN, Mich. ALLAN CHURCH, 44 years old, and his former wife, Cheryl, 37, are still surprised by a judge's divorce decree stipulating that their three adolescent sons continue to reside in the family home while the parents, who were given joint custody, take monthly turns living with the children.

title: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1982; International
description: France has agreed to pay substantially higher prices for natural gas imported from Algeria. The new accord was seen as a victory for Algeria, which has long sought to raise gas prices to the level of world oil prices. The move caused fresh concern that Western Europe may become dependent on possibly unreliable energy sources. (Page A1.)

title: IOWA ELECTRIC LIGHT & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DOCTORS CENSURED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: The Massachusetts Medical Society said today that it had censured three doctors who wrote highly favorable letters of recommendation for a colleague recently convicted of raping a nurse. They were also placed on a year's probation.

title: SUNSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: C.I.A. ADOPTS CODE TO AVERT ABUSES BY EX-AGENTS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, in response to disclosures about the Libyan activities of former agents, has adopted a new code of conduct that prohibits the use of public office and inside information for private gain, according to agency officials and Congressional sources.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $6,743,000

title: CONGRESS
description: It will be some months before the Administration sends Congress its specific propos als for President Reagan's ''new federalism'' program, White Ho use officials told Congressional Republicans today.

title: 5 Guatemalans Reported Slain by Guerrillas
description: Leftist guerrillas killed five people and injured 17 in two attacks on Government targets, the army announced today.

title: Let Buses Loose
description: ''It's such a comfort to take the bus,'' goes the old jingle, but it's not one that many people take to heart. In the 1970's, intercity buses steadily lost passengers to planes and cars. Now buses have hope for a comeback, thanks to a legislative initiative to eliminate wasteful regulation.

title: Sony Buys Maker O f Taping Devices
description: The Sony Corporation of America said that it had acquired MCI Inc., a privately held manufacturer of professional recording studio equipment based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: I.C.C. HEAD ASSAILED ON TRUCKING
description: In a report signed by 15 members of Congress, including seven Republicans, the committee suggested that President Reagan name new members to the commission who favor more competition and less regulation in trucking.

title: Transit Report
description: CONRAIL: Of 121 trains scheduled in yesterday morning's rush hour, 20 were late and one was canceled.

title: 'JOHN HEARTFIELD, PHOTOMONTAGIST'
description: ''JOHN HEARTFIELD, Photomontagist'' is a look at the witty, impudent works of the German artist, assembled by a film maker whose work also has an impudent strain. As directed by Helmut Herbst, this German documentary assembles many Heartfield posters and book jackets. It also tries to examine the technique of photomontage, and offers a sketchy view of the Nazi Germany in which Mr. Heartfield launched his political barbs against Hitler and his regime.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday at 2:30 P.M. for robbing a private home at 2314 63d Street in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section. The police said the suspect, Edwin Velez of 2391 Bedford Avenue, would be charged with ''numerous'' crimes against the elderly in the Bensonhurst, Flatbush and Sheepshead Bay areas. ... Two armed men held up a branch of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company at 1275 Avenue of the Americas, near 51st Street.

title: Bridge: A Poor St art Can Be Good If End Pro ves Satisfactory
description: There are times when one can start on the right foot and finish on the wrong foot, and, vice versa. That seems to be the moral of the diagramed deal, reported by Dal Beers of Cromwell, Conn., from an insurance league in Hartford.

title: CHIEF DONOVAN ACCUSER BARS UNDERGOING LIE DETECTOR TEST
description: The chief witness in the investigation of corruption charges against Raymond J. Donovan, the United States Secretary of Labor, refused yesterday to take a lie-detector test.

title: Arbour Adds All-Stars
description: John Tonelli of the Islanders and Barry Beck and Ron Duguay of the Rangers are among eight players added by Coach Al Arbour to the Wales Conference team that will play the Campbell Conference next Tuesday night in the National Hockey League's All-Star Game at Landover, Md. None of the Rangers had been chosen among the first 12 players picked to the Wales team, by balloting of sportswriters, but Tonelli joins Mike Bossy of the Islanders, who was selected for the starting six, and another teammate, Bryan Trottier, selected for the second team.

title: E.E. Cummings Art Show
description: The art of E. E. Cummings will be displayed at the Gotham Book Mart, 41 West 47th Street, all this month. Gallery hours are from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. The late poet's work in the show includes paintings, watercolors and drawings.

title: NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PENN VIRGINIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fortunate Finland
description: The remarkable point about Finland's election of a new President is how unremarkable it all seems. Mauno Koivisto, a Social Democrat, will replace the right-of-center Urho Kekkonen, Finland's President for 25 years. Moscow celebrates a ''clear tilt to the left,'' but that dramatic interpretation has somehow eluded the new President. Mr. Koivisto talks of slogging forward in familiar paths.

title: Required Reading Starting; START
description: Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, speaking in the Senate on resuming talks with the Soviet Union on limiting strategic arms. Jan. 25, 1982:

title: HOME INVADED, WOMAN RAPED
description: Three men broke into a Queens home yesterday, tied up a couple and two of their children and raped the couple's 20-year-old daughter before fleeing with jewelry, money and a color television set, the police said.

title: Rains Flood Southeast; Snow Covers Midwest
description: A vast storm system flooded the Southeast with seven-inch rains yesterday, blanketed the Middle West under nine inches of snow and brought freezing rain to the Northeast.

title: SPORKIN ENJOYING MOVE TO CASEY AND COMPANY
description: A top official of the Central Intelligence Agency spent a week in California last month attending a securities conference. But the session had nothing to with national security.

title: SETON HALL LOSES 8th STRAIGHT, 90-80
description: Things continued to go from bad to worse for Seton Hall tonight. The Pirates lost their eighth game in a row, 90-80, to Syracuse, and with eight difficult games left in the schedule the possibility of going without another victory the rest of the season is not remote.

title: INTERSTATE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hanna Mining Net Off 66.4%
description: The Hanna Mining Company reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 dropped 66.4 percent, to $4.2 million, or 47 cents a share, from $12.5 million, or $1.39 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Revenues dropped 28.6 percent, to $62.3 million, from $87.3 million.

title: SICKLE CELL LINKED TO 2D ILLNESS
description: Victims of sickle ce ll anemia, an untreatable and often fatal genetic disorder affecting American blacks, may suffer milder symptoms if they ha ve a second hereditary disorder called alpha-thalassemia, researcher s said today.

title: I.B.M.'s Unit In Iran Closed
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has shut down its Iranian subsidiary following a dispute with the Government about ownership, the company and the official Iranian press agency, Irna, announced separately.

title: DANCE: SIMONS TROUPE
description: ALTHOUGH it was sometimes strange, Ton Simons's choreography was always clear at last Thursday night's performance by Ton Simons and Dancers at the Kitchen. The young Dutch choreographer's love of sharp imagery resulted in works so strongly pictorial that they could easily be described in terms borrowed from painting or design.

title: EL SALVADOR AND 2 NEIGHBORS FORM UNION AIMED AT BOLSTERING JUNTA
description: Quietly encouraged by the Reagan Administration, Honduras, Costa Rica and El Salvador have formed a political alliance apparently aimed at bolstering the Salvadoran junta and isolating Nicaragua's leftist regime.

title: Man, 34, Is Slain
description: Mark Hertzan, a 34-year-old man who the police said recently inherited a stable of horses, was shot to death yesterday afternoon in his East Village apartment building.

title: Washington Post's Net Up
description: The Washington Post Company, reaping advantages from the demise of The Washington Star, reported today that earnings surged 17 percent in the final quarter of 1981 although the full-year profit declined.

title: RESTORING THE DECORATIVE DESIGNS OF OLD IRONWORK
description: IRONWORK is an important element in the architectural texture of the city. Fire escapes on the fronts of small apartment buildings, decorative railings of brownstones, window guards and the filigree iron front doors of elegant town houses are visual embellishments in the cityscape.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Greyhound Corp. announced that the company had purchased nearly one million shares of its common stock.

title: Bryant Plans a Shrine
description: Paul (Bear) Bryant would like a museum or some other kind of shrine built on the Alabama campus as a memorial to his record as the most successful coach in college football history, and he says he'll even pay for it. ''All last year everybody wanted to talk about the record, and I didn't,'' said Bryant, recalling the period leading up to the triumph over Auburn, which gave him 315 career victories, one more than Amos Alonzo Stagg.

title: NEVADA NATIONAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating earns; C-Net income

title: U.S., Canada In TV Ad Rift
description: Ten Senators introduced legislation today to retaliate against a Canadian tax law that discourages Canadian businesses from advertising on United States television stations.

title: Beatrice Sale
description: The All-American Bottling Company of New York, a company organized by Forstmann Little & Company, an individual and institutional investment partnership, said it had acquired for $105 million the soft drink division and the Silver Spring Water Company from the Beatrice Foods Company. James L. Dutt, chairman and chief executive officer of Beatrice Foods, said the sale was part of the company's continuing asset redeployment plan.

title: Gannett Gains 14% in Quarter
description: The Gannett Company, a media conglomerate that publishes 85 daily newspapers, said today that it had earned $54.6 million, or $1.01 a share, in the fourth fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31, up 14 percent from the $47.9 million, or 88 cents, posted for the period a year earlier.

title: SCURRY-RAINBOW OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Analysis
description: Governor Carey, whose attacks on President Reagan's economic policies have been steady and frequent, has based his proposed state budget on economic projections that seem as optimistic as the President's own.

title: News An alysis
description: As the tempo of the fighting in El Salvador has heightened, the political debate over Administration policy has been complicated by often contradictory reports from the Government, members of Congress and the press about the civil war there.

title: Warriors 90, Suns 88
description: PHOENIX (AP) - Bernard King of Golden State slammed through a missed shot by a teammate, Purvis Short, with one second remaining to beat Phoenix. The victory moved Golden State (25-18) past Phoenix (24-18) and into third place in the Pacific Division.

title: Poisonous Fumes Force 1,200 From Pocono Area
description: More than 1,200 people fled their homes today to escape poisonous hydrogen chloride fumes from a wrecked truck. The Mayor of Stroudsburg, a resort borough in the Pocono Mountains region of eastern Pennsylvania, declared a state of emergency.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Saoul Mamby will defend the World Boxing Council's superlightweight championship against Kim Sang Hyun, a former champion, on April 11 in Pusan, South Korea. ... A former club official who was accused of being a spy for the owner of the Cleveland Browns has filed a $39 million suit against Sports Ilustrated. An article in the magazine said that Robert Nussbaumer, then a vice president and director of player personnel, was observed listening through a door in 1977 when Forrest Gregg, then the head coach, was talking to his players.

title: RICHARDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Abscam Figure Sues Writer
description: Melvin Weinberg, a key figure in the Abscam trials, has asked a state judge to order Jack Anderson, the columnist, away from his 16-year-old son, Melvin Jr., to spare him from harassment in the wake of his estranged wife's suicide. Mr. Weinberg's lawsuit, filed Tuesday in Martin County Circuit Court, also charged that Mr. Anderson's syndicated column was ''a substantial contributing cause for the suicide'' of Cynthia Marie Weinberg. Her body was found last Thursday, one week after she publicly accused her husband of lying in the Abscam trials.

title: CECELIA BASS LEUCHTER
description: Cecelia Bass Leuchter, a lawyer who founded The Vineland ( N.J.) Times and later was publisher of The Vineland Times-Journal, died Tuesday in Bryn Mawr, Pa. Mrs. Leuchter, a resident of Vineland, was 86 years old.

title: Federated Pact
description: Federated Department Stores and Children's Place Inc., a children's wear retail chain based in Fairfield, N.J., announced jointly in Cincinnati th at they had reached a tentative settlement that would conclude liti gation that had temporarily delayed consummation of the proposed $45 million merger between Federated and Children's Place. Federated sai d the full terms are to be given Children's Place shareholders next week, but that the agreement will allow Children's Place shareho lders to vote again on the proposed merger if they wish.

title: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JERSEY'S 7 G.O.P. HOUSE MEMBERS SUING TO VOID REDISTRICTING
description: The seven Republican members of the House of Representatives from New Jersey announced today that they would file suit in an effort to overturn the state's Congressional redistricting map.

title: 92D ST. Y CONCERT HALL WILL GET ACOUSTIC SHELL
description: AN acoustic shell designed by Cyril Harris will be installed on the stage of the 92d Street Y's Kaufmann Concert Hall this spring. It is expected to improve the sound in one of the city's most active smaller halls. The shell, to cost $150,00, will be installed in early April.

title: A KEY REAGAN AIDE TO RESIGN
description: Martin Anderson, the longtime adviser to President Reagan who has served this last year as assistant for policy development, said tonight that he would resign Thursday for personal reasons.

title: Firestone Tire Savings
description: Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said Wednesday that energy-saving methods instituted at its factories over the past decade had shaved $44.5 million from forecast energy costs during the 19 81 fiscal year. The company said the savings, based on fuel requirem ents for dozens of plants worldwide from October 1980 toOctober 1981, amounted to the equivalent of about 2.4 million barrelsof oil.

title: DATA CARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: B-Reflects a foreign currency accounting change

title: A FRESH LOOK FOR WINFIELD HOUSE
description: LONDON THE official headquarters of the United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's is an imposing, modern and boxy structure on Grosvenor Square, in the heart of London's fashionable West End. In reality, however, vast amounts of embassy business are transacted about one mile to the north during an array of social events held at a stately, Georgian-style residence called Winfield House.

title: SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income represents net assets; net assets at Dec 31, 1981 are after distribution to shareholders of $2.57 a share during the 12 month period and taxes of 39cents a share paid on long-term capital gains retained by the company

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 earnings were increased by $11.9 million because of adoption of the new accounting standard for foreign currency translations and $7.5 million from sale of tax benefits

title: COLONIAL LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
To the Editor:     Your editorial ''Phone Message to Congress'' (Jan. 25) shows uninformed and illogical thinking:
description: * There is no possibility local phone rates will double, on average. Whatever subsidy long distance provides to local, the most that local rates could go up is probably 30 to 40 percent, and this would be over a time span of probably no less than five years.

title: Jet Hijacker Is Identified As 1980 Cuban Refugee
description: A young Cuban refugee who hijacked an Air Florida jet to Havana on Tuesday was a mong the thousands of Cubans who came here in 1980 by sea from the port of Mariel, Government sources said today.

title: HIRAM WALKER MAY SUE DAVIS OIL
description: Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., a major Canadian producer of distilled spirits, reported yesterday that its net income in the fiscal first quarter, ended Dec. 31, fell 57.2 percent, to $37.1 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review of the television program ''Conversations in Black'' in Monday's Times, the director of the Frederick Douglass Creative Arts Center was incorrectly identified. He is Fred Hudson.

title: EQUIFAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN CENTURY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $187,700 for the quarter and $250,100 for the 6 months; C-Including tax credits of $181,600 for the quarter and $503,400 for the 6 months

title: KENNEDY SECRETLY TAPED SESSIONS IN WHITE HOUSE
description: President Kennedy secretly tape-recorded hundreds of phone conversations and meetings in the White House from the summer of 1962 until his death in November 1963, including some with such foreign leaders as Andrei Gromyko and Josip Broz Tito.

title: UNITED STATES SURGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest year have been restated in accordance with FASB Statement No 52; results for the year ago period have been restated in accordance with FASB Statement No 43

title: CANDIDATES GET ON THE TRACK WITH JERSEY-TO-CAPITAL TRAIN
description: A special 17-car train that some call the politicians' Phoebe Snow - the plush passenger train that ran between Hoboken, N.J., and Chicago until about 15 years ago -made its 44th appearance in the last 45 years on the tracks between New York and the nation's capital today.

title: Agency Says Colleges Need Higher Standards
description: Congress was urged Wednesday to impose academic standards on colleges that would force them to expel students receiving Federal aid who have failing grades.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Coach of Kings
description: Don Perry, coach of the Los Angeles Kings, was suspended for 15 days yesterday by the National Hockey League for having ordered Paul Mulvey to leave the bench and join in a team fight during a game last month.

title: Continental Loss; Piedmont Up 78.8%
description: Continental Air Lines reported yesterday that it had large losses for the fourth quarter and the year ended Dec.31, 1981. Its loss for the final quarter of the year was $13.4 million, compared with a loss of $15.1 million for the fourth quarter of 1980. The loss for 1981 was $60.4 million, almost three times the 1980 loss of $20.7 million.

title: 76ers 122, Bullets 96
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Julius Erving scored a game-high 32 points, and Andrew Toney had 22, including the field goal that gave Philadelphia its biggest lead, at 122-94, with 21 seconds left.

title: BIG 3 CAR SALES OFF 23.8% AS G.M. HAS BIG DROP
description: The nation's Big Three automobile makers said today that their domestic new car sales had d eclined 23.8 percent in the last 10-day selling period of January.

title: GRAND KABUKI TO TOUR U.S.
description: The Grand Kabuki of Japan will appear in the United States in a four-week tour that will open June 29 at the Metropolitan Opera House. The engagement will run through July 10.

title: TV Rival Sues Einhorn Over White Sox Pact
description: The Chicago White Sox, the centerpiece of the cable-television sports network forged by Eddie Einhorn, the team's owner, were sued today by a rival cable network, which contends that it has a contract to carry the team's games.

title: SIGNAL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $9.5 million reversal of deferred tax expense related to UK stock reflief legislation and $15.3 million savings on the discontinuance of providing deferred income taxes on undistributed export income;C-Includes $15.3 million credit from discontinued operations; 1980 results restated to include Ampex acquired in January 1981 for 14.1 million common shares of Signal

title: STAGE: JONES AND PLUMMER'S 'OTHELLO'
description: BY the end of the ''Othello'' that opened on Broadway last night, you will, I think, ache for James Earl Jones's noble Moor - a massive mountain of strength reduced to so much dust in his smothered Desdemona's boudoir. But up until then, you may ache even more for Christopher Plummer's Iago.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday, raising the yield on the Treasury's new 14 5/8 percent 10-year notes to 14.68 percent from 14.55 percent estimated a day earlier.

title: 9.7% SHARE OF HEUBLEIN ACQUIRED
description: The General Cinema Corporation, the nation's largest movie theater chain and independent soft-drink bottler, disclosed yesterday that it had purchased 9.7 percent, or 2.1 million shares, of Heublein Inc., owner of the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation and the country's top producer of vodka and mixed cocktails.

title: Dow Declines 7.52, to 845.03
description: Concern over rising interest rates sent the stock market moderatelylower yesterd ay in active trading. The Dow Jon es industrial average finished off 7.52 points, at 845.03. In th e overall market, declining issues on the New York StockExchange outs cored gainers by an 873-to-572 margin.

title: Advertising; J.W.T.  Suspends Executive
description: THE J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY said in a prepared statement, issued yesterday in response to an inquiry, that it had placed the head of its JWT Syndication and spot-buying units on an unpaid leave of absence pending the results of an investigation into improper record keeping i n the syndication unit that was disclosed by its auditing depa rtment.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: A FEW fearless guests dared to wear fur but most of the outerwear was either cloth or filled with down. The occasion was the New York Zoological Society's 86th annual meeting, which began the other evening at Lincoln Center and wound up in the wilds of Central Park.

title: Hervey P. Clark Is Dead at 82; Was San Francisco Architect
description: Hervey Parke Clark, a San Francisco architect for 40 years, died Sunday in Woodside, Calif., after a long illness.

title: SOVIET ARMY ATTACHE EXPELLED BY U.S. ON ESPIONAGE CHARGE
description: The United States said today that it had expelled the senior military attache in the Soviet Embassy here on espionage charges.

title: A LANDLUBBER'S WINTER GUIDE TO THE SEAPORT
description: SOUTH STREET, once the heart of seafaring New York, is a lot more these winter weekends than just a place to visit ships - although the climb up the gangway is always worth making. This weekend, for instance, without once leaving terra firma, you can attend an oldfashioned Sunday reading of the great American sea novel, ''Moby-Dick,'' take a tour down 18th-century streets, browse for book bargains, get a card for your Valentine hot off the press and warm your shivering timbers with hot grog.

title: SPECTRADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FRIONA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
McLean Accepts $101.3 Million Bid
description: SALEM, N.C., Feb. 4 (AP) - The McLean Trucking Company said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by the Meridian Express Company, a privately owned transportation holding company based in Dallas, in a cash buyout valued at $101.3 million.

title: RANGERS TIED, 4-4, BY FLAMES
description: The Rangers extended their undefeated streak to six games tonight, but had their winning streak broken at four when the Calgary Flames tied them, 4-4, with less than three minutes to play.

title: ACOUSTIC MUSIC: MIKE MAINIERI AND WARREN BERNHARDT
description: THE vibraharpist Mike Mainieri and his longtime cohort, the keyboardist Warren Bernhardt, made a rare appearance as a duo at Seventh Avenue South Tuesday in a program of acoustic music enhanced with synthesizer.

title: WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BISCAYNE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SAVING VOTING RIGHTS
description: The Administration opposes the pending amendment to the Voting Rights Act that would prohibit any law ''which results in a denial or abridgement'' of the right to vote on account of race or language. Senators who oppose the amendment argue that it is possible to prove intent to discriminate and also that the proposed amendment will result in proportional representation by race. The extreme difficulties of proving discriminatory intent and the plain words of the bill itself clearly refute both arguments.

title: SCHERER, R P, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BROADWAY
description: year-old head of Paramount's theatrical activities.

title: MOVIE LYRICISTS OPEN Y SERIES ON THEIR SONGS
description: ''LYRICS AND LYRICISTS,'' the series in which authors of some of America's most successful stage and film songs discuss and sing their works, will devote its entire 12th season to movie musicals. The series begins this Sunday and Monday evenings at 8 at the 92d Street Y.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ARABIAN HORSES and art will co-star on Saturday, Feb. 13, in the first auction of its kind ever conducted by Sotheby Parke Bernet and Tom Chauncey Arabians at Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: MEMO: MEESE AND ENVIRONMENTALISTS
description: At the White House last week, the leaders of three major environmental organizations, Russell W. Peterson of the National Audubon Society, Jay Hair of the National Wildlife Federation and J. Michael McCloskey of the Sierra Club, met with Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to the President, and other Administration aides.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 5, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FIXING MR. REAGAN
description: If it ain't broke, the great Georgia philosopher Bert Lance once said, don't fix it. For violating that elemental wisdom on the issue of tax exemption for private segregated schools, President Reagan now finds himself in a fix of his own. It couldn't happen to a nicer guy.

title: PORT JERVIS FLOOD FEAR ROUTS 110
description: Officials of Port Jervis, N.Y., concerned that the Orange County city would be flooded by the ice-clogged Delaware River, declared a state of emergency yesterday and removed 110 residents from homes along the river.

title: Nassau G.O.P. Amends Rules To Keep Margiotta in Post
description: The Nassau County Republican Committee voted unanimously to amend its bylaws last night so that its chairman, Joseph M. Margiotta, could remain in his $50,000-a-year position pending appeal of his conviction on Federal mail fraud and extortion charges.

title: Discovision To Sell Videodisk Operation
description: Discovision Associates, a joint venture of the International Business Machines Corporation and MCA Inc. that manufactured and marketed videodisks and disk players, said yesterday that it was withdrawing from its business and laying off most of its employees.

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CABARET: THE MORIARTY STYLE
description: WHEN Michael Moriarty, the actor, director, playwright, poet, composer, songwriter, pianist and singer, started a nightclub career seven years ago his performance as a pianist and singer was in a lowkey, tentative vein. Since then he has continued to make occasional nightclub appearances, between movies, theater and television, cultivating and honing the base on which he started.

title: WINIFRED SPEAKS
description: Winifred Speaks of Westport, Conn., a poet and short-story writer, died in Norwalk Hospital on Tuesday. She was 79 years old and was the widow of John Speaks.

title: BILL ON SENATE TV IN DEBATING STAGE
description: The Senate voted nearly unanimously today to open debate on a bill to permit televising of its proceedings, but opponents are continuing a strong campaign to keep cameras out of the chamber.

title: Loans for Bangladesh
description: Bangladesh will get $45 million in interest-free loans to help its textile and fertilizer industries, the World Ban k announced today. The loans, to run for 50 years, will be given by t he International Development Association, an affiliate of the bank. A loan of $30 million will go to rehabilitate 15 plants and install c enters to control quality.

title: CENTRAL LOUISIANA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,507,792 for the qr and $21,356,708 for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $6,426,487 for the qr and $18,179,154 for the yr

title:
ADVERTISING;
Addendum
description: * Grey Advertising is forming Rada Recruitment Communications in Chicago.

title: A COACH'S WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: RIP TORN PLAYS DICTATOR IN 'MAN AND FLY'
description: IMAGINE Hitler training Chaplin to be ''The Great Dictator,'' and you will have some of the flavor of Jose Ruibal's ''The Man and the Fly'' (''El Hombre y la Mosca''), a bitter but playful black comedy starring Rip Torn at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.25-16.50. ** Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Miss McPartland Plays
description: The jazz pianist Marian McPartland will appear Sunday night at 8 at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey, 760 Northfield Avenue, in West Orange.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PITTSTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $1,610,000 for the qr and yr; the 1981 fourth qr included about $4 million of net income from the disposal of two small percents of real property which were not required for the company's operati

title: HONDURA S DETECTS NO MAJOR ARMS SUPPLY TO SALVADOR REBELS
description: Despite United States charges that Nicaragua is stepping up arms shipments to Salvadoran guerrillas, no evidence is available here to indicate that the weapons are passing through Honduras, which borders on both Nicaragua and El Salvador.

title: James Convy, 62, Led Naval Design Concern
description: James J. Convy, chairman of the board of Gibbs & Cox Inc., naval architects and marine engineers, died Wednesday at Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 62 years old and had recently moved to Jericho, L.I., after living for many years in Elmont, Queens.

title: CASCADE NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STOCKMAN CONFIRMS STATES CAN LOSE IN 'SWAP' PLAN
description: David A. Stockman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, publicly acknowledged for the first time today that some states might suffer a net loss of Federal money after 1987 as a result of President Reagan's ''new federalism'' proposals.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES FOR OIL TUMBLING
description: Despite one of the worst cold spells in memory, demand for home heating oil and other petroleum products has weakened substantially, dropping prices sharply in the past 10 days.

title: MAID TELLS JURY VON BULOW LIED TO WIFE'S DOCTOR
description: Claus von Bulow lied to a doctor about his wife's condition as she lay unconscious in her bed on Dec. 27, 1979, her personal maid testified today at Mr. Von Bulow's trial for attempted murder.

title: NEWELL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest yr results increased by $376,000 from a change in accounting for foreign currency

title: News Analysis
description: Whether illusion or reality, Mayor Koch is perceived by his fellow politicians as such a potentially strong statewide candidate that his consideration of a possible candidacy for Governor has ''frozen'' a half-dozen other potential candidates in place.

title: Concord String Night
description: The New York premiere of George Rochberg's Quintet for Two Violins, Viola and Cello, written for the 10th anniversary of the Concord String Quartet, will be a highlight of a performance by the quartet Sunday night at 8 in Alice Tully Hall, Broadway and 67th Street.

title: YOUTHS AND MINERS ARE JAILED IN POLAND
description: Courts in Gdansk have sentenced 101 youths to jail from one to three months for participating in clashes with security forces there Saturday. And in Katowice, courts have given nine miners prison terms of three to seven years for organizing a strike last month.

title: TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WILLIAMS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $10,373,000 gain from discontinued operations

title: EX-HEAD OF U.S.I.A. IS CHOSEN TO DIRECT FOREIGN POLICY GROUP
description: Leonard H. Marks, a former director of the United States Information Agency, was elected chairman of the Foreign Policy Association yesterday.

title: Arkansas Won't Appeal Creation Science Ruling
description: Attorney General Steve Clark said today that he would not appeal the ruling that struck down Arkansas' creation science law because he did not think he could win.

title: EUROPEANS DEVISE RAPID METHOD TO DETERMINE IF NUMBER IS PRIME
description: Two Europeans have devised a rapid solution to a problem that has tantalized mathematicians for centuries: how to determine whether a large number is a prime number, indivisible by any other number except 1 and itself.

title: Northrop to Buy Vacant Ford Plant
description: The Northrop Corporation said it was completing plans to buy the Ford Motor Company's vacant auto assembly plant in Pico Rivera, Calif., near Los Angeles, for $65 million.

title: Walesas Have Baby, Their Seventh Child
description: Roman Catholic Church sources said today that Lech Walesa's wife had given birth to a daughter, the couple's seventh child, but that a priest had been barred from visiting the detained union leader to tell him the news.

title: SENATE VOTES CURB ON JUDGES' POWER TO REQUIRE BUSING
description: The Senate today approved a proposal that could virtually eliminate busing as a tool for racial integration of the public schools. The proposal drew strong support from both parties and passed by a vote of 58 to 38, a sign that busing had become highly unpopular in many communities.

title: MURPHY MOTOR FREIGHT LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after writeoff of operating rights of $3,538,000 for qr and yr...C-After tax credit of $1,904,000

title: Bid for Cannon Has 72% Reply
description: David H. Murdock, the Los Angeles financier who controls the Pacific Holding Corporation, said that his offer of $44 a share for the stock of Cannon Mills Inc. had attracted 72 percent of the textile manufacturer's shares.

title: Sports of The Times; Goalie Plays in a New Arcade
description: ZOLTAN TOTH will not soon forget his first game of human pinball, with him playing the part of the flippers at the bottom of the machine. If his intellect should grow hazy about that first game, his elbows and hips and knees will shoot a little pain into his memory.

title: MATHEMATICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $131,000 for the qr and $130,000 for the 6 mos

title: REAGAN PROPOSES OWN PLAN TO CUT MISSILES IN EUROPE
description: President Reagan announced today that the United States had presented the Soviet Union with a draft treaty that proposed the elimination of medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: HEAVY ON THE MUSIC AND EASY ON THE SALVATION
description: If the mention of the Salvation Army Band conjures up a uniformed couple on a street corner, one with a tambourine and the other with a horn, take another look - or better, another listen. Tonight, the Salvation Army's 36-piece band will present a concert that its organizers say will be heavy on the music and easy on the salvation.
''The notion that anybody has been misled, anybody has been deceived, anything has been rigged, is absolutely and utterly without foundation.'' - Mr. Stockman. (A18:5.)

title: Mitterrand to Visit Japan
description: President Francois Mitterrand will pay an official visit to Japan from April 14 to 18, the first by a French head of state, presidential officials said today.

title: Knicks Prolong Laker Decline
description: For the last six weeks, the Los Angeles Lakers have been struggling. They have split their last 14 games, the latest a 98-94 loss to the Knicks Wednesday night.

title: Florida Court Upsets Curb on Campus Life
description: The Florida Legislature violated the First Amendment rights of students last year when it threatened to withhold state dollars from universities that recognized or provided meeting space to groups advocating a homosexual way of life or sexual relations between unmarried persons, the Florida Supreme Court ruled today.

title: POP JAZZ
description: AS the movie ''Fame'' tried to illustrate, there is no other place like New York City where talented children from different ethnic backgrounds can become musically educated while experiencing a rich urban culture and a diverse street life. One result of the crossfertilization between white, black and Hispanic music students has been the emergence of a generation of musicians that doesn't think twice about crossing traditional barriers between pop, jazz and classical, or about mixing salsa, funk and rock.

title: 'NIGHT CROSSING,' FLIGHT FROM WEST GERMANY
description: ''COME on - we're going for a ride!'' ''Going for a ride in that?'' ''Why are you cleaning the bathtub now?'' ''When the police find out we've gone, they'll be in here, and I won't have them all saying I'm a bad housekeeper!''

title: CITY BALLET: 'THE CAGE' AND 'SQUAR E DANCE'
description: BY placing a revival of Jerome Robbins's ''The Cage'' and the season's first performance of George Balanchine's ''Square Dance'' on Tuesday night's program at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet offered two radically different views of society. Whereas one ballet divided society into predators and victims, the other extolled friendly cooperation.

title: COLUMBIA PICTURES INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
BONN DENIES MOSCOW HALTED DEPLOYMENT OF SS-20 MISSILES
description: The West German Government has indications that the Soviet Union is continuing to deploy SS-20 nuclear missiles targeted on Western Europe, an official source said today.

title: PLASTICS: FAST GROWTH STALLS
description: In the last 10 years, executives in such industries as forest products, steel, tires and oil turned to petrochemicals to get in on the the fast-growth business of plastics.

title: Ex-Pentagon Officials Assail Weapons Plan
description: Two Democrats who have been senior officials in the Defense Department said today they had analyzed President Reagan's program for improving the nation's strategic nuclear forces and found it wanting.

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXEMPTIONS BILL ASSAILED AT HEARING
description: President Reagan's proposed legislation to bar tax exemptions for racially discriminatory private schools ran into more opposition today at an all-day hearing before the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee.

title: Squealing on Teen-Agers
description: Sex sells jeans, perfume and cars. Conversely, jeans, perfume and cars sell sex. The audience at a raunchy revue is not applauding the costumes, nor do wine and cheese attract the customers to the kind of party that sells ''marital aids'' instead of Tupperware. The pursuit of a ''good sex life'' is sanctioned not only by millions of Americans but by the I.R.S., which allows a tax deduction for sex counseling. This is life in the United States.

title: ART: FROM GLOUCESTER THE BYPASSED HAVEN
description: ABOUT certain subjects even the most studiously objective and fairminded of critics cannot be expected to write with complete detachment. Some element of personal piety or loyalty is bound to insinuate itself into the discussion, and all you can do in such circumstances - unless you decide to avoid such subjects altogether -is to make a declaration of your interests and leave it to the reader to make allowances for the inevitable bias.

title: NEW YORK'S OPERA SCENE: SMALL, AMBITIOUS YOUNG TROUPES
description: NEW YORK is an opera town: two major companies, important new productions, a host of world-famous singers and an army of eager fans attest to that. But another, perhaps even more telling sign of the importance of opera for the city is the number of smaller companies that offer unusual repertory, ambitious young singers, low ticket prices and intimate settings that sometimes convey operatic drama better than a larger house could ever do.

title: U.S.-A.T.&T.  Delay Sought
description: The Justice Department, in connection with itsantitrust cas e against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, filed a reque st with the Federal District Court here late today to postpone unti l next Wednesday the deadline for filing a competition impact statem ent that was due Friday.

title: REAGAN REPORTED ASKING BENEFIT CUT
description: President Reagan plans to ask Congress to reduce spending on Medicaid and Medicare by at least $5 billion in the next fiscal year, Congressional sources reported today.

title: UNITED ASBESTOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LATE RALLY HELPS DOW CLOSE UP 2 POINTS
description: A late rally in energy and other blue-chip issues spared the stock market from another sizable decline yesterday. Thirty minutes before the closing bell, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 6 points. It finished at 847.03, up 2 points. The Dow outperformed the overall market, which showed 839 declines and 583 advances. Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 53.3 million shares from Wednesday's 49.6 million.

title: OFFICERS CLEARED BY A GRAND JURY IN 'ANGELS' CASE
description: An Essex County grand jury has found no grounds for indicting two Newark police officers in the fatal shooting of a member of the Guardian Angels in December, law enforcement officials announced today.

title: 42ND AND 8TH, CROSSROADS FOR RUNAWAYS
description: The irresistible call of family and blood that summons so many others is barely a murmur to her. ''I'm not coming home, mom,'' she says over the telephone. ''You're going to put me away anyway, so why should I?'' Her name is Shelia. She is 14 years old, lithe, with brown hair and hollow eyes. She lives in a hotel for transients in New Jersey with her mother, and she has run away - again.

title: ON THE RIVIERA, A MORALITY TALE BY GRAHAM GREENE
description: For the past 15 years Graham Greene has been living in an unremarkable fourth-floor apartment overlooking this Cote d'Azur port: a quiet, elusive presence. It is not that the townspeople do not know about him - he tries to be away during the tourist rush - but they respect the fact that even when he is not off to Congo or Paraguay or Panama, his mind is.

title: ORCHESTRA: YOUNG MUSICIANS
description: STRAUSS'S Don Juan thrives on sustaining desire rather than fulfilling it; in the Opus 20 tone poem, he is continuously unsettled, passionately yearning for what Goethe called the ''Eternal Feminine,'' and militantly opposed to ever reaching it.

title: Mr. Reagan's Contempt
description: Why should Congress have to pass a new law barring tax exemptions for segregated schools before the Reagan Administration will obey the law already on the books?

title: No Headline
description: West Virginia Beats Rutgers

title: Grumman's Net Drops 73.5%
description: The Grumman Corporation said today that its net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 dropped 73.5 percent, to $2.7 million, or 12 cents a share, from $10.2 milli on, or 78 centsa share, in t he comparable period of 1980, mainly because of a $30.8 million loss on its troubled Flxible bus subsidiary.

title: A Bit Too Friendly
description: Angel Rodriguez, a catcher for Alexandria of the Class A Carolina League, has been suspended for one year by th e National Association of Profession al Baseball Leagues for tipping off pitches, in Spanish,to rival Lati n American batters. The suspension is retroactive to Aug. 21, 1981 , when the catcher was suspended indefinitely for ''misconduct on the field.''

title: RECORD SET ON 30 YEAR U.S. BONDS
description: The Treasury sold new 14 percent bonds yesterday at an average yield of 14.56 percent, a record for a new 30-year issue that showed the extreme reluctance of investors to buy long-term bonds even though inflation has subsided.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Signed six players to one-year contracts: Jody Davis, catcher; Mike Griffin and Dickie Noles, pitchers; Scott Fletcher and Pat Tabler, infielders, and Mel Hall, outfielder. DETROIT (AL) - Agreed to contract terms with Dave Tobik and Dan Petry, pitchers, and Tom Brookens, third base- man. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Agreed to con- tract terms with Thad Bosley and Bob Skube, outfielders; Dwight Bernard, pitcher, and Steve Lake, catcher. PITTSBURGH (NL) - A

title: BAUSCH & LOMB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,897,000 for t qr and $4,257,000 for the yr and losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $25.8 million for the qr and $33.1 million for the yr...C-Net income after a loss of $390,000 from discontinued operations...D-After a loss from discontinued oper of $258,000

title: Stock Repurchase By Sun Company
description: The Sun Company, a major domestic integrated oil producer, said that its board of directors had authorized the repurchase of its own common stock totaling up to $100 million.

title: MCNEIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The adoption of F.A.S.b. statement 52 increased net income in latest yr by 61 cents and by 1 cent in the previous yr

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE gleam is back in Jack Nicholson's eye. A year ago, he was tired. He had made five movies - ''Going South,'' ''The Shining,'' ''Reds,'' ''The Postman Always Rings Twice'' and ''The Border'' - one after another and, he says, ''I needed time off. So I took the year. I filled up. I feel great.''

title: HYPNOSIS IS ON TRIAL AT STOUFFER HEARING
description: When Betty Jane Scheihing was on the witnessstand Wednesd ay in Westchester County Court here, she spoke crisply, directly and seemingly without emotion in describing how she saw the earliest mome nts of the fire that killed 26 executives at Stouffer's Inn on Dec. 4 , 1980.

title: PENTHOUSE JURORS HEAR HO W SPA F LOURISHED
description: Jurors in the libel suit against Penthouse magazine are hearing how two Las Vegas casino officials and two land developers parlayed their $4 million investment and large infusions of money from a union pension fund into La Costa, a resort they say is worth $250 million.

title: TIE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
R&D DATA CURBS HURT MORE THAN RUSSIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Lions Hire Marchibroda As an Offensive Coach
description: The Detroit Lions have hired Ted Marchibroda, a former head coach of the Baltimore Colts, as offensive coordinator and quarterback coach.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Stores Corp. has elected Elliot J. Stone, Frank W. Harvey and Frank T. Reilly vice presidents. Also ann ounced were the appointments of Ruben L. Slape as vice presid ent-credit; Frank S. Fuino Jr. as treasurer, and Robert J. Strecha y as controller.

title: SPECTRA-PHYSICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VIOLINIST: MACOMBER RECITAL
description: CURTIS MACOMBER is a musician able to do so many things well that he may find it difficult to choose among them. In his violin recital Tuesday at Alice Tully Hall, Mr. Macomber began with J.S. Bach's Partita in E minor, zoomed directly into Meyer Kupferman's very modern Three Pieces for Unaccompanied Violin, ricocheted from those into Fritz Kreisler arrangements of pieces by W.F. Bach and Dvorak, and bounded through Ysaye's transcription of a Saint-Saens piano etude before settling into Chausson's Concerto for Violin, Piano and String Quartet with Jonathan Feldman, pianist, and the Atlantic String Quartet.

title: FEDERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MONOCLONAL ANTIBODIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: Results for the latest first qr include a nonrecurring charge of $543,000 reflecting the cumulative effect on the fiscal yr ended Oct 3, 1981 of an accounting change

title: Greece to Buy Oil From the Soviet Union
description: Greece has concluded an agreement with the Soviet Union for the purchase of two million tons of Soviet oil in 1982, Under Secretary of Commerce Ioannis Papaspyrou announced today.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $4.8 million for the qr and $5.9 million for the yr

title: How Much More for Salvador?
description: What is one to make of the new alarms - and commitments - concerning El Salvador? To justify much more military and economic aid, and even vague threats of direct American action, President Reagan has just certified the unlikely: that the junta is becoming more respectful of human rights and therefore showing promise of popular appeal. And Secretary of State Haig suggests the unproven: that outnumbered guerrillas are beating an American-equipped army mainly because of Soviet and Cuban arms.

title: ARMED MAN HOLDS DOCTORS HOSTAGE
description: A man armed with a .357 magnum pistol, distraught over the death due to leukemia of his 8-year-old son, tookthree doctors and a nurse hostage at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital today and demanded to talk with nati onal news rep orters.

title: Republic Closing Buffalo Bar Mills
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said that it would suspend operations at a Buffalo plant next week and warned that sluggish business ''undoubtedly would soon lead to reductions'' in supplemental benefits paid to some of its furloughed workers.

title: LAWYER IS ACCUSED OF SEEKING $17,000 FROM CLIENT 'TO BRIBE' JUDGES
description: A Manhattan lawyer was charged yesterday with attempting to steal $17,000 from his jailed landlord client by telling him that the money would be used to bribe three judges in a civil suit against the landlord.

title: European Skating Title Won by a West German
description: Norbert Schramm won the men's title in the European figure skating championships tonight.

title: I.O.C. Seeks U.N. Vote On Anti-Boycott Pledge
description: Monique Berlioux, president of the International Olympic Committee, will meet Wednesday with Secretary General Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations to discuss possible adoption of a n anti-boycott resolution for future Olympic Games.

title: HARCOURT BRACE WEIGHS PARTIAL MOVE OUT OF CITY
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, one of the country's largest publishing houses, is thinking of moving at least part of its operations out of New York City.

title: REALTY ASSESSMENT RULINGS ANSWER QUESTIONS AFFECTING CITY AND NASSAU
description: A multimillion-dollar future problem for taxpayers in New York City and Nassau County and the solution to a past political puzzle both can be found in the murky prose of a recent ruling by the state's highest court .

title: BANKS INCREASING FEES FOR LOANS AND SERVICES TO INDIVIDUAL CLIENTS
description: Interest rates and fees paid by individuals for banking services are rising dramatically as banks across the country try to make more money on their retail services or reverse losses.

title: BONRAY DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXCERPTS FROM TALK IN COCKPIT AND TOWER
description: Following are excerpts from transcripts of conversations among members of the crew of an Air Florida plane that crashed Jan. 13 near Washington National Airport, and of conversations between the crew and ground control, as issued yesterday by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: NEW ADVANTAGES IN THE SALE OF A HOUSE
description: Even though the real estate market softened a bit during 1981, a host of new and established tax subsidies continued to make owning a home one of the best investments around. Not only can mortgage interest payments be claimed as an itemized deduction each year, but people who sell homes they have held for more than a year at a profit can also qualify for long-term capital gains treatment. That means that they must report only 40 percent of the profit as ordinary income.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After extraordinary charges of $36,448,000...C-Net income

title: TOPICAL COMEDY AND WALL ST. CRASH
description: ON Sunday, WNET, Channel 13 introduces ''Not the Nine O'Clock News,'' a British topical revue that is funny through and through. Though the series made its debut in Britain in 1979 opposite the evening news on BBC-1 (hence the title), it has traveled beautifully. And it doesn't seem the least bit dated. The show's debts to ''Saturday Night Live,'' ''Monty Python's Flying Circus'' and even ''That Was the Week That Was'' are apparent, yet derivativeness is not a problem. Also, the half-hour format is a great help, since it highlights the program's freshness and never allows it a chance to drag.

title: Economic Scene; Fiscal Distress Of the States
description: AS the nation awaits President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1983, bits and pieces of it have been leaking all week long. Will the deficit be $90 billion, as earlier advertised? Or will it be a mere $85 billion? The unveiling early next week will be closely watched by millions across the nation. Meanwhile, nobody but the ailing municipal bond market is paying attention to the budgetary plight of the states.

title: People
description: * Thomas J. McDonough has been appointed advertising director of TV Guide magazine.

title: ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations, retroactive to July 1, 1981; results for the yr-ago periods reflect the adoption of the LIFO inventory valuation method and for the retroactive adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 43 regarding accounting for compensated absences

title: PROFITS PLUNGE 72.6% AT DOW CHEMICAL
description: The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday that the worldwide economic recession and an accounting change had caused net income in the fourth quarter to plunge 72.6 percent, as sales rose 7.9 percent.

title: Michigan Worker Hurt I n Nuclear Plant Blast
description: Leaking hydrogen gas exploded today in an electrical generator at the Palisades nuclear plant, critically injuring a worker but not releasing any radiation, officials said.

title: B.P. Refinery Output
description: The British Petroleum Company has reduced output at its Rotterdam oil refinery, the second largest in the Netherlands, to around 40 percent of rated capacity, or about 62 million barrels a year, a company spokesman said here today.

title: SENATORS' AIDE LOOKS BACK 27 YEARS
description: When Howard Shuman came to Washington 27 years ago, Southerners ran the Senate, Lyndon B. Johnson was the majority leader and Joseph R. McCarthy had just been censured.

title: ART: PERU'S 'NAZCA LINES' AS SEEN FROM AIR
description: WHO made the ''Nazca lines,'' drawings so vast they can be seen only from the air, in the Nazca desert along the south coast of Peru? And why? These birds, beasts, flowers, spirals, mazes, grids and geometric motifs thousands of feet long and drawn on the soft flats and hillsides of the desert, ha ve been known for more than 40 years. But they are still a mystery to archeologists, who say they are contemporary with the Paracas-Nazca Indian culture (around 300 B.C. to A.D. 900).

title: Nuclear Project Bond Rating
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday reaffirmed its AAA rating for outstanding revenue bonds of the Washington Public Power Supply System's nuclear generating projects No.1, 2 and 3, as well as the $500 million of new bonds scheduled for sale next week.

title: CELANESE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $250,000 for the qr and $4,476,000 for the yr and a gain on the sale of assets of $4,362,000 for the qr and yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $546,000 for the qr and $2,230, for the yr

title: Canadian, U.S. Women Sweep Downhill
description: North American skiers stunned the European and Scandinavian competitors today at the world Alpine championships by sweeping the top three places, and six of the top 10, in the women's downhill. At the finish, the Canadian and American teams reveled together as though they shared a common flag.

title: Article 201069 -- No Title
description: An executive of the Ford Motor Company said today that the company would post a loss ''slightly in excess of $1 billion'' when it officially reported its results for 1981 in a few days.

title: JACQUOLYN M. GILLISPIE
description: Jacquolyn Mercer Gillispie, Miss America 1949, died Tuesday of leukemia at the age of 51.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL REAGAN OVER E.P.A.
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and other Congressional Democrats accused President Reagan and his Administration today of breaking a tradition of bipartisanship on environmental issues by seeking to destroy the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: PRENTICE-HALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Money Fund Assets Lower
description: Assets of the nation's 168 money market funds declined $900 million, to $186.8 billion, in the week ended Wednesday , the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: AMERICAN AGGREGATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'VENOM,' SNAKE-AND-KIDNAP STORY
description: VERY early in ''Venom'' three ill-tempered kidnappers find themselves beseiged by the London police in an elegant Eaton Walk town house with their would-be kidnapee, who is an asthmatic, 10-year-old American boy, as well as with the boy's grandfather, who has just had stomach surgery, and a black mamba snake, which is originally from Africa and is, as one character says, the deadliest snake in the whole ''wold.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Business Day article last Friday on earnings at Texaco Inc. incorrectly reported the date and the impact of the sale of Texaco's interest in the Bel- ridge Oil Company. The sale was in 1980, and the earnings statement for that year excluded the $402 million gain from the sale.

title: AIDE DIES HELPING HOMELESS WOMAN
description: The official who supervises New York City's shelter program for homeless men and women died of an apparent heart attack early yesterday after arranging the emergency transfer of an ill ''shopping-bag lady'' from Grand Central Terminal to Bellevue Hospital.

title: RULE ON GLOVES AMENDED
description: The rule, designed to reduce the risk of eye injury, went into effect Jan. 15. The amendment announced yesterday provides that boxers competing in 8- or 10-round fights will have until May 15 to ge t used to the gloves before they become man datory once again.

title: Coach Defends Conduct
description: Joe Williams, the Florida State basketball coach, appeared yesterday before a special university committee that is investigating charges by a former player who has charged that he was given drugs so he could play despite injuries. Williams told the five-member panel that he has never forced a player to play if the athlete told him he couldn't perform.

title: Columbia Net Increases 32.3%
description: Columbia Pictures Industries, which agreed in January to be acquired by the Coca-Cola Company for $750 million in cash and stock, said yesterday that earnings for its second fiscal quarter rose 32.3 percent from a year earlier.

title: PRESIDENT GETTING NEW CHIEF OF POLICY AS ADVISER RESIGNS
description: Edwin L. Harper, a deputy budget director, is the leading candidate to replace Martin C. Anderson, who is resigning as chief of the White House Office of Policy Development, Administration officials said today.

title: COLOMBIA AIDS U.S. IN A DRUG SEIZURE
description: A 14-month joint operation by the United States and Colombian governments has resulted in the seizure of 6.4 million pounds of marijuana, or one-fifth of the amount that enters this country annually, the Government announced today.

title: UNHELPFUL MESSAGES FOR POLISH REFUGEES
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Real Estate; PART OF OLD ST. GEORGE HOTEL IN BROOKLYN TO BE CO-OPS
description: NO doubt because it was designated a historic district (New York City's first) in 1966, much of Brooklyn Heights, where housing revitalization began in the 1960's, still retains the feel of a turn-ofthe-century middle-class enclave.

title: Rally for Solidarity
description: Supporters of Solidarity, the Polish labor union, will take part in a rally Sunday at 7 P.M. in Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HELPING HANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: At budget time, the late Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, a honey-voiced Republican from Illinois, used to regale his colleagues with the observation, ''A billion here and a billion there, and pretty soon you're talking about real money.''

title: WEBB CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Director Is Hinted For Mediation Service
description: The Reagan Administration appears poised to select a new director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service despite earlier indications that it would nominate Kenneth E. Moffett, the veteran mediator now serving in the post.

title: Party to Celebrate Morosco Birthday
description: Scores of actors, actresses and playwrights will hail the Morosco Theater on its 65th birthday and at the same time support the Committee to Save Theaters at a champagne and buffet ''Toast to the Morosco'' supper tonight in the new O'Neal's Times Square Restaurant,at 147 West 43d Street.

title: JOE BOWIE AND HIS DEFUNKT IN TOWN FOR TWO GIGS
description: JOE BOWIE has been around and back again, playing his trombone behind blues musicians in his native St. Louis, blowing avant-garde jazz in Europe, working as musical director for a popular Chicago soul singer, then plunging into the distinct but sometimes overlapping punk and funk scenes in downtown Manhattan. His band, Defunkt, reflects the diversity of its leader's background and the varied stops he has made along the way. It's as funky as James Brown, and as creatively fractured and extreme as the music of Mr. Bowie's former employer, James Chance, the leader of the Contortions.

title: PRESSED STUDY OF 100 GREAT BOOKS
description: Stringfellow Barr, a prominent author and educator who, as president of St. John's College in Annapolis, Md., introduced a radically new curriculum composed entirely of the study of 100 great books of man's past, died Tuesday night of pneumonia at a nursing home in Alexandria, Va. He was 84 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photograph that appeared in the Sports People column on Wednesday was incorrectly identified. It showed Ed Price, former head football coach at the University of Texas. It should have shown Eddie Price, formerly a star running back for Tulane and the New York Giants.

title: MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AIR FARES TO FLORIDA WILL RISE
description: The major airlines, seeking to end the current fare war, have filed new fares effective March 1 that would push the one-way trip between New York and Florida back to $135 from the current $77.

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'PERSONAL BEST,' OLYMPIC LOVE
description: CHRIS CAHILL (Mariel Hemingway) and Tory Skinner (Patrice Donnelly) meet by chance when they are trying out for positions on the women's track team that will represent the United States in the 1976 Olympics. Tory, who is pretty in a skinny, androgynous way, takes one look at the comparatively voluptuous Chris and likes what she sees or, as she says later of Chris, ''She has speed, strength and flexibility - everything I've always wanted.''

title: Publisher Goes To CBS Unit
description: Since Geo magazine was sold out from under him by Gruner + Jahr, most of adland has been wondering where Peter G. Diamandis, 50-yearold frequent publisher and occasional agency man, would turn up next. The answer is CBS Publications.

title: PARTY FOR SINGLE-PARENT FAMILIES
description: ''You're wonderful, Daddy!'' 8-year-old Lila exclaimed happily as the bowling ball Fred Margulies had sent zooming down the lane smashed into the pyramid of pins. ''Hey, you're pretty terrific yourself,'' h er father said, beaming back. Two lanes away a boy of 10 years, disappoin tment in his voice, was complaining to his mother, ''I'm terrible at bowling and I'll never win the trophy.''

title: Michigan Curb on Liquor Ads Voided by Attorney General
description: Attorney General Frank Kelley ruled today that the state's ban on advertising the prices and brands of alcoholic beverages was an ''unconstitutional restraint upon the freedom of commercial speech.''

title: Advertising; Coca-Cola TV Ads To Begin
description: YESTERDAY, 2,000 Coca-Cola bottlers were in Atlanta to see the new advertising from McCann-Erickson that goes with the previously announced new theme line, ''Coke is it.''

title: ARGENTINA'S DEEP CLEFT
description: Human rights violations in Argentina are not a disease but rather a symptom.

title: ART: SHE FOUND THE NEW IN AMERICAN PAINTING
description: THERE is nothing to hanging an exhibition, some people think. If the art is right, and the space is clear and clean, you can go out to lunch and leave the show to put itself on the wall. The full fatuity of this point of view was made clear to me close on 30 years ago, when I watched Dorothy Miller, then on the staff of the Museum of Modern Art, as she was installing exhibitions of what was then called''the new American painting'' at the Tate Gal lery in London and at the Venice Biennale.

title: THOMAS & BETTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: latest yr results reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. statement No 52 concerning foreign currency translation which increased net income by $663,000

title: Protest on Pedroza
description: Howard Albert, the manager of Juan LaPorte of New York, a top featherweight contender, has filed a written complaint with Rodrigo Sanchez of Panama, the president of the World Boxing Association, charging that Eusebio Pedroza should be disqu alified as champion. Albert contended that Pedroza, in gaining a u nanimous decision over LaPorte at Atlantic City on Jan. 24, used dru gs or stimulants during the fight and that he committed at least 32 d eliberate and flagrant fouls. Pedroza was penalized 2 points over 15 rounds by the referee.

title: Market Place; How Nike Sets A Fast Pace
description: NIKE Inc., which did not exist 20 years ago, has become a major factor in an industry that has stymied a lot of companies: marketing specialty shoes. Part of Nike's secret is that, unlike many other shoe enterprises, it does not spend a lot of money on factories. Instead, Nike buys its shoes from South Korean and other foreign manufacturers.

title: NEW YORK PLANS GRAFFITI DRIVE
description: The Koch administration, which successfully used a public-relations effort last year to persuade New Yorkers to use less water, is preparing similar campaigns designed to reduce litter and graffiti in New York City.

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $624,000 for the qr and $2,569,000 for the yr and a gain of $54,527,000 for the yr from the sale of Proprietary Medicine business... C-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,149,000 for the qr and $7,275,000 for the yr

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We trusted you last year, the public trusted you last year, and we were deceived, deliberately deceived.'' -Senator John H. Glenn Jr., to David A. Stockman, director, Office of Management and Budget. (A18:5.)

title: Veeco Instruments Appoints Top Officer
description: Allen E. Busching, 49, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Veeco Instruments Inc., a Melville, L.I., manufacturer of electronic power supplies, specialty power semic onductor s and industrial equipment. He succeeds Richard Projain,46, who resig ned ''to pursue other business interests'' and will become a cons ultant to Veeco.

title: GRACE, W R, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: yr-ago results have been restated for pooling of interests

title: PIA ZADORA IN CAIN'S 'BUTTERFLY'
description: ''BUTTERFLY,'' James M. Cain's once-shocking 1946 novel about a humorless, God-fearing Appalachian coal miner named Jess Tyler who has an incestuous relationship with his nymphet daughter, has been turned into a most entertainingly sleazy melodrama, the very secondrateness of which defines an essential quality missing last year from Bob Rafelson's immaculate screen version of Cain's ''The Postman Always Rings Twice.''

title: U.S. HOUSING VOUCHERS FOR CITY OPPOSED
description: The Federal housing-voucher program that the Reagan Administration is seeking to make the cornerstone of its national housing-aid effort would have a ''devastating'' impact on the ability of low-income families in New York City to find adequate shelter, according to a study scheduled to be released tomorrow.

title: THE HIGH COST OF HOSPITALS' FAILURE TO SPOT AND TREAT ALCOHOLISM
description: To the Editor:

title: KANSAS CITY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Malaysia Offers to Send Political Inmates Abroad
description: The Malaysian Governmentsaid today that it had released 168 political detainees held without trial since last July under its tough securit y laws. It offered freedom overseas to the remaining 444 still u nder detention.

title: Mulvey Starts Life in Minors
description: In the waning moments of the New Haven Nighthawks' practice at Veterans Memorial Coliseum this morning, most of Paul Mulvey's new teammates had skated off, leaving him virtually alone in the arena.

title: BARTON BRANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: Betsy King shot a 4-under-par 68 and took a one-stroke lead today in the first round of a $125,000 tournament sponsored by Elizabeth Arden.

title: BOOM AND BUST OVERLAP IN CLEVELAND
description: It isn't quite Dallas, but for a Northern industrial city gripped by a prolonged recession, Cleveland is showing remarkable vitality in its downtown skyline.

title: French Air Crash in Djibouti
description: A French military transport plane crashed into a desert mountain during a training exercise Wednesday in Djibouti, killing 31 Foreign Legion paratroopers and the crew of five, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: Grace Merger Chief Named To New Job
description: When W.R. Grace & Company decided many years ago to change its emphasis from shipping to broad industrial diversification, D. Walter Robbins Jr., a newly hired executive, was placed in charge of the company's acquisition efforts. Now Mr. Robbins, who has been running Grace's development and planning activities since then and has been largely responsible for ferreting out and analyzing acqusition possibilities, has been named a vice chairman of the New York-based corporation.

title: Israeli Soldier Goes Berserk And Shoots 10 in Boot Camp
description: An army conscript went berserk in a boot camp in southern Israel Tuesday night night and shot 10 soldiers before turning his weapon on himself.

title: President Resigns Post at Fairchild
description: Fairchild Industries announced yesterday that its president, John F. Dealy, had resigned after settling his contract, which had been scheduled to expire in September 1983. Mr. Dealy, 42 years old, was succeeded by Edward G. Uhl, 63, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the corporation, which is based in Germantown, Md.

title: EMOTIONAL MOMENT
description: Her heart, she said, ''will always remain in Cuba,'' but her allegiance, Juanita Castro swore yesterday, now belongs to the United States.

title: NASHUA, NOTED RACE HORSE, DEAD AT 30
description: Nashua, one of thoroughbred racing's best competitors and sires, was destroyed late Wednesday after it had been determined that he was suffering from incurable ailments resulting from old age.

title: BRITISH COLUMBIA TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Revs are from telecommunications operations and do not include manufacturing sales of $188,930,000 for the latest yr and $188,374,000 for the previous yr

title: Schwartzwalder Cited
description: Floyd (Ben) Schwartzwalder of Syracuse and the late Ralph (Shug) Jordan of Auburn, two coaches who led their teams to national championships in the 1950's, were elected yesterday to the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame.

title: DANCEMOBILE ROLLS IN FOR BLACK DANCE SERIES
description: Because February is Black History Month, the members of the Harlem Cultural Council's Dancemobile staff decided to offer audiences what Geanie Faulkner, the Dancemobile administrator, calls ''a little dictionary of black dance history.'' The result is a Dancemobile Winter Series at Symphony Space, the performing arts space on the Upper West Side.

title: EXPERTS WARN CUTBACKS MAY REVIVE SERIOUS CHILDHOOD EPIDEMICS
description: A panel of health experts warned today that cutbacks in the Federal Government's childhood immunization program could result in new epidemics of polio, measles, rubella and other serious childhood diseases that have been all but wiped out.

title: GOLDWATER TESTIFIES HARCOURT GAVE NO AID ON MANUSCRIPT
description: Senator Barry Goldwater testified in Manhattan yesterday that he had submitted ''a good manuscript'' of political memoirs to Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, but that the publishing company had rejected it without giving him editorial assistance.

title: CITY BALLET: 'UNION JACK'
description: EVEN by his own standards, George Balanchine's ''Union Jack'' lies far beyond the regulation definition of a ballet and herein lies this particular work's lode of genius.

title: ANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $38,000 for the qr and $158,000 for the 6 mos and a gain of $18,000 for the 6 m on the sale of assets...C-Including a gain of $2,647,000 on the sale of nursing centers

title: KERR-MCGEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: the shr earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split effective Oct 21

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All companies acquired before Dec 31, 1981 are accounted for on a pooling of interest basis

title: Canada Expansion By Telecom Unit
description: Northern Telecom Canada Ltd., a unit of Northern Telecom Ltd., announced a $40 million expansion program in Calgary, Alberta, to manufacture electronic telephone systems and other business communications equipment.

title: SUNDAY WALK TO SCALE HEIGHTS OF PROSPECT PARK
description: PARKS are one of the few places where city dwellers can get a real sense of the seasonal changes that once directed human life.
