Most people seem to prefer to witness winter from behind a steamy apartment window. The parks seem deserted then, with only a few dog walkers and joggers to witness their bleak beauty and new serenity. But this Sunday, parks throughout the city will be the scene of free walks, workshops and seminars conducted by the Urban Park Rangers.

title: Ex-Treasurer of Illinois Is Found Slain in Hotel
description: A former State Treasurer, Donald R. Smith, was apparently strangled today in a hotel along the city's Magnificent Mile, the police said.

title: PIERCE SAYS HE'S HAPPY IN CABINET
description: When Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was shown a ''Doonesbury'' comic strip this week by his press secretary, he was anything but amused.

title: FUSION GUITAR: AL DI MEOLA
description: AT 27, Al Di Meola is one of the two or three most technically accomplished guitarists working in the jazz-fusion idiom. A speed demon who is able to match John McLaughlin in the dexterity of his scalar runs, Mr. Di Meola has an impressive stylistic range that embraces both hard rock and a softer melodic lyricism.

title: VAUGHAN-JACKLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GREAT LAKES FOREST PRODUCTS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: Not Slow Enough
description: Perhaps remembering a 72-51 loss to Dickinson at their home court in Allentown, Pa., on Dec. 1, the Muhlenberg Mules played possession basketball at Carlisle, Pa., in a rematch against Dickinson on Wednesday night, working the ball around a four-corner offense. Their only shot of the first half was a good one in the final minute and enabled the Mules to hold a 2-0 lead at halftime.

title: COTTON GLUT'S COST TO GROWERS
description: The biggest cotton harvest in 30 years has just been tallied in the nation's Sun Belt farmlands, which stretch westward from South Carolina to the fertile fields of the central San Joaquin Valley in California.

title: North Stars 3, Flyers 3
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Bobby Smith got the tying goal at 2:27 of the final period to cap a Minnesota rally from a 3-0 deficit. Philadelphia is now winless in eight games, with four losses and four ties in the span.

title: BRIEFING
description: I F a library of former President Richard M. Nixon's papers is ever finally established, it might be interesting to include relevant documents on the quiet negotiations now under way between Mr. Nixon's lawyer and Duke University, which first invited such a library but then qualified the invitation when faculty members proved less than enthusiastic.

title: SALVADOR GUERRILLAS ATTACK MILITARY POSITIONS IN TOWN
description: Guerrillas attacked military positions in a town 10 miles northeast of here Wednesday night, and witnesses there said today that at least three civil guards were killed before the rebels were driven off. Seven Government soldiers were reportedly wounded.

title: TRI-STATE MOTOR TRANSIT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $3.6 million tax credit from write-off of operating rights...C-Net loss after $9,827,000 loss from write-off of operating rights

title: 1890: A DEFENSE OF VOTING RIGHTS
description: In 1890, Congress narrowly defeated a measure known as the Force Bill, intended to prohibit discriminatory polling practices in Federal elections. Following are excerpts from a defense of the measure by Robert M. La Follette, Republican representative from Wisconsin.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adams Resources and Energy Inc. said it had agreed in principle to sell all the capital stock of one of its coal mining units, Plastic Universal Corp., to Kaneb Services Inc., for $10 million.

title: CITIZENSHIP REVOKED ON NAZI ROLE
description: A Federal judge yesterday revoked the citizenship of a 73-year-old Queens man who he found had hidden his role as a Ukrainian policeman and had ''assisted the Nazis in persecuting civilian Jews.''

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 income includes a gain of $46 million, of 74 cents a shr, from the sale of Amax's 30 percent interest in Adobe Oil & Gas Corp and sale of Canadian oil and gas interests, a $22 million pretax writeoff of the remaining book value of the investment in Botswane RST Ltd and gross income of $23 million from sales of tax benefit leases; the 1980 net income includes a net gain of $12 million on the sale of shrs of Louisiana Land & Exploration Co

title: LOG SHOW KENNEDY SECRETLY TAPED 325 TALKS
description: The John F. Kennedy Library today released a log of White House conversations taped by President Kennedy showing that the taping was more extensive than previously indicated.

title: DEFAULT IS REAGAN'S
description: With all due solemnity, the White House press office has declared that the memo quoted in this space a few days ago -revealing national security adviser Clark's order to secretly circumvent regulations requiring that Poland be placed in default - was a leak of classified information, subject to the latest lie-detector rules.

title: In the Hospital
description: On the sick list are Senator Paula Hawkins of Florida, Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, and Chubby Checker, the singer.

title: No Headline
description: Don Perry, the Kings' coach, today said he thinks his 15-day suspension was too severe a penalty.

title: LIETZKE AND FEZLER, AT 66, SHARE ONE-SHOT LEAD IN CROSBY GOLF
description: For four decades the unpredictability of what is called ''Crosby Weather'' has been one of the legends of the professional golf tour, and today provided an example: The weather was not wintry, rainy, foggy or cold; it was merely perfect for the first day of the 41st Bing Crosby National Pro-Am.

title: Dome Might Leave Alsands
description: An executive of Dome Petroleum Ltd. said today that there was ''a definite possibility'' Dome might become the third company to withdraw from the $13 billion Alsands oil sands project because it questions the profitability of the venture.

title: Sportswriter Suspended O ver Conflict of Interest
description: The Minneapolis Tribune today suspended a sportswriter for 60 days without pay because of what the paper contended was a conflict of interest involving coverage of the Minnesota North Stars.

title: SLEEPER AT THALIA, 'WHY SHOOT THE TEACHER?'
description: ''WHY SHOOT the Teacher?'' is a charming, attractively modest movie directed by Silvio Narizzano, who hasn't much been heard from since ''Georgy Girl,'' which he also directed. ''Why Shoot the Teacher?'' which was made several years ago and has reportedly been a success in Canada, opens today at the Thalia. It's one of the better previously overlooked efforts the theater has unearthed.

title: Mets Agree 'in Principle' On Trade for Reds' Foster
description: The Mets and the Reds reached agreement ''in principle'' yesterday on a trade that would bring George Foster, Cincinnati's leader in home runs and runs batted in for each of the last six seasons, to New York.

title: THE SECOND TIME AROUND
description: Sometimes Administration officials have trouble getting the story straight. On Tuesday, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan created confusion by saying that the President did not have immediate plans to go ahead with deregulating natural gas.

title: ATLANTA WITNESS SAYS WILLIAMS TALKED OF 'CONFESSING'
description: The prosecution rested its double murder case against Wayne B. Williams today with a witness who said the defendant had told her he might confess the killings under certain circumstances.

title: PUBLISHING: WHEN BOOK DOES ITS OWN PROMOTION
description: MANY authors would never believe it, but publishers spend considerable time and money trying to drum up attention for at least some of the titles on their list. But it is l ike a gift from the godswhen one of their books generates its own pub licity.

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1980 earnings have been restated for a change in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: KAISER ACCEPTS OFFER BY HILLER
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement in principle for an investment group headed by Stanley Hiller Jr. to acquire most of the company for about $350 million in cash.

title: Heileman Brewing Net
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company, a major regional brewing and bakery concern, reported today that sales and earnings rose for both the fourth quarter and 12 months of 1981. During the fourth quarter, earnings rose 12.7 percent, to $8 million, or 60 cents a share, from $7.1 million, or 54 cents a share, during the 1980 quarter. Sales rose 2.8 percent, to $201.9 million, from $196.4 million.

title: ROCK: CRYSTAL SHIP AT CLUB
description: JUDGING from the performance of Crystal Ship recently at the Bottom Line, it doesn't take much to satisfy the tastes of rock necrophiles these days. Though this New Jersey-based quintet faithfully reproduced the music of the Doors, with arrangements that were close to the originals, it failed utterly to evoke the satanic sleaziness that was always the group's primary appeal.

title: White House Details Policy on Recordings
description: A White House spokesman said today that the only meetings President Reagan recorded were interviews by journalists.

title: MOHAWK RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings for 1980 reflect 50 percent stock divd

title: Fiat Schedules Layoffs
description: Fiat, Italy 's l eading auto maker, told unions today that it will lay off 40,000 auto and steel workers for one week in March and 60,000 workers for one week in April to reduce bulging inventories. The auto maker has alrea dy idled 60,000 workers, or roughly half its blue-collar work force, for two weeks sofar this year to compensate for slumping sale s.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1982
description: International Medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe would be eliminated under a draft treaty presented to the Soviet Union by the United States, President Reagan announced. The proposal was introduced at the arms reduction talks under way in Geneva. At the same time, the White House said, the United States rejected a Soviet proposal, saying it was based on a distorted missile count. (Page A1, Column 1.) Continued Soviet missile deployment was reported by an official West German source. The official said that Bonn had indications that the Kremlin had not halted the deployment of SS-20 nuclear missiles targeted on Western Europe. (A8:1-2.)

title: 2 OF STEEL GIANTS IN WEST GERMANY AGREE TO MERGE
description: Two of West Germany's largest steel companies agreed today to merge their steelmaking activities in a new joint venture that would form Europe's second-largest steel company.

title: LUXURY AND A MAUVE MOOD AT NEW PARIS HOTEL
description: Le Monde called it ''a triumph of Petro-Baroque.'' Le Nouvel Observateur described it as @''Helveto-Saudian.'' The critic Robert Courtine said it was a ''mauve-colored Roissy - and just as boring'' (Roissy is the local name for Charles de Gaulle Airport).

title: GENERAL REINSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Undercover Officers Charge 23 in Car Insurance Scheme
description: Twenty-three persons have been arrested on charges that they asked undercover officers to dispose of cars so they could report the vehicles stolen and collect on the insurance.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operatons of $1,226,000 for the qr and $1,982,000 for the yr...C-Includes $55,929,000 gain from discontinued operations; yr-ago results restated to reflect vacation liability and company merger on a pooling of interests basis

title: U.S. Denies Harassing A Libyan Jetliner
description: The Navy today denied a Libyan accusation that F-14 fighters from the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy buzzed a Libyan jetliner last Sunday. But it said that planes from the carrier inspected five unidentified aircraft that later turned out to be commercial airliners.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 5-2, FOR 7TH IN ROW
description: The Islanders tied a club record for consecutive victories when they earned their seventh tonight, 5-2, over the Washington Capitals at Capital Centre.

title: Concern on Doping
description: The president of the General Assembly of Sports Federations is concerned about the shortage of laboratories for dope-testing in connection with the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: Reeves Brothers Gets Buy-Out Bid
description: Reeves Brothers Inc., a major producer of apparel fabrics, industrial textiles and foam produ cts, said it had received a $70-ashare le veraged buyout offer from a group of investors and current manag ement that would be valued at about $165 million.

title: MCDERMOTT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1982; International
description: Weak demand for oil, despite the cold winter, has depressed prices severely in the wholesale markets over the past 10 days. Traders say heating oil and crude oil prices have dropped more than 5 percent on the spot market, after holding steady for several months. A similar trend is developing in gasoline prices. The decline puts pressure on OPEC nations to cut official contract prices, as some have begun to do through disguised discounts. (Page A1.)

title: PEPSICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $17,762,000 for the qr and yr; Pepsico siad that foreign exchange gains were $20,814,0 in 1981 and $11,930,000 in 1980; effective Dec 28, 1980 Pepsico adopted the LIFO method of inventory valuation for substantiall all domestic inventories which reduced 1981 net income by $4,58 or 5 cents a shr and fourth qr 1981 net income by $1,412,000 or 1 cent a shr

title: TOP POLISH PRELATES MEET WITH POPE
description: Three leaders of Poland's Roman Catholic Church reported to Pope John Paul II today on their stalled effort to mediate between the Polish military rulers and the suspended independent trade union Solidarity.

title: PILOT SAW PERIL JUST BEFORE JET FELL IN POTOMAC
description: The two pilots of a jetliner that crashed in Washington talked repeatedly, often jokingly, about a snowstorm and the buildup of snow on the wings of their own plane and others as they waited to take off. And they differed over the significance of instrument readings even as the p lane roared down the runway, only to fall, moments later, into the Potomac River.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE SAFETY NET. By Heinrich Boll. Translated from the German by Leila Vennewitz. 314 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: Auto Federation Chief Opposes Delay of Race
description: Jean-Marie Balestre, president of the International Auto Sports Federation, said today that he would try to prevent the postponement of the Argentine Grand Prix.

title: RAYMOND INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lendl Defeats Connors Fo r First Time, 6-4, 6-3
description: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia tonight scored his first victory over Jimmy Connors, prevailing by 6-4, 6-3 despite feeling ill during most of the match in the $350,000 Molson Tennis Challenge.

title: ROBINS, A H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest yr earnings reflect adoption of new accounting method for foreign currency translation; yr-ago fourth qr restated to reflect adoption of LIFO method of accounting

title: RESTAURANTS
description: T first glance, Le Cherche-Midi, which opened four months ago on First Avenue between 51st and 52d Street, looks like a winner. And judging by the almost full house there the four times we visited, it is already attracting a loyal coterie. Simply but handsomely designed to suggest a countrified Proven,cale setting, Le Cherche-Midi's rough white walls, terra cotta tile floors, baskets, antique accessories and delicate floral arrangements create a clean, gentle and unpretentious background. The menu has equal charm and appeal.

title: Mabel Mercer's 82d
description: Her longtime accompanist was at the piano and the room was primed for music when someone mentioned that it was Mabel Mercer's 82d birthday and that it was a shame the singer wasn't there to celebrate with her fans.

title: Chromalloy to Sell 25 More Businesses
description: The Chromalloy American Corporation, a highly diversified manufacturing, agricultural-products, financial services and transportation concern, said yesterday that it intended to sell 25 businesses that have a total net asset value of about $146 million.

title: ENGELHARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $5,210,000

title: U.S. CAMPAIGNING AGAINST ARAB MOVE AT U.N.
description: In a sharp break with normal diplomatic practice here, the United States is waging an open and vigorous campaign against an Arab resolution in the General Assembly that urges countries to punish Israel for ann exing the Golan Heights.

title: Berkshire Ski Trip
description: A cross-country skiing trip through the Berkshire Mountains of Massachusetts is planned this weekend by Country Cycling Tours, which specializes in bicycling and skiing excursions.

title: Military Analysis
description: The development of a retaliatory capacity in chemical warfare in order to deter the Soviet Union has become an essential element in the Defense Department's effort to catch up with Soviet military expansion over the last decade.

title: Budget Official Urges Higher Arms Estimates
description: Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told Congress today that it should require the Pentagon to make higher, more realistic estimates of cost increases for weapons than the Reagan Administration has been making.

title: 3D COURTHOUSE ESCAPEE SEIZED
description: A third inmate of the nine who escaped from a courthouse in Brooklyn last month was captured yesterday in an apartment in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, the police said. A 24-year-old woman in the apartment was charged with harboring a fugitive.

description: B-After extraordinary items of $3,000 for latest qr and $35,000 for 1980 periods...C-Includes $93,000 of extraordinary gains from utilization of income tax credits...D-Includes extraordinary gains of $815,000 from the settlement of indebt- edness and carryforward of income tax credits

description: B-Including an unusual gain of $8.1 million ro 18 cents a shr from the settlement of litigation with International Business Machines Corp

title: No Income, No Tax
description: A follow-up: Agnes de Mille, who was sounding off against the income tax the other day, offered a clarification of one of her statements yesterday. The eight years in which she filed no incometax returns, she said, were years in which she had no income and thus was not required to file.

title: REAGAN AND MUBARAK VOW TO PURSUE EFFORTS FOR PEACE
description: President Reagan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt concluded their talks today with mutual pledges to pursue peace efforts in the Middle East through the Camp David agreements.

title: WHAT THE TURKISH-SOVIET TRADE PROTOCOL MEANS
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIONS AT NEWS TO SET UP TRUST AS AID TO PAPER
description: The unions at The Daily News yesterday authorized the creation of a trust that they said could acquire any or all of the stock of the financially troubled newspaper and help raise capital for needed improvements.

title: Grace Climbs 20% in Quarter
description: W.R. Grace & Company, a diversified natural resources, chemicals and retailing concern, reported yesterday tha t earnings in the fourthquarter jumped 20 percent, to a record $81.7 million, or $1.71 a share, on the strength of a 60 percent jump i n operating profits fromits energy-related businesses.

title: HEILMAN, G, BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN BECKONS THE LOCAL BOSSES OF YESTERYEAR
description: To the Editor:

title: SMALL-BUSINESS HEAD SELECTED
description: The White House announced today that Michael Cardenas had resigned as administrator of the Small Business Administration and that President Reagan had nominated James Sanders, a former San Francisco insurance broker, for the post.

title: F.D.A. Backs Drug Makers
description: Dr. Arthur H. Hays Jr., commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, said today that drug patents should be extended to reflect the seven years companies usually lose during reviews by his agency.

title: Itel in Accord With Creditors
description: The Itel Corporation, an equipment leasing company that filed for protection from its creditors in January 1981, said that it had reached an agreement with representatives of its unsecured creditors on major elements of a proposed reorganization plan.

title: PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The yr-ago 9 mos reflects an accounting change

title: CHB FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. PRINTS BEST SELLERS ALL ITS OWN
description: When it comes to good reading and best sellers, the Government Printing Office is not one of the publishing houses that automatically spring to mind.

title: Bonny LNG Is Disbanded
description: The Government announced today the breakup of a consortium with Western oil companies that was to build a $14 billion liquefied natural gas project, but said the Government would continue the project's development.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Wednesday on the Mi- chael C. Rockefeller Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art gave in- complete credit for the installation of the art. It was designed by Stuart Sil- ver, consultant designer to the mu- seum, and Clifford LaFontaine, design associate and project coordinator.

title: Bridge: An Old Stratagem Works If the Situation Calls for It
description: Among the various forms of deception available at the bridge table is one that used to be called ''the old Army game.'' The declarer boldly leads a weak suit in the hope that the defenders will be dissuaded from leading it themselves.

title: Friday; A BOOKMAN AT COLUMBIA
description: Books, letters, photographs and memorabilia documenting the late M. Lincoln Schuster's more than 40 years with the company of which he was co-founder - Simon & Schuster, the book publishers - will be exhibited today through Feb. 26 in the rotunda of the Low Memorial Library on the Columbia University campus, Broadway and 116th Street. Among more than 130 items on view, from Schuster papers given to the university over the last decade, is a memo that was the genesis of the company, suggesting ways to bring good books to a wider public. There are also letters from Bernard Berenson, Max Beerbohm and Bertrand Russell; a proof of the first printing of Joseph Heller's ''Catch-22'' and a 1928 edition of Felix Salten's ''Bambi,'' translated from German by Whittaker Chambers, with a foreword by John Galsworthy. Admission is free. ORNETTE COLEMAN UPTOWN

title: GIBSON-HOMANS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ex-Illinois Attorney General To Begin Jail Term March 8
description: William J. Scott, former Attorney General of Illinois, was ordered by a judge today to surrender to the Federal authorities March 8 to begin serving his 366-day prison term for filing a false income tax return.

title: SPLIT EMERGES ON MADRID TALKS
description: The United States and West Germany are divided over what course to follow next week when some 20 foreign ministers attend the Madrid Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.

title: CORDURA CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
CREDITORS DO NOT THINK IMPACT WILL BE SEVERE
description: The major lenders to Laker Airways said yesterday they were unsure of how the collapse of the British discount airline would ultimately affect them, although they were guardedly optimistic that they would suffer no significant financial harm.

title: Boston Log Shows R unway Was Unplowed
description: A runway at Logan International Airport here had not been sanded or plowed for almost two hours before a DC-10 aircraft slid into Boston Harbor two weeks ago, according to operational records.

title: THE COMPANY MAN
description: I work for a big company. I'm small. I'm much smaller than the company. My boss told me so himself. He said, ''The company is much bigger than you.''

title: BUILDER STUMBLES ON POTENT FOE - BUTTERFLIES
description: After two years of intense legal, scientific and political maneuvering to liberate 3,600 acres of valuable real estate occupied by squadrons of shy blue butterflies, Sherman Eubanks seems more amused than angry.

title: CONTROLLER REHIRING OPPOSED
description: A panel of 16 safety experts urged yesterday that the Federal Government stand firm in its refusal to rehire the air traffic controllers who were dismissed after illegally striking last August.

title: Luke P. Carroll, 66; Newspaper Executive
description: Luke P. Carroll, a veteran newspaper editor and executive, died Thursday at his home in suburban Barrington. He was 66 years old.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Gambia and Senegal will be known as Senegambia. 2. The employees work for the civil rights division of the Justice Department.

title: JUDGE CALLS EVIDENCE 'THIN' IN A RULING ON STOUFFER CASE
description: The judge in the arson and murder trial of Luis Marin, accused of setting the fire that killed 26 persons at Stouffer's Inn, said today that the ''thread connecting the defendant with the commission of the alleged arson is extremely thin.''

title: Emma D. Crispin Is Wed in Florida
description: Emma Dorita Crispin, president of Emmy Crispin & Associates, a public-relations concern in New York and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to William Wellington Wolbach, president of the Cotton Bay Club and its parent company, South Eleuthera Properties Ltd., in Eleuthera, the Bahamas.

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Says 6 Americans Are Being Held in Iran
description: Five Americans are being held in Iranian prisons in addition to a naturalized United States citizen jailed nearly two years ago, the State Department said today.

title: REVENUES MAY RISE FOR OTHERS
description: The demise of Laker Airways is likely to make it easier for other carriers to raise fares and fill more of their seats on the hotly competitive North Atlantic routes, airline executives and analysts predicted yesterday. This in turn would help such hard-pressed airlines as Pan American World Airways and British Airways, but not enough to improve their fortunes dramatically, they said.

title: Hartford Ballet Festival
description: The Hartford Ballet will observe its 10th anniversary in Bushnell Memorial Hall in Hartford on Feb. 18, 19 and 20.

title: FOOD IS HOT, PLATE IS HOTTER
description: ''There are two tragedies in life: One is not to get your heart's desire; the other is to get it,'' said George Bernard Shaw, and it's a thought that comes to mind often in restaurants where food is presented on searingly hot plates. For too long, many kitchens sent hot food out on cold plates, a careless practice that is objectionable in any case, most of all with sauces with high fat content, because it makes them congeal at low temperatures.

title: STRINGS: AMERICAN QUARTET PRESENTS BARTOK
description: The American String Quartet got off to an excellent start in the mid-1970's by winning both a Naumburg Award and the Coleman Competition in its first year of existence. And it has done well since then, having toured in Europe and Taiwan as well as the United States.

title: NATURAL RUBBER PRODUCERS: WELCOME PRICE ADVANTAGE
description: The growth of synthetic rubber's share of the world rubber market ha s been slowing lately as consumption of all kinds of rubber has in creased.

title: Bridge: Suit Combinations Altered By Game's Circumstances
description: Circumstances alter suit combinations. Consider this common situation:

title: COATS AND RESTAURANT LIABILITY
description: ''N OT responsible for the loss of personal property,'' read the signs at many New York restaurant checkrooms. But what do the words really mean? If the checkroom loses, say, an expensive fur coat, wouldn't it be required to compensate the customer?

title: GOLDWATER WINS BOOK SUIT
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Harcourt Brace Jovanovich had breached its contract to publish the political memoirs of Senator Barry Goldwater because it failed to provide him with normal editorial assistance.

title: Region; Radioactive Spill A t Nine Mile Point
description: Radioactive sludge sloshed Friday from a holding tank into the ventilation system of the Nine Mile Point 1 reactor building, contaminating three Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation employees, who were not injured, officials said.

title: U.S. STARTS REPLACING SALVADORAN COPTERS DESTROYED IN REBEL ATTACK
description: The Reagan Administration has begun sending UH-1H Huey helicopters to El Salvador to replace aircraft destroyed or damaged in a guerrilla attack on a Salvadoran air base last month.

title: TIME TO DISCARD A CRAZY-QUILT COURT SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: KUSTOM ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
NO GAIN SEEN IN LABOR MARKET
description: The unemployment rate unexpectedly declined three-tenths of a percentage point to 8.5 percent in January after rising rapidly in several earlier months, according to figures released today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: CITY BALLET: NEW ROBBINS 'GERSHWIN'
description: Yes, one would call Jerome Robbins's newest ballet, ''The Gershwin Concerto,'' a masterpiece. With its sophistication and urbanity, its mixture of the symphonic and the idiomatic, this new Robbins classic matches George Gershwin's Piano Concerto in F on more than its own ground. As Gershwin might have said, 'Swo nderful - and it is wonderfully l ed by Maria Calegari, Christopher d'Amboise, Darci Kistler and M el Tomlinson.

title: U.S. TO ASK SAUDIS TO HELP COORDINATE SECURITY AID TO GULF NATIONS
description: The United States plans to propose to Saudi Arabia that the two countries undertake ''basic, coordinated security assistance'' to nations around the Persian Gulf, a senior Defense official said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: W ITH friends like these ... Some of Pre sident Reagan's most fervent supporters are about to issue some un usual and biting criticisms of the Administration's armscontrol polic ies. Asserting that Carter ''holdovers'' and ''careerists' ' are ''conducting business as usual'' at the Arms Control and D isarmament Agency, the conservative Heritage Foundation says, essenti ally, that the department shows evidence of ''no commitment'' at all to the President's program. The agency head, Eugene V. Ros tow, is labeled a ''long-time Democrat.''

title: Your Money; Settling Fights With Brokers
description: MR. X was in a tizzy. On the advice of his broker, he invested $3,000 in options to buy and sell stocks and promptly lost $1,153. Mrs. Y was in a funk. Her broker made one trade after another in her $137,000 account, running up the amount she had to pay in commissions and losing $3,000 on poor investments.

title: Just Desserts From Harvard's Hasty Puddings
description: Harvard's Hasty Pudding Club, which bills itself as the nation's oldest theatrical organization, yesterday named James Cagney and Ella Fitzgerald as its man and woman of the year.

title: MUBARAK, IN WASHINGTON SPEECH, PLEDGES TO PURSUE TIES WITH ISRAEL
description: President Hosni Mubarak promised today that even after Egypt regains all of Sinai from Israel on April 25, ''we will continue to build bridges of understanding and friendship with the Israeli people.''

title: Nehemiah Wins Easily In Los Angeles Meet
description: Renaldo Nehemiah, who ran a world-indoor best of 6.82 seconds last Saturday in Dallas, won the 60-yard hurdles in 6.96 seconds tonight in The Los Angeles Times Indoor Games.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS;% MAN IN THE NEWS; NO-FRILLS PIONEER
description: Today, as Laker Airways collapsed, an aide said that Sir Freddie, its founder, was very upset. Perhaps so, but not long ago, as the storm clouds gathered over his airline, Sir Freddie had boasted: ''Bein g broke is nothing. I was born broke, and if I wasbroke tomorrow, I wouldn't stay broke long.''

title: Region; JURY ACQUITS 2 IN CORRUPTION CASE
description: SYRACUSE (AP) - A jury in State Supreme Court Friday acquitted Assemblyman Michael J. Bragman and William Steffan, a contractor, on all counts of a four-count indictment stemming from politicalcorruption charges in Onondaga County.

title: MISS HESS WINS 3RD GOLD MEDAL IN SKIING
description: Erika Hess reacted like a champion at a tense moment in her slalom race today and won her third gold medal of the world Alpine skiing championships.

GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Penn Beats Columbia
description: Karl Racine scored 4 points in overtime tonight to lead Penn to a 52-47 triumph over Columbia.

title: Text of resolution is on page 5.
description: The General Assembly adopted a sweeping resolution today that urges nations to isolate Israel for annexing the Golan Heights.

title: A VOLUNTEER MASCOT
description: Last week the Philadelphia 76ers were looking for mascot help. They advertised for would-be Chickens or would-be Phanatics, but to no avail.

title: HOW TO DISMANTLE YOUR OWN AGENCY
description: When he accepted the job of Secretary of Education a year ago, T.H.Bell did it with the understanding that his task was to preside over the dismantling of his own department. This week, his natural good humor still intact despite cries of rage from the education community that he has been part all his adult life, the Secretary sat at a conference table in his sunny o ffice, a block or so from th e Capitol, and explained why the Administration, in its budget to be released Monday, anticipates converting the department into a less v isable foundation without Cabinet status:

title: TOP REAGAN AIDES CONFER IN PRIVATE
description: Senior White House officials met with President Reagan's top campaign strategists at Camp David today for an unusual meeting devoted in part to plans for protecting Mr. Reagan from political damage resulting from the decline in the economy.

description: The Government accused Christina Onassis tonight of evading $50 million in taxes on inheriting her father's shipping empire.

description: This is not a column about New York. It is, rather, about history. And about short memories.

title: ALABAMIANS CONCERNED AS JOB HUNT GETS TOUGH
description: The Town Hall meeting had been billed as a small gathering at which citizens could voice their concern about the worsening state of the economy. But it attracted more than 800 people.

title: AN ENTHUSIASM FOR EXPANSION BROUGHT LA KER TO BANKRUPTCY
description: When the history of air travel in the 1970's is written, Sir Freddie Laker will be remembered as the man who gained success by tearing down the barriers to airline price competition between England and America - and who suffered his demise because he believed too strongly that he could do the same elsewhere.

title: Military in Suriname Takes Over Government
description: The National Military Council said today that it had taken over direct rule of Suriname after the resignation Thursday night of President Hendrik R. Chin A Sen and members of his Cabinet.

description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is issuing its third zero-coupon Eurobond since Jan. 12, a $400 million, 10-year issue yielding 14.51 percent, the lead manager, Salomon Brothers International, said here today. This yield is based on a price of 23.75 percent, which, excluding commissions, will provide $95 million.

title: K.G.B. Agents Search Home of Soviet Writer
description: The Soviet security police searched the apartment of the writer Georgy Vladimov today and briefly detained his wife for questioning.

title: BRITAIN ORDERS SANCTIONS OVER POLAND
description: Britain imposed economic and diplomatic sanctions on Poland and the Soviet Union today to demonstrate displeasure with the imposition of martial law in Poland.

title: U.S., in Shift, Renews Order At Lockheed
description: The Defense Department has reversed an earlier decision to stop buying the Lockheed P-3C antisubmarine aircraft for a five-year period, a Lockheed spokesman said today.

title: Award to Beethoven Society's Spiritual Father
description: Although he is the head of his own pharmaceutical advertising company, Robert A. Becker devotes much of his time to his ''great loves - Gilbert and Sullivan and Beethoven.''

description: Western Airlines said that its lender had granted it a $19 million loan and a four-month waiver of technical default on its existing $90 million debt.

title:
PATENTS;
Device Helps Support A Slide Projector
description: Dr. Jerold B. Spitz, a Hartford physician who is also assistant clinical professor at the University of Connecticut, was bothered while delivering lectures by the difficulty of raising a slide projector to the proper height for displaying images.

description: B-Includes $1.7 million net from discontinued operations plus a gain of $14.4 million on sale from discontinued operatio and a $4.1 million extra credit...C-Includes net from discontin operations of $3.7 million...D-Includes net from discontinued operations of $9.6 million plus gain or sale of discontinued operations of $14.4 million and a tax credit of $4.1 million... title:
PATENTS;
A Satellite To Chart The Earth
description: AN automatic system for mapping the earth from a satellite has been patented for the Department of the Interior. The mapping satellite, called the Mapsat, is proposed as the successor to the Landsat, or land satellite, used by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief article in some copies of Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect date for a rally in support of the Polish labor union Solidarity. The rally is to- night at 7 in Town Hall.

title: POLISH DEBTS: EXTENT OF U.S. LIABILITY
description: A high-level Treasury Department official said today that the Federal Government might have to pay American banks nearly $2 billion owed to them by Poland over the next three years because of Federal loan guarantee agreements.

title: AIRLINES ASSISTING LAKER PASSENGERS
description: Most major airlines with flights between Britain and the United States said yesterday that they would honor tickets of Laker Airways passengers who were suddenly stranded when the Skytrain halted service yesterday morning.

title: POLISH UNIONISTS GET HARSH SENTENCES
description: Despite a pledge by the Government that Solidarity members would not be punished for union activities carried out before martial law was imposed, union activists are receiving severe court sentences for relatively minor infractions of martial law.

title: BOEING TO TRIM ITS STAFF ON COAST
description: The Boeing Company, faced with a downturn in the commercial airline business, said it will cut 4,000 to 5,000 positions from its Puget Sound-area work force this year.

title: ADOPTEES' BEST INTERESTS
description: You couldn't pick them out of a crowd, but adopted people are different. Two traits set them apart: a vague sense of disconnection or dislocation, and difficulty forming a strong sense of self. The lack of a specific heritage, which tells them how and where they fit into the cycle of life, is thought to be the root of the problem. To be missing a past might not sound like much, but that's because the rest of us have always known where we came from. ''My Mom has really gotten interested in genealogy in the last few years,'' one 16-year-old adoptee wrote me, ''and it's fine for her, but it doesn't do anything for me.''

title: TIME TO DISCARD A CRAZY-QUILT COURT SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING 'OUT ON A LIMB' OVER DISCLOSURES ON TAXES
description: In an age of news disclosures and fierce competition among reporters to be first with a story, it is hardly unusual to see articles in which insiders predict what some public official is going to do.

description: B-The 1981 period was the first yr of operation for New York Air, a unit of Texas Air Corp

title: AUGAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

PATENTS;
Compound May Help Fight Tumors or Germs
description: An acid compound named melanodocin, isolated from Caribbean sponges, has been developed at the University of Oklahoma in Norman for possible use as an antitumor and antibiotic agent. Prof. Francis J. Schmitz of the department of chemistry and four associates were granted patent 4,314,057 this week, assigning it to Research Corporation, a New York foundation that handles many inventions for universities.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
News An alysis
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt hopes that today's victory in a confidence vote in Parliament will bring an appearance of stability to his Government, but the expression of support carries very few guarantees with it.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS; Coming and Goings
description: Ilie Nastase has been suspended from the Grand Prix circuit for 21 days by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council for having incurred more than $5,000 in minor-offense fines in the last 12 months. The suspension begins Monday. ... Frank Kush, the new coach of the Baltimore Colts, will return to Arizona State's Sun Devil Stadium to lead his team in an N.F.L. exhibition game against the Atlanta Falcons on Aug. 21. Kush was dismissed as head coach at Arizona State in 1979 amid accusations that he had punched a player and tried to cover up the incident.

title: A 2d Church Gives Homeless Shelter
description: Calvary-St. George's Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square has become the second religious institution in the city to set up a voluntary shelter program for the homeless.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday misidentified Joseph L. Bower of the Harvard Business School and Almarin Phillips of the Wharton School. Mr. Phillips's picture was at left and Mr. Bower's at right. The caption misquoted Professor Bower. He said A.T.& T. had been burdened with its operating companies' old assets, but not necessarily obsolete assets.

title: CINCINNATI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FINANCIAL GENERAL BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Students on Social Security Will Be Told of Benefits' End
description: The Social Securi ty Administration said today that it would send out corrected pamphl ets to nearly 800,000 student beneficiaries over the next four week s to alert them to a gradual ending of their benefits.

title: 76ERS BEAT NETS WITH HELP OF KEY STEALS
description: The Nets, described by Philadelphia 76ers Coach Billy Cunningham as a team ''stepping rapidly up the ladder,'' missed a few rungs tonight. And the missteps contributed to a 116-112 loss to the 76ers at the Spectrum.

title: HECLA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gunmen Kill 2 Ugandans
description: A leading member of Uganda's opposition Democratic Party and a housing official were killed and several other people were wounded Thursday night when gunmen opened fire on a group sitting outside a store in Kampala, the Ugandan capital, the opposition party said today.

title: Port Jervis Ends Flood Alert
description: Authorities today ended a state of emergency that was imposed in fear that ice jams on the Delaware River might cause flooding. The emergency in this Orange County city was ended at 5 A.M. after the ice jams broke up and high waters subsided. Mayor E. Arthur Gray had imposed it on Thursday.

title: SAVE-WAY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE WRONG SITE FOR A 'SLIVER'
description: To the Editor:

title: Meeting Called On Foster Pact
description: The Mets and Tom Reich, the agent for George Foster, arranged yesterday a meeting for this weekend in Florida in an attempt to negotiate a contract that could bring Foster to New York. They were working under the agreement ''in principle'' that the Mets had reached with the Reds to talk with Foster, who can become a free agent after this season.

title: Rancher Pleads Guilty In Texas 'Mercy Killing'
description: A retired rancher pleaded guilty to a charge of murder today, telling the court that he shot his older brother, who was terminally ill, because he ''was just begging me to get him out of his misery.''

title: LUCAS HELPS KNICKS BEAT CLIPPERS, 90-85
description: The Knicks got a poor game out of their system against the struggling San Diego Clippers, who let them get away with a 90-85 victory before 6,274 fans at the Sports Arena.

title: OF SNOWFLAKES AND A SOUND COMMON PERCEPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Hi-Shear to Join With Raybestos
description: Hi-Shear Industries and Raybestos-Manhattan Inc., two suppliers to the aerospace industry, announced today that they had reached agreement in principle to merge into a new unit through an exchange of stock.

title: 'High Dudgeon' Over Idaho's Rabbit Roundup
description: The president of the Fund for Animals, Cleveland Amory, said yesterday that he was in ''rather high dudgeon'' over an Idaho court's refusal to issue a restraining order to stop the clubbing of jack rabbits by members of the Mud Lake Farmers Committee.

title: TORIN CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a tax loss carryforward of $230,000; the 1981 net includes $569,000 from the adoption of the new accounting standard for foreign currency translation

title: SYRIAN CHIEF IS SAID TO THWART PLANNED COUP
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has thwarted a planned military coup and begun a purge of his officer corps, according to reports reaching the United States.

title: NEW YORK UNEMPLOYMENT RATE HOLDS STEADY
description: The recession does not appear to be deepening in New York City and New York State judging from the relatively small changes in the unemployment rates last month, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

title: REWARD IS OFFERED IN MURDER
description: A $5,000 reward was offered yesterday for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the murderer of Stanley Stoehrer, secretary-treasurer of Local 365 of the Service Employees Union, representing 1,800 cemetery workers in the metropolitan area.

description: Laker Airways, the brash upstart company that dramatically transformed air travel across the Atlantic with its nofrills fares, declared bankruptcy today and halted all flights.

title: Irving Moselowitz, 75, Dies; Ex-Head of Bond Industries
description: Irving Moselowitz, former president of Bond Industries Inc., died yesterday at Florida Medical Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he had been living in retirement. He was 75 years old and a former resident of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Transfer of Cuban Refugees To Seattle School Called Off
description: The last 23 Cuban refugees from Fort Ch affee, Ark., will not be coming to Seattle. The young, single men will remain in Federal prisons in Chicago an d Texarkana, Tex., until Cuban Refugee Resettlement of Washington ca n find a new halfway house for them.
