title: Letter: On the Carey Budget; No Time for New Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGISLATURE'S FRESHMEN GIVE IT A PASSING GRADE
description: The 23 state legislators who came to Albany for the first time last year have completed their first legislative session, fought and lost political and personal battles and seen many of their dreams deferred.

title: WHY A MEDIA SPECIALIST GETS ALBANY'S CONTRACTS
description: Four state agencies have contracts totaling $190,000 a year with an outside public-relations concern, even though each has a separate public-information office.

title: Spy Denies Holdup Charges
description: Christopher Boyce, a convicted spy, pleaded not guilty Thursday to charges that he held up banks in three Western states in the 19 months while he was a fugitive from a Federal prison. United States Magistrate Jim Christensen set bond at $1 million in the event that Mr. Boyce, convicted on 1977 of selling satellite data to Soviet agents, is released from prison. He is serving a 40-year term at a Federal prison in California.

title: WHITTAKER NEAR BRUNSWICK VI CTORY
description: The Whittaker Corporation said today that, as of Thursday night, its bid to acquire 49 percent of the Brunswick Corporation was oversubscribed.

title: WOOD FORMS FOUND IN CHILE ARE BELIEVED HEMISPHERE'S OLDEST
description: What could be the ''oldest architectural structure in America,'' believed to be 12,000 to 14,000 years old, has been discovered in Chile, a University of Kentucky anthropologist announced today.

title: INSTACOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rangers' Johnstone Out
description: Eddie Johnstone, who has scored five goals in the first five games of the Rangers' eight-game trip, said today that he broke the third finger on his right hand during Thursday night's game with the Flames. Bob Williams, the team's physical therapist, said the injury would keep Johnstone, a right wing, from playing for about two weeks. The Rangers did not immediately disclose whether they would add a forward to their roster in time to play against the Oilers in Edmonton Sunday night.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
4 Thrift Units Are Acquired
description: A California savings and loan association was given Government permission today to cross state lines and acquire four institutions in Florida and Georgia.

title: Suitcase in Bus Terminal Is a Missing Woman's
description: An employee at the Greyhound bus terminal has found a suitcase belonging to Joan Webster, of Newark, N.J., a graduate student from Harvard University who has been missing since late November.

title: Aqueduct Closed 3 More Days
description: Thoroughbred racing at Aqueduct, which often proceeds through snow, sleet and subzero temperatures, has been canceled through at least next Monday because of warmer weather.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC PLAYS BARBER, BRUCH AND BEETHOVEN
description: The New York Philharmonic conducted by Erich Leinsdorf played Barber, Bruch and Beethoven Friday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall. Barber's First Symphony began the proceedings, and Beethoven's Fifth ended them.

title: MILLER TECHNOLOGY & COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Italy's Press Is Struck
description: Printers and teletype operators began a 24-hour strike at 7 A.M. today, idling all news agencies and preventing the publication of Saturday newspapers. They are seeking a new contract. On Wednesday, journalists staged a similar strike.

title: Honors for 2 Who Have Practiced 'Healing Arts'
description: Two recipients of honorary degrees Thursday night at the University of South Carolina in Charleston had something in common. One was Itzhak Perlman, the violinist, who received an honorary medical degree, and the other was Dr. Albert P. Sabin, the 75-yearold vi rologist who is retiring from the university in June.

title: DORADO MICRO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $191,000 or 3 cents a sh

title:
PATENTS;
Measuring the Heat From Earth's Interior
description: A method of measuring the flow of heat obtainable from the earth's interior has been devised for the Department of Energy.

title: CANADIAN UTILITIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BLOCK PLANS TRADE POLICY
description: Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block said today that he was developing a policy to deal with all issues of international commodity trading.

title: REVUE: 'HULA' AND PHONOGRAPH MIX THEATER AND THE DANCE
description: Since the days of 78's, young people have played records and acted them out in time to the music. The effect is given big-screen treatment in Herbert Ross's movie ''Pennies From Heaven.'' As Descartes might have said, ''I lip-synch, therefore I am.'' Call it a case of wish fulfillment. The mimicry can be extended into body language, everyman as Elvis. ''Hula,'' a new short work directed by Elizabeth LeCompte at the Performing Garage, is labeled ''Record Album Interpretation No. 1,'' which is fancy linguistic footwork to describe our old familiar phonograph friend.

title: Union and Ford Meet Briefly
description: Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers met for an hour today, and scheduled weekend meetings to discuss possible cost-saving concessions by union workers.

title: OPEC Talks Discussed
description: OPEC oil ministers may be summoned to a special session to review crude oil pricing and production levels because of the continuing world surplus, the president of the group said here today. OPEC is not scheduled to meet in regular session until May, but the president can call a special meeting.

title: TOBACCO LAYOFFS
description: The Brown & Williamson Corporation said it would lay off about one-third of the 2,800 workers at its tobacco plant here as part of a consolidation of operations at a newer plant in Macon, Ga. The company said that a small reduction in the work force is expected in the third quarter of 1982, and the plant's third shift will be phased out entirely by the end of the year.

title: No Headline
description: PEKING JOURNAL IMPLIES PURGE OF PARTY MAY BE IN THE OFFING

title: North Carolina Beats F urman, 96-69, for 17th
description: Sam Perkins scored 22 points and Michael Jordan had 21 as North Carolina beat Furman, 96-69, in the nightcap of a doubleheader tonight.

title: UNION HEADS SENTENCED IN FULTON MARKET PAYOFFS
description: Twin brothers who headed a seafood union were sentenced to prison terms yesterday for obtaining labor payoffs in ''a pattern of racketeering'' in the Fulton Fish Market in Manhattan.

title: CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 results reflect the adoption of an accounting change for the foreign currency translations

title: News Analysis
description: It was an extraordinary courtroom scene: Before a grand jury had completed its proceedings and before a criminal charge had been filed, a prominent surgeon was identified in court by the Bronx District Attorney's office as the ''primary suspect'' in an attempted murder.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a tax credit of $516,000

title: SRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Summary; SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1982
description: International A pledge to pursue ties with Israel even after the completion of the Israeli withdrawal from Sinai on April 25 was made by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. ''This policy is irreversible,'' Mr. Mubarak said in a speech at the National Press Club in Washington. ''It is the trend of the future.'' (Page 1, Columns 2-3.) Isolation of Israel was urged in a resolution adopted by the United Nations General Assembly concerning Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights. Eighty-six nations of the third world and the Soviet bloc voted for the document, and 21, including the United States, voted against it. (1:1.) A Soviet military attache was trapped by the Federal Bureau of Investigation with the aide of an informer. The attache, Maj. Gen. Vasily I. Chitov, was later declared persona non grata and expelled. (1:6.)

title: UNION ELECTRIC STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DON'T COMPROMISE EMERGENCY CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: RAIDER TRAINER CLEARED BUT CHIDED
description: The National Football League said yesterday that an investigation by its security department had found no support for charges that George Anderson, head trainer for the Oakland Raiders, had bet on league games, placed bets for other Raider employees, including players, or passed on information about the condition of Raider players to bookmakers, However, Mr. Anderson has been sent a lette r of reprimand, according to Commissioner Pete Rozelle, for b etting on ''nonfootball events'' with one bookmaker and for ''sociali zing'' with another, two activities that he has acknowledged. ''He was told it was poor judgment,'' Commissioner Rozelle said last ni ght. The commissioner also said that Mr. Anderson had been ''cautio ned'' about ''any future involvement.''

title: THIRD HIGHEST SALARY
description: Rickey Henderson, the Oakland A's 23-year-old left fielder, won the third highest salary ever awarded in baseball arbitration and will earn $535,000 this season.

title: WHITE AIDE OF NONWHITE SOUTH AFRICAN UNION FOUND HANGED IN CELL
description: A white official of a predominantly nonwhite trade union who was detained for interrogation by the security police more than two months ago was found hanged in his cell early today, according to a police announcement.

title: Region; Officer Wounded; 5 Held in Holdup
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP) - Five men were arrested Friday following a shootout in which a police officer was wounded trying to stop several men who had held up a social club.

title: Fire Kills 4 of 5 In Queens Family
description: The family in the ground-floor apart ment smelled smoke. The man opened the front door to let in fresh air. A fire flared up, and the man's wife and three children died in the ensuing blaze and collapse of the two-story building in Queens shortly after noon yesterday.

title: Rick Kuhn Sentenced to 10 Years
description: Rick Kuhn was sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment yesterday for his part in a point-shaving scheme that was hatched during the 1978-79 season, when he played basketball for Boston College.

title: ROBINSON NUGENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'ADJUSTMENTS' TO INCOME CAN REDUCE TAX BILL
description: People who opened Individual Retirement Accounts or used their cars for business last year may be in for a pleasant surprise. The new tax law has dramatically increased the amount of business depreciation that some can claim on their 1981 tax returns, and an important court decision has liberalized the use of I.R.A.'s. Anyone who had such expenditures in 1981 may be able to claim them as ''adjustments'' to income, and substantially reduce the amount of their tax bill.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48. 1. A confederation of two African nations was formed this week. What are the two nations, and what will the confederation be called? 2. Some 200 employees of a Federal agency have written a letter of complaint to their boss about a stand the Government has taken. Name the agency, and describe the issue.

title: DIETZEL REASSIGNED
description: Paul Dietzel, under fire because of mounting deficits in the athletic department and protests from unhappy football fans, was removed yesterday as athletic director at Louisiana State Universit y. The L.S.U. Board of Supervisors m et with Dietzel for fourhours and agreed without opposition to reassi gn him to be assistant to the school's president ''for the developme nt of projects and programs.'' No new athletic director was name d. Dietzel will keep hissalary of $66,000 a year under contract to Ju ly 31, 1983.

title: U.S.-A.T.&T.  Delay Given
description: Judge Harold Greene of Federal District Court here, who has charge of the antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, granted permission today to the Justice Department to file by next Wednesday a requested statement describing the ''competitive impact'' of the proposed settlement of the case.

title: Oil Price Cut S een in Britain
description: Britain is going to cut the price of its North Sea oil by $1.50 a barrel in the next few days, to about $35, industry sources said today.

title: Awacs Protest in Europe
description: About 120 demonstrators from the Netherlands, West Germany, Denmark and Belgium protested outside a NATO air base near the Belgian border where American-made Awacs aircraft are to be stationed, the police said.

title: PAT FASHIONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SALVADOR CIVIL WAR PROVIDES DISCOMFORTS AND MINOR SPOILS
description: Salvadorans traveling along one of the country's major highways were exposed to the inconveniences brought by civil war today when they were asked for monetary donations by rebel soldiers and for their identification cards by Government forces.

title: TEXT OF THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY RESOLUTION ON ISRAEL
description: Following is the text of the resolution approved by a vote of 86 to 21 today by the ninth special emergency session of the General Assembly:

title: Sue Carol Ladd, Ex-Actress And Widow of Alan Ladd, 72
description: Sue Carol Ladd, an actress and widow of Alan Ladd, died Thursday of complications from a heart attack suffered two weeks ago, at the University of California Medical Center. She was 72 years old.

title: NORWESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A SOLVENT OLYMPICS PLANNED
description: The announcement was fairly routine - another television-rights agreement for the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics. But sandwiched around the $10.6 million contract for Australian rights came questions about security, financing and criticisms from the Soviet Union.

title: Books of The Times; Growing Up in the 50's
description: Braided Lives. By Marge Piercy. 441 pages. Summit Books. $15.50.

title: DOCTO R AND NURSE ARE SHOT BY PATIENT AT V.A. HOSPITAL
description: A 57-year-old patient shot a physician in the face yesterday morning at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in the Bronx and then fired a random shot that struck a nurse before he put down the gun and surrendered to guards.

title: RKO DENIED BID FOR STAY AT STATION
description: Justice William J. Brennan of the Supreme Court today refused RKO General Inc.'s request that he postpone the carrying out of a lower court ruling that would terminate the company's authority to operate WNAC-TV, Boston.

title: MUSE AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-The company started operations in July 1981

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Chemical Corp. said it had sold part of its acid producing business to Welland Chemical Ltd. for an undisclosed price.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Eight hundred thousand dollars. We have spent $800,000 chasing butterflies.'' - Sherman Eubanks, land developer. (1:3.)

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The guys were hanging around the gallery talking about graffiti. It is their lives, they said, and it is their art.

title: ANDERSON JACOBSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TOY MAKER AND PHILANTHROPIST
description: Louis Marx Sr., often called the Toy King of America, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Governors Against Crime
description: A Firm Hand in Albany

title: BUCKEYE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago results have been restated for changes in the minority interest for shrs in a subsidiary

title: CONVENTION GROUPS BUSY BOOKING HOLE IN THE GROUND ON WEST SIDE
description: New York City's convention center is a hole in the ground just off the Hudson River, a thicket of pillars amid mud puddles and construction rubble, but already, its operators say, the files in its sales offices are bulging with acceptances.

title: AMERICAN PETROFINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: CELTICS WIN ON PARISH JUMP SHOT, 145-144

title: Arthur S. Golden Weds Gertrude Legge
description: Gertrude Anna Legge and Arthur Sulzberger Golden were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's grandmother, Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, in New York City. State Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Greenfield performed the ceremony.

title: El Paso Pipeline
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company, a unit of the El Paso Company, said it had filed for an additional 250 million cubic feet of pipeline capacity from the Anardarko and Arkoma Basins in Oklahoma.

title: DEFICITS AND TIGHT MONEY VIEWED AS THREAT TO A 1982 RECOVERY
description: A moderate economic recovery is likely this year, but its prospects are threatened both by growing budget deficits and by the Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy, according to a forecast released today by the Congressional Budget Office.

title: CBS PLUNGES BY 42.3% ON1.7% REVENUES GAIN
description: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that a loss on the disposal of its mass-market paperback book assets caused earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981 to plunge 42.3 percent, while revenues edged up 1.7 percent.

title: NORTH CAROLINA NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW HAMPSHIRE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SPORTS AGENCY RAISING HOPES IN LAKE PLACID
description: A state agency designed to manage and promote year-round recreation here is taking shape in a bid to raise this Adirondack ski resort from the economic doldrums that set in after the 1980 Winter Olympics. The agency, the Olympic Regional Developmen t Authority, was established last year by the Legislature to m anage the $100 million complex of sports facilities erected for the Olympics by the Federal Government, as well as state-owned ski runs a nd jumps and several municipally operated skating rinks and cross- country trails.

title: G.M. Canada Cuts
description: General Motors of Canada Ltd. said it will lay off more than 2,500 workers at its trim and transmission plants in Windsor, Ontario, for one week starting Monday. Shutdowns at a number of assembly plants across the United States were cited by a company spokesman as the reason for the layoffs. The shutdowns have created high stocks of trim products and transmissions, he said.

title: Joseph Tholl, 72, an Analyst Of Writing and Documents
description: Joseph Tholl, an internationally recognized handwriting and docum ent analyst w ho helped the police here solve thousands of crimes in a 27-year c areer, died at his home in Peninsula Thursday. He was 72 years old.

title: British Ice-Dance Pair Retain European Title
description: Jayne Torville and Christopher Dean of Britain today retained their ice-dancing title at the European figureskating champ ionships.

title: AT AMERICA'S VOICE
description: Parties to the ancient and running dispute at the Voice of America about news versus propaganda should worry less about theory and more about practice. P urists on both sides can continue indulging the ir conceits and mutual suspicions only at the expense of the high r ank in international broadcasting that the Voice, which is 40 years o ld this month, has earned with hard work.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM CANADA

title: AN INFORMER HELPED F.B.I.'S AGENTS TRAP SOVIET ARMY ATTACHE
description: The arrest of a senior Soviet military attache last weekend came after the Federal Bureau of Investigation arranged for an informer to pass to him what the Russian was led to believe was a sensitive document, a high-ranking Government official said today.

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Guatemala Editor Slain In Machine Gun Attack
description: The editor of the daily newspaper La Nacion, Roberto Hiron Lemus, was killed by machine gun fire today near his home, the police said.

title: HEALTH INSURANCE: UNDERSTANDING COVERAGE
description: Too often people learn what is -and, more important, what is not - covered by their medical insurance policies the hard way: when faced with a staggering bill for services they thought were covered. In other cases people miss out on services or reimbursement because they do not realize what is due them or how to file and follow through on a claim. A national survey by the Rand Corporation published last summer found that when the policy required that a deductible (the amount the consumer

title: Singer in Pact To Sell Division
description: The Singer Company, an industrial concern with operations ranging from sewing m achines and aerospace systems to furniture, control devices and o ther products, said it had agreed in principle to sell its air-condi tioning and heating equipment division to a newly formedcorporation.

title: HEALY'S GONE, SO WHO'S ON FIRST NOW?
description: conditioning unit at home had gone on the fritz.

title: SHARP MILITARY RISE SOUGHT
description: Reagan Administration officials today projected a deficit of $91.5 billion for the next fiscal year, a sharp increas e in military expenditures and deep cuts in social programs. The projections were given to members of Congress in a preview of th e Administration's budget.

title: The Constitution as Cudgel
description: Lobbyists who claim to represent the interests of taxpayers have persuaded 31 state legislatures to use the Constitution as a tactical weapon. They want to convene a new constitutional convention to pass an amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget -or at least to use the threat of such a convention to force Congress to pass it instead.

title: TOTAL PETROLEUM (NORTH AMERICA) LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DAVID CLYDE RETIRES
description: David Clyde, the pitcher who caused a sensation when he went from high school baseball to the Texas Rangers 1974, is retiring at the age of 26. Clyde, whose has been plagued with arm troubles, compiled a 4-10 record with a 6.95 earned run average last season for Tucson, a farm club of the Houston Astros.

title: Hitachi Sets Texas Plant Expansion
description: Hitachi Ltd. will expand facilities at its plant in Dallas to triple capacity by the middle of this year. The plant, operated by Hitachi Semiconductor America Inc., assembles about 300,000 of the 16- and 64-kilobit random access memory, or RAM, chips a month, it said.

title: GRIEVING FATHER KILLED BY POLICE
description: A man who was described as distraught over the death of a son was shot and killed by the police tonight after he had held three people hostage more than 24 hours at a hospital where the boy had been treated for leukemia, the police said.

title: SPECTRA-PHYSICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1980 figures have been restated to reflect the May 31, 1981 acquisition of Quanta-Ray Inc

title: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RAYBESTOS-MANHATTAN INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 27
Mrs. von Bulow's Maid Denies Alcohol Report
description: Martha von Bulow drank only ''once in a while'' and was not bedeviled by alcohol, drugs or sweets, as the defense conte nds, her maid testified today at Claus von Bulow's trialfor attempted murder.

title: Sentence in $300,000 Holdup
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn man involved in a $300,000 armed robbery last July of the Peykar Oriental Rug Store in Westbury was sentenced today to a prison term of 18 to 54 months. The defendant was Carlos Villanuva of 550 Maple Street, who pleaded guilty last October to a reduced charge of attempted firstdegree robbery.

title: IF THE BROADWAY MALL PROVES TO BE A MISTAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: HATTERAS INCOME SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income figures represent net investment income

title: CHEMICAL BANK SIGNS FLORIDA NATIONAL DEAL
description: The Chemical Bank moved to tighten its shaky grip on Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. yesterday by signing a ''definitive agreement to merge'' with the Jacksonville, Fla., holding company when interstate banking becomes legal.

title: 5 Youths Indicted In Extortion Plot
description: Five teen-age residents of the Edenwald city housing project in the Wakefield section of the Bronx were indicted on charges of extorting more than $20,000 from a disabled couple in the project.

title: THE POLICE BLOTTER
description: Three men held u p the Wahba Trading Company on the fifth floor of 163 West 23d Street early yesterday and escap ed with $4,900 in cash.

title: AIRLINES SET PACE AS STOCKS ADVANCE
description: Airline issues led the stock market higher yesterday in active trading. Bank and drug stocks also showed strength, while several other issues moved ahead as a result of takeover developments. The Dow Jon es industrial average rose 4 points, to 851.03. Stock prices over a ll showed even better gains, as indicated by the 1,040 advances and 402 declines on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: MRS. KING TO GO ON
description: Billie Jean King ended speculation about retirement by announcing that she will play in the $100,000 Avon tournament from Feb. 15-21 at the Summit in Houston. ''I never said that I was contemplating retirement after Detroit,'' said Mrs. King, who is 38 years old.

title: TRADE DEFICIT WIDENS FOR NONMILITARY GOODS
description: Despite a decline in oil imports, the nation's trade deficit for nonmilitary goods grew to $27.84 billion last year from $25.3 billion in 1980, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: WORKING WOMEN: EASING BURDEN
description: Almost 52 percent of American women are now in the work force, and they are facing increasing pressures because of their ''double work roles'' - at the workplace and in the home - a conference on working women was told this week.

title: NEW ORLEANS VOTING TODAY, WITH MAYOR SEEKING RE-ELECTION
description: A few days ago, at a cocktail party, Mayor Ernest N. Dutch Morial paced the thickly carpeted living room of affluent friends in uptown New Orleans and addressed the issue faced most often in his current campaign for re-election: his own personality; specifically, his purported arrogance.

title: REICHHOLD CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After foreign currency translation losses of $1,177,000 for the qr and $79,000 for the yr and an extraordinary charge of $2,380,000 for the yr...C-Including foreign currency translation gains of $751,000 or 11 cents a shr for the qr and $1,637,000 or 24 cents a shr for the yr; results for the latest yr reflect the adoption of an accounting change for foreign currency translations which increased net income by $2,809,000 or 40 cents a shr for the yr

title: SOMETIMES A MOVIE MAKES A STUDIO PROUD
description: The word that Warner Bros. and the Ladd Company executives use most frequently when talking about ''Chariots of Fire'' is ''pride.''

title: Burns Leads by One on 69-136
description: George Burns said he was a ''little wilder'' today than he was yesterday, but with some luck he scored a three-under-par 69 to take a one-stroke lead after the second round of the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am. Burns, who won this tournament in 1980, completed 36 holes at 136, eight under par.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.4 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday reported a drop of $1.4 billion in the nation's money supply, a smaller decline than the $3 billion to $5 billion the markets had expected.

title: Two Officers Arraigned In Death in Milwaukee
description: Two policemen charged with misconduct in the death of Ernest Lacy were arraigned today and released on bond. Mr. Lacy, who was being arrested for a rape but later was shown to be innocent, died while in police custody last July 10.

title: DOCTOR TELLS ATLANTA JURY HE DOUBTS 2 WERE SLAIN
description: A physician from New York state testified today that it was his opinion the two young black men Wayne B. Williams is accused of killing and dumping in a river were not murdered.

title: Mary A. Pierce Bride Of Phillip Ryder Kraft
description: Mary Agatha Pierce, daughter of Mrs. John Greeley Pierce of New York and the late Mr. Pierce of Boston, was married at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Chur ch yesterday to Phill ip Ryder Kraft. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Arthur Kraf t of Camp Hill, Pa.

title: Cuts Planned By Harvester
description: The International Harvester Company said that it will halt production of tractors at its Farmall plant in Rock Island, Ill., for two months starting March 8.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1982; Companies
description: Laker Airways declared bankruptcy and halted all its flights. The brash upstart of the trans-Atlantic routes, caught in a cash squeeze, had been trying to reschedule an outstanding debt of over $300 million incurred in the purchase of new aircraft, but a major creditor appears to have cut off its credit. (Page 1.) Trans-Atlantic fares may rise now, but not enough to aid the ailiing airline industry significantly. (33.) Laker's major creditors were hopeful that the collapse would cause them no lasting harm. (33.) Most carriers will honor Laker passengers' tickets. (33.)

title: A TURKEY YOU KNOW IS GOING TO FOLD
description: No longer were America's enemies sneering this week about the pitiful helpless giant of the free world. No longer were Communist renegades telling their comrades, ''America is like a paper mynah bird - talk so much, do so nothing.''

title: DEFENDING THE PRICE OF RUBBER
description: Defending the ''blue line'' is John J. Reidl's specialty. He doesn't play hockey; he plays the world's rubber market. He is manager of the International Natural Rubber Organization's buffer stock, and thousands of the world's rubber producers rely on him to keep international rubber prices from getting out of hand.

title: News Analysis
description: The crisis in Poland has escalated the concept of default from that of a tool used by creditors in collecting unpaid debts to a potentially powerful political weapon in the conflict between Washington and Moscow.

title: Zapata Loses Title
description: Amado Ursua of Mexico stripped the World Boxing Council's super flyweight title from Hilario Zapata of Panama with a knockout in the second round tonight. Zapata was making the ninth defense of the title he won by defeating Shigeo Nakajima of Japan in March 1980.

title: Margaret Sieck to Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Sieck of Newport, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Sieck, to Robert H.B. Baldwin Jr., son of Mr. Baldwin of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., and Geraldine W. Baldwin of New Vernon, N.J.

title: The Week in Business; PRIME RATE UP, MONEY SUPPLY DOWN
description: The prime rate was increased by major banks to 16 1/2 percent from 15 3/4, raising the specter of generally higher interest rates. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan termed the prime-rate increase a ''temporary phenomenon'' that would not hurt a spring recovery. On Friday, the Federal Reserve said the money supply fell $1.4 billion in the latest reporting week, a drop that might ease pressures for more credit-tightening.

title: Reagan Unwraps His 1983 Budget, Without Ribbons
description: Reviewing President Reagan's budget proposals for fiscal 1983, unceremoniously unwrapped by the White House yesterday, it was Republicans who were glumest. Last year had given them the Program for Economic Recovery. Next year, Mr Reagan says, will come the New Federalism Initiative. This year is an awkward moment in Federal revenues, Federal spending and that yawning gap in between, the Federal deficit, that last week the Administration took pains to finesse.

title: CORPORATE AID IS SOUGHT IN LIGHT OF EXPECTED DAY-CARE CUTS
description: Corporations in New York City are being asked to help their employees with child day care in the light of expected ''enormous cuts in the Federal budget'' for publicly supported centers.

title: SAYS BIG DEFICITS WILL GO ON
description: President Reagan, facing skepticism in both parties, released a Budget Message today urging Congress to ''stay the course'' by shrinking the social responsibilities of the Government while expanding the nation's military strength.

title: POLAND THREATENS TO BOYCOTT TALKS
description: Poland has warned that it will not take part in the resumption of talks next week in Madrid on East-West cooperation in Europe if the issue of martial law in Poland is raised by the West.

title: Brooklyn Schoolboy Excels in Track Meet
description: Dave Peletier of Brooklyn's Wingate High School set a meet record of 49.2 seconds in the 400-meter dash and later anchored Wingate's 1,600-meter relay team to victory at the West Point invitation meet today.

title: REAGAN AND 'NEW FEDERALISM' ARE READY TO GO ON THE
description: ROAD By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

title: CORRECTION
description: Due to erroneous information provided by the Rondo Dance Theater, an article in last Sunday's Westchester Weekly section included an incorrect date for the dance company's March performances. The program at the Purchase campus of the State University of New York will be given on March 6 at 8 P.M. and March 7 at 3 P.M. For tickets, call 234-9575.

title: 'WHEN ONE'S CHILD IS HANDICAPPED': READERS RESPOND
description: Being the father of a handicapped child in 1982 is to always feel out of sync with society. In a time when men of all ages and middleaged men in particular are encouraged to self-actualize, it's having one's own needs and desires come second to those of the handicapped child. At the same time, it's not avoiding the the crown of martyrdom; any parent of a handicapped child needs that crown in order to survive this grand test.

title: PASSING THE TAX BUCK
description: HARTFORD ON the floor of the United States Senate a few years ago, Russell B. Long, the Louisiana Democrat who was then chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, grew exasperated with fellow Senators who kept proposing amendments to a major tax bill.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART In relation to the stature of his initial gift, Marc Chagall is beyond any doubt the most exasperating artist alive. (And alive he is, by the way, and shaping up for his centenary, which falls due in l987.)

title: CONSUMER RATES
KOCH CRITICIZES PARTY POLICIES
description: Mayor Koch, in the third of a series of statements on national issues, today urged the Democrats to stop being ''the party of the poor.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ZERMATT
description: PAUL LEWIS is a Paris-based correspondent for The Times. By PAUL LEWIS At this time of year, sleigh bells and the soft neigh of horses greet the visitor to Zermatt, perhaps the mos t attractive of Switzerland's picture-postcard Alpine resorts . And this year, after two poorish ski seasons, the snow is excellen t. Every chalet roof is neatly topped with snow, and the horizon is r inged by a ragged friezeof white crags, sloping down to the valley wh ere the homes and inns of the village huddle around a green-steepled church.

title: DISPUTE RENEWED OVER USE OF ROCK SALT ON ICE
description: When snow falls in the city, rock salt follows - and each winter a struggle is renewed between naturalists and city officials over its use.

title: NOW'S THE TIME HOUSE SWAPPERS BUCKLE DOWN
description: A house is an asset that can be bought and sold, but it can also be traded. Ditto the condominium and cooperative apartment. Swapping houses for vacation purposes is hardly a new phenomenon. Those who operate as intermediaries in such exchanges say that they are constantly growing. This is the time of year when arrangements for the summer months are normally set in motion.

title: Mariko Masuoka, Architect, to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Yoshito Masuoka of W ayland, Ma ss., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mariko Masuoka, to William N. Goetzmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Goe tzmann of Austin, Tex.

title: SOAP OPERA FANS ARE SEEING STARS
description: If Ellen Stewart, the long-suffering heroine of CBS's ''As the World Turns,'' is having second thoughts about asking her husband of 25 years to move out, she won't after this Wednesday. That's when she will meet Suz Baker, the carefree divorcee who will help her readjust to life as an unmarried woman.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: MAKING A CASE FOR 'RAGTIME'
description: To the Editor:

title: Naples
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL TO AIRPORTS: COST RISES
description: THE traffic on the Long Island Expressway had been moderate, and there seemed to be no threat from icy conditions or heavy winds. The Chicago-bound traveler felt, in short, that now that she had reached La Guardia Airport, she could relax and look forward to her flight.

title: COLLEAGUES MISS WILLIAMS'S WORK
description: talk of ''inner strength,'' ''keeping up to speed'' and of ''virtually every minute spent on politics.''

title: Grantham Tour
description: To the Editor:

title: LISA DOLIN TO WED IN APRIL
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Martin Dolin of Waynesboro, Ga., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Dolin, to Scott Robert Mlyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Mlyn of New York. An April wedding is planned in Augusta, Ga.

title: PLAY: 'FLUX,' COMEDY ABOUT WRITING
description: Jess, the heroine of Susan Miller's ''Flux,'' is a college English instructor who keeps ''The Elements of Style'' handy in her pocket at all times. ''Flux,'' now at the Second Stage, often sounds as if it were written by Strunk and White. ''Vigorous writing is concise,'' lectures Jess to her students in the opening scene. ''Don't avoid detail and treat a subject only in outline.'' Later on she adds that writers should ''trust the reader'' and ''not try for a literary coup every couple of minutes.'' True enough, but what are we to make of Miss Miller's play? ''Flux'' is far from concise, is bereft of illuminating details, and treats its subject only in outline. It tries for a literary coup every couple of minutes.

title: TEACHING: UNREWARDING BUT INDISPENSABLE
description: When I first read Marianne Sikorski's article, "Teaching Problems, in and OUt of the Classroom" (Jan. 24), I found myself nodding in agreement in light of my 33 years in an elementary classroom. Then, on reflection, I began to wonder if I was really honest in my affirmative reaction, especially when I recalled the yellow-edged notes in my upstairs file at home from youngsters whose lives had been affected by what I said in class.

title: VIETNAM WAR GOAL OF U.S. CRITICIZED
description: A major United States mistake in the Vietnam War was seeking the destruction of the Vietcong guerrillas rather than that of the North Vietnamese Army, according to a new study by a much-decorated former platoon leader in Vietnam.

title: The Nation; 'Larry, We're Going Down'
description: Freezing weather, the suspected cause of last month's crash of an Air Florida jet near Washington's National Airport, dominated the talk between the airliner's pilots in the moments before its fatal takeoff. In a tape of the cockpit conversation released last week, Capt. Larry Wheaton and his co-pilot, Alan Pettit, joked nervously as snow fell on the runways and the planes waiting to use them. Mr. Pettit even suggested that the exhaust from a jet in front of the Air Florida Boeing 737 might blow some of the snow off its wings.

title: OCEAN-DUMPING PROTEST ENDS
description: RAINBOW WARRIOR, the ship operated by Greenpeace, the international marine environmental group, wound up its protest last Thursday against ocean dumping - but not voluntarily.

title: Music View; DO YOU 'HEAR' BLUE OR SEE RED WHEN YOU LISTEN TO MUSIC?
description: For a history of ''The Yellow Sound,'' see page TKtk.

title: MAKING A CASE FOR 'RAGTIME'
description: To the Editor:

title: WPIX Clarifies Status of Bureau
description: As a point of clarification, we do not have a television production facility at our New Jersey bureau in Rutherford.

title: Laura Nelle Nesbit Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Chester M. Nesbit of White Plains of the engagement of their daugh ter, Laura Nelle Nesbit,to Gerald Kingsley Wilders, son of Mr. and Mr s. Victor T. Wilders of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Ma y in the Roman Catholic Church of Immaculate Heart of Mary in Scarsda le. Msgr. James G. Wilders, an uncle of the future bridegroom, w ill perform the ceremony.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Seeks to Deport Man On War Crimes Charge
description: The Federal Government is seeking deportation of a Ukrainain accused of taking part in the executions up to 350 Jews in World War II.

title: SERVICES ARE THE NEW TRADE FRONTIER
description: In the White House and Congress, there is visible concern over America's ''invisible exports'' -services. These include banking, engineering and construction, insurance, air and ocean transport and telecommunications.

title: FOR AND AGAINST NOSTALGIA ON TRAINS
description: Some may see the old trains only as dirty and rundown holdouts whose time has come, none to soon, to an end. But those of us who are sentimental -or, more importantly, sentient - will disagree, as Miss Stanger did.

title: POLICE, SCHOOLS AND COURTS PLANNING COORDINATED FIGHT ON JUVENILE CRIME
description: Hundreds of public school administrators and key law enforcement officials gathered yesterday for the first time to discuss ways of coordinating their handling of the growing problem of juvenile crime in New York City and its schools.

title: STUDENTS CRITICIZE THEIR OWN EARLY SLOTH
description: "WHEN I was in high school, I couldn't wait to graduate. I couldn't wait to get out. Now I wish I could return."

title: No Headline
description: De Paul (20-1) Posts 15th in a Row, 67-66

title: Around the Nation; Policeman Shot Dead On Bus Patrol in Chicago
description: A uniformed police officer was shot dead on a Chicago Transit Authority bus Friday, a day after police officers were assigned to extra duty on the system.

title: A NEW EDICT RESTRICTS TURKS IN CONTACTS WITH FOREIGNERS
description: Turkey's military authorities have barred Turkish institutions from any contact here with representatives of official or unofficial organizations abroad, without official permission.

title: Barbara Schlesinger to Be Wed in Fall
description: The engagem ent of Barbara Schlesinger to Michael Amdurer has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Carl Schlesinger of Rutherford, N.J., parents of th e bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Dr. Stanley Amdurer of Po rtals Nous, Majorca, and the late Frieda Neugebauer Amdurer.

title: WHAT'S WRONG IN SOUTH AFRICA IS A MATTER OF COLOR PRETORIA VIEW A
description: 'TOTAL ONSLAUGHT'

title: Wendy's Split
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''In Stocks, Don't Follow the Leader'' (Jan. 31), it is true that Wendy's International stock dropped from 17 5/8 to 13 7/8 in the first nine months of 1981. However, a stock split of threefor-two resulted in an 18 percent gain for investors during the period described. LEONARD K. TOWER Fairview Park, Ohio, Jan. 31, 1982

title: 3 FACTORS STIRRED CONTROVERSY, BURKE SAYS OF HIS TENURE
description: TRENTON HIS EIGHT years in office, Fred G. Burke, New Jersey's departing Commissioner of Education, said, were characterized by ''possibly the most sweeping'' changes in education law ''in the last quartercentury.''

title: Artis Seized in Jersey On Driving Violation
description: John Artis, the convicted murderer who was freed from state prison six weeks ago, has been arrested on motor vehicle violations.

title: ISLANDERS WIN 8TH STRAIGHT BY 6-2
description: The Islanders' ran their winning streak to eight games, a club record, tonight with an easy 6-2 vi ctory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: U.S. FACES MALPRACTICE PAYMENT FOR SURGEON
description: She does not know that a Federaljudge ruled Jan. 21 that the Government must pay a $2.1 million malpractice award as a result of the actions of a doctor who treated her, at one time the ranking Air Force hear surgeon.

title: SENATE PUTS THOSE SOCIAL ISSUES ON THE FRONT BURNER
description: THE economy and the Federal budget are high-priority matters on Capitol Hill these days, but conservative lawmakers remain determined to press for enactment of their ''social issues'' agenda. Last week the Senate, ignoring arguments that the measure was unconstitutional, approved the most stringent antibusing legislation ever enacted by either chamber, an amendment that would take away the power of Federal courts to order students to be bused more than five miles or 15 minutes from their homes.

title: Unpredictable a Winner In San Vicente Stakes
description: Unpredictable scored a 1 1/4-length victory today in the 41st running of the San Vicente Stakes for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita.

title: SIERRA CLUB S HIFTS TO DIRECT BACKING FOR CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATES IN
description: '82 By PHILIP SHABECOFF Speci al to the New York Times

title: The World; Neighbors Try A Fresh Start
description: Despite sporadic attempts to resolve their differences, India and Pakistan seemed resigned to a future that repeated their past history of mistrust and animosity.

title: USE OF HISTORIC SCHOOL QUESTIONED
description: CANTERBURY A 177-year-old house that was the site of what is believed to have been the first school in the United States for black girls has become the object of a tug of war of sorts between the town, which wants to convert it to a library, and the Connecticut Historical Commission, which is restoring it as a museum dedicated to the school's founder, Prudence Crandall.

title: DAY-CARE CUTS RAISING CONCERN
description: THE budget squeeze came all at once. Within one month, Loretta Mascia's food-stamp allowance was dramatically reduced, her rent was raised and she learned that services for her children at the Pelham Day Care Center were about to triple in price. ''The new day-care fees will make it almost impossible for me and my kids to survive on my salary,'' said Miss Mascia, a single parent who grosses $10,500 a year as a bank teller. ''Twelve dollars per child a week may not sound like a lot of money to some people, but to me it's a fortune. It's going to cost me so much to pay for day care now that I'm beginning to think it might not be worth it. I might be better off if I quit my job and went on welfare.''

title: Ellen Ackerman Becomes Bride Of W.H. Eyre Jr.
description: At St. James Episcopal Church yesterday, Ellen Jean Ackerman, daughter of Mrs. Daniel H. Ridder of Long Beach and Pebble Beach, Calif., and Jack R. Ackerman of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married to William Hudson Eyre Jr. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eyre of New York and Sharon, Conn.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 16 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 3 21 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 2 12 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.)
