Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 8 8 13 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman.

title: MUST NEW YORK BEND THE LAW TO MAKE THE COURTS WORK?
description: It was perh aps inevitable that a fight over the appointment of judges to the State Supreme Court would end up adding one more case to New York's burgeoning judicial backlog. So it was last week, as anAppellate Div ision panel weighed a challenge by the Manhattan District Atto rney, Robert M. Morgenthau, to Chief Judge Lawrence

title: Food; HOW TO RIPEN THE AVOCADO, AND THEN ENJOY ITS FLAVOR
description: THE avocado is enjoying more attention than usual this year. But not for reasons that make growers happy. There is such a glut that some avocado ranchers have seriously suggested turning the butterylike fruit into dog food.

title: A CLIMBER TRIES ZERMATT ON SKIS
description: JEREMY BERNSTEIN is a staff writer for The New Yorker. His latest book is ''Science Observed.'' By JEREMY BERNSTEIN

title: BUDGET PLAN WOULD RAISE U.S. DEBT TO $1,260 BILLION
description: President Reagan is submitting a budget for the next fiscal year that would add $124 billion to the gross Federal debt and lift it to an astronomical $1,260 billion by Sept. 30, 1983, budget documents showed today.

title: Corporate Dance Fund Sets a Record
description: The National Corporate Fund for Dance Inc. raised $505,600 from 206 corporations last year, a record amount for the fund-raising institution, which released the figure. The money was distributed to its seven member troupes: the American Ballet Theater, San Francisco Ballet, Joffrey Ballet, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Eliot Feld Ballet and the Merce Cunningham and Paul Taylor Dance Companies.

title: Juliane Janis Engaged To Richard Greifinger
description: Dr. and Mrs. Michel Janis of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Juliane F. Janis, to Richard Alan Greifinger, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Greifinger of South Orange, N.J.

title: Pope to Visit Spain
description: Pope John Paul II will visit Spain in mid-October for the 400th anniversary of the death of St. Teresa, the Vatican said today. John Paul leaves on a weeklong tour of four African nations on Friday.

title: Reporter's Notebook; THE RANGERS' ROAD TO SUC C ESS
description: The Rangers have now traveled 4,202 miles in 12 days to play six hockey games. By next Saturday, they will have traveled another 2,428 miles and played two more games.

title: Foreign Affairs; REAGAN'S CARIBBEAN HOLIDAY
description: It's easy enough to see why President and Mrs. Reagan want to spend a few days with their old Hollywood friend Claudette Colbert here after a miserable winter.

title: BROWN IS FARING POORLY IN THE CALIFORNIA POLL
description: Despite a fat campaign chest and maximum exposure as a guest on radio talk shows, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. is faring poorly in public opinion polls both as a candidate for the United States Senate and in his role as Governor.

title: THE YOUNG FARMERS
description: Farmers do not compete with one another. In fact, large growers can often better afford the risks associated with new crops or cultural practices; if these ventures are successful, the ''secrets'' are widely shared in the farm community.

title: 8 Bus Passengers Slain On Road in Guatemala
description: An armed gang forced passengers to get off two buses on a rural road, then burned the buses and opened fire on the passengers, the police said today. They said eight people were killed and several injured.

title: Crayfish
description: To the Editor:

title: ARIZONA TOWN, NEXT TO NOWHERE, WANTS PRO FOOTBALL STADIUM
description: Where most people see only sagebrush and jack rabbits, Cecil Kin ser pictures a giant domed stadium, ringedby acres of p arking lots and crowded to the rafters with tens of thousands of cheering pro football fans.

title: The Region; Kean Sticking To His Pledges On Cabinet Jobs
description: As only the second Republican Governor of New Jersey in the last 28 years, Thomas H. Kean would have surprised few and delighted many of the party faithful by loading his Cabinet from their ranks. But as his administration continued to develop last week, with Senate committee approval of three more appointees, it seemed clear that patronage was not a top Kean priority.

title: TRIPLE BILL HAS BREVITY BUT NOT WIT
description: DAVID LITT'S mission of producing "original" works by new playwrights on the Island has been mostly unaccomplished. Under the banner, the Contemporary Theater, which began two years ago as the Contemporary Playwrights Theater, Mr. Litt has fitfully presented new one-act plays - mostly his own and mostly disagreeable - and a smattering of "classical" works.

title: Shattered by Tom Wolfe's Attire
description: I've always found Tom Wolfe to be a consummate perfectionist (''Tom Wolfe: The Great Gadfly,'' by Tony S chwartz, Dec. 20).

title: RESIDENTS FIGHT MOVE TO SET UP A PAROLE OFFICE
description: A plan to move the state's Parole Division offices into the Tribeca section of lower Manhattan faces opposition from the neighborhood's residents, who have voiced fear s that the 2,700 former offenders who report to the board regularly will bring crime to this increasingly residential p art of the city.

title: Met Ballet Will Perform New Bonnefous Work
description: The Metropolitan Opera Ballet will perform Jean-Pierre Bonnefous's new ''Three Overtures'' from Feb. 26 to 28 at City College's Aaron Davis Hall.

title: Practical Traveler; CONDOMINIUM TIME-SHARING
description: M ore and more vacationers are discovering that it can be much cheaper, more comfortable and sometimes more luxurious to rent an apartment or villa owned by another vacationer than to stay at a resort hotel.

title: JAZZMEN AT ODDS WITH STEREOTYPICAL SWING
description: When Duke Ellington said, ''It don't mean a thing if it ain't got that swing,'' he coined a dictum that most jazz fans can still agree on - at least until they get down to definitions. What is swing, exactly? And since what is swing to me isn't necessarily swing to you, what kind of swing did Ellington mean by ''that'' swing? These considerations are not purely philosophical. Every time a musician comes along whose manner of swinging is new or different, a critic or an influential older musician is likely to complain that the newcomer doesn't swing at all. And if his music doesn't swing, well, it doesn't mean anything.

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER For its 20th anniversary, La Mama is having a celebratory season, presenting revivals of its past successes and new works by its favorite writers and directors. One of the recent revivals, Sam Shepard's ''The Unseen Hand,'' has moved into an open-ended engagement at the Provicetown Playhouse.

title: PARTISAN CULTURE, PARTISAN POLITICS
description: THE TRUANTS Adventures Among the Intellectuals. By William Barrett. 270 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $15.95.

title: 'THE PLAYS WE WRITE ARE AMERICAN PLAYS'
description: To the Editor:$

title: DEBATE RENEWED ON GROUP RENTALS
description: SOUTHAMPTON TOWN officials and their lawyers are lining up against homeowners and their lawyers again in the annual attempt to pass a law regulating summer group rentals.

title: FOSTER AND METS NEARING ACCORD
description: George Foster, a slugging star with the Cincinnati Reds for the last decade, will apparently be wearing the uniform of the New York Mets this sea son and for the next several years.

title:
Gardening;
FRIENDLY AND HELPFUL SYMBIOTIC PLANTS
description: MOST people would agree that a good marriage is one in which both partners contribute as well as benefit from the relationship. It seems that the plant world is filled with such unselfish relationships. We are just now learning of the importance of fostering similar relationships among the plants that we grow in our gardens, forests and fields.

title: Travel Guides
description: To the Editor:

title: A WIDER VIEW OF A POET
description: T he new Grasmere and Wordsworth Museum, which opened last October in England's Lake District and contains the largest collection of Wordsworthian memorabilia in the world, is a prime place to start a pilgrimage to the countryside in which the 19th-century Romantic poet lived.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption last Sunday in the Greater New York Automobile Show section (distributed in the New York region only), accompanying an article about the sales of imported cars, incor- rectly identified the third automobile from the top of page 16. It was a Peu- got 505 STI.

title: On Language
description: Good Courtisanship KIMBLE MEAD

title: VANDERBILT MUSEUM SEEKS A FRESH START
description: CENTERPORT LIGHT snow brushed softly across the deserted cobblestone drive that winds past a stand of linden trees and down to the main house on the grounds of the Vanderbilt estate. Although the museum is closed to the public for the winter, it was alive with activity as work to upgrade the facility continues throughout the cold-weather months.

title: The Nation; Reagan Has One Less Reaganite
description: Another veteran of Ronald Reagan's long march to Washington has had enough of life at the top. Martin C. Anderson, the chief of the White House Office of Policy Development, who has been called the Administration's conservative conscience, said last week that he was resigning effective March 1 to become a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University.

title: '83 BUDGET PROCESS BEGINNING NOW WILL PROBABLY TAKE A YEAR
description: If history is any indication, Congress will take more than a year to dispose of the budget it is receiving from President Reagan. In the process it will break some of its own rules, establish a few new ones and delay many of the tougher decisions. Congress will also undoubtedly make many changes in the President's proposals, rejecting some appropriations and adding money elsewhere.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Elizabeth Treanor Plays Bloch Violin Sonata
description: Elizabeth Treanor, a young English violinist who has studied at the Juilliard School in New York, played Schubert, Bloch, Schumann and Szymanowski at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday night. Miss Treanor has a strong technique and a positive attitude toward her music; and what she lacked in subtlety - which was a great deal - was often averaged out by the enthusiasm of her music-making.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Cu stom Mementos For a Loved One
description: The originality of the custom-decorated, milk chocolate or dark semisweet chocolate greetings hand-lettered by Roger Gutwillig of St. Moritz Chocolatier in Scarsdale can add an element of fun to Valentine's Day.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Black Sabbath concert at Madison Square Garden, which is listed today in The Guide (section 2A), has been postponed to May 17.

title: Scott Ferguson Fiance Of Andrea Cushman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norton Cushman of Burlington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Norton Cushman, to Scott Sherwood Ferguson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Walker Ferguson of Westerly, R.I., and Munich, West Germany.

title: DEBATE HEATING UP ON SCHOOL AID CHANGES
description: ALBANY ''FLAT grants, 'save harmless' endangered'' was how Governor Carey predicted the headlines might read on the accounts of a three-year study by the New York State Special Task Force on Equity in Education.

title: ...AND INTELLIGENCE PEDDLED NO OPTIMISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Mubarak Has a Meeting With Mrs. Thatcher
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher held what a British spokesman described as an ''extremely useful'' 90-minute meeting today.

title: Business Conditions; COAL'S BRIGHT OUTLOOK
description: Harsh winter weather has cut coal production and delayed shipments, but continued strong demand from utilities is expected to widen coal's share of the energy market this year.

title: MANILA FILM FESTIVAL PROVES ALL-OUT SPECTACULAR
description: From the start, the First Manila International Film Festival promised to be like no other film festival. A production masterminded by the Philippines' First Lady, Imelda Marcos, the festival was designed to promote the Philippines as the Ca nnes of theEast.

title: SCHOOL PAPER LISTS LIQUOR-SALES LIST
description: RIVERHEAD A LIST of places where under-age students can buy alcoholic beverages has become the prize in a tug-of-war between school and town officials in Riverhead.

title: No Guns. No Nothing.
description: The budget that Ronald Reagan offers this week is the first that fully reflects his own political choices - and the last not warped by the next Presidential campaign. With this set of numbers, Mr. Reagan defines his Presidency. And a moment's reflection about those numbers shows that he has made a momentous choice, reversing the priorities he himself used to proclaim.

title: AEOLIANS WEATHER 20 YEARS
description: Twenty years ago, the Aeolian Chamber Players took their name from Aeolus, the Greek god of the winds. That choice may have been fortunate. Many breezes have blown across our musical world since the group's founding, and looking back as the quartet celebrates its anniversary next Saturday night with a concert in Merkin Concert Hall at Goodman House, it appears that the Aeolians have been at the center of many of those gusts.

title: Five Choreographers Named for Workshop
description: Five choreographers have been selected for the Ballet Theater Foundation's 1981-82 Workshop Program. The choreographers, chosen from 60 applicants, are Helen Douglas, Victoria Uris, Philip Grosser, Peter Sparling and John McFall.

title: FISCAL YEAR, POLITICAL SEASON
description: HARTFORD AS a political document, the state budget that Governor O'Neill has proposed to the General Assembly was tailor-made for an election year.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CHAMELEON By William Diehl. 374 pp. New York: Random House. $14.50. THE MAHDI By A.J. Quinnell. 297 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $13.50.

title: M. C. Hayes Is the Fiance Of Miss Conn
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Hadley L. Conn Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisabeth Ann Conn, to Michael Christopher Hayes of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Hayes of Port Washington, L.I.

title: Kevin O'Connor to Star In Series at the Clurman
description: The Harold Clurman Theater on West 42d Street will offer a series of plays starring Kevin O'Connor, beginning with ''Chunky's Hunch'' by Rochelle Owens. Directed by Elinor Renfield, ''Chunky's Hunch'' will start previews on Thursday and open Feb. 16. K The play, a bout a drink-sodden, middle-aged artist, was given a showcase prod uction at the Theater for the New City last season.

title: Alison Smith Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Procter Smith Jr. of Montclair, N.J., and West Chop, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Alison Leigh Smith, to Jonathan Parker Hitesman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wood Hitesman of Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, formerly of Bedford, N.Y.

title: What Commuters Contribute to the City
description: According to a recent New York Times article, ''Koch to Ask Commuter Tax Rise,'' the Mayor is once again seeking to plug gaps in upcoming municipal budgets.

title: REAGAN'S MILITARY BUDGET PUTS EMPHASIS ON A BUILDUP OF U.S. GLOBAL POWER
description: The Reagan Administration will be asking Congress for authority to spend $1,640 billion in the next five years on the armed services, with special emphasis on building American capability to project power around the globe.

title: Fashion; SUCCESS FOR THE DRESS
description: Fashion By June Weir

title: COSTA RICA TO PICK NEW LEADER TODAY
description: Around one million Costa Ricans go to the polls Sunday to pick a president whose main challenge will be to prevent this tiny democracy from being swept up by the political instability convulsing the rest of Central America.

title: DISPUTE HALTS PROJECT BURNING TOXIC WASTE AS FUEL
description: The huge Alpha Portland Industries cement kiln here has stopped burning hazardous waste as a fuel in a confrontation between technical innovation and government regulation.

title: SORTING EDISON'S PAPERS EXPECTED TO TAKE 20 YEARS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK WHAT started in 1978 as a fast project to compile, edit and publish the papers of Thomas Alva Edison - born 135 years ago this Thursday - is becoming, according to its director, ''one of the most exhaustive historical investigations ever launched.''

title: GRIEF, A SIEGE AND DEATH AT A HOSPITAL
description: For 34 hours, the father of a child who had died of leukemia held this city captive as the four hostages he took in the hospital where his son had been treated.

title: Ideas and Trends; Objective Tests, Subjective Consequences
description: Are the standardized tests used by schools and by employers to evaluate prospective applicants (a) scientifically valid in measuring ability and predicting performance or, (b) culturally biased against minority groups? Last week, after a four-year study of the tests and their social context in America, a panel formed by the National Academy of Sciences concluded that the answer must be carefully qualified.

title: Basques Free Industrialist
description: A 76-year-old West German industrialist kidnapped for ransom by Basque separatists a month ago was released Friday night in good condition, his family said. Three workers found the man, Josef Lipperheide, near a harbor on the outskirts of Bilbao and took him to police headquarters, where he was met by his family, the authorities said.

title: Laura Bradley, Artist, Betrothed
description: Montgomery Sears Bradley of Washington and Marcia Williams Bradley of Hatfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Bradley of New York, to Massimo Pierucci, also of New York.

title: Miss Belden I s Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Allen Belden of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Cluett Belden, to James Douglas Nail, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Nail of Oak Park, Ill.

title: T.E. Holmes Marries Patricia Lenore Shevlin
description: Patricia Lenore Shevlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Shevlin of Jenkintown, Pa., was married yesterday to Theodore Edward Holmes, son of Theodore D. Holmes of Charlotteville, N.Y., and the late Mildred Holmes.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Sinatra Mystique
description: Weeks of hoopla had preceded the big moment, and now it was at hand: Frank Sinatra's boyhood home in Hoboken, N.J., was up for auction.

title: 45 FOOD OUTLETS FAIL INSPECTION
description: The New York City Department of Health released the names of 45 food establishments last week that were cited for violations of the city's health code.

title: THE CASE FOR KEEPING U.S. AID TO COLLEGES
description: Michael I. Sovern is president of Columbia University. By Michael I. Sovern

title: THE OMINOUSLY SINGLE-MINDED STUDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Military Air Crash Kills 53 in South Korea
description: A military transport plane crashed into South Korea's highest mountain on a military exercise, killing all 53 people aboard, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: Missile Found in Germany
description: American explosives experts found fragments of a missing air-to-air missile in a hayloft today after a farmer reported a hole in the roof of his barn. A United States Air Force F-15 jet fighter based in West Germany lost the live missile during a drill Monday.

title: THE SPACING OUT OF DORIS LESSING
description: THE MAKING OF THE REPRESENTATIVE FOR PLANET 8 Canopus in Argos: Archives. By Doris Lessing. 145 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: Q&A
description: QUESTION: Several years ago I learned that one could purchase a round-the-world airline ticket, good for one year, for a bout $1,200. The only condition was that holders of such t ickets were subject to availability of seats at the time they wanted to use the flight, sortof a standby system. Are such tickets curren tly available, and, if so, how much do they cost? - G.H., Toms River , N.J. ANSWER: Pan Am's round-the-world fare costs $2,200 in economy and $4,400 in first class; it has a minimum use of 14 days and a maximum of 180, and the entire itinerary has to be booked 21 days in advance of your departure. Air India also offers round-the-world fares in conjunction with Northwest Orient and with Continental Airlines. A 22/80-day ticket with Northwest costs $1,799 in economy and $2,900 in first class; a 365-day ticket with Continental costs $2,299 in economy and $3,499 in first class.

title: GREEK FARE IN A CAFE ATMOSPHERE
description: FOR the last year, Cafe Lindos has been a particularly pleasant addition to Smithtown's Main Street restaurant row. The word cafe in the name tells it all. The atmosphere is that of an informal coffeehouse with assorted desserts and pastries, but complete lunches and dinners are also served. The hours are flexible in that almost any item on the menu may be ordered at any time.

title: Export-Import Bank Faces Stiff Cut in '83
description: The Export-Import Bank, which makes loans at below-market interest rates to the foreign purchasers of American products, would suffer a significant cutback in President Reagan's new budget.

title: COPENHAGEN
description: To the Editor:

title: AMTRAK CUTS FACE TOUGH BATTLE IN CONGRESS
description: Presidential budgets normally include spending cuts that the White House knows are unlikely to be adopted by Congress. An example in this year's budget involves Amtrak, the national railroad system.

title: MADRID'S 'FIFTH COLUMN' HARBORS MEMORY AND HOPE
description: Poised for what many thought would be the final assault on Madrid at the outbreak of civil war in 1936, Gen. Emilio Mola was asked which of his four columns would take the capital. Coining a phrase that becam e instantly celebrated, the general replied that it was his hidde n ''fifth column'' of right-wing supporters inside Madrid that w ould deliver the city.

title: RIO'S VENERABLE TEAROOM
description: Dowtown Rio de Janeiro has suffered the sam e fate with tourists that the west side of Manhattan once did with ocean-liner regulars who used to remark that they only passed thro ugh it when they were on their way to Europe. Most travelers to Ri o glimpse the business center only in traveling back and forth betwe en the airport and the resort hotels in the beach neighborhoods of C opacabana, Ipanema and Leblon.

title: HUNTING FOSSILS IN MARYLAND
description: SETH S. KING is a reporter in The Times Washington bureau By SETH S.KING

title: BITTER AND BITTERSWEET
description: THE DEATH OF DESCARTES By David Bosworth. 182 pp. Pa.: Pittsburgh University Press. $9.95. DUBIOUS PERSUASIONS By Jack Matthews. 155 pp. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. $10.95.

title: Montana Senator Divorced
description: Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, and his wife, Ann, a freelance writer, were divorced Friday after nearly seven years of marriage, his office announced.

title: Viktor Glushkov, 58, S oviet Computer Expert
description: Viktor M. Glushkov, a prominent Soviet computer scientist, died Jan. 30 in Kiev after a long illness, according to news reports received in the United States. He was 58 years old.

title: TV View; A SERIOUS SUBJECT FLAWED BY COMPROMISE
description: When television entertainment claims to be getting serious, duck fast. There are notable exceptions, carefully crafted and nurtured productions such as ''Friendly Fire'' or prestigious adaptations of stage productions. But, too often, when the television studios and networks tackle serious subjects like rape or child pornography, the smell of titillation permeates all their protestations about social responsibility. Or, on another level, there is the project that professes to tackle a controversial subject but ends up merely exploiting it. Which brings us to ''Pray TV,'' the made-fortelevision movie shown on ABC last Monday.

title: AN ANGRY BUSINESSMAN'S WAR ON CRIME
description: From his executive suite in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, Vic Barouh can check the sales reports from his $150 million officeequipment empire, call his factories in Ireland and Puerto Rico, watch his Ko-Rec-Type trucks fill on the loading docks and recall the day he started his business in 1955 with $48,000.

title: Wine; THE POSSIBLE DREAM
description: THE POSSIBLE DREAM

title: WHY MUST AIR CRASHES DOOM THEIR VICTIMS?
description: To the Edit or: In spite of the two recent air crashes (Washington, Boston) which illustrated t he fatal fragility of modern commercial aircraft and thelack of prepa redness on the part of flight crews, passengers and ground emerge ncy teams, there has been no hue and cry raised in The Times or any other publication concerning the question of air crash survivability .

title: MARINO, COHALAN EYE STRATEGIES FOR STATE RACES
description: TWO Long Island Republicans with statewide ambitions -State Senator Ralph J. Marino of Muttontown and Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan -are following different routes to possible positions on the state ticket this year.

title: The World; Schmidt Puts It All on the Line For Jobs Program
description: Like a diva repeatedly announcing her retirement to boost the box office, Helmut Schmidt keeps threatening to give up the West German Chancellorship. Last week, he pulled together his unraveling coalition of Social Democrats and Free Democrats and successfully resorted to a vote of confidence on a $5.3 billion job creation program.

title: LEGISLATORS FAIL IN REMAPPING BID
description: In the ornate blue and gold Senate chamber of the Pennsylvania General Assembly, the motto inscribed on a wall behind Lieut. Gov. William W. Scranton 3d, who was presiding, was heavy in both lettering and import.

title: Asher ben Mazliach Is Dead; Israeli Samaritan High Priest
description: The high priest of Israel's Samaritans, Asher ben Mazliach, died in Nablus today. He was 87 years old. The Samaritans claim descent from colonists brought to Samaria by the King of Assyria to replace Hebrews exiled after the defeat of the kingdom of Israel in 722 B.C. and from remnants of the tribes of Ephraim, Menasseh and Levi who remained in the country.

title: TEXT OF THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET MESSAGE TO CONGRESS
description: Washington, Feb. 6-Following is the text of President Reagan's Budget Message to Congress, which was made public today by the White House

title: U.S. TO RAISE TECHNOLOGICAL LEVEL OF PRODUCTS THE CHINESE CAN BUY
description: A ranking United States trade official said today that the Reagan Administration hoped to raise the level of American technology that China was permitted to buy.

title: YANKS SEND PLAYERS 2D LETTER
description: The Yankees, faced with a delay in the opening of their spring training camp, have sent a second letter to their players emphasizing that the invitation they received about six weeks ago to report to camp early was just a request.

title:
FOOD;
PUTTING ONE'S HEART INTO CHOCOLATES
description: OCEANSIDE IN the morning when the sun beams through the front window of Chocolate Reflections, the red curtains are drawn to insure that the meltables inside remain intact. But a large sign saying ''Open'' encourages customers to enter this minuscule shop.

title: MUNICH
description: Volker Schlondorff's ''Circle of Deceit,'' opening in New York Thursday at the Paris Theater, is a film set in the Lebanese civil war that turned out considerably less political than planned. It is a case of art as ideological instruction for the artist: The director went to Beirut, shot his movie in the ruins of the city, and eventually stepped clear of some of his original political preconception. From screenplay to cutting room, the film's message changed. Reality, or a bit of it, had gotten in the way.

title: Business Conditions; U.S. LABOR COSTS EASE
description: The United States recorded the lowest rate of increase in manufacturing unit labor costs among industrialized nations during the 1970's, a recent study by a Citibank economist shows.

title: MAKING IT IN WASHINGTON
description: RUNNING AND FIGHTING Working in Washington. By Brett Duval Fromson. 204 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: The Nation; New Frontier Left Its Own Oral History
description: It had already been disclosed that, like several other occupants of the Oval Office, President Kennedy dabbled with tape recorders. Last week, though, after the John F. Kennedy Library released a 29-page log of telephone conversations and meetings recorded during his Administration, it appeared that Mr. Kennedy had concluded that even some of the New Frontier's more mundane utterances were worth preserving.

title: THE SOVIET MAGAZINE THAT SAID NYET
description: AN END TO SILENCE Uncensored Opinion in the Soviet Union. From Roy Medvedev's Underground Magazine ''Political Diary.'' Edited and With Introductions by Stephen F. Cohen. Translated by George Saunders. 375 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $19.95.

title: JERSEY CITY'S 'Y' BEING TRANSFORMED
description: JERSEY CITY LIKE many of its counterparts throughout the country, the Jersey City Young Women's Christian Association was suffering severe financial problems, and its board of directors considered closing the 11-story building on Fairmount Avenue.

title: Yachting Struggles With Issue of Pros
description: Professional ocean sailboat racing will make its United States debut this spring in a trans-Atlantic race featuring close to $100,000 in prize money.

title: FLORIDA STATE INQUIRY HEARS FROM PLAYERS
description: James Bozeman's resignation from the Florida State basketball team may have come because he was afraid he would lose his starting position, his teammates said today in testimony before a panel investigating why Bozeman left the squad.

title:
Camera;
SHOOTING IN BAD WEATHER
THE SUPPLY SIDE'S LAST STAND
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN is to deliver his budget for fiscal year 1983 to Congress tomorrow, and, as indicated by Administration figures disclosed late last week, he is not backing down from his supplyside commitments. But for months now the economy has been ganging up on him, and he faces a diverse and growing group of opponents on Capitol Hill and in the hinterlands:

title: PATRICK WHITE EXPLAINS HIMSELF
description: FLAWS IN THE GLASS A Self-Portrait. By Patrick White. Illustrated. 260 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: 11 Die in Peruvian Bus Crash
description: Eleven people were killed and 17 were seriously injured when a bus ran off the road and plunged 300 feet down a hillside near the village of Pasamayo, 35 miles north of Lima, the police said today.

title: Follow-U
description: Though the Allies agreed at the end of World War II to destroy all articles that might revitalize the Nazi movement, a big collection of paintings and other art done in Nazi propaganda units ended up in the United States. The art was seized by American troops; the Army kept it as ''historical documentation.''

title: The Nation; A Dim Spotlight On Libyan Affair
description: How do you prevent former Central Intelligence Agency employees from peddling their expertise to foreign governments? With difficulty, if at all, it appeared from testimony last week before the House Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: Gunmen on Motorcycles Kill Ex-Iran Aide and His Brother
description: Two gunmen on motorcycles killed a former deputy minister and his brother in Teheran Friday night, Iran's official press agency reported today.

title: THE BODIES IN A BARRIO: PROVOCATION OR ATROCITY?
description: During the early morning hours last Sunday, Salvadoran Army soldiers patrolled through the rutted, dirt streets of San Antonio Abad, a barrio of mud huts and shacks on the western edge of San Salvador, where pigs and children play in garbage at the foot of a green forested volcano.

title: CUTS IN FUNDS CAUSING DECLINE IN LEGAL AID IN CIVIL CASES
description: TWO separate events have led to a cutback in delivering legal assistance to those individuals involved in civil litigation on Long Island who are unable to afford a lawyer.

title: Politics
description: THERE is a noticeable difference at this point between the Republican and Democratic campaigns for United States Senator from New Jersey. The Republican race has already begun, while the Democrats seem to be standing around wa iting for something to happen.

title: ROLAND BARTHES MEETS THE SEX PISTOLS
description: SOUND EFFECTS Youth, Leisure, and the Politics of Rock 'n' Roll. By Simon Frith. 294 pp. New York: Pantheon Books.Cloth, $18.50. Paper, $8.95.

title: Gallery View; SPOTLIGHT ON 17TH-CENTURY DUTCH PAINTERS; BOSTON
description: As of this moment, and for those above all who love Dutch 17thcentury painting, the greater Boston area has to offer a most remarkable double event. At the Fogg Art Museum in Cambridge there is the first-ever retrospective of the work of Jacob van Ruisdael. As Ruisdael died exactly 300 years ago and is universally agreed to be one of the great Dutch painters of all time, this exhibition cannot be called premature.

title: Nets Top Pistons, 125-120
description: Ray Williams isn't going to get the Nets in the playoffs all by himself, but it appears he's trying. Williams hit a personal season high of 36 tonight and led the Nets to a 125-120 victory over the Detroit Pistons before a crowd of 12,080 in the Silverdome. Last Wednesday night Williams had 34 in a victory over Atlanta, and Friday night he had 20 in a loss to Philadelphia.

title: WHAT'S WRONG IN SOUTH AFRICA IS A MATTER OF COLOR
description: THE African National Congress of South Africa was created, 70 years ago last month, to defend Africans against repressive white laws. As the repression grew after the National Party took power in 1948, the A.N.C. moved from gentle protest to rocket attacks on police stations.

title: The Young Farmers
description: One might infer from reading David Kline's article ''The Embattled Independent Farmer'' (Nov. 29) that young people are not going into farming.

title: SOCIAL PROGRAMS FACING SUBSTANTIAL REDUCTIONS
description: In his budget for the coming year, President Reagan proposes substantial cuts in such Government benefit programs as welfare, food stamps, Medicaid, Medicare and subsidized housing.

title: AMZIE MOORE, 1960'S LEADER FOR VOTING REGISTRATION, DIES
description: Amzie Moore, a key figure in the civil rights movement and the voter registration drive in Mississippi in the 1960's, died Monday in Bolivar County (Miss.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Cleveland, Miss.

title: DAVE SCHULTZ: A LETTER TO MY SON ABOUT VIOLENCE
description: Dear Chad:

title:
About Westchester;
Mamaroneck IT was in some ways reminiscent of the school play: there were the anxious participants, the last-minute fluttering over home-made costumes, the family members wielding flash cameras.  Here, though, the relatives in the audience were children, not parents, and the stage clothes had actually been worn by the performers years before, and in the background hovered nurses in starched white uniforms.
description: This was a 1920's musical review, staged recently at the Sarah R. Newman Nursing Home here. The private facility, which serves 270, has a skilled nursing unit and, for those who are ambulatory and require minimal medical attention, a health-related section known as the Pavilion. The 15 cast members had been drawn from the Pavilion and were performing in its activities room for their fellow residents. Earlier in the week, they had put on the show for the skilled nursing unit.

title: Antiques View; A BAROMETER FOR STERLING SILVER
description: For the second time in less than three years, the work of Paul Storr, the early 19th-century British silversmith, is in the limelight. And once again, the action is at an auction at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street. There, on Thursday, in a sale of English and Continental silver, 58 offerings by Storr will be gaveled in the largest assemblage of such glittering wares to appear at public sale since the auction house dispersed 57 examples in the collection of Janiece Christner, a Dallas collector, in June 1979.

title: No Headline
description: Gophers Upset by Hoosiers

title: U.S. MAY HELP GULF NATIONS BUILD ARMS INDUSTRY
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that United States assistance to Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf nations in building an arms industry was ''a very real possibility.''

title: IN DEFENSE OF REAGAN'S NEW FEDERALISM
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S State of the Union message outlined a framework by which a proper Constitutional balance of power will be restored between the Federal Government and state and local governments.

title: MARCH IS BEGUN IN ALABAMA TO BACK VOTING RIGHTS LAW
description: A small band of Southern civil rights workers, followed by nearly 300 sympathizers, today began a 140-mile march in support of the Federal Voting Rights Act and in protest against the vote fraud conviction here of two black political activists.

title: Economic Affairs; HERE IS WHY YOU LOST YOUR JOB$
description: D EAR JOE: I was sorry to hear that you had lost your job. If it is any comfort, you may think of yourself as a foot soldier, wounded in our country's battle against inflation.

description: NONFICTION BAD DREAMS. By Anthony Haden-Guest. 15 CHARLES DARWIN: A Man of Enlarged Curiosity. By Peter Brent. 28 AN END TO SILENCE: Uncensored Opinion in the Soviet Union. Edited by Stephen F. Cohen. 11 FLAWS IN THE GLASS: A Self-Portrait. By Patrick White. 9 KIPLING AND CONRAD: The Colonial Fiction. By John A. McClure. 16 LOST HERO: The Mystery of Raoul Wallenberg. By Frederick E. Werbell and Thurston Clarke. 16 RUNNING AND FIGHTING: Working in Washington. By Brett Duval Fromson. 14 SICILIAN LIVES. By Danilo Dolci. 11 SOUND EFFECTS: Youth, Leisure, and the Politics of Rock 'n' Roll. By Simon Frith. 14 THE TRUANTS: Adventures Among the Intellectuals. By William Barrett. 1 THE ULTIMATE FISHING BOOK. Edited by Lee Eisenberg and DeCourcy Taylor. 15 U.S. v. CRIME IN THE STREETS. By Thomas E. Cronin, Tania Z. Cronin and Michael E. Milakovich. 18

title: A GUIDE TO CRETAN PLACES AND PLEASURES
description: Crete is 160 miles long and 36 miles wide, dominated by four mountain ranges. The Ida Massif, rising to a height of 8,060 feet, is at its center. Because of the island's strategic location, almost equidistant from Europe, Asia Minor and Africa, Crete has been the focus of contention throughout history. Dorian, Roman, Byzantine, Arab, Venetian and Turkish conquerors have all left their marks on the island - without, however, subduing the proud and pleasure-loving Cretans.

title: THE COLORS OF SPRING
description: PETER LEVI is a poet and classical scholar at Oxford; he is the translator of Pausanias' ''Guide to Greece'' and author of the ''Atlas of the Greek World'' and, most recently, ''The Hill of Kronos.'' By PETER LEVI

title: Topics; Bankruptcies, Fiscal and Moral
description: Laker's Landing

title: Music; LIBRARIES OFFERING NO-COST CONCERTS
description: APARTICULARLY fertile source of free cultural activity in the county is the public libraries, which, in addition to lectures, films and a variety of other happenings, offer musical programs.

title: AT (FRANCO-)AMERICAN MOTORS, PARIS TAKES THE WHEEL
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich. J OSE J. DEDEURWAERDER, who was named president of American Motors last month, is trying to overcome two obstacles as he fashions a strategy to help his company out of an industrywide slump. The first, which the Belgian-born auto executive freely ac knowledges, is his lack of experience in marketing American cars. It 's a problem, he believes, but one his American colleagues can helphi m solve.

title: RELICS OF GREAT PALACES
description: ROBERT PEAR is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times. By ROBERT PEAR

title: RIYADH'S MARKETS REFLECT ITS PAST AND FUTURE
description: To visit this city's souk is at once to wander into A rabia's exotic past, glimpse its future and to sense theoften confusi ng present linking the two.

title: 'WHEN ONE'S CHILD IS HANDICAPPED': READERS RESPOND
description: I READ, with great interest and empathy, Barbara Gerbasi's article, ''When One's Child Is Handicapped'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 17). I share her feelings, yet I wish she had gone a step further.

title: R.R. Porter Weds Miss Santangelo
description: Georgia Ann Santangelo and R. Roderick Porter, who are with the Chemical Bank in New York, were married yesterday at the Westchester County Club in Rye, N.Y. The Presbyterian ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. A.L. Sunderwirth.

title: PARENT NETWORKS CATCHING ON
description: IN the war against teen-age abuse of alcohol and marijuana, one more weapon has been added to the arsenal. It's called parent networking, the objective of which is to bring to sprawling, diverse economic and ethnic suburban neighborhoods a sense of mutual community values.

title: The World
description: United States and Soviet negotiators, observing the rule that diplomacy, to be serious, should be discreet, have dutifully kept mum about their talks in Geneva on limiting intermediate nuclear weapons in Europe. But Leonid I. Brezhnev last week showed Moscow's hand and President Reagan promptly produced an American counter ploy.

title: THE TET OFFENSIVE WAS NO SURPRISE TO JOHNSON
description: To the Editor:

title: ENERGY COSTS CALLED PERIL TO CITY'S ECONOMY
description: The high cost of energy is hurting New York City's economy, according to many who gathered at the New York Hilton Hotel for a Conference on Urban Energy Strategies.

title: NOTEBOOK: MARIN CASE, FROM HYPNOSIS TO UNDERCOVER WORK
description: ''THERE are many ways of inducing hypnosis, and it doesn't take very long,'' Sheldon Malev, an associate professor of psychology at Westchester Community College, said last week. His voice came from a tape recorder atop the prosecutor's desk at a preliminary hearing in the arson and murder trial of Luis Marin, accused of setting fire to the Stouffer's Inn in December 1980.

title: PRIMITIVE MAN IS THE STAR
description: Afire burns brightly at the mouth of a cave. A cheerful campfire, it seems as the camera closes in, one of those warming evocations of species nostalgia played out so often by Boy Scouts. Around this fire, however, sit or squat creatures wrapped in animal skins who look like our distant ancestors. Predators howl and snarl in the surrounding darkness.

title: 'Village' Zoning Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: MITTERRAND'S MODEST REVOLUTION
description: Richard Eder is The Times's bureau chief in Paris. By Richard Eder Tocqueville described the intellectual atmosphere of the years before the French Revolution as a feverish mixture of fears and fads; a restless search for new formulations - as if all the world's troubles for the previous millenniums were a matter of mislabeling - and a disposition to take rationalism in such disordered doses that it slipped into mysticism and the supernatural.

title: Copenhagen
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Finance; THE DANGERS IN AN OVERDRAFT ACCOUNT
description: C HASE MANHATTAN calls it Cash Reserve. At Chemical, it's Privilege Checking. Manufacturers Hanover Trust has Preferred Personal Checking, while Citibank has both Ready Credit and Checking Plus.

title: Westchester Housing; NEW LEGISLATION SOUGHT ON CO-OPS
description: "A TENANT shouldn't have a baseball bat at his head," State Senator John E. Flynn said. "But if an owner wants to sell his building, you have to respect that feeling."

title: A NEW LOOK AT DINOSAURS
description: John Noble Wilford, who reports on science for The New York Times, is the author of the recently published ''The Mapmakers'' and is currently writing a book on dinosaurs. By John Noble Wilford

title: Vicki Singleton's 73 For 210 Leads by 1
description: Vicki Singleton struggled on the back nine today but recovered to retain a one-stroke lead over four other golfers after three rounds of the $125,000 Elizabeth Arden Classic.

title: MILWAUKEE POLICE TARGET OF SIT-IN
description: The people sat and waited in the District Attorney's office, although they said they were tired of waiting for justice to be done.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY THAT EVOKES SCULPTURE
description: EAST ISLIP SCULPTURE is by nature a three-dimensional art form. Photography, in contrast, is implicitly two-dimensional, and its primary relation to sculpture is as a recording device. True, there are sculptors who incorporate photographic elements in their carvings or constructions. But for most , the camera is a tool chiefly em ployed for documentationand publicity purposes.

title: Parade on St. Patrick's Day To Honor an Irish Protester
description: Robert Sands, the first of the 10 Irish hunger strikers who died in the Maze prison in Belfast last year, has been named honorary grand marshal of this year's St. Patrick's Day parade in New York City, the chairman of the parade committee said yesterday.

title: A Democrat's Response To Purcell's Comment
description: John McQuiston's interview with County Executive Francis Purcell (''As Second Term Begins, Purcell Offers His Views,'' Jan. 17) was interesting and even edifying in part. However, I must take personal exception to one segment of his reflections.

title: LEONTYNE PRICE- STILL THE DIVA
description: Prickly at reminders of her longevity as a singer, and at questions of retirement from the opera stage, Leontyne Price, who will be 55 this week, speaks in explosions of half-sentences delivered in a curiously flutey voice. Like the velvety notes the celebrated soprano floats above the orchestra, her phrases hang suspended in mid-air, punctuated by throaty, uproarious laughter and the animated gesticulation of extravagantly bejeweled hands.

title: Jamaica
description: To the Editor:

title: 'TONY BROWN'S JOURNAL' ENDURES
description: Dapper, bespectacled and 48 years old, Tony Brown is the only black producer of a nationally televised serious black program, ''Tony Brown's Journal.'' His 12 years in television have shorn him of the notion that television wanted creativity and that all black people wanted freedom.

title: NUTRITION AND THE NURSING MOTHER
description: It might be easier or more fashionable to blame Ross Laboratories for the decline in breast-feeding, but I believe that the fault lies with physicians.

title: Sound; SPEAKERS ADOPT AN ENGLISH ACCENT
description: Maybe our imagination is runnning away with us, but sometimes it seems that a loudspeaker's nationality shows in its voice. We have known American speakers that sounded forthright and foursquare - some of them even a bit forward and brash. And now several English speakers are sounding off on these shores which - for all their individual differences - share certain Britannic traits. They all seem to be making music with an Oxford accent: quite reserved, polite and smooth, yet with a kind of sturdy self-assertion.

title: PHYSICAL CHANGES
description: NIGHT THOUGHTS OF A CLASSICAL PHYSICIST By Russell McCormmach. Illustrated. 217 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $15.

title: John (Taps) Gallagher, 76; Coached Niagara Basketball
description: John (Ta ps) Gallagher, who coached basketball at Niagara University for 30 years, died here today after a long illness.

title: KENYAN SAYS ASIAN MERCHANTS RUIN ECONOMY
description: President Daniel arap Moi said today that Kenya's large Asian community was ''ruining the country's economy'' and that Asians found guilty of hoarding or smuggling currency would be deported.

title: ADAPTING TO THE RISE IN SUBURBAN CRIME
description: A YOUNG mother in Fairfield now regularly leaves the baby sitter with instructions on how to use the one-digit code in the family's phone that alerts the police in case of an attempted break-in.

title: Recordings; SAINT-SAENS' ORGAN MUSIC: A CASE OF UNJUST NEGLECT
description: What do most people know about Camille Saint-Saens? Next to nothing, probably, apart from the fact that he composed ''The Carnival of Animals,'' ''Danse macabre,'' ''Samson et Dalila,'' the ''Organ'' Symphony No. 3 and a bunch of flashy piano concertos.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: LOST HERO The M ystery o f Raoul Wallenb erg. By Frederick E. Werbell and Thurston Clarke. Illustrated. 284 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill. $12.95.

title: ''Uncommon'' Point
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TWO years ago, the State Transportation Department issued a report that described 80 bridges on Long Island as ''structurally deficient'' and in danger of becoming safety hazards. But now things are looking up for these bridges. The department has allocated $27 million from the last Federal Highways Act specifically for bridge repairs over the next five years.

title: Punishing Poland Proves Difficult
description: Just as President Reagan was imploring Wars aw's martial law rulers last weekend to ''Let Poland Be Poland,'' an Administration hardliner leaked a decision he regarded as le tting Poland off the hook. Washington had agreed to pay American b anks $71.3 million in Government-guaranteed Polish debt due in Janu ary without declaring Poland in default.

title: ROWDINESS CURTAILS PARADE
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH STUART TOBIN did not like the look of things outside the window of his pharmacy on Main Street after the St. Patrick's Day parade in this resort village last year. ''It had to be that about 80 percent of the people walking around had an open bottle or a filled glass in their hands,'' Mr. Tobin said. ''We have a law against drinking in the streets.''

title: THE TRADE ISN'T A BARGAIN
description: Simple arithmetic suggests that the New Federalism, proposed by President Reagan in his State of the Union Message, would require state governments to raise taxes an average of 8.81 percent in fiscal 1984.

title: FARES A PUZZLE FOR NJ TRANSIT
description: NEWARK THE puzzle that New Jersey's mass-transit experts rack their brains trying to solve is not a Rubic's cube but, rather, how to raise fares without losing riders.

title: CONTROL OF SAN FRANCISCO FERRY STIRS A STORM
description: The California Public Utilities Commission has become a party to a quarrel between powerful interests that are contesting control of a valuable ferry route between Fishermen's Wharf and this community across the bay.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe, Lendl Gain Final

title: BAG FOUND IN BOSTON IS NO HELP IN SEARCH FOR JERSEY STUDENT
description: The recovery of a suitcase belonging to a missing Harvard graduate student has provided no fresh clues to her whereabouts, Massachusetts police officials said yesterday.

title: COMPLAINTS RISE OVER WATER-BILL METHODS
description: THE Public Service Commission is investigating about 35 "high bill" complaints filed last year by New Rochelle Water Company customers in Dobbs Ferry, Hastings and Ardsley.

title: TEACHERS RECEIVING 1.4-MILLION BACK PAY
description: CHECKS for up to $81,000 each in back salaries and interest were handed to a group of present and former Yonkers school teachers last week as a 1975 job-security dispute neared resolution.

title:
Other Business;
BUTTONS UP
description: For years, the American button has been on the defensive. Hi-tech closures such as nylon zippers, snaps, and velcro fasteners closed out many a button maker. Straight button imports also hurt, as did imports of buttonequipped clothes, which now account for half the apparel sales in the United States. Many a button maker turned into a jobber, or distributor, of imported buttons.

title: FIVE SPECIAL WASHINGTON HOTELS
description: Considering the diversity of visitors that Washington attracts, it is not surprising that the city has an equally diversified assortment of hotels, appealing to widely different tastes. One perhaps knows what to expect in branches of large chain hotels, and so the real interest lies in finding out about smaller establishments that are independently owned or belong to lesser-known chains.

title: Art; POOLING OF RESOURCES PRODUCES STIMULATING SUCCESS
description: WITH landscapes at the Museum Gallery of the White Plains Public Library and figure paintings at the College of New Rochelle's Castle Gallery, ''Contemporary Realism'' is now in full cry. This tripleheader, which includes a display of still lifes in The Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson that was recently reviewed by John Caldwell, is a triumph of collaboration between local nonprofit institutions and commercial dealers in Manhattan. It is also a welcome gust of professionalism on the Westchester scene, where normally art of this caliber is viewable only in museums.

title: Missouri Suffers 1st Loss
description: Nebraska upset Missouri, the nation's top-ranked team, 67-51, in a Big Eight Conference game tonight. It was the first loss of the season in 20 games for Missouri, which had been the only major college team with an unbeaten record.

title: Candace Marie Dunlop Is Married To Patrick J. McMahon in New York
description: Candace Marie Dunlop, a marketing manager with the William Underwood Company in Westwood, Mass., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Patrick James McMahon. He is manager of business development with the organic-chemicals division of the W.R. Grace & Company in Lexington, Mass.

title: Ideas and Trends; A Mammal Ahead Of Its Time
description: Some 160 million years ago, there lived a species of small, meateating mammals called multituberculates, no larger than woodchucks, with bladed, bumpy-surfaced teeth. Then, a scant 110 million years ago, the same mammal appeared, but eating leaves with leaf-grinding teeth.

title: Therese Ann Boyle to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Boyle of Garden City, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Therese Ann Boyle, to Kevin Timothy Coughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Coughlin of Franklin Lakes, N.J. A May 15 wedding is planned. Miss Boyle is a sales representative with the Eastman Kodak Company in New York. Her fiance, a lawyer, is with the Newark firm of Mattson, Madden & Polito.

title: Sept. 11 Wedding For Adele Troy
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Troy 2d of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Adele Folger Troy, to Christopher Wiggins Smiles, son of Barbara Coon Smiles of Durham, N.H., and the late Peter F. Smiles.

title: THE QUIET, POKERLESS TWILIGHT OF 'THE LARGO EIGHT'
description: In the pool hall at Ranchero Village, a tranquil trailer park for retired people, an empty container of playing cards on a dusty table is what remains of a once-thriving nickel-and-dime poker game.

title: Protecting Atlantic Salmon
description: REPRESENTATIVES of nations engaged in the production or harvesting, or both, of Atlantic salmon have agreed to a treaty aimed at conservation of the species.

title: MASTERS OF UNPLEASANTNESS
description: WHEN the third and final volume of Lawrance Thompson's biography of Robert Frost was reviewed in 1977 in the New York Times Book Review (a volume completed by his friend and student R.H. Winnick after Thompson died), I was amused by but not disrespectful of the reviewer's frank horror at the revelations of some of the less attractive aspects of Frost's character. So shocked was this critic that he declared that, if he had known earlier what sort of a man Frost actually was, he would have left any room the poet entered. I found this worth a smile because the chief faults of Frost that so offended the critic - vanity, paranoia, selfishness - seemed to me to be the characteristic afflictions, amounting almost to professional deformations, of most poets. I recognized them instantly in myself and, after a moment's thought, in most other poets I knew. On the whole, we are a rather unpleasant lot, and have to try to be nice by strenuous exertion and muscular effort, and can only envy those who are effortlessly kind and considerate.

title: THE COLD TRUTH ABOUT WINDOWS BECOMES CLEAR
description: IT is a truth universally acknowledged that people in possession of glass houses cannot afford to be warm. My apologies to Jane Austen for this liberal paraphrase, but this truth has made an increasing and cold impression on us throughout our years in the country.

title: MAKING A CASE FOR 'RAGTIME'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rowdies Rout Cosmos, 10-3
description: The Tampa Bay Rowdies eliminated the Cosmos from playoff contention in the North American Soccer League's indoor season with a 10-3 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: Around the Garden
description: THIS WEEK: Cut branches of forsythia, quince, pussy willow, apple and peach to force indoors for a hint of spring . . . Check needled evergreens planted near the house for damage from ice and/or heavy snow; prune broken limbs . . . Start seeds of geraniums, coleus and vinca indoors. Soon, Soon Gardeners have cabin fever, a common seasonal malady. But this winter of many discontents, it has struck in epidemic proportions. Snow and ice recede to fog, rain, wet and mud, but for only a time. There is anxiety they will return to clutch the landscape again in winter, never to release it for spring. Trapped indoors, gardeners may turn into restless, often short-tempered species.

title: BUILDING A BUSINESS WITH FREE SAMPLES
description: IN the summer of 1978, after graduating from the State University in Oneonta with a Bachelor of Arts degree, Peter P. Costa went to work as a construction laborer.

title: News Analysis
description: Exactly a year ago today President Reagan said in a television address that the nation's trillion-dollar debt was of a magnitude ''literally beyond our comprehension.'' Yet the budget he released today would lead to more than $270 billion in new debt in the next three years a lone, and more than $500billion if he fails to get his spending cuts or tax revisions throughCongress. The fact th at Mr. Reagan could contemplate a possible 50 percent increase in t he national debt in a mere three years shows how far much his econ omic thinking has been transformed by events of the last12 months.

title: Elizabeth D'Ursi Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Dante D'Ursi of Needham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Rooney D'Ursi, to Joseph George Wermter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Wermter of Seminole, Fla. The wedding is planned for May 22.

title: STAGING A KANDINSKY DREAM
description: For an essay on the relationship between sound and color, see Donal Henahan's column on page 21. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Janet Tassel is a freelance writers who deals frequently with the arts. By JANET TASSEL

title: Peking Rejects Call by Hanoi For Talks on Border Dispute
description: China has rejected a call by Hanoi for a resumption of negotiations on the China-Vietnam border dispute, a Government spokesman said today.

title: HAIG CALLS TAIWAN A 'DIFFICULT ISSUE' IN TIES WITH CHINA
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has said that ''extremely sensitive discussions'' are under way with Peking over the Taiwan issue and that he is ''not in a position to predict the outcome.''

title: BALD EAGLE POISON
description: To the Editor:

title:
Business Forum;
THE UNSTEADY HAND AT THE FED
description: T HE American economy is deep in recession and, in theory at least, a self-correcting process should be at work. The cost of money ought to be falling and cheaper money, in time, ought to pull us out of recession.

title: COLLEGE TRYING TO BRIDGE A CULINARY GAP
description: MAYS LANDING THE casino boom of the last three years has brought not only gambling halls to Atlantic City, but many new restaurants, as well, ranging from coffee shops to gourmet rooms, with more expected.

title: AFFISHIONADOS
description: ''Fish story'' may mean exaggerated nonsense to most Americans, but THE ULTIMATE FISHING BOOK (Houghton Mifflin/Hilltown, $40) proves conclusively that not all anglers' tales are malarkey. Editors Lee Eisenberg and DeCourcy Taylor have collected original essays from nine avid fishermen - who just happen to be writers.

title: Stage View; AN ECCENTRIC 'MACBETH,' AND EMPTY 'HEART'
description: Nicol Williamson brings some helpful minor insights to the ''Macbeth'' he is now performing at Circle in the Square. As he comes from the witches for a first meeting with his Lady, for instance, his line-readings immediately suggest that he and his spouse have already spent an evening or two around the castle discussing the possibility of Duncan's sudden demise. The notion isn't really new to either of them and this hint at an earlier conspiracy speeds the evening's opening stages along nicely, bypassing as it does that whole thorny argument about which of the co-conspirators is truly the more ambitious. They, in the language of a later day, are in this thing together.

title: Investing; IN STOCKS, ALL THE SAINT ARE SINNERS
description: Picking an issue on ethical grounds may be an appealing thought, but it is not as easy as it seems.

title: CANADIAN PARLEY ON ECONOMY FAILS
description: Three months after a hard-won agreement on constitutional change, Canada's federation has once again come under severe stress after the breakdown Thursday night of a conference on the economy.

title: Ideas and Trends; Censure for Things Unsaid
description: When it comes to recommending colleagues for medical positions, a Harvard Medical School committee now advises faculty members to adopt a ''golden rule'': Write unto others what you would have them write unto you, including information on your colleague's character. The Massachusetts Medical Society agrees and in a separate action last week, it censured three Harvard-affiliated physicians for not following that rule.

title: In the Land of Khmer Rouge
description: As a relief worker on the ground in Cambodia and now as projects officer of Oxfam America, a Boston-based nonprofit relief and development agency, I have been involved since August 1980 with the international effort to aid the six million people inside Cambodia (''In the Land of Khmer Rouge,'' by Christopher Jones, Dec. 20). During this time, I have traveled the length and breadth of the country, most recently visiting the magnificent Angkor temple complex at precisely the time Ieng Sary alleged, according to Mr. Jones, that these temples were under Khmer Rouge control.

title: T. S. Dermody Fiance Of Margot E. Bramble
description: James H. Bramble and Mary Boze Bramble of Ithaca, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margot Elizabeth Bramble, to Terence Shawn Dermody, son of Mr. and Mr s. Donal A. Dermody, also of Ithaca.

title: BUDGET BRINGS ATTACKS IN CONGRESS FROM REPUBLICANS AND DEMOCRATS ALIKE
description: Congressional Democrats today assailed President Reagan's proposed budget as ''unfair'' and ''unworkable,'' while Republicans expressed shock at the size of the deficit and predicted that the President would have trouble selling the budget to members of either party in an election year.

title: Susan Chalsty to Be Bride of John Neely on Aug. 7
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Chalsty of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Chalsty, to John Hamlin Neely, son of Mrs. John Howard Neely 3d of Summit, N.J., and the late Mr. Neely. The wedding is planned for Aug. 7 in Short Hills.

title:
Design;
THE WALLS HAVE AN ANGLE
description: The problem, and the challenge, was to find affordable living and working space for a professional couple and t heir two quite differentcareers in rent-expensive Manhattan.

title: Mark Evans, Miss Mensch Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Mensch of New York and North Salem, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Sena Mensch, to Mark Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gawayne Evans of Gosport, England.

title: COE TO LECTURE
description: Sebastian Coe, 1980 Olympic 1,500-meter champion and 1979 Track and Field News ''Athlete of the Year,'' has been named the Kiphuth Fellow for 82 at Yale University and he will be in residence there Wednesday through Saturday.

title: THE M AKING OF A COLLEGE CONFERENCE
description: O N a summer day several years ago, at a restaurant in Milan, Italy, Dave Gavitt, the athletic director and former basketball coach at Providence College, sat with Lou Carnesecca, the coach at St. John's University, killing time before a flight home at the end of a series of clinics. Their flight had been delayed for eight hours, so rather than wait at the airport, they found a place to eat and talk.

title: The Master's Voice
description: But that was different. Partisans of John Kennedy and Franklin Roosevelt rush to the rescue following the news that both Presidents, no less than Richard Nixon, secretly taped conversations in the White House.

title: B. W. Madding to Wed Miss Quintrell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Quintrell of Gates Mills, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Stearns Quintrell, to Bruce Wallace Madding, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon F. Madding of Hillsborough, Calif.

title: The World; Mubarak's Two Calling Cards
description: After the death of Anwar el-Sadat, Hosni Mubarak got so tired of being asked to reconfirm Egypt's commitment to the Camp David accords that he said he might start carrying a sign. But the question keeps coming up anyway, as the days dwindle before April 25, when Israel is to return the rest of Sinai to Egypt. Of late, Mr. Mubarak's answers seem aimed at smoothing Egypt's way back into the Arab fold as much as at reassuring Israel and the United States.

title: ON BEING A WAITRESS AND NOT ASHAMED
description: I just finished reading Vivian Kellerman's article about waitressing. Hoorah, hooray and three cheers for her. It's time somebody spoke out for our profession.

title: CHANGES IN TWO TYPES OF PENSIONS PROPOSED
description: President Reagan today proposed trimming the cost-of-living adjustments that have swelled the pensions of 2.3 million former Federal employes, sometimes so generously that they make more in retirement than their successors earn on the job.

title: Midwest States to Hear Reagan on Federalism
description: President Reagan will address state legislatures in Iowa and Indiana and a Republican fund-raising event in Bloomington, Minn., next week about the his plan to decentralize the Federal government.

title: No Headline
description: UConn Wins Its 16th by 67-59

title:
Gardening;
FRIENDLY AND HELPFUL SYMBIOTIC PLANTS
description: MOST people would agree that a good marriage is one in which both partners contribute as well as benefit from the relationship. It seems that the plant world is filled with such unselfish relati onships. We are just now learning of th e importance of fostering similar relationships among the pla nts that we grow in our gardens, forests and fields.

title: SAM HUFF'S WORLD: ANOTHER LOOK BACK
description: SO Sam Huff has finally made it to the Pro Football Hall of Fame. And, based on what we have been reading and seeing on television since his election, ''The Violent World of Sam Huff'' will be born again.

title: Crafts
description: stretching shows with its current presentation of glass and neon sculpture.

title: Around the Nation; Amtrak Train Hits Car, Killing 5 on West Coast
description: An Amtrak train smashed into a car that had driven around a closed crossing gate and onto the tracks tonight, killing five persons, Los Angeles County sheriff's officials said.

title: Future Events Dining and Dancing
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Such Good Friends Feb. 10 - There's nothing static about the annual benefit sponsored by the Friends of the Henry Street Settlement. The group of working men and women in their 20's and early 30's like to move around. Having, in previous years, tried out such spots as the Tavern on the Green and the Rainbow Room, they've settled on the Sotheby Parke Bernet galleries, York Avenue at 72d Street, for the 1982 edition from 8 P.M. to midnight. There'll be cocktails, dinner and dancing to the music of the Fat Ammons Band, to say nothing of a raffle and a silent auction. Proceeds to the settlement's Louis Abrons Arts for Living Center, which provides a showcase for young playwrights and performers. Tickets, $75.

title: The Region; Take-Home Addiction
description: Besides questioning the long-term efficacy of treating addiction by creating addiction, critics of methadone maintenance programs have cautioned that, without strict monitoring and control, the programs might become part of the problem they were designed to solve.

title: Headliners; A Flap Over a Flip
description: Justice may be blind, but it shouldn't depend on blind luck, say critics of Manhattan Criminal Court Judge Alan J. Friess.

title: CHANGING OF A CLUB TO CAMP IS FOUGHT
description: SETAUKET THE transformation of a community swim and tennis club into a day camp has aroused anger in Setauket, particularly in Strathmore, where the camp is situated.

title: NOVICE LANDLORDS GET HOW-TO ADVICE
description: Three months ago Anthony Origlio was paying $250 a month in rent to share a loft. Now he is a partner in a five-story, $275,000 brownstone on West 16th Street.

title: Art View; DE STIJL IS SURVEYED IN AN EXTRAORDINARY EXHIBITION; MINNEAPOLIS
description: For the large public that nowadays takes a keen interest in the history of modern art, the most important event currently occurring in this country is the definitive exhibition called ''De Stijl: 1917-1931, Visions of Utopia,'' which has just opened at the Walker Art Center. It has been 30 years since the late Alfred H. Barr Jr. devoted an exhibition to this Dutch avant-garde movement at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. In the interim, much new information on the movement has come to light, and an even greater significance has come to be ascribed to its achievements. Clearly, the time had come to take a fresh look at these achievements, and this is what the Walker has now done, both in the exhibition organized by Mildred Friedman, the museum's curator of design, and in the accompanying book that Mrs. Friedman has edited for the occasion and that will long serve as a standard work of reference on the subject. The result is a major contribution not only to our understanding of De Stijl itself but to our appreciation of the entire European avant-garde in the period between the two World Wars.

title: Mailbox: The Knicks' Funk
description: To the Sports Editor: The Knicks are playing to 60 percent capacity in a dead arena. My own experience suggests a couple of reasons for their decline.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE BUDGET
description: SPENDING: $757.6 billion, up 4.5 percent; cuts in Government benefit programs, including welfare, food stamps, health care and housing; $14.2 billion cuts in ''discretionary'' spending.

title: Kevin J. Lockerbie to Wed Kimberly Joseph June 19
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hart T. Joseph of Columbia, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly May Joseph, to Kevin John Lockerbie, son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Bruce Lockerbie of Stony Brook, L. I.

title: M.C. Hayes Is the Financee of Miss Conn
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Bradley L. Conn Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisabeth Ann Conn, to Michael Christopher Hayes of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Hayes of Port Washington, L.I.

title: THE USES AND ABUSES OF TELEVISION IN NEW JERSEY
description: NEW JERSEY is the seat of a pioneering educational venture that can play a vital role in the future of the state, but that at the moment is grossly underutilized. It is the cooperative educational media model called the New Jersey Community College Telecommunications Consortium Inc.

title: Dr. Selma J. Glick Dies at 62; Youth Board's Research Chief
description: Dr. Selma J. Glick, research director of the New York City Youth Board, died Thursday at Montefiore Hospital after a brief illness.

title: Wendy Hiller Betrothed
description: The engagement of Wendy Valerie Hiller to Dr. James Scott Meyer has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Hiller of Oakland, N.J., Miss Hiller's parents. Dr. Meyer is a son of Mr. and Mrs Joel Meyer of Miami.

title: Susan Sherlock To Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul Sherlock of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Sherlock, to Albert R. Matlin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Matlin of Woodbury, L. I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: JOYCE'S DUBLIN
description: To the Editor:

title: A REAR VIEW LOOK AT STATION ARCHITECTURE
description: There is, in gas stations, a kind of miniature history of American architecture - or at least there used to be. In the 1920's, 1930's, and even into the 1940's gasoline stations were built in the form of little colonial houses, Chinese pagodas, Art Deco palaces, Spanish Mission haciendas, and Greek temples.

title: Great Neck as Seen By a Resident
description: Like Hansel and Gretel, blinded to truth by the external trappings of sweetness, Richard Shepard (''About Long Island,'' Jan. 17) distorts the real Great Neck. His knowledge of this community is, after all, se condhand, that of an ''on-the-fly journalist'' generalizing from the casual testimony of two tieless friends who work but do n ot live in Great Neck. To use Mr. Shepard's own words, such a simpli stic view ''proves the difference between being a tourist and b eing a settler.''

title: FAST HORSES, BEAUTIFUL WOMEN AND MURDER
description: BAD DREAMS By Anthony Haden-Guest. 420 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $14.95.

title: James Brennan, Bank Aide, And Katya Laric Are Wed
description: The marriag e of Katya Laric, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Laricof New York a nd Mill River, Mass., to James J. Brennan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jame s H. Brennan of Trenton, took place yesterday. Msgr. Thomas A. Lue bking performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Chur ch in Manhattan.

title: 'NEW FEDERALISM' MEANS NEW FEARS IN PUERTO RICO
description: Government and business leaders here are apprehensive about how ''new federalism'' will affect the hundreds of millions of dollars that Puerto Rico gets from Washington each year.

title: DEMOCRATS, MOOD OPTIMISTIC, PLAN ELECTION MOVES
description: After a year of defensiveness and defeat in the face of President Reagan's overwhelming popularity, Democratic Party activists seem ready to come out swinging as they prepare for the Congressional elections in November.

title:
Dining Out;
TASTEFUL SURROUNDINGS IN BREWSTER
description: ATTRCTIVELY set in woody isolation at the top of a steep driveway, The Arch continues to be one of the area's uniquely charming dining places. Within the roomy country house, the polished dining rooms extend welcome with rich wood tones, comfortable chairs, roses and romantic candlelight at well-spaced tables, opulent silk flower arrangements that pick up the draperies' motif , firelight in one room, lush fo liage in another. One has the feeling of dining in someone's tas tefully decorated home rather than in a restaurant.

title: On Being a Waitress And Not Ashamed
description: I was delighted to read Vivian Kellerman's article on being a waitress and not being ashamed of it (''You Don't Have to Tell Them You're a Waitress,'' Opinion Page, Jan. 17).

title: REVIVAL OF FIGURATIVE ART IN EVIDENCE AT UCONN
description: STORRS FOR a museum to focus on a new artist takes some institutional courage. Official recognition of the living, especially the young, is certainly not the big deal it once was, but it is still not to be taken lightly. Nor can the selecting be easy, for deserving candidates are now so numerous that if all were to be considered they'd be in their dotage before the die was cast.

title: Children's Books
description: PETROSINELLA By Giambattista Basile. Adapted From the Translation by John Edward Tayl or. Illustrated by Diane Stanley. Unpaged. New York: Frederick Warne. $11.95. (Ages 5 to 9) By NATALIE BABBITT

title: THE FIG TREE IN WINTER DRESS
description: BRIDGEPORT TO escape the killing chill of a climate that is unnatural for them, fig trees around here must spend the winter incognito. Some assume bizarre disguises which make them look like something out of a Surrealist's dream; others go underground.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH SECRETARY OF STATE
description: Following are excerpts from an interview given by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to The New York Times on Friday:

title: Lieut. Erin Clark Is Engaged to Marine
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Patrick Clark Jr. of Oldwick, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Second Lieut. Erin Elizabeth Clark, U.S.M.C., to Second Lieut.

title: Sunday Observer
description: All in the Family PATRICK MCDONNELL

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
SHOW AND TELL
description: A powerful tale of Italian laborers in the United States, ''Christ in Concrete,'' created a considerab le literary stir when Pietro di Donato's auto biographical novel appeared in 1939. A film was made in England by Ed ward Dmytryk in 1949 with Sam Wanamaker and Lea Padovaniin the lead r oles, and it, too, walked off with a lion's share of international awards. Today at 2 P.M., the Emma S. Clark Memorial Library in Se tauket will have both the film and the novelist on tap. Mr. di Donato , a local resident, will introduce the movie and then discuss it an d his later work. The program is free, and the library is at 120 Mai n Street.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
21 STORIES OF FAITH IN HACKENSACK
description: THERE is a stretch about eight blocks long and a block and a half wide that is one of the great surprises of Hackensack. Known variously as The Heights or The Ridge, and situated on a ridge facing east to New York City, it used to be an area of grand old mansions that became r ooming houses or fraternity houses as the years passed.

title: Film View; WHEN MOVIE THEATERS AND PATRONS ARE OBNOXIOUS
description: Cast a small feather in almost any direction and you'll hit someone who will predict that the days of seeing movies in theaters are numbered. These prognosticators may well be right, but not necessarily because motion picture exhibition is about to be rendered obsolete by the introduction of increasingly inexpensive home video equipment, wall-sized television screens and the availability of first-run films on cassettes or disks. When movie theaters finally disappear, technology will be only one of the reasons, and maybe not even the principal one.

title: TRYING TO PUT A PEOPLE'S IDENTITY INTO FOCUS
description: SEA CLIFF WHEN he first began a project that has preoccupied him for almost three years now, the photographer Arthur Leipzig took his Jewishness for granted. Raised in an Orthodox home, he had ''rebelled at an early age and was never religious,'' he said. And while he hasn't found religion as a result of creating ''Photographs of Jewish Life Around the World,'' an exhibition that opens today at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor, his globe-trotting journeys to document the state of the contemporary Diaspora have brought him something else: a sense of identity.
