title: A Gift From the General
description: There are special reasons for liking Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, U.S. Army. Following his release from the hands of the Red Brigade, he complained less about violent kidnapping than many of us complain about late trains or inclement weather.

title: MIGHTY MOUSE (AND OTHERS) ON THE WAY TO SAVE THE DAY
description: Mister Trouble never hangs around. When he hears this mighty sound: "Here I come to save the day," That means that Mighty Mouse is on the way. Might Mouse is on the way*

title: Sharon Roitsch To Marry May 1
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Roitsch of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Elise Roitsch, to Andrew Thomas Malloy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Malloy of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is planned for May 1.

title: U.S. CUTS WOULD REDUCE SOCIAL SERVICE PROGRAMS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The deep cuts in domestic programs proposed in the Reagan Administration's budget would affect New York area residents most in health care, mass transit, employment training and housing, according to a preliminary analysis by state and city officials.

title: Nutrition and the Nursing Mother
description: When the research team of the Human Lactation Center found that ''the poor and undernourished third-world women are physically unable to breast-feed,'' why did they conclude that formula-feeding the infant was the answer (''The Controversy Over Infant Formula,'' by Stephen Solomon, Dec. 6)?

title: Ideas and Trends; U.S. Insists on Sea Law Changes
description: After eight years of negotiations among 150 nations, including the United States, the so-called Law of the Sea treaty may not make it to the shores of the Potomac. President Reagan has indicated that whether or not the United States signs the accord will depend on the Administration's success in changing its proposed curbs on seabed mining.

title: Rhoda Sue Miller Sets Marriage to a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Miller of Spring Valley, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rhoda Sue Miller, to Mark Jonathan Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Miller of Whitestone, Queens. The families are not related The wedding is planned in May.

title: PRESIDENT TO RESTORE $17 MILLION IN CUTS AT MINE SAFETY UNIT
description: A last-minute decision by the Reagan Administration to restore $17 million of a planned budget cut at the Federal Mine Safety and Health Administration may avert a temporary protest strike threatened by the United Mine Workers of America, union officials said today.

title: SIDES OUTLINE STANDS IN REV. MOON'S TAX CASE
description: Federal prosecutors and defense lawyers have outlined their conflicting views of tax-fraud charges against the Rev. Sun Myung Moon in preparation for his trial next month.

title: CRAYFISH
description: To the Editor:

title: PATRICIA BIEDERMAN ENGAGED TO LAWYER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Biederman of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Biederman, to William J. Robbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Robbins of Merrick, L. I.

title: Around the World; Bolivia Devalues Peso And Bans Meetings
description: Bolivia's five-month-old military Government announced a devaluation of the peso on Friday night and banned meetings today to maintain public order.

title: BOOKS INTO ASHES
description: My novel ''Slaughterhouse-Five'' was actually burned in a furnace by a school janitor in Drake, North Dakota, on instructions from the school committee there, and the school board made public statements about the unwholesomeness of the book. Even by the standards of Queen Victoria, the only offensive line in the entire novel is this: ''Get out of the road, you dumb m(-----------).'' This is spoken by an American antitank gunner to an unarmed American chaplain's assistant during the Battle of the Bulge in Europe in December 1944, the largest single defeat of American arms (the Confederacy excluded) in history. The chaplain's assistant had attracted enemy fire.

title: Chess; A NEW STAR IS RISING
description: One of the brightest new stars of the game is the Soviet Union's Lev Psachis. So far ranked only as an international master, the 22-year-old Psachis will soon overcome that formality.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Changing times. Next to ''The Joy of Sex,'' the longest runner on the trade paperback best-seller list is ''What Color Is Your Parachute?: A Practical Manual for Job-Hunters and Career-Changers.'' It's been there three years, and its sales now exceed 1,500,000 copies.

title: LAWYERS APLENTY, BUT TOO FEW JOBS
description: IT'S a buyer's market for legal talent in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, according to attorneys and others close to the legal profession. Although statistics on the subject are scarce, there is an abundance of lawyers seeking a relatively small number of job openings.

title: Leisure; GARDEN BOOKS THAT MAY BEAR FRUIT
description: ------------------------------------------------ -------------------- Neal Johnston is lawyer who has learned to be a gardener. By NEAL JOHNSTON

title: No Headline
description: Oilers Defeat Maple Leafs, 5-1

title: Deborah Payne Davis Plans a May Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard W. Davis of Unionville, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Payne Davis of New York, to Randolph Chase Ludacer, son of Ellen Varian Ludacer and Randy Ludacer of Key West, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

title: HOW A PLUGGED-IN OUTFIT WINS CABLE BIDS
description: It has been two and a half years in the making, and still has a way to go. But late this week, New York City's protracted cable television competition will take a substantive step toward completion when the six companies that made it to the final round get a glimpse of the fine print - the first draft of their contracts.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE No one has to be reminded that the New York City Ballet is currently in residence at the State Theater. But just in case you hadn't noticed, ''Orpheus,'' one of the company's past signature works, will turn up sandwiched between two more recent productions on Friday night.

title: HEART MONTH PROCLAIMED
description: President Reagan this week proclaimed February as American Heart Month and invite d Americans to join him in"reaffirming our commitment to the resolution of the nationwide problem of cardiovascular disease."

title: CONCERT: 'SOLIDARITY,' TRIBUTE TO POLAND
description: A program described as a benefit concert for the people of Poland, and entitled ''Solidarity,'' was presented at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening. The event featured performances by the Polish cellist Cecylia Barczyk, who has been a student at Yale University since 1977 and who requested political asylum in this country late in December, following the declaration of martial law in Poland.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Betty Oberacker Offers Book II of 'Clavier'
description: One of the more impressive and rewarding piano recitals of the new year came Thursday evening, when Betty Oberacker played the second book of Bach's ''Well-Tempered Clavier'' at the Abraham Goodman House.

title: Westchester Guide; THE GREAT BULB GIVEAWAY
description: Spring will arrive Friday at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, when yellow daffodils, tulips, crocuses and forsythia, complemented by white azaleas and witch hazel will go on display under the glass dome of the Crystal Palace. It is the largest exhibition to be undertaken there in recent years, according to Margaret Lovero, spokesman for the facility.

title: QUESTIONS ON CHIMNEY SWEEPING
description: A CLEAN chimney may mean the difference between life and death for thousands of homeowners who are using wood and coal stoves as well as fireplaces this winter. However, many homeowners do not realize that their chimneys should be cleaned to avoid creosote buildup, while those who do are having trouble finding reliable sweepers to do the job.

title: The Perry Ellis Look
description: A little over a year ago, we were virtually unprepared when a customer (usually young) asked for the pattern and yarn to knit a ''Perry Ellis sweater'' (''Designing an Empire,'' by John Duka, Jan. 3). Now variations of his dimpled sleeve and cables are incorporated in almost every model sweater we make, and ladies of all ages are clamoring for more. SYLVIA MILLER, Newton Upper Falls, Mass.

title: Topics; BANKRUPTCIES, FISCAL AND MORAL; Conscientious Objector
description: Paul Mulvey, a forward on the Los Angeles Kings ho ckey team, was not considered a particularly skillful player . At 6-4, he was prized for his eagerness and ability to fight.

title: The Nation; From the Annals Of Migrant Labor
description: In a North Carolina courtroom last month came a glimpse of the underside of rural America; witnesses described a ''reign of terror'' on the sweet potato farm where they said they had been forced to work, and a jury convicted three field bosses of conspiring to kidnap, intimidate and enslave eight migrant farm laborers.

title: A Correction
description: The participants in the July 1955 summit meeting in Geneva were incorre ctly identified in an article in The W eek in Review of Jan. 24. Those attending were President Eisenhower , British Prime MinisterAnthony Eden, French Prime Minister Edgar Fau re and Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai A. Bulganin.

title: Virginia Women Better Indoor Relay Standard
description: Virginia's distance medley relay team bettered its world best time to highlight the fifth annual Princeton women's relays today at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Around the Nation; Negotiator for Ford Issues Layoffs Warning
description: Ford Motor Company's chief negotiator warned today that layoffs could be ahead if the contract concession talks with the United Automobile Workers collapsed as they had with the General Motors Corporation.

title: Bridge; PSYCHOLOGICAL FINESSE
description: Atwo-way finesse is never a guess. That statement, like virtually all other sweeping generalizations about bridge, is untrue. But it is not far from the truth, and the substitution of ''hardly ever'' for ''never'' would give it validity.

title: PACKING IT IN: SECRETS OF TRAVEL WITH ONE BAG
description: RONA JAFFE is the author of 11 books, including ''Class Reunion'' and her most recent novel, ''Mazes and Monsters.'' By RONA JAFFE

title: LIVING WITH CRIME: THREE VIEWS
description: IN the old days, my mother used to dish out enough philosophical advice to have launched a successful business in kosher fortune cookies.

title: AFRICAN AIDES DISCUSS SAHARA AT KENYA PARLEY
description: Nine African foreign ministers met here today to discuss the Western Sahara, where an Algerian-supported guerrilla organization known as the Polisario Front has been fighting Morocco for more than six years.

title: POPE SEES HOPE OF UNITY IN RENEWED TIES TO BRITAIN
description: Britain has restored full diplomatic relations with the Vatican four months before the planned visit by Pope John Paul II to England, Scotland and Wales.

title: Headliners; Is It Soup Yet?
description: There are no golden arches outside the restaurant in Crissier, Switzerland, owned by Fredy Girardet. Indeed, some culinary authorities say the renowned chef's three-star establishment is the greatest in the world.

title: THE PERRY ELLIS LOOK
description: You might be interested to hear of Regine Sicart's ''place in the fashion pantheon.''

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: WHEN your term of office begins just 10 months before the next election, you can't wait long before trying to persuade the voters that you are doing a good job. It took Barbara B. Kennelly four days to get started.

title: Anne Starr Ervin to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Ervin of Ambler, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Starr Ervin, to J. Elliott Woltz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Woltz of Mount Airey, N.C. A May wedding is planned.

title: WEIRATHER CAPTURES DOWNHILL FOR AUSTRIA'S 1ST GOLD MEDAL
description: Austrians, desperate for a hero at the world Alpine skiing championships, found one today as Harti Weirather came through by winning a gold medal in the men's downhill.

title: About Books and Authors
description: Doctor O.W.

title: Ronalda Nicholas Plans to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Ronald G. Nicholas of Kingston, Jamaica, and Philadelphia and Grayce N. Nicholas of Philadelphia of the engagement of their daughter, Ronalda Ay Nicholas, to Rathnakanth Prasoon Wilson. He is the son of T.J.m. Wilson and Indira Wilson, both of Madras, India.

title: COUNTY IS MOUNTING DRIVE TO CUT ARSON
description: AIDED by a $5,206.50 state grant that becomes available this month, a Westchester task force is preparing to carry out a plan for a major spring offensive against arson. The plan, which will be presented to the County Legislature for final approval tomorrow night, calls for extensive training of public-safety personnel, establishment of a publiceducation program and a long-awaited, 24-hour hot line.

title: CITY BALLET: 'DAVIDSBUNDERLERTANZE'
description: George Balanchine's ''Robert Schumann's 'Davidsbunderlertanze' '' might be a mouthful of an idea to retain but it is also shorthand for the great ballet that had its first performance of the season Friday night at the State Theater with the New York City Ballet.

title: COMMUNIST RIVALS IN SPAIN PLAN NEW PARTIES
description: With the Communist Party of Spain in disarray over the doctrine and practice of Eurocommunism, a former Jesuit is championing the formation of a rival, pro-Soviet party.

title: Ideas and Trends; Teachers In The Hot Seat
description: If Johnny's teacher can't learn, there's not much hope for Johnny. That argument, and widespread dissatisfaction with schools, have given rise to the idea that teachers should be required to show they have done their homework too.

title:
Photography View;
BUILDINGS SEEN FROM THREE DIFFERENT PERSPECTIVES
description: How differently the same subject - buildings - is treated by three photographers currently having gallery exhibitions: Werner Mantz, Andreas Feininger and Patrizia della Porta. Werner Mantz, whose first American exhibition is at Prakapas Gallery, 19 East 71st Street, through March 6, is an architectural photographer pure and simple. He flourished in Germany and Holland in the 1930's, and he photographed buildings in a style that was basically clean and modern, though it was not yet fully free of the sepia tones and soft, atmospheric effects of early 20th-century art photography.

title: NANCY MAHWINNEY ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Nancy Jean Mahwinney to Jon Jay Sunner, son of Mrs. Virginia Sunner of Bethel Park, Pa., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gerhard H. Laube of Great Neck, L.I., stepfather and mother of the future bride. An April 3 wedding is planned in Pittsburgh.

title: SOCCER TEAMS KEEP RIVALRY FRIENDLY
description: EAST RUTHERFORD ALTHOUGH off to disappointing starts in their maiden seasons of professional indoor soccer, the New Jersey Rockets and the Cosmos are nonetheless enthusiastic over their new fans and their new home, the Brendan T. Byrne Arena here.

title: THE ART OF A COSMOPOLITAN PEOPLE
description: JOHN RUSSELL is art critic for The Times. By JOHN RUSSELL

title: READING THESTOCK TABLES
description: To the Business Editor: While reading the stock tables in your newspaper, I realized that I was having trouble aligning the name of the company with its stock price and change for the day. Upon further reflection, it seemed to me that presentation of the data in the stock tables should be altered sli gh tly to make reading the tables easier.

title: Art; ELEGIAC VIEWS OF A FADING WAY OF LIFE
description: MONTCLAIR WRITING as a naturalist about the oyster, Oliver Goldsmith said that it resembled the mussel, ''except for the thickness of its shell and its greater imbecility.''

title: The White House Looks for an Exit
description: Laurence H. Tribe last week suggested how the Administration could end the embarrassment created by its bungled effort to grant tax exemptions to racially segregated private schools. It's simple, the Harvard Law School professor told a House hearing; the White House should ''Just 'fess up that they've blown it, that the law got in their way.''

title: REVUE: NOT 'BORN TOO LATE'
description: Three young groups that have been building modest successes individually have been brought together at the New Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, in a revue called ''Born Too Late'' that offers opportunities for them to appear in broader perspective than they have on their own.

title: Headliners; Tough Work
description: Studs Terkel, who has spent much of his life talking and writing about other people's work, probably never thought anyone would want to ban his. But then, he had probably never been to Girard, Pa., population 2,500.

title: Malling the Waterfront
description: I am among the many individuals who have wandered around the shabby buildings at the South Street Seaport Museum (''A Mall Covers the Waterfront,'' by William Severini Kowinski, Dec. 13). I have spent many a day feeding the market cats and walking through the cobblestone streets.

title: Environews
description: LAST year was considered an important one for the approval of legislation that some of those concerned with the environment believe will affect millions of New Jerseyans in the coming years.

title: CHECKING THE METER ON THE FLOW OF DATA
description: Since its enactment in 1966, the Freedom of Information Act has become a well-established part of the Washington landscape. Documents and other data obtained under provisions of the law have resulted in dramatic disclosures, including accounts of how the Federal Bureau of Investigation once kept Martin Luther King Jr. under surveillance and, just last month, how the United States military secretly sprayed herbicides on Laos during the Vietnam War.

title: 9 SEEK MOFFETT SEAT
description: NEW BRITAIN POLITICIANS abhor a vacuum, and nine of them are seeking to fill the vacuum left in the Sixth Congressional District by Representative Toby Moffett's decision to leave his seat and try for one in the United States Senate.

title: Reading and Writing; IS DECENCY COMING BACK?
description: In his book on writers and psychoanalysis, Edmund Bergler quoted an interesting remark made by a patient of his who was a novelist. He was such an accurate observer of human nature, the patient said, that there wasn't a single decent person in any of his books.

title: Julie A. Charlton And Lawyer Plan Wedding in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Roddy Charlton of Atascadero, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Anne Charlton, to James Anthony FitzPatrick Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Anthony FitzPatrick of Plattsburgh, N.Y.

title: City Hall Notes
description: New York City has passed a fiscal milestone by formally asking the Treasury Department to authorize the last $300 mill ion in Federal loan guarantees available under a 1978 act th at helped keep the city afloat during its financial recovery.

title: SUBURBAN HOME RENTING ON RISE
description: IN the old days, most suburban towns were not known for readily available rental housing. Occasionally, a few houses would be offered for rent, but the tendency in these towns was to disdain rentals. After all, they were a reminder of the urban ills from which many suburbanites had fled.

title:
Dining Out;
A GAME BIRD IS ALWAYS AVAILABLE
description: TO DINE out at anything beyond a fast-food spot these days i s no mean financial undertaking. And so it is alwa ys a relief to come across a restaurant that doesn't charge the e arth for middling fare.

title: FORDHAM DEFEATS IONA, 73-65
description: Fordham rallied from a 6-point deficit in the second half and beat Iona, 73-65, knocking the Gaels out of first place in the Metro Atlantic Conference yesterday..

title: Victory by Knicks I s Lacking in Focus
description: There were different assessments of Friday night's lethargic 90-85 victory by the Knicks over the San Diego Clippers, a game in which the Knicks shot 46 percent from the floor and the Clippers 42 percent.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: The Scottish World Edited by Harold Orel, Henry L. Snyder and Marlyn Stokstad. 328 pages. Abrams. $45.

title: Westchester Journal
description: CLOSED and mired for months in financial difficulties, New Rochelle' s Wild Cliff Museum has been given t entative new guidance toward fiscal responsibility and streamlined programs aimed at acquainting young people with their natural e nvironment.

title: Business Conditions; MARKET RALLY FORECAST
description: Weak corporate earnings, growing Federal deficits and high interest rates have helped depress stock prices, but the market may soon strengthen, one forecast of stock performance suggests.

title: GRENADA LOOKS TO CUBAN WAYS AND U.S. TOURISTS
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada - The crowd clapped rhythmically and began to sing: ''When the Yankee soldiers come, ''When the Yankee soldiers come, ''I want to be in the front line, ''When the Yankee soldiers come.'' Nearly a thousand people had gathered on the waterfront of this island nation's capital to commemorate the death of a local hero. But the occasion rapidly turned into an anti-American rally, reinforcing the belief here that Washington is on the ver ge of military action against Grenada.

title: Around the Nation; Mayor of New Orleans Faces Runoff in March
description: Ernest N. Morial, the first black mayor of New Orleans, and Ron Faucheux, a white state representative, were forced into a runoff election in today's election for Mayor.

title: Miss Herman Fiancee Of William Jarrett Jr.
description: Mrs. Walter L. Herman of Scarsdale, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Nancy Barbara Herman, to William Sheldon Jarrett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jarrett of Newtown, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN ''THIS body,'' proclaims a T-shirt and a lapel pin for sale at the Human Bean at 982 Church Street, a newcomer on the oldest and most unchanging street I know of in this village, ''is all natural. It contains no artificial preservatives, additives, coloring or flavoring.''

title: UPSTATE GUARD DIES AFTER SCUFFLE WI TH A PRISONER
description: A prison guard at the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y., died yesterday after a scuffle with an inmate he and another guard were escorting inside the upstate maximum-security prison, authorities said.

title: Antiques; RECESSION AFFECTS DEALERS, TOO
description: PRINCETON AS SCHOLARS, dealers, curators, critics and collectors rummage among the remnants of history, there is a growing recognition that virtually no period or culture is without interest.

title: GROUP ACTS TO SAVE A 1931 MOVIE PALACE
description: TORRINGTON IT was the talk of the county. Thousands jammed Main Street in Torrington on Aug. 19, 1931, to celebrate the opening of an 1,800-seat, half-million-dollar motion picture palace built by the Warner Brothers Corporation. The marquee, ablaze with hundreds of blinking lights, proclaimed that the evening's feature film would be ''The Star Witness.''

title: THE LANDSCAPE AND THE BODY
Brittany
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW FILM BY COSTA-GRAVAS EXAMINES THE CHILEAN COUP
description: Fact: A young American freelance writer named Charles Horman was killed during the 1973 coup that brought the Pinochet regime to power in Chile.

title: Washington; NOTES ON EUROPE
description: If you look at the world from Paris instead of from W ashington, it remains the same but seems quite different. History a nd geography change the angle. They produce different newspapers, d ifferent impressions on the television screen, different priorities a nd even ways of discussing the common problems of economic and m ilitary security in the Western alliance.

title: ROAD SALT SUPPLIES AT A LOW
description: WESTCHESTER communities began building up their depleted stores of road salt last week but some town highway departments reported that supplies remained low because additional deliveries have been delayed by transportation difficulties.

title:
Comment;
POWER OF BABBLE
description: A CCORDING to conventional wisdom many management problems are caused by a ''lack of communication.'' But, if anything, the reverse may be true: Too much talk, and too many meetings and memos are prime confusion creators.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ

title: STATE SCHOOLS NOW MOVING TO SELECTIVITY
description: The nation's major state universities, faced with budget problems and increased demand from students, are becoming increasingly selective about the people they admit to their halls of learning.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Crazy, isn't it? Every morning when I put the gun on, all I can think about is the insanity of it. This has gotten to be an uncontrollable situation.'' - Vic Barouh, owner of a factory in a high-crime area of Brooklyn. (1:2.)

title: Children's Books
description: RARE TREASURES FROM GRIMM Fifteen Little-Known Tales. Selected and Translated by Ralph Manheim. Illustrated by Erik Blegvad. 99 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $12.95. (Ages 7 to 10) By JOYCE MILTON

title: KIM HEITMAN IS BETROTHED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Amato of North Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of West Orange, N.J., of the engagement of Mrs. Amato's daughter, Kim Kathryn Heitman, to Michael Alan Collins Pithey, son of Augustine Pithey of Durbin, Natal, South Africa, and the late Ludovic Alan Pithey. Miss Heitman is program controller of ABC Sports and her fianc'e is ABC-TV production manager for the 1984 Olympics. A September wedding is planned.

title: Directors (Cont.)
description: To the Business Editor: One more word on ''Professor Director'' (Jan. 17 and Jan. 31): If the academic world does indeed form a pool from which directors can be fished then the fishermen might think a bit more about who or what they hope to catch.

title: Illinois Bank is Held Insolvent
description: The First National Bank and Trust Company of Tuscola, Ill., was declared insolvent today and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was appointed receiver to protect its customers' funds and t o arrange sale of the bank.

title: Peter Smolian Fiance Of Marion T. Barnes
description: Eleanor J. Summers of Lakewood, Calif., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Marion Theresa Barnes, to Peter Jay Smolian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Smolian of Redding, Conn.

title: New Jersey Guide; A PLAY WITHIN A PLAY
description: It's an extraordinary title for an extraordinary play: ''The Persecution and Assassination of Marat as Performed by the Inmates of the Asylum of Charenton Under the Direction of the Marquis de Sade.''

title:
Gardening;
FRIENDLY AND HELPFUL SYMBIOTIC PLANTS
description: MOST people would agree that a good marriage is one in which both partners contribute as well as benefit from the relationship. It seems that the plant world is filled with such unselfish relationships. We are just now learning of the importance of fostering similar relationships among the plants that we grow in our gardens, forests and fields.

title: Crime
description: The veteran Harold Q. Masur gives us a slick novel about hankypanky in the business world in THE BROKER (St. Martin's, $13.95). It features the head of a Wall Street investment banking company, who handles the affairs of a shark planning to take over a film company. That means a proxy fight - a subject very much in the news these days.

title: New Jerseyans
description: BARBARA LIPTON set up her movie projector in the Eskimo village of Kwigillingok, in southwestern Alaska, last November and showed the folks there films of themselves.

title: CHINA'S GENIUS WITH VEGETABLES
description: FEI LO is the author of ''The Dim Sum Book: Classic Recipes from the Chinese Teahouse.'' By EILEEN YIN-FEI LO V egetarianism in China is as old as Buddha. And the Chinese co ncept of elaborately arranged artistic banquets of many courses is as old as Confucius. Somewhere in time, felicitously and naturally, th e ideas came together. These days the vegetarian banquet, with beancu rd, vegetables and doughs artfully dressed to appear as something th ey are not, is common to such disparate parts of the country as Ca nton, Peking or Shanghai, whose cuisines are quite different.

title:
ANTIQUES;
'COUNTRY SHOW AT WINDHAM'
description: WINDHAM FOR 20 years, what visiting collectors like to describe as a nice, friendly country show has been held here each February as a benefit for the Windham Free Library Association. The Windham Antiques Show next Friday and Saturday will be staged in the Congregational Church on the town green. Funds raised will help pay for a much-needed addition to the library building, a handsome brick structure originally built for the now-defunct Windham National Bank.

title: Hockey in Revival At Bowling Green
description: With a month to go in the college hockey season no truly outstanding teams have emerged from the hectic race in the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Division I. But elsewhere it appears that the West will produce the favorites for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in Providence, R.I., next month.

title: AND A PRISON HELPS OUT, TOO
description: TRENTON THERE is no mistaking a class in gourmet cooking at the Department of Corrections for Cordon Bleu training in Paris. For one thing, the student discoursing on vinaigrette sauces is a convicted killer. And although students are taught how to prepare Hollandaise and Bearnaise sauces, curries, quiches and entrees such as chicken Cordon Bleu, they must also sling hash and grill cheeseburgers.

title:
Numismatics;
A POSSIBLE USE FOR THE LIBERTY HEAD DESIGN?
description: Few Americans lament the apparent passing of the Susan B. Anthony dollar, but many coin collectors do regret one aspect of the ''minidollar's'' short, sad history: The fact that Congress chose to cast aside the Liberty Head design prepared for the coin initially by Frank Gasparro, then the United States Mint's chief sculptor-engraver. Now Mr. Gasparro has broached an idea that could well give that much-acclaimed design its rightful place in the sun: He suggests that it be used on a commemorative coin for the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: 'THE PLAYS WE WRITE ARE AMERICAN PLAYS'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ISRAEL CONDEMNS U.N. RESOLUTION

title: INFLUENCE OF UNITED STATES ON OLYMPICS IS SLIPPING
description: The United States will stage the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, yet American influence within the International Olympic Committee is at an all-time low.

title: Free Speech Movement
description: To the Editor:

title: News An alysis
description: The Reagan Administration budget for the fiscal year 1983 is based on a body of economic assumptions that are optimistic and fraught with uncertainity. If the assumptions go sour, as many of them did in last year's economic forecast, the budget, already burdened with a high deficit, could look much worse.

title: TURKEY PLANNING LEGAL ABORTIONS
description: Turkey is once again taking the lead on women's rights in the Islamic world with preparations for a new law to legalize abortion and permit voluntary sterilization.

title: SMALLER DEFICITS DEPEND ON ADOPTION OF CUTS
description: Every year since 1975 the President of the United States has produced a budget document in which the Government's income was projected to match its spending two years in the future, with expanding surpluses anticipated in later years.

title: STAGE: 'VATZLAV,' COMEDY BY MROZEK AT THE QUAIGH
description: Slawomir Mrozek's ''Vatzlav'' is a three-ring circus of a comedy, cataloguing the injustices - and the sheer craziness - of civilization. In 77 scenes, some of them as brief as blackouts, Mrozek turns his title character loose on a mythic landscape.

title: Dance View; WILL THE PENNSYLVANIA BALLET SURVIVE?
description: The warning signs are here. The Pennsylvania Ballet announces a suspension of activity for 90 to 120 days because of an extremely severe debt and cash obligations. The Joffrey Ballet shortens rehearsals by one week and its administrative staff takes a temporary pay cut. The Minnesota Dance Theater, after suspending its own activity, reorganizes with its founder no longer at the helm.

title: Editors' Choice
description: in-law's funeral in Rumania realizing on the spot the harshness of that country and in flashback the violent decay of human decency in his own country.

title: London Barbers
description: To the Editor:

title: LIVING WITH CRIME: THREE VIEWS
description: OUR small Connecticut village - with its eclectic collection of 300 years of American architecture, its tree-lined streets, its narrow harbor, its cluster of shops and post office - seems almost like a stage set, so serene is its aspect. Preserved like a fly in amber by the boundaries of modern improvements - highway, Post Road, railroad - it has a population that runs the gamut from conservative Yankees, descendants of the first settlers, to trendy young millionaires.

title: A Curb on Electronic Games Is Voted by a Town in Florida
description: The Ormond Beach Commission has approved an ordinance that prohibits electronic games from being placed within 1,000 feet of a school, church or youth activity center.

title: CONCERT: CLARION CHORUS
description: Musical naivete is a quality quite hard to come by. Only a few composers possessed it, fewer used it to profound ends. At Newell Jenkins's Clarion Concert on Wednesday night in Alice Tully Hall, there was a profusion of naivete on display, not all of it sophisticated enough to hold one's attention.

title: BRAZILIANS FAVOR CUBAN TRADE TIES
description: Many Brazilian businessmen are pressing for a restoration of Cuban-Brazilian trade in defiance of United States efforts to tighten the boycott against Cuba.

title: U.S. Parthenon
description: To the Editor:

title: A LEGACY THAT GREW PENNY BY PENNY
description: WHEN I was growing up and money was tight, we had an understanding in our family that nothing must ever be wasted. Now, whenever I tell my own children about some of the economies we practiced in those days, they are amazed.

title: The Region; O'Neill Returns, Budget in Hand
description: Returning to the Statehouse in Hartford last week for the first time since suffering a heart attack nearly three months ago, William A. O'Neill proposed a budget that seemed calculated to boost his chances of remaining Governor of Connecticut after the November election.

title: Travel Advisory; WINTER SPORTS, A BULLET TRAIN; Living Like A Millionaire
description: Surrounded by thousands of acres of forest, with snow-clad mountains in the distance and a shimmering lake at its doorstep, Sagamore Lodge in the Adirondacks has been called a monument to rusticity. Built for Alfred G. Vanderbilt in 1897, the three-story millionaire's vacation retreat has been opened to the public for the first time this winter - and at a fee that is certainly less than princely.

title: Around the World; Angola and Cuba Agree O n Issue of Withdrawal
description: Cuban troops will be withdrawn from Angola ''as soon as all signs of possible invasion'' by South Africa have ended, the Angolan and Cuban Foreign Ministers said in a joint statement received here today. Estimates of the size of the Cuban force range from 12,000 to 20,000 troops.

title: SWEATERS FROM KITS
description: There are two kinds of Perry Ellis sweaters: the ones the designer sells, and the ones women knit for themselves from yarn and instructions supplied by needlework stores. Starting next month, there will be a third kind: sweaters women knit for themselves from kits supplied by Perry Ellis.

title: Gateway Park Chief Given Regional Post
description: The superintendent of the Gateway National Recreation Area in New York and New Jersey has been appointed director of the National Park Service North Atlantic Region.

title: Children's Books
description: SIR GAWAIN AND THE GREEN KNIGHT By Selina Hastings. Illustrated by Juan Wijngaard. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $8.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By KARLA KUSKIN

title: RESEARCH FARES WELL, BUT AID FOR STUDENTS IS CUT
description: Scientific research at universities and elsewhere generally fares reasonably well in President Reagan's proposed budget for the 1983 fiscal year. At the same time the President would cut sharply funds for grants and loans to college students.

title: FICA and IRA
description: To the Business Editor: I fail to understand why a contribution of $2,000 annually to an Individual Retirement Account will produce a millionaire in 30 years, while a generally larger sum deposited over a longer period with the Federal Insurance Compensation Act will produce a shaky Social Security retirement benefit of possibly $15,000 annually.

title: SWANS ARE GONE, BUT ART DECO GRACE RETURNS TO BRONX APARTMENT HOUSE
description: It is in the Bronx of abandoned, burned-out buildings, but Noonan Plaza, an apartment house at 168th Street and Ogden Avenue in the High Bridge section, is remembered by Frederick Ginsbern as a place where swans paddled gracefully and peacefully in the courtyard's pool.

title: No Headline
description: Olson V aults 18 -9 1/4

title: Children's Books
description: THREE ROMANCES Love Stories From Camelot. Retold by Winifred Rosen. Illustrated by Paul O. Zelinsky. 120 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $8.95. (Ages 12 and Up) By CAROL VAN STRUM

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1982
description: International The U.S. and China are involved in ''extremely sensitive discussions'' over the Taiwan issue, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said. but he was ''not in a position to predict the outcome.'' American officials had previously said that talks were going on with Peking over its complaints about the Administration's decision to continue arms sales to Taiwan, which China regards as an infringement on its sovereignty. Mr. Haig's remarks in an interview seemed to indicate concern for future relations not expressed previously. (Page 1, Column 3.)

title: NL SPENT MILLIONS
description: TRENTON OVER the last several years, NL Industries of Sayreville has spent, by its own account, some $20 million in new equipment to control air pollution and reduce the concentration of pollutants it dumps in the Atlantic.

title: FOUNDATION FOCUSES ON NEWARK
description: MONTCLAIR WHEN the United States prepared to enter the Spanish-American War in 1898, Percy Chubb did not hold the Spanish fleet in high esteem. Other insurance executives worried about an invasion of the Eastern Seaboard, but Mr. Chubb - a founder of the Chubb & Son Insurance Company - played a hunch and ordered his concern to offer complete insurance coverage for ships at sea, as well as protection for houses along the New Jersey shore (at 1 percent of property value) in the event of bombardment.

title: EAST 18TH ST. FOUNDRY REPRODUCES ART TREASURES
description: Using techniques familiar to ancient Egyptians, Greeks and Oriental artisans, a small foundry in Manhattan is catering to a modest boom in demand for bronze reproductions of art treasures.

title: Tammy Maxwell Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Maxwell of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Tammy Fern Maxwell, to Gary Mark Charles Hornung, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Hornung of Swampscott, Mass. The wedding is planned for April 3.

title: 'Pennies From Heaven'
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICS EVALUATE THE BURKE YEARS
description: MANY critics emphasize two mitigating factors in evaluating the performance of Dr. Fred G. Burke as the state's Commissioner of Education: He assumed the post at a time when New Jersey's educational system was in chaos, and he was sincere in his efforts to aid its 1.2 million schoolchildren.

title: M.P. Lubas Weds Jean H. Kramer
description: Jean Hull Kramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Kramer of Branchburg Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Peter Lubas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Lubas of Cranford, N.J. The Rev. William Morris performed the ceremony in St. Helen's Roman Catholic Church, in Westfield, N.J.

title: MRS. LUCE GOES TO WASHINGTON
description: A number of friends thought she'd be upset, livid or litigious. There it was on magazine stands across the country, a cover banner reading ''Clare Boothe Luce, From Courtesan to Career Woman.''

title: Dr. Patrice Desvigne To Be Married in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd J. Desvigne of St. Albans, Queens, and Mystic Isles, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Patrice Marie Desvigne, to Dr. Herbert Wallace Nickens, son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman W. Nickens of Washington.

title: THE USES AND ABUSES OF TELEVISION IN NEW JERSEY
description: THERE can be no doubt that many of the problems we have struggled to overcome in New Jersey for several decades have been exaggerated by the absence of extensive, intensive and intelligent television coverage of the state by a VHF station capable of reaching a mass audience.

title: BUILDER GRASPS 'LUCKY' CHANCE
description: The year 1980 began inauspiciously for Bruce Eichner. In January a fire destroyed the old Hotel Margaret overlooking the East River in Brooklyn Heights, just as he was finishing rebuilding it as a luxury cooperative.

title: GAS STATIONS: TUNING UP FOR THE 1980'S
description: HOUSTON Y OU see them in every big city, tucked away on dusty corners, abandoned to the memory of an earlier America. As the first structures built to serve the automobile, they established themselves more than half a century ago as an inseparable part of the landscape and of everyday existence itself. Cast in a fascinating array of shapes, they became, as a group, one of the most widespread kinds of commercial buildings in the land.

title:
Speaking Personally;
LIFE AMONG THE DESCENDANTS OF AARON BURR
description: IUSED to think that my family tree died of Dutch elm disease. There was, I believe, some measure of distinction from a Bavarian burgermeister on my mother's side.

title: 'THE WOMEN' ON POLICE MOST-WANTED LIST
description: To the New York City detectives who concentrate on trying to catch bank robbers, they have become known simply as ''the Women.'' Since Dec. 28, they have become the city's most active team of bank robbers, holding up 11 banks in Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn.

title: GROUP AIDS 8TH AVE. LEASING
description: Let real estate brokers specialize in selling office buildings, or leasing Fifth Avenue shops for $300 a square foot. Matt Meyers has some special properties to rent - the former sites of a peep show and a brothel, among others.

title: STADLER LEADS ON 64-206
description: Before the final day of a golf tournament, Jack Nicklaus says, he usually figures his chances of winning on the basis of ''how many guys'' are ahead of him. By that criterion Nicklaus stands a reasonable chance in Sunday's final round of the 41st Bing Crosby National Pro-Am. Four strokes off the pace, Nicklaus, a 20-year veteran who has often surged ahead on final rounds, would need to pass only three players to win.

title: Food
description: Plugging the Leek

title: THE NATIONAL BANK OF MERRILL LYNCH
description: BOUNTIFUL, Utah, is a tranquil farm community of barely 40,000 people. It is also the home of the Utah Bank and Trust Company. Utah Bank's deposits, now some $41 million, have slid about $1 million in the last two years. Morris H. Atwood, the president, says he isn't sure who has been rustling his long loyal checking account customers but high on the list of suspects he puts Merrill Lynch & Company, the financial services firm that offers customers high-yielding moneymarket funds with check-writing privileges.

title: CONCERTIZING AFTER A 20-YEAR INTERMISSION
description: GARDEN CITY ALTHOUGH a bad review has been known to cut short a career in the arts, rave notices rarely, if ever, have revived a career that has been on hold for 20 years. Yet that's exactly what has happened to Valentino Marconi, the pianist, who put a promising concert career on a back burner some two decades ago, opting for teaching, home and family, instead.

title: LIVING WITH CRIME: THREE VIEWS
description: IT was a bitter cold Sunday afternoon. The sun was setting and the children had exhausted their imaginations and mine. The 3-year-old girl asked the two older boys, ages 5 and 8, to play house with her. They were so desperate for one more game, they agreed.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: ANEW long-range master plan for the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in Morris County is being prepared by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. It will replace an outmoded plan drafted in the late 1960's and chart the uses and needs of the sanctuary for the next 10 to 20 years.

title: Prospects
description: The Budget Impasse

title: BUDGET ORIGINALLY SCHEDULED FOR RELEASE IN TUESDAY PAPERS
description: President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1983 was originally scheduled for publication in Tuesday newspapers, with copies distributed to reporters in advance to help them prepare their articles. But a White House spokesman released news organizations from the delay agreement this morning, saying that unauthorized disclosures and printing errors on Government documents had rendered the delay meaningless.

title: A Correction
description: A transmission error incorrectly identified the musical director of the Bay Area Friends of the Fine Arts Orchestra last week. He is Mark Orton.

title:
Other Business;
THE SUPPLY SIDE OF PUBLISHING
description: If there's any doubt about the trickle-down effect of Reaganomics, one need only enter a bookstore. The Government's new tax law has provoked a veritable flood of new tax guides.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF EUDORA WELTY. (HBJ/Harvest, $8.95.) Fortyone stories, the yield of 40 years of work by one of our foremost writers of fiction. Eudora Welty's scene is usually the changing South, where she has passed most of her life, but - as our reviewer Maureen Howard observed when this collection was published in hardcover in 1980 - ''the richness of her talent resists a summing up. We can place her with her models, Chekhov and Katherine Anne Porter. The stories are magnificent.''

title: Quake Off West Coast
description: A strong earthquake estimated at 5.25 on the Richter scale rumbled under the ocean off California and Oregon early today, scientists said. There were no reports of injuries or damage.

title: MEMO BY E.P.A. CHIEF PROMISES JOB SECURITY
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, distributed an unusual memorandum to agency employees on Friday promising that no one would be involuntarily laid off in the current fiscal year.

title: Machu Picchu
description: To the Editor:

title: SPARE DECOR BUT AN AMPLE MENU
description: GLENVILLE THE lyrical and overblown description of the food preparation process on many menus has an oral version that can be just as misleading. Waiters and waitresses adept at the technique can describe each dish in such loving detail that the mouth waters. Like the written variety, however, the oral description frequently outshines the dish that is served.

title: Mormonism And Feminism
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN DEBT TO F.D.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: By Theodore W. Libbey; Music: Debuts in Review; Anush Quartet, Trio Of Strings With Flute
description: To really enjoy the New York debut program of the Anush Quartet, presented last Sunday at Carnegie Recital Hall by the New York chapter of the Armenian Students Association, one had to like abrupt shifts of gear. The group, which is a string trio with flute, not a string quartet, opened its program with Mozart's Quartet in D for flute and strings (K. 285), skipped to some quaint pieces in folk style by the Armenian composers Komitas and Alemsha, then doubled back to the 18th century and Beethoven's Serenade in D for string trio (Op. 8), all on the first half of its program.

title: ISRAEL'S UZI SUBMACHINE GUN: SALES OF A LEADING EXPORT HAVE BEGUN TO
description: SLOW By JANE FRIEDMAN

title: Queens Fire Kills Boy; Off-Duty Fireman Hurt
description: The 4-year- old son of a fireman was killed and the boy's father wascritically bu rned in a fire that swept through the family's home in Springfield G ardens, Queens, last night, authorities said.

title: For and Against No stalgia on Trains
description: Tobie Stanger extolled the virtues and nostalgia of the old passenger cars on the Hoboken-Morristown rail line (Opinion Page, Jan. 24). I would like to condemn her to 25 years on this railroad (the former Erie Lackawanna, which is now operated by NJ Transit), as many thousands are condemned.

title: ELIZABETH HICKS WILL BE MARRIED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Livingston Hicks 3d of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Stuyvesant Hicks, to Peter Matthiessen Wheelwright, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Jefferds Wheelwright of Camden, Me.

title: Free Trade
description: To the Business Editor: ''Jobs and Imports: We Can't Have Both'' (Jan. 31) by June H. Collier does little more than entreat the Government t o protect the author's company. Quite obviously the author' s company prospers as the United States automobile industry prosper s. Is it any wonder then that Mrs. Collier asks protection in the name of American patriotism? Of course not! No doubt a 20 perc ent tariff on manufactured goods, which she advocates, woul d be terrific - for her auto-parts business.

title: The 4th of 9 Escapees Is Captured in Queens
description: The fourth of nine prisoners who escaped from the State Supreme Court Building in Brooklyn last month was recaptured yesterday afternoon in an apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens, authorities said.

title: THE UNWILLING REVOLUTIONARY
The New York Times Magazine; February 7, 1982
description: William Safire 13 On Language Good Courtesanship Russell Baker 20 Sunday Observer All in the Family John Noble Wilford 22 A New Look at Dinosaurs Recent discoveries are shaking up paleontology - challenging some of our ideas about dinosaurs, their evolution and, possibly, the extinction of life itself. Richard Eder 42 Mitterand's Modes t Revolution Elizabeth de Mauny 44 The Winter Years of Nadezhda Mandelstam Michael I. Sovern 74 The Case for Keeping U.S. Aid to Colleges Marilyn Bethany 78 Design The Walls Have an Angle Terry Robards 82 Wine The Possible Dream June Weir 86 Fashion Created With a Leg to Stand On Craig Clairborne with Pierre Franey 88 Food Plugging the Leek 93 Puzzles Answers, Pag 91 110 Letters Cover: Photograph by Mark Hanauer/Visages Copyright 1982, The New York Times

title: Orioles Sign 9 Players, 3 From Arbitration List
description: Nine play ers, including three who had asked for sal ary arbitration, agreed to contracts with the Baltimore Orioles today , giving the team 28 signed members.

title: PHYSICIAN GETS $3.8 MILLION IN MALPRACTICE SUIT
description: A physician has won a $3.8 million malpractice award against two colleagues in a lawsuit charging that his daughter's paralysis resulted from improper diagnosis and treatment.

title: PRODUCER WITH A MOSTLY MIDAS TOUCH
description: His play had opened to rave reviews, his opening night party had been a smash and, in the small hours of the morning, producer Morton Gottlieb was headed home - not in a limousine, proper theatrical transport, but by subway. Why? ''I was going to take my bicycle,'' Mr. Gottlieb explains, ''but I decided to splurge.''

title: THE 25% OF 'EXPENDITURES' WASHINGTON NEVER SEES
description: The President's request for 1983 spending and revenues includes the most up-to-date compilation of more than 100 tax breaks that include something for nearly everyone - from investment tax credits for business, to exemptions for the blind, to tax deductions for mortgage interest payments by homeowners. While none involve direct exp enditures of Government funds, together they represent hundreds ofbillions of d ollars of foregone tax revenues that disproportionately benefit wealt hy individuals and businesses.

title:
Stamps;
SAYING IT WITH FLOWERS
description: A new ''Love'' stamp has been issued by the United States Postal Service, just in time to adorn this year's Valentine greetings. It may be called a lovely surprise since it was issued with virtually no advance notice. Sweethearts young and old will have to scurry to get the stamps and mail their greetings for Feb. 14. Obviously, this year no other stamp will do.

title: Albert Stable After Surgery
description: Former House Speaker Carl Albert was listed in stable condition Friday night after prostate surgery at Oklahoma Memorial Hospital, relatives said. The 73-year-old veteran Democrat was resting in the post-intensive care unit, said Mike Riley, a hospital spokesman.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Mace at Retail
description: For years, Smith & Wesson, the firearms manufacturer in Springfield, Mass., restricted sales of Chemical Mace to lawenforcement agencies. Last November the company began to test-market it at retail.

title: THE WINTER YEARS OF NADEZHDA MANDELSTAM
description: Elizabeth de Mauny has worked for Reuters and other news organizations in London and Paris. She and her husband now live in France. By Elizabeth de Mauny Once again, we took the muddy track that wove its way through a patch of dispirited bushes to one of those widely spaced apartment blocks of the new Moscow suburbs. The slight woman who received us had become so shrunken in the three years since we had last seen her that my initial reaction was shock. But once she was tucked in a blanket on the old chaise longue in her kitchen, prepared to hold court as before, I felt less alarmed. Her voice, though weaker, still had much of its resonance, and our mere presence -visitors from England - seemed to have a stimulating effect.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Poisoned Building
description: It was a simple enough fire at the outset: a smoky blaze Feb. 5, 1981, in a basement transformer of the 18-sto ry State Office Buildingin Binghamton, N.Y. The building's ventilatio n system sucked up the fumes, and before the fire was out, every off ice on every floor was sprinkled with deadly soot.

title: STRUGGLE IN SALVADOR PINCHES WASHINGTON'S 'VIETNAM NERVE'
description: WASHINGTON IN the foreign relations committee rooms, there was something hauntingly familiar about the political crossfire last week. Mistrustful wrangling over the casualty count and the reliability of press reports about faraway massacres of civilians by their government's troops. Members of Congress, protesting the brutality of an American ally and also alarmed by stepped-up guerrilla attacks, asking where it all would end. Top State Department officials contending the local military had made enough progress in curbing violence against civilians to justify sending more aid lest the regional dominoes start to fall.

title: FROM 'LITTLE MARY DECKER' TO A WORLD-CLASS STAR
description: IN 1969 I didn't know what track and field was. Running was something I did with my brother and some of his friends while playing chase games.

title: Views
description: Cartoon layout pg 2 CARTOON CAPTIONS with new deal cartoon John Branch The San Antonio E xpress-News with Jaruzelski and martial law cartoon Jim Margulies Rothco with Federal Programs baby delivery cartoon Dana Summers The Dayton Journal Herald with trickle up cartoon Bob Englehart The Hartford Courant Los Angeles Times Syndicate Views A portfolio from around the nation caption with Summers cartoon of Federal program baby delivery ''It's from the White House ...they've run out of room! ...'' ''It's from the White House ...they've run out of room! ...''

title: Sports of The Times; Majoring in Probation
description: IN and out of the ring, boxing always has been typecast as a brutal business, the ''red light district'' of sports. And it is. But boxing is almost a boys' choir now in contrast to the garbage dump that so much of college athletics has become. Call college athletics the ''green light district'' of sports now. Anything goes.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Reached agree- ment on one-year contract terms with nine players, including three who had filed for salary arbitration. Those three are Sammy Stewart and Tim Stoddard, pitch- ers, and Gary Roenicke, outfielder. The others are Dan Grah am, catcher, and five rookies, Mike Boddicker, Brooks Carey and Bill Swaggerty, pitchers, Willie Roys- ter, catcher, and Drungo Hazewood, out- fielder. CHUNICHI (Japan) - Signed Ken Macha , ou

title: David Lawrence Wilson Fiance of Charlotte Hamlin
description: Mrs. Henry Bragdon of South Dartmouth, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Charlotte Hamlin, to David Lawrence Wilson, son of Dr. Robert Wilson and the late Mrs. Ruth Wilson of Somerville, N.J. The wedding is planned in late May.

title: About Cars; AUTO INDUSTRY SHOWS ITS NEW OFFERINGS
description: THE first time I heard the magic phrase, the room was crowded and hot. It was 1980, and Philip Caldwell was talking into the microphone about Ford Motor Company's awful year. The place was Cape Canaveral, Fla. The event was Ford's year-end press conference, and the company's chairman was talking about ''pent-up demand.''

title: Home Clinic; THERE'S AN ART TO THE CRAFT OF JOINING TWO PIECES OF WOOD
description: WOOD screws create a much stronger joint than nails do when used for assembling wooden cabinets, pieces of furniture or other projects made of wood, which is why they are preferred by most serious woodworkers. Another reason many prefer screws is that they also make it possible to take joints apart when necessary without ruining any of the parts.

title: Sports of The Times; Another College Going to the Dogs
description: JUST when it seemed that major college sports could not become more sordid, a new scandal has erupted involving drugs, sex, illegal payments, forging of grades, unauthorized meals and favoritism from teachers at Sunbelt State University.

title: LAKER HOLDS FIRST MEETING WITH HIS AIRLINE'S RECEIVERS
description: Sir Freddie Laker held his first meeting with his bankrupt airline's receivers today, as thousands of his customers around the world scrambled to make alterna tiv e travel arrangements.

title: Lobby Chairs
description: To the Editor:

title: EVERYONE HAD A HARD LUCK STORY
description: SICILIAN LIVES By Danilo Dolci. Translated by Justin Vitiello. Collaborator, Madeline Polidoro. 304 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $16.50. Paper, $6.95.

title: POLAND'S COST TO THE EAST
description: While the installation of a military Government in Poland brought a sigh of relief to worried neighboring Governments in East Germany and Czechoslovakia, the economic price of suppressing the liberalization movement in Poland must be giving those allies second thoughts.

title: Joyce's Dublin
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Meyer Fiance Of Miss Pochapin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stuart W. Pochapin of Spring Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Lynn Pochapin, to Dr. Fredric B. Meyer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Meyer of Longmeadow, Mass., and Gayhead, Martha's Vineyard, Mass. The wedding is planned for May.

title: RELATIVE SENSE OF WELL-BEING MOTIVATES DONORS TO NEEDIEST
description: ''In awareness of what we have enjoyed and knowing that there are many less fortunate.'' That brief note from Sylvia F. Kruteck of S carsdale, N.Y., attachedto a check for $250, is like many messages ac companying donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The c ontrast of one's own good fortune with the hardship and misery suf fered by many others is a continuing inspiration to contributors to t he Fund.

title: SALVADOR QUESTIONING SOLDIERS ON AIR BASE ATTACK
description: Salvadoran military authorities are investigating whether air force soldiers collaborated with guerrillas in a recent attack on the Ilopango air base, according to an air force soldier who said he had been interrogated.

title: IN A 'TYPICAL' U.S. TOWN, REVOLUTIONS COME SLOWLY
description: In 1935, Robert and Helen Lynd, a husband-and-wife team of sociologists, went back to a small city they had depicted in the pioneering study, ''Middletown,'' 10 years before, to measure the changes they assumed had been wrought by the Great Depression. To a great extent, they were surprised by what they found. ''Whatever changes may have occurred elsewhere in the city's life - i n business,education, or charity,'' they wrote in ''Middletown in Transition,'' published in 1937, ''here in these big and little, clean and cluttered hou ses in their green yards, one gained that sense, always a bit startli ng to the returning visitor, of life's having gone on unaltered in one's absence.''

title: AFTER RETIREMENT, WE CHOSE TO STAY IN FLATBUSH
description: On a sunny May morning in 1953, my wife and I and our two daughters moved from a three-room apartment into our own home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Television Week
description: THE CRASH "The Day the Bubble Burst: The Social History of the Wall Street Crash of 1929," a 1979 best-selling book by Gordon Thomas and Max Morgan-Witts, documented the nationwide events that led to the fateful day of Oct. 29, 1929. NBC and 20th Century-Fox bought the film and television rights and have produced a three-hour "factual drama," "The Day the Bubble Burst," which will be broadcast Sunday on NBC beginning at 8 P.M.

title: A COMPLETE CATALOGUE OF FEMALE SUFFERING
description: BRAIDED LIVES By Marge Piercy. 441 pp. New York: Summit Books. $15.50.

title: Paula E. Welles, Banker, Fiancee
description: Paula E. Welles, an assistant vice president and loan officer in the shipping department of Citibank, N.A., and Marc A. Forlenza, manager of worldwide fuel-oil sales for Maraven of Venezuela, in Caracas, plan to be married May 15 in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: 'DEEP IN THE COALS, WE DETECTED A GLOW'
description: ONE evening my husband, Erwin, struggled through the front door with a 300-pound coal stove (in 50-pound pieces) and a triumphant smile on his face.

title: REDISTRICTING ISSUES SPLIT CITY COUNCIL
description: Members of New York's City Council, their collective and individual political futures clouded, are deeply divided over how the Council should resolve its serious legal challenges. The divisions reflect ideological, racial, legal and personal diffe rences.

title: New Fight Date
description: The World Boxing Association cruiserweight title fight between Robbie Williams of South Africa and Ossie Ocasio of Puerto Rico was rescheduled for Feb. 13, promoters announced today. The fight had been scheduled for last Saturday, but a thunderstorm forced cancellation.

title: U.S.  Explosives Expert s Digging Out Sidewinder
description: American explosives experts used jackhammers today to dig out a live United States Air Force Sidewinder air-t o-air missile embedded in the concrete floor ofa barn.

title: ADRIAN WILLIAMSON, A PIONEER IN MILITARY AVIATION, IS DEAD
description: Adrian Williamson Sr., who as a colonel in the Army Air Corps acccepted the Japanese surrender in Hong Kong at the end of World War II, has died at the age of 89.

title: Two Mayors Are Slain In Guatemala Violence
description: Two city mayors were murdered over the weekend, officials reported today. Mayor Manuel Ren Carague of Chichicastenango, 55 years old, was shot to death by unidentified assailants as he walked on a side street toward the city's main plaza where the busy Sunday marketplace was open, the national police said.

title: Thailand-Japan Bond
description: The Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand is to sign a contract here Friday with a Japanese syndicate to raise a 10 billion-yen, 8.9 percent, 12-year Samurai bond at par through private placement, the lead manager, the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, said Friday.

title: SCHOOL BOARD 3 BAFFLED BY ODD EXPENDITURES
description: Community School Board 3 on the West Side of Manhattan has been thrown into turmoil by the discovery of expenditures in recent weeks of more than $1,000 drawn on a school board account for such items as limousines, liquor and cash.

title: The Court Strippers
description: Some senators want to rewrite the old maxim that for every wrong there's a remedy. The current right-wing version is that for every right that the Federal courts recognize, there should be a law that strips the courts of the power to enforce it.

title: Civil Rights Marchers On Way to Montgomery
description: A dwindling group of civil rights activists began the second leg of a 160-mile march to Montgomery, the state capital, today to protest the convictions of two black women on charges of vote fraud.

title: THE MAKING OF A CHIEF OF STAFF, 1981
description: Late last year, as the Reagan high command was casting about for ways to gain the upper hand against its critics in 1982, the White House chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, seized on a proposal for turning back Federal programs to the states as a potential centerpiece for President Reagan's State of the Union Message.

title: A Correction:
description: W. W. Rostow's reference, in his letter published Feb. 7, to a taping session with CBS should have been dated July (not Jan.) 24, 1981. We regret the typographical error.

title: DENG SAID TO YIELD DAY-TO-DAY DUTIES
description: PEKING, Feb. 7 - Correction: February 10, 1982, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

title: THE METS' BEST HITTER
description: Dave Anderson

title: SIMONS CAPTURES CROSBY GOLF BY 2 SHOTS
description: Even when Craig Stadler appeared to be running away with the tournament today, Jim Simons maintained his patience, chipping away at the lead. He finally overtook Stadler on the back nine of the Pebble Beach Golf Links, shot a final-round 66 and won the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am by two strokes.

title: OUT OF THE PICKLE; BOSTON, Feb. 7 - The Justice Department was due to file by Jan. 11 its Supreme Court brief in two cases challenging the denial of tax exemptions to schools that discriminate on racial grounds. On Jan. 8 the brief was ready to go to the printer, approved by Justice's tax division, the Solicitor General's office and the Internal Revenue Service. But that day President Reagan reversed the Government's policy on racist schools. The brief was not filed.
description: Congressional committees looking into the change of policy obtained the draft brief, and it makes illuminating reading. It shows what Government lawyers thought about the issue before politics intervened. And I think it points a way out of the dilemma in which the Administration finds itself because of its clumsy attempt to change the rules.

title: Howard Sets Mar- k In Princeton Relay- s
description: Ed Simms of Howard held off Ed Yearwood of Morgan State to give his mile-relay team a victory at the Princeton indoor relays today at Jadwin Gymnasium. Yearwood ran the final quarter-mile in 46.6 seconds but could not overcome the lead given to Simms by Oliver Bridges, Richard Louis and David Charlton.

title: Report on Health Care Finds Pattern of Bias
description: Blacks and members of other minority groups often need health care more than whites but they generally get less care, and of lower quality, than whites, a National Academy of Sciences report says.

title: Dogdom Focusing on Westminster
description: The most prestigious canine event, the 106th Westminster Kennel Club show, opens a two-day run at Madison Square Garden this morning. The show world provided a prelude yesterday with 21 specialty events at nine sites.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE REBEL ANGELS. By Robertson Davies. 326 pages. Viking. $13.95

title: Required Reading; As Cal Put It
description: President Reagan in remarks to the Association of Independent Television Stations Jan. 27, l982: I've been kidded a few times because I now and then praise silent Cal Coolidge. He was a real communicator.

title: DANCE: 'GENEROUS SPACES,' 'FOLK SONGS' OF JULIE FRAAD
description: JULIE FRAAD'S new ''Folk Songs'' had the advantage of a glittering score by Luciano Berio, pretty peasant dresses designed by George Hudako and pert performances by three good-looking dancers - Jan Brecht, Scott Bryant and B.J. Manilla. And, the opening work on a program of new and recent dances performed on Saturday night at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, ''Folk Songs'' seemed a pleasant if extended flow of wheeling turns, falls and skips.

title: HAIG, REJECTING VIETNAM PARALLEL, REFUSES TO BAR FORCE IN CARIBBEAN
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., refusing again to rule out the use of military force in the Caribbean region, says that it is wrong to draw parallels between American involvement there and in Vietnam because Central America is at the heart of American strategic concerns.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH SECRETARY OF STATE
description: Q. There is great fascination with El Salvador and th e Caribbean right now. Could you share some idea of what is going to happen in the next few weeks?

title: Talks on Umpires To Resume Today
description: Negotiations between the umpires' association and major league baseball were scheduled to resume in Manhattan today with less than a month before the umpires are to report for spring training.

title: No Headline
description: LENDL BEATS MCENROE IN 4 SETS

title: No Headline
description: U.C.L.A. Stymies Irish Bid

title: ISRAEL TO BUILD JET FIGHTERS TO EASE RELIANCE ON U.S.
description: Israel has decided to produce its own generation of an advanced jet fighter plane, to be named the Lavie, as a way of reducing the country's dependence on aircraft purchases from the United States.

title: TV: THE YEAR ON THE HOME SCREEN
description: ''THE Third Annual TV Guide Special,'' a two-hour look at the 1981 television season tonight at 9 P.M. on NBC, is the sort program you can watch with about a third of your attention and not miss much. That's not to suggest it isn't semiworth watching, particularly if you're curious about what happens on television all year long - but only want to spend portions of two hours finding out.

title: MUSIC: SHERIFF CONDUCTS THE KIBBUTZ
description: FOLLOWING in the footsteps of its counterparts from elsewhere in the world, the Kibbutz Chamber Orchestra of Israel played in the biggest hall it could find Wednesday night, as if to second the notion that ''chamber'' somehow refers to the num ber of performers needed to pla y a piece, and not to a musical environment.

title: THOMAS S. BOYLAND, BROOKLYN LEGISLATOR AND FORMER TEACHER
description: Thomas S. Boyland, a Democratic Assemblyman from Brooklyn, died yesterday while attending a convention of black legislative leaders on Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 39 years old.

title: WHAT CAN BE WRONG WITH FOREIGN DOCTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Conference on Stage Productions Is Set
description: A how-to conference in which theatrical luminaries will discuss the legal and financial ins and outs of ''Producing for the Commercial Theater'' will be held on March 5, 6 and 7 at the Carter Theater, 250 West 43d Street.

title: MORE THAN 60 OTHERS ARE INJURED
description: Fire raged through the top two floors of a 10-story tourist hotel today, killing at least 32 people and injuring more than 60, fire officials said.

title: PRESIDENT GOING TO MIDWEST TO TEST STRENGTH
description: President Reagan will venture into the bracing 1982 election air of Minnesota, Iowa and Indiana this week, offering his theories of federalism and his record as a fund-raising attraction to a region that is critical to the hopes of his party this fall.

title: SURVEY FINDS ECONOMY STILL WEAK
description: A sampling of the opinions of purchasing managers from the nation's industrial companies indicates that the economy remained weak in January. However, the rate of decline slowed, according to the survey, taken by the National Association of Purchasing Management and released yesterday.

title: STOCKMAN DEFENDS REAGAN'S PROPOSAL AND SIZE OF DEFICIT
description: Budget Director David A. Stockman contended today that there were few acceptable alternatives to President Reagan's proposal for a $91.5 billion deficit in the budget for the fiscal year 1983. And he said Congress would be substantially responsible if the President's budget was not approved and the economy stalled.

title: SALVADOR REBELS TRY TO BLOCK ROAD
description: Rebel forces attacked Government military patrols over the weekend near the provincial capital of Usulutan, about 70 miles east of the capital, burning several trucks.

title: U.S. Concedes S ending Pensions After Deaths
description: The Government has been sending pension checks to hundreds of dead persons, including one who died 16 years ago, acco rding to a spokesman for the Federal personnel agency.

title: 6 Gulf Countries Warn Teheran on Subversion
description: Saudi Arabia and five other Arab nations warned Iran today against ''subversive actions'' in the Persian Gulf region. The warning, contained in a communique issued at the end of a twoday conference of the Gulf Cooperation Council, appeared to be in response to last December's report of an Iranian plot to overthrow the Government of Bahrain.

title: THE RIPPLES OF TOKYO'S AGRICULTURAL POLICIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Haig Says Polish Crisis Is Threatening Detente
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said tonight that the signatories to the Helsinki Final Act must view the crackdown in Poland as ''a fundamental and perhaps fatal threat'' to the entire East-West process of reconciliation worked out as a result of that 1975 agreement.

title: DECLINE AT NEW YORK RETAILERS
description: Retail sales at New York's biggest department stores fell an average of 2.8 percent in January from a year earlier, the first such decline in four years, according to a spot-check.

title: BRIEFING
description: I DLENESS is the advocates' workshop. The sudden settlement of the Government's antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company stranded a platoon of Justice Department lawyers, forcing them to decompress after years of arcane research and paper strategizing. Some of them, fearing days devoid of contention, discovered that they could program their Wang electronic word processors with Atari's Space Invaders game.

title: MEMBER OF THE BANKING FAMILY
description: Henry Sturgis Morgan, a member of the banki ng family and founding partner of Morgan Stanley & Company, the inve stment banking concern, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospi tal after a brief illness. He was 81 years old and lived in New York and Northport, L.I.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Working Group of the Ad Hoc Com- mittee on the Drafting of an Interna- tional Convention Against the Train- ing of Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BISHOP CALLS POLES 'SICK' WITH ANGER
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic primate of Poland, said today that Poland was ''sick'' and that its people were ''overcome by anger'' at events in their country.

title: EXTRA RUNWAY LIFTS VAULTER
description: Billy Olson credited a little more runway for the extra inches he was able to gain in breaking his world indoor-best mark in the pole vault Saturday night at the Portland Federal Mason-Dixon Games.

title: Sonics 99, Clippers 97
description: SEATTLE (AP) - A 20-foot jump shot by Gus Williams broke an 86-86 tie and sent Seattle on its way to victory. The victory kept Seattle a half game ahead of the Los Angeles Lakers, who won at Boston, in the Pacific Division race.

title: Lopes Says Trade To A's Is Near
description: Davey Lopes said Saturday that ''just a formality'' stands in the way of his being traded from the Los Angeles Dodgers to the Oakland A's.

title: JOHN CAEMMERER, CHAIRMAN OF STATE SENATE TRANSIT PANEL
description: John D. Caemmerer, chairman of the New York State Senate's Transportation Committee and one of the Senate's most influential and outspoken members, died of cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 54 years old and lived in East Williston, L.I.

title: Bump Wills Loses Arbitration Case
description: Bump Wills, the Texas Rangers' second basem an who apparently is losing his job to Doug Flynn, also has lost h is salary arbitration case.

title: Sadri Winner
description: John Sadri, capitalizing on his big serve and his opponent's temper tantrums, defeated Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4, in the final of the United Bank Tennis Classic today. It was the second tournament the North Carolinian had won in his three years as a pro.

title: BEANPOT: COLLEGE HOCKEY AS A SOCIAL MUST
description: BOSTON BOB BARICH, a junior at Boston University, had no idea of the magnitude of the first two Mondays in February, when four college hockey teams compete for a small silver beanpot and transform the dreariest point of the New England winter into a frantic social highlight of the year.

title: STAGE: 'METAMORPHOSIS IN MIN IATURE'
description: AS Gregor Samsa awoke one morning from uneasy dreams, he found himself transformed into the actor David Rounds. At the Cubiculo, Mr. Rounds is enacting a ''A Metamorphosis in Miniature,'' a cameo version of Kafka's nightmare vision. The performance is the most persuasive metamorphosis of man into beast since Zero Mostel turned into Eugene Ionesco's ''Rhinoceros.''

title: A Convincing Performance by 2 Strasberg Boys
description: ''Young people,'' Lee Strasberg was saying yesterday, ''should not be encouraged to go into the theater.'' That, he explained, is a decision that should be made ''when they are more conscious of the problems.'' Mr. Strasberg, who heads the Actors Studio, was explaining why his wife, Anna, said no when Ira Cirker, the director of an Actors Studio production of ''My Prince the King'' by Victor Wolfson, said that the Strasberg sons, 12-year-old Adam and 11-year-old David, would be ideal for the parts of two immigrant boys in the play.

title: Fibak Planning Visit to Poland
description: Wojtek Fibak, the professional tennis player who is probably Poland's most famous athlete, said yesterday that he would ''definitely go to Poland in the next few weeks to visit my mother, father and sister.'' They live in Poznan, where Fibak went for 10 days in December before martial law was imposed.

title: Breath of Summer Air
description: For baseball fans who can hardly wait for spring training to begin and to whom the start of the regular season in April seems decades away, a blessing has been bestowed. The Caribbean World Series in Mexico has been televised live every day since Thursday.

title: MUSIC: MICROTONAL FORAYS BEYOND THE 12-NOTE SCALE
description: ABOUT the only thing wrong with the American Festival of Microtonal Music - every new-music series has its dud pieces, so that doesn't count - is the use of the word ''festival.'' This is really a continuing series of concerts, one every few months, when the organizers assemble a program and find the time, energy and money to put it on.
