At its best, last Tuesday evening's concert at Christ and St. Stephen's Church was a valuable contribution to New York's musical life.

title: MARCH DANCE FESTIVAL TO HONOR THELMA HILL
description: A two-day festival of solos and duets will be presented March 5 and 6 by the Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center in Brooklyn in honor of the late Miss Hill.

title: REPORTS OF NUCLEAR CACHE UNSETTLE UPSTATE VILLAGE
description: It's not featured in any ''I Love New York'' promotional campaign; the Mobil Touring Guide ignores it, and Rand McNally seems to have overlooked it.

title: RISE OF VENTURE CAPITALISTS
description: Like many other new companies in the electronics industry, the Synapse Computer Corporation is being backed by venture capitalists who have given it start-up funds in return for a stake in the company.

title: GAS PRICE DECONTROL HOPES DIM
description: Prospects that the Reagan Administration will press its plan for accelerated decontrol of natural gas prices have dimmed noticeably in the past few weeks.

title: LISTING DEDUCTIONS: THE RANGE IS BROAD
description: One step in preparing tax returns that many people enjoy is completing Schedule A, where the costs of ever ything from straightening a child's teeth to the sales tax on a new car can be itemized and deducted. Last year the courts approved deductions for everything fr om hair transplants for a prematurely bald man to the cost of whisk y prescribed by a doctor to relieve angina pain. A wide variety of medical expenses, ranging from vitamin pills prescribed by a doctor to prosthetic devices for patients recovering from mastectomy, are deductible as long as the cost exceeds a certain level. The rule is that an individual can claim only those expenses that exceed a ''floor'' for total medical expenses of 3 percent of his or her adjusted gross income.

title: THEATER: SLADE'S 'SPECIAL OCCASIONS'
description: SUZANNE PLESHETTE left the New York theater for Hollywood over two decades ago, but she hasn't been wasting her time. In recent years - most notably during her six-season run as the sensible yet wooly wife on television's ''The Bob Newhart Show'' - she has been honing her considerable talent as a comic actress. This is no small feat, for television usually tends to wear down and coarsen its stars as the years roll by. But not Miss Pleshette. Though working in a medium that often prizes falseness, she became incapable of giving a performance that was anything less than honest.

title: PENSION FUNDS' INVESTMENTS OUTSIDE NEW YORK DEBATED
description: New York State's largest public-employee pension fund is committed to spending more than $760 million in the next three years to finance commercial real-estate investments outside the state, including hotels in Louisiana, Texas, California and Arizona, a land development project in Colorado and an office building in Florida.

title: STENMARK CAPTURES SLALOM FOR 3D TIME
description: Ingemar Stenmark, stung by the loss of his giant slalom title to Steve Mahre last week, skied flawlessly today to retain the world slalom championship that he first won in 1978 and then recaptured at the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: LACIURA WINS COMPETITION FOR SINGERS
description: Anthony Laciura, who rendered a song from John Philip Sousa's ''El Capitan,'' was the principal winner tonight at the National Opera Institute's competition for young singers.

title: EASING OF U.S. RULES ON AID FOR DISABLED IS SOUGHT
description: After finding that thousands of mentally and physically disabled people were losing Federal Social Security benefits as the result of stepped-up reviews of their cases, New York's Social Services Commissioner has called for basic changes in what she termed ''very stringent'' Federal eligibility requirements.

title: Stranger Tells Deputie s In Florida He Killed 1 3
description: Investigators from four states examined evidence today that could confirm a confession to a sixstate rampage possibly involving 13 slayings.

title: SCHMIDT FRUSTRATED BY REGIONAL PARTY VOTES
description: Three Social Democratic regional party conventions passed motions on security and nuclear weapons issues today that disavowed or contradicted the programs that won a vote of confidence for Chancellor Helmut Schmidt in Parliament on Friday.

title: Guard at Upstate Prison Died Of Heart Attack After Scuffle
description: An autopsy has shown that a prison guard who died after he was kicked in the groin by an inmate at the maximum-security Clinton Correctional Facility suffered a fatal heart attack, officials said.

title: FLIRTING: ELUSIVE BEHAVIOR
description: T HE glory of flirtation, aside from its undeniable pleasure as a pastime, is that it has so frustrated social scientists' attempts to study it. ''The major charm of flirtation is that it's such a very difficult behavior to study, because it's so subtle and evanescent,'' said Maury Silver, an assistant professor of psychology at Johns Hopkins University.

title: Aqueduct Racing Set Wednesday
description: Aqueduct, closed by hazardous track conditions last Thursday, is scheduled to reopen Wednesday. The announcement was made yesterday after Ogden M. Phipps, chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, met with stewards and the maintenance crew, which is putting down 3,000 tons of sand to serve as a new cushion for the inner track.

title: The Sport of Kongs
description: Whenever Pete Squires, a 31-year-old road runner from Yonkers, passes the Empire State Building in the company of friends, they invariably ask him, ''Did you really run up that thing?''

title: EXECUTIVES SEE HARD TIMES WITH HUGE BUDGET DEFICITS
description: President Reagan's 1983 budget proposal set off alarm bells in the business community over the weekend. While most business leaders said the new budget contained few surprises, many apparently had hoped for some last-minute reprieve from the projections for very large budget deficits in the next few years. Instead, the budget proposal stirred predic tions of higher interest rates, further deterioration of the economy and even talk ofthe possiblity of a financial crisis. This wa s despite the Administration's optimistic economic assumpti ons - including 5 percent economic growth in 1983 - that it sai d would help hold the 1983 budget deficit to $91.5 billion instead of the $100 billion or $150 billion predicted earlier.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IN WRITING

title: DEMOCRATS FOUNDERING IN WAKE OF CUTS
description: The all-day conference was called to discuss ''Democratic Alternatives,'' and some concrete ways of responding to President Reagan's budget-cutting policies actually did emerge. But mostly, as local Democrats convened in a Manhattan public school yesterday, there was anger, criticism, confusion, defiance and even fear.

title: NOBELIST TELLS FUTURE SCIENTISTS OF HER LIFE
description: Malcolm Murray is 12 years old, is in the seventh grade at Randolph Intermediate School in Morris County, N.J., wants very much to be a physicist and is therefore, he says, a skeptic. Mostly, he is skeptical about grown-ups.

title: NEW YORK AIDES ASSAIL U.S. CUTS IN SOCIAL SERVICE
description: As officials from the New York area began closer scrutiny of the social-service cuts proposed in President Reagan's budget, new areas of major concern began to emerge today in programs ranging from legal services to reimbursement for the protection of diplomats.

title: KEACH IN AUSTRALIAN 'ROAD GAMES'
description: ALTHOUGH ''Road Games'' was made in Australia, the Outback might as well be the New Jersey Turnpike in this new small thriller. One kangaroo crosses the road for local color and -the high point of the film - a pet dingo, a wolflike Australian canine, in the last reel turns out to be only a barking dog. Whether the beast also barks in Australian cannot be determined easily, but what is certain is that most of the actors in this little horror show speak pure Los Angeleno.

title: A Realty Tax With Soft Spots
description: The recent flap over tax valuation of cooperative apartments in New York City vindicates the market-value property tax law that the Legislature turned down. Despite the fears of homeowners that accurate appraisals would raise their t axes, the Legislature might have adopted a law requiringtaxing distri cts to appraise all properties at true market value. To protect homeo wners from drastic increases, tax rates on different properties co uld have been made dependent on their uses.

title: Shootout Leaves Clues To Slaying of Trooper
description: Two Massachusetts state troopers engaged in a shootout early this morning with two men believed to be members of a gang suspected of being involved in the killing of a New Jersey trooper in December, the authorities said today.

title: KNICKS LOSE TO BLAZERS BY 100-98
description: Calvin Natt spoiled Maurice Lucas's homecoming as a Knick tonight by making two key free throws and outjumping Lucas for the game-saving rebound as the Portland Trail Blazers scored a 100-98 victory before 12,666 fans at the Coliseum.

title: News Analysis
description: In the month since it stirred a major controversy over tax exemptions for segregationist private schools, the Reagan Administration has become increasingly entangled in a legal and political web from which there seems to be no easy or ready escape.

title: ENTERPRISE ZONES
description: Apparently uninfluenced by widespread criticism of the enterprise-zone idea, President Reagan has put forward the zones as the main initiative in his urban policy. It is either an unreasonable idea, destined to fail, or a dangerous one, destined to be a catastrophe.

title: 6,000 in Ohio Town Turn Out For 17 Tons of Free Cheese
description: More than 6,000 people turned out here to get free cheese made available by the Federal Government, and all 17 tons was gone in eight hours, officials say.

title: Dr. Virginia Drobner Is Wed to Joseph Katz
description: Dr. Virginia Brodkin Drobner, a psychiatrist, and Joseph W. Katz, who heads his own public-affairs counseling and lobbying company in Trenton, were married yesterday at the Nassau Inn in Princeton, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Howard Hersch.

title: State's Chief Judge Warns Congress
description: Proposals now before Congress that would deprive the courts of jurisdiction in areas such as abortion and busing pose a ''serious threat to judicial independence,'' according to New York State's Chief Judge.

title: IN PRAISE OF RECESSION
description: Hardly anybody has a good word for recession these days, and nobody at all expounds upon the blessings of unemployment. Whatsamatter, the sensitive reader will ask, is this man bonkers? Is he not aware of the widespread human misery reflected in 16 percent out of work in Michigan, the despair of a person who wants to work but is forced to go on the dole, the shattered dreams of entrepreneurs forced into bankruptcy?

title: CLEARING UP A BIT OF FOG
description: Since last summer, a fog impenetrable enough for a horror movie has periodically shrouded the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway near the Gowanus Canal, tying up traffic and spurring mistaken reports of smoke.

title: SMITHSONIAN FLOURISHES ON AND OFF ITS 'CAMPUS'
description: The familiar Smithsonian national attic, crammed with art works, dinosaurs, old clothes and antique airplanes,is only part of the Institution. Out of the same odd clutch of Victorian cas tles and severely mod ern galleries operates o ne of the largest and most successful culture colleges in the countr y.

title: HARVARD LESSENS RELIANCE ON S.A.T.
description: After conducting a detailed internal study, admission officials at Harvard College say that this year they are relying significantly more on achievement tests than on the Scholastic Aptitude Test, or S.A.T., the standardized ability test used to screen college applicants.

title: A Fitting Leader for St. Patrick's Day Parade
description: He was educated in Ireland and has promoted Irish culture and the Gaelic language, and now Brother Charles Quinn will preside over one of the grandest Irish celebrations of all.

title: PATHMARK OPERATOR SELECTS A PRESIDENT
description: Leonard Lieberman, 53 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Supermarkets General Corporation, the operator of the Pathmark supermarket chain in the Northeast. He succeeds Herbert Brody, 67, who continues as vice chairman and chief executive officer of the Woodbridge, N.J., company.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday Although details of President Reagan's Budget Message have already been made public, the long-awaited package goes to Capitol Hill officially at noon today. Mr. Reagan is to brief the Congressional leadership in the morning, but he won't stick around long for reaction. Following a luncheon tomorrow for all-star hockey players, he takes off on a two-day trip to sell his New Federalism to state legislators and Republican Party leaders in Des Moines, Minneapolis and Indianapolis. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. will be on the road this week, too, traveling to Madrid, Lisbon, Marrakech and Bucharest. At a conference in Madrid on East-West security and cooperation in Europe, he is expected to draw attention to the crackdown in Poland. On Capitol Hill this week, there will be plenty of controversy, beginning today when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hears the Administration's explanation for granting aid to El Salvador. Assistant Secretary of State Thomas Enders and Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Humanitarian Affairs, will be among the witnesses. 2 P.M., Room 4221, Dirksen Office Building. Perennial Question: The Senate Judiciary Committee takes up the question of gun controls and just how restrictive they should be. 10 A.M., Room 2228, Dirksen Office Building. Senatorial Question: First thing on the floor agenda this week is a hotly contested resolution that would permit radio and television broadcasts of floor activities. The House already permits such activity. 11 A.M. Budgetary Question: Beginning at 10 A.M., the Senate Armed Services Committee will open four days of hearings on how much military spending to authorize. Deputy Secretary of Defense Frank Carlucci will testify. Room 1202, Dirksen Office Building. Tuesday The House Subcommittee on Health and the Environment will consider whether Federal regulations should require that parents be notified when minors receive family planning assistance from the Government in the form of prescription drugs or devices. Secretary of Health and Human Services Richard S. Schweiker, who has proposed such regulations, will testify. 10:45 A.M. Room 2322, Rayburn Office Building. Morning Coffee: While the President is on the hustings, Nancy Reagan will be a guest this morning at the Congressional Club, an organization of current and former Congressional wives. Wednesday The Senate Subcommitte on Arms Control, Oceans, International Operations and Environment is scheduled to take another look at acid rain and its effects. 10 A.M. Room 4221, Dirksen Office Building. Youth Power: Some 200 high school students will gather in Washington for Conference II, four days of discussion on the Constitution and its amendments. White House Counselor Edwin Meese 3d is to give the opening address. Shoreham Hotel. Thursday Two days of hearings on extending the Voting Rights Act begin before Senate Judiciary Committee at 9:30 A.M. Room 2228, Dirksen Office Building. Money Men: They'll talk when the Senate Banking Committee holds its twice yearly oversight hearing on American monetary policy. Top Witness: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Paul A. Volcker. White House Diplomacy: The Reagans are to hold the first of two black-tie dinners for Ambassadors who are accredited to the United States. Holiday Time: House of Representatives recesses for Lincoln and Washington birthdays. Senate leaves tomorrow. Friday Producer prices are published. Look for continued abating of inflation rate at the wholesale level.

title: Coast Bus Plunge Kills 2
description: A school bus filled with teen-agers returning from a religious retreat swerved out of control on a steep mountain highway today and plunged over an embankment, killing a boy and a girl and injuring at leas t 24 others, the California Highway Patrol said. The bus from the First Baptist Churchof Reseda, a Los Angeles suburb, was returnin g from a weekend retreatin the San Bernardino Mountains.

title: MRS. CARNER WINS ON LINKS BY SHOT
description: JoAnne Carner struggled to a par 72 today, but held on for a one-stroke victory over Jo Ann Washam in the $125,000 Turnberry Isle Golf Classic.

title: GUITAR: ALICE ARTZT PLAYING AND EXPLAINING
description: ALICE ARTZT made a point of exposing her Merkin Concert Hall audience to a lot of little-known music for the guitar last Tuesday, claiming as New York premieres her performances of Dionisio Aguado's ''Fandango'' and Johann Kaspar Mertz's ''Fantaisie Hongroise'' and ''Liebeslied,'' and leaving open the possibility that the three selections from Giuliani she played might also be premieres.

title: CIVIL DEFENSE: A MYTH
description: United States civil defense officials, inspired by a reaffirmed Presidential directive that authorizes a new and expanded civil defense policy, are reviving dangerous and illusory assumptions about life after nuclear war.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTRODUCTION TO STATE DEPT.'S HUMAN RIGHTS COUNTRY REPORTS
description: Following are excerpts from the introduction to the 1981 Human Rights Country Reports prepared by the State Department, submitted to Congress and made public today:

title: Paper Merger Called Off
description: Officials of the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company have called off a proposed merger with the Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company. Dave Kruidenier, Register chairman, said Saturday that the Des Moines board's merger committee had voted unanimously to recommend to the full board that the merger talks be terminated. Mr. Kruidenier would not give any reasons, nor would John Cowles Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Minneapolis company.

title: 500 FETUSES FOUND BY STORAGE COMPANY IN REPOSSESSED CRATE
description: The disposal of 500 human fetuses found packed in formaldehyde in a metal storage container may have violated state abortion law, criminal investigators said today.

title: MARION S. FELDMAN
description: Marion S. Feldman, a worker in charitable a nd philanthropic causes,died at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Cente r on Saturday after a brief illness.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are confident that, with God's help, we will be able to explain to ourselves the reasons for our anger, in a dialogue, and not by force.

title: It's The One Wins Strub Stakes
description: It's The One, ridden by Walter Guerra, raced to the richest victory of his career today, capturing the $285,200 Charles H. Strub Stakes for 4-year-olds at Santa Anita.

title: N.F.L. Crossfire
description: Since 1968, the National Football League Players Association has published The Audible about 10 times a year. The magazine, sent to active and retired N.F.L. players, often presents the views of the players union in its dealing with management.

title: The Grounding of Sir Freddie
description: It was nearly dawn last Friday morning when Sir Freddie Laker, his eyes red with fatigue, his customary grin missing altogether, finally conceded defeat.

title: Chile Trade Deficit Up
description: Chile had a 1981 trade deficit of $2.6 billion compared with a $764 million deficit in 1980, a Central Bank statistical bulletin said.

title: SCIENTIFIC AMERICAN, IN AD DRIVE, STIRS DEMOGRAPHIC BATTLE
description: Neatly framed and hanging on the wall of the office is the number 1,350 -this year's target for advertising pages in Scientific American, which sold 1,134 pages last year. ''That's so I never forget what we're all about,'' said C. John Kirby, the magazine's advertising director.

title: REPORT ON GINNA PLANT SAYS STAFF ACTED 'LATE'
description: Radioactivity was released into the atmosphere during the recent nuclear accident at the Robert E. Ginna plant because operators were ''too late'' in turning off emergency pumps, according to a preliminary evaluation by a staff member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: WHAT CAN BE WRONG WITH FOREIGN DOCTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Gianettino Gains Kidde Unit's Business
description: Gianettino & Meredith, a Mountainside, N.J., agency, has just received more than $3 million in business from Victor Business Products, a Chicago-based subsidiary of Kidde Inc., which is already a client for corporate advertising.

title: EUROPE'S SILENT, PRO-AMERICAN MAJORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Leora Nussbaum, Student , Is Bride of Jonathan Kuk in
description: Leora Nussbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Nussbaum of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Jonathan Kukin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ira Kukin of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi H. Leibowitz, dean of the Rabbinical Seminary of America, performed the ceremony at the Terrace-on-the-Park restaurant in Flushing Meadow Park in Queens.

title: An App raisal
description: They are sprouting like weeds in odd corners of the Upper East Side, and at least one seems imminent on the West Side. They are not particularly large, but they are, in their own way, as destructive of the city's ambiance as the vast monoliths of midtown.

title: WEIN B ERGER WARNS OF TRADE THAT HELPS THE SOVIET UNION
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger sent a message to Congress, dated today, asserting that a major aim of national strategy should be to cut off the flow of economic resources and Western technology to the Soviet Union. He argued that this trade has been instrumental in Soviet military development.

title: FRENCH PARTY AFFIRMS PRO-SOVIET STAND
description: France's Communist Party wound up its 24th annual congress this weekend with a series of widely expected decisions that reaffirmed its pro-Soviet stance and its support for the military crackdown in Poland.

title: A Roundup Of Account Activity
description: Last week ended with a lot of activity in the account area. George Lois, who once helped contribute the Pontiac Choirboys to local advertising legend, now has the opportunity to make a similar contribution.

title: Canadian Index Falls
description: Statistics Canada's l eading economic indicator fell in November for the fifth cons ecutive month, the Government agency said. The decline in the ke y gauge of future economic activity suggests that a recovery fr om the current recessionis not imminent, although there are signs tha t the recession may losesome of its momentum in the first quarter of 1982, the agency added in its announcment Friday. The composite lead ing indicator, which hasa base of 100 for 1971, fell to 128.41 in Nov ember from 132.21 in October.

title: COSTA RICA ELECTS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Luis Alberto Monge, a former union organizer and longtime friend of American labor leaders, swept to victory in today's Costa Rican presidential election, taking well over half the votes in a crowded field of six candidates.

title: Profit Up 31.6% At Halliburton
description: The Halliburton Company reported that net income in the fourth quarter increased 31.6 percent, to $184.1 million, or $1.56 a share, from $139.9 million, or $1.19, in the corresponding 1980 quarter.

title: N.J. Police Acted In Racing Inquiry
description: The New Jersey State Police rigged at least one thoroughbred race at Atlantic City Race Course last year in an undercover operation that included the Meadowlands track in East Rutherford, The Newark Star-Ledger reported yesterday.

title: Commodities; The Future Of Market Monitor
description: THE Commodity Futures Trading Commission is preparing to face its moment of truth on Feb. 23, when Congress begins hearings to determine whether the regulatory agency should exist after its Federal mandate expires Sept. 30.

title: UPSET OF MISSOURI CHEERS NEBRASKA
description: After Nebraska's stunning 67-51 upset of top-ranked Missouri Saturday night, Jack Moore, the Cornhuskers' 5-foot-9-inch senior point guard, said he wouldn't realize the full impact of the victory for some time.

title: VERMONT WILL VOTE ON ARMS RESOLUTION IN ITS TOWN MEETINGS
description: Nuclear weapons will share the agenda with snowplows and school budgets in more than 60 percent of Vermont's municipalities on Town Meeting day next month.

title: EX-MEDIC SAYS ARMY KEPT FALSE RECORDS ON RADIATION
description: A former Army medic, breaking 25 years of silence, said today that he was ordered to enter false data to hide the fact that soldiers at four atomic tests in 1956 and 1957 were exposed to dangerously high levels of radiation.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: On an attempted field goal in professional football, the ball goes through the uprights, untouched by any player, after having bounced once on the ground. Does the field goal count?

title: PRINCESS MARGARET: ANOTHER CHAPTER IN A ROYAL STORY
description: Having spent most of her life playing the role of the royal family's most celebrated black sheep, Princess Margaret is settling into a far less controversial middle age.

title: Washington Watch; Services Gain Lobbying Arm
description: WASHINGTON WHAT do bankers, accountants, lawyers, doctors, retailers, insurance agents, data processors, engineers, stockbrokers and advertising representatives have in common? They are all part of that heterogeneous grouping known as the services industry.

title: Perry Didn't Invent Violence
description: IT took Don Perry 51 years to reach the major league of hockey and only two week s more for him to get in trouble. He was suspended for six games for ordering Paul Mulvey to leave the bench and join in a fight. Perry says ''I'm no different from most other hockey coaches,'' an d he is more right than wrong - even though his minor league teams did have a history of brawling. As National Hockey League offici als gather in Washington for the All-Star Game tomorrow night, they w ould be making a grave mistake by regarding Perry as an isolated prob lem fresh from the minor leagues.

title: WHEN A PERSON'S RIGHT THREATENS HIS LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: MORRIS SPECTOR, 79, JUSTICE FOR 23 YEARS ON NEW YORK COURT
description: Morris E. Spector, a justice of New York State Supreme Court for 23 years, died Saturday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 79 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arkla Inc., Little Rock, Ark., has elected B.E. Harrell president of the Arkla Exploration Company subsidiary and Jim Wilhite president of the Arkla Industries subsidiary.

title: CHAMBER CONCERT: BRISCO QUIN TET
description: THE Brioso Quintet exhibited many of the qualities we can now take for granted in young chamber groups late Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall: it was accurate, energetic and well trained in repartee.

title: ISLANDERS CAPTURE 9TH STRAIGHT
description: The Islanders ran their club-record winning streak to nine games tonight by defeating the Buffalo Sabres, 7-3, at Memorial Auditorium. It was the sixth consecutive loss for the Sabres and the first time they had dropped two home games in a row since February 1979.

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE TYPICAL SAUDI DRIVER
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn to Add Garbage Facility
description: The city has started construction of a Brooklyn facility where garbage trucks will dump refuse into barges for transfer to a Staten Island landfill, officials said yesterday.

title: Egyptian Arms Aide in Israel
description: Lieut. Gen. Ab@drab el-Nabi Hafez, Chief of Staff of the Egyptian armed forces, began a five-day visit to Israel today. It was the first visit by an Egyptian commander to Israel, although Israeli Chiefs of Staff have visited Egypt several times. General Hafez was received by his Israeli counterpart, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, and later called on Defense Minister Ariel Sharon.

title: Flames 8, Leafs 2
description: Guy Chouinard had two goals and three assists to pace Calgary.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1982
description: International Human rights conditions are declining in Central America and several African nations, the Reagan Administration said in its first report to Congress on human rights worldwide. Rights violations in El Salvador by both left and right continued to be numerous, but ''there was a downward trend in political violence,'' the report said. The Soviet Union's activities in Afghanistan and Poland were sharply criticized. Taiwan, Zaire and South Africa also made a poor showing. (Page A1, Column 4.) The use of military force in the Caribbean region was again not ruled out by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. In an interview he said that it was wrong to draw parallels between American involvem ent there and Vietnam because Central America was at the heart of American strategic concerns. However , Mr. Haig said that ''there are no current plans'' for the use of American forces. (A1:2-3.)

title: RUNOFF VOTE SET FOR NEW ORLEANS
description: Mayor Ernest N. Dutch Morial has been forced into a runoff in his bid for re-election, marking the first time this century that an incumbent elected Mayor here has faced such a struggle for political survival. The runoff election will be held March 20.

title: PENTHOUSE LIBEL TRIAL IS ENTERING 11TH WEEK
description: The $490 million libel suit brought by the California resort La Costa against Penthouse magazine will enter its 11th week tomorrow in Superior Court here. It has generated 43 volumes of trial transcript, containing more than 9,500 pages of testimony and argument, but only now, according to lawyers on both sides, is it getting to the heart of the case.

title: LAKERS TOP CELTICS AFTER TRAILING BY 20
description: Larry Bird drew the loudest cheer today from the sellout crowd of 15,320 in Boston Garden when his 55-foot shot dropped through the net in the second quarter against the Los Angeles Lakers. But the ball was not in play and the basket did not count, and that was the type of day it was for Bird, the Celtic forward who had only 11 points, more than 13 below his average.

title: PLAN CASTS DOUBTS ON ABORTION AID
description: Among the many issues raised by President Reagan's ''new federalism'' is the future of Medicaid-financed abortions. Supporters of the right of choice on abortion say they fear that sweeping realignment of governmental responsibility for health and social services could spell the end of the Medicaid abortion program, which has already been sharply reduced. Opponents of abortion contend that the plan would serve as a helpful step on route to the abolition of abortion.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA FOUND TO REGRESS ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: The Reagan Administration, in its first report on human rights around the world, said today that the situation was deteriorating in Central America and several African nations.

title: WITH ICE CREAM AND DETERMINATION, ST. PAUL CELEBRATES LIFE BELOW ZERO
description: By 11 A.M., the winds had slowed to a mere breeze, the sun was bright and the temperature had risen sharply to 7 degrees below zero Fahrenheit.

title: CALL THEM 'MOBY-DICK' ENTHUSIASTS
description: ''Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon,'' Herman Melville urged in ''Moby-Dick.'' ''Go from Corlears Hook to Coenties Slip and from thence, by Whitehall, northward. What do you see?''

title: WEINBERGER SAYS OUTLAY IS NEEDED
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said tonight that it would be a ''tragic mistake'' to cut military spending planned for 1983.

title: BATAAN DEATH MARCH SURVIVOR
description: Services were held Friday for Col. Edgar Harland Keltner, believed to have been the oldest survivor of the Bataan Death March of World War II.

title: 4,500 BUILDINGS TO LOSE RENT SUBSIDIES
description: About 4,500 apartment houses in New York City will be dropped from rent-stabilization rolls this week because their owners failed to pay dues to the group that represents them, the organization said yesterday. Under the l aw, apartments in these buildings, which account for more than 9 p ercent of those on the group's rolls, would now come under rent co ntrol.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1982; The Economy
description: The Administration cautioned Congress that lawmakers would have to bear the responsibility if the President's budget were not approved and the economy faltered as a result. In issuing the warning, David A. Stockman, the budget director, said there were few acceptable alternatives to the President's budget plans. (Page A1.).

title: WESLYAN TO BAR SOME POOR BECAUSE OF REDUCED U.S. AID
description: Wesleyan University, in response to proposed cuts in Federal student aid, is ending an admissions policy that did not consider student a bili ty to pay. The school will now reject some students who cannot afford the full tuition.

title: A Royal Turnout for a Luxembourg Bride
description: It was another of those royal gatherings, this time in Luxembourg, where Princess Marie-Astrid, daughter of Grand Duke Jean and Grand Duchess Josephine-Charlotte, was married Saturday to Christian of Hapsburg-Lorraine, a Brussels banker.

title: OILERS SNAP RANGERS' UNBEATEN STREAK AT 6 WITH 8-4 TRIUMPH
description: The Edmonton Oilers pummeled Ed Mio, the Ranger goalie, with 43 shots tonight, and eight of them went in the net as the Oilers turned Mio's homecoming into a defeat that left the goalie near tears and broke New York's unbeaten streak at six games.

title: JOHN REED A SOVIET SCREEN HERO, TOO
description: AS if the Kremlin had resolved to retrieve one of its heroes for its own, film makers are putting the finishing touches to a Soviet version of the tumultuous life of John Reed, the American journalist whose involvement in the Bolshevik revolution is depicted in Warren Beatty's ''Reds.''

title: HOLDEN CAULFIELD'S NEW YORK
description: There have been a lot of reasons to think about J.D. Salinger's ''Catcher in the Rye'' lately. The book's 30th anniversary last year was unexpectedly marked on the front pages rather than in book reviews. The young man who shot John Lennon was reading ''Catcher,'' his Bible, when arrested. Almost every obituary for the Biltmore Hotel remembered Holden Caulfield, who ''sat down on one of those leather couches right near the clock in the lobby and watched the girls.''

title: 7 African Aides Draft P lan for Western Sahara
description: Seven African foreign ministers have drafted a cease-fire plan for Western Sahara involving troops from the United Nations and the Organization of African Unity, O.A.U. sources said today.

title: CHEESE PROGRAM HITS DELIVERY SNAG
description: New York State's program for the distribution of surplus cheese under the Federal Government's nationwide program was scheduled to begin today, but many agencies in New York City, where most of the state's needy live, said they were still awaiting the state's approval to participate.

title: Penguins Lose Goalie to Sabres
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins have lost the goaltender Paul Harrison, through waivers, to the Buffalo Sabres, according to the Penguins' general manager, Baz Bastien.

title: LET LATIN AMERICA BE LATIN AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: POWER AUTHORITY ISSUE
description: This week's largest new bond issue is in the tax-exempt sector, where the Washington Public Power Supply System plans to sell at least $500 million of new AAA-rated bonds to finance construction of three nuclear power plants.

title: VIOLIN: NAUMBURG WINNER
description: WHEN Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, winner of the Naumburg International Violin Competition for 1981, played the Tchaikovsky concerto at Carnegie Hall several weeks ago, she was almost undone by her own exuberance. Saturday night in recital at Alice Tully Hall, a different tale was told. Here Miss Salerno-Sonnenberg's hot blood flowed smoothly and confidently.

title: FORMER CHANCELLOR GETS GULF STATES UTILITIES POST
description: After spending 18 years in academia and a year in industry, Paul W. Murrill, 47 years old, will join the Gulf States Utilities Company as chairman and chief executive officer. He succeeds W. Donham Crawford, who is retiring for medical reasons from the Beaumont, Tex., electric utility at the age of 58. Norman R. Lee, 57, will remain president and chief operating officer.

title: Chrysler Adds To Rebate Plan
description: The Chrysler Corporation joined its major competitors today in offering rebates of up to $2,000 on certain car and truck models.

title: SAUDIS MAY CURB OIL OUTPUT
description: Saudi Arabia, confronted by sharply declining oil prices and a substantial excess in world supplies, may be ready to make deep cuts in its oil production.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Thursday incorrectly identified the departing French Ambassador. He is Francois deLaboulaye.

title: News Analysis
description: When they wax rhetorical, members of the dominant Afrikaner group in South Africa still tend to sound biblical. So, in prescribing what the country must do to counter what they call a ''total onslaught'' against it by the Soviet Union and other purveyors of ''devilish ideologies,'' a judicial commission of inquiry declared last week that the time had come ''for us to gird our loins for the struggle now upon us.''

title: GIMBELS V. GIMBEL: A MERCHANT DEFENDS HIS NAME
description: This time of year, with the tourists gone, the shelves are empty in the Gimbel & Sons Country Store. The heat has been turned off, and snow frosts the dock out the back door that in warmer days disgorges sailors coming in to shop.

title: SHORT TERM RATES STRENGTHEN
description: The credit markets are full of analysts with cogent, sensible reasons why i nterest rates should be lower this year than last. They are also full of analysts who look at the same economic data and cometo the opposi te conclusion - that interest rates will rise.

title: 9 Kurds Executed in Iran
description: Nine Kurdish guerrillas have been executed in the northwest city of Sanandaj after being found guilty of armed rebellion, the Islamic Republic newspaper in Teheran reported today. It did not say when the nine were executed.

title: Checks and Balances
description: The National Basketball Association, an organization whose appeal and integrity rest heavily on statistical accuracy and expert timing, is endeavoring to make sure that the courtside officials in charge of such details are competent to handle their assignments.

title: Young & Rubicam Wins Hall mark Card Account
description: Young & Rubicam has emerged as the victor in the hard-fought, lengthy competition for the advertising account of Hallmark Cards, which has been estimated at about $15 million.

title: More Taxis, by Another Name
description: Where have all the taxis gone? On radio call. It's never been easy to hail a taxi at rush hour in New York. Now, with a greater proportion of cabs committed to more lucrative radio service, it has become almost impossible. That is why the creation of the Fugazy Express, an unmetered car service that will compete head-to-head with taxis for radio calls, is so welcome.

title: SOVIET CALLS ROOSEVELT A SAINT, REAGAN A HYPOCRITE
description: Soviet authorities have marked the centenary of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's birth with perhaps the most elaborate commemoration that they have ever a ccorded an American political figure.

title: BALLET: EGLEVSKY PERFORMS VILLELLA'S NEW 'HARLEQUIN'
description: THE real pleasure that the Eglevsky Ballet provided on Friday night was that of seeing good dancing and at least one fine familiar ballet. There was also a premiere on the program at Hofstra University's John Cranford Adams Playhouse in Hempstead, L.I. But its dancing was of greater interest than its choreography.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; 6 Tourists Describe Abduction by Guerrillas

title: No Headline
description: Rockets Win; Malone Has 47

title: Mugabe Cites Discovery Of Arms on Nkomo Farm
description: The Government announced Saturday that a huge cache of arms had been found on a farm owned by the party of Joshua Nkomo, and Prime Minister Robert Mugabe was quoted today as saying that the discovery indicated that the party planned to seize the Government.

title: Bridge: In Europe, Americans See Some Differences in Game
description: Those accustomed to American tournament play who then move to Europe find that the game is different in several major respects. Some of these were reported recently by Rudy and Rose Pick, formerly of Metuchen, N.J., and now living in The Hague.

title: No Headline
description: Flyers Win on Late Rally, 5-4

title: Mary McCarthy's Triumphant Return to Vassar
description: Thomas Wolfe, after writing about his friends and kin around Asheville, N.C., was so shaken by their outrage that he concluded - as the title of one of his books states - ''You Can't Go Home Again.'' It would seem Mary McCarthy hasn't encountered a similar problem.

title: Marketplace; Speculation In Utility Stock
description: COMMONWEALTH EDISON and its underwriter believe that a speculator attempted unsuccessfully to manipulate the company's stock just before the pricing of a 10 million-share secondary offering last Wednesday.

title: MICHAEL C. O'BRIEN SR.
description: Michael C. O'Brien Sr., founder and former president of M. C. O'Brien Inc., a real-estate company in Brookl yn and on Long Island, died Friday at St. Johnland Nursing Home in K ings Park, L.I. Mr. O'Brien, who lived in Brooklyn and Garden Cit y, L.I., was 96 years old.

title: BOSTON OPERA: 'DIE SOLDATEN' HAS U.S. PREMIERE
description: Sarah Caldwell is honor ed for her labors of love, for American premieres of operas that no one else will touch, at least not until she has shown the way. Unfort unately, while love may insure a loving performance, it does not guar antee a good performance.

title: NEW HEAD OF XTRA SEES IMPROVED SECOND HALF
description: William D. Evans, 34 years old, a former professional basketball player, has been appointed president of the Xtra Corporation, a transportation leasing company based in Boston. He succeeds Charles F. Kaye, 54, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: NETS DOWN CAVALIERS, 110 TO 94
description: There are certain games a basketball coach would like to preserve forever. Larry Brown, the Nets' coach, said the 110-94 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight was one of them.

title: QUIET KEN GRIFFEY TAKES HIS PLACE
description: CINCINNATI KEN GRIFFEY eased his Mercedes 380-SEC along the interstate, crossed fr om Kentucky into Ohio and peered into the future. Here he was, the quie t man of the Cincinnati Reds, sitting in his quiet car, headed for hi s home in the quiet suburbs of a quiet city. And, down the road? A n ew life as the right-field replacement for the unquiet Reggie Jackso n on the decidedly unquiet New York Yankees.

title: Advertising; Another Change At J.W.T.
description: IN another major management change, Walter J. O'Brien, head of the Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., will be moving east to become president of the company, replacing Greg Bathon, who has resigned the post.

title: A HEYDAY FOR COMPETITIVE FISHING
description: ONCE regarded as an essentially contemplative endeavor perhaps overlaid with the desire to refine one's angling skills as a meal or two was gathered, much sport fishing is now enmeshed in the same razzle-dazzle one finds in organized athletic encounters.

title: General Foods Issue
description: The General Foods Corporation said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the public offering of $150 million principal amount of notes due Feb. 1, 1989. The issue, managed by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., Goldman, Sachs and Compa ny and Salomon Brothers Inc., is expected to be offe red in the near future, the company said.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Steve Trout, pitcher, won arbitration ruling on salary; Bill Almon, infielder, and Bobby Molinaro, outfielder, lost arbitration rulings.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: WHEN the Westinghouse Science Talent Search announced last month that students from New York City's Bronx High School of Science and Stuyvesant High School had won 38 of its 400 nationwide awards, once again the spotlight was put on the role of elite public schools.

title: KAISER STEEL POST S $513.8 MILL ION LOSS
description: The Kaiser Steel Company said yesterday that it lost $513.8 million in the fourth quarter of last year in contrast to a profit of $73.9 million, or $10.50 a share, in the similar period of 1980. Sales were down 12.8 percent, to $227.5 million, from $261 million.

title: DelBello Delivers State of the County
description: WHITE PLAINS (UPI) - Westchester County Executive Alfred B. Del-Bello delivered his State of the County address yesterday to members of the County Board of Legislators.

title: NO NEWS IS BAD NEWS
description: If a major museum or ballet company that had been a part of New York life for over 60 years was in economic trouble and in danger of closing, one could reasonably expect a community hue and cry.

title: Celanese Off 10.3% in Period
description: The Celanese Corporation reported that net income in the fourth quarter dropped 10.3 percent, to $35 million, or $2.18 a share, from $39 million, or $2.64 a share, in the 1980 period. Sales slipped 3.2 percent, to $884 million, from $913 million.

title: VON BULOW MAID ALTERS STORY ON DISCUSSION ABOUT DIVORCE
description: Maria Schrallhammer, the chief prosecution witness in the case charging Claus von Bulow with trying twice to kill his wife, Martha, admitted today to having said something different in her testimony than she had said to a Rhode Island grand jury last May.

title: Bridge: Head of World Federation Proves Mettle in Bermuda
description: As one might expect, the president of the World Bridge Federation, Jaime Ortiz-Patino of Switzerland, does a great deal of traveling. Last month he was in Bermuda for the popular annual regional tournament there.

title: NEW YORK STATE'S INVITATION TO A 'WEALTH DRAIN'
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTHUR H. STEIN
description: Arthur H. Stein, former administrative attorney and hearing officer of the Parking Violations Bureau in Manhattan, died Sunday of a heart attack.

title: Swiss Executive Plane Is Hit By Guerrilla Fire Over Beirut
description: A Swiss executive jet was hit by Palestinian antiaircraft fire aimed at Israeli planes over Beirut today and made an emergency landing, the state radio reported.

title: U.S. AND BONN REACH TROOP PACT
description: After more than two years of negotiations, the United States and West Germany have agreed on a program aimed at increasing the effectiveness of American units that would be flown here at a time of crisis or war.

title: Bonn Military Spending Up
description: West Germany said today that it increased military spending by a real 3.4 percent last year. It said that within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization the rate of increase was second only to that reported by the United States.

title: Commodity Price Drop
description: Commodity prices fell to a 21-year low in 1981, threatening recent modest economic growth in the third world, an official of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development said today.

title: S.& P. Raises Rockwell Ratings
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said it had raised the ratings on senior debt of the Rockwell International Corporation, a major defense contractor that was recently awarded a contract to build 100 B-1 bombers, to double-a from double-a-minus.

title: MINE WORKERS DELAY WALKOUT PROTESTING CUTS IN SAFETY FUNDS
description: Leaders of the United Mine Workers today delayed a threatened national walkout to protest increasing coal mine fatalities after receiving assurances from the Reagan Administration that financing for the Federal mine safety enforcement program would be restored to 1980 levels.

title: AN ACTOR TAKES THE DIRECT APPROACH
description: Like many in the theater, John Rubinstein has always had his special ambitions. And since his student days at the University of California at Los Angeles, the 35-year-old actor said the other day, his goals have been to play ''just about any role in Chekhov'' and to direct.

title: MR. REAGAN'S COURSE: STEADY - AND MISGUIDED
description: In contrast to Jimmy Carter's fast and frequent economic turnabouts, there's a certain allure to President Reagan's decision to hold to the course he set last year. "Our task is to persevere; to stay the course; to shun retreat," he says in his annual budget message. But steadfastness does not impart wisdom. The course Mr. Reagan urges once more upon the national may be consistent, but it is also dangerous, wasteful and even cruel.

title: MASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JACLYN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4 percent stock divd paid in June

title: U.S. Warhead Defused In West German Barn
description: United States demolition experts defused the damaged warhead of a Sidewinder missile today that was lost a week ago from an F-15 jet fighter.

title: Public Services; Litter Bearers
description: New York's City Hall, which last year cut down on water waste with a clever conservation plan, will now try to persuade people to litter less loosely. Hope for the campaign hangs on the proposition that people don't really like dirt.

title: ECONOMISTS VOICE DOUBTS ON BUDGET
description: Several conservative economists who are members of President Reagan's Economic Advisory Board expressed reservations today about various aspects of the President's 1983 budget, particularly the projected deficits.

title: Coast Guard Keeps Band at Academy
description: The United States Coast Guard reversed two planned budget cuts yesterday, allowing its band to remain at the service's academy in New London, Conn., and keeping the research vessel Evergreen in service.

title: Jet Record-Setter
description: The world seemed just a bit smaller yesterday thanks to a couple of helicopters, a British Airways Concorde and David Springbett.

title: CONCERN VOICED OVER 'NEW FEDERALISM'
description: At least two Cabinet members have privately expressed misgivings about President Reagan's ''new federalism,'' and their concerns tend to diminish the prospects for Congressional approval of his proposals.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANHEUSER-BUSCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BANK SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating loss...C-Net loss

title: PUBLISHER LED IN MANY FIELDS
description: John Hay Whitney, master of one of the great American fortunes and a pace-setting leader in a kaleidoscope of fields, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Heat From Meditation
description: Many skeptics might doubt that a person in a cold room could raise the temperature of his fingers and toes several degrees through meditation.

title: The Talk of Palmdale
description: From the spacious divided freeway that swoops across the bare Mojave Desert to the town of Palmdale, it's obvious that somebody had big plans. One of several nascent condominium projects catches the eye in the wide-open spaces. And over there are a bright new City Hall and Cultural Center in the ''early California'' a dobe style. And finally,the apple of the local eye, a sprawling aircr aft assembly building that Lockheed Aircraft planted in the desert a decade ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A $250 billion deficit over the next three years is totally unacceptable.'' - Senator Dan Quayle, Republican of Indiana. (B14:4.)

title: BRITAIN CUTS PRICE OF NORTH SEA OIL AS GLUT CONTINUES
description: Britain cut prices of its North Sea oil by $1.50 a barrel today, to $35. The cut, a little over 3 cents a gallon, reflected the surplus of oil in world markets and was the biggest by a major oil-producing nation since the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries unified its crude oil price structure last October.

title: EXPOSURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Bowie Faces Choice
description: Sam Bowie, the 7-foot-1-inch junior center who was expected to be the mainstay of Kentucky's basketball team but who instead has been on the sidelines all season because of a stress fracture in his shin, says a decision will be reached by tomorrow whether he will rejoin the Wildcats or be red-shirted until next autumn. ''There's not too many games left on the schedule,'' he said, ''so I'll have to make a decision one way or the other.

title: HIS HOMETOWN NOW LIKES JOHN STEINBECK BETTER
description: JOHN STEINBECK died in 1968 at the age of 66. Had he lived, he would be celebrating his 80th birthday in a few weeks. The Salinas Valley, where the Nobel Prize-winning novelist was born and raised, and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures are celebrating it for him.

title: D'AMATO AND KEAN, 2 SUPPORTERS OF REAGAN, ASSAIL HIS BUDGET PLAN
description: Two Republican supporters of President Reagan - Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York - attacked his proposed budget yesterday as one that cared more for the military than for people.

title: THE CONFLICTS IN GUATEMALA-PRESENT AND PAST
description: To the Editor:

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results reflect FIFO accounting

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for fiscal 1981 include extraordinary tax credits of $179,984 or 7 cents a shr for the qr and $293,530 or 11 cents a shr for the 6 mos; shr earnings and shrs outstndg are fully diluted

title: PAUL BLYE
description: Paul Blye, a former mayor of Chatham Township and Rutherford, died Sunday at Overlook Hospital.

title: Pacers' Owner Blocked
description: Sam Nassi, the principal owner of the Indiana Pacers, said yesterday that pressure from his other business interests had led him to transfer the team presidency to a minority partner, Frank Mariani. But the National Basketball Association stepped in quickly, reminding Nassi that a transfer of managerial control required league approval. Further, it said, approval in this case will not be pro forma, because of reports that Mariani has business ties with Jerry Buss, owner of the Los Angeles Lakers, and therefore may be engaged in a conflict of interest as the Pacers' chief administrative officer.

title: Bond Prices Decline Sharply; 6-Month Bills Bring 13.93%
description: Prices for notes and bonds fell sharply yesterday, reflecting concern that proposed Federal budget deficits of $91.5 billion in the fiscal year 1983 and $275 billion over the next three years dim prospects for lower interest rates.

title: PUG FAILS IN BID FOR A 2D BEST
description: The top-winning dog of 1981, Ch. Dhandy's Favorite Woodchuck, failed last night in his quest for a second straight Westminster Kennel Club best in show at Madison Square Garden.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashland Coal, Huntington, W.Va., has named Paul F. Goad Jr. senior vice president of operations, and he remains president of Addington Brothers Mining, a subsidiary.

title: FORT HOWARD PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IN CHINA, THE LOSS OF GRAIN PRODUCING LAND HAS OFFICIALS WORRIED
description: The Chinese Government is apparently becoming anxious that the continuing loss of vital grain-producing acreage to cash crops and urban spread could impair the nation's ability to feed its population of nearly a billion people.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A gunman trying hold up a Brooklyn candy store at 1195 Halsey Street in the Bushwick section fatally shot the owner in the chest and escaped. The victim, identified as Miguel Montalvo, 40 years old, of 526 Wilson Avenue, was taken to Wyckoff Hospital, where he died shortly after the 3:30 P.M. shooting. ... A two-alarm apartment fire at 10 A.M., apparently not suspicious, severely burned Mario Lanyato, 37, and his wife, Anlinto.

title: N.F.L. Appeals for Shift
description: The National Football League asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit today to overrule a judge's decision that denied the league's request for a change of venue for the retrial of the Oakland Raiders' suit against it. Judge Harry Pregerson had ruled that the retrial of the antitrust suit, brought by the Raiders and the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission, should remain in Los Angeles. In the original trial the jury could not reach a unanimous verdict.

title: WHY ARE BLACKS LESS SUICIDE PRONE THAN
description: WHITES? By JOSEPH WILLIAMS

title: BOSTON U. WINS BEANPOT
description: Boston University, using strong forechecking to bottle up Boston College, won its 12th Beanpot hockey tournament championship, 3-1, before 14,693 at Boston Garden tonight.

title: California Court Rejects 'Adults-Only' Housing
description: Landlords may not refuse to rent apartments solely because the applicants have young children, the California Supreme Court ruled today.

title: AMDISCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains from discontinued operations of $27,000 for the latest first qr and $97,000 for the yr ago first qr

title: Gretzky on Violence
description: Wayne Gretzky, the high-scoring star of the Edmonton Oilers, thinks that physical force is necessary to hockey, ''but not goons whose only talent is bashing heads.''

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $42,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Pentecostals in Soviet Get 2d Room at Embassy
description: Two families of Pentecostalists who have lived for three and a half years in a cramped basement room of the United States Embassy moved into a second room today, doubling their living space.

title: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
THE PLEASURE
description: Just a few short months ago, Richard V. Allen was invited e verywhere. On any give n night, Mr. Allen, then President Reagan's national security advi ser, could be seen chatting with diplomats on Embassy Row, sipping cocktails at the Georgetown Club or tossing off bon motsat chic priva te dinners. If Mr. Allen told a joke, funny or not, his listeners would often collapse in giggles. If he began a sentence w ith, ''As the President said today . . .'', a hush would fall over th e other guests.

title: A PAGE-TURNER FROM PIANIST'S MEMORY
description: In traveling the concert trail, musicians love to trade stories about the hardships they encounter, such as ill-tuned pianos, lost music and missed plane connections.

title: JOCKEYS' DEFENDERS PONDER ENTRAPMENT
description: Attorneys for the three jockeys who have pleaded not guilty to charges of fixing thoroughbred races at the Meadowlands last fall said yesterday that they are strongly considering a defense based on New Jersey state laws against entrapment by law-enforcement officers.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Michiko Kakutani PURSUITS OF HAPPINESS. The Holly- wood Comedy of Remarriage. By Stan- ley Cavell. 283 pages. Harvard Univer- sity Press. $17.50.

title: CITY ANNOUNCES MEASURES TO FIGHT TRANSIT CRIME
description: City officials, faced with growing concern about transit crime, announced a series of measures yesterday designed, they said, to reassure people about using bus and subway lines.

title: NEW LEADER IN COSTA RICA
description: From the moment he lost Costa Rica's presidential election in 1978, Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez began planning his comeback, increasingly confident that a powerful party machine and disillusionment with the administration would insure his victory this year. By the time the polls opened Sunday, it was apparent that the strategy had worked. Mr. Monge's campaign had been cautious almost to the point of dullness, but his National Liberation Party had recovered its traditional domination of Costa Rican politics. The unpopularity of the right-of-center President, Rodrigo Carazo Odio, had reached t he point that he was even heckled when he went to vote.

title: Marathon Cuts Oil Offer
description: The Marathon Oil Company today reduced the price it pays for most high-quality oil by $1, to $34 a barrel. The company said it would pay $34.35 a barrel for south Louisiana high-quality crude, down 65 cents, and $33 a barrel for west Texas low-quality crude, down $1.

title: Touring Cuban Theater To Appear April 23
description: Teatro Escambray, a 12-year-old Cuban theater, will tour North America in April.

title: BROADWAY AT 57TH: HIROSHIMA
description: Picture Three Mile Island at 57th Street and Broadway. Unless restrained by a district court order tomorrow in a suit brought by New York City, the Federal Department of Transportation is to issue new regulations Thursday that override New York restrictions and direct that highly radioactive nuclear fuel be shipped by truck on interstate highways. Since 1977, the city has banned such shipments from its streets. More than 200 local governments followed suit. The department, in pre-empting ordinances to standardize a patchwork quilt of local regulations, is increasing the hazard to people across America.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-net loss after an extraordinary writeoff of $5,889,000 for the qr and 6 mos

title: ELECTRONIC ASSOCIATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $417,000 for the qr and $889,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $341,000 for the qr and $1,246,000 for the yr

title: Whittaker in Court Defeat
description: The Whittaker Corporation lost a bid in court today to head off a possible attempt by the Brunswick Corporation to sell its profitable and fast-growing medical-equipment manufacturing business.

title: NEW HEAD IS NAMED AT M-G-M
description: Frank Rothman, a top Hollywood lawyer for the entertainment industry, w as named today to head a reorganized Metro-Goldwyn -Mayer Film Company, one of the nation's oldest movie makers. The a ppointment was interpreted in the industry as a vote of no confidence in M-G-M's two top executives, Frank E. Rosenfelt and David Begelma n.

title: Sentencing Put Off In Williams Case
description: The sentencing of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey on his bribery conviction for his involvement in Abscam has been postponed again until next Tuesday to give him additional time to recuperate from hernia surgery.

title: GOAL IN SALVADOR CALLED POLITICAL
description: The Administration declared once again today that it was not seeking a military solution in El Salvador but that further military and economic aid was needed there.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A NEAR DRUMMER

title: STRINGS: ROCHBERG PREMIERE
description: GEORGE ROCHBERG'S new Cello Quintet asked several questions of its listeners at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening. The Concord String Quartet commissioned the piece, and, with the cellist Anthony Elliott, gave its first New York performance.

title: People
description: * C. Dayton Titsworth joins Korda Rand Levine as executive vice president-management and Jack Robson as senior vice president, creative director.

title: Gun Mishap Fatal at Movie
description: A 26-year-old man who went to a movie with a pistol in his waistband accidentally shot himself to death as he squirmed in his seat, the police said. The .38-caliber derringer discharged Sunday night, killing George Levi Purdom Jr., of Fresno, the bullet going into his stomach and then into his chest.

title: PUBLIC SERVICES; No Growth, Minus
description: The budget that Governor O'Neill proposes in Connecticut is called no-growth, but it promises even less than that. The $3.17 billion total includes no replacement for the expected cuts in Federal help or any increase in welfare benefits.

title: Madeline Foley, 59, Cellist; A Marlboro Festival Founder
description: Madeline Foley, a cellist and founding member of the Marlboro (Vt.) Music Festival, died after a heart attack Feb. 2 at the Four-in-Hand Inn in Marlboro.

title: SHORT, MORNING TO NIGHT
description: The short skirts that are so prominent in the warm weather collections of the Paris couture also turn up in the clothes New York designers have developed for summer. They range from the swingy loose dresses Oscar de la Renta shows in silk crepe, hand painted in colorful swirls and circles suggested by the paintings of So nia Delaunay, to the sporty skinny cotton and linen skirts Bill Blass presents for Blassport. They include brief culottes as well as dresses with divided skirts and run the gamut from day to evening clothes.

title: THE OLYMPIC SECRET OF JOHN THOMAS
description: AT the time, John Thomas kept his hernia a secret. He didn't want anybody to consider it an alibi if he did not win the 1964 Olympic high jump in Tokyo.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Marshall Field S ues Icahn Group
description: Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago-based retail chain, said it had filed suit against Carl C. Icahn and 11 individuals and companies, charging that their purchases of more than 14 percent of Field's common was illegal. Last week, Icahn and affiliated companies said that they had increased their holdings to 14.7 percent of Field's common.

title: CUTS IN U.S. AID INCREASE TUITION AT 4 UNIVERSITIES
description: Tuition costs are rising at four major private universities as a result of reduced Federal aid for higher education, inflation and the increasing costs of giving financial aid to students.

title: Du Pont Reports 52.6% Gain; Anheuser Up, Schlitz Down
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that the inclusion of the results of Conoco Inc. caused earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981 to increase 52.6 percent, while revenues more than doubled.

title: AN EXPERIMENT IN RESCHOOLING THE
description: SCHOLAR By GENE I. MAEROFF

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS BUDGET AS HE OPENS MIDWEST TOUR
description: At the first stop of his two-day tour of the Middle West, President Reagan today altered his plan to devote the trip to promoting his ''new federalism'' proposals and turned instead to the defense of his new budget.

title: HOYAS DEFEAT SYRACUSE
description: Eric Floyd scored 27 points and Pat Ewing had 22 for Georgetown in a 96-79 victory over Syracuse tonight. Georgetown (19-5) won its fifth game in a row and improved its record in the Big East Conference to 8-3. Syracuse (13-8 and 5-4) was led by Erich Santifer, who had 21 points.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1982; International
description: Britain cut prices of its North Sea oil by $1.50 a barrel, to $35. The reduction, reflecting the world oil surplus, was the most substantial one by an oil producing nation since OPEC unified its oil price structure last October. The OPEC move was meant to help eliminate the surplus, but since then, because of recession and conservation, oil consumption by industrialized nations has continued to fall short of projections. Separately, Iran was reported planning a $1-a-barrel cut to increase sales of its crude oil. (Page A1.)

title: RAIL RATE IN CANADA MAY RISE
description: The 85-year-old rate for moving grain by railway in Canada, one of the world's biggest transport bargains, will finally be raised if the Government gets its way.

title: NEWCOMER CAUSES STIR IN LIVELY TURKISH PRESS
description: While many newspapers in other countries are struggling to survive, Turkey's press is thriving. Advertising revenue and circulation have been going up, some newspapers have added magazine supplements and a new daily newspaper is about to come out to challenge Turkey's big five. T hese developments have occurred despite the military rulers' restrictions on political comment, the country's economic recession and the risingcost of newsp rint.

title: SCRIPPS AWARD TO CUNNINGHAM
description: The 1982 Samuel H. Scripps-American Dance Festival Award of $25,000, the largest annual prize in the performing arts, has been given to Merce Cunningham, the modern-dance choreographer.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 2 incorrectly stated the ownership of the Scandinavian Airlines System. It is a consortium of airline companies in Sweden, Denmark and Norway.

title: ALLEN ORGAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOME OF CAREY'S REQUESTS ARE CUT IN BUDGET ACTION BY STATE SENATE
description: The State Senate today approved a $185.6 million deficiency budget that cut Governor Carey's requests by $23.5 million. Similar action by the Assembly is expected later this week.

title: COPTERING SALVADOR
description: Cayetano Carpio is the senior leader of the Salvadoran g uerrillas. He heads the Popular Forces of Liberation, one of the l argest organizations of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation F ront. This statement is excerpted from a talk in El Salvador with R oger Boyer - this is a pseudonym, requested by the interviewer, who f ears being denied readmission to El Salvador - for the Interlink P ress Service, which distributes third-world news.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SAUDIS SAILING TO MODERNITY
description: Driving north from this bustling city, the fine sand whistling across the road gives the appearance of early morning ground fog. The passing scenery includes camels, oases of date palms and, everywhere, sun-bleached, bone-white desert. On the car radio is the droning, hypnotic voice of Ummkultham, the dead Egyptian singer still revered throughout the Arab world. The title of her song: ''From Here We Start an Old Story.'' Today in Saudi Arabia, there often seem to be only new stories.

title: Labonte Placed Second
description: After reviewing films of the finish in Sunday's Busch Clash, Nascar officials today awarded Terry Labonte second place. Photographs showed Labonte's Buick beat Neil Bonnett's Thunderbird to the finish line of the Daytona International Speedway by ''an inch,'' said a Nascar spokesman, Jim Hunter. Bobby Allison won the race.

title: KEEPING THE TROOPS IN LINE BY LETTING THEM STRAY
description: Representative Trent Lott tries to stay a step ahead of the game. As the Republican whip in the House, the Mississippian helped create the strategy that produced almost unanimous party support for President Reagan's economic program last year, but as the new session of Congress heats up, Mr. Lott is already shifting to Battle Plan B.

title: LETTER URGES WARSAW TO EASE RULE
description: A group of 18 literary, scientific educational and cultural leaders have sent a letter to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's Prime Minister, calling for an end to martial law and ''a speedy restoration of basic human rights in Poland.''

title: Senate Confirms 6 Kean Nominees
description: TRENTON (AP) - The State Senate unanimously confirmed five more department heads and the state police superintendent nominated by Governor Kean, settling 14 of his 21 top appointments.

title: 13 Filipinos May Be Freed
description: Thirteen Filipinos, including one accused of bombing a convention of American travel agents, may be freed if they plead guilty to subversion, a lawyer said today on the first day of trial. The lawyer, Rene Sagisag, said the believed an agreement on guilty pleas could provide the Government with material for antidissident propaganda. Twenty people were wounded in the October 1980 bombing of the American Society of Travel Agents convention in Manila.

title: JACOBS STARTING HIGH JUMP COMEBACK
description: He was disappointed, disillusioned and depressed. He found the world making demands on him, and he did not know how to handle them. Besides, he was injured.

title: ASTRO DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $676,000 or 24 cents a shr from the sale of a drilling rig

title: Dane Criticizes U.S. Policies
description: Cooperation between the United States and Western Europe is being undermined by Reagan Administration policies on El Salvador and Poland, Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen of Denmark said today.

title: ON HIDING AN ELEPHANT
description: Trying to hide a budget deficit of nearly $100 billion is a little like trying to hide an elephant under a bedsheet. The ears and tail may not be clearly discernible, but there sure is something enormous under the covers.

title: 'ARTIFICIAL BLOOD' TESTS EXPANDING IN U.S. AMID HIGH
description: HOPES By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GIAMATTI'S DEFENSE OF LATIN
description: The president of Yale sent this reply to Kempton Dunn, a seventh grader: Dear Mr. Dunn:

title: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations which reduced net income for the latest 6 mos by the equivalent of 2 cents a shr

title: Bednarek and Coffey Are Signed by Giants
description: The Gi ants announced today thesigning of 10 free agents. They were: Jeff Bednarek, a defensive end f rom the University of Pacific; Larry Coffey, running back, West Vir gina Wesleyan; Kevin Evans, safety, Arkansas; Mickey Fitzgerald, r unning back, Virginia Tech; Mike Lush, safety, East Stroudsburg (Pa .) State.

title: Columbia Is Given A Chemistry Chair
description: The widow of a Columbia University alumnus will donate $1.5 million to establish a chemistry professorship in his memory.

title: Menuhin's Father Dies at 89
description: M oshe Menuh in, father of the violinist Yehudi Menuhin, died Thursday at L os Gatos Community Hospital in California. He was 89 years old. Be sides his son, he is survived by his wife, Marutha; a daughter, Yal ta; eight grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren.

title: FLORIDA COUNTY FIGHTS TO CURB PHOSPHATES MINING
description: A company of enormous wealth and diversity came to town in 1965 with the intent of establishing a $650 million industry out on a plain of good-for-nothing scrub brush. The county doesn't want it and people here get absolutely livid when the subject comes up.

title: COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $133,076 for the qr and $265,916 for the 6 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $61,224 for the qr and $93,279 for the 6 mos

title: FALCONBRIDGE COPPER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PARENTS OF ATLANTA DEFENDANT CITED FOR CONTEMPT
description: The parents of Wayne B. Williams and a defense witness were cited for contempt of court today by the trial judge, who said they had violated a court order by discussing the murder case with the news media.

title: Reagan A pplauds A ll-Stars
description: The 34th National Hockey League All-Star Game, which will be played Tuesday night at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., may be unable to match the thrill the 40 players received at a luncheon today with President Reagan at the White House.

title: Algeria-Italy Gas Talks Set
description: Algerian and Italian officials will resume negotiations here Tuesday on the price that Italy will pay for imported Algerian natural gas, Algerian Government officials said today.

title: U.S. Examining Records Of Radiatio n Exposure
description: The Federal authorities today began looking into a former Army medical aide's charges that the exposure of soldiers to high levels of radiation in tests of atomic weapons had been covered up in the 1950's.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: I T had all the makings of a baby-grand Italian opera - that, or a cat fight. In a telegram and phone call to the publisher of Women's Wear Daily, the Italian designer Giorgio Armani announced last week that the press would not be permitted to view his show in March unless its members agreed not to report on it until his clothes were actually in the stores -which means five months later. Mr. Armani also said that in future he would have only one show a year, open to the public and in a different city each time.

title: Market Place; Hi-Shear Bid For Raybestos
description: HOLDERS of undervalued shares often hope for a merger at an attractive price. But Hi-Shear's new plan to acquire Raybestos-Manhattan at little more than a third of book value was a shock to some.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a change in accounting

title: HAIG AND BONN OFFICIAL TALK IN MADRID
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany met today to try to reconcile differing approaches to the Madrid conference on European security, which reconvenes Tuesday in a session that the West hopes to use to denounce the military crackdown in Poland.

title:
Advertising;
Taking the Chaos Out Of Co-ops
description: THERE'S one thing that retail advertising experts agree on when it comes to co-op advertising. There's a awful lot of it around that is going unspent. That brings them sorrow.

title: President of La. Downs Is Facing Dismissal
description: Officials of Louisiana Downs moved today to dismiss Vincent Bartimo, the track president and general manager, accusing him of the unauthorized spending of nearly $800,000.

title: FIRE FAILS TO DAUNT MERCHANT
description: Donald Margolin's eyes wandered up to the I-beam that ran the length of his New York Furniture Store at 820 Eas t Tremont Avenue in the Bronx. It was charred and twisted like a piece of ribbon candy, and just above it, where the roof used to be, sunlight streamed into the one-story building.

title: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nikolai Semyonov, 63, Soviet Atom Arms Aide
description: Nikolai A. Semyonov, a leader of the Soviet nuclear weapons program, died Jan. 28 in Moscow, according to Soviet news reports received in the United States. He was 63 years old.

title: 2 IN SHOOTOUT LINKED TO KILLING OF JERSEY TROOPER
description: Two men who were in a shootout Sunday with two Massachusetts state troopers had been under surveillance because they were associates of a suspect in the murder of a New Jersey trooper, the Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police said today.

title: TV: 'ANY FRIEND,' A FANTASTIC STORY
description: TRAPPED between two oddly unbelievable characters in the drama ''Any Friend of Nicholas Nickelby Is a Friend of Mine,'' a hokey homily - ''believe in your dreams'' or perhaps ''be compassionate to people who pretend they're someone else'' - struggles to assert itself.

title: Juilliard Symphony Bills Rare Mussorgsky Pieces
description: Three rarely heard short works by Mussorgsky and the Toushmalov orchestration of ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' will be performed by the Juilliard Symphony in Alice Tully Hall on Friday at 8 P.M. James Conlon will be the conductor.

title: CHINESE TRY TO QUELL RUMORS THAT DENG'S POWER IS FADING
