description: British car output fell to a provisional 71,000 units in January from 78,000 in December but was ahead of the 70,000 units produced in January 1981, according to Department of Industry figures released today.

title: Zimbabwe Gets a Grant To Expand Radio Links
description: Zimbabwe today took a major step in reducing dependence on white-ruled South Africa for communicating with the outside world.

title: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumer installment debt fell $173 million in December as Americans paid off more than they borrowed for the first time since July 1980, the Federal Reserve Board reported. It said credit extended for new purchases declined 2.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted $26.87 billion. The figure was seen as new evidence that t herecession was worsening as 1981 ended. (Page D1.)

title: LETTERS
description: Editor's Note - The talking cash registers described in the article do have a means of dealing with uncoded fresh produce and discount coupons.

title: FLORIDA EAST COAST RY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STAGE: ELIZABETH SWADOS'S 'LULLABYE'
description: WHEN Elizabeth Swados speaks directly from the heart, she writes songs that both haunt and disturb. ''Lullabye and Goodnight,'' her new musical at the Public's Newman Theater, contains several such songs - the best to be heard from Miss Swados since ''Every Now and Then'' and ''Lullabye From Baby to Baby'' in ''Runaways.'' Yet the show itself is a failure, done in by the other, less ingenuous aspects of its author's sensibility.

title: Eagleburger Wins Approval
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today approved President Reagan's choice of Lawrence S. Eagleburger to be Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. Mr. Eagleburger, a career Foreign Service officer, has most recently served as Assistant Secretary for European Affairs. In his new post, he will be the No. 3 official in the State Department. He succeeds Walter J. Stoessel Jr.

title: Careers; Executive Perspective In Schools
description: IN-RESIDENCE programs are being widely used at graduate schools of business to introduce students to business leaders. At the same time, the programs provide the executives with an interesting experience, sometimes tinged with nostalgia.

title: FEDERATED INVESTORS reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Results include oil and gas operations; share earnings give effect to a 4-for-1stock split, effective Jan 21, 1981

title: CLUETT PEABODY & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,921,000 for the quarter and $3.4 million for the year; C-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,686,000 for the quarter and $4,206,000 for the year

title: ERHARDT DEFENDS HIS STYLE AS A COACH
description: Ron Erhardt sat in a hotel coffee shop late last week, in between goodbyes and introductions. He had spent much of the week saying goodby e to some New England Patriots, players he coached for three seasons until he was dismissed last Dec. 22. He was planning a trip to New Y ork, where Monday he spent his first day at work as the Giants' offen sive coordinator.

title: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $7,426,000 charge from the settlement of four lawsuits

title: I.R.A. Party Banned From Irish Networks
description: The Government today banned the state-run radio and television networks from giving air time in the coming general election to Sinn Fein, the legal political front of the outlawed Irish Republican Army.

title: Jersey Republicans Sue on Districting
description: The seven Republican members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation filed suit in Federal District Court asking that the New Jersey Legislature be ordered to redraw the Congressional redistricting map adopted by the Democratic-controlled Legislature and signed by former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne on Jan. 19.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 10, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Working group of the ad hoc com- mittee on the drafting of an interna- tional convention against the training of mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S. INSISTS ON EXPORT BAR ABROAD
description: Deputy Commerce Secretary Lionel H. Olmer told Congress today that, despite strong objections from its European allies, the United States believes it can enforce its export control laws overseas to block the use of American technology in constructing a proposed 3,000-mile pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: New Tower of Babel
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: NEW PROVISIONS OF FER INCREASED TAX CREDITS
description: People who bought equipment for their business, paid someone else to look after their children, or installed storm windows and insulation last year may be able to reduce their 1981 tax bills by deducting part of the costs as a tax credit. New provisions in the law have liberalized the amount of investment credit that can be claimed on certain business property and increased the credit that investors with royalties from oil and gas interests can claim against the ''windfall profits'' tax. But other provisions, such as increases in child care credit, did not take effect until 1982 and will only be reflected on returns filed in April 1983.

title: BRIEFING
description: H OUSE SPEAKER THOMAS P. O'NEILL Jr. was walking through another photo opportunity yesterday, meeting with the Congressional Arts Caucus about a high school art contest, shaking hands with this visitor and that, being introduced to Jean Stapleton, the actress. Then it dawned on him, and he did a double take worthy of Archie Bunker.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the 15 most popular television programs of the last week (Monday, Feb. 1, to Sunday, Feb. 7), according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the number of households with television sets. Rating Program Network 1 30.2 60 Minutes CBS 2 29.6 "Superman" Pt. 1 ABC 3 28.4 Dallas CBS 4 25.2 Trapper John, M.D. CBS 5 25.2 Too Close for Comfort ABC 6 24.9 Three's Company ABC 7 23.5 "World War III" Pt. II NBC 8 23.1 Hart to Hart ABC 9 22.8 Dukes of Hazzard CBS 1 0 22.8 Magnum, P.I. CBS 1 1 22.7 M*A*S*H CBS 1 2 22.4 The Jeffersons CBS 1 3 22.0 Falcon Crest CBS 1 4 22.0 Fall Guy ABC 1 5 21.7 Archie Bunker's Place CBS

title: PRO POSAL TO END GRADUATE LOAN PROGRAM IS ATTACKED
description: Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the president of Rutgers University, echoing the assessment of officials at other universities, said yesterday that President Reagan's proposal to eliminate guaranteed loans for graduate and professional students would have a devastating effect.

title: Laker May Start New Airline
description: As receivers began seeking buyers for chunks of Sir Freddie Laker's bankrupt airline empire today, the flamboyant pioneer of cheap trans-Atlantic fares announced he was considering starting a new airline.

title: No Headline
description: PRIVATE CONCERN SEEKS TO BUY A SPACE SHUTTLE

title: G.T.E. UP 1.7% IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation reported yesterday, that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981 increased 1.7 percent, while revenues advanced 14.6 percent.

title: KOCH, ANGRY AT U.N., WOULD ALTER ISAIAH WALL
description: In support of an Israeli protest against the United Nations, Mayor Koch says he will seek to alter the ''swords into plowshares'' wall inscription on First Avenue and add a reference to ''hypocrisy, immorality and cowardice.''

title: DEMOTIONS IN A FRENCH FOOD GUIDE
description: PARIS The Gault-Millau Guide France 1982, just published, upgrades a single French restaurant to the guide's highest rating, four toques, while downgra ding several of the most traditional and fashionable French dining rooms.

title: Transit Report
description: L.I.R.R.: Of the 134 scheduled morning rush-hour trains, one was canceled and 39 were late.

title: Argentine Grand Prix Removed From Agenda
description: The Argentine Grand Prix, the second race of the Formula One season, was canceled today by the International Auto Sport Federation. The federation said that the race, which was to have been held March 7 in Buenos Aires, was being withdrawn from the calendar, indicating rejection of an Argentine request that it be rescheduled for later in the year.

title: Atlanta Jury Is Told Of Altered Body Report
description: An expert on water flow told the jury in Wayne B. Williams murder trial today that prosecutors had put pressure on his colleague to change a report on how a body would float in the Chattahoochee River.

title: KISSINGER TO UNDERGO CORONARY BYPASS OPERATION
description: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State,wi ll undergo major surgery Wednesday at the Massachusetts General Ho spital to relieve obstructions in his coronary arteries.

title: Rockets 129, Clippers 121
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Moses Malone scored 33 points and Elvin Hayes added 24 for Houston, which withstood a 53-point fourth-quarter rally by San Diego. It was the Rockets' sixth victory in a row.

title: SUPERIOR OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $22.2 million benefit from the acquisition of 100 percent of Canadian Superior; 1981 shr earnings reflect a 5-for-1 stock split paid in June 1981

title: NIXON LOSES LEGAL APPEAL ON RELEASE OF SECRET TAPES
description: A Federal appellate court today rejected Richard M. Nixon's latest attempt to keep portions of some 6,000 hours of White House ta pe recordings from bei ng released to the public.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1982
description: International East-West acrimony marked the resumption in Madrid of the 35-nation conference on security and cooperation in Europe. The United States and the Common Market told the Soviet Union and Poland that they would not complete negotiati ons for a new agreement as long as the crackdown in Poland continues. A split over tactics was apparently averted by We stern nations when they agreed not to conclude a new treaty but no t to quit the conference. (Page A1, Column 1.) An American shift on human rights was confirmed by Elliott Abrams, the Reagan Administration's senior human rights official. He said he opposed United States ratification of a United Nations covenant setting international standards in economic and social rights. Mr. Abrams said that the covenant, one of three signed by the Carter Administration and now before the Senate, set unrealistic goals for poor nations. (A3:4-6.)

title: AIDE IN WHITE HOUSE GOT 9% LOAN FROM A ROCKEFELLER TO BUY HOUSE
description: A White House official, Joseph W. Canzeri, borrowed $400,000 on unusually favorable terms from Laurance S. Rockefeller and a California developer to finance the purchase of a three-story town house in Washington, according to public records and information provided by Mr. Canzeri and his lawyer.

title: Article 243075 -- No Title
description: The Texas Air Corporation said yesterday that it had an unaudited consolidated net loss of $25.7 million for the fourth quarter in contrast to a restated net income of $429,000, or 6 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 1980.

title: CONTINENTAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect adoption of FASB Statement No 52regarding foreign currency translations

title: Let's Buy the Oil Glut
description: Item: Unable to sell enough oil to finance the war with Iraq, Iran hopes to double exports by reducing its price by $1 a barrel.

title: POPE CALLS VOICE FOR SOLIDARITY IN POLAND VITAL
description: Pope John Paul II declared today that only the full restoration of the rights of Solidarity offered a way out of the Polish crisis.

title: Carting Rates Rise
description: The city's new Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Simon P. Gourdine, announced that the maximum fee that licensed private carting concerns may charge for hauling commercial refuse from business establishments in the city had been raised.

title: TIPS FOR SELECTING FRESH FRUITS AND VEGETABLES
description: General Suggestions

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CUT

title: Fare Could Rise 30, An M.T.A. Aide Says
description: Bus and subway fares could go up by as much as 30 cents this year under a possible combination of Federal aid cuts, transit wage increases and shortages in state tax collections, the Metropolitan Transit Authority's executive director said today.

title: MUSICAL: THE CAREERS OF 2 'HOOFERS'
description: THE inspiration for ''Hoofers,'' a tiny musical at the tiny Wooden O, a theater on the third floor of 335 West 38th Street, is apparently the career of Fred Astaire and his sister, Adele, fro m their start as children in small-time vaudevi lle to international acclaim and her decision to leave the stage t o marry an English peer.But that is virtually the only thing that is inspired in this dolefulaffair.

title: 'DALLAS' STRIKES NO OIL ON JAPANESE TV
description: TOKYO ''DALLAS,'' the CBS-TV series whose smarmy characters, petty intrigue and camp have captured the fancy of viewers in more than 60 countries, is a flop in Japan.

title: POP: 'LYRICISTS' SERIES AT Y CELEBRATES E.Y. HARBURG
description: THE ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series at the 92d Street Y began its 12th season Sunday evening with a ''celebration'' of the late E.Y. Harburg.

title: STUFFED DUMPLINGS: THEY GET AROUND
description: THE stuffed dumpling, humble as it may seem, is a dish with a fascinating history, going back many centuries and interwoven into the cuisines of a number of countries.

title: GENERAL TELEPHONE & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of 9,465,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and a charge of $141,404,000 for the year from discontinued operations

title: New Sanctions Ordered Against Wichita State
description: The Missouri Valley Conference ordered new sanctions against Wichita State University's basketball program today for infractions found earlier by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: KAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CURTISS-WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $3,158,000 for the quarter and $7,518,000 for the year from discontinued operations; C-Including a gain of $34,131,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations

title: ALBERTO OF ARROWS IS SOLD TO CLEVELAND
description: The New York Arrows, the only champion in the four-year history of the Major Indoor Soccer League, sold Luis Alberto to the Cleveland Force yesterday for an undisclosed amount of cash. ''Alberto's sale is just the beginning of a couple of other moves that could ma terialize by the end of the week,'' said Krikor Yepremian, th e general manager of the Arrows. Alberto was one of the team's origin al members when it was formed four years ago.

title: Dutch Joblessness Rises
description: Dutch unemployment rose to a postwar record of 452,500 in January from 449,700 in December, according to provisional seasonally adjusted figures released by the Government today. The number of jobless in January 1981 was 311,400.

title: FORGOTTEN CHRISTIAN VICTIMS OF SOVIET REPRESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: House Subcommittee Backs Contempt Citation for Watt
description: A House subcommittee recommended today that Interior Secretary James G. Watt be cited for contempt of Congress for defying a subpoena for documents that President Reagan cloaked in executive privilege.

title: DOCTOR IN VON BULOW CASE SAYS HE WAS SUSPICIOUS
description: The doctor who first treated Martha von Bulow when she went into her second coma in 1980 said he suspected then that she might have been secretly injected with insulin before her first coma a year earlier.

title: BANISTER CONTINENTAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALLIED VAN LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $752,000 for the quarter and year; C-Including a tax credit of $399,000

title: WEDDING FEASTS IN A CAFE NEAR CITY HALL
description: WITH a plastic-coated menu tucked under one arm, Ellen Hart Sturm picked up a pecan pie edged with strawberry cream, grabbed a bottle of chilled California champagne by its neck and began weaving her way through the tables and stools of her Lower Broadway coffee shop, en route to the booth where the Neuman wedding party was in midcelebration.

title: EUROPEANS BATTLE JAPANESE TV TUBES
description: The closure of the sprawling one-story building where Videocolor, a Thomason-Brandt enterprise, manufactures 22- and 26-inch picture tubes illustrates the slippage in West Germany's once strong electrical industry and the deep penetraiton of Far Eastern manufacturers into European radio, television and high fidelity.

title: HOMESTAKE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports of The Times; The Referee at the Dog Show
description: WHEN Louis H. Harris points his finger, dogs and people trot in tight little circles. He is a judge at dog shows, and he is one of the best of his breed. Basketball referees and tennis officials would have been jealous watching Harris serve as ringmaster for seven varieties at the Westminster Kennel Club show yesterday. Nobody bit him or snarled at him, or kicked dirt on his shoes. ''I'll bet some of them are saying nasty things about me on their way home in the car,'' Harris said. ''But they know better than to smart off in the ring. They would have to appear before a committee and be judged right away. That's the way it should be in tennis.''

title: Leonard Will Retire At CBS News March 1
description: William A. Leonard, a CBS News reporter, broadcaster, producer and executive for 37 years, will retire March 1 as president of CBS News.

title: FINDING A METHOD TO REDUCE STRESS
description: ''IF I can do anything about it, I'll do it. If I can't, I just forget it. Take things as they come and don't worry about them.'' This was how Robert Yarborough of Meridian, Miss., summed up his approach to life upon reaching the age of 100. He was one of hundreds of American centenarians who expressed similar attitudes, as reported in a newly published study ''Living to Be 100: 1,200 Who Did It and How They Did It,'' by Osborn Segerberg Jr. (Scribners, $19.95).

title: POOR MAINLY SILENT AFTER WELFARE CUTS, STATE OFFICIALS FIND
description: State welfare officials across the nation were expecting protests, demonstrations and lobbying campaigns in behalf of poor people after the Reagan Administration's cuts in welfare benefits took effect, but the main response of the poor so far has been silence.

title: Dean Witter Moves Include New Chief
description: In a restructuring of the Dean Witter Reynolds Organization following its acquisition by Sears, Roebuck & Company last Dec. 31, Robert M. Gardiner, 59 years old, has been promoted, effective Feb. 15, to chairman and chief executive officer of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., the broker-dealer subsidiary of the securities firm that accounts for about 80 percent of its revenues.

title: Medical Problems Cited At Florida State Inquiry
description: Pernell Tookes, a former Florida State basketball player, today told a special university committee investigating allegations of improprieties in the program that he had received incompetent care for a knee injury he suffered before the season.

title: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,165,000 for the quarter and $1,440,000 for the year; C-Including income from discontinued operations of $194,000 for the quarter and $387,000 for the year

title: Jersey to Study Charges Police Rigged a Race
description: The New Jersey Racing Commission said today that it would look into charges by a jockey that undercover detectives of the state police had rigged a race at the Atlantic City track as part of an inquiry called Opera tion Glue.

title: STOUFFER'S JUDGE SAYS STATEMENTS ARE ADMISSIBLE
description: The judge in the Stouffer's Inn fire case ruled today that although the police had sometimes been ''coercive'' in their questioning of the defendant, Luis Marin, most of his statements to investigators could be used against him during his trial for murder and arson.

title: TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An article Monday on a dispute be- tween a store in Maine and BAT Indus- tries Ltd. gave an incorrect ranking for BAT. It is 29th on the Fortune magazine list of the 500 largest corpo- rations outside the United States.

title: TEXTRON SETS STOCK REPURCHASEE
description: Textron Inc. said directors had authorized the repurchase of 500,000 of the company's common shares in the open market from time to time.

title: BASS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
SCHWEIKER DEFENDS PROPOSAL FOR TEEN-AGE CHASTITY RULE
description: Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, clashed with Democrats in the House today over the consequences of a proposal to notify parents when their teen-age daughters received birth control devices.

title: THE FIRST CHILLING EFFECT
description: An old-timer grants permission to publis h his following letter on condition his name be withheld:

title: MOSCOW'S LORELEI
description: East Germany is the most hardline, repressive state in the Soviet bloc, more so than the Soviet Union itself, but it often shows the opposite face to the West Germans. Like Lorelei on the Rhine long ago, East German leaders can sing a seductive song.

title: Anheuser-Busch Cable Participation
description: Anheuser-Busch, probably already the largest advertiser on cable television, chose the first annual Cable Advertising Conference in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom to announce even further involvement.

title: MICROPIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TALKS HELD ON LONDON TIMES
description: Management of the financially troubled Times newspapers met with union leaders today under an ultimatum from the owner, Rupert Murdoch, who is threatening to shut the papers if the staff is not cut back nearly 25 percent.

title: AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
BEST BUYS
description: AFTER a couple of weeks of high prices, several meat items are now reasonable buys. Leg of lamb is selling at $1.79 a pound in some supermarkets, and lamb for stewing at $1.39 a pound. The leg of lamb becomes more tender if marinated in yogurt for a few days before being roasted. The stewing meat can be ground by the butcher and made into a bracing curry. It is also good in shepherd's pie, covered with a thick layer of mashed potatoes that sop up the juices, and baked until the crust is golden brown.

title: NEW YORK, ETC.
description: TIME was when bills, no matter how big the amount due, at least looked skinny and undernourished on the outside. A swipe of the thumb, or letter opener, and out fell a single slip of paper that could be assimilated at a glance. No more.

title: Woman Takes Seat on Court
description: Judge Betty Roberts of the State Court of Appeals formally took her seat Monday on the Oregon Supreme Court, becoming the first woman top be a justice in the 124-year history the court.

title: BIRTHDAY THAT HAS LONG BEEN BIG EVENT
description: ''THE Americans, that cool and sedate people,'' a French visitor wrote in 1781, ''are roused, animated and inflamed at the very mention of his name.'' On George Washington's birthday his countrymen rejoiced with parades and singing, barbecues and bell ringing, bonfires and balls.

title: A BASIC METHOD FOR PREPARATION
description: There are many ways of preparing stuffed dumplings. Here is one basic method: 1. Roll out dough into a rectangle of any length but about four inches wide. 2.

title: AROUND THE Nation; Parents Seeking Delay In Move on Book Protest
description: Parents who protested use of Studs Terkel's book ''Working'' in high school classes because it contains profanity have now asked the school board to delay any decision on the issue.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.E. Staley Manufacturing Co. said it had agreed to buy a 40 percent interest in Bio-Technical Re sources I nc. of Manitowoc, Wis.

title: IN TORONTO'S UNDERGROUND MALLS, ALL IS NOT BALMY
description: When John Hannah leaves for his job as a stockbroker in the morning, he goes underground. He does not come out until after dark. And that is perfectly normal.

title: ARAMCO'S TOUGH OIL FIELD
description: RUB'AL KHALI, Saudi Arabia - In English, the wastes that make up this region are called the Empty Quarter. It amounts to one of the largest deserts in the world, occupying 250,000 square miles.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS CRITICS OF BUDGET FOR ALTERNATIVES
description: President Reagan conceded today that the projected deficit in his 1983 budget was ''too big,'' but he continued his harshly worded attacks on ''knee-jerk'' critics who offer no alternative to the Administration's economic recovery program.

title: Boxing Chief Seized
description: Jose Sulaiman, president of the World Boxing Council, was arrested in Mexico City, where he was accused of plotting to smuggle archeological artifacts out of the country, in violation of Mexican law. The charge was brought, the police said, after investigators had discovered the relics at a factory Sulaiman owns in an industrial suburb of the capital.

title: REAGAN PLAN TO MAKE COLLEGE AID HARDER AND COSTLIER TO GET
description: Many college students would either become ineligible for grants or would find it more costly to obtain student loans starting this fall under the budget proposed this week by President Reagan.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
CORRECTION
description: An article Monday on Deng Xiaoping gave an incorrect title for Glen Renfrew of the Reuters news agency. He is the managing director.

title: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including foreign currency translation gains of $4.3 million for the quarter & $16.4 million for the year; C-Including foreign currency translation gains of $1.6 million for the quarter and $24 million for the year

title: Mrs. Paul's Kitchens Fin ed
description: Mrs. Paul's Kitchens and three of its officers pleaded guilty Monday to illegally tapping into the city's sewer system from 1975 to 1979. As part of a plea agreement, Judge Leon Katz of Common Pleas Court fined the company $100,000 and ordered it to make $148,573 in restitution, of which $98,000 has already been paid. The prosecutors recommended probation and fines for the employees, David Bohannon, John Majewski and Richard Wolf.

title: MACRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: B-After extraordinary charge of $103,000; C-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $627,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $995,000 for the year

title: ONE VIEW OF THE BUDGET
description: Quest ion: Is this the Administration that promised fiscal r esponsibility and a balanced budget?

title: POLISH ISSUE CITED; Excerpts from Haig speech, page A13.
description: The United States and the Common Market told the Soviet Union and Poland today that they would refuse to continue the current negotiations here on East-West cooperation until martial law is ended in Poland.

title: 12 WIN CITY BROWNSTONES IN HARLEM
description: After nearly three years of controversy, New York City housing officials yesterday selected purchasers for 12 brownstones the city owns in Harlem through a lottery that was weighted in favor of people living in Harlem.

title:
F.B.I. INFORMANTS;
WASHINGTON - The Federal Bureau of Investigation has repeatedly claimed that the Freedom of Information Act has ''dried up'' its sources. Director William H. Webster, asserting that the act has cost his agency hundreds of informants, says that they have become ''an endangered species.''
description: True? To find out, NBC News, using the Freedom of Information act, obtained the F.B.I.'s own files on the act. They tell a dramatically different story.

title: A POLITICAL ACTION UNIT OF THE LEFT
description: The Democratic left, looking to the Republican right as a role model, is about to try its hand at negative campaigning, a prospect that has this city's Democratic establishment a little edgy.

title: North Korea Proposes Parley on Reunification
description: North Korea called today for a conference of 100 political figures representing North and South Korea to discuss reunification, the North Korean Central News Agency reported.

title: 7.5 MILLION TISCH GIFT TO N.Y.U
description: New York University's School of the Arts has been given $7.5 million by Laurence A. Tisch and Preston Robert Tisch, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John Brademas, president of the university. The school has been renamed the Tisch School of the Arts.

title: SOVIET MISSILE BID IS REJECTED BY U.S.
description: The United States said today that a Soviet proposal for reducing the number of medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe was unacceptable.

title: RANGERS RALLY, TIE BLUES, 3-3
description: The Rangers flirted with defeat for most of their game against the St. Louis Blues tonight, but their two envoys to the National Hockey League's All-Star Game, and a bit of luck, helped them gain a tie with two and a half minutes left.

title: Castro Denies Cuba Received Offensive Jets From Russians
description: President Fidel Castro denied today that Cuba recently received offensive jet fighters from the Soviet Union.

title: EGYPT'S CHIEF TURNS FROM DIPLOMACY TO ECONOMICS
description: President Hosni Mubarak has completed his first international tour as Egypt's leader and is ready to tackle what he has labeled his chief priority - restructuring Egypt's economy.

title: PEACE FORCE IN CHAD FACING A FUND SHORTAGE
description: The Organization of African Unity was told today at a special meeting here that it could no longer afford to maintain a peacekeeping force in Chad unless new emergency financial donations were forthcoming.

title: Chan Sy Is Confirmed As Cambodia Premier
description: A Cambodian military figure believed to have spent more than 15 years in Vietnam has been elected Prime Minister of the pro-Vietnamese Government in Cambodia.

title: PACIFIC TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
NETS SUBDUE PISTONS, 115-108
description: With a fourth-quarter rally led by Mike O'Koren's defense and Ray Williams's offense, the Nets beat the Detroit Pistons tonight, 115-108, for their third straight victory.

title: Editors' Group Opposes South Africa Press Rules
description: The World Press Freedom Committee, which represents 33 organizations of editors, publishers, broadcasters and reporters, urged Prime Minister P.W. Botha of South Africa today to reject a Government commission's proposals that would limit press freedom.

title: Butterfly
description: Butterflies are teases, setting lepidopterists to sloshing through mud while they embroider the air. They are also noisy (some can chirp, rattle or squeak), sociable (clustering at waterholes like flies around a bar) and extraordinarily wingloose (the North American monarch flies south in the autumn, north in the spring).

title: A PLASTIC SURGEON IN VIETNAM
description: Dr. Arthur Joseph Barsky, a pioneering plastic surgeon who treated Vietnamese children during the Vietnam War and victims of the Hiroshima atomic bombing, died Tuesday in southern France at the age of 83. He lived in the village of Le Beausset and maintained an apartment in Manhattan.

title: MEENAN OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DREYER'S GRAND ICE CREAM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
MOUNTAIN FUEL SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Reflects an $11.3 million reduction which was ordered as part of the settlement of the so-called Wexpro case; C-Net income

title: Republic Airlines
description: Republic Airlines said it plans to indefinitely lay off 1,000 employees, or about 7 percent of its work force, over the next several months. The company has already told 250 pilots, 90 mechanics and 40 cleaners that their jobs will be eliminated. All of Republic's pilots and the majority of its flight attendants - 3,200 employees - have agreed to defer one month's wages to improve cash flow, said a spokesman.

title: China Sets Rules for Oil Drilling
description: China today announced the rules under which foreign oil companies would be allowed to help develop its offshore oilfields, and said that bids for drilling would be invited soon.

title: SENATOR INTRODUCES BILL ON TRADING RECIPROCITY
description: The chairman of the Senate's trade subcommittee today introduced legislation to reinforce the President's powers to withdraw trading privileges in the United States from countries that do not provide American exporters with reciprocal market access.

title: CONNECTICUT BALLET FACES BANKRUPTCY
description: The Connecticut Ballet will declare bankruptcy if it does not raise $115,000 by May 31, officials of the 10-year-old company say.

title: DANCE: THE BUCKET THEATER
description: THE Bottom of the Bucket ... but Dance Theater developed 11 years ago from dance classes taught by Garth Fagan, director of the company, to nondancers on the Rochester campus of the State University of New York College at Brockport. The black modern-dance company, seen last week at the Theater of the Riverside Church, has been renamed the Bucket Dance Theater. It is now a recognized professional modern-dance company. But its roots define Mr. Fagan's choreography and help to make it unfailingly original.

title: CHAD REBEL IS SAID TO WEIGH ATTACK
description: Chad's rebellious former Defense Minister, Hissen Habre, says he will attack toward the capital, Ndjamena, if the Organization of African Unity does not make progress toward a settlement in the war-ravaged land, according to reports reaching here from eastern Chad.

title: Guatemalan Leftists Say They Are Joining Forces
description: Guatemala's four major leftist guerrilla groups have announced that they are joining forces in their war against the G overnment of Maj. Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia.

title: More U.S. Layoffs By Caterpillar
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said that it would indefinitely lay off a further 2,500 employees in the United States and partly shut down several domestic manufacturing plants during April and May.

title: KENTUCKY CENTRAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALBANY OFFICE DISPUTES CITY ON '83 BUDGET
description: The New York State Comptroller's office warned yesterday that the Koch administration's proposals for closing the city's impending budget deficit would not be sufficient to do the job.

title: ROCK: CANADA'S ROUGH TRADE OPENS THE NEW DANCETERIA
description: DANCETERIA, one of the most influential rock clubs in recent years, reopened last week as the New Danceteria, at 30 West 21st Street. The New Danceteria is essentially an upscale model of the old - a handsomely designed three-story affair with three dance floors, a video lounge, video games, a restaurant and bars, and a stage for live entertainment.

title: EARLY CALIFORNIA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $387,000 for the quarter and $1.1 million for the 9 months; C-Including a gain of $874,000 from discontinued operations

title: TWO U.S. DRUG AGENTS ABDUCTED FROM HOTEL AND SHOT IN COLOMBIA
description: Two United States drug enforcement agents in Colombia were abducted from their hotel by five armed men posing as policemen who took them to a remote area and shot and seriously wounded them, Federal officials reported here tonight.

title: ITALY'S NEW INDUSTRIAL STRATEGY
description: The economic policies emerging in Italy make it clear that some of the country's favored industrial traditions and fiscal prejudices may be falling victim to the economic slump.

title: HYDRAULIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AVENUE OF INFLUENCE

title: 5 Greenpeace Protesters Sit On Smokestacks in 3 States
description: Five environmentalists, sitting hundreds of feet up, on smokestacks in Ohio, Indiana and Arizona, said yesterday they could maintain their vigil against acid rain ''indefinitely.''

title: DOW UP 6.09
description: Stock prices moved higher yesterday in a performance that Wall Street analysts described as a fairly typical response to the market's recent weakness. However, several issues sustained losses in the takeover sector.

title: CONAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'CIRCLE OF DECEIT,' WAR CORRESPONDENT IN BEIRUT
description: ''WHY is peace at home so unbearable? Just because it's peace?'' These questions come from Georg Laschen (Bruno Ganz) at the beginning of ''Circle of Deceit,'' a film in which Georg leaves his family in West Germany to go work as a war correspondent in Beirut. ''Is it by chance,'' Georg's wife asks angrily, ''that there's always a war in the places you go?''

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN do-it-yourselfers shop for hinges for cabinets, chests or wall units, they will have to consider more than color, finish and decorative styling. They must also make certain to picks the hinge that will best fit the door involved.

title: BELL'S PERPLEXED STOCKHOLDERS
description: Flush with some inherited money, Ruth Spencer put some of it into American Telephone and Telegraph stock soon after she got out of college. Now retired and a widow living in Terrell, Tex., she still has the stock, but with A.T.& T. splitting up the Bell System, she isn't sure what to do with it.

title: Required Reading; The Right to Vote
description: Vilma S. Martinez, President and General Counsel of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, testifying at a hearing before the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on the Constitution about the Voting Rights Act. Jan. 27, 1982:

title: STERLING BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Joseph D. Gleason, Executive Of Federal Employees' Union
description: Joseph D. Gleason, executive vice president of the American Federation of Government Employees since 1976, died Sunday at a hospital in Alexandria, Va., where he was being treated for cancer.

title: STUDENTS GET BOARD FOR BABY-SITTING
description: IN New York, where baby sitters and space are both at a premium, anoffshoot of Europe's au pair system seems to be thriving: it is a simple exchange program in which, typically, 20 hours of child care a week is bartered for a student's bed and bo ard.

title: THE APARTMENT OF THE FUTURE: A LUXURIOUS DESIGN FOR TODAY
description: IN the late 1960's and early 70's it was easy to conjure up the image of a modern interior: streamlined, open space, shiny su rfaces and glossy walls - a living area geared to hi gh technology and often dubbed ''space age.''

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Paul Shmyr, a defenseman, received a broken thumb last Saturday night in St. Louis and will be lost to the Hartford Whalers for o ne to two weeks ... William Wirtz, president of the Chicago Black Hawks,said he will ask the general manager, Bob Pulford, to stay on as interim coach for the rest of the season. Pulford replaced Keith Magnuson, who was dismissed last week ... Kevin Willhite of Cordova High School n ear Sacramento, Calif., named by Parade magazine as the country's top high school running back last year, signed a national letter-of-int ent to play football for Oregon yesterday, the first dayletters could be signed. The 6-foot, 195-pound back had said that he would attend Washington.

title: Health Cuts Are Seen As 'Return to Dickens'
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed cuts in the health budget are a ''return to the world of Charles Dickens'' and are likely to set off local epidemics of polio and measles, public health groups warned today.

title: MAKING FLOWERS LAST LONGER
description: Here are some tips provided by the Flower Council of the Netherlands to make cut flowers last longer.

title: CABARET: ANGELA BOFILL
description: ANGELA BOFILL is still such a raw talent that one wonders what sort of entertainer she will be five years from now. At her opening last week at the Savoy, the Bronx-bred Spanish-speaking diva displayed two contradictory sides of her personality.

title: KISSINGER 'EXCELLENT' AFTER TRIPLE BYPASS IN CORONARY SURGERY
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger underwent a triple heart bypass operation today to repair blocked and narrowed arteries. His doctors said he had come through the surgery in ''excellent condition.''

title: JUDGES SET A DEADLINE ON TEXAS REDISTRICTING
description: The department last month rejected a plan passed by the Legislature last Aug. 10. The department said the plan failed to meet requirements of the Voting Rights Act.

title: RETAIL SALES FELL 1.1% IN JANUARY
description: Retail sales dropped 1.1 percent in January, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline, the fourth in the last seven months, had been expected in light of heavy snow, which discouraged shopping in parts of the nation; the recession; a sales decline at auto showrooms, and continued high unemployment, which left many Americans with little money to buy more than essentials.

title: METS SIGN FOSTER TO FIVE-YEAR, $10 MILLION CONTRACT
description: George Foster, one of the major leagues' best power hitters, signed a five-year Met contract yesterday worth at least $10 million, an agreement that makes his average annual pay the second-highest in baseball. Only Dave Winfield, whose complicated contract with the Yankees includes cost-of-living escalator clauses that bring his 10-year deal to a projected total of $22.5 million, earns more in the c ourse of a s eason.

title: Direct Marketing Unit Planned by B.B.D.O.
description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn has joined the crowd of agencies taking a special interest in direct marketing and it, too, will on March 1 establish a special unit, daringly called BBDO Direct.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 11, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Working group of the Ad Hoc Com- mittee on the Drafting of an Interna- tional Convention Against the Train- ing of Mercenaries - 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Yankees Open an Early Camp
description: With their host looking on, 23 Yankees sweated today through the first day of the early spring party to which they had been invited.

title: Labor Dept. to Review Curb On Exposure to Cotton Dust
description: The Labor Department announced Tuesday that it would review tough Federal limits on exposure to cotton dust that the Carter Administration adopted to eliminate ''brown lung'' disease among textile workers.

title: CHEMINEER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
A Democrat Crosses the Line
description: ''Put up or shut up,'' President Reagan said Tuesday to critics of his budget and its near-$100 billion deficit. So Senator Ernest Hollings did. By yesterday morning the North Carolina Democrat had not only taken up the President's challenge but did so in a way that puts Mr. Reagan's effort to shame.

title: SAFEGUARD BUSINESS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year ago results restated to reflect adoption of accounting for compensated absences

title: U.N. RIGHTS OFFICIAL STEPS DOWN, CITING 'POLICY DIFFERENCES'
description: A 47-year-old Dutchman who has been director of the United Nations Human Rights Commission since 1977 announced today that he was leaving the post because of ''major policy differences with the leadership of the organization in New York.''

title: DIGILOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Including investment tax credits of $1.00 a share in 1981 against 65 cents in 1980

title: No Headline
description: 22 TOP GUERRILLAS KILLED, IRAN SAYS

title: HERS
description: JUST when we thought the buddy-buddy film was finished - no more Paul Newman and Robert Redford riding off into the sunset -male bonding resurfaces in a new form. The latest twist is fathers and sons or, to use the currently fashionable term, ''male parenting.''

title: BRALORNE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
GAX METROPOLITAIN INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
GIBSON ANNOUNCES HE'LL SEEK 4TH TERM AS NEWARK'S MAYOR
description: Warning potential rivals that they should ''come out with their armor on,'' Kenneth A. Gibson announced his candidacy today for a fourth term as Mayor of the state's largest city.

title: FORTEPIANO: HAYDN BY BILSON
description: IT is hardly worth debating the virtues of ''authentic'' instruments anymore. The philosophical questions are trivial, the musicological questions irrelevant. Such instruments as the fortepiano, for example, quite simply reveal late 18th- and early 19th-century keyboard music in ways the piano cannot.

title: HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; C-Including income of $607,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for investment tax credits

title: WATT ASSERTS HE WOULD GO TO JAIL RATHER THAN YIELD SENSITIVE DATA
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt said today that it was very likely he would be held in contempt of Congress, but he added that he would go to jail if necessary to keep from turning over to members of Congress documents they want to see.

title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec31
LONG-TERM BOND PRICES RISE
description: Prices of long-term bonds rose as much as a point yesterday, spurred by signs of a weak economy and hints from Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that the Fed might not tighten monetary policy further in the near future. Although ec onomists still disagree about the strength of the economy and t he likelihood of a recovery next quarter, the most recent data p ointed toward weakness. Yesterday, for example, the Commerce Depa rtment announced a 1.1 percent decline in January retailsales, much w eaker than Wall Street forecasts of no change.

title: Chacun a Son Gout
description: Confirmed oenophiles may choke at the thought, but when it comes to identifying fine wines, there may be nothing better than a beer bust the night before.

title: ICE TICKLES FUNNY BONES EVEN IN WORST OF WINTERS
description: The Detroit Police Department got a novel emergency call the other day. ''Guy called and said he couldn't get his car started in the cold,'' Lieut. Fred Williams said. ''Wanted to know if we could recommend a car thief who was good at starting cars.''

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $3.6 million, or 45 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $281,000, or 4 cents a share, for the year-agoquarter; year-ago results have been reclassified to segregate printed circuit board business as a discontinued operation; share earnings are per Class A shares

title: ANCHOR HOCKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an unusual gain of $2.5 million, or 24 cents a share

title: KELLY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Abscam Death Ruled Suicide
description: The Palm Beach County authorities have ruled that Cynthia Marie Weinberg took her own life, despite contentions from her lawyer that she was unlikely to commit suicide. Toxicological tests released Tuesday showed that the estranged wife of Mel Weinberg, a key figure in the Abscam bribery cases, drank alcohol mixed with a depressant before she hanged herself Jan. 26.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard THE MOSQUITO COAST. By Paul Ther- oux. 374 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $13.95.

title: PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
THOMAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $300,000 gain for the quarter from annual inventory adjustments and $540,000 gain due to an accounting change; C-Includes $1.1 million due to an acounting change

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SCREEN: COPP OLA'S 'ONE FROM THE H EART' OPENS
description: BEING one of the only two people I know who elected to miss the two highly publicized unsneak previews of Francis Coppola's ''One From the Heart'' at Radio City Music Hall several weeks ago, I'm now mystified by the comparative kindness of most of the reports coming out of those screenings. Maybe people felt obligated to Mr. Coppola, as guests to a host, or perhaps they believed he could do a fast reediting job to transform a tiny, unrealized idea into a major work of popular cinema art. Maybe they were simply embarrassed and sad.

title: LONE STAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Technology; Developing Disk Cameras
description: THE new amateur cameras introduced last week by the Eastman Kodak Company have been called ''disk cameras'' because they replace the traditional film rolled inside a cartridge with a 15-exposure film disk that rotates automatically after every shot.

title: COUPLE'S DEATH LINKED TO TWO HELD IN ASSAULT
description: Two Brooklyn men who were arrested Tuesday for breaking into a home in Whitestone, Queens, last week and terrorizing and assaulting a family are suspects in the murder of an elderly couple in the Richmond Hill section of the borough last November, authorities said yesterday.

title: HARCOURT BRACE MOVING FROM THE CITY
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, one of the country's largest publishing concerns, will move its headquarters and most of its operations out of New York City to Florida and California.

title: FROM GREENHOUSES ABROAD TO THE U.S.: FLOWERS IN A DAY
description: VALENTINE flowers these days may be freesias, gerberas, anemones, alstroemerias, sprays of orchids, unusual lilies, cut amaryllis, heliconias, proteas or gingers. The names are exotic and so are the flowers. They come from all over the world - the Netherlands, Italy, Israel, South Africa and South America. The jet age has made a radical change in the cut flowers being sold in the New York City area and throughout the United States. Flowers cut in Europe are being delivered fresh by air freight the next day.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm not going to lie. Many of us can't be effective at this time.

title: Tennis Group Threatens Cancellation Over Ban
description: The Men's International Professional Tennis Council has threatened to cancel a $150,000 Grand Prix tournament scheduled for Copenhagen in two weeks unless qualified South African players a re allowed to compete.

title: Carter Agrees On 8-Year Pact
description: Gary Carter, the all-star catcher for the Montreal Expos, said tonight that he has agreed to an eight-year contract, but would not confirm that it would pay him $15 million, a figure previously reported.

title: Detroit Chief Gets Award
description: When William L. Hart took over as Police Chief in Detroit five years ago, two officers were assigned to crime prevention. Now there is a $4 million crime prevention program with 150 officers and widespread community support, and the police report that crime is down sharply.

title: Mines and Rails Are Mutually Captive
description: To the Editor:

title: SMOKE DETECTOR DANGERS: A FALSE ALARM?
description: ''IJUST found out that my new smoke detector is the radioactive kind,'' the inquiries usually begin. ''Is it really safe?'' As a new law went into effect on Jan. 1 requiring that nearly two million smoke detectors be installed in the five boroughs, tenant organizations expressed concern that ionization smoke detectors, which contain a small amount of radioactive material, could pose a health risk. In recent weeks, according to Mayor Koch's office, residents in hundreds of apartment houses asked their landlords not to install ionization detectors, and politicians, including the Manhattan Borough President, Andrew Stein, called on the city to halt their use.

title: NEW DELAYS SEEN AT 3 MILE ISLAND
description: Extensive corrosion problems will delay the restarting of the undamaged nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island near here by six to 12 months, the president of the operating company said today.

title: Military Analysis
description: The war between Iran and Iraq has dragged for more than 17 months. There have been some slight shifts in the tactical position in the last six weeks, mostly in Iran's favor. But victory remains distant for either side despite the extravagant claims made by the Governments in Teheran and Baghdad.

title: ADJOURNMENT LIKELY AT MADRID TALKS
description: The troubled East-West conference on security and cooperation in Europe appeared today to be heading toward adjournment as the Polish delegation indicated that it would continue parliamentary maneuvers to prevent speeches attacking the military crackdown in Poland.

title: Account
description: * Shapiro's Wines to unrelated Shapiro/Budrow & Associates.

title: Tracks to Add Racing Dates
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board is expected to approve a proposal for 34 consecutive days of racing at Belmont Park next summer and 27 consecutive days at Saratoga Race Track next August. These would be the longest stretches of racing without a day off in the history of either track.

title: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1982; The Economy
description: The Federal Reserve Board will continue to pursue a tight monetary policy this year, Paul A. Volcker, the Fed's chairman, said in presenting his annual monetary targets to Con gress. Mr. Volcker said spending cuts and tax increases to reduce pro jected Federal budget deficits were crucial to recovery. However, h e did not directly criticize President Reagan's projected budget deficits. (Page A1.)

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: Year-ago share earnings adjusted for Nov 19, 1981 3-for-2 stock split

title: COMMODORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUILDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $1,000 from discontinued operations

title: Coffee, but No Juice
description: During preparations to receive President Reagan in the Indiana General Assembly this week, a White House advance team passed on the word that the President liked fresh orange juice and that some should be on hand.

title: QUESTOR CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After $21.6 million loss from discontinued operations and $31 million in charges of which $25 million is associated with the previously reported divestiture of the domestic operations of the company's parts business

title: REBELLION ERUPTS IN CENTRAL SYRIA, DIPLOMATS REPORT
description: A revolt against the Government of President Hafez al-Assad has been under way for eight days in the central city of Hama, Western diplomatic sources reported today. About 8,000 Government soldiers were said to have the city under siege.

title: CONCERT: PERLMAN OFFERS THREE VIOLIN CONCERTOS
description: LIKE any entrepreneurial organization in the entertainment business, Lincoln Center loves to showcase stars, and at Avery Fisher Hall last night it was Itzhak Perlman's turn in a ''Live From Lincoln Center'' telecast carried by the Public Broadcasting System. This was no bargain-basement affair. Ticket prices ranged from $15 to $35 for those who paid to get in (there were many invited guests), and the concert was underwritten by Exxon, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: CALENDAR: VALENTINE'S DAY FLOWER SALES
description: Valentine's Day Flower Sales

title: DOUGLAS & LOMASON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Russians Buy U.S. Corn
description: After a two-month lull, the Soviet Union today resumed buying American grain. It ordered 150,000 metric tons of corn for delivery by Sept. 30, the Agriculture Department said. This makes 10.9 million tons of grain - 5.9 m illion wheat and 5 million corn -that the Russians have bought f rom the United States inthis crop year.

title: EX-JUSTICE JOINS IN SUIT AGAINST COOKE
description: A former acting justice who served in State Supreme Court for 10 1/2 years and was recently reassigned to a lower court has joined a lawsuit against Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke's new rotation plan.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Reflects $790,000 pretax gross profit gain from inventory adjustment

title: Ryder and Hall Set Stock Plan
description: Frank B. Hall & Company, a leading insurance brokerage, said that Ryder System Inc. has agreed not to buy more than 10 percent of Hall's outstanding shares pending a hearing on Hall's motion for a preliminary injunction against further purchases by Ryder.

title: EXCERPTS FROM VOLCKER'S TESTIMONY TO COMMITTEE
description: Following are excerpts from testimony of Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, today before the House Committee on Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs:

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 25-year-old woman who was six months pregnant was raped at gunpoint and stabbed in the stomach at about 12:45 A.M. after she entered what she thought was a gypsy cab. The woman, who was not identified, was attacked after the driver of the ca r drove her about 20 blocks to Boston Road and Wilkins Avenue, near Crotona Park, the Bronx, where he raped her.

title: Whittaker Raises Brunswick Offer
description: The Whittaker Corporation yesterday sweetened its $320 million offer to acquire the Brunswick Corporation amid reports that Brunswick, which has been fighting the move, has agreed to sell a key division for $450 million to an unidentified company.

title: CONTINENTAL AND ALLIED TO BUY SUPRON
description: Moving further into the oil and gas business, the Allied Corporation and the Continental Group announced yesterday that they had agreed to buy the Supron Energy Corporation of Dallas on a 50-50 ba sis for $35 a share, or $714 million in cas h.

title: Sit-In in Spanish Prisons
description: More than 350 prison guards have locked themselves in jails throughout Spain to protest working conditions, a prison spokesman said today. Enrique Galavis, the prison director, was due to meet representatives of the guards, who want better pay, more help and improved fringe benefits.

title: Gulf Repurchase
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it has authorized another stock repurchase program to buy back 10 million of its common shares.

title: AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS AND LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-There is no year-ago share earnings figure because the company first issued stock in December 1980

title: BYRD ASKS PRESIDENT TO RESUBMIT HIS 1983 BUDGET
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, today called on President Reagan to withdraw his proposed budget for the fiscal ye ar 1983 in the face of what the West Virginia Democrat called mounti ng ''cries of shock'' from both Democrats and Republicans.

title: BRITISH STUDY EMBRYO 'BANKS'
description: A plan to set up ''banks'' of frozen embryos has prompted a government investigation of the ethics of ''test tube'' baby techniques, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today.

title: MCGRAW-EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1981 quarter and year results reflect the adoption of foreign currency translation accounting change

title: WEINBERGER, IN JORDAN, DISCUSSES SALE OF U.S. ANTIAIRCRAFT MISSILES
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger completed a brief visit to Oman today, flew to the aircraft carrier Constellation in the Gulf of Oman, and then came here tonight to discuss the sale of air defense missiles and possibly F-16 fighters to Jordan.

title: Israel Assails Vote in U.N.
description: The Israeli Parliament in Jerusalem today rejected a United Nations resolution condemning the annexation of the Golan Heights. The opposition abstained from the vote in Parliament because it was critical of the Government's extension of Israeli law to the area.

title: FIRST OF SURPLUS CHEESE IS GIVEN TO CITY'S NEEDY
description: A scuffle broke out at a church in Queens yesterday when the church ran out of surplus cheese that it was distributing to the needy. Almost 200 people were left waiting in line in the cold on New York City's first day of participation in the Federal Government's nationwide program.

title: MOUTAIN MEDICAL EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page picture caption yester- day misidentified the diplomat sitting at the Madrid conference on European security with Leonid F. Ilyichev of the Soviet Union. He was Yuri V. Dubinin, Soviet Ambassador to Spain.

title: DETERMINING TAX BILL: CHARTS ARE REDESIGNED
description: For any taxpayer, the bottom line is fi guring out how much he or she owes the Government. There are two basic ways to determine the tax that must be paid. One can use the tax tables, in which the tax is precompute d, or the tax rate schedules, which require separate calculations. This year, major design changes will make either computation a new exercise for many people. With taxable income under $50,000, the easiest way to figure the tax is to consult the tax tables, because they do not require any mathematical computations; the appropriate tax is already on the printed page. The numbers incorporate the 1 1/4 percent general tax credit, reflecting the 5 percent across-the-board tax cut that went into effect last Oct. 1.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: IT was in 1945 or thereabouts that the news got around that the open fire was on its way out all over the developed world. In London, where I lived at the time, this came as a blow. London houses had in their every room a chimney and a chimney piece and sometimes a chimney corner.

title: SALE OF SINGLE TICKETS HIT BY RECESSION
description: THERE has been a significant drop in single-performance ticket sales for concerts in some of New York's major concert halls - Avery Fisher Hall, Alice Tully Hall and Carnegie Hall -and an increased tendency for last-minute buying of tickets. Ex ecutives at Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall attribute the drop t o the recession in the economy.

title: ATHLONE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $1,767,000

title: WEAN UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WHITE HOUSE AIDE RESIGNS IN AFTERMATH OF LOANS
description: Joseph W. Canzeri, a White House official, resigned today after a disclosure that he had borrowed $400,000 on favorable terms from Laurance S. Rockefeller and a California developer to purchase a town house in the capital.

title: NATIONAL GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1980 have been restated

title: Half a Judicial Loaf
description: To a state whose judiciary is much too distracted by buck-passing and acrimony, Governor Carey has quietly offered a significant - and workable - reform. His justice message last week asked New York's Legislature for a constitutional amendment to merge the Balkanized trial courts into a single system. To speed it along, he offered to drop his standing request to halt the election of judges.

title: UNITED ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THEATER: ECHOES OF 1945, 'THE POTSDAM QUARTET'
description: THE scene is Potsdam, 1945, and Churchill, Stalin and Truman are carving up Europe to suit individual purposes. While world leaders yearn, ''The Potsdam Quartet'' fiddles. Four British musicians soothe the statesmen with Haydn, Bartok and - special request from Stalin - Borodin. David Pinner's play ''The Potsdam Quartet'' (a New York Theater Workshop production at the Lion Theater) takes place in an antechamber between concerts. The idea, one assumes, is to parallel the political division of spoils with a commentary on the decline of the empire. This may be what Mr. Pinner has in mind, but it is not what he has on stage.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $884,000 for the quarter and $674,000 for the year

title: 6 SALVADORAN SOILDERS FACE COURT IN SLAYING OF AMERICAN NUNS
description: El Salvador's military authorities today surrendered six National Guard soldiers to a civilian court that will decide whether they should be tried in the murder of three American nuns and a lay worker 14 months ago.

title: ALZA CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec31

title: More on the Stoop
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Permit me as an architectural historian to present a different interpretation of the New York stoop than contained in the letter recently printed (''Brownstone Stoops,'' Jan. 28, in response to ''The Front Stoop Makes a Comeback,'' Jan. 7).

title: Lab Technician Changes Story in Von Bulow Case
description: A hospital technician changed her account today and testified that tests showing a high insulin level in the blood of Martha von Bulow were taken before doctors gave her glucose.

title: L OW FARES CITED AS CAREY VETOES PATH'S BUDGET
description: Calling the 30-cent PATH fare unreasonably low, Governor Carey has vetoed the commuter system's $80 million 1982 budget. It was the Governor's first veto of a decision by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the agency that runs the PATH system.

description: The 1980 share earnings restated for 10% stock dividend paid in December 1981

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Cleveland Electric Illuminating filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $75 million of 30-year fi rst mortgage bonds, withunderwriters led by Morgan Stanley.

title: Market Place; Australia's Se arch for Oil
description: SPECULATORS in Australian oil shares hope that a growing exploration effort Down Under will lead to big profits. Australia has been encouraging exploration to reduce its dependence on Saudi Arabian oil, which now accounts for about 35 percent of what the nation uses. Virtually all of Australia's domestic oil comes from the Gippsland Basin in the southeast.

title: POPE EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year ago results have been restated for the acquisition of putman Mills as of July 1 1980
