'TARGETED' AT REP. RICHMOND, SUSPECT CHARGES
description: A defendant in a Federal drug case has provided a detailed account of how he sai d Government agents entrapped him and sought to turn him into an i nformer against a United States Representative.

title: COMPUTER MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: Results are historical and not pro forma

title: WNYC to Feature Carter and Glass
description: AM and FM will broadcast two different performances of Elliott Carter's new work, ''Night Fantasies,'' this month. Also scheduled are broadcasts of Philip Glass's Music in 12 Parts.

title: QUEBECOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $1,774,000 loss from discontinued operations; C-After $354,000 loss from discontinued operations and $496,000 special gain; 1980 results restated to reflect discontinued operations of Philadelphia Journal

title: HEAD OF PENSION PANEL SAYS CONSENSUS IS UNLIKELY
description: The chances are less than 50-50 that the new commission studying Social Security will be able to produce a clear majority in favor of any package of recommendations, according to the commission's chairman.

title: IN THRIVING TULSA, FEW WORKERS' HANDS ARE IDLE
description: John and Mary Bross, two refugees among the great stream arriving here from the economically stricken North, have never stayed in the $423-a-night executive suite in downtown Tulsa's understatedly elegant new Excelsior Hotel, where neither the nearzero freeze of Oklahoma winter nights nor the economic chill afflicting most of the country can penetrate.

title: BAYLESS, A J, MARKETS INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Jan 2
description: Results are for 12 weeks and 52 weeks for the latest periods and 3 and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods

title: BLACK CAUCUS IN ALBANY SUES FOR DISTRICTING PLAN
description: The Black and Puerto Rican Caucus of the State Legislature today sued the leaders of the Legislature to force them to agree on new Senate, Assembly and Congressional district lines by March 1.

title: Joe Greene Retires
description: Saying that his ''plans are to live, to enjoy the easy life,'' Joe Greene announced his retirement as a player after 13 seasons as a defensive tackle for the Pittsburgh Steelers. Greene, who is 35 years old, was selected as an all-pro in 10 seasons.

title: MAPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CANCER AGENCY REVOKES GRANT TO RESEARCHER
description: The National Cancer Institute disclosed today that it was withholding the remainder of a three-year grant it had awarded a New York cancer researcher who was under investigation on charges of falsifying data at the Boston University Medical Center.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: In winter, when boots and shoes frequently get wet, it is handy to have a sure way to dry them right down to the toes overnight. There are two electric shoe and boot dryers available in several catalogues which put out gentle and steady heat which will dry overnight but will not, according to the manufacturers, make shoes and boots stiff or cracked.

title: MEDIQ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After income from discontinued operations and nonrecurring items of $7,000 inlatest quarter and $573,000 in earlier period

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $2,346,000 related to the disposal of Autovox SPA

title: Poland Said To Reduce Bank Debt
description: Poland is steadily reducing its outstanding debt on interest payments due Western banks last year, probably with help from Moscow, banking sources said here today.

title: WOMETCO CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-Includes $1,697,000 gain from the sale of subsidiary

title: Bomb Injures a German Who Organized Escapes
description: A West German who is said to have helped hundreds of East Germans escape to the West was badly injured when a letter bomb went off at his hotel in this B avarian resort, the police said today.

title: GDANSK WORKERS UNBOWED, AWAIT THEIR SPRING
description: All was quiet inside the Lenin Shipyard today. Quiet but not quite normal. ''How can anything be normal?'' demanded a 42-year-old worker in a yellow hard hat standing to one side in a cavernous hull shop as automatic cranes swept back and forth carrying hunks of steel on giant magnets.

title: JHIRMACK ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After extraordinary gain of $460,000

title: Air Force Plans to Add 100 Missile Warheads
description: The Air Force disclosed today that it would increase by 100 the number of nuclear warheads in its landbased intercontinental missile force.

title: POLICEMAN SLAIN IN A SHOO TOUT
description: An off-duty Housing Authority police officer in civilian clothes was shot to death in an exchange of gunfire in Brooklyn's East Flatbush section shortly before 1 A.M. today, a police spokesman said.

title: U.S. Steel Debt Payment Set
description: The United States Steel Corporation said it will attempt to pay back the $3 billion it borrowed to acquire the Marathon Oil Company within two years, partly by selling approximately $1 billion in assets this year and next.

title: PANEX reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: B-Includes $919,000 tax credit

title: INDIANA FINANCIAL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Archibald Cox Retiring
description: The first special prosecutor in the Watergate case, Archibald Cox, will retire from full-time teaching at the Harvard Law School in the spring.

title: 1,575 Seek Six Driver Jobs
description: The personnel department at Pierce Transit is hopping these days. Openings for six part-time bus driver positions brought applications from 1,575 people.

title: MOLSON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $2 million writeoff from the sale of Vilas Furniture unit; the company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto Stock Exchanges

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC GROUP
description: MONDAY'S concert by the New York New Music Ensemble at Carnegie Recital Hall took a look at some of the basic themes of 20th-century music.

title: 'ISRAEL HAS LOVED THE SINAI'
description: To the Editor:

title: COAST CONCERN CITED ON 'FALSE STATEMENT' ABOUT NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that the Pacific Gas and Electric Company had made ''material false statements'' about its Diablo Canyon nuclear plant in California.

title: CENTRONICS DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
AGAINST TRIDENT II
description: Surprisingly, alone among the new generation of strategic weapons, the Trident II submarine-launched ballistic missile has v irtually escaped public criticism.

title: Q & A
description: Q. The beige tiles and the sink in my bathroom have become chipped and show signs of wear. Is there any kind of durable paint that can be applied to these worn spots and cracks? - J.J.S., New York City.

title: COURT GIVEN DATA ON U.S.-BELL PACT
description: The Justice Department, in papers filed today with the United States District Court here, says it will ''work closely'' with the states, Federal agencies and ''interested parties'' in deciding the final form of the divestiture plan it will accept from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to settle the Government's antitrust case.

title: WINTER, JACK, INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $200,000 gain from discontinued operations; C-After $1,177,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Ted Stepien, the owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, has paid $35,875 to Gayle Falinski, who received a broken right wrist on June 25, 1980 when she was hit by a softball that Stepien dropped from the top of the 700-foot Cleveland Terminal Tower as a stunt designed to promote a softball team that Stepien then owned. ... Bob Gross, a forward who is the last remaining member of the Portland Trail Blazer team that won the National Basketball Association championship in 1977, has asked to be traded. Gross said he is unhappy coming off the bench in relief of Calvin Natt.

title: A LAW BY ANY OTHER NAME
description: For reasons now lost in history, the Embargo Act of 1807 was popularly dubbed ''The Oh! Grab Me Act.'' So says no less an authority than the United States Code, a compilation of the nation's laws, which lists what it calls the ''popular names'' by which certain statutes were or are known.

title: PUBLISHERS SAY CITY IS STILL CENTER OF INDUSTRY
description: Some of New York's major book publishers say it would be difficult to maintain a successful trade-book publishing operation outside the New York metropolitan area.

title: RCA CUTS VIDEODISK UNIT'S PRICE
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that it had slashed the suggested retail price of its videodisk player by $150, as part of what an official called a ''shift in strategy'' to bolster sales.

title: U. N. Palestine Refugee Unit Short of Funds for Education
description: Olof Rydbeck, head of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, said today at a news conference that the agency would have to shut schools for 339,000 children under its care unless it received $20 million within six weeks.

title: AVX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; results include discontinued operations

title: ROBERT N. RICKLES, LED CLEAN-AIR UNIT
description: Robert N. Rickles, who served as Commissioner of Air Resources under Mayor John V. Lindsay, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Central Motel in Albany. He was 46 years old and a resident of North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: STAGE: KIMBERLEY'S 'UNICORN' AT THE NO SMOKING PLAYHOUSE
description: IN ''The Unicorn'' at the No Smoking Playhouse, the playwright, Michael Kimberley, ingenuously violates several cardinal rules of dramaturgy. Never begin with a rifle on stage unless you want to trigger your conclusion. Never name two brothers Louie and Hughie unless you want to make the audience think about Donald Duck. And, most of all, avoid unicorns and all glass figurines as symbols. Break these rules, particularly if you smash a glass unicorn, and it is two acts of bad luck for theatergoers.

title: OCCIDENTAL NET UP 35.5%
description: The Occidental Petroleum C orporation reported yesterday that strongearnings gain s by its coal division offset declines in oil and gas earnings and helped lift 1981 fourth-quarter earnings by 35.5 percent. Reve nues advanced 40.6 percent.

title: ATLANTA EXPERTS DISPUTE IDEA OF BODY DROPPED OFF BRIDGE
description: A water expert and a diver testified today that it was unlikely that Nathaniel Cater's body was thrown into the Chattahoochee River from the spot where prosecutors say Wayne B. Williams dropped it.

title: YOUNG ROBBER STABS A CHILD OF 9 AND THEN SETS A FIRE UNDER HIM
description: A 9-year-old boy was stabbed four times and left bleeding on a burning mattress in his Bronx apartment Tuesday afternoon. The police said his assailant was 12 to 15 years old and that he smashed the boy's piggy bank and fled with a handful of dollar bills.

title: CONSULTANT FOR MANAGEMENT
description: Edwin O. Griffenhagen, a consulting management engineer who founded Griffenhagen & Associates, now known as Griffenhagen-Kroeger Inc., of New York City, died Tuesday in Quincy, Ill.

title: HARTE-HANKS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect acquisitions on a pooling of interests basis

title: Cuomo Plans to Run Despite Talk by Koch
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo denied yesterday that his prospective candidacy for Governor had been deflected by Mayor Koch's talk of running.

title: FRENCH APPROVE NEW SOVIET LOAN
description: A group of French banks announced an agreement today to lend the Soviet Union $140 million more to help finance purchases of French-made equipment for construction of a 3,000-mile natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe that the United States does not want built.

title: ELLIS ISLAND SOUTH
description: The exodus of desperate Haitians to South Florida has raised hackles, fears and some decent sympathies. So many gripping issues are entangled that there is a tendency for outrage to narrow into lines that never meet. That can't ease matters, let alone produce solutions.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER SOCIETY PERFORMS DVORAK
description: THE Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society, with its eccentric programming of rarely heard works, already acknowledges that our concert halls are museums. It is just determined to add a bit of spice to the exhibitions.

title: BRIEFS
description: * General Host Corp. said it had purchased 140,500 shares of its common stock, or 2.8 percent of the total outstanding, for $10 a share, or $1,405,000.

title: THE ANATOMY OF BIGGEST TRADE
description: UP in front of the Mets' logo and behind a cluster of microphones, George Foster was wearing a gray velour jacket, a gray shirt, a gray tie and a rosy outlook befitting someone who had just been guaranteed $10 million. For the first time in their history, the Mets had a Tiffany hitter on display in their Diamond Club, and now somebody asked George Foster if, when he was with the Cincinnati Reds, he was ever distracted by jetliners taking off from nearby La Guardia Airport and thundering over Shea Stadium.

title: ARVIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''It really is a joy to have something of your own.

title: WHAT JAPANESE FIRMS IN THE U.S. THINK OF LABOR: A CASE IN POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: CREATORS OF MUSICALS PAY HOMAGE TO THE PAST
description: ONE of the incidental amusements of watching Broadway musicals is to notice how often their creators pay homage to their own past hits - or to other people's. Although sometimes such regurgitations can lead to artistic dead ends - witness the recycling of ''Follies'' in ''Merrily We Roll Along'' - the references to the past are often sly, affectionate, appealing.

description: Candidate at State

title: URBAN-BUSINESS PARTNERSHIPS URGED IN FACE OF BUDGET CUTS
description: Faced with budget cuts and President Reagan's program of ''new feder alism,'' the b est hope for the nation's urban areas is to form partnerships with business, the Committee for Economic Development said today .

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
East Germans Jailed by Swiss For Espionage Against Iran
description: An East German couple found guilty of spying on Iran for the Soviet Union were sentenced to prison today by a Zurich district court.

title: Texaco Closings
description: T exaco U.S. A., a unit of Texaco Inc., said that it would close its refineries in West Tulsa, Okla., and Casper, Wyo., because both have been marginal in operating efficiency.

title: People
description: * William C. Allen and Peter F. Rossi named senior vice presidents at the DR Group.

title: OIL FINISH HELPS OAK GAIN FAVOR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores furniture for antique dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: VW Offers Rebate
description: In an effort to counteract a sharp decline in sales, Volkswagen of America said it would offer $350 cash incentives to buyers of 1982 VW Rabbit sedans and pickups, its first direct rebate program. The offer, which applies to vehicles bought and delivered between Feb. 11 and April 10, puts VW in line with the other major domestic auto makers that have announced rebate programs in recent weeks. A spokesman for VW said the Rabbit rebate offer ''is a response to the current competitive environment in the automotive market.''

title: ARAFAT ASKS ARABS TO WELCOME P.L.O.
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has called on Arab countries along Israel's borders to allow their territory to be used for guerrilla activity. While he mentioned no names, he was apparently addressing Syria and Jordan.

title: NORTH CAROLINA COPES WITH CUTS
description: North Carolina officials, like those in other states, have gained the unenviable power of deciding which services to deliver and which to cut. And choose they must. New Federal budget reductions, begun in the current, 1982 fiscal year, will increase in fiscal 1983.

title: BUDGET SEEN IMPERILING PUBLIC BROADCASTING
description: Frank Mankiewicz, president of National Public Radio, said today the Administration's proposed budget reduced spending on public broadcasting so much that it threatened plans to shift toward private-sector support.

title: POP: BOBBY & THE MIDNITES
description: BOB WEIR, the singer, writer and guitarist who has contributed as much, if not more, to the success of the Grateful Dead than anyone else, appeared last week with his own band, Bobby & the Midnites, at the Palladium. They turned in a three-hour set that was considerably sharper and more disciplined than one might expect from the Grateful Dead and their extended family.

title: STOUFFER RULING UPHOLDS PROSECUTION
description: The judge in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial today rejected a defense claim of prosecutorial misconduct. He said he had found there was ''no suppression of evidence'' before the grand jury.

title: Rockies Consider Lawsuit
description: Peter Gilbert, owner of the Colorado Rockies, has given the National Hockey League until 5 P.M. Tuesday to discuss an $8 million offer he has made to the league to gain unanimous approval of his application to move the franchise to the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Net Income Up 22.1% At Ogilvy & Mather
description: Ogilvy & Mather International yesterday was the first of the public agencies to announce fourth-quarter results, and they were good.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1982
description: International A new West European-Soviet accord was announced by a group of French banks. They said they had agreed to lend the Soviet Union an additional $140 million to help finance purchases of French-made equipment for a planned 3,000-mile natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe. As a result, the Soviet Union will not have to use its own scarce foreign currency. (Page A1, Column 1.) The importance of Western unity in the face of the crackdown in Poland was stressed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. Speaking at a news conference in Madrid, Mr. Haig said that Washington should not bring additional pressure on its West European allies to slow or halt their plan to build the natural gas pipeline from the Soviet Union. (A1:1-2.)

title: CONGRESS DIVIDED ON CLEAN AIR BILL
description: With its chairman describing it as a bad bill even before debate started, a subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee began consideration today of comprehensive legislation to amend the Clean Air Act of 1970.

title: BEEFSTEAK CHARLIE'S INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,120,000, or 32 cents a share, for th latest year and $938,000, or 38 cents a share, for the previous year

title: Two Episcopal Vicars Are Named by Cooke
description: Msgr. Emerson J. Moore and the Rev. Victor R. Yanitelli have been appointed episcopal vicars of Central Harlem and East Manhattan, respectively, the Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday.

title: PREMATURE ATTACK ON SOUTH AFRICAN PRESS LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: NATURAL GAS ASSOCIATION IN MANAGEMENT SHIFT
description: Those who follow the twists and turns of natural gas politics regard the next few weeks as crucial. Either President Reagan will decide to send up a bill to accelerate decontrol of gas prices or the already reduced prospects for such legislation this year will completely evaporate.

title: BIC APPOINTS FOUNDER'S SON AS PRESIDENT
description: Bruno Bich, the 35-year-old son of the founder of the Bic Pen empire, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Bic Pen Corporation, based in Milford, Conn. As president, he succeeds Robert P. Adler, 48, who was named chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer of the company, which is controlled by Societe Bic of France.

title: EVENING OF JANA HAIMSOHN
description: JANA HAIMSOHN presented her ''vocal/music/dance/ language/performance art'' at the Kitchen on Tuesday night. While no facet of that description could have stood on its own with much potency, together they added up to an engaging portrait of Miss Haimsohn herself.

title: ALBA-WALDENSIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
4 POLISH MINERS JAILED IN STRIKE
description: Four Silesian coal miners were jailed today on charges of having organized a strike in which nine people were killed during the first week of martial law in Poland.

title: Smith-Templeton Deal
description: The long-negotiated trade that would send Ozzie Smith from the San Diego Padres to the St. Louis Cardinals for Garry Templeton is apparently about to take place. The Cardinals have scheduled a ne ws conference this morning, presumably to announ ce the exchange of shortstops.

title: News Analysis
description: The 17-month-old border war between Iraq and Iran has brought a new set of tensions to the Middle East in recent days.

title: JOHN HANCOCK INVESTORS INC reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets figures represent net assets; shares outstanding are capital shares

title: NEW YORK CITY HONORS EIGHT OF ITS OWN
description: IT was one of those rare occasions when well-known New Yorkers play second fiddle to the city's less-heralded citizens, and the result Tuesday night at the sixth annual New Yorker for New York Awards was a well-orchestrated evening of dinner, dancing, speechmaking and camaraderie.

title: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest year include a gain of $4,455,000 from the sale of Omnicare Inc stock and a gain of $881,000 on the sale of an Australian licensee; results for the previous year include a gain of $1,070,000 on the sale of Quaker Chemical stock and a gain of $318,000 from the sale of fixed assets

title: HOME BEAT
description: BECAUSE of the recent brouhaha about the expensive china Nancy Reagan ordered for the White House, Carleton Varney, an interior decorator, is particularly insistent that the pattern he designed for another First Lady was in the planning stages two years ago. ''You don't create a line of china overnight,'' he said.

title: And Now, a Log Cabin for an Ex-President
description: There was a time when Presidential candidates made political capital of having been born in a log cabin, and a few Presidents were.

title: OREGON PORTLAND CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brazilian Trade Surplus
description: Brazil's balance of trade swung to a surplus of $50 million in January from a deficit of $133 million a year earlier, the Finance Ministry reported today. Exports were $1.7 billion in January, up less than 1 percent. Imports were $1.7 billion, down 9.4 percent.

title: Sawdon & Bess Gains
description: Sawdon & Bess, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, has added its fourth Pontiac dealers association, having gone to San Diego to do it. And, the agency reports, the Pontiac Dealers of Southern California will be spending about $1 million on advertising. The previous agency was Jack Lawlor Advertising in Pasadena, Calif.

title: A SHORTCUT TO SPRING: FORSYTHIA BRANCHES
description: Rare is the garden that does not have at least one forsythia. The ubiquitous shrub is the gardener's shortcut to spring. Branches clipped now will bloom indoors in a week to 10 days. The closer the season for blooming outdoors, the faster the shrub will force indoors.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MRS. CHISHOLM PLANS TO RETIRE FROM CONGRESS
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of New York and the first black woman to win a seat in Congress, said today that she would not seek another term.

title: LAKER HINTS AT A NEW AIRLINE VENTURE
description: Sir Freddie Laker all but announced plans today for a new cut-rate service even as his Laker Airways empire began to break apart.

title: GRANT TINKER'S FIRST SIX MONTHS AT THE HELM OF NBC
description: IN the six months since Grant Tinker replaced Fred Silverman as NBC's chief executive, the network's severe crisis shows News An alysis little sign of abating, but the style of dealing with it has plainly changed.

title: Schools to Require Foreign Language
description: Beginning in 1985, students earning diplomas from New York City's public high schools must complete one year of study in a foreign language or pass a proficiency test in one, according to requirements to be promulgated later this month.

title: MGIC Delays Merger Vote
description: Stock prices of the Baldwin-United Corporation and the MGIC Investment Corporation tumbled after MGIC postponed a shareholders' vote on its proposed $1.2 billion acquisition by Baldwin-United.

title: Realty Trust Says It Can't Pay on Bonds; Troubled Realty Trust
description: The South Atlantic Financial Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in Miami, announced yesterday that it would be unable to pay at maturity $16.9 million worth of outstanding subordinated debentures that come due next Monday.

title: Pakistan Decides to Preserve Its Ban on Political Activity
description: President Mohammad Zia-ul-Haq and his Cabinet decided today not to lift a 28-month-old ban on political activity.

title: A FEDERAL 'SHELL GAME' ON MENTAL DISABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDERSON, IN A SOLO APPEARANCE, ASSAILS REAGANOMICS AT COLUMBIA
description: Little more than a year ago he swept into speaking halls surrounded by a phalanx of Secret Service agents, a jostling pack of reporters and camera crews at his heels.

title: Economic Analysis
description: In the face of evidence that the recession is still deepening, President Reagan and his economic advisers are predicting that the economy will turn around and grow strongly and inflation will slow in the second half of 1982 and later.

title: OKLAHOMA CHILDREN'S CENTER DROPS 2 AFTER ABUSE CHARGES
description: Two employees were dismissed from the Oklahoma Children's Center amid reports that a girl had been solicited for prostitution and other children had been allowed to grow marijuana, officials said today.

title: ON THE PRESSURES AND POLITICS OF WAITING ON LINE
description: THE British queue up and the Americans wait in line, except for New Yorkers, who wait on line. No one seems to know the reason for this local idiom. It is something to ponder while waiting in/on line. Another thi ng to ponder: It is estimated that Americans spend up tofive years of their lives in that tedious, stressful but unavoidable process known as waiting. The estimate comes from Dr. Thomas Saaty, aUniversity of Pittsburgh mathematician and systems analyst who is also an autho rity on waiting lines or queues, as scientists call them.

title: WESTMINSTER BANK SELECTS NEW CHIEF
description: The National Westminster Bank, Britain's second-largest commercial bank after Ba rclays and the owner of the National Bank of North America, anno unced yesterday that Philip Wilkinson, now one of two deputy group chief executives, will become its new group chief executive, ef fective January 1983.

title: ALLIED MAINTENANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STAGE: 'WHALES OF AUGUST,' BY DAVID BERRY, AT THE WPA
description: DAVID BERRY'S ''The Whales of August,'' at the WPA, is set in a summer home off the Maine coast. But philosop hically and dramaticallyspeaking, this play is only a stone's throw f rom Ernest Thompson's Golden Pond. Mr. Berry gives us two quarrelso me elderly characters - in this case, widowed sisters from Philadelph ia - who have vastly different outlooks on old age. Spunky Sarah ( Bettie Endrizzi) believes that one can never live too long, th at every sunrise brings a new chance to seize the day. The crotchety, elder Libby (Elizabeth Council) is all too ready to give up and embr ace the ''escort'' of death.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan has asserted that criticism of his new budget was ''knee-jerk'' partisan politics, but his Republican allies in Congress are so dismayed by the prospect of huge deficits that they are talking of developing a bipartisan compromise that would revise the Reagan program without repudiating it.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Seeks Security Advice
description: Mayor Tom Bradley will meet with State Department officials to discuss security for diplomats, it was learned today.

title: 4 DEMOCRATS URGE U.S. TO SEEK A TRUCE IN SALVADOR
description: Four Democratic members of Congress introduced a resolution today calling on the Reagan Administration to seek an internationally supervised cease-fire in El Salvador and negotiations leading to a political solution to the civil war there.

title: ST JOHN'S WINS IN OVERTIME
description: St. John's withstood a strong comeback by Connecticut tonight, and in what Coach Lou Carnesecca described as ''the best game they've played this season,'' the Redmen won, 93-82, in overtime at Civic Center.

title: Agnes de Mille to Get The Blackwell Award
description: Agnes de Mille has been named recipient of the 1982 Elizabeth Blackwell Award.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,804,000 for the quarter and $7,668,000 for the year and $1,419,000 foreign currency loss for the quarter and $3,903,000 pre-tax foreign currency gain for the year and $3 million pre-tax gain for the quarter from the sale of investment tax credits and $34,715,000 pre-tax loss for the year from the sale of securities and $25,834,000 pre-tax provision for the year for costs related to the opening of Atlantic City Hotel and Casino;C-Net income after $56,000 loss from discontinued operations for the quarter

title: GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $9,000, or 1 cent a share, for the latest first quarter and $35,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year-ago first quarter on the dispositionof real estate and mortgages

title: FOR STENMARK, THE CHALLENGE GOES ON
description: Ingemar Stenmark gazed straight ahead, beyond the person who was questioning him in the crowded interview room. Except for its freckles, the skier's face could have been stone. His hands were folded and trembling.

title: Egypt-Canada Nuclear Pact
description: Egypt initialed an agreement today for the purchase of Canadian nuclear power equipment. The United States, France and West Germany have already agreed to build eight nuclear power stations in Egypt.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ANNUAL REPORT OF ECONOMIC COUNCIL
description: President Reagan transmitted his Economic Report to Congress today. The 357-page document, with explanatory tables, comprises the Economic Report of the President, signed by President Reagan, and the Annual Report of the Council of Economic Advisers, signed by Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman, and the other two members, Jerry L. Jordan and William A. Niskanen. The following excerpts are from the council's Annual Report: A Summary of Economic Conditions General economic conditions during 1981 reflected the transitory effects of the necessary changes in Federal economic policies. The major elements of the Administration's economic policy are designed to increase long-term economic growth and to reduce inflation. Uniformly favorable near-term effects were not expected.

title: NORWAY CUTS OIL PRICE
description: Norway will cut the price of its North Sea crude oil by $1.50 a barrel, a spokesman for Statoil, the Governmentowned oil company, said today. The new price of $33.50 a barrel will be effective early next week, the spokesman said.

title: BERG ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $71,250, or 5 cents a share, from the reduction of a liability in connection with the sale of a subsidiary in an earlier year

title: JAZZ: HENDERSON BACK EAST AGAIN
description: JOE HENDERSON, a tenor saxophonist who established himself in the 1960's, playing with Horace Silver and Herbie Hancock, came East from California last week to play at the Lush Life, Bleecker and Thompson Streets, where he surrounded himself with an excellent local rhythm section - Joanne Brackeen, piano; Ron Carter, bass, and Adam Nussbaum, drums.

title: Defining the Money Supply
description: In his testimony before the House yesterday, Paul A. Volcker, Federal Reserve Board chairman, used terms to define the money supply that may not be generally familiar.

title: Advertising; Knoxville Fair Sets TV Spots
description: THE TV drum beating for the 1982 World's Fair in Knoxville, Tenn., begins this Saturday with 40 spot markets and will continue until the fair ends Oct. 31.

title: RENOVATION BRIGHTENS MT. VERNON
description: Two centuries after the American Revolution, an artistic revolution is transforming the interior of George Washington's stately home with bright, not to say garish, hues that scientific analysis has established beyond a molecule's doubt as the Founding Father's personal taste.

title: Buffalo G.I. Found Unfit for Trial
description: A 26-year-old Army private charged with killing one man and stab bing anot her on the same day in New York has been found mentally unfit to stan d trial.

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN WINS VOTE ON POLISH LOANS

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $179 million pretax gain from the first quarter sale of the Beta Field offshore southern California, $78.7 million attributable to a change in accounting for foreign currency from the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 and $20 million reduction from the early application of interpretation of FASB Statement No36; previous 1981 quarters have been restated to conform to the adoption of FASB Statement No52; fourth quarter results include the sale of Federal tax benefits and a large tax charge

title: WILDLIFE REFUGE IN JERSEY BLAZING TRAIL INTO 90's
description: In the winter, the Great Swamp sleeps. The golden saxifrage and swamp rose are gone, the green heron and blue-winged teal have flown south and the black oak stands bare in the wind.

title: ST. PATRICK'S DAY CLASSES SET BY CATHOLIC SCHOOLS
description: Roman Catho lic schools in the Archdiocese of New York, like Catholic scho ols elsewhere in the metropolitan area, will hold classes on St . Patrick's Day.

title: INVESTORS GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a special charge of $8,413,000; C-Including a special gain of $9,113,000

title: ELECTRONIC MODULES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
VOLCKER SAYS FED PLANS TO CONTINUE TIGHT MONEY STAND
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, announced today that in the coming year the central bank would continue to pursue a tight monetary policy. He said this policy was necessary to fight inflation but would still permit a recovery from the recession.

title: Aikens Wins Raise
description: Willie Aikens, Kansas City's first baseman, has won his salary arbitration case.

title: WARNING ON BANK DECONTROL DISPUTE
description: Senator Jake Garn, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, warned today that there may not be any action on bank deregulation in Congress this session if the banking and securities industries cannot resolve their differences.

title: Bridge: An Engli sh Author Packs Much Qual ity in 208 Pages
description: Quality apart, there are two measures of the value of a bridge book. You can count the cost per page, or you can estimate the amountof technical help for the reader.

title: REAGAN TERMS INFLATION FIGHT CRITICAL PRIORITY
description: In his first Economic Report to Congress, President Reagan declared today that his Administration was trying to break with past practice and create a strong, noninflationary economy ''in which the private sector is the key engine to growth, employment and rising living standards.''

title: DEPLETING OUR CAPITAL
description: BARRE, Pa., Feb. 10 - It did not generate big headlines at first, but around the country one idea in President Reagan's budget is arousing a new kind of concern and resistance. That is the proposal to cut back drastically - in many cases to eliminate - federally insured loans and other help for college and graduate school students.

title: HAIG OPPOSES CONTINUAL PRESSURE ON EUROPE OVER SOVIET GAS DEAL
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that, despite differences with the Western Europeans over a natural gas pipeline from the Soviet Union, the United States should not use the Polish crisis as an excuse to pressure them to cancel or cut back on the project.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New Yor k and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: MATHEMATICAL APPLICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VERMONT AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings for 1980 reflect a 15% stock dividend declared in November 1981 and paid in January 1982

title: EXPANDED PAY TV OVER AIR IS SOUGHT
description: In a development that could signal the strongest threat yet to cable television, a New York communications company sought permission yesterday to create over-the-air services that would offer five channels of pay television and other information services. The company , the Microband Corporation of America, urged the Federal Commu nications Commission to allow three such ''wireless cable'' syste ms in each of the nation's 50 largest television markets.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on health insurance on the Style page last Saturday incorrectly reported the part of the charge t hat a patient covered byMedicare must pay for a hospital stay. Since Jan. 1, a patient must pay the first $260 plus $65 a day if hospital ized from 61 to 90 days.

title: EASTERN CO reports earnings for Yr to Jan 2
TWO VISA DISPUTES ANNOY AND INTRIGUE INDIA
description: The award of a United States entry visa to an Indian advocate of Sikh separatism and the denial of a Soviet visa to an Indian Communist who holds the Order of Lenin have raised indignation and speculation here in the last week.

title: EARNINGS; Continental Telephone Advances 24.5%
description: The Continental Telephone Corporation reported yesterday that rate increases helped lift net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 by 24.5 percent, while sales advanced 37.5 percent.

title: Addendum
description: * Spring magazine, to have its premiere issue in April, will increase its rate base to 400,000 from 250,000 with its first regular issue in October.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt FEVER. By Robin Cook. 365 pages. Put- nam. $13.95.

title: HOLLINGS TO THE RESCUE
description: Senator Ern est F. Hollings of South Carolina is a mong the few entitled to ask sharp questions of those who voted las t year for the Reagan tax cuts and now proclaim their anguish at th e impending deficits their votes helped produce. Such questions as:

title: ANDREW YOUNG'S ATLANTA PLAN
description: When Andrew Young, Atlanta's new black Mayor, talks about his plans for running local government, he generates considerable enthusiasm in the white business establishment that had become disenchanted with Maynard Jackson, his predecessor and the city's first black Mayor.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes 1.8 million gain from the sale of real estate

title: IMC MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; Undervalued P arking Lots
description: ''ALLRIGHT AUTO PARKS is not for sale,'' its chairman, A.J. Layden, said by telephone. But that has not discouraged a Hong Kong group now seeking control of the nation's largest operator of parking lots. The group, led by Deanlake Investments, tol d the Securities and Exchange Commission in January that it had pu rchased 14 percent of Allright's stock and went on to say that it i ntended to increase its holdings to 51 percent.

title: No Meeting on Rockies
description: John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, said he was undecided when to reconvene the board of governors to discuss the fate of the Colorado Rockies. Peter Gilbert, the Rockies' owner, wants to move them to Byrne Meadowlands Arena and has privately said he is considering an antitrust suit if the league doesn't take him up on his pledged $8 million inducement to the league.

title: WEATHER OFFIC
description: Weather offices at the three major airports in the New York metropolitan area would be closed under the Reagan Administration's proposed 1983 budget and most of the airports' weather services would be performed by private forecasters or shifted to the Federal Aviation Administration, officials of the National Weather Service said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Officials of Norte Vista High School ordered the coach of its girls' basketball team, which lost to Riverside Poly, 179-15, last Jan. 26 to forfeit tonight's rematch.

title: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: B-Net loss; C-After $397,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: 2 Views at Shortstop
description: Ozzie Smith is happy to join the St. Louis Cardinals and Garry Templeton is glad to leave them. Said Smith: ''It took a long time, but it finally happened.

title: New Products Lag
description: The year is getting off to a slow start as far as new product introductions go, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News. There were only 75 compared with 85 in January last year and 90 that month in 1980. It includes a health food product for dogs with the brand name Cher Ami. Arf.

title: CABARET: DOROTHY LAMOUR
description: DOROTHY LAMOUR, who has been off the road since she toured in ''Hello, Dolly!'' 14 ye ars ago, is breaking i n a new nightclub act atIbis, 151 East 50th Street, a room where she sang many yea rs ago when it was called the Versailles.

title: ELEANOR POWELL, TAP DANCER OF STAGE AND FILMS, IS DEAD
description: Eleanor Powell, the exuberant, nimble tap-dancing star of dozens of Hollywood musicals in the 1930's and 40's, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 69 years old.

title: TELECONCEPTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DURIRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FLORENCE BARRY
description: Florence Barry, the founder of Encore Enterprises, a fashion resale business, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan.

title: NEW QUESTIONS POSED ABOUT TAPES IN INQUIRY ON MONTEFIORE ASSAULT
description: New questions emerged yesterday about two tape recordings that have become the focal point of an investigation into an attempted murder of a Bronx hospital administrator.

title: AT SOVIET FUR AUCTION, CAPITALISM REIGNS SUPREME
description: With a few bangs of a gavel here recently, a pokerfaced Soviet official started a process that should culminate sometime next winter when a small number of wealthy women take turns before furriers' mirrors, nod their approval and step into the street with coats valued at $75,000 to $100,000 apiece.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DISAGREEMENTS, BUT NO REBELLION
description: Angry dissent against Reagan Administration civil rights policies, simmering among career lawyers in the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division for months, boiled over recently after the Administration announced its plan to grant tax exemptions to segregationist public schools.

description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $1,600,000 on the exchange of 7% debentures; C-Net loss after a loss of $45,000 from discontinued operations

title: Financier Planning Laker Deal
description: Roland Rowland, a prominent financier here, said today that he expected to become a participant in a new ''people's'' airline with Sir Freddie Laker, to replace his closed Skytrain.

description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $800,000 for the quarter and $4.2 million for the year; C-Including an extraordinary gain of $2.8 million for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $2 million for the year

title: ODES TO VALENTINE AT 8 MANHATTAN CLUBS
description: SEVERAL of the singers and musicians who will be celebrating love musically this Valentine's Day weekend gathered around the reproducing piano at the New Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005), the other day to discuss the state of love songs.

title: 'QUEST FOR FIRE,' A PREHISTORIC ODYSSEY
description: NOT many movies demand the suspension of disbelief that Jean-Jacques Annaud's ''Quest for Fire'' insists upon, and earns. The audience is asked to imagine that it is seeing what a movie camera would have seen, had the movie camera been invented 80,000 years ago. Some skeptici sm is in order, but it vanishes fast. ''Quest for Fire'' is more than just a hugely enterprising science les son, although it certainly is that. It's also a touching, funny and suspenseful drama about prehumans.

title: Article 244532 -- No Title
description: A King County Superior Court jury has awarded $6.4 million to Christopher Thompson in his suit against the Seattle School District over a 1975 football spinal injury that left him paralyzed from the neck down.

title: UNWED COUPLE WINS STAY FROM EVICTION IN APPELLATE RULING
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday affirmed a lower-court ruling that landlords cannot evict unmarried couples from an apartment rented in the name of one of them simply because they are unmarried.

title: THE FOLLY OF GIVING OFFICIAL SPIES PRIVATE COVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: VENUE, PERILED
description: Congress is about to consider a proposal that, if e nacted, w ould severely curtail citizens' abil ity to ensure that the executive branch obeys the law.

title: ART SALES DUE NEXT WEEK
description: MODERN and Impressionist paintings, drawings and sculpture will be in the spotlight next week, with three sales of moderate-price art and an exhibition of a major collection that is to be sold next month in London. In an auction next Wednesday at 2 P.M., Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, will offer Paul Gauguin's ''Countryside in Brittany,'' an 1879 oil on canvas, which is estimated to sell for as much as $80,000; Pierre Bonnard's ''Woman Dressing,'' from around 1906 (up to $60,000), Armand Guillaumin's ''Windmills in Holland,'' dated June 1904 (up to $45,000), Maurice de Vlaminck's ''Houses and Wheat Fields'' (up to $45,000) and Maurice Utrillo's ''Church at Murato,'' a 1933 oil and black chalk on canvas (up to $45,000).

title: G.M. Shutdowns To Lay Off 26,200
description: The General Motors Corporation said it will temporarily close seven of its 29 domestic car and truck plants next week and will add another facility to the list of plants to be closed during the week of Feb. 22.

description: To the Editor:

title: FRANK W. REICKERT
description: Frank W. Reickert, the general manager of the United Nations catering services, died Wednesday in New York.

title: 51% OF MANHATTAN FELONY CHARGES FOUND REDUCED
description: A Police Department study tracking 3,000 felony arrests that were processed by the Manhattan District Attorney found that 51 percent were reduced to misdemeanors and concluded that a third of those reductions were not the result of legal problems.

title: TELEVISION SCRUTINIZED: COMEDY AND MAGIC SHOWS
description: ANYONE who plans to spend any part of this weekend glued to the television screen ought to consider Sunday's ''Nova'' episode at 8 P.M. on Channel 13 must viewing. Titled ''The Television Explosion,'' this hourlong documentary presents the potential dangers of new television technology in horrifying detail.

title: COURT OFFICERS STUDY FOR CAREER AS NURSES
description: They are burly types - even a bit tough. And from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. five days a week they need to be tough, as senior court officers who deal with a variety of perpetrators. But the other evening one of them helped an aged and confused man into bed at Long Island College Hospital with the gentleness of a mother tucking in a child.

title: Weekly Auto Output Jumps
description: United States auto makers planned to build 54 percent more cars this week than they did last week, but domestic auto production was expected to remain 16.2 percent below output in the same week last year, Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry journal, reported today.

title: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1982; The Economy
description: Businesses reduced inventories by 0.4 percent in December, matching the biggest decline during the 1975 recession, new Commerce Department figures indicated. The drop was interpreted as a sign that companies were trying to break out of the current downturn. The report said sales also fell, by 0.6 percent, leaving the inventoryto-sales ratio unchanged at 1.49. (Page D1.)

title: Suspect Arraigned In Brink's Robbery
description: The seventh suspect in the $1.6 million robbery on Oct. 20 of a Brink's armored truck was arraigned under heavy security Thursday in Rockland County Court.

title: LABARGE INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-Including a gain of $800,000 from changes in estimates of income taxes and a plant closing; C-Including an increase of $572,000 resulting from an accounting change

title: SCIENTIFIC SOFTWARE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The latest year share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split in Nov 1981

title: FRANCE DEFENDS NICARAGUAN DEAL
description: The French Defense Minister said today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had recently told Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson that the French sale of arms to Nicaragua was ''peanuts.''

title: FIGHTING DOGS' ATTACKS RAISE ALARM ON COAST
description: Last Sunday, a San Francisco man told the police, he was set upon by a pit bull when the dog's owner slipped the leash and shouted, ''Kill him, kill him!'' The dog attacked, biting the man on the abdomen, arm, hand and leg and sending him to the hospital.

title: GENERAL HYDROCARBONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ottawa Urges Rejection Of Power Sale to U.S.
description: The Canadian Government has stepped in to urge the rejection of a proposed sale of Ontario electricity to New Jersey because production of the electricity would produce acid rain. The proposal has embarrassed the Government and environmentalists, who fear that their campaign to persuade the United States to join in a program to reduce acid rain will be threatened.

title: WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN ABANDONS PLAN TO REINFORCE FIRST 40 MX SILOS
description: The Reagan Administration, again revising its plans for deploying the new MX missile, said today that it had dropped its proposal to place the missiles on a short-term basis in silos reinforced to withstand a nuclear attack.

title: Purse Fund to Benefit From Teletrack Betting
description: Purses for races at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga will be enriched later this year by payments from Teletrack, the New Havenbased facility that televises and takes bets on those races.

title: Cooling-Off Period
description: There was supposed to be a ''get- acquainted'' lunch next Wednesday between the new Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, and the Mayor of his host city, Edward I. Koch. But now Mr. Perez de Cuellar is saying that perhaps a delay is in order.

title: Judge Keeps Ban O n Nuclear Waste
description: A Federal judge extended his Feb. 1 order temporarily barring the transportation of large nuclear-waste shipments through New York City.

title: UNIT AGAIN TIES ASPIRIN TO REYE'S SYNDROME
description: The national Centers for Disease Control today reiterated an advisory to physicians and parents that treating children's chicken pox and viral infections with aspirin might increase the risk of Reye's Syndrome, a sometimes fatal disease.

title: OGILVY & MATHER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-The adoption of FASB Statement No 52 increased income by $380,000 for the quarter and $1,818,000 for the year; C-The adoption of FASB Statement No 52 increased income by $151,000 for he quarter and $117,000 for the year

title: FERRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DOUBLE HOLIDAY CREATS A SURGE IN TRAVEL BY AIR
description: For some, it is simply Friday. For others, today begins a four-day holiday. And for airlines to warmer places, it is busy. ''It's going to a very, very good weekend for Pan Am to Florida,'' said William H. Waltrip, president of Pan American World Airways. A spokesman for Eastern Airlines put it a bit differently. ''We're swamped,'' said Paula Musto, ''absolutely swamped.'' Eastern provides 20,000 seats every day between the three New York area airports and Florida, and, Miss Musto said, ''I'll guarantee almost every one will be full'' from today until Monday.

title: TEDDY BEAR MAKES IT
description: If that teddy bear sitting at a table with the British actors Peter Bull and Anthony Andrews at the Four Seasons yesterday looked familiar, there was a good reason.

title: MINNESOTA GAS CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
GARCIA'S OF SCOTTSDALE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
POPE STARTS WEST AFRICA TRIP TODAY
description: Nine months after an assassin's bullets nearly took his life, Pope John Paul II will resume his travels Friday with an seven-day, four-nation journey to West Africa.

title: SEVERAL KEY CHANGES MADE IN 3 STATES' TAXES
description: State taxes are usually an afterthought once the Federal return has been completed, but this year there are several important new developments that will affect residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. New York, for example, has lowered the maximum tax on wage and salary income, increased the standard deduction, and created a new tax credit for solar- and wind-energy systems installed in a residence. Connecticut has enacted a new unincorporated business tax and New Jersey has added a ''use'' tax form intended to extract sales tax from people who buy merchandise out of state.

title: DR. JAMES JOSEPH
description: Dr. James Joseph, professor of physics at St. John's University, died Wednesday at Queens General Hospital after suffering a heart seizure at the school earlier in the day. Dr. Joseph, who was a resident of Great Neck, L. I., was 56 years old.

title: FREE 1,000, EGYPTIAN COURT SAYS
description: An Egyptian court ruled today that 1,000 people jailed last September by President Anwar el-Sadat should be freed at once.

title: WHEELABRATOR-FRYE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $5.2 million loss from discontinued operations for the quarter and $1.3million gain from discontinued operations for the year; C-Includes $5.5 milliongain from discontinued operations

title: O.A.U. SAYS IT WILL PULL OUT FORCE UNLESS CHAD AND REBELS HALT WAR
description: The Organization of African Unity said today that it would withdraw its peacekeeping forces from Chad by June 30 unless President Goukouni Oueddei arranged a cease-fire and started negotiating with rebels who are trying to overthrow his Government.

title: ISRAELI HAWK IS NEW ENVOY
description: If Moshe Arens were doing what he really liked best, he would not be Israel's seventh ambassador to the United States. He would be designing airplanes.

title: LEISURE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; C-After a gain of $234,000 on exchange of debentures

title: CHEM-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNPREDICTABLE 'LOVE AND MONEY'
description: ''LOVE & MONEY,'' written, produced and directed by James Toback, is about a skinny, short-fused young man named Byron Levin (Ray Sharkey) who, when the film begins, is working in Los Angeles at a boring job in one of those banks that probably spends as much money advertising toasters as it does announcing interest rates.

title: WAY IS CLEARED FOR FEB. 22START OF STOUFFER TRIAL
description: Witnesses to the fatal Stouffer's Inn fire who were hypnotized to aid their memory will be permitted to testify in the arson and murder trial, according to a ruling today in Westchester County Court.

title: FOSTER, L B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Storytelling Sessions on West End Ave.; Storytelling Sessions On West End Avenue
description: At the stroke of midnight tomorrow, Ron Sopyla, actor, puppeteer and teller of tales, will share some bloodcurdling yarns from around the world as part of ''New York Storytelling,'' a monthlong program at the West Side Theater Center, West End Avenue and 107th Street. Earlier in the evening, at 8 and 10:30, ''Stories Before Dawn,'' tales about dreams, will be told by Anastasia Gourely and Lorraine Ackerman.

title: GF BUSINESS EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include $167,000, or 7 cents a share, for the latest fourth quarter andyear and $486,000, or 19 cents a share, for the year-ago fourth quarter and year from LIFO liquidations

title: MAYORS ASSERT PRESIDENT'S BUDGET THREATENS THE WELL-BEING OF CITIES
description: The United States Conference of Mayors, representing local officials in 840 cities, today joined the growing chorus of criticism of President Reagan's budget proposals.

title: COMDATA NETWORK reports earnings for Yr to Dec31
The Issue of Too Many Points
description: Ray Haskins has at times been accused of breaking the tradition among coaches of not trying to run up the score against opponents. Haskins is the coach of Alexander Hamilton High School, the Public Schools Athle tic League defending basketball champion. Last Wednesdaynight, his te am defeated Sheepshead Bay, 179-61, in its regular season finale .

title: U. S. WOULD REDUCE REGULATION OF LIQUOR INDUSTRY
description: The Reagan Administration, as part of its plan to abolish the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, proposed today a sharp curtailment in Federal regulation of the liquor industry.

title: HAIG, IN MOROCCO, SEEKS U.S. LANDING RIGHTS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and King Hassan II conferred here today on a wide range of topics, including the possibility of landing rights for the Rapid Deployment Force being planned for the Middle East.

title: TEXAS GAS TRANSMISSION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a $16,536,000 extraordinary charge; C-Includes $8,509,000 extraordinarygain

title: SAN JOSE TV STA TION WINS 2ND DUPONT AWARD IN A ROW
description: A 90-minute television documentary on the atomic bomb, ''The Day After Trinity,'' has brought television station KTEH of San Jose, Calif., its second consecutive $20,000 Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Award for independent broadcast productions. Jon Else produced the film.

title: BRIEFING
description: NOW, a Tactical Change

title: Isaiah Amended
description: And it came to pass that Blum, the Israelite, called Koch, the king of the city, to ask why the words of the great visionary of peace, Isaiah, were permitted to grace the wall opposite that citadel of lawlessness, the United Nations. Koch said he would not remove the inscription - about swords and plowshares - but would hasten to add words of indignation at the hypocrisy of the U.N.

title: The Man at the Controls In Sale of Laker Assets
description: After a successful all-night scramble to sell off two package-tour companies owned by Laker Airways, William Mackey, 57, who was appointed last Friday as one of the receivers in the bankruptcy of the British carrier, now faces an even more difficult problem: finding buyers for the crippled company's 20 grounded aircraft.

title: Shockley, Nobel Winner, Files For Senate Race in California
description: William Shockley, the Nobel Prizewinning physicist whose racial view of genetics has made him the center of international controversy, has filed to run for the Senate as a Republican.

title: Bonn Enforcing Curbs On Soviet Diplomats
description: West Germany has started to enforce existing travel limitations involving Soviet diplomats, informed sources said today.

title: THIOKOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $88,000 for the quarter and $192,000 for the year; C-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $365,000 for the quarter and $1,614,000 for the year

title: EXPLORATION SURVEYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STUDENTS LEARN HOW TO SHARE BY GIVING TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: Encouraged perhaps by compassionate teachers, youngsters are learning the meaning of sharing and giving, and many are contributing through their classrooms to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: GRACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANNE GAULT ANTONIADES
description: Anne Gault Antoniades, a retired United States Foreign Service officer in Greece who wrote many books about that country, died in Athens on Feb. 5. She was in her 80's. Mrs. Antoniades, a New York City native, joined the Foreign Service in the 1920's and was posted in several European cities before her assignment to the Embassy in Greece in 1930.

title: Peking Stresses Deng Retains All His Posts
description: China today mov ed to dampen speculationabout position of Deng Xiaoping, who has not been seen in public since Jan. 12, by saying he retained all his posts.

title: Hanauer Firm Censured
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured a New Jersey municipal bond dealer and several employees who it said had used fictitious accounts and other financial misdealings to hide the identity of customers.

title: BLUE CHIP STAMPS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including securities gains of $33,000; C-Including securities gains of $449,00

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 12, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the Drafting of an International Convention Against the Training of Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M.

title: PHONE-MATE reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Latest year results reflect change to LIFO accounting

title: A KIDNAPPING AS SEEN BY BERTOLUCCI
description: PRIMO (Ugo Tognazzi), who has risen from his peasant background to become the owner of a large cheese factory in Parma, northern Italy, awakens one morning in his factory's board room, surrounded by empty liquor bottles, half-filled glasses and the other debris of a riotous birthday party thrown for him by his employees. He has a terrible hangover and feels his age, but he is not unhappy.

title: Rebuff in Madrid
description: At the opening of Tuesday's session of the Madrid conference on European security, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. looked startled when he was approached by a man not on the agenda.

title: TAKEOVER BILL SIGNED IN FRANCE
description: France's industrial nationalization bill, the biggest Government takeover of private industry since World War II, was signed into law today by the Socialist Prime Minister, Pierre Mauroy.

title: Henry St. Cityscapes
description: As the artist Joseph Delaney saw it, not all the parades in New York City are confined to formal walks down Fifth Avenue.

title: 'MISSING' BY COSTA-GAVRAS
description: IN addition to making movies that galvanize the emotions in ways that can be simultaneously fascinating and infuriating, Costa-Gavras, the Greek-born, French film maker (''Z,'' ''The Confession''), also has a knack for stirring up publicity from the most unlikely sources.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cooper Industries said its joint venture with Rolls-Royce Ltd. had received three orders for more than $18 million to supply gas turbine-compression systems for use in Canada, the United States and Mexico. Cooper's share of the contracts is over $9 million.

title: FORT SMITH, HAS A BAD MORNING AFTER
description: Take a little hill town, flood it with refugees and Federal bureaucrats, overrun it with the world's press, then take them all away and what is left behind, in the case of Fort Smith, is 71,000 people with a touch of xenophobia. They have just told Washington essentially what Greta Garbo long ago told Hollywood.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If they like my language as much as I like their money, then we'll have an agreement.'' - Peter J. Pestillo, Ford negotiator at talks with auto union. (A17:3.)

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LEARNING THE SOCIAL GRACES AND OTHER RITES
description: The names of Peyton Carter, DeeDee Pflager and Jennifer Heller mean nothing on the charity circuit. Their faces are not seen at black-tie galas or at balls. Yet they know a thing or two about benefits, these three. Eleven-year-olds go to benefits, too.

title: UNITED STATES SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end from Oct 31 to Sept 30

title: INTEGRITY ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted

title: Supron Executives Receive a Bonanza
description: A.M. Weiderkehr, chairman of the Supron Energy Corporation, has plenty of money for cat food these days now that the Allied Corporation and the Cont inental Group have fo rmed a partnership to buy the company.

title: CITY STEPS UP COURT ACTIONTO AID HOMELESS AND OTHERS
description: Reacting to the death on the street last month of a homeless woman, the city is moving more quickly to get court permission to forcibly hospitalize people in immediate physical danger who refuse help.

title: Noguchi and 'Shinto' again.
description: WHAT should turn up as a gift to the city of Jacksonville, Fla., but ''Shinto, '' the dismembered sculpture by Isamu Noguchi that once hung in the N ew York headquarters of the Bank of Tokyo Trust Company at 100 Broadw ay. Two years ago the bank took down the 1,600-pound Noguchi, an a luminum rhomboid 17 feet long, which it commissioned in 1975 and whic h hung point down from the coffered ceiling of the lobby, on the ground that it frightened customers and employees. Too big to leave the bank in one piece, it was cut into a pile of sc rap metal and stored.

title: POLICE LOOKING FOR 2 IN BROOKLYN SLAYING OF A HOUSING OFFICER
description: Two gunmen may have taken part in the slaying of an off-duty Housing Authority police officer shortly after midnight yesterday near his home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: AMERICAN FILTRONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UGI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1982
description: International Three missions to El Salvador have been set by Democratic members of Congress amid rising uncertainty about United States policy there. The three delegations' trips were planned separately, Congressional aides said, because they are being undertaken for different committees and offices. (Page A1, Column 2.) Thousands of Syrian troops battled insurgents in the central city of Hama for the ninth day, according to Western diplomats in Damascus. The Government again denied that fighting was taking place. (A1:3-4.)

OUTLOOK FOR THE REVITALIZATION OF HARLEM
description: As the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development prepared to award 12 of the many brownstones it owns in Harlem, Anthony B. Gleidman, the agency's commissioner, kept telling reporters that the lottery's most significant point was the ''message'' being sent to private financial institutions.

title: Singer to Close Jersey Factory
description: The Singer Company, a diversified electronics, consumer products and aerospace manufacturer based in Stamford, Conn., said it will discontinue manufacturing operations at its Elizabeth, N.J., plant by the end of the year because of reduced demand for the industrial sewing machines produced there.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $35,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Kissinger 'Alert' at Hospital
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was ''alert'' and talking to doctors today, a day after undergoing open heart surgery to relieve three clogged arteries. His wife, Nancy, was permitted to visit him in the intensive care unit at Massachusetts General Hospital, where the 58-year-old patient was listed in stable condition.

title: Publisher Joins Manufacturer In Plan to Buy News Service
description: The Pulitzer Publishing Company said today that it had joined a New York industrial products company in attempting to purchase the assets of the States News Service in Washington.

title: AUTO TALKS REACH A PARTIAL ACCORD
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company reached tentative agreement today on an ''economic framework'' for a new contract, but Douglas A. Fraser, the president of the union, warned that other issues remained to be resolved.

title: TRUS JOIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PENTECOSTAL REUNION AT EMBASSY
description: The authorities permitted a 30-year-old Soviet Pentecoastal to return to the United States Embassy briefly today for a reunion with family members with whom she had shared refuge there until being hospitalized during a hunger strike.

title: DRIVERS' POTHOLES PLAGUE A BUSINESSMAN'S BOON
description: Eddie Murphy was working New Jersey Route 3 like a ball boy at a tennis match - standing poised on the shoulder until traffic whizzed by, then pouncing onto the roadway to snatch a hubcap and darting off. Holding up the gleaming, spoked wheel cover of a Cadillac, he predicted that 1982 would be a vintage year.

title: RADIOFONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A NEW MAN IS SELECTED BY THE CUBS
description: The odds are that President Reagan is blissfully unaware of the distinction, but he has been chosen for membership in one of Washington's most exclusive and recondite organizations, the Emil Verban Memorial Society.

title: Limon Troupe in Bronx
description: The Jose Limon Dance Company will present t hree works tonight at 8 in the Lehman College Center for the Performi ng Arts, on Bedford ParkBoulevard West, the Bronx. . On the program a re the premiere of a revised version of Murray Louis's ''Cleopatra ''; Anna Sokolow's ''Magritte, Magritte,'' and Limon's ''The Moo r's Pavane.'' Tickets are $7 to $11. For ticket and travel informat ion, call (212) 960-8833; Chargit, (212) 944-9300.

title: SAND IN MY SHOES
description: Let's see if we can figure out the direction of U.S. policy toward Cuba.

description: A superintendent in the city's Sanitation Department has been dismissed for allowing the illegal dumping of liquid wastes in a Staten Island landfill and for paying off a subordinate to help him, officials said yesterday.

description: The Reagan Cabinet is sharply divided over how much pressure to apply to European allies - and American technology suppliers - to try to block construction of a $10 billion pipeline to transport Siberian natural gas 3,000 miles to Western Europe.

title: PUBLISHING: BOARDROOM PRODUCES A COLUMNIST
description: ABOUT 18 months ago George P. Brockway was grousing about high interest rates and the Federal Reserve Board, when his luncheon companion suggested that he write an article about it. ''That weekend it rained, and I didn't play tennis, so I did write it up, sent it to The Washington Monthly and they printed it,'' said Mr. Brockway. One thing led to another, and now Mr. Brockway, who is chairman of W.W. Norton & Company, the book publishers, is a monthly columnist - not for The Washington Monthly but for The New Leader, the 59-year-old magazine of news and opinion, which appears every other week.

title: A STAGE SET FOR DINING IN SOHO
description: GOING to restaurants seven nights a week, we rarely feel called upon to dress up in between; usually, a simple, unobtrusive outfit suffices. But we discovered that dinner at the three-and-half-monthold Wings on Wooster Street in SoHo is something else again, with a dining room that suggests a dream-world Art Deco ocean liner. The romantic room, with its pink walls, rose-velvet banquettes, serpentine streak of blue neon across the ceiling and fantastic, stylized fabric-flower sculptures, is a stage that inspires appropriate costumes from its cast of diners. At the very least, a marvelous silk shirt seems called for, preferably in pink, rose, white or silver gray, the most flattering colors in this softly diffuse lighting.

title: Guccione Is Reinstated As Penthouse Defendant
description: Robert Guccione, the publisher of Penthouse magazine, was reinstated today as a defendant in a $490 million libel case by the Rancho La Costa resort.
