title: SYRIAN TROOPS ARE SAID TO BATTLE REBELS ENCIRCLED IN CENTRAL CITY
description: Thousands of Syrian troops battled insurgents in the central city of Hama today for the ninth day, Western diplomats said. Their reports of fighting, first made on Wednesday, were again denied by the Government and termed ''expressions of dreams.''

title: Reagan House Deal Studied
description: Th e Federal Bureau of Investigation islooking into accusations of fraud or forgery involving an investment group that tr ied unsuccessfully to buy President Reagan's former homein Pacific Pa lisades, it was disclosed today. The Zoller Group of Palm Desert i s suspected of using false documents to misrepresent the sale pric e, the bureau said. Mr. Reagan's attorney, Roy Miller, told the auth orities late last month that documents in the aborted sale had been altered to misrepresent the price. The house was subsequently sold to another buyer.

title: MAREE IS MOVING AT HIS PACE
description: Last summer, the first for Sydney Maree in international track competition, he became the third-fastest miler in history. His time of 3 minutes 48.83 seconds in beating Steve Ovett of England had been bettered only by Sebastian Coe of England (3:47.33) and Ovett (3:48.40).

title: CAPITOL WIVES FINDING SEPARATE CONSTITUENCY
description: The political wife. The phrase conjures up visions of an attentive, self-sacrificing helpmate, a tireless campaigner and uncomplaining listener, a beautifully grooomed companion and loving homemaker.

title: Weather Curtails Golf
description: Amid strong winds and driving rain, Bobby Clampett shot a five-under-par 67 and took the lead today in the weather-curtailed first round of the $325,000 Hawaiian Open golf tournament.

title: I.B.M. Computer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new mo del of its Series 1 line of small computers.

title: Pabst Brewery Closing Delayed
description: A Federal judge has ordered the Pabst Brewing Company to keep its Peoria Heights brewery open pending completion of arbitration proceedings between the company and its unionized workers.

title: KEY PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday gave an incorrect name for the Federal law restricting political activities by Federal employees. It is the Hatch Act.

title: American Joins 2-for-1 Fares
description: American Airlines, which is engaged in a fare war with Braniff International Airways and Delta Air Lines, said it had expanded its two-for-one program to include all domestic ticket offices as long as the flight touches Dallas-Fort Worth Airport at some point. Braniff initiated the promotional battle on Wednesday by offering second tickets for $1 to travelers who purcha sed tickets on any domestic flight, including Hawaii destination s. The tickets must be purchased in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, howe ver.

title: HOLIDAYS UNITE!
description: To the Editor:

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VIOLIN: STEPHANIE CHASE PLAYS AT THE 92ND ST. Y
description: SOME anglers are content to fish for trout from the banks of a stream; for others, only the deep sea and big game fish will do. One such adventurer seems to be Stephanie Chase, a recent winner of the young musicians competition sponsored by the American Jewish Congress and Pepsi-Cola, who went after the blue marlins of the violin literature on Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y and played them valiantly, even if at times they seemed a bit more like sharks.

title: Satellite Contract Opposed by Ford
description: The Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation, a unit of the Fo rd Motor Company, said it had asked the Federal Commu nications Commission to deny permission to the Communication s Satellite Corporation to build the Intelstat 4 communication s satellite.

title: Dr Pepper Net Rises by 9.1%
description: The Dr Pepper Company, the soft-drink maker, said today that it earned $7.2 million, or 35 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1981, 9.1 percent more than the $6.6 million, or 33 cents a share, in the comparable period in 1980.

title: Wife of Lucius Allen Is Ruled a Suicide
description: LEE'S SUMMIT, Mo., Feb. 11 (UPI) - The death of Melanie Rose Allen, the 34-year-old wife of the former professional basketball player Lucius Allen, was a suicide, the Jackson County Medical Examiner's Office said today.

title: 16 GALLERIES SHOW NEW ART FROM FRANCE
description: IT isn't necessary to be an octogenarian to remember a time when the New York art scene was largely dominated by painting and sculpture imported from France. Even as recently as the 1950's, when the New York School had already produced much of its most distinctive work, it was automatically assumed by a great many critics, curators and collectors here that art coming to us from Paris was bound to be vastly superior to almost anything produced on native soil. The reasons for subscribing to this view were not ridiculous, however. As a matter of fact, more than a few American artists felt the same way. It was in Paris, after all, that the highest artistic standards had been set for as long as anyone could remember. For tastes both academic and avant-garde, Paris had long been the art capital of the Western world and it hardly seemed possible that things would ever be otherwise.

title: COLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REYNOLDS, R J, INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OTB SEEKING A TIGHTER REINON ITS COMPUTERS
description: Michelle Mon Amour won the sixth race and paid $9.40 at the Saratoga track last Aug. 16. For New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation, the race produced an unexpected loss of $9,649.

title: A TENOR WHO LOVES TO 'BELT OUT' BALLADS
description: It seems that everybody's favorite tenor is singing love songs these days - not the usual arias and art songs, but good, oldfashioned sentimental ballads. It's part of a phenomenon known as ''crossover,'' which occurs when a classical artist takes aim at a wider audience by programming or recording popular music.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT WARRIORS
description: Maurice Lucas scored a season-high 35 points to help offset Bernard King's 40-point performance for Golden State last night at Madison Square Garden as the Knicks defeated the Warriors, 120-117.

title: STAGE: GILFORD IN 'WORLD OF SHOLOM ALEICHEM'
description: NO Broadway season should lack Jack Gilford, and it's our good fortune that he has come our way twice during this one. Yet it's hard to leap for joy, because neither of Mr. Gilford's vehicles has shown off his talents to complete advantage.

description: Some simple suit combinations are in reality far from simple. Suppose you are in three no-trump and that dummy's only substantial asset is a diamond suit that looks like this:

title: Diablo Canyon Utility Denies Violating Laws
description: Officials of the Pacific Gas & Electric Company said today that they misunderstood Government instructions concerning a final draft outlining a proposed audit of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant, and said the utility did not violate any Federal laws.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Pilots Should Pilot
description: A teacher who was an extraordinary judge of young people used to say of students in whom he detected special promise that they had ''the habit of command.'' That description of an important quality atmoments of stress came back to mind as I read the transcript of the conversations between the two pilots of the i ll-fated Air Florida flight 90. ''The habit of command'' was hard to detect in the cockpitduring the approximately 30 minutes before th e plane's takeoff and plunge into the Potomac River.

Reynolds Industries said yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981 increased 29.9 percent, to $177.8 million, or $1.62 a share, from $136.9 million, or $1.23, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenues advanced 8.9 percent, to $3.07 billion, from $2.82 billion.

title: WHITES BACK SOUTH AFRICA UNION PROTEST
description: Important elements of the white establishment, including two English-language universities as well as major corporations, cooperated today with a call by black trade unions for a protest over the death in detention of a white union organizer who had been held without charge.

description: The battle for the soft contact lens market between Bausch & Lomb Inc. and Wesley-Jessen Inc., a subsidiary of the Schering-Plough Corporation, has added a new dimension with the Food and Drug Administration's arrival on the scene.

title: Poetry in Village
description: Twenty Greenwich Village residents will give poetry readings in the auditorium of the Jefferson Market Library, Avenue of the Americas and 10th Street, tomorrow at 1 P.M. The two-hour program will include first-time readings by children from local elementary schools and published works by older residents. Also featured will be selections from the Quill, a poetry magazine rooted in the Village from 1917 to 1924. Admission is free.

As several dozen readers informed us, after reading the article about laws and the names they acquire that appeared on this page this morning, the explanation is quite simple: Embargo spelled backwards is O Grab Me.

title: REINCARNATION OF 'CAT AND CANARY'
description: ''THE CAT and the Canary,'' a 55-year-old prototypical film thriller in the English manor, is back in another reincarnation, perhaps its fourth as a movie, at the Thalia, where it is playing today and tomorrow. The manor creaks mysteriously and the plot creaks transparently in this amusingly suspenseful remake directed by Radley Metzger.

title: 76ers Sign Dawkins

Dawkins, a 25-year-old center in the final year of a seven-year contract he signed out of high school in Orlando, Fla., is expected to receive a base annual salary of $700,000 before incentive clauses that cover rebounding, blocked shots and postseason awards.

title: Mario Montessori, 83, Dies in the Netherlands

title: Friday; GLOBETROTTERS BOUNCE IN
description: Those basketball virtuosos are back in town with some familiar feats. They dribble and pass behind their backs, between their legs and without looking; shoot a ball and have it return (by elastic attached to the hand), and break into an impromptu baseball game (with basketball). They, of course, are the renowned Harlem Globetrotters. Led by Hubert (Geese) Ausbie and Fred (Curly) Neal, they will bring their capers to three sites this holiday weekend: tonight at 8 at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., (516) 794-9100; on Saturday at 2 and 7:30 P.M. at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., (201) 935-3900, on Sunday at 1 P.M. and on Monday at 10:30 A.M. and 2:30 P.M. at Madison Square Garden, 564-4400. title: CITY BALLET: 'BAISER DE LA FEE' AND VIENNA WALTZES' RETURN

George Balanchine has probably never viewed choreography in such a programmatic fashion. Yet in some of his ballets he appears to take conscious delight in problem-solving. Two such works were offered by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Cunningham & Walsh
description: Cunningham & Walsh has been tapped to do corporate advertising as well as advertising and public relations for the office equipment of Ricoh of America, marketer of Japanese-made copiers. The account, which will reportedly bill $2 million, was formerly handled by Harrison Higgins and the New York office of Hakuhodo, the Japanese agency.

title: Advertising; Showtime And Xerox Campaigns
description: A VISIT yesterday to 909 Third Avenue at 51st Street was rewarded with news of two very different advertising campaigns. One will be aimed at business executives in hopes of selling them the high-technology office equipment of today and the future. It was put on display on the 18th floor by a team from Needham, Harper & Steers and Michael E.G. Kirby, director of corporate advertising and promotion of the client, Xerox.

description: Ivan Hlinka scored Vancouver's second successful penalty shot of the third period by beating Gil Gilbert, the goaltender, with 30 seconds left to gain a 4-4 tie.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review of the movie ''Circle of Deceit'' yesterday was accompanied by an incorrect photograph. It showed Paul Theroux, whose new novel, ''The Mosquito Coast,'' was also reviewed yesterday.

WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY FESTIVITIES
description: This weekend, Washington's 250th birthday will be celebrated in New York in a variety of ways - concerts of colonial music and dancing, a parade up Fifth Avenue, a birthday party with a giant cherry cake and several museum exhibitions that illuminate George Washington the farmer, surveyor, family man, general, first President of the United States and the New Yorker (for a time).

COE ASSAILS DRUG USE BY ATHLETES
description: Indiscriminate use of drugs among world-class athletes is the major problem in international sports, according to Sebastian Coe, Britain's middle-distance track star.

title: New Official Talks About M-G-M Plans
description: Frank Rothman, 55, a Los Angeles lawyer who was named last week as chairman and chief executive of the new umbrella company for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, has a clear idea of what he would like to accomplish.

title: White House to Seek Increase in Aid to Turkey
description: The Reagan Administration will ask Congress for an additional $115 million in military and economic aid for Turkey next year, State Department officials said today.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Tax-Free Bond Guide
description: Interest paid on bonds issued by state and local governments and authorities are exempt from Federal income tax, but their treatme nt for purposes of state taxes varies widely across the country.

title: YIELDS STAY IN NARROW RANGE
description: Short-term interest rates rose and long-term rates fell in quiet trading yesterday. Yield changes in all sectors were small. Many analysts said the approaching four-day weekend made traders cautious and encouraged investors to stay on the sidelines where yields of 15 percent to 15 1/2 percent were readily available in money market instruments due in a few months or less.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: W HAT Estee Lauder cosmetics are to women's faces, the three imaginative playgrounds donated by the Lauder Foundation are to Central Park. They help brighten things up. The other night, the woman behind those three parks -Evelyn Lauder, daughter-in-law of Estee - was honored by the Parks Council at its annual benefit dinner in the landmark Villard Houses at 457 Madison Avenue.

title: GRAHAM MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Restated for new FASB rules covering foreign currency translations

title: REUSCHEL, YANKEES STILL APART
description: Rick Reuschel, like Tommy John, is involved in a contract dispute with the Yankees and, like John, has not reported to the team's voluntary camp.

title: Baker, Yarborough Win Berths in Daytona 500
description: Buddy Baker and Cale Yarborough each won a 125-mile qualifying event today to assure themselves the second row for Sunday's Daytona 500 stock car race. In the front row, which was determined by earlier qualifying, will be Benny Parsons, on the pole, and Harry Gant.

title: NUCLEAR PANEL OFFERS STANDARDS TO MEASURE SAFETY
description: In an attempt to establish improved safety goals for nuclear power plants, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today proposed standards that for the first time would attempt to measure how many people might be killed or injured in a reactor accident.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
3 Yonkers Officers Indicted in Thefts
description: Three Yonkers police officers were indicted on charges of burglary, grand larceny and possession of stolen goods.

title: 'MAKING LOVE,' SUDSY ROMANCE
description: CLAIRE and Zack of Arthur Hiller's ''Making Love,'' are a lot like Jenny and Oliver of Mr. Hiller's ''Love Story,'' except that they have a problem. The problem's name is Bart, and his involvement with Zack would have been unthinkable, or at least unfilmable, in a bigstudio soap opera of ''Love Story'' vintage. Twelve years later, things have changed just enough to let Bart play a role about as real and important as Zack's or Claire's in a thoroughly oldfashioned, wonderfully sudsy romance. Something old, something new.

title: TRI-CHEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FANS REACH OUT AND TOUCH A NET
description: THERE is a new look in New Jersey - three of them, to be exact. The first is the new Byrne Meadowlands Arena, and the second is the New Jersey Nets under Larry Brown, a team striving for the glorious mediocrity of .500 tonight.

title: CLOSER U.S. ATTENTION TO YEMEN
description: The perhaps apocryphal story has it that Ibn Saud, the former King of Saudi Arabia, issued a warning from his death bed in 1953: Beware of Yemen; it is your Achilles' heel. He was not referring to Southern Yemen, once a British colony and now a Soviet client state, but Yemen, the Yemen Arab Republic, with Sana its capital. What happens in Yemen can decisively affect what happens in Saudi Arabia.

title: AMERICAN MAIZE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BURDEN PUT ON TENANTS FOR CO-OP EXEMPTIONS
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice has ruled that elderly and handicapped tenants seeking legal exemptions from eviction when a building becomes a cooperativ e must prove they are eligible for them.

description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Steve Shutt scored his 350th goal and helped Montreal to win its 10th consecutive triumph and to become the first N.H.L. team with 2,000 victories.

title: INVENTORIES CUT 0.4% IN DECEMBER
description: American businesses reduced their inventories by four-tenths of 1 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported today. Government analysts saw the drop as a sign that companies were trying to fight their way out of the recession, but some private economists were more cautious in interpreting the data. The drop in inventories held by manufacture rs, retailers and othersnearly kept pace with a sales drop of six-ten ths of 1 percent in December, leaving the closely watched invento ry-to-sales ratio for the month at 1.49, the same as in November. T he ratio represents the number of months needed to liquidate inventor ies on hand at the prevailing sales pace.

title: Second Man Is Sought In Slaying o f Diplomat
description: An all-points bulletin was issued tonight for a 21-year-old Armenian, the second man named by the police in the assassination of Kemal Arikan, the Turkish consul general in Los Angeles.

title: PHILIPS CABLES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
TRANSITRON ELECTRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ADVERTISING
description: Three ex-ad salesmen had their talents recognized at Time Inc. yesterday and that means steps up the corporate ladder. William M. Kelly Jr., 52 years old, was promoted to publisher of Money from his position as worldwide advertising sales director of Time magazine.

title: ART: RETURN OF THE ONCE DESPISED 'BELLE-PEINTURE'
description: THE first thing to be said about the current informal festival of Fr ench art is that it is not at all stuffy. Consecrated bores are fe w. No one line is pushed. Artists in their early 20's have not beento ld to go away and come back in 10 years, The general tone - of wh at is discussed here, at any rate - is relaxed and uncontentious. Th ere is even something of a return to what was once much despised - '' la belle peinture,'' or fine painting.

title: NEW COONEY EXAMINATION SET
description: Gerry Cooney, whose injured left shoulder is only ''75 percent recovered,'' according to his trainer, will be examined by his doctor today in an effort to determine whether Cooney can make his $10 million March 15 payday date with Larry Holmes.

title: THE FANCIFUL DROPOUTS ON 'CANNERY ROW'
description: ''CANNERY ROW,'' David S. Ward's screen adaptation of the late John Steinbeck's novellas ''Cannery Row'' and ''Sweet Thursday,'' is the project from which Raquel Welch was sacked early in the production amid a lot of hard feelings. Miss Welch should send a large bouquet of roses to whoever is responsible. The only people who emerge from this precious nonsense smelling good are Richard MacDonald, the English production designer, and Sven Nykvist, the Swedish cameraman.

title: SUDAN IS SKEPTICAL ABOUT O.A.U.'S ROLE
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry said today that he did not believe the Organization of African Unity's peacekeeping force in Chad was able to ''stop war by military means''and he called Chad's President, Goukouni Oueddei, an obstacle to peace.

title: ISLANDERS WIN 10TH IN ROW
description: With 4 minutes left in the second period tonight, the Islanders and the Chicago Black Hawks were tied, 2-2. In the next 18 minutes, six different Islanders scored to give New York its 10th consecutive victory, 8-2.

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS WARN REAGAN ON BUDGET: SEE POSSIBLE SHIFT
description: After being warned today by Republican Congressional leaders that his budget could not be approved in its present form, President Reagan said that he wanted to give Congress ''running room'' to cut the budget to reduce the deficit. But he said that he was not ready to compromise on his plans to reduce income taxes and increase military spending.

description: Year ago share earnings adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split in July 1981

title: Rockets Lose to Spirit
description: The New Jersey Rockets absorbed their 15th loss in 20 games in the Major Indoor Soccer League when the Pittsburgh Spirit defeated them, 5-2, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight. Pittsburgh scored all its goals in the first half, two by Billy McNicol, and one each by John O'Hara, Marcio Leite and Stan Terlecki. Joe Horvath and Fred Grgurev, who got his 21st of the season, scored for the Rockets.

title: VERIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Economic Scene; C.E.A.'s Use Of 'Plonking'
description: THE late Stephen Potter, famous as the discoverer of Gamesmanship (''the art of winning at games without actually cheating''), also made important but less noticed contributions to economics, which he called ''the plonking science.'' By plonking he meant the uttering of trite and obvious ideas in a heavy, pompous manner.

title: NEW DATA SUGGEST VIRUS MAY CAUSE FORM OF HUMAN CANCER
description: New evidence reported today strengthened the case that a virus has a role in causing a type of adult leukemia.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cellular Systems has named Kenneth Alan Horowitz executive vice president in charge of operations. * Corodian Corp., Albany, has named Kenneth T. Lally president.

title: Dow Down 1.99; Takeover Stocks Rise
description: The stock market declined slightly yesterday to register its third loss of the week. However, several energy issues posted strong gains in reaction to acquisition plans or takeover rumors.

title: A Treaty to Save Salmon
description: It's hard to think of another creature as free and wild as the Atlantic salmon. Bred in fresh water, it finds its way to the ocean, migrating hundreds or even thousands of miles to feed and grow, and then returns to its native stream to spawn.

title: PORTMAN PLAN CLEARS ANOTHER HURDLE
description: A Federal judge decided yesterday that two theaters could be demolished to make way for construction of the Portman hotel in the Times Square area. But he delayed the demolition until next week to allow the plan's opponents to appeal to a higher court.

title: 'REDS' AND 'GOLDEN POND' TOP OSCAR NOMINATIONS
description: Warren Beatty, Hollywood's current version of the Renaissance Man, was nominated for four Academy Awards today for ''Reds,'' his complex epic about the life of the radical American journalist John Reed.

title: Narcotics Suspect Named in Tax Case
description: A 36-year-old man said by the police to be a major narcotics dealer was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal tax-evasion charges that accused him of receiving more than $750,000 of unreported income in one year.

title: A THRIVING AMERICAN FORCED-LABOR INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Nurse Gets Promotion
description: She has received 28 academic awards and professional honors, taught at five universities and written more than 100 books and articles, and now Dr. Faye G. Abdellah has become the first woman and the first nurse in the 184-year-history of the Public Health Service to be named Deputy Surgeon General. Dr. Abdella h, who was born in New York City and received a doctorate in education psychology from Columbia University, has been an officer of the service's commissioned corps for 30 years and holds the ran k of rear admiral.

title: APPELLATE COURT REINSTATES TWO OF ABSCAM CONVICTIONS
description: A divided Federal appellate court today reinstated the convictions of a Philadelphia city councilman and a former council president on charges growing out of the Federal bribery investigation known as Abscam. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit thus ov erturned the ruling of Judge John P. Fullam of United States Di strict Court, who had reversed a jury's verdict against George X. Sc hwartz, the former Council president, and Harry P. Jannotti, who re signed as the majority leader of the council during the prosecutionbu t is still a member.

title: 8-Hour Videotape Introduced by RCA
description: The RCA Corporation yesterday introduced the industry's first eight-hour blank tape for use in video cassette recorders, giving its users a two-to four-hour advantage over competitive tapes now on the market.

title: Walker Seeks Pro Pact
description: Herschel Walker, the Georgia running back, has decided to investigate the possibility of giving up his final two years of eligibility and mounting a legal challenge that would allow him to play next season in the National Football League. The league has a rule against drafting college players before their class ha s graduated.

title: AMCA INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including special gains of $1.2 million for the latest year and $3.6 million for the previous year; year-ago results have been restated to reflect changes inaccounting for foreign currency translations; results are in US dollars; the company was formerly Dominion Bridge

description: WEST VIRGINIA CLINCHES TITLE

title: Texaco Card Fee Upheld by Court
description: A Federal judge has ruled that Texaco Inc. can collect a 3 percent processing fee from gasoline retailers on their credit-card sales.

title: Riflemen Ordered to Pay $2 Million in Slaying Case
description: The National Rifle Association must pay more than $2 million in damages because a gun stolen from its headquarters was used in a murder, a jury ruled today.

title: RORER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest periods results include the effect of FASB Statement No 52; results for 1981 restated to include the acquisitions of Neomed Inc and Cilco Inc

title: Asking for the Moon on Defense
description: By proposing such an immense new defense budget, President Reagan may think he conveys an image of triumphant strength. In fact, the only victory is one of ideology over realism. As criticism from Republicans as well as Democrats already shows, proposing so much for defense in a time of economic distress and staggering deficits has only one sure effect: cutbacks will be made. The only question is where.

title: Economic Aide Quits, White House Reports
description: Myer Rashish, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, resigned a month ago, the White House said today.

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Drifter Held in 4 Deaths Leads Police to 3 Bodies
description: Robert Dale H enderson, a parolee froma Wyoming prison, today led the police to the bodies of three of the 12 persons he contends that he killed in a cr ime spree through several states. All three had been bound and shot in the head.

title: BRUNSWICK OUTFLANKS A BIDDER
description: The Brunswick Corporation, in a strategic move to frustrate a $600 million takeover bid by the Whittaker Corporation, disclosed yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to sell its Sherwood Medical Group to the American Home Products Corporation for $425 million.

title: 'KARAMAZOV' PLAY, WITH CAST OF JUST 4, DUE ON BROADWAY
description: ''NICHOLAS NICKLEBY'' is gone, but yet another British adaptation of a classic novel is on its way to Broadway. ''Brothers Karamazov,'' which was commissioned by the Edinburgh Festival last summer to commemorate the 100th anniversary of Dostoyevsky's death, is due in November. However, while ''Nicholas Nickleby'' lasted eight and a half hours and had a huge cast, ''Brothers Karamazov'' will approach the epic novel of Dostoyevsky from another extreme, with a cast of only four actors and the brothers' saga told in a drama of conventional length. The ''Brothers Karamazov'' adaptation was w ritten by Richard Crane,formerly resident dramatist at the National T heater in London. With his wife, the director Faynia Williams, Mr. C rane founded the experimental Brighton Theater Company 18 mont hs ago. Miss Williams directed the B righton troupe in the premiere of ''Brothers Karamazov'' at Edinburgh and will stage the New York produ ction, which is to be cast with an all-male cast of American acto rs that canplay as an ensemble. The producer is Manheim Fox, a co-pro ducer of ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' and he plans to capitalize ''Kar amazov'' at$650,000.

title: Turks Jail 3 for Hiding Man Who Tried to Kill Pope in '81
description: A martial law court today sentenced to prison three accomplices of Mehmet Ali Agca, the man who tried to assassinate Pope John Paul II, on convictions of hiding Mr. Agca after his escape from a Turkish prison in 1979.

description: B-Operating earnings; C-Net income

description: If anything causes Mary McCarthy to bristle, it is women who believe that a college education makes them too good to wash diapers.

Tesoro Profits Decline 2.6%
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that its net income in the first fiscal quarter of 1982, ended Dec. 31, slipped 2.6 percent, to $22.4 million, or $1.35 a share, from $23 million, or $1.44 a share, a year earlier. Sales dropped 23.7 percent, to $660.8 million, from $865.7 million.

title: DOCTOR IN ATLANTA TRIAL DISPUTES CAUSES OF DEATH
description: The top forensic pathologist in the Israeli Army contradicted local medical examiners today at Wayne B. Williams's trial for murder when he testified that it was impossible to determine how Nathaniel Cater and Jimmy Ray Payne had died.

title: Notes On People; Lillian Gi sh Backs the Arts, but Grammatically
description: Celebrities like Geraldine Fitzgerald, Geoffrey Holder, Peggy Cass and Maria Burton had no objection to delivering the tagline ''You Gotta Have Arts!'' during tapings in New York for WBZ-TV in Boston.

title: SYRIAN FORCE S SAID TO GAIN UPPER HAND IN BATTLE AGAINST DISSIDENTS
description: Syria said today that its campaign against dissidents in the central city of Hama was going so well that it would reopen the main road to the city on Sunday morning.

description: Because of an editing error, a review of the film ''Love and Money'' in Weekend yesterday included an incorrect reference to the director King Vidor. Mr. Vidor is alive and plays a role in the film.

title: UNEXPECTEDLY, MRS. THATCHER'S FORTUNES BRIGHTEN
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's chances of winning the next general election, which were considered almost nonexistent three months ago, appear to be improving.

title: PATH LINE: FARE IS LOW, DEFICIT HIGH
description: Each morning, as New Yorkers line up to purchase their 75-cent subway tokens, thousands of New Jersey commut ers put 30 cents into turnstiles an d head for a trip to Manhattan on the Port Authority Trans-Hudson system.

title: VIOLETS ARE RED, ROSES ARE BLUE
description: ''All you need is love'' sang the Beatles, imposing their pop imprimatur upon a theme common to poets since the days of St. Paul. Yet this same love is the theme of our most frivolous holiday, St. Valentine's Day, and is celebrated primarily by elementary school children, who cut out paper hearts and exchange cards, and, by the rest of us, with enough candy to sink the Scarsdale diet until April.

title: Sports People; Kitchener Rockies?
description: While Peter Gilbert, the owner of the Colorado Rockies, petitions the National Hockey League to allow him to move his team to New Jersey, he continues to check other locales. Having scouted Ottawa a couple of weeks ago, Gilbert yesterday toured Kitchener, Ontario, where eager city officials showed him the 7,000-seat Kitchener Auditorium, an arena that, local engineers said, could be expanded to seat 15,000. Gilbert came away saying that he was ''very well impressed'' but making no commitments.

title: Sheila Mosler Wed to Dr. B.C.  Maglich
description: Sheila Jane Sanders Mosler, vice chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, was married yesterday to Dr. Bodgan C. Maglich, a physicist who is chairman of Science Transfer Associates in New York and the Fusion Energy Corporation in Princeton, N.J. Surrogate Millard L. Midonick performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply expanded by $2.3 billion in the latest week, continuing a three-month trend of rapid growth well above the Fed's targets.

title: BRONX BOXER GOES LONG WAY QUICKLY
description: Davey Moore said the other day that he was ''waiting for somebody to pinch me.'' He still finds it difficult to realize that 12 days ago, in his ninth professional fight, his second scheduled for 10 rounds or more and only his third in the weight class, he won a world boxing title from a Japanese junior middleweight in Tokyo.

title: Ex-Nazi Given 4-Year Term
description: Friedrich Paulus, 75 years old, a former captain in the Nazi SS, was sentenced to four years in jail today for complicity in the killing of at least 161 Poles near Lublin in World War II.

title: Notes On People; Role for a Smoker
description: When the producers of ''Agnes of God,'' the forthcoming drama, were negotiating with Lee Remick to return to Broadway after an absence of 16 years, they neglected to ask her an important question.

title: Zellerbach Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said that it lowered the Crown Zellerbach Corporation's commercial paper rating to prime-two, from prime-one. At the same time, the rating on the Series A 4.625 cumulative convertible preferred stock was lowered to baa, from single a. The company's senior unsecured debt remains classified single a, it said. Moody's said the ratings reflect the continuing contraction of cash flow and fixed coverages as a result of adverse economic conditions.

REAGAN ORDERS INQUIRY INTO REPORT U.S. AIDES IN SALVADOR HAD RIFLES
description: President Reagan ordered an investigation today into why five American advisers in El Salvador apparently violated United States policy by carrying M-16 rifles in what may have been a combat zone.

title: About New York; A CLASS LESSON SPEAKS LOUDER THAN WORDS
description: Sam Dui Lu and Michael Watson are friends. Anyone can tell the two like each other by the way they sit cross-legged on the floor and giggle and whisper and giggle again. Michael leans over and hums secrets into Sam's ear, and Sam leans over and does the same.

title: NETS BEAT WARRIORS TO REACH .500 MARK
description: Of the 113 points the Golden State Warriors had been averaging each game this season, Bernard King (23.7) and World B. Free (23.5) had been accounting for more than 47. Tonight, however, they shot 6 for 26 from the field and scored only 20 points between them as the Nets beat the Warriors, 109-98, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

description: Revenue figures represent underwriting revenues and net investment income

title: HAIG VISITS RUMANIA AFTER URGENT PLEA FOR TALKS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. arrived here tonight for talks on Saturday with President Nicolae Ceausescu in response to an urgent request for the meeting by the Rumanian leader. This is Mr. Haig's first visit as Secretary to a country that is a member of the Warsaw Pact, and it takes on pa rticular importance given the rising East-West tensions over the crackdown in Poland. Earlier this week, Mr. Haig led Western natio ns in attacking the Soviet Union and the Polish Government at a m eeting of the East-West conference in Madrid.

title: THEATER: 'SECRET LIVES OF THE SEXISTS'
description: Charles Ludlam is fearless in his new Ridiculous Theatrical Company farce, ''Secret Lives of the Sexists.'' In the pivotal role of Phil Landers, a ''physical culture'' expert who teaches housewives aerobic exercises, he variously appears as a heterosexual, as a heterosexual masquerading as a homosexual and as a female sexpot in full blonde-bombshell regalia. In one scene, Mr. Ludlam must hang by his fingernails from the ledge of ''the Swan B eauty Salon''; in another, he i mpersonates a mewing baby in a carriage in Central Park.

title: Around the Nation; Prisoner Frees Hostages In Marion, Ohio, Jail
description: A man armed with a shotgun, who had taken hostages for a second time in six weeks, surrendered today in a county jail.

title: U.S.-China Quake Project Set
description: China and the United States are setting up an experimental base in south China to study earthquake prediction, the official New China News Agency reported today. For the first phase, 33 permanent observatories have been built in an area of western Yunnan Province where quakes are frequent.

title: COMMISSION URGES U.S. TO MINT A NEW GOLD 'COIN'
description: The United States Gold Commission recommended today that the Government mint a new gold ''coin'' that would be sold in competition with coins made by Canada, South Africa and other countries.

title: OFTEN PLAYED VILLIAN IN FILMS
description: Victor Jory, a stage actor in the classical tradition whose fame among movie audiences was as a gravel-voiced villain, was found dead yesterday by the police in his apartment in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 79 years old.

title: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $449,000 for the quarter and $484,000 for the 9 months; C-After a loss of $42,000 for the quarter and a gain of $8,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations

title: Briefing
description: Holocaust Guilt

title: POPE GETS EXUBERANT GREETING IN NIGERIA
description: Greeted with exuberance by huge crowds in black Africa's most populous city, Pope John Paul II today began an eight-day journey to four West African nations.

title: HARWICKE COMPANIES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Dec 20
SMALL BUSINESS
description: Last February, when Irv Hyatt opened a videotape cassette store with $25,000 he had gotten from the sale of his pizzeria, he had two competitors. Since then, two other tape shops have opened.

title: Kissing And M aking Up
description: The United Nations has gone too far this time. For the Secretary General to postpone a lunch with Mayor Koch just because the Mayor accused the world body of ''hypocrisy, immorality and cowardice'' is an act of ill grace.

title: GLATFELTER, P H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transactions
description: FRIDAY; BASEBALL

title: LODGE & SHIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jury Convicts Man Of Plotting Murder
description: A Manhattan State Supreme Court jury found Arnold Iannacone guilty of second-degree manslaughter yesterday in connection with the Oct. 19, 1980, murder of his brother-in-law, Anthony Fiore, a Citibank vice president.

title: TRAVELERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An item in Notes on People last Saturday incorrectly identified the university that awarded honorary de- grees to Itzhak Perlman, the violinist, and Dr. Albert P. Sabin, the virologist. It was the Medical University of South Carolina in Charleston.

title: HEALTH EXTENSION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
F.C.C. AND CONGRESS IN LICENSE STANDOFF
description: The Federal Communications Commission and Congress are in a standoff after the regulatory agency, in an extraordinary move, voted to ignore orders to set up a lottery for distributing licenses for broadcasters and others.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.N.A. Not available because markets closed for Lincoln's Birthday.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Ask Muhammad Wins Whirlaway at Aqueduct
description: The search for a local runner to compete in the spring classics began unofficially yesterday at Aqueduct with the $50,000-added Whirlaway Stakes, an early-season opportunity for trainers to try their promising colts around two turns.

title: Winnipeg Ballet Tonight
description: The ''Dance Celebrity Series'' at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University features the Royal Winnipeg Ballet tonight at 8 o'clock in the Concert Theater, on Northern Boulevard, Greenvale, L.I. Among the dances will be ''Rodeo,'' choreographed by Agnes de Mille with music by Aaron Copland. Tickets are $12.50 and $15.50. Information: (516) 626-3100.

title: CONVICTED THIEF MADE REAGAN BID
description: The San Diego County District Attorney's Office said today that William C. Ogle, a principal in the failed sale of President Reagan's home in Pacific Palisades last month, was convicted of grand theft in 1976 and served time in a state prison.

title: Fulmar Oil Output
description: The North Sea Fulmar Field, 170 miles east of Dundee, Scotland, has begun production at the rate of 30,000 barrels of oil daily, the operator, Shell U.K. Exploration and Production Ltd. said.

title: Bridge: American Clubs Could Use A Bit More Gung-Ho Spirit
description: Clubs in Europe tend to have substantially more club spirit than do those on this side of the Atlantic. Duplicate players here tend to treat a club as they would a movie theater - a convenient place for an evening's entertainment, but in no sense requiring their loyalty or regular support.

title: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Around the Nation; 1,000 Salvadorans in U.S.  For Combat Training
description: A final group of Salvadoran soldiers arrived here today to begin Green Beret training. In all, almost 1,000 troops from El Salvador are to take part.

title: DEMOCRATS ARRIVE ON SALVADOR TOUR
description: Two Congressional groups arrived here today and began a round of tours and meetings in an effort to obtain information from officials about conditions in El Salvador.

title: LINCOLN, BRADFORD, AND THE CONSERVATIVES
description: Unflattering views of Abraham Lincoln are by no means unusual of late. But the work of one revisionist scholar, Prof. M. E. Bradford of the University of Dallas, more than any other has created a storm among neo-conservatives and Moral Majority supporters and others on the right over the sensitive issues of states' rights, morality in government, and race.

title: GLASROCK MEDICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including net income from discontinued operations of $165,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $306,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 9 months; C-Including a gain of $3,492,000 on the disposal of investments in subsidiaries

title: RETARDED AND PRECIOUS
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisp Play Postponed
description: ''Lord Alfred's Lover,'' a play by Eric Bentley that had been scheduled to start performances March 12 at the Courtyard Playhouse, with Quentin Crisp portraying Lord Alfred Douglas, has been postponed until next September. The production, to be directed by Mr. Bentley, will be presented by the Stonewall Repertory Theater, with Maxim Mazumdar also in the cast.

title: Sports of the Times; SO WHAT WOULD THEY PAY PAFKO?
description: ANDY PAFKO was the George Foster of my youth, an age so hazy now that only a few things stand out, such as Pafko and snapping my fingers to such stirring hits as ''Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo.''

title: PROJECT TO SHIP GAS FROM ARCTIC NEARS APPROVAL IN CANADA
description: Less than 1,000 miles from the North Pole lies a rich field of natural gas that, by 1986, is expected to flow to homes in eastern Canada and, indirectly, to increase the supply of gas to the United States.

title: SEISCOM DELTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company acquired the United Geophysical Corp from the Bendix Corp in a purchase transaction July 1981

title: REAGAN RESCINDS RIGHTS NOMINATION IN WAKE OF OUTCRY
description: President Reagan, bowing to opposition from civil rights groups and several Democratic Senators, today withdrew his nomination of William M. Bell for the chairmanship of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. He announced his intention to nominate an Education Department official for the job.

title: Kissinger Is Transferred
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was moved from an intensive care unit today, and his condition was upgraded to satisfactory, officials at Massachusetts General Hospital said. The 58-year-old Mr. Kissinger underwent open heart surgery Wednesday to bypass three clogged arteries.

title: Around the World; Finnish Social Democrat Is Asked to Form Cabinet
description: Mauno Koivisto, the newly elected President of Finland, today formally asked Kalevi Sorsa, a Social Democrat, to form a new coalition cabinet.

title: 350 ATTEND SERVICES FOR WHITNEY AT CHURCH NEAR HIS ESTATE ON L.I.
description: John Hay Whitney, the publisher, diplomat, philanthropist, investor and sportsman who died Monday at the age of 77, was eulogized here today as a man of ''strength whose great sense of amusement made him so vivid in the lives of those who knew him.''

title: LOUISIANA OFFICIAL ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted the president of the Louisiana Senate, his law partner and three other persons on charges of participating in a $6 million fraud scheme.

title: Frances M. Schwartzstein Married to Charles Jackson
description: Frances Miriam Schwartzstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Schwartzstein of Trenton, and Charles Vivian Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Jackson of Cults, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, were married yesterday. The Rev. Hays Rockwell, rector of St. James's Episcopal Church, and Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony in the Columbia University Chapel.

title: Woman, 57, Slain in 'Village'
description: A 57-year-old woman was stabbed to death in her apartment at 110 Bedford Street in Greenwich Village yesterday afternoon.

title: Notes On People; New Dean for Pennsylvania Law School
description: Robert Mundheim, a former general counsel of the Treasury Department, has been chosen by the president of the University of Pennsylvania as the next dean of the university's law school. The nomination by the president, Sheldon Hackney, is subject to the approval of the board of trustees, which is expected to ratify the choice.

title: U.S. EASES CURBS ON VISITING SOVIET SCIENTIST
description: The State Department has lifted most of the restrictions it had imposed on a Soviet scientist's access to research in a coming visit to Stanford University.

title: Stocks Edge Down As Trading Slows
description: The stock market drifted lower yesterday in sharply curtailed trading on the eve of the Washington's Birthday weekend. Stock exchanges will be closed on Monday.

title: JEFFERSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $349,000 for the quarter and $1,061,000 for the year; C-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $757,000 and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $928,000; D-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,609,000 and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $928,000

title: A PECULIAR GATHERING AT THE LOTTO JACKPOT
description: To the Editor:

title: COPPERFIELDS MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $78,000 on the sale of investments; C-Net income including a gain of $529,000 on the sale of investments

title: EMILY L. KOLFF
description: Emily L. Kolff, whose charitable work on Staten Island and the Lower East Side spanned 30 years, died Tuesday, her 90th birthday, at her home in Oakland, Calif.

title: FUNDS FOR NEW LAKER VENTURE
description: An agreement has been reached that could provide Sir Freddie Laker with the financing he needs to begin another lowfare, trans-Atlantic airline service, his new partner, Roland W. Rowland, announced tod ay. But the new venture might have some problems getting off the ground.

title: Mentally Disabled? Fill Out This Form
description: To a 40-year-old with the pseudonym Harry Baird, daily life is intolerable. ''He has the fragile ego structure of a chronic schizophrenic,'' says one of his psychiatrists. He suffers from hallucinations, some of which prompt him to attempt suicide. His social worker adds: ''When you speak to this man, he simply doesn't understand what you are talking about. ... He could not even get to an appointment at the Social Security office.''

title: OZARK AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Scottdale to Close
description: Scottdale Mills Ltd., which survived the Great Depression without cutting back production or employees, said it is going out of business in April with the loss of more than 500 jobs.

title: ALGOMA STEEL CORP LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: ROCKWOOD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $134,000, or 1 cent a share; C-Net loss; D-Including income from discontinued operations of $8,419,000, or 78 cents a share; the results include operations of Oxford Homes Inc since the date of acquisition, April 25, 1980

title: YANKS SEEK DENNY TO PROD REUSCHEL
description: The Yankees have quietly but emphatically begun pursuing John Denny, the most attractive free agent still free.

title: ADDED DAMAGE BARS REOPENING OF GINNA PLANT
description: The discovery yesterday of damage to unused tubes in the steam generator at the Robert E. Ginna nuclear power plant in Ontario, N.Y., has delayed plans to resume operation of the facility.

title: NEWSSTAND'S LUCK
description: To the Edit or: It may seem to your reporter to be ''in defiance of astronomical odds'' that the same outlet should sell the two highest payoff ticket s in New York State lottery history (''Manhattan Newsstand Sel ls 2d Multimillion-Dollar Lotto Ticket,'' news story Feb. 4). But this event is really less improbable than it appears.

title:
PATENTS;
Generator in Flashlight
description: Carlos L. Jimena of Salt Lake City was granted patent 4,315,301 this week for a flashlight that generates its own electricity and needs no battery.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr ot Jan 4
description: Sales for the latest fourth quarter includes $5.9 million from the recently acquired Printex Corp; year-ago results have been restated

title: PREPARING THE RETURN: WHERE TO FIND HELP
description: Every year, millions of Americans have someone else prepare their tax returns, and this year even more people will be seeking help because of the complexities of the new tax law.

title: British Official Resigns
description: Sally Oppenheim resigned today as Minister for Consumer Affairs for what she said were personal reasons. No replacement was announced by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: SIGMOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Just as they say pitching is 80 percent of baseball, in a Congressional race the candidate is 80 percent of winning. A good candidate can win it, no matter how bad the conditions, and a bad candidate can lose it, no matter how good the conditions.'' - Representative Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. (8:2.)

title: News Analysis
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger achieved scan t results in his three-day visit to Saudi Arabia this week and thus reopened the question of whether the

title: FOR WHOM THE COIN IS TOSSED
description: To the Edit or: With predic table sensationalism and pious indignation, the media condemn Judge Alan Friess for fixing the sentence of a subway jostler at 20 instead of 30 days by flipping a coin (news story Feb. 2).

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includinga gain of $27,424,000 on the sale of company's interest in Mississippi Gas Properties

title: WEST GERMANS WIN SHIFT OF NATO TALKS TO BONN
description: An Atlantic alliance summit meeting scheduled for Brussels in June has been shifted to Bonn at the request of West Germany as a way of improving relations with the Reagan Administration, West German and United States officials said today. The switch was officially announced today b y Larry Speakes, the deputy White House spokesman, who said that i n addition to visiting France, Italy and Britain in June, President Reagan would also go to Bonn. Mr. Speakes did not discuss the reason for the shift.

title: Marshall Field, Icahn Talks
description: The Icahn Capital Corporation, the head of an investor group that holds an 17.2 percent stake in Marshall Field & Company, disclosed that the president of the Chicago-based retail chain had offered to help find a third party to buy Icahn's Marshall Field holdings.

title: IRRATIONAL,INEFFICIENT MULTI-COURT SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: 'HORRIBLE' LEAP BEST FOR MEET
description: Carol Lewis watched her brother Carl fly through the air and land in the long-jump pit for a Madison Square Garden record of 27 feet 3 3/4 inches last night during the 75th annual Wanamaker Millrose Games.

title: CONCERT: BOSTON SYMPHONY
description: Gustav Mahler's arrival as a repertory staple has been a relativly recent one, and so a long-standing performance tradition for his music, with sharply defined alternative possibilities, has not had time to develop. On the whole, however, as with most music, there seem to be Classical and Romantic approaches to his work. Mahler was an unabashed Romantic who still had about as keen an ear as anyone for the potential of the modern symphony orchestra. The trouble with some of the more unbuttoned Mahler performances is that subtleties are clumsily slu rred. Yet the Classicists too often tame his music into politeness.

title: White House Aide Promoted
description: John F.W. Rogers, a member of the White House staff, was promoted today to Deputy Assistant to the President for management. The former special assistant for administration will report to Richard G. Darman, deputy to James A. Baker 3d, the chief of staff.

title: WOMAN, 55, KILLED AND HUSBAND HURT IN BROOKLYN ROBBERY
description: A 55-year-old woman was shot to death and her husband was wounded by three masked men who broke into their home in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn early yesterday and robbed them of $4,000, the police said.

title: The Law Demystified
description: William Bradford Reynolds, the Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, is ''mystified.'' He can't understand why Congress will not swiftly pass an Administration bill to deny tax exemptions to racist schools. In an interview, he told The Times's Stuart Taylor Jr. that if Congress doesn't act, ''it may well come to a point where the Administration will be granting tax exemptions because Congress has not enacted legislation to say don't do it.''

title: Guard for Journalist Causes Press Protest
description: An armed guard was assigned today to a visiting journalist from Peking who was spending the day in the White House press room, but the escort was withdrawn when reporters protested.

title: AIR WISCONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC: TENNSTEDT LEADS SHUBERT 9TH
description: In the face of great musical talent, the wisest course usually is to put yourself in its hands. Let happen what will. At any rate, while the finale of Schubert's Symphony No. 9, the ''Great'' C major, was being propelled along wildly Thursday night by Klaus Tennstedt, the listener had no choice. It was climb in the saddle with the German conductor and enjoy the breathtaking ride. Mr. Tennstedt, at the head of the New York Philharmonic in a guest appearance, led a performance of Schubert's mightiest symphony that dared the orchestra to follow him into those fearsome regions that lie beyond instrumental and ensemble excellence.

title: Around the World; India Reports Crimes Against Untouchables
description: The Government announced today that 11,743 cases of crimes against untouchables were reported in the first 11 months of last year.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 51.

title: EDUCATORS CRITICIZE SCIENCE FOUNDATION'S PRIORITIES
description: The National Science Foundation was criticized yesterday as having focused its financing on graduate programs that it felt would create scientists instead of on programs for the majority of people who would be voting on issues that would determine the future of American society. A spokesman for the foundation defended its financing priorities, saying, ''Graduate programs are where future scientists and engineers are coming from.''

title: BBDO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results have been restated to reflect the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding accounting for foreign currency translations

title: Around the Nation; School Groups Safe After Hawaiian Storm
description: By The Associated Press Twenty-three youngsters and three adults stranded for a night in the crater of a dormant volcano by winds gusting to 150 miles an hour hiked to safety this afternoon.

title: Peggy Masback Cahn Is Bride of Todd May
description: Peggy Masback Cahn, a senior systems designer at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and Todd May, chief economist and member of the board of editors of Fortune magazine, were married yesterday in the Cosmopolitan Club. Acting Justice Felice K. Shea of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: MARKETS CLOSED
description: The listings of foreign exchange quotations and Treasury issues were not available yesterday because the markets involved were closed for the Lincoln's Birthday holiday.

title: Jacob Goodman Dead; Zionist Leader Was 87
description: Jacob Goodman, New York industrialist and a leader of the Zionist Organization of America and the Zionist movement, died Thursday while vacationing in Safety Harbor, Fla. He lived in New York City and was 87 years old.

title: HAZELTINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After pretax losses of $5.3 million for the quarter and $9.1 million for the year relating to discontinuance of the word processing project; C-Net income

title: DON'T SEEK NUTRITION IN A POTATO CHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: British Steel Output
description: British steel output averaged 280,800 metric tons a week in January, up 19.7 percent from the 234,500 tons produced weekly in January 1981, the British Steel Corporation and the British Independent Steel Producers Association said today. Output in December 1981 averaged 263,600 tons a week.

title: QUESTIONS ON STATE REAPPORTIONMENT
description: The Democrats and Republicans in the New York State Legislature have begun to make public their plans for redrawing the state's political boundaries, and the proposals are so radically different that it almost seems the two parties are dealing with different states.

title: COWLES COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Patents;
Efficiency Raised for Solar Cells
description: VOLTAGE solar battery to be patented next week for the RCA Corporation is considered by the company to represent an excellent way of making solar cell panels on a large scale to produce electricity.

title: 2 U.S. EXECUTIVES QUIT OXFORD PRESS
description: Two top officials of the Oxford University Press, the New York branch of the oldest publisher in the English-speaking world, have resigned in a dispute with the company's British parent. At issue is the parent company's recent decision to bring under British control the department that produces materials for teaching American English as a second language.

title: CONNECTICUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Ozark Airlines Net Up 10.3%
description: Ozark Airlines reported yesterday that its earnings advanced 10.3 percent in the fourth quarter, to $4.3 million, or 45 cents a share, on more shares outstanding, from $3.9 million, or 56 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Revenues increased 10.2 percent, to $94.7 million, from $85.9 million.

title: De Gustibus; 2 MISSING TREATS FROM WINTERS PAST
description: Although the variety of street foods available in New York is staggering in both quantity and diversity, two winter specialties that were standards 40 or 50 years ago are almost absent from the current scene.

title: U.S. REPORT ON SALVADOR SAYS ITS LAND PLAN IS 'IRREVERSIBLE'
description: A report on El Salvador's land redistribution program, requested by a Democratic Congressman critical of the Salvadoran junta and paid for by the United States Agen cy for International Development, has con cluded that the program is ''irreversible'' and ''proceeding reasonab ly well'' in its first phase.

title: ST LAWRENCE CEMENT CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After special losses on closing of Kingston, NY plant of $1.3 million; C-Net loss after special losses on closing of Kingston, NY plant of $5.6 million

title: HOW NEW YORK CITY'S INCENTIVE BOARD WORKS
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. RECRUITING IN MISSOURI FOR HOUSE CONTESTS
description: Many Republican leaders consider the discovery, care and feeding of strong candidates for the House of Representatives to be as important to their hopes for success in this year's Congressional elections as campaign money, the economy and President Reagan. And nowhere is the party more deeply involved in the recruiting effort than in Missouri.

title: KAHLER CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $563,000 from discontinued operations; C-After a loss of $167,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $555,000, or $1.22 a share

title: ANAREN MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TYSON FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
A CONTROVERSY OVER WIDELY SOLD DIET PILLS
description: Gloria Jean Davis's head began pounding on June 6, 1978. She saw bright, flashing lights. Then her right arm and leg became partly paralyzed. Finally, in an ambulance on the way to Palmyra Park Hospital in Albany, Ga., the mother of four slipped into unconsciousness.

title: Consumer Saturday; SEATS CAN PROTECT CHILDREN IN AUTOS
description: F OR years traffic-safety experts have argued that if all small children rode in cars equipped with a relatively inexpensive product - a child-safety seat - the number killed or injured in crashes would be sharply reduced.

title: Oil Prices Weaker on Spot Market; Spot Oil Prices Weaker
description: Crude oil prices continued to weaken on the spot market this week as supplies remained far in excess of demand and buyers continued to show little interest, market sources said here today.

title: Inflation Rate 12% in Britain
description: Britain's annual inflation rate was 12 percent in January, unchanged f or the third consecutive month, the Government sa id today.

title: FOR WHOM THE COIN IS TOSSED
description: To the Editor:

title: Profit Up 8.4% At Travelers
description: The Travelers Insurance Company reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter increased 8.4 percent, to $96.9 million, or $2.28 a share, from $89.4 million, or $2.10 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Operating income of the Hartford-based insurer increased 2.4 percent, to $99.6 million, or $2.34 a share, from $97.3 million, or $2.30 a share.

title: Books of The Times; On First Novels
description: SOUNDING THE TERRITORY. By Laurel Goldman. 307 pages. Knopf. $13.50.

title: Air India Seeks Loan
description: Air India is seeking $225 million in a Euroloan and export credit package to pay for at least three aircraft from Airbus Industrie, the maker of the A-300 Airbus, banking sources said here today. The Euroloan will probably be for about $130 million. A 10-year maturity is likely, with a split spread of 3/8 to 1/2 percent above London interbank offered rates, the banking sources added, although a 3/8 percent margin throughout is possible.

title: Taiyo Studies Alsands Stake
description: A Japanese consortium is considering investing in the $13 billion Alsands synthetic oil project after the withdrawal of two American oil companies, the head of the Canadian subsidiary of the Taiyo Oil Company said here today.

title: BROWN & SHARPE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KANSAS-NEBRASKA NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JAPANESE EARNED LABOR HARMONY
description: To Ichiro Shioji, the current contract talks between the United Automobile Workers Union and the major American auto makers have a familiar look. The key is sue in the negotiations - trading wag e-and-benefit concessions for job security during a period of eco nomic adversity - is the same one Japan dealt with successfully three decades ago.

title: KERR GLASS MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $2 million from the sale of property

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May 1981

title: ALLIES REBUKING REAGAN SHARPLY ON BIG DEFICITS
description: President Reagan's proposed budget has drawn highly unusual public attacks from West European finance ministers, central bank chiefs and many private economists, who assert that the big projected deficits will further depress their own economies.

title: ALBERTA ENERGY CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a $12.7 million writeoff of an investment in Petalta project including a provision for anticipated 1982 costs

title: LORETTA COLBORNE
description: Loretta Colborne, a retired New York City school principal, died Tuesday at her home in Long Beach, L.I. She was 77 years old.

title: Missouri Vote Deals Setback To the Equal Rights Proposal
description: The proposed equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution has been dealt a setback in Missouri by a crucial State Senate committee vote, and even the measure's supporters say the blow is probably fatal.

title: FORD AND UNION RECESS PAY TALKS AMID OPTIMISM
description: Talks between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers recessed late tonight without agreement on a contract tying wage and benefit concessions to greater job security, but both union and company officials expressed optimism that the final details would be resolved Saturday.

title: DOMAN INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
BROOKLYN COURT TOLD OF TORTURE OF PARAGUAYAN
description: Tales of torture in Paraguay and Argentina, as well as of the effects that torture has on victims and their families and on society as a whole, were recounted in a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday.

title: Lobby Is Called a 'Hate' Group
description: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith charged today that the Liberty Lobby was leading an anti-Semitic propaganda drive and called the conservative group's founder ''the mastermind of the hate network.''

title: Symptomatic Relief for Subway Crime
description: The Koch administration and the Transit Authority have put their heads together on a plan to provide more protection against crime in New York's subways. They offer welcome symptomatic relief for the problem of subway crime, but it should not be seen as a full remedy.

title: DEBTS LEAD TO A BANK TAKEOVER
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced last night that Great American Banks Inc. of North Miami had purchased the Metropolitan Bank and Trust Company of Tampa. Fla., because the Tampa bank was about to fail.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. Dr. A. Bartlett Giamatti, the president of Yale University, counseled the boy in Latin to ''know thyself.'' He was responding to a letter the boy wrote in a Latin class project, asking his opinion about the value of studying a ''dead language.''

title: PATENTS;
description: A book-sized analog computer weighing less than two pounds is regarded by its inventor as an excellent learning tool for students. Edwin Z. Gabriel of Eatontown, N.J., was granted patent 4,315,320 this week.

title: INTERTEC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $153,000 for the quarter and $221,000 for the 6 months; C-Net loss including tax credits of $1,145,000 for the quarter and $1,883,000 for the 6 months and a charge of $6.5 million for the quarter and 6 months on the closing of the company's retail packaging operation

title: Broken Hill's Net Down
description: Australia's largest company, Broken Hill Proprietary, said today that its earnings for the six months ended Nov. 30 fell by 36 percent, to $87.5 million dollars, or about $94.5 million in United States currency, from the first six months of 1980.

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1982; The Economy
description: The nation's basic money supply expanded by $2.3 billion in the latest week, the Federal Reserve reported, continuing a three-month trend of rapid growth well in excess of the Fed's targets. The key M-1 measure grew at an annual rate of 20.7 percent in January. Analysts said such an increase clouded prospects for an early decline in interest rates. (Page 31.)

title: SCREEN: AN ANTHOLOGY 'THE KILLING OF AMERICA'
description: The Greatest Hits approach can apparently be applied to anything. That, at least, is the message of ''The Killing of America,'' a compendium of everyone's favorite real-life death scenes.

title: Lauren Bacall to Stay In 'Woman of the Year'
description: Lauren Bacall, star of ''Woman of the Year,'' has agreed to extend her New York contract in the long-running musical at the Palace Theater ''for an indefinite period,'' it has been announced by James M. Nederlander, chairman of the board of the Nederlander Organization Inc.

title: FIRST MARINE BANKS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Jose Sulaiman, the president of the World Boxing Council, was freed on $10,000 bond in Mexico City, having been formally charged with illegal possession of archeological artifacts. Sulaiman said he had not known about a Mexican law requiring that archeological treasures be registered with the Government.

title: MOSINEE PAPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Staub Named P layer-Coach
description: The Mets yesterday appointed Rusty Staub, a career .280 batter who is beginning his 20th major league season, as a player-coach.

title: FERROFLUIDICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HEALTH RISK SHUTS RUTGERS BUILDING
description: A Rutgers University building whose occupants were found by the state to have an excessive number of cancers was closed Thursday night after air samples yielded increased levels of a hormone suspected of causing cancer. Earlier monitoring had found sharply lower readings. Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, president of Rutge rs, said he had ordered that classes in the building, Smith Hall, be suspended until further testing by the state and Federal governments determined its safety.

title: NEW EMBRYO FUROR IN BRITAIN
description: A Government spokesman says that disclosures that followed a meeting of the British Medical Association's ethics committee might alter the views of medical groups advising the Government on the implications of research on ''test tube'' babies.

title: CRUM & FORSTER INSURANCE COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pennsylvania Told to Resume U.S. Aid to 18,000 Families
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the Pennsylvania Department of Public Welfare to resume paying supplem ental Federal welfare benefits to nearly 18,000 low-income fa milies across the state.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP SLIM 0.4%
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods continued to rise at a subdued pace in January, despite the sharpest jump in food prices since the 1980 drought, the Labor Department reported today.

title: AIR FLORIDA CRASH: COCKPIT CONVERSATIONS FAIL TO ANSWER KEY QUESTIONS
description: ON TAKEOFF By RICHARD WITKIN News An alysis

title: Arab Officials Begin Meeting About the Golan Annexation
description: Arab foreign ministers opened a special meeting tonight to discuss Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: Columbia Tops Yale
description: Darren Burnett scored 18 points and Richie Gordon added 14 as Columbia scored a 67-55 victory over Yale at Levien Gym last night. Yale was led by Butch Graves, who had 17 points, and Steve Leondis with 14. Columbia improved its record to 9-7 over all and 4-3 in the Ivy League. Yale dropped to 11-8 and 5-2, but remained in first place. Columbia led by 30-28 at halftime. Yale tied the game at 32-32 with 18 minutes 23 seconds left in the game on a jumper by Graves. Eric Clarke's jumper with 16:56 remaining put the Lions ahead by 2 points, and they never trailed thereafter.

title: SCIENTIFIC LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a special charge of $4,674,000; C-Including a special gain of $12,885,00

title: A.T.&T.; IS WRONG
description: Large increases in local telephone rates were first and foremost among the dire forecasts that immediately followed the proposed antitrust settlement between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department, in which A.T.&T.; agreed to divest itself of the 22 Bell System companies that provide most of the country's local telephone service. Such increases are not necessary.

title: Around the World; F-16 Sale to Venezuela Avoids Veto by Congress
description: The sale of two dozen F-16 fighters to Venezuela can proceed because the deadline for a Congressional veto passed today.

title: SALAZAR BEATEN
description: There were nine starters in the Avon Mile for women last night, but only one counted. From the start, Mary Decker Tabb said goodbye to the others and ran the fastest women's mile ever indoors - 4 minutes 21.47 seconds.

title: MET MUSEUM TO AID CABLE TV
description: ABC Video Enterprises Inc. and the Metropolitan Museum of Art have agreed to collaborate on five hours of cultural programs for ARTS, a cable-television service of Hearst/ABC Video Services.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUCKBEE-MEARS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec31
TECK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income after $2,753,000 gain on sale of investments; the company is listed in the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: Hill Street Cheers
description: Do you ever wonder what life is like for the cops who work the night shift on ''Hill Street Blues''? They never show us that. All we see is the day crew, and their troubles are hair-raising enough to satisfy anybody but the most insatiable glutton for gore.

title: Sports People; Schnelker Back to Pack
description: The Green Bay Packers are looking forward to having the wide receivers John Jefferson and James Lofton in tandem for a full season next autumn, and yesterday, in creating the position of offensive coordinator, they hired to fill it an old pro who knows a thing or two about the passing game. He is Bob Schnelker, the former Giant receiver who was offensive coordinator at Detroit last season and who coached Green Bay's quarterbacks and receivers from 1966 through 1977. ... Richard Todd, the Jet quarterback, has appealed the $1,500 fine imposed by the National Football League for his scuffle last November with Steve Serby, a reporter for The New York Post. The appeal will be heard by Commissioner Pete Rozelle.

title: Bangladesh Retains Premier
description: Shah Azizur Rahman has been retained as Prime Minister in President Abdus Sattar's new Cabinet, which was installed today. On Thursday, Mr. Sattar dismissed his 42-member Council of Ministers, charging that many were corrupt, and set up an 18-member group to run the Government.

title: Sports People; Benirschke Optimistic
description: Two weeks after doctors had removed what remained of his large intestine, Rolf Benirschke was discharged yesterday from Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, buoyed by the knowledge that he had finally won an on-again, off-again battle with poor health that almost took his life two years ago. Benirschke is only 27 years old and appears to be just entering his prime as the place-kicker of the San Diego Chargers, for whom he has set a National Football League record in career accuracy (82 field goals in 111 attempts, a .739 percentage).

title: CHAMPIONS OF OLDER WORKERS OPPOSING MANDATORY RETIREMENT
description: If there is more and more talk lately about abolishing discrimination in employment based on age, it is hardly surprising. Every day there are more and more Americans living and working longer than ever before, and they are the chief lobbyists for the change.

title: SANITAS SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $272,000 on discontinued operations

title:
PATENTS;
Hammer Strikes Twice To Aid the Handicapped
description: A hammer for use by handicapped persons has an extra head that can increase the force of a blow. Dr. Boris Schwartz of Hawthorne, N.J., who has other medical-surgical inventions, received patent 4,314,593 this week for the adjustable tool.

title: KAISER STEEL CUTS ITS EMPLOYEE COSTS
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation, which announced last week that it lost $513.8 million in the fourth quarter of 1981, said today that it had cut executive salaries by 10 percent and instituted a wage freeze for all salaried workers.

title: Asarco Expects Quarter Deficit
description: Asarco Inc. is currently operating at a loss and expects to report a deficit for the first quarter if depressed copper, silver, lead and zinc prices do not improve, Charles F. Barber, chairman, said after an analysts' meeting in New York. Asarco earned $18.3 million in last year's first quarter and $15.3 million in the fourth quarter of 1981. Mr. Barber observed, however, that the four th-quarter earnings included $27 million pre-tax from tax benefit leasing arrangements, $3.3 million from last-in, first-out inventor y liquidations and $5.7 million from foreign currency adjustments, ne arly all of which floweddown to after-tax earnings. Asarco's fourth-q uarter tax provision wasonly $217,000.

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPUTERVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
