description: B-After losses on the sale of discontinued operations of $700,000 for the quarter and $3.2 million for the year and a $785,000 loss from discontinued operations for the year; C-After losses from discontinued operations of $231,000 for the quarter and $143,000 for the year

title: Notes On People; Bess Truman Is 97
description: The nation's oldest living First Lady, Bess Truman, will celebrate her 97th birthday today at her Civil War-era home in Independence, Mo., with a small party.

title: KANE FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Buffalo Hearing Put Off for 5 Suspected of Helping I. R. A.
description: A hearing on charges of trying to enter the United States illegally was delayed today for five men suspected of intending to purchase arms for the Irish Republican Army.

title: U.S. AND MOROCCO AGREE TO SET UP JOINT MILITARY COMMISSION
description: The United States and Morocco announced agreement today on a joint military commission and on steps that are exp ected to lead to transit rights f or American military forces.

title: BELO, A H, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GREY ADVERTISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings for the latest quarter and year give effect to amounts attributable to redeemable preferred stock; revenue figures represent billings

title: FINGERMATRIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

PATENTS;
A Triple Lock Helps Strengthen Handcuffs
description: Improved handcuffs, with a triple lock instead of the usual double one, were patented this week for the Department of Commerce.

title: FEWER LEGAL AID LAWYERS COPING WITH THE INCREASING TROUBLES OF THE POOR
description: In and out of the drab legal aid office the poor people come and go, la den with the troubles that fester in the forbidding concrete towe rs of the nearby Robert Taylor Homes, one of the world'slargest publi c housing projects.

title: TESORO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wassaja Seeks Spinks's Title
description: For Michael Spinks ''first things first'' means defending his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title today against Mustafa Wassaja, a Ugandan who lives in Denmark. Then Spinks wants a chance at Mike Weaver's W.B.A. heavyweight title, which would mean a couple of bigger firsts. Today's nationally televised bout (ABC, Channel 7 in New York, 5 P.M.) from Atlantic City is the first light-heavyweight title fight in which both contestants are undefeated.

title: Poland Debt Plan Gains
description: A Federal judge today temporarily upheld the Reagan Administration's plan to avoid a default by Poland and insure repayment of that country's loans to United States banks.

title: DIAMOND INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr toDec 31
Continental Illinois Loans
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said that the level of its nonperforming loans rose to $653 million at the end of 1981, from $444 million a year earlier, but that the level was still below the 1975 recession peak of $705 million.

title: French Oil Imports Off
description: French crude oil imports fell 18.2 percent in 1981, to 91.8 million tons, from 112.2 million tons in 1980, according to customs office statistics released today. Gas imports rose 7.4 percent in 1981, to the equivalent of 17.3 million tons of oil, from 16.1 million tons in 1980, the customs office said. There are approximately 7.7 barrels per metric ton of oil or oil equivalent.

title: GIBSON, C R, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in December 1981

title: Gretzky Scores His 70th Goal
description: Wayne Gretzky of the Oilers tonight became the second player in National Hockey League history to score 70 goals in a season as Edmonton beat the Washington Capitals, 5-3.

title: TRI-CHEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notes On People; Ascap Honors Miss Merman as Its Pied Piper
description: The fourth Pied Piper's Award of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers will go to Ethel Merman, the Broadway star who's been belting out song hits since 1930, when she introduced ''I Got Rhythm'' in George Gershwin's ''Girl Crazy.''

title: Mavericks 103, Sonics 100
description: DALLAS (UPI) - Jay Vincent scored 38 points and grabbed 16 rebounds for Dallas. Vincent had 22 points in the first half, which ended with the Mavericks leading the SuperSonics by 60-56.Jack Sikma had 30 points and 17 rebounds for Seattle.

title: G.M. Withholds 1980-'81 Bonuses
description: The General Motors Corporation said that for the second year in a row, it will not award executive bonuses. Citing the company's poor economic performance, the G.M. bonus and salary committee ''determined that there would be no bonus awards related to the years 1981 and 1980,'' the company said when it released financial statements on the company's performance.

title: Index; International
description: Britain's Conservative Party is making a comeback 2 Soviet abandons effort to block discussion of Poland at Madrid 3 Haig arrives in Rumania for talks 3 Around the World 6 NATO summit meeting shifted to Bonn at Germans' request 26 Government/Politics Republicans active in recruiting Congressional candidates 8 Convicted felon linked to aborted Reagan house purchase 10 The low-fare PATH system be- comes bistate issue again 27 Washington Talk Briefing 10 Haig's new man in the Middle East talks 10 General Around the Nation 8 Despite trial, von Bulow is still welcomed by Newport society 9 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Washington's Birthday will be ob- served on Monday (though the actual date is Feb. 22). Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices -Closed. Post offices - Closed; only special delivery and express mail delivered. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Subways and buses on Saturday/holiday schedules; commuter rail lines on holiday schedules. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed.

title: Article 189781 -- No Title
description: Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's state-owned oil company, is arranging a $2 billion loan through a group of six international banks, it was disclosed here today.

title: Yonkers Council Votes Prezioso City Manager
description: The City Council voted at a special session tonight to name Sal J. Prezioso City Manager. The vote was 11 to 1, with one member absent.

title: No Headline
description: VON B"ULOW STORY DESCRIBES NEWPORT HIGH SOCIETY

title: DORSEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a nonrecurring charge of $1.5 million on the disposition of plant facilities; C-After a nonrecurring charge of $3.4 million for the quarter and year onthe disposition of plant facilities

title: BAYUK CIGARS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $625,000 on a discontinued pension plan; C-Including a taxcredit of $288,000 and a credit of $245,000 from an accounting change

title: GENERAL AMERICA OIL CO OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHRISTIANA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; C-Including a gain of $1,317,000, or 54 cents a share, on the sale of magazine

title: ALEXANDER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANGRY CARTING CONCERNS TO ACT ON 'UNFAIR' RATES
description: The city's 400 private garbage collectors, protesting what they called unprofitable new rates set by the Department of Consumer Affairs, declared yesterday that they would initiate countermeasures. Among those they cited were an end to Saturday and overtime collections, layoffs and an attempt to renegotiate a union contract reached after a 17-day strike in December.

title: Armco May Sell Coal Reserves
description: Armco Inc. is considering selling some of its coal reserves, which total nearly one billion tons, Harry Holiday, chief executive officer, told analysts.

title: Do-It-Yourself I.R.A. Plans
description: A GENERAL perception of the new Individual Retirement Accounts seems to be that they are passive investments that call for prudence and conservative judgment. After all, the goal is to save for old age, so there's a tendency to look upon I.R.A.'s as a lifetime plan that people enroll in now and forget about until it's time to collect.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1982
description: International Reports that five U.S. military aides in El Salvador were carrying M-16 rifles on a training mission in what appears to have been a combat zone will be investigated by the Pentagon under an order by President Reagan. The State Department has said the military advisers are permitted to carry only side arms, which they may use only in self-defense. (Page 1, Columns 1-2.) El Salvador's land redistribution plan is ''proceeding reasonably well'' in its initial phase, according to a report paid for by the United States Agency for International Development. However, the report recommends that the Salvadoran junta speed the transfer of land titles and curb harassment of farm workers. (7:1-2.)

title: PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 17
Frank Lilien, Retired Partner Of New York Engineering Firm
description: Frank Lilien, a consulting engineer and retired partner of Tippetts-Abbett-McCarthy-Stratton, a New York engineering concern, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: Tanker Breaks Up in Atlantic; 14 Crewmen Feared Drowned
description: A gale split a tanker in half Friday in the North Atlantic and 14 crewmen were presumed drowned. Another 18 huddled on half of the sinking hulk until they abandoned ship early today, and rescue officials here said they were uncertain if the men were in lifeboats.

title: INTERNATIONAL INCOME PROPERTY reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
HAIG'S NEW MAN IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: Richard Fairbanks, who almost went into the Foreign Service and who almost went into politics, is now about to plunge into one of the most difficult diplomatic and political tasks in the world. With little time to prepare, he will be leaving for the Middle East shortly as the Secretary of State's representative in the peace process.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May 1981

title: LAB'S CLOSING POINTS UP U.S. QUANDRY ON SAFETY
description: The closing of a classroom building at Rutgers University after Federal investigators found increased levels of a hormone in the air underscores a national quandary: The legal and accepted practices applied to work places in the chemical industry do not apply to most research laboratories, and there appears to be little agreement among scientists as to what precautions ought to be observed at such laboratories.

title: TOCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
E.E.C. STEEL EXPORT CUT
description: Steel producers in the European Economic Community, accused by American steelmakers of unfair trade practices, will hold down exports to the United States in this year's second quarter, E.E.C. industry sources said today.

title: Injured Baryshnikov Cancels Week on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO (UPI) Feb. 12 -Mikhail Baryshnikov has canceled his first week of American Ballet Theater performances opening Tuesday at the Opera House because of a knee injury suffered in Clevela nd earlier in the week.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Damson Oil Corp. said it completed its purchase of seven gasgathering and processing facilities from Crystal Oil Corp., for $27.5 million.

title: SOVIET ENDS MADRID EFFORT TO BAR TALKS ON POLAND
description: The Soviet Union today abandoned its efforts to block the discussion of Poland at the Madrid Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, and Western foreign ministers resumed their attacks on Warsaw for suppressing Solidarity.

title: KEAN FAVORS CHALLENGE TO REDISTRICTING
description: The Kean administration said today that it wouldsupport a law suit by the state's seven Republican members of Congressthat asks for a special Federal Court review of the state's Congressional redistricting plan.

title: Around the World; Polish Pilot Diverts Airliner to West Berlin
description: A Polish airline pilot diverted a domestic flight with 23 people aboard to West Berlin today. The pilot brought his wife, two daughters, his wife's cousin and the cousin's wife and their child with him as passengers, West Berlin officials said, and asylum was sought for all.

title: NEW BRUNSWICK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
REDCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
VISHAY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1980 share earnings reflect 5% stock dividend in April 1981

title: Cooney Fight 'Definitely On'
description: ''The fight is not in jeopardy. The kid is working out every day.'' With those words yesterday, Dennis Rappaport, co-manager of Gerry Cooney, appeared to dispel any remaining doubts that Cooney's challenge to Larry Holmes for the World Boxing Council's heavyweight title would take place as scheduled March 15 in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: MERCURY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TOWNER PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a tax credit of $75,000

title: SPIRAL METAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income after an extraordinary gain of $193,000; C-Net income after an extraordinary credit of $518,000

title: STUDYING WOMEN'S LOVE 'STYLES'
description: THE Hallmark Company estimates that 800 million valentines will be exchanged in the United States today. ''That means,'' said Dr. Bonnie Maslin, a psychologist, ''that in spite of everything, there is something very fundamental about wanting to be wanted.''

title: THE TWO FLAGSHIPS OF STAMFORD MALL
description: THEY are at opposite sides of the Town Center Mall in Stamford, Conn., like two giant bookends - Macy's, a smooth beige monolith of a department store, and J. C. Penney, a dark red-brick building. Scheduled to open to the public on Thursday, both stores are expected to draw a portion of their customers from the county.

title: NUCLEAR PROTEST LEADS TO LAWSUIT
description: A politically conservative public service law firm has filed an unusual lawsuit against individuals and organizations that protested at the Diablo Canyon nuclear reactor last September.

title:
About Westchester;
NEW ROCHELLE
description: TO a casual observer, it probably appeared that someone famous had been checked into the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center last week. A tangle of cables led from the hall to one of the rooms; inside, a young man sat on a bed, smiling, while cameras were angled and microphones adjusted and a producer briskly issued directions.

title: Headliners; Fast Break
description: Rather than face the music of a federal investigation, presidential trouble shooter Joseph W. Canzeri decided to skip the show. Mr. Canzeri resigned last week as executive assistant to the White House deputy chief of staff, Michael K. Deaver, after disclosures that he had borrowed $200,000 each from Laurance S. Rockefeller and Donald M. Koll, a real estate delveloper in Newport Beach, Calif. Mr. Canzeri, who worked for Nelson Rockefeller and managed the Rockefeller family estate, said he used the money to finance a $380,000 townhouse in Georgetown. Mr. Canzeri said he saw ''nothing wrong'' in obtaining the low-interest loans, but resigned because he did not want the President to be ''bruised or blackened'' by his actions. It was also discovered that Mr. Canzeri had submitted expense claims to the Government and to the Republican National Committee for the same trips. Although unsure of what he'll do next, Mr. Canzeri said he had a couple ideas: ''I'll either become a mortgage banker or a certified punlic accountant.''

title: A NEW FILIPINO COALITION CHALLENGES MARCOS
description: Politicians who favor a peaceful challenge to the 16-year-old authoritarian Government of Ferdinand E. Marcos have formed a coalition for a new attempt to bring about a pluralist democracy.

title: REJECTED SUITORS: TAKE HEART!
description: AMAN who is rejected in love often feels that he cannot go on. Without his beloved, he thinks, life will be empty and he will have no future. Rubbish! The fact, of which historians remind us, is that scores of famous men attained great success and happiness only after losing in love. And the women who spurned them? Their names are simply unimportant footnotes.

title: DANCE: DANZ, INC., A NEW COMPANY
description: The Harlem Cultural Council has sought to emphasize the infinite variety of black dance during its Dancemobile Winter Series at the Symphony Space. Appropriately enough, therefore, Friday night's program was shared by a promising new modern dance company and a troupe that specialized in traditional Haitian dance.

title: ROCK: CLEMONS'S NEW BAND
description: One of the stalwarts of Bruce Springsteen's E Street Band is the saxophonist Clarence Clemons, whose raw, King Curtis-style of horn playing provides Mr. Springsteen with his strongest link to 1960's soul music. Mr. Clemons is no technical virtuoso, but his feel for 60's soul runs deep, and in his work with Mr. Springsteen he is sometimes almost a second voice.

title: WATT REPORTS ON 'YEAR OF CHANGE' AT INTERIOR
description: In a handsomely produced report to the President on the Interior Department's accomplishments over the past year, Interior Secretary James G. Watt boasts of his agency's ''extraordinary success'' at making changes ''that can lead to the restoration of America's greatness.''

title: Catholic Migrants
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAY: WEINSTEIN'S 'PARTY'
description: Arnold Weinstein's ''The Party,'' a verse play with music by Laurence Rosenthal, is not your average cup of tedium. It is interminable, a three-act, two-hour-and-45-minute farewell to the 1950's, a kind of New York-art-scene version of ''The Cocktail Party'' without T.S. Eliot's lightness. It is more of a wake than the suggested celebration.

title: GETTING TWO FOR ONE
description: Fortunate is he who gets two birds with one stone these days. If you produce a fine piece of prepared analysis and win a game, you usually cannot expect to extract a second victory with it.

title: The World in Summary; A Balance Sheet On Human Rights
description: The Reagan Administration likes to practice ''quiet diplomacy'' to deal with human rights violations by friendly nations. Last week, it went modestly public, including in its first rights report to Congress condemnations of the usual suspects (Moscow, Warsaw, Havana) plus relatively candid critiques of such allies as El Salvador, Guatemala, Ha iti, Israel, South Africa, Pakistan and Taiwan.

title: Brooklyn College Sets Gershwin Show
description: George and Ira Gershwin, who were born in Brooklyn, will be the subjects of a celebration at Brooklyn College from March 8 through April 5. ''Celebrating the Gershwins: An Exhibition and Entertainment'' will feature more than 100 items - paintings, photographs, posters, sheet music, letters and sculpture.

title: Theater in Review; A BIT OF DARING IN 'FLIRTATIONS'
description: HERRICKS BRAVO to the Nassau Repertory's artistic director, Clinton J. Atkinson, for unearthing a fascinating, forgotten play. Actually, for most of us, Arthur Schnitzler's ''Flirtations'' (from the German ''Liebelei'') has been unseen and unheard of. Using a new translation by A.S. Wensinger and Susanne Mrozik, Mr. Atkinson dallied with such other titles as ''Light of Love,'' ''Playing With Love'' and ''The Love Game''; the closest literal equivalents of the German title are ''The Little Love'' and ''A Negligible Love Affair.''

title: THE LURE OF COMMERCE
description: FOR the last several years, the Syrian Government of President Hafez al-Assad has held an international trade fair each fall, and by 1981 the demand from American, Japanese and European exhibitors was so great that the display area had to be expanded. Even as the Syrian Government has been moving politically closer to the Soviet Union, its economic policies are beginning to reflect a realization that Syria can profit immensely from cooperating with the West's private entrepreneurs.

title: 30% OF CITY'S CHILDREN GET SOME WELFARE AID
description: Nearly 30 percent of New York City's children are growing up with welfare aid for part of their lives, according to new city studies. More than 10 percent of the city's overall population is receiving welfare family help at a given time.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe, Kriek Reach Memphis Final

title: A BOEING FAMILY IN TURKEY
description: ANKARA SOME Americans are made for export, they say. Marsden Albright, contracts manager for Boeing Services International in Turkey, and his wife Aneitta are that kind. The Albrights, who lived with their three children through the worst of Turkey's troubles, love the country and the people and are thinking of retiring here one day.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF TENTATIVE PACT
description: Provisions of the tentative Ford-U.A.W. pact include: Elimination of the 3 percent annual pay increase for production workers for the life of the contract, a nine-month freeze on costof-living increases, and elimination of the six paid personal holidays.

title: ABOUT DELIVERING THE VALENTINE MESSAGE
description: IT's the season of Cupid instead of Santa Claus, but Valentine's Day, like Christmas and many of our other hol idays, seems to have fallen prey to American commercialism. Listen to the advertisements. I heard three the other morning, and they wer e all built around the same theme: Show your spouse, mother, sister, girlfriend or boyfriendthat you really love them - buy them somethin g!

title: CONFLICT IS FOUND IN VIEWS ON NEEDY
description: ''Public welfare'' leads the list of services provided by state and local governments that Americans would cut most severely if money was short, but ''aid to the needy'' would be retained ahead of such things as streets, highways, colleges and par ks.

title: Food; ONION BAGELS, YES- AND NOW, SPINACH OR CHOCOLATE CHIP
description: HOW do you like your bagels? Sesame? Onion? Pumpernickel? How about spinach? And are you ready for chocolate chip? Countless bagel bakeries on the Island have bagels in several flavors, but at Bagel Boss in Hicksville, the varieties definitely break new ground. Chocolate chip and spinach bagels, which they bake regularly, might appeal to the curious, ready to sample anything new.

title: The Wheel Turns Wins Berlo Dash at Aqueduct
description: David T. Greathouse's The Wheel Turns took the lead at the start and never gave it up in winning the $56,800 Berlo Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Crafts
description: FAIR LAWN THE convict ion that finely crafted wood makes a good marriage with fabric collag e has prompted the Kornbluth Gallery to match up contemporary furniture by Michael Coffey with appliqued hangings by Madge Hunting ton.

title: HE LOST IT AT THE FILMS
description: REVERSE ANGLE A Decade of American Films. By John Simon. 466 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. $17.95.

title: COAST LAYOFF PLAN PUTS RACE BEFORE SENIORITY
description: The Berkeley school board has adopted a plan for laying off teachers that would make a teacher's race a more important criterion for maintaining a job than seniority.

title: The Drinking Age Matters
description: Governor Carey's proposal to raise the age for buying liquor in New York from 18 to 19 is not a matter of prudery. It's a matter of li fe and death.

title: Paul J. Sitarz Is Fiance Of Kimberly B. Banker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Banker of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Beatrice Banker, to Paul John Sitarz, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Sitarz of New Bedford, Mass.

title: Julie Levinson Fiancee Of Andrew D. Fately
description: Julie Anne Levinson, a broadcast coordinator for the Lever Brothers Media Group in New York, and Andrew David Fately, an institutional stock trader with Oppenheimer & Company, plan to be married March 21.

title: C.D.C., A CANADIAN CURIOSITY, BUILDS AND EMPIRE
description: TORONTO ''T HEY'RE a heads-up outfit,'' said David Schulman, an analyst with Geoffrion Leclerc Inc. ''But ...'' ''I think they're very good,'' said Ira Katzin, an analyst for Pitfield Mackay Ross Ltd., ''I'm very confident in the management of the company. But ...''

title: NURSES ASK SAME PAY AS MEN IN SIMILAR JOBS
description: More than 1,200 nurses, all but 33 of them women, are on strike against four San Jose hospitals, demanding that they be paid what men would be paid in a comparable profession.

title: Index; International
description: In some parts of Ireland, Ulster is main election issue 3 Murdoch accused of move to ease closing of the Times of London 5 Israeli says Arab terrorism influ- ences West's reporting 9 China concluded a trade agree- ment with Poland last month 11 U.S. doctors, after visit, call Po- land's health care poor 12 Tension rises in Aegean amid Turkish fears of Greek move 16 Despite terrorism and economic crisis, Italy avoids disaster 20 Archeologists at Pompeii find re- mains of 20 21 Government/Politics Redistricting poses a challenge to North Carolina Congressman 30 Views differ on ''welfare'' and ''aid to needy'' 31 Study finds voting rights being violated in South 32 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Washington's Birthday will be ob- served tomorrow (though the actual date is Feb. 22). Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal offices - Close d. State and mun icipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed, with only special delivery and express mail delivered. Banks - Close d. Stock and com modity markets -Closed. Transportatio n - Subways and buses on Saturday/holiday schedules; commuter ra il lines on holiday schedules. Libraries - C losed. Schools - Clo sed.

title: The World in Summary; First Prize Is A Hot Potato
description: Costa Rica proved anew last week that it is free, democratic and shuns political extremes. But political virtue gets you only so far at the bank.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Two of the most interesting of the new generation modern-dance choreographers will be performing this week. Elizabeth Streb, who will present new and recent work at The Kitchen Thursday through next Sunday, has moved from making high-energy, pure dance pieces to dance that is limited and in a sense defined by the equipment on which it is performed - here a high, steeply inclined wooden plane and slightly tilted wooden disc.

title: Headliners; Long Road Out
description: As it turns out, Lidiya Vashchenko, the Soviet Pentecostalist, may have to go East to get West, but after four years of waiting, almost any route is a shortcut. After a brief reunion with family members at the United States Embassy in Moscow last week, Miss Vaschenco, who lived at the embassy until Jan. 30, left with her sisters for their home in Chernogorsk, Siberia where she will file papers for emigration.

title: The Nation in Summary; Neck-and-Neck In New Orleans
description: Mayor Ernest N. Morial was the first black graduate of the Louisiana State University Law School and was the first black politician since Reconstruction to win a seat in the Louisiana Legislature. Four years ago he became the city's first black Mayor.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Extra Savings For a Birthday Sale
description: Denim Mine in the Bazaar of Mount Kisco Mall is having a presidential birthday sale until Feb. 21, and prices usually discounted 20 percent are reduced an additional 50 to 70 percent. The four-year-old store carries nationally advertised ladies' basic clothing in sizes 4 to 18 and juniors from 3 to 15; girls' 7 to 14; men's 25 waist to 52 waist and boys' sizes 8 through 20.

title: Dining Out; A WELCOME JAPANESE ADDITION
description: NEW HAVEN GOOD entry-level vibrations are no guarantee of a satisfactory dining experience. Fortunately, at Hatsune, a new Japanese restaurant in New Haven, they are a happy portent of good things to come.

title: Reading and Writing; THE NEW THRILLER
description: ''Chameleon,'' by William Diehl, and ''The Mahdi, by A.J. Quinnell, are examples of a trend in suspense novels. Like many other trends today, this one is away from the personal, toward the political and the abstract. The early thrillers were about crimes of passion - motivated by love, hate, greed, envy or jealousy - but the typical hyped-up mystery novel of today is about crimes of dispassion, committed for convoluted reasons eventually traceable to politics or to a lust for power that is very close to politics.

title: Shaktman Will Leave Pittsburgh Theater
description: When his contract expires June 30, Ben Shaktman, artistic director of the Pittsburgh Public Theater, will end his fulltime involvement with the theater. Mr. Shaktman plans to devote his time to personal creative projects, including screenplays. However, he will serve as artistic adviser to the theater's board of directors.

title: HUDSON'S OTHER SHORE MAY NOT BE DEAD IN THE WATER
description: Though its views of the Manhattan skyline are unsurpassed, the New Jersey side of the Hudson River may itself be unsurpassed as an eyesore. The docks and railroad yards of the once-vital waterfront lie rotting and rusting, the victims of vandalism, abandonment and neglect.

title: THE PARTY WASN'T FUN
description: WHICH SIDE WERE YOU ON? The American Communist Party During the Second World War. By Maurice Isserman. Illustrated. 328 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. $19.95.

title: DARK VOLUMES
description: WHISPER TO THE EARTH By David Ignatow. 88 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown. Cloth, $10.95. Paper, $6.95. THE MAN IN THE BLACK COAT TURNS By Robert Bly. 62 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $10.95.

title: AID LOSS TO FORCE CLINIC TO TURN AWAY SOME POOR
description: Fifteen hundred of the 2,500 adult patients served by the Comprehensive Family Care Center in the Bronx have been told that they will be turned away at the end of this month if they cannot afford the higher fees necessitated by the center's loss of a $350,000 Federal grant.

title: A PROPOSED $12 BILLION CUT IN HOUSING IS ASSAILED
description: A proposal by the Reagan Administration to rescind $12 billion already authorized for a housing program over the next 30 years has provoked widespread criticism from housing officials in New York and advocates for the poor.

title: THE COOPERATIVE ECONOMY
description: ''NO BACKWARD STEP!'' The battle cry, coined by John L. Lewis in the 1920's to rally his coal-smudged army of union miners against pay cuts, epitomizes the adversarial spirit that has characterized the approach of both labor and management at most bargaining tables since then.

title: Donna Magid To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Magid of Port Chester, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Donna Magid, to Dr. Elliot K. Fishman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Fishman of Pikesville, Md.

title: Owner Seeks Solutions To Rockets' Problems
description: Ed Tepper, president of the New Jersey Rockets, the only expansion team in the Major Indoor Soccer League, says that he will know more about the future of the struggling franchise in the next month.

title: LAWYERS CRITICIZE INTEGRATION PLAN
description: The Justice Department's approval of the Chicago Board of Education's plan to rely ''almost exclusively'' on voluntary pupil transfers to cure pervasive school segregation was assailed today by civil rights lawyers who said the plan should be rejected by the courts.

title: INFLATION IN ISRAEL DIPS AT LAST
description: JERUSALEM FACED w ith 1980's inflation rate of 133 percent, disturbing even ina country whe re wages are adjusted upward as living costs rise, YoramAridor took o ffice a year ago as Israel's Finance Minister. Espousinghis own form of supply-side economics, he set out to reverse the policies of h is predecessor.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 2 22 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 2 1 17 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 3 4 3 MARCO POLO, IF YOU CAN, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $13.95.) Blackford Oakes's quest for a mole in the C.I.A. takes him to Russia. 4 3 13 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 5 12 2 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 6 10 17 RABBIT IS RICH, by John Updike. (Knopf, $13.95.) Harry Angstrom of ''Rabbit, Run'' returns in the chips but unfulfilled. 7 6 2 THE DEAN'S DECEMBER, by Saul Bellow. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) During a deathbed vigil in Rumania, a college dean from Chicago realizes some truths about his own land. 8 15 2 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer.

title: GOODE IS JUMPING WITH JOY
description: Milton Goode remembers the first time he high-jumped. ''I come from Tinton Falls, N.J.,'' he said. ''It was in my sophomore year at Monmouth Regional High School. Our physical education teacher was telling us about different track events and how to do them.''

title: CHINESE EXHORTED TO ORTHODOXY
description: PEKING CONCERN seems to be lingering within the Chinese leadership over how far the country should stray from its Marxist orthodoxy in overhauling its economy. China's pragmatic new push toward modernization is not without political baggage.

title: Emily Saxe, M.A. Nydam Will Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Daniel Saxe Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Saxe, to Mark Allen Nydam, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ralph Nydam of Corsica, S.D.

title: Q&A
description: Question:A friend and I are planning to walk a stretch of the Appalachian Trail in mid-June, starting perhaps near Washington, D.C. and traveling south. Could you tell us where to get information on trail facilities, difficulty, and the like? - D.F., Hoboken, N.J. Answer:The Appalachian Trail Conference (Post Off ice Box 236, Harper's Ferry, W. Va. 25425; 304-535-6331) i s the organization to write or call for detailed information on the trail. The conference will mail you a brochure describing its organ ization, a list of 60 affiliated clubs and a list of publications. Among these are a series of 10 guidebooks that provide maps and the kind of supporting information you need - where to find grocerie s and supplies, for example - for hiking the trail, which extends from Georgia to Maine. If you would like to do your hiking as part o f a group, among the organizations you could try is the Sierra Clu b. Its outings department (50 Bush Street, San Francisco, Ca lif. 94108; 415-981-8634) can supply a brochure describin g expeditions sponsored by the environmentalist organization; they ha ve outings in the regionyou mention.

title: The World in Summary; Sandbagged in Saudi Arabia
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger pulled an all-nighter in Saudi Arabia last week, but apparently it didn't get him a passing grade in Saudi-American relations.

title: EFFORT BY METHODISTS TO RAISE FUNDS FOR TV MINISTRY FALTERS
description: An effort by the United Methodist Church to raise $25 million for television broadcasting is faltering, and the 10-million member denomination is transferring staff members from its office of communications to shore up the special campaign.

title: Washington Birth Is Marked
description: In observance of the 250th birthday of George Washington, President Reagan has issued a message commemorating the first President as ''a man whose unsurpassed contributions to our nation place him first in the hearts of all patriotic Americans.'' Washington's birthday will be observed as a Federal holiday on Monday, although he was born Feb. 22.

title: G.A.O. Finds $12 Million Loss
description: In Food Stamp Distribution

title: Politics; A COMMISSION TO STUDY TAX STRUCTURE
description: HARTFORD ALTHOUGH it hasn't got a lot of attention so far, one recent action by the General Assembly seems likely to set the stage for a major legislative debate on Connecticut's tax structure next year.

title: G. R. Avery, Miss Thrush Will Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Thrush of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Lauriston Elizabeth Thrush, to G. Randall Avery, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Avery Jr., also of Westport.

title: Theater; SAVOY'S 'STOMPIN' ROCKS BRIDGEPORT
description: ''STOMPIN' '' is a new show created for the Downtown Cabaret Theater, only it's not as new as some might say it is. Its creators, who both worked with Claude McNeal, the D.C.T.'s first artistic director, have produced their own version of the sort of show he used to stage in Bridgeport. While he built his pastiches of music and slides around decades of American life, Judith Lisi and Stanley Wietrzychowski have built their show around Harlem's legendary Savoy Ballroom, which was devoted to jazz and swing.

title: Jersey Casinos Bolster Economy, Study Finds
description: A Federal Reserve Bank study of the impact of casino gambling on the Atlantic City area has found that the industry ''has pretty much lived up to its advance expectations in providing jobs and s timulus.''

title: LOSS OF ITS INSTUMENTS FAILS TO UNSTRING ISRAEL ORCHESTRA
description: The harpsichord and two bass fiddles were borrowed, the rehearsal harp was restrung and with them, the Kibbutz Chamber Orchestra of Israel planned to continue its American tour last night at Brooklyn College, braving the apparent theft of the group's original instruments.

title: No Headline
description: Virginia Wins on Final Shot

title: HEATING FUNDS TO BE SHIFTED TO SOCIAL SERVICES
description: New York State, in a budget shift, will let local governments spend$10 million in Federal funds on social-servic e programs rather than on winter heating aid for low-income families .

title: Cynthia Barradas, Executive, Br ide Of Donald Eli tzer
description: Cynthia Maria Barradas, controller of the Stevenson Capital Management Corporation in New York, was married yesterday to Donald Brian Elitzer, vice president-corporate finance of Rothschild Inc., in New York City. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler at the Burden Mansion in Manhattan.

title: ISLAND OASIS ON THE NILE
description: WILLIAM E. FARRELL is chief of The Times bureau in Cairo. By WILLIAM E.FARRELL

title: ED REITER; Foreign Coins Continue to Intrigue Collectors
description: Things have been gloomy in the coin market lately, but not all the news has been bad. One of the more encouraging developments has been the continued strength of foreign and ancient coins. These have held their own for the most part, even as prices were plummeting for United States material.

title: MURDOCH IS ACCUSED OF UNLAWFUL PLOY WITH TIMES OF LONDON
description: The former editor of The Times of London charged today that its present owner, Rupert Murdoch, had acted unlawfully in a corporate move that could make it easier for him to close the paper.

title: Around the Nation; Jurors Inspect Bridge C ited in Atlanta Deaths
description: Jurors who are trying Wayne B. Williams for murder bundled up against a cold wind today and inspected a twolane bridge over which Mr. Williams is accused of throwing Jimmy Ray Payne, 21 years old, and Nathaniel Cater, 27, into the Chattahoochee River last spring.

title: IN RUSSIA, AN ECONOMY ENCUMBERED
description: MOSCOW MORE than 65 years ago, a core of zealous men made a revolution that promised Russians freedom and material well-being. But the freedom never came, and after decades of slowly improving living standards the 267 million people here find themselves harnessed to a stagnating economy that seems in-capab le of providing the comforts of the capitalist West.

title: Japan's Robot Revolution
description: Japan may have a ''love affair with robots,'' but should we in the United States emulate the Japanese and also become enamored of such automatons (''Japan's Love Affair With the Robot,'' by Henry Scott Stokes, Jan. 10)? Apparently no unemployment has resulted in Japan asa consequence of the introduction of robots in industry; however, here it might be a different story. While the making of robots would provide jobs for skilled people, in the long run, an increasing number of wor kers would inevitably be thrown out of work because of the applicati on of these very robots to the production of consumer goods.

title: BENEFITS FOR POOR PEOPLE FACE DEEPEST CUTS
description: Federal programs specially intended for poor people would sustain proportionally deeper cuts than other Government benefit programs under President Reagan's budget for the coming year.

title: Catty Catechesis
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WORLD OF WONDERS OF ROBERTSON DAVIES
description: MANY years ago I learned that nothing calls forth more pleasure than the perceived failure of a presumptively educated man to know what he is supposed to know. I gave such pleasure some 10 years ago when a friend of marked scholarly attainment discovered that I did not know about Robertson Davies. ''And you a Canadian!''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; New Warning, Fresh Criticism
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control got a double dose of criticism last week when it reiterated warnings that using aspirin to treat children with chicken pox or viral infections might lead to ''possible increased risk'' of Reye's syndrome, a sometimes fatal disease. The advisory, which appeared in the centers' Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, released last week, was based on an expert panel review of four studies and echoed an advisory issued in 1980.

title: THE AIRLINES: STACKED UP IN RED INK
description: SIR FREDDIE LAKER makes sparks. He made sparks in igniting air-fare wars over the North Atlantic and he made sparks in declaring bankruptcy. The ques tion of the moment is whe ther Laker Airways' collapse, provoked this month when its banker s cut off its lifeline, will prove as trend-setting as did Sir Freddi e's fare cutting. Some other airline officers fear that things are j ust that ominous.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; The Pope Takes His Mission to Moslem Africa
description: Pope John Paul II once called Africa ''ripe for the harvest'' of Roman Catholicism. Last week, he began his trip to predominantly Moslem West Africa bearing both the seeds of evangelism and the olive branch of ecumenical rapprochement.

title: The Nation in Summary; Going for the Chemical Bomb
description: Citing security concerns and the ''absence of a verifiable ban on producing and stockpiling chemical weapons,'' President Reagan last week called for an end to a 13-year-old moratorium on the manufacture of lethal nerve gas weapons.

title: IN FRANCE, 'A POLICY OF CHANGE'
description: PARIS NINE months after Francois Mitterrand was elected President of France with the seemingly impossible mandate of restoring full employment during a world recession, the country's new Socialist leadership is finding its policies bumping awkwardly against the realities of economic life.

title: STOCK TABLES
description: To the Business Editor: Certainly, the only argument that can be leveled against the idea is that everyone is already used to reading the stock tables the hard way. People don't accept changes - even to their advantage - too easily. But a newspaper like The New York Times should take the lead in implementing this more convenient stock lising. LOUIS J. ZIVOT Greenwhich, Conn., Feb. 7, 1982

title: Elizabeth Tollefson to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John J. Egan Jr. of Newport, R.I., of the engagement of Mrs. Egan's daughter, Elizabeth Catherine Tollefson, to Charles R.V. Portner, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Alexander Portner of Washington. Miss Tollefson, daughter also of the late Dr. George A. Tollefson, and her fiance plan to be married June 19.

title: FROM LITTLE SLIVERS OF TISSUE, BIG FRUIT CROPS MAY GROW
description: Draped across a small hillside in a plot belonging to the Federal Government's Beltsville Agricultural Research Center stand scores of strange little trees. Some are barely three feet high, few exceed five feet. But come summer, barring natural catastrophes, these midgets will yield normal-sized apples, peaches and pears in varieties familiar to fruit lovers.

title: Investing;$
description: D ESPITE more than a year of lackluster markets and declining trading volume, the commodity futures fund, or pool as it is better known, has become one of the fastest-growing alternate investments around.

title: EXPERT SAYS FIND DISPUTES HISTORY OF POMPEII
description: Archeologists have recently found the remains of about 20 people who died in the fire and lava that flowed from Mount Vesuvius onto Pompeii and Herculaneum 1,903 years ago.

title: USING GAME THEORY, VIA POKER, TO EXAMINE REAGAN'S FISCAL '83 BUDGET
description: 52,0CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - Playing President is like playing poker. But when the President is caught bluffing in a high-stakes game, who loses? The stakes, in a legendary night of giants at the Institute for Advanced Study, in Princeton, were smaller, but revealing. Some young mathematicians had inveigled the great mathematician Johnny von Neumann, who invented game theory with his elegant ''minmax'' theorem, into playing poker with them.

title: POPE TO NIGERIANS: DEFEND THE FAMILY
description: Pope John Paul II said mass today for hundreds of thousands of Nigerian Catholics at the outskirts of this city, which was a battleground that changed hands many times during the country's civil war.

title: A COMPOSER'S COOPERATIVE THAT WORKS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently on musical subjects. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: STOCK TABLES
description: To the Business Editor: Yes! ROBERT L. EDGELL Chairman, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Publications New York, N.Y., Feb. 9, 1982

title: WHO ARE THE TRUE MODERNISTS?
description: ALL THAT IS SOLID MELTS INTO AIR Th e Experienc e of Modernity. By Marshall Berman. 384 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.50.

title: Mindy Cress Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Cress of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mindy Cress, to Steven David Cohen, son of Joyce Cohen of Haverhill, Mass. Miss Cress and her fiance, members of the class of '82, at the New York University School of Law, plan to be married in August.

title:
Art;
A SHOW WITH PLEASING ECCENTRICITY
description: AMAGANSETT QUITE a few banks on the Island have taken to showing art on a fairly regular basis, but in the case of the Goodfriend Capital Corporation in the Mortgage Building on Montauk Highway, art is more than an incidental interest. Goodfriend is a private bank specializing in art-related services, such as vault storage, art brokerage and investment counseling, but its concerns extend beyond the needs of investors and collectors to include those of artists, whose work is marketed and promoted through an exhibition program.

title: 'WORKING YOUTH' REPORT STRESSES APPEARANCE
description: Young people looking for jobs in New York City's youth employment market should pay particular attention to their appearance and to factors indicating their reliability, according to a new report on ''Working Youth.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1982
description: International An order to leave El Salvador has been given to a senior American military adviser for having carried a rifle on training missions in violation of United States regulations. Ambassador Deane R. Hinton announced that Lieut. Col. Harry Melander, who has been in El Salvador for more than four months, would return to the United States next week. He said that Colonel Melander was one of five American advisers who were carrying M-16 automatic rifles while helping Salvadoran soldiers replace a bridge that had been blown up by guerrillas. The other armed Americans received ''firm, oral reprimands,'' Mr. Hinton said. (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: U.S. PROSECUTORS SAY MOB CONTROLS FULTON MARKET
description: Organized crime controls the Fulton Fish Market completely, from the arrival to the departure of the fish, according to Federal prosecutors conducting in a continuing investigation.

title: WE MUST ATTACK VIOLENT BEHAVIOR AT ITS SOURCE
description: SOCIAL SERVICE and mental-health workers know from experience that those who suffer severe emotional deprivation as children frequently end up in penal or mental institutions.

title: BUILDERS GO ALL OUT FOR 'AFFORDABILITY'
description: In 1976, in the midst of a real-estate recession, a home builder named Gary Minchew of Valdosta, Ga., went to a seminar on how to save money in construction. He says he has never been the same since.

title: Crime
description: About a year ago James Sherburne started a series of historical mysteries featuring Paddy Moretti, the sportswriter for The Spirit of the Times in the 1890's. ''Death's Pale Horse'' was a pleasant entertainment, and so is its successor, DEATH'S GRAY ANGEL (Houghton Mifflin, $10.95).

title: P.S.E.&G.; DECISION ASSAILED AND HAILED
description: NEWARK THE $390 million rate increase granted to the Public Service Electric & Gas Company by the state's Board of Public Utilities last week was more than $100 million higher than any utility had ever received from state regulators.

title: IN PARIS, CHOCOLATE DELUXE
description: PATRICIA WELLS is a writer who lives in Paris. By PATRICIA WELLS

title:
Long Island Guide;
KIBBUTZ ORCHESTRA
description: Although musicians have been known to moonlight to support their art, the 36 members of an ensemble that begins a two-performance stand on Long Island tonight at the Fine Arts Center at the State University at Stony Brook have a corner on the unusual-occupations market. They're part of the Kibbutz Chamber Orchestra of Israel, and when at home they split their professional lives straight down the middle: three days with the orchestra and three days on the job. Eliazer Cager, a cellist, is a star volleyball player on Israel's championship team; Mira Tischler, a flutist, drives a tractor; Shmuel Nir, the contrabass, keeps bees, and Georges Am-Shalem, a violinist, is a physician.

title: SRI LANKA, THE 'RESPLENDENT ISLE'
description: COLIN de SILVA was born in Sri Lanka. His novel about the reign of the warrior king Gamini, ''The Winds of Sinhala,'' has just been published by Doubleday. By COLIN de SILVA

title:
Gardening;
THE VIRTUES AND HAZARDS OF STARTER KITS
description: PREPLANTED starter kits for vegetables and annual flowers have begun to make their appearance in the stores. Northrup King's Punch 'n Grow has added a feature this year. The plastic tray has a reservoir at one end. A wick connecting the reservoir to the planting compartment keeps the planting medium uniformly moist.

title: Business Conditions; STATES WORKER LAYOFFS
description: Federal cutbacks and a weak economy are taking a toll on state workers around the country, a recent survey shows. According to the Bureau of National Affairs Inc., a private publishing company that is based in Washington, D.C., state governments laid off an estimated 12,500 employees in the 1981 fiscal year, and another 16,300 workers have been or will be laid off in this fiscal year.

title: INDIA'S PAST AND PRESENT CONSPIRE IN AN OUTBR EAK OF CORRUPTION
description: Late last month, in an unusual radio broadcast to the nation, President Sanjiva Reddy deplored what he described as a sharp drop in public morality. ''The values and sanctions which had in the past enabled us to live together in peace appear to be losing their hold,'' he said.

title: NEW-WAVE ROCK: WAITRESSES
description: At their best, the Waitresses, who appeared at the Peppermint Lounge on Wednesday, remind one of an intellectual answer to the Go-Go's. Even though the sextet includes two women and four men, their lead singer, Patty Donahue, plays a consistent character on stage - a bratty, independent, young woman who is always debating sexual politics in a very practical, nonideological way that brings in all the detritus of everyday life.

title: SHOPPING CENTER PLANS OPENING MINUS 132 STORES
description: IN circumstances that are unusual for a new shopping center, the Stamford Town Center, a huge urban renewal complex, is to open Thursday with its two anchor stores but minus its connecting mall and the 132 small stores and service establishments expected within it.

title: The Editorial Notebook; First Love and Candlelight
description: How interesting that Diane Keaton's face should adorn the cover of Newsweek as Valentine Day falls. Like that other Diana, Miss Keaton has an emblematic face and manner. She is gauze and lavender, almost what used to be called old-fashioned, an actr ess who can convincinglysay ''la-de-d a.'' And the Princess of Wales, too, exudes a period femininity; s he could play the heroine in any of the BBC's Victorian or Edwardian serials.

title: BEDFORD PASSES BAN ON GUNS AND TRAPS
description: AN ordinance to regulate trapping and hunting was passed last Tuesday evening by the Bedford Town Board after it heard two hours of impassioned remarks from the hunters, trappers and landowners in the standing-room-only audience. In a 4-to-1 vote, the board passed the Firearms and Traps Ordinance, which bans the discharge of firearms, setting of traps and use of the long-bow within the town of Bedford unless it is done by a landowner on his own property or by a person who has written permission of the property owner.

title: JOBLESSNESS: A GROWING SCOURGE
description: RattnerIn few places in the world and in few instances in history has the scourge of unemployment been visited quite so swiftly or quite so overwhelmingly as in Britain in the past 30 months. Within that period, just half the life of a full-term British Government, a jobless total that has not exceeded 1.5 million since the Great Depression of the 1930's has soared past 3 million. Unemployment had surged to 11.7 percent of the labor force last month, in line with projections by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development that it would reach 12.25 percent this year, up from 11 percent in the second half of 1981.

title: SORRY, WRONG NUMBERS
description: WASHINGTON RONALD Reagan got almost everything he wanted from Congress last year, using to full effect his personal charm, a flair for oratory and a sure sense of political direction. After the uncertain zig-zag pragmatism of Jimmy Carter, his ideological self-assurance seemed to fill a popular ache for leadership.

title: The World in Summary; Glimpse of Gdansk Is Revealing
description: ''The winter is yours, but the spring will be ours.'' The defiant slogan, scrawled in chalk on a shipyard gate in Gdansk, was noted last week by Western reporters on a Government-conducted tour of the Baltic city, their first visit there since martial law was declared in Poland on Dec. 13. Shipyard employees questioned when officials were looking the other way said they were not working at top efficiency. They hoped, the workers added, for eventual restoration of Solidarity, the independent union founded in Gdansk in August 1980.

title: HAWKING ARMS OVERSEAS
description: AS the costs of sophisticated military hardware escalate, arms manufacturers are seeking foreign orders more than ever to raise their output and thereby keep unit prices affordable. This trend, defense strategists and industry analysts say, raises the disturbing question of whether the industrial powers will be able to afford to arm themselves in the coming decade without arming the rest of the world at the same time.

title: TURKS FEAR A NEW GREEK MOVE IN THE AEGEAN
description: Tensions are increasing between Turkey and Greece over the Aegean Sea. Turkish officials have repeatedly warned in recent weeks against any attempt by Greece to proclaim an extension of its territorial waters from 6 to 12 miles in the Aegean, where it has 2,383 islands, some only a few miles off Turkey. The Turkish Foreign Ministry says such an extension would virtually close the Aegean to Turkish traffic.

title: A BALANCING ACT IN BONN
description: BONN WITH unemployment at a 29-year high and bankruptcies multiplying , all that seem s to be heating up in the West German economy is the discussion ov er what to do. As things grow progressively worse, Germany's lea ders, partly for political consumption and partly out ofconviction, a re looking for the cause of the malaise not at home but abroad.

title: DEVELOPMENT RUFFLES QUOGUE
description: THE little East End village of Quogue lies off the beaten path. It is a quiet place where the ambience of an earlier era can still be felt, especially along Quogue Street, the main t horoughfare lined with graceful old houses.

title: STATE AIDE SEES PHONE RATE RISE IN WAKE OF SUIT
description: ONLY one certainty has surfaced in the maelstrom unleashed by the American Telephone & Telegraph Company antitrust settlement: Local telephone rates will go up.

title: Around the Nation; Father of Slain Boy Asked to Come Forward
description: A Colombian whose 2-year-old son was accidentally shot to death was urged today to talk with the police, but the embittered man said he was marked for death and would ''take a few of them with me.''

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: JOBLESSNESS: A GROWING SCOURGE
description: MOSCOW Unemployment, Soviet officials never tire of boasting, does not exist under the dictatorship of the proletariat. But the chronic waste and inefficiency of Soviet workers sometimes drive planners to mumble that a limited dose of joblessness may not, after all, be amiss.

title: WILL I.A.T.A. FLY AGAIN?
description: After four years of heavily competitive fare wars and expansion into new markets, many of the world's airlines, some of which have been driven close to bankruptcy, are now seeking greater cooperation on fares and markets.

title: AGENCIES SCRAMBLE FOR CASINO MONEY
description: AT THE start of the 1981 fiscal year last J uly, the state's Casino Revenue Tax Fund showed an unexpended surplus of $51.4 million, whichby law could be spent only on property-tax an d utility-bill relief for New Jersey's elderly.

title:
Gardening;
THE VIRTUES AND HAZARDS OF STARTER KITS
description: PREPLANTED starter kits for vegetables and annual flowers have begun to make their appearance in the stores. Northrup King's Punch 'n Grow has added a feature this year. The plastic tray has a reservoir at one end. A wick connecting the reservoir to the planting compartment keeps the planting medium uniformly moist.

title: Nancy L. Nichols, Financial Analyst, Is Betrothed to Donald V. Dougherty
description: The engagement of Nancy Lynne Nichols to Donald V. Dougherty has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Foster Nichols of Brookville, L.I. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald N. Dougherty of Old Tappan, N.J.

title: CHINA AND POLAND SIGN TRADE ACCORD
description: Late last month, a Polish trade delegation concluded an agreement here with the Chinese providing for a 25 percent rise in trade between the countries in 1982.

title: The World in Summary; Looking for Mr. Deng
description: Publicizing the daily doings and personal health of their elderly leaders is not at all the Chinese way. But last week, after Deng Xiaoping, China's aging paramount leader, had been absent from view for more than a month - including the lunar new year observances - international speculation about his whereabouts provoked official clarification.

title: Long Islanders; BASKETBALL SCANDAL TURNS UP IN A NOVEL
description: BACK in the days when Leo Rutman was living with his parents in Oceanside and enrolled in the drama program at Hofstra with such future Hollywood luminaries as Francis Coppola and Joel Olianksy, he wrote his first play, called ''Memories of a Lost Morning.'' ''It was ab out a basketball player and his wife breaking up as a result of wha t they had found out about each other through his involvement i n being a big-time college basketball player,'' he said.''It was part of the revelations of the play that he had shaved points.''

title: ALL-DAY KINDERGARTEN GAINS
description: UNDAUNTED by impending cuts in Federal and state aid, officials in a number of Long Island dist ricts are pursuin g plans aimed at extending their educational programs by adopt ing all-day kindergartens.

title: STOCK TABLES
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. Tisch is on the right track. Now, if the name of the listed company could come first (i.e., company -close - net change for the day) I would completely applaud the revision. F.H. PENNINGTON JR. President, EDC Inc. Easton, Conn., Feb. 8, 1982

title: The Region in Summary; Cancer Risk At Rutgers
description: For years, Rutgers University faculty members complained that working at the Newark branch's Smith Hall seemed to make people sick and was, as one of them put it, ''like living in a cesspool.'' As the building was ordered closed last week, they learned it was, if anything, worse.

title:
Dining Out;
THERE'S EVEN A MENU FOR CHILDREN
description: THE VILLA in Bridgewater has been quietly successful for the last 19 years. This is due in part to the many businessmen from nearby companies who lunch and entertain at the restaurant.

title: STUDY FINDS VOTING RIGHTS BEING VIOLATED IN SOUTH
description: The American Civil Liberties Union accused states in the Deep South today of continuing to discriminate against black voters despite Federal enforcement efforts under the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Reader Comment; BELL LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor: The assertions of MCI chairman William McGowan concerning my statements and testimony about Southwestern Bell's 1981 Texas rate request simply miss the point.
To the Editor:

title: Columbia 79, Brown 56
description: Darren Burnett and Richie Gordon combined for 33 points last night as they led Columbia to a 79-56 Ivy League victory over Brown.

title: MILLIONS FOR WARSAW, NO CORN FOR POLES
description: The Reagan Administration is punishing the Polish people while supporting the martial-law Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski.

title: Bruin Scores 26 for Syracuse In 78-71 Triumph Over UConn
description: Syracuse employed its strengths - quickness and defense - and defeated Connecticut, 78-71, in a Big East Conference game today before a sellout crowd of 15,425 at the Civic Center.

title: Other Business
description: How to Read It

title: Mayor of Hiroshima Assails U.S. A-Tests
description: The Mayor of Hiroshima, the first city to be attacked with a nuclear weapon, denounced the United States today for conducting two rounds of nuclear tests.

title: Political Notes; CAREY DEBT FROM 1978 DWINDLING
description: As he prepares to leave office, Governor Carey has effectively eliminated what had been a 1978 campaign debt of nearly $1 million. The virtual elimination of the debt, which had been signaled in the Carey campaign's latest financial report to the State Board of Electaons, was confirmed by Robert J. Morgado, the Governor's secretary and chief fund-raiser. It permitted the Governor to announce early in the political year that he would not seek reelection, since it was generally agreed that to continue fund-raising he would have had to remain a potential candidate. Large contributors are not usually interested in lame-duck officeholders.

title: Harriet Tunick Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Edith Tunick of Fort Lee, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter, Harriet Diane Tunick, to Peter Jay Nathan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nathan of New City, N.Y. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Arthur P. Tunick. A January wedding is planned.

title: Intar Theater to Stage Arrabal Tragicomedy
description: ''The Extravangant Triumph of Jesus Christ, Karl Marx and William Shakespeare,'' a tragicomedy by Fernando Arrabal, will be presented in English at the Intar Theater, 420 West 42d Street, beginning April 5.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Herb Ellis, Charlie Byrd and Barney Kessel, guitarists all, have given several concerts in New York in recent years, together or in other formations that sometimes included still another guitarist, Joe Pass. Mr. Kessel and Mr. Ellis both came out of the tag end of the big band era. In the 40's, Mr. Ellis played with Glen Gray's Casa Loma Orchestra and Jimmy Dorsey's orchestra; Mr. Kessel was with Chico Marx (whose drummer was Mel Torme) and Bob Crosby.

title: SUGARING ON TAP AT NATURE CENTER
description: THE sugar maple is the official New York State tree. In celebration of maple sugar season, when warmer days alternating with freezing nights cause the sap to flow in the tree, the Greenburgh Nature Center is offering workshops and special events covering the social, historical and technical aspects of maple sugaring.

title: SHUBERT DISKS SHOW APT ARTISTRY
description: The Piano Sonata in A minor (D.537) springs from Schubert's 21st year, and with it begins a great decade of adventure. This astonishing outburst of fruitfulness would end with Schubert's death in 1828 at the age of 31, and one of his touching farewells to life was to be another piano sonata -the B flat Major.

title: A.H. Cabot Weds Stacey McGreer
description: Stacey Elizabeth McGreer and Andrew Hull Cabot were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Keene, N.H., by the Rev. Gregory Sammons. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Willis McGreer of Walpole, N.H. Her husband is the son of Caroline Foote Cabot of Manchester by-the-Sea, Mass., and the late Henry Bromfield Cabot.

title: THE E.E.C., PAST ITS PRIME AT 25?
description: Western Europe is preparing for the 25th anniversary of its free-trading Common Market in March against a background of mounting popular disillusion with the Community's achievements and real fears that Europe's commitment to economic integration may not survive the world recession.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: CONNECTICUT Public Television has cut out Saturday morning broadcasts, and is considering further cuts as the Reagan Administration reduces support for public broadcasting.

title: THOUSANDS MOURN A 'MARTYR' IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Bearing the coffin of a white trade union organizer who died in detention and the flag of the outlawed African National Congress, a cortege of more than 1,000 blacks and whites wound its way slowly for about four miles today through downtown Johannesburg and its white suburbs.

title: Other Business; HOW TO PLAY REAGANOMICS...
description: It was as inevitable as the run on jelly beans. Some people in Detroit opened a business called the Stockmann Manufacturing Company, and at the Toy Fair that opens in New York next week, they will introduce a new board game called ''Reaganomics.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
Italian Journalists Strike
description: A 24-hour strike by print journalists that prevented the appearance of daily newspapers ended this morning, and broadcast journalists then began their own 24-hour news blackout. All are demanding better pay and conditions in contract talks.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Dubinsky Duo Bows To New York Audiences
description: A ''debut'' suggests some downy-cheeked youngster, so the word has curious connotations when applied to the first New York recital Thursday night in the Abraham Goodman House of the Dubinsky Duo. This consists of Rostislav Dubinsky, violinist, and his wife, Luba Edlina, pianist.

title: RED WRITERS FOR THE SILVER SCREEN
description: THE HOLLYWOOD WRITERS' WAR By Nancy Lynn Schwartz. Completed by Sheila Schwartz. Illustrated. 334 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: SALT SUPPLIES LOW
description: THE snow, freezing rain, ice and biting cold accounting for hazardous dri ving conditions have dealt a blow to road supplies and snow removal budgets of many towns.

title: California Official Says 49%
description: Failed to Register for Draft

title: SCHOOL BIDDING CO-OP FORMED
description: IN a move they expect to decrease costs and greatly facilitate the purchasing process, three small school districts have joined to form the Island's first cooperative bidding system for general school supplies.

title: THE ATLANTIC: IN SEARCH OF A RARE ROLE
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman jumped up and down, whooping, when the December Atlantic Monthly's cover flashed on the television screen during the Nov. 10 ''CBS Evening News.'' The Atlantic's now-famous David Stockman story - in which President Reagan's budget director revealed his doubts about the Reagan budget -had broken. Zuckerman, a 44-year-old multimillionaire real-estate developer and the magazine's new owner, left the banquet he was attending and rushed to his Boston town house to do the yeoman chores that gladden driven men. He made sure that copies of The Atlantic would be at the White House by morning. When a newsman couldn't wait overnight, Zuckerman dictated the Stockman article over the phone.

title: Julie Fleitas Sets August Wedding
description: Julienne Hogan Fleitas, merchandise assistant in the Angela Cummings department of Tiffany & Company, plans to be married in August to John Paul Havens, an assistant vice president in the arbitrage department of Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York.

title: Around the Nation; Missing Priest Tells Of Collecting Thoughts
description: A missing priest, whose grieving parents were considering holding his funeral, called a close friend and said he disappeared five weeks ago to travel and ''collect his thoughts.''

title: Bettye Blatman, Banker, Is Bride
description: Bettye Ann Blatman and Thomas George Manuel were married yesterday at the Rosemary Hall Chapel in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith, a Congregational minister, performed the ecumenical ceremony.

title: Art; AMERICAN IMPRESSIONISM DAZZLES
description: BROOKVILLE IF, with very modest expense, you want to escape the boisterous winter bedeviling us for a splendorous splash of sunshine and warmth, try the exhibition of American Impressionism at Long Island University's C.W. Post Art Gallery. As soon as you walk into the gallery, you will perceive a rise in your spiritual, if not physical, temperature, with illuminous radiance of color and form surrounding you.

title: SO THE DAY FOR THE JOB INTERVIEW ARRIVED
description: GRADUATING from Hofstra University in December, I was thrust rather rudely upon the bitter world of unemployment. While everyone was experiencing the postholiday blues, I was immersed in the depression peculiar to the jobless as well.

title: TRAIL-SKIING GAINS NEW ENTHUSIASTS
description: CROSS RIVER THE first thing that Bill Munzer, a cross-country ski enthusiast, does when he awakens is look outside to see if any new snow has fallen.

title: COCKPIT FIGHT REPORTED ON JET THAT CRASHED IN TOKYO
description: Investigators into the crash of a Japan Air Lines DC-8 in which 24 people died on Tuesday say there was a struggle in the cockpit only moments before the jetliner fell into Tokyo Bay 300 yards short of the main runway at Haneda Airport. It was also reported that the captain had been grounded for a year because of a psyc hosomatic illness.

title: CLASSIFICATION IS MORE THAN A MATTER OF FISH OR FOWL
description: If it flies , has two legs, yellow feathers and sings, it's a canary. Right ? Well, yes, if you're satisfied with simple answers. But if the person asking the question happened to be a taxonomist, or a scientis t who specializes in the identification and classificatio n of organisms, things would quickly get more complicated. He would want to know, for example, precisely what kind of canary it was - a pure-bred Harz Mountain finch, or an American hybrid - wher e it fits on the evolutionary scale, or what species it's most clo sely related to.

title: Machu Picchu
description: To the Editor:

title: MOZART WAS A REALIST ABOUT THE GAME OF LOVE
description: The Metropolitan Opera, ever mindful of its seasonal responsibilities, has brought us a basically admirable new production of Mozart's ''Cosi fan tutte,'' which is subtitled ''The School for Lovers.'' The opera itself, its changing reputation since its 1790 premiere, and this production raise issues that seem nicely appropriate for Valentine's Day.

title: The Nation in Summary; Watt Against The House
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt said last week he would rather go to jail than yield to a House demand for information. That would probably be O.K. with some members of Congress, but they want the data anyway.

title: WHY I LOVE L.I.
description: MY friends all said I was crazy to move back to Long Island. Maybe, if they equate sentimentality with craziness, they were right. Ever since I left the Island 15 years ago to attend college away from home, I longed to return to the place where I was raised. Why? It is a question I ha ve asked myself, and ans wered from others, many times.

title: Spinks Keeps Title By Knockout in 6th
description: Michael Spinks, who appeared to spend the first five rounds deciding how to end the misery for Mustapha Wassaja, finally chose the left hook from ''my variety bag of punches'' and stopped the challenger in the sixth round of their World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title bout today at the Playboy Hotel Casino. Wassaja was ''completely out on his feet,'' according to Referee Tony Perez, who ended the fight at 1 minute 3 6 of the round. Spinks, who had been battering Wassaja, lashed out wi th a left hook to the head that drove him into the ropes. Wassaja w as dazed, his left hand down and his right gripping the top strand. I n rapid succession, Spinks drove four left hooks to the head, the last two after Perez had begun screaming, ''Stop it, stop it, plea se!''

title: Business Conditions; TAXES AND THE G.D.P.
description: Although the thrust of the Reagan Administration's economic program is to stem what it sees as uncontrolled Government spending, growth in total tax receipts as a percentage of gross domestic product has been far slower in the United States than in many other industrial countries.

title: BOY, 15, FACING LIFE IN ALABAMA PRISONS AS ADULT
description: A 15-year-old boy has been sentenced here to life in the Alabama penetentiary system, where he will become the youngest of the state's 6,200 adult prisoners.

title: MISS NEUHAUS TO BE MARRIED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rice Neuhaus of Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Elder Neuhaus, to Richard Weldon Weekley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Weldon Truitt Weekley. Both families are of Houston, where the ceremony will take place in March in Christ Church Episcopal Cathedral.

title: PAUL THEROUX'S YANKEE CRUSOE
description: THE MOSQUITO COAST By Paul Theroux With Woodcuts by David Frampton. 374 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95.

title: AID FOR AGED BLIND
description: ON a recent morning, Milton Feld, director of the Home for the Aged Blind in Yonkers, returned to his office after having driven several residents to Mercy College. It was not one of his usual tasks, but no one else was available that morning, and he felt that it was important for the residents to attend the classes, which they had been auditing regularly throughout the semester.

title: WHY PLAYERS WANT ALTERED SALARY PLAN
description: In a couple of days, sports fans will be reading about collective bargaining in the National Football League. Just when they have breathed a sigh of relief that baseball has returned to sanity, fans must now keep fingers crossed that the N.F.L. owners will not force a strike in the way baseball owners forced a shutdown in that industry. But before any of the noncombatants can understand the stakes or the battle, a few facts must be set forth.

title: Airport Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Crafts; KNITTER IS MAKING CRAFT INTO AN ART
description: YONKERS LINDA MENDELSON speaks of the scarves she creates on her knitting machine as ''little posters almost, especially if they say something,'' and most of them do. A new Valen tine series includes, in addition to the obligatory hearts, a des ign pleading ''Love Me Tender'' in flowing script in three color c ombinations - dark gray with pink lettering, beige with magenta and b lue with red. There is also a dramatic checked design in bolder hue s with the ends ornamented by Japanese characters that she found int eresting - the characters for the word sushi, one of herfavorite food s. If that seems farfetched, the fiber artist, as she calls herself , argues that Valentine's Day is an excuse for indulgingin ''anything you love.''

title: JOB OFFICES OFF HOOK
description: TRENTON JUST as hundreds of New Jersey Civil Service employees were packing their supplies and preparing to close or consolidate Employment Service offices around the state last week, the Department of Labor and Industry got a reprieve from President Reagan's budget cuts and halted the closings -at least temporarily.

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY 76ERS, 114-107
description: The failure to execute plays in the final minutes has been a major reason why the Knicks have lost 13 of their last 19 games. The pattern continued last night in a 114-107 loss to the Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden.

title: No Headline
description: Canadien Streak Hits 11

title: POSTWAR JUSTICE
description: THE PLEDGE BETRAYED America and Britain and the Denazification of Postwar Germany. By Tom Bower. Illustrated. 462 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: WHY OWNERS MUST MAINTAIN THEIR CONTROL
description: THE importance of the negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement can be measured in one word - control. The club owners have it and the Players Association wants it.

title: STORIES AND SOMETHING ELSE
description: LEVITATION Five Fictions. By Cynthia Ozick. 158 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.50.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: SCIENCE: GOOD, BAD AND BOGUS By Martin Gardner. Il lustrated. 408 pp. Buffalo: Prometheus Bo oks. $18.95.

title: Elisabeth L. Clark to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Merrell Mays Clark of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Lynne Clark, to Stephen Marshall Jenks, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Pearson Jenks of Toledo, Ohio.

title: FAMILY CLOSENESS SPURS GIFT TO NEEDIEST
description: ''The enclosed contribution represents parents, children and grandchildren in our family and is given in deep gratitude for our wonderful family and with the hope that the gift can help some other family share together a few of the joys we've been granted.''

title: SOME CASES OF SUSPICIOUS DEALINGS
description: It is a curious fact of bridge history that judges and juries have never had to consider a case of cheating, which, though not a criminal matter, can readily give rise to a civil action.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Let the Users Foot the Bill
