description: The best things in life are free for some people. But the Reagan Administration wants higher rates for the great outdoors - at least for those portions administered by the National Park Service.

title: RELEASE OF FEDERAL FUNDS LETS LIBRARIES CONTINUE PROGRAMS
description: Several special programs that were about to be curtailed severely or eliminated from New York City's public libraries have received new life with the Reagan Administration's release of $20 million it was withholding from libraries around the country.

title: Other Business; ...AND HOW IT MIGHT ALL END UP
description: WASHINGTON Most weekdays, Anne Witt, deputy administrator for sol id waste management in Washington, rides through the s treets of the District of Columbia on a tractor-trailer filled with 85-gallon polyethyline garbage containers, which she is delivering t o 58,000 households.

title: Shanghai School Bans Jeans
description: A Shanghai university has banned students from wearing jeans, miniskirts and low-cut shirts because such clothes are ''unorthodox,'' the China Daily newspaper said today. The ban, similar to directives issued at other Chinese campuses, also bars men with long hair and mustaches. Girls with long hair must wrap it or wear it in braids, the newspaper said.

title: U.S. TESTS 2 ATOM WEAPONS
description: Two nuclear weapons were detonated 30 minutes apart Friday beneath a vol-canic plateau at the Nevada test site, sending shock waves felt in Las Vegas 100 miles away. Each weapon had a yield of 20 to 150 kilotons, a maximum equivalent of 150,000 tons of TNT. The atomic bombs dropped on Japan in World War II had a yield of 20 kilotons.

title: GAS PIPELINE IS PRODUCING LOTS OF STEAM AMONG ALLIES
description: PARIS THERE were signs of a letup last week in the trans-Atlantic storm over Western Europe's plans to import large quantities of Soviet natural gas in the late 1980's. Deputy Secretary of Commerce Lionel H. Olmer assured Congress that the Reagan Administration was determined to block construction of the pipeline that would bring heretofore untapped Siberian gas 2,800 miles to the West. But Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. later sought to calm the air, assigning overriding priority to preserving Western unity in the face of the Soviet-supported crackdown in Poland.

title: WORLD ECONOMY: PULLING APART
description: IN 1982, the world economy, which has been growing increasingly interdependent for decades, is being subjected to the most powerful disintegrative pressures, both economic and political, of the postwar period. Foremost among these pressures are recession and rising unemployment. In the United States, Canada, Britain, West Germany and the other Western industrialized countries, the slump is expected to lift total unemployment to 28.5 million workers in the second half of this year. High youth unemployment is exacerbating radicalism in Western Europe.

title: Article 190520 -- No Title
description: A man accused of leaving three puppies to die at the city dump has paid a $200 fine instead of spending two nights at the freezing, snow-covered landfill.

title: BASKETBALL DREAM THAT MAY NOT COME TRUE
description: THREE weeks ago, on Friday, Jan. 22, Seton Hall University announced with regret that Howard McNeil, a senior, and two other basketball players, Daryl Devero and Clark Young, were being declared academically ineligible and would be forced to sit out the rest of the season. McNeil had known about this two days before, but he had kept the information from his wife, Liz.

title: OPEC'S LOSS OF MASTERY
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has always been an ungainly sort of club. Besides occasionally going to war against one another, members have engaged in the lesser indiscretions of privately cheating on official prices to raise sales while publicly accusing their fellows of exactly the same behavior. In a particularly memorable flourish, one member (Iraq) distinguished itself by kidnapping the oil minister of another member (Iran) in 1980.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Straub Takes Bowling With a Closing Strike
description: Bill Straub threw a game-ending strike in the 10th frame and defeated Mike Aulby of Indianapolis, 217-212, today to win the $115,000 Rolaids Open on the Professional Bowlers Association tour.

title: KNOW THY GOOSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Mailbox; Thanks, Reggie, For the Memories
description: To the Sports Editor: The Yankees' not signing Reggie Jackson was a big mistake.

title: Frances Boynton T o Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. David P. Boynton of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Flint Boynton, to Henry Adams Ashforth 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ashforth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Peru, Vt. The wedding is planned for August.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Wisconsin 'Navy'
description: When the steel bridge across the Mississippi River from Prairie du Chien, Wis., to Iowa began to crack, it was closed in January 1981, and Prairie du Chien took emergency steps to raise funds for repairs: the Chamber of Commerce established a ''navy'' and offered to commission anyone as a commander for $5.

title: Eastern L.I. Women And Networking
description: Having read Phyllis Bernstein's informative ''Networking: Goals and Doubts'' (Jan. 17), it occurs to me that your readers might wish to know that eastern as well as western Long Island women are engaged in networking.

title: FLORISTS ACCLAIM CUPID ON THE HECTIC 'BIG DAY'
description: In the flower district on West 28th Street early yesterday morning, florists' vans packed the narrow way for their Valentine Day deliveries, but some of the old-timers were grousing about the decline of love in an unsentimental age.

title: Westchester Guide; WASHINGTON RETURNS
description: George Wash ington not only slept in the county, but he established his headquart ers for the Battle of White Plains in Elijah Miller's farmhouse in 1776.

title: ASSAD SAID TO BE IN CONTROL DESPITE REBEL UPRISING
description: The bitter fighting between thousands of army troops and insurgents barricaded in the city of Hama does not appear to have posed an immediate threat to the regime of President Hafez al-Assad, Western diplomats here said today.

title: HISTORY IS CANVAS OF LARCHMONT ARTIST
description: PAINTINGS of George Washington hanging permanently in Larchmont's Murray Avenue School and for the rest of this month at the Bank of New York in Larchmont may strike the viewer as having been done with exceptional skill. Depicting Washington sitting heroically on horseback, accepting Cornwallis's surrender at Yorktown, and being sworn in as President of the United States, the paintings tell a story while demonstrating meticulous attention to detail. They are the work of the Larchmont artist Alton Tobey, whose two children, now grown, once attended the Murray Avenue School.

title: Inches and Inches Of Mail in a Box
description: In the Jan. 24 issue is an article by Allen J. McGill (''The Envelope That Didn't Say 'Occupant,' '' Opinion Page) who complains about the letter carrier's jamming mail into his letterbox. Writes Mr. McGill: ''There must be a law saying that you can't fit 500 cubic inches of tightly packed material into 400 square inches of space.''

title: Connecticut Housing; 'GOOD FORTUNE' HAS ITS COSTS
description: NEW HAVEN ROLAND GILLIAM, a communications specialist with the Meridan office of Southern New England Telephone, was not exactly in the market for a house.

title: NEW APPROACH FOR COLLEGES IN THE STATE
description: THERE is nothing singular about the problems facing Connecticut's higher education system in the 1980's. Like other state systems that expanded rapidly in the last two decades, Connecticut's public colleges and university must now contend with sharp cutbacks in Federal financing and the prospect of steep enrollment declines as the ''baby-bust'' generation of the 1970's reaches college age.

title: CHANGES NEEDED IN RULES ON NONEVICTION CO-OP CONVERSIONS
description: Faced with increasing tenant sophistication, a soft market, tight money and high interest rates, sponsors of cooperative conversion plans have adopted a new tactic: the noneviction proposal.

title: Cardinal Said to Share Florida Bank Account
description: John Cardinal Cody, who is expected to retire Dec. 24, his 75th birthday, shared a Florida savings account in 1972 with his step-cousin, Helen Dolan Wilson, The Chicago Sun-Times reported in Sunday editions. Peter Foote, a spokesman for the cardinal, refused to comment on the article.

title: MET OPERA: ZEFFIRELLI'S NEW 'LA BOHEME'
description: There is a moment in Franco Zeffirelli's new production of ''La Boheme'' at the Metropolitan Opera when his intentions become clear. As Musetta props herself up in an overcrowded cafe to sing ''Quando me'n vo soletta,'' the hordes of Parisians stomping around the stage suddenly freeze in midgesture, as if entranced by the glories of song.

title: A SENSE OF PLACE AND GLORY
description: HERBERT MITGANG, a cultural correspondent for The Times and a Lincoln biographer, is author of the play, ''Mister Lincoln,'' published this week by Southern Illinois University Press. By HERBERT MITGANG

title: P.S. 199 STRESSES ARTS IN EFFORT TO BROADEN MAKEUP
description: Gayon Clark, a fifth-grader at Public School 199 on West 70th Street, was ''too shy,'' she said, to sing in front of others. But with some gentle prodding by Nancy Guarino, an actor with the Sidewalks Theater, a classical company, Gayon and several of her classmates stood in front of their class recently and sang a song per fectly in tune.

title: TEEN-AGERS' ABORTIONS INCREASING ON L.I.
description: A TEST confirmed that she was pregnant. Troubled and guilty about the predicament she faced, resulting from a relationship with her first and only boyfriend, she asked a rabbi if, by having an abortion, she would be committing a sin.

title: No Headline
description: Arguello Stops Busceme, Retains Crown

title: Colombia Holds 3 in Shooting Of 2 American Drug Agents
description: The police said they had arrested two Cubans and a Briton today in connection with the kidnapping and shooting here last Tuesday of two American drug enforcement officers.

title: Villanova Defeats St. John's
description: Rollie Massimino, the Villanova basketball coach, started the day as another victim of crime when he found that his automobile had been stolen during the night from outside the Nassau County motel where the team stayed.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: 'The Wall' Lives For life-and-death drama, few chapters of World War II surpassed the fierce ghetto struggle of Polish Jews against the Nazis, as depicted in John Hersey's 1943 best-seller ''The Wall.'' Ten years later, the powerful novel was adapted for Broadway by Millard Lampell and ran for six months. And now Mr. Lampell has reconstructed ''The Wall'' as a three-hour made-for-television film, scheduled for showing on CBS starting at 8 P.M. on Tuesday.

title: BRUNSWICK, AND WHITTAKER'S HEALTH
description: LOS ANGELES I T was a major renovation, involving the dismantling of one of the most misshapen temples of the wheeling-and-dealing conglomerate era. Joseph F. Alibrandi sold 96 of 150 businesses during his first five years as head of the Whittaker Corporation.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: AN ARMFUL OF WARM GIRL, by W.M. Spackman. (Van Vactor & Goodheart, 24 Lee St., Cambridge, Mass., $5.95.) It's back in 1959, and Nicholas Romney, Princeton grad and Philadelphia banker, is in New York working off the frustrations of a newly collapsed marriage, pursuing an old flame and in turn being pursued by a young actress who may or may not be his own daughter. When this novel was published in 1977, John Leonard praised it for having all the ingredients of a now departed civilization: romance, wit, intelligence, geniality, sex without tears and a genuinely lovable leading character.

title: NONPROFIT THEATERS IN A BIND
description: Nonprofit theaters increased their income by more than 22 percent last year, while their expenses rose by almost 23 percent, according to a survey of 121 nonprofit professional theaters. The study also found that the share of expenses that the theaters devote to artististic salaries has steadily declined.

title: SONG: DIAMANDA GALAS
description: Diamanda Galas offered Friday night's audience at The Kitchen a comprehensive vocabulary of human anguish. Miss Galas is primarily a singer, and the second half of her concert relied heavily on the power of her soprano voice.

title: YOUTHS' HOPES OF JOBS ON ASSEMBLY LINES FADING
description: Willie James Parks started counting on a life on the assembly line, maybe even working next to his father, when he was 16 years old.

title: Theater; 9-PLAY GREEK CYCLE IN A DAY OR 3 NIGHTS
description: THIS Tuesday, previews of ''The Greeks'' begin at the Hartford Stage Company. This is an umbrella title for nine plays that can be seen over three separate evenings or in one full day -next Sunday or on Sunday, Ap ril 4, beginning at noon and ending after 11 P.M. If onechooses, just one section can be seen, because each is complete in itself.

title: Politics; ONLY 'REFORM' VOTE BY A COUNTY LEADER
description: THE new Nassau Democratic county leader, Martin Mellman, was the only county leader to join with the Reform Caucus of the Democratic State Committee to vote for a recent resolution asking the Democratic National Committee to change its plan to have a bloc of 500 uncommitted public and party officials at the next Democratic National Convention.

title: Dominican Republic Hotel Availability
description: Based on information supplied by the Dominican Tourist Information Center, the ''Caribbean Update'' listing on Jan. 24 reported that the Hotel Santo Domingo and the Casa de Campo resort complex were fully booked for February.

title: ABRIDGED ROOSEVELT
description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIMANTIC SENDS A VALENTINE TO ITSELF IN 10-DAY FESTIVAL
description: LOVE'S labor is not lost on Willimantic. Self-proclaimed ''Romantic Willimantic'' today concludes a 10-day ''Valentine's Week'' bounty of poetry, concerts, contests, singing telegrams, flags, posters and free premarital blood tests.

title: DID FLORIO LOSE 'ITALIAN' VOTES? AND IF SO, WHY?
description: IHAVE only recently recovered from - to me, at least - the unexpected defeat of Representative James J. Florio in his bid for the governorship. As the shock wanes, I have set for myself the task of explaining the cause(s) for his defeat.

title: Around the World; Lisbon Says It Foiled Plot In General Strike Friday
description: The Portuguese Government said today that the police had foiled a plot in connection with a Communistorganized general strike that was staged on Friday.

title: No Headline
description: Rockets Beat Bullets for Eighth Straight

title: FISCAL PLANS BEAR THE TELLTALE SIGNS OF COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS
description: WASHINGTON ''C OST-BENEFIT analysis,'' the tool being used by the Reagan Administration to weigh the effectiveness of a multitude of Federal programs and regulations is coming under scru tiny itself. Skeptics are questioning its utility, its reliability and the intellectual integrity of those who promote it without regard to its limitations.

title: COSTA-GAVRAS'S STRIKING CINEMATIC ACHIEVMENT
description: In Jerry Bruck's fine documentary, ''I.F. Stone's Weekly'' (1973), Mr. Stone, the gadfly of American journalism, is seen addressing a graduating class at Amherst College. He recalls his early days as a cub reporter and the excitement he felt at his first big fire. ''Wow!'' he remembers saying to himself. ''Here I am! I'm a reporter! I'm covering this fire!'' or words to that effect. Sometimes, Mr. Stone goes on, the reporter is so carried away by the spectacle that he forgets there may be people being burned.

title: G.R. Broom Weds Patricia Herndon
description: Patricia Louise Herndon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Herndon of Valparaiso, Ind., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Raymond Broom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Broom of Guilderland, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Portasik performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Tarrytown, N.Y..

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Edelton Gloeden Offers Guitar Recital
description: With many recitalists gravitating toward programs whose main purpose seems to be to excite the listener, it is refreshing to find one like the Brazilian guitarist Edelton Gloeden, who, for his North American debut on Thursday at the 92d Street Y, fashioned an appealing program out of selections more notable for their musical interest than their flashiness, and played as if the audience weren't even there. Mr. Gloeden's approach was marked by a mixture of modesty and sensitivity that delighted more often than it dazzled, and seemed particularly well suited to the program's all-English first half, devoted to short works by Peter Philips and John Dowland and to Benjamin Britten's absorbing Nocturnal after John Dowland (Op. 70). Although a memory lapse in the galliard to Philips's Chromatic Pavane and a few poorly executed passages in the Britten marred the guitarist's performance, his accounts were colorful and evocative.

title: Wilson Aide Pleads Guilty
description: A former employee of Edwin P. Wilson, the former Central Intelligence Agency operative who is now a fugitive, has pleaded guilty to two counts of training terrorists for the Libyan Government. Douglas M. Schlachter Sr. made the plea under an agreement in which other counts were dropped in return for his cooperation. His attorney said Mr. Schlachter thought he was working for an operation sanctioned by Washington.

title: DENNY REJECTS YANKS' OFFER AND WILL STAY WITH INDIANS
description: George Steinbrenner, whose checkbook and salesmanship have attracted so many f ree agents to the Yankees, has frightened one away. John Denny, a pitcher who was the object of a last-minute signing effort by the Yankees, decided today to return to the Cleveland Indians.

title: Black Hawks 6 Maple Leafs 4
description: TORONTO (UPI) - Ted Bulley scored three goals, including the decisive one at 3:06 of the final period. Tom Lysiak gave Chicago a 1-0 lead on a first-period breakaway at 3:23, but Toronto scored four times in a span of 3:17 to take a 4-1 lead.

title: The Trouble With Terrorism By Russell Baker
description: It's always seemed odd to me that after a group of terrorists commits a vile and odious deed they rush messages to the public to claim credit for it. Sometimes, competitive terrorists who had nothing to do with the hellishness call up editors or broadcasters and mendaciously claim credit for it anyhow.

title: Mimi Tracy Betrothed To Sean W. O'Donnell
description: Virginia I. Tracy of Short Hills, N.J., and William I. Tracy Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mimi Tracy, to Sean William O'Donnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John O'Donnell of Union, N.J.

title: KEAN TURNS UP RHETORIC A BIT
description: TRENTON PRESIDENT REAGAN'S economic policies are becoming too big a pill for Thomas H. Kean's fledgling administration to swallow, and the state's new Republican Governor sent word to Washington last week that he was starting to choke.

title: MEXICO, AFTER THE FIESTA
description: The four-year-long fiesta of unbridled public spending, imports and foreign borrowing that followed confirmation of Mexico's new-found oil wealth has now given way to a morning-after feeling of regrets at the prodigality.

title: WILL FOOD OUTPUT BE SUFFICIENT?
description: ONE of the most respected authorities on world food problems is Howard J. Hjort, who retired at year-end as chief economist for the Department of Agriculture. In a recent interview with Ann Crittenden of The New York Times, Mr. Hjort, who is now an economic consultant in Washington, shared some of his views on th e global food outlook for the 1980's.

title: Key West Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTS EDUCATION FLOWERS IN NEW YORK
description: Milos Forman, when he teaches in Columbia University's film program, likes to ask students challengingly: ''What are you doing?.'' Without fanfare, Robert Redford has dropped in on the film program, and talked about his work. The program's other supporting players include the directors Jose Quintero and Robert M. Young.

title: The Right Tone on Human Rights
description: In its first country-by-country report on human rights, the Reagan Administration provides what both law and conscience require - a fair accounting of abuses, by friend or foe. Exactly what the United States can or should do about repression elsewhere will plainly remain a matter of argument. But the evidence needed for that debate is here laid out, in grim detail and length (1,142 pages). And that is a salutary landmark for an Administration that came to office not really believing a human rights policy was needed.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Some Colleges Retreat on Aid
description: ''From each according to his abilities, to each according to his needs'' - the admissions policy followed by many of the nation's private colleges throughout the 1970's - may, as a result of President Reagan's proposed cuts in Federal student aid, change to a less egalitarian approach. Last weeken d, Wesleyan University in Connecticut voted to end its ''aid-blind'' admissions policy, which guaranteed that all students who were acce pted received sufficient aid to attend.

title: NEW ROCHELLE IS CHEERED BY TWO STORE CONVERSIONS
description: ''FOUR years ago, you could shoot a cannon down Main Street at noon and not hit anybody for miles,'' said John Heller, New Rochelle's Director of Planning. But, he added, new office buildings, new restaurants and new tenants in formerly empty stores have brought this city ''the kind of trouble we like - traffic problems for the first time in years.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: MUSIC New York is a crossroads for international mu sical glamour, as a glance of this week's schedule attests. But t his city's musical life is also defined by its humbler events.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN AGONIES: THE MEXICAN VIEW
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING STOCK OF SERGEI TANEYEV
description: Sergei Taneyev might easily be described as the missing link in 19th-century Russian music, though in many ways he was the least ''Russian'' composer of his generation. He was a superb craftsman, one of the best-trained and most literate musicians Russia produced during the century of her artistic flowering - but, as may readily be inferred from hearing the music he wrote, his thinking and esthetic outlook were fundamentally European. A recent Pro Arte release of three disks devoted to Taneyev's music doubles the size of his listing in the Schwann catalogue, and provides a welcome opportunity to take stock of a composer whose role in Russian musical life was significant, but little of whose music is known in the West.

title: JOBLESSNESS: A GROWING SCOURGE
description: BONN On a tranquil Sunday last fall, sermons in Frankfurt's churches, both Roman Catholic and Protestant, took an unaccustomed twist. In place of the usual ecclesiastical exhortations, the faithful heard bitter words about the evils of unemployment.

title: GOLD'S GREAT FIZZLE
description: JOHANNESBURG EARLY in 1981, when the price of gold started to sag from the dizzy heights it had reached the previous year, a respected investment house here had some consoling thoughts for its clients. Developments in Poland, it pointed out, might bring about a deterioration of relations between the United States and the Soviet bloc, and then ''gold could rapidly regain its attractions as a hedge.''

title: KODAK'S RADICAL NEW PICTURE-TAKING SYSTEM; Jack Manning
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a photographer on the staff of this newspaper, and the author of several books on photography.

title: WHAT TO LOOK FOR WHEN BUYING A USED CAMERA
description: As new models of single-lens reflex (SLR) camera brands proliferate, older models become available in the used market - often in excellent condition. For instance, my neighbor has a popular brand six-year-old SLR and just bought a new camera because it is lighter in weight. His old model did suffer from some shutter problems, but they've been repaired properly, so whoever gets his older model will get a good camera at a considerable savings.

title: Art; RUTGERS PAYING TRIBUTE TO THE ART OF REALISM
description: NEW BRUNSWICK HOW many deaths has realism died? How many epitaphs have been written in this century alone, proclaiming that realism had ceased to exist because it was at an irrecoverable impasse, because it offered no more visions or aspirations to artists, because it had been completely exploited as an artistic style?

title: JOBLESSNESS: A GROWING SCOURGE
description: NEW DELHI Unemployment in India is like everything in this country: huge, complicated and open to interpretation. It is increasingly becoming a political problem, not because it is on the rise, which it is, but because of a recent sudden and sharp growth in urbanization.

title: By Sports of The Times; Rolf Benirschke's Second Choice
description: IN the playoffs for the Super Bowl six weeks ago, his 29-yard field goal lifted the San Diego Chargers to a 41-38 overtime victory over the Miami Dolphins in one of the most exciting games in pro football history. And now, in his hospital bed, Rolf B enirschke smiled as he related that moment to himself.

title: THE JONES-PLUMMER 'OTHELLO' IS TWICE-BLESSED; Walter Kerr
description: Anumber of sensitive and sometimes bold improvements have been made in the James Earl Jones-Christopher Plummer ''Othello'' since it first stirred excitement in Connecticut last summer, and I think none is prov ing mo re helpful at the Winter Garden than an unexpected and sorrowing cal m that descends - if only briefly - upon the Moor and the bride he is preparing to kill.

title: The Region in Summary; N.J. Toughens Law on Juveniles
description: Proposals to toughen New Jersey's juvenile justice system, vetoed in one of Brendan Byrne's last acts as Governor, may be among the first signed by his successor, Thomas H. Kean.

title: 'MISS RHAPSODY' STILL A DRAW AT 79
description: TO THE scores of adoring fans who turn out to hear her sing the blues and swing tunes of a bygone era, she is ''Miss Rhapsody''- and that is the way she is billed in her current appearance at one of the ''in'' spots on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: Reagan Sets Day of Prayer
description: President Reagan has proclaimed May 6 as a National Day of Prayer, continuing a ''remarkable'' tradition that originated more than 200 years ago. The first National Day of Prayer was proclaimed in 1775, and the observance became official 30 years ago through an act of Congress.

title: A VISITOR'S GUIDE TO SRI LANKA
description: S ri Lanka - formerly Ceylon - is a pear-shaped island in the Indian Ocean, separated from the southeast coast of India by the Palk Strait and the Gulf of Mannar. It is just above the Equator and is 270 miles long, 140 miles across at its widest point, and covers an area of 25,000 square miles. Sri Lanka has a hot, tropical climate with two monsoon periods - from December to the end of January in the north, and from May through July on the southwest and central hills.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Whistle-Blowing
description: New York City school regulations prohibit all forms of corporal punishment, but officials at Junior High School 22 in the Bronx were using a two-foot-long paddle, called ''the smoker,'' to enforce discipline. Irving Sandrof, a guidance counselor at the school, blew the whistle.

title: SOUTHEAST ASIAN REFUGEES IN BROOKLYN RENEWING STRUGGLE FOR A BETTER
description: LIFE By LAURIE JOHNSTON

title: MELISSA MATHER, BANKER, IS ENGAGED
description: Melissa R. Mather, an assistant treasurer at the Bank of New York, and John W. Kunstadter Jr., an assistant manager with Citibank's international services division, plan to be married in April.

title: Question on Planning The Yorktown Mall
description: If Coventry, England, can be compared to Yorktown, call me ''Lady Godiva.'' That tactic of tax protest would have made The Times long before now, but the opponents of the Jefferson Valley Mall chose instead a 12-year arduous battle of picketing, petitions, public hearings, debates, elections, letters, satire and the courts. This was certainly more democratic, if not that dramatic.

title: Personal Finance; SELLING A DIAMOND COULD TAKE FOREVER
description: D IAMONDS are still a girl's best friend - as long as she doesn't try to sell them. In fact, negotiating the sale for her few grams of compressed carbon can be no easier - or more profitable - than trying to peddle Polish zloty futures.

title: Politics; RACE FOR GOVERNORSHIP IS TOPIC
description: ''THE Big Apple is peeling,'' said Samuel J. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, when he came to the county just over a week ago. ''The Democratic Apple is rotten in Albany,'' he declared, to Republican cheers. ''What New York needs is a New Apple.''

title: THE PRESIDENT'S WAR ON 'MORE OF THE SAME'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation in Summary; Wel l, It's One Way to Keep the Russians Guessing
description: Since last fall, when the White House announced its nuclear arms catch-up program, the proposed MX missile has been a weapon without a pad to call its own.

title:
Economic Affairs;
YOU, TOO, WILL PAY FOR ASBESTOS
description: T HERE are enough economic problems to be solved in 1982 to keep us all busy. Even so, you should begin working on one that's just beginning to emerge above the horizon. Little is known about this problem except that there are going to be thousands of occupational disease victims each year, that they have to be provided substantial compensation, and that such compensation will be so large as to impair operation of an important sector of the economy.

title: Major News in Summary; Six Soldiers, Four Murders
description: The State Department's annual human rights report last week conceded that critics of El Salvador's junta have a point. The country's system of justice, it said, ''does not function effectively when politically motivated crimes are brought before it.''

title: Babi Yar's Legacy
description: I am a poet, a Ukrainian by nationality (''Babi Yar's Legacy,'' by Lucy S. Dawidowicz, Sept. 27). I was born and grew up in Kiev. I studied and wrote all my books there. Not long ago, I completed a film about the lessons of Babi Yar, at the Kiev Film Studio. When I was looking through wartime and late prewar documentaries, I was struck by one of them.

title: 900 YEARS OF ENGLISH ARCHITECTURE
description: R.W. APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The New York Times. By R.W.APPLE Jr.

title: THE JESUITS
description: At the Villa Cavalletti in Frascati, workmen are busily adapting the 18th-century pseudo-Renaissance mansion and adjoining buildings that normally serve as a spiritual retreat center into the setting for an extraordinary assembly of provincial superiors of the Society of Jesus. The regional heads have been summoned to the villa outside Rome not, as would have been customary, by their Superior General but by order of Pope John Paul II. As the heads of the Jesuit infrastructure from all over the world prepare for the meeting, which begins on Feb. 23 and will last at least a week, thousands of others within the order anxiously speculate about what lies ahead for the largest, most prestigious and often most controversial organization of priests and brothers in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: BIRTH CENTERS: PROS AND CONS
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK THE midwife gently guided Bruce Miller's fingers over the protruding belly of his wife, Margaret, at her recent seventh-month prenatal checkup. ''Here's your baby's foot and here's a shoulder,'' said Robin Glaser, director of Midwifery Services at Familyborn, an out-of-hospital birth center on Route 27 here.

title: No Headline
description: North, Levi Share 2-Shot Lead
To the Editor:

title: A Decided Taste For Cantonese Food
description: Florence Fabricant's review on Jan. 24 of the Kwong Ming resturant added a new dimension to her profession - a reviewer who is not ashamed to tell her public that she is right and they are wrong about what they like.

title: PARLEY TO EXPLORE A MUSIC TRADITION
description: day session at Essex County College is one of many events being held in observance of Black History Month.

title: No Headline
description: POLISH EX-ENVOY, CALLED C.I.A. SPY, GETS 25 YEARS

title: JAPAN'S ROBOT REVOLUTION
description: Henry Scott Stokes's article, which mentioned robots in car factories in Japan, made me envious. I do believe the old American rumor that American cars coming off our assembly lines on Mondays and Fridays may be faulty because of slipshod worker habits: Monday workers are suffering from weekend hangovers and too much play, and Friday workers are anxious to get away for the weekend.

title: SALVAGE AND SAVOIR-FAIRE
description: arl Mann knows all about the Plan-and-Scheme world of contemporary interior design. He is a major supplier of fabrics, floor and wall coverings and graphics to the interior-design trade, a collector of primitive and ethnic art - Kilim rugs, New Guinea aboriginal art and Rajasthani Temple hangings - and a well-known collagist.

title: By Theodore W. Libbey; Music: Debuts in Review; Mija Kang, Soprano, O ffers the Standards
description: The Korean-born soprano Mija Kang offered a fairly standard sampling of the repertory on her Tuesday night program in Carnegie Recital Hall, but her interpretations showed thoughtfulness and, occasionally, an individuality that lifted them above the routine. Though she did not always go far enough with her ideas, her accounts of songs by Purcell, Brahms and Strauss on the program's first half managed to convey the feeling behind the settings and were especially effective when imagery, rather than intensity of emotion, was the primary concern, as in Purcell's ''Sweeter Than Roses.''

title: No Headline
description: Fordham Triumphs In Overtime, 58-56

title: RECITAL: MISS OPPENS, PIANIST
description: Ursula Oppens has built a reputation as a performer of contemporary music, but her piano recital at the Metropolitan Museum Thursday night offered only one 20th-century piece -Elliott Carter's ''Night Fantasies.''

title: Elephantine Island How to get there
description: Egyptair, the national airline, flies three times daily to Aswan from Cairo. The round-trip fare is $97.40. On arriving at the Aswan Airport, you take a taxi and ask for the Aswan Oberoi ferry, which is in the center of Aswan.

title: About Long Island
description: TODAY is Valentine's Day, and I know that the occasion calls for intimate dining with my loved one at some cozy North Shore gourmet hideaway or at one of the more ebulliently romantic establishments to the south. I mentioned this to my loved one the other day, but she, having been sharing bed and board with me for several decades, was not swept off her feet by this invitation to a one-night affair away from home.

title: HELEN DUKAS, 85, EINSTEIN'S SECRETARY, IS DEAD
description: Helen Dukas, personal secretary to Alb ert Einstein for 28 years and archivist and co-trustee of his papers after his death in 1955, died Wednesda y at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. She was 85 years old and lived in Einstein's house in Princeton with his 82-year-old s tepdaughter, Margot Einstein.

title: PENTAGON WILL SPEND WELL, BUT PERHAPS NOT WISELY
description: WITH projections putting costs at $1,640 billion over the next five years, President Reagan's defense budget for fiscal year 1983 is the most comprehensive program for national rearmanent the United States has known since World War II. But the very size of the budget raises questions about the philosophy and wisdom behind proposed military spending.

title:
Gardening;
THE VIRTUES AND HAZARDS OF STARTER KITS
description: PREPLANTED starter kits for vegetables and annual flowers have begun to make their appearance in the stores. Northrup King's Punch 'n Grow has a dded a feature this year. The plastic tray has a reservoir at one end. A wick connecting the reservoir to the plantingcompartment k eeps the planting medium uniformly moist.

title: Mailbox; A Bizarre Twist Of Tennis Justice
description: To the Sports Editor: Justice can be bizarre. In the Wimbledon tennis tournament last summer, John McEnroe was fined $5,000 for unsportsmanlike conduct.

title: Westchester Journal
description: ALTAIR AIRLINES, one of the handful of little commuter airlines that has been serving the Westchester County Airport over the years under the shadow of bigger names, has decided to move up in the world. It plans to soon start operating jet aircraft under a new grant of authority from the county.

title: UCONN BROADCASTER CALLS THEM FOR FUN
description: STORRS TIME has not diminished the voice. It is still deep, confident, sharp, punctuated with enthusiasm. The words come at a fast clip and with a Brooklyn twang.

title: CANADIAN ENERGY IN FLUX
description: CALGARY, ALBERTA ''SPRING time,'' said the bank vice president as he peered out his skyscraper window at the blowing snow obscuring the construction cranes, ''that's when the rubber will meet the road out here.'' ''Spring breakup,'' he said, anticipating that time between late March and May when winter releases its bitter grip on the United States' northern neighbor and chief trading partner, has always been a special, almost spiritual, time in Canada. It brings the sudden start of a cramped growing season and an almost hectic appreciation of the country's few warmer days.

title: The Region in Summary; Turning Money Into Electricity
description: Nuclear power plants, notoriously hard to build, can also be hard not to build. The State Public Service Commission last week allowed construction to continue on the Nine Mile Point 2 reactor near Oswego, N.Y., despite critics' contentions that good money would be thrown after bad.

title: COMMERCIAL'S ON PUBLIC TV? DON'T DESPAIR QUITE YET; John Jay Iselin
description: There she was, Celeste Holm holding up a bottle of Elixircol and delivering a pitch for the all-purpose potion. And there were viewers blinking in disbelief, for the commercial message was pointedly interrupting a John Cheever drama on public television. In this instance, it did not take long to get the correct message. Mr. Cheever had purposefully written a parody of commercials into the script of his ''American Playhouse'' drama, ''The Shady Hill Kidnapping.''

title: Around the World; 16 Crewmen on a Tanker In the Atlantic Are Saved
description: A Dutch helicopter pulled 16 crewmen to safety today from a broken tanker adrift in the North Atlantic, the British coast guard said.

title: A SOAPY FARRAGO
description: DEAR FRIENDS By Tom McHale. 378 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $16.95.

title: DESPITE DIVISIONS AND CRISES, ITALY AVOIDS DISASTER
description: After a century of national unity, Italy is still two countries. The north, with its industries and technology, is part of Europe - ''the southern tip of the Ruhr,'' a Milanese industrialist said only half facetiously. The largely rural south is part of the underdeveloped Mediterranean third world. Naples and Palermo evoke Alexandria, not Hamburg or Le Havre.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART With every year that passes we miss Robert Smithson more. When Smithson was killed in an accident in 1973 he was only 35 years old, but he was already famous as the man who - with Walter de Maria - had taken art out of the studio and put it into the wilderness.

title: MARCH DOOMSDAY? DON'T PLAN ON IT
description: Will the world come to an end on March 10, or at least suffer terrible earthquakes, because all the planets are lined up in a devastating configuration? So many people have asked the Kitt Peak National Observatory in Arizona this question that the observatory has issued a seven-page analysis to deny that the Earth will face some special danger on that date.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THE statewide problem of overcrowding in state prisons and county and city jails was brought closer to a head last week when Newark filed suit charging that Essex County corrections officials had been derelict in their duties by not admitting about 100 prisoners to county facilities.

title: NEW OUTLOOK TRIED IN NEWARK SCHOOLS
description: NEWARK THOUSANDS of schoolchildren here are sporting large yellow buttons these days that proclaim: ''Newark Students Will Succeed.'' The buttons are the brainchild of Dr. Columbus Salley, the new executive superintendent of the 64,000-student school system, which he said was viewed by many as one of ''failure and mediocrity.''

title: Correction
description: References in last week's Personal Finance column to the rates applicable on overdraft balances in Manufacturers Hanover Trust Preferred Personal Credit accounts were unclear.

title: INVESTIGATORS WIDEN INQUIRY AT CLOSED RUTGERS LAB
description: Federal investigators yesterday began to widen their search for potentially dangerous substances in a Newark building closed Thursday by Rutgers University.

title: HELP IN STOCKING A FISHING LIBRARY
description: THIS column has sometimes mentioned that in this country in recent decades the torrent of titles devoted to fly fishing for trout comes close to being equaled only by books dealing with the wooing of smallmouth and largemouth bass.

title:
Antiques;
BASIC FURNITURE FEATURE OF SHOW
description: GUILFORD GOOD collections of attractive, basic New England furniture and accessories will dominate the Guilford Antiques Show next Friday and Saturday.

title: AMERICA'S NATIVE MUSIC POURS FORTH IN REISSUES
description: America has its blues lovers, its country music fans, its jazz aficionados, its rock-and-rollers, its specialists in rhythm-andblues and gospel music and soul. Anyone who investigates any of these musics very deeply soon realizes how imprecise and artificial the categories are. Blues performers are influenced by country music and jazz, much soul is thinly secularized black gospel music, early rock and roll was an amalgam of rhythm-and-blues and country music, and so on.

title: U.S. TELLS OFFICER WHO CARRIED RIFLE TO LEAVE SALVADOR
description: A senior United States military adviser has been ordered to leave El Salvador as a result of having violated American regulations restricting the weapons that advisers are permitted to carry with them on training missions.

title: The Fed
description: To the Business Editor: ''The Unsteady Hand at the Fed'' (Feb. 7) by Gordon Williams forces me to conclude that the majority of the members of the Federal Reserve Board are a bunch of ''dunderheads'' or they have a vested interest in keeping the economy on an uneven keel for some unfathomable reason.

title: Iris M. Reiter Married To Frederick S. Green
description: Iris Miriam Reiter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Reiter of Coral Gables, Fla., was married yesterday to Frederick Stuart Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Green of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Michael A. Eisenstadt performed the ceremony at Temple Judea in Coral Gables.

title: KOCH WEIGHS PLEASURES AND PAIN OF LIFE IN ALBANY
description: During his first two terms in office, Mayor Koch made coyness a successful po litical craft. But in appearing to orchestrate anxiety over whether he will run for Governor, he may have elevated it to an art.

title: Allison Sees Daytona As a Four-Man Event
description: Bobby Allison is starting the Daytona 500 today back in seventh place. Benny Parsons, who is driving Allison's old car, will take the green flag from the pole position, but Allison does not rate Parsons as one of his chief competitors.

title:
Gardening;
THE VIRTUES AND HAZARDS OF STARTER KITS
description: PREPLANTED starter kits for vegetables and annual flowers have begun to make their appearance in the stores. Northrup King's Punch 'n Grow has added a feature this year. The plastic tray has a reservoir at one end. A wick connecting the reservoir to the planting compartment keeps the planting medium uniformly moist.

title: Scholarly Achievement
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Choice
description: in-law's funeral in Rumania realizing on the spot the harshness of that country and in flashback the violent decay of human decency in his own country.

title: Soccer Fever Is Due In Spain
description: Finding a hotel room in many parts of Spain this June and July will be as easy as discovering a cache of Spanish gold. More than a million more foreign visitors than usual will be pouring into Madrid, Barcelona and 12 other cities for an event that, though it is a mystery to many Americans, is the summit of the world's most popular sport - soccer.

title: Reader Comment; BELL LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor: William C. McGowan's ''Comment: Ma Bell's Myths'' (Jan. 24) includes statements that as a career Bell System employee who has worked with the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Western Electric, New York Telephone and A.T.& T. I would rebut.

title: Local hotels and inns
description: The area around Bradford (though not the town itself) is well endowed with hotels and inns. A few miles away on the A36, in the village of Hinton Charterhouse, stands the Homewood Park Hotel, a refurbished 18th-century mansion with an excellent dining room; a double room costs about $70, dinner for two, about $50.

title: NEW ROLE FOR JUNIOR LEAGUE
description: CONCERNED about the effect of Federal cutbacks on local programs, the Junior League of Northern Westchester has decided to break with tradition and supply money and volunteers to two local social-service agencies.

title: DR. C.T. HELMES TO WED EMILY BULIAN
description: Mrs. Max J. Bulian of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Boca Raton, Fla., has announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Sue Bulian, to Dr. C. Tucker Helmes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Helmes of South Salem, N.Y.

title: TROTTIER SCORES 5 IN ROUT OF FLYERS
description: Bryan Trottier scored five goals, and Mike Bossy assisted him five times to lead the Islanders to an 8-2 rout of the Philadelphia Flyers at Nassau Coliseum today.

title: Article 190342 -- No Title
description: A Fort Lauderdale attorney showed up at Hialeah Park today with a Pic Six ticket worth $382,244 from the racing program on Jan. 25. It was believed to be the largest parimutuel payoff ever in North America.

title: The Week in Business; PRODUCER PRICES CLIMB ONLY SLIGHTY
description: Producer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, up only slightly from December's increase of three-tenths of 1 percent. Higher food prices caused by bad weather pushed the index higher, but the relatively low rate of inflation cheered the White House. ''This is a continued sign of progress in getting inflation down,'' said Presidential spokesman Larry Speakes.

title: Business Conditions; ALL QUIET ON LABOR'S FRONT
description: Persistent economic weakness and the end of the three-year contract cycle last year resulted in the lowest number of strikes in 40 years. Figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics show that 2,577 strikes involving six or more workers and lasting at least one day occurred last year.

title: 'Highlights in Jazz' Upcoming Concerts
description: Vocalists as well as instrumentalists are among performers for the ninth-anniversary series of the ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert series produced by Jack S. Kleinsinger.

title: Headliners; That's Svelte
description: Doctors at Massachusetts General Hospital said former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger was doing ''very well'' after four-and-a-halfhours of heart bypass surgery last week. But the patient may spend some uneasy moments in the next three weeks contemplating a recovery program that could be called ''dietary diplomacy.''

title: HER DEEPEST PASSION WAS D.H. LAWRENCE
description: H.D. The Life and Work of an American Poet. By Janice S. Robinson. Illustrated. 490 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $17.95.

title: 'HAVE WE GOT A DEAL FOR YOU'
description: They aren't offering free toasters or television sets yet, but that may not be far off for the developers of a number of cooperatives in and around Brooklyn Heights.

title: TAX LAW PROVES A SLEEPER
description: WASHINGTON IT WAS the great Congressional tax-break brouhaha of 1981, and it so upset a few New Jersey l awmakers that they are trying to rescind or alter guidelines they originally voted for on Dec. 16.

title: COMMERCIAL WORK WAS BEST; Andy Grundberg; SAN FRANCISCO
description: The recent rehabilitation of the reputation of Paul Outerbridge is remarkable both for the rate at which it was accomplished and for what it reveals about the ways in which reputations are made (and unmade) in the world of art. From his death in 1958 until the late 70's, Outerbridge was virtually a nonperson in terms of photographic history, having escaped mention in Beaumont Newhall's standard ''History of Photography'' and most other historical texts as well. His output of delicate platinum prints and strident color-carbro prints long seemed hopelessly irrelevant, if not hokey, to modern eyes.

title: Wendy E. Avrett, A Fashion Editor, Wed to C.S. Weiss
description: The marriage of Wendy Elizabeth Avrett, a fashion editor at Glamour magazine, to Charles Stanard Weiss, a vice president in the corporate finance division of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York, took place yesterday at the Congregational Church in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Charles Smith performed the ceremony.

title: LETTERS SHOW FRANKFURTER A SECRET VOICE OF BRANDEIS
description: Louis D. Brandeis, in his 23 years on the United States Supreme Court, paid Felix Frankfurter, who was then a Harvard law professor, more than $50,000 to further the Justice's goals on public policy, according to previously unpublished letters.

title: Joan L. Lippert, Editor, Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lippert Jr., of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Layton Lippert, to Benjamin Carter Indig, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Sanford Indig of Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: PACKED ICE TAKES A TOLL ALONG THE SHORELINE
description: ALONG the shoreline, the power of this winter's crop of saltwater ice has made its mark. Dock pilings, once proudly vertical, now lean at cockeyed angles. Floating wharves that suffered the strain of moving ice show scars in the form of jagged breaks in weathered wood.

title: MAN SHOT TO DEATH IN A DISPUTE ON IRT AT 137TH ST. STATION
description: A 20-year-old man was fatally shot last evening on a West Side IRT subway train, apparently because he refused to share a marijuana cigarette with three youths who accosted him and a friend, according to the police.

title: Julie Howard Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Searcy Howard of Atlantic Highlands, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Elizabeth Howard, to John David Geraci, son of Frederick Entress Geraci of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Anita Adams Geraci of Greenwich, Conn. A May 22 wedding is planned. Mr. Howard is an executive vice president of Citicorp.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Arch Ensemble Offers Four Coast Composers
description: There was a time when California could claim the major modernist composers as residents. Both Stravinsky and Schoenberg went into exile there, each blissfully ignoring the presence of the other.

title: THE REWARDS OF MAKING MUSSELS
description: There are times, during research on food and cooking, that we discover a fact or observation that sticks with us like a securely fastened fishhook.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Time to Revise The Family Tree?
description: Until recently, a group of creatures known as ''ramapithecines'' sat as securely as anything can at the base of the human evolutionary tree. At 9 to 12 million years old, they were widely considered the earliest known hominids, or primate ancestors to man and the African apes.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Back in Capistrano
description: The news report in March 1981 suggested that the swallows were wary of returning to Capistrano - at least to the famed Franciscan mission to which tourists flock each spring.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Bobcat Census
description: Ruling in February 1981 that the United States was not counting its bobcats carefully enough, the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia banned the export of all bobcat pelts effective July 1981.

title: Around the Nation; Catholics Set Up Fund For Nuclear Workers
description: A Roman Catholic missionary group has set up a fund to support workers who want to quit their jobs at the Pantex factory in Amarillo, Tex., where all American-made nuclear weapons go through the final stages of assembly.

title: Children's Books
description: JUMP SHIP TO FREEDOM By James Lincoln Collier and Christopher Collier. 198 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $9.95. (Ages 11 to 15) By CYNTHIA KING

title: DR. CHERYL SOLED TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Soled of Teaneck, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Cheryl Soled, to Randall James Reid, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Reid of Watchung, N.J. A March wedding is planned.

title: Mepham Girl Sets Mark Of 2:51.6 in 1,000 Run
description: Chris Curtin, a sophomore at Mepham High School, set a girls' state indoor record for the 1,000-meter run, then won the 1,600 yesterday at the Long Island Coaches track and field meet in the 102d Engineers Armory.

title:
Speaking Personally;
LIK E AN OLD SOLDIER, AN OLD FARM JUST FADES AWAY
description: THE relationship between a farmer and his land is as inexplicable as love. Those who heed the call of Mother Earth are proud, hardworking fatalists who have a genuine partnership with the soil. Farmers, the original ecologists, know that nothing is taken from the ground unless something is returned.

title: Miss McMillan To Wed June 26
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard I. McMillan Jr. of Wayzata, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tammis Archambo McMillan, to Gary Richard Vibbard, son of Earl Richard Vibbard of Endwell, N.Y., and Mrs. Monroe Vibbard of Syracuse.

title: I.R.A. BACKERS CAMPAIGN IN IRISH VOTE
description: Sean Kelly, a young volunteer in the parliamentary election campaign, spent today following a time-honored political ritual - knocking on doors asking for votes. But though Mr. Kelly's method was familiar, his message was unusually harsh.

title: FOR 'ROBESON,'A FAMILIAR TURF
description: NEW BRUNSWICK WHEN investigators for the House Committee on Un-American Activities asked Paul Robeson in 1956 why he had left Russia to return to the United States, he replied:

title: Westchester Housing; 'CRISIS TEAMS' AIDING THE ELDERLY
description: ''WE don't have bag ladies in Westchester, and nobody would be allowed to live in a cardboard box on the sidewalk and freeze to death,'' said Dr. Andrew S. Ferber, a psychiatrist at the Huguenot Community Center in New Rochelle.

title: Robert Morris
description: To the Business Editor: ''A New Stamp Honors a Banker; It Took a While'' (Jan. 31) ascribes Robert Morris's bankruptcy and disgrace to losses connected with his land speculation. It seems, however, that a factor in Morris's financial failure was also his decision, around 1793, to build a new mansion for himself in the center of Philadelphia.

title: Sonia Renee Tyler Is Bride
description: Sonia Renee Tyler, daughter of Justice Andrew R. Tyler of the New York State Supreme Court and Mrs. Tyler of New York, was married in Yonkers yesterday to Athol Barrington Chen, son of Sybil Chen of Montego Bay, Jamaica. Msgr. Joseph Troy performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church. The bride attended Boston University. Mr. Chen, a freelance writer, graduated from Columbia Univerity.

title: Martha Brunner-Orne, Expert on Alcoholism
description: Dr. Martha Brunner-Orne, a psychiatrist and authority on alcoholism, died of cancer Thursday at her home in Boston. She was 86 years old.

title: TWO KINDS OF HEROINES
description: MARRIAGE By Gwen Davis. 265 pp. New York: Arbor House, $12.95. THE GRANDDAUGHTER By Lois Wyse. 307 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95. By CAROLYN SEE

title: Duana George Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Angelo George of Mountain Lakes, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Duana Marie George, to Henry Philippe Loustau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Loustau of Triadelphia, W. Va.

title: No Progress On Valenzuela
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers have met again with Fernando Valenzuela's representatives, but the result is the same - a $600,000 gap.

title: STOCK TABLES
description: To the Business Editor: Daily bond tables, too. SIMEON H.F. GOLDSTEIN New York, N.Y., Feb. 8, 1982

title: STUDY SAYS DRUGS INFLUENCE CRIMINAL BEHAVIOR
description: A behavioral scientist who has observed more than 200 acts of felony in Manhattan over the last two years says he has proved an assumption he set out to test: that people who commit crimes while under the influence of drugs behave differently from those who commit the same crime while not under the influence of drugs.

title: U.S. DOCTORS CALL POLAND'S HEALTH CARE POOR
description: American doctors just back from Poland have reported that the condition of that country's health care system, which they described as poor and severely strained, could become critical if the political and economic situation continued to worsen.

title: Jennifer Marina Lee to Be Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Lee of New York, London and Florence have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Marina Lee, to Jeffrey Francis DeLaurentis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent DeLaurentis of Orange, Conn.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: An Ad Is Born KIMBLE MEAD

title: POLAND'S STAGGERING PROBLEMS
description: PARIS DURING two months of martial law, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski has reversed all the freedoms that Poles won during the last year, restored a measure of sullen order to the country and virtually obliterated external signs of the Solidarity trade union movement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I urge you to listen to the real voices of the American people, not just the squeaky wheels. May you draw strength from them as I have.'' -President Reagan in a letter to Republicans in Congress. (27:4.)

title: PLAN URGED TO LET LOCALITIES TAX MOST STATE LAND
description: Local governments would be permitted to collect taxes on nearly all land owned by the state under a new proposal by the New York State Board of Equalization and Assessment.

title: FROM SEA TO SHINING SOUND
description: TO live on Long Island is to have the beach; to have it at all seasons and to have it when I love it best: winter. Then, it is the antithesis of its summer self. The parking lots are empty, the boardwalks devoid of strollers. I share the sands with itinerant birds and meandering gulls. As far as the eye can see, it is only ocean, sky and beach.

title: 2 MARKETING RIVALS DIFFER IN APPROACH AT STAMFORD MALL
description: THEY are at opposite sides of the Stamford Town Center, like two giant bookends -Macy's, a smooth beige monolith of a department store, and J.C. Penney, a dark red brick building.

title: IN TOKYO, ANXIETY OVER GROWTH
description: TOKYO JAPAN'S economy remains the envy of most of the industrialized world but, in the opinion of Government officials and other analysts, it is now at a crucial juncture. Japan, they agree, needs to increase its economic growth. Yet, some private economists say, the Government, trying to balance its budget, is needlessly tied to a program of fiscal restraint that will hinder expansion.

title: JAPAN'S ROBOT REVOLUTION
description: Henry Scott Stokes might have looked back further than Charlie Chaplin's ''Modern Times'' to suggest man's interest in robots. Legends regarding man-made workers go back as far as medieval times.

title: COLUMBIA TO BUILD COMPUTER FACILITY
description: Columbia University will begin erecting a $5.2 million computer science complex next month on the terrace of the School of Engineering and Applied Science on Amsterdam Avenue at 119th Street.

title: CONCERT: BOSTON POPS LED BY JOHN LANCHBERY
description: The Boston Symphony was in town this week, which meant that all a number of its players had to do on Friday night was trade their tails for blue dinner jackets and voila, the Boston Pops in Carnegie Hall. Under the exuberant direction of the British conductor John Lanchbery, the band made excursions into opera, operetta, the ballet and the Broadway repertory, playing most of the fare quite vividly.

title: SLEEPY FLORIDA 'BOOM TOWN'
description: ROY BONGARTZ is a writer who lives in Rhode Island. By ROY BONGARTZ

title: STOCK TABLES
description: To the Business Editor: I liked Mr. Tisch's format very much. My compliments. NATHAN DIAMOND Vice President, Investments Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Atlantic City, N.J., Feb. 8, 1982

title: CUTTING THE LINES TO PRETORIA
description: NAIROBI,KENYA HOSTILE divers attached limpet mines to eight marker buoys in Mozambique's Indian Ocean port of Beira last fall and blew them up. At about the same time, saboteurs attacked the railway linking the port with the hinterland and with the rich markets offered by Africa's newest independent state, Zimbabwe.

title: Major News in Summary; Syria Pulls A Tiger's Tail
description: A Syrian Army raid Feb. 2 on Moslem Brotherhood cells in the northern city of Hama mushroomed into a bloody embarrassment for the regime of President Hafez al-Assad.

title: THE MOVE TO DANCE-DRAMA
description: Since the 50's, modern dance has tended to be plotless or abstract. Although innovations have been made - innovations as various as Merce Cunningham's ''chance'' dances, Alwin Nikolais's technological extravaganzas and the Judson Dance Theater's experiments with ''ordinary'' movement - the resultant dances have seldom been thematically explicit. Now, however, several choreographers are deliberately introducing dramatic or thematic elements into their works.

title: A COMEBACK IN BRONXVILLE
description: Opposite the bustling commuter railroad station of this affluent community a steep hill rises at a forbidding angle for a quarter of a mile until it reaches the ivy-covered red brick apartment building known as 64 Sagamore.

title: POLITICAL SOUVENIRS IN HARTFORD
description: A NEW trove of American political lore could lure historians, students of the American Presidency and amateur political campaign buffs alike to Hartford by the middle of 1983, as the nation's largest private collection of buttons, banners and campaign memorabilia is assembled under the auspices of the University of Hartford.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN TUCSON
description: TOM MILLER, the author of ''On the Border: Portraits of America's Southwestern Frontier,'' contributes to The Times from Tucson. By TOM MILLER

title: Environews
description: ROBERT E. HUGHEY, the new Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, has been criticized by environmentalists as lacking proper qualifications and for being on the other side of the ecological fence because he is a municipal planner. But the charges may be unfounded.

title: A REMARKABLE EXHIBITION OF BLACK FOLK ART IN AMERICA; WASHINGTON
description: It was the role of black folk art to make the unbearable bearable. When all else failed, and society had given the thumbs-down signal once and for all, art was the restorative that made it possible to go on living. That is the message of a monumental exhibition called ''Black Folk Art in America, 1930-1980'' that can be seen through March 28 at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington. Quite apart from its size - there are nearly 400 pieces on view, some of them very large - it is on every count a most remarkable affair. Where most major exhibitions draw upon an already voluminous bibliography, this one had to be put together piece by piece on the rumor, hearsay and the hot tip.

title:
Dining Out;
JAPANESE SPOT OPENS IN THE NORTH
description: IT might seem unfair to comment upon a restaurant that has been open for only two weeks; however, because upcounty dining places represent so few cuisines, and certainly none in the traditional Japanese style, Cho Cho San in Thornwood, seconds off the Saw Mill River Parkway, merits special interest.

title: Schedule of Meetings By Council This Week
description: The following meetings of the City Council are scheduled for this week: TUESDAY - Committee on Youth Services, 1 P.M., City Hall.

title: Foreign Affairs; HAITI HAS NO BOOTSTRAPS
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 12 - Last October's ''interdiction'' agreement between the Haitian and U.S. Governments, plus internment of illegal immigrants in Miami, has served their immediate aims of blocking the flow of refugees. The U.S. Coast Guard cutter assigned to intercept boats that slip past newly vigilant Haitian patrols has only found two loads of migrants to turn back on the high seas, one after it stopped in Cuba. The procedure, as explained by U.S. officials, rivals Graham Greene for farce. People are asked where they came from and why they want to go to the U.S. If they say they're looking for work or a better life, they're sent back, registered with the International Red Cross, given $20 to get home and told to complain to the U.S. Embassy if anybody persecutes them for having tried to leave. If they can convince the Coast Guard they're fleeing for political reasons, it has to take them to the U.S., but so far nobody has managed that.

title: STOCK TABLES
description: To the Business Editor: Yes, yes, yes! RU TH B. ROUFBERG Kendall Park, N.J., Feb. 8, 1982

title: MANY NATIONS FEATURE PICASSO; Samuel A. Tower
description: There has been a splendid display of Pablo Picasso's works on stamps issued in recent months while American collectors were preoccupied with a rash of new issues for the higher postage rates. This display deserves special notice, particularly since countries are still adding to this philatic art show. Thisseems to be a time of anniversaries - the 100th anniversary of Franklin D. Roosevelt's birth, the 250th anniversary o f Washington's birth, the 800th anniversary of the birth of St. Francis of As sisi, the 100th anniversary of the death of Charles Darwin. A ll of these have or are being commemorated on stamps. The commemorati ves making up the Picasso exhibit marked the 100th anniverary o f the birth of the titanof 20th century art.

title: CABARET: BARBARA COOK SINGS
description: Barbara Cook's voice - a strong, clear, well-developed and beautifully controlled soprano - is not what one would normally expect to find in a nightclub or cabaret. That, and the fact that she has an outgoing personality that fills a small room as completely as her big, positive voice does, has gained her a devoted following both in clubs and in the concerts that were a natural consequence of her nightclub success.

title: REVENUE IS SOUGHT FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: With President Reagan having rejected, for the moment, a proposal to raise fuel taxes to finance highways and mass transit, transportation experts who say more money will soon be needed are looking for other possible sources of revenue.

title: THE BACKSTAGE SHOW AT THE MET IS FASCINATING, TOO
description: One Saturday afternoon last month, as stage crews were preparing the set for the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''La Boheme,'' one of the giant stage lifts malfunctioned, leaving Franco Zeffirelli's elaborate scenery in the lurch. Technicians worked feverishly to correct the problem, but not wanting to risk further mechanical trouble in the middle of the performance, they made a decision: ''La Boheme'' would go on elevated a foot higher than usual.

title: SPRINGFIELD, A LIVING SHRINE
description: HAROLD HOLZER is director of public information for WNET/THIRTEEN. He has written extensively on Abraham Lincoln, and won the 1980 Barondess/Lincoln Award for his contributions to the Lincoln field. By HAROLD HOLZER

title: Around the World; Mubarak Calls for Curbs on Population Growth
description: President Hosni Mubarak said today that if Egypt's population continued to grow at its present rate, it could wreck the chances for economic recovery.

title: BEYOND THE POTHOLES, ADMINISTRATION ECONOMISTS SEE A ROAD TO PROSPERITY
description: PERHAPS there's never been anything quite like Reaganomics before, but the Administration's first Economic Report, transmitted to Congress last week, had a familiar upbeat tone to it.

title: RISING LEGAL COSTS CONCERN BOARD
description: MOUNTING legal expenses for the county in connection with lawsuits stemming from alleged faulty design and construction of the Westchester County Courthouse have resulted in a proposed new law being placed before the County Board of Legislators to give the legislators firm control over such costs.

title: REAGAN RULES OUT BIG BUDGET SHIFTS
description: President Reagan said in a letter to Republican members of Congress today that ''where we have honest differences'' on the budget, ''you can count on me to be a willing listener.'' But he added, ''This is no time for turning back.''

title: ISRAELI CRITICIZES MIDEAST REPORTING
description: The director of Israel's Government Press Office has charged that the Palestine Liberation Organization and Syria have achieved some success in using terrorism against American and European correspondents to influence reporting on the Middle East.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Danyal Lawson, Pianist.  Plays Prokofiev Sonata
description: To end his program at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday, Danyal Lawson, pianist, turned in an account of Prokofiev's Sonata No. 7 (Op. 83) that gave evidence, if not of overwhelming technical prowess, at least of a sense of the piece's direction and expressive dimension. But the aggressively straightforward manner of playing that Mr. Lawson rightly favored in the sonata, where the premium was on harshness of sound and brute force of ideas, seemed to be the only manner that he possessed.

title: THE RESHAPING OF THINGS TO COME
description: arl Lagerfeld uses a cinch. Gianfranco Ferre's method is stitching and quilting. Mariuccia Mandelli's answer is manipulated pleating. Halston contours with swoops of drapery. And Bill Blass's solution is a stiff bustier made of snakeskin.

title: CO-OPS IN MOOD TO HOLD THE LINE
description: At a cooperative apartment house on Central Park West in the 70's, the board of directors would very much like to automate the elevators, replace certain drafty windows and modernize the heating system. The mortgage came due a year ago, a logical time to borrow the money to make such improvements.

title: Andrea Judell Will Be Bride Of Alan Markowitz May 31
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Judell of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Robert Judell, to Alan Neil Markowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Markowitz of Seaford, L.I.

title: COLONEL HOUSE'S SECRET RECORDING MACHINE
description: To the Editor:

title: DAINTY SNOWDROPS MAY BE THE FIRST TO BLOSSOM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Megan Fulweiler is a freelance writer. By MEGAN FULWEILER

title: RUMANIAN WARNS HAIG OVER SANCTIONS ON POLAND
description: Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, told Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today that continued American sanctions against Poland would set back the chances for an early resolution of the crisis there.

title: COPTER PAD REQUEST PROMPTS A DEBATE
description: CORNWALL ''I SUPPOSE it seemed just as astonishing in 1900 when someone said he planned to drive his locomobile into town,'' S. Dillon Ripley told the Cornwall Planning and Zoning Commission last week. Mr. Ripley, who is the secretary of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, was speaking in behalf of a request by the prospective buyer of his late mother-in-law's Cornwall estate to create a helicopter landing pad on the property.

title: Lincoln-Mercury Cougar Slain
description: The cougar that served as the Lincoln-Mercury advertising trademark was shot and killed today after it attacked a 9-year-old boy at an automobile show.

title: SERIOUS DESIGNER FLIRTS WITH WHIMSY
description: James Galanos has been, by his own count, in the fashion business for enough years to be unaffected by its ups and downs. ''I've reached the point where I do my collections and don't pay attention to what anybody else is saying or doing,'' he observed before he presented his spring and summer collection at the Plaza Hotel Friday afternoon.

title: A $6.5 MILLION 'VOTE OF CONFIDENCE'
description: He who gives alms in secret is greater than M oses. - TalmudA gift in secret averts anger. - Proverbs HARTFORD

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH THE MILITARY?
description: Senator Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado, is a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee. His legislative aide, William S. Lind, helped him prepare this article. By Gary Hart There is an anecdote about a conversation in the mid-1930's betweenthe French Pr ime Minister, Leon Blum, and Charles de Gaulle, then a French Army c olonel. The future leader of France reproached Blum about the sta te of the country's defenses.

title: JUDGE IN SALVADOR FREES ONE OF SIX IN NUNS' DEATH
description: A Salvadoran judge today freed one of six former National Guardsmen being held in the 1980 deaths of four American churchwomen and ordered the others held for further investigation.

title: Dining Out; HOW THE PUB STYLE IS CHANGING
description: E.A. BENTLEY'S in Syosset is cut from the same mold as many of the newer casual, pub-style restaurants that have been opening on the Island. It's time to comment on these places.

title: JOHN S. GAITHER WILL WED SHIRLEY ANDERSON IN JULY
description: Mrs. Harry Anderson of Greenwich, Conn., ha s announced the engagement of her daughter, Shirley Ann Ander son, to John Stokes Gaither of Bedford, N.Y. He is a son of Mrs. P. Stokes Gaither of Dedham, Mass., and the late Mr. Gaither.

title: PROTECTIONISM: THE GATHERING STORM
description: AT the end of the 1970's, after international trade liberalization accords were successfully completed, it looked as if the everrampant forces of protectionism had been dealt a forceful blow. Yet barely two years after the trade talks known as the Tokyo Round came to an end, nations are quarreling as they haven't since the 1930's over market access, discrimination, reciprocity, pricing - over the general principles of fairness in trade. And protectionism is on the march again.

title: STOCK TABLES
description: To the Business Editor: Great idea! Please do it! DR. JOHN R. VIG Colts Neck, N.J., Feb. 7, 1982

title:
Business Forum;
THE BUDGET DEFICIT IS A RED HERRING
description: T HE attack on what we have come to know as Reaganomics will intensify over the coming weeks as Congress deliberates the first budget resolution for fiscal year 1983. The President will be hardpressed to beat off the attack. He is hampered by the lack of any credible allies in the fight, because most of his economic team and senior advisers and all of the Republican leadership in the Senate have spent the last six months arguing against his program.

title: Connecticut Guide; HARTFORD BALLET GALA
description: The Hartford Ballet has mounted a gala program to celebrate its 10th anniversary at 8 P.M. Thursday through Saturday in Bushnell Hall. Drawing on the background of its director, Michael Uthoff, whose parents were members of the Jooss Ballet in Europe, the company has imported Anna Markard, daughter of Kurt Jooss, to direct ''The Green Table.'' The ballet was choreographed by her father and acclaimed as a masterwork at its Paris premiere in 1932.

title: ART-ROCK: ROSENBLOOM
description: Davis Rosenbloom has worked with Glenn Branca and others on the lower Manhattan art-rock scene, so one might have expected his own music to partake of the same combination of rock onslaughts and classical form. But Mr. Rosenbloom's ''Departure,'' which opened a three-night run Thursday at Inroads, at 150 Mercer Street, is in fact a good deal more conventional than that.

title: The World in Summary; Manotoc Case Is Closed, Sort Of
description: He was kept blindfolded for most of his 41 days as the captive of leftist insurgents, Tommy Manotoc told a news conference in Manila last week. Judging from his vague comments after his purported rescue by Government troops, he also seems to have heard very little and remembered even less.

title: Postal Service Reports $588 Million '81 Loss
description: The Postal Service, saying it lost nearly $588 million last year, attributes its deficit to cuts in its subsidy and delays in raising mail rates.

title: STONY BROOK LURES RESEARCH SC IENTISTS
description: STONY BROOK BY offering young medical researchers opportunities they do not have in their present positions, the Medical School of the State University at Stony Brook has been hiring award-winning scientists away from such institutions as the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Children's Books
description: THE STOLEN LAKE By Joan Aiken. 291 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $10.95. (Ages 10 and Up) By BRYNA J.FIRESIDE

title: 'MONTEZUMA' REACHES NEW YORK-AT LAST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joan Peyser is editor of The Musical Quarterly. By JOAN PEYSER

title: Not Working
description: President Reagan believes people want to work and should work and it's clear what he thinks Washington ought to do about it: promote economic growth and thus produce jobs.

title: THE AMERICAN MISSION
description: Like Jesuits in other areas of the world, American members of the order teach the young, fight injustice and serve the pastoral needs of a wide variety of Roman Catholics. The 4,616 priests, 437 brothers and 704 scholastics in the order's 10 provinces in the United States constitute the largest Jesuit community in the world. Their interests and theology may differ, but they have generally absorbed the qualities associated with their land.

title: Mrs. McLaughlin Wed to a Lawyer
description: Margaret Campbell Findley McLaughlin and Edwin Charles Laurenson were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: TEXT OF REAGAN LETTER TO G.O.P. LAWMAKERS
description: Following is the text of a letter from President Reagan to Republican members of the Senate and the House of Representatives dated Feb. 13:

title: No Headline
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wellington T. Mara of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ann Mara, to John Robert McDonnell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McDonnell of Allenhurst, N.J. A July wedding is planned. Miss Mara, an alumna of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greeenwich, Conn., and Boston College, received an M.S. degree from Fordham University.

title: Prospects
description: Credit Demand May Ease

title: 2 Young Sisters Killed, 3 Injured in Bronx Fire
