description: Two sisters, aged 8 months and 3 years, were killed and three of their sisters were injured yesterday afternoon in an apartment fire in the Tremont section of the Bronx.

title: IS HISTORY THE ENEMY OF PROGRESS?
description: TRADITION By Edward Shils. 334 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $20.

title: FESTIVAL HONORS JAMES JOYCE
description: AN outcast in his home country of Ireland, banned for many years in the United States and shunned and censored elsewhere, James Joyce is nonetheless considered by many to be the leading writer of the 20th century, one whose stream-of-consciousness style brought a vitality and freshness to modern literature. In Westchester, devotees of the artist are joining others worldwide in honoring the 100th anniversary of the artist's birthday this month, with a seven-day celebration.

title: Around the World; Law on Nationalization In France Is in Effect
description: The French nationalization bill became law today when it was published in the official gazette.

title: Cynthia Robbins To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy J. Robbins Jr. of King of Prussia and Fairview Lake, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Cynthia Hope Robbins of San Mateo, Calif., to Dr. Robert Roth, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Roth of Schenectady, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: WOMAN MAY HAVE RECOGNIZED KILLER, POLICE SAY
description: A Greenwich Village woman who was found stabbed to death Friday in her apartment may have recognized the person who killed her, the police said yesterday.

title: BISHOP BACKS PLAN TO LEASE ST. BART'S LAND TO DEVELOPER
description: The Episcopal Bishop of New York has approved the proposed leasing of land by St. Bartholomew's Church to a developer for the construction of a 59-story office building on Park Avenue.

title: EX-UNIONIST LEADS A COAL COMPANY IN BITTER DISPUTE WITH MINERS' UNION
description: On one s ide of a bitter 11-month stalemate her e are 160 striking members of the United Mine Workers ofAmerica. On t he other side is a coal company whose uncompromising chief negotia tor is about to draw his pension - from the coal union.

title: A. J. Wheeler Fiance of Miss McGeorge
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur McGeorge of Greenville, Del., and Ellsworth, Me., of the engagement of their daughter, Antonia Harman McGeorge, to Arthur Jackson Wheeler, son of Mrs. Frederick McGeorge Bundy of Manchester, Mass., and the late Howard Wheeler of Marblehead, Mass., and Key Biscayne, Fla. The wedding is planned for May.

title: CONCESSIONS MADE
description: The United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company reached a tentative agreement tonight on a new national contract that includes wage and benefit concessions by workers in return for assurances of greater job security.

title: FUNNY FAUNA AND FLORA
description: The creature above is a ''Light-footed Pipe Puffin (fumatorium foetidum),'' which ''habitually goes up in smoke. Rare bird from Briarland; feeds on dry leaves and fumes a lot; supposed to be shy, but lightning-quick and very curious.

title: A WINTERTIME IDYLL IN YELLOWSTONE
description: WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT is chief of the Denver bureau of The Times. By WILLIAM E.SCHMIDT

title: Children's Books
description: THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE The Story of the Gilbert & Sullivan Operetta. Adapted by Ward Botsford. Illustrated by Edward Sorel. Unpaged. New York: Random House. $8.95. (Ages 8 and Up) By ELAINE EDELMAN

title: River Cruise to Sacramento
description: The route was discovered first by Spanish padres, then by fur traders, gold-seekers and pioneer farmers. They found miles of sheltered waterways along which paddlewheel steamers would later make their way - into the California Delta.

title: A COLLECTOR'S SAGA
description: Over the last 40 years, Tsao Yee Chao has assembled one of the most impressive private collections of Chinese jades and ceramics in the world. Mr. Chao, chairman of the Wah Kwong Shipping and Investment Company of Hong Kong, began his collection by acquiring Chinese jades and paintings. More recently he switched to porcelains and pottery, concentrating at first on Ching and Ming wares. Lately, however, the focus of his interest is on the earlier Tang and Sung periods of ceramics, robust vessels which have been more popular in the West than among today's Chinese art collectors in Hong Kong.

title: Zimbabwe Finds Arms Cache
description: Security forces searching for illicit hoards of arms have found another cache of munitions in the province of Matabeleland, the police said today. A spokesman said the dump, with more than 36,000 rounds of small ammunition and 124 rockets, was hidden in a forest 100 miles north of Bulawayo.

title: Stock Tables
description: To the Business Editor: I heartily applaud and endorse the suggestion of James S. Tisch in ''Reading the Stock Tables'' (Feb. 7) to list the closing price and price change before the name of the stock.

title: HOW PROPOSALS ON SCHOOL AID AFFECT COUNTY
description: MORE than half the school districts in Westchester County could lose all of their state education operating aid if the State Legislature decides to adopt certain policy recommendations proposed by the state's Special Task Force on Equity and Excellence in Education. Some other school districts in the county, however, could gain as much as $350 per pupil under the same proposals.

title: Gail Bartram Lockhart Is Fiancee of Leslie Adams
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey S. Lockhart of Fairfield, Conn., and Wilmington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Bartram Lockhart, to Leslie A. Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram J. Adams of Wilmington. An August wedding is planned in Southport, Conn.

title: SHIPBOARD CLEANLINESS AND YOUR HEALTH
description: How safe is it to sail on a cruise liner that fails to meet the sanitary standards of the United States Public Health Service? The question has been asked before but has been revived because of the following:

title: The Parthenon
description: To the Editor:

title: ACTORS FUND PUSHES NURSING HOME PLEA
description: ENGLEWOOD STARS whose fees would ordinarily total millions of dollars - James Stewart, Elizabeth Taylor, Ethel Merman, Orson Welles, Helen Hayes and others - will converge at Radio City Music Hall tonight for a benefit for the Actors' Fund of America.

title: Israel's Minority In the Middle Rafik
description: Halabi, the Druse Arab, although admittedly enjoying the freedom and opportunities of a Western democracy in Israel, expresses his sense of alienation from his own Arab roots by asking, ''Who is Rafik Halabi?'' (''Israel's Minority in the Middle,'' Dec. 27). Rafik Halabi, Israeli patriot and soldier, asks, ''If the Israelis have accepted a Druse Arab in complete friendship and trust, why are they afraid of the West Bank Arabs?''

title: REDISTRICTING POSES PROBLEMS FOR A CAROLINA CONGRESSMAN
description: The North Carolina General Assembly has approved a Congressional redistricting plan that would make urban Durham County part of the now largely rural district of Representative L.H. Fountain, a conservative Democrat.

title: WOMEN IN CRISIS
description: STORIES UP TO A POINT By Bette Pesetsky. 114 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $9.50. TAKING CARE By Joy Williams. 246 pp. New York: Random House. $12.50.

title: Fines Urged for a Lack Of Atom Plant Devices
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has proposed fines of $1,000 a day beginning March 1 for eight nuclear power plants that have failed to meet a deadline for installing accident warning systems.

title: Cooney Suffers Pain
description: Gerry Cooney, who is scheduled to challenge Larry Holmes in Las Vegas, Nev., March 15 for the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship, experienced ''obvious pain'' while working out yesterday and will suspend sparring until after he undergoes tests on his injured left shoulder tomorrow or Tuesday.

title: COMMODITY PRODUCERS' TOUGH LIFE
description: However wretched their economic lots were in 1981, the poorer countries that supply much of the world's exportable raw materials can expect even worse conditions this year. Most commodity prices that the third world receives today are only slightly above their 1976 dollar levels, but the value of the dollar has shrunk to 55 cents since then.

title: Maria Pedemonte Fiancee Of Richard T. McBride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Juan Pedemonte of Rio de Janeiro have made known the engagement of their daughter, Maria de los Angeles Pedemonte, to Richard Tillinghast McBride, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lee McBride of Rye, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: CHEMICAL WARFARE LESSONS OF TWO WARS
description: To the Editor:

title: WITNESS UNDER U.S. PROTECTION CHARGED IN KILLING
description: A former New York City insurance agent who has been protected by the Justice Department since testifying about racketeering in the garment center in the mid-1970's is being tried here on first-degree murder charges.

title: Mailbox; Differing Notions Of Amateurism
description: To the Sports Editor: In her article in last Sunday's Times (''From Little Mary Decker to World Class Star'') Mary Decker Tabb seems to epitomize the confusion that is rampant in track and field today.

title:
Speaking Personally;
REMEMBRANCES OF MOTHER'S PET, DUKIE: MORE THAN A DOG?
description: DURING the last seven years, I've come to appreciate how life in Westchester can dim the urban past. Despite the daily contrast of working in New York City, the personal concerns and joys of a suburban style of life are soon accepted as the way of things. And as the erstwhile city places of earlier years are encountered less frequently, remembrances of things past somehow soften and fade.

title: HEALTH CARE PLAN GETS FINAL REVIEW
description: The Reagan Administration is putting the finishing touches on a plan to slow the rise in medical costs. Many health experts say the proposal would bring the most sweeping changes in American medicine since Medicare and Medicaid were enacted nearly two decades ago.

title: Food; LAMB COMING INTO ITS OWN ON AMERICAN TABLES
description: ALTHOUGH lamb has long been the principal meat in the Middle East, North Africa and Greece, it has never been a particular favorite among Americans, who have preferred beef. But in recent years Americans have decided that lamb is rather glamorous and have given it a major role at dinner parties. Rack, saddle or leg of lamb, roasted so that the meat is moist and pink inside, and served with roast potatoes or stewed white haricots has become almost as popular as in France.

title: ALL THE PRESIDENT'S DEADBEATS
description: ''A comprehensive effort to collect $33 billion in delinquent debts has been launched and will recover $1.5 billion in 1982 and $4 billion in 1983.'' - President Reagan's Budget Message By DAVID SHRIBMAN

title: BANKING ON THE U.S. FOR STABILITY
description: AS economic and political conditions deteriorate in most of the world, bankers are increasingly focusing their attention on the United States, a country perceived as a haven of stability. In most other regions, however, with Southeast Asia a notable exception, banks are retrenching. They are cutting back their international lending and are redirecting their investment strategies in attempts to capture a bigger part of the American and Southeast Asian markets.

title: Cubs' Tidrow Re-Signs, Gets 3-Year Contract
description: Dick Tidrow, who had a 3-10 record as a relief pitcher with the Chicago Cubs last season and then became a free agent, has signed a three-year contract with the Cubs.

title: CUTS IN SOIL EROSION PROGRAM WORRY FARMERS
description: John R. Block, the Secretary of Agriculture, had the unenviable chore of telling a convention of local soil conservation officials in Phoenix how dedicated the Reagan Administration was to preventing even more of the nation's farmland from blowing or washing away.

title: U.S. APPEALS JUDGE DENOUNCES REAGAN CRIME-FIGHTING IDEAS
description: Judge David L. Bazelon, an influential member of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, has criticized the Reagan Administration's proposals for fighting crime as ineffective.

title: International Economic Survey February 14, 1982
description: OUTLOOK A World Economy Divided. By Leonard Silk Cover The Gathering Storm of Protectionism.

title: About Books and Authors
description: A Member of the Fugitives

title: Me ts Sign Brooks and Wilson
description: With George Foster finally signed as the man expected to lead them in run production next season, the Mets yesterday got around to signing two players they hoped Foster would be driving across the plate.

title: View of a Newcomer On Mall Economics
description: As a newcomer to the Yorktown area, I disagree with Virginia Franklin's statements. As a new resident, formerly from the North Bronx, I was very pleased to discover the abundance of shopping malls.

title: Theater; 'LINDBERGH' LANDS WITH LITTLE ROAR
description: FOR those who read show credits, Claude McNeal is neither the composer nor the lyricist of ''Charles A. Lindbergh vs. the Roaring 20's,'' but rather the author and slide gatherer for what is described as a ''multimedia variety musical.'' It is one of two that An Evening Dinner Theater is presenting for runs of three weeks each; the other will be ''The Fabulous Forties.'' Mr. McNeal for five years was the main creative force behind the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport, Conn., where he created and staged 16 new shows during the mid 1970's.

title: TAIWAN'S EXPORT-LED GROWTH
description: TOKYO TAIWAN'S economy, buffeted by world oil price increases and severance of diplomatic relations with Japan and the United States in the 1970's, is bearing up well with the possibility of rapid growth in the early 1980's despite a world recession.

title: Judith Hofmeister Is Bride of Nelson Brinckerhoff
description: Judith N. Hofmeister, who teaches sixth grade at the Frenchtown School in East Greenwich, R.I., was married at St. Luke's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Nelson F. Brinckerhoff, who expects to graduate in June from the New York Law School. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alfred W. Burns, rector of the church, and the Rev. Susan Case Hofmeister of the First Presbyterian Church of Davenport, N.Y., the bride's sister-in-law.

title: Howe G. Wheelock Jr.  Weds Candace Smith
description: Candace Ann Smith and Howe Grove Wheelock Jr., who are with the Crocker National Bank, were married yesterday in San Francisco. The Rev. Philip M. Compton performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: OLDER WOMEN AND IMPORTANT HATS
description: Age alone does not dictate fashion. Can a young woman with large hips wear tight jeans? Can a young woman with short chubby legs wear an above-the-knee, pencil-slim skirt? At any age a critical eye is essential. The women in the 1950's all wore hats; the young looked adorable, and the mature sophisticated and worldly. CAROLINE REINER New York City ------

title: THE POLISH CRISIS COULD BE A WATERSHED FOR THE WEST AS WELL AS FOR THE EAST
description: WESTERN foreign ministers last week packed up their preoccupation with the Soviet role in Poland and took it on the road - specifically to Madrid, where 35 countries have been reviewing the 1975 Helsinki accords on European security and human rights. As in other forums, the United States was partly successful in persuading the allies to get in step on strategy. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., insisting that Polish martial law was ''a fundamental and perhaps fatal threat to the entire Helsinki process,'' got the European allies to postpone the nearly completed negotiations on supplementary East-West accords. But the Europeans fought off American pressure to underline the point by walking out of the conference.

title: Sports of The Times; A Walker Runs for Justice
description: HERSCHEL WALKER wants to be a lawyer and he wants to play in the National Football League. He may need the legal skills in order to use his football skills.

title: Philip Halpern to Wed Marcia Wierda in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Wierda of Manhasset, L.I., and Rock Hall, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marcia Louise Wierda, to Philip L. Halpern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Halpern of East Williston, L.I., and Lauderhill, Fla.

title: PROPOSAL FOR JOB CORPS RECALLS ROOSEVELT PLAN
description: Few of this city's recent celebrations of Franklin Delano Roosevelt's 100th birthday have passed without nostalgic references to the Civilian Conservation Corps, that President's cherished vehicle for getting thousands of jobless, hungry youths off the streets and putting them to work refurbishing the nation's parks and forests.

title: NEW YORK TO TORONTO TRA IN
description: ANDREW H. MALCOLM is Toronto bureau chief for The New York Times. By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

title: STOCK TABLES
description: To the Business Editor: Very practical. MILTON LEEDS Southbury, Conn., Feb. 8, 1982

title: Music; A MUSICAL SATURDAY WITH MORE AHEAD
description: I SPENT an enjoyable musical Saturday afternoon sitting in on the Norwalk Symphony's annual ''family'' concert last weekend, then headed over to Greenwich for Patricia Handy's conducting debut at one of the Philharmonia's subscription concerts.

title: BEYOND THE ROMANTIC MESSAGE
description: CLEANING out my closet is not one of my favorite chores, especially if I intend to do a thorough job of it and use a stepladder for the high shelves. But sometimes there's an added bonus. Last week I received such a pleasant dividend.

title: JOBLESSNESS: A GROWING SCOURGE
description: ROME IT has been a tough winter for Italian workers and particularly forthose under t he age of 30. Unemployment has been mounting steadily, reaching 8.4 percent at the end of 1981, according to official Government st atistics, and almost three-quarter of the just-under 2 million men a nd women out of work are between the ages of 14 and 30.

title: Richard Drisko, Engineer, To Wed Alison L. Altman
description: Ronny C. Altman of Great Neck, L.I., and Dr. Sheldon G. Altman of Lido Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Lori Altman, to Richard Carl Drisko, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard M. Drisko of Pittsburgh.

title: KRISTIN DUFOUR, EDITOR, TO BE MARRIED IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. O'Brien of Chester Springs, Pa., have announced the engagement of Mrs. O'Brien's daughter, Kristin Elizabeth Dufour, to Christopher May, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel H. May of Norwell, Mass. A June wedding is planned in Chester Springs.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: WHEEL AND SEA DEALS; Motorhomes With Extras
description: Motorhome folks wouldn't wander any other way. They prefer to steer clear of checking in and out of hotels - and hotel bills - and to keep the family together under one private and permanent roof as they roll along from landmark to beauty spot, in and out of cities and across borders.

title: WHY EARLY TV WAS A GOLDEN ERA FOR DRAMA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Fielder Cook has just completed an original screenplay, which is scheduled to go into production shortly starring Kristy McNichol. By FIELDER COOK

title: TRUST ACTS TO SAVE A FARM IN SHARON
description: SHARON IN an effort to help preserve the nation's farmland, a private trust organization in Washington, D.C., announced this month its plans to buy a farm in northwestern Connecticut that is on the market for $750,000.

title: THE BROWN DECISION--TO THE JUNKPILE?
description: In recent weeks, the Senate floor has been the setting of a far-reaching civil rights debate that is likely to occupy the entire Congress through much of 1982. The issue is whether Federal courts should be prohibited from issuing or enforcing orders designed to remedy unconstitutional school segregation.

title: IT'S HIGH NOON FOR DUMPERS IN JERSEY CITY
description: JERSEY CITY BEFITTING his nickname, Earl Zela (Tex) Aldredge, a badge on his chest and a 10-gallon hat on his head, stalks this city's streets on the lookout for outlaws - the environmental kind.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Marcel De Taranto, Pianist, Plays Mozart
description: Marcel De Taranto, founder-conductor of the Metro Community Orchestra and a teacher at Erasmus Hall High School, made his debut as pianist at the Abraham Goodman House on Tuesday night. A native of Istanbul who came to this country in 1967, Mr. De Taranto studied music at the Manhattan School and Brooklyn College.

title: ARMS FOR JORDAN WILL BE PRESSED BY WEINBERGER
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he would urge President Reagan to sell more arms to Jordan.

title: Susan Weiss Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Weiss of Wayne, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Alexandra Weiss, to Joseph Esposito, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Esposito of Gillette, N.J. The wedding is planned for July 3. Miss Weiss is a landscape architect for Architect's Collaborative in Cambridge, Mass., and her fiance an engineer with the Anderson-Nichols Engineering Company in Boston.

title: Cynthia Arnold Engaged
description: Cynthia Wyard Arnold, an international officer for the Mellon Bank International in New York, plans to be married in April to Gerhard Erwin Bruckermann, a bank manager in the international division of the Westdeutsche Landesbank in Dusseldorf, West Germany. Mr. and Mrs. Calvin L. Arnold of Ligonier, Pa., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. Erwin Bruckermann of Solingen, West Germany, and the late Mr. Bruckermann.

title: DISMAY GIVING WAY TO DESPAIR
description: PORT OF SPAIN, TRINIDAD THE goodwill that marked the economic conference of rich and poor nations held last fall in Cancun, Mexico, appears to have done little to reduce the gap between the developing world's perception of its problems and the Reagan Administration's proposed solutions to them. Indeed , dismay in many of the smallest, poorest lands is now giving way to a sense of desperation and fear that economic woes will bring increased social and political unrest.

title: SOLAR DEVELOPMENT IN TEWKSBURY
description: TEWKSBURY TWP. THE front of the dishwasher beeps and blinks like the control panel of a starship. Down at earth level, a heat pump softly clicks off and on in time with temperatures rising and falling in the heat well.

title: NO RUSH FOR 13 1 2% MORTGAGES
description: DESPITE a substantial easing of income eligibility requirements as well as the maximum allowable sales price, the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority experienced no great rush for its recent offering of low-cost mortgages. On Jan. 25 the authority, a state-chartered independent agency de signed to help moderate-income people buy homes, announced that it wa s making $200 million available for low-cost residential mortgages.Th is was the first time the agency had been able to offer sp ecialrate loans in almost a year. That rate is 13 1/2 percent, ap proximately 4 percentage points below current charges of most le nders in the state.

title: No Headline
description: Misses Flanders, Nelson Are 1, 2 in Cup Downhill

title: Home Clinic; IF THE FLOOR SAGS, HERE'S HOW TO GIVE IT SUPPORT
description: A FLOOR that dips or sags often needs additional support in the basement -either because an exceptionally heavy weight has been added (for example, a large piano, a large cast iron stove or a bookcase filled with many volumes), or because one of the supporting columns under the floor has cracked, rotted or otherwise started to give way.

title: FOR ASIA, AN UNEVEN GROWTH
description: MANILA ON the eve of its 15th birthday, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean as it is generally known, has become an organization of economically dissimilar countries. When its members, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thail and, banned together in 1967, they hoped that post-colonial Southeast Asia could develop a culturally diverse, politically agreeable and economically interdependent trading unit, freer than the formal European Common Market, but still a functioning trade bloc.

title: STERN AT THE HELM
description: Isaac Stern, is known not only for his pro d igious fiddling, but also for his generosity in helping promising young performers and forhis successful drive to save Carnegie Hall. O n Feb. 24, he will lend his talents to the New Jersey Symphony Orches tra in a benefit concertat Newark's Symphony Hall.

title: A SELECTION
description: 1. Lenotre,several shops, including 17 Avenue Victor Hugo (501-71-71), 121 Avenue de Wagram (924-70-30) and 44 Rue d'Auteuil (524-52-52). Everything about Lenotre is neat, fresh and elegant: cakes, pastries, chocolates, even whole carry-out meals. 2. Maison du Chocolat,225 Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honore (227-39-44). A good selection of wines, champagnes and armagnacs, as well as Robert Linxe's creamy, ethereal chocolates. 3. Dalloyau,with three Paris shops: 101 Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honore (359-15-58); 69, Rue de la Convention (577-84-27), and in the Centre Beaugrenelle shopping mall (575-59-62). Superb croissants as well as classic, creamy chocolates. 4. Tanrade,18 Rue Vignon (742-26-99). Marrons glaces and rochers, little rounds of toasted almonds covered with chocolate. 5. Bonbonnerie de la Trinite,4 Place Estienne d'Orves (874-23-38). A father-to-son operation since 1925. Fresh-flavored, intense chocolates, some decorated with a dainty candied violet. 6. A La Mere de Famille,35 Rue du Faubourg Montmartre, Paris 9 (telephone: 770-83-69). In business since 1761, it offers simple, old-fashioned chocolates, some flavored with cassis and framboise. 7. Neuhaus-Catalin,Shopping center at Rond-Point des Champs-Elysees, lower level (562-02-15). Belgian chocolates, sweeter and less bold than their French counterparts. 8. Meurisse,49 bis Avenue Franklin Roosevelt, just off the Rond Point (225-06-04). Bold, cocoa-buttery chocolates. Try turinos, rounds of chestnut cream and rum, or brunas, almonds coated in dark, bitter chocolate. 9. Puyricard,27 Avenue Rapp (705-59-47). A sober, old-fashioned shop selling chocolates made in the artisanal manner in Aix-en-Provence - rich and creamy, with the intensity of good, South American chocolate. 10.

title: DIGITAL DISKS: PRO AND CON; Hans Fantel
description: Digital records are no longer an oddity. They have become a staple in the market, and considered judgment of their merit can be based on a broad sampling. With some reservations, reaction has been mostly favorable, particularly since problems prevalent during the initial shakedown period of the new technique are now on the way to being surmounted. Even so, opinion among audio fans remains divided, ranging from prejudicial denigration to uncritical enthusiasm.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Small houses, great dreams. The two paperbacks that lead off our New and Noteworthy annotations this week - W.M. Spackman's ''An Armful of Warm Girl'' and George Stade's ''Confessions of a Lady-Killer'' - have a number of interesting things in common.

title: MR. REAGAN, PRESS EL SALVADOR TO NEGOTIATE
description: It is time for President Reagan to think the unthinkable: He should press for negotiations between the Government in El Salvador and the opposition.

title: REDUCTION SOUGHT IN POTATO PESTICIDES
description: RIVERHEAD RESEARCHERS have stepped up the hunt for methods to reduce the amount of pesticides that growers apply to 18,300 acres planted in potatoes on the East End.

title: Older Women and Important Hats
description: Concerning hats on older women, we are the ones who kept hats alive (''Are Hats Taking Off?'' by Carrie Donovan, Jan. 3).

title: ONE GARDENER'S SECRET OF SUCCESS
description: Over Thanksgiving weekend last year, six weeks after our first frost, we ate 16 vegetables from our garden: not canned or frozen but fresh. The accomplishment turned me into an autumn version of the Garden Bore.

title: BEHIND THE SCENES IN BATTLE OVE R LIBRARY
description: TO the casual observer, activity at the Mount Pleasant Public Library in Pleasantville is normal: a brisk but orderly in-and-out movement of books, records and cassettes, students from the nearby high school roosting in carrels, elderly readers dipping into newspapers and magazines in the lounge area, staff members shushing the young in the children's room.

title: LATINS FACE LONG SLUMP
description: RIO DE JANEIRO BESET by spiraling foreign debts, a continuing population explosion and vulnerability to the global economic slowdown, South America has little hope of reversing a slump in its growth this year. The 1980's have ended a period of substantial economic expansion for most South American countries, and the only encouraging aspect at the start of 1982 is that the year probably won't be quite so bad as 1981.

title: Children's Books
description: A VERY NOISY DAY Written and Illustrated by Rolf Myller. 32 pp. New York: Atheneum. $9.95. (Ages 4 to 8) By KARLA KUSKIN

title: FORD'S THEATER: THE FINAL ACT
description: STEPHEN B. OATES, a professor of history at t he University of Massachusetts at Amherst, is the author of '' With Malice Toward None:The Life of Abraham Lincoln'' and other books on Lincoln and the Civil War era. His biography of Martin Luther King Jr., ''Let the Trumpets Sound,'' will be published by Harper & Row in August. By STEPHEN B. OATES

title: JOBLESSNESS: A GROWING SCOURGE
description: TOKYO Japan's unemployment problem is one that other industrialized nations wish they had. Its 2.1 percent jobless rate is far lower than elsewhere, and it is extremely stable. The yearly peak was 2.2 percent, reached in 1978, when this oil-poor nation was in the throes of adjusting to high-cost energy.

title: AMERICANS DOMINANT IN TECHNOLOGY
description: AMERICAN businessmen talk these days about new technology as the trump card in international competition. Confronted with a competitive onslaught based in part on advancing technology in Japan and, to a lesser extent, Western Europe, they are plunging resources into research and development.

title: Navy May Reopen Base Annex On Key West for Training Use
description: The Navy is thinking about reopening for ''strategic and training purposes'' the 76-acre Truman annex to the Key West Naval Air Station, long closed and listed as for sale, a Navy spokesman , said Friday.

title: The Nation in Summary; Nixon Loses a Round on Tapes
description: So far, Richard Nixon's claim that almost anything a President says in private meetings in the Oval Office or signs his name to is confidential isn't holding up very well. Last week, a Federal appeals court upheld a ruling that the contents of Mr. Nixon's White House tape recordings can't be presumed to be confidential -and thus unavailable for public scrutiny - merely because he was President.

title: THE BIRTH OF DANIEL
description: EARLY in her second pregnancy last year, Donna Horvath decided that she would not have her child in a hospital, as she had done with her son, Joseph, in 1978.

title: Art; NEW GALLERY, CHANGES AT THE HUDSON
description: YONKERS SOME of the changes at the Hudson River Museum will be especially noticeable for those who, like the reviewer, have not been there in a while. First, the museum now opens at noon, closing at 7 P.M. Wednesday through Sunday and at 9 P.M. Thursdays.

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE Nassau Board of Elections symbolizes the growing rol e of women in politics and government. With the appointment of A. Pat ricia Moore as the Democratic commissioner of the bipartisan boa rd, the topleadership of the board is entirely female.

title: Around the Nation; USAir and Teamsters Seek to Avert a Strike
description: Representatives of USAir and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters resumed negotiations today with a Federal mediator on hand, trying to work out an agreement that would avert a threatened strike by baggage and cargo handlers.

title: HIGH PRICE OF A STRONG DOLLAR
description: The dollar, which America's trading partners blamed for sapping the strength from their economies last year, is likely to remain high through 1982, and analysts and economists are beginning to wonder if the price of a strong dollar is becoming too high.

title: CHILL DEVELOPS IN U.S. LINKS TO THE DUTCH
description: This year the Dutch are proudly celebrating their 200th consecutive year of friendly diplomatic relations with the United States. There is only one problem: relations at the moment are not very warm.

title: Prof. Carol Thompson Wed in Montana
description: Carol Thompson, associate professor of theater arts at City College and until recently chairman of the department, was married yesterday to Patrick Hemingway, a widower, of Bozeman, Mont. The Rev. Dr. Ian Wilson performed the ceremony at the West Yellowstone (Mont.)

title: WHO WIELDS THE POWER IN HOLLYWOOD?
description: LOS ANGELES Spiraling production costs, a slump at the box office, and, in some quarters, disillusionment with the wunderkind school of filmmaking, are causing strains these days in the economic -creative partnership that makes Ho llywood run. Francis Ford Coppola, the Oscar-winning director whos e two ''Godfather'' movies are considered classics by some film his torians, says again he may be facing bankruptcy and blames his pr oblems on the fact that ''the studios,'' not creative people, contr ol the movies.

title: OLDER WOMEN AND IMPORTANT HATS
description: If women do not look good in hats, it is not because they are ''older,'' but because designers do not take into sufficient account differing facial contours, complexions and body proportions of the enormous variety of women in this country. They are, rather, for the most part catering to that largely nonexistent ideal of female fashion which one may describe as a combination of mannequin, ingenue and child sex goddess. SUSAN N. FAULKNER Jackson Heights, N.Y.

title: The Region in Summary; Shirley Chisholm Calls It a Day
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm has earned a national reputation as a scrapper during her seven terms in Congress, but last week she tossed in the towel. The news that she would not seek re-election was no surprise.

title: GIBSON IS RUNNING, DESPITE TROUBLES
description: NEWARK THE announcement by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson last week that he would seek an unprecedented fourth term came at a time when a grand jury investigation was still hanging over his head and the trial of one of his top aides, on charges of assault, was slowly wending its way through the judicial system.

title: BRITIAN'S MONETARIST MUDDLE
description: LONDON IF ever monetarism - which emphasizes a close hold on the growth of money and credit - was to have a full-scale test, the opportunity came in the spring of 1979, when Margaret H. Thatcher was elected Prime Minister of Britain, committed to a conservative economic program emphasizing monetarist doctrine.

title: Rangers End Trip With a 3-2 Victory
description: The New York Rangers concluded an eight-game two-week trip tonight with a 3-2 victory over the Whalers on a goal by Don Maloney in the third period.

title: HOW HE WROTE THAT PLAY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jeremy Gerard is a freelance writer specializing in theater. By JEREMY GERARD

title: The Region in Summary; Albany Given A Hotfoot on Redistricting
description: In two months of wrangling over the reapportionment of New York, the only boundaries legislative leaders in Albany have agreed on are battle lines. While the Republicans and Democrats continued to squabble, the Black and Puerto Rican Caucus moved last week to push the matter ahead by hauling both sides into court.

title: L.I. IN KEY ROLE IN REDISTRICTING
description: ALBANY IN drawing political lines, as in most other things, beauty is in the eye of the beholder. The Democrats and the Republicans here are now at a stalemate over how to redraw the state's boundaries for Congressional, Assembly and Senate districts. The Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus got the courts involved in the argument last week by suing the legislative leaders to force them to draw political lines by March 1.

title: Judith Nelson Engaged To Jeffrey L. Camps
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Z. Nelson of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Beth Nelson, to Jeffrey Lowell Camps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell C. Camps of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is planned for July 31.

title: RIGHTS MARCHERS PASS SELMA BRIDGE
description: Hundreds of people joined the Carrolltonto-Montgomery voting rights march today as it left Selma over a bridge where, 17 years ago, police wielding clubs attacked participants in the Selma-to-Montgomery march of 1965.

title: Vicky Ann Moon a Bride
description: Vicky Ann Moon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Moon of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married in Washington yesterday to Leonard Mark Shapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Shapiro of Syosset, L.I. Retired Chief Judge Gerard Reilly of the District of Columbia performed the ceremony at the Mount Vernon College Chapel. The bride, who owns High Horse Antiques in Georgetown, Washington, will keep her name. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Shapiro is deputy sports editor of The Washington Post.

title: Bench Is Robbed
description: Johnny Bench reported Saturday that his 1976 World Series ring and and other jewelry worth $16,000 had been stolen. The police said the items were taken from an unlocked concession stand at Palo Verde Park, where Bench had been filming baseball tips for a television series.

title: FRANCE'S IDEA MAN
description: A fellow in a black outfit, wearing a chain around his neck that made him look like a wine steward, kept leading people through one door of the office and out another. That is because the huissier cannot lead anyone in to see the President of France without first passing through the adjacent office of Jacques Attali.

title: Faulty Elevator Causes 2 Injuries
description: An elevator at the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South last Thursday descended 31 stories at its ''fast speed'' and halted in the hotel's basement, according to Joseph Ferranti, who supervises elevator inspections for the city's Department of Buildings.

title: Rhoda Agriss Is Married
description: Rhoda Agriss, a cosmetics consultant in New York, and John A. Conway of Rye, N.Y., a senior editor of Forbes magazine, were married yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel.

title: SCHOOL TAX RUMBLES
description: Publicly, the Reagan Administration is standing fast on its position that it must give tax exemptions to racist schools unless Congress passes a law - while Congress feels no new law is needed. But inside the Administration, officials are under pressure to find some way out. That is because they can see embarrassing events ahead.

title: BIG PLANS FOR LITTLE COMPUTER
description: In an industry in which egos frequently are as large as the products are small, Adam Osborne may take the prize for each.

title: Swiss Take Title In 4-Man Bobsled
description: Switzerland won the fourman world bobsled championship today, ending the domination of East Germany, which had won five of the last six championships.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1982
description: International Nearly 200 Poles were arrested in Poznan, a city in western Poland, when they tried to hold a demonstration to protest martial law, the Warsaw radio said. In Warsaw, a series of symbolic protests urged by the Solidarity trade union failed to take place. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel will oppose more arms sales to Jordan by the United States. Israel's Cabinet Secretary, Aryeh Naor, said that Israel ''won't sit in silence'' over the potential change in the Middle East balance of power in a response to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's announcement Saturday that he would recommend to President Reagan the sale of more arms to Jordan. (A1:3.)

title: Pacers 107 Trail Blazers
description: Johnny Davis sco red 25 points to lead Indiana,wh ich went ahead for good, 22-21, with 10:13 left in the second qu arter on a layup by George McGinnis. The Pacers increased their le ad to 68-57 on a free throw by Louis Orr, and Portland got no cl oser than 7 points.

title: Successful Eye Surgery for Betty Comden
description: For years Betty Comden made her way around New York in a fog, the victim of a hereditary eye disease that impaired her vision. Yesterday the 62-year-old lyricist and scriptwriter was casting a clear eye on familiar surroundings. ''It's extraordinary - I could see right away,'' said Miss Comden, who underwent a corneal transplant on her right eye at the Eye and Ear Hospital in Pittsburgh last Tuesday.

title: 10th GRADERS LEARN BY TEACHING KINDERGARTENERS
description: They pass each other constantly in the corridors, on the stairways and in the lunchroom, but normally the high-school students and kindergarten pupils at the Lenox School have little communication. ''The teen-agers pat the little ones on the head and remark, 'Oh, aren't they cute,' '' said Zeva E. Spiegler. ''And the younger ones resent that; they want to be regarded as fellow students.''

title: EARLY MUSIC: GRANDE BANDE PLAYS HAYDN
description: PERHAPS the Ensemble for Early Music's Grande Bande devoted most of its rehearsal time to only one work on the program at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night. But for whatever reason, aside from Haydn's Symphony No. 44, there were enough problems with both execution and spirit in the program of Haydn compositions celebrating the 250th anniversary of the composer's birth to make it more a duty than a pleasure to pay close attention.

title: NORTH CAROLINA TOPS GEORGIA
description: James Worthy scored 19 points today to lead North Carolina to a 66-57 victory over Georgia. North Carolina (20-2), ranked second in both national wire-service polls last week, led by 44-35 early in the second half. Georgia cut the deficit to 48-47 with 9 minutes 25 seconds to play. But Worthy hit a pair of free throws for a 3-point lead, and when the Tar Heels regained possession, they implemented their fourcorners delay offense.

title: Around the Nation; Passenger on Jet Seeks $850,000 for Boston Skid
description: A passenger on a World Airways DC-10 that slid off a runway into Boston Harbor last month has filed a $850,000 lawsuit charging ''negligence and carelessness'' by the flight crew.

title: Daphne Verley Bride Of R. E. Pietrafesa 2d
description: Daphne Madeleine Verley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alain Verley of Cazenovia, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Edward Pietrafesa 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Pietrafesa of Fayetteville, N.Y. The Rev. Thierry Verley, brother of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Fayetteville.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA WINS NO. 4
description: Martina Navratilova won her fourth consecutive tournament on the Avon tennis circuit today with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Barbara Potter.

title: FRANCE BEGINS $8 BILLION TAKEOVER OF PRIVATE INDUSTRY AND BANKING
description: France's Socialist Government began taking control of a huge slice of the country's privately owned industry and banking this weekend.

title: Polite Rebuff Wins
description: Angel Cordero brought Polite Rebuff from off the early pace to a four-length victory yesterday in the $54,100 Ruthless Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: HOWARD M. BLACKWELL
description: Howard M. Blackwell, retired vice president of Pan American World Airways, died Wednesday in North Beach Hospital, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 69 years old and had been living in Fort Lauderdale in retirement. Previously he was a resident of Point Pleasant, N.J. Mr. Blackwe ll is survived by his wife, Anne; a son, Richard of Mountainside, N.J., and two grandchildren.

title: Required Reading The Right to Vote
description: Vilma S. Martinez, president and general counsel of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, testifying before the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on the Constitution about the Voting Rights Act. Jan. 27, 1982:

title: Japanese Buy Firestone Plant
description: A Japanese tire company confirmed today th at it will buy a Firestone plant that employs 1,000 people.

title: Penn 79, Harvard 62
description: Willie Oliphant scored 14 points and led a second-half surge for Pennsylvania in its Ivy victory. Don Fleming had 21 points for Harvard (8-11 and 3-4 in the Ivy League). Penn (10-9 and 5-3) scored 18 of the last 24 points in the game.

title: Miss Stacy Scores
description: Hollis Stacy held off a challenge by Patty Sheehan by shooting a five-under-par 67 today to win a $125,000 tournament.

title: Congress; EVEN ELEVATOR MUSIC IS ELECTION YEAR
description: A new political show opened on Capitol Hill last week, and it could be called ''Who's to Blame ?'' Last year, the question that dominated Congressional debate over economic policy was, ''Will the President's program work ?'' Many members, Democrats as well as Republicans, however, never even reached that issue, but simply asked, ''Doesn't the President deserve a chance ?'' The overwhelming answer was yes.

title: 'BORN YE 11TH DAY OF FEBRUARY 1731-2'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruins 2, Oilers 2
description: Dave Lumley's goal on a 10-foot wrist shot with 1:35 remaining enabled Edmonton to tie Boston in a hard-hitting, close-checking game.

title: BRIDGEMARKET'S INVITATION TO UNFAIR COMPETITION
description: To the Editor:

title: CULTURAL INSTITUTIONS OF PHILADELPHIA FEEL EFFECTS OF A TROUBLED ECONOMY
description: No one is singing the blues yet at the 125-year-old Academy of Music, the palatial home of the Philadelphia Orchestra and the setting for opulent opera performances. Nevertheless, a vague sense of uneasiness has invaded its back offices as executives hear echoes of hard times among sister institutions and their cousins.

title: CELTICS BEAT LAKERS BY 108-103
description: Larry Bird, frustrated offensively most of the game, scored on a 3-point play with 19 seconds remaining to help the Boston Celtics to a 108-103 victory over the Lakers today.

title: DRIVERS OF THE WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCUSTOMED POVERTY INTENSIFYING RURAL MAINE
description: Gertrude Spearin, a gnome of a woman with only a few teeth left, was trying to shovel away the four feet of snow that had buried her mailbox.

title: COURT STUDYING CASE OF CASINOS VERSUS COUNTERS
description: Six justices of the New Jersey Supreme Court have been hearing a case involving two government agencies that disagree on how to handle skillful blackjack players who can sometimes beat the house at Atlantic City's casinos.

title: Europeans May Act on Japan Trade
description: Impatient with the lack of progress in curbing Japan's big trade surplus with Europe, the European Commission has proposed lodging a formal trade complaint against Japan under article 23 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, Common Market sources said.

title: DEBATE OVER WILDERNESS AREA LEASING INTENSIFIES
description: Just outside the border of a sanctuary for the vanishing California condor, a mountaintop is dominated by a cluster of massive oil pumps that themselves resemble great birds of prey as they peck endlessly at the earth.

title: Andrea Negroni Bride of U Aung
description: Andrea Lee Negroni, daughter of Dione L. Negroni of Merritt Island, Fla., and Jaime L. Negroni of Ensenada, P.R., was married yesterday to U Aung, son of U Nu, former Prime Minister of Burma, and Daw Mya Yee of Rangoon. The nondenominational ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by the Rev. Albert Ahlstrom, the university's Lutheran chaplain.

title: Kuwait Offers a P.O.W. Plan
description: Kuwait is prepared in principle to be a staging point for families visiting prisoners captured in the Iraqi-Iranian war, a Government spokesman said today. Iraq and Iran announced agreement in principle last month for visits by families of prisoners taken during the 17-month-old Persian Gulf war.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday This will be an unusually quiet week in Washington, almost as quiet as the dog days of August. Today is an official Government holiday, in honor of Washington's Birthday, with most Government offices closed; the Senate and House are in recess all week for the Lincoln-Washington holidays; the Supreme Court is in midwinter recess. President Reagan has little that is official on his schedule until Wednesday, when he will meet with Prime Minister Wilfried Martens of Belgium, who is to be in town for three days. Mr. Martens will be seeing the President both in his capacity as Prime Minister and as the current President of the European Community Council, which is worried about high interest rates and steel trade with the United States. Nancy Reagan leaves today on a two-day trip to Tampa, Fla., and Dallas to take a look at drug-prevention and treatment programs, spotlighting a problem about which she has expressed concern. Members of the Cabinet will be traveling this week as well. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Vice President Bush will try for better ties with organized labor when they drop in on the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Executive Council meeting in Miami. Later in the week, Secretary of Energy James B. Edwards is going to Idaho Falls for several speeches, a Lincoln dinner and a little political arm-twisting. He hopes to get Senator James A. McClure's support for the bill that would dismantle the Energy Department, a measure that the Idaho Republican, who heads the Energy Committee, does not at the moment favor. Old Soldiers: The American Legion, one of the largest and most powerful veterans' organizations, begins a three-day conference at the Capitol Hilton Hotel this morning. It will take a look at subjects as varied as veterans' rehabilitation and international terrorism. The Legion leadership, intent on maintaining benefit programs, will see the President on Tuesday. Tuesday Energy-related associations and professional groups, 8,000 strong, join forces at the Sheraton Washington Hotel for a three-day conference and exposition on ''Energy Efficiency in the 1980's.'' Scheduled: Two hundred speeches. Vice President Bush and Engergy Secretary Edwards will carry the Administration's message to the meeting. 9:30 A.M., ballroom. Wednesday Latest figures on new housing starts are due today. A combination of weather and high mortgage rates makes for little optimism. Play It Again: In a continuing series of meetings on Capitol Hill, David A. Stockman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will give members of the House Budget Committee an overview of the Administration's proposed 1983 budget. 10 A.M., room 210, Cannon Office Building. Thursday Norman Ture, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Tax and Economic Affairs, Irving Kristol, the editor and new conservative, and others will argue that the concept of ''supply-side economics'' has been around for a long time and is not a new invention, when they gather for an economic policy conference sponsored by the Heritage Foundation and Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation. 9 A.M., Quality Inn on Capitol Hill. Friday Personal income data for January come out today. Wages and salaries, major components of this index, have recently been declining. So it is probable that the new figure will indicate a futher slowing of the economy.

title: Around the World; Mobil Oil Rig Listing Off Nova Scotia Coast
description: A Mobil Oil drilling rig was listing 15 degrees in a storm in the North Atlantic early Monday, and 34 men were preparing to abandon the platform, the Halifax rescue center reported.

title: A Song in Their Hearts
description: She was a mezzo-soprano who came to the Glyndebourne Festival to sing, and he was a director who was there to direct. That fateful production of ''Cosi fan tutte'' was back in 1978, and if it wasn't love at first song, it wasn't long before Maria Ewing and Sir Peter Hall found they had more than Mozart in common.

title: Clerc Is Winner
description: Jose-Luis Clerc dropped the first set, then recovered to beat Fritz Buehning, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, in the final of the $300,000 Richmond World Championship Tennis tournament today. The first prize was $100,000.

title: Study Finds Car Ownership Costs Most in Los Angeles
description: Los Angeles drivers paid the most per mile, 57.9 cents, to own and operate their automobiles in 1981, and Detroit was the cheapest place to drive among the nation's 20 largest cities, according to an annual survey by the Hertz Corporation.

title: News Analysis
description: The continuing differences between Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger seem so obvious to some ranking officials that they say the effective management of the Reagan Administration's foreign policy is being threatened.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1982; Energy
description: Congress shows little interest in abolishing the Department of Energy, a step that has long been sought by the President. Key House and Senate members object to the move, and many others find it politically unappealing. (D1.)

title: KNICKS DROP 2ND IN ROW TO 76ERS, 117-105
description: The Knicks are a very good basketball team - for at least 40 minutes. However, a game lasts 48, and in those final eight minutes they are often plagued by thoughtless execution and breakdowns on defense.

title: Princeton 59 Dartmouth 45
description: Kevin Mullen scored 16 points, 13 in the second half, to lead Princeton. Gary Knapp and Craig Robinson had 12 points each for the Tigers.

title: SYRIANS REPORTING KEY ROAD IS OPEN
description: The Syrian authorities said today that they had reopened the main highway running through the embattled city of Hama, but that troops were still rooting out die-hard insurgents from narrow alleys and underground catacombs in the ancient quarter.

title: Anna Panayotou Bride of Martin Gold
description: Anna Eve Pa nayotou, an associate with the New York law firm of Simpson, That cher & Bartlett, was married yesterday to Martin Elliot Gold, directo r of corporate law and chief of the economic developmentdivision of t he New York City Corporation Counsel's office. Criminal Court Judge E rnest Bianchi performed the ceremony at the Tavern-onthe- Green.

title: VC RECOVERY
description: To the Editor:

title: JUGGLE THE BOUNCING BALL
description: Eight days ago, Alan Nyanjong Abuto of Kenya juggled and bounced a soccer ball for almost half a day, keeping it off the ground for 11 hours 36 minutes 19 seconds. His feat, performed in Kennedy Gymnasium at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., before hundreds of students and faculty, will be submitted to Guinness Book of World Records for accreditation.

title: RANGERS RALLY TO DEFEAT NORDIQUES,5-2
description: The Rangers received a standing ovation when they took the ice last night, but after 38 minutes many fans appeared ready to retract that greeting as the Rangers trailed the Quebec Nordiques by 2-0. Then the Rangers scored three goals in the next five minutes and finished strongly to post a 5-2 victory - and receive another standing ovation.

title: KRIEK TOPS MCENROE IN FINAL
description: Johan Kriek defeated John McEnroe, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4, today for the United States national indoor tennis championship.

title: Life on Ice
description: The word ''columbarium,'' usually used for the vaults in which the ashes of the dead are stored, is derived from the Latin for dovecote. Since dovecote does not imply death - only niches - columbarium could also be used to describe a bank housing frozen human embryos and fertilized eggs. Australia has such a depository; Dr. Patrick Steptoe, a pioneer in in vitro fertilization, plans another in Britain. Actually, columbarium is more appropriate for an egg bank than it is for dead storage, doves being at various times fledglings, embryos and eggs.

title: Spurs 114, Sonics 94
description: SAN ANTONIO (AP) - Mark Olberding scored 25 points and Dave Corzine, a reserve center, had a season-high 23 points and 12 rebounds to lead San Antonio.

title: SCRIPPS EXECUTIVE
description: Mark Ferree, an executive of the Scripps-Howard newspaper chain for more than 25 years, died Saturday at his home here, apparently of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: NEW MANAGER OF YONKERS SEES NO 'BED OF ROSES'
description: A courtly, white-haired university administrator who has spent part of the last four years organizing such seminars as ''New Fiscal Realities'' and ''Labor Relations'' now has his chance to practice what he preached.

title: Around the World; Soviet Premier Gloomy; On Relations With U.S.
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov of the Soviet Union, making an unusually gloomy assessment, says there are no signs that United States-Soviet relations are moving in a ''favorable direction.''

title: BOBBY ALLISON WINS AT DAYTONA FOR 2ND TIME
description: Bobby Allison, who lost the 1981 Grand National driving title to Darrell Waltrip, benefited today when Waltrip's car blew its engine with 125 miles left, and Allison went on to win the Daytona 500 for a second time.

title: Pitt 69, Duquesne 68
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Andre Williams tipped in a field goal with 29 seconds to go for the victory margin in the Eastern Eight game.

title: Long Shot Beats Super Moment
description: Score Twenty Four, who had won only two minor stakes races and had gone off at odds of 13 to 1, scored a 2 1/2-length upset victory today in the $214,200 San Antonio Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: Landmark Store Closes
description: Maison Blanche, the ornate, turn-ofthe-century department store on Canal Street, was closed Saturday. Goudchaux Department Stores of Baton Rouge had bought Maison Blanche, but will operate only its three suburban branches.

title: Dr. Naomi Kaplan Is Wed To Dr. John S. Tamerin
description: At Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester in Chappaqua, N.Y., yesterday, Dr. Naomi G. Kaplan of Chappaqua, a pathologist and director of laboratories at the Peekskill (N.Y.) Community Hospital, was married to Dr. John Samuel Tamerin of Greenwich, Conn., a psychiatrist. Rabbi Chaim Stern performed the ceremony.

title: Surveyor of the Course
description: Jeff Simke was applying for a new job last October: The 26-yearold Florida State graduate who majored in hotel management prepared a three-page resume, wore a business suit that he calls ''Eastern conservative'' and underwent an intense 90-minute interview. He got the job.

title: Impressionists at C. W. Post
description: ''A Century of American Impressionism,'' an exhibition of more than 110 paintings by more than 70 artists, will be on view through Feb. 28 at the art gallery of the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University, Northern Boulevard and Route 25A, in Greenvale, L.I. The artists include Mary Cassatt, Childe Hassam, Maurice Prendergast and John Henry Twachtman.

title: Bridge: Over the Years, a Sequence In Bids Gets New Meaning
description: The traditional meaning of one common bidding sequence has undergone a shift in recent years. It starts with one no-trump, and after a Stayman response reaches two hearts like this:

title: FTLP: FREE TRANSLATION, LINGO, PENTAGON
description: Since the days of the early New Deal, Washington has seen steady growth in the creation, use and perhaps misuse of abbreviations, initials and acronyms. No agency of Government has been immune.

title: 4,000 EAST GERMANS DISPUTE OFFICIAL DEFENSE POLICY
description: A youthful crowd of about 4,000 took part in a public discussion of peace and disarmament in Dresden, East Germany, Saturday in the first such meeting in which official East German defense policies were called into question.

title: Great Western Appeal
description: The Great Western Sugar Company plans to seek a new trial after a Federal court jury recommended Thursday that the company and the Hunt brothers of Dallas pay up to $25 million for breaching contracts with sugar beet growers. Jack A. Fulton, spokesman for Great Western, issued a statement Saturday calling the jury recommendation ''improper'' and said the company would seek a new trial or appeal. The suit, a class action by growers in five states, alleged that Great Western had failed to pay growers their share of an estimated $51.4 million in profits on futures trading.

title: M Is for the Mess the Children Make
description: When 18-year-old Beth Shaver returned from school the other day in San Ramon, Calif., she saw her dirty laundry piled high on the front porch next to a sign that read:

title: Why Washington?
description: Why, of all the Founding Fathers, remember George Washington? Thomas Jefferson, the ardent democrat and master of arts, seems more a 20th-century man, and recognizable heritors of James Madison can be glimpsed today in the higher courts and lecture halls of New Haven and Cambridge. Washington seems to recede into historical mists.

title: Fu el Oil Costs Down in City
description: The average costs for heavy heating oil used in New York City apartment houses have fallen below levels of a year ago, the first year-to-year decline since the Consumer Affairs Department started monitoring energy prices in October 1979.

title: Soviet Buys U.S. Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 350,000 metric tons of American corn for delivery through Sept. 30, the Agriculture Department said. Officials also reported Friday sales of 250,000 tons of wheat to China that had been listed as going to ''unknown'' destinations. With the latest sales, the Soviet Union has bought nearly 11.2 million tons of American grain - more than 5.8 million wheat and 5.35 million corn - for delivery in 1981-82.

title: G.M. VS ITS WORKERS
description: General Motors wants to cut my pay. That d oesn't surprise me. G.M. has always wanted to cut my pay.

title: POLISHING THE IMAGE IN JERSEY
description: In the age of image, New Jersey has a problem. The barbs and cuts come from all quarters, but are sharpest closest to home. Woody Allen, a New Yorker, once wrote: ''A certain intelligence governs our universe, except in certain parts of New Jersey.''

title: Two Men Charged In Robbery-Killing
description: Two men have been arrested and charged in the shooting death last Dec. 10 of a woman in the lobby of her East Side apartment building.

title: TRIAL RAISES QUESTIONS ON TEXAS PRISON CONDITIONS
description: The trial of an inmate in the slaying of a warden has brought out some disturbing allegations against prison officials.

title: OF INTEREST, INFLATION, TAXES AND 'FREE MONEY'
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: JOHNNY CARSON REVISITS OLD NEBRASKA HOME
description: FOR the first half of ''Johnny Goes Home,'' Johnny Carson's 90-minute special on NBC-TV tonight at 9, it's hard to imagine any but his most rabid fans - the sort who consider him an honorary member of the family after his 20 years as host of ''The Tonight Show'' - being much moved.

title: POLES ARREST 194 TO CRUSH PROTEST IN CITY OF POZNAN
description: The police arrested 194 people in the western city of Poznan Saturday when they tried to hold a demonstration to protest martial law, the Warsaw radio said today.

title: GLUYAS WILLIAMS, CARTOONIST
description: Gluyas Williams, a former cartoonist for The New Yorker magazine who satirized suburbanites, died Saturday in Hahnemann Hospital in Boston. He was 93 years old and lived in West Newton, Ma ss.

title: WELL, IT SEEMED LIKE A GOOD IDEA
description: Political and art critics of more than a century ago were aghast when Horatio Greenough's marble statue of George Washington was unveiled at the Capitol.

title: Levi Victor by Shot
description: Wayne Levi made a four-foot putt to save par on the 17th hole, then parred the 18th to win the $325,000 Hawaiian Open golf tournament by a stroke today.

title: BUSINESS CLIMATE WARM IN SAN DIEGO
description: Four new office buildings are nearing completion in the central business district that rims San Diego Bay. As the first new towers to be built here in seven years, they are symbols of this city's economic surge.

title: JOBS SCARCE FOR UNSKILLED APPLICANTS
description: Only a small fraction of help-wanted advertisements in New York State's newspapers are for so-called entry-level jobs, and each of these is attracting nearly 23 applicants, according to a survey sponsored by State Department of Labor.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a computation error at the Hayden Planetarium, the Alma- nac section of the Weather Forecasts and Records from Feb. 1 through Feb. 8 listed incorrect times for the rising and setting of Mars. The correct times will be found today on page D8.

title: THE VALUE OF A PH.D.
description: ''Everybody knows'' that a Ph.D. is a poor f inancial investment for a college graduate. The cost-benefit c alculation in dollars is simple. And if the doctorate is an u neconomic pursuit, it stands to reason that graduate programs shouldn ot be supported by alumni gifts or subsidized by Government grants.

title: 5 Are Injured in Derailment
description: An Amtrak train bound from Washington to Montreal jumped the tracks in a remote section of Holyoke today, slightly injuring five of the more than 150 persons aboard, officials said. The train was rounding a curve 10 miles north of Springfield.

title: Good, Clean Hockey
description: Rick Middleton, the right wing for the Boston Bruins who has averaged more than 40 goals and 53 assists in each of the last three seasons, is more than just a scoring machine. He has become one of the National Hockey League's premier wings by improving offensively and defensively since he entered the league in 1974.

title: Article 246430 -- No Title
description: Next year - as in the old Brooklyn Dodger baseball war cry, ''Wait till next year'' - may be getting closer. The State Legislature has approved $30,000 in a supplemental deficiency budget to make a feasibility study of a domed sports stadium for Brooklyn.

title: WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY
description: Washington's Birthday will be ob- served today (though the actual date is Feb. 22).

title: USAir Pay Talks Continue
description: Representatives of USAir and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters continued negotiations today after the midnight deadline for a strike threatened by nearly 900 baggage handlers and fleet service personnel in Boston, Buffalo, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh. USAir officials said that there would be no interruption in service if a strike occurred.

title: RIGHT-TO-TAPE BATTLE FORMING
description: In the simplest terms, it's a battle between Hollywood and Tokyo, although the lobbyists on both sides are quick to call such a characterization a bit misleading.

title: China Warns U.S. May Face 'Another Vietnam' in Salvador
description: China criticized President Reagan's policy on El Salvador today, accusing United States-backed troops of ''slaughtering'' civilians and warning that the Americans could face ''another Vietnam.''

title: THE VIETNAM BURDEN OF U.S.  MILITARY CHIEFS
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADIAN TAR SANDS: HOPE AND CHALLENGE
description: The thick muskeg, now frozen, rests on 50 feet of clay and rock in Northwestern Canada. Beneath that geologically mixed cover lies a vast mass of black sand with an untapped energy potential. Whether the potential will be realized may depend on the outcome of a meeting Wednesday in a distant board room.

title: FERNANDO VALERA, SPANISH REPUBLICAN WHO LED EXILE UNIT
description: Fernando Valera, the last president of the Spanish Republic's government-in-exile, died Saturday after a long illness, family members said. He was 83 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in Metropolitan Report in some editions on Friday incorrectly described the conviction of Arnold Iannacone in connection with the slaying of Anthony Fiore, a Citibank vice president. Mr. Iannacone was convicted of second-degree manslaughter.

title: JOHN PAUL, IN NIGERIA, ENCOUNTERS POLES
description: Pope John Paul II was greeted by several hundred Poles, waving flags and singing Polish hymns, as he rode in an open car today through multitudes of Nigerians who had flocked here to celebrate mass with him.

title: Miss Busch Wins Gold in Skating
description: Karin Busch and Andrea Schoene of East Germany overcame the Olympic champion, Natalya Petruseva of the Soviet Union, to win the gold and silver medals in the world speed skating championships today.

title: MAVERICKS HALT NETS'STREAK
description: Jay Vincent, a rookie forward, and Wayne Cooper, a journeyman forward turned center, helped the Dallas Mavericks stop the Nets' winning streak at four games today.

title: LEONARD SEES EARLY KNOCKOUT
description: ''Reno,'' said Sugar Ray Leonard, ''is not a place for gambling. It's a place for love and fights.'' Leonard's comments came today in the garish setting of a gambling casino at the ''unofficial'' weigh-in for his fight Monday night against Bruce Finch, Leonard's first defense of the world welterweight championship he won by stopping Thomas Hearns last September.

title: To Ronald Shelp
description: June Mueller Peno, widow of Joseph David Peno,, and Ronald Kent Shelp, vice president of the American International Group, were married yesterday. The Rev. Gerald W. Porter performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension.

title: Swiss Triumphs
description: Switzerland's Doris De Agostini won the final women's downhill race on the World Cup schedule today. Her time was 1:36.67, which was 26-hundredths of a second faster than that of her teammate, Maria Waliser. Canada's Gerry Sorensen, the world downhill champion, rallied to take third in 1:37.10.

title: NATO CHIEF SEEKS A RISE IN ARMS OUTLAYS BY THE EUROPEANS
description: Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, the supreme commander of allied forces in Europe, said today that he would call on NATO defense ministers to set a real growth rate of 4 percent a year as a goal for alliance forces for the period from 1983 to 1988.

title: Bucks 125, Cavaliers 97
description: Marques Johnson scored a season-high 30 points, connecting on 13 of 14 shots, as Milwaukee won its ninth straight game. The Bucks scored the game's first 8 points and were never in trouble, as they led by 63-45 at halftime.

title: VOLCKER SAYS RATE RISE IS DUE TO HUGE DEFICITS
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that big Government budget deficits were the cause of high interest rates. He added that continued heavy Federal borrowing would jeopardize any sustained recovery from the recession.

title: Agricultural Problem Seen
description: Despite current surpluses, United States agricultural markets may face serious pressure in the future because of demands from domestic consumers and foreign buyers and the use of crops for fuel, according to a report released today.

title: U.S. MISSIONARY SLAIN OUTSIDE GUATEMALAN SCHOOL
description: A 37-year-old American missionary from Wisconsin was killed outside his school in western Guatemala by four unidentified gunmen, United States Embassy officials here said today.

title: NEW HAVEN WANTS YALE TO INVEST IN CITY PROJECT
description: Jolted twice lately by shocks to downtown development plans, New Haven city officials want Yale University to invest part of its $800 million endowment in an $80 million downtown redevelopment project.

title: 'BORN YE 11TH DAY OF FEBRUARY 1731-2
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Turks Set Restrictions On Foreign Contacts
description: The military junta banned unions and professional groups today from having contacts with foreigners unless they have prior permission.

title: S.W.C. to Study Punching Incident
description: Southwest Conference faculty representatives said today that they would continue to investigate the incident involving Darrell Walker, an Arkansas basketball player who had been ejected from a game for hitting an opponent.

title: SALVADOR PRELATE CONCERNED OVER NUNS' CASE
description: The senior Roman Catholic Church leader in El Salvador said today that he hoped that court action taken against five National Guard soldiers in the murder of four American churchwomen was not just a gesture intended to justify further United States aid.

title: NICARAGUANS CHALLENGE U.S.: PROVE YOUR CHARGES
description: The Nicaraguan Government has accused the Reagan Administration of issuing ''lies and half-truths'' against the 30-month-old revolution and has challenged Washington to prove its charges that Nicaragua is shipping arms to Salvadoran guerrillas.

title: HOW STRATFORD, ONTARIO, SURVIVED A STORMY YEAR
description: ''WHEN I was young in Budapest in World War II,'' said John Hirsch, ''the Russians were always bombing the city by day and the Americans and British bombed us at night.'' ''Between waves, you could come up for a breath of air before the next attack. That's the way I felt at Stratford last year.''

title: STATE MAY REQUIRE UTILITIES TO ABSORB PART OF OVERRUNS
description: Can a carrot-and-stick approach build and finance a $4.9 billion nuclear power plant? And if it can, will investors go along?

title: FLYERS SUBDUE KINGS
description: Ron Flockhart and Brian Propp, linemates, scored two goals apiece as the Philadelphia Flyers extended their eight-year undefeated string against Los Angeles with a 6-4 victory in the National Hockey League tonight.

title: DRUSE IN GOLAN START A STRIKE OVER ARREST OF 4 CHIEFS BY ISRAEL
description: The Israeli authorities arrested four local Druse leaders over the weekend, and today the Druse in the Golan Heights began an indefinite general strike in protest.

title: SONG RECITAL: MARTIN BEST
description: THE seven centuries of song preceding 19th-century lieder and arias are blatantly ignored in our seasonal deluge of vocal recitals. But the songs of the 12th through the 18th century weren't written for the concert hall or opera house.

title: MAHRES FIRST AND SECOND
description: PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Feb. 14 (AP) - Phil and Steve Mahre, the 24-year-old twins from Yakima, Wash., are returning home with one world championship title, one World Cup crown and eight World Cup victories.

title: Judi-Ellen Dash Is Wed to Banker
description: Judi-Ellen Dash, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dash of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Frank Javier Amador Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Amador of Caracas, Venezuela. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Philip Berkowitz at the couple's apartment in North Bergen, N.J.

title: Briefing
description: Sartorial Subsidy

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We got a triple-A bond rating, lakes, mountains, 127 miles of shoreline, the Las Vegas of the East, two major sports franchises and a race track that's beating the pants off New York.

title: WHAT AN ETHIOPIAN MUST DO TO PROVE DESERVING OF ASYLUM
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Boy Attacked by Cougar Is in Stable Condition
description: A 9-year-old boy who was attacked at an auto show by a live cougar used as a promotional prop by Lincoln-Mercury underwent surgery for severe neck wounds and was listed in stable condition today, hospital officials said.

title: Taiwan-Japan Trade
description: Taiwan has announced a ban on the import of 1,500 Japanese consumer products as a move toward redressing its trade imbalance with Japan.

title: OPEC Talks May Be Held
description: Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, president of OPEC, is discussing the possibility of calling a special meeting to survey the weak oil market, the official news agency said today.

title: Barbara Billauer, Lawyer, Married to David Love
description: Barbara Pfeffer Billauer, a lawyer with the New York firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle, and David Love, first deputy commissioner of the New York City Department of Transportation, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Louis Gerstein at the Spanish Portuguese Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: JAZZ: WELLSTOOD-DAVERN-ROSENGARDEN TRIO
description: PAUL J. WEINSTEIN is a jazz fan who does not think it should be necessary to stay up late and go to smoke-filled rooms to hear jazz. Several years ago, as an alternative, he initiated the once-a-month ''Heavenly Jazz'' series at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th Street and Fifth Avenue, on Sundays at 5 P.M. Now he has started another early, smokeless jazz series at the New School at 6 P.M., one Friday a month.

title: Rockies 5, Capitals 3
description: DENVER (AP) - Aaron Broten's seventh goal of the year broke a 3-3 tie and sent Colorado on to victory. Broten tipped in a slap shot by Steve Tambellini at 13:29 of the third period, which proved to be the game-winner.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner QUESTION: In a professional basketball game, the player dribbling the ball bounces it accidentally off the foot of the opponent who is guarding him. Is this a kicked ball?

title: TOM SEAVER AGAIN A MET?
description: NOW that George Foster has been measured for a uniform, the Mets' new owners and their general manager, Frank Cashen, should be thinking ahead to another trade with the Cincinnati Reds, one that would mean that the magic really is back, one that would put Tom Seaver back in his Mets uniform.

title: U.S. SAYS SCHOOLS IMPROPERLY BANKED GRANTS
description: Federal auditors have recommended that the Government try to recover $219 million in interest that they say scores of colleges improperly earned by banking Federal funds that should have been spent immediately.

title: CITY'S FUND TO BROADEN INVESTMENT
description: New York City's employee retirement funds, whose purchases of municipal bonds were crucial to the city's financial rescue in the 1970's, are planning to invest in multimillion-dollar construction loans as well as to continue buying high-yielding home mortgages on property in the city.

title: THE GUIDE
description: REMEMBERING WASHINGTON

title: Aircraft Carrier in Home Port After 3 Years of Overhauling
description: The Enterprise, the world's first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, was back in San Francisco Bay today after three years of overhauling.

title: ROGERS IS PROVING HIS POINT
description: TWICE in his eight years as a professional hockey player, Mike Rogers, now the Rangers' leading scorer, felt he had proved his scoring and playmaking skills. So twice he decided to settle down for the rest of his life where he found himself playing.

title: Man Held in Hijack Attempt
description: A man who said he wanted to hijack a Braniff International jet boarded the empty plane and locked himself in the cockpit until Federal agents talked him into surrendering early today, the police said. The man, who was not identified, was being held in the Amarillo jail. He did not have any weapons and no one was hurt, the authorities said.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT WHALERS FOR 12TH IN A ROW, 9 TO 1
description: The Islanders romped to their 12th consecutive victory today, defeating the Hartford Whalers, 9-1. Four players scored two goals each.

title: Books Of The Times
