description: By Mary Cantwell IMAGINARY CRIMES, by Sheila Ballan- tyne. Viking. 265 pages. $13.95.

title: THE YOUNGEST GLOBETROTTER
description: THE Harlem Globetrotters are a show team, and they win every game they play, but Lionel Garrett had to play the best basketball of his life to make the team. Surviving that tryout camp in California - 50 men fighting for five spaces - let him say that he and his teammates are more than a comedy act that beats the Washington Generals every night and twice on holidays.

title: CITY DEPLOYING GUARD DOGS TO PATROL BUILDINGS IN PARKS
description: The Parks Department is using German shepherd dogs to guard some of its most frequently vandalized buildings and other parks facilities in Brooklyn, as part of a major reorganization of its security operations.

title: Saudi Telephone Order
description: NV Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken said it and Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson had received a 425 million guilder order for an extension of the telephone network in Saudi Arabia. This brings total Saudi telephone network orders for the companies' joint venture to 11.5 billion guilders since 1977. The most recent order is for an automatic mobile telephone network, Phil ips said.

title: OIL WEALTH WORRIES IVORY COAST LEADER
description: This West African country, one of the most prosperous in the third world, is on the verge of an oil boom. Within two or three years, the Ivory Coast will start to export crude oil from its sizable offshore reserves. But industrial activity in this French-oriented capital city has already become frenetic.

title: OUR ITALIAN CONNECTION
description: At a time when Britain is growing weaker, West G ermany is proving to be an unreliable and even duplicitous ally, andF rance is drawn to a Gallic-Socialist brand of independence, Italy h as become an unusually crucial American partner in Europe and the M editerranean.

title: CONGRESSIONAL PANELS TO REVIEW MINE SAFETY
description: Two Congressional committees are beginning the first public review in four years of occupational safety in coal mining, the most hazardous of all industrial vocations.

title: FORD PACT BACKED BY UNION'S BOARD
description: The International Executive Board of the United Automobile Workers today unanimously approved a tentative agreement between the union and the Ford Motor Company that will result in wage and benefit concessions by workers in return for assurances of increased job security.

title: SOLVING PROBLEMS ON THE JOB
description: T HEY call on their lunch hours, speaking softly into the telephone so the others in the office will not hear. They do not say who they are or where they work, and no one asks. The details of their stories vary and yet there is a common theme: ''My boss makes me so angry, I feel like quitting.''

title: VOWS TO PRESS ITS SOVEREIGNTY FIGHT
description: After patching up a split over tactics, Quebec's ruling Parti Quebecois ended a special convention here today determined to make the largely French-speaking province independent after the next election.

title: Malaysia to Resettle 30,000
description: Thirty-thousand families will be resettled on farms to grow rubber trees and oil palms under a $287.3 million rural development program, the Government said today. It said the settlers would be given land titles after they began producing crops.

title: THEATER: VIGNETTES BY A.R.GUR NEY JR.
description: IN one of the many vignettes that make up A.R. Gurney Jr.'s new play, ''The Dining Room,'' an aunt proudly poses with her collection of Waterford crystal for a photo-snapping nephew. The aunt is all smiles and coos. She's most pleased that the nephew has left his studies at Amherst to come down and take her picture.

title: SCHMIDT REBUFFED ON MISSILE PLAN
description: A regional Social Democratic Party conference adopted a motion today rejecting the deployment of Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe, and called on Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Government to end preparations for basing them in West Germany.

title: EDWARD KAHN
description: Edward Kahn, a retired vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Wednesday of cancer at his home in Doylestown, Pa.

title: The Costa Rican Difference
description: Costa Rica's condition can be tersely summed up: worthy, democratic and broke. In no other Central American country are free elections and the orderly rotation of power taken for granted. So nobody doubts that the recently elected Luis Alberto Monge will take office as President in May, putting his left-of-center party in power once again. But what are his and Costa Rica's prospects if the bottom falls out of the economy?

title: Around the World; Pentecostalist in Soviet Calls Off Hunger Strike
description: Avgustina Vashchenko, the 52-year-old Pentecostalist who started a hunger strike seven weeks ago with her daughter while they were in sanctuary at the United State Embassy here, said today that she had ended her fast.

title: HEAVYWEIGHT BEATEN IN 1957 TITLE BOUT
description: Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, the Rockaway Beach heavyweight who lost a bid for the world championship in 1957, died yesterday morning at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens. He was 50 years old.

title: MORE WOMEN DECIDE TO BECOME OBSTETRICIANS
description: As recently as 1970 many women who decided that they wanted to be treated by fe@male obstetrician-gynecologists had a difficult time finding one. When they did manage to do so they were often told something like: ''Sorry, the doctor isn't taking any new patients. She has too many already.''

title: Critics to Continue Fight on St. Bart's
description: Parishioners who oppose plans by St. Bartholomew's Church to lease part of its land for a 59-story office building said they would continue to fight the project despite its approval by the Episcopal Bishop of New York.

title: 2 ARRESTED IN CHICAGO'S SEARCH FOR KILLERS OF POLICE
description: A street-by-street search by police officers for the killers of two of their comrades resulted today in the arrests of two suspects.

title: RETARDED TEEN-AGE GIRL MISSING
description: An 18-year-old mentally retarded girl has been missing since leaving Julia Richman High School in Manhattan on Wednesday. She was last seen by a teacher that afternoon.

title: CONCERT: I NUOVI VIRTUOSI
description: THE name I Virtuosi di Roma is almost synon ymous with the 20thcentury's rediscovery of the Italian Baro que. This marriage of performer to music, made a generation ago, se emed a happy one -the elegance and style of a small virtuoso string ensemble perfectly complementing the then less-known personaliti es of Vivaldi, Corelli and their contemporaries.

title: THE NIGHT IS FILLED WITH STARS FOR ACTORS' FUND BENEFIT GALA
description: A ''Night of 100 Stars'' lit up the cavernous stage of Radio City Music Hall last night with twofold glitter. As word had spread about the event - a benefit for the 100-year-old Actors' Fund of America - more and more entertainers had asked to join the roster. And by show time, it had become a night of 200 stars.

title: Shimura, 76, Actor In Films by Kurosawa
description: Takashi Shimura, who often appeared in films directed by Akira Kurosawa, died of pulmonary emphysema in a Tokyo hospital on Thursday. He was 76 years old.

title: Around the Nation; Unions Plan to Create Jobs Using Pension Fund
description: A $500 million program to use union pension funds to create construction jobs was announced today as members of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Executive Council gathered here for a midwinter meeting.

title: British Air Strike Continues
description: British Airways said today that most of its flights were operating normally despite a strike by 2,000 baggage handlers and other ground staff at London's Heathrow Airport.

title: Clayton Triumphs
description: Mike Clayton posted a finalround 68 today to win the $108,000 Victorian Open golf tournament at the Metropolitan Golf Club.

title: DANCE: LIM ON TROUPE IN LOUIS'S 'CLEOPATRA'
description: OVER the last few years, the Jose Limon Dance Company has been judiciously seeding newer dance into its repertory of pieces by such signature modern-dance choreographers as Mr. Limon and Doris Humphrey.

title: Denver Lindley, Editor, Dies; Translator of Mann, Maurois
description: Denver Lind ley, a magazine and book editor who also translated intoEnglish books by Thomas Mann, Andre Maurois and Erich Maria Remarque,died Thursday at the Tucson (Ariz.) Medical Center.

title: MINE IN SPAIN IS CRIPPLED BY PRICE SLUMP
description: Less then three years ago, King Juan Carlos and Alfonzo Escamez, president of Banco Central and a friend of the monarch, opened a vast open-pit metals mine near here. At the time, the project was hailed as the model investment of the post-Franco era.

title: They Can't Eat Bullets
description: The Reagan Administration's first year produced few successes as great as the record-breaking sale of arms abroad. It has lined up sales of $25 to $30 billion for fiscal 1982, more than twice the volume in 1981. That is a deliberate but drastic and dangerous reversal of Jimmy Carter's fitful restraints.

title: DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY STAYS ALIVE
description: The Reagan Administration's plan to abolish the Department of Energy has met so much resistance in Congress that legislative approval of such a measure seems unlikely this year.

title: Warriors 103, Kings 93
description: Purvis Short scored 24 points and World B. Free scored 18 to lead Golden State, which snapped a three-game losing streak without its leading scorer, Bernard King, and leading rebounder, L a rry Smith. King has a pulled groin and Smith an injured back.

title: Overwhelming Support
description: ''It sure tells you,'' the vacationing Army officer was saying, ''that there's a lot more good people than bad in this world. It's something a guy like me just doesn't expect.''

title: MUISIC: AEOLIAN PLAYERS
description: THE Aeolian Chamber Players, who played Bartok, Gunther Schuller, George Crumb and Brahms at the Abraham Goodman House on Saturday night, seemed in the course of the evening to split themselves into two distinct musical personalities.

title: JOHN ACCEPTS PACT: 2 YEARS, $1.7 MILLION
description: A telephone call that began with ''Happy Valentine's Day'' ended today with an agreement that has made Tommy John a happy Yankee again.

title: Cooney to Undergo Tests
description: Dennis Rappaport, co-manager of the top heavyweight contender Gerry Cooney, said that Cooney left training camp at the Concord Hotel in Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., yesterday and returned home to await tests on his injured left shoulder.

title: CITY'S PUBLIC SCHOOL ATHLETICS ERODED BY YEARS OF CUTBACKS
description: On a June afternoon in 1913, when an army of schoolboys dressed in white shirts and dark knickerbockers demonstrated their physical skills at a Central Park extravaganza, Theodore Roosevelt clapped youngsters on the back with cries of ''Bully!'' and congratulated the Public Schools Athletic League for ''making these boys good young Americans.''

title: A HOLIDAY FOR LOVERS OF BOOKS
description: '' 'It is New Year's Eve, and little Gretchen is wandering up and down the hill,' '' John Melser read melodramatically from an 1893 children's book yesterday at the third annual Greenwich Village Antiquarian Book Fair at Public School 3.

title: MINORITY CAUCUS STRESSES VOTERS' ROLE
description: The New York State Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus, gathered here for its 11th annual legislative weekend, was exhorted today to use its political strength as a tool to bring about positive change for minorities and the poor.

title: Philadelphia Council Is Polled On Asking a Member to Leave
description: An informal verdict of the Philadelphia Council is expected Tuesday on the issue of asking Harry P. Jannotti, a council member, to take a leave of absence, according to the council president, Joseph E. Coleman.

title: Eve Bergman Is Married
description: Eve Bergman, who is in sales with Sulzberger-Rolfe Inc., a New York real-estate company, and Robert C. Lape, a producer of radio and television commercials and food-related programs, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Town Hall in Washington, Conn., by Connecticut Probate Judge Janet Wildman. The bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Barnett Bergman of New York and London. Mr. Lape, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. C.R. Lape of Akron, Ohio.

title: A Natural Rebounder
description: Ray Smith of Armstrong State College in Savannah, Ga., thinks that it is ''nice'' that he is the leading scorer in college basketball this season. But the 6-foot-7-inch junior is prouder that he is also leading all rebounders with an average of 15.6 a game.

title: N.F.L AND PLAYERS BEGIN TO NEGOTIATE CONTRACT TOMORROW
description: Negotiations between the Management Council of the National Football League and the N.F.L. Players Association begin tomorrow in Miami Beach at the Diplomat Hotel, an aptly named site because a lot of diplomacy is going to be required of both sides.

title: Oil Nations Become Net Borrowers
description: Oil-exporting countries have become net borrowers of funds from major Western banks for the first time since the end of 1978, the Bank for International Settlements said today.

title: L.I. Student Admits 250 House Burglaries
description: A high school student charged with the burglary of a neighbor's home has told investigators he committed more than 250 house burglaries since last August, the police said.

title: THE LADY IN THE BOX
description: More than 35,000 people in New York City are now said to make their ''home'' in the subway system, in doorways, in boxes on the street. Last month, one of them -a 61-yearold woman named Rebecca Smith - froze to death in her makeshift cardboard hut. Perhaps there is, in Mrs. Smith's life and death, a lesson for us all.

title: Commodities; Heating Oil Contracts In Dispute
description: DID the heating oil futures market narrowly escape a default this month that could have undermined the exchange where the fuel is traded, along with some brokerage houses and their clients who use the market? Or was it just a case of ''slight congestion'' that temporarily delayed the fulfillment of contractual obligations that day?

title: WITNESSES IN ATLANTA DISPUTE HOMOSEXUALITY ISSUE IN TRIAL
description: Two defense witnesses testified at the murder trial of Wayne B. Williams today that Mr. Williams had expressed a dislike for homosexuals. Prosecutors have asserted that Mr. Williams is a homosexual and that his sexual preference played a part in the deaths of the two young black men he is accused of killing.

title: News Analysis
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger spent most of last week touring the Middle East trying to strengthen American military ties with the Arab nations and talking about redirecting policy away from Israel.

title: NICARAGUA PRESSED TO REDUCE SOVIET-BLOC TIES
description: Nicaragua is coming under growing pressure from Western governments and political parties to reduce its alignment with the Soviet bloc in foreign affairs and provide improved guarantees of political pluralism at home.

title: St. John's Triumphs In 2 Overtimes, 77-76
description: Chris Mullin hit a 3-point play with 18 seconds remaining in the second overtime period tonight to give St. John's a 77-76 Big East Conference victory over Providence.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: NATURE designed the coronary arteries in our hearts to widen and narrow from moment to moment in response to the body's needs for oxygen and other blood-borne nutrients. Through muscular activity, our arteries expand when we exercise or impose other physiological demands, and they contract when we rest or decrease the demands.

title: 'WORKING ON' BLACKS; ''I think, for the most part, blacks are not supportive of the President. ... that's a job we are working on in the Administration and at the Republican National Committee.'' - Richard Richards, Chairman, R.N.C.
description: Well, let's see. On Feb. 12, the Reagan Administration gave the following demonstrations of ''working on'' its problem with blacks:

title: Portuguese Facing More Union Walkouts
description: Portugal faced more work stoppages today, three days after a Communist-led one-day strike.

title: BEHIND THE BRINK'S CASE: RETURN OF THE RADICAL LEFT
description: Four months after the slayings of a Brink's guard and two policemen in an armored-car robbery in Rockland County, a complex story has begun to emerge of a subterranean culture sustained by a small network of people who view themselves as warriors in a global revolution.

title: Magnuson Resigns Post
description: Keith Magnuson, head coach of the Chicago Black Hawks, resigned tonight after his team lost, 4-1, to the Vancouver Canucks.

title: NORMAN E. HANDEL
description: Norman E. Handel, former president of the A. Harris Company, which became the Sanger-Harris Company, owners of a chain of department stores, died Sunday in Baylor Hospital here.

title: WEEK'S OFFERING LIGHT AS HIGH RATES PERSIST
description: The combination of a four-day week and high interest rates has discouraged many potential issuers of notes and bonds. Although this week's volume is light, analysts warn that corporations and the Treasury will soon return with large issues of notes and bonds. Corporations, they explain, have a pent-up demand for long-term debt issues while the Treasury must continue its record borrowings to finance the Federal deficit.

title: RECESSION'S BITTER PILLS, FOR ALL BUT THE POWERFUL
description: To the Editor:

title: USAir and Teamsters Reach a Tentative Pact
description: Faced with the first strike in its history, USAir reached a tentative agreement early Monday on a labor contract with the teamsters union.

title: LOVE, LABORS LOST; Wasted Work
description: Why do some of the best things done in Government fail to impress Government? For example, the United States spent $80 million over seven years on an experiment called ''supported work'' for hard-toemploy people. The trial succeeded in reducing the dependence of chronic welfare recipients on public assistance.

title: SLOW GROWTH HELPS CUT INFLATION IN WESTERN ECONOMIES AND JAPAN
description: Inflation in the seven largest non-Communist industrial nations has dropped sharply in the last year as a result of slow economic growth, reduced wage demands and falling commodity prices. Economists expect the downward trend to continue.

title: KOCH IS ASSAILED BY PRAVDA AND HE REPLIES WITH RELISH
description: Pravda, the newspaper of the Soviet Communist Party, attacked Mayor Koch yesterday for criticizing the United Nations and said he was seeking to ''curry favor with the Zionist lobby of New York'' as he contemplates a race for Governor.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why is salt added to the ice in a hand-cranked ice cream freezer when the primary effect would seem to be the lowering of the mixture's freezing point - and thus a melting of the ice? Does this in some way enhance the removal of heat from the ice cream?

title: WHEN JUDGES TAKE A ROLE IN POLITICS, SECRET OR NOT
description: Several years before he was appointed to the United States Supreme Court in 1939, Prof. Felix Frankfurter of the Harvard Law School stated the philosophy he thought should guide all appointees to the highest court.

title: Raymond Stevens, Expanded Scope of Arthur D. Little Inc.
description: Raymond Stevens, former president and chief executive officer of Arthur D. Little Inc., a management consultant and research concern in Cambridge, Mass., died Sunday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 88 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: No Headline
description: Virginia Wins, 56-52

title: 10-DAY CAR SALES OFF BY 4.8%
description: Car sales for the nation's Big Three auto companies fell 4.8 percent in the first 10 days of February, the smallest decline this year.

title: Bridge: A Game May Be Overbid But Saved by a Little Skill
description: Roman Catholic priests are often enthusiastic bridge players, but whether the game is compatible with monastic life may be another question. However, an English writer named David Bird has based an entertaining series of articles in the English publication Bridge Magazine on the exploits of an abbot and his monks.

title: PARTIES IN ISRAEL UNITE IN OPPOSING ARMS FOR JORDAN
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin, backed by all of Israel's major political parties, appealed publicly to President Reagan today to reject Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's proposal to sell advanced weapons to Jordan.

title: PEN NOMINATES SIX BOOKS FOR ITS 1982 FAULKNER AWARD
description: Six books have been nominated for the 1982 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction. They are: ''Sixty Stories''by Donald Barthelme (G. P. Putnam's), ''Take Me Back'' by Richard Bausch (Dial Press), ''The Chaneysville Incident'' by David Bradley (Harper & Row), ''Ellis Island and Other Stories'' by Mark Helprin (Delacorte/Lawrence), ''Housekeeping'' by Marilynne Robinson (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) and ''A Flag for Sunrise''by Robert Stone (Knopf).

title: 'OFF-TOPIC' DEBATING HOLDS FORTH ON NORTHEAST'S CAMPUSES
description: A perversion of traditional debating that amounts to organized verbal sniping is taking hold on college campuses in the Northeast.

title: Demonstration Is Halted In a Yugoslav City
description: The police said today that they broke up a demonstration Sunday night by several hundred people in Pristina, capital of the southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo, where nine people died in Albanian nationalist riots last spring.

title: RECESSION'S BITTER PILLS, FOR ALL BUT THE POWERFUL
description: To the Editor:

title: New Librarian at Yale's Beinecke Center; A New Yale Librarian
description: Whitworth College is a small regional-based Presbyterian school in Spokane, Wash., with about 1,200 students and a library of just 100,000 volumes, none of them especially rare, the Whitworth librarian said yesterday.

title: Psychiatric Tests Given To Pilot in Tokyo Crash
description: The pilot of a Japan Air Lines DC-8 that crashed in Tokyo Bay last Tuesday, killing 24 passengers, underwent psychiatric testing today and was quoted as saying that he ''felt nausea'' and pushed the control stick forward moments before the crash, Transit Ministry investigators said.

title: Ex-Guard Indicted in Murder Of Theater Director in Texas
description: A former security guard at the Alley Theater was indicted today in the strangling of the theater's managing director in a robbery.

title: Hunter Shoots 3 Friends, One of Whom Kills Him
description: A 23-year-old hunter wounded three companions, apparently for no reason, and then was shot to death by one of the wounded men, Zandt County sheriff's officers said today.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Larry Bradford, left- handed relief pitcher, won salary arbitra- tion appeal. He was awarded $130,000 for 1982. The club had offered $90,000. He re- ceived $80,000 last season.  BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed to one- year contracts: Cal Ripken Jr., infielder; Mark Corey, John Shelby and Dallas Wil- liams, outfielders.  CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Steve Hen- derson, outfielder, and Ty Waller, third baseman, Ryne Sandberg, outfielder, and Bill Hayes, rookie catcher. All received one-year contracts.
description: SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - An- nounced retirement of Phil Francis, full- back, who was out all last season with a knee injury.

title: J.W.T. Will Disclose Results of Inquiry
description: Concerned about inquiries into the suspension of one of his top media executives, Don Johnston, chief executive of the J. Walter Thompson Company, on Friday broke his silence to stress in a telephone call that because of all of ''the rumor and speculation,'' he wanted to say that ''we do not have a problem with any client'' and that the matter is purely internal. Additionally, he said, because the JWT Group is a public company it would at the conclusion of the company investigation release the results.

title: SMITH A STANDOUT AS FAIRLEIGH CAPTURES METROPOLITAN TRACK
description: It did not figure to be one of Randy Smith's better days. Smith, a Fairleigh Dickinson junior from Camden, had an aching left knee that hurt only when he ran. He did not think he was long-jumping well. He hit four of the five hurdles in the 55-meter high hurdles final.

title: POLAND'S REGIME RULES OUT TALKS WITH WALESA IF HE HAS ADVISERS
description: A Government minister who has met several times with Lech Walesa said today that there would be no negotiations with Mr. Walesa as long as he insisted on having his advisers at his side.

title: Gielen Coming to Carnegie
description: Michael Gielen will make his first appearance as music director of the Cincinnati Symphony at Carnegie Hall next Monday at 8 P.M. He will conduct the Mahler Seventh Symphony and join the pianist Alfred Brendel in Liszt's Piano Concerto No. 2. Mr. Gielen took over the orchestra two seasons ago. Tickets are $8, $11, $12.50 and $15. Call 247-7459.

title: A GROWING PANORAMA OF SUMMER CHOICES
description: The operative word in summer fashions continues to be ''choices.'' Or, if you prefer, ''options.'' Kasper, the designer of dresses for Joan Leslie and of separates for J.L.Sport, who has been using both terms to introduce his collections for the past year, believes any dictation in fashion has long vanished.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: STRIPPED of pedagogical euphemisms, tests divide the winners from the losers. Since there are usually more losers, or low scorers, than winners, people who hate tests outnumber those who do not. In a society that clings to the statement that ''all men are created equal,'' dislike of tests - the tool that gives the lie to that assumption - will always be controversial. They are understandably least popular with those who are at the bottom of the social and economic pyramid and face an arduous climb up.

title: Talks on Latin Novels Will Begin March 17
description: A series of lectures and discussions on contemporary Latin American literature will be given on six consecutive Wednesdays beginning March 17.

title: IRMA RHODE, 82, FOOD EXPERT AND AUTHOR OF SEVERAL BOOKS
description: Irma Rhode, a food expert who wrote a number of cookbooks, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MET OPERA: MISS HORNE IN "IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA"
description: ANY production of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' that starts out with Marilyn Horne as its Rosina has already taken a long stride toward the winner's circle. Miss Horne, as she demonstrated dazzlingly last night in the Metropolitan Opera's new mounting of Rossini's comic masterpiece, is unapproachable nowadays in the role, certainly among currently active mezzo-sopranos and probaby among sopranos as well. Hers is, of course, the mezzo-soprano voice for which the part was written, the rare breed known as coloratura mezzo. To have her back on the Metropolitan stage, even in the few performances the company has been able to offer her this season, is reason for celebration.

title: CORRECTION
description: A graph in some copies of Sports- Monday yesterday, accompanying an article about the hockey player Mike Rogers, included an incorrect label. His goals and assists for the 1981-82 season have been scored with the New York Rangers.

title: Soviet Ship in Trouble Off the Canadian Coast
description: A Soviet freighter with 37 people aboard was reportedly sinking early today in the stormy North Atlantic 65 miles east of the area where the oil rig Ocean Ranger was said to have sank the day before.

title: MRS. REAGAN, IN FLORIDA, SEES EFFORTS TO FIGHT DRUG ABUSE
description: Toby, one of the third- to fifthgrade students at the Pinellas Park Elementary School here, was explaining the relaxing exercises.

title: An Owner Snubbed
description: The National Hockey League has ignored a deadline set by Peter Gilbert, the owner of the Colorado Rockies, who offered $8 million to the league in exchange for permission to move his team to the Meadowlands in New Jersey. At last week's league meeting in Washington, Gilbert repeated his determination to move the financially troubled franchise; made his offer and set a deadline that will pass today without a meeting by the N.H.L. board of governors.

title: BOTTOM-UP U.S. AID
description: Development experts are coming to recognize that the conventional ''top-down'' approach to African rural development, with large amounts of external assistance given by donor governments to African governments, has not yielded the hopedfor benefits.

title: SPRINGLIKE WEATHER A BONUS AS THE LONG WEEKEND ENDS
description: A burst of springlike weather lured New Yorkers into the streets yesterday to stroll or shop. They shed the down coats and scarves of the last cold weeks and brought home bargains from Washington's Birthday sales.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Plants That Kill Ticks

title: CHARITIES AND CITIZENS LEND A HAND TO CITY'S HOMELESS
description: An unusual popular movement to help the city's homeless is taking shape in New York City. Individual New Yorkers and churches, synagogues and private groups - such as the Astor Foundation and the Exxon Corporation - are beginning to join in the effort. And the city's Human Resources Administration has noted in the last few weeks a marked increase in calls from residents reporting homeless men and women in their neighborhoods who need help.

title: U.S. IS DISCOVERING LATIN AMERICA'S LITERATURE
description: AMERICANS will do anything for Latin America except read about it, the journalist James Reston once observed. But a growing number of book publishers in the United States, hopeful that this is no longer the case, are issuing translations of more books by more Latin writers than ever before.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1982
description: International Israel appealed to President Reagan to reject Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's proposal to sell advanced weapons to Jordan. The plea was made by Prime Minister Menachem Begin, who was backed by all of Israel's major parties. Speaking in Parliament, Mr. Begin presented an array of statistics showing what he called an ''almost unimaginable flow of sophisticated weapons reaching the Arab states from both the East and the West.'' The buildup, he said, is jeopardizing Israel's military edge over the Arabs. (Page A1, Column 6.) A huge drilling rig reportedly sank in a storm off the coast of Newfoundland, and all 84 men aboard were said to be missing in 50-foot-high waves and feared dead. (A1:4-5.)

title: FUMES DISABLE 12 FIREFIGHTERS
description: At least 12 firemen were temporarily disabled yesterday by fumes while fighting a small fire in a factory on the former site of the Fort Hamilton Army base in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: Bleep, Bleep
description: The Mizuno Corporation, the largest producer of baseball equipment in Japan, will appeal to the American love of gadgetry at a New York news conference today and unveil electronic gloves and helmets that could make hand signals obsolete. If the new equipment caught on, and was approved by the baseball commissioner and the rules committee, a catcher would press a button in his glove and transmit a message to the pitcher, who would press his own buttons to accept or shake off the sign.

title: D'AMATO OPPOSES AMENDMENT TO RIGHTS ACT
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he opposed the extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 as approved in a bill in the House of Representatives last fall and that he favored instead an extension of the present act.

title: Reliance Picks Banker For Capital Investments
description: Henry R. Silverman, 41, a lawyer and investment banker, has been appointed president of the Reliance Capital Investments Corporation. Reliance Capital, a subsidiary of the Reliance Financial Group, will handle leveraged buy-outs, real estate transactions and other venture capital activities.

title: TV: HERSHEY'S 'THE WALL,' DRAMA OF NAZI HORRORS
description: THE compelling power of John Hersey's 1950 novel, ''The Wall,'' a fictional account of the courageous resistance to Nazi genocide among Jews in the Warsaw ghetto, lay in his capacity to evoke the humanity and the frailty of a series of individuals faced with daily terror and almost inevitable death.

title: Frances Denney Appoints President
description: Hans P. Bryers, 50-years-old, has become president of Frances Denney Inc., a cosmetics maker based in New York. He succeeds William M. Fine, 55, who plans to open the W.M.F. Fund, a corporate consulting firm, on March 1.

title: Arizona State Upsets U.S.C. Women, 53-51
description: Kym Hampton sank a layup with 25 seconds left to give Arizona State a 53-51 upset victory over secondranked Southern California in women's collegiate basketball tonight.

title: PCB'S IN SOIL DELAY BUILDING OF MAJOR JERSEY INDUSTRIAL PARK
description: An old garbage dump here that is to be the site for a major industrial park is contaminated with buried pockets of toxic polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's. The landowner, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, disclosed the pollution today.

title: NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: T HE watchword for the week was ''civilized.'' How could it be otherwise? James Galanos, the designer whose clothing is unmatched in quality and price in this country, was in town, and almost immediately the level of social exchange seemed elevated as if by ripple effect.

title: Contare Is First
description: Stephen C. Clark's Contare came up in the final strides and captured the $56,100 Sporting Plate Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Ridden by Donald MacBeth, Contare covered the six furlongs in 1:10 2/5, scoring by a head over Feathers Lad.

title: Campaign Ruled Out
description: A follow-up: He switched his party affiliation from Democrat to Republican, he took a close look at a new Congressional district in his native San Diego and now Richard Morefield has made up his mind. He will not be a candidate for the House this year.

title: LIBRARY TO OPEN FORMALLY THURSDAY
description: The new Mid-Manhattan Library, a spacious complex of airy rooms, open stacks and bright colors, will be formally opened to the public Thursday.

title: No Headline
description: DISTRIBUTION OF U.S. CHEESE STOCKS IS SMOOTH

title: COLLEGE PRESIDENTS ASSAIL CUTS IN EDUCATION BUDGET
description: Thirteen college and university presidents and a law-school dean lined up today to fire opening salvos against Federal student-aid cuts in a battle that they said they would pursue in Congress.

title: SALVADOR ELECTION BRINGING FEAR OF NEW VIOLENCE
description: United States officials and Salvadoran leaders are now saying that the elections next month, far from ending the political violence, are likely to be the prelude to increased fighting.

title: The Reagan Tax Increase
description: Raising taxes could allay the politically fearsome deficit in his new budget, but President Reagan vows to stand by the income tax cuts enacted last year - for some people. The same budget would sharply increase the amounts that Government deducts from the incomes of a whole class of Americans: the poor.

title: REVUE: SATIRE OF THEATER
description: ''FORBIDDEN BROADWAY,'' a satirical revue in the upstairs supper club at Palsson's, 178 West 72d Street, is not as ominous as the title might suggest except to such people as Lauren Bacall, Patti Lupone, Ethel Merman, Ann Miller, Rex Harrison and others who are mercilessly carved up in Gerard Alessandrini's lyrics. For anyone else, and possibly even for these victims, ''Forbidden Broadway'' is a hilarious and brilliantly wicked parody and commentary on the contemporary Broadway theater, primarily the musical theater.

title: News Analysis
description: A tentative contract between the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company trades immediate wage and benefit concessions by workers for assurances of job security that may only prove their value over time, if at all.

title: MINISTER ACTS STRONGLY ON ARGENTINE ECONOMY
description: Faced with a deep recession and the highest inflation rate in the world, Roberto T. Alemann, Argentina's new economics minister, is taking vigorous steps to improve the country's economy.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: New Fuel Cell Tests

title: NATIONAL STOCK PLAN OPPOSED
description: Almost seven years after Congress mandated a national securities market, Wall Street is gearing up for the first crucial test of that system. But the experiment is drawing stiff opposition from brokers, who say that the new system may cut sharply into their profit margins.

title: Japan-U.S. Trade Gap
description: Japan, under pressure from Western trading partners over what they say are protective market practices, today announced figures showing that the trade gap with the United States and the European Economic Community was growing.

title: UKRAINIAN BOY'S SISTER, 19, FINDS LOVE AND FREEDOM IN AMERICA
description: But having her 14-year-old brother, Walter, at the center of a custody battle in which the Soviet Union and the United States are on opposite sides has set her apart from other young people.

title: PRINCIPAL OF BROOKLYN SCHOOL CHIDED FOR MUSLIM'S SPEECH
description: As a result of an address at a school assembly that some teachers said was anti-white and anti-Jewish in tone, the principal of a high school in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section has been told he must now get permission before inviting speakers to address the students.

title: KENYA'S ASIANS WORRIED OVER ATTACK BY PRESIDENT
description: Many of Kenya's 100,000 Asian residents are expressing concern and bewilderment over the recent charge by President Daniel arap Moi that some traders and businessmen among them are ruining the nation's economy through corrupt practices.

title: Peter Max Heads Down to Knoxville World's Fair; New Job for Peter Max
description: It is a world's fair, after all, so when it came time to sign up an official artist for this year's exposition, it seemed only natural that the folks in Knoxville would turn to a painter who was born in Germany, spent various parts of his boyhood in China, Tibet, South Africa, Israel and France, graduated from a Brooklyn high school and put in time at such places as London and Japan before finally settling in the ultimate melting pot on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: OFFSHORE RIGS REMAIN VULNERABLE STRUCTURES
description: The reported sinking of an oil rig off Newfoundland yesterday was a further reminder that, even though such platforms are designed to ride out the most severe storms, they are vulnerable.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Microsystems Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., has elected Robert M. Penn president and chief operating officer and a member of its board of directors. Two new vice presidents were named: William E. Nicholson and Thomas E. Woodard.

title: Pac-Man Sublicenses Extend Bally's Profits
description: Pac-Man became a hit last year in America's video game arcades by running around inside a little electronic maze eating dots. These days he could probably eat steak.

title: Reputation of a Witness Issue in von Bulow Trial
description: A newspaper article labeling a potential witness in Claus von Bulow's trial for attempted murder as a prostitute apparently provoked the judge to ask jurors today whether they were reading about the case.

title: MRS. THATCHER, ON TOUR, TINKERS A BIT WITH HER IMAGE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher stood in the high-ceilinged hall of the Victorian school building she once entered daily and reminisced about her early efforts to win admission to Oxford University.

title: Sullivan Award To Carl Lewis
description: Carl Lewis, who set the world-best indoor mark of 28 feet 1 inch in the long jump last month, received the Amateur Athletic Union's Sullivan Award tonight as the nation's outstanding amateur athlete for 1981.

title: Royal Holiday
description: The travel reservations say simply, ''Mr. and Mrs. Hardy,'' but everything else about the trip has the earmarks of a royal vacation, including the actual identities of the incognito travelers.

title: Jet Exhibitions Set
description: The Jets will open their exhibition schedule in Green Bay on Aug. 14, the team announced yesterday. The Jets will be at Houston Aug. 21 and then will play two games at the Meadowlands in New Jersey Aug. 28 against the Giants and Sept. 4 against Denver. All games start at 8 P.M. Eastern daylight time.

title: RECESSION'S BITTER PILLS, FOR ALL BUT THE POWERFUL
description: To the Editor:

title: Chevy Camaro Z28 Wins Car of Year Award
description: At a luncheon in Los Angeles yesterday, Petersen Publishing's Motor Trend magazine announced that its Car of the Year award for domestic vehicles has gone to the Chevrolet Camaro Z28.

title: Iran and Soviet Sign Accords on Power Plants
description: Iran's Energy Minister said today that he had signed economic agreements with the Soviet Union. The Energy Minister, Hasan Ghafuri-Fard, said the agreements call for the completion of two gas-powered electric plants, a 1,260-megawatt station in the oil center of Ahwaz and an 800-megawatt station in the central Iranian city of Isfahan.

title: Mrs. Kirkpatrick Says U.N. Is 'Dismal Show'
description: The United Nations is ''a very dismal show'' in which conflicts are worsened rather than resolved, the chief United State delegate, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, said today.

title: Jamaica Sets Bauxite Pact
description: Jamaica's five major bauxite and aluminum companies said today that they had reached agreement on a new contract with the industry's trade union after lengthy negotiations that provoked protest strikes.

title: YEN SAGS, AGGRAVATING TRADE PROBLEMS
description: In recent weeks, Japanese Government officials have watched with growing concern as rising United States interest rates have weakened the yen, threatening to intensify Japan's trade problems.

title: A POLITICAL BID BY A DAUGHTER OF REP. BOGGS
description: Barbara Boggs Sigmund, hoping to follow in the footsteps of her father and mother, today declared her candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Representative from the newly created Seventh Congressional District.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dan Pastorini was arrested for drunken driving early yesterday. He was picked up doing 100 miles an hour on the Pacific Coast Highway near Newport Beach, Calif.

title: LEONARD STOPS FINCH
description: Sugar Ray Leonard pummeled Bruce Finch into submission at 1:50 of the third round tonight and retained his unified world welterweight championship.

title: BRIEFING
description: House Is Nice, the Pool Too

title: COONEY INJURY LIKELY TO DELAY HOLMES FIGHT
description: With his March 15 bout against Gerry Cooney almost certain to be postponed, Larry Holmes began searching for an alternative opponent yesterday.

title: U.A.W. Ratifies Concessions To Insure Jobs at Budd Plant
description: The United Automobile Workers at the Budd Company have approved economic concessions that will add jobs and should insure the future of the plant, company officials said today.

title: SOUTHEAST ASIANS SEE SOVIET THREAT
description: Southeast Asian officials and defense analysts, in a private conference with political and military officials and civilian specialists from the United States and other countries, have identified Soviet influence in Vietnam as a principal threat to the non-Communist nations of the region.

title: Kafka 'Metamorphosis' Extends Run to Sunday
description: ''A Metamorphosis in Miniature,'' which was to have closed last Sunday, has had its run extended through next Sunday at the Cubiculo Theater, 414 West 51st Street.

title: TOUGH TEST EXPECTED IN FALL FOR MINNESOTA REPUBLICAN
description: Minnesota Republicans, who captured the governorship and both United States Senate seats from the Democrats in 1978, are concerned that they will lose ground in the fall elections because of voter dissatisfaction with their economic policy.

title: Manhattan Woman Surpasses 1,000 Points
description: Sheila Tighe, a Manhattan College sophomore, surpassed the 1,000-point mark in just her 54th game tonight as the Lady Jaspers defeated C.W. Post, 53-49.

title: POLICE CONNECT RING OF ROBBERS TO MURDER CASE
description: The police searched for at least two more men yesterday in an effort to break a robbery ring that they said had been preying on tenants of luxury East Side apartment buildings. Two suspected members of the ring were arrested over the weekend on murder charges.

title: NOAH DIETRICH, THE CHIEF AIDE TO HOWARD HUGHES, IS DEAD
description: Noah Dietrich, financial adviser and chief executive for Howard R. Hughes for more than 30 years, died yesterday at Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 92 years old and lived in Palm Springs.

title: JOSEPH MACKEY, 72, AN AVIATION PIONEER WHO OWNED AIRLINE
description: Joseph C. Mackey, a barnstorming pilot in the early days of aviation and former head of Mackey International Airlines in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., died Sunday in Davie, Fla., near his home in Fort Lauderdale. He was 72 years old.

title: COLLEGES STRUGGLE TO COPE WITH U.S. AID CUTS
description: Colleges and universities are scurrying to find ways to cope with the loss of as much as $2.2 billion in Federal money for student aid next fall.

title: 3 Climbers Killed in Scotland
description: Three climbers were swept to their deaths and five were injured in two avalanches today on Ben Nevis, Britain's highest mountain. Helicopters and rescue teams using tracker dogs and electronic equipment searched for survivors on the northeast side of the 4,406-foot mountain in the Scottish Highlands.

title: KEYWORTH ON NEW PRIORITIES IN SCIENCE
description: WASHINGTON FOR the last several months, the scientific community has awaited President Reagan's budget with trepidation. Rumors were rife that Federal support for basic research, particularly in biology, medicine and space science, would suffer deep cuts.

title: Chess: Dimitry Gurevich of Bronx Leads Reykjavik Tourney
description: After four rounds of the 10th Reykjavik international tournament, Dimitry Gurevich, a 25-year-old international master from the Bronx, held the lead with a perfect 4-0 score.

title: Lament for a Coach
description: George Raveling, the Washington State basketball coach, said it reflected poorly on collegiate athletics that Dick DiBiaso had been forced to resign as Stanford coach.

title: Talking Business with Salim B. Lewis of S. B. Lewis The Outlook For Mergers
description: After a 10-year hot streak, mergers and acquisitions appear to have slowed considerably. Salim B. Lewis, an arbitrageur and investment banker who manages his own small Wall Street firm, S. B. Lewis & Company, put together one of last year's biggest mergers - American Express and Shearson Loeb Rhoades.

title: Ronald Barsano, an Artist, Marries Linda Hill in Taos
description: Linda Hill was married yesterday to Ronald James Barsano, an artist. The Rev. Roger L. Martinez performed the ceremony in St. Frances of Assisi Roman Catholic Church in Taos, N.M.

title: Topics Love, Labors Lost
description: Living Together

title: FETAL HEALTH: A NEW VIEW EMERGES
description: HERSHEY, Pa. ANEW understanding of how a mother affects her unborn child is emerging from a landmark series of studies based on nearly 60,000 births in the United States. The studies, which followed more pregnancies, and for longer periods, than had been done before, raise questions about the safety of working until the end of pregnancy and explain how sexual intercourse, cigarette smoking, poor nutrition and advanced maternal age can compromise the health and survival of the fetus.

title: JOCKEY'S EDUCATION GOES BEYOND TRACK
description: Two years ago, Kenny Skinner awoke one morning and realized that he wanted to study literature and philosophy. He had dropped out of high school in Vancouver, British Columbia, seven years earlier, at the age of 16, to exercise and ride horses at Exhibition Park, the local track. Now he was a regular on the New York circuit, riding quality stock and winning about 60 races a year, but his primary interest in life was Kim Sengara, whose parents owned horses he had frequently ridden to victory in Vancouver.

title: PROSPECTS DIMMER FOR LOWER RATES
description: The path to lower interest rates, if one can be found this year, is likely to be a circuitous one. Credit market participants have to contend with rapid money supply growth that has raised fears of a tighter monetary policy and higher short-term interest rates while record-size Treasury borrowings put upward pressure on longer-term rates.

title: ART UPSTAGE BY HORSES AT AN ARIZONA AUCTION
description: Arabian horses upstaged paintings and sculpture in the first auction of ''living art'' by a major house in the United States.

title: Carter's New Pact: 7 Years, $14 Million
description: Gary Carter, baseball's premier catcher, joined George Foster, Mike Schmidt and Dave Winfield today in becoming one of the game's financial elite.

title: BUDWEISER STILL NO. 1 IN SALES
description: Budweiser had long touted itself as the ''King of Beer.'' But five years ago, after a damaging three-month strike at its brewer, Anheuser-Busch Inc. of St. Louis, it seemed in danger of losing its crown.

title: OIL PIPE DEMAND WEAKENS
description: The oil industry's strong demand for pipe and tubing, which has bolstered the profits of American steelmakers during the last year, has started to weaken, steel industry executives and analysts say.

title: By Sports of The Times; More Than Just Mean
description: AFTER a long, cold practice at Three Rivers Stadium, the Pittsburgh Steelers had hurried into their locker room for warmth and serenity. But soon a Steeler was shouting and snarling at life in general as he yanked off his equipment. At a nearby locker, Joe Greene lifted his head and glared at his noisy teammates.

title: HITLER'S LOST BATTLE
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOMES FOR LUNCH

title: E.E.C. Assails U.S. Policies
description: European Economic Community finance ministers today voiced alarm at the impact of United States policies on the world economy and said the message would be conveyed to Washington later this week.

title: TEXT OF LABOR STATEMENT
description: The Reagan Administration economic policies, which caused the current recession, must be reversed. This recession has rapidly become the worst since the Great Depression. The Republican Administration cannot blame anyone else for this recession. The recession was started in July 1981 with Reagan's job-destroying, tight-money, budget-slashing policies. These policies must be stopped. Antirecession, job-creating programs must be started immediately.

title: Advertising; New Shop Seeks Its Own Niche
description: TWO former leaders of the Needham, Harper & Steers creative department in New York, Lois Korey and Allen Kay, have opened their own advertising agency with $6 million in billings.

title: No Headline
description: Paul Owens, the general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, said tonight that it was ''99 percent certain'' that the club would trade outfielder Bake McBride to the Cleveland Indians for Sid Monge, a left-handed relief pitcher.

title: LABOR CHALLENGES REAGAN ON BUDGET
description: Accepting President Reagan's challenge to produce alternatives to his 1983 budget or keep quiet, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. demanded today that any increases in military spending be on a pay-as-you-go basis, with new tax surcharges meeting the new costs.

title: A Retired Coat Maker Heads Garment Group
description: Mac Levy started his first women's coat and suit business on Seventh Avenue 43 years ago and has been at it through thick and thin ever since. But now Mr. Levy, 69, has left his business enterprises in the hands of his partner and younger brother, Sidney, to become the salaried executive director of his industry's trade group, the New York Coat and Suit Association.

title: A QUESTIONABLE BLOW FOR THE RIGHT TO PRIVACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Manitoba Set to Charge Player With Assault
description: Manitoba Attorney General Roland Penner said today that assault charges would be filed within two days against Jimmy Mann, the Winnipeg Jet forward.

title: China Sets Oil Plan
description: China took fresh steps today toward the long-awaited exploitation of its offshore oil by forming a national offshore oil company, the China National Offshore Corporation, and announcing that foreign companies would soon be invited to tender bids. Preparations have been made for bidding for rights to exploit the offshore oil reserves, and the new corporation will soon send letters of notification to the more than 45 foreign companies, about half of them American, which are eligible to bid, the New China News Agency said.

title: EXPEDITION FROM INDIA ARRIVES IN ANTARCTICA
description: ASCIENTIFIC expedition from India has landed on the coast of East Antarctica. Its stated purpose was to perform oceanographic, seismic, climate and other scientific research on the remote ice-locked continent.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt NIGHT CALL FROM A DISTANT TIME ZONE. By Herbert Lieberman. 313 pages. Crown. $12.95.

title: Influence on Writers By Duse to Be Discussed
description: Lynn Middleton, actress and biographer, will give a dramatic presentation and discuss the influence of the actress Eleonora Duse on such literary figures as Amy Lowell, Anton Chekhov and George Bernard Shaw in the ''Talks With Writers'' series on Tuesday, March 2, at 8 P.M. at the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: A Brain For Two Seasons

title: RECESSION'S BITTER PILL, FOR ALL BUT THE POWERFUL
description: To the Editor:

title: A NATIONAL JOKE
description: Everyone keeps ruling that the City Council is an illegal legislative body -Federal Courts, the Justice Department - but the Council keeps rolling blithely onward toward oblivion. And perhaps toward enshrinement as a national joke.

title: NOON STROLLERS TEAM UP TO RESCUE 2 BOYS IN ICY LAKE IN CENTRAL PARK
description: At least four people came to the rescue of two brothers who plunged into a lake in Central Park yesterday while playing on its rapidly melting cover of ice, according to the police.

title: IN THE PRISONS OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Between Us Cables
description: Eventually, cable television will let subscribers talk back to their sets - not in pique about dreadful programs, you may be sure, but to give orders to banks, department stores and the suppliers of other services. Warner Amex has experimented with such ''interactive'' two-way cable in Columbus, Ohio, and companies seeking cable franchises elsewhere now routinely promise it. Home shopping and accounting, fire and theft security systems and even the remote scanning of library catalogues are among the promised conveniences.

title: British Output Drops
description: Government hopes of a gradual recovery in the British economy received a setback today when official figures showed a sharp drop in industrial output for the last two months of 1981. Despite record North Sea oil and gas production, industrial output fell by 1.7 percent in November and an additional 1.1 percent in December. The fall was even more pronounced in the manufacturing sector, partly because of disputes in the auto industry.

title: MEDICAL CARE HELD INADEQUATE FOR ATHLETES IN CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: A coach at a Brooklyn high school believes his athletes are forging doctors' signatures on the preseason medical examinations required by state law, a coach in Manhattan characterizes the physicals provided in city health clinics as ''garbage,'' and a Board of Education official says the current system of screening young athletes in New York City is virtually impossible to police. The three men and other coaches, administrators, city officials and medical experts interviewed in an examination of high school sports agree that preventive care for teen-age athletes in the public schools is inadequate. They say that state requirements are too lax or not appropriate for New York City and that the existing rules are implemented haphazardly by the local high schools.

title: THE FAILURE OF METHADONE MAINTENANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Grey Net Income Fell 8.3% in Fourth Quarter
description: Grey Advertising has released its fourth quarter and year-end financial statement.

title: SOVIET PREMIER HINTS AT OVERTURE TO IMPROVE RELATIONS WITH CHINA
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov said in an interview published here on Sunday that the Soviet Union is ''not going to keep from concrete steps'' toward improved relations with China, but that the process ''must not be one-sided.''

title: Market Place; New Focus At G.& W.
description: GULF AND WESTERN INDUSTRIES, known for its aggressive behavior, is trying to gain more respect from the business community by accenting its profitability.

title: NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES' STOCK REPURCHASE
description: The last few months have been rather hectic for Ben W. Heineman, president and chief executive of Northwest Industries, the diversified manufacturer that, until a few years ago, was a weak sister in the anemic railroad and steel industries.

title: Sullivan Award Winners
description: 1930 - Bobby Jones, golf 1931 - Bernie Berlinger, all-round 1932 - Jim Bausch, all-round 1933 - Glenn Cunningham, track 1934 - Bill Bonthron, track 1935 - Lawson Little, golf 1936 - Glenn Morris, allround 1937 - Don Budge, tennis 1938 - Don Lash, track 1939 - Joe Burk, rowing 1940 - Greg Rice, track 1941 - Leslie MacMitchell, track 1942 - Dutch Warmerdam, pole vault 1943 - Gil Dodds, track 1944 - Ann Curtis, swimming 1945 - Felix (Doc) Blanchard, football 1946 - Arnold Tucker, football 1947 - Jack Kelly, rowing 1948 - Bob Mathias, allround 1949 - Dick Button, figure skating 1950 - Fred Wilt, track 1951 - Bob Richards, pole vault 1952 - Horace Ashenfelter, track 1953 - Sammy Lee, diving 1954 - Mal Whitfield, track 1955 - Harrison Dillard, track 1956 - Patricia McCormick, diving 1957 - Bobby Morrow, track 1957 - Bobby Morrow, track 1958 - Glenn Davis, track 1959 - Parry O'Brien, shot-put 1960 - Rafer Johnson, all-round 1961 - Wilma Rudolph, track 1962 - Jim Beatty, track 1963 - John Pennel, pole vault 1964 - Don Schollander, swimming 1965 - Bill Bradley, basketball 1966 - Jim Ryun, track 1967 - Randy Matson, shot-put 1968 - Debbie Meyer, swimming 1969 - Bill Toomey, decathlon 1970 - John Kinsella, swimming 1971 - Mark Spitz, swimming 1972 - Frank Shorter, track 1973 - Bill Walton, basketball 1974 - Rick Wohlhuter, track 1975 - Tim Shaw, swimming 1976 - Bruce Jenner, decathlon 1977 - John Naber, swimming 1978 - Tracy Caulkins, swimming 1979 - Kurt Thomas, gymnastics 1980 - Eric Heiden, speed skating 1981 - Carl Lewis, track

title: Valenzuela Fires Away
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the first player to win the Cy Young and rookie of the year awards in the same season, may sit out next season if the Los Angeles Dodgers do not make him a better offer, his agent said yesterday. ''When someone has you by the neck and is choking you, you do what you have to do to survive,'' said Tony De-Marco, the agent for the 21-year-old left-hander.

title: 200 Bush Fires on Tasmania
description: More than 200 bush fires swept across the Australian island of Tasmania today, threatening the state capital of Hobart and several other towns. Fire officials called the situation ''desperate.''

title: HOME PARTIES THAT PAY
description: ''I've got that Tupper feeling up in my head, up in my head, up in my head ...'' The ''Tupperware ladies,'' and a few men, sang this corporate song and clapped, filling the large meeting room at the Ramada Inn with their enthusiasm for the polyethylene bowls and all they have provided.

title: Iran Cuts Oil Price for Second Time
description: Iran told buyers today that it had cut its crude oil prices by a dollar a barrel for the second time this month as a world glut continues to alarm the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, OPEC, industry sources said.

title: Plane Forces Van Off Road
description: A pilot ran out of fuel and landed his small plane on U.S. Route 51, running a van off the highway as he touched down, the police said. No injuries were reported. The police said Billy Tyree of Sparta, Tenn., tried to land his Cessna at the Streator airport Sunday night but found it too windy.

title: CROSS BETWEEN CORN AND A WILD RELATIVE YIELDS A PERENNIAL CROP
description: FOR thousands of years farmers have had to plant a new corn crop every spring. Recently, however, an American-Argentine collaboration bred a perennial variety by crossing corn with a distant wild relative, teosinte, which is native to Central America.

title: TEACHER TRAINING SNARED IN UNCERTAINTY
description: LAST week, the State of Florida turned down a program calculated to improve the education of teachers. The Higher Education Committee of the Florida House of Representatives rejected a bill to give scholarships to future teachers in ''areas of critical need,'' especially science, mathematics and foreign languages. The proposed legislation had drawn praise from educators nationwide and one leader - Ernest L. Boyer, the president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching - had hailed the plan as a model for the remaining 49 states.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1982; The Economy
description: Inflation around the world has been dropping sharply, with the rate down to about 8 percent in the seven largest non-Communist industrial nations. Economists, who attribute the drop partly to slow growth, expect the downward trend to continue. (Page A1.)

title: TV: AN OCCULT WHIMSY
description: HOW do you like your whimsy? ''Come Along With Me,'' which WNET-TV, Channel 13, will show at 9 o'clock tonight, stars Estelle Parsons as a clairvoyant - frizzy hair, flat-heeled shoes, uneven hemline, speaking without punctuation in a rusty voice, and smiling a mysterious smile because she knows things other people don't. She talks to spirits; she does a little shoplifting; she changes her name from Mabel Lederer to Angela Motorman. It is the kind of whimsy that Miss Parson does particularly well, and if this is enough for you, you will be amused by ''Come Along With Me.'' There is not much to it besides that.

title: JAMES CAMPBELL HODGE
description: James Campbell Hodge, retired chairman and chief executive officer of Warner & Swasey Company, died Friday at his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 79 years old.

title: Campbell-Mithun Gains Pentax Unit's Business
description: The Pentax Corporation of Englewood, Colo., the American marketing subsidiary of a Japanese camera and optical equipment company, has consolidated all of its advertising with Campbell-Mithun Advertising, Minneapolis, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A respected United States Cabinet member comes to Jordan and doesn't demand of Jordan - certainly not publicly - support of the Camp David accords.

title: New York School Aid Is Still Unfair
description: The bill for New York's discriminatory method of financing public education is coming due. A court long ago declared it unconstitutional to permit wide discrepancies in school expenditures for rich and poor communities. But the disparities persist.

title: RARE DUCK MAY CONFOUND PREDATORS, BUT ORNITHOLOGISTS KNOW ITS SECRETS
description: THE scientists had been told by a South American wildlife expert that there was ''something funny'' about the ducks that lived in the Atlantic off Puerto Melo on the coast of Argentina. It seemed odd, they were told, that several experienced birders had observed the ducks but could not agree on their proper identification.

title: JOHN PAUL ASSURES AFRICANS OF RESPECT FOR THEIR VALUES
description: Pope John Paul II preached today, the fourth day of his pilgrimage to Africa, on the Roman Catholic Church's respect for the many cultures of this world.

title: NORTH CAROLINA REPUBLICAN,MARK II
description: One of the first things you notice about Senator John P. East's office is the big picture of Jesse Helms. The photo shows Senator Helms, flanked by Senator East and two other men, and it is the only political picture on the wall. That is unusual by Capitol Hill decorating standards. But then the relationship between Senator Helms and Senator East, who are both North Carolina Republicans, is unusual.

title: CONCERT: 2 THEATER PIECES BY NOEL DA COSTA
description: IT is easy to forget that music's original home was not in the concert hall but in celebrations of daily life. The origins of opera lie in the folk tradition; music was connected to myth and story, to community sharing of sensations and sense.

title: BREEDING ANIMALS FOR THE LAB
description: Henry L. Foster may have built his company from nothing into the acknowledged world leader in its field in the past 35 years. He may have set new standards of customer service, work conditions and product quality. He may have helped save thousands of lives.

title: 0. Spring in Your Steps
description: Boots aren't just for winter. Bendel's has some very attractive ones, designed by Fausto Santini of Italy, which are meant to be worn with spring's new short hemlines. The boots, which come in two versions, have linen tops with the shoe part done in leather. One style, in white or black, has an asymmetrical cuff at the top. The other has a high linen top to crush down to midcalf or ankle length and can be had in red, royal blue or off-white. Either pair is $150 in the Shoestrings section on the store's fourth floor.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to Jan 2
'Over the Edge' to Run In Area Movie Houses
description: ''Over the Edge,'' a 1977 film that was highly praised when it was recently given its premiere at Joseph Papp's Public Theater, will begin engagements in theaters in the metropolitan area starting Friday.

title: PRICE OF GASOLINE IS TUMBLING AS A GLOBAL OIL GLUT PERSISTS
description: The current oversupply of crude oil worldwide has caused gasoline prices in the United States to drop by at least 2 cents to 3 cents a gallon in less than a month, and analysts say further reductions are a near certainty.

title: THE HMONG OF LAOS HAVE NOT BEEN WIPED OUT
description: To the Editor:

title: TIMES APPOINTS 3 EXECUTIVES
description: The New York Times Company yesterday announced three appointments - two in the magazine group, which includes Family Circle, Golf Digest and Tennis, and a third in the marketing department of The Times.

title: 4 Jockeys, 2 Trainers Lose Race-Fix Appeals
description: Four jockeys and two horse trainers lost appeals today of convictions resulting from a race-fixing scheme at Garden State Park in 1974 and 1975.

title: NEW YORK TIMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $6,287,000 for the quarter and $22,498,000 for the year from equity in the earnings of associated companies; C-Including income of $3,874,000 for the quarter and $13,014,000 for the year from equity in the earnings ofassociated companies

title: FLICKINGER, S M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 23
ISRAEL AGAIN SHUTS WEST BANK SCHOOL
description: The leading Palestinian university in the Israeli-occupied West Bank was ordered closed today for two months by the Israeli military government, an army spokesman announced today.

title: Index; International
description: A clamor for change is sounding across the Sudan A2 Hope fades for 84 lost in oil rig dis- aster off Newfoundland A3 Zimbabwe seizes property owned by Nkomo's party A4 Around the World A5 Reagan urged to stress military threat in Caribbean A6 Pope says of Poland, ''I do not lose hope'' A9 West Bank university closed again by Israel A11 Government/Politics Stein assails Transit Authority on tunnel reconstruction B2 James Emery seeks G.O.P. nomi- nation for New York Governor B3 New accusations leveled against Labor Secretary's company B5 Inquiry ordered on vote to decer- tify air controllers' union B8 Washington Talk Briefing A20 Nancy Reagan stopping accept- ance of loans of gowns A20 Totals of food stamp users remain a shifting target A20 Decisions: Valve on heating de- vice recalled by maker A20 Federal Elections Commission battles Lance and Udall cases A20 General Around the Nation A16 Tennessee prison riddled with ra- cial violence A16 Growth of nearby Bath shipyard spills over to Portland, Me. A16 Fire heavily damages dozen stores in Jamaica mall B3 Missing retarded girl is found un- hurt in Manhattan B4 Health/Science Space shuttle is moved to its launching pad A16 Living Section Food Improvisation: Unlocking a se- cret of great cooking C1

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.N.A. Not available because markets were closed for Washington's Birthday.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to De 31
S.O.R.C. Triangle Race To Windward Passage
description: Windward Passage, owned by William Johnson of Atlanta today won the Ocean Triangle race of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference.

title: POE & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AUDIOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CROWLEY FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Military Analysis
description: The cumulative effect of any sale by the United States of modern fighters and mobile Hawk missiles to Jordan on the balance of air power in the Middle East is a major concern for Israeli planners.

title: STEIN ASSAILS THE TRANSIT AUTHORITY ON LENOX AVENUE TUNNEL PROJECT
description: The Transit Authority has asked the Federal Government for $150,000 to study a flooding problem on the Lenox Avenue subway line that the authority has already spent nearly $25 million to solve, Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan charged yesterday.

title: Rudy May Doubting His Role
description: Rudy May fears that he will be this year's version of Ken Holtzman on the Yankees. Holtzman was the pitcher who was the invisible man of the Yankees in 1977. He wore a Yankee uniform, but he was seldom seen in a game. May, who was involved in a trade for Holtzman in 1976, says he expects that could be his plight with the Yankees.

title: MID-AMERICA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Insurance Venture
description: Alexander & Alexander International Inc., a New York-based international insurance brokerage, said it had acquired for an undisclosed price a 21 percent equity interest in the French insurance brokerage of Cie Europenne de Coutage d'Assurances et de Reassurances. Alexander said Cie Europenne de Coutage is the fourth-largest insurance broker in France. It said its stake is the first financial link between the two concerns, which have been corresponding brokers for more than 15 years.

title: STUDENT AID: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
description: The Federal Government has provided direct financial aid to college students for nearly a quarter-century -since legislation was passed in 1958 amid a wave of national concern over the Soviet Union's launching of the first earth satellite.

title: WINE TALK
description: Summertime travelers through the Loire Valley of France are often tempted to stop at restaurants beside the meandering river, order a bottle of the local white wine and contemplate the verdant beauty that surrounds them as the water slides by. Often the wine will be made from the sauvignon blanc grape, although the labels will say Pouilly-Fume, Sancerre, Quincy, Reuilly or any of a number of other local names.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Presidential View
description: Saying it ''would clarify what is now a very murky picture,'' Howard Swearer, the president of Brown University, suggested it might be time for open affiliation between professional teams and major college sports powers. ''In effect, the major football and basketball - and to a lesser extent, hockey - powers have become the farm clubs for the professional teams,'' Mr. Swearer said in an eight-page assessment of college athletics that was delivered to Brown's trustees last weekend and released yesterday. ''May not the time have arrived when it would be desirable to recognize openly this symbiotic relationship ... and make the necessary structural changes?'' He said such a move would further improve finances for universities now being overwhelmed by the lure of television revenues, and would curb scandals involving academic cheating, recruiting and financial-aid violations.

title: WILLIAMS IS GIVEN 3 YEARS AND A FINE IN ABSCAM INQUIRY
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey was sentenced today to three years in prison and fined $50,000 on charges of bribery and conspiracy. The charges grew out of the Justice Department's Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: POPE ASSERTS OF POLAND, 'I DO NOT LOSE HOPE'
description: Pope John Paul II told the Polish community here, in the presence of the ambassador of the martial law regime of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, that he remained hopeful that the prayers of the Polish people would be answered.

title: GRESCHNER IN HOSPITAL
description: The Rangers said yesterday that Ron Greschner, the defenseman who also plays left wing, was in traction at Lenox Hill Hospital because of back trouble, and would stay for perhaps a week.

title: HAZELTON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of new accounting rules for foreign currency translations

title: MUNSINGWEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $3,204,112 loss from discontinued operations and disposition of South Robeson Mills inc

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Decision File
description: Every day Federal agencies and courts make decisions that affect the lives of Americans. Here are some recent cases: Gas Valve Recall

title: TURK THOUGHT TO BE ACCOMPLICE IN ATTACK ON THE POPE IS ARRESTED
description: A Turk thought to have been an accomplice of Mehmet Ali Agca, the man who tried to kill Pope John Paul II, has been arrested and is being held by the police, according to a court spokesman in Hamburg.

title: Turks Tell U.S. Senator Of Military Aid Needs
description: Turkish leaders told the chairman of the Senate Armed Forces Committee today that the Turkish armed forces needed more American military assistance.

title: ASSEMBLY'S EMERY JOINS G.O.P. GOVERNORSHIP RACE
description: James L. Emery, the Assembly minority leader, ruled out a reelection campaign yesterday, taking his chances instead on winning the Republican nomination for Governor.

title: Interpublic Group's Net Dropped 23.1% in '81
description: If currency exchange rates in 1981 were the same as in 1980, according to the Interpublic Group of Companies, its net income would be up 15 percent. However, they were not the same and net income was down 23.1 percent.

title: FORTRESS PRISON HARBORS VIOLENCE THAT ERUPTED IN DEATH OF 2 BLACKS
description: Months of racial tension and violence led up to the killings of two black inmates by white prisoners this month in Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary. The facility is part of a troubled state system, on trial itself for more than four years, that has been found guilty by a state judge of inadequacies in virtually every area.

title: Brunswick's Unit Sought
description: The American Home Products Corporation began a $425 million tender offer in a transaction intended to give it ownership of the Brunswick Corporation's Sherwood Medical unit.

title: FUTURES IN STOCKS APPROVED
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission opened the way for a broad expansion of futures trading based on stock market indexes today by approving a proposal by the Kansas City Board of Trade to deal in such instruments.

title: Market Place; How One Pro Picks Stocks
description: SEVEN years ago Barry Ziskin, a money manager, set forth benchmarks of stock market value, and since then he has limited holdings to shares that meet his guidelines.

title: RISING INCOMES IN CHINA PRODUCE MANY INCENTIVES TO CHEAT BYUERS
description: Along Peking's bustling market street of Chongwenmen recently, city inspectors noticed that one bakery was selling its pastries by the box without bothering to weigh them.

title: MRS. REAGAN DEPLORES A DRUG 'EPIDEMIC'
description: The narcotics problem among young Americans has reached epidemic proportions, Nancy Reagan said at an informal news conference today aboard the Air Force plane carrying her to Texas from St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Rally Pares Dow Loss to 2.47
description: The stock market closed moderately lower yesterday after a late rally pared sharp losses earlier in the day that were sparked by interest-rate fears.

title: BEST BUYS
description: FOOD prices are beginning to return to normal after the sharp rise caused by recent freezing weather. The average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City fell back $2.21 to $107.38 during the period from Feb. 1 to 12, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GROUND LEVEL

title: Comings and Goings
description: Manny Goldstein, the former assistant basketball coach convicted on fraud charges stemming from a recruiting scandal at the University of New Mexico, is seeking a new trial, saying he has new evidence to prove he is not guilty. ... Earl Weaver, the Orioles' manager, has been fined $1,065 by a Baltimore County judge who indefinitely revoked Weaver's driver's license and imposed a suspended sentence. Weaver was arrested on the violation last Aug. 31. ... John Kinsella, a former Olympic swimmer, has been sentenced by a Federal judge to spend 12 weekends in jail and fined $30,000 for failing to file Federal income tax returns. Kinsella, now a stockbroker, pleaded no contest to charges of failing to file returns in 1975, 1976 and 1977.

title: To the Middle East, by Carpet
description: In Saudi Arabia, humiliation. In Jordan, mystification. In Israel, indignation. Thus ends another of Defense Secretary Weinberger's good-will missions to the Middle East.

title: AMERICAN AGRONOMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results are pro forma; the company changed its fiscal yr-end from Nov 30 to Sept 30, effective Sept 30, 1981

title: Economic Scene; Reagan Eases Rift With Fed
description: DETENTE has broken out between the Reagan Administration and the Federal Reserve Board. On the television talk shows, the preferred medium of officials who wish to make high policy pronouncements without danger of severe cross-examination, the chairman of the Fed, Paul A. Volcker, has praised the Administration for proposing $55 billion in deficit-shrinking measures for the fiscal year 1983, and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has praised Mr. Volcker for doing ''a good job.''

title: Kroger Profit Climbs 77.7%
