description: The Kroger Company, the nation's secondlargest grocery retailer (after Safeway Stores Inc.), said today that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981 rose 77.7 percent, to $52.6 million, or $1.72 a share, from $29.6 million, or $1.07 a share, a year earlier.

title: 18 ON SOVIET FREIGHTER DIE
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Feb. 16 - Planes and ships searched in vain today for survivors among the 84 men who were aboard an oildrilling rig that listed and sank in a storm off Newfoundland on Monday.

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $636,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the purchase of subordinated debentures

title: AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Real Estate; Building Is Strong in Ski Areas
description: DEVELOPERS in ski resort areas contend that business is still lively despite a slow economy. There have been better years, they say, but ski area development has not been hurt as badly as other sectors of the real estate market.

title: Father's Vigil Ends
description: Scotty Morrison, the vice president in charge of officiating for the National Hockey League, was told yesterday in St. John's, Newfoundland, that his 24-year-old son, Perry, was among those believed to have died in the sinking of an oil rig Monday in the North Atlantic. Perry Morrison worked as a deep sea diver for Hydrospace Marine Serices aboard the rig.

title: OLD REPUBLIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: For Dostoyevsky, crime and punishment were indissolubly linked, but he was not a bridge player. At the bridge table, as in real life, crime often goes unpunished and the innocent often suffer heavy penalties.

title: SHOT WITH :01 LEFT SEALS KNICKS DEFEAT
description: The Dallas Mavericks call it the ''One'' play. It is designed to spread out the defense and get the ball to an open man, any open man, for an easy jumper. Last night, it went to the most unlikely man.

title: J.L. Hudson Plans Employee Cuts
description: The J.L. Hudson Company, which operates 19 department stores in Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, said it is laying off 280 management employees. The layoffs are aimed at streamlining the company's management structure, P. Gerald Mills, president and chief executive, said in a statement.

George Busbee, former Mayor Maynard Jackson and other state officials about whether there was political pressure to prosecute Mr. Williams. The officials have denied any pressure.

title: Doctors Examine Cooney

title: AN INDOOR MOVE FOR MODERN'S MASTERPIECES
description: With great respect but with a job to do, the movers have come to the Museum of Modern Art. Stacked quite humbly frame to frame in a corner against a bare wall were a Matisse and two Mondrians. Four Matisse sculptured heads lay on a cloth on the floor looking for all the world like a family of sleeping sisters. A life-size George Segal sculpture, lashed to a dolly and wood frame, seemed tortured where once it was exalted.

title: WEISWEILER OUSTED AS COSMOS' COACH
description: Citing a ''divergence of views as far as the immediate future'' of the team was concerned, the Cosmos yesterday dismissed Hennes Weisweiler, who had led the club to two North American Soccer League championship games in his two years as coach.

title: A Fifth Official Song
description: Most states manage to struggle along with a single official state song, but not Tenneessee, perhaps because of Nashville's reputation as the home of country music.

title: A.T.& T. ASKS CHANGES IN INTERNATIONAL RATES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in an effort to increase international calling during offpeak hours, asked permission today to restructure its overseas rates and establish two new discount periods for all international calls. The changes would mean higher rates for callers who cannot take advantage of the new discount periods.

title: IRISH VOTERS' PROBLEM: ECONOMICS, NOT ULSTER
description: Despite a common perception abroad that Ireland's principal issue is Ulster, the parliamentary election tomorrow will be decided on economics. The divisive issue of Irish reunification has been secondary during the brief election campaign in the wake of Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald's unexpected budgetary defeat last month.

title: SETON HALL SNAPS 11-GAME LOSS STREAK
description: The longest losing streak in the 80-year history of Seton Hall basketball came to an end at 11 games tonight when Dan Callandrillo sank two foul shots with 12 seconds left to give the Pirates a 61-59 upset of Connecticut in a Big East Conference game.

title: Would-Be Hijacker Stopped at Miami Airport
description: A man identified as Jesus Villa Munoz of Hialeah fired on two Miami International Airport gate agents and the police today after he tried to board an Air Florida flight to Key West in a hijack attempt, the police said.

title: UNION'S LEADERS FORESEES STRIKE OR CUTS AT G.M.
description: The United Automobile Workers will probably face a choice of accepting a sharp rollback of wages and benefits at General Motors this fall or calling a strike from a weak position, the union president, Douglas A. Fraser, said today.

title: Combustion Engineering
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 increased 28.1 percent, to $54.3 million, or $1.64 a share, from $42.4 million, or $1.30 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Fourth-quarter sales increased 4.8 percent, to $1.04 billion, from $991.8 million.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1982
description: International President Reagan assured Israel that the United States remained committed to maintaining the Israelis' military superiority over their Arab neighbors and said that no new ''requests'' had been made to sell military equipment to Jordan. The assurance, made in a letter to Prime Minister Menachem Begin, followed reports quoting Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and his aides as saying they favored selling advanced weapons to Jordan. (Page A1, Column 6.) Doubts about the Salvadoran Army were increasing as the senior United States military commander in Latin America began a three-day visit. The commander, Lieut. Gen. Wallace H. Nutting, arrived in San Salvador at a time of rising concern about whether the Salvadoran armed forces can defeat the rebels, even with more United States aid. (A1:4-5.)

title: ASSESSING FRESHNESS OF CITY'S MEAT AND POULTRY
description: IN New York's butcher shops and supermarkets there are aged prime ribs from Iowa, rosy pork roasts from Nebraska and Ohio, plumplooking chickens from Maryland and Pennsylvania, neatly rolled and ready-for-roasting lamb from Colorado and Utah and even milk-fed veal from Brooklyn. There is no doubt that the city offers shoppers a remarkable variety of meat and poultry. But how fresh is it? Most of the meat in stores here is available within four or five days of being slaughtered; poultry often within a day or two. However, freshness, if one is talking about age alone, cannot be easily defined for these foods. The fact is, beef actually improves in flavor if it is aged properly for a week or two. To some tastes, lamb and many types of This is the second of four articles on freshness in food. game are also better after aging. Anyone who has tried to eat a chicken or turkey the same day that it is killed knows what it's like to eat rubber; these birds have to sit for a day, long enough for the muscles to relax, before they can be properly cooked. Pork, veal and organ meats need to be eaten quickly, certainly within a week, or they will spoil.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: SUNDAY breakfast is a sliced orange, Spanish omelet, two pieces of whole-wheat toast with margarine and a glass of skim milk. Monday dinner is roast beef with mashed potatoes, corn, green beans and spinach, rye bread with margarine and grapes. Wednesday lunch is a lentil and rice casserole, sprout salad and two pieces of wholewheat bread with margarine. Saturday's bedtime snack is corn flakes with milk, half a banana and two graham crackers.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Police scuba divers recovered the body of a man from a car that had plunged into the Hudson River from Pier 79 at 39th Street at 6:15 P.M. He was not immediately identified. ... Mrs. G. Oliver Koppel, the wife of the Bronx Assemblyman, was robbed of $10 at knifepoint at 12:50 P.M. by a teen-ager while riding on the Seventh Avenue IRT subway line between the 242d and 238th Street stations. ... The nephew of Margaret Monahan, 57, who was stabbed to death last Friday in her apartment at 110 Bedford Street in Greenwich Village, surrendered to the police last night, the police said. Accompanied by a lawyer, the nephew, Thomas J. Monahan, 27, of Amityville, L.I., gave himself up to Sixth Precinct detectives at about 10 P.M., the police said, and was charged with homicide.

title: Rights Plan Dead in Virginia
description: The proposed Federal equal rights amendment's last chance for ratification in Virginia vanished today when proponents failed by a single vote to squeeze it through the State Senate. The vote was 20 to 19 for the amendment, one short of the 21 votes needed for a majority in the 40-member Senate. The defeat left the amendment still three states short of the required 38 that must ratify it by a June 30 deadline if it is to become part of the Constitution.

title: MET OPERA: MISS HORNE AS ROSINA IN 'BARBIERE'
description: ANY production of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' that starts out with Marilyn Horne as its Rosina has already taken a long stride toward the winner's circle. Miss Horne, as she demonstrated dazzlingly Monday night in the Metropolitan Opera's new mounting of Rossini's comic masterpiece, is unapproachable nowadays in the role, certainly among currently active mezzo-sopranos and probaby among sopranos as well. Hers is, of course, the mezzo-soprano voice for which the part was written, the rare breed known as coloratura mezzo. To have her back on the Metropolitan stage, even in the few performances the company has been able to offer her this season, is reason for celebration.

title: 12 Hurt in Philippine Clash
description: Seven workers and five policemen were wounded today in a clash between strikers and riot policemen at a textile factory in suburban Manila, the police said. Officers said the clash began when the workers, on strike for higher wages since Thursday, tried to prevent four trucks loaded with textiles from leaving the factory by throwing rocks at them and at nearby policemen.

title: TOTALS FOR FOOD STAMPS ARE A SHIFTING TARGET
description: Are the food stamp rolls growing or shrinking? Do budget cuts exist only in the eyes of the beholder? Those questions have arisen as a result of a repetition by President Reagan. In his budget last year, Mr. Reagan said that one in 10 Americans were receiving food stamps. At his request, Congress then tightened the eligibility criteria. Agriculture Department officials predicted that 875,000 Americans would be cut from the program.

description: Q. When I dined in a friend's home where curry was served, there was a peculiar side dish that tasted quite fishy. I was told it was called Bombay duck. Have you ever heard of such a dish?

description: B-Including a gain of $13,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $1.4 million, or 69 cents a share, on the sale of foreign licensing rights

title: LIBERTY NATIONAL INSURANCE HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Analysis
description: In the last two weeks, Mayor Koch has spent a good deal of his time talking publicly about the ''hypocrisy'' he sees at the United Nations, about his musings on whether to run for Governor, about biblical quotations to be carved into a wall on First Avenue and about the ''sellout of Israel'' that he attributes to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: FRANK J. DUFFICY DIES: FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY
description: Frank J. Dufficy, a former assistant United States attorney who testified against Tammany Hall about the sale of judgeships in 1952, died last Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. HAS NOT ALTERED POLICY ON ISRAEL
description: President Reagan told Prime Minister Menachem Begin today that the United States remained committed to maintaining Israel's military superiority over its Arab neighbors and said there were no new ''requests'' to sell Jordan military equipment.

title: E.E.C.-U.S. Talks
description: Prime Minister Wilfried Martens of Belgium arrived here today for talks with President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. over the European Economic Community's uneasiness with current United States economic policies. Mr. Martens will meet Mr. Reagan Wednesday morning and have lunch with Mr. Haig. He is also to speak at the Center for Strategic Studies at Georgetown University.

title: Ohio Concern Under Study
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating allegations that an Ohio company misled investors into buying $1 million worth of bogus contracts for deferred delivery of coal, according to documents filed today in Federal District Court here.

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The company changed its yr-end from a fiscal yr ended Aug 31 to a calendar yr; results for the previous yr are for the yr ended Aug 31, 1980; two major accounting changes were made in 1981 that affected earnings; in Dec changes in the method of valuing domestic inventories from first-in, first-out, LIFO, reduced 1981 earnings by 41 cents a shr; the company also adopt the new F.A.S.B. No 52 rules that govern the translation of foreign currencies, increase earnings by 26 cents; the net result was a reduction of 15 cents in shr earnings

title: WALESA IS SAID TO EXPECT RELEASE
description: Lech Walesa believes he will be freed from detention by March 7 to attend the christening of his daughter, a Roman Catholic priest said today after a meeting with the Polish labor leader.

title: Two Sentenced In Attack on Nun
description: Two Manhattan men who had pleaded guilty to reduced charges in a rape and mutilation attack on a nun in East Harlem last October were sentenced yesterday to prison terms.

title: MAJOR EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; results for the latest and year-ago quarters are pretax

title: REAGAN IS PRESSED ON CARIBBEAN AID
description: The State Department wants President Reagan to speak out more strongly on military threats to the Caribbean in a speech he is planning to make on a development plan for the region, Administration officials say.

title: BRIEFING
description: Top Don at Cram City

title: Soviet Buys More Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 200,000 metric tons of corn - nearly 7.9 million bushels - from the United States for delivery by Sept. 30, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: ELECTIONS UNIT'S TASKS: UDALL AND LANCE CASES
description: Bert Lance, the resilient Georgia banker driven from Washington under a cloud almost five years ago, is living in the sunshine of prosperity again. He has regained control of his old bank in Calhoun, Ga., gone into the Texas Ruby chili business and is considering running for Governor.

title: Executive Cup Race
description: It may not be the America's Cup, but yachtsmen from Westchester and Nassau Counties could be racing against each other this summer if a challenge by the Westchester County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, is accepted by the Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell.

title: REPUTED ATTICA REVOLT LEADER TO GET A NEW TRIAL ON ASSAULT
description: UF814ALBANY, Feb. 16 (AP) - A reputed leader of the Attica prison uprising in 1971 must be given a new trial for a 1979 assault conviction, New York's highest court ruled today.

title: WYMAN-GORDON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE POP LIFE
description: LOU ANN BARTON is a 28-year-old singer from Fort Worth. She made a few brief appearances in New York between 1978 and 1980 and impressed critics, musicians and audiences with her talent, her individuality and her radiant enthusiasm. She clearly deserved the chance to record an album, but there was doubt that she would attract the interest of a major record label. Singers who don't write their own material are notoriously difficult to match up with the right songs and the right producers, no matter how gifted they are. And Miss Barton was singing mostly blues and soul, which have not been widely popular in recent years.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gillman an Eagle Again
description: The Philadelphia Eagles went from the Super Bowl to elimination by the Giants in the one year he was retired.

title: DYCO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VOLUNTEERS TRY TO RAISE SPORTS FUNDS
description: At Adlai Stevenson High School, the basketball coach sells tattered uniforms, and his players sell candy to raise money for new equipment. At Boys and Girls High, parents and neighbors donate trophies and T-shirts for an annual basketball tournament. At Benjamin Franklin High, the basketball players wash cars and the coach reaches into his pocket to pay for out-of-town trips. At DeWitt Clinton High, anyone who puts a quarter into a fruit-juice machine is contributing 6 cents to the athletic department. Coaches, administrators and New York City officials involved in scholastic sports agree that Board of Education funds are no longer sufficient to maintain competitive, well-equipped and completely safe athletic programs. As a result, a recent survey of scholastic sports showed, schools conduct individual fund-raising events and seek volunteer help to continue fielding teams in a time of fiscal restraints. These efforts are more successful in some areas than others and therefore create inequities in a public school system that is supposed to serve rich and poor communities equally.

title: PANEL SAYS UTILITY USED OUTDATED NUCLEAR DATA
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded that the Pacific Gas and Electric Company used data that were two years out of date in building several earthquake-safety features of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant.

title: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
THE DEATH OF A PSYCHIATRIC PATIENT: THE GRAY AREA OF RESTRAINT
description: The death of a 27-year-old patient in a violent struggle with workers at the Manhattan Psychiatric Center last December has prompted investigations by the District Attorney's office, the New York City Police Department and two state agencies.

title: I.B.M. to Offer Volume Discounts
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would offer volume discounts for its System/34 and System/ 38 processors and price reductions on midrange and highrange models of the System/34.

title: Bethlehem's Vice Chairman Resigns; Board Cutbacks Set
description: Richard F. Schubert, a 45-year-old vice chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, announced his resignation yesterday, effective June 30, citing ''a personal decision to leave and pursue other opportunities.'' Mr. Schubert, a longtime Bethlehem official who spent about five years in the top echelons of the United States Labor Department, had been president of Bethlehem for a year before becoming vice chairman in 1980.

title: CAMPBELL TAGGART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PIONEER IN PAPERBACK PUBLISHING
description: Kurt Enoch, a pioneer in the paperback publishing field in Europe and the United States and a co-founder of New American Library, died Monday while on vacation in Puerto Rico. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Home-Court Advantage Is Declining in N.B.A.
description: The home-court advantage appears to be declining in the National Basketball Association.

title: Cavaliers Get Robinson
description: Only hours before last night's trading deadline in the National Basketball Association, the Cleveland Cavaliers acquired Cliff Robinson, formerly a first-round draft choice of the Nets, from the Kansas City Kings in exchange for another forward, Reggie Johnson. Robinson was traded by New Jersey to the Kings last spring in the deal that brought Otis Birdsong to the Nets. ... Kansas City also sent the center John Lambert to the San Antonio Spurs for a thirdround draft selection in 1984 and cash.

title: Armenian on West Coast Charged in Firebombing
description: The brother of the Armenian man accused of assassinating the Turkish Consul General was arrested today and charged with the 1980 firebombing of the diplomat's home.

title: BLACK AND WELL TO DO
description: I grew up in the kind of town few people believe exists: a black upper-middle-class suburb full of colonial-style houses and Volkswagen Rabbits. Yes, Virginia, there is a black bourgeoisie, it has existed for years, and it summers on Martha's Vineyard.

title: VW of America Plans a Shutdown
description: Volkswagen of America said it will suspend production at its assembly plant here for three weeks because of declining auto sales.

title: WALSH GETS 12 YEARS IN SEWER BRIBERY PLOT
description: The design engineer for four federally financed sewer projects in three states was sentenced yesterday to 12 years in prison and an $85,000 fine for racketeering and conspiracy in connection with the construction of the projects, including a $932 million sewer project in Suffolk County, L.I.

title: Remember Strategic Minerals?
description: The nation cheered last March when President Reagan declared himself eager to reduce dependence on imported minerals. The American economy had paid a high price for its failure to prepare for the oil shocks of 1974 and 1979. A wise society would guard against similar disruptions in other critical materials.

WRITER AND DIPLOMAT WAS 88
description: Nicholas Roosevelt, a diplomat, writer, conservationist and scion of the Roosevelt family of Oyster Bay, L.I., died Tuesday at Community Hospital in Monterey, Calif. He was 88 years old and resided in Big Sur, where he had moved after retiring from The New York Times in 1946.

title: BOTH SIDES SPURN PROPOSALS AT START OF N.F.L. CONTRACT TALKS
description: The opening meeting between management and labor to negotiate a new contract for pro football ended today with angry words.

title: 51 Indians Are Slain In Guatemala Village
description: Fifty-one Mayan Indians were dragged from their huts in a remote town and beheaded, officials said today. The army blamed leftist guerrillas, but the village's mayor said he did not know who killed them.

U.S. Warns Nicaragua Over 'Alien Influences'
description: President Reagan told Nicaragua's new Ambassador to the United States today that the sacrifices of the Sandinist revolution must not result in a new dictatorship in Central America.

title: Burlington Names A Chief Executive
description: Richard C. Grayson, 61 years old, has been named to the new post of chief executive officer of the Burlington Northern Inc. transportation group, as well as chairman of its Burlington Northern Railroad subsidiary, effective April 1. He will be succeeded as president of the railroad by Walter A. Drexel, 51, an official of the parent corporation.

title: CLAMOR FOR CHANGE IS SOUNDING ACROSS THE SUDAN
description: The dervishes dance here on Fridays. The dance is a deep-rooted tradition, performed by those who see themselves as close to Allah, for Islam is a powerful force in the Sudan, America's most prominent ally in East Africa.

title: AFTER TRAGEDY, 'BRAINSTORM' RESUMES
description: Douglas Trumbull gave a party on Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's Stage 29 on Feb. 5 and presented the cast and crew of his movie with champagne and bright red T-shirts. What was unusual was the legend printed on the shirts: ''Lloyds of London presents 'Brainstorm.' Coming soon to a theater near you.''

description: B-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $147,000

description: Here are some other ''arrangements'' for a good olfactory memory. All of them are tomato-based one way or another. Kept in mind, they enable the cook with a keen nose to say with confidence, ''Oh, yes, that's done like this.''

title: PRESIDENT OF CARNEGIE CORP. TO RESIGN
description: As Alan Pifer prepares to resign the presidency of the Carnegie Corporation, he foresees a time of deepening hardship for the nation's poor.

title: BATH SHIPYARD'S SUCCESS A BOON FOR PORTLAND, ME.
description: Defying the current recession and a long-term malaise in the American shipbuilding industry, the Bath Iron Works has embarked on a $46.7 million dollar new ship repair facility here, heavily financed by state and city money.

title: TEXT OF LETTER BY PRESIDENT REAGAN AND PRIME MINISTER MENACHEM BEGIN
description: Reagan's Letter Dear Menachem: Recent press reports have presented incorrect and exaggerated commentary regarding U.S. military assistance policies for the Middle East.

title: MACDERMID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Another 'Good Person' for Public Citizen
description: Joan Claybrook, a lawyer who worked for Ralph Nader before joining the Carter Administration as head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, rejoined the consumer movement yesterday and took over as president of Public Citizen, the organization Mr. Nader founded. It is the umbrella organization for five consumer groups that work on issues relating to energy, health, law, tax reform and lobbying.

title: Reagan Conference Is Set
description: President Reagan will hold his eighth nationally broadcast news conference Thursday at 2 P.M., Eastern standard time, the White House announced today. Mr. Reagan last met reporters in a formal news conference on Jan. 19. The session Thursday will be held in the White House East Room and will be broadcast live.

title: ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $17,226 from discontinued operations

title: LYON METAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Another Phillie Traded
description: A shakeup is going on in Philadelphia, where the Phillies have only 14 players left from their team that won the 1980 World Series. Yesterday Bake McBride became the third starter, after Larry Bowa and Lonnie Smith, to be traded away during the current offseason. McBride, a 33-year-old outfielder who hit .277 last year, was sent to the Cleveland Indians for Sid Monge, a 30-year-old left-handed relief pitcher who made the all-star team in 1979. ... The Detroit Tigers scored their first victory in five salary-arbitration rulings when Jack Morris, the club's top pitcher last season, who had asked for $650,000 this year, was told he would get $450,000.

title: TV: A FORGOTTON REBELLION OF SLAVES
description: WHEN an uprising succeeds, it becomes the basis for a national legend, but when it fails it becomes a footnote to history. ''A House Divided: Denmark Vesey's Rebellion,'' the drama on WNET-TV, Channel 13, tonight at 8, does a remarkably good job of taking this littleknown revolt of black slaves in Charleston, S.C., in 1822 and elevating it from footnote to an important part of American history.

title: Dartmouth Profits From a 'Squirrel's' Endeavors
description: Nobody in his family was interested in taking it over, the insurance company was getting on him about keeping it right there in his house and there didn't seem much sense in locking it away in a vault. So after a lifetime of collecting stamps, H. Meade Alcorn Jr. cleaned out his study, packed up albums dating back to the ones his father gave him in 1924 and presented the entire collection to his alma mater, Dartmouth College.

title: SAMUEL LAPOF
description: Samuel Lapof, founder and chairman of Bar-Ray Products Inc. of Brooklyn, manufacturer of X-ray equipment and X-ray shielding devices that Mr. Lapof invented, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Judge Says Davis Had No Oral Pact to Shift Team
description: Al Davis, the Oakland Raiders' managing general partner, did not have an oral contract as he claimed with the other National Football League owners to move his team to Los Angeles, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: TEENAGE MOTHERS AND BABIES IN SCHOOL
description: Once faced with dropping out of high school, teen-age mothers here are staying in class to learn English, science and mathematics - and how to care for their newborn babies.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK
description: Hambros Bank Ltd. is organing a $125 million five-year bond for the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, banking sources said here today. The bond will carry fixed 16 percent interest and is expected to be issued at par, the sources said.

title: A REQUIEM FOR HOPKINS, TRUE POET OF THE BLUES
description: ''A THOUSAND years my people was slaves,'' Lightnin' Hopkins used to sing, ''when I was born they teached me this way / tip your hat to the peoples / Be careful, son, about what you say.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want you to know that America's policy toward Israel has not changed.

title: MARSHALL FIELD BID BY ICAHN BLOCKED
description: A Federal judge in New York yesterday temporarily barred a group headed by the New York financier Carl C. Icahn from acquiring any more shares of Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago-based retail chain.

title: Advertising; JWT Finds $18 Million Irregularity
description: HAVING worked all through the long weekend, accountants and lawyers for the JWT Group have estimated that ''fictitious account entries into a computer'' of the JWT Syndication unit over the past four years led the publicly held corporation to take credit for $18 million in revenues that never existed.

title: Careers; Retiring Workers Get Tuition
description: BACK in 1976 the International Business Machines Corporation announced a bold new program, offering tuition dollars to employees approaching retirement. The money could be used to finance training for a second career or even a hobby.

title: No Headline

title: A G.M. MODEL'S SLOW DEBUT
description: Just after General Motors introduced its new ''A'' cars a few weeks ago, J.D. Power & Associates, a market research firm specializing in the purchasing habits of auto buyers, got an interesting phone call.

title: Firefighter Suffers Fatal Heart Attack
description: A firefighter suffered a heart attack and died yesterday while fighting a blaze in Queens, fire officials said.

title: HERSHEY FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1982; Energy
description: Gasoline prices in the U.S. have dropped 2 cents to 3 cents a gallon in less than a month because of the worldwide oversupply of crude oil. Further reductions, analysts say, are all but certain. Since last April, the national average price of gasoline has dropped by about a nickel, to $1.35, according to Platt's Oil Price Report, a trade publication. The decline in pump prices is in marked contrast to the near-tripling between 1973 and last April. (Page A1.)

title: Black Writers' Panel at Negro Ensemble Monday; Black Writers' Panel Set at Negro Ensemble
description: ''What It Means to Be a Black Playwright'' will be discussed Monday at 7:30 by Paul Carter Harrison, Joseph Walker, Alexis DeVeaux and Charles Fuller at the Negro Ensemble Company's Theater Four. Works by the four have been presented by the N.E.C.

description: Gluyas Williams was typical of a gifted group of cartoonists whose best work helps define our social memory. In Mr. Williams's case, the feat was achieved by black-and-white figures with chunky midriffs - the unmistakable inhabitants of clubland, the bridge table, the class reunion and business lunch.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Notes on People column on Mon- day gave an incorrect name for the ac- tress who is taking over the female lead in the Broadway production of ''Amadeus.'' She is Caris Corfman.

title: TV: LOIS GIBBS FIGHTS THE BATTLE OF LOVE CANAL
description: UNDER the direction of a softspoken executive named William Self, CBS-TV has carved out a special niche in the area of made-fortelevision movies. title: Chief Gets Extra Post At Travelers
description: Edward H. Budd, 48, president and chief executive officer of the Travelers Corporation, has been elected to the additional post of chairman. He succeeds Morrison H. Beach, who reached the retirement age of 65 last month and who retired after 43 years with the big insurance company.

title: CHORALE: SMITH SINGERS
description: ONE of the more remarkable aspects of Stravinsky's legacy is that it consists of works in practically every significant compositional genre. Small wonder, then, that groups of every size and shape are marking his centennial this year.

title: Weak Steel Demand Seen
description: European Economic Community steelmakers do not expect a rebound in their United States sales this spring but have made no decision to limit deliveries, sources close to the producers' association, Eurofer, said today.

title: LIE DETECTORS LIE
description: While the Reagan Administration's reliance on polygraph tests in its campaign to deter unauthorized disclosures to the news media is unlikely to plug all leaks, the practice highlights the threat to personal privacy by employers' use of the so-called lie detectors.

title: WALL ST. SETS UP SHOP IN SINGAPORE
description: Wall Street, already well entrenched in Hong Kong, is establishing a permanent presence in Singapore. In quick succession, five brokerage houses - Dean Witter Reynolds, Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, Drexel Burnham Lambert, Shearson Loeb Rhoades and an affiliate of the First Boston Corporation - have opened offices in the island nation at the southern tip of Asia's Malayan peninsula.

description: The New York State Court of Appeals declared today that parties seeking to change custody agreements in divorce cases did not have to prove that ''extraordinary circumstances existed.''

description: The Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe today expropriated farms and other properties belonging to a political party headed by one of its own Cabinet ministers, Joshua Nkomo. It also ordered a police raid on the Salisbury office of Mr. Nkomo's party.

title: LARGEST NON-EARTH MOLECULE DETECTED NEAR A CONSTELLATION
description: Radio astronomers in Ottawa have discovered what they describe as ''the largest and heaviest molecule yet detected outside the earth's atmosphere.'' This and similar discoveries have led astronomers to believe they are seeing the most elemental building blocks of life in much greater profusion in the universe than they had believed to be the case before.

title: Five Indicted in Buffalo On Illegal Entry Charge
description: Two Irish nationalists and three Canadians were indicted in Federal District Court here today on charges of trying to enter the United States illegally.

title: SALE OF CHRYSLER'S TANK UNIT SEEN
description: The Chrysler Corporation has agreed to sell its defense division to the General Dynamics Corporation, Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today.

title: REAGAN AND VOLCKER IN TALKS
description: President Reagan and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, met Monday to discuss monetary and budget policy, Administration officals confirmed today. No details of the conversation were made public.

title: MICRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOLMES, COONEY TO FIGHT JUNE 11
description: After getting a second opinion on Gerry Cooney's shoulder injury, the promoters announced yesterday that his heavyweight title fight with Larry Holmes had been postponed from March 15 to June 11.

title: Egypt Lowers Oil Price
description: Egypt has reduced its oil price by $1 a barrel because of the worldwide oversupply, an oil official said here today. The cut, the latest indication of the pressure on prices, lowers the price of a barrel of light Egyptian crude oil to $33 and is retroactive to Feb.1. Egypt exports about 200,000 barrels of its daily production of about 650,000 barrels.

title: Reagan News Session To Be Televised Today
description: President Reagan will hold a televised news conference today at 2 P.M. in Washington.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $340,100 on investment sales and a $200,000 writedown of investment securities to their net realizable value

title: OFFICIAL IN ISRAEL ASSAILSTHE TIMES
description: Zev Chafets, the director of Israel's Government Press Office, has criticized The New York Times for deleting from an interview with him published on Sunday his criticisms of the paper for not reporting the detention last summer of two of its correspondents by a Palestinian faction in Lebanon.

title: Foreigners Cut U.S. Investing
description: The value of foreign investment in United States manufacturing fell nearly 29 percent last year from 1980, a business research group said yesterday.

title: FACES OF AMERICA HANG IN THE HOUSES OF THREE COLLECTORS
description: BOSTON SITTING with Nina Fletcher Little is a bit like sinking gently into history. One discovers a young America. The mullioned windows of her sitting room, framed when the Massachusetts farmhouse that is her principal home was built in 1812, look out on snowy woods, gray and white in the dusk of winter. The tall clock by the door chimes softly and then ticks on, as steadily as it has since her great-greatgrandfather, a Salem clockmaker, built it around 1820.

title: FOOTE CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALLIED SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Jan 9
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,178,000 for the 12 weeks and $2,002,000 for the 28 weeks and a net gain of $32,780,000 for the 28 weeks on the settlement of Chapter 11 debts... C-Including tax credits of $852,000 for the 12 weeks and $1,589,000 for the 28 weeks and a net loss of $1.2 million for the 28 weeks on the settlement of Chapter 11 debts

title: NETS TOP BULLS BY 115-105
description: Phil Johnson's first and last game this season as head coach of the Chicago Bulls ended in a 115-105 loss to the Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CAREY CALLS FOR BIG CHANGE IN FINANCING PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: Governor Carey proposed today a broad program to change the way public education is financed in the state. It would include a one-cent increase in the state sales tax, now 4 cents on the dollar, and would call for $8.6 billion in new state education aid over the next five years.

title: BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Rev figures represent oil and gas sales

title:
CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
MAKING OPERA REALISTIC CAN BE A DELICATE TASK
description: ALOT of money and effort is expended in opera's attempts at realism, and the results are often quite impressive. Anyone who has seen the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''La Boheme,'' which was directed and designed by Franco Zeffirelli, has seen a good example of how the machinery of realism works: Through attention to the minutest details of lighting, scenery and costuming, through the application of highly sophisticated techniques of stagecraft, and not least through the painstaking coordination of gestures and actions on the stage, the production achieved a formidable sense of illusion.

title: Corsican Rebels Set Off 19 Bombs in France
description: Nineteen bomb attacks took place here and in Versailles today, mostly against Government property.

title: Soviet Reports Output Drop
description: Soviet industrial and agricultural production dropped in several key sectors during January compared with the same month last year, according to data published today by the weekly Economic Gazette.

title: NATIONAL CITY LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $475,000...C-After a charge of $7,946,000 for the qr and yr...D-Includes a tax credit of $1,751,000...E-Net loss

title: VOLUNTEERS TRACKING DOWN NEW YORK'S SIGNIFICANT INTERIORS
description: IF you happen to notice some inquisitive notebook-toting people snooping around building lobbies in New York these days, they may not be cause for suspicion. They may be volunteers for the Significant Interiors Survey, a joint project of the American Society of Interior Designers and the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Atlanta Jurors Are Told Of Williams's Activities
description: A long-time friend of Wayne B. Williams testified under cross-examination today that he saw the defendant cleaning out a back room shortly after his first encounter with the police and that he had never known Mr. Williams to date a woman.

title: New Envoy to Mideast To See Israeli Leaders
description: Richard Fairbanks, President Reagan's new special envoy to the Middle East, arrived in Israel today for talks on the Palestinian autonomy issue.

title: Gretzky Scores 2 Goals As Oilers Triumph, 7-4
description: Edmonton's Wayne Gretzky, closing in on two league records, scored a pair of goals and added three assists tonight to pace the Oilers to a 7-4 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Don't Say It!
description: Just how difficult it is for people to avoid saying the obvious was illustrated the other day when Angela Lansbury, in London, received a much-delayed trans-Atlantic telephone call from William Livingstone, a New York music writer. The call concerned her new recording of ''The Beggar's Opera.''

title: SAMUEL LAPOF
description: Samuel Lapof, founder and chairman of Bar-Ray Products Inc. of Brooklyn, manufacturer of X-ray equipment and X-ray shielding devices that Mr. Lapof invented, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: HOME BEAT
description: FOR the last three years, Stan Magnan and Gary Payne have worked together on environmental and graphics projects.

title: TV: DEFEAT'S COST, 'CHILDREN'S STORY'
description: THE Place: Right here. The Problem: They have just defeated us in a terrible war.The Peculiar Part: They haven't even rumpled our clothes.

title: Technology; Computers From Bacteria
description: WILL computers one day be grown in test tubes? A small but growing number of researchers see that as a possibility. They envision the day when computers will be made out of proteins or other chemicals, rather than the silicon now used. In what would be a merging of two glamour fields - electronics and genetic engineering - they say that bacteria could be manipulated to produce computer components in the same way they are now being engineered to turn out insulin and other chemicals.

title: State Investigating Tax Unit Worker
description: An employee of the state's Taxation and Finance Department is being investigated to determine if he deposited funds that should have gone into state accounts into his own bank account, District Attorney Sol Greenberg of Albany County said.

title: THE RIGHT TO VOTE MUST NOT BE A RIGHT TO WIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Warriors 121, Celtics 105
description: World B. Free and Purvis Short each hit key baskets late in the fourth quarter tonight to lead the Golden State past Boston and knock the Celtics out of first place in the Atlantic Division.

title: Uniroyal Net Down
description: Uniroyal Inc., citing the recession and the depressed auto industry, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 93.6 percent, to $300,000, from $4.7 million a year earlier. The earnings were used to pay dividends only on the company's preferred stock, so the profit translated into a loss of 3 cents a common share, compared with income of 17 cents a common share in the fourth quarter of 1980. Fourth-quarter sales fell 6 percent, to $558.4 million, from $596.2 million in the last quarter of 1980.

title: Flyers Take Aim at Islanders
description: If the Islanders are to tie the 52-year-old National Hockey League record of 14 consecutive victories tonight in Philadelphia, they will have to do it against a team and a coach unimpressed by winning streaks.

title: PERSUADING A TREE TO SURVIVE INDOORS
description: ''ARE they real?'' ask passers-by watching John Mini's crew tend the 25-foot trees in lobbies around town. The vegetation sprouting in interior plazas and atriums in the many new commerial buildings in Manhattan is definitely not artificial. Nor are they special new species. They are really quite ordinary house plants: dracaena, ficus and schefflera - although somewhat oversized - and the secrets of the professional gardeners who plant them should prove of interest to gardeners at home.

title: People
description: * John Carlino promoted to senior vice president at Keyes Martin, Springfield, N.J. * Stephen A. Bayer named a partner at Specht, Gilbert & Partners.

description: B-Includes $43,000 gain from discontinued operations and $1,424,000 gain from disposal of discontinued operations... C-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $113,000 for t qr and $90,000 for the yr and $549,000 gain for the 6 mos from the sale of a facility

title: RPS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Braniff Layoffs
description: The Braniff International Corporation has told its employees that reduced air traffic and the sagging economy could lead to the furlough of as many as 1,000 workers, an airline spokesman said. However, no layoffs have been announced, said Sam Coats, a Braniff vice president. Braniff furloughed more than 1,000 workers in August after the air traffic controllers' strike began.

title: NORMICK PERRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income which included a gain of $3.9 million for the yr from sale of 49 percent in subsidiary

title: THEATER: GUNTON BACK IN 'HOW I GOT THAT STORY'
description: TO see Bob Gunton in Amlin Gray's ''How I Got That Story'' is to be reminded that some actors really can do anything - or everything. Mr. Gray's harrowing black comedy about Vietnam, which opened at the Westside Arts Theater last night, asks that Mr. Gunton play an entire war-torn society all by himself. Not only must the actor impersonate more than 20 characters - characters of 2 sexes, 2 nationalities and all social strata - but he also must provide the sounds of Vietnam's gunfire, its bombing runs, its incessant background rock music. And Mr. Gunton does it all - without makeup, without elaborate costumes, without letup. Through sheer actor's magic, he transforms himself into a one-man ''Apocalypse Now.''

title: 'Have Gun, Will Travel'
description: He hasn't applied for the job, but Joseph Wambaugh, the police sergeant-turned-novelist, is one of 11 present or former law enforcement officers being considered for the position of Police Chief in Houston. And Mr. Wambaugh says he is ready to take the position if it is offered.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The tenure of Hennes Weisweiler as coach of the Cosmos ended Tuesday, but he said from his home in Neuss, West Germany, that he had not been ''fired.'' Rather, he said, his departure was a matter of ''mutual agreement'' between him and the club. ...

title: Witness Criticized In Stouffer's Case
description: The judge in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial described Edson F. White, a potential defense witness who testified last week in preliminary hearings, as ''a fraud and a charlatan with little or no respect for the truth.''

title: Carl Marks Starts Unit
description: Carl Marks & Company, a Wall Street investment firm, has established a subsidiary, the CM Capital Corporation, to handle its leveraged-buy-out and venture-capital activities, and has named two of the concern's executives to run it.

title: PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revs for the 1981 fourth qr and yr was increased by $1.8 million for the qr and $2.6 million for the yr as a result of acquisitions made by the company in 1981

CIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: ''Europe is in greater danger than the Americans have understood so far.

title: Margiotta Found Eligible to Vote
description: The State Board of Elections ruled unanimously that Joseph M. Margiotta, the chairman of the Nassau County Republican Committee, was eligible to vote while he appeals his Federal fraud and extortion conviction.

title: 'Washington in Review' Marking 15 Years
description: ''Washington Week in Review,'' public television's longest-running program, will celebrate its 15th anniversary Feb. 26 with a retrospective program as well as its customary examination of current events in Washington.

title: Amateur Boxer Dies After Injury to Head
description: An amateur boxer injured at a Golden Gloves tournament here last week died tonight at St. Joseph Hospital, doctors reported.

title: FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Cast Seeks Partner For Container Unit
description: The Cast group, a trans-Atlantic cargo shipper that has incurred the wrath of several major American ports by its price-cutting, said it was seeking a buyer for half of its container operations as part of a forced financial realignment.

title: KOCH IS CAUTIONED BY CONTROL BOARD ON BUDGET FOR '83
description: The executive director of New York State's Financial Control Board warned yesterday that New York City's finances were in their most perilous shape since the crisis of the mid-1970's. In addition, a report from the board's staff said, there is ''an unusual degree of uncertainty'' in city plans to balance the budget for the coming fiscal year.

title: T
description: HE warm surroundings of a crafts workshop might be a good way to spend a cold winter day. If the current registration schedule at cultural and historical organizations is any indication, there will be a variety of classes to choose from. Here is a sampling:

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DRILLING IS HALTED AFTER LOSS OF RIG
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Feb. 17 - Oil-drilling operations off Newfoundland are being suspended, and two offshore platforms are being brought in for inspection following the sinking Monday of the storm-battered rig Ocean Ranger with the presumed loss of 84 men.

title: 13 EXPERTS NAMED TO COUNCEL REAGAN'S ADVISER FOR SCIENCE
description: A White House Science Council was created today to counsel the President's science adviser on major technological issues.

title: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1982; The Economy
description: David A. Stockman, the budget director, indicated some flexibility in the Administration's plans for cutting the budget. Testifying under heavy criticism before the House Budget Committee, he said that some portions of last year's tax cuts could be scaled back or repealed to increase Government revenues. (Page A1.)

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: VARIOUS kinds of thermometers are particularly helpful in winter for keeping track of the temperature, humidity and wind-chill factor. Two catalogues have a large selection of weather instruments, including thermometers, hygrometers and windscopes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An item in Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly reported the value of an acquisition by the Hughes Tool Company. The transaction was valued at $60 million.

title: VERSATILE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
RECITAL: GOODE PLAYS BACH, SCHUBERT AND PERLE
description: ONE of the frustrations of following talented young pianists as their careers unfold is that so many turn out to be water lilies. They bloom beautifully in the morning sun, but shrivel up in the afternoon. The afternoon, for most of them, is in their late 30's or early 40's when, the challenge of competitions past and the flush of excitement of being a minor celebrity gone, they begin to settle for routine performances and a general leveling-out of intensity.

title: SPAIN GETS WARNING ON BASQUE NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Spain's largest private utility company has announced that it will suspend work on a nearly completed nuclear power plant outside Bilbao, which has been attacked by Basque terrorists, if the Government does not resolve its dispute with the Basque home-rule authorities over control of the project.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recently spilled nail-polish remover on a mahogany dresser. This left a spot about six inches in diameter where the fruitwood finish seems to have been removed. Is there any way I can finish that spot without having the entire piece refinished? -H.R., Glen Cove, L.I.

title: News Analysis
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders' challenge to the Reagan Administration's military spending policies represents a clear departure from the federation's past policies. But, some union officials acknowledged here today, it also demonstrates the glacial slowness with which change often comes to the labor movement.

title: South African Navy Ship Sinks After Collision
description: One of South Africa's two frigates collided with a naval supply ship and sank early today in stormy seas south of the Cape of Good Hope.

title: THELONIOUS MONK, CREATED WRY JAZZ MELODIES AND NEW HARMONIES
description: Thelonious Monk, the pianist and composer whose wry, angular melodies and unusual harmonic progressions are among the most striking contributions to the jazz repertory, died yesterday in Englewood Hospital in New Jersey at the age of 64. He had suffered a stroke on Feb. 5.

description: Net income for the latest yr includes proceeds from the settlement of litigation

title: SCHMIDT WORRIED OVER U.S. DEFICITS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt contends that West European society is in danger of political and social destabilization as a result of the world's continuing economic crisis.

title: LEE STRASBERG OF ACTORS STUDIO DEAD
description: Lee Strasberg, father of ''Method acting'' in America, artistic director of the Actors Studio, stage director, film actor and a major figure in world theater, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: HENRY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REVOLUTIONARY SLOGANS SURPRISE THE POPE IN AFRICA
description: Pope John Paul II looked slightly surprised today when President Mathieu Kerekou of neighboring Benin ended a speech of welcome by shouting, ''Ready for the revolution - the struggle continues!''

title: Dow Off 3.71 in Fourth Straight Decline
description: The stock market, as measured by the popular averages, sustained its fourth slight decline in a row yesterday. Analysts said that a major disappointment weighing upon market sentiment was the decision of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company not to raise its dividend. The nation's most widely owned company had raised the cash payout in February in five of the last six years.

title: Spanish Tourist Office Gives Account to Grey
description: The Spanish National Tourist Office has given its advertising account in the United States with billings of about $1.5 million to Grey Advertising.

title: EX-CONVICT LINKS MAFIA TO A RESORT
description: A former convict and police informer who was paid $17,500 by Penthouse magazine as a $100-an-hour consultant on organized crime has testified that he saw a number of reputed mob figures at La Costa, a California resort and health spa.

title: HERITAGE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
ROTELCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Second Mattel Agency
description: Kenyon & Eckhardt's newly enlarged Los Angeles office has become Mattel's second agency to Ogilvy & Mather. K.& E. says that it is working for the toymaker's new PPP Inc. division but will not identify what the division does.

title: Foot, Cone Net Up 20.5% in 4th Quarter
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications yesterday released its fourth-quarter financial results. Net income at the agency rose 20.5 percent, to $5.3 million, or $1.91 a share, from $4.4 million, or $1.61 a share, in the corresponding 1980 quarter.

title: Holiday Inns' Net Up
description: Holiday Inns Inc. announced today that earnings in the final quarter of 1981 rose 11 percent, to $13 million, or 39 cents a share, from $11.7 million, or 34 cents, in the similar period a year earlier.

TROUBLED NICARAGUA
description: Nicaragua, Alexander M. Haig Jr. has charged, is ruled by ''a violent minority'' that has transformed it into ''a totalitarian, militarized state'' that exports ''subversion and armed intervention throughout Central America.'' Faced with the Sandinists' ''greater internal repression, acceleration of arms buildups and strengthened links to the Soviet Union,'' Washington says it has no alternative but to plan military reprisals: the ''whatever is necessary'' of Mr. Haig's Senate testimony.

PRIME RATE UP TO 17% FROM 16 1 2%
description: Banks across the country raised their prime rate by half a point, to 17 percent, yesterday, touching off new fears of further increases that would drive the economy deeper into recession.

Mercury Morris Sues
description: A damage suit filed in Miami by Mercury Morris, once an elusive running back with the Dolphins, contends that injuries he received in a traffic accident six years ago prematurely ended his career. The defendant is the United Sanitation Service, which owns the truck with which Morris's automobile collided in an accident that Morris says caused severe hand and neck injuries.

title: REAGAN WILL UNVEIL CARIBBEAN AID PLAN TUESDAY
description: President Reagan plans to deliver his speech on improving the welfare of the Caribbean area to the Organization of American States Tuesday, White House officials said today.

RANGERS DEFEAT PENGUINS WITH 3D-PERIOD SURGE, 5-3
description: It was, said Coach Herb Brooks of the Rangers, ''a funny game, a strange game.'' It was also, said Brooks, acceptable ''because I'm happy to win on the road, even if it isn't artistic.''

title: BARTHELME TAKES ON TASK OF ALMOST DECIPHERING HIS FICTION
description: Donald Barthelme, whose short stories in The New Yorker and 10 books (to name three tantalizing titles: ''Snow White,'' ''Come Back, Dr. Caligari,'' ''Unspeakable Practices, Unnatural Acts'') have placed him on the summit of modern fictional invention, turned the tables on his critical interpreters Tuesday night. He did what he has seldom done: interpreted himself - somewhat.

title: Bridge: Casual Players Get Chance To Play With the Experts
description: The casual tennis player with little experience never has the opportunity to play doubles with, say, John McEnroe. And if he did, nervous tension would probably cause him to double-fault repeatedly.

title: Change in Rights March Upheld in U.S. Court
description: A Federal judge tonight refused to order city officials to allow a Southern Christian Leadership Conference group to retrace the steps of the 1965 voting rights march.

title: Vivion De Valera Dead at 72; Son of the Irish Statesman
description: Vivion De Valera, son of the Irish statesman Eamon De Valera, died of cancer Tuesday in a Dublin hospital. Mr. De Valera, a politician and newspaper publisher, was 72 years old.

title: COMA LAID TO INSULIN INJECTION
description: A Harvard Medical School neurologist who treated Martha von Bulow after her second coma in 1980 stated flatly on the witness stand today that her condition had been caused by low blood sugar from an injection of insulin.

title: Monk Tributes on Radio
description: A 33-hour tribute with Thelonious Monk's music began yesterday at noon, shortly after Mr. Monk's death became known, and will continue through 9 P.M. today on WKCR-FM.

title: No Headline
description: A sniper killed three persons and wounded at least three others, including a deputy, today as he fired weapons from a trailer. A man was taken into custody more than four hours after the shooting began.

description: B-Including tax credits of $178,000 for the qr and $799,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including income of $178,422 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change

title: FORCE OF 1,200 KEEPS THE HILL SECURE
description: It is no longer political extremists trying to shoot up the House or blow up the Senate who are giving the Capitol Hill police their biggest security headaches.

title: GALA TO BENEFIT O'NEILL CENTER
description: ''Broadway Celebrates Noel Coward and Gertrude Lawrence,'' an evening to benefit the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, will take place March 1. The high point will be a performance at the Ambassador Theater of the London production of ''Noel and Gertie,'' a revue devised by Sheridan Morley based on the letters, plays and songs of Coward and Miss Lawrence.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BOSTON (AL) - Signed Bruce Hurst, John Tudor, Luis Aponte, Mike Smithson and Dave Schoppee, pitchers; and Julio Valdez, shortstop.

title: Oil Find by AGIP
description: AGIP, the state-owned oil company, said today that a consortium in which it holds a 40 percent interest had struck oil in Alberta, Canada. The well is ready for production, but details of its capacity are not available, an AGIP spokesman said.

title: 2 GARMENT DISTRICT OFFICERS ACCUSED OF ACCEPTING BRIBE
description: A detective and a sergeant with the New York City police were arrested yesterday in a continuing investigation into police corruption in Manhattan's garment district.

title: TRANSWAY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $10,520,000 writeoff for discontinued cruise ship operations

title: TRW NET OFF 46% IN QUARTER
description: TRW Inc. reported yesterday that a write-off of nearly $35 million resulting from the disposition of its unprofitable digital telephone-switching business caused earnings to plunge 46 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981, while sales slipped 2.3 percent.

title: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFING
description: Immigration Limit

title: STAGE: 'CLOWNMAKER,' A PLAY ABOUT NIJINSKY AND DIAGHILEV
description: THAT intensive, obsessive relationship between Nijinsky and Diaghilev is exceedingly difficult to encompass on stage or on film, but the playwright Richard Crane has cluttered his course with extra obstacles. His play ''Clownmaker,'' directed by Isaiah Sheffer at the Wonderhorse Theater, is snarled with attitudinizing and artiness. It is a tedious play on a tantalizing subject.

title: Exxon Price Cuts
description: The Exxon Corporation said it is reducing its wholesale prices for No.2 (home heating) oil, diesel fuel and kerosene by one to 5.5 cents a gallon at Gulf and East Coast locations in reseller tankcar lots, effective today. Exxon also said it is cutting its New York harbor barge posted price for home heating oil by 6.5 cents to 94.3 cents a gallon.

title: HISTORIC COLD & SNOW
description: To the Editor:
