description: Yr-ago results are historical and not pro forma

title: STATE PROPERTY IS NEGLECTED, MAINTENANCE WORKERS ASSERT
description: A painter who works for the State Office of General Services said today that the agency operated on ''the breakdown principle.'' Joseph Kowalski, the painter, said this meant that the only time repairs were made was when a piece of equipment broke down. Basic maintenance, he said, just did not happen.

title: No Headline
description: N. CAROLINA ROUTS WAKE FOREST, 69-51

title: New Coalition Cabinet Is Formed in Finland
description: The formation of a new coalition Government was announced today with Kalevi Sorsa, the chairman of the Social Democratic Party, as Prime Minister.

title: FIRST COINVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DIVIDEND UNCHANGED AT A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company decided yesterday not to raise the dividend on its common stock despite 1981's record revenues and earnings.

title: 'WHY THIS DOWNGRADING OF EDUCATION'
description: To the Editor:

title: Laker Air Licenses Are Suspended
description: Laker Airways, the low-fare trans-Atlantic carrier that went into receivership on Feb. 5, had its operating licenses suspended by Britain's Civil Aviation Authority, a move that puts on hold the company's plans to begin flying under another name.

title: Cannon Stock Trading Halted
description: The Pacific Holding Corporation, the cornerstone holding of David H. Murdock, the Los Angeles financier, said it had acquired about 98 percent of Cannon Mills Inc. outstanding common shares through its $44-a- share tender offer.

title: Hamilton Scores 100 In Playoffs
description: Alexander Hamilton, which had gained the final berth of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs with a third-place finish in the Brooklyn III division, began its title defense yesterday with a 100-73 victory over Thomas Jefferson at South Shore High School. It was the ninth time this season that Hamilton had scored more than 100 points.

title: FORGET ABOUTH THE REDISTRIBUTION OF
description: WEALTHTo the Editor:

title: AETNA LIFE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Consumers Digest To Accept Advertising
description: Some 22 years ago Arthur Weber gave up electrical engineering, which he did not really like anyway, to go into magazine publishing and find a better way of life. The magazine, a bimonthly, is Consumers Digest.

title: STEPAN CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes net loss of $446,000 from the sale of assets... C-Includes $1,793,000 net gain from the sale of assets; 1980 results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable Dec 31, 1981

title: Copter Saves Four From Sinking Boat
description: An Air Force helicopter rescued four crew members from a Massachusetts-based fishing boat that had been slowly sinking in Atlantic waters off Montauk, L.I., authorities said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error in an ar- ticle about baseball contracts on Tues- day, the name of one baseball player was incorrectly substituted for that of another. The player who will earn $100,000 for each season he wins the most-valuable-player award and a maximum of $300,000 annually in at- tendance bonuses is George Foster of the Mets.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PORTABLE electric quartz heaters have become quite popular in the last couple of years because they can be used for spot heating, to keep people warm when thermostats are lowered or when the central heating system is not operating, but without having to heat the entire room. However, these heaters are primarily directional; that is, they are intended to warm people or objects almost directly in front of them, not off to one side.

title: KIDDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Goodyear Sees U.S.  Tire Sales Increase
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said that total United States automobile tire sales in 1982 could rise 3 percent, to 130 million units, because of pent-up demand and increasing use of automobiles.

title: BACARDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMPCO-PITTSBURGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income for the latest yr includes a gain of approximately $4.3 million or $1.12 a shr, from the sale of Crouse-Hines Co common stock; results for the latest periods include operations of Buffalo Forge Co which was acquired in 1981

title: Insulin Pump Studied In Deaths of Diabetics
description: The National Centers for Disease Control began an investigation today into unexplained deaths of diabetics who used insulin infusion pumps.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1982
description: International A two-day police sweep in Poland found 145,000 people to have been violating martial-law regulations, the authorities announced. As punishment, they said, 128,000 people were issued warnings, 3,500 were detained for questioning, 7,000 were fined a total of $29,000 and 4,000 were given court summonses. (Page A1, Column 6.) Zimbabwe's unity regime broke apart as Prime Minister Robert Mugabe dismissed his partner, Joshua Nkomo, from the Cabinet and accused him of plotting to overthrow the Government by force. The dismissal of Mr. Nkomo and three members of his party effectively ended the coalition that was established 22 months ago when Rhodesia became independent. (A1:5.)

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $100 million principal amount of floating-rate notes due 1985, to be sold through Warburg Paribas Becker-A.G. Becker.

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $4.3 million after tax charge from the disposition and termination of certain operations

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The company changed its yr-end from a fiscal yr ended Aug 31 to a calendar yr; results for the previous yr are for the yr ended Aug 31, 1980; two major accounting changes were made in 1981 that affected earnings; In Dec a change in the method of valuing domestic inventories from FIFO to LIFO reduced 1980 earnings by 41 cents a shr; the company also adopted the new F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translation

title: Here and Now, Deficits Do Matter
description: Now that President Reagan confronts an unprecedented run of dozendigit Federal deficits, he has taken up the sometime cry of liberals that deficits don't really matter. If only the economy will grow fast enough and Congress will cut spending hard enough, they will begin to shrink, he predicts, and do little damage. Few share the President's faith. But in any case, the size of his gamble clearly turns on that old question: do deficits matter?

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: GEORGIA COURT TO STUDY CUSTODY RULLING IN RACE-RELATED DISPUTE

title: CROP LOSS IS LAID TO OZONE EFFECTS
description: Ozone, a major air pollutant, is costing the nation losses of $2 billion to $4.5 billion a year in production of corn, wheat, soybeans and peanuts, according to the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.

title: AIDES EXPECT STATE RACE BY KOCH
description: Most of Mayor Koch's closest friends and advisers think he should run - and will run - for the Democratic nomination for governor. ''He's getting a lot of input from people, and I think most of them are telling him to run,'' said David Garth, who would be the chief strategist in a Koch state campaign.

title: INVENTOR LOST SIGHT AS YOUTH
description: Ralph R. Teetor, who became a noted inventor and industrialist even though he was blinded in a boyhood accident, died in a hospital Monday.

title: PATRIOT BANCORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: 1980 results include those of Brookline Trust Co and Harbor National Bank

title: West Germany Curbs Travel To Soviet by Senior Officials
description: The West German Government said today that it was curbing visits to the Soviet Union by senior officials and restricting scientific contacts to protest continued martial law rule in Poland.

title: Luescher Triumphs
description: The former World Cup champion, Peter Luescher, won the giant slalom event at the Swiss Alpine skiing championships today. He had an aggregate time of 2 minutes 40.95 seconds for two runs.

title: STOCKMAN HINTS AT NEW FLEXIBILITY ON TAXES AND THE MILITARY BUDGET
description: There is some flexibility in the Reagan Administration's stance on taxes and military spending, David A. Stockman, the budget director, suggested today in Congressional testimony.

title: Japanese Unionists March
description: About 3,000 union members marched by the Japanese Parliament building here today, calling for wage increases and income-tax cuts, the police said.

title: A CERAMIC INNOVATOR IN JAPAN
description: Kazuo Inamori, the 50-year-old president of the Kyoto Ceramic Company, has a well-deserved reputation as an unconventional man in this convention-abiding nation.

title: The Editorial Notebook Pond Power
description: Electricity from sunlight? Arco, Texas Instruments and a few other big companies speak cautiously about creating highly sophisticated technologies for the mass production of photovoltaic cells. And before the White House clipped the agency's wings, NASA dreamed of giant satellites beaming solar power back to Earth by microwave.

title:
ABROAD AT HOME;
FACING THE MUSIC
description: LewisBOSTON, Feb. 17 - He is a German musicologist, a specialist on Schumann. Forty years ago, when the Nazis occupied Paris, he was an official there in charge of seizing art works, especially from Jews. He worked for Alfred Rosenberg, the Nazi racial theorist. He wrote about ''the Jewish mentality'' in music.

title: L.I.U. WINS, FORDHAM LOSES
description: St. Joseph's reached 20 victories when the Hawks defeated Fordham, 65-54, with a strong second-half performance at Madison Square Garden last night. Usually 20 victories assures a well-regarded team of a spot in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tournament, but the Hawks have not been ranked among the nation's top 20 this season.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A DIFFERENT VIEW

title: Sales Fall in Canada
description: Retail sales in Canada fell two-tenths of 1 percent in December, to $8.11 billion (Canadian), seasonally adjusted, after a 4 percent rise in November, Statistics Canada said today.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: MESA PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The shr earnings figures are fully diluted

title: AFTER SIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $203,300 for the qr and $545,100 for the 6 mos...C-Net income after a loss of $35,400 for the qr and income of $260,300 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations

title: PLOT IS CHARGED
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe dismissed his coalition partner, Joshua Nkomo, from his Cabinet today and accused him of scheming to overthrow the Government by force.

title: A Song of Thanks
description: She may be better known for her rendition of Handel's Concerto for Harp in B flat (Op. 4, No. 6), but Emily Mitchell played ''Danny Boy'' yesterday at the Midtown North Precinct headquarters in gratitude for the recovery of her $20,000 harp.

title: TAMPAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hewlett Drops Computer Price
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced that it had reduced prices up to 21 percent on its personal office computer and introduced a new model capable of handling more information at a faster rate than its previous models.

title: WINFIELD LIKELY TO BAT 4TH, IS NOT EAGER TO FILL JACKSON'S ROLE
description: Dave Winfield assumed one of Reggie Jackson's old spring training roles today, but he is not prepared to take Jackson's role during the season.

title: Steeler Kolb Retires
description: Another of the outstanding linemen of the championship years of the Pittsburgh Steelers retired yesterday. Jon Kolb, an offensive tackle whose devotion to weight lifting made him one of the strongest men in the National Football League, became the third lineman to announce his retirement in recent weeks, following Joe Greene, a defensive tackle, and Sam Davis, a guard.

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to give effect to costs deferred in connection with the company's market development program; this had the effect of increasing net income by $342,000 or 3 cents a shr, for the qr and $609,000 or 5 cents a shr for the 6 mos

title: Cecil Taylor Will Lead A Big Band in 'Village'
description: Cecil Taylor, the pianist, will lead a big band, which has been named the Expanded Unit, in a series of engagements at Lush Life, 184 Thompson Street, near Bleecker Street.

title: U.S.-Canada Rift to GATT
description: The United States today formally complained to Canadian officials that Canada violates international fair trade rules by imposing special conditions on foreign investors.

title: STARTS IN HOUSING OFF IN JANUARY
description: Housing starts fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January after rising slightly in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: NEW MANAGERS IN FRANCE
description: France's Socialist Government today dismissed the heads of three major industrial groups and 20 banks that it had just nationalized and appointed new managers to run them.

title: HEAD OF JOINT CHIEFS PROPOSES OVERHAUL OF SYSTEM
description: Gen. David C. Jones, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that he would try in his last few months in office to achieve ''some substantial changes'' in the organization and workings of the Joint Chiefs system, seeking more authority for the chairman and more unified military planning.

title: Amicable Settlement
description: After going through a difficult divorce-court fight to keep the $2.5 million house he bought before he married Farrah Fawcett, the actor Lee Majors said yesterday that he had decided to give the house to her.

title: Negotiators for N.F.L.  Can't Agree on Time
description: Jack Donlan and Ed Garvey, the chief negotiators who will resume contract talks Thursday, today could not agree on a time to start the meeting.

title: More Salvador Aid Opposed
description: Archbishop James A. Hickey of Washington today opposed any increase in American military aid to El Salvador. Archbishop Hickey, who has visited the country several times, said, ''The path to eventual peace and justice in El Salvador is more likely one of negotiations, democratic participation and economic reform.''

title: GENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ROBBERS KILL STORE EMPLOYEE
description: The assistant manager of a Red Apple spermarket on the Upper East Side of Manhattan was shot to death last night when an armed band of five men attempted to force him to open up the store's safe, the police said.

title: 145,000 IN POLAND FOUND TO VIOLATE MARTIAL-LAW RULE
description: The Polish authorities said today that a two-day police sweep had discovered as many as 145,000 people guilty of offenses, most of them apparently petty, against martial law rules.

title: 'ROSENKAVALIER' TO OPEN MET SEASON FOR 1982-83
description: THE 1982-83 season of the Metropolitan Opera will open on Sept. 20 with Richard Strauss's ''Der Rosenkavalier.'' The cast will include Kiri Te Kanawa as the Marschallin and Luciano Pavarotti as the Italian singer, along with Tatiana Troyanos as Octavian, Judith Blegen as Sophie and Kurt Moll as Ochs, with James Levine conducting.

title: Opera: Domingo Joins 'La Boheme'
description: Placido Domingo, the third tenor to appear as Rodolfo in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Puccini's ''La Boheme,'' entered the cast in the performance given Tuesday. Because he is at the top of the international tenor heap, one might have expected Mr. Domingo to be relaxed about this assignment.

title: SCOT LAD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: B-Includes tax credits of $127,000 for the qr and $1,517,000 for the 9 mos

title: STANLEY WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Reflects the adoption of F.A.S.B. statement No 52 for translating foreign currency which increased income by 15 cents a shr for the qr and 39 cents a shr for the yr; net income also includes a 13 cents a shr gain from the sale in the second qr of the Stanley Drapery Hardware business in the United States and Canada...C-Reflects the adoption of F.A.S.B. statement No 52 for translation of foreign currency which decreased income by 3 cents a shr for the qr and increase income by 6 cents for the yr

title: CP NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $793,000 or 47 cents a shr from the cumulative effect of change in the method of recording revs

title: RAMPART GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from equity in earnings of affiliates of $148,400 for the qr and $71,800 for the 9 mos and tax credits of $140,600 for the qr and $737,600 for the 9 mos...C-Net income D-Includes $175,800 tax credit

title: GOLAN SCHOOL STEIKE IN 4TH DAY
description: Israeli Druse teachers serving in the Israeli armed forces unlocked the doors of strike-bound schools in the Golan Heights today as a general strike by 13,000 Druse there entered its fourth day.

title: POLAND PAYING INTEREST DUE IN 1981, BANKS SAY
description: Poland yesterday paid up all the past-due interest it owed for 1981 to one major New York bank, and other leading banks said payments have been quickly flowing in for the past two weeks.

title: Article 247948 -- No Title
description: Integrated circuit chips valued at $1.5 million were stolen from an unguarded warehouse last weekend in Parsippany-Troy Hills, N.J., by a band of selective thieves, authorities disclosed.

title: STUDY SHOWS FEMAL FERTILITY DROPS SHARPLY AFTER AGE OF 30
description: An unusually large and rigorous study of female fertility appears to demonstrate that the ability of women to become pregnant decreases sharply from the age of 31 to that of 35. The study shows the decline coming earlier and more precipitously than had generally been thought.

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES NAMES NEW CHIEF
description: Harold O. Shattuck, a 44-year-old computer executive, has joined System Industries Inc., a manufacturer of storage subsystems for minicomputers based in Milpitas, Calif., as president and chief executive offficer. He succeeds Edwin V.W. Zschau, 42, who announced yesterday that he would seek the Republican nomination for a Congressional seat in California. Mr. Zschau will continue as chairman of the company.

title: RIGHTS CHIEF HOLDS 'TENSE' MEETING WITH LAWYERS
description: In what some participants described as a tense two-hour meeting, more than 60 rank-and-file lawyers of the Justice Department's civil rights division questioned their chief, William Bradford Reynolds, about his policies, especially those concerning tax exemptions for private segregationist schools.

title: AIDE SAYS JORDAN WILL SEEK ARMS FROM OTHER SOURCES IF U.S. BALKS
description: Jordan's Foreign Minister has declared that his country will seek other sources of arms if it cannot get them from the United States.

title: Addendum
description: * Camera Arts magazine to go from bimonthly to a monthly publication, effective with the September issue.

title: PENNCORP FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,708,000 for the qr and $20,008,000 for the yr, $281,000 loss for the qr from investments and $101,000 gain for the yr from investments...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $413,000 for the qr and $79,000 for the yr and gains from investments of $226,000 for the qr and $1,334,000 for the yr

title: CHARTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,770,000 for the qr and $48,229,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,085,000 for the qr and $9,122,000 for the yr

title: TV: PROF. COREY TAXES TAXES
description: IF you have cable television and tune in to see Professor Irwin Corey disburse advice on filling out income-tax returns - as you can on Teleprompter Channel 10 at 10:30 o'clock tonight - can you deduct the cost of your cable television?

title: 2 KINDS OF ETHICS
description: Because ethics are taught primarily by example, the Republican Party has done more in recent years for public moral education than any other American institution.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RELIABILITY INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
GIFFORD-HILL & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $3.1 million from the early payment of debt

title: AFFILIATED HOSPITAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $374,000 for the qr and $669,000 for the yr

title: Miami Judge Trades Shots With a Suspect
description: A county civil judge, armed with a pistol, interrupted an armed robbery Tuesday and exchanged shots with a teen-aged suspect while chasing him down an alley, the authorities said.

title: HERS
description: MANY are wronged but few are chosen as feminist martyrs and heroines. We can see stars in the making when such exceptional women as Karen Silkwood, Mary Cunningham, Joan Little, Sonia Johnson and Billie Jean King run afoul of a sexist society and create instant morality plays. But for the moment I'm fascinated even more by two women whose notorious mistreatment did not gain them much sympathy.

title: Probation for Roberts's Son
description: Ronald D. Roberts, son of Oral Roberts, the evangelist, has been sentenced to a year's probation in exchange for pleading guilty to obtaining a controlled drug, Tussionex, with a forged prescription.

title: OPENING IS POSTPONED INDEFINITELY FOR BIG SHOPPING MALL IN STAMFORD
description: The scheduled opening Thursday of the $140 million Stamford Town Center, the largest urban shopping mall in the New York metropolitan area, was postponed indefinitely today because of a delay in installing a fire-alarm system and minor construction flaws.

title: Padres Shorten Fences
description: The San Diego Padres, who hit only nine home runs at home last season, are making some adjustments in Jack Murphy Stadium for 1982. The center-field fence will be moved 15 feet closer to the plate, to a depth of 405 feet, and the entire outfield wall will be lowered from 17 feet to 8 1/2.

title: ATLANTIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to Jan 1
CAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income for the latest fourth qr reflects an increase of $628,000 or 9 cents a shr from a change in Britain's tax law

title: TRANSFER OF FUNDS TO MUSLIMS VOIDED
description: A judge has ruled that $4.6 million belonging to Elijah Muhammad was assets of his estate and should not have been transferred to the Black Muslim sect he founded.

title: KYRA NIJINSKY, 'SHE DANCES ALONE'
description: OH: Kyra Nijinsky, the daughter of the legendary dancer, makes her entrance into ''She Dances Alone'' aboard a fire engine. The engine charges into an open field, bearing Kyra, who is soon surrounded by white-robed little girls apparently confusing her with Isadora Duncan.

title: Judging Judges, and History
description: These are difficult days for those who like their heroes liberal, wise and ethical. Two weeks ago the historical spotlight fell on John Kennedy secretly taping Oval Office conversations. Now center stage is occupied by the heroic Louis Brandeis. A Penn State political scientist, Bruce Murphy, finds the revered jurist making secret arrangements to stay active politically, despite his appointment to the Supreme Court in 1916.

title: Eva Glimcher, Founder Of Pace Art Gallery
description: Eva Glimcher, an art dealer and co-founder of the Pace Gallery, died on Sunday of heart failure in Mt. Carmel East Hospital in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Ravitch Offers Measure For Binding Arbitration
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority recommended a bill to the State Legislature yesterday that would provide for binding arbitration in case of a deadlock in transit negotiations.

title: Profit Declines At Charter Co.
description: The Charter Company reported today that profit fell sharply in the final quarter of last year, largely because of losses associated with closure of The Bulletin newspaper in Philadelphia and the planned shutdown of its Dayton Press unit.

title: Rubin Epstein, Banker, Dead; Brandeis University Trustee
description: Rubin Epstein, president of the City Bank and Trust Company of Boston, died Monday at New England Deaconess Hospital, Boston, Mass., after a long illness.

title: THE CITY
description: A man said to have robbed a bank at Penn Plaza of $1,353 was tripped by one pedestrian as he attempted to flee and held by four others until the police arrived to arrest him, the police said.

title: News Analysis
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have roundly dismissed each other's opening bids in the European missile negotiations, leaving the impression that the talks are hopelessly bogged down after only two and a half months.

title: SHOTGUN BLASTS KILL 7 MEMBERS OF ONE FAMILY
description: A mail carrier and six members of his family were killed by shotgun blasts at their rural home, and the police said today that they had a ''very weak suspect'' but no motive.

title: LOCAL LEADERS OF AUTO UNION ENDORSE CONTRACT WITH FORD
description: Local leaders of the United Automobile Workers at the Ford Motor Company voted today, 132 to 12, to accept a tentative agreement that includes wage and benefit concessions by employees as well as company assurances on job security.

title: Playboy Posts Loss in Quarter
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc., citing losses connected to the sale of its British gambling operations and two resort hotels, said today that it lost $13.2 million in its fiscal second quarter compared with net income of $1.3 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter slipped to $64.3 million from $65 million.

title: KENNEDY IS FAVORED OVER MONDALE IN '84 IN POLL OF DEMOCRATS
description: Democrats around the country solidly prefer Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts over former Vice President Walter F. Mondale for their party's 1984 Presidential nomination, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: IN WILLIAMS CASE, SPLIT LOYALTIES
description: The Senate is a place that cherishes its traditions with a pride bordering on smugness. But the members of this fraternity will soon face a painful choice between two of their most hallowed principles: loyalty to each other as individuals, and loyalty to the Senate as an institution.

title: AVOIDING THE COST OF PROFESSIONAL MOVERS
description: MOST New Yorkers these days are so excited upon finding a new apartment they can afford that moving may come as an afterthought - and an expensive one.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: IT seems, especially in this country, that we are used to copies and adaptations - both in furniture and clothing - of the more inventive European ''originals.''

title: AMALGAMATED SUGAR REFINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EQUITABLE SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary increase of $2,231,699 or $1.19 a a shr from the redemption of a mortgage-backed bond at a discount

title: Advertising; A 'Python' Star Joins Ad Game
description: JOHN CLEESE, the tallest of the British twits in ''Monty Python's Flying Circus,'' has found a strange way of repaying our hospitality to his group on our public telly and in the flicks. He's coming back in advertising. And he couldn't be more delighted.

title: Council President To Oppose Gibson
description: City Council President Earl Harris, saying that it was ''time for a change,'' announced his candidacy for Mayor.

title: DELAY ASKED ON BILL ON COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Federal Communications Commission and the Reagan Administration urged a House subcommittee on telecommunications today to delay its work on a comprehensive communications bill until details of the proposed antitrust settlement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are made final.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Cynics and Cooney
description: IN boxing, motives are almost always assumed to be ulterior. Even before Gerry Cooney's ailing left shoulder yesterday put off until June 11 his confrontation with Larry Holmes for the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship, cynics had their theories.

title: DECORATING FOR TRADITIONALISTS: WHEN DETAILS COUNT
description: EVEN if they were not as accomplished as they are in the use of swag and finial, valance and pleat, and all the other traditional details that carry with them the promise and fulfillment of luxury and comfort, still Stephen Stempler and John Cronin would be near the top of the New York decorating establishment by dint of the clientele of their partnership.

title: 3 GOVERNORS IN WEST WEIGHING 'NEW FEDERALISM'
description: Now that Ronald Reagan has defined ''new federalism'' as the cornerstone of his Administration's domestic policy, a group of Western Democratic governors have gained importance as potential allies of the President in the pursuit of that approach to Federal-state relations.

title: FOX, CBS AGREE TO JOINT CABLE, HOME VIDEO VENTURE
description: On the heels of a weekend when 20th Century-Fox's three new movies - ''Making Love,'' ''Quest For Fire'' and ''The Amateur'' - did extremely well at the box office, Fox has announced a joint venture with CBS Inc. to create and market programming for cable television, video cassettes and videodisks. The venture will also allow Fox to move its film and television production facilities to CBS's 60-acre Studio Center in the San Fernando Valley.

title: 102 U.S. FUGITIVES SEIZED ON COAST
description: Attorney General William French Smith announced today that 102 people were arrested in the Los Angeles area in a recent nine-week period in a special Justice Department operation that he said was designed to apprehend major fugitives, including ''dangerous, violent criminals.''

title: STARTING OVER: LIFE AFTER RETIREMENT
description: WILLIAM B. MACOMBER, a former Ambassador to Jordan and Turkey, left the Department of State five years ago and now, at age 61, presides over the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: RIO GRANDE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CLOAK AND DAGGER BUSINESS BOOMING
description: The figures are secret. So are the contents of the recruiting interviews. But the Central Intelligence Agency can say this much: More people than ever are trying to join up.

title: HOLIDAY INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Colombian Drug Arrests
description: The police arrested three Colombians and seized 24 tons of marijuana intended for the United States, a spokesman said today.

title: Hartford Unit In Deposit Bid
description: The Hartford Federal Savings and Loan Association, confronted two weeks ago by a near run in which more than $9 million was withdrawn by nervous depositors, today began to try to lure back its customers.

title: KOCH SUDDENLY ENDORSES 2 G.O.P. CANDIDATES
description: Unexpectedly last night, Mayor Koch endorsed two Manhattan Republicans for re-election: Representative Bill Green and State Senator Roy M. Goodman.

title: JAMES A. LOGIE
description: James A. Logie, a former vice president of the Hickey Freeman Company, died Monday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Upper Montclair.

title: RISE AND FALL OF A CHINESE VERSION OF SOLIDARITY
description: To the Editor:

description: B-Net loss...C-Reflects costs of $14.5 million associated with the shutdown of certain operations

description: B-Includes $1.6 million pre-tax gain from the sale of a plant

title: BIO-RAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Talks for Herb Brown
description: Herb Brown, who led the Detroit Pistons into the playoffs twice in the late 1970's, will be interviewed for the position as head coach at the University of Arizona.

title: LIBERTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operatioos of $11,775,000 for the qr and $13,225,000 for the yr...C-Net income including a gain of $367,000 from discontinued operations...D-After a los of $252,000 from discontinued operations

title: Market Place; P.& G. Returns To Spotlight
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE may be a haven in an uncertain economic environment, as many on Wall Street are saying. Today analysts are scheduled to appear at company headquarters for a meeting with top management. No one expects the colossus of Cincinnati to pull a bar of Super Ivory out of a hat, but that is not the point.

title: EUROPEANS TAKE CASE TO REAGAN
description: President Reagan told representatives from recession-plagued Western Europe today that his economic policy, intended to foster noninflationary growth in the United States, was the best way to deal with the world's economic ills. ''We think it will work,'' he said.

title: MEGGYESY REJOINS THE N.F.L. SCENE
description: The old battles were never fully resolved for Dave Meggyesy, who, during the late 1960's and early 1970's, was perhaps pro football's leading counterculture figure.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
People Head to Pan Am
description: Gerald L. Gitner, president and chief operating officer and a director of People Express Airlines, resigned those positions yesterday to become senior vice president of marketing and planning at Pan American World Airways. He succeeds John B. Andersen, 62, who is retiring.

title: SOLDIER, 26, IS FOUND COMPETENT FOR TRIAL ON MURDER CHARGES
description: The director of the Mid-Hudson State Psychiatric Center said yesterday that a 26-year-old Army private charged with murders in New York City, Buffalo and Niagara Falls had been found mentally competent to stand trial.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 18, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Advisory Committee for the World Assembly on Aging - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.N. AIDE SEES LITTLE TO CURB SPREAD OF ATOM ARMS
description: The new Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency thinks that several countries could soon acquire nuclear weapons but that there is little more his agency can do to stop them than it is already doing.

title: ENERGY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 IN STATE'S LOTTO GAME WIN $1.75 MILLION EACH
description: Three makes a crowd. That is how the New York State Lottery Commission explains that it got 35 first-place winners in a Lotto game last month. Most of the time, there are no more than four first-prize winners. Yesterday, the total was down to two.

title: CENTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating income...C-Net income

title: France Curbs Japan Imports
description: France has tightened import restrictions against Japanese motorcycles and television sets, officials at the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Lardner, McCullough Will Read Own Works
description: David McCullough and Ring Lardner Jr. will read from their works March 1 at 8 P.M. as part of the ''Writers in Performance'' series at the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Las Vegas Busboy Gets Life Term in Fatal Fire
description: Philip Bruce Cline, a former busboy at the Las Vegas Hilton, was spared the death penalty but was sentenced to life imprisonment without parole today for the murder of eight persons in a fire at the resort last February.

title: Nestor Chylak, Umpire For 25 Years, Is Dead
description: Nestor Chylak, an American League umpire for 25 years and assistant supervisor of umpires since 1979, died today at the age of 59. He apparently suffered a heart attack.

title: PRODUCTION DOWN 3% IN JANUARY
description: Industrial production fell 3 percent in January, the biggest decline since May 1980, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday. The decline, which was considerably larger than many economists had expected, reflected industry's efforts to work off inventories in the face of a deteriorating economy and lower sales.

title: BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revs for the latest yr include $5,776,000 from a gain on the sale of property which increased net income by $2,440,000 or 9 cents a shr

title: MOTORISTS PROTEST PLANS TO RAISE TOLLS
description: Representatives of the millions of New Yorkers who drive automobiles gathered in a midtown hotel yesterday to argue against a proposed toll increase of 25 percent or more on the seven bridges and two tunnels operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

title: Angola and Senegal Set Up Diplomatic Ties
description: Angola announced today that it had established diplomatic relations with Senegal, a country that had previously refused to recognize the Marxist Government in Luanda because of the presence of Cuban troops in the country.

title: INTEREST RATES FALL MODESTLY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell modestly yesterday as investors and traders decided that signs of a weak economy pointed toward lower rates in the future. A sharp drop in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market from 16 5/8 percent in the morning to 6 percent late in the day also led traders to pay higher prices for most issues.

title: Mark Set for Assists
description: Terri Crowley, a junior guard for C.W. Post, bettered her school assists record tonight in a 75-60 victory over New Haven. tonight.

title: O'Higgins Bank Loan
description: The American Express International Banking Corporation today announced an agreement on a $35 million syndicated loan to O'Higgins Bank, a private Chilean institution. The seven-year loan will be used by O'Higgins for mortgage lending, it said in a statement.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes $800,000 gain from the sale of the company's interest in Altran

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMF Inc., White Plains, has appointed George C. Nebel president of its AMF Wheel Goods division in Olney, Ill.

title: CRAWFORD ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Auto Backlog At 97 Days
description: The five leading domestic auto makers had a 97-day supply of unsold cars on their lots Feb. 1, setting a record backlog for the beginning of February, a trade journal reported today.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
News Analysis
description: ''There can be no disagreement that New York's school-finance program must be reformed,'' Governor Carey said today in making public his program to change the way the state assists its school districts. ''History demonstrates that we cannot accomplish this needed reform by a business-as-usual approach.''

title: Staten I. Wins In 4 Overtimes
description: The College of Staten Island, the nation's top-ranked Division III team, struggled to a four-overtime, 59-57 victory over John Jay College last night in a City University Conference game. The score was 47-47 at the end of regulation.

title: WAS NEVER IN ARMY, CAPUTO SAYS
description: Former Representative Bruce F. Caputo, a Republican candidate for United States Senator from New York, has described himself as a Vietnam-era ''draftee'' and an Army lieutenant although he was neither.

title: No Headline
description: Boston College 80 Georgetown 71

title: 5 JAILED IRISH ALIENS PLANTO FAST
description: Five Irish nationalists arrested at Niagara Falls, N.Y., earlier this month for illegally entering the United States are refusing to wear prison clothing and are clad only in their underwear and blankets, according to their lawyers. One of the five began a hunger strike yesterday and will be joined by the others at five-day intervals, the lawyers said.

title: YALE TO CONDUCT RESEARCH FOR INDUSTRY
description: Yale University entered the controversial field of industrysubsidized research yesterday with the announcement that it had signed a three-year, $1.1 million research contract with the Celanese Corporation, a manufacturer of chemicals and fabrics.

title: Tacoma Sets Utility Loan
description: The Tacoma City Council has agreed to lend $10.1 million to the troubled Washington Public Power Supply System for termination of two of its five nuclear power plants.

title: SEXUAL HARASSMENT CITED IN A REPORT
description: A report released by a women's rights organization said today that nearly all woman working at four Government-financed construction projects said they had been sexually harassed on the job.

title: S.E.C. OVERRULED STAFF ON FINDING THAT CITICORP HID FOREIGN PROFITS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission last month overruled its enforcement staff and declined to bring a civil action against Citicorp despite staff findings that the bank's top management had directed a scheme for seven years that had circumvented and at times violated other countries' tax and currency laws, according to S.E.C. documents and Government officials.

title: ARAB WOMAN IS WOUNDED AS ISRAELIS BREAK UP MELEE
description: An Arab woman was superficially wounded in the head today as Israeli troops fired into the air to break up protests in the occupied West Bank.

title: Commodore Computers Plans Big Campaign
description: Commodore Computers, a Pennsylvania-based company that is a bigger force in the worldwide computer market than it is at home, will break a very aggressive network television advertising campaign next Wednesday on behalf of its low-priced VIC-20 model personal computer.

title: WHO'S SCARING WHOM?
description: Ominous but ambiguous rumbles about what t he U.S. might do to Cuba have become a current staple of foreign p olicy noises from Washington. They are hard to read. Does the A dministration have firm intentions? What are they?

title: DI GIORGIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income for the latest yr includes a gain equal to 26 cents a shr from a fire insurance settlement and a loss equal to 28 cents a shr from divestiture; net income for the previous yr includes a gain equal to 42 cents a shr from the sale of a mobi home park

title: BOARD'S LEADER DENIES MISUSING SCHOOLS' FUNDS
description: The chairman of Community School Board 3 on Manhattan's Upper West Side last night denied assertions that he had misused school funds and said that attacks on him by other board members were ''vicious'' and ''politically motivated.''

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: Results are for 13 weeks in the latest period and 14 weeks in the yr-ago period

title: AGNES P. HAYES
description: Agnes P. Hayes, a former coordinator for Community Planning Boards in Queens and a former Democratic leader in Queens Village, died Sunday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. She was 72 years old and lived in Queens Village.

title: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $263,000 for the qr and $469,000 for the yr; shr earnings reflect 10 percent stock divd

title: UNIROYAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from the purchase of debt and capital lease obligations of $1 million for the qr and $7.6 million for the yr and tax credits of $1.3 million for the qr and $6.4 million for the yr...C-Includes $600,000 gain from the purchase of debt and capital lease obligations... D-Net loss

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.A.R Corp. said Synalloy Corp. and the chairman of Synalloy's executive committee hold 254,000 A.A.R. shares, or 6.4 percent of the total outstanding stock.

title: PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $4.4 million for the qr and $3.5 million for the 6 mos...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $1.1 million for the qr and $1 million for the 6 mos

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from a safe harbor lease of $10,690,000 for the quarter and $22,918,000 for the year, gains from the sale of aircraft of $2,031,000 for the quarter and $8,576,000 for the year and a $1,048,000 gain for the year from the exchange of share of a subsidiary for 700 shares of PSA Inc; C-Net loss; D-Includes $4,587,000 gain from the exchange of shares of a subsidiary

title: MEDICAL RESIDENTS TREAT THEMSELVES TO R AND R
description: When Maureen Glabman, a Manhattan editor, plans a dinner party, she not only has to consider the menu but also the work schedules of almost 50 physicians. Mrs. Glabman, the wife of a third-year resident at Beth Israel Hospital, usually finds that one-third of the potential guests are either on duty in the emergency room or on call by the internal medicine department.

title: Wallace Losing a Job
description: George C. Wallace, the former Governor of Alabama, has been a busy man - too busy, in fact, according to the Alabama Ethics Commission. It has ruled that Mr. Wallace was violating state law by drawing an $18,000 salary as a special counselor to the Governor while holding a $68,355-a-year position as director of rehabilitation services at the University of Alabama at Birmingham.

title: TRANSIT UNIT NOT LIABLE FOR CRIME IN SUBWAY, TOP STATE COURT RULES
description: New York City's Transit Authority is not legally required to protect a passenger from crime in the subways or to supply additional police protection to known high-crime areas in the system, the State Court of Appeals held yesterday.

title: Draft Registration Rises After Prosecution Threat
description: The Government's warning that it would prosecute young men who did not sign up for possible service in the armed forces has caused a surge in draft registration, the head of the Selective Service System said today.

title: TALKS RESUME MARCH 15
description: The N.F.L. Players Association tonight angrily rejected every proposal on a new contract from the Management Council. Today's 10-hour bargaining session ended with both sides deciding to end this first round of talks after only two meetings and to reconvene in Washington on March 15.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Big Playboy Ad
description: Playboy magazine said that its March issue is going to carry its biggest ad ever, a 24-page insert created by Chiat/Day, Los Angeles, for Yamaha motorcycles featuring the manufacturer's 1982 models in three series, plus a six-page foldout inroducing a new bike called the Vision. The insert beats the 20-page ad in last year's March 1981 issue, which was also for Yamaha.

title: A Domino Has Two Sides
description: Suppose the Presidential tongue hadn't slipped. Asked at his news conference yesterday whether he was trying to undermine the leftist Government of Nicaragua, Mr. Reagan began to say, ''Well, no, we're supporting them. ...'' Then he realized that he was still thinking of El Salvador.

title: BAKER, MICHAEL, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ESSEX CHEMCIAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect 10% stock dividends paid Feb 10, 1981 and Dec 18, 1981

title: FILM: WAJDA'S 'WITHOUT ANESTHESIA'
description: ''Without Anesthesia'' (''Bez Znieczulenia'') was shown as part of the 1979 New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of Oct. 9, 1979. The film is playing at the Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street.

title: Mobil Gas Pact Set In New Zealand
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation announced that it had signed a series of agreements with the New Zealand Government to build what it termed the world's first full-scale, natural gas-to-gasoline plant.

title: FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $68.3 million and a foreign currency translation loss of $576 million; C-Including a tax credit of $435.4 million and a foreign currency translation loss of $22 million

title: Reynolds & Reynolds Selects New Chairman
description: Edwin F. Strasser, 60, the president and chief executive officer of the Reynolds & Reynolds Company, a producer of computer systems and business forms, has been elected to the additional position of chairman. He succeeds Richard H. Grant Jr., 69, a member of the family that owns a controlling interest in the Dayton, Ohio, corporation.

title: Kathy Postlewait Leads
description: Kathy Postlewait shot a career best six-under-par 66 today to take a one-shot lead after the first round of the $150,000 Bent Tree Ladies Classic.

title: CUTS IN FEDERAL ARTS BUDGETS TO HIT SMALL GROUPS HARDEST
description: Small arts organizations and avant-garde groups, which rely heavily on Government money, appear likely to suffer most from budget cuts being proposed by the National Endowment for the Arts. In some cases they may be forced to close, according to cultural leaders interviewed around the country.

title: BLOW TO G.O.P.
description: The Republican Party lost its third strong Middle Western candidate in three months today as Gov. Robert Ray of Iowa, the nation's senior Governor, said he would not seek reelection.

title: CAPUTO RETAINS SUPPORT FOR RACE
description: Leaders of the Right to Life and Conservative Parties said yesterday that disclosures that Bruce M. Caputo had described himself inaccurately as a Vietnam-era ''draftee'' and Army lieutenant would not diminish their support for his campaign to become United States Senator from New York.

title: SON OF EX-G.M. HEAD ACCUSED
description: Thomas Estes, the oldest son of Elliott M. Estes, the former president of the General Motors Corporation, stood before a Federal magistrate today and pleaded not guilty to charges that he used his family name and false documents to extract millions of dollars from local banks and business associates.

title: U.S. MAY REPEAL RULES LIMITING LEAD IN GASOLINE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would consider relaxing or repealing its rule that large oil refiners limit the amount of lead they add to gasoline on the ground that the the pollution-control measure was becoming outmoded.

title: PARENTS FIGHT ORDER ON SPEAKERS
description: The Parents Association of Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn called upon authorities of the school system yesterday to rescind an order requiring the school's principal to get permission to invite outside speakers to the school.

title: Crime? Elementary, My Dear Mr. Mayor
description: Mayor Koch got some advice last night on how to fight crime from a 9-year-old schoolboy in Queens. At a town hall meeting at Public School 139 in the Rego Park section, Mr. Koch read a letter that he had received from Jason Glenn, a fourth grader at the school.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL METS (NL) - Named Bob Apodaca as coach of Jackson farm in Texas League; Bobby Valentine as roving instructor spe- cializing in offensive play; Glenn Borg- mann as a coach at Columbia of South At- lantic League, and John Cumberland as coach of Lynchburg of Carolina League.  CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Bill Buckner, first baseman, to a five-year, $2.6 million contract.  MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Tim Cor- coran, first baseman, and Ron Washing- ton, infielder.  MILWAUKEE (AL) - Si
description: QUEBEC (NHL) - Mario Marois, de- f enseman, was suspended by the National H ockey League for six games for a stick- s winging incident Feb. 14 against the R angers. SOCCER FORT LAUDERDALE (NASL) - Re- leased Arsene Auguste, defender.

title: LEASEWAY TRANSPORTATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $2,020,000 from the writeoff of motor carrier operating rights

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MILTON ROY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENERGY METHODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LORD NELSON AND TWO MUSIC SHOWS
description: ''MASTERPIECE Theater'' turns relatively spicy this week with ''I Remember Nelson,'' a four-part series that will begin Sunday at 9 P.M. on WNET-TV. The series, as Alistair Cooke points out in his introduction, isn't quite a conventional biography. Instead, it tells the story of Adm. Horatio Nelson from the viewpoints of four people who knew him.

title: MARCHERS REACH ALABAMA CAPITOL
description: Black civil rights leaders from across the South, flanked by a host of black officials and 3,500 to 5,000 supporters, converged on the Capitol here today to call for extension of the Federal Voting Rights Act and the release of two political activists convicted of vote fraud.

title: Thai atmosphere and a lively pub.
description: ''SAWATDEE,'' we are told, means ''welcome'' in Thai. To New Yorkers, and especially those living on the Upper West Side, the huge, two month-old Baan Thai restaurant on Broadway, between 102d and 103d Streets, deserves a heartfelt ''sawatdee.''

title: Elizabeth Fowler; 102.4 Billion Coupons
description: Manufacturers last year distributed a total of 102.4 billion cents-off coupons, according to Nielsen Clearing House estimates.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for 12 wks to Jan 2
description: B-Including a gain of $6,828,000 for the 12 weeks and 40 weeks

title: CANDIDATE FAVORING NAPALM USE GAINS IN SALVADOR
description: The concern of American officials over holding elections amid the violence here is being compounded by alarm that a man linked to that violence may do very well in the voting.

title: ROLLINS BURDICK HUNTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $285,500 gain on the disposition of a subsidiary; year-end revenue results include investment income of $9,895,000 in 1981 and $7,351,000 in 1980

title: WHAT LAWYERS DO
description: To the Editor:

title: SETON HALL DEFEATS NOTRE DAME, 71-58
description: Dan Callandrillo, fourth in the nation in scoring this season, had 28 points tonight to lead Seton Hall to a surprisingly easy 71-58 victory over Notre Dame and complete a big night for local teams and guards at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: CAR-TOWING COMPANY HALTS ITS WORK FOR CITY
description: A private company with the $2.5 million city contract to tow away illegally parked cars in Manhattan has halted its operations. City officials said they had started legal action charging the company with abrogating its contract.

title: SEXTET OF SCHOLARS SINGS EVERYTHING FROM MOTETS TO MOTOWN
description: One way to be introduced to the King's Singers is to go into a record shop, ask to listen to their recording of Byrd's motets, and instead have the sales clerk take down their recording of songs by Flanders and Swann. Another way might be to go to their concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening expecting to hear another stuffy vocal recital.

title: U.S. TRIMS COMPLAINTS ON STEEL
description: The International Trade Commission today rejected more than half the cases brought by the domestic steel industry in its filings of unfair trade complaints against steelmakers from eight European countries and Brazil.

title: Woman, 18, Is Killed In Explosion in Jersey
description: An 18-year-old woman was killed today in an explosion in a parking lot behind a beauty shop here.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard CHINABOUND. A 50-YEAR MEMOIR. By John King Fairbank. Illustrated. 480 pages. Harper & Row. $20.

title: PEOPLES DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 16
description: The company's first quarter is a 16-week period while the remaining quarters are 12 weeks

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: T HE glow from Valentine's Day warmed the entire week, brightened by celebrations for worthy causes. Former Ambassador Angier Biddle Duke and his wife, Robin Chandler Duke, between them hold dozens of honors for their good deeds. Another was added earier this week when they received the Citizens Union's 1982 Distinguished Service Award.

title: KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOODRICH, B F, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $9.2 million, or 46 cents a share, from a divestment, a gain of $27.4 million, or $1.38 a share, from the sale of tax benefits and incomeof $6.6 million, or 33 cents a share, mainly from the liquidation of inventories arising from a divestiture; C-Including an extraordinary gain of $18 million, or 93 cents a share, from the exchange of convertible preferred stock for outstanding debentures and a gain of $22 million, or $1.14 a share, from divestments of businesses and from the sale of shares in foreign businesses

title: No Decision on Young
description: A judge reserved decision yesterday on a motion by The Daily News for a preliminary injunction that would bar the sports columnist Dick Young from writing for The New York Post.

title: THE THEATER PAYS FINAL TRIBUTE TO STRASBERG
description: Outside, in Shubert Alley yesterday morning, the letters on the New York State license plate of the parked Mercedes station wagon that belonged to him read: METHOD.

title: FISCHER & PORTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RANGERS TIE, 4-4, IN LAST 1:26
description: The Rangers seemed to have an easy assignment last night, playing the Colorado Rockies, who have the poorest record of the National Hockey League's 21 teams. Instead, the Rangers needed a goal with 86 seconds left to escape with a 4-4 tie.

title: Bergtraum Girls Defeat Curtis in Tourney, 57-54
description: Janice Long, a junior guard, scored 27 points and led Murry Bergtraum High School of Manhattan to a 57-54 victory over Curtis in the opening round of the Public Schools Athletic League girls' basketball tournament yesterday at Susan Wagner High.

title: KNICKS PURSUING WESTPHAL
description: The Knicks said last night that they have made a new offer in an attempt to obtain Paul Westphal, a former all-star guard who is a free agent.

title: FIRST LADY FINDS A CAUSE
description: It has not been spelled out, but it is apparent that an increasing number of Nancy Reagan's public appearances will be devoted to social issues, particularly the problem of drug abuse among the young.

title: ENERGY SOURCES INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Continental Grain Company has elected Myron R. Laserson an executive vice president and general manager of the World Grain division.

title: POP JAZZ
description: SALSA has been meeting jazz on street corners, in nightclub shows and late-night jam sessions, even in concert halls for several years now. But salsa is salsa (or Latin music, if you prefer) and jazz is jazz (or black classical music, if you prefer). Each music has maintained its identity and for the most part their meetings have been on-again, off-again affairs.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Ad Unit Resolves Lemonade Complaints
description: January was lemonade month at the national advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus as the self-regulatory body settled complaints involving Coca-Cola's Minute Maid lemonade crystals and General Foods' Country Time lemonade flavor frozen concentrate advertising.

title: MEXICO DEVALUES PESO 30%
description: The Mexican peso was abruptly devalued by about 30 percent today after the Government announced it would no longer intervene on exchange markets to support the currency.

title: RACERS' WHEELCHAIR BAN BACKED
description: Organizers of the New York City Marathon are under ''no legal compulsion'' to open their annual fall foot race to participants in wheelchairs or to skateboarders, the State Court of Appeals ruled today.

title: TELECO OILFIELDS SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $522,000 for the quarter and $1,750,000 for the year;C-Includes $1,445,000 extraordinary credit; Revenues for both 1980 periods havebeen reclassified to include net recoveries for abandon tools of $324,000, and $845,000; share earnings adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split in April 1981

title: Advertising; New Wine Campaign For Ruffino
description: SCHIEFFELIN & COMPANY, one of the oldest American wine importers, is beginning a major television and print campaign for Ruffino white wines from one of the world's oldest grape-growing areas -the sunny slopes of Orvieto, a small city lying on the direct rail line between Rome and Florence. The campaign is also pushing Ruffino Chianti Classico red wines, already a big seller in this country.

title: VIACOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $1.9 million extraordinary gain and $5.4 million provision in the fourth quarter to cover loss on donation of a broadcasting property

title: 6-Game Ban for Marois
description: Mario Marois of the Quebec Nordiques has been suspended for six games as a result of a stick-swinging incident against the Rangers on Feb. 14. The suspension was announced in Montreal by Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League's executive vice president, after a hearing on Wednesday. O'Neill noted that it was the second match penalty assessed against Marois in two years.

title: ART: SMITHSON SCULPTURE COMES TO THE WHITNEY
description: EVEN before his accidental death in 1973 at the age of 35, the American sculptor Robert Smithson was well on his way to becoming something of a cult figure on the contemporary art scene. Since that time - he died in a plane crash in Texas while inspecting one of his costly ''earthworks,'' which was then under construction on a ranch near Amarillo - Mr. Smithson has become an international legend. It is for this reason, no doubt, that the exhibition called ''Robert Smithson: Sculpture,'' which has now come to the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street (through April 18), has been chosen to represent the United States at the Venice Biennale this year.

title: TIMES STUDYING CHARGE ON ARTICLE IN MAGAZINE
description: The New York Times said yesterday that it was investigating questions that had arisen about an article on Cambodia that appeared in The New York Times Magazine Dec. 20.

title: CAREY'S PLAN ON SCHOOL AID TO BENEFIT CITY AND SUFFOLK
description: Governor Carey's education-aid proposal, which would raise state assistance to school districts by about $742 million this year, would give almost 60 percent of the increase to New York City and Suffolk County, according to a detailed analysis of the plan released today.

title: WOLVERINE ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Citibank Warned By Official in '80
description: The Comptroller of the Currency, in an unusual private letter and report to Citibank's board of directors in December 1980, expressed concern about some of the bank's trading in foreign currencies and said that certain of its accounting and audit procedures raised serious questions about Citibank's safety and soundness, according to Government documents and officials.

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Chemical Weapons Ban Is Proposed by Kremlin
description: The Kremlin today urged a ban on all chemical weapons and denied that the Soviet Union had ever used such weapons.

title: WOODSTREAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results in 1981 include Wabash Inc acquired in January 1981

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Art: Smithson Sculpture Comes to the Whitney
description: EVEN before his accidental death in 1973 at the age of 35, the American sculptor Robert Smithson was well on his way to becoming something of a cult figure on the contemporary art scene. Since that time - he died in a plane crash in Texas while inspecting one of his costly "earthworks," which was then under construction on a ranch near Amarillo - Mr. Smithson has become an international legend. It is for this reason, no doubt, that the exhibition called "Robert Smithson: Sculpture," which has now come to the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street (through April 18), has been chosen to represent the United States at the Venice Biennale this year.

title: G.M. Ohio Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would eliminate a work shift at its ''J''-car assembly plant here beginning March 1, placing 3,400 workers on indefinite layoff.

title: REVAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHORT INTEREST ON THE BIG BOARD UP A BIT IN MONTH
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest has risen only a fraction of one percent in the month ended Feb. 11.

title: PLAN TO PRESENT REAGAN A MEDAL SETS OFF DISPUTE
description: A controversy is growing within the National Conference of Christians and Jews over a humanitarian award the organization will present to President Reagan at a dinner in New York City on March 23.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Lerner to direct musical version of 'Idiot's Delight.'
description: ALAN JAY LERNER, a mainstay of the musical theater as a librettist and lyricist, is going to make his Broadway debut in a new role. After looking around for a director for his new musical, based on Robert E. Sherwood's 1936 antiwar play, ''Idiot's Delight,'' Mr. Lerner has picked the most suitable candidate: himself. The musical, which has a book and lyrics by Mr. Lerner and music by Charles Strouse, is to go into rehearsal in August and open in New York in December.

title: ART: VISITS OF BROOKLYN BEFORE THE BRIDGE
description: ''BROOKLYN don't seem to be like any other place on earth,'' opined George Washington Plunkitt, boss of Manhattan's 15th Assembly District, around the turn of the century. ''Once let a man grow up amidst Brooklyn's cobblestones, with the odor of Newtown Creek and Gowanus Canal ever in his nostrils, and there's no place in the world for him except Brooklyn.''

title: TRIBUTE TO MAN RAY AT THE ZABRISKIE GALLERY
description: STATELY as it sounds, ''Publications and Transformations'' is the title of a show by ''the last of the red-hot Dadas,'' as Man Ray (1890-1976) called himself. The display, at Zabriskie Gallery, 29 West 57th Street, includes about 70 items, of which roughly half are books, portfolios and other printed matter, and the other half a selection of photographs, drawings, collages, paintings and miscellaneous objects. Complementing the exhibition of Man Ray photographs now at the Pompidou Center in Paris, ''Publications'' remains through March 13, when it will travel to Meredith Long & Company in Houston.

title: Money Funds' Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's 172 money market funds, including one newly organized fund, declined by $753 million, to $184.99 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: JOSLYN MANUFACTURING SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $300,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a gain of $725,000 from discontinued operations for the year; C-Included net from discontinued operations of $2,531,000 for the quarter and $5,068,000 for the year; per share figures were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in September 1981

title: VON BULOW LOVER TESTIFIES ON AFFAIR
description: A 36-year-old former actress said that she and Claus von Bulow were lovers and that he talked about divorcing his wife and marrying her before and after his wife went into a coma in December 1979.

title: GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,340,000 for the quarter and $90,607,000 for the year; C-After a loss of $165,000 for the quarter and a gain of $19,384,000 for the year from discontinued operations; D-Net income; year-ago results have been restated to show a correction of the income tax provision allowable to both continuing and discontinued operations

title: ONE FOR THE BOOKS
description: The controversy over removal of nine books from the Island Trees school district's high school library points directly to fundamental questions about the nature of community in modern American society and about our political tradition.

title: CONCERT: YUN-BOH CHEUNG
description: BOH CHEUNG, a Korean-born pianist who made her New York recital debut last season, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday evening with a program of sonatas by Mozart, Beethoven and Chopin. Under the circumstances, one might have expected Miss Cheung's playing to emphasize those qualities that give the music of each composer such individuality.

title: FORD LOST $1.6 MILLION LAST YEAR BUT UNION PACT RAISES '82 HOPES
description: The Ford Motor Company reported yesterday that it lost $346 million in the fourth quarter and $1.06 billion for all of 1981, an improvement over a $1.54 billion loss in 1980.

title: HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AILING ECONOMY IS KEY ISSUE
description: The people of Ireland voted for a new government today for the second time in eight months. The dismal state of the economy overshadowed the violence in Northern Ireland as a campaign issue.

title: CHURCH MISSING $165,000, TREASURER VANISHES
description: The 59-year-old treasurer of a Rockland County Episcopal church, who had been a respected member of his century-old congregation for 27 years, has absconded with at least $165,000, and possibly as much as $300,000, in church funds, the Rockland County District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Brazil Aide at Unesco Dies
description: Paulo de Berredo Carneiro, a biochemist who long served as Brazilian delegate to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in Paris, died here Wednesday. He was 80 years old. Mr. Carneiro's career was associated with Unesco since the agency's founding in 1945.

title: British Taxpayers Escape a Set of Bills
description: A follow-up: Margaret Thatcher, Britain's Prime Minister, told the House of Commons she would foot any unpaid bills that might otherwise fall on British taxpayers as a result of the rescue of her son, Mark Thatcher, after he became lost in the Sahara last month.

title: NEW HEAD CALLS CITY COLLEGE A MODEL
description: Dr. Bernard W. Harleston, the president of City College, yesterday urged educational institutions to reject a system of values that placed a ''higher fiscal priority'' on weapons and military preparedness than on ''the education of our nation's young men and women.''

title: ACROSS INDIA, A RURAL TIDE IS ENGULFING THE CITIES
description: Indian demographers poring over the results of last year's national census are reporting that the suddenly burgeoning growth of major cities represents a more troublesome statistic than the overall steady population rise with its evocations of Malthusian doom.

title: LABOR COUNCIL URGES MORE DRASTIC ACTION ON POLAND SITUATIONS
description: The executive council of the A.F.L.- C.I.O. today urged President Reagan to honor a promise made last month to take more drastic action against the Soviet Union and the Polish Government if conditions in Poland did not improve.

title: DON'T SURRENDER COLLEGE SPORTS TO MONEY
description: To the Editor:

title: SHORT-TERM RATES ARE LOWER
description: Short-term interest rates fell half a percentage point and more yesterday as traders in the credit markets seemed to decide that the future was not so bleak as it appeared just a few days ago.

title: No Headline
description: Edwin H. Shutt, 54 years old, who joined Tampax Inc., a manufacturer of feminine protection products, last June as president and chief operating officer has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds E. Russell Sprague, 66, who continues as chairman of the company, which has its headquarters in Lake Success, L.I.

title: 'All Savers' Rate to Rise
description: The interest rate on new tax-exempt ''All Savers'' certificates will rise slightly, to 10.79 percent, next week, from the current rate of 10.76 percent, officials said today. The rate change, effective Sunday, will cover certificates issued through March 20.

title: AUCTIONS
description: CENTURY art will be in the spotlight in exhibitions this weekend and in sales next week at three of New York's auction houses. The bidding begins at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, next Thursday at 10:15 A.M. with a sale starring Jean Francois Millet's ''The Water Carrier,'' an oil on panel from about 1860, showing a woman carrying a pail. It is expected to sell for as much as $200,000. Also notable in that sale are two paintings of the equestrian world by Sir Alfred Munnings, ''The Newmarket Start,'' from about 1900, an oil on board painting of a horse race (up to $120,000), and ''Lady on Horseback,'' from the same period (up to $90,000); Gustave Courbet's ''The Shepherdess,'' signed and dated 1862, a pastoral scene of sheep grazing in a field (up to $90,000); Jean Baptiste Camille Corot's ''The Lake,'' from the 1860's (up to $70,000), and two paintings by Joaquin Sorolla y Bastida - ''Sonny,'' from 1905 (up to $50,000), and ''A Fisherman on a Beach Near Valencia,'' from 1910 (up to $45,000).

title: A Deadline Passes For Times of London
description: Rupert Murdoch's deadline for voluntary layoffs to prevent the closing of The Times of London and its sister paper, The Sunday Times, passed today without an agreement with the union, company officials said.

title: No Headline
description: Polish Clergy Criticized By the Military Again

title: No Shortage in Coffee Is Seen
description: The world's coffee crop in the 1982-83 growing year will be ample to meet world demand, despite frost damage in Brazil, the London commodity brokers, Gill & Duffus, predicted today.

title: FORD MOTOR CO OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

ADVERTISING;
People
description: * Sean Driscoll has joined Warwick, Welsh & Miller Inc. as a senior vice president.

title: Sports of The Times; Hurricane Jackson's Long Arms
description: THE Rev. James C. Kelly remembers the first time he visited Calvary Baptist Church - driving down New York Boulevard into South Jamaica and having traffic stop in front of him.

title: VOPLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; 1980 results restated for FASB Statement No 43 for accounting forcompensated absences which decreased 1980 net income by $41,000

title: UNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. AID FOR PAKISTAN
description: .8,2CHICAGO - The Administration's arguments for the proposed unconditional package of $3.2 billion of mostly military aid for President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq's Government in Pakistan seem persuasive.

title: FIRST BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including equity in earnings of an affiliate of $3,752,000 for the quarter and $6,733,000 for the year; C-Including equity in earnings of an affiliate of $838,000 for the quarter and $6,379,000 for the year

title: BALDOR ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Oil Executive Held Briefly in Beirut
description: Gunmen described as disgruntled job applicants kidnapped an American oil executive, a Lebanese colleague and their driver today, but the men were released unharmed seven hours later.

title: Icahn Lifts Stake In Marshall Field
description: A group headed by the New York financier Carl C. Icahn has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has raised its interest in Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago-based retail chain, to 19.4 percent from 17.2 percent.

title: POPE LANDS EQUATORIAL GUINEANS' FAITH
description: Pope John Paul II was greeted with fervor today on his arrival in this heavily Roman Catholic country, which had undergone 11 years of persecution of the church.

title: 70 Indicted in Drug Case Linked to Stock Car Plot
description: Three national stock car racers were among 70 persons indicted in Florida and North Carolina in connection with a major drug-smuggling operation, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: F.A.A. Opposing Curbs On Airports by Localities
description: The Federal Government is starting a drive to protect the nation's airports against what it considers unreasonable curfews and other limitations because of noise or environmental concerns, J. Lynn Helms, the Federal Aviation Administrator, said today.

title: TINY INDUSTRY, MODEL LOBBYING DRIVE
description: It is not so big as the automobile industry, which has 723,000 employees, nor even so large as the footwear industry, which has 143,800. But like those ailing industries, the spring clothespin industry, which employs 427 people, has come to Washington to lobby for Federal help against imports.

title: CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MASLAND, C H, & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $326,000; C-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $62,000; the year-earlier sales figure excludes sales of $6,356,000 in the discontinued Dawson Home Center division

title: WAYNE WILLIAMS'S FATHER AND EXPERT REBUT FIBER EVIDENCE
description: Wayne B. Williams's father testified today that carpet squares used to link his son to the slaying of a young black man were not purchased until after the victim's body was found.

title: 2 Get Prison Terms in Killing Of Khomeini Foe in Maryland
description: Two men were sentenced to prison today for their roles in the murder of a critic of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran.

title: SIMMONDS PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes benefit equal to 8 cents a share from the adoption of FASB StatementNo 52 and a loss equal to 5 cents a share related to the sale of the company's meal operations in Holland; C-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,489,000 for the quarter and $7,986,000 for the year and $1,400,000 tax credit for the quarter

title: Dow Reverses Decline, Edges Up 1.33
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday after four straight declines. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 1.33 points, to 828.96. Despite the market's token advance, however, caution remained widespread.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1981 have been restated for an accounting change

title: Florida Bank Suit Amended
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation said it had amended its lawsuit against Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. and the Chemical New York Corporation to request an injunction that would prohibit Chemical from exercising any of the warrants or options that Florida National earlier granted to it.

title: Canadiens 5, Blues 3
