description: MONTREAL (AP) - Mark Napier and Pierre Mondou each scored twice as Montreal rolled to a five-goal lead and extended its unbeaten streak to 14 games.

title: SWANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nationalized Sector to Get Aid in France
description: The French Government will pump about $1.6 billion into its five newly nationalized industrial groups in 1982 and 1983, Industry Minister Pierre Dreyfus disclosed today.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NATIONAL CAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; year-ago share earnings have been restated for FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: The Fitter Parent
description: In New York State this month, a woman lost custody of her children. She was deficient in her religious duty to them, shared her bed with the man she later married, stayed out too late and allowed her male friend to violate the Sabbath by turning on television. Their father, who presumably can give them a better home, has them now.

title: UNIT DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Why Nolte stopped being a stage actor.
description: HIS hair is blond again - dyed black to play Doc in ''Cannery Row,'' it has gone through shades of orange on its way back - and he is barefoot and searching under the napkins on the room-service trolley and through the mucky ashtrays for a butt or two that will get him through an interview. Big and cheerful, Nick Nolte looks like the professional football player he wanted to be. ''I played all through school,'' he says, ''but I just wasn't good enough.''

title: LOGETRONICS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $956,000 from reversal of deferred federal income taxes; all figures were restated to include the acquisition of two units accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis; the company said that 1981 figures do not include acquisition of Dunn Systems completed Dec 21, 1981

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS HIS NOMINATION OF MINISTER TO CIVIL RIGHTS AGENCY
description: President Reagan today defended his choice of the Rev. B. Sam Hart as a nominee to the United States Civil Rights Commission, saying that the radio evangelist ''is not against equal rights'' for women.

title: CAVENHAM USA INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Jan 2
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,602,000 for the 12 weeks and $3,466,000 for the 40 weeks; C-Including a gain of $6,828,000 for the 12 weeks and 40 weeks on the redemption of preferred stock

title: DAME NGAIO MARSH, THE AUTHOR OF 32 MYSTERY NOVELS, DIES AT 82
description: Dame Ngaio Marsh, whose writing style and vivid characters and settings made her a mystery novelist of world renown, died yesterday at her home in Christchurch, New Zealand. She was 82 years old.

title: KDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Included a gain of $706,000 from repurchase of debentures

title: Mideast Questions That Linger
description: To the Editor:

title: BRADLEY HEARS ALARM IN VOICES BACK HOME
description: Senator Bill Bradley came home from the Hill this week to perform one of the oldest rituals of elective office - taking the pulse of the district.

title: MALONE'S DOMINANCE GROWS
description: Moses Malone pulled back the curtains in his hotel room and gazed at the gray and foggy scene outside. ''It was 81 degrees in Houston,'' he said, laughing, as he considered life in the National Basketball Association and the sudden changes in weather the players face as they travel around the country.

title: ELECTRONIC MEMORIES MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $103,000 for the quarter and $328,000 for the year on the repurchase of bonds; C-Including a gain of $385,000 on the repurchase of bonds

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing on Feb. 4 in the Executive Changes column of Business Day gave an incorrect title for John T. Maske, who was promoted at Prime Comput- er. He was named corporate vice president, field engineering.

title: COMBINED INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated for an accounting change for foreign currency translations

title: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOLDUP SUSPECT IS A SUICIDE AS POLICE CLOSE IN
description: A 34-year-old man suspected of having committed about 50 robberies in physicians' and dentists' offices since October shot himself to death in his Brooklyn motel room early yesterday when he saw the police closing in.

title: There Was Another Way
description: Having proposed huge budget deficits for the next three years, President Reagan promised at yesterday's news conference to ''devote the resources of my Presidency to keeping deficits down.'' But how?

title: ARAPAHO PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated for an income tax adjustment

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alpha Industries and Microdyne Corp. announced an agreement to merge. Alpha will exchange 0.63 share of common stock for each share outstanding of Microdyne.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1982
description: International No combat plans for American troops have been set, according to President Reagan. At a televised new conference, he reiterated that ''there are no plans to send American combat troops into action'' in El Salvador or anywhere else, but he declined to discuss any options that his Administration might be weighing to bolster the Salvadorn Government. (Page A1, Col. 3.) A contender in Salvadoran elections has been publicly linked by United States officials with violence and extremism. Ambassador Deane R. Hinton has told Salvadoran leaders that his main worry about the March 28 balloting has become the unexpectedly strong showing of Roberto d'Aubuisson, a cashiered army officer long associated with coup attempts and paramilitary terror campaigns. (A10:1-4.)

title: PORTLAND GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STEWART INFORMATION SERVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $64,000 gain from the sale of title plants; C-Includes $370,000 gainfrom the sale of title plants

title: ACCORD ENDS RAIL STRIKE IN BRITAIN
description: Britain's largest rail shutdown in 27 years came to an end early this morning when the railroad agreed to pay striking engineers a 3 percent pay increase.

title: STAGE: ROBERT ALTMAN DIRECTS CHER
description: FORGET about whether or not Mayor Koch is going to run for Governor. The truly momentous question of the month is: Can Cher act? The answer, alas, is not to be found at the Martin Beck, where America's most beloved one-name entertainer made her Broadway debut last night. In Ed Graczyk's ''Come Back to the 5 & Dime Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean,'' Cher does get to sling a few down-home epithets, to shake her torso and to drink a few Lone Star beers - all of which she does with game bonhomie. But act? Cher has but one speech of any duration, and the director, Robert Altman, demands that she deliver most of it with her back to the audience.

title: Market Place; Datapoint's Gloomy News
description: THERE'S a rule of thumb in Wall Street that, once earnings estimates are reduced, they are likely to be reduced again. That is exactly what has been happening with Datapoint. The company's management met with analysts yesterday only to disappoint them further.

title: RENOVATION PLANS READY FOR ARCHIVES IN 'VILLAGE'
description: An unusual arrangement, reached after six years of negotiation among government agencies, community groups and a private developer, has cleared the way for the long-awaited renovation of the Federal Archives Building in Greenwich Village.

title: Chief Financial Officer Named by RCA Corp.
description: Richard W. Miller, a 41-year-old executive of the Penn Central Company, will join the RCA Corporation as chief financial officer on March 1 and will be given the title of executive vice president two days later. He will succeed Frank T. Alfieri, 51, RCA's chief financial officer for the last two years. Mr. Alfieri had been hired by Maurice R. Valente, who was RCA's president briefly in 1980. He had remained chief financial officer, even after Mr. Va@lente's dismissal, and will continue as an executive vice president with responsibility for special business projects.

title: FEES OF PUBLIC INTEREST LAWYERS UNDER ATTACK
description: When this city's mostly liberal ''public interest'' lawyers were riding high a few years ago, they asked Congress to put a little old-fashioned American financial incentive into their mission of representing the poor, the downtrodden and the environment.

title: SCREEN: SCOLA'S 'PASSIONE D'AMORE'
description: ''Passione d'Amore'' (''Passion of Love'') was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of Oct. 5, 1981. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 1, Broadway at West 62d Street.

title: A 94.7% Drop For Polaroid
description: The troubled Polaroid Corporation reported yesterday that earnings dropped 94.7 percent, to just $1.7 million, or 6 cents a share, in the fourth-quarter of last year. Sales of $445.3 million were off 3.3 percent from $460.6 million in the comparable 1980 quarter, when net income was $32.3 million, or 98 cents a share.

title: UMC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $2,083,000 for the quarter and$2,986,000 for the year; C-Includes $315,000 gain from discontinued operations

title: MAN GUILTY IN SLAYING OF CHILD
description: A Brooklyn jury yesterday visited a rooftop from which the 8-yearold son of a Hasidic rabbi was thrown to his death, then returned to court and quickly found the defendant guilty of murder.

title: DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES VOICE LIFE'S JOYS AND SORROWS
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, an act of giving can express happiness and sadness together, and donations are sometimes made both to celebrate joyful occasions and to voice concern and sympathy for the distress of others.

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including income of $168,000 applicable to 1981 sales adjustments

title: No Headline
description: MINNESOTA WINS, 76-66

title: REGAL-BELOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DENG, GONE 37 DAYS, BACK IN PEKING
description: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, emerged today after an absence of 37 days and said that a ''revolution'' was under way to reduce the bloated government bureaucracy.

title: L.I. POLICEMAN SAID TO DEFRAUD FELLOW OFFICERS
description: A 10-year veteran of the Police Department of this Nassau County village was arrested today and charged with having defrauded a dozen fellow officers of $50,000 to $60,000 over two years in a bogus investment scheme.

title: KRATOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Austrian Gets U.N. Post
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today named Kurt Her@ndl of Austria to become head of the United Nations Human Rights Division.

title: BRIEFING
description: Arranging Lines for Kemp

title: 'ENTRAPPED' SUSPECT PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: A Brooklyn man who contends that he was entrapped by Government agents bent on making him a Congressional informer pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn to charges of cocaine distribution and conspiracy. He remained free on a $50,000 bond pending a court appearance in two weeks.

title: ROAN CONSOLIDATED MINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Boston's Earnings Rise
description: First Boston Inc. reported yesterday that strong gains in all areas of its business caused earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981 to increase to $24.4 million, or $4.30 a share, from $4.2 million, or 75 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980.

title: POLAROID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $30.4 million pre-tax reserve to cover the cost of a program to improveproductivity

title: Red Wings 4, Maple Leafs 3
description: DETROIT (AP) - Willie Huber scored at 14:36 of the third period to give Detroit the come-from-behind victory.

title: U.S. Sailors Like Australia
description: American sailors rate western Australia as their No. 1 choice for rest and recreation leave, according to a survey by the Department of Tourism.

title: 'Party' on 14th St. Stage
description: ''The Party,'' a comedy in verse with songs by Arnold Weinstein, can be seen at the New York Art Theater, 116 East 14th Street, tonight and tomorrow evening at 8.

title: REVERING LOSES ARBITRATION BID FOR HIGHER PAY THAN $250,000
description: Dave Revering and Ron Davis, two of the Yankees' three players who filed for salary arbitration, yesterday traveled in opposite directions between Fort Lauderdale and New York, so Revering did not have a chance to provide Davis with an idea of what he could expect in his case today.

title: 1977 'PURPLE TAXI'
description: ''A PURPLE TAXI,'' Yves Boisset's 1977 romantic drama that opens today at the Thalia Theater, was photographed entirely in the picturesque, rainbow-dappled countryside of Ireland, but it seems to be stateless, a movie made just outside the world's three-mile limit. The language is English, the director French and the cast members English, Russian-English, American, French and Italian, with some bit parts played by Irish actors.

title: A.T.&T. to Delay Changes in Rates
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it had agreed to postpone, until April 2, the proposed effective date of its plan to restructure charges for most interstate long-distance calls.

title: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $1.9 million, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $40 million, or 49 cents a share, for the year from the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations; C-After losses from discontinued operations of $7 million for the quarter and $23 million for the year

title: NO COMBAT PLANS FOR EL SALVADOR, REAGAN DECLARES
description: President Reagan said today that there were ''no plans to send American combat troops into action'' in El Salvador or anywhere else.

title: SORG PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAW FIRM IN DIABLO CANYON CASE HIRED BY SUFFOLK
description: Peter F. Cohalan, the Suffolk County Executive, announced today that the county had hired as legal counsel the firm that won suspension of the operating license of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant in California.

title:
ADVERTISING;
IPSO to Be Introduced Next Month in U.S.
description: Next month a product called IPSO will be introduced into this country, but there is no need for alarm. What is an IPSO? It's pellet-type candies inside small plastic boxes that can be fitted together and used as building blocks.

title: Tennessee Court Rejects Senate Redistricting Plan
description: A Chancery Court judge ruled today that Tennessee's State Senate reapportionment plan was unconstitutional and issued a temporary injunction preventing the state from conducting Senate elections under the 1981 plan.

title: Friday; 'MONTEZUMA' AT JUILLIARD
description: The opera ''Montezuma'' by Roger Session will receive its New York premiere tonight in a performance by the Juilliard American Opera Center, conducted by Frederik Prausnitz, in the Juilliard Theater at Lincoln Center. The libretto, by Giuseppi Antonio Borgese, is about the Spanish conquest of the Aztecs in Mexico and is based on the chronicle by Bernal Diaz del Castillo, a member of the Cortez expedition. Mr. Sessions says that the opera is ''really about fascism.'' Performances tonight and Tuesday at 8 and Sunday at 3 P.M. Admission is $4 and $5. Information: 874-7515. BROADWAY CABARET

title: Bridge: New Yorkers to Compete In Niagara Falls and China
description: Players from New York City will compete in two rather unexpected places a month from now. For the Spring Nationals, starting March 19, a large group will visit Niagara Falls, N.Y., where the scenic splendor will be available for the first time to participants in a national championship.

title: IRAN SAYS KHOMEINI WILL BE SUPPLANTED BY ELECTED COUNCIL
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, will be replaced by an elected ruling council to be chosen in a special election, the Iranian press agency said today.

title: MERCHANTS APPLAUD SELF-TAXATION LAW AS BOON TO THE CITY
description: More than 100 New York City merchants and civic leaders - double the number expected - turned up at the World Trade Center yesterday to applaud what is, in effect, a new tax on business.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 19, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Advisory Committee for the World Assembly on Aging - 10:30 A.M.

title: ART: LOADING BRUSH PAINTINGS OF MAURICE FREEDMAN
description: MAURICE FREEDMAN is a very good painter. It at once emerges from his retrospective exhibition at the Midtown Galleries, 11 East 57th Street, that by 1930 he had learned from Andre Lhote and others in Paris how to draw with the loaded brush, how to handle rich and strong color without letting it get out of hand, and how to give individuality to the objects of everyday.

title: LAMSON & SESSIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,965,000 for the quarter and $12,520,000 for the year

title: MAJESTIC WILEY CONTRACTORS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PERINI CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 results restated for FASB Statement No 52

title: U.S. PLANS TO CUT CONTRIBUTIONS TO LOANS FOR POOR COUNTRIES
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it wants to cut by 26.1 percent its future contributions to lowinterest loans made by international development banks to poor countries.

title: A SWITCH FOR MX
description: When the Carter Administration announced that it would shuttle 200 MX missiles among 4,600 shelters scattered over Utah and Nevada, the basic goal was described as a ''survivable'' missile force that no Soviet first strike could destroy.

title: PRESIDENT BACKS FEDERAL RESERVE AND TIGHT MONEY
description: President Reagan gave his unqualified endorsement today to the Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy, saying that the Administration and the nation's central bank could bring down inflation and interest rates faster by ''working together than by working at crossed purposes.''

title: Forced Shelter
description: When Mayor Koch once said he wanted to sweep the streets of homeless people and confine them for 72 hours, the result was a shouting match. Civil libertarians said wholesale roundups of the homeless would violate their constitutional rights.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Jan 2
description: Results for the year-ago period are for 17 and 53 weeks

title: A FITTING FOCUS OR BUDGET CURBS
description: To the Editor:

title: ERNST, E C, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $557,000 for the quarter from expenses related to Chapter 11 proceedings, prepetition debt and legal expenses, a loss of $824,000 for the 9 months related to Chapter 11 proceedings and legal expenses and claims income of $6,130,000 for the 9 months; C-Net income; D-Including a gain of $850,000 for quarter from tax sharing agreement, claims income of $1,433,000 for quarter and $389,000 for 9 months related to Chapter 11 proceedings and legal expenses and extraordinary gain of $12,652,000 for 9 months

title: NAPCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $9,791,000 from the sale of discontinued operations

title: HELMUT'S PIPELINE
description: You have to admire the West German Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt. He is not afraid to give an on-the-record interview to a writer he knows disagrees with him.

title: AN ALBERTA DISTRICT ELECTS WESTERN SEPERATIST TO FIRST PUBLIC OFFICE
description: Voters in Alberta today elected the first separatist to public office in western Canada. The new member of the Alberta Legislature is Gordon Kesler, a 36-year-old oil scout, rancher and rodeo competitor. He is also deputy chairman of Western Canada Concept, a year-old political movement dedicated to taking Canada's four Western provinces - Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba and Saskatchewan - out of the 115-year-old Canadian Confederation into some form of independence or of association with the United States.

title: BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec31
THE JUDY KAYE NOBODY KNOWS
description: haired singer who is one of the four members of the cast of ''Can't Help Singing,'' the new and praiseworthy salute to Jerome Kern in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, is going through an identity problem.

title: THOMPSON FINDS NEW IRREGULARITY
description: While the advertising community was still reeling from J. Walter Thompson's disclosure on Tuesday that an estimated $18 million of nonexistent revenues had been logged into an agency computer, the company announced yesterday that its accountants and lawyers had uncovered an additional $6.5 million that was recorded in the fourth quarter of last year.

title: HARVESTER DECLARES $299.4 MILLION LOSS
description: The International Harvester Company, which averted bankruptcy last year with a record-setting $5.1 billion restructuring of its short-term debt, announced at its annual meeting today a $299.4 million loss for the first quarter of its 1982 fiscal year.

title: Failures Reach 40-Year High
description: More businesses failed in the week ending Feb. 11 than in any week in the last 40 years, and possibly since the Depression, Dun & Bradstreet said in a survey released yesterday.

title: THE 9 OLDEST RESTAURANTS IN THE CITY: A CRITIC'S GUIDE
description: EUROPEAN cities often rely on antique restaurants to attract tourists and locals alike. In New York, however, a higher value is placed on newness -on the most modern restaurant or the latest restaurant fad. It is no wonder, then, that so many of the city's oldest and most beautiful restaurants have disappeared, among them the tiled, mirrored and brass-trimmed Original Joe's in downtown Brooklyn, the mellow old cafe in the Lafayette Hotel on University Place, Cavanaugh's on West 23d Street in Chelsea and the Claremont Inn, which probably dated back to Revolutionary War days and which overlooked the Hudson from a bluff at 125th Street.

title: FAIRCHILD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a net gain of $18.4 million, or 99 cents a share, from sale of the company's investment in Bunker Ramo Corp in June 1981

title: Economic Scene
description: THE President is giving ground so slowly on his budget and the huge deficits he is projecting that it is hard to be sure whether he is giving ground at all. At his news conference yesterday, President Reagan offered one of his favorite remedies for balancing the budget: an attack on waste and inefficiency. He said he would appoint a private-sector commission on cost containment. However, as though in recognition of the incredulity that might greet this standard ploy for rooting out scores of billions in waste, Mr. Reagan said this would represent ''the largest effort of its kind ever attempted.''

title: Holmes Favors Frazier
description: If Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, could pick between Jimmy Young and Larry Frazier as his opponent for the interim title defense while waiting for Gerry Cooney's shoulder to heal, it would be Frazier. ''He's stronger and bigger and he hasn't had a shot yet,'' Holmes said of Frazier.

title: Lovellette's Lessons
description: Clyde Lovellette, a former collegiate and professional basketball star, is not looking for glory as coach at White's Institute in northern Indiana. ''If you come here for a winning record or to win the state championship, forget about it,'' Lovellette, who is from Terre Haute, Ind., said recently.

title: REAGAN PRESSES FOR APPROVAL OF CUTS IN FEDERAL SPENDING
description: President Reagan warned today that economic recovery would be ''set back'' if Congress failed to approve his proposed reductions in Government spending, and he called on fellow Republicans to ''soften'' their opposition to his program.

title: PRESIDENT DENIES LAPSES LAID TO HIM IN THE PRESS
description: At his news conference today, President Reagan said that the news media wronged him after his last such session and that he had proof of the accuracy of statements and anecdotes that he used Jan. 19 to support his policies.

title: Article 248620 -- No Title
description: Warner Communications, the conglomerate that earned most of its $3 billion revenues last year from people who spent money to be entertained, announced yesterday that it had given $1.5 million in grants to more than 100 nonprofit arts and culture organizations.

title: Allen Joins Alouettes
description: George Allen, who never had a losing record in 12 years as a head coach in the National Football League, will become head of football operations of the losing and debt-ridden Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SOUTHLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
American Officer Ends His Visit to El Salvador
description: Lieut. Gen. Wallace H. Nutting, the head of the Southern Command in Panama, said today that there were ''no quick, easy, cheap solutions'' to the war in El Salvador.

title: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan endorsed the tight money policy of the Federal Reserve Board. He told a news conference that interest rates were high in part because of concern that the Administration and the Fed were at odds. (Page A1.) He warned recovery would be delayed if Congress didn't enact proposed spending cuts. (A21.)

title: PRODUCER OF MUSICAL CHARGES FEATHERBEDDING
description: Stevie Phillips, producer of ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,'' announced yesterday that the long-running musical would have to close soon because of what she charged was ''outrageous featherbedding'' by the musicians' union.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FACTORY USE DROPS TO 70.4%
description: American manufacturers operated at 70.4 percent of capacity last month, down 2.6 percentage points from December to the lowest level since 1975, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: SMALL TOWN IN MICHIGAN FEELS THE DREAD THAT FOLLOWS MASS MURDER
description: Merle Bednacht has locked his door for the first time in 10 years, and Patrick Smith has moved the citizens' band radio from his truck to his wife's car.

title: GENERAL TIRE UNIT MAY SELL 4 CONCERNS
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company disclosed yesterday that it was negotiating with Brentwood Associates, a venture capital company based in Los Angeles, for the sale of four companies that are part of General's Aerojet-General Corporation unit.

title: BOUNDARY LINES FOR THE COUNCIL SET IN 3 COUNTIES
description: The Districting Commission for New York's City Council approved new boundaries in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island yesterday, but prolonged the months-old redistricting controversy by postponing until next week votes on disputed boundaries in the Bronx and Manhattan.

title: MUSIC: PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA PLAYS RAVEL
description: RICCARDO MUTI and the Philadelphia Orchestra offered a varied concert Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, and the audience seemed to enjoy it. But for reasons of performance, composition or this reviewer's tastes, there were problems with every piece on the program.

title: Safeway Net Up in Quarter
description: Safeway Stores Inc., a leading grocery retailer and food processor, said today that its fourthquarter profit rose by 13.6 percent but that its full-year earnings fell by 4 percent.

title: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISLANDERS CAPTURE 14th STRAIGHT TO TIE N.H.L. RECORD
description: The Islanders tied a 52-year-old National Hockey League record tonight when they won their 14th straight game, a 7-4 triumph over the Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum.

title: 'DIALOGUE WITH A WOMAN DEPARTED' AT PUBLIC
description: LEO HURWITZ'S gentle, expansive ''Dialogue With a Woman Departed'' is a work of powerful extremes. It is, on the one hand, a very personal effort, Mr. Hurwitz's four-hour poem to his wife and coworker, Peggy Lawson, who died in 1971. Mr. Hurwitz recites rhythmically on the soundtrack, invoking the things his wife cared about, capturing ''the particulars of the world she strode into, breathed, saw with her own eyes.''

title: KOCH AND REGAN IN DISAGREEMENT ON FEDERAL CUTS
description: Two potential rivals for Governor next fall, Mayor Koch and State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, disagreed politely - but firmly - yesterday on how much New York City had been hurt by President Reagan's domestic policies.

title: REAGAN SEEMS CONFUSED ON VIETNAM'S HISTORY
description: President Reagan sidestepped a question today that sought reassurance that the United States would not secretly become more deeply involved in El Salvador's civil war, but in rejecting a reporter's suggested analogy to Vietnam, Mr. Reagan seemed confused about Vietnamese history.

title: Cyprus Talks Called; 'No Cause for Worry'
description: The Greek Government announced plans today for an ''urgent meeting'' Friday on the Cyprus issue.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We cannot back away on national defense without sending a message to the world, to our allies as well as our potential adversaries that would be very unwise.'' - President Reagan. (A21:1.)

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC AFFAIRS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference at the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: FOR JAZZ AND THE CLASSICS, A HOLIDAY FOR
description: STRINGS By BERNARD HOLLAND

title: SALVADORANS AT FT. BENNING 'A SMATTERING' OF JUNGLE WAR
description: A group of five soldiers struggled to find a way to move a heavy, cumbersome, two-wheel cart across the water with only bridge pilings and a few boards to work with, and time was running out. Two-thirds of the way across, the soldiers and the cart plummeted into the water.

title: COTTON STATES LIFE & HEALTH INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
APACHE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $175,000 for the quarter and income of $200,000 for the year from discontinued operations; C-Including income from discontinued operations of$167,000 for the quarter and $667,000 for the year

title: Mauney's 63 Leads Golf
description: Terry Mauney bettered the competitive course record at Riviera Country Club today with an eight-under-par 63 to take the first-round lead in the $300,000 Los Angeles Open.

title: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: Results for the latest periods have been restated for the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: CONROCK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $1,912,000 on the sale of land

title: MALARIA IS DETECTED IN BABY GIVEN BLOOD IN A BOSTON HOSPITAL
description: A baby born at a Boston hospital developed malaria and doctors say they suspect it was caused by a transfusion of blood infected by malaria.

title: ISAIH AS ADOPTED BY PLANTATION SLAVES
description: To the Editor:

title: TEAM'S BOLD STYLE PRAISED BY TORREY
description: The New York Islanders carved a little piece of history in ice tonight. Bill Torrey, their general manager, ecstatically greeted a whooping and hollering bunch of Islanders as they rushed back to the dressing room after their 7-4 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: STAGE: 'CHUCKY'S HUNCH,' AN ARTIST'S CONFESSION
description: ridden letters to his second former wife, who is herself a lucky lottery winner.

title: California Utility Is Told To Cut Its Electric Rates
description: The California Public Utilities Commission has ordered a $100 million cut in the electric rates of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company. The cut, announced Wednesday and effective immediately, was requested by the utility, which asked that it take effect April 1.

title: BRITISH UNCOVERING EMBASSY OF YORE
description: For months, decorators, painters and paperhangers have swarmed through the rooms of the British Embassy. Workers have stripped the paint off the pillars in the ballroom, restoring the original marble. They have replaced the modern mirrors with original smoked glass and papered the walls with bright new designs.

title: Buckner Is Satisfied
description: Bill Buckner says everything is ''hunky-dory.'' Buckner, the Chicago Cub first baseman, almost doubled his annual salary on Wednesday when he agreed to a five-year, $2.6 million contract.

title: THE PROPER SUPREME COURT REACTION TO FALSE CLAIMS OF JUROR BIAS
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLISHING: WHY AVON ISN'T GOING TO THE A.B.A.
description: MORE than 800 exhibitors are expected at the American Booksellers Association's four-day convention and trade exhibition in Anaheim, Calif., on May 29, the annual extravaganza at which book publishers big and small parade their forthcoming titles before a major gathering of booksellers, but Avon Books is staying home in New York.

title: A TAP EXTRAVAGANZA IN BROOKLYN
description: The grimy, Theater District rehearsal studio doesn't look like heaven. And - stocky or thin, tall or short, dressed in slacks, jackets and winter hats - the men working out in the studio certainly don't look like angels. But the scene they're rehearsing occurs in some celestial time and place, where the great tap dancers of the past have come together to recall the musical extravaganzas of Harlem in its heyday and, as tappers inevitably do, to challenge one another to top their best steps.

title: MARATHON HOLDERS RESIST U.S. STEEL BID
description: The United States Steel Corporation's $5.9 billion merger with the Marathon Oil Company ran into a snag yesterday with the disclosure that several large financial institutions controlling millions of dollars worth of Marathon shares would vote against a merger on the ground that U.S. Steel's terms are too low.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some editions of Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly identified the state agency that employs a supervisor who is under investigation for possible misappropriation of state funds. The supervisor is employed by the Bureau of Accounts of the Department of Audit and Control.

title: Haig Is Said to Criticize British Cabinet Official
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. once privately referred to the British Foreign Secretary, Lord Carrington, as ''duplicitous,'' according to notes of a participant in one of his senior staff meetings quoted by The Washington Post tonight.

title: GULF NUCLEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RICHARD ADLER PLANS PARK COMPOSITION
description: Richard Adler, co-author of the music and lyrics of ''The Pajama Game'' and ''Damn Yankees,'' who recently has turned his attention to serious compositions, plans to compose a symphonic work inspired by his visits to national parks.

title: 'THREE BROTHERS,' ITALY'S OSCAR NOMINEE
description: VERY early in Francesco Rosi's ''Three Brothers,'' the camera is following an old farmer, Donato Giuranna (Charles Vanel), as he makes his purposeful way down a rocky country lane. He walks with vigor but also with care. It's the sort of path on which one can easily slip, and a slip, when you're 80-odd years old, can be dangerous.

title: Actors Win Praise From Auntie Mame Herself; Auntie Mame Likes Play
description: On hand for the opening night of ''Auntie Mame,'' as presented by the ninth grade at Intermediate School 70, on the edge of Greenwich Village, was Auntie Mame herself, Marion Tanner, on whom her late nephew, Patrick Dennis, based his play.

title: ENERGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company was incorporated on June 4, 1980 and had no material operations forthe year-ago periods

title: U.S. WEIGHS ASKING HIGH COURT ACTION ON TAX EXEMPTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration, spurred by a new Federal appeals court order, is considering asking the Supreme Court to decide whether racially discriminatory private schools are entitled to tax exemptions, White House officials said today.

title: Rough Road in New Jersey
description: Governer Kean of New Jersey faces some sharp curves on transportation policy. One involves the New Jersey Transit Corporation's request for a 15 percent fare increase and $30 million more in annual subsidies.

title: To Wrack And Rome
description: Oxford was enchanting in the old days. Everyone carried Teddy bears and dined on plover's eggs and got sent down for wearing grubby offthe-rack suits. Afterward we drove around in lovingly preserved antique cars and learned to distinguish Chateau d'Yquem from Montrachet and they sent us up again.

title: Miss Horne, Ill, Cancels
description: Because Marilyn Horne is ill, the mezzo-soprano part in this afternoon's performance of Verdi's Requiem at the Metropolitan Opera House will be sung by Florence Quivar.

title: CALVIN EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books of The Times The Art of Teeming
description: MALGUDI DAYS. By R.K. Narayan. 246 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: MATAGORDA DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE QUOTATIONS KOCH WEIGHED
description: ''Woe to those who decree iniquitous decrees, and the writers who keep writing oppression.''

description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.6 million for the qr and $4.7 million for the yr...C-After a loss of $242,000 from discontinued operations...D-Net income after a loss of $1.5 million loss from discontinued operations and a credit of $731,000 from an accounting change

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: RIGHTS MARCHERS' PRIDE
description: When the Carrollton-to-Montgomery march for voting rights ended here Thursday, it had proved more than a test of strength for the movement to extend the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: THOMAS BRANDON, MOVIE DISTRIBUTOR
description: Thomas Brandon, a pioneer film producer and distributor who was the founder and first president of the New York Film Council, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Brandon, who lived at Crotonon-Hudson, N.Y., was 72 years old.

title: SUNS HAND KNICKS 4TH LOSS IN A ROW
description: The Knicks, plagued by final-quarter collapses in recent games, sealed their 104-90 loss to the Phoenix Suns in the second period last night.

title: PHIBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRIAL OF COUP PLOTTERS OPENS IN SPAIN
description: Amid high public expectations, the court-martial of the 32 officers and one civilian accused of plotting and executing last year's failed military coup opened today in a heavily guarded converted warehouse.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FATHER CHALLENGES EVIDENCE AGAINST SON IN ATLANTA TRIAL
description: The father of Wayne B. Williams offered alibis and limited documentation in testimony today designed to punch holes in the prosecution's murder case against his son. But the defendant's father, Homer Williams, modified some of his statements under crossexamination.

title: Classicist Is Named 11th Jefferson Lecturer; 11th Jefferson Lecturer
description: The highest honor the Federal Government confers for outstanding intellectual achievement was bestowed yesterday on Emily Townsend Vermeule, a distinguished classicist, archeologist and scholar of ancient Greek culture.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Houston Industries' subsidiary, the Houston Lighting and Power Company, said it had filed an amendment with the Securities and Exchange Commission lowering from 30 years to 10 years the maturity date of a proposed public offering of $125 million in first mortgage bonds, to be sold through a Dean Witter Reynolds group.

title: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Feb 20, 1981

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST (BOSTON) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 21
J I Case Cutback
description: J I Case of Racine, Wis., a construction and agricultural equipment unit of Tenneco Inc., said it plans to temporarily halt production in four states during the week of April 11 in a move that will affect about 5,500 hourly workers. It said the one-week shutdown of plants in Racine; Bettendorf and Burlington, Iowa; Rock Island, Ill., and Terre Haute, Ind., was necessary because of declining sales and the need to reduce inventories. The company added that further cutbacks were likely.

title: BERKELEY BIO-MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $311,000 from discontinued operations which was equal to 54 cents a shr for the qr and 53 cents a shr for the 6 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,528,000 or $3.60 a shr for the qr and $3,375,000 or $3.41 a shr for the 6 mos; the company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: 3 I.R.A. Supporters Deported To Canada by U.S. Officials
description: Three of the five Irish Republican Army supporters arrested at Niagara Falls, N.Y., on Feb. 6 for illegally entering the United States were deported to Canada late Friday by the Immigration and Naturalization Service without a hearing, the agency said.

title: Denver Campaigns To Keep Rockies; Campaign for Rockies
description: It has been a long, bleak winter for the Colorado Rockies, who have spent this season playing in the city's half-empty McNichols Arena while compiling the worst record in the National Hockey League.

title: Prisoner Rebuffed
description: TRENTON (UPI) - An appeals court judge has rejected a plea that the state be barred from force-feeding a prison inmate who began a hunger strike more than two months ago.

title: NARRAGANSETT CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After capital gains of $1.9 million for the latest qr and $2,000 for yr-earlier period...C-After capital gains of $4.3 million for latest yr and $4.6 million for 1980; the 1980 yr per shr results adjusted to reflect a 1.75-for-1 stock split paid in Dec 1980

title: Arrows Regain First
description: The New York Arrows regained first place in the Eastern Division of the Major Indoor Soccer League tonight with a 6-4 victory over the Cleveland Force.

title: To Misspeak Is Human
description: At a speech-cum-discussion with New York City schoolteachers the other day, one of them asked me if I believed public officials were more honest these days than they were when I covered the State Legislature back in the late 1960's.

title: Derby Winners Are Mated
description: Genuine Risk, who two years ago became only the second filly to win the Kentucky Derby, was bred Thursday to Secretariat, who won the 1973 Derby.

title:
PATENTS;
Temperature Control For Apartment Houses
description: A temperature regulator and recorder for apartment houses has been invented by Frank C. Martucci of Fort Lee, N.J., a retired foreman for the Health and Hospitals Corporation of New York. He received patent 4,315,595 this week.

description: Results for the latest qr and 9 mos include operations of Gwaltney of Smithfield Ltd, a subsidiary acquired Oct 27;yr ago results have been restated to reflect a change to the LIFO method of valuing inventories at Smithfield Packing Co which reduced net income by $339,000 for the qr and $837,000 for the 9 mos

BRIEFS

title: Radical and Four Others Indicted in Tax Fraud
description: Susan Saxe, a radical bank robber, and four other inmates at Framingham State Prison have been indicted for income tax violations, officials said.

title: A COMMUNITY MEETS TO TALK ABOUT CRIME
description: More than 350 residents of this village on Nassau County's South Shore gathered in the local high school auditorium Thursday night to talk about crime in their community, its effect on their lives and what the police ought to be doing about it.

title: MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-After $30 million gain on sale of a subsidiary; preferred divds exceeded net income in 1981

title: ON REFEREEING IN THE P.S.A.L.
description: THERE was a bright golden haze in the gymnasium, created by students in a corner of the bleachers smoking ''those funny little cigarettes,'' the basketball official remembers. And when he got nearby he had to squint like a scout when making a call.

title: BY THEIR WITS
description: People who come to New York often have to live by their wits, and one of the more witty efforts being made by out-of-towners is done by the Chicago City Limits, the largely improvisational comedy troupe that is now onstage at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street.

title: A Long Wait for the Next Headmistress; A New Headmistress
description: When Juliana Schmemann resigned last year as headmistress of the Spence School, the private girls' school at 22 East 91st Street, Margaret A. Johnson, the retired head of Milton Academy, agreed to serve as acting headmistress while Spence searched for a permanent replacement.

title: LEHIGH PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 Mayors Attack; Cuts In Federal Aid to Cities
description: The Mayors of Baltimore, Indianapolis and Charleston, S.C., told Congress today that the nation's cities could not absorb additional cuts in Federal funds and that the Reagan Administration should look elsewhere for savings.

title: James River Acquisition
description: The James River Corporation, a leading producer of specialty paper products, announced that it had signed a formal letter of agreement to acquire certain paper-making operations of the American Can Company for $420 million in cash and stock.

title: HARWOOD COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $59,000...C-Net income... D-Including an extraordinary credit of $35,000...E-Net loss

title: CHIEF OF S.E.C. GAVE D'AMATO CONTRIBUTIONS TOALING $2000
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York and chairman of the Senate subcommittee that oversees the Securities and Exchange Commission, received two $1,000 contributions from the chairman of the commission, John S.R. Shad.

title: PACIFIC POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results include a net gain of about $10 million on the sale of securities

title: OUTLINE OF JAPANESE AID TO U.S. RECEIVES LUKEWARM REACTION
description: Japanese business leaders are said to be interested in creating a $10 billion fund for low-interest loans to spur job creation and economic recovery in the United States. A wealthy Japanese-American businessman said yesterday that he had presented the idea to many of them and to Japanese Government officials during a November visit.

title: OPERA: ENSEMBLE DOUBLE BILL
description: The Opera Ensemble of New York chose ''bereavement'' as its theme in its double-bill presentations at the Lillie Blake School Theater, at 45 East 81st Street. But there was little to mourn in Wednesday night's performances. Both Ralph Vaughan Williams's ''Riders to the Sea'' and Puccini's ''Gianni Schicchi,'' with their complementary tragic and comic visions, were finely sung and acted. They served as a reminder that opera can be more alive when treated as drama than when treated as spectacle or as a showcase for stars.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WE'RE ON THE WRONG SIDE IN EL SALVADOR
description: Hey, Asner. What gives you and your actor friends the right to speak out about United States foreign policy? Who do you think you are?

title: PREMIER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MINE SAFETY CHIEF DEFENDS PROGRAM
description: The recent surge in the number of accidental deaths in the nation's coal mines was described today as ''unacceptable'' by the Reagan Administration's chief mine safety enforcer.

title: WITOLD TRAMPCZYNSKI
description: Witold Trampczynski, Polish Ambassador to the United States in the 1970's, died Thursday at the age of 72. An economist by training, he was Deputy Finance Minister from 1950 to 1956, Foreign Trade Minister until 1968 and then head of the State Planning Commission. He joined the diplomatic service in 1971 and served in Washington until 1977.

title: BRONX ROBBERIES LAID TO 'GROUP' OF FIVE YOUTHS
description: Five teen-agers have been arrested in connection with a recent series of armed robberies in the Bronx, including three that resulted in the slayings of the shopowners, the police said yesterday.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 47. 1. This man, Harvey Victor, most emphatically does not H New York. What is the reason?2. Lieut. Col. Harry Melander, a military adviser, was ordered to leave El Salvador because he violated American regulations. What was the violation?

title: Letter: On Balancing the Budget Enact Jefferson's Debt Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Good for Ford ...
description: The tentative agreement between Ford and the United Auto Workers won't provide salvation for either. But the proposal, which still must win approval from Ford's rank and file, is a historic step in the right direction by a union accustomed to oversized wage increases and a company that helped it get them. What's good for Ford, in this case at least, is good for the country.

title: Court Tells Army To Reinstate Cadet
description: A Federal court yesterday ordered the Army to reinstate a female cadet who had been ousted from the United States Military Academy at West Point because she broke a rule barring consumption of alcoholic drinks within 20 kilometers of the academy.

title: Kinney Asset Sale
description: The National Kinney Corporation, a janitorial, parking and construction services concern, said it was selling certain assets of its National States Electric subcontracting unit to a privately owned concern it did not identify. Kinney said that the price would depend on future performance of the unit and that the sale might result in a $1 million charge against 1981 earnings.

title: MACANDREWS & FORBES CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $1,498,000 from discontinued operations; the company changed its yr-end from a fiscal yr ended Jan 31 to a calendar yr; the yr-ago results are for 11 months ended Dec 31, 1980

title: ; John Jay 63, Queens 61
description: John Jay improved its record to 18-6, 9-4 in the City University conference, in the game at Queens College.

title: LINCOLN INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordianry gain of $55,000...C-Net income after extraordinary gains of $68,000 for the qr and $212,000 for the 9 mos...D-After an extraordinary loss of $337,000; in both 1980 periods the amounts have been restated

title: A PHILANTHROPIST IN MIDWEST
description: Helen Foresman Spencer, a philanthropist who donated more than $18 million to cultural institutions in the Middle West, dies Monday at her home here. Her age was not disclosed.

title: GEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $27,156,329 for the qr and yr on the sale of a subsidiary

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HESSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Education Dept. Seeks Suit Against Ohio
description: The Education Department asked the Justice Department today to sue the State of Ohio for failing to integrate its state college system, specifically Central State University near Dayton, as required by the Civil Rights Act.

title: CONTROLLING THE COST OF FUNERALS
description: I T is a major expense that comes at a time when people don't want to talk about money, when they don't want to compare prices, when they don't want to press salesmen about the cost of what they are selling. But the price of a funeral can make a big difference to a family that suddenly must face new bills and life on a reduced budget.

title: Baryshnikov to Undergo Knee Surgery; Baryshnikov Surgery
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov, artistic director and a principal dancer of American Ballet Theater, will undergo exploratory microsurgery early next week to determine whether he has torn cartilage in his left knee.

title: MURDOCH WARNS TIMES OF LONDON
description: Rupert Murdoch, owner of The Times of London and The Sunday Times, said tonight that he would definitely close the two papers on Monday unless an agreement was reached on voluntary work force reductions.

title: HOW TO DOUBLE THE NUMBER OF TAXICABS
description: To the Editor:

title: POVERTY RATE ON RISE EVEN BEFORE RECESSION
description: Alex Chatman, the first black to be elected a county administrator in South Carolina, has his own ways of knowing that hard times have returned to Williamsburg County.

title: HAIG IS CONFIDENT EGYPT AND ISRAEL ARE COMMITTED TO AUTONOMY PACT
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that he was ''very confident'' that Egypt and Israel would remain committed to seeking an agreement on Palestinian self-rule since it was the only approach ''that offers promise'' in advancing the cause of peace in the Middle East.

title: Pat Henry, 58, Comedian; Was Opening Act for Sinatra
description: Pat Henry, the comedian who was the opening act for Frank Sinatra for more than two decades, was found dead Thursday in his suite in Caesars Palace Hotel. He was 58 years old.

title: HIS ASPIRING STUDENTS SEEKSTRASBERG STILL
description: It might have been the advice of a college drama teacher, or the recommendation of the director of a local repertory company who thought a man's reach should exceed his grasp.

title: CULLINANE DATABASE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SILKEN BLOOMS FOR ALL SEASONS
description: A dozen long-stemmed roses cost about $60 and may last a week. The variety in fabric can cost as little as $10 a dozen and will last indefinitely. That's one good reason for the increased popularity of fabric flowers for the home, for party centerpieces and even for bridal bouquets. Another is that no color or variety is ever out of season.

title: DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HUMAN LIFE BILL'S LIMIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Killers of Guards Given Life Terms
description: Two men were sentenced to 75 years to life in prison yesterday for the murders of three Purolator Inc. security guards, one of whom was an off-duty Hartford police officer, during a $1.8 million robbery in Waterbury, Conn., on April 16, 1979.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for QTr to Jan 31
THEATER: '49,' MUSICAL ABOUT A TRIBAL SHAMAN
description: At the center of Hanay Geiogamah's ''49,'' a contemporary tribal musical at La Mama, is a shaman called Nightwalker. As the oldest man of his Indian tribe, he leads his people from past to future, foretelling a time when there will be an end to singing, dancing and storytelling. In a sense, he is pleading for the preservation of the ancient oral tradition: learn history and live by its lessons. The evening is both a celebration of old ways and a call for renewal.

title: News Analysis
description: When Zimbabwe became independent 22 months ago, Prime Minister Robert Mugabe had an absolute majority in Parliament but Joshua Nkomo still had one of the country's two guerrilla armies under arms. Thus a possible alternative to a political compact was renewed civil war.

title: Nebraska Church School Vows to Remain Open
description: A minister who was jailed for operating a nonaccredited school in defiance of court orders will not close its classrooms, his wife says.

title: BERGEN IS INVESTIGATING DEATH BY A BOOBY-TRAP
description: The Bergen County Prosecutor said Friday that his detectives were satisfied that the boyfriend of an 18-year-old pregnant woman did not make the pipe bomb that exploded and killed her.

title: Allen Buys Into Club
description: Maybe George Allen has found a boss he can work for.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It couldn't have been me speaking - it was too clear.'' - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. commenting on remarks reportedly made in staff meetings. (6:1.)

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
T-BAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Negotiators in Geneva Meet for Over 3 Hours

title: WHAT SMOKE DETECTORS DETECT BESIDES SMOKE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: A Deferred Reagan Defense

title: SOTHEBY'S 'SLIMMING,' DENIES TROUBLE
description: Sotheby's, the world's biggest art-auction house, acknowledged today that it was reducing operations and laying off employees in England and New York City, but denied reports of money problems that could make it ripe for a takeover.

title: PRINCETON OPENS A 5-YEAR CAMPAIGN TO RAISE $275 MILLION FROM ALUMNI
description: Princeton University officially opened a five-year campaign today to raise $275 million from its alumni. Unlike most fund drives, only a small amount of the money will be used for so-called ''brick and mortar'' projects.

title: Chamber Ballet U.S.A.  Plans March 6 Benefit
description: Chamber Ballet U.S.A., a ballet company created by Finis Jhung, will give a benefit March 6 at 8 P.M. at Mr. Jhung's studio, 2182 Broadway, at West 77th Street.

title: Recruiting Payoff by Coach Is Reported
description: Baron Hill, a former basketball player for Furman University, said today that while he was being recruited 11 years ago he was given $1,000 by Joe Williams, who at the time was Furman's head coach.

title: Braniff Furloughs 825; More Cuts Set
description: Ailing Braniff Airways, which posted a net loss of $85 million for the first nine months of 1981, said it has furloughed 825 employees and will make additional cuts during the next 90 days as part of its latest round of budget tightening.

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1982; The Economy
description: Senator Bob Dole in effect halted the sale of unused business tax credits by announcing he would seek to repeal the controversial measure, retroactive to today. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan opposed the move and said he had not been consulted by Mr. Dole, who is chairman of the Finance Committee. The Senator's repeal proposal was reportedly backed by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. (Page 1.)

title: Harvard 52, Cornell 51
description: Joe Carrabino, a sophomore forward, made two free throws 42 seconds into overtime to give Harvard a 52-50 lead. Cornell's Ken Bantum cut the Harvard lead to a point when he made one of two free-throw attempts with 1:53 to play, but Cornell missed two field goal attempts in the final 7 seconds.

title: DOW DECLINES 4.66 AS RALLY CUTS LOSS
description: A late rally narrowly saved the stock market yesterday from closing at its lowest level since May 1980. After dropping by as much as 6.38 during the day, the Dow Jones industrial average finished with a loss of 4.66 points, at 824.30. This was barely above its close last Sept. 25 at 824.01, viewed by technical analysts as a key ''support'' level. Had the average finished below the September figure, it would have marked the lowest closing since 822.53 on May 15, 1980.

title: 'ROAD TO FREEDOM' SHOW AT LIBRARY
description: It begins with a Revolutionary War broadside exhorting slaves to join the Colonial militia fighting the British Redcoats in exchange for their freedom. It ends with a photograph of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. when he addressed marchers in Washington during a peaceful civil-rights demonstration in the 1960's.

title: ENVOY TO EL SALVADOR URGES U.S. TO ALLOW ADVISORS TO CARRY RIFLES
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador has asked the Reagan Administration to permit American military advisers there to carry rifles as well as pistols for personal protection, State and Defense Department officials said today.

title: OFFSHORE DRILLERS UNDETERRED
description: At this minute, more than 470 mobile drilling rigs are boring deep into the earth's crust beneath the floor of the ocean. Despite initial expressions of shock and grief following the sinking of a drilling rig operated by the Mobil Corporation off Newfoundland this week, the offshore oil industry -which works all over the world, 24 hours a day, 365 days a year - has not slackened its drive to find and produce oil and gas.

title: CONGRESSMAN ASSERTS SALVADOR DOES NOT WANT U.S. TROOPS
description: A Democratic member of Congress who led a delegation to El Salvador this week has reported to the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., that no one in the Salvadoran Government wants American troops sent to that country.

title: JUDGE POSTPONES DECISION ON PLEA OF AFGHANS DETAINED IN CALIFORNIA
description: At least six more weeks of indecision stretched before a group of Afghan refugees today when an administrative law judge put off hearings on their applications for political asylum.

title: MARDI GRAS, AS SEEN FROM PURITAN BOSTON, HOME OF OTHER MASKING RITUALS
description: Since I moved away from New Orleans a few years ago, I've found myself marking the date for Mardi Gras each year with a mixture of regret and relief. Relief that I don't have to invent yet another costumed identity, regret that I won't experience that whirl of mad oblivion before the somberness of Lent.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: SEATTLE (AL) - Julio Cruz, second baseman, won his arbitration case and was awarded a $375,000 salary.

title: ROBLIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $236,000 for the qr and income of $263,000 for the yr from discontinued operations...C-Net income...D-Incl ing income of $238,000 for the qr and $717,000 for the yr from discontinued operations

title: HARVARD MAY REINSTATE PLANS FOR FOGG ADDITION
description: After a storm of protest over Harvard University's cancellation of a projected $7.8 million addition to its Fogg Art Museum, the university is said to be reconsidering its decision. Plans for the building, the first American commission for the English architect James Stirling, were abandoned early this month for a variety of reasons, including a fear of overruns in construction cost and a concern for anticipated deficits in running the Harvard art-museum complex.

title: SEALED AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $301,000 for the qr and $324,000 for the 6 mos

title: Soviet Airline Office Bombed in Washington
description: Two bombs exploded early today outside the Washington office of the Soviet airline Aeroflot, shattering a glass door but injuring no one, the police said.

title: Penn 81, Yale 62
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Paul Little scored a career high of 20 points, and Michael Brown had 18 as Pennsylvania won its eighth straight game.

title: OIL PRODUCTION BY SAUDIS SLIPS TO 3-YEAR LOW
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, has let its oil production slide about 500,000 barrels a day, to a level between 7 million and 7.5 million barrels a day, oil analysts and traders said yesterday. Since November, the Saudis have cut production by 3 million to 3.5 million barrels daily.

title: TONKA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $207,000 for the qr and $2,694,000 for the yr and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $13,224,000 for the qr and yr

title: 'WARM LINE' FOR PARENTS
description: Parents who wonder how to deal with such problems as sibling rivalry, temper tantrums, breast feeding, setting disciplinary limits or any other situation that might arise in the course of rearing a young child can now get free expert guidance simply by making a telephone call. The Childen and Infant Parenting Service, known as Chips, of the New York University Psychoeducational Center operates what it calls a ''Warm Line'' to counsel parents on a variety of nonmedical early-childhood issues.

title: BARRY, R G, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

PATENTS;
Device to Help Pilots Land in Poor Weather
description: Apparatus to determine the position of an aircraft in relation to a runway was patented this week for the Boeing Company of Seattle.

title: MONARCH MACHINE TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $1,991,000 from the liquidation of a foreign subsidiary

title: BASCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
'DEATH WISH II'
description: ''Death Wish II,'' which opened yesterday at the Loews State 2 and other theaters, is even more foolish, more tacky and more selfrighteously inhumane than the 1974 melodrama off which it has been spun by the none-too-nimble fingers of Michael Winner, who directed the original film.

title: Your Money; If Dividends Go Unclaimed
description: MRS. M of Boston owned stock and received dividend checks regularly in the mail. She moved to San Francisco and left a forwarding address with the Post Office. For a year, her checks arrived regularly. Then they stopped.

title: Resch Looks to Foil Islanders
description: Glenn (Chico) Resch and the Colorado Rockies are all that stand between the Islanders and their 15th consecutive victory, a feat no National Hockey League club has accomplished.

title: KEAN SETS CONDITIONS FOR BACKING PATH FARE RISE
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey hinted yesterday that he would agree to an increase in the 30-cent PATH fare in exchange for concessions by the Port Authority on other matters. Among the concessions he was seeking, he said, was an increase in the rents New York State pays for its office space in the World Trade Center complex, which is owned by the authority.

title: ATLANTIC PUBLISHER RESIGNS
description: Bruce Gray resigned yesterday as publisher of The Atlantic, the Boston-based 125-year-old literary magazine. Mortimer B. Zuckerman, owner of The Atlantic, said that he expected to name a new publisher next week. Mr. Gray, the former publisher of CBS's World Tennis magazine, joined The Atlantic last spring after Garth Hite had resigned as publisher.

title: Bucks 106, Cavaliers 88
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Sidney Moncrief scored 26 points to help Milwaukee extend its winning streak to 11 games, the longest in the league this season. The Bucks surpassed Philadelphia's streak of 10 consecutive victories acheived earlier this season and sent the Cavaliers to a seventh consecutive loss. Milwaukee and Philadelphia are tied for the best record in the league (38-14). Cleveland (11-41) has the worst record. Cleveland trailed by 57-56 early in the third quarter before Moncrief scored the next 7 points on three layups and a free throw. He scored 13 in the third quarter. Brian Winters, who finished with 20 points, scored 10 in the final quarter for the Bucks. James Silas led Cleveland with 31 points.

title: MUSIC: TENNSTEDT CONDUCTS MAHLER'S NINTH
description: Any performance of Mahler's Ninth Symphony by the New York Philharmonic is fraught with local connections; this perhaps quintessential statement of Mahler's Austrian heritage was composed during his first season as conductor of the Philharmonic. But the connections for the current performances are especially strong. The first, Thursday night, was dedicated to the memory of Bruno Walter, who led the first performance of the symphony in 1912 and who was later so closely associated with the Philharmonic himself.

title: SENATE POSTPONES FOR THIRD TIME DEBATE ON EXPULSION OF WILLIAMS
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. has won a third delay of deliberations by the United States Senate of a resolution calling for his expulsion for ''ethically repugnant'' conduct in the Abscam case.

title: PERSONAL INCOME RISES AFTER DROP IN DECEMBER
description: Americans' personal income rose a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in January after falling in December for the first time since the 1974-75 recession, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A.M.C. OFF $47.2 MILLION
description: The American Motors Corporation, continuing to show the impact of the prolonged slump in auto sales, reported yesterday that it lost $47.2 million in the fourth quarter of 1981, sharply higher than the $29 million loss in 1980's fourth quarter.

title: Soviet Diplomat Dies
description: Andrei A. Smirnov, a former Soviet diplomat, has died at the age of 76, the newspaper Vechernyaya Moskva said Tuesday. He served in Nazi Germany, Iran, Austria, West Germany and Turkey before being made a Deputy Foreign Minister in 1969. He retired in 1973.

title: CHEM-NUCLEAR SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Jan 1982

title: OH BARRICADES, FELLAS, AND SEND BACK THE VIN
description: It was not exactly a "shot heard 'round the world,'' but the recent sneak attack by the Academie Fran,caise on the infiltration of ''Franglais'' into France's scientific reports may well be the spark that ignites the next major world conflict - a war of the words, so to speak.

title: Poland Arrests a Priest On Charges of Slander
description: A Roman Catholic priest has been arrested and put on trial for a sermon that was said to slander the Government and Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski, a Government spokesman said today.

title: SUPERIOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reagan Aide Dismisses Comments on Vietnam
description: President Reagan's chief spokesman today dismissed Mr. Reagan's rambling and factually incorrect account of Vietnamese history at Thursday's news conference as having little relevance ''to the problems he was elected to deal with today.''

title: VISITING CONGRESSMEN OPPOSE AID
description: El Salvador's Minister of Defense told a visiting United States Congressional delegation that if the Salvadoran Government was to defeat the rebels his army needed patrol boats, cargo planes, electronic surveillance equipment, 10 fighter jets and enough helicopters to simultaneously transport two battalions.

title: QUOTRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CITY BAN OF A-WASTE SHIPMENTS UPHELD
description: A Federal judge overturned yesterday a new Federal rule that would have permitted trucks to carry large amounts of nuclear waste through New York City and other urban areas.

title: Car Imports in Germany
description: Foreign penetration of the West German auto market fell to 22.9 percent last month from 24 percent in December and 27.9 percent in January 1981, the federal Motor Office reported today. Registrations of new foreign-made cars fell to 33,809 last month from 34,999 in December and 46,894 in January 1981, it added. Japanese manufacturers suffered the largest drop, selling 11,420 cars, or 7.7 percent of total sales in West Germany last month, compared with 18,133 cars, or 10.8 percent of total sales, in January 1981.

title: CONNECTICUT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Includes a one-time gain from the sale of its broiler business of $1,344,000 or 27 cents a shr; the company said that all fiscal 1981 figures ae pro forma; the latest qr consisted of 13 weeks compared to 14 weeks for yr-earlier perio

title: AMONG LANGUAGES, THE LIVING DESERVE OUR CHIEF CONCERN
description: To the Editor:

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-Including a tax credit of $3,612,000

title: DOCUMENTED HUNGER OF POOR
description: Dr. Raymond M. Wheeler, a North Carolina physician who championed the rights of blacks and the poor in the South for more than three decades and, in the 1960's, almost alone documented the extent of hunger and malnutrition among poor children in the United States, died Wednesday in Charlotte, N.C. He was 62 years old.

title: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordianry gain of $161,000

title: NORTHWEST AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
P.& G. WOOS THE ANALYSTS
description: Procter & Gamble, the $11.4 billion package goods giant with an awesome name in marketing and an unchallenged reputation for secrecy, gathered more than 250 financial analysts and institutional investors here Thursday, told them virtually nothing and sent them away happy.

title: OXOCO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes an $11,000 credit for the qr and a credit of $499,000 for the yr from reduction of deferred income taxes arising from deduction of prior yr losses

title: PLAN BY DEMOCRATS EFFACES OLD 'SILK STOCKING' DISTRICT
description: A redrawing of New York City's political map in which Manhattan's ''silk stocking'' Congressional District would be totally unraveled was proposed yesterday by Democrats.

title: ARROW ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $2,805,000 for the qr and yr

title: Refinery Layoffs
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said it would lay off 298 employees at its refinery in Puerto Rico and suspend operations there by March 15 unless there is a ''significant change'' in the company's prospects. The company, which emerged from Chapter 11 last year, recently lost a major contract to supply refined products to Esso Puerto Rico. Donald D. McCuaig, Commonwealth's chairman and chief executive officer, said that the company would continue to operate a products terminal at its Penuelas facilities after the shutdown.

title: Franklin Tops Clinton; Berry Scores 25 Points
description: Walter Berry, a senior center, scored 25 points, and Ken Hutchinson, a junior forward, had 17 to lead Benjamin Franklin to a 67-60 victory over DeWitt Clinton in opening-round play of the Public Schools Athletic League boys' tournament yesterday. The game, played at Brandeis High in Manhattan, marked the end of a long-standing interborough rivalry.

title: U.S. and Hungary Will Grant Reporters Multiple Exit Visas
description: The United States and Hungary agreed today to grant each other's journalists multiple entry and exit visas, enabling them to visit when they please.

title: New Mattel Games Will Fit Atari Units
description: Mattel Electronics, a division of Mattel Inc., introduced several modified versions of its Intellivision video games that can be played on video game equipment sold by the Atari division of Warner Communications.

title: 20 Soldiers in India Reported Killed by Rebels
description: Tribal insurgents ambushed and killed 20 Indian soldiers in the northeastern state of Manipur today, state officials reported.

title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trevino's Welcome
description: Manager John McNamara has said that Alex Trevino, obtained from the Mets in the George Foster deal, will be the Cincinnati Reds' starting catcher this year. The first thing Trevino has caught is criticism, as have the Reds, from a couple of other Cincinnati catchers, Joe Nolan and Mike O'Berry.

title: BLUEFIELD SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fairleigh Dickinson 98 Towson State 85
description: Marcus Gaither scored 31 points to lead Fairleigh Dickinson (14-10 and 10-3) in an E.C.A.C. Metro South game.

title:
PATENT;
Processes Refined To Make Fine Wire
description: The scientists who patented for the International Business Machines Corporation in 1980 a method of making the finest metal wires ever fabricated have invented improvements in the apparatus. Patent 4,316,093 was granted this week to Alec N. Broers, Jerome J. Cuomo, Robert B. Laibowitz and Walter W. Molzen Jr. of the I.B.M. Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: CITY TOWS CARS, REPLACING CONCERN THAT QUIT
description: The New York City Department of Transportation has begun towing away illegally parked automobiles in midtown Manhattan following the discontinuation last week of a private towing company's services there.

title: UNITED SERVICES LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Burtons, 'Close Friends,' Announce Divorce; Divorce for Burton
description: The separation and approaching divorce of Richard Burton and his third wife, Susan Hunt Burton, was announced yesterday in New York. The couple, married in 1976, have actually been separated since last August, said Nancy Seltzer, a spokesman for Mr. Burton's agent, Valerie Douglas, but ''family considerations and Mr. Burton's health made it inappropriate to make this announcement prior to this date.''

title: FORMER PREMIER GAINS A NARROW VICTORY IN IRELAND
description: Former Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey's Fianna Fail Party won a narrow and probably inconclusive victory this morning in Ireland's second general election in seven months.

title: Gretzky Sets Points Mark
description: Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers scored three goals and had two assists tonight to surpass his National Hockey League record for points in a season and leaving him one short of the record for goals in a season.

title: IT'S WELFARE THAT SHOULD BE ALL-FEDERAL
description: To the Editor:

title: WNET to Run Auction From April 29 to May 2
description: TV will broadcast ''The Thirteen Collection,'' its fifth fund-raising auction of art and antiques, from April 29 to May 2.

title: COLLEGES ARE FACING HARD CHOICES ON USE OF TV SPORTS MONEY
description: Even as they try to cope with inflation, Federal budget cuts and declining enrollments, many of the nation's best-known universities find themselves faced with deciding how to spend the millions of dollars that is becoming available for television rights to their major sports events.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Steve Wainwright, the lawyer for Marvin Hagler, the middleweight boxing champion, said ''only the opponent, site and date have been changed'' for Hagler's next defense. Hagler was scheduled to fight Mickey Goodwin on March 6 in San Remo, Italy.

title: South Korean to Visit Paris
description: The South Korean Foreign Minister, Lho Shinyong, will meet President @Francois Mitterrand and other French officials during a two-day visit to Paris beginning Monday, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: HOW TO DOUBLE THE NUMBER OF TAXICABS
description: To the Editor:

title: EL SALVADOR AS 'DOMINO'
description: As construction crews prepare to break ground for a Vietnam War Memorial on the Mall, a different kind of remembrance of that conflict has taken shape here, a debate over whether United States involvement in El Salvador is leading toward a new Vietnam.

title: KOCH CHANGES MIND ON INSCRIBING OWN QUOTATION ON THE ISAIAH WALL
description: Mayor Koch changed his mind yesterday and said he had decided against adding a biblical inscription to the so-called Isaiah Wall as a protest against the United Nations across the street on First Avenue.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1982
