description: International Saudi Arabia has cut its oil output by 3 to 3.5 million barrels daily since November beause of the worldwide oversupply. The Saudis, who are the world's largest oil exporters, have let daily production slide to between 7 million and 7.5 million barrels from a previous level about 500,000 barrels higher. The total output is the lowest in three years. In addition, Standard Oil Company (Ohio) cut the price of oil produced on the Alaskan North Slope, and Exxon confirmed that it reduced the price of heating oil, kerosene and diesel fuel. (Page 1, Column 5.) The Pope indicated disagreement with President Reagan over the American sanctions against Poland following the martial-law crackdown there. He also was ambiguous in his reponses when he was asked whether he planned to visit Poland in August. (1:1.)

title: The Plague on Mitchell-Lama Houses
description: Ever since the first Mitchell-Lama middle-income housing developments were financed by New York State, there have been two ways of looking at them. As housing they are safe, sanitary, sometimes architecturally distinguished homes for families of modest means. But as government investments, they are financially plagued.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $3.1 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday a $3.1 billion drop in the nation's basic money supply in the week ended Feb. 10, a bigger-thanexpected decline that caused interest rates to plummet.

title: Helene Cavanagh Wed To Ex-Representative
description: Helene Henning Cavanagh, managing director of Alan Campbell Inc., designers and manufacturers of decorative fabric and wallpaper in New York, was married yesterday to Stuyvesant Wainwright 2d of Wainscott, L.I., former Republican Representative from the First Congressional District of Long Island. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Francis Creamer at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L. I.

title: Alert Is Declared At Three Mile Island
description: Officials declared a minor alert at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant today after workers discovered a buildup of possible ''combustible gas or gases'' within Unit 2, the reactor that was damaged in 1979 by the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident.

title: A.T.&T WOULD SET UP SEVEN REGIONAL UNITS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in the first indication of how it will accomplish a vast restructuring of its far-flung resources, today disclosed a plan to divide its 22 major local phone companies among seven regional holding companies.

title: 3 GUESTS AT THE HOTEL PIERRE REPORT TE LOSS OF $1 MILLION IN ROBBERY
description: Three guests at the Hotel Pierre told the police they were robbed of $80,000 in cash and more than $1 million in jewelry by two masked gunmen shortly after midnight yesterday.

title: 15 Are Killed in Moscow In Escalator Accident
description: At least 15 people were killed Wednesday when an escalator in a suburban Moscow subway station collapsed in the evening rush hour, according to people familiar with the accident.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Orioles Sign Flanagan
description: The Baltimore Orioles have signed Mike Flanagan, one of three Cy Young Award winners on their staff, to a five-year contract estimated at $3 million, ending five months of negotiations.

title: Agency Reminds Men On Draft Registration
description: The grace period for young men who have failed to register with the Selective Service System expires at the end of this month.

title: Dr. Joseph Moldaver; Neurology Ex-professor
description: Dr. Joseph Moldaver, a retired professor of neurology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: FINNIGAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $585,000 for the qr and $778,000 for the yr from the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations...C-Net income

title: Phillips Loan Pact
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company has completed a $400 million revolving credit and term loan agreement, National Westminster Bank Ltd. said as the loan's joint lead manager. Part of the financing will be used to develop the Maureen Field in the British North Sea, where the company's British unit has a 34 percent share, it added. The loan will also be used for further North Sea oil exploration.

title: Adm. Paul H. Ramsey, Leader of a Task Force
description: Vice Adm. Paul H. Ramsey of the Navy, retired, died Monday at Coronado Hospital. He was 77 years old. Admiral Ramsey was the air warfare director for the Chief of Naval Operations before he took command of Task Force 77, made up of half a dozen swift attack carriers of the Seventh Fleet.

title: A STEP TOWARD BETTER EMERGENCY MEDICAL CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: REVISIONS SOUGHT FOR CLEANAIR ACT
description: Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, declaring that ''the Clean Air Act is fundamentally sound,'' announced today that he would introduce amendments Monday that would make only ''moderate'' changes in the law.

title: HLH PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS TAX CUT AFFECTING LEASING APPEARS NEAR END
description: Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, today in effect halted one of the most disputed aspects of last year's sweeping tax cut: the sale of unused business tax credits that would have cost the Treasury more than $3 billion in revenue by early fall.

title:
Patents;
Ultrasonic Treatment For Cancer
description: WASHINGTON A METHOD of selecting and destroying cancer cells, patented this week, is to employ ultrasonic waves that cause vibration. The system is to be computer-driven and use lasers to determine resonant frequencies.

title: U.S. PRESSED ON EUROPE TIES
description: Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo of Italy, in a speech at Georgetown University here, proposed Thursday that the United States and the European Economic Community enter into a treaty relationship.

title: Football Crossfire
description: Did Vince Lombardi Jr., the assistant executive director of the National Football League Management Council, challenge Gene Upshaw of the Oakland Raiders to come to his side of the bargaining table and fight? And did Upshaw, president of the N.F.L. Players Association, provoke Lombardi by attempting to intimidate him physically? Each side had a different version Thursday night after a negotiating session on a new football labor contract. Lombardi said that ''there was a lot of macho posturing on their side.

title: An Appraisal
description: Its angular form covered in green glass has been towering over Park Avenue and the Racquet and Tennis Club for more than a year, and the huge interior public space at its base has been open for some months now. The 44-story Park

title: CLARY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $84,000 from discontinued operations... C-After a loss of $187,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $11,000

title: COAST SLAYER GETS LIFE TERM
description: Stating that a death sentence would have been fair and just, Judge Lawrence Rittenband of Superior Court sentenced Frederick Jerome Thomas to life in prison Tuesday without chance of parole for the murder of Sarai Ribicoff. Mr. Thomas, 22 years old, was saved from the gas chamber in December when the 12-member jury that convicted him unanimously came up with only seven votes for the death penalty. Miss Ribicoff, 23, was the niece of former Senator Abraham Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut.

title: Nathan Witt, Labor Lawyer; Ex-Secretary of the N.L.R.B.
description: Nathan Witt, a labor lawyer who was secretary of the National Labor Relations Board from 1937 to 1941, died Monday at University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Phibro Net Off 25.9%
description: The Phibro Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 25.9 percent from a year earlier on a 15.9 percent drop in revenue.

title: PURITAN-BENNETT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
APPLIED DEVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.9 million for the qr and $4.1 million for the yr which included losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1.1 million for the qr and $1.5 million for the yr...C-Net income...D-Including income from discontinued operations of $558,000 for the qr and $1.6 million for the yr and a charge of $413,000 for the yr for an accounting adjustment; results for the latest yr have been restated

title: HAIG AND LABOR UNIT AT ODDS ON SANCTIONS AGAINST SOVIET
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. told the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council today that it would be pointless to halt grain sales to the Soviet Union or impose additional trade sanctions unless all other exporting countries joined the United States in doing so.

title: AUSTRIAN LOAN TO SOVIET
description: A group of Austrian banks has announced an agreement to lend the Soviet Union $596.6 million over the next two years at low interest rates, at a time when Moscow is known to be suffering from an acute shortage of convertible currency.

title: New York Tech 79 Stony Brook 61
description: Lyord DeBerry scored 20 points and grabbed 12 rebounds, and Bill Williams scored 16 points and took 16 rebounds as New York Tech won its final home game of the season. DeBerry, a 6-3 sophomore forward from Brooklyn, became the sixth Tech player to score more than 400 points and grab more than 200 rebounds in a season.

title: INTEGRATED ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-There are no comparable yr-ago results because the company commenced operations on Nov 10, 1981; results for latest period are for the 7 weeks following an exchange off on Nov 10, 1981

title: SCHWAB SAFE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
U.S. ISSUES RULE ON WARNING PARENTS ON BIRTH-CURB AIDS
description: The Reagan Administration today formally issued a rule that would require parents to be notified whenever children under the age of 18 received oral contraceptives or prescription birth-control devices from family planning clinics using Federal funds.

title: BERTHA GOLDFARB
description: Bertha Goldfarb, who was active in philanthropy with her husband, the late Jack Goldfarb, died Wednesday in Palm Beach, Fla. Mrs. Goldfarb, who lived in Palm Beach and New York City, was 82 years old.

title: RECEIVERSHIP DECLARED AT DELOREAN
description: John Z. DeLorean, the flamboyant American entrepreneur, in a move that amounted to a declaration of bankruptcy, called in receivers today for his Belfast auto maker in a last-ditch effort to keep a slimmed-down version of the company operating.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS BUYS CHRYSLER TANK DIVISION
description: The Chrysler Corporation today announced the sale of its profitable tank-making division to the General Dynamics Corporation for $348.5 million in cash. Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler chairman, said the sale helps to give the company, which is expected to report a loss of $500 million for 1981, ''a large cash cushion to ride out the current slump.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, the Auctions column in Weekend yesterday misidentified the gallery where a sale of Chinese art will be held Tuesday. The sale, at 10 A.M. and at 2 P.M., will be at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street.

title: Princeton 71, Brown 59
description: Craig Robinson scored 20 points to lead Princeton (8-12 and 4-4 in the Ivy League).

title: AMERICAN MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PHYSICIAN FOR MRS. VON BULOW TELLS JURY OF HIS SUSPICIONS
description: A doctor who cared for Martha von Bulow for 26 years testified today that he had seen no signs of what her husband, Claus, had described as drinking and drug abuse.

title: Rizzuto Is Yanks' First Spring Casualty
description: The Yankees' bunting coach was not perched at the bunting cage outside the clubhouse but rather was seated in the clubhouse with his bandaged right hand in a tub of cold water.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. He is the advertising man in charge of a promotional campaign for the state of New Jersey. 2. In carrying an M-16 automatic rifle while helping Salvadoran soldiers erect a bridge, he violated regulations restricting the weapons that advisers are permitted to carry on training missions.

title: EVIDENCE OF INFECTIOUS ORGANISM THAT DEFIES LABELING IS REPORTED
description: A group of scientists in San Francisco have reported evidence suggesting the existence of an infectious organism with characteristics unlike any organism known.

title: CHAMBER: A NEW CYCLE BY ROREM
description: Ned Rorem's ''Winter Pages,'' a quintet for clarinet, bassoon, piano, violin and cello in 13 movements, received its world premiere last Sunday in Alice Tully Hall, the centerpiece on a program of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

title: A U.S. ARMS IMPORT CURB ANGERS ALLIES
description: Officials at the State and Defense Departments have become concerned that an import restriction that Congress enacted late last year may jeopardize arms cooperation efforts between the United States and its allies.

title: Bridge: A Fine Feeling of Triumph When It's Least Expected
description: Tournament bridge-players, en masse, are well-provided with sad stories: How they bid a splendid slam that nobody else reached, and were defeated by a 5-0 trump split; or how they played correctly but ran into the one distribution that was due to gain for the obvious but inferior line of play.

title: HEALTH-MOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Catalysts Enhance Sensitivity to Light
description: Photosensitizing catalysts that promote useful chemical reactions in the presence of light have been invented by three university chemists. Patent 4,315,998 was granted this week to Douglas C. Neckers, Erich C. Blossey and A. Paul Schaap.

title: HEALTH-CHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $59,000 for the qr and $211,000 for the yr and tax credits of $8,000 for the qr and $58,000 for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $65,000 for the qr and $208,000 for the yr and a tax credit of $70,000 for the qr and yr

title: BALANCING AND BLENDING MENUS
description: Almost as important as being able to cook well is the ability to plan menus that balance and blend flavors and textures of various dishes to the greatest advantage. Many cooking schools teach menu planning and it is covered in some cookbooks, but there still seems to be a great misunderstanding of the subject.

title: NETS DEFEATED BY ROCKETS, 103-96
description: The roar from the 12,736 fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight was as robust as it had been all season.

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
description: B-After extraordinary charges of $574,000 for the qr and $3,475,000 for the 9 mos resulted from settlement of antitrust action against Riegel Products Corp relating to periods prior to the acquisition of Riegel by James River

title: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Mary Decker Tabb Lowers Mile Mark
description: Mary Decker Tabb ran the fastest official women's mile ever, recording a time of 4 minutes 20.5 seconds tonight at the San Diego Invitational indoor track meet.

title: POPE APPEARS SET AGAINST SANCTIONS
description: Pope John Paul II indicated today that he disagreed with President Reagan's imposition of sanctions against Poland in response to the martial-law crackdown there.

title: City Ballet Plans State Tour
description: Following its last performance at the New York State Theater tomorrow, the New York City Ballet will undertake a state tour beginning March 4 at Shea's Buffalo Theater in Buffalo, where the company will appear through March 7. Its tour schedule also includes the Eastman Theater in Rochester (March 10-14) and the Civic Center's Crouse-Hinds Theater in Syracuse (March 17-21).

title: UNION LEADERS HAIL AUTO ACCORD BUT SOME DOUBT ITS ADAPTABILITY
description: But they caution that while the agreement appears to contain a number of new and imaginative measures, it may not be applicable to unions and companies in other industries.

title: Lionel and 2 Units In Chapter 11 Filing
description: The Lionel Corporation, a diversified producer and retailer of electronics equipment and toys, announced yesterday that it and its wholly owned subsidiaries, Lionel Leisure Inc. and the Consolidated Toy Company, had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.

title: The Big Event
description: The 1982 Edinburgh International Festival of Music and Drama is set to run Aug. 22 to Sept. 11, focusing on on Italy's contributions to European culture. Italian companies will go to Edinburgh - although they will not necessarilperform Italian works - and Italian works will be performed by non-Italian companies.

title: Mailbox; Taxpayers, Beware of Games
description: To the Sports Editor: As surely as one could predict that two years prior to the event, the headline ''A Solvent Olympics Planned'' (New York Times, Feb. 6, 1982) would appear, it is equally certain that sometime in 1984, we will read, ''Federal Bailout Sought as Olympic Deficit Soars.'' PIERRE A. LEHMULLER

title: 'BAN THE BOMB' WITH A STRONG DUTCH ACCENT
description: THE antinuclear movement in the Netherlands is one of the strongest in Western Europe. It has mobilized public opinion against the deployment of American cruise missiles so successfully that the Dutch Government has indefinitely postponed a decision on whether to accept the missiles, which had been earmarked for Holland by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The key figure in the campaign has been Mient Jan Faber, a boyish-looking 40-year-old scholar of topology, one of the more abstruse fields in mathematics. He heads the Interchurch Peace Council and has helped to train numerous activists for antinuclear movements elsewhere in Western Europe. R. W. Apple Jr., chief of the London bureau of The New York Times, interviewed him recently at a convent outside Haarlem where he was conducting a seminar for disarmament leaders. Excerpts from their conversation follow.

title: MEXICO'S ROAD TO TROUBLE IS COATED WITH OIL (1975-81)
description: When Mexico discovered large new oil reserves in the late 1970's, it vowed to avoid the mistakes of other third-world energy exporters that had allowed oil to dominate and distort their economies, sometimes with disastrous political results.

title: CUT IN ACTIVITIES OUTSIDE CLASSES A BROAD THREAT TO ENRICHMENT
description: EXTRACURRICULAR activities have long been considered an important part of the educational process in American schools. Students have been encouraged to participate in such activities as sports, music, drama, writing for the school paper and others, in the belief that such participation would provide enrichment beyond the regular school program. That this belief is widespread may be seen in the almost universal inclusion of activities in school programs, as well as in the emphasis placed on involvement in activities in the typical college application.

title: THECAR SALESMEN
description: Plymouth may be doing well but its salesmen are finding it hard going these days. Working on commission, they have to try to get as much money as they can for each car because volume sales aren't there any more.

title: A MAGNIFICENT DEER, BUT NOT MINE
description: I HAVE been waiting for my deer to return. Last summer a deer wandered onto the lawn, poking its way gracefully out of the woods. It took me by surprise.

title: IDIOSYNCRATIC AMERICANA
description: WILLIAM ROBBINS is a correspondent for The Times based in Philadelphia. By WILLIAM ROBBINS

title: IS CINCINNATI READY FOR MICHAEL GIELEN?
description: Another musician might refer to it as his calling, but Michael Gielen speaks of conducting as if it were a cause. Resorting to the language of protest, he outlines his concerns as the music director of the Cincinnati Symphony, a post he assumed in 1980, in terms that might suggest he was preparing a crusade. But while the substance is radical - words like ''conflict,'' ''confrontation'' and ''truth'' arise constantly in the German-born conductor's discussion of the relationship between music and society - the tone remains that of a rational, patient intellectual.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Arlene Slater-Stone, Soprano, Gives Recital
description: Arlene Slater-Stone, a soprano who began and then broke off a promising career several decades ago, returned to the concert stage last Sunday evening at the Abraham Goodman House. Judging from the communicativeness and the depth of feeling in Miss Slater-Stone's singing, serious musical development has gone on during her absence.
To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary
description: President Reagan may have reason to laud the American spirit of giving in times of adversity. With economic recession and rising unemployment, ''those who can give are giving more,'' said Steve Delfin, a spokesman for United Way of America, the fundraising mechanism for some 37,000 nonprofit agencies.

title: News Summary; News Summary; SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1982
description: International The State and Defense Departments are divided over what to do about Western sanctions against Moscow in response to the Polish crackdown. Both sides have agreed to submit the matter to President Reagan. The debate has delayed the departure for Europe of a team headed by James L. Buckley, Undersecretary of State for Security Assistance, to discuss sanctions with the allies. (Page 1, Col. 1.)

title: RULING DUE ON CASINO UNIONS
description: CAMDEN JUDGE Stanley S. Brotman of Federal District Court here is expected to decide next week whether the state's Casino Control Commission can regulate labor unions.

title: TRAIN TRACKS IN THE YARD SHRUGGED OFF BY BUYERS
description: Two years ago a builder from Bayside, Queens, bought an odd-shaped parcel of land in a prime location in the Kew Gardens section of his borough. He paid $30,000.

title: The Region in Summary; A Rival for Gibson's Turf
description: When Kenneth A. Gibson announced this month that he would seek a fourth term as Mayor of Newark, he warned potential challengers to stay off the stump unless they came out ''with their armor on.'' Judging from the feisty tone City Council President Earl Harris took last week in announcing his candidacy, Mr. Gibson may want to suit up in steel himself.

title: EL SALVADOR AND ITS WOULD-BE 'SOCIAL REFORMERS'
description: T o the Editor: Once again we are subjected to a propaganda onslaught designed to win sympathy for forces fighting a government which, for all its shortcomings, happens to be friendly to the United States.

title:
LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR;
MORE VIEWS ON ASSESSMENTS
description: As co-chairwomen of the New York Suburban Coalition Against Reassessment, we applaud the points made in the two letters of rebuttal responding to ''Assessments Still Muddled Despite New Law.'' However, we believe there is one vital factor that continues to be overlooked about the new state property tax law, and it's this:

title: PATCHING A HOLE IN THE WALL OR CEILING: ONE EFFECTIVE METHOD
description: WHEN it beomes necessary to patch or fill in a hole in a ceiling or wall that is made of gypsum board (more commonly referred to as drywall), the do-it-yourselfer is often confused about how to make the necessary repair because the hole has no backing against which patching material can be applied.

title: NOVELS BY THREE EMERGING WRITERS
description: SOUNDING THE TERRITORY By Laurel Goldman. 307 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.50.

title: THE PRIVATE LIVES OF TWO PUBLIC PEOPLE
description: LIKE IT WAS The Diaries of Malcolm Muggeridge. Selected and Edited by John Bright-Holmes. 560 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $18.

title: Bruins 7, Red Wings 5
description: DETROIT (UPI) - Terry O'Reilly and Barry Pederson each scored two goals for Boston. John Ogrodnick had two goals for the Red Wings, who on two occasions held a two-goal lead.

title: ADOPTION LAWS ARE CRYING OUT FOR REFORM
description: IN THE last six months, newspaper articles, letters-to-the-editor columns and television have dealt with the controversy over adoption reform. Even those not involved in the adoption triangle have become aware of the fight to make adoption more open and humane.

title: Around the World; 200 in Zimbabwe Shout Support for Nkomo
description: About 200 demonstrators ran through the streets of the capital today shouting slogans in support of Joshua Nkomo, the junior coalition Government partner who was ousted by Prime Minister Robert Mugabe, officials said. The demonstrators dispersed peacefully at the request of the police.

title: CRIME
description: Lovejoy, who does not appear to have a first name, is the antiques dealer who has a genius for everything in his profession except making money at it. He is now in his fifth adventure, THE VATICAN RIP by Jonathan Gash (Ticknor & Fields, $10.95), and one feels entitled to ask how it is that a man with so all-inclusive a knowledge of his field should always be broke. But then again, Lovejoy is really an artist, and artists are notorious for dying in garrets.

title:
ANTIQUES;
WOOD SERVED COLONISTS WELL
description: IN earlier times, wooden utensils such as ladles, cooking forks and canteens, and wooden tableware - bowls, basins, cups, plates and platters - were as common in the Connecticut kitchens as aluminum, plastic and glass are today.

title: Getting There
description: Two trains depart daily from the Austerlitz station in Paris - one each morning, one each evening - for the 10-hour ride to Perpignan. One-way fares are $101 in first class, $67 in second class.

title: Other Business; THE CENT IN CENTENNIAL
description: The winter of 1882 was a propitious time to be born to fame, it seems. Virginia Woolf arrived on Jan. 25, Franklin D. Roosevelt came along five days later, to be followed by James Joyce, on Feb. 2. In the winter of 1982, those events have proven rather good for all those businesses that cash in on Great Events.

title: U.S. JUDGE ASSAILS SENTENCING OF FELONS TO COMMUNITY JOBS
description: A Federal judge has assailed the growing number of programs under which nonviolent and white-collar criminals are sentenced to perform community-service work as an alternative to prison. He said that such sentencing would have the ''effect of sending individuals who may be moral degenerates and perverts into ghetto neighborhoods to work with underprivileged children.''

title: SOME TAX QUERIES
description: TAX time for local homeowners is bringing about more questions than usual this year. The Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 contained a number of provisions that directly affect the lives of anyone owning, investing, renting, improving or selling a home.

title: Around the World; Israelis Break Up Protest On Closing of University
description: The army used tear gas today to disperse a demonstration of some 200 Israelis and 50 Arab high school students in the Israeli-occupied West Bank town of Ramallah north of Jerusalem.

title: THE END OF A NASTY WAR
description: THE REFUSED The Agony of the Indochina Refugees. By Barry Wain. 288 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.50.

title: The World in Summary; Iran Without The Ayatollah
description: Those who have wondered whether Iran's Islamic revolution could make do without Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini may soon find out. Although Iranian officials last week dismissed reports that the Ayatollah was dying as so much imperialist Zionist propaganda, the Iranian press agency said the 81-year-old imam would be replaced by a ruling council of between three and five members.

title: Hilary Neal Cole Is Bride Of Exploration Geologist
description: Hilary Neal Cole, assistant manager in national sales planning of Home Box Office in New York, and Patrick Richard McDonald, an exploration geologist for the producing department-Eastern Hemisphere of Texaco Inc. in Purchase, N.Y., were married yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Rhodes. He was assisted by the Rev. Philip Caruso, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
HOUSING;
THE APPEAL OF A 2-FAMILY HOUSE
description: TO THOSE who were raised in the outlying boroughs of New York City, the two-family home is hardly a new phenomenon. In the suburbs, however, semi-attached houses, duplexes, twins or mother-daughters - as such residences have been known - have seldom been considered the housing type of choice.

title: STATE OFFER ON PARKS TAX COULD AID L.I.
description: ALBANY THE State of New York could become a major taxpayer to Long Island school districts and county governments under a new proposal recently unveiled here. The State Board of Equalization and Assessment would like thousands of acres of state parkland, open space, state university campuses and large hospital complexes on the Island - 32,294 acres in all - to be subject to all local property taxes. When phased in after five years, the plan would produce nearly $28 million on the Island, $3.4 million in Nassau and $24.3 million in Suffolk, the board predicted.

title: Robert Apfel, Jai A. Imbrey Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Imbrey of Bethesda, Md., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jai Alison Imbrey, to Robert C. Apfel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray L. Apfel of Hollis Hills, Queens. A May wedding is planned.

title: Channel Isles
description: To the Editor:

title: BEING JERZY KOSINSKI
description: Barbara Gelb, a regular contributor to The New York Times Magazine, is the author of the recently published paperback ''So Short a Time,'' about the journalists John Reed and Louise Bryant. By Barbara Gelb

title: A shot of ouzo goes with everything
description: The Recipe When the hot Mediterranean sun smothers the harbor towns of Greece in the afternoon, the cafes fill with villagers quietly sipping the most Greek of all drinks - ouzo. Aniseed-flavored liquor, from Pernod in Marseilles to arrack in Aleppo, has for centuries gone hand in hand with hot afternoons and snacks in Mediterranean and Middle Eastern countries.

title: BEATING THE ODDS AT BLOWING GLASS
description: LAMBERTVILLE WHEN Leonard DiNardo sets up shop next weekend at the Winter Market of American Crafts in Baltimore, his two dozen blown-glass vessels will be those that have overcome the odds.

title: Future Events That's Entertainment
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Jam Session Feb. 24 - The Beaux Arts Ball sponsored by the National Urban League Guild always draws capacity crowds to the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom and the 42d edition should be no exception. ''A Salute to Jazz - An American Treasure,'' as it is billed, will have as guests of honor Barney Josephson, whose Cookery and Cafe Society clubs have provided a showcase for black jazz artists, and Suzanne De Passe, president of Motown Productions. Lena Horne heads the sponsors committee for the event, proceeds from which go to National Urban League employment, education and housing projects. Co-chairmen are Billy Taylor, jazz pianist, and George Wein, jazz festival producer. Entertainment will be by the Dexter Gordon Quartet and the jazz trumpeter Adolphus (Doc) Cheatham. Tickets, $50 in advance, $55 at the door. Subscription of $85 in advance includes special champagne breakfast.

title:
LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR;
Volunteer Worker Suggests Involvement
description: The article ''Living With Crime: Three Views'' was most interesting. As a volunteer for over five years at the Bridgeport Office of Adult Probation, I concur with all three viewpoints but find an important point missing.

title: Rebecca Allen Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Arthur Allen of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Watson Allen, to Steven Niles Barlow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Clifford Barlow of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Quotation of the Day; Quotation of the Day
description: ''The feeling out here is one of lost confidence. No one elected Ronald Reagan to preside over a recession.'' - Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa. (1:5.)

title: HOW JUNK MAILERS CAN BARK UP THE WRONG TREE
description: GILDA BROWN is neither a reader, a writer, a gardener, an investor, a voter nor a joiner. But she gets mail from strangers who heap on the flattery, telling her that she should buy from, contribute to or become a member of their organizations because she is informed, inquiring, open-minded and involved.

title: GREENLAND TO VOTE ON COMMON MARKET STATUS
description: In a referendum that could have significant ramifications in Europe, the residents of this huge Arctic island are voting Tuesday on whether to stay in the Common Market.

title: ONE MAN'S REVOLUTION
description: BYZANTIUM ENDURES By Michael Moorcock. 373 pp. New York: Random House. $14.50.

title: Reed Named to Hall of Fame
description: Willis Reed, the captain and center of the Knicks when they won National Basketball Association championships in 1970 and 1973, was named yesterday to the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame. The 6-foot-10-inch Reed, who is now the coach at Creighton University, was one of seven basketball figures selected for induction May 3 at Springfield, Mass.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW COIN MAY PLACE WASHINGTON ON HORSEBACK
description: The new George Washington commemorative half dollar apparently will portray the nation's first president on horseback. Officials at the United States Mint declined to disclose specifics about the design pending formal review and approval, but Mint Director Donna K. Pope confirmed early this month that the horseback motif was one of the alternatives being weighed - and barring a last-minute change, it appeared that this would be the version used.

title: Dalkey
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSESSION WITH TECHNIQUE
description: One of the most moving moments in all cinema must be the sequence in Federico Fellini's ''Amarcord'' when the good people of Rimini row out upon a cellophane sea, in the middle of a soundstage night, to witness the Italian liner Rex's setting off on her maiden voyage. thout warning there suddenly looms over the flotilla of tiny boats the great shape of the Rex, a floating palace ablaze with lights, accompanied by dance music heard distantly, as if the Riminians were eavesdropping on another world.

title: Mailbox; Pro Hockey For Its Own Sake
description: To the Sports Editor: The tempest surrounding Paul Mulvey's refusal to play ''hammer'' and the question of the coach's right to ask him to do so continues the build-up of interest and concern about violence in hockey. It raises for me an issue that I haven't seen mentioned.

title: Davis a Loser in Arbitration
description: Ron Davis joined Dave Revering today as a loser to the Yankees in salary arbitration. The Yankees announced that Robert Stutz, the arbitrator, had ruled in their favor, awarding Davis a salary of $300,000 instead of the $575,000 the relief pitcher sought. Bobby Brown's case remains to be decided among the Yankees who filed for arbitration.

title: MASTERWORK GROUP EXPANDS
description: OVER the years, the Morristown-based Masterwork Music and Art Foundation has fostered a variety of cultural endeavors, notably the Masterwork Chorus, whose annual visits to Manhattan to sing Handel's ''Messiah'' have become identified with the Christmas season.

title:
LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR;
MORE VIEWS ON ASSESSMENTS
description: I HAVE just finished reading the letters to the editor written by Virginia Salow and Rose Eisner in response to the article ''Assessments Muddled Despite New Law.'' They are mistaken in their arguments that full-value assessments would necessarily mean higher taxes. Property taxes are revenues generated to balance the difference between projected expenditures and projected income of town, county and school district budgets. This revenue is a constant.

title: THE IRONY ATTACKS ON REAGAN BUDGET
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S proposed budget has encountered bipartisan opposition in Congress, and his ''new federalism'' plan to turn over to the states an array of Federal programs has brought skepticism from state officials, including the Democrats in Connecticut.

title: N.J. REPUBLICANS SQUIRMING UNDER THE PRESSURE OF VICTORY
description: Because of their frustrating refusal to work together, New Jersey Republicans have often seemed to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory. Now that the G.O.P. has actually snatched a victory, if a slim one, in last fall's gubernatorial election, it seems inevitable that the party is having trouble coping with success.

title: CHOOSING A PHONO CARTRIDGE
description: Four different types of phono cartridges currently compete for public favor, each employing a different principle, and each touted as superior to the others. Technical polemics have done little to clarify the subject, particularly since commercial interest gets in the way of rational discussion and - as often happens in arguments among audio designers - the sound mixes with the fury.

title: 10 CROATIANS ON TRIAL ON RACKETEERING CHARGE
description: Ten men who advocate Croatian independence from Yugoslavia have been portrayed as ''conspirators'' by the prosecution and as ''patriots'' by the defense in a Manhattan trial on charges involving murder, arson and extortion.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Shorter Rest; For Columbia
description: For technicians tending America's space shuttle, the race is on to return the vehicle to duty every two months. Last week, they seemed to be gaining.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: 1040 time. Step into any well-stocked bookstore these midwinter days, and you'll be confronted by displays of two dozen new books with a variety of titles but a single theme: ''Perfectly Legal: 275 Foolproof Methods for Paying Less Taxes.'' ''How You Can Use Inflation to Beat the IRS.'' One is named, hyperbolically, ''How to Pay Zero Taxes.''

title: HOME OF JAPAN'S SHINTO GODS
description: HENRY SCOTT STOKES is chief of The New York Times bureau in Tokyo. By HENRY SCOTT STOKES

title: Business Conditions; TIME TOPS TV GUIDE
description: TV Guide magazine lost its top spot last year among the nation's leading magazines in terms of advertising revenues. Time magazine, with revenues up 13 percent to $253.4 million, took first place, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.

title: Military Analysis
description: The position of the Israeli forces facing southern Lebanon is considered extremely strong by United States analysts. However, these analysts report that there has been no evidence that the Israelis in the region are prepared, at the moment, for anything more than giving an explicit warning to the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Syrian Army and Air Force in Lebanon.

title: Architect to Wed Miss Fleischmann
description: The engagement of Susan Timmons Fleischmann to William Manning Erickson has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Fleischmann 3d of Weston, Mass., parents of Miss Fleischmann. Her fiance is the son of Patricia Launer Erickson and Charles Leslie Erickson Jr., both of Baltimore.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Duds for Sale or Rent, New or Recycled
description: The Workingman's Closet in New Rochelle has a price card for sturdy, new washable work-place apparel for men and women that lists the charges for used work clothes on the other side. The highest prices on the reverse side are $7 for hip-length or Eisenhower-length outer jackets, $12 for coveralls and $15 for blazers. Those prices are dropped through April, with a two-for-one sale on overstocked used clothing, marking shirts to $1, pants and smocks to $1.50, and shopcoats and lab gowns to $2.50 each if two are purchased.

title: ETHIOPIA SAID TO OPEN DRIVE AGAINST ERITREA REBELS
description: Ethiopian Government forces opened a full-scale offensive last week backed by Soviet weapons and military advisers to eradicate the 20-year-old Eritrean independence struggle, a spokesman for the Eritrean People's Liberation Front said in New York.

title: NASHUA: CLASS AND CHARACTER
description: PERHAPS one of the hardest things surrounding the passing of Nashua, on Feb. 4, has been trying to answer this question: What did the old horse mean to me, to the thoroughbred racing business and to the farm?

title: Rainbow Trout May Be in Hot Water
description: THE FUTURE of the hydroelectric facility that many believe would destroy the first-class rainbow trout fishery in New York State's Esopus Creek is still in doubt.

title: by Cynthia King
description: GET ON OUT OF HERE, PHILIP HALL By Bette Greene. 149 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $9.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By CYNTHIA KING

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Jx FICTION 1 2 18 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 3 4 MARCO POLO, IF YOU CAN, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $13.95.) Blackford Oakes's quest for a mole in the C.I.A. takes him to Russia. 3 4 14 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 4 1 23 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 5 5 3 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 6 9 15 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $14.95.) A dauntless woman leads her family from Czarist Russia to Palestine to New York's diamond center. 7 10 42 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 8 8 3 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer.

title:
LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR;
Crime Victim Urges Fight to End It
description: I found it a curious coincidence to read your articles on crime (''Adapting to the Rise in Suburban Crime'' and ''Living With Crime: Three Views,'' Feb. 7) almost exactly one year after I had become a victim of this scourge. As such, I find it extremely defeatist to talk in terms of simple adaption - have we given up the fight to eliminate such horrors?

title: I.R.S. WORKER DISMISSED IN '44 GETS HEARING
description: For 38 years, ever since he was dismissed by the Internal Revenue Service for preparing a 300-page report about government corruption, Andrew J. Susce has sought to clear his name.

title: EDINBURGH: FESTIVE AND STEADFAST
description: CITY STEWART PARKER is an Irish playwright, born in Belfast; his ''Spokesongs'' has been produced in Dublin, London and New York. By STEWART PARKER

title: WHAT'S DOING IN CARACAS
description: JOSEPH MANN contributes to The Times from Caracas. By JOSEPH MANN

title: 'OPTIMISM'CITED BY U.A.U. AIDES HERE
description: SINCE the end of January, when talks between the United Automobile Workers and General Motors collapsed, the G.M. assembly plant in North Tarrytown has been shut down for all but one week. However, officers of U.A.W. Local 664, which represents the plant's 4,600 hourly workers, say that an ''optimistic and positive mood'' continues to exist among the membership.

title: MORE BUCKS FOR THE BANG
description: THE GLOBAL POLITICS OF ARMS SALES By Andrew J. Pierre. A Council on Foreign Relations Book. 352 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $5.95.

title: CONCERT: A SALUTE TO FINNEY
description: Friends, students and admirers helped Ross Lee Finney celebrate his 75th birthday Thursday at the Symphony Space. The music was by Mr. Finney and some of his more successful students - including Roger Reynolds, George Crumb, William Albright and Robert Ashley.

title: TYPEWRITERS, LOVE AND KISSES
description: THERE has never been a better time for romance. The grand passion is all the rage. Harems, knights in shining armor, scoundrels and handsome heroes and brave damsels who defy distress are carousing their way across the pages of best-selling romance novels, spurred on by the grandest passion of all, love.

title:
LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR;
Kerosene Heaters And the State Law
description: In response to your Jan. 24 article ''Homeowners Find Fuel-Oil Substitutes,'' I offer my opinion that kerosene heaters are a tragedy waiting to happen, and the laws on kerosene heaters are not conflicting or ambiguous. The New York State Fire Prevention Code, Section F402-3.4, states:

title: No Headline
description: Weiskoff and Miller Tie for the L.A. Lead

title:
Reader Comment;
ASBESTOSIS
description: P ROFESSOR PAUL MacAVOY's article ''You, Too, Will Pay for Asbestosis'' (Feb. 14) points out an interesting problem facing the insurance industry as a result of asbestos litigation. It suggests that the cost for indemnifying claims will ultimately be borne by the American public in the form of higher insurance premiums.

title: FARMERS'INVESTMENTS
description: business men all around the country who buy stocks and bonds from Edward D. Jones have similar goals, the company believes. And as a result, they also have remarkably similar investment portfolios.

title: How to visit the shrine
description: Making Arrangements For those who don't speak Japanese, a visit to the shrine at Izumo and its inner sanctuary is best arranged through the Japan National Tourist Organization in Tokyo, which will get in touch with the shrine's Tokyo branch and ask permission for the visit. The tourist organization is also the best source of interpreters; there are said to be only six part-timers in Shimane prefecture, the region encompassing Izumo and Matsue. The charge, according to the prefectural tourist office in Matsue is about $42 a day. The Yagumo Honjin inn also requires interpreters as well as reservations for lunch. Getting There The quickest way to get to Izumo from Tokyo is by air, a round-trip cost of about $174. The alternative is to go by bullet train, perhaps with a stopover at Kyoto, changing trains to Okayama, and getting onto a local express. The entire journey takes about seven hours and costs about $63. The merit of the train is that it enables one to see the startling contrast between the densely crowded southern seaboard, one line of factories and forests, and the sparsely inhabited parts north of the mountains. Further Reading ''Shinto Art: Ise and Izumo Shrines'' by Yasutada Watanabe, published by John Weatherhill, New York, and Heibonsha, Tokyo, is the best guide to the two holiest spots in Japan. It is an architectural detective story in which Professor Watanabe traces 1,500 years of history and unfolds the mysteries of the shrines' origins in the prehistoric age.

title: A BOUNTIFUL HARVEST OF VIOLIN LITERATURE
description: For fanciers of violin music, the disk releases of the last few months have been especially bountiful, bringing new recordings of repertory staples as well as unusual works, performed by both the established stars of the violin world and the latest generation of contenders.

title: Headliners; Caputo's Army
description: Former Representative Bruce F. Caputo made no bones about it: he'd been ''a soldier'' and was proud of it.

title: CAPE MAY SEEKS TO BALANCE DEVELOPMENT AND PROTECTION
description: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE BUCKING the tide that has swept most of the rest of the state and country, Cape May County has been undergoing considerable housing development in recent years. In the face of this, state and private environmentalists have tried to preserve the county's scenic and ecologically sensitive areas.

title: Fidrych to Join Red Sox
description: Mark (The Bird) Fidrych, whose arm ailments have kept him in the minor leagues for three seasons, will join the Boston Red Sox next week in spring training at Winter Haven, Fla., the team announced today.

title: Topics; PASSING RITES
description: Topics Passing Rites The State of Estates

title:
DINING OUT;
ODD COMBINATIONS CAN WORK
description: THE three-month-old Parsippany Hilton Hotel is a handsome place, and its interior is a visual pleasure. Lush greenery, flowing pools of water, enormous Oriental cachepots and smart colors give the hotel a sophisticated air.

title: HAIG URGES A WARNING BY REAGAN ON SALVADOR
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has urged President Reagan to warn in his forthcoming speech on the Caribbean that the United States will do ''whatever is prudent and necessary'' to protect El Salvador from foreign-backed subversion, Administration officials said today.

title: 14 'Angels' Are Issued Summonses in Subway
description: Fourteen Guardian Angels who were being filmed by a Canadian television company were issued summonses Friday night for entering the subway system without paying, officials said.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK PUTS A WORLD VIEW IN A NUTSHELL
description: JEANE J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate at the United Nations, last week made clear the Administration's resolve not to repeat in El Salvador the mistakes of Vietnam as it sees them. The following remarks in reply to questions at an American Legion conference in Washington were taped by CBS News.

title:
LONG ISLAND HOUSING;
SHARING OF HOMES IS GAINING AS A WAY TO HELP THE ELDERLY
description: FLORAL PARK AFTER Hans Hinz, a retired hairdresser, was widowed, he continued living in his Bayside apartment. However, he was in ill health and could manage only with the help of a homemaker who came in three times a week.

title: CURRNET REPORTS ON DURABLE HITS
description: ''Annie''

title: UNITED WAY GIFTS SET A RECORD
description: At a time of recession and rising unemployment, Americans contributed a record $1.68 billion to campaigns of United Way organizations last fall and winter, the charity has announced.

title: DAMAGED UPSTATE REACTOR TO BE CLOSED UNTIL AT LEAST MAY 1
description: The Robert E. Ginna nuclear reactor in Ontario, N.Y., where a burst tube in a steam generator led to the accidental release of radioactive steam on Jan. 25, will remain shut until at least May 1, the Rochester Gas and Electric Company, the operating utility, has announced.

title: ALLIED BLUNDERS
description: ROME '44 The Battle for the Eternal City. By Raleigh Trevelyan. Illustrated. 366 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $17.95. By NORMAN LEWIS

title: Around the Nation; Expert Says Police Should Have Heard Car
description: An expert on sound testified today that Wayne B. Williams could not have sneaked his car onto a Chattahoochee River bridge to dump a body because a noisy metal expansion joint in the bridge would have given him away.

title: Courtney E. Cash Is Wed to Ensign
description: Courtney Elizabeth Cash, daughter of Francis Armistead Cash of Bristol, Va., and the late Elizabeth Wall Cash, was married in Richmond yesterday to Ens. Lloyd Montague Mustin 2d, U.S.N. He is the son of Rear Adm.

title: GEORGETOWN TRIUMPHS
description: John Bagley scored 35 points, 21 in the second half, to lead Boston College to a 90-81 Big East victory over St. John's yesterday at Alumni Hall in Queens.

title: A WAY OF LIFE IS DISAPPEARING
description: ''RAPE!'' I shout at the thundering, unheeding trucks loaded with Pine Barrens treasures. They roll past our house in increasing numbers, carrying pines and mosses, wildflower roots and lovely old snags that have been removed.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE new Speaker of the Assembly, Alan J. Karcher, Democrat of Sayreville, will have a rather unusual legislative aide working for him tomorrow: a candidate for the United States Senate. But for the aide, Howard Rosen, a Millburn lawyer, it's just one more job.

title: A NEW GENERATION OF DWARF FRUIT TREES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joanna May Thach is a writer who gardens on Long Island. By JOANNA MAY THACH

title: Miss Kruesi, G. J. Carlson Will Be Wed
description: The engagement of Charlotte Kimball Kruesi to George Jeffrey Carlson of Southport, Conn., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Oscar Rogers Kruesi of Bernardsville, N.J., and Tinmouth, Vt., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. George Henry Carlson Jr. of Madison, N.J., and the late Mr. Carlson.

title: CONSUMER RATES
FAIR WEATHER AHEAD; Southern Tours of Homes and Gardens
description: Spring comes early to the South, and at least two regions - the city of Savannah, Ga., and the state of Virginia - will take advantage of the generally good weather and profusion of blossoms on such plants as azaleas and dogwood to offer tours of historic homes and gardens. In Savannah, the 47th annual Tour of Homes and Gardens is scheduled from March 28 to April 1, and in Virginia, the Garden Club of Virginia's 49th annual Historic Garden Week goes from April 24 to May 2.

title: Dell R. Rodman Weds Susan Sumter Brawley
description: Susan Sumter Brawley and Dell Ray Rodman, who are guide-dog instructors at Guiding Eyes for the Blind in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., were married yesterday in New London, Conn. The Rev. Wallace Anderson performed the Congregational ceremony at the home of Lieut.

title: Personal Finance; THERE'S SOMETHING BETTER THAN AN I.R.A.
description: I T'S like an Individual Retirement Account, only better. It cuts your income taxes, allows you to put away more money than with an I.R.A., but still lets you get your hands on the funds in an emergency - without a penalty.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THERE were a lot of frantic meetings and telephone calls in Stamford last week as Thursday came and went without the opening of the Stamford Town Center.

title: TOURISM DRIVE HITS UNLIKELY SNAG: EAST END
description: JUST as travel industry efforts to promote Long Island abroad as a prime vacation spot are beginning to translate into increasing numbers of European, Japanese and South American visitors, some people here are expressing doubts about whether those numbers will translate into better profits for them.

title: THE NEW REALISM IN PORTRAYING HOMOSEXUALS
description: Ahandsome 30-year-old doctor, Zach has been happily married for eight years to Claire, a successful television programming executive. But lately Zach has begun to stray. He is powerfully attracted to a young writer whom he meets as a patient but who - a lunch date and a dinner later - becomes a lover. When Zach's wife goes away for the weekend on a business trip, Zach turns up at the writer's apartment for a prolonged tryst. The resulting strains on his marriage precipitate a crisis.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: in-law's funeral in Rumania realizing on the spot the harshness of that country and in flashback the violent decay of human decency in his own country. THE FAMILY IDIOT, by Jean-Paul Sartre.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: ALICE JAMES: A Biography, by Jean Strouse. (Bantam/Windstone, $4.95.) The life of Alice James (1848-92), who until recently has been remembered only as the chronically ill, eccentrically brilliant younger sister of the philosopher William James and the novelist Henry James and as the keeper of an interesting diary. In the course of this judicious, beautifully written book, winner of a 1981 Bancroft Prize in history, Jean Strouse adds to our understanding of the condition of American women in the 19th century.

title: THE PRIVATE LIVES OF TWO PUBLIC PEOPLE
description: CLARE BOOTHE LUCE By Wilfrid Sheed Illustrated, 183 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $12.95.

title: A $150,000 Robbery At Daily News Plant
description: Three robbers, one of them armed with a handgun, took $150,000 from the Brooklyn printing plant of The Daily News yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: STAGE: 'THE TEAK ROOM' EXPLORES DANCER'S LIFE
description: Margaret Beals explores her life in ''The Teak Room,'' a new onewoman play written and performed by the dancer at the York Players Theater at the Church of the Heavenly Rest. It is a life whose fantasies began in the ''teak room,'' a wooden enclosure brought back from Japan to her family home in Brookline, Mass., by Miss Beals's grandfather. As she grew older the fantasies continued, grounded now in dance, a world as inextricably familiar and grotesque as any foreign chamber.

title:
LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR;
'Lots of Company' On Water Bills
description: The article by Gail Mack on complaints over water-bill methods (''Complaints Rise Over Water-Bill Methods,'' Feb. 7) was a revelation. I now realize I have lots of company in my billing complaints with the New Rochelle Water Company.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: ART It may be perverse, but - other things being equal - I prefer portraits of places to portraits of people. I can see the people I like almost any time, and they are quite as fascinating to me as the great figures of the past, but the places I like tend to be either far away or gone forever.

title: Re-creating the Power of the Sun
description: Jeremy Bernstein's excellent article ''Re-creating the Power of the Sun'' (Jan. 3) suggests one basic question: If a functioning fusion furnace is already available -namely, the sun - why spend $20 billion to re-create it? Out in space, the sun's life-giving rays shine 24 hours a day. There, where there are no clouds or night, storage facilities, which are needed to use solar energy at the earth's surface, are unnecessary.

title: Penguins 6, Flyers 5
description: PITTSBURGH (UPI) - Mike Bullard scored two power-play goals to help Pittsburgh end a streak without a victory of 0-7-2, which was one short of the team record. Philadelphia has not won in nine consecutive road games.

title: ELECTION LEAVES NEXT GOVERNMENT OF IRELAND IN DOUBT
description: The Irish Republic, confronted by its most serious economic crisis since World War II, emerged today from a second general election in seven months with the prospect of continuing confusion and instability.

title: SOUL: WOMACK SINGS AT THE RIT
description: Although Bobby Womack, the Cleveland-born soul singer and protege of the late Sam Cooke, has had a long and successful solo career, he has never achieved the stature enjoyed by such contemporaries as Marvin Gaye, Wilson Pickett or James Brown.

title: THE DANCE: HANYA HOLM PREMIERE
description: Ever since her arrival from her native Germany in 1931, Hanya Holm has been a major force in American dance. Choreographically, she may be growing more cheerful with each passing year. For instance, one of her most recent works was appropriately titled ''Jocose.'' And on Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church the Don Redlich Dance Company offered the premiere of Miss Holm's ''Ratatat,'' another jocose work.

title: Australia
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
WHEN THE ARTIST USES TECHNOLOGY AS A TOOL
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE technological boom of recent years has put many new tools at the artist's disposal. It has also led to much debate over the creative application of electrostatic copiers, computers and video equipment. The real question, of course, is not whether machines can make art, but whether artists can make art through the creative use of innovative mechanisms. Not surprisingly, it is in printmaking, a field in which mechanical techniques play an essential role, that we find some of the most imaginative applications of the new technology.

title: AUSTRALIA
description: To the Editor:

title: PHOTO EXHIBIT IN BROOKFIELD DEPICTS ICELAND'S PAST
description: BROOKFIELD THE Brookfield Craft Center has opened its 1982 gallery season in an unorthodox way - with a show of color photographs taken in Iceland by the center's director, John I. Russell. The photographs in the show, which runs through Feb. 28, are not exactly travel pictures, for the geysers and the active volcanoes, such as the one that gave birth in the 60's to the offshore island of Surtsey, are nowhere to be seen. And, though some prints are of art and needlework, esthetic revelation isn't the show's main purpose, either.

title: Topics; PASSING RITES; Rank Inaccuracy
description: Bruce Caputo has come up with an interesting way of ending the Vietnam vet's sense of estrangement from other Americans: let nearly everyone qualify as a veteran. A former Congressman and present aspirant for New York's Senate seat, Mr. Caputo considers himself a veteran because for 2 1/2 years he held a civilian job in the Pentagon.

title: PATCHING A HOLE IN THE WALL OR CEILING: ONE EFFECTIVE METHOD
description: WHEN it beomes necessary to patch or fill in a hole in a ceiling or wall that is made of gypsum board (more commonly referred to as drywall), the do-it-yourselfer is often confused about how to make the necessary repair because the hole has no backing against which patching material can be applied.

title: EDWARD D. JONES, COUNTRY BROKER
description: MARYLAND HEIGHTS Mo. A ROUND Wall Street, you don't hear much about a brokerage firm called Edward D. Jones & Company. And why should you? With $11 million in capital, it is a mere one-hundredth the size of Merrill Lynch. Its name rarely shows up in the ''tombstone'' ads that list firms selling new issues of securities or on the ground-floor retail outlets of big-city office buildings.

title: Hockey Teams Eye Tourney
description: The college hockey playoffs begin March 19, and the talk about selections and seedings for the national collegiate tournament is heating up. The ice hockey committee, headed by Charlie Holt, the New Hampshire coach, is bound to displease more than a few people when it picks and ranks the eight teams that will participate in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's first round.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Prosecutor's Vow
description: When Eugene Gold stepped down last December after 13 years as District Attorney of Brooklyn - the nation's third largest prosecutor's office - he said he wanted to devote his future to helping the Jewish people.

title: SEX EDUCATION DEBATED ANEW
description: LINDENHURST TEN years ago, the controversy surrounding the teaching of sex education in public schools played to packed houses at school board meetings all over the Island. That controversy is being revived in Lindenhurst.

title: VIETNAM AND SALVADOR-A BATTLE FOR HEARTS AND MINDS
description: WASHINGTON THE words from the scene are chillingly familiar. The President said, ''We are losing the fight with the guerrillas in the countryside.'' The visiting American general said the United States would have to rethink its policy of not allowing American advisers to accompany local troops on combat missions. The Defense Minister told visiting Congressmen that a government victory was not possible without more United States military aid. A non-American diplomat said the government ''cannot win without troops from the United States, or someone.''

title: BASEBALL BURSTS INTO FULL BLOOM
description: There is not a negotiating session in sight. On the horizon, instead of a strike, is the prospect of the first complete baseball year - start of spring training to end of World Series - since 1979.

title: POVERTY AND INFANT MORTALITY
description: Poverty may be the reason why women in minority groups are more likely than whites to bear small babies with a high risk of death, a new study says.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: POP MUSIC Lush Life, the new Greenwich Village jazz club at the corner of Bleecker and Thompson Streets, has instituted a decidedly contemporary big band policy on Sunday nights. Tonight and next Sunday night, the drummer, Beaver Harris, and the pianist, Don Pullen, are leading a 12-piece band that ranges through jazz history, ''from ragtime to no time'' as Mr. Harris once put it.

title: SURE SIGN OF SPRING
description: There's a break ahead in the search for spring, and it's being provided by the 16th annual New Jersey Flower and Garden Show in Morristown.

title: NEW CURBS ON ENTRY INTO U.S. ANGER FILIPINOS
description: The screening, put into practice because illegal immigration has become a serious problem, is aimed at determing whether the applicant is a geniune tourist who will return home. Despite the screening, hundreds of Filipinos on temporary visas disappear upon reaching the United States.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE busy conference room next to County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's office has echoed to the angry shouts of political leaders, to the numbing drone of a fiscal expert and to many sounds in between. Last week, for a few moments, the echoes were musical, compliments of Pete Seeger.

title: CONTRACTORS TELL HOW CLIENTS GO AWRY
description: Harry Prince was all but finished building a $250,000 house in eastern Long Island two years ago when the owners changed their minds.

title: The World in Summary; No Clear Winner In Ireland
description: Jim Kemmy, a Socialist independent who brought down the last Irish Government, could wield that power again. In elections last week, neither major party won a majority of seats in the 166-member Parliament and both had to scramble for the support of Mr. Kemmy and other independents.

title: Kathleen Wick To Be May Bride Of F. L. Galacar
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Arms Wick of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Wick, to Frederic Lang Galacar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Galacar of Ipswich, Mass.

title: Ruth Sprachner Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Julius B. Sprachner of Lakewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ruth Ellen Sprachner, to Howard Gerald Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gordon of Morganville, N.J. Oceanside, L.I. An August wedding is planned. Miss Schramm is a

title: The Region in Summary; In Jersey, PCB Spells Trouble
description: The past may have caught up with the future in Elizabeth, N.J. The city, famous for its chemical storehouses, learned last week that construction of a major industrial park that would shore up its sagging economy was endangered by chemical pollution.

title: Canadiens 2, Sabres 2
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Bob Gainey scored his second goal of the game in the third period, giving Montreal the tie and extending the Canadiens' unbeaten streak to 15 games.

title: A GIFT CAN TURN INTO A HIGH-YIELD INVESTMENT
description: One of the basic rules-of-thumb that most of us learned at our grandmother's knee is: Never give a ruff and sluff if you can avoid it. There are numerous exceptions to this, on an expert level, but rather fewer to the corollary: If the opponent gives you a ruff and sluff, accept the gift gracefully.

title: TRENTON TIMES JOURNALISTS QUIT OVER NEW POLICIES
description: A quarter of the news staff at The Trenton Times has left in recent weeks as the paper's owners have moved to increase the business office's control over what had been a money-losing operation.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Back in the Sun Mobil Oil wants a neglected segment of American athletics restored to its proper place in popularity, and on television. The corporation is sponsoring the USA/Mobil Track & Field Championships at Madison Square Garden on Friday and also underwriting a live telecast of the meet from 9 to around 11 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: 2 JUSTICES' FRIENDS BACK SECRET ROLE
description: Friends and associates of Louis D. Brandeis and Felix Frankfurter have greeted a new history detailing the extensive extrajudicial activity of the two Supreme Court Justices with a mixture of surprise, disappointment and defensiveness. But the disclosures, they seem to agree, will do little to diminish the historic stature enjoyed by two of the nation's most prominent jurists.

title:
LETTERS;
Metaphorical Duality
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ENDOWMENT HEAD EXPLAINS GRANT REDUCTIONS
description: To some, it might seem a career step sideways - from an important post in the White House to the chairmanship of a small Federal agency facing deep budget cuts. But Frank Hodsoll, formerly Deputy Assistant to the President, campaigned vigorously for his new job as Chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. ''Nobody came along and offered it to me,'' says the 44-year-old lawyer and career government official. ''I asked for it, and I really had to sell myself.''

title: CRACKDOWN ON LAWS ON CHILDREN
description: IT has been against state law for 60 years to refuse to rent apartments in the state's cities to families with children, and illegal for 18 months - after extension of the state law - to do so in towns and villages. The State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, has decided to crack down on landlords who turn away families with children, but some landlords in the county claim that they have never heard of the law.

title: Souk strategies Varied Prices
description: Be aware that there are different quotes for different folks, with local Arabs enjoying the best prices and American tourists perhaps the worst. Purchases made during the week, rather than on Saturday, are likely to be cheaper.

title: NETS WIN AS GMINSKI EXCELS
description: As the halftime guest tonight on the New Jersey Nets' cable television broadcast, Stacy Gminski was recounting the medical problems that had befallen her husband, Mike, in his two seasons in the National Basketball Association.

title: GROUPS STRUGGLE TO PROTECT PARKS IN BUDGET CRISIS
description: ''Political boss William Ward, who seems to have run Westchester on lines drawn up by the Pharaohs, was sitting on a park bench in Cleveland. He spied a 'Keep Off the Grass' sign. This annoyed him. He began to ponder how little grass there would be for Westchester County people to enjoy if a lot of land wasn't bought up quickly. On his return he set up the Westchester Park Commission and instructed it to buy up waste land. As to how it would be used, he said, they could worry about that later.''

title: NICHOLSON'S CONTRIBUTION TO ABSTRACTIONISM
description: For much of his very long life Ben Nicholson, who died in London on Feb. 6 in his 88th year, was regarded by many good judges as the most distinguished living English painter. This opinion was not unanimous. Other painters had their champions, and there were people who found Nicholson's work both juiceless and repetitive. But in the United States, in Switzerland, in Germany and in his native England he had a solid constituency.

title: 'IF YOU TREAT THE EARTH WELL...'
description: IT was alway easy to recognize old John from a distance - the small, thin silhouette, the stooped, shuffling gait, the baggy trousers, the fedora hat that went out of style in the 1940's. At 87, he was probably the most recognizable person in the neighborhood.

title: SALVAGING THE UNEMPLOYED
description: HIGH unemployment and displaced workers are the negative symptoms as New Jersey moves, at an increasing rate, from a strong manufacturing base to a service-oriented economy. Although the shift is national in scope, the impact is greater in New Jersey because of the state's deep manufacturing roots.

title: CABARET: MCGOVERN
description: Maureen McGovern, doubling from ''The Pirates of Penzance'' to a post-theater performance at Les Mouches, 11th Avenue at 26th Street, brings a strong bravura flair to her cabaret program.

title: N.F.L. AND PLAYERS' UNION FORESEE PROBLEMS IN LABOR TALKS
description: Both sides in pro football had anticipated so keenly an explosive meeting between players and management to discuss a new contract that their opening talks last week fulfilled their own prophecy.

title: MARY C. THOMAS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Barrington Thomas of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Caroline Thomas, to John Edward Fraser, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Fraser of Clinton, N.Y. A June wedding is planned. Miss Thomas is a physical education teacher in Salem, N.H. Her financee is head football and track coach at Phillips Exeter Academy.

title: Richard Moye Fiance of Lauren Geiger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Geiger of Millington, N.J., and Harpsville, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Anne Geiger, to Richard Hamilton Moye, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Harold Moye of Chatham, Mass. The wedding is planned for August.

title: STATE TAXES MOVE UP
description: After a brief decline in 1979, state and local property taxes grew by $3.6 billion in the 1980 fiscal year, to $68.5 billion, according to a survey by the Tax Foundation, a Washington-based nonprofit organization that monitors developments in tax and fiscal matters across the country.

title: Boston Benefit Concert
description: A group of Boston musicians against nuclear arms will give a benefit concert in Boston's Symphony Hall tonight at 7:30. Proceeds will be shared by the Council for a Nuclear Weapons Freeze and the American Friends Service Committee.

title:
Economic Affairs;
THE BUDGET: LET THEM EAT JELLY BEANS
description: A Presidential budget deserves the closest scrutiny. Budgets are the central tool by which Presidents can translate their philosophies, their visions for the country, into reality. By examining both the broad sweep and minutiae of budgetary proposals, we can trace Presidential wishes and fantasies.

title: Randy Flaxenburg to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis Flaxenburg of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Randy Maris Flaxenburg, to David Morrill Reed Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Reed of Newtown Square, Pa.

title: A WHITTREDGE CELEBRATION
description: MORRISTOWN IF MONTCLAIR can boast of George Inness as a former resident, Summit can counter with his near-contemporary, Worthington Whittredge (1820-1910), who lived there for the last 30 years of his life.

title:
Investing;
HOW TO PICK A STOCKBROKER
description: M AYBE you've already had one of those late evening phone calls. The fellow says he represents Bache, or Merrill Lynch, or Paine Webber. He says you are probably wondering about getting back in the market and he says he can help. That's one way to get yourself a stockbroker - and it isn't necessarily a bad way. Someone who keeps such late hours might be equally diligent about handling your account.

title:
DINING OUT;
FRESHNESS FROM THE STOVE TOP
description: SPIFFY in blue linen against warm wood tones and touches of Tiffany-style glass, the informal dining rooms of Harry's Sauteuse in Larchmont are popular with neighborhood diners. As suggested by the shallow sauteing pan of the restaurant's name, the kitchen favors the top-of-the-stove cooking that lends itself to fresh, fast preparation of light foods - veal, chicken, fish, vegetables - cooked when ordered.

title: RESUME FOR A GUERILLA
description: To the Editor:

title: Alison Hale To Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Lodge Hale 3d of Portland, Me., and Charleston, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Emery Hale, to Christopher George Chapman, son of Judge Ralph Chapman of Brattleboro, Vt., and the late Hope Severance Chapman.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
WINTER FESTIVAL
description: If art is in the eyes of the beholder, then it's quite fitting for the Long Island State Park and Recreation Commission to end its annual Winter Arts Festival with the ''Great American Cookie Contest.'' And it will be held today at Bethpage State Park in Farmingdale, where from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. amateur bakers will put their reputations - and wares - on the judging line. While only the judges get to taste the entries, spectators who attend this ''Mardi Gras gala'' can take advantage of the music, folk and square dancing, and marionette show that will also spark the day's free festivities at the park's golf clubhouse.HAVE BATONS, WILL WAVE

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A Knight to Remember It will take some doing for the CBS version of Sir Walter Scott's ''Ivanhoe,'' to be broadcast from 8 to 11 P.M. on Tuesday, to surpass or even match the rousing, intelligent spectacle produced by M-G-M in 1952, with a large cast headed by Robert Taylor, Elizabeth Taylor, George Sanders, Joan Fontaine and Felix Aylmer.

title: GIBSON IS FACING A TOUGH CAMPAIGN
description: NEWARK THE announcement by City Council President Earl Harris last week that he will oppose Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson in the May 11 election presents Mr. Gibson with his most formidible opponent since he unseated the late Hugh J. Addonizio in 1970.

title: 'BEING CAREFUL IS NOT IN MY NATURE'
description: Anthony Andrews, hailed for his portrayal of the handsome, effete and alcoholic Sebastian Flyte in ''Brideshead Revisited,'' the dramatization of Evelyn Waugh's book now being shown on public television, will charge in armor on a black stallion Tuesday evening at 8 in a wildly different part. He will play the title role in ''Ivanhoe,'' a three-hour film adaptation of the Sir Walter Scott novel on CBS.

title: TIN CANS WITH A SECRET LIFE
description: A FEW months ago, Philip and Lorna Sarrel cleared a few of the shelves in their Woodbridge home, packed up the contents - some old tin containers -and sent them to Yale University's Center for British Art.

title: THE LURE OF THE DOLLAR
description: Unlike a year ago, when rising American interest rates prompted central banks in other countries to raise interest rates to prop up their own currencies, the latest upward surge in American interest rates has gone unanswered abroad.

title: Thomas Plotz to Wed Catherine Klion
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Klion of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine B. Klion, to Thomas J. Plotz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles M. Plotz of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for May 30.

title: ELECTRONICBULLETIN BOARDS
description: With the proliferation of personal computers has come a new medium of communication -the computer bulletin board. There are 200 to 300 of these electronic clearinghouses around the country.

title: ARTICHOKES: WHERE LESS IS MORE
description: The artichoke is the only vegetable, if it is a vegetable, of which there is more after it has been eaten.... In place of the tightly balled flower head is a large dish filled with bracts, each bearing teeth marks so plainly that a dentist could identify the eater.'' From ''Foodbook'' by James Trager. By MARIAN BURROS

title: The Nation in Summary; Labor's Florida Meeting Creates A Topical Storm
description: Two months ago, after the White House called them in for peace talks, members of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council got a full dose of the old Reagan charm; since then there have been lower-voltage followup applications by Vice President Bush. Last week, as the council held a policy-making meeting at Bal Harbour, Fla., it seemed clear that the treatment hadn't quite taken.

title: Elinor C. Dwyer Is Engaged to John McKenna Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Dwyer Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elinor Chilton Dwyer, to John Arthur McKenna Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McKenna of Fairfield, Conn.

title: UP AT BAT, GEORGE FOSTER
