description: CINCINNATI THE photographer, sitting in the living room of George Foster's home, wondered about settings for shots for the story he was assigned to.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: NATURALLY, the snow was six inches deep and still coming down the night I came home to a silent furnace and a cold house. The doorknobs were icy, the dog hysterical and the houseplants catatonic. Even the indestructible philodendron looked a little blue.

title: THE EXPERIMENT BEGINS
description: THE VINEYARD OF LIBERTY The American Experiment. By James MacGregor Burns. 741 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Airport Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH COULD WIN IN A 3-WAY RACE FOR U.S. SENATE
description: WHO would win a three-way contest for the United States Senate with Prescott Bush Jr. running as a Republican, Representative Toby Moffett running as a Democrat and the incumbent Senator, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., running as an independent?

title: NO WAKE FORESEEN FOR D.O.E.
description: NEWARK THERE is no wrecking ball sitting in a corner of Leonard S. Coleman Jr.'s spacious office at the headquarters of the state's Department of Energy.

title: CURRENT REPORTS ON DURABLE HITS
description: ''The Pirates of Penzance''

title: Foreign Trials Set for Yachts
description: For the first time in the history of the International Catamaran Challenge Trophy, better known as the Little America's Cup, there will be foreign trials this summer. This will be followed by the match race series between the foreign challenger and the American defender starting Sept. 11 on Long Island Sound, according to plans for the 17th challenge.

title: U.S. HEALTH DIRECTOR CHOSEN
description: President Reagan said Friday that he would nominate James B. Wyngaarden of the Duke University School of Medicine to direct the National Institutes of Health. If confirmed, Dr. Wyngaarden, the chairman of the department of medicine at Duke since 1967, would succeed Donald S. Fredrickson.

title: A Warrior for Wildlife Men like Paul Ssali make life more humane for us all (''A Warrior for Wildlife,'' by John Heminway, Jan. 10).  Having traveled the world for years, I have never seen a society that tolerates cruelty to animals that would not also tolerate cruelty to people. It is a good way to judge a society - by the way it treats animals.
description: Thank you for a fine article. HUGO KRUEGER Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: CARNEGIE HALL BEGINS $20 MILLION RENOVATION
description: Construction has begun on the first phase of a $20 million Carnegie Hall renovation that officials hope to complete by the centenary of the hall in 1991.

title: Around the World; Battle Said to Continue In Port North of Beirut
description: Heavy fighting continued in Tripoli, Lebanon's second largest city, for a second day today, and police sources said 8 people had been killed and 17 wounded.

title: SAUDI AWACS DEAL: WORTH A SECOND GUESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvador Policy Protest Is Staged in New York
description: A three-hour protest in New York against United States military aid to El Salvador drew a crowd estimated by the authorities at up to 4,000 people yesterday.

title: NAPLES
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; PASSING RITES; Fatso's Tuesday
description: Every year on the Tuesday before Ash Wednesday, people not ordinarily known for religiosity renounce such sins of the flesh as chocolates, martinis and cheesecake.

title: No Headline
description: No.1 Virginia Tops N.C. State by 45-40

title: LAW GIVING STATE CONTROL OF DISABLED CHILD IS UPSET
description: A Federal judge has struck down a New York State law that required parents of a physically or mentally disabled child to transfer custody to the state before the child could go into a statesubsidized residential treatment center.

title: FOOD
description: ALL PUFFED UP ven after decades of working with virtually all aspects of food preparation, we continue to be awed by the ''windblown'' miracles that occur when various foods are submitted to oven heat. We are thinking of such dishes as souffles that rise high above the rims of their pans, of various breads that inflate on their baking sheets and of puff pastries that in theory flake into a thousand sheets, or a mille-feuille, as they bake.

title: CHURCH'S LIBRARY STORES FAMILY DATA
description: THE time may be close at hand when anyone who wants to trace his family's history will be able to do so because of a project undertaken by the Mormon Church 44 years ago.

title: Cigars
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE
description: WHO'S RULING THE ROOST? legend often repeated in the lush vineyards of Tuscany in northern Italy dates from the 13th century and is said to account for the use of the gallo nero, or black rooster, as the emblem of the region and of the consortium of producers of Chianti Classico, the fine local red wine that now has a worldwide following.

title: THE BUSINESS G.M. AND CHRYSLER REFUSED
description: Henry B. Halicki makes movies, two of them so far, which he writes, produces and stars in. He also promotes them with a zeal P.T. Barnum might envy. In his latest effort, a half-million-dollar-budget film called "Junkman," Mr. Halicki portrays an independent film maker whom the big Hollywood studios try to do in, using airplanes and blimps. They fail.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Pope Concludes African Journey
description: If Pope John Paul II journeyed to West Africa as ''the good shepherd,'' the region's Roman Catholic flock clearly warmed to his ministrations. The Pope ended his eight-day visit last week in Benin and Equitorial Guinea much as he began it in Nigeria and Gabon - to the cheers, chanting and flag waving of tens of thousands of faithful.

title: REP. ROUKEMA HEARTENED BY VISIT TO HER DISTRICT
description: Representative Marge S. Roukema, the first term Republican from New Jersey's mostly affluent Seventh District, came home this week to listen to her Bergen County constituents. What she heard was, all things considered, heartening.

title: Realty News; LEASE NEAR SEAPORT SIGNED
description: The British have landed in full force on the downtown office market in Manhattan. Reflecting the rising prices and continued strong demand for office space downtown, a new lease was recently signed for the entire building at 175 Water Street with an intital gross rent of $38 a square foot. The developer is British, the tenant is British, the broker is British and even the lease was drawn in British fashion.

title: Janet Schramm Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Max Schramm of Boca Raton, Fla., formerly of Teaneck, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Janet Schramm, to Scott Philip Ball, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Ball of Oceanside, L.I. An August wedding is planned. Miss Schramm is a public-relations assistant at the Rowland Company in New York, where Mr. Ball is a marketing representative with Computer Sharing Services. divorce.

title: JOHN GUARE STIRS UP A 'BREEZE'
description: In the service of his own very special brand of lyrical absurdism, John Guare has populated the stage with as zany and variegated a funhouse (some would say madhouse) of characters as can be found in the modern theater. Remember Artie Shaughnessy, the loony zoo-keeper and song-writer (''Where is the devil in/Evelyn?'') in Mr. Guare first big success, the 1971 ''House of Blue Leaves''?

title: THE HIGH ROAD TO SPECIAL INNS IN THE HIGHLANDS
description: CRAIG CLAIBORNE is the food editor of The Times. By CRAIG CLAIBORNE

title: SOME PROSPECTS OF EDINBURGH
description: Sightseeing

title: G. A. Dudley Weds Barbara McNamee
description: Barbara Cooley McNamee, chairman of the First Albany Corporation, a region securities firm in Albany founded by her late husband, Daniel V. McNamee Jr., was married yesterday to George Austin Dudley. Mr. Dudley is an architectural, planning, environmental and urban design consultant in New York.

title: A SELECTION OF SCOTISH COUNTRY INNS
description: Inverlochy Castle Write to: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hobbs, Inverlochy Castle, Fort William PH33 68N, Highland, Scotland. 13 rooms. Opens at Easter.

title: Loan to the Rumanians Is Deferred by the U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration has deferred the granting of a $65 million commodity loan that Rumania had sought in order to buy on credit American corn and soybean meal, an Administration official said today.

title: FROMN HER ORDEAL, HELP FOR SHUT-INS
description: ''IT casts a black cloud over every single thing that we've been fighting,'' Stephanie Joyce Kahn said. ''We're not an idea any more - we're a full-fledged reality. The program stands on its own. The merits have been praised. We're just hoping that we stay alive.''

title: St. Louis Symphony Set For 2 Carnegie Concerts
description: The St. Louis Symphony, conducted by it music director, Leonard Slatkin, will give two concerts in Carnegie Hall on March 19 and 20 at 8 P.M.

title: Brett G. Auletta to Marry Jean M. Trotta in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony R. Trotta of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Marie Trotta, to Brett George Auletta, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Auletta of Greenlawn, L.I.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: ocean dumping protest in Raritan Bay earlier this month, will file a $75,000 cross claim against NL Industries Inc. of Sayreville in Federal District Court.

title: The World in Summary; Salvador Junta Wants Lots of Help, and Soon
description: Administration critics have been quick to warn against repeating the errors of Vietnam in El Salvador, but not everybody agrees on the history that ultimately turned Saigon into Ho Chi Minh City. Last week, President Reagan added to the confusion. He said North Vietnamese Communists had refused to participate in an election to unify the country, when in fact it was the Saigon Government that refused to participate. It is El Salvador where leftists are boycotting March 28 elections, leaving the field to President Jose Napoleon Duarte's Christian Democrats and rightist parties. The Government barred the guerrillas from participating unless they first laid down their arms.

title: BRONX YOUTH, 16, IS CHARGED WITH 9 RAPES AND ROBBERIES
description: A 16-year-old resident of the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx was arrested last night and charged with the rape and robbery of nine women in his neighborhood since Feb. 4, the police said.

title: CURRENT REPORTS ON DURABLE HITS
description: ''Children of a Lesser God''

title:
GARDENING;
INNOVATIONS IN COLD FRAMES
description: A SERIOUS gardener soon learns that there are times when it is desirable to grow one's own plants. New and unusual varieties are often unavailable from usual sources as started plants. If you want to have them, you must start them from seed, cuttings or grafts.

title: THEY WANT TO SELL SOFTWARE LIKE HAMBURGERS
description: ITEM: Sales of all software, for personal computers as well as big business computers, are now running into billions of dollars - in fact nearly $14 billion annually, according to the Data International Corporation of Framingham, Mass. That is half as much as the sales of all types of computer hardware.

title: Katharine Moore Becomes a Bride
description: Katharine Louise Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Moore of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Donald Mark Harring, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Harring of Severna Park, Md. The Rev. Edward A.M. Cobden Jr. performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: The Nation in Summary; Iowa Governor Joins Dropouts
description: As if the uproar over Reaganomics wasn't worry enough for the Grand Old Party, political burnout appears to be epidemic among influential Republican Governors in the Middle West. Robert Ray, Governor of Iowa for 14 years, is the latest apparent victim.

title: Mailbox; Red-Shirting, Alabama Style
description: To the Sports Editor: David Nelson's opinion that red-shirting probably originated at Alabama (Question Box, The New York Times, Feb. 8, 1982) is confirmed by my own experience at that institution. However, it was a practice at Alabama long before Nelson is aware.

title:
GARDENING;
INNOVATIONS IN COLD FRAMES
description: A SERIOUS gardener soon learns that there are times when it is desirable to grow one's own plants. New and unusual varieties are often unavailable from usual sources as started plants. If you want to have them, you must start them from seed, cuttings or grafts.

title: WHAT TO EXPECT FROM AN AGENT
description: O nce upon a time you could walk into most travel agencies, plot a detailed itinerary for an extensive overseas vacation and expect an expert to make all the arrangements for you for the same price you would pay if you did it all yourself. The agent would get commissions on sales, but nothing else. Today, however, you may have to do it yourself because many agents lack the wherewithal to help or are unwilling unless you are a regular customer who provides them with substantial business.

title: CORONA FACING RETRIAL IN FARMWORKER DEATHS
description: A retrial of one of California's most celebrated mass murder cases will begin Monday at the Alameda County Courthouse in Hayward.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH LOCAL TV NEWS?
description: A&L SCHWARTZ FINAL TRIMMED VERSION

title: Major News in Summary; 'Operation Calm' - A Misnomer?
description: One sector of Polish society apparently has no trouble fulfilling its quota. Police and soldiers snared 145,000 violators of martial law, the state press agency said last week, in a two-day sweep that included raids on 51,000 places of business and checks on 60,000 cars. The agency said most of the detainees were let go after hearing lectures and paying fines, but conceded that adherence to martial law was ''not too good.''

title: SALVADORAN REBEL SAYS WAR IS IN 'DEFINITIVE' PHASE
description: A top guerrilla commander interviewed in this hilltop rebel stronghold said today that the insurgents were resolved on making 1982 the ''definitive'' year of their armed struggle against the Government.

title: THERESA MURTAGH AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Murtagh of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Theresa Murtagh, to Michael Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Young of Allendale, N.J.

title: Bravos for Bumbry And Verrett
description: Harold Schonberg's ''A Bravo for Opera's Black Singers'' (Jan. 17) was a vibrant and informative study of opera life. However, this business of black divas versus white divas becomes an aggravating - if not boring - subject.

title: Turf Cup to The Bart In Hialeah Record Time
description: The Bart moved into the lead at the top of the stretch today to win the $175,550 Hialeah Turf Cup in course record time of 1:26.

description: Election leaves next government in Ireland in doubt 3 Work proceeding on Soviet pipe- line 3 West Berlin party group backs Schmidt on missiles 4 Around the World 5 Greenland to hold a referendum on its Common Market status 6 Saudis and the P.L.O. are at odds over cooperation with U.S. 8 Ethiopia said to open big offen- sive against Eritra rebels 10 Lech Walesa is quoted in the Pol- ish press 11 New restrictions on entry into U.S. anger Filipinos 15 Salvadoran rebel says war is in ''definitive'' phase 20 Honduran-Nicaraguan tension fo- cuses on Indian border region 21 Haig urges Reagan to issue a warning on El Salvador 22 Government/Politics F.A.A. defends move to oppose curbs on noise at airports 23 Republicans spent 5 times more than Democrats on '80 race 24 Brandeis and Frankfurter friends chagrined by new findings 27 Democratic tie support for ''new federalism'' to economy 28 I.R.S. employee dismissed in 1944 finally gets a hearing 29 Albany Notes: Carey ''doing his job'' 30 Polls by Regan and Lehrman show different results 31 Agreement reached on cleanup of West Valley nuclear waste site 34 Responsibility for cleaning streets becomes issue 38 Federal judge assails alternative- sentencing programs 38 Rep. title: Foreign Affairs; DISPUTE AND DRIFT
description: The leak of notes from Secretary of State Haig's weekly staff meetings gives off a bad odor. For one thing, it is unpleasant even to an eager reporter like myself to see informal and sensitive Government discussions published for no visibly higher purpose of journalistic service than to display that leaks continue.

title: Dr. Eugene R. Gillman Weds Dr. Ilana Lustig
description: Dr. Ilana Denise Lustig, an obstetrician at the New York University Hospital, and Dr. Eugene Robert Gillman, who practices internal medicine in Bayside, Queens, were married yesterday. Rabbi Mordecai Rubin performed the ceremony at the Barbizon Plaza Hotel.

title: RENE DUBOS, SCIENTIST AND WRITER, DEAD
description: Dr. Rene Dubos, a bacteriologist who brought a profound humanity to the study of man's harm to himself through environmental pollution, died yesterday morning at New York Hospital. It was his 81st birthday.

title: VOUCHERS: WILL THEY HELP POOR?
description: Since the Reagan Administration came into office it has been slowly unfolding a bold new policy for housing the nation's poor: It wants to give them housing vouchers, much like the food stamp program.

title: Crime Update; A RED HERRING IN A MURDER IN QUEENS
description: On Monday, Jan. 11, the body of 36-year-old Isabelle Garcia, a post office supervisor, was found by her brother in the bedroom of her home at 108-12 48th Avenue in Corona, Queens. She had been shot in the head and had been dead for several days.

title: Bomb Kills 3 in Nicaragua
description: A bomb planted inside a piece of luggage exploded tonight at the Managua airport, killing three people and wounding three others, the Government radio station said. It said the luggage had been unloaded from a Salvadoran airliner that arrived from El Salvador.

title: HARVARD TO INCREASE CHARGES FOR TUITION AND BOARD IN '83
description: Harvard College's undergraduate tuition and room and board charges will be increased next year by almost 15 percent, to $12,100, the college has announced.

title: Christine A. Drummey Wed to William Eakins
description: Christine Anne Drummey, daughter of Mrs. M. Duryea Drummey of Port Washington, L.I., and John F. Drummey Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday in Manhattan to William Shannon Eakins, son of Mrs. William S. Eakins of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mr. Eakins. The Rev. Daniel Warren performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: SEVERE WINTER MOVES DONORS TO AID NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: ''I hope this will warm or feed some people in this dreadful winter. I give in gratitude for all the comfort the Lord has given me.''

title: DAYAN'S COLLECTION
description: The controversial antiquities collection of Moshe Dayan, the late Israeli soldier-statesman and archeologist, has been purchased by Laurence and Wilma Tisch and given as a gift to the American Friends of the Israel Museum. The first exhibition at the museum in Jerusalem of some of the more than 800 objects in the collection, which is valued at $2 to $3 million but was purchased from the estate of General Dayan for $1 million, will open on the first anniversary of his death in October.

title: MADISON AVENUE SCANDAL
description: The disclosure shook Madison Avenue. The J. Walter Thompson agency said last week that some $18 million in nonexistent revenues had been fed into a computer at a unit, JWT Syndication, over three years and nine months.

title: ASTRONOMY HOPES FOR REFLECTED GLORY
description: Thirty-four years ago, the telescope atop California's Palomar Mountain inaugurated an astounding era in astronomy. With its mammoth reflector mirror, 200 inches in diameter, Palomar saw farther into space than any existing optical telescope. It was thus able to play a pivotal role in the discovery, mapping and exploration of quasars, pulsars, radio galaxies - almost every new celestial phenomenon of the last three decades.

title: Calvin Rutstrum Dead Wrote Wilderness Lore
description: The death of Calvin Rutstrum, a writer who prepared countless future disciples for canoe travel in ''The Way of the Wilderness,'' was announced Thursday. He was 86 years old.

title: F.A.A. MOVES TO OPPOSE AIRPORT NOISE CURBS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, which is planning a campaign against local restrictions on commercial airport operations to cut noise, was prompted to act because of increasingly crowded conditions on and in the air near the airports, with little prospect for relief.

title: PUBLISHING
description: To the Business Editor: "The Supply Side of PUblishing" (Jan. 7) was most informative. However, the critique on the "deduction-stretching suggestions of some of the how-to books" omitted one final bit of advice. When you're deducting the price of the book from your income tax, don't mention the title. PAUL A. BAUER President, Bauer Industries Inc. Mineola, N.Y., Feb. 10, 1982

title: Terese Bienfait Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles C.A. Bienfait Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Terese Brent Bienfait, to John Poor Townsend Blake, son of Mrs. Reginald T. Townsend of Cross River, N.Y., and the late Forrester Avery Blake.

title: A Lucky Hat Trick About halfway though her colorful article ''Europe's Icemen Cometh'' (Jan. 3) Robin Herman recognizes that the Slovaks are not Czechs, and yet in her introduction she writes, ''... three Czechoslovak brothers ... .'' The Stastnys are Slovak brothers.
description: The term ''Czechoslovak'' was used by the Czech leadership before and after World War I to make the Western world believe that the Slovaks were Czechs, and therefore part of one nation, an assimilation process.

title: A 'COACH' FILLED WITH DANCE-DRAMA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- David Sears writes frequently about the performing arts. By DAVID SEARS

title:
PERSONALLY SPEAKING;
RECALLING THE DAYS AT HOME
description: IWENT to see my house last summer. Not the one I live in now in White Plains. I mean the one that when I say ''my house,'' the words get stuck in my throat, because there is something of that house that is me and always will be. If I say that it is the house I grew up in, you'll understand. It's the house my father built in northern Westchester, and we helped him because he made us help.

title: AMERICA'S OTHER BUDGET
description: William Barry Furlong is a management consultant in Washington who writes on economic subjects. By William Barry Furlong

title: CITY STREET-CLEANING DEBATED IN ALBANY
description: The Assembly is considering a bill that has raised a lively debate over who is primarily responsible for keeping New York City's streets clean - the city's residents or their government.

title: SIR WINSTON CHURCHILL'S QUARRELS WITH LATIN
description: To the Editor:

title: SARA PARTON ENGAGED TO JAMES PELGRIFT
description: James Parton of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Sara Lawson Parton, to James DeLancey Pelgrift, son of Robert Youngs Pelgrift of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Elizabeth Schroeder Pelgrift.

title: CHAMPIONING JAPANESE MUSIC
description: Japanese composers? Probably the only one whose name springs to mind is Toru Takemitsu. He was championed by Seiji Ozawa, and there was considerable interest in him about 15 years ago. His music did appear on some of the avant-garde programs around New York and elsewhere in the country. But in recent years he does not seem to have been played much. Aside from Mr. Takemitsu, how many Japanese composers does one encounter?

title: Patsy L. Gassel Bride of Lawyer
description: Patsy Louise Gassel, a senior program specialist in the division of income maintenance of the New York State Department of Social Services in New York City, and Edward Ira Handelman, an associate with the New York law firm of Corbin, Silverman, Sanseverino & Taylor, were married yesterday. Cantor Ellen Stettner Math performed the ceremony at the Tower Suite.

title: JAPANESE NUCLEAR EXPERTS ROBBED ON SOVIET TRAIN
description: Four Japanese nuclear experts traveling from Moscow to Leningrad aboard the overnight express last month were knocked out by gas sprayed under their compartment door and robbed. Some diplomats say the bizarre incident may have overtones of industrial espionage.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IRVINGTON THE small silhouette of a headless, cloaked rider astride a muscled horse gallops across the screen. Next comes a 10-inch figure of a man, gaunt and gangling, clad in 19th-century coat and breeches. Following that, there is a woman, with full skirts, pinched waist and sleeves edged in lace that appears as a dark, spidery filigree against the white background.

title: The Nation in Summary; Not So Easily Gotten Rid Of
description: Some campaign promises are harder to keep than others, and one of the hardest for President Reagan may be his is his pledge to do away with a Jimmy Carter creation, the Department of Energy. Some Capitol Hill heavyweights, including the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, have already declared their opposition.

title: EDWARD M. COHEN TO WED DORI LYNN KAM IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Max Kam of Bayside, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dori Lynn Kam, to Edward Michael Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Cohen of Roslyn, L.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: MILITARY MEN SAY CONGRESS CUTS TOO CLOSE TO BONE
description: For years, Congress has attacked military spending plans with vigor and, to the Pentagon's way of thinking, has succeeded far too often. Military and budget experts say that Congress always manages to cut the military budget in a way that does the most damage, sacrificing operations and maintenance spending while protecting spending for expensive weapons systems.

title: CHARLES SHAW-IN THE MINIMAL TRADITION
description: The name of Charles G. Shaw (1892-1974) is not one that is very well known to students of American painting. In the standard books on the subject it tends to turn up, when it turns up at all, on the list of painters who were involved in launching the American Abstract Artists group in the 1930's, but Shaw's own work is rarely, if ever, discussed in this or any other context. Yet he was never exactly a neglected or obscure figure. He exhibited frequently, he had important friends in the art world, and he remained very alert to what was going on until the end of his very long and happy life. He also enjoyed the esteem of certain contemporaries -among them, the late Ad Reinhardt - who were never famous for overpraising the work of their fellow artists. Yet Shaw remains an almost unknown painter, and the two exhibitions that the Washburn Gallery is currently devoting to his work - paintings of the 1930's and 40's at 42 East 57th Street, and paintings of the 60's at 113 Greene Street in SoHo (both through March 13) - are likely to give many people their first glimpse of it.

title: TALES OF A FLYING PAPER TIGER
description: R.V. DENENBERG is a writer who lives in the Hudson Valley. By R.V.DENENBERG

title: WORK PROCEEDING ON SOVIET PIPELINE
description: As United States policy makers continue to voice concern over plans to build a new natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe, work has quietly begun on the 2,800-mile project through the Soviet Union, using pipe arriving from West Germany.

title: WEST BERLIN PARTY BACKS SCHMIDT ON MISSILES
description: The Social Democratic regional party organization in West Berlin gave clear backing today to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's policy on the possible deployment of new American nuclear missiles in West Germany.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; John Murphy, Pianist, Offers Rachmaninoff
description: At his debut Tuesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, the pianist John Murphy gave Rachmaninoff's Opus 32 Preludes a finely detailed coloration. It almost seemed as if the works were by Debussy, more French than Russian.

title: WILLIAMS'S DEFENDER IN ROLE RELUCTANTLY
description: WHEN the Senate begins debate Tuesday on whether Harrison A. Williams Jr. is fit to continue to serve, the man in the limelight will be one who has avoided it - Senator Daniel K. Inouye.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A SHOP THAT PULLS NO PUNCH
description: BERGENFIELD AL BRAVERMAN wears two caps. He is a fight manager who has managed, among others, Chuck Wepner of Bayonne, who in 1975 almost went the distance (15 rounds) with Muhammad Ali. And he is in partnership with his wife, Renee, and son, Gary, in a newly opened antiques store at 66 West Main Street in this Bergen County community.

title: SPOTLIGHT IS ON THE COUNTY'S CULTURAL GROUPS
description: WHITE PLAINS IN preparation for next year's County Tricentennial celebration, the White Plains Library and the Westchester County Historical Society have joined in a series of programs at the library entitled ''We the People.'' The free monthly spotlights will give various county multicultural groups an opportunity to share their unique history and culture with other Westchester residents. In addition, people who wish to learn how to record their personal and family history can participate in the program ''Climbing Your Family Tree'' given Feb. 27 by Marilyn Greenspan, a historian.

title: BUSINESS A RENTS LAB COAT AND ACADEMIA HOPES FOR THE BEST
description: A year and a half ago Harvard University aborted plans for its own bioengineering company, deciding at the last that a profit-making business, backed and staffed by the university, could undermine academic integrity. But Harvard's unwillingness to go into business did not dampen its interest, and that of other universities, in joining with business for research and profit. With Federal cuts threatening university budgets, interest has led to romance on many campuses; last week, Yale University and Celanese Corporation, a chemical and fabric manufacturer, tied the knot.

title: A Saturday Matinee Hero I was rather surprised by Russell Baker's column ''Taking Heroes Seriously'' (Sunday Observer, Dec. 20). I have talked with a number of friends and students about ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' and I have not encountered one who expressed the opinion that it is a burlesque which debunks the kind of baloney dad and mom really took seriously.
description: Instead, the mood of ''Raiders'' is created by the careering optimism and ferocious energy of Indiana Jones, as played by Harrison Ford. Mr. Ford somehow gets the audience to want to believe not only that Jones can survive everything that happens in the film, but, furthermore, that it is all real. If ''Raiders'' is billed as the ultimate Saturday matinee, it is because Indiana Jones is an American type of hero in the grand old style.

title: FACING THE WEEKEND SQUARELY
description: Rising from an existing foundation, a new weekend house in the Catskills by the architect Peter Marino uses the square as a theme: Each successive level and nearly all the windows reiterate that basic shape. In an ironic twist, however, the formal ''front'' of the house is its northwest corner (far left), which seems to be leaning a metaphorical shoulder into the winter winds. Accentuating this corner is a contrasting brow that also calls attention to the portal (left), which leads to the front door. The scantily glazed north and west walls act as windshields to those on the south and east by extending above and beyond the adjacent roofs (above).

title: Miss Minor Wed To Thyn S. Smith
description: Emily Joan Minor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Minor of Columbus, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Thyn Stephen Smith, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Warren G. Smith of Piqua, Ohio. The bridegroom's father, pastor of the Congregational Christian United Church of Christ in Piqua, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am planning a vacation in Mexico for the months of January, February and March of next year, and I want to stay in Guadalajara. I will be traveling by car and would like to stay with a family or in some small apartment with maid service. Where can I get reservations and price information on such accommodations? - J.A.L., Plainview, N.Y. Answer:A spokesman for the Mexican National Tourist Council says that one organization that might provide you with suitable housing is an educational group that will arrange lodgings without obligating you to the Spanish-language classes it offers. The group is Cemanahuac Educational Services (Apartado 21-C, Cuernavaca, Morelos, Mexico) and they have listings of host families who provide travelers with single or double rooms and a full breakfast for as little as $14 a person in double occupancy; extra meals are $3 to $6 each.

title: Over the Rainbow
description: ''I'm clearer now about the struggle against patriarchy and its many manifestations,'' said Ntozake Shange, whose theater piece, ''For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/ When the Rainbow is Enuf,'' will finally reach television in the American Playhouse series on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. on Tuesday.

title: TO BE BECALMED BY COLLIOURE
description: TERRI SCHULTZ is a journalism teacher at New York University. By TERRI SCHULTZ

title: Helen Potter To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Potter of Chicago have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Barton Potter, to Henry Whitney Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley A. Wagner of Ipswich, Mass.

title: Margaret Mary McDonnell Married To William D. Genge, Ad Executive
description: Margaret Mary McDonnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward McDonnell of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Dean Genge, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Harrison Genge of Pittsburgh. The Very Rev. Paul J. Walsh performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

title: 'MARAT SADE'GIVEN EXCITING REVIVAL
description: MONTCLAIR AS AN actress of demonstrated ability, Olympia Dukakis, artistic director of the Whole Theater Company, meticulously selects her plays and ensembles, and she has got down to business once again with Peter Weiss's ''Marat/Sade.''

title:
LETTERS;
CULTURE BOUND
description: To the Editor:

title: SAUDI ARABIA'S NEW CAPITALISM
description: KARL MARX theorized that the economic life of a society passes through four distinct stages slavery, feudalism, capitalism and socialism - over a period of hundreds, if not thousands, of years.

title: COLLEGE FOR THE LEARNING DISABLED
description: Ron Winslow, who teaches journalism at the University of New Hampshire at Durham, writes frequently about education and science. He is also the co-author of ''Open and Shut,'' a nonfiction book. By Ron Winslow

title: FOR RESCH MIXED EMOTIONS
description: On a Nassau Coliseum facade tonight, a bedsheet banner greeted Glenn (Chico) Resch, the former Islander goaltender who was returning for the first time since his trade to the Colorado Rockies a year ago.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY OPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: THE RECESSION DOESN'T LIVE HERE ANYMORE
description: While much of the country wrestles with high unemployment and declining productivity, Long Island stands out in happy contrast. The national unemployment rate is 8.5 percent, but Long Islanders are watching theirs sink toward 5 percent. And, when the Federal Reserve Board marked the recession's progress last week with a report that industrial production fell 3 percent in January, it was clear that Long Island's economy did not contribute to the decline.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHYIt is easy to get tired of photographs of details of pizza parlors, clothing stores and barber shops, even when they are in color. From Atget right down to the present day, people have made this type of photograph, and after a while, they all tend to run together in the mind.

title: THE BILDUNGSROMAN THAT DIDN'T BUILD
description: BONE OF MY BONES By Sylvia Wilkinson. 272 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $13.95. By DAVID QUAMMEN

title: NOVELS BY THREE EMERGING WRITERS
description: A BIGAMIST'S DAUGHTER By Alice McDermott. 282 pp. New York: Random House. $13.50.

title: PATCHING A HOLE IN THE WALL OR CEILING: ONE EFFECTIVE METHOD
description: When it becomes necessary to patch of fill in a hole in a ceiling or wall that is made of gypsum board (more commonly referred to as drywall), the do-it-yourselfer is often confused about how to make the necessary repair because the hole has no backing against which patching material can be applied.

title: NOVELS BY THREE EMERGING WRITERS
description: IMAGINARY CRIMES By Sheila Ballantyne. 265 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'Jane Doe'
description: She was about 30 years old and near death when found naked in a state park near Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in September 1980. After she had recovered physically, she was plagued by a memory lapse so total that she could not recall the taste of such things as mustard.

title: SAUDIS AND THE P.L.O. ARE AT ODDS OVER U.S.
description: A dispute has broken out between Saudi Arabia and the Palestine Liberation Organization over Riyadh's military cooperation with Washington.

title: ISLANDERS BEAT ROCKIES, 3-2, FOR RECORD 15TH STRAIGHT (pg.1)
description: The Islanders broke a 52-year-old National Hockey League record in dramatic fashion tonight when they won their 15th consecutive game by defeating the Colorado Rockies, 3-2, at Nassau Coliseum. John Tonelli scored the winning goal with 47 seconds to play.

title: The Region in Summary; Carey Would Plug School-Aid Gaps With Sales Tax
description: The courts have found New York's system of financing public education unfair. Last week, the Legislature seemed to find Governor Carey's plan to reform it impolitic and therefore unattractive.

title: ITALIAN SKILL AND CARE IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD IF one had to summarize with a single word Carbone's - an oldtimer on the Hartford restaurant scene - it could well be ''professionalism.'' From the friendly efficiency of the front-room staff to the careful, knowledgeable kitchen preparation, a meal at Carbone's is an example of a restaurant that knows what it is doing. Considering that the 43-year-old establishment is in its fourth generation of family ownership, perhaps this should not be surprising.

title: THE NEW CONVERTIBLES
description: Fashionby Andre Leon Talley handbag has more than one life to live. Women just don't have the time, or the inclination, to switch bags as they switch roles in their daily routines.

title: Major News in Summary; Mugabe's Grip Gets Tighter
description: Having Joshua Nkomo in the Zimbabwe Cabinet was like having ''a cobra in the house,'' Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said. Last week, he accused his Minister Without Portfolio (and onetime ally) of plotting subversion. He dismissed Mr. Nkomo and three other Cabinet members in what many observers saw as a step toward eventual oneparty rule.

title: OPERA: JULLIARD GIVES SESSIONS 'MONTEZUMA'
description: Like other major works of Roger Sessions, ''Montezuma'' has been a long time coming home. Eighteen years after its premiere in Berlin, the beloved composition teacher's three-act opera received its first New York performance Friday night at the Juilliard Theater in a handsomely designed and effectively staged production by the Juilliard American Opera Center. Mr. Sessions, who celebrates his 85th birthday this year, has been on the Juilliard faculty since 1965, so this mounting of his most ambitious stage work was something of a gesture of homage.

title: By William Safire
description: High Diver

title: Topics; PASSING RITES; More Than Mayhem
description: Fans of detective fiction are as wedded to certain writers as beer drinkers to their favorite label. They'll accept substitutes, but nothing delights them like a new book from a skilled old hand.

title:
LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR;
Solution Is Offered To Smoking Problem
description: I refer this letter to Melvin L. Gold, smoker, whose letter appeared Jan. 31.

title: TANGLE ON REDISTRICTING STALLS PHILADELPHIA RACE
description: Anna Peti, a waitress at Emil's on South Broad Street, touched a finger to her lips, then reached across the lunch counter to pinch her Congressman's cheek.

title: Headliners; An Heir's Error
description: Although he is better known as the manager of the fighter Muhammad Ali, Herbert Muhammad until recently was the administrator of his father's estate, his father being the late Elijah Muhammad, founder and spiritual leader of the Black Muslims. Mr. Muhammad was ordered replaced last week as administrator of the estate by a judge who also ruled that $46 million had incorrectly been transferred to the Muslim community, now called the World Community of Islam in the West. The ruling, which came in response to a petition for recovery filed on behalf of Mr. Muhammad's 21 legitimate and illegitimate children, said that the money should be paid back into his personal estate.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE DEEPER IMPLICATINS OF DEVOTION TO SKIING
description: YOU can always tell when you see one. Like astronomers without scopes, they chart the skies, gazing heavenward for the first glimpse of that microcosm of perfection - the snowflake.

title: Oregon State 40 Washington State 36
description: Rob Holbrook and A.C. Green combined for Oregon State's final 11 points in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

title: THE GROSS NATIONAL ILLUSION
description: C ONSUMER spending is two-thirds of G.N.P., of the total production of goods and services. Right? Wrong. Consuming is no part of the gross national product. While G.N.P. is the sum of its parts, its parts are no part of G.N.P. But, you exclaim, everyone knows that if consumer spending rises, G.N.P. rises. Right? Wrong.

title: SAUDIS CUT OIL OUTPUT; GASOLINE PRICES FALLING
description: SAUDI ARABIA CUT oil output to its lowest level in more than four years. The country now will pump 7 million to 7.5 million barrels a day, trimming 500,000 barrels from production. Gasoline prices have fallen at least 2 cents to 3 cents a gallon in less than a month because of the worldwide surplus of crude oil.

title: Catherine Meyer Bride Of Steven L. Seligman
description: Catherine Canfield Meyer and Steven Lyle Seligman were married yesterday in the Faculty Club of Trinity College in Hartford. Associate Justice Anthony Armentano of the Connecticut Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: FEE INCREASES APPROVED ON HUNTING AND FISHING
description: New York State residents will pay more for hunting, fishing and trapping licenses under legislation signed by Governor Carey this week. The fee increases were among several proposed by Mr. Carey in his 1982-83 budget to raise revenues for a variety of programs and services.

title: COLLEGE BEGINS SUDDENLY FOR SOME HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS
description: MYSTICA KENNEY is the 17-year-old daughter of a single parent and the mother and chief supporter of her own 19-month-old baby boy. She is also a second-semester senior at Ellington High School, who holds a part-time job and takes part in extracurricular activities at the school. And now, in a sudden move and change in her life, she is also a newly enrolled college freshman.

title: by Marilyn Kaye
description: LOU IN THE LIMELIGHT By Kristin Hunter. 296 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $12.95. (Ages 12 to 15) By MARILYN KAYE

title: LATIN BORDER AREA BECOMES VOLATILE
description: The marshy, undeveloped Miskito Indian region on the Caribbean coast has become the focus of Nicaraguan fears of an exile invasion and Honduran alarm at a Nicaraguan military buildup.

title: Lodging and dining out
description: A good place to stay for visitors to the Mercer Mile is the Warrington Motor Lodge (215-343-0373) on State Route 611 at Warrington, about five miles from the Pennsylvania Turnpike and about the same distance from Doylestown. Its 75 rooms are priced at $35 single, $40 double, and they are set back from highway noise, with a pool in a wooded setting.

title: The Nation in Summary; Stone Walls, Marble Halls
description: An appeals court may one day rule that, as Harrison A. Williams Jr. asserts, he was railroaded by malicious prosecutors. But last week, in a Federal courtroom in Uniondale, L.I., Mr. Williams, the only senator caught in the Government's Abscam net, was sentenced to three years in prison and fined $50,000.

title: POLLS TAKEN BY REGAN AND LEHRMAN AT ODDS
description: Pollsters for State Comptroller Edward V. Regan and Lewis E. Lehrman, a rival for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York, have come up with widely varying results in surveys that occurred at the same time and queried a similar number of Republicans.

title: Ann G. Roberts Bride of Clarke Donovan, Lawyer
description: Ann Grace Roberts, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Nelson Roberts of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Clarke Steven Donovan, son of Patricia Donovan of Hillsdale, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: 3 Queried by Bankers Trust On Apparent Embezzlement
description: Two employees and a former official of the Bankers Trust Company have been questioned in the apparent embezzlement of $1.2 million in bank funds in the last year, a company spokesman said yesterday. He said a ''substantial amount'' of the missing money has been recovered,

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Jean-Yves Thibaudet, Pianistic Tradition
description: Young Concert Artists has a fine record in the discovery of important young musicians, but its presentation Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y of a 20-year-old French pianist named Jean-Yves Thibaudet may have been special. Mr. Thibaudet was not entirely successful in combating the dead acoustics of the Kaufmann Concert Hall. But he gave evidence of a considerable talent, nonetheless.

title: STAGE: 'LYSISTRATA' REVIVED AT EQUITY LIBRARY THEATER
description: ''Lysistrata'' is a satisfying play, not because it is a farce (there are funnier farces), not because it is ribald (ribaldry on the stage has been done to death), and not because it is an early plea for the emancipation of women.

title: THE RETREAT OF THE MASS MERCHANTS
description: Of all the products that the chairman of Woolworth could cite in reflecting on the state of his business, it may be revealing that he picks one that offers protection from belligerent weather. "If there's not much difference in buying galoshes at Woolworth or at Macy's," said the chairman, Edward F. Gibbons, "we don't want to give our customers a reason to go elsewhere, especially in tough period like this one."

title: U.S. CATHOLIC BISHOPS OPPOSING ADMINISTRATION'S SALVADOR POLICY
description: A guerrilla commander says 1982 will be the ''definitive'' year of the war in El Salvador. Page 20. By KENNETH A. BRIGGS

title:
GARDENING;
INNOVATIONS IN COLD FRAMES
description: A SERIOUS gardener soon learns that there are times when it is desirable to grow one's own plants. New and unusual varieties are often unavailable from usual sources as started plants. If you want to have them, you must start them from seed, cuttings or grafts.

title: Albany Notes; CAREY ANNOUNCES HE'S DOING HIS JOB
description: Politicians generally issue press releases to announce the new, the far-reaching or at least something they hope will make news.

title: CROWDED CALENDAR OF DATES CROPS UP
description: AT times, it seems that what is needed is some sort of Lord High Cultural Calendar Keeper, whose primary function would be to apportion concert dates in such a way as to minimize the familiar feast-or-famine situation we often face. What a pity, for instance, that no fewer than three major orchestral programs, each distinctive and worthy in its own right, have been scheduled for Saturday evening; similarly, four chamber recitals have to battle for attention a week from this afternoon. That is how things stand, however, so here are some of the choices.

title: CITY OPERA SEARCHES FOR STABILITY
description: When the New York City Opera opens its spring season Wednesday night with the American premiere of Wagner's ''Die Feen,'' the occasion may well be a brilliant one. But behind the scenes, the company seems beset with troubles. The word ''crisis'' is too strong. But both inside and outside the company, people are wondering about the City Opera's artistic purpose and financial stability.

title: ABORTED IDEALS
description: AT THE CENTER By Norma Rosen. 325 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.95. By ROBERT MINER

title: SENATOR PRYOR IN ERROR ON DEFENSE CONTRACTS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE AIDES SAYING THEY LACK VOTES FOR BUDGET
description: Administration officials are conceding that President Reagan currently lacks the votes in Congress to pass his 1983 budget. As a result, the White House has decided to try to prolong the budget debate into the fall, if necessary, to reduce the pressure on Mr. Reagan to alter his economic proposals.

title: LEONARD C. CARTWRIGHT
description: Leonard Carl Cartwright, a retired chemical engineer, died Friday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 70 years old. Mr. Cartwright taught chemistry at Harvard University and spent most of his career working for Foster D. Snell Inc., consulting chemists and engineers.

title: Mailbox; Scholatic Sports Need a Boost
description: To the Sports Editor: I applaud your showcasing the plight of our public school athletic programs (The New York Times, Feb. 15-17, 1982). New York City can proudly boast an enrollment of 1,000,000 students within its school system. The thousands of youngsters eager for athletic paricipation are among the very finest anywhere in the world. And yet, no one outside of the immediate coaching community is in anyway aware of the programs, much less the caliber of our city youth.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Windfall in Texas
description: F. O. Masten, a western Texan who liked to call himself a ''dirt farmer,'' began his career by picking cotton as a stoop laborer. When he died in January 1980, his property around the city of Sudan was reported worth $50 million.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Southampton Wins, 2-1, And Increases Its Lead
description: Mike Channon scored on a header as Southampton beat West Ham United, 2-1, today. The victory boosted Southampton's lead in the English League First Division soccer standings to 4points.

title: Katherine Koch, Painter, Fiancee
description: Kenneth Koch of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Katherine Loth Koch, to Mark Lloyd Statman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Statman of Smithtown, L.I. The wedding is planned for August in Southampton, L.I.

title: Miss Nugent, Producer, Engaged to J.F. Stern
description: Nelle Nugent, the Broadway producer, will be married on April 7 to Jolyon Fox Stern, president of DeWitt Stern, Gutmann & Company, a New York insurance-brokerage concern.

title: Susan Williams Spencer Married to Eric T. Miller
description: Susan Williams Spencer and Eric Thomas Miller were married yesterday at the bride's home in Bronxville, N.Y. The Presbyterian ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Easton of the Reformed Church of Bronxville.

title: Deputy Minister Runs Mile in 1:41 at Workout
description: Deputy Minister, last year's 2-year-old champion who bruised or wrenched an ankle Jan. 27, worked out today at Gulfstream Park, completing a mile in 1:41.

title: POLISH PRESS QUOTES WALESA AS DENYING HE SIGNED LEAFLETS
description: The Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, quoted today in the official Polish press for the first time since the union's suspension, denied issuing any signed statements since his arrest after the military takeover on Dec. 13.

title: Madrid Plotter Reports Belief in King's Support
description: Lieut. Col. Antonio Tejero Molina said under oath that he led the coup attempt against the Spanish Government a year ago in the belief that King Juan Carlos supported the attempt, it was disclosed at his trial today.

title: Wendy Abrams Affianced To Lawrence Alan Bassell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Abrams of West Hartford, Conn., and Laguna Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Abrams, to Lawrence Alan Bassell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Bassel of Woodmere, L.I.

title: EVEN THE HIGH COURT DISCOVERS THAT NOT ALL THE FACTS ARE IN THE RECORD
description: What do judges know and how do they know it? The turmoil within the Reagan Administration over what legal positions to take and how to present them to the Supreme Court has cast new, intriguing light on the question, usually an academic inquiry encrusted with rules of evidence and concepts of ''judicial notice.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: A LONGER RECESSION In his press conference last week, President Reagan tried to calm the Financial markets by voicing strong support for the Federal Reserve's tough money policies. While Mr. Reagan's intentions were good, analysts say his perception of the source of Wall Street's skittishness is misplaced.

title: London Visitors to Get New View From Old Bridge; Keystone Press A landmark for 88 years, Tower Bridge spans the Thames near the Tower of London.
description: When London's Tower Bridge was built across the River Thames in 1894, it was equipped with high catwalks to allow pedestrians to cross the river when the main roadway was raised to let tall ships pass through. But after only 16 years, the catwalks were closed.

title: LECTIRES TO EXPLORE FACTS OF SINGLE LIFE
description: ASERIES of lectures designed to dispel society's myths about the nuclear family -''On Your Own: A Provocative Look at Being Single in a Coupled World'' - is to be given each Tuesday in March at Sarah Lawrence College.

title: Major News in Summary; It Looks Like A Long Year On the Budget
description: In politics as in life, anxiety is catching. Last week, even adept clinicians would have been hard put to distinguish who was the more concerned - legislators away testing the sentiments of recessionracked constituents before tackling Administration budget wishes for 1983 or White House tacticians pondering a new ''strategy of patience'' designed to stretch out the debate until the economy - they hope - picks up.

title: The World in Summary; Schmidt's Trouble At the Grassroots
description: Helmut Schmidt rallied his Social Democratic Party and won a vote of confidence for his economic and defense policies in Parliament Feb. 5. Since then, however, four regional party conventions have contradicted or disavowed key elements of the West German Chancellor's program, in particular deployment of new medium-range American nuclear missiles.

title: Pamela Pollak Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Pollak Jr. of Wilton, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Ann Pollak, to Louis Joseph Hepp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Hepp of Athens. Miss Pollak and her fiance are graduates of Franklin and Marshall College. She is a science teacher at the Saddle River (N.J.) Day School and Mr. Hepp is a budget controller with ABC World News Tonight in New York. divorce.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Not the Egg Roll, Sonny
description: ON the theory that Gulf and Western might get away with shipping its teams to the suburbs, it seems like a good idea to visit Madison Square Garden, before it's too late.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT
description: To the Business Editor: There is nothing inherently wrong with economic explanations that are gossipy and anecdotal; however Barbara Bergmann's article "Here is Why You Lost Your Job" (Feb. 7), left me with two disturbing impressions.

title: WITH THE REBELS IN EL SALVADOR
description: Like most of the countries in Central America, El Salvador is small and impoverished, the kind of place the world has tended to ignore. In recent years, however, it has been embroiled in a brutal civil war involving conservative and Marxist ideologies - a conflict that has become the focus of growing concern by Washington.

title: THOUGHTS ON THE PRESIDENCY
description: A President will never hear the truth again. Everybody in high places stands in a room full of mirrors and sees himself multiplied by servile reflection. The Oval Office can easily become such a room.

title: Crete
description: To the Editor:

title: The World in Summary; Wherever Deng Was, He's Back
description: Reports of his eclipse were greatly exaggerated, Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, demonstrated last week. He reappeared on Chinese television after 37 days out of sight and quashed speculation that he had been ill or displaced.

title: CRITICS'CHOICE
description: 20TH-CENTURY MUSIC The Orient has held a great fascination for Western musicians of this century, from the French Impressionists's entrancement with Japanese music and Stravinsky's elegant, sonorous Chinoiserie to the Indian aura surrounding Philip Glass's recent ''Satyagraha.''

title: No Headline
description: A new word has entered Spain's political vocabulary: La Ministra. Last December, in an otherwise unimaginative Cabinet shuffle, Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo startled his countrymen by naming a woman to his Cabinet. After some consulting of dictionaries, it was decided that his choice to head the Ministry of Culture, Soledad Becerril y Bustamante de Atienza, was a ministra, distinct from the 17 male ministros in the Cabinet.

title: Lynn Oshita Wed To Jed Brickner
description: Lynne Michiko Oshita, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Oshita of Aiea, Hawaii, and Jed Walter Brickner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip W. Brickner of Riverdale, the Bronx, were married yesterday. The Rev. Fred Minuth performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Cathedral in Honolulu.

title: STATES WANT A DEAL WITH REAGAN, BUT NOT THIS DEAL
description: The nation's governors, here this weekend for their winter meeting, face the task of finding a way to keep President Reagan's ''new federalism'' alive in the hope it can be transformed into something the states think they can handle.

title: Hamilton Held to 59 In Victory
description: Wingate used a zone defense and forced Alexander Hamilton, the defending champion, to wait for good shots yesterday in the Brooklyn quarterfinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament.

title: Yale to Stage Premiere of Fugard Play
description: The world premiere of a three-character Athol Fugard play, '' 'Master Harold' ... and the Boys,'' will be presented by the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven from March 9 through 27.

title: PATCHING A HOLE IN THE WALL OR CEILING: ONE EFFECTIVE METHOD
description: When it becomes necessary to patch of fill in a hole in a ceiling or wall that is made of gypsum board (more commonly referred to as drywall), the do-it-yourselfer is often confused about how to make the necessary repair because the hole has no backing against which patching material can be applied.

title: Canucks 4, Whalers 2
description: Stan Smyl's shorthanded goal at 8:45 of the second period was the game-winner. Smyl pounced on a loose puck in his end and raced the length of the ice, beating the goalie, Greg Millen, with a bullet drive from 15 feet out.

title: PHOTOGRAPHER FINDS WOOD IS HIS FOCUS
description: THERE are many people who dream about transforming a hobby or special interest into a full-time occupation, but John Bickel has gradually turned fantasy into reality.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Swiss Chamber Group Plays Without Leader
description: The Swiss Chamber Orchestra, an assemblage of 13 string players and a harpsichordist, made its New York debut last Sunday afternoon in the Hunter College Assembly Hall with a program that mixed Baroque concertos with an early suite for strings by Leos Janacek and the third of Rossini's suites of ''Ancient Airs and Dances for Lute.'' The group showed discipline and animation in its playing and was able to achieve extraordinary effects in its shading of dynamics, especially on the soft end of the scale.

title: SUSAN FARBER TO BE WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving S. Farber of Florham Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Wendy Farber, to Kent Charles Kimball, son of Betty Kimball and Murry J. Kimball, both of Portland, Ore. A May 16 wedding is planned. Miss Farber is studying forensic medicine at Union College in Cranford, N.J.

title: Headliners; Headliners; The First Lady's Gowns
description: Apparently to put an end to all the chittering, Nancy Reagan announced last week that she would no longer acccept free, high - fashion gowns from American designers. An aide said the First Lady stopped the practice because ''she just got tired'' of being misunderstood. ''She felt she was helping the American design industry by publicizing American fashion,'' the aide said. Mrs. Reagan had already donated 13 dresses, including her inaugural ball gown, to various museums, although Administration officials conceded that the museum project was an effort to limit the public relations damage.

title: CALL IT NOUVELLE CONTINENTAL
description: HUGO'S in Smithtown is not only new, it's nouvelle. The sign for the restaurant announces ''nouvelle French cuisine,'' and the majority of dishes on the menu bear descriptions that sound like that style.

title: Talks Continue On Westphal
description: The Knicks and Howard Slusher, the agent for Paul Westphal, continued their talks yesterday in their effort to reach an agreement that would bring the free-agent guard to New York. But a source close to the negotiations said, ''problems still remain.''

title: AN IVY LEAGUE PRESIDENT LOOKS AT COLLEGE SPORTS
description: THE national intercollegiate athletic situation is in considerable flux and, I believe, may have entered a period of rapid transition. Many colleges and universities are facing critical questions that cannot be begged for long.

title: WOMAN, 29, FOUND SLAIN WITH AX IN HER HOME IN ROCHESTER SUBURB
description: A 29-year-old woman was found dead in the upstairs bedroom of her home in this Rochester suburb Friday afternoon, the victim of an ax attack, according to the police.

title: HER HEART IS IN THE FOLK TRADITION
description: country music of what she calls her ''lower-class British mongrel immigrant'' ancestors, when Miss West began a career that was to take her to the first rank of interpreters of Anglo-American folk music she was studying piano and composition at the Mannes School of Music in New York.

title: TELEVISION
description: 'Muggable Mary'Mary Glatzle - 5 feet, 2 inches tall and about 100 pounds - has made her living getting mugged. ''I did get hurt a few times,'' she said.

title: Dare Ergmann Becomes the Bride Of Thomas Elliott
description: Darrach-Lee Ergmann, an account executive with Ogilvy & Mather Inc., the advertising agency, and Thomas Christopher Elliott, a vice president in the international department of Salomon Brothers Inc., investment bankers, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Kenneth B. Swanson in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: THAT OLD BOOK MAGIC
description: Walking on upper Broadway one evening, I saw a man selling books that were laid out neatly on the sidewalk. People were stopping to examine the books, and a woman was making a purchase. When I drew closer, I saw that these books had probably been salvaged from trash or garbage cans, that they were the sort of volumes people put out in shopping bags or cardboard boxes when they thin out their shelves or when they move. Two titles caught my eye: ''The World Almanac of Facts, 1959'' and ''The New School Spring Catalogue, 1971.''

title: PLANS APPROVED FOR KENNEDY CENTER ADDITION
description: The Federal Commission of Fine Arts has approved the initial design for an addition to the John F. Kennedy Center for Performing Arts. The addition would house an institute for the advanced training of graduate students in theater and music.

title: Barbara Powers to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. David H. Brophy of Bridgewater, Conn., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Brophy's daughter, Barbara Bradford Powers, to Kris Thomas Brenard, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Brenard of Brown Deer, Wis. A June 19 wedding is planned. Miss Powers is a daughter also of the late W. Howard Powers Jr. of New York. Day School and Mr. Hepp is a budget controller with ABC World News

title:
STAMPS;
A COMMEMORATIVE THAT BREAKS WITH TRADITION
description: The United States has issued scores of Washington stamps since 1847 - on regular issues, on commemoratives, on official stamps, on envelopes and cards, on saving stamps, revenues and proprietaries and even on a Confederate stamp - but never one like the one coming out tomorrow to mark the 250th anniversary of his birth.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: RADWASTE By Fred C. Shapiro. 288 pp. New York: Random House. $14.50.

title: THE ART OF KEEPING LONG-RUNNING BROADWAY SHOWS FRESH
description: In 1979, two years after ''Annie'' opened on Broadway, Martin Charnin, the show's director, refused to renew the contracts of some 20 cast members. ''The company was stagnant,'' said Mr. Charnin. ''The people were just walking through their performances. They weren't reacting anymore. I could have put a midget in there and nobody would have looked down. I thought it was time to get new blood.''

title: THE CASE FOR TIGHTENING THE REINS ON LANDMARKING
description: The writer of the following article served as Corporation Counsel from 1975 to 1977 under former Mayor Abraham D. Beame. He now practices law as counsel to the firm of Botein Hayes Sklar & Herzberg, and is adjunct professor of local government law at New York Law School. By W. BERNARD RICHLAND

title: SAVING ENERGY THE HARD WAY
description: THERE was something about the rallying call that roused me: Saving energy is ''the moral equivalent of war.'' With a zeal I hadn't felt since I was a Junior Commando collecting scrap metal and wastepaper at the end of World War II, I set about making my home airtight. Every gasket I stuffed into a wall outlet, preventing an infusion of cold air, seemed a victorious strike against those high-rolling Sheiks. Meanwhile, my husband caulked. And caulked. And caulked.

title: PACT REACHED ON WEST VALLEY A-SITE CLEANUP
description: A long-planned cleanup of the hazardous West Valley nuclear storage site near Buffalo has cleared a major obstacle with an agreement permitting transfer of the property to the Federal Energy Department, state energy officials announced.

title: OPERA: MUSGRAVE'S 'ARIADNE'
description: A new production of Thea Musgrave's chamber opera ''The Voice of Ariadne,'' which received its New York premiere at the City Opera in 1977, was unveiled Thursday at Marymount Manhattan Theater by the Chamber Opera Theater of New York. Based on ''The Last of the Valerii'' by Henry James and set in Rome a century ago, Miss Musgrave's opera deals with the myth of Ariadne as a metaphor for a couple's marriage.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: By Sports of The Times; 'Cooney May Never Fight Me'
description: HE grew up here and he still lives here, a heavyweight champion who is comfortable with his roots. His artistic autograph decorates the brick facade of Larry Holmes Enterprises Inc., one flight up from the tasteful quiet of his restaurant and bar next to the flashing lights of his thumping disco.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Sabra Loomis, Soprano, Discusses Her Songs
description: Sabra Loomis, a soprano who made her debut Wednesday at the Abraham Goodman House, clearly cares a great deal about vocal literature. A graduate of Radcliffe College who has studied singing and interpretation in Salzburg and France, she spoke knowledgeably to her audience about the songs and arias she performed.

title: RE-CREATING THE POWER OF THE SUN
description: Our best wishes go to Harold Furth, at Princeton, for future success. Our hearts took a collective leap, however, when we read Jeremy Bernstein's mention of the ''now-ancient cyclotron machine at Harvard.''

title: Article 250203 -- No Title
description: IF county officials have their way, Kensico Dam Plaza, the long grassy carpet in front of the dam that has been a familiar sight to millions of people over the last half century, is likely to be refurbished over the next few years in a program intended to improve a major park while seeking to protect nearby residents.

title: Pregnancy Pressures
description: It was a bad week for women who have put off having children. In a cover story, Time magazine said the birth rate is shooting up and offered anecdotal evidence in the form of photos of radiant, pregnant celebrities. Social pressure: hurry up, everybody's doing it.

title: THE DANCE: ELIZABETH STREB
description: Elizabeth Streb's Thursday night program at the Kitchen made one think about the ways that different dance forms either cope with or try to ignore physical effort. For instance, there are those forms - among them, classical ballet - that often disguise effort and focus the viewer's attention instead on the attainment of some goal of formal beauty or expressiveness.

title: Jenifer McVay Clarke Wed to George Simson
description: Jenifer McVay Clarke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Clarke of Tacoma, Wash., was married yesterday to George Barrett Simson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Humphrey B. Simson of Weston, Conn. The Rev. Robert L. Bast performed the ceremony at the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Weston.

title:
LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR;
15-Year-Old Student On Teaching Problems
description: Marianne Sikorski's article ''Teaching Problems, in and Out of the Classroom'' (Jan. 24) couldn't have been written any better; unfortunetly the same applies to the truth of her article. I myself, being a 15-year-old student, can sympathize with the behavioral problems that exist in and out of the classroom.

title: CONSUMER GUIDE TO MOSCOW
description: SERGE SCHMEMANN is a correspondent for The New York Times in Moscow. By SERGE SCHMEMANN

title:
DANCE VIEW;
FORMER SOVIET STARS AS SEEN BY A COLLEAGUE
IN GREECE, STARTERS CAN GO THE DISTANCE
description: PAUL ANASTASI contributes to The Times from Athens. By PAUL ANASTASI

title: AN EAST END EDEN REAWAKENS
description: IF the bleak days of winter are good for nothing else, they do present an opportunity to do those hateful tasks easily put off during more pleasant weather. Perhaps it is not so much opportunity as the fact that winter often finds one housebound with no excuse not to get something done.

title: ACROSS THE SOUND
description: In the early 18th century, Lord Cornbury, British Governor of New York, had his authority repeatedly flouted by eastern Long Island constituents. According to historians, they perceived New England, particularly Connecticut across the sound, as their cultural, commercial, social and governmental seat.

title: PENTAGON PLOYS
description: WASHINGTON DEFENSE Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger concluded a tour of the Middle East last weekend talking of new arms for Jordan and leaving the impression of an American tilt away from Israel and toward the Arab states. Among those accompanying him on the trip and reinforcing that impression was Francis J. West Jr. Mr. West did the staff work for the trip and frequently, on a not-for-attribution basis, explained to reporters what Mr. Weinberger was really doing.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; New Time Factor For Women Who Defer Pregnancy
description: While more career women are waiting longer to have children, a new report on female fertility suggests they might do well to reevaluate their timetables.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Announced that Ron Davis, pitcher, lost his case in salary arbitration.

title: A Polish Winter Everywhere
description: In the matter of Poland, everyone is losing. Though its spirit lives, Solidarity has been crushed. Though the Poles go to work, their production is abysmal. General Jaruzelski's martial law preserves a surface calm, but his ministers tremble at underground pamphlets that warn, ''The winter is yours but the spring will be ours.''

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
P.H. POLK'S GENIUS VERSUS MODERNISM
description: There is nothing naive or artless about the formal studio portraits of P. H. Polk, the 83-year-old black photographer from Tuskegee, Ala., whose work is on view at Ledel Gallery, 168 Mercer Street, through March 6. On the contrary, Polk's portraits show every sign of having been conceived and executed by an accomplished workman who knew what he wanted and how to get it.

title: RETURNING TO PRIVATE LIFE: A JARRING TRIP
description: TRENTON AFEW weeks ago, they had chauffeurs and press secretaries and made decisions that affected the lives of seven million people. Today, the former Governor, Brendan T. Byrne, and the people who were his top aides are trying to become readjusted to living living as private citizens.

title: BIGGER CARS' RETURN WORRIES DETROIT
description: The big car, that smooth-riding, chrome-bedecked land yacht that once seemed part of the American birthright, is making a modest comeback on the nation's highways after apparently being doomed to extinction by high gasoline prices.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHILE a comprehensive reform of the system of taxation of stateowned land is several years away at the least, State Senator Caesar Trunzo, Republican of Brentwood, is pressing for more immediate state tax payments on a strip of stores along Sunrise Highway that has become a particular irritant to the surrounding community.

title: No Headline
description: U.C.L.A. CAPTURES 12TH IN A ROW, 79-53

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: A Triumph of Tenacity

title: Operating Costs Are Not Compact
description: WHILE fuel prices have been creeping down in the last several weeks, the cost of owning and driving a car continues to climb. That is not news to anyone whose pocketbook has been keeping steady company with an automobile, but the actual rate of ascent is more than a little startling.

title: JUDY COLLINS'S RENAISSANCE
description: ''Times of Our Lives'' (Elektra E1-60001), Judy Collins's 19th album in 20 years, is an impressive comeback by a singer and songwriter whose recent work had disappointed even her long-time admirers. With five original songs that range from narrative ballads to art songs, ''Times of Our Lives'' finds Miss Collins's soprano, which had deteriorated badly in the late 70's, substantially restored. Though she may have lost the resonant chest tones that gave her early protest singing a real punch of outrage, her voice has regained the rich, silvery sureness it had 10 years ago.

title:
LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR;
A 'Social Tax' In an Unequal Society
description: As a beleaguered resident of New Haven, I drew some morose gratification from the account of crime and apprehension in the better class of suburbs, thinking that, as these experiences continue, they might motivate our more prosperous and influential citizens to do something about them.

title: AGAINST THE UNION
description: FEDERALIST Edited, With Commentary and Notes, by Herbert J. Storing. With the Assistance of Murray Dry. 7 Volumes. 1,755 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $175. WHAT THE ANTI-FEDERALISTS WERE FOR By Herbert J. Storing. With the Editorial Assistance of Murray Dry. 111 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. Paper, $4.95.

title: Christopher James Kennan Will Marry Domitilla Enders, Architecture Student
description: Thomas Ostrom Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, and Mrs. Enders of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Domitilla Elena Enders, to Christopher James Kennan, son of George F. Kennan, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia, and Mrs. Kennan of Princeton, N.J.

title: Blood Pressure Said to Vary If Taken in a Doctor's Office
description: Blood pressure readings taken in a doctor's office, where some people experience anxiety, may be abnormally high in patients already suffering from hypertension, according to a report in the issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association dated Friday.

title: LAWYERS AT ODDS ON TACTICS TO AID STRIKING CONTROLLERS
description: A flamboyant Miami lawyer, whose defense for 200 dismissed air traffic controllers is that they were coerced by their union into going on strike, is vowing legal action against the Washington lawyer for nearly 3,000 other former controllers.

title: Hawks, Sonics In 4 Overtimes
description: To Eddie Johnson, an Atlanta Hawks guard, it appeared that ''every time I looked up on the clock there was another five minutes left to play.''

title: No Headline
description: February 21, 1982 NONFICTION CLARE BOOTHE LUCE. By Wilfrid Sheed. 3 THE COMPLETE ANTI-FEDERALIST. Edited by Herbert J. Storing. Assisted by Murray Dry. 9 FIVE O'CLOCK COMES EARLY: A Young Man's Battle With Alcoholism.

title: CHANGES IN SPRING TV SHOWS ANNOUNCED BY THE NETWORKS
description: TV, NBC-TV and ABC-TV have announced program changes in their prime-time spring schedules. On ABC, eight series will have trial runs for the 1982-83 season. CBS will have three additions and NBC one. The new programs on ABC are: ''Joanie Loves Chachi,'' a half-hour spinoff from ''Happy Days,'' will make its debut March 23 at 8:30 P.M. It replaces ''Laverne & Shirley,'' which will return later in the spring.

title: ELECTION CHALLENGE LEADING TO A TRIAL NEITHER SIDE WANTS
description: IN a rare case growing out of an election campaign, a Bethpage anti-abortion activist is scheduled to be tried next month in Nassau County Court on charges of perjury and election-law violations.

title: Samuel Chapin Fiance of Caroline Davis
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Shippen Davis Jr. of Shrewsbury, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Shippen Davis, to Samuel Garrison Chapin of South Carver, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler G. Chapin of New York and Plymouth, Mass.

title: REPUBLICANS SPENT 5 TIMES MORE THAN FOES ON '80
description: The Republican Party spent nearly five times as much as the Democrats on the 1980 elections, the Federal Election Commission reported today in figures that reflected the Republicans' steadily growing financial advantage.

title: CURRENT REPORTS ON DURABLE HITS
description: Walter Kerr is on vacation. H ow fresh are long-running Broadway shows? In connection with the page one article by Suzanne Daley which explores the question, several Times critics have revisited some of Broadway's most durable productions. Their reactions follow.

title: The Region in Summary; Koch's Budget Rates No Stars
description: New York City's fiscal watchdog, the State Financial Control Board, growled at Mayor Koch's 1983 spending plan last week but refrained from biting him on the budget.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Bergmann makes a very good point in criticizing President Reagan for "brandishing the want ad section to show that there are plenty of jobs." As someone with considerable recent experience with the want ads, I have learned that:

title: NO CELEBRATION FOR MRS. TABB
