description: Mary Decker Tabb, newly crowned as the world's No.1 female miler, wasn't celebrating after a recordshattering night in the Jack in the Box Invitational indoor meet Friday.

title: DEMOCRATS TIE STAND ON REAGAN PLAN TO ECONOMY
description: Leading Democratic governors, assembling for the winter meeting of the National Governors Association, joined their party's Congressional leaders today in telling President Reagan that stimulating the economy was more important than his plans for swapping programs between Federal and state governments.

title:
GARDENING;
INNOVATIONS IN COLD FRAMES
description: A SERIOUS gardener soon learns that there are times when it is desirable to grow one's own plants. New and unusual varieties are often unavailable from usual sources as started plants. If you want to have them, you must start them from seed, cuttings or grafts.

title: Denise Partenope Wed To Dr. M.R. Schoenfeld
description: Denise Terese Partenope, a registered nurse in the intensive carecoronary care unit of the Greater Paterson General Hospital in Wayne, N.J., and Dr. Mark Richard Schoenfeld, a surgical resident in the Rutgers University residency program, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Cormac McDonnell and Rabbi Irving Baumol at St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Salem, N.J.

title: Around the World; Cambodia Accuses Thais Of Chemical Warfare
description: The Vietnamese-backed Government in Phnom Penh has accused Thailand of firing shells containing ''poisonous chemicals'' into Cambodia, the Hanoi radio said today. Thailand denied the report.

title: ON SAVING ENERGY
description: The second Westchester County Energy Fair, to be held this weekend at the County Center in White Plains, is expected to draw more than the 15,000 who attended last year.

title: SCHOOLS STEP UP FIGHT ON VANDALISM
description: IN an attempt to curb rising vandalism costs, several of the Island's school districts have begun innovative policies, including the use of cash incentives and rewards for students who have helped to prevent vandalism or who have provided information to school officials that led to the arrest of vandals. Some districts have put trailers, with tenants, on school grounds, while others are using guard dogs and roving patrols to survey the sites.

title: WAGNER COMPOSED SOME EARLY OPERAS, TOO
description: Doesn't it strike you as odd that in a period when we have been shaking awake and ordering out for re-inspection so many of the lesser operas of Verdi, Bellini, Donizetti and Rossini, no matter how crude or immature, the youthful efforts of Wagner have not been called up for the same sort of scrutiny? In Germany, of course, the three operas that Wagner completed before ''Der Fliegende Hollander'' have never gone undiscussed, and it is possible to read of an occasional festival performance there. But in this country even the most avid Wagnerite has had little chance to learn firsthand about ''Die Feen,'' ''Das Liebesverbot'' or ''Rienzi.'' Only ''Rienzi'' has had a major presentation hereabouts in recent decades: two years ago Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York performed a concert version at Carnegie Hall.

title: Headliners; A Suspect's Sanity
description: Although Joseph G. Christopher may have some psychiactric problems, the director of a New York State psychiatric center said last week that the Army private is sane enough to stand trial for murder.

title: COUNTY SEEKS AID OF PASNY TO SAVE JOBS
description: WHITE PLAINS SEEKING ''energy equity'' to preserve industrial jobs, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello has approached the Power Authority of the State of New York with a package of requests for help.

title: THE DARK SOULS OF ORDINARY PEOPLE
description: BEYOND THE PALE And Other Stories. By William Trevor. 256 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95.

title: 29 Establishments Fail Health Inspection
description: The New York City Department of Health released the names of 29 food establishments found to be in violation of the city's health codes. Following a final re-inspection, ten establishments were allowed to reopen and ten others were closed for failure to correct their violations.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Oil Rig and Its Crew Are Lost
description: It was called the biggest and best of deep water oil drilling rigs: 10 stories high, 262 feet wide, 398 feet long and sturdy enough, it was presumed, to withstand 115-mile-an-hour winds, 3 knot currents and 110 foot waves.

title: MUSICIANS GO ON THE ROAD
description: CONNECTICUT campuses often boast a rich diversity of concert activity, but sometimes it's also nice to stay home and have collegiate culture come to you.

title: CHANNEL ISLES
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Hugwork

title: Rosemary Gombar Is Wed At Yale to James R. Stutz
description: The marriage of Rosemary Gombar, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon A. Gombar, to James R. Stutz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Stutz, took place in New Haven yesterday.

title: HOW A CHRYSLER DEALER SURVIVES
description: PLYMOUTH, which stands on six and a half acres of grass and asphalt on a corner near the East-West Expressway here, has been owned by A. Coolidge Elkins since 1951. He took the business over from his father, who became a Chrysler dealer in 1926 after selling everything from Overlands to Stanley Steamers since 1918.

title: Fordham Sets Back Manhattan by 74-62
description: Fordham raised its record to 16-8 and earned a first-round bye in the Metro Atlantic Conference playoffs with a 74-62 victory over Manhattan yesterday at Rose Hill Gym.

title: No Headline
description: LENDL MOVES INTO FINAL WITH NOAH

title: Loughlin Retains Title
description: Bishop Loughlin scored 54 points yesterday and retained its title in the 55th Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor track championships at the 102d Engineers Armory in Manhattan.

title: WILL NORTH HAVEN'S BIG NEW MALL BE NEW HAVEN'S DEATH KNELL?
description: The pious merchants who founded this city 344 years ago envisioned a Christian utopia that, in worldly moments, could rival the commercial vitality of New York and Boston. Their descendants may have their hands full keeping up with North Haven.

title: A LUCKY HAT TRICK
description: Robin Herman's account of the happy outcome of the three Stastny brothers' fortunes contrasts unhappily with the fate of the son of another Czechoslovak sports figure. Marian Stastny was saved from imprisonment on trumped-up charges by the publicity surrounding his still-active brothers.

title: HE ONLY WANTS THE VERY RICH
description: I n 1965, Cleon T. Knapp was 26 and working as a jack-of-all-trades in the offices of Architectural Digest, a small-budget, Los Angelesbased trade journal founded by his maternal grandfather. ''We had a three-person office then,'' he recalled recently in an interview in New York. ''I was writing, doing picture layouts, selling advertising space and helping with distribution.''

title: 'HAMLET' IN A HURRY, BUT WITH STYLE
description: PORT JEFFERSON ''THIS play presents a world so wicked that you have to keep running to keep your legs from being stolen out from under you.'' The play is ''Hamlet.'' The statement is by the director, Frank Rutledge. It appears in the program for the production at Theater Three, where Shakespeare's tragedy, which Mr. Rutledge envisions as a nonstop blood-and-thunder melodrama with no time out for posturing or soliloquizing, gives the last three of its 15 scheduled performances on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

title: Around the Nation; Blacks March to Protest 'Suspicious' Deaths
description: About 400 blacks strode past jeering, hooded Ku Klux Klansmen today and walked 11 miles to the courthouse here to demand an investigation of what they termed a ''series of unsolved murders'' of blacks in rural Walton County since 1946.

title: SYRIA SAID TO RAZE PART OF REBEL CITY
description: Syrian tanks are methodically leveling vast areas of Hama, the nation's fifth largest city, as they continue to battle rebels led by Moslem fundamentalists, according to residents who have escaped the besieged city.

title: AT ANTIQUE SLEIGH RALLIES, THE COMPITITION IS ALL IN FUN
description: A WHIRL around a snowy, open field in an antique, horse-drawn sleigh would seem to some an exhilarating way to spend a winter day. But for many Connecticut devotees of the sport of sleigh riding, that's not quite enough.

title: CONDEMNED TO WRITE ABOUT REAL THINGS
description: From time to time The Book Review has invited both new and established writers to comment on various aspects of their craft: their imaginative and autobiographical sources, their practices of composition, the origin of their sense of vocation. These essays are intended to provide a forum for writers to consider the rewards and perils of their craft.

title: VOTERS REPORTED LESS CONFIDENT OF REAGAN PLAN
description: Members of the House of Representatives who provided President Reagan with his victories in economic battles last year now report that their constituents are losing confidence in Mr. Reagan's economic program and are taking a more critical look at his latest budget and tax plans.

title: Reported Robbery at Pierre Being Studied by the Police
description: The police said yesterday that they were continuing their investigation into the report of a robbery of more than $1 million in cash and jewels from three guests at the Hotel Pierre on Friday.

title: Boxing Notebook; State Commission Misses a Connection
description: The New York State Athletic Commission says it was ''an administrative foul-up'' and ''it shouldn't have happened.'' But on Feb. 8, the commission allowed Mike Thomas, a welterweight then on a 12-bout losing streak, to fight in a main event at the Richmond Hill Arena in Queens, less than two months after it ruled Thomas ineligible to fight in a preliminary at the Felt Forum because he had lost six bouts in a row. After being knocked out by Todd Longmuir, Thomas has now lost 13 straight and has been permanently retired by the commission.

title: AT AN AIR-GUITAR PARTY
description: THE singer strums intently, the last metallic notes of a solo pulsing and electric with concentration. Her performance almost convinces the audience that she holds a real guitar, and not a tennis racquet.

title: WHO'S 'ENTITLED' TO WHAT? IT DEPENDS
description: What is an ''entitlement'' program, and who is ''entitled'' to receive assistance from the Government at the expense of other people in society? Those questions are at the heart of the debate over President Reagan's 1983 budget request. And because entitlements represent a long-term national commitment for automatic spending, similar questions are likely to bedevil Federal officials for the next decade.

title: HEALTH
description: Daniel Laskin is a freelance writer living in Maryland. By Daniel Laskin

title:
FOOD;
A BUTCHER SHOP THAT SPECIALIZES IN 'OLD-FASHIONED WAYS'
description: MALVERNE ''THERE'S nothing I won't do for a customer,'' said Pat Carbone, who twice a week drives to Manhattan's 14th Street wholesale meat market in his refrigerated truck to hand-pick the meat for his butcher shop here.

title: PAKISTAN HAS A CONFLICT BETWEEN SCIENCE AND ISLAM
description: Some months ago when Pakistan's only Nobel prize winner, the physicist Abdus Salam, returned from Europe for a visit, his lecture at the Quaid-I-Azam University in Islamabad was picketed by Islamic fundamentalists.

title: MOSCOW WAS NEVER LIKE THIS-AND IT STILL ISN'T
description: At the height of Poland's experiment with freedom last summer, a Soviet television correspondent explained why Warsaw was a great foreign posting for him. The lifestyle was Western, consumer goods and food more plentiful than at home, and he was free to roam and gambol without fear of being compromised or provoked.

title: A STATE OF LIMBO RULES THE LIVES OF POLISH ALIENS
description: WHEN the immigration agents approached Helena shouting, ''Polish? Polish?'' she felt no surprise, only the confirmation of her worst fears. She knew she possessed neither the valid visa nor the work permit - for her $64-a-week job cleaning offices - that the agents wanted to see. ''There was a risk,'' the 40-year-old former bookkeeper said of her Oct. 21, 1981 arrest here. ''I just took it.''

title: PUT A CONCERT IN YOUR POCKET
description: To see it is nothing special. Sized no larger than a carton of cigarettes and weighing only one pound, the Casio VL-Tone has a keyboard, a calculator face and several buttons on its surface. To hear it is something else.

title: Brooklyn 57 Staten Island 49
description: Playing at home and without Rich Micallef, their top scorer, for the final 16 minutes, Brooklyn College upset the College of Staten Island, the nation's No.1 Division III team. Brooklyn led from the 1-minute mark.

title: The Region in Summary; Nursing Homes Inquiry, Part 2
description: In an investigation that resulted in eight arrests, a one-man grand jury in Connecticut concluded last year that the state Medicaid program had overpaid nursing homes by more than $8 million over three years because of fraud and waste. But the corruption didn't end with the inquiry, so last week another one-man grand jury was appointed to launch a new one.

title: AH, IMPETUOUS YOUTH!
description: When you are 18 years old and defeating your strongest opposition in games of brilliancy-prize caliber, as Gari Kasparov of the Soviet Union is doing, how can you be expected to develop humility?

title: Follow-Up on the News; Fatal Sleep
description: Eighteen Laotian refugees in different parts of the United States were dead - and all under strikingly similar circumstances. The deceased - 17 men and a woman - were all young and had appeared to be healthy.

title: DEBATE ON CURBS AGAINST MOSCOW TO GO TO REAGAN
description: Differences between the State and Defense Departments over future Western sanctions against the Soviet Union in response to the Polish crisis are so deep that both sides have agreed to submit the matter to President Reagan, Administration officials said today.

title: Around the Nation; Radio Signals Prompted Alert at 3 Mile Island
description: Signals from two-way radios at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant apparently interfered with monitoring instruments and prompted an alert at the damaged No. 2 reactor, plant officials said today.

title: HAGGLING IS AN ART IN JERUSALEM'S BAZAAR
description: JANE FRIEDMAN is a writer who lives in Jerusalem. By JANE FRIEDMAN

title: Knicks Defeat Rockets, 122-106
description: Coach Red Holzman was forced to go to his bench early yesterday and to use players who have not produced recently. The move did not pay off immediately, but by the time the Knicks defeated the Houston Rockets, 122-106, at Madison Square Garden, Marvin Webster, Larry Demic, Randy Smith and Sly Williams had made major contributions to help end the team's four-game losing streak.

title: The Trial of Spain
description: The trial of 32 senior officers on charges of plotting to extinguish Spanish democracy could and should be a landmark, and not just for Spain. A year ago, the Madrid Parliament was besieged by Civil Guards trying to trigger a military coup.

title: Richard Greene Weds Katherine L. Barrett
description: The marriage of Katherine L. Barrett, an associate editor at The Ladies' Home Journal, to Richard H. Greene, an associate editor at Forbes magazine, took place yesterday at the Manhattan home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Barrett.

title: 13-0-3 Canadiens Top Rangers
description: The Montreal Canadiens and the Rangers played almost evenly at Madison Square Garden last night in an exciting game of swift skating, deft passing and quick shooting.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Public Energy Co., Dallas, has elected Paul R. Jackson a senior vice president.

title: Market Place; Closed-End Funds' Status
description: SHARES of investment companies with fixed capital - they are called closed-end funds - generally sell at discounts that narrow in good markets and widen in bad ones.

title: News Analysis
description: An unusual incident early last week lent fresh momentum to the guessing game as to who will succeed Leonid I. Brezhnev as leader of the Soviet Communist Party when he dies or steps aside in the face of growing physical debility.

title: Sibson Winner on Decision
description: Tony Sibson of Britain, the European middleweight champion, scored a unanimous decision over Dwight Davison of Detroit today in a 12-round bout.

title: CYPRUS ISSUE: A PROD FOR THE WRONG PARTY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE IMPACT OF TWINS ON SIBLINGS
description: HEY are interlopers who seem to require excessive amounts of their parents' energy and who attract an inordinate amount of attention. Strangers stop on the street and exclaim, ''Oh, look at the twins - aren't they just adorable.'' The single child stands there wondering, ''Who do they think I am? Why don't they notice me, too?''

title: COLLEGE TO OFFER WEAPONS TRAINING
description: Reasoning that firearms, not file cards, will better prepare students for the job market, officials at a college here are replacing a library science program with one in lethal weapons training.

title: CITY A KEY STOP ON DOMINICAN CAMPAIGN TOUR
description: The candidate swept into Kennedy International Airport and was greeted by a swarm of supporters. He held a meeting with his New York-based political consultants, chatted with reporters and delivered an old-fashioned stem-winder to hundreds of chanting, clapping, banner-waving members of the party faithful at a West Side church.

title: STUDY IS CRITICAL OF U.S. AIRCRAFT MAKERS
description: United States aircraft manufacturers have failed to meet the needs of the domestic commuter industry, leaving most of the business to foreign interests, a Government study said.

title: NOAH BEATS LENDL, ENDING STREAK AT 44
description: Yannick Noah of France ended Ivan Lendl's winning streak at 44 matches today with a 3-6, 6-2, 7-5 victory in the final of the $200,000 Congoleum Classic tennis tournament.

title: Sonics 103, Celtics 100
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Gus Williams was Seattle's hero, scoring 34 points, including two free throws with three seconds to play.

title: Dutch Plastics Venture
description: Two of Europe's biggest chemical producers, Akzo Zout Chemie and Shell Nederland Chemie, said Friday that they planned to cooperate in a joint plastics venture that would involve the chlorine and vinyl chloride monomer plants of Akzo and the ethylene and polyvinylchloride plants of Shell. Akzo's current chlorine capacity is 100,000 tons a year and its vinyl chloride monomer capacity is 500,000 tons a year. Shell said its ethylene production capacity is 630,000 tons a year and its polyvinylchloride production capacity is 180,000 to 200,000 tons a year.

title: Sports World Specials; Borrowing a Game Plan
description: They are football players who want a share of television revenue, better pensions and hospitalization plans. Recently, they almost had a strike because management would not recognize their union.

title: U.S. Envoy Has Talks In Egypt on Palestinians
description: Richard Fairbanks, the new United States special envoy to the Israeli-Egyptian talks on Palestinian autonomy, met here today with Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali and said afterward that they had agreed on the next steps in the autonomy process. He provided no details.

title: GOVERNORS INSIST 'NEW FEDERALISM' MUST BE TIED TO REAGAN'S BUDGET
description: The nation's governors today rejected the Reagan Administration's appeal to put their unhappiness with President Reagan's proposed budget out of their minds when they consider his ''new federalism'' proposals.

title: CONCERT: CYCLE OF BEETHOVEN BY BARENBOIM
description: DANIEL BARENBOIM and the Orchestre de Paris completed their transit of Beethoven's symphonies at Carnegie Hall on Friday night with a program that brought together the beginning and the end of the cycle. On such a program the door is open to many approaches. One might have been to emphasize those elements of structure, sound and style that link the First Symphony to the symphonies of Mozart and Haydn, and to let the Ninth, by contrast, show the extraordinary distance Beethoven had traversed by the end of his symphonic career.

title: A Dance Celebration
description: A benefit concert, dance films, free classes and panel discussions will highlight ''50 Years of Dance in Education,'' a celebration at New York University's Washington Square campus, March 29 through April 2.

title: AUTO PRICE CUT SOUGHT BY DEALERS
description: Consumers now look at cars more as transportation appliances than as an expression of their success in life, and this has made them more practical and intensely price-sensitive.

title: PROSPEROUS KUWAIT FACES RETRENCHING
description: Ice-skating in a lavish air-conditioned rink has emerged as a year-round fad in this desert emirate, where summer temperatures regularly soar to 125 degrees.

title: KOCH IS PLANNING TO ANNOUNCE RUN FOR GOVERNORSHIP
description: Mayor Koch will announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor today, City Hall aides said yesterday. The scheduled announcement at a Gracie Mansion news conference comes after several weeks of speculation about Mr. Koch's intentions, fueled by the Mayor's public comments and reports of his private meetings with friends and advisers.

title: It's Father Guido, the Producer
description: Don Novello might not look like a leader. In the robes of Father Guido Sarducci, his ''Saturday Night Live'' character, he was once detained by the Vatican.

title: THE BARE TAX LOOPHOLES-AND SEAL THEM
description: To the Editor:

title: FEAR RETURNS TO PROJECT WHERE MAYOR STAYED
description: Since Mayor Jane M. Byrne moved out of the Cabrini Green public housing complex, residents say that fear, gang violence and despair have moved back in.

title: Reaganomics and the Yen
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports World Specials; Background Music
description: Nobody seems to know from where the idea sprung, but for the first time in 15 years there will be spirited band music during a track and field meet at Madison Square Garden. On Friday when the USA/Mobil championships are contested, an 11-piece band from Yale will provide appropriate background music.

title: Army Cancels Its Plans To Adopt a New Pistol
description: The Army has announced that it has canceled plans to buy a new 9-millimeter pistol to replace old-model side arms because none of the proposals submitted by manufacturers met ''essential requirements.''

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE NATION; Attacks in Miami Linked To Anti-Castro Group

title: CORPORATE NEW ISSUES GROW A BIT
description: Underwriters plan to offer about $475 million of new corporate notes and bonds this week, up from the pace of earlier this year but still far less than the potential volume should interest rates decline.

title: Good, Like Glickman
description: GOOD, like Nedick's. Good, like Nedick's. Good, like Nedick's. For several generations of young New Yorkers, the last sound before falling asleep was the brisk voice of Marty Glickman. It was hardly a case of Glickman's voice having any narcotic qualities; it was rather that we were exhausted from a day of playing stickball with a Spaldeen and running to the luncheonette for an egg cream.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday on a proposed treaty between the united States and the European Economic Community misstated the membership of the community and of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Greece is a member of both organizations; Norway is a member only of NATO.

title: A FORECAST FOR FALL DESIGNS
description: The curtain opened on the fall fashion scene Friday when Muriel Grateau brought her collection of austere daytime clothes balanced by extravagant evening styles from Paris to New York. The advancedseason showing is part of the speed-up of fashion seasons that is apparent all over the world.

title: Mrs. Harris Takes Step On Capital Mayoralty
description: Patricia Roberts Harris, who was the only black Secretary in President Carter's Cabinet, appears ready to run for mayor of the District of Columbia.

title: MILLIONS SPENT IN CONTEST FOR 'SHOWCASE' DENVER CABLE CONTRACT
description: In a decision that will be watched closely across the nation, tomorrow night the Denver City Council will choose the winner among three companies that have been bidding for the exclusive franchise to wire more than 226,000 homes for cable television.

title: VOLUNTEERS IN ARMED FORCES TEST 'ABOVE AVERAGE'
description: An experiment in which a broad sample of young people was given a standard military qualification test has indicated that the all-volunteer armed forces are attracting recruits ''a cut above the average.'' It also showed that, in verbal and mathematical skills, black youths scored only about half as well as whites.

title: AGE DISCRIMINATION CHARGES FOUND IN SHARP RISE IN U.S.
description: Complaints that employers have discharged and demoted workers solely on the basis of their age have soared in the last two years, bringing on renewed Congressional scrutiny of stronger measures to discourage such action.

title: WRITER ADMITS HE FABRICATED AN ARTICLE IN TIMES MAGAZINE
description: A 24-year-old American freelance writer today admitted after three days of questioning that an article he wrote for The New York Times Magazine about a trip with Khmer Rouge guerrillas to Cambodia was a fabrication.

title: ARTHUR SMITH
description: Arthur Smith, vice president of the Duke Ellington Society and a designer of jewelry, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Brooklyn.

title: Sports World Specials; Trainer in Training
description: When she was playing basketball at Mesa Junior College in San Diego in 1975, Lyn Hersey sprained an ankle. As her sore ankle was treated, Miss Hersey, a physical education major who was taking a course in the basics of athletic training, began thinking that she might be interested in becoming a trainer, too.

title: FISHING PROHIBITED IN NEW YORK STATE PARK
description: New York State has just bought 2,865 acres on the east bank of the Neversink River, one of the finest trout streams in the United States, but the purchase will not enable the public to fish the river for years, if ever.

title: RECITAL: MENUHIN AND COKER
description: YEHUDI MENUHIN and Paul Coker played music for violin and piano yesterday at Avery Fisher Hall. There were duo sonatas by Brahms and Bartok and Bach's Partita in D minor for violin alone.

title: Mailer Feels 'Responsibility' for Slaying
description: ''I have a very large responsibility for the death of Richard Adan.'' So said Norman Mailer, the author who helped win parole for Jack Henry Abbott, the long-term convict who killed Mr. Adan shortly after being released from prison last year.

title: DELAY OF A SUBSIDY COSTS CITY
description: New York City's Housing Authority is expected to lose hundreds of thousands of dollars in interest payments because Congress, amid political wrangling over the 1982 budget, was late in passing its spending bills last year, Federal and city officials said yesterday.

title: Privilege and Secretary Watt
description: Many an environmentalist would enjoy the spectacle: James Watt, the pugnacious Secretary of the Interior, led in chains to the well of the House of Representatives, there to answer for ''contumacious'' stonewalling of an Interior subcommittee. Yet Mr. Watt might also relish it; he says he's willing to go to jail to defend President Reagan's claim of executive privilege.

title: MANY CONCERNS REPORT DECLINES IN NET INCOME
description: Corporate earnings showed weakness over a broad front in the fourth quarter and for all of 1981 as high interest rates, a sluggish economy and a strong American dollar abroad continued to depress financial results of the nation's biggest companies.

title: Marathon to Finn
description: Martti Kiilholma of Finland won the first Long Beach World Runners Marathon today in 2 hours 17 minutes 10 seconds, Ric Sayre of Akron, Ohio, was second in 2:18:23. The first woman to finish was Tish Husak in 2:58:06.

title: POLISH MODERATES FACING CHALLENGE
description: The Central Committee of Poland's Communist Party will meet this week for the first time since martial law was declared Dec. 13, the Polish press agency P.A.P. announced today.

title: Nets Lose to Pacers, Fatigue
description: Larry Brown, the coach of the Nets, called it ''ridiculous.'' Jack McKinney, the coach of the Indiana Pacers, said it was ''goofy.''

title: Marxist M.P.'s in Ireland To Drive 'Hard Bargain'
description: A Marxist group with three seats in Ireland's Parliament said today that it would drive a ''hard bargain'' for its support for a new Government.

title: A DEFENSE POLICY THAT IGNORES THE FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Lebanon Premier in Riyadh
description: Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan of Lebanon arrived in Saudi Arabia today at the start of a Persian Gulf tour for talks on the worsening situation in his country. He was quoted by the Saudi Press Agency as saying at Riyadh airport that the main aim of his trip was to explain ''the dangers facing Lebanon and the challenges which are imposed on it by the Israeli enemy, which daily threatens to occupy south Lebanon.''

title: A SCAVENGED BUILDING REFLECTS BRONX DECAY
description: The building endured for 57 years and emptied out in a month. When it was built in 1924, its five stories of ornamental brick and limestone rose solidly from the suburban splendor of the Bronx. Now it stands charred and vacant.

title: TOOL ORDERS IMPROVED IN JANUARY
description: Orders for new machine tools, long viewed as an important economic indicator, improved markedly last month, but were still far below the level of January 1981.

title: JOBLESS RATE IS 9.5% IN E.C.C.
description: Unemployment in the European Economic Community hit a post-World War II record of 9.5 percent in January, providing new evidence of Europe's continuing recession, according to figures released Friday.

title: IN A REBEL STRONGHOLD IN EL SALVADOR
description: Contrary to Government assertions that El Salvador's guerrillas are hit-and-run combatants who control no territory, in this hilltop area less than 25 miles from the capital they have established a primitive network of schools and clinics and even an embryonic judicial system.

title: THE FORGOTTTEN PLIGHT OF TWO LATIN REPUBLICS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1982
description: International Polish Communist leaders will meet formally this week for the first time since martial law was imposed Dec. 13, the official news agency announced. The meeting is apparently intended to demonstrate that the party has not permanently ceded its ''leading role'' in the Goverment to the military rulers. Political sources said that it could bring about a clash between the moderates who predominated before martial law was declared and hard-liners. (Page A1, Column 3.) A writer admitted fabricating an article about a trip with Khmer Rouge guerrillas to Cambodia that appeared in The New York Times Magazine Dec. 20. The writer, Christopher Jones, a freelance, confessed when confronted by a Times editor and two Times correspondents. He said he had not visited Asia last year in preparation for the article and that he had concocted it without even leaving Spain, where he has been living. (A1:1-2.)

title: Arrow President Resigns Position
description: After just eight months in the job, Alfred J. Stein, 49 years old, resigned Friday as president and chief executive officer of Arrow Electronics Inc., an electronics distributor based in Greenwich, Conn. He was succeeded by John C. Waddell, 44, chairman of the company.

title: VIDEO GAME FOR SENATE REPUBLICANS
description: Republican Senators have summoned the power of space-age technology to speed their political messages to the living rooms of faraway constituents.

title: STAGE: MISS PETERS IN 'SALLY AND MARSHA'
description: Sally (Bernadette Peters) is a 30-year-old housewife from South Dakota who has just moved with her salesman husband and two kids to a cramped apartment on the Upper West Side. Marsha (Christine Baranski) is a 30-year-old native New Yorker who lives with her orthopedist husband and two kids across the hall. Sally believes in church and family, Dale Carnegie and ''The Sound of Music,'' baking pies and making potholders. Marsha is devoted to 19th-century novels and four-letter words, Freud and Bertolucci, takeout Chinese food and anxiety attacks. ''All you have is opinions,'' complains Sally to her perplexing, chain-smoking neighbor. ''All you have is orgasms over blenders,'' comes the tart reply.

title: FOREIGN WORKERS IN WEST GERMANY LIVE UNDER THE SHADOW OF PREJUDICE
description: They were professors all, men, by German measure, who could have easily chosen abstraction or euphemism. Instead, they said this: ''It is with great concern that we observe the undermining of the German people through the presence of several million foreigners and their families, the de-Germanization of our language, our culture and our national character.''

title: Iona a Winner In 5 Overtimes
description: Tom Foley of Iona, who had not entered the game until the second overtime period, scored on a driving layup with four seconds left in the fifth overtime period to give Iona a 102-100 victory Saturday night at Fairfield, Conn. The game, which took three and a half hours, was two overtime periods short of the major-college record set by Bradley and Cincinnati last December.

title: TRAINING A BEST FRIEND TO STAY FRIENDLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks and Westphal Close
description: The Knicks were optimistic yesterday that they would soon sign Paul Westphal, the free-agent guard. ''If everything goes the way it has been,'' a source in the Knick organization said, ''it could happen in a few days.''

title: REGIONAL DISPUTE DIVIDES THE SUDAN
description: A debate is sharpening in the Sudan over the destiny of the southern part of the country, an area that is ethnically affiliated more to the bulk of black Africa than to the Arab northerners who predominate in Khartoum.

title: Currencies Devalued
description: Common Market finance ministers today agreed to devalue the Belgian and Luxembourg francs by 8.5 percent and the Danish crown by 3 percent against all other currencies of the European monetary system. Belgium had wanted a 12 percent devaluation.

title: WITH SUSLOV GONE
description: The death of Mikhail Suslov is no guarantee that Moscow will relax domestic or international policies. On the contrary, the post-Suslov era may be more unpredictable than any period since Stalin's death.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: DELOREAN IN U.S. TO DRAW INVESTORS FOR AUTO COMPANY
description: John Z. DeLorean slumped in a chair in his corner office on the top floor of 280 Park Avenue and said sardonically: ''If stress will kill you, I should be dead.''

title: News Analysis
description: While Mayor Koch turns his attention to a race for Governor, City Hall must deal in the coming months with an array of complicated and important issues.

title: BILLY OLSON IS INCHING AHEAD ON WAY TO A 19-FOOT VAULT
description: AWEDNESDAY luncheon in New York will honor the first men to have pole-vaulted indoors 15 feet (Cornelius Warmerdam), 16 (John Uelses), 17 (Bob Seagren) and 18 (Steve Smith). If those record-breakers wait two days, they may see Billy Olson make the first 19-foot vault indoors.

title: WHY THE KID GLOVES?
description: Blunder, incoherence and policy disaster increasingly mark the Reagan Presidency. The reporters and editors who watch official Washington know how bad it is, but they are not really saying it on television or in the papers. They are still giving Ronald Reagan a cushion.

title: TV: 'SUSANNE SOMERS SPECIAL' ON CBS
description: BY dint of her own soft-core exhibitionism and the advice of a slick Svengali-style husband-manager, Suzanne Somers has evolved into one of the least appealing personalities on television.

title: Times Weekday Price To Increase in Region
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that it would raise the suggested newsstand price of its weekday issues to 30 cents in the New York region starting next Monday. The price in that region - within 50 miles of the city - has been 25 cents since September 1979.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FEAR IS PART OF JOB IN BEIRUT
description: In this battered city, there are bombings, kidnappings and political murders literally every day. Armed men of a variety of beliefs, factions and paymasters kill with little reluctance. There are no laws and no sanctions.

title: CAMBODIANS PRESS ANTI-VIETNAM PACT
description: The Prime Minister of the ousted Pol Pot regime in Cambodia and the exiled Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that they had reached a preliminary agreement on forming a coalition to oppose the present Vietnamese-backed Government in Phnom Penh.

title: Charlene Corenman a Bride
description: Charlene Corenman, former manager of public relations with Frank Barth Advertising in New York, was married at the Tavern on the Green yesterday to John Paul Margaritis. He is vice president and director of client services for Burson Marstellar Public Relations in Los Angeles. Justice William Kapelman of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Corenman of Fort Lee, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. George Margaritis of Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: A CONFIDENT SWAN IS EAGER TO SHOW PROGRESS OF ARM
description: While his Met teammates spent the winter fishing, golfing and enjoying their families, Craig Swan pitched and pitched some more. First at the Payson Complex here with Manager George Bamberger watching, and later at Shea Stadium with Bud Harrelson behind the plate, Swan tested the shoulder that has kept him on and off the disabled list for 18 months.

title: The Mirror Of a Team
description: IN the glow of the Islanders' 15th consecutive victory Saturday night, their general manager, Bill Torrey, was trying to assess the significance of the record winning streak.

title: No Headline
description: Writert. Police, believing he was heavily armed, spent 3 1/2 hours talking

title: U.S. Accuses Louisiana Of Errors on Welfare
description: Louisiana made nearly $1 million in mistaken payments in a welfare program for foster children in the fiscal years 1979 and 1980, Federal auditors charged today.

title: No-Name Muskie
description: Three weeks ago, when the city council in Portland, Me., voted to rename the municipal airport after Edmund S. Muskie, the former Secretary of State and longtime Maine Senator, the council found itself in the midst of a controversy.

title: CHURCH RENEWS ITS FAITH DESPITE LOSS OF $300,000
description: The Rev. John A. Andrews preached a stern sermon at the Christ Church of Ramapo in Suffern, N.Y., yesterday morning. Exhorting his listeners to renew their commitment to their religion and their church, he said, ''This parish church today has a better chance of becoming whole and strong and beautiful for Christ than at any other time in its 142-year history.''

title: Despite Woes, JWT Retains Buy Signal
description: The headline in the Feb. 9 Research Digest of the Dean Witter Reynolds brokerage, reads, ''JWT Group (JWT/NYSE) Advertising Campaign for New Kodak Camera Should Keep Bright Earnings Picture.''

title: How Much Tuition Aid?
description: Pell grants, SEOG's, GSL's - they sound like so much gibberish but to many college students, their parents and universities, these Federal tuition programs are the lifeblood of higher education. President Reagan wants to cut them drastically and private colleges, especially, are alarmed. Equal opportunity, social mobility, even the existence of some private schools are said to be at stake.

title: THE NEW RAPALLO
description: Why, after 35 years, are 350,000 American troops stationed in Europe? The announced purpose is to deter a Soviet attack. Most Americans have been sold on the notion that Europe is our first line of defense, same as in the last two world wars, and it would make sense to stop the oncoming Russians ''over there.''

title: Wajda in Paris to Make A Film About Danton
description: The Polish film director Andrzej Wajda, who has not been seen in public since martial law was imposed in Poland last December, flew here from Warsaw tonight. He said he intended to return to Poland next fall.

title: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: In a National Hockey League game, a player on Team A loses his stick as Team B applies pressure near his goal. A few seconds later, a player on Team B also drops his stick and, being closer to the Team A stick, picks it up, gets to the puck, shoots and scores.Is that legal?

title: U.S. Aide to Discuss Missing G.I.'s in Hanoi
description: The United States Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense, Richard L. Armitage, arrived here today en route to Hanoi on a trip designed to underline American concern over some 2,400 Americans still officially listed by the Pentagon as missing in action in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

title: Boeing Pilot Takes 757 for First Flight
description: Soon after John H. Armstrong, 45, landed his Boeing 757 airliner in Everett, Wash., about 1 P.M., Pacific standard time, last Friday, he was on the telephone to a reporter talking about the first short flight of this new-generation aircraft, which was built in the Seattle area. But there was little excitement in his voice, perhaps because Mr. Armstrong has a test pilot for the Boeing Company since 1965, and its chief test pilot since 1980.

title: REP. RICHMOND HELPED FUGITIVE GET JOB ON PAYROLL OF HOUSE DOORKEEPER
description: An escaped convict got a clerical job in the House of Representatives last year with the help of Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn, according to official records and interviews with law enforcement officials and others.

title: City Beats Baruch
description: Tim Taylor and Michael Richardson combined for 37 points to lead City College to a 79-75 upset victory over Baruch College yesterday at the Holman Gym.

title: 4-1 OBGYN WINS WOODHAVEN BY A NECK
description: The shortage of promising 3-year-olds in New York this year was underlined at Aqueduct yesterday when colts based in Pennsylvania and Maryland took the top three spots in the $54,700 Woodhaven Stakes.

title: FIELD SEEKS DIFFERENT PARTNER
description: Marshall Field & Company, frightened by the biggest takeover threat it has yet faced, is scrambling to find a more acceptable merger partner than the Icahn group, which has already purchased a 19.4 percent interest, or to turn up a purchaser for the roughly 2.1 million shares owned by Icahn.

title: TRADERS HAIL MONEY FIGURES
description: Since interest rates began rising in late November, credit market participants have said that the prospect of huge Federal budget deficits and the Federal Reserve's tight money policy were causing high rates.

title: AN OFF DUTY POLICEMAN IS SHOT TO DEATH CHASING TWO ROBBERS IN THE BRONX
description: A 23-year-old off-duty police officer was fatally wounded last night when one of the two robbers he was chasing in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx suddenly turned and fired a pistol at the officer's car, the police said.

title: AN AGENDA FOR THE LEFT
description: T he time is ripe for revival on the left, that spectrum extending from mainstream Democrats to democratic socialists. Lacking thus far has been a credible agenda, objectives and programs consistent with a politics at another state of advance in the Great Society. Here is one attempt to sketch an approach to renewed progress.

title: DANCE: 'TAPPIN' UPTOWN'
description: THREE years ago, the Brooklyn Academy of Music had a hit in ''Steps in Time,'' a tap extravaganza that featured some of the best tap dancers of the 1930's and 40's. On Friday, the academy presented another tap festival, which, if not quite so extravagant as the first, was still, at least on opening night, a tap fan's dream.

title: FOGG BUILDING IS NOW GIVEN A GO-AHEAD
description: Harvard University announced tonight that it has reversed a decision made earlier this month and would proceed with plans to build an addition to the Fogg Art Museum, pending an additional $3 million fund-rasing drive to be completed by March 15.

title: THE 'STRIPPER' MAKES PROFITS FROM SALVAGE
description: The stripping from derelict buildings of metal fixtures and appliances is an underground practice whose short-term prey is inanimate and whose eventual victims are the people of entire neighborhoods.

title: Run to Robinson
description: Rudy Robinson of the North Shore Track Club pulled away to a 200-yard victory yesterday in the New York Road Runners Club 10-kilometer run in Central Park.

title: Princeton Women Take Ivy Swim
description: Betsy Lind, a Princeton freshman, won two more titles today for a total of five individual victories in three days as she led the Tigers to their fourth consecutive Ivy League women's swimming championship.

title: Black Hawks 5, Nordiques 3
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Ted Bulley scored twice and Tom Lysiak assisted on three goals for Chicago over slumping Quebec. The Nordiques have won only three of their last 16 games.

title: People
description: * Judith Ann Aiello has been elected a senior vice president at Backer & Spielvogel Inc.

title: F.C.C. Ready to Issue Cellular Radio Orders
description: The Federal Communications Commission, after more than 13 years of deliberations and delays, plans to issue final orders as early as this week authorizing a new form of mobile telephone service called cellular radio, according to senior officials in the agency.

title: Zungul Scores 3; Arrows Triumph
description: Steve Zungul scored three goals in a game for the 12th time this season to help the New York Arrows to their fifth consecutive Major Indoor Soccer League victory, 10-2, over the Phoenix Inferno before 7,104 at Nassau Coliseum today.

title: Monday, February 22, 1982; The Economy
description: Today's auto buyers seek transportation, not status symbols, dealers assert as they convene in Atlanta. At their annual meeting they also called for permanent price cuts rather than rebates. (D1.)

title: Leo Model Is Dead; Chairman Of Bache, Model, Roland Firm
description: Leo Model, an investment broker and chairman of Bache, Model, Roland International, a division of Bache, Halsey, Stewart, Shields, Inc., died yesterday in St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center after a short illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LOPEZ PORTILLO URGES TALKS ON REGION
description: President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico began a major initiative today to reduce political tensions in Central America with the warning that this could be the ''last opportunity'' to avoid a ''conflagration'' in the region.

title: WHAT THE TURKS THINK OF THEIR GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Cambodian leaders hold talks on forming a coalition A3 West Germans are critical of for- eigners living there A3 Deadline extended in talks on Times of London A3 Reporter's Notebook: In Beirut, fear is a part of the job A4 Around the World A5 Clashes continue for third day in northern Lebanese port A6 Regional-autonomy issue divid- ing the Sudan A7 In a rebel stronghold in El Salva- dor A8 44 nations meet today in India on global economy A9 Government/Politics Volunteers in the military test ''above average'' A13 New York a key stop on Domini- can campaign swing B3 Delay of housing subsidy costing city in interest payments B4 Washington Talk Briefing A14 The Calendar A14 The Presidency: Leaving the budget up to Congress A14 Senate Republicans take to televi- sion A14 Required Reading A14 General Around the Nation A12 Residents say fear moved in when Mayor Byrne moved out A12 Contest for Denver cable fran- chise draws national attention A12 How scavengers hastened demise of a Bronx apartment house B1 Church in Suffern renews faith despite loss of $300,000 B2 For ''strippers'' of buildings, the goal is profits B3 Industry/Labor A.F.L.-C.I.O. mounts effort to re- coup election losses B7 SportsMonday Baseball: Mets' Swan eager to test pitching arm today C3

title: RUSSELL IS NAMED CHIEF CRITIC
description: John Russell, an art critic for The New York Times, has been appointed chief art critic, and Grace Glueck, an art news reporter and columnist for the newspaper, has been named art critic. The appointments, announced by A.M. Rosenthal, executive editor of The Times, will be effective April 1.

title: RADICAL THERAPY FOR FAMILIES
description: Donna was 21 years old, she lived with her parents and two sisters in a big house in the suburbs, and she had suffered from chronic anorexia nervosa since the age of 13. Her parents had taken her from doctor to doctor without finding a cure. Finally, one suggested that the family consult a team of therapists who had been experimenting with a new kind of treatment that produced extraordinarily rapid results with previously untreatable cases.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 22, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Advisory Committee for the World Assembly on Aging - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Chemical's Broker Rate
description: New York's Chemical Bank said Friday that it had lowered its broker loan rate to 16 percent from 16 3/4 percent, effective immediately.

title: No Headline
description: Gretzky's 76th Goal Ties League Mark

title: THEY HAD FACES THEN, AND SOME STILL HAVE
description: LOS ANGELES IN 1937 the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences published its first Players Directory. Of some 1,800 actors and actresses listed in that slim book 35 years ago, only 26 remain among the 13,000 ''Ingenues,'' ''Leading Men,'' ''Characters and Comedians,'' etc., in the two-volume, 15-pound 150th edition published this month. They include Don Ameche, Lew Ayres, Ralph Bellamy, Olivia de Havilland and her sister, Joan Fontaine; Buddy Ebsen, Henry Fonda, Fred MacMurray, Ray Milland, Lloyd Nolan, Martha Raye, Cesar Romero and Mickey Rooney.

title: A Suspect in Robbery Found Hanged in Cell
description: A man awaiting trial on a robbery charge committed suicide yesterday by hanging himself in his jail cell on Rikers Island, authorities said.

title: Commodities; Where Platinum Is Headed
description: OF all the noble or base metals, none has had so bizarre and brief a history as platinum. For most of the past 14 months, for example, platinum has been selling at a discount to gold, despite the fact that the dull gray metal is far rarer and vastly more important to many industries than gold.

title: BIG 10 RACE SCRAMBLED AGAIN
description: With the end of the regular season only two weeks away, followed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, predicting who will win the Big Ten title and who will qualify for at-large bids is difficult as usual. Three of the conference's top teams - Iowa, Minnesota and Indiana - were upset Saturday to keep the race in a scramble.

title: RAY WILLIAMS IS AT TOP OF HIS GAME
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. EVERY day, life for Ray Williams begins here, at a small room at the top of the stairs. This is where he lives, and the room is the focal point in the modest $70,000 house that he purchased for his mother three years ago.

title: UNIONS AND CITY HOPING TO AVERT A TRANSIT STRIKE
description: With formal contract talks between New York City transit officials and the unions representing the 35,000 bus and subway workers expected to begin in a few days, both sides are indicating a desire to negotiate peaceably and to settle their differences without another strike.

title: Receiver of Delorean Outspoken Accountant
description: Sir Kenneth Cork, who was appointed last Friday as the British Government's trouble-shooter in charge of the insolvency of DeLorean Motor Cars Ltd., remembers the first time that he was called upon to sort out a financial quagmire. It was in 1943, he recalled, when General Dwight D. Eisenhower told him that an officer's mess in Italy was in trouble.

title: Three Mile Island Owner Denies Any Gas Buildup
description: The operators of the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear plant said today they were almost certain that there was no buildup of potentially combustible gases in the plant last week.

title: Jersey Inmate on Protest Fast Vows to Resist Force-Feeding
description: An inmate at Trenton State Prison who has refused food for 71 days said today that he would use whatever strength he had left to resist attempts to force-feed him.

title: Beth Daniel Wins
description: Beth Daniel, shooting a final-round 68, scored a four-stroke victory today in the Bent Tree Ladies Classic.

title: GERSHOM SCHOLEM, PROFESSOR OF JEWISH MYSTICISM, IS DEAD
description: Prof. Gershom Scholem, widely regarded as the world's foremost authority on Jewish mysticism, died Saturday night in Jerusalem. He was 84 years old.

title: Antiboycott Violation Fine
description: A United States subsidiary of a Japanese export concern has been fined $91,000 for violating antiboycott regulations, the Government said Friday.

title: MEXICO OUTLINES STABILIZATION PROGRAM
description: The Mexican Government has announced a package of economic measures, including a cutback in public spending, aimed at stabilizing the economy following last week's 30 percent devaluation of the Mexican peso.

title: POP: DEL SHANNON, 60'S TEEN-AGE STAR
description: IN recent years, it has become something of a tradition for younger rock stars to help revive the careers of older musicians who were formative influences. Elton John helped bring back Neil Sedaka in the mid-1970's.

title: THERE IS NO ANGER AS TORRE LOOKS BACK
description: Joe Torre was talking today about his dismissal by Frank Cashen last October after nearly five years as the Mets' manager and the Mets' hiring of George Bamberger.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt GREED IS NOT ENOUGH: Reaganomics. By Robert Lekachman. 213 pages. Pan- theon. $13.50.

title: Seton Hall Takes Big East Track
description: Seton Hall's 1,600-meter relay team sprinted away from Villanova today as the Pirates successfully defended their Big East indoor track title.

title: 44 NATIONS MEET TODAY IN INDIA ON ECONOMIC PLANS
description: In an attempt to rekindle global negotiations on a revised economic order, delegations from 44 mostly underdeveloped nations will meet here Monday to discuss strategy.

title: Going Out Guide
description: WRITER IN THE WORKS

title: Senator Kennedy Celebrates 50th Birthday
description: It is one of those milestones that many people would prefer to pass looking the other way, but not Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who turns 50 today.

title: 29-YEAR OLD NEIGHBOR IS CHARGED
description: Two young girls were killed and a neighbor was charged in the slayings after bloodhounds led the police to his home about 150 yards from the murder scene, authorities said today.

title: SAUDIS DENY REPORTS OF OIL OUTPUT CUTS
description: Saudi Arabia yesterday denied that a formal decision had been made to let production fall beneath the official ceiling of 8.5 million barrels a day.

title: OUTDOORS: A SHOW WITH SOMETHING FOR ALL
description: THOSE who would like to believe that winter's grip on the Northeast is slackened, perhaps even broken, can hasten the feeling by attending the World Fishing and Outdoor Exposition being held here at the Rockland Community College Fieldhouse, Feb. 24-28.

title: Required Reading Smith on Lawyers
description: Attorney General William French Smith, speaking to the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association, in Chicago. Jan. 25, 1982: For the past year, as Attorney General of the United States, I have gained new insight into the role of lawyers in our society, and the public's understanding of that role. The Attorney General, like all lawyers, represents clients and is the advocate for their interests in the courts. In addition, however, the Attorney General owes another allegiance, as do all lawyers, an allegiance to our Constitution and legal system, to the effective operation of the legal system and to its preservation and improvement.

title: RAVITCH ASSAILS PROPOSAL TO HALT U.S. TAX BENEFIT
description: The proposed change or repeal of a Federal tax-leasing provision is jeopardizing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's plans to generate more than $480 million of a major improvement program, the agency's chairman said yesterday.

title: ISLANDER STREAK SNAPPED, 4-3
description: The Islanders' record winning streak ended tonight with a 4-3 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins, a team they had defeated four times while running up 15 consecutive victories.

title: Advertising; Bullish On Bicycle Business
description: JAMES C. McCullagh, 40 years old, arrived in New York on Friday from Emmanus, Pa. - by bus. His transportation is noted only because those who know him might think the editor and publisher of Rodale Press's Bicycling magazine might have chosen a cheaper mode. But do not mistake Jim McCullagh for a biking enthusiast. Those are his readers. He is an enthusiast for an enthusiast's magazine.

title: Sports World Specials; A Real Water Bug
description: According to National Collegiate Athletic Conference rules, a contestant in a dual swimming meet can enter only three events. But a versatile Columbia senior, Lincoln Djang from Las Cruces, N.M., took part in all 11 swimming events - eight as an unofficial competitor - last Wednesday as the Lions defeated Monmouth College, 87-25, at the Columbia pool.

title: Coast Turf Event To High Counsel
description: High Counsel overtook Handsome One to win the $112,900 Sierra Nevada Handicap by a nose today at Santa Anita.

title: No Headline
description: Wichita State Beats L.S.U.

title: LABOR TURNS TO POLLS AND COMPUTERS TO RECOUP 1980 ELECTION LOSSES
description: After the 1980 election losses of so many of labor's good friends in Congress and in many state legislatures, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Committee on Political Education is now mustering all available political technology to keep this from happening again this fall or in 1984.

title: TUBING, TOXIC WHEN BURNED, PUT IN SUBWAYS
description: The Transit Authority is installing at 74 subway stations a kind of plastic electrical tubing that is outlawed in many New York City buildings because it emits toxic fumes when heated.

title: No Headline
description: Bucks Roll to 12th in a Row

title: WATSON TAKES PLAYOFF
description: Tom Watson finished an impressive comeback by making a twisting 32-foot birdie putt on the third hole of sudden death today to defeat Johnny Miller and win the $300,000 Los Angeles Open.

title: Washington Watch; Japan Shows Steel Restraint
description: WASHINGTON TO avoid even more serious trade frictions than already exist, Japan has been imposing voluntary restraints on its exports of steel to the United States, according to American officials and steel industry analysts.

title: 15 ARE REPORTED DEAD AS BATTLES IN LEBANON PORT GO ON FOR 3D DAY
description: Street battles raged in Lebanon's northern port of Tripoli today for the third successive day, despite intensive efforts to arrange a lasting cease-fire.

title: CHAMBER: GUARNERI QUARTET
description: FOR better and occasionally for worse, the Guarneri Quartet responded in kind to the varying qualities of its program Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Arriaga's D minor Quartet, the early-19th-century work of a short-lived Spanish composer, was more eager than refined, and the Guarneri responded to its rough textures with some rough playing and jagged intonation of its own.

title: Hawks 109, Blazers 97
description: Eddie Johnson scored 16 of his game-high 27 points in the fourth quarter and led a second-half Atlanta comeback. The Hawks, who won their fourth straight game on the road, trailed, 64-47, at halftime but held the Blazers to just 33 points in the second half as Johnson and John Drew came alive on offense.

title: Sports World Specials; Fighting for a Job
description: ''I guess it's back to reality,'' said Mickey Goodwin who, joining the legions of Detroit's unemployed, was about to climb into his 1977 Dodge half-ton truck last week. ''I'm in the process of looking for a job.''

title: PINIELLA BATTLING BELT LINE
description: Lou Piniella has a clause in his new contract with the Yankees that says he has to weigh 200 pounds or less by the official reporting date, March 1. Piniella weighed 206 pounds today.

title: Vatican Plans to Build Bomb Shelter for Library
description: The Vatican will begin building a $1.6 million bomb shelter in June to protect its library collection against nuclear attack, a Vatican official said today.

title: TIMES OF LONDON TALKS CONTINUE
description: The publisher Rupert Murdoch and union leaders agreed today to a 24-hour extension of Mr. Murdoch's deadline to close The Times of London and its sister newspaper, The Sunday Times.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We can say that a federalism that is approached on the heels of devastating 1983 budget cuts is not likely to succeed.'' - Richard A. Snelling of Vermont, Republican chairman of the National Governors Association. (B7:4.)

Grace & Co. 1,759,337 + 3 81,721 + 20 Hercules Inc. 649,000 + 3 16,028 - 48 Int.

title: A LEANER, SCRAPPIER CHRYSLER
description: Once again, the Chrysler Corporation has hobbled through the valley of death, emerging leaner and scrappier than ever before. Despite the worst automobile market in 23 years, analysts say that Chrysler, the car company with nine lives, is reasonably well-poised to ride out the current slump and take full advantage of the economic upturn when, and if, it comes.

title: SAME PRIORITY, DIFFERENT STRATEGY
description: A year ago, White House strategists frequently fretted that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was sounding off too much about El Salvador and distracting attention from the President's top priority - the budget.

title: Padilla Captures 3,000 on Coast
description: Doug Padilla, a Brigham Young student from Hayward, Calif., won the 3,000-meter run at the San Francisco Games Saturday night in 7 minutes 46.2 seconds, the second fastest time indoors by an American this year.

title: WATT TO SEEK BAN ON MINERAL LEASES FOR FEDERAL LANDS
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, in a major policy change, said today that he would ask Congress to bar all mining and drilling in Federal wilderness areas until the end of the century.

title: TRIAL OVER BRIDGE CHEATING TO BEGIN
description: The players, Larry Cohen and Dr. Richard Katz, resigned from the American Contract Bridge League in January 1977, after they were accused of cheating by league officials. They subsequently denied that they had cheated, contended that they had been coerced into resigning, demanded reinstatement and sued the league for $40 million. The league is the nation's principal contract bridge organization.

title: BRIEFING
description: Environmental Apoplexy

title: Bridge; NEW PROGRESS IN SIGNALING EXPLAINED IN A MONOGRAPH
description: It is obviously helpful and important for serious players to understand something about bidding conventions that may be used against them. You may not wish to use them, but unfamilarity may put you at a disadvantage.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly identified the most recent Mayor of New York City to have become Governor. He was John T. Hoffman, in 1868.

title: 2 Banks Cut Prime
description: Two smaller banks, the Ameritrust Company, based in Cleveland, and the UMB Bank and Trust Company, a New York subsidiary of United Mizrahi Bank Ltd. of Israel, lowered their prime lending rates today to 16 1/2 percent from 17 percent. Most major banks raised their prime lending rates last week to 17 percent.

title: SOUTHERN METHODIST NAMES BUSINESS DEAN
description: Roy A. Herberger Jr., 39, will join Southern Methodist University on June 1 as dean of its Edwin L. Cox School of Business. The Dallas position has been vacant since November 1980, when Alan B. Coleman, 53, resigned. Mr. Coleman is now president of the Foundation for the Southwestern Graduate School of Banking at S.M.U.

title: TWO REAGAN POLICIES ASSAILED
description: Civil rights activists, declaring they know ''who our enemies are,'' attacked the Reagan Administration's civil rights and budget policies today, charging that they were efforts to wipe out 20 years of progress toward the goal of equality.

title: DANCE: JIM SELF IN 'LOOKOUT,' REVIVING DADA
description: DADA lived again on Thursday when Jim Self presented ''Lookout,'' the first week's piece of a two-week engagement by Mr. Self at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: MINE SAFETY APPLIANCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reflect a decrease of $1,345,000 for the latest qr and an increase of $2,426,000 for the latest yr resulting from changes in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: THE OPPORTUNITY THAT THE MAYOR COULDN'T REFUSE
description: In the end, after weeks of fueling speculation and openly delighting in the political ruckus he had wrought, Mayor Koch made his decision to run for Governor on his own, after a small, nonpolitical brunch filled with nonpolitical people, and for perhaps the most basic of reasons.

title: N.J. Authority to Discuss Rangers
description: Officials of the New Jersey Sports and Exhibition Authority expect to learn today how much longer they will have to wait for a decision by the Madison Square Garden Corporation on whether the Rangers intend to move to Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: GOVERNORS ASK REAGAN TO MODIFY 'FEDERALISM'
description: The nation's governors told President Reagan today that they wanted a different and smaller swap of responsibilities than he outlined last month under the banner of ''new federalism.'' Mr. Reagan expressed a willingness to negotiate, according to Presidential aides and several Governors present at the White House meeting.

title: Law for Bryant to Work Past 70 May Be Invalid
description: A judge suggested today that legislation allowing Bear Bryant, the 68-year-old Alabama football coach, to remain on the university payroll past the age of 70 is not valid under the state constitution.

title: GEOPHYSICAL FIELD SURVEYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NEW BILL COULD AID SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS
description: Federal regulators and Congressional leaders announced plans today to help the nation's ailing thrift industry and a new study forecast that more than 1,000 thrift institutions would fail or be forced to merge by the end of 1983.

title: Juilliard Quartet Plays All-Beethoven Program
description: The Juilliard Quartet has always been an ensemble in motion - a group driven by its breakneck tempos, driven in its quest for absolute clarity and driven in the hard, steely quality of its sound.

title: TRECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a charge from tax credit reversal of $161,000 for the qr and a tax credit of $473,000 for the 9 mos and a gai of $108,844 from asset swaps for the qr and 9 mos... C-Includes a charge from tax credit reversal of $234,000 for the qr and a tax credit of $324,000 for the 9 mos

title: INVITATION TO LITTER
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $908,000... C-Including a tax credit of $30.6 million, a gain of $7.1 milli from the sale of real estate and a gain of $13.9 million from t sale of tax benefits...D-Net los including a gain of $26,427,00 discontinued operations, a gain of $49,441,000 on the exchange debentures and a loss provision of $57 million for the disposal of aircraft

title: INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $250,000 or 13 cents a shr on the sale of lease interests...C-Including income of $200,000 or 11 cents a shr on the sale of some assets and income of $44,000 or 2 cents a shr from discontinued operations

title: BASIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $799,000...C-Including a tax credit of $934,000 and income of $535,000 representing prior year's administration and interest costs expended as incurred pending the third qr acknowledgement of proper classification as recoverable pre-production costs under the company's oil and gas license agreement in Greece and now recoverable from production revs

title: New Sub to Be Used in Titanic Search
description: A leader of the effort to locate the sunken British ocean liner Titanic in the depths of the North Atlantic said today that the exploration team would resume the search in 1983 with an aluminum submarine.

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $87,000 for the qr and $165,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including extraordianary tax credits of $98,000 for the qr and $137,000 for the 6 mos

title: U.S. Steel Resists Marathon Change
description: David Roderick, the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said today that the company would not change its offer for the remaining outstanding shares of the Marathon Oil Company.

title: BANK, THRIFT MERGE IN MINNESOTA
description: The Marquette National Bank of Minneapolis, in the nation's first merger between a commercial bank and a thrift institution, announced yesterday that it had acquired the ailing Farmers and Mechanics Savings Bank of Minneapolis. The move will create the fourth-largest commercial bank in the city, with deposits of more than $1.1 billion.

title: Precision Pilot Dies in Crash
description: The lead solo pilot in the Navy's Blue Angels precision flying team was killed today when his A4 Skyhawk jet crashed in the southeastern California desert after completing a looping maneuver.

title: POLES PUBLISH LIMITS ON UNION ACTIVITIES
description: The Polish Government published proposals today for the future of trade unions that would guarantee their independence, but curtail the use of strikes and prevent them from becoming a political movement.

title: Start With a Bang
description: Though we don't think of ourselves as crabby, we wince whenever we hear ''ground zero'' misused. The culprit this weekend was Richard Wirthlin, who does political polling for President Reagan and now for Lewis Lehrman, a Republican candidate for governor of New York. Mr. Wirthlin, a calm and likable man, was asserting that Mr. Lehrman had recently improved his position compared with State Comptroller Edward Regan, as demonstrated by his jump from ''ground zero'' in a poll taken last fall.

title: TURNER CONSTRUCTION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Included a gain of $1,312,000 from sale of stock

title: Stars Conquer Whalers On McAdam's Goal, 8-7
description: Dino Ciccarelli scored two goals tonight and led the Minnesota North Stars to an 8-7 victory over the Hartford Whalers. The North STars had trailed by 3-0 early in the second period.

title: Grumman's President Named Chairman of Flxible Bus Unit
description: In a move to strengthen its money-losing Flxible bus subsidiary, the Grumman Corporation assigned its secondhighest executive to Flxible today and said that it was restructuring another subsidiary that makes fire trucks, ambulances and yachts, among other products.

title: Heublein Sues Major Holder
description: Heublein Inc., the distiller, has filed suit against the General Cinema Corporation, contending that the theater operator made ''misleading and incomplete disclosures'' in acquiring a nearly 10 percent stake in Heublein.

title: Chinese Are Addicted To Rubik's Cube, Too
description: Supply is not meeting the demand in China for ''magic cubes,'' the popular name for Rubik's Cubes.

title: Drake Star Killed
description: Damita McClinton, a Drake University track star, was killed Sunday in an automobile accident on a highway five miles north of here. Two other athletes were seriously injured. They were Cheryl Carl, a sprinter, and Toni Brewer of Queens, New York, a basketball player.

title: 2d Innis Son Slain
description: A man who was shot to death Saturday night in Harlem was identified yesterday as the 26-year-old son of Roy Innis, the leader of the Congress of Racial Equality, the police said. It is the second time that one of Mr. Innis's sons has been shot to death.

title: A Top Scorer Arrested
description: Quintin Dailey of the University of San Francisco, the nation's fifth-leading scorer in major college basketball, was arrested yesterday and accused of five felonies, including attempted rape.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Michael Diaz and Miguel Ibarra, catchers, Willie Hernandez, pitcher, and Carmelo Martinez, infielder.

title: STRUGGLING TO FIND A PLACE FOR THE MX
description: In many ways the controversial MX has become a missile in search of a hole in the ground. Its wanderings are a bit of a political embarrassment to the Reagan Administration. After castigating the Carter Administration's MX program during the 1980 campaign, the Reagan team has had four different notions of where to put the MX over the past 13 months, without settling on a satisfactory long-term answer.

title: Jury Selection Begins In the Stouffer's Trial
description: Jury selection in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial began today with 25 of the first 75 potential jurors rejected because of possible bias or for hardship reasons.

title: THIS IS PARTNERSHIP?
description: The Reagan Administration has tied United States prosperity to the fortunes of big business. But the sharp drop in the stock market after the Administration projected a record deficit in the fiscal 1983 budget was only the latest sign of business' worries about Reaganomics. Despite the rhetoric about ''partnership'' between business and Government, they have yet to define together the country's economic problems or plan how to solve them.

title: BICKFORD CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
STRIKE GIVES CO-OP CITY A DAY TO KEEP ON COATS
description: ''I thought I must be in Alaska,'' Gertrude Goldstein said about waking up yesterday in her apartment in Co-op City in the northeast Bronx. She said it felt like 40 degrees below zero.

title: CONGRESS LEADERS HINT AT TAX RISES
description: Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders suggested today that tax increases of some kind for individuals or corporations might be enacted to pay for President Reagan's military buildup and shrink the budget deficits he has asked Congress to accept.

title: Two Charged in Selling Computers to Soviet Bloc
description: An Englishman who owns a concern that makes computer gear and an employee were arraigned in Federal District Court today on charges of selling the high technology devices, which are ''controlled for national security reasons,'' to three Communist nations.

title: STAFF IS REDUCED AT TIMES OF LONDON
description: Rupert Murdoch, the owner of The Times of London and The Sunday Times, risked their future tonight by ordering the dismissal of 210 employees despite the opposition of trade unions.

title: GREATE BAY CASINO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRODUCT SAFETY AGENCY BANS USE OF FORMALDEHYDE FOAM INSULATION
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission today banned the sale of urea formaldehyde, a once widely-sold foam insulation, on the ground that it ''poses an unreasonable risk of injury.''

title: Reagan's Latin Talk Is Planned Tomorrow
description: President Reagan will present his development plan for the Caribbean and Central American region in a speech Wednesday to the Organization of American States, the organization said today.

title: POT LIQUOR OR POTLIKKER?
description: In an article on Senate debates on food that ran on this page Feb. 10, mention was made of a 1935 filibuster in which Huey Long lectured his colleagues on the merits of potlikker. Due to an unfortunate consultation with a dictionary, that great Southern delicacy was referred to as ''pot liquor,'' prompting the following communication from a regional authority on the subject: Dear Sir:

title: Alcan Reduces Aluminum Output
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said it is reducing production at its Arvida, Quebec, smelter by 43,000 metric tons a year because of depressed sales and the need to balance production and inventory.

title: AIR FORCE TOLD TO FREE OFFICER IN 'SECRETS' CASE
description: The United States Court of Military Appeals today dismissed court-martial charges against Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke, the missile-launch crew member who was accused of passing information to the Soviet Embassy, and the Air Force discharged him.

title: Topics; Whoppers; Fast Trash
description: New York's two-year-old ''18-inch'' law requires property owners to sweep the sidewalk in front of their property and 18 inches into the road or be liable for fines of up to $250. Many consider the law unenforceable.

title: Birdsong Hurt Again
description: Otis Birdsong, the Nets' $1 million-a-year guard, injured his right leg in Sunday's 118-107 loss to the Indiana Pacers, and the Nets said yesterday that his availability for tomorrow night's home game against the Milwaukee Bucks was questionable.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. and Continental Group said that, based on a preliminary count of shares tendered, the offer by an Allied subsidiary for Supron common stock had been oversubscribed. About 17.2 million shares of Supron common stock had been tendered.

title: Marcos Plans Saudi Visit
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos is expected to visit Saudi Arabia next month, a palace announcement said today.

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After extraordinary income of $12,275,000 or 52 cents a shr

title: Heavy Selling Hits Northwest
description: The stock of Northwest Industries, the big, Chicago-based conglomerate, was hit by heavy selling again yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in a continuing reaction to the company's repurchase of 5 million of its own shares at $75 apiece.

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Islanders Pondering Post-Streak Effect
description: Now that their record 15-game winning streak is history, the Islanders have to face some tough questions as they approach the final 20 games of the National Hockey League season.

title: Flanagan's Knee Stiff
description: Mike Flanagan, no stranger to injuries, is back on the Baltimore Orioles' casualty list, at least briefly.

title: MCQUAY-PERFEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Boyer Quits Managing
description: Ken Boyer, who has lung cancer, had tried to carry on anyway as manager of the Louisville Redbirds of the American Association, but the club said that the task had proved impossible. The 50-year-old Boyer, once an outstanding third baseman for the St. Louis Cardinals and their manager from 1978 to June 1980, was named to the minor league job last November.
