Shortly afterward, he learned that he had cancer in both lungs. A. Ray Smith, owner of the Lousiville team, said he hoped to name a successor to Boyer sometime this week. ... The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported that in the mid-1970's Daniel R. McCarthy, a minority investor in the Yankees, owned 30 percent of a Buffalo business whose other owners have since been identified by Federal authorities as having connections with organized crime. Mr. McCarthy, who sold his shares in the business five years ago, was quoted as having said that he had invested in the concern on the advice of his law partner and that he had merely been a passive investor.

title: 'CHOKE HOLD' BY POLICE SET FOR REVIEW
description: The Supreme Court today agreed to review a Federal court order that limited the Los Angeles Police Department's use of the ''choke hold'' or ''strangle hold'' to restrain potentially violent suspects.

title: LOOKING OVER JORDAN
description: King Hussein took a risk last month when he s ent Jordanian volunteer troops to aid Iraqi forces fighting Iran. H is decision was prompted by the Iranian-backed coup attempt in B ahrain and by growing Islamic fundamentalism in the Gulf states, S yria, and on the West Bank. What the King wants most is an Arab c onsensus on peace with Israel, but he calculates that the Arabs willn ot be able to agree on a peace plan as long as Iraq and the Gulf aret hreatened by revolutionary Iran.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Food Market Alert Will Be No More
description: The Department of Agriculture has published its last issue of Food Market Alert. The Alert was a good-news letter used to notify 17,000 hospitals, schools, restaurants and other bargain hunters whenever a bumper crop of turkeys, apples or other foods were about to swamp the market, thus producing a bargain. The newsletter, which helped farmers and consumers alike, became a victim of its own success. ''It was a budget-identifiable line item, costing $80,000 to $90,000 to produce,'' said Lewis Brodsky, spokesman for the Federal agency, which is avidly looking for identifiable line items to cross out this year

title: Talking Business with Dragan of the Yugoslav Government Rising Output In Yugoslavia
description: Zvone Dragan calls himself a ''qualified supply-sider.'' The 43-year-old economist is vice president of the Yugoslav Federal Executive Council and his country's highest economic officer.

title: Tribute to Grace
description: She may be known now as Her Serene Highness Princess Grace of Monaco, but back home in Philadelphia come March 31, she will introduce what is to be called, plainly, the Grace Kelly Film Festival.

title: Spanish General Asserts King First Backed Coup
description: Gen. Luis Torres Rojas, one of three generals on trial in connection with an attempted coup last year, said in evidence read today that he believed King Juan Carlos first backed the coup, but then changed his mind.

title: SCHMIDT SEEKS MERGER WITH PABST BREWING
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said yesterday that it had received an ''unsolicited'' cash merger proposal from an investment banking firm representing C. Schmidt & Sons Inc., a Philadelphia brewer. Analysts said Pabst was almost certain to reject the offer.

title: INTEREST RATES FALL SHARPLY
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday, extending the declines that began late Friday following news of a larger-than-expected drop in the nation's basic money supply.

title: BRIEFING
description: Children's Lobbyist

title: AN OLD-FASHIONED HOLDOUT
description: DURING the World Series last year, Fernando Valenzuela's agent, Tony De Marco, was extolling the Mexican left-hander's virtues to several others in a midtown coffee shop. Among his listeners was Al Campanis, the Los Angeles Dodgers' vice president for player personnel. As Tony De Marco talked, Al Campanis quietly kept slipping little green tomatoes into the agent's cup of coffee, until it overflowed.

title: KOCH, ANNOUNCING FOR GOVERNOR, PROMISES TO SERVE 'ALL THE PEOPLE'
description: Transcript of Koch announcement of candidacy, page B4. By FRANK LYNN

title: Chess:; Lev Albert of New York Wins Reykjavik Tourney
description: Lev Alburt, a 36-year-old New York grandmaster, won the $6,000 first prize in the 10th Reykjavik international tournament with a score of 8 1/2-2 1/2.

title: FRIENDS PAY TRIBUTE TO MONK WITH HIS MUSIC
description: Almost 1,000 friends and followers of Thelonious Monk, the jazz pianist and composer who died Wednesday, filled the Sanctuary of St. Peter's Church at Lexington Avenue at East 54th Street. The crowd overflowed into an adjoining area to take part in the funeral service for Mr. Monk yesterday morning. It was the largest crowd gathered in the church since it moved into its new building in 1977.

title: News Analysis
description: In offering himself for Governor yesterday, Edward I. Koch cited his record as Mayor as a big reason why voters should elevate him to the Statehouse in Albany.

title: LIFE'S ORIGIN: A SCIENTIST'S SEARCH FOR THE VERY BEGINNING
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md. THE question could not be more intellectually challenging: What was the origin of life on earth? Nowhere is the question being asked with more optimism that it just might be answerable, than in the laboratory and mind of Dr. Cyril Ponnamperuma here at the University of Maryland.

title: Judge Lifts Order Restricting Icahn
description: A Federal judge in New York lifted a temporary order barring members of an investment group headed by Carl C. Icahn from acquiring additional stock in Marshall Field & Company.

title: 'SALMON'S MURDEROUS TROUBLE IS ACID RAIN'
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Jeffrey Zeiler and Lois Underhill have been named senior vice presidents at Cadwell Davis Savage/Advertising.

title: UNIVERSAL TELEPHONE INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
A Lie in The Times
description: When a newspaper uses precious front-page space, as The Times did yesterday, to expose a lie in its own columns, it is trying to do much more than confess a procedural lapse. The point is to reaffirm a compact with the reader: that what is printed has been honestly gathered and labeled; that any credible challenge will be rigorously examined, and that serious error will get prompt and conspicuous notice.

title: IRAN IS SAID TO CUT OIL PRICES IN WIDER BREACH WITH OPEC
description: For the third time in less than three weeks, Iran yesterday undercut further the official oil price set by OPEC, according to buyers of Iranian crude. The cuts were seen as an open breach of OPEC discipline.

title: HEROIN VALUED AT $70 MILLION REPORTED SEIZED
description: Federal agents said yesterday that they had seized 115 1/2 pounds of heroin that had been smuggled into the United States from Italy in elaborate espresso machines. They estimated the street value of the drug to be $70 million.

title: Philharmonic Solution
description: It is, as a New York Philharmonic official put it, ''a truly significant milestone in the world of music.'' The occasion? The orchestra's upcoming 10,000th concert.

title: WATT IS CRITICIZED BY A HOUSE LEADER
description: In a new step in an increasingly tense confrontation, a House subcommittee chairman accused Interior Secretary James G. Watt today of seeking to impede Congress's constitutional duty to oversee Government activities.

title: Chicago Ad Executive Returning to New York
description: Alvin Hampil, creative heavyweight and an expatriate New Yorker in Chicago, is due back in the Big City very soon.

title: West Sahara Guerrillas Stir an African Dispute
description: Foreign ministers of the Organization of African Unity opened a week-long meeting today amid protests by Morocco over the seating of a delegation from a guerrilla group seeking independence for Western Sahara.

title: G.N.P. REVISION TRIMS FOURTH QUARTER DECLINE ,
description: The American economy was not so weak during 1981's last quarter as previously announced, the Commerce Department reported today. It said the gross national product declined at an annual rate of 4.7 percent instead of the 5.2 percent announced last month.

title: THE MOOD IN WARSAW: 'SOMETHING'S GOT TO GIVE'
description: The ancient ecclesiastical chants, murmured responses, bowed heads and glimmering Baroque decorations at St. Anne's Church in central Warsaw on a recent evening belied the tension.

title: New College President
description: It was George Washington's birthday yesterday, so officials at the 200-year-old Washington College, in Chestertown, Md., took the opportunity to announce that Douglass Cater would become the college's 23d president.

title: WABC IS DROPPING MUSIC FORMAT TO SWITCH TO TALK AND NEWS
description: music radio station in the country, is switching to a format of talk programs and news. Battered by low ratings and the loss of its once-vast teen-age audience to FM stereo stations, WABC is doing what has been done by all but one of the AM stations owned by the American Broadcasting Companies.

title: SENATE HEARING TO INVESTIGATE ENFORCEMENT OF PENSION FUND LAWS
description: Nearly five years after the Labor Department sued to recover $27.2 million owed to a Nevada union pension fund by the operator of the Dunes Hotel in Las Vegas, the case is still unresolved and the debt has grown to more than $45 million, according to Senate investigators and Government documents.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Saturday on the tentative contract agreement between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers misstated a provision of the agreement. Workers would continue to receive cost-of-living payments, but increases in that category, based on the Consumer Price Index, would be deferred for nine months.

title: TV: 'FOR COLORED GIRLS' ON 'AMERICAN PLAYHOUSE'
description: NTOZAKE SHANGE'S ''For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf'' has had an interesting marketing history. The work began as poems being read in San Francisco bars around 1970. Later, the pieces began to take dramatic shape at Woody King's New Federal Theater in New York. Then, in the mid-1970's, widespread acclaim and success were gained with a stunning stage production mounted for the Public Theater that later moved to Broadway - in the days before Joseph Papp took to making embarrassing singing commercials for radio.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF THE ANNOUNCEMENT BY KOCH
description: Following is the text of Mayor Koch's announcement of his candidacy for Governor: I have decided to run for Governor of New York State. I will start my official campaign in April. A great deal of thought has gone into this decision. I love the job I have and the city which I serve. As I have said repeatedly, I never planned to run for another office.

title: ADJUSTING TO ELECTRONIC OFFICE
description: The National Blank Book Company used to make a handsome living producing bound ledgers for office accounting records. Today, as a division of Dennison Manufacturing Inc., National's peak ledger sales have been surpassed by its sales of data binders for computer printouts.

title: CONTROLLER SUSPENSION VETOED
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis late today reversed a recent decision by J. Lynn Helms, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration, to suspend about 1,200 air traffic controllers who initially joined the nationwide walkout last August, a spokesman said.

title: DATATRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income after an extraordinary net loss for the qr and 6 mos on the early retirement of debt

title: ARMY WINS SOME MINDS IN SALVADOR
description: ''Here, all these peasants support the army,'' said the 58-year-old army lieutenant, his automatic rifle resting on his knees as he sat on the gnarled roots of a sprawling shade tree.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Cigarette smoking is clearly identified as the chief preventable cause of death in our society.'' - Dr. C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States. (C2:4.)

title: PAGEAMERICA COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $900,000 for the qr and $46.6 million for the yr...C-Including a gain from discontinued operations of $3.2 million... D-Net income after a loss of $4.3 million from discontinued operations

title: TECHNICIANS PREPARE FOR MAJOR FUEL TEST ON SPACE SHUTTLE
description: Technicians began inspections today to prepare the space shuttle Columbia for another major test this week: the loading of more than a half-million gallons of liquid fuel.

title: MURRAY KAUFMAN, 60, IS DEAD
description: Murray Kaufman, the former New York disk jockey known to millions of rock fans as Murray the K, died late Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He had waged ''a long battle with cancer,'' according to his manager, Rick Olson. Mr. Kaufman was 60 years old.

title: HIGH STOY TECHNOLOGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN PRECISION INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: UNION LEADERS TAKE THEIR WORK TO A SUNNY SPOT
description: It is always a curious and, in part, incongruous spectacle, the annual migration of the nation's labor leaders to this sliver of a sun-splashed city on the Atlantic Ocean. Here the labor men and women demand a better lot for the poor and the unemployed and then baste themselves in the sun, pay fancy prices, and otherwise live the good life.

title: The Koch Warranty Expires
description: To politicians, alas, a vacuum is as attractively abhorrent as it is to nature itself. Once Governor Carey withdrew from a run for reelection, the pull of his not-yet-empty space was immediately felt in New York's City Hall. And in Edward Koch's struggle with himself, the mayoralty has now lost out.

title: 2 BROTHERS FACE CHARGES IN RAPE OF A 2D WOMAN
description: Two brothers from Greenwich, Conn., whose plea bargaining on rape charges four months ago caused public protests were in court today, charged with the rape of another woman.

title: U.S. Told to Speed Up Release of Cubans
description: An angry Federal judge told the Government today to speed up the release of Cubans approved for freedom from the Atlanta Penitentiary or he would develop a plan of his own.

title: WESTERN DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOLD MOVES AT BUFFALO SAVINGS
description: Ross B. Kenzie realized in 1979 that his career at Merrill Lynch had come to a dead halt. So, the 48-year-old West Point graduate and native of upstate New York went back to Buffalo to head a little-known, highly conservative institution, the Buffalo Savings Bank.

title: POP: J. GEILS ROCK CONCERT
description: THE J. Geils Band's sudden spurt in popularity after 13 years is a textbook example of how small changes in a musical recipe, cued to current rock fashions, can have a miraculous effect on a band's career.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: C'EST PARIS

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; revs and shr earnings figures for fourth qr were not available; shr earnings are fully diluted

title: No Headline
description: Boston College Tops Syracuse, 88-77

title: The Muddy Road To Albany
description: The suspense is finally over. Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he wants to be ''the Governor of all of the people.'' Early opinion polls and The New York Post, which has become a Koch political pamphlet, report the Mayor far in front of all potential opponents, both in the Democratic primary and the November general election.

title: HIGH COURT DENIES BID BY MOBIL
description: Closing its books permanently on the Mobil Oil Corporation's abortive effort to acquire the Marathon Oil Company, the Supreme Court today refused to hear Mobil's final appeal of the adverse an-titrust rulings that blocked the takeover.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Apr 1981

title: SLATER STEEL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: SURGEON GENERAL REPORT BROADENS LIST OF CANCERS LINKED TO SMOKING
description: In one of the strongest indictments of cigarettes since the landmark Federal report on smoking 18 years ago, the Surgeon General of the United States today broadened the list of cancers linked to cigarette use. He declared smoking ''the most important health issue of our time.''

title: Soviet Corn Purchase
description: The Soviet Union has purchased another 100,000 metric tons of American corn, Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block said today. The sale brings American grain sales to the Soviet Union during the current marketing year to 11.5 million metric tons.

title: A Smaller Particle Maker
description: Ordinarily, free protons - hydrogen atoms stripped of their electrons - are supplied to particle accelerators by a Cockcroft-Walton generator as much as three stories tall. The huge size of such generators limits their usefulness for cancer treatment and other applications.

title: SYBRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $521,000 for the qr and $3,001,000 for the yr, a gain of $1.5 million for the qr from the sale of the company's remaining interest in the Shinko-Pfaudler affiliate, reductions of $5.8 million for the qr and $6.2 million for the yr resulting from nonrecurr net charges for restructuring costs primarily involving instrum tion manufacturing operations in Europe and relocation expenses for the U.S. dental equipment and consumer products and an incr of $4.7 million for the yr from the sale of assets...C-Includin income from discontinued operations of $1,770,000 for the qr an $3,826,000 for the yr

title: City College Wins With 26-Point Streak
description: City College and Hunter advanced last night to the quarterfinal round of the City University Athletic Conference basketball tournament.

title: Commodity Fraud Cited
description: The huge growth in trading of such commodities as gold and crude oil has prompted widespread fraud that is beyond the reach of Federal regulators, according to a Congressional committee that will open hearings on the subject on Tuesday.

title: The Man With No P.A.C.
description: Walter Mondale has the Committee for the Future of America. Edward Kennedy calls his the Fund for a Democratic Majority. Ernest Hollings's ''friends'' have organized the Committee for a Competitive America.

title: DeLorean Gets $5 Million Loan
description: John Z. DeLorean, the founder of the DeLorean Motor Car Company, which has been taken over by the British Government, said he had borrowed $5 million from Citibank as part of a plan to keep his United States marketing company afloat.

title: Victims in 2 Incidents Fatally Stab Assailants
description: Two men, one attempting to commit a robbery and the other trying to break into an apartment, were fatally wounded by their would-be victims in separate incidents yesterday, the police reported.

title: YALE STUDENTS WORRY OVER RISING FEES
description: Pamela Grundy, a sophomore at Yale University, may drop out for a year to work. James and Ann Bethel, whose daughter has been accepted for admission in the fall, will sell a house. Daniel Arzuaga, a freshman, does not know what he will do. He can only pray the sun shines on his concession stand at Orchard Beach in the Bronx this summer.

title: MET MUSEUM OF ART DECIDES NOT TO SHOW EXHIBIT FROM ISRAEL
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has decided against a proposed archeological show from Israel as ''inappropriate'' because it would include material from the disputed West Bank, and would pose security problems for the museum.

title: The Bottom Line Is an Hourlong News Format; Plug for a News Format
description: If Fred W. Friendly was waxing eloquent yesterday, there was a reason. He was writing a speech. ''I've had a fire in my belly going on for a quarter of a century and I want to let that fire glow at Washington Square,'' said the former television news executive, who will deliver the 3d annual Chet Huntley Memorial Lecture at New York University on March 10.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What is the explanation for the ''green flash'' that is sometimes seen just as the sun sets at sea on a clear horizon?

title: POLITICOS ABET END RUNS AROUND THE RENT LAWS
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Using Debt To Lift Profits
description: SHAKESPEARE'S sage advice - ''Neither a borrower, nor a lender be'' - doesn't necessarily apply to corporations. ''History suggests that companies that use debt well will generally record the best share gains once Wall Street sees an improvement in the economy and begins buying stocks aggressively,'' says Donald W. Mitchell, president of the Mitchell Investment Management Company of Cambridge, Mass., which specializes in pension fund investment.

title: HESTON AWAITS ASNER'S REACTION TO PROTEST
description: Charlton Heston said he would not support a drive to remove Ed Asner, a champion of the rebels in El Salvador, as president of the Screen Actors Guild, but would wait to see how Mr. Asner reacted to ''the firestorm of protest that has sprung up.''

title: OPERA: NEW LEADS IN 'COSI FAN TUTTE'
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Cosi fan tutte'' gained a new pair of lovers Saturday night. Pilar Lorengar assumed the soprano role of Fiordiligi, and Lenus Carlson became Guglielmo.

title: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr include income equal to 18 cents a shr attributed to a change in accounting methods

title: DOTS POSE A BARRIER TO LEAKS
description: Fear stalks this city, fear of getting caught leaking a document. Or is it paranoia? Consider the recent release of President Reagan's proposed 1983 budget. It was preceded by the usual spate of leaks from one source or another unhappy with what the President had in mind for some favorite program. One such leak consisted of most of the budget for the Department of Health and Human Services. But it arrived with the tops and bottoms of every page clipped off.

title: HAIG FEARS EXILES FROM LATIN AREAS MAY FLOOD THE U.S.
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. told the nation's governors today that the United States might be flooded with refugees if radical trends in El Salvador and other countries were not stopped.

title: BRAUN ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PACER TECHNOLOGY & RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MAZZEI IS RENAMED COACH OF COSMOS
description: Julio Mazzei, the head coach of the Cosmos from 1979 until midseason in 1980, was reappointed to that position yesterday, but the team made it clear that his new tenure would be a brief one.

title: 2 Ford Locals Approve Pact With Concessions
description: Ford Motor Company workers in two United Automobile Workers locals have overwhelmingly approved a contract involving concessions on wages and benefits in return for increased job security.

title: THEY CAME HOME TO L.I.U.
description: The players took some strange detours before the nation's highestscoring college basketball team was assembled on the northwest corner of Flatbush and DeKalb Avenues -in the old Brooklyn Paramount Theater, where the biggest motion pictures played and Frank Sinatra sang in person.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
OAK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings figures and the number of shrs have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock distribution in Mar 1981

title: U.S. Merges Thrift Units
description: The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation last weekend merged three failing thrift institutions into the Talman Federal Savings and Loan Association of Chicago, and created a savings and loan with assets of almost $6.4 billion.

title: MET OPERA: A 'REQUIEM' FOR FRANCIS ROBINSON
description: VERDI'S Requiem may be most at home not in the concert hall or the church, but where it was Saturday afternoon, in the Metropolitan Opera House. It was a benefit performance in memory of Francis Robinson, who was intimately associated with the Met. He was the press and tour director, a guest on opera broadcasts, the host of ''Live From the Met'' telecasts, and he was affectionately known as ''Mr. Metropolitan.''

title: A FEDERAL VIEW OF NEW YORK'S CRIME PROBLEM
description: Rudolf W. Guiliani knows from investigative and personal experience the intractable problems of fighting crime in New York City.

title: UPJOHN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods include income of $5.3 million for the qr and $17.5 million for the yr from a change in accounting for the company's foreign operations a gain of $15.9 million for the qr from the sale of the company's clinical laboratory operations and a gain of $3.3 million for the qr from a legal judgment against one of the company's suppliers

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $5,000 for the latest first qr and $8,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: BLAIR, JOHN, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MEXICO HOPING U.S. BACKS PEACE PLAN
description: Senior Mexican officials said today that President Jose Lopez Portillo hoped that his Central American peace initiative would influence President Reagan's views on the region before his scheduled address to the Organization of American States Wednesday.

title: BEKINS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a pretax loss of $185,000 for the qr and a pretax gain of $1,239,000 for the yr on the sale of real estate and a tax credit of $500,000 for the yr related to the 1980 writeoff of motor carrier operating rights...C-After a charge of $1,504,000 for the qr and yr from the writeoff of motor carrier operating rights and a pretax gain of $1,612,000 for the qr and yr from the sale of real estate

title: SUPREME COURT OVERTURNS NEW YORK OIL-TAX RULING
description: The United States Supreme Court overturned today a ruling by a Federal appeals court that had invalidated a key section of New York State's tax on oil companies' receipts.

title: WINGED BEAN HAILED AS A POTENT WEAPON AGAINST MALNUTRITION
description: THE winged bean, a plant virtually unknown six years ago, has definitely taken off. It is now being grown in more than 70 countries. A thousand researchers in more than 60 countries receive The Winged Bean Flyer, a newsletter established to keep scientists abreast of the rapid developments concerning this seeingly miraculous plant. The highly nutritious crop promises to become the soybean of the tropics, where it alone may do more than any combination of foods to counter malnutrition.

title: Accounts
description: * Toshiba America Inc., Tustin, Calif., to N.W. Ayer Inc., Los Angeles, for their line of office copiers.

title: CUOMO VOWS 'FRIENDLY' RUN AGAINST KOCH FOR STATEHOUSE
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that his rematch with Mayor Koch would be comparatively inexpensive and ''friendly,'' would go beyond the state's Democratic Convention into a primary and would end differently from last time.

title: Bridge: A Psychologist Who Plays May Be Better at His Work
description: The bridge community in New York City has included a handful of players who survived the Nazi concentration camps in World War II. This small band was diminished last month with the death of Otto Feuer, a bridge analyst of considerable distinction. He contributed two entertaining articles to the magazine Bridge World, recounting some of the clinical experiences of a certain ''Dr. Downone, bridge psychiatrist.''

title: MUSIC: BACH CELLO SUITES PERFORMED BY YO YO MA
description: IN his recital in Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon, Yo-Yo Ma's approach to two Bach solo Cello Suites was almost conversational. But his was the sort of conversation that immediately went to the heart of the matter, making the subject appear so simple and elegant that appreciative silence was the best response.

title: Norwegian Triumphs
description: Berit Aunli of Norway today won her second gold medal of the world Nordic skiing championships by taking the women's 5-kilometer cross-country race.

title: Hanoi Says U.S. Exploits Issue of Missing G.I.'s
description: Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam said today that the United States was using the issue of missing servicemen as a ''political weapon'' and he threatened not to cooperate in the search for them.

title: LOWENSTEIN, M, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After gain of $1,189,000 from lower 1981 effective tax rate than estimates used in the first three qr and a charge of $697, from adoption in the fourth qr of LIFO and the new F.A.S.B. rul for translation of foreign currency...C-After charge of $1,498, or 45 cents a shr from adoption of LIFO and new F.A.S.B. rules. D-After gain of $1,172,000 or 32 cents a shr from the sale of t plants and closing of a third plant

title: MOST NATIONS REJECT ROLE IN SALVADOR ELECTION
description: Despite strong United States lobbying efforts abroad, only a few of the 60 nations that have received invitations from the Salvadoran Government have agreed to send observers to an election for a constituent assembly on March 28.

title: 'A PEACEFUL TOWN' IN JERSEY MOURNS SLAYINGS OF 2 OF ITS 'BEST LITTLE GIRLS'
description: Jennifer Hanna and Heather Tranter were bright and happy second graders and inseparable friends. They rode the bus to Durban Avenue School together, went to meetings of Brownie Troop 341 together and played together in the woods and gullies near their homes here.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: G EOFFREY BEENE did not want dessert. No, he said, in his Louisiana drawl, he did not want the chocolate mousse, not the torte, nor the tart, and no part of the pie. No, thank you, just coffee; he wanted to talk. He had just returned from a three-day stint at Neiman-Marcus in Houston where he had staged fashion shows (known in the business as trunk shows), and returned to report that the troubled economy hasn't affected his business, at least not yet anyway. Over $289,000 worth of his clothing was sold to the fashion-conscious, well-heeled women of Houston.

title: British Retail Sales
description: Britain's retail sales index rose a seasonally adjusted 2.3 percent, to a provisional 107 in January, from a revised 104.6 in December, the Department of Trade said today.

title: WTC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-After a loss of $2,259,000 from discontinued operations; yr-ago results were restated

title: CABARET: LEE ROY BROWN
description: THE musical ''42d Street'' is playing in a theater on West 44th Street, and a new cabaret, Broadway, opened last week on West 43d Street. But, despite the misleading addresses, Lee Roy Reams, who is starring in the musical, managed to find his way to the cabaret to do three post-theater performances last weekend, performances that he will repeat this Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

title: AS TRADE FRICTIONS MOUNT, NEW JOURNAL GIVES JAPAN'S SIDE
description: During the past couple of weeks, 17,000 foreign government officials, politicians, corporate executives and other socalled opinion leaders, mostly in the United States and Western Europe, have received a glossy new magazine.

title: TV: 'IVANHOE' IN 3-HOUR PRODUCTION
description: IF Sir Walter Scott had been a television film maker - which, as discriminating members of the audience for tonight's ''Ivanhoe'' may remember, he was not -who knows that he wouldn't have come up with something as colorful as this production? A little on the long side -it runs three hours, beginning at 8 P.M. on CBS-TV, this ''Ivanhoe'' is still lavish and bright.

title: ACKLANDS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1982; Energy
description: Iran cut its oil price by $2 a barrel, the third reduction in three weeks, to $30.20 a barrel, according to buyers of Iranian crude. Analysts said that Iran, which is now undercutting its OPEC-based price by $4, is posing a sharp challenge to OPEC's presumed primacy in setting prices. (Page A1.)

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF SURGEON GENERAL'S REPORT ON SMOKING
description: Following are some highlights of the Surgeon General's Report on Smoking:

title: Snowstorm Traps Italians
description: The police rescued scores of snowbound drivers and put them up in barracks overnight in this southern town as many parts of Italy had their lowest temperatures this winter. Abandoned trucks blocked part of the highway between Salerno and Reggio Calabria after snowstorms along the Appennine Mountain chain.

title: ADVANCED PATENT TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: AROUND THE NATION; National Radio Ends U.P.I. Merger Talks

title: Car Dealers Decline by 984
description: The number of dealerships in the nation selling American automobiles fell by 984 last year as sales slumped to their lowest level in 20 years, the trade newspaper Automotive News reported today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp. said it had agreed with Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group to issue about 280,000 shares of common stock and to exchange them for up to $20 million principal amount of American Hospital Supply's 7 7/8 percent debentures held by Merrill Lynch.

title: DANCE: RIVERSIDE FEATURES 3 UNFAMILIAR CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: FEELING tired of the same old faces in dance, one can always seek out new ones simply by attending the hit-or-miss novice-choreographer evenings that crop up at the Riverside Dance Festival.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON CHOOSES PRESIDENT
description: Clifford R. Meyer, 58 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Cincinnati Milacron Inc., the country's leading manufacturer of machine tools with close to $1 billion in sales last year. As president, he succeeds James A.D. Geier, 56, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the company.

title: DIVERSITY FOR SUMMER NIGHTS
description: Grand or simple. Elegant or casual. Sleek and glittery or sweet and ruffled. Clothes to wear on summer evenings come in all these modes -and then some. They are as uncomplicated as a dimity print cotton camisole worn with a flouncy matching skirt or as structured as a ball gown with balloon sleeves, tiny waistline and bouffant skirt propped by petticoats.

title: ZIMMER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that the shr earnings reflect a 9-to-5 stock split paid in Jan 1982

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $3 million from discontinued operations

title: Baldwin's AMIC Must Be Divested
description: The Justice Department filed court papers to allow the Baldwin-United Corporation of Cincinnati to acquire the MGIC Investment Corporation.

title: CAPUTO ASSERTS ARMY REMARK WAS A MISTAKE
description: In his first public appearance since newspaper accounts that he had inaccurately described himself as a former ''draftee'' and Army lieutenant, Bruce M. Caputo apologized yesterday.

title: SENECA OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; 1980 results have been restated

title: Nico Castel Performs In 'Hebraic Tradition'
description: The Western musical tradition is considered such a secular achievement that it is easy to forget its deep roots in Christian ceremony and liturgy. Even the concert-hall situation has echoes of religious ritual; Virgil Thomson has reminded us that opera is often a dramatic reworking of the mass.

title: PRINCE STARS UNKNOWEN IN MUSICAL 'A DOLL'S LIFE'
description: Harold Prince has signed an unknown, Betsy Joslyn, to star in his new production, ''A Doll's Life.'' The musical, which has book and lyrics by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, and music by Larry Grossman, is a kind of sequel to Ibsen's ''A Doll's House'': it concerns what happens to the main character, Nora - to be played by Miss Joslyn - after she closes the door on her husband at the end of that play.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WAKING. By Eva Figes. 88 pages. Pantheon, $ 7.95.

title: CASTLE, A M, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The U.N. Today; Feb. 23, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Commission on International Trade Law, Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: RULES ARE TIGHTENED FOR METS
description: The 28 Mets who assembled at the Payson Complex today for the first spring workout found that their new manager, George Bamberger, had some new rules and routines.

title: 7 NUCLEAR UTILITIES MISS DEADLINE
description: Nunzio J. Palladino, chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said today that seven utilities had failed to meet the commission's deadline this month for installing emergency warning systems and that escalating fines would be imposed starting March 1.

title: HOSPITAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WHAT'S ON
description: Following are the formats of the main radio stations heard in the New York City area: WADO-AM: a Spanish-language music station. WBAI-FM: a noncommercial listener-supported station, with predominantly talk.

title: Workers Buy Company
description: Employees and retired workers of the National Freight Company, Britain's largest highway-freight concern, bought the business from the Government today for $101 million. Some 10,000 of the company's employees joined with the retirees to raise the money and take advantage of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's policy of returning Government-owned companies to private ownership.

title: Icing a Winning Record
description: John MacInnes, the coach with the most victories in the history of college hockey, said he would resign at Michigan Tech at season's end. In 26 seasons there, his record shows 552 victories, 293 defeats and 38 ties.

title: TIME FOR A MASSIVE SALE OF FEDERAL ASSETS
description: To the Editor:

title: SINGER PLANT CLOSING: A WAY OF LIFE ENDS
description: The Singer Company is closing its mammoth plant here. Moving on to a marketing strategy of more costeffective foreign production and diversification in aerospace products, it is finished with this aging city now.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1982
description: International United States plans for the Caribbean were stressed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. He warned American governors that this country might be flooded with refugees if radical trends in El Salvador and other countries were not halted. President Reagan will present the Administration's program to enhance the security and well-being of the Caribbean area in a speech to the Organizaton of Amerian States that is set for tomorrow. (Page A1, Column 6.) Stepped-up peacekeeping in Lebanon is expected to be approved by the Security Council, according to United Nations officials. They said the Council was set to approve plans to send 1,000 more troops to join the 6,000-member force from 11 countries. The peacekeepers are stationed in southern Lebanon as a shield against Palestinian guerrilla raids that could provoke a new invasion by Israel. (A1:3.)

title: CONWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $175,000 for the qr and $1,136,000 for the yr...C-Including income of $642,000 from discontinued operations

title: MUSIC: GIELEN CONDUCTS CINCINNATI SYMPHONY
description: MICHAEL GIELEN became music director of the Cincinnati Symphony two seasons ago, but last night in Carnegie Hall he led his first New York concert with the orchestra.

title: Players Tied to Loans
description: At least three players on New York Tech's 1979-80 basketball team reportedly received cash from Sam Stern, the athletic director and at that time the coach. The Long Island newspaper Newsday, which reported the payments, said the players were Kelvin Hicks, Larry McCardin and Mike Roberts, members of a squad that reached the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division II tournament.

title: SALVADOR MAY USE NON-U.S. ADVISERS
description: The Salvadoran Minister of Defense said today that there were no foreign military men helping his troops except for American advisers, but he said it was possible he would ask for such assistance from ''Argentina and other countries.''

title: REALIST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the last two months of 1981 include operations of Blount Electronics

title: Advertising; Who Tops Ad Agency Mergers?
description: TED BATES/WORLDWIDE, fifth largest throughout the globe among American agencies, is very eager to be known as the agency that made the biggest acquisition in agency history.

title: CARNATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: FRIEND OF EXTREMISM IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: To the Editor:

title: ESTERLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to exclude foreign currency translation adjustments in accordance with F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results reflect the acquisition of Huck Manufacturing Co in Aug 1980

title: 13.04 DROP PUTS DOW AT 811.26
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 13 points yesterday in heavy trading, to 811.26, its lowest level since May 1980. Most Wall Street professionals were surprised because the accepted wisdom had been that falling interest rates would touch off a rally in the recently faltering stock market.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW MEXICO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERTHERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income for the latest yr reflects a loss equal to 7 cents a shr in income taxes resulting from increased tax credits and adjustments

title: CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BARNES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Immigration Chief Sworn In
description: Alan Nelson was sworn in today as head of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, becoming the agency's first permanent director in two and a half years. Attorney General William French Smith administered the oath to Mr. Nelson, a former lawyer for the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company in San Francisco. Mr. Nelson is the first permanent commissioner of the service since October 1979, when Leonel J. Castillo resigned.

title: A THIRD PANEL SEEKS CITIBANK REPORTS
description: The House Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs subcommittee today asked C. Todd Conover, the Comptroller of the Currency, for information about his office's investigation into Citibank's foreign exchange trading.

title:
MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
Three Swedish Pianists Pool Keyboard Talents
description: Three performers with ties to Sweden pooled their talents on Saturday evening in an unusual program of keyboard music in Alice Tully Hall. The three - Staffan Scheja, Ragnar Grippe and Michael Smith - were all identified as pianists, even though the principal activity of the latter two seems to be composition. Mr. Grippe, in fact, never touched the piano during the concert; he occupied himself with an instrument called the Synclavier II, a computerized synthesizer keyboard that resembled, from a distance, a small electric organ.

title: BLISS, A T, & CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
BROWN OF YANKS LOSES PAY CASE, SEEKS A TRADE
description: The Yankees today won the Bobby Brown salary arbitration case to go with their victories involving Ron Davis and Dave Revering, giving them the most successful arbitration record of any team.

title: Scherwood & Schneider
description: Scherwood & Schneider has been agency for Parr Securities Discount Brokers for a couple of months, and has even run advertising for it. But only now has it announced a new account. Billings for the year sould come to $1 million.

title: American Air Reports Loss
description: American Airlines Inc., continuing to feel the impact of a soft economy and declining air traffic, reported yesterday that it lost $20.3 million in last year's fourth quarter, substantially narrower than its $61.5 million loss in the similar 1980 quarter.

title: TANZANIAN MILITARY ADVISERS WILL BE SENT TO MOZAMBIQUE
description: Tanzania has promised to send military advisers to neighboring Mozambique, where they will replace some Soviet personnel, according to military sources here.

title: The Quiz Kid
description: The Presidential news conference inevitably includes an element of quiz-show suspense. ''Stump the President,'' it might be called: can he display amazing factual mastery over the most complex or trivial subjects? Can the questioners trip him up on issues that any President ought to know about?

title: Soviet Expected to Rule On Pentecostals' Visas
description: Soviet officials are expected to rule by late March on emigration applications of Lidiya Vashchenko and other family members living in Siberia, a sister said today.

title: SELL AND LEASE BACK
description: How many times have New Yorkers smiled over the story about the rube who returns to his hometown from a visit and proudly displays his deed to the Brooklyn Bridge?

title: WILLIAMS, IN ATLANTA, TESTIFIES IN HIS OWN DEFENSE
description: Wayne B. Williams, asserting that he was ''scared,'' took the stand in his own defense this afternoon and said, ''I haven't killed anybody, or thought about it, or plan on even thinking about killing nobody.''

title: FOSTER WHEELER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $3,961,884 for the qr and yr from the sale of a Panama City plant; rev figures represent billings

title: PROPOSED FOOD STAMP CUTS ARE ASSAILED
description: President Reagan's proposals for further reductions in social welfare programs, especially food stamps, ran into heavy criticism on Capitol Hill today, with the Roman Catholic Church joining academic experts and a prominent Republican Senator in expressing doubts about some of the Reagan proposals.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: KNICKS READY TO OFFER WESTPHAL $150,000 FOR REST OF SEASON
description: Paul Westphal, the free-agent guard, is expected to sign an offer sheet with the Knicks today, according to a source close to the negotiations. Under the National Basketball Association's right-offirst-refusal rule, the Seattle SuperSonics, Westphal's last team, have the opportunity to retain him by matching the Knicks' offer.

title: PROPOSAL TO LIFT GAS PRICE TO BE STUDIED
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is expected to take up at a meeting on March 10 a proposal for raising the price of ''old'' natural gas by perhaps as much as two-thirds.

title: 15 DIE IN TEHERAN BOMB BLAST
description: Fifteen Iranians were killed and 60 wounded by a bomb that exploded today in the center of Teheran, the Iranian state radio reported.

title: HARNISCHFEGER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a change in the method of accounting for compensated absences

title: Englishwoman Wins Blackburn Play Prize
description: Nell Dunn, an Englishwoman, has won the $2,000 1981 Susan Smith Blackburn Prize for the female writer of ''a work of outstanding quality for the English-speaking theater'' for her first play, ''Steaming.'' The drama is running in London.

title: CGA COMPUTER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Net income; results reflect accounting on a purchase basis for an acquisition

title: McKeon New N.Y.R.A. Head
description: Gerard J. McKeon, an auditor who rose through the corporate ranks, was named president of the New York Racing Association yesterday. The N.Y.R.A., the non-profit trusteeship that operates Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga Race Track, had interviewed ''more than a dozen'' candidates for the job, according to Ogden Mills Phipps, the chairman of the board. Mr. Phipps has been acting president since the resignation Jan.1 of James P. Heffernan, who left for a job with General Instrument, a computer-technology concern.

title: Saddled
description: ''It couldn't have been me speaking - it was too clear,'' Secretary of State Haig said the other day. He was responding to a Washington Post report of comments he had made at a score of confidential staff meetings.

title: 1.55 Million Abortions Reported in 1980
description: By United Press International Some 1.55 million legal abortions were performed in the United States in 1980, ending about one of every four pregnancies, the Alan Guttmacher Institute reported yesterday in its seventh annual abortion survey.

title: Sergio Jeans to Altman
description: Englishtown Sportswear, which says that last year it put $12 million behind advertising its Sergio Valente jeans, has just assigned its jeans advertising to Altman, Stoller, Weiss, which has not turned out any jeans advertising for three years since Blue Bell moved out with Wrangler. The previous agency was Fischer Lewandowski, Ltd.

title: GAMEX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Article 251218 -- No Title
description: Six Eurobonds totaling $600 million were issued today, one of the largest daily volumes in the past year. Hiram Walker, Citicorp, the European Investment Bank, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, Canadair and Occidental Petroleum all floated current coupon dollar bonds.

title: Sine Nomine Singers Mix Sacred and Profane
description: It takes a fair amount of daring to program a mass by Obrecht on the same program with a scatological canon by Mozart and a drinking ditty by Brahms. But Harry Saltzman, leading his Sine Nomine Singers, did all that and more Saturday night in the Merkin Concert Hall; the 24 singers brought to each work a sense of style, poise and energy.

title: A RHODES SCHOLAR AT ONLY 18
description: Nina Teresa Morishige, the Japanese-American mathematical genius who, at age 18, is among the youngest students to win a Rhodes Scholarship, has worked her way through an impressive list of honors, academic and other, during her four undergraduate semesters here at Johns Hopkins University.

title: AMERICAN STERILIZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BETHLEHEM STEEL HIRES OUTSIDER FOR NEW UNIT
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has established a new business unit, the Bethlehem Supply divison, to provide products and services to the oilfield industry, and it has hired James M. Gordon Jr., 51, as its president. The division - which emerged from Bethlehem's longexisting activities in such products as pipe and pumping units - will be based in Tulsa, Okla., and will join five other separate corporate operations formed in recent months.

title: Transit Report
description: L.I.R.R.: Of 134 trains scheduled during yesterday morning's rush hour, 10 were reported late and none were canceled. The average delay was 7.2 minutes, with the longest delay on the 8:11 from Babylon, which ran 10 minutes late. Yesterday afternoon, the 3:53 from Long Beach derailed just east of the Long Beach trestle.

title: BALLY'S PARK PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New York Agency In Movie Location Drive
description: In such trade publications as Millimeter, Variety, On Location, Backstage and The Hollywood Reporter, various states and cities are running ads in hopes of luring motion picture and television commercial production, which are part of an historically important industry in New York.

title: Woman Hit by Baseball Loses in Appeals Court
description: The Michigan Court of Appeals today reversed a jury award of $258,850 for an injury suffered by a woman who said she had been hit by a baseball during a game at Tiger Stadium.

title: THIRD-WORLD ECONOMIC STAFF URGED
description: President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania appealed to the world's developing countries today to establish a technical secretariat that would marshal data and direct strategies to win concessions from the industrialized nations on the restructuring of international economic relations.

title: SAN DIEGO PLAYERS VOTE CANCELLATION AND FREEZE
description: To save the San Diego Symphony from bankruptcy, the musicians have voted to cancel the orchestra's six-week summer season and freeze their salaries.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE United States suffers from a serious depletion of expertise on Soviet and East European affairs. The Soviet Union is estimated to have three times as many academic specialists examining American foreign policy as the United States has engaged in the study of Soviet foreign policy.

title: OFFENDING CAPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH COURT WILL LET DEAF LAWYER UTILIZE VIDEO DISPLAY TUBE
description: The Supreme Court, bending its own rules, announced today that it would allow a deaf lawyer to set up a special computer-assisted system in the courtroom to enable him to argue a case later this year.

title: AN EMPHASIS ON EXCELLENCE
description: WHILE students at many high schools consider research nothing more than copying a few paragraphs from an encyclopedia, youngsters at Stuyvesant High School and the Bronx High School of Science learn early that it is a process of painstaking discovery that may mean weeks of effort simply to identify a topic worth investigating.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aamco Transmissions Inc., Bridgeport, Pa., has appointed Eileen Courtney general counsel.

title: PRESCRIPTION DRUGS ARE ADVERTISED TO PATIENTS, BREAKING WITH TRADITION
description: IN a radical departure from traditional practices that bears wide implications for the patient-doctor relationship, at least two drug companies have begun to promote prescription items directly to patients, with the blessing of the Federal Food and Drug Administration. Until now, prescription drugs have been heavily advertised, but only to the medical profession.

title: VIDEO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After provision of $820,000 for discontinuance of direct mail distribution operation...C-Net income

title: AMERICAN SOLAR KING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PAN AM CHIEF PREDICTS LOSSES MAY END IN 1982
description: Pan American World Airways, which has been losing about $1 million a day, has a chance to break even and perhaps report an operating profit this year, C. Edward Acker, chairman and chief executive officer, predicted yesterday.

title: NEWFOUNDLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
HELEN RUTH HENDERSON
description: Helen Ruth Henderson, the second woman to serve in the Virginia House of Delegates, the retired executive secretary of the International Division of the Girl Scouts of America, died Saturday. She was 83 years old.

title: G.M. to Cut Unit
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would phase out its Oldsmobile division forging facility here, resulting in the indefinite layoff of 320 hourly and salaried workers.

title: IOWA SOUTHERN UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WHITE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Salem, Mass., Drifter Held in Fire Attempt
description: A 24-year-old drifter was arrested today in connection with an attempt to set fire to a Salem police station on the same night the National Guard armory and the Masonic Temple in this historic seaport were destroyed by fire.

title: Harvester Sells Stake in Komatsu
description: The financially troubled International Harvester Company said it had sold its 50 percent share in the Komatsu International Manufacturing Company in Japan to Komatsu Ltd., its partner in the venture, for about $51 million in cash.

title: COMMODITY WATCHDOG CRITICIED
description: Members of a Senate subcommitee urged today that the states be allowed to take over many of the enforcement powers of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which, they said, has failed to protect investors from deceptive sales practices and commodity-related investment fraud schemes.

title: Market Place; Semiconductor Maker's Goals
description: ANALOG DEVICES INC. stumbled badly in 1981, interrupting a fiveyear history of impressive earnings growth. But the company's fans think it has begun to emerge from the recession while most other semiconductor makers are still in the doldrums.

title: ACME UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: REGIONAL TRUCKERS DEBATE LABOR COSTS
description: Frederick Reed, who has driven trucks for Hemingway Transport Inc. for 23 years, recently got a letter from Richard E. Edwards, the company's president and chief executive officer.

title: P.L.O., TAKE THE STEP
description: If the Palestine Liberation Organization refuses to join the diplomatic game for the West Bank soon, there may be no game to play.

title: HUMAN-IMMUNOLOGY PIONEER
description: Dr. Edward C. Franklin, professor of medicine at the New York University School of Medicine and an international authority on the human immune system, died Saturday at New York University Medical Center after a long illess. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: KELSEY-HAYES CANADA LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 split in July 1981

title: JET AMERICA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-There are no comparable year-ago results because the airline started operations in November 1981

title: REPUBLIC FINANCIAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INVENTING ECONOMIC SOLUTIONS
description: The time has come for a wage-price freeze, to be immediately followed by a new, long-term system for negotiating wage norms on a national rather than industry-by-industry basis.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
'Onion Field' Killer Paroled in California
description: A killer whose case inspired the book and movie ''The Onion Field,'' was paroled from Soledad Prison today.

title: INTERMOUNTAIN GAS INDUSTRIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JEWISH GROUPS PROTEST DECISION OF THE MET
description: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith yesterday called the Metropolitan Museum of Art's decision not to display an exhibition of Jewish, Christian and Islamic artifacts a ''regrettable and indefensible action.''

title: AMERICAN BROADCASTING COS INC (ABC) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
APPEALS PANEL UPHOLDS TRIAL BAN ON STATEMENTS MADE BY HINCKLEY
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld a lower court's ruling forbidding the Government to use statements by John W. Hinckley Jr. as evidence at his trial for shooting President Reagan. The court said the information had been obtained unconstitutionally.

title: KAY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Track Star's Setback
description: Joao Carlos de Oliveira of Brazil, the holder of the world record in the triple jump, may have to have his right leg amputated below the knee. De Oliveira's problems began with an automobile accident last Dec. 22 in which he was severely injured. Resulting complications caused infection, and doctors, who are planning surgery at Irmeas Penteado Hospital in Campinas, Brazil, in an effort to save the leg, say the threat of gangrene remains constant.

title: CALLAHAN MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Q&A
description: IN response to a reader's inquiry about something called monkey bread, I pointed out that it is the hard-shelled, fleshy fruit of an African tree known as the baobab. I added that I was not aware of an actual bread by that name. Numerous readers wrote and telephoned to point out that there is, indeed, a loaf known as monkey bread, made with yeast and filled with currants.

title: MISGUIDED EFFORTS TO CURB FEDERAL COURTS
description: To the Editor:

title: USAir to Buy 10 Boeing Planes
description: USAir has taken options on 10 additional fuel-efficient Boeing 737-300 aircraft, bringing to 30 the number of planes it expects to purchase over the next six years, the airline announced.

title: Co-op City Gets Back Heat and Hot Water
description: Heat began returning slowly for the nearly 60,000 residents of Coop City in the northeast Bronx at about 6:30 A.M. yesterday, according to Milton Present, assistant general manager of Riverbay Corporation, which runs the development. Full heat service was back later in the day.

title: DEMOCRAT SAYS HE'S CANDIDATE FOR O'NEILL SEAT
description: Setting the stage for a challenge to Gov. William A. O'Neill, Ernest N. Abate, the Speaker of the State House of Representatives, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: SUIT FILED TO BLOCK MARATHON TAKEOVER
description: The Dreyfus Corporation, the holder of some $50 million of Marathon Oil Company stock on behalf of investors, filed suit yesterday to block Marathon's acquisition by the United States Steel Corporation on the ground that the terms are unfavorable.

title: The Talk of Northwest Jersey
description: Not long after the Vernon Valley and Great Gorge ski areas opened about a decade ago, Lois and Wheymer South sold their 30 milking cows and all but five of the 130 acres on their farm.

title: TRANSCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Mayoral Hopeful
description: It's official: Patricia Roberts Harris is a candidate for mayor of the District of Columbia. A week after a fund-raising committee was formed in her name, Mrs. Harris said yesterday that she would run in the Democratic mayoral primary set for Sept. 14.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $111,000 for the quarter and $269,000 for the year; C-Including a tax credit of $131,000; share earnings and shares outstanding giveeffect to the 3-for-2 stock split on Feb 19, 1982

title: DRUMMOND MCCALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter reflect a change to FASB Statement 52 regarding accounting for foreign currency translations; share earnings reflect a 5% stock dividend in July

title: GOLDWATER AND JANE FONDA LEAD CIVIL LIBERTIES RALLY
description: Norman Lear, the television producer, put Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona and Jane Fonda, the actress who is a liberal activist, on the same stage Monday night in a celebration of American civil liberties aimed indirectly at the nation's religious right.

title: UGANDAN GUERILLAS ATTACK ARMY BARRACKS IN KAMPALA
description: Anti-government guerrillas, said to be supported by Libya, were reported today to have attacked the main army barracks in Kampala, the Ugandan capital.

title: Ignoring Kids With Kids
description: Society pays a high price for adolescent childbearing. Experts estimate the financial cost of the resulting dependency and welfare at more than $5 billion a year. Sex counseling, adoption and abortion services can help. Unfortunately, the proposed 1983 Federal budget makes the task of providing that kind of help more difficult.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a nonrecurring net charge of $134.3 million related to the restructuring and planned sale of certain operations

title: UNCLE SAM SQUEALS
description: The story: The Reagan Administration has issued a new rule stating that if persons under 18 obtain birth-control devices the Federal Government must send a note home to their parents.

title: Pritzker Interests' Masonite Stake
description: Interests of the Pritzker family have purchased about 10 percent of the stock in the Masonite Corporation for investment purposes, a family spokesman said.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: AND-ROLL isn't always a matter of big bucks, arenas full of screaming teen-agers, smoke bombs and hundred-thousand-dollar stage sets. The music first flourished in the 1950's in juke joints and seedy rundown theaters, and when a modern rock-and-roll band connects with its own special audience in the sweaty dance-rock clubs that are the modern-day jukes joints, special things can happen.

title: IU INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $3 million for quarter and $847,000 for year and extraordinary gain of $12,640,000 for year; C-After loss of $2,315,000 for quarter and gain of $7,133,000 for year from discontinued operations, gain of $96,146,000 for year on disposal of discontinued operations, extraordinary losses of $39,000 for quarter and $31,319,000 for year and loss of $3,318,000 for quarter and year from cumulative effect of change in accounting principles

title: WHY LIONEL SOUGHT CHAPTER 11 SHELTER
description: The Lionel Corporation, which has concentrated on toy retailing ever since selling its well-known train business more than 10 years ago, was apparently forced into bankruptcy proceedings last week because of poor store locations, ill-timed acquisitions and marketing mistakes.

title: Michel Panaieff, 69, Teacher And Dancer for Ballet Russe
description: Michel Panaieff, ballet dancer and teacher, died of cancer Feb. 8 in Los Angeles, where he had a ballet studio. He was 69 years old. Mr. Panaieff, born in Novogorad, began to dance seriously in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, where his family had emigrated from Russia.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alpine Geophysical Corp. said it had acquired Precision Products Inc. of North Haven, Conn. for about $3 million, including $2.8 million in cash and debentures and 50,000 shares of Alpine common stock.

title: STOCK INDEX FUTURES TO START TRADING
description: The Kansas City Board of Trade, a small commodities exchange that has only traded hard red winter wheat, has been waiting for tomorrow for the past four and a half years.

title: Phillips Forms Merger Team
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, a rumored takeover candidate, said it had formed a special management team to monitor and make preparations for ''any takeover bid that might occur.''

title: INSTACOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Leach Seeks Trade
description: After eight years with the Philadelphia Flyers, Reggie Leach has asked to be traded. Leach, a 31-year-old wing, scored 45 goals for the Flyers in 1974-75 and 61 in 1975-76, when he led the National Hockey League.

title: KELLOGG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AERO-FLOW DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXPER TIES BOTH OF VICTIM'S COMAS TO INSULIN
description: One of the country's leading experts on blood sugar reviewed more than two years of Martha von Bulow's medical records and said today that both her comas had been caused by injections of insulin.

title: ISRAELI PARLIAMENT TAKES UP THE FOREIGN-PRESS ISSUE
description: The Israeli Parliament took up the question today of intimidation of Western journalists by Palestinian and Syrian terrorists in Beirut and Damascus.

title: SUSPECT IN ATLANTA MURDERS ANGRILY DECLEARES INNOCENCE
description: Wayne B. Williams today angrily turned back attempts by prosecutors to shake his story, lashing out at his accusers and declaring: ''I'm innocent, and that's all there is to it.''

title: AMISH MUST PAY SOCIAL SECURITY TAXES FOR THEIR EMPLOYEES
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that members of the Old Order Amish Church who operate businesses must pay the Social Security and unemployment taxes required of all employers, despite their religious belief that paying the taxes is a sin.

title: KOCH, IN INTERVIEW DISPARAGED THE LIFE OF THE SUBURBANITE
description: Mayor Koch, who announced his candidacy for Governor on Monday with a pledge to represent New York State's urban, rural and suburban interests equally, has declared in a published interview that life in the suburbs is ''sterile.''

title: EXOTIC VEGETARIAN DISHES FROM THE EAST
description: THE most obscure herbs, spices and exotic produce are taken for granted these days. There is hardly a recipe for which the right ingredient cannot be found somewhere in the city. And the easy access to foods both new and long-neglected means that meals are becoming more creative, and so are some cookbooks.

title: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1982; The Economy
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress he still had doubts about President Reagan's economic program. He said that even if budget deficits were held within current projections, there would be some question whether a sustained recovery was possible. He advised further spending cuts, possibly in the military sector, or deferring the last year of Mr. Reagan's tax cut. (Page D11.) G.O.P. Congressional leaders told the President that his 1983 budget proposal was dead and that they would draft an alternative with the Democrats. (A1.)

title: LIBERALS' CHAIRMAN ASSAILS KOCH, WHO RECALLS A '77 ELECTION 'SLUR'
description: The New York State chairman of the Liberal Party criticized Mayor Koch yesterday, jeopardizing the Mayor's chances for a party endorsement of his candidacy for Governor.

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A MEDICAID TAKEOVER WILL WEAKEN THE 'NET'
description: Though the nation's governors told President Reagan on Monday that they would accept a full Federal takeover of Medicaid, the President ought to reconsider his position.

title: CHRISTIE'S IN MAJOR WINE SALE
description: Christie's, the auction house, plans to offer the wine collection of the late Dr. George H. Resek for sale April 17 in Chicago. The collection, consisting of some 2,300 bottles, is believed to be one of the most important to come on the market in the United States in recent years.

title: D'Arcy Names New Chairman
description: Alvin Hampel, who has long yearned to move formally from the creative side of the agency world to business side, is going to be doing it in a big way next Wednesday when he becomes chairman of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York, which bills about $80 million. He will be replacing John Jay deGarmo, 57 years old, who has been chairman since D'Arcy acquired his deGarmo agency, with its $60 million in billings, in January 1980. Mr. deGarmo resigned.

title: BIRD WATCHERS ALIGHT IN MORNING CHILL - FOR THE LOVE OF IT
description: DAWN didn't crack one recent frigid Saturday - it peeped briefly through the clouds and went back to bed. The dozen bird watchers huddled on Long Island's easternmost tip were not so lazy. Up since 5:45 A.M., they continued to scan the frigid Atlantic from their windswept perch at the foot of the Montauk Point lighthouse.

title: IN ENGLAND, CHEF BROTHERS GET 3RD
description: STAR By R.W. APPLE Jr. LONDON THEY come from Charolles, a small town in the hills of central France. As youngsters, they tasted the superb gastronomic specialties of the surrounding region - Charolais beef, Beaujolais and Burgundy wines, Bresse chickens, Auvergne cheeses.

title: Tennessee Bank Fails
description: The Bank of Yorkville in Tennessee has failed and its deposits of $6.5 million and 1,560 accounts have been assumed by the First Citizens National Bank, Dyersburg, Tenn., the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reports. It was the nation's fourth bank failure this year.

title: E.P.A. HOT LINE ANSWERS QUESTIONS ABOUT PESTICIDES
description: From his storefront office Tony Mollhagen counsels anxious pregnant women, backyard gardeners and worried farmers.

title: NO PENALTIES FOR 1,000 STRIKERS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, acting on orders from Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis, has abandoned plans to discipline hundreds of air traffic controllers who struck briefly last summer but then complied with President Reagan's back-to-work order.

title: INTER-REGIONAL FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc on Dec 31, 1981

title: E-H INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Israel Allocates Funds to Pay Settlers Leaving Sinai Homes
description: The Israeli Government approved plans today to add $2.3 billion to the budget for the current fiscal year. Cabinet officials said the extra allocation was to cover a rise in food subsidies, civil service wage increases and higher compensation for settlers scheduled to evacuate Sinai next month under the peace treaty with Egypt.

title: THE DEPRESSION SHAPES A VIEW OF MONEY
description: FOR 25 years my mother worked as a clerk in the New York Public Library. In addition, two nights a week she taught English to foreigners at a high school in Manhattan. On Mondays and Wednesdays she left the house at 8:30 in the morning and got home after 10:30 at night. After answering questions all day at the Inquiry Desk at the 42d Street Library, where at least she could sit down most of the time, she was on her feet in the classroom for three hours, coaxing, cajoling, encouraging a group of eager immigrants: 20-year-old Ecuadorean villagers, quick learners who would soon be running art galleries on Madison Avenue; Polish grandmothers who would return shyly to her beginners' class year after year.

title: BANK TRIES TO TURN MARKET FORECASTING INTO SCIENCE
description: At Chemical Bank, specialists are trying their best to make real estate a science. The result is a new set of predictions for what is likely to happen in commercial and residential real estate in 15 cities across the country. In the real estate industry, where analysis of market conditions has traditionally been based in large part on intuition, Chemical's work will surely stir debate.

title: SECURITIES RULE SHIFT OPPOSED
description: A controversial Securities and Exchange Commission proposal that would simplify underwriting procedures is being greeted with dismay on Wall Street as it comes up for S.E.C. action Wednesday.

title: TIPS FOR FISH BUYERS
description: Whole fish: The surest signs of fresh fish are bright, clear eyes; gills showing red underneath; firmness; skin with luster, and no fishy odor. The eyes may not be quite as clear in winter because of the cold, but they should not be clouded over, bloodied or sunken. Freshly caught fish retain a protective mucouslike film on the skin for several hours - look for it if you ever buy fish directly from a fishing boat or at the docks.

title: Fiat Allis Bids For License
description: A refusal by the Reagan Administration to permit Fiat Allis North America Inc. to sell $710 million worth of construction equipment to the Soviet Union could cause the company's collapse, Fiat Allis officials said in a letter sent to the Commerce Department.

title: FABERGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,144,634 for the quarter and $5,416,004 for the year; C-After losses from discontinued operations of $198,346 for the quarter and $486,809 for the year

title: Bra of Norway Is First In Cross-Country Skiing
description: Oddvar Bra of Norway won the 15-kilometer cross-country race at the world Nordic skiing championships today.

title: SYRIA OFFERS PICTURE OF HAMA REVOLT
description: Syria, in its first official description of nearly three weeks of fighting in the city of Hama, accused the militant Moslem Brotherhood today of atrocities against members of the ruling Baath Party and their families.

title: BULOVA WATCH CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including pretax gains of $150,000 for quarter and $2,142,000 for year fromisposition of assets; C-Net loss including pretax gain of $170,000 from disposition of assets; D-Including tax credit of $128,000 and a pretax gain of $1,918,000 from disposition of assets; results reflect the adoption of FASB Statement No52 regarding foreign currency translations which increased net income by $1,117,000, or 28 cents a share, for the quarter and decreased the net loss by $1,221,000 for year

title: DURABLE GOODS ORDERS FALL
description: Orders for new durable goods fell 1.5 percent in January compared with December, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the fifth decline in the past six months, as the recession continued unabated.

title: Kansan Wins Trans-Atlantic Pancake Race
description: In yesterday's annual Shrove Tuesday Trans-Atlantic Pancake Race, Barbara McCaffrey, a physical-education teacher who won in Liberal, Kan., bested the time of Rosemary Ludgate, who won her third straight pancake race in Olney, England. Runners in the race must carry a pancake in a pan and flip and turn it, on the run, at least twice.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The disfigured face of Coney Island is the face of failed urban renewal in the last two decades: high-rise housing projects with graffiti in the elevators, abandoned buildings of brick and stone with their windows broken and their rooms laid bare and, next to some of these, identical buildings with scalloped shades at the window and police locks on the door, places in which someone has dug in and vowed not to be moved.

title: NATIONAL PARAGON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $27,565 for the quarter and $74,290 for the 9 months; C-Including a tax credit of $57,400

title: Unicorp American Names a President
description: The Unicorp American Corporation, a holding company with a variety of real estate assets that is moving its headquarters from Blue Bell, Pa., to New York City, has elected William Kirschenbaum, 37 years old, as president. He succeeds Herbert Barness, 57, who will remain in the Philadelphia area and continue as chairman of the Barness Organization, a real estate financing and development company.

title: REPUBLIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PUBLIC TV STATIONS FAIL TO PICK UP CAVETT SHOW
description: The ''Dick Cavett Show,'' the daily half-hour talk series that has run on public television for the last three years, failed this week to receive financing for next season from public-television stations, and will not return unless alternative support can be found.

title: ELSIE T. STRAHAN
description: Elsie T. Strahan, who had been chief nutritionist for the New York City Board of Education when she retired in 1965, died Friday at her home in Manhattan.

title: The Photocopier as Fink
description: It's bad enough that the world is full of handwriting experts able to finger you because of the way you cross your t's. And typewriter experts who'll state that the letter in question was typed on a machine in your possession.

title: Westvaco Net Drops
description: The Westvaco Corporation reported yesterday that net income in its latest fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31 dropped 57.6 percent, to $8.3 million, or 32 cents a share, from $19.6 million, or 77 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Irish Nationalist Led Into Canada
description: One of five Irish nationalists arrested on Feb. 6 on charges of illegally trying to enter the United States from Canada was freed on $10,000 bail and escorted back across the border.

title: FROM LUST TO LOVE
description: To the Editor:

title: ELIZABETHTOWN WATER CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
