JUDGE AND EX-CHIEF OF GENERAL SERVICES
description: Robert Lowe Kunzig, an associate judge of the United States Court of Claims who was the former head of the General Services Administration, died Sunday at Georgetown University Hospital after a short illness. He was 63 years old.

title: JAPAN ORDERS CAUTIOUS SANCTIONS AGAINST MOSCOW
description: The Japanese Government announced today that a cautious package of economic and diplomatic sanctions would be imposed against Poland and the Soviet Union to protest military rule in Poland.

title: Careers; Guidance For Law Students
description: LAST week Adelphi University was host to an all-day workshop for college advisers in the metropolitan New York area on the job outlook for lawyers and on the new Law School Admission Test, which will start to be used on June 16.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10% stock dividen declared on Feb 19 1982

title: REGAN BACKS HELP FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: The Secretary of the Treasury said yesterday he would favor exempting mass-transit programs from a proposed repeal of a Federal tax-leasing law that could cost New York almost half a billion dollars.

title: EXCELSIOR INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including capital gains of $236,000 for the latest year and $28,000 for the previous year and a reduction of $486,000 for the previous year from a change in accounting principle

title: MACY, R H, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared yesterday which were $1.89 for the latest quarter and $1.83 for earlier period; the latest 6 months was $2.64 a share against $2.55 for year-ago period

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MET PLAN: VERSATILE INFIELD
description: It is George Bamberger's plan to start the season with a group of infielders who can play more than one position, and the Mets' new manager began such an experiment today when Tom Veryzer, Wally Backman and Ron Gardenhire worked out at shortstop and second base. When Hubie Brooks arrives Monday, the third baseman will also work out at other positions in the infield.

title: Cable Banking Set in Florida
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc., publisher of The Miami Herald, and Southeast Bank, Florida's largest bank, announced plans for an electronic bank-at-home service using the customer's television set and cable hookup.

title: BELL & HOWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $1,545,000 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations, tax credits of $890,000 for the quarter and $3,735,000 for the year and a gain of $2,129,000 for the year from an accounting change; C-Including tax credits of $2,080,000 for the quarter and $7,230,000 for year; year-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change for compensated absences

title: HIGH COURT DECLINES TO RULE ON BANNING YOUTHS AT ARCADES
description: Young fans of video games who were waiting for a definitive Supreme Court decision on their right to play the games in malls and arcades will have to wait awhile longer.

title: Rose Extending Pact
description: Pete Rose has reached an ''agreement in principle'' with the Philadelphia Phillies that will keep him with the team through 1984, according to Bill Giles, the Phillies' president. Rose signed a four-year contract in December 1978, with the club retaining an option for 1983, but Giles said yesterday that he wanted to insure that Rose would be in Philadelphia as he approaches Ty Cobb's major league record of 4,191 hits.

title: Nicaragua Reports the Killing Of 3 Guerrillas Near Honduras
description: Three anti-Government guerrillas were killed in a clash with Nicaraguan troops near the Honduran border, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: WESTPHAL AGREES TO PROPOSAL BY KNICKS
description: Paul Westphal, the free-agent guard, passed a four-hour physical examination yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital and signed an offer sheet with the Knicks before last night's game against the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Bank Reform Needs a Nudge
description: The nation's 45-year-old system of regulating banks and other financial institutions is obsolete. Virtually all would benefit from a looser rein. Indeed, a new study from the Brookings Institution suggests that without reform a quarter of all savings and loan concerns may fail. But all the money businesses have some residual desire to shackle competitors. So they are jostling for legislative advantage and may prevent reform for yet another year.

title: WINE TALK
description: THIS is the story of a gastronomic calamity -not a calamity of monumental proportions, but one that is memorable because it could so easily have been avoided if only somebody had known better. It involves the president of the Comite Interprofessionel du Bourgogne, four bottles of rare and fine Burgundy and an excellent French restaurant in Manhattan.

title: BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $254,000; C-Net income

title: ARTS AND LETTERS GROUP ELECTS 14 NEW MEMBERS
description: Two internationally renowned novelists born in Europe and now American citizens will be among the 14 new members named today as having been elected to the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, the national organization that honors achievement in art, literature and music.

title: LIPE-ROLLWAY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Nov 29
MACY POSTS 5.1% GAIN IN QUARTER
description: R.H. Macy & Company, the first of the nation's major retailers to report earnings in the most recent fiscal quarter, said yesterday that net income increased 5.1 percent and sales advanced 10.4 percent.

title: ABITIBI-PRICE INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a $4 million loss on the sale of a paper mill; C-Including a $7 millionspecial gain

title: Liquor Officials Object To Closing U.S. Office
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to eliminate the agency that helps regulate the liquor industry could lead to watered-down alcohol and infiltration by organized crime, a Senate subcommittee was told Monday.

title: RICHMOND TANK CAR CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes an unrealized loss of $4,724,000, or 18 cents a shar C-Reflects a reversal of $2,458,000, or 10 cents a share, of investment tax credits reflected in income for the first nine months of 1980; D-Includes income of $6,858,000, or 27 cents a share, from the recovery of prior years' deferred credits related to a British subsidiary, a gain of $3,228,000, or 13 cents a share, on a vessel sale, and an unrealized foreign currency translation loss of $3,528,000, or 14 cents a share; E-Includes a gain of $2,783,000 or 11 cents a share, from the sale of a 50% interest in a vessel and an unrealized foreign currency translation loss of $913,000, or 4 cents a share; All share earnings give effect to a 3-for-2 stock split distrib in June 1981

title: DEBATE OPENS ON PEACE FORCE
description: The Security Council opened debate today on a United Nations plan to increase the size of the peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon from 6,000 to 7,000 soldiers.

title: RANGERS TO DECIDE WITHIN 2 MONTHS WHETHER TO OMVE
description: The Madison Square Garden Corporation yesterday reached an agreement under which the Garden-owned Rangers must commit themselves by April 22 to either moving to New Jersey or remaining at their current home in the famed midtown arena.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Italian Police Find Red Brigades Hide-Out
description: The police found personal belongings of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier in an apartment used by the Red Brigades as a hide-out during his abduction, the authorities reported today.

title: Brown-Forman Net Up
description: The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation announced yesterday that its net profits in the third fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31 rose 14.6 percent, to $20.3 million, or 80 cents a share, from $17.7 million, or 70 cents a share, in the similar period last year.

title: COURT MARTIAL BARS SPANISH NEWSPAPER FROM REBELS' TRIAL
description: The lieutenant general presiding over the court martial of 32 officers and a civilian implicated in last year's unsuccessful military coup today expelled the editor of a Madrid newspaper at the demand of defense lawyers upset over an article it published today.

title: KLOSS VIDEO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $64,800 for the quarter and $162,300 for the year; C-Including tax credits of $189,800 for the quarter and $259,000 for the year

title: The Siren Song of Editorial Cartooning
description: A follow-up: Last June, Jeff MacNelly, twice a winner of the Pulitzer Prize for editorial cartooning, left that line of work to devote full time to his widely syndicated comic strip, ''Shoe.''

title: Transactions; FOOTBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AFC) Named Mike Westhoff assistant offensive line coach and weight-training coordinator.

title: 7 KILLED AND 60 HURT BY 2 CAR EXPLOSIONS AT MARKET IN BEIRUT
description: At least seven people were killed and 60 wounded when two car bombs went off within minutes of each other in a crowded seaside shopping district here this afternoon.

title: PANEL SEEKS SALT LABELING COMPROMISE
description: Representative Henry A. Waxman, chairman of a House subcommittee on health and the environment, put off a vote today on legislation that would require the food industry to disclose on package labels the sodium content of most processed foods.

title: NUCLEAR CHIEF CONFIRMED
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of Vice Adm. Kinnaird McKee to succeed Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, who has retired as head of the United States Navy's Nuclear Propulsion Program.

title: USLIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $5,801,000 on the disposal of a subsidiary; C-After a loss of$234,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $10,594,000 on the disposalof discontinued operations

title: TELETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $98,400 for the quarter and $245,900 for the 6 months on the sale of interest in subsidiaries and a gain of $37,900 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of investments; C-Net loss after extraordinary credits of $10,300 for the quarter and $9,600 for the 6 months

title: ISLANDERS RENEW AN INCENTIVE
description: There was a new beginning but an old incentive for the Islanders tonight as they returned to Nassau Coliseum to face the Chicago Black Hawks: finish first over all in the National Hockey League race.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jerry Martin, a light heavyweight contender, discharged Leon Tabbs, his manager-trainer, saying Tabbs's control had been such that Martin had had little or no control of his business affairs. ... For the second straight week, 38-year-old Billie Jean King lost a firstround tournament match. Having been defeated, 4-6, 6-2, 6-3, by Virginia Ruzici in Oakland, Calif., Monday night, she said: ''I'm pretty discouraged.

title: New Head Of Victaulic Plans Growth
description: George F. Naumann, 51, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Victaulic Company of America, a major manufacturer of mechanical piping products. As president, he succeeds Joseph E. St. Clair, 61, who was appointed to the vacant post of chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer of the corporation, based in South Plainfield, N.J.

title: Rebels Kill 14 Thai Soldiers
description: Fourteen Government soldiers were killed and 50 were wounded in a five-day assault on a mountain stronghold of Communist Party forces in southern Thailand, a military spokesman said today. Fighting is continuing in Suratthani and Nakhon Sithammarat Provinces, said the spokesman of the Internal Security Operations Command.

title: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOVERNORS VOTE TO NEGOTIATE PROGRAM SWAPS
description: The nation's governors, without a dissenting vote, agreed today to negotiate with the Reagan Administration over swaps in Federal and state responsibilities, but on a smaller scale than President Reagan first proposed.

title: RADIOACTIVE WASTE SAFE ON TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title:
METROPOLITAN DIARY;
RUBIKQUITY WITHOUT END
description: FELICIA LAMPORT

title: CONCERT: CINCINNATIANS
description: MICHAEL GIELEN became music director of the Cincinnati Symphony two seasons ago, but Monday night in Carnegie Hall he led his first New York concert with the orchestra.

title: CITY AND HUNTER MOVE INTO QUARTERFINALS
description: City College and Hunter advanced Monday night to the quarterfinal round of the City University tournament, the annual basketball festival of 10 public colleges in New York.

title: PEI QUITTING PROJECT IN ACOUSTIC DISPUTE OVER THE BEAUMONT
description: The architect I.M. Pei has resigned from the Vivian Beaumont Theater renovation project at Lincoln Center after differences with the acoustician Cyril Harris over the design.

title: MURDOCH SAYS HE IS 'OPTIMISTIC' ON FUTURE OF TIMES OF LONDON
description: Britain's oldest and most prestigious newspaper, The Times, went to press on schedule tonight, and the chances of keeping it alive seemed to have improved slightly.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt PINBALL. By Jerzy Kosinski. 287 pages. Bantam. Hardcover, $14.95; paperback, $7.95.

title: No Headline
description: HESTON-ASNER STRUGGLE IS SPLITTING ENTERTAINERS

title: Nippon Steel Aids Unit of Armco
description: A team of experts from Japan's Nippon Steel Corporation will visit the Armco Corporation's Middletown Works next week to suggest ways of improving quality and productivity, Armco said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny Land and Mineral Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 500,000 shares of common at $6 to $9 a share, to be sold through a Drexel Burnham group.

title: A New View on Crime and Punishment; Painful Punishment
description: As a professor and associate dean at the School of Criminal Justice of the State University of New York at Albany, Graeme Newman has given a lot of thought to crime and punishment.

title: REVLON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HUNT, PHILIP A, CHEMCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Including a foreign currency translation gain of $556,000 and a tax credit inthe company's Belgian subsidiary; C-After a loss of $57,000 from discontinued operations; year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accountingfor foreign currency translations

title: Dow Edges Up 1.72, to 812.98
description: The Dow Jones industrial average edged higher yesterday after plunging Monday to a 21-month low amid investor worries over the recession and its impact upon corporate profits. However, other market averages posted token declines.

title: CZAR RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
Bridge: A Good Paradox Enables Defense to Beat a Contract
description: Some bridge deals turn out to be what W. S. Gilbert might have called a ''most ingenious paradox.'' When the diagramed situation occurred in the recent Bermuda Regional Championships, West had to make a difficult opening lead against a humble one no-trump contract.

title: S.E.C. to Hold Hearing Into Protested Game
description: The executive committee of the Southeastern Conference will meet Thursday to consider last Saturday's protested basketball game between Louisiana State and Tennessee, Commissioner Boyd McWhorter said today.

title: American International Appoints a President
description: Russell V. Stephenson, a 61-year-old former president of two regional airlines that were merged into larger carriers, has been appointed president of American International Airways, a new charter line with headquarters in Trevose, Pa. He succeeds Ron Fune, 36, who will become president of a subsidiary airline that American International intends to establish in Reno.

title: Irving E. Gershon, Architect, A Designer of Gateway Plaza
description: Irving E. Gershon, an architect who practiced in Manhattan for 40 years, died Friday at New York Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FINE ITALIAN HAND IN STUFFED FOODS
description: THE use and preparation of stuffed foods know no national boundaries - the appeal is universal. But if I were asked to name the one country in which stuffed foods have the greatest and most imaginative uses, it probably would be Italy.

title: Soviet General Reported Killed in Afghanistan
description: Western diplomatic sources said here today that a Soviet general was killed last month in Afghanistan when the helicopter he was in was downed by Islamic guerrillas.

title: MYERS, L E, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Feb. 8 describing a new Soviet film about John Reed gave the year of Leon Trotsky's death incorrectly. Trotsky was assassinated in 1940.

title: TV: CHILD ACTORS, FROM CUTE TO EVIL
description: THE child actor is the subject of ''Hollywood's Children,'' an hourlong documentary on WNET-TV at 8 o'clock this evening. The survey, narrated by Roddy McDowall, who once wrenched hearts across the nation as the serious little boy in ''How Green Was My Valley,'' begins with the earliest movie days, when children were little more than convenient props, to the almost total disintegration of innocence in recent years, with Louis Malle's ''Pretty Baby'' using Brooke Shields to symbolize what he calls ''the apprenticeship of corruption.''

title: NATIONAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $891,000

title: ABC Net Up 14% in Quarter
description: The American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday that its profit in the fourth quarter rose by 14 percent from the comparable period a year earlier, but that its earnings for the entire year were virtually unchanged from 1980.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: B-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $137,000 for the quarter and $205,000 for the 9 months

title: Two Killed in Fire In New London
description: Two persons were killed, 12 firefighters were injured and about 45 people were left homeless Monday by an early-morning fire that destroyed nearly half a city block on Franklin Street.

title: CRONUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After loss of $1,353,000 from discontinued operations

title: BRITISH EXPERT PRAISES NEW M-1 TANK
description: The Army's new M-1 tank, a center of controversy in its development and production, has received a qualified endorsement from a former British officer who says he believes that in time the vehicle's engine, a focus of the criticism, ''may well be hailed as a real innovation.'' He added that the tank's speed performance, its combat compartment and its fire control systems were commendable.

title: Title Fight Off
description: Because he wants more time to train, Kim Tae Shik of South Korea has withdrawn from a title match March 13 in Mexico against Juan Herrera of Mexico, the World Boxing Association flyweight champion, Kim's handlers said today.

title: DRIVE ON AGAINST CONNECTICUT TOLLS
description: In the towns such as this one that line the Connecticut Turnpike, few things are loathed as thoroughly as the tollbooth. On Monday night, a group of the disgruntled met here to plot their legislative assault on their 35-cent foe - a battle they acknowledge may wear on for years - and to vent their collective venom.

title: ROMANCE REIGNS SUPREME
description: To the Editor:

title: Quebec Official Resigns After Shoplifting Charge
description: Claude Charron, a major figure in Quebec's ruling Parti Quebecois, resigned today as majority leader of the Assembly after being charged with shoplifting in a Montreal department store.

title: GLEASON WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including foreign currency translation gains of $953,000 for the latest year and $804,000 for the previous year

title: Questions for Congressman Richmond
description: Last year Representative Frederick Richmond, the Brooklyn Democrat, helped put a fugitive on the House payroll. Is it too much to ask of Mr. Richmond that he admit or deny knowing that the man was an escaped felon?

title: Sears Sets Fund
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company introduced its previously announced U.S. Money Market Trust, a fund for investment in Federal or Federal agency securities.

title: FRESH SALMON FROM FARM IN A FJORD
description: THE most magnificent-looking fish on the market lately have been the Atlantic salmon flown fresh from fish farms in Norway: big, plump and firm, their skins of gleaming silver dappled slightly in black and their eyes bright and sparkling. Put them in water and you would expect them to swim. They are excellent eating, a rosy-colored delicacy that has been available here only since the end of December.

title: 1. One Second to 10 Hours
description: When you're preparing a meal of several dishes that have different cooking times, a handy gadget to own is a kitchen timer that can be programmed to sound off after three different time spans. West Bend has made a small, battery-operated timer that has a range from one second to 10 hours for each of its three channels. It could also be used for timing telephone calls and games or for tricky chores like hair coloring. The Lee Bailey section at Bendel's has it, priced at $35.

title: MUELLER, PAUL, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; C-Including equity in earnings of a joint venture of $229,000

title: OIL GLUT LEADS TO GASOLINE PRICE CUTS
description: At the Vickers discount service station on Pecos Street, the sign advertises self-service regular gasoline at $1.089 a gallon, and every one of the 12 pumps is humming.

title: HADRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $1,122,000 attributable to the sale of certain computer tapes relating to a foreign language translation system

title: Frederick Poe Graham Dead; Ex-Times Reporter and Editor
description: Frederick Poe Graham, former aviation editor and war correspondent for The New York Times, died yesterday in Ripley, W.Va. He was 74 years old.

title: N.F.L. AVERAGE PAY DISPUTED
description: The Giants averaged $76,000 in salaries and the Jets $78,000 last season, according to a survey prepared by the National Football League Players Association.

title: ROBBERS' VIOLENCE PUTS A COMMUNITY ON PATROL
description: In the 16 years that Martha Badger has lived in an area of Queens called the Crescents, there have been two burglaries near her. The first was several years ago and a few blocks away, but the second was closer in both time and place - it occurred last month, across the street.

title: JAILED LANDLORD SAID TO HAVE GOT BIG TAX BREAK
description: A landlord serving a jail term for harassing and threatening tenants in a building on the Upper West Side has, since 1977, received more than $2.1 million in property tax exemptions and abatements for seven other Manhattan buildings, a member of the City Council disclosed yesterday.

title: Grand Central Is Focus Of Mixed-Media Show
description: Grand Central Terminal, the railroad nexus, and its influence on the physical, economic and social life of the city, is the subject of a New-York Historical Society exhibition, ''Grand Central Terminal: City Within the City.''

title: OMEGA OPTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FATAL MINE BLAST LAID TO SMOKING
description: An investigator for the Federal mine safety agency testified today that a Tennessee coal mine explosion that killed 13 men Dec. 8 was set off when a miner lighted a cigarette.

title: NUCOR CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
A TEAM AT STATE IS KEY TO EL SALVADOR POLICY
description: Who is making Administration policy on El Salvador? President Reagan, of course, along with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and numerous officials at the Agency for Intenational Development, the National Security Council and the Central Intelligence Agency. Some Congressional committees and a number of private individuals and study groups also are involved.

title: STUDY ACCUSES JUSTICE DEPT. OF WAGING ATTACK ON CIVIL RIGHTS LAWS
description: A study released today by the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights said that the Justice Department, under the direction of Attorney General William French Smith, is attacking the nation's civil rights laws in an effort to narrow the remedies available to people whose rights have been denied.

title: DYSAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Grolier Club Exhibition Marks Joyce Centenary
description: A display of first editions of works by James Joyce is among the attractions at the Grolier Club's exhibition marking the centenary of Joyce's birth.

title: U.S. TO COOL PEACE IDEAS MEXICAN LEADER OFFERED
description: The United States reacted coolly today to a Central American peace initiative announced by President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico.

description: The results are restated to adjust for a change in the fiscal yearend to January from July

title: MORAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: INTERTHERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: MATSUSHITA ELECTRIC INDUSTRIAL CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 20
description: Share earnings are per American Depository Shares

title: THE JOINT CHIEFS NEED A STRONGER CHAIRMAN
description: Gen. David C. Jones, who will retire as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in June after having served with the Joint Chiefs longer than any other officer, has begun his valedictory by circulating a provocative set of proposals for reforming the nation's senior military council.

title: BASS-BARITONE: JAN OPALACH
description: MONDAY night in Alice Tully Hall, Jan Opalach showed us why he won the Naumburg Foundation's 1980 vocal competition. The young bassbaritone seems to have all the qualities necessary to a successful career - a healthy technique featuring delicate control even at the wispiest of pianissimos and then a communicative, flexible personality that moves confidently from mood to mood.

title: ALLEN GROUPINC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POP: 'GREAT GUITARS' LESS ONE
description: THE three guitarists who normally perform as ''The Great Guitars'' - Charlie Byrd, Herb Ellis and Barney Kessel - had their ranks broken in their concert Friday evening at Town Hall by the absence, because of illness, of Mr. Ellis. His place was taken by Tal Farlow and Gerry Mulligan, the baritone saxophonist, was added to the lineup.

title: PRIME CUT HALF-POINT TO 16 1 2%
description: The nation's leading banks reduced their prime lending rate yesterday by half a percentage point, to 16 1/2 percent, and a number of bankers and economists predicted that the prime would drop further in the coming week.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Systems Inc., Arlington Heights, Ill., has appointed Norman E. Walack vice president and chief financial officer.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
CORRECTION
description: A Reuters article in Business Day on Jan. 18 incorrectly reported a domestic oil estimate. The American Petroleum Institute estimated 1981 domestic oil demand at an average of 15.9 million barrels daily, while domestic crude oil production was 8.6 million barrels daily, little changed from 1980.

title: BRIEFING
description: 'Concern' on Herbicide

title: Iran Oil Sales To Japan Fall
description: Japanese imports of crude oil from Iran may continue to decline, stopping after April when current delivery contracts expire, industry sources said here today. No Japanese importer or refiner has renewed expiring contracts since December, they added.

title: Advertising; A Test for Public TV
description: TV, Channel 13, has begun a test to see if by increasing the length of sponsor identification before and after programs it can also increase its revenues. It is the the first step down a possible road toward some form of advertising.

title: NEW ACTING JUSTICE MAKING 'A SMOOTH TRANSITION'
description: ''This kind of work is absolutely fascinating,'' said Edward C. Alfano, a newly assigned acting justice in the criminal division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: REAGAN TO UNVEIL A 70 PERCENT RISE IN CARIBBEAN AID
description: President Reagan plans to announce in his speech on the Caribbean Wednesday that he will ask Congress to increase American economic and military assistance to the region by over 70 percent this fiscal year for a total of more than $1 billion, Administration officials said today.

title: I.R.A. Guerrillas Destroy A British Cargo Ship
description: Twelve Irish Republican Army guerrillas seized a British cargo vessel in a sea inlet early today, cast its 10-man crew adrift in a lifeboat and blew up the ship, the police said.

title: Spy's Term Lengthened
description: Christopher Boyce, the convicted spy, was sentenced today to three more years behind bars for his 1980 escape from Federal prison, which touched off a 19-month international manhunt that ended last summer with his capture at a hamburger stand. Federal District Judge Lawrence Lydick handed down the sentence to the man who was convicted in 1977 of spying for the Soviet Union and sentenced to 40 years in prison.

title: STUDENT AID: THE STATUS AT WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable News to Carry Reagan's Latin Talk
description: President Reagan's address on the Caribbean today will be carried live by the Cable News Network starting at 12:30 P.M. The speech, to the Permanent Council of the Organization of American States, will outline the President's development plan for the Caribbean and Central American region.

description: As mysteriously as it appeared, the price surge that threatened to wreak havoc in the tin market has seemingly receded.

description: A report to New York City's Police Commissioner says that while integrity in the Police Department is high, small groups of officers in some units have been able to get away with corruption for periods of time without detection by their superiors.

title: ACCUSED BRIDGE TEAM AND LEAGUE SETTLE DISPUTE
description: The American Contract Bridge League and two former members, Dr. Richard Katz and Larry Cohen, both of whom resigned in 1977 after being accused of cheating, reached an out-ofcourt settlelement Monday night in a long civil suit that had shaken the loftiest ranks of the nation's contract-bridge players.

title: VOLCKER EXPRESSES CONCERN ON BUDGET DEFICIT
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in his first appearance on Capitol Hill since the President endorsed Federal Reserve policies last week, indicated today that he still had problems with the President's program.

description: Meets on United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon at 3 P.M.

title: Economic Scene; How to Assist Thrift Industry
description: THE problem of the nation's ailing savings industry is approaching the ultimate crunch, and there are a variety of proposals as to how to deal with it.

title: A CONSUMER'S GUIDE TO FRESH FISH
description: MORE than 175 million pounds of fish pass each year through the barnlike structures of the Fulton Fish Market in Manhattan, making it the largest central clearing house for fish in the country. According to an official of the Fishery Council, the public relations arm of the market, most of this fish is consumed within the New York metropolitan area.

title: RANK ORGANIZATION LTD reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-After extraordinary charges of $3.6 million for the latest year and $37 million for the previous year; results have been translated at the rate of 1 pound equals $1.85

title: POLISH DEBT PAYMENTS TO U.S. CITED
description: Poland has paid ''almost'' all of its overdue interest on borrowings from Western banks, and these institutions will shortly sign a rescheduling agreement covering principal payments that fell due last year, Beryl W. Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today.

title: THE 1982 SINAI CAMPAIGN: ISRAELI PUBLIC RELATIONS
description: Occupied Sinai - The group of Israelis and Egyptians stood quietly near the edge of a precipice overlooking the Red Sea and watched the last dazzling play of daylight as the sun set behind the granite mountains of the Sinai Desert.

description: Year-ago results have been restated to exclude foreign currency translation gains in accordance with FASB Statement NO 52

title: U.S. TO SEEK HIGHER TAXES ON LARGE TRUCKS TO RAISE HIGHWAY FUNDS
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis told a House panel today that he would soon submit a plan to increase taxes on large trucks in the hope of raising as much as $1 billion in new funds for Federal transportation programs.

title: STRAIGHT TALK FROM BURNS CAPTIVATES WEST GERMANS
description: In the space of about 20 minutes, Ambassador Arthur F. Burns told a group of West German reporters that their country suffers from insufficient education in its own history, from economic problems rather more basic than its Government likes to let on and from heeding some silly advice from Jimmy Carter.

title: LEON SPINKS STARTS OUT IN A NEW CLASS
description: Four years to the month after he won the heavyweight title from Muhammad Ali, Leon Spinks has conceded what many boxing experts said all along: that he was just too small to be a heavyweight.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: AT least 101 hazards must be hurdled at large parties, ranging from plain boredom to repeated elbow jabs in the ribs and clothes sloshed with wine and onion dip. All that pales in comparison with the greatest hazard of all: the boor who marches over and, in a challenging tone of voice, says, ''I'll bet you don't remember me.''

description: LOUISVILLE CAPATIALIZES ON TURNOVERS TO UPSET MEMPHIS STATE

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: VIRTUALLY every first-rate French chef loves the food of his childhood, which most often turns out to have been bourgeois: chicken in the pot, a simple lamb stew or meat cooked and served with dried beans or peas.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MOST people have chicken pox as children. It is the one remaining common, contagious, serious childhood disease for which there is no vaccine, and it often passes from one child to another in families, play groups and preschool and elementary classrooms.

title: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LABOR DEPT. ASSAILED ON PENSION FUND LOANS
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch accused the Labor Department today of ''blatantly coddling'' Morris A. Shenker, a Las Vegas casino owner, in its investigation of $24.4 million in loans granted to Mr. Shenker by a Nevada pension fund.

description: Ronald S. Godwin, vice president of the Moral Majority, said today that the conservative group would soon begin organizing tours to Israel ''to transform as many concerned American citizens into well-i@nformed, educated friends of Israel as possible.''

description: The baseball schedule says the Yankees' season begins April 6, but for Rick Cerone it is March 6, when the exhibition schedule begins.

description: Fire broke out at an oil refinery and petrochemical plant in the Polish city of Plock today, causing slight damage, the Polish press agency P.A.P. said.

description: The case involved a pregnant woman who was beaten and then burned with a hot iron by her former boyfriend. The former boyfriend was arrested on a charge of felony assault, but the Manhattan District Attorney's office reduced the charge to a misdemeanor.

description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: British Jobless Drop
description: Unemployment in Britain fell slightly this month but stayed above the 3 million mark, the Department of Employment reported today. It said that the February total to date was 3.04 million, down 25,700 from January. The figure represented 12.6 percent of Britain's 24 million work force, compared with 12.7 percent in January.

title: CANVAS PASTRY BOARD
description: IN recent years I have had to cook under circumstances that are nothing short of primitive. No kitchen at all, sometimes. Such circumstances - they crop up during travel for cooking demonstrations -do have their positive aspects. They call on every resource of a cook and every bit of portable equipment that can reasonably be taken along, equipment that probably would not be tested otherwise.

title: NEW YORK AUDIT FINDS ABUNDANCE OF Q-TIPS
description: The Sanitation Department has two-man trucks, three-man trucks, litter baskets and many a broom. It also has a six-year supply of Q-Tips, a 21-and-a-half-year supply of plumbing equipment and 1.5 million obsolete snow-removal tickets (in quadruplicate).

MARATHON LIFE OF AN 80-YEAR OLD
description: SHE was 72 years old, and she was a little bored after giving up the store. ''I wanted to be outdoors,'' says Ruth Rothfarb, ''and I'm not the type of person to just retire.''

title: QUOTES FROM THE GENERAL
description: We need to spend more time on our war fighting capabilities and less on an intramural scramble for resources.

description: B-There are no comparable year-ago results because the company began operationson July 1, 1981

title: A.T.&T. Officials Criticize Bill; Bell Officials Criticize Bill
description: Officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and presidents of five of its local Bell companies told a House panel today that a comprehensive telecommunications bill was no longer necessary because a proposed antitrust settlement promises to restructure much of the telephone industry.

title: Three Derby Prospects In the Flamingo Prep
description: Three leading Kentucky Derby prospects will meet for the first time as 3-year-olds Wednesday in the Flamingo prep at Hialeah. One is Deputy Minister, the 2-year-old champion of 1981, who is making his first start since injuring an ankle while finishing fifth in the Bahamas Stakes Jan. 27.

title: KOCH SEEKS REDRAWING OF A CITY COUNCIL DISTRICT
description: Mayor Koch, who vowed he would not get involved in drawing the disputed City Council district lines, has requested that one district be redrawn in a way to protect a Puerto Rican incumbent.

title: OBSERVANCE OF LENTEN SEASON BEGINS TODAY
description: The season of Lent begins today, Ash Wednesday. For the next six weeks, Christians will examine their consciences and focus their worship services on repentance and forgiveness of sins.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''To maintain an organized society that guarantees religious freedom to a great variety of faiths requires that some religious practices yield to the common good.'' - Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, from a unanimous Supreme Court decision. (A15:2.)

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the most popular television programs of the last week (Monday, Feb. 15, to Sunday, Feb. 21), according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets. Rating Program Network 1 29.9 Dallas CBS 2 27.7 60 Minutes CBS 3 25.2 Falcon Crest CBS 4 25.0 Too Close for Comfort ABC 5 24.3 Three's Company ABC 6 23.8 Magnum, P.I. CBS 7 23.6 "The Jerk" (S) ABC 8 22.8 Alice CBS 9 22.7 Dukes of Hazzard CBS 1 0 22.6 Hart to Hart ABC 1 1 22.3 Jeffersons CBS 1 2 22.2 One Day at a Time CBS 1 3 22.1 Archie Bunker's Place CBS 1 4 21.8 FallGuy ABC 1 5 21.7 Little House on the Prairie NBC (P)remiere (R)epeat (S)pecial

title: G.O.P. LEADERS TELL PRESIDENT HIS PLAN ON BUDGET IS DEAD
description: Republican Congressional leaders told President Reagan today that his budget proposal for the next fiscal year was dead and that they would work with Democrats to produce an alternative package.

title: 4 Held in Newark With 200 Silencers
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Authorities said they arrested three men and a woman here after they got off a bus from North Carolina with 200 silencers. The arrests by local officers and Federal agents came after a yearlong undercover investigation by the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms into the manufacture in Colorado and sale of the devices that silence the blast of a .22-caliber pistol.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE quality of those fruits and vegetables that were scarce because of the bad weather last month has not been good in recent weeks. But now leafy vegetables - lettuce, spinach, escarole and chicory - broccoli and citrus fruits are much improved. Supplies are plentiful and the prices low.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Fiat Tunisian Contract
description: Fiat TTG, a subsidiary of Fiat S.p.A., the Italian auto maker, said today that it had been awarded a contract to supply the Tunisian Gas and Electricity Company with five gas turbines capable of generating 200,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity. The contract is worth more than $40 million, the company said.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 16.50 17.00 19.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 12.88 13.83 15.03 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.27 12.51 14.18 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.74 12.88 13.72 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 13.95 13.94 13.40 30-YR. TREAS. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SYRACUSE SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,638,000 on the disposition of property and plan equipment

title: AMAREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Minnesota Guard Quits
description: Mark Hall, the guard who was reinstated to the University of Minnesota's basketball team by Federal court order last month despite an unsatisfactory academic record, quit the team yesterday. Hall cited recent negative publicity over ''legal difficulties'' stemming from charges that he had billed $800 worth of personal telephone calls to the university, which is conducting an investigation into the allegations. ''My coach is being subjected to unfair pressure and criticism, and I am unable to concentrate on my game,'' Hall said in a statement. ... Financial-aid records at Marshall University in Huntington, W. Va., were subpoenaed last fall by a Federal grand jury looking into the assistance given five or six former football players, according to Marshall's president, Robert Hayes. Mr. Hayes spoke one day after the campus newspaper published an article that said a former coaching assistant, in return for $200 from each of the players, had helped them receive more Federal grant money than they were entitled to. Mr. Hayes said he did not know whether the grand jury's investigation was continuing.

title: COACHMEN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Renter Weighs DeLorean Deal
description: Budget Rent a Car Inc., a unit of the TransAmerica Corporation, is considering buying 2,000 sports cars directly from the Belfast factory of the insolvent DeLorean Motor Company, Budget executives said.

title: RAYMOND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including equity in extraordinary income of Teleco of $147,000 for the quarter and $533,000 for the year; C-Including equity in extraordinary income of Teleco of $375,000; Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100% stock dividend in April 1981

title: Cambridge, Mass., Votes Removal of Draft List
description: The Cambridge City Council Monday night ordered a Selective Service list of young men registered for the draft removed from city hall. The Selective Service System in Washington said it was the first time a local government had taken such a step.

title: Contamination of Two Is Called Deliberate
description: Two Brown University laboratory researchers apparently were deliberately contaminated with radioactive phosphorous, a university official said today.

title: Gretzky Goes Home to Relax
description: With two days off before continuing his pursuit of the National Hockey League record for goals in one season, what did Wayne Gretzky do?

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IMPERIAL OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly for notes and bonds yesterday, a move that was not too surprising after the robust drop in rates in the last week, market participants said. Short-term rates are now almost two percentage points less than a week ago, while long-term Treasury bond yields have dropped almost a percentage point.

title: BANKAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including gains of $14,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $52,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months on the sale of investments; C-Including gains of $1,165,000, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,629,000, or 45 cents a share, for the 6 months on the sale of investments

title: METHODE ELECTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NETS LOSE TO BUCKS
description: The Milwaukee Bucks, who had a 12-game winning streak snapped by the Knicks Tuesday night, returned to their winning ways with a 113-106 victory tonight over the Nets.

title: RECITAL: KING'S SINGERS
description: THE King's Singers, a male vocal sextet from England, made adoring subjects of their Carnegie Hall audience Sunday evening with a program that combined some of the finest and funniest singing available this side of Land's End.

title: CHRYSLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
KETCHUM & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Net loss; C-Includes gain of $2,005,000 from the sale of assets of Bio Products Inc subisidary

title: Quebec Legislator Guilty On Shoplifting Charge
description: Claude Charron, who until Tuesday was the majority leader of Quebec's Assembly, pleaded guilty in a Montreal municipal court today to a shoplifting charge. He was fined $300.

title: WE MUST REINSTATE THE DRAFT
description: The proposed $258 billion defense budget, up 15 percent from fiscal 1982's total, will not by itself redress the deteriorating military balance. To offset the Soviet Union's military buildup and meet the defense challenges of the rest of this century, we must reinstate the draft.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFING
description: 'Concern' on Herbicide

title: QUAKER CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to conform to FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Valenzuela Balks
description: The team plane that carried many of the Dodgers from Los Angeles to their spring training site in Vero Beach, Fla., did not carry Fernando Valenzuela, the left-hander who won the National League's Cy Young and rookie-of-the-year awards in 1981. Valenzuela, who is not required to report to spring training until Monday, chose not to make the trip because his contract negotiations with the Dodgers are stalled.

title: Bridge: Settlement in Los Angeles Averts Puzzles for a Jury
description: A curious chapter in the history of the game ended Monday in Los Angeles when a last-minute agreed settlement disposed of an impending court case that would probably have lasted more than a month.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of National Liberty Corp, acquired in Jan 1981

title: THE TILE ALTERNATIVE: NEW DESIGN SCHEMES
description: WHILE many designers have devised ways of dealing imaginatively with tile, there are few opportunities in the real world of designerand-client relationships for budget-free and fanciful tiling schemes. Price and high installation costs tend to make tile applications a luxury in interior design.

title: DINNER IS SERVED, AT TIMES IN A BARROOM
description: One of A.R. Gurney Jr.'s most successful plays is ''Scenes from American Life,'' which could serve as an umbrella title for his body of work. In his newest play, ''The Dining Room,'' at Playwrights Horizon, he once again focuses his gently satiric eye on his favorite subject, the WASPs of northeastern America, neglected figures in our contemporary theater.

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS THE USE OF 'TESTERS' IN INQUIRIES ON HOUSING BIAS
description: The Supreme Court, in a unanimous decision today, upheld a broad definition of access to the Federal courts on the part of individuals who want to sue landlords for violating the Fair Housing Act of 1968.

title: KNICKS TROUNCED BY PACERS,118-87
description: The Knicks put a quick finish tonight to the little optimism they may have generated with their victories over the Houston Rockets and Milwaukee Bucks.

title: AUTOMATIC SWITCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After pretax foreign currency translations losses of $271,346 for the quarterand $2,744,135 for the year; C-After pretax foreign currency translation lossesof $425,471 for the quarter and $911,014 for the year

title: CONTROLLER CITATIONS REPORTED
description: An air traffic controller on duty last month when a World Airways DC-10 skidded off an icy runway into Boston Harbor was cited three times in 1980 for operational errors, it was reported tonight.

title: CANADA SOUTHERN PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific, Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: TANNETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $464,000, or 20 cents a share

title: How to Wait in Line
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I read your article on lines (''On the Pressures and Politics of Waiting in Line,'' Feb. 11) while standing on one - at the bank. What amazed me is that no one else on the line was reading.

title: People
description: * Al Lieberman has been named senior vice president, director of marketing for Silhouette Books, a division of Simon & Schuster.

title: RULING SOUGHT ON TAX EXEMPTIONS FOR SCHOOLS PRACTICING RACIAL BIAS
description: The Reagan Administration plans to ask the Supreme Court on Thursday to rule that there is no basis in current law for denying tax exemptions to racially discriminatory private schools, Administration sources said today.

title: ST. JOHN'S SUBDUES SETON HALL
description: David Russell scored 19 points, 13 in the first half, as St. John's defeated Seton Hall, 82-65, last night in a Big East Conference game before 5,261 at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
TUBING PLACEMENT HALTED IN SUBWAY
description: The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would stop installing plastic electrical tubing in subway stations as a result of warnings by health authorities that the material releases toxic fumes when burned.

title: INTERNATIONAL TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: Results for the latest year reflect an extraordinary charge equal to 12 cents ashare for the Hartford tax settlement; results for the previous year reflect a gain equal to 59 cents a share from the sale of British Columbia timber operation

title: Tobin Says Fed Imperils Recovery
description: The Federal Reserve Board's tight-money policies - and not the Administration's huge budget deficits -threaten to ''stop a new recovery before it gets very far,'' James Tobin, who was awarded the 1981 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, said yesterday in New York.

title: HIGH COURT BARS UTILITY RESTRICTION
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a state may not prohibit a private utility from selling the energy it generates to customers in other states.

title: Plan to Buy Advent Ended
description: The Kloss Video Corporation said it had scrapped plans to acquire the Advent Corporation, a maker of stereo speakers and large-screen televisions that has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code since last year.

title: CARNIVAL IN RIO: FESTIVITIES SHIFTING INDOORS
description: Thousands of skimpily clad men and women were still dancing to the pounding percussion of a samba band at 4 A.M. Packing the floor and standing on every table and chair, they were a joyous, sweaty mass of waving arms, wriggling hips and undulating bodies.

title: NO SUPPORT BY JAPAN OF AID PLAN
description: The Japanese Government does not endorse a plan proposed last week by a Japanese-American businessman for private industry in Japan to provide $10 billion to finance job-creating projects in the United States.

title: AID PLAN GENERALLY PRAISED BY LEADERS OF BOTH PARTIES
description: Congressional leaders from both parties today generally praised President Reagan's plan for increased aid to Latin America, but some predicted that the $350 million package would have trouble passing Congress at a time of tight budgets and rising deficits.

title: DEBATE ON SAFETY OF UREA FOAM AND PLASTIC TUBING
description: THE anxiety level of homeowners may have risen several notches in the last four days, after news reports were published about two synthetic products often found in the home.

title: BILL WOULD BAR WILDS DRILLING
description: A Congressman acting on behalf of the Reagan Administration introduced legislation today that would bar drilling and mining in Federal wilderness areas for the rest of the century but would also make it easier to withdraw protection from wilderness areas.

title: CHRISTO SAYS PUBLIC BACKS 'GATES' PLAN
description: Christo, the artist who wants to install a series of bannerlike fabric ''gates'' of steel arching over 27 miles of Central Park's walkways, yesterday came up with a new wrinkle in his effort to convince the city to let him put up his monumental, $6 million project.

title: ABITIBI-PRICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Clare H. Timberlake; Longtime U.S. Envoy
description: Clare Hayes Timberlake, who was Washington's first Ambassador to the Congo, now Zaire, during that country's violent transition from being a Belgian colony, died Monday in a nursing home in Bethesda, Md., after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Fort Sumner, Md.

title: QUOTES FROM THE GENERAL
description: We need to spend more time on our war fighting capabilities and less on an intramural scramble for resources.

title: 'MAN OF IRON' WILL STAY IN OSCAR RACE
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences refused today to accede to the Polish Government's request that ''Man of Iron'' be withdrawn as Poland's entry for an Academy Award. ''Man of Iron,'' a movie directed by Andrzej Wajda that extols the Solidarity union movement, is one of the five finalists in the foreign-language category.

title: HERS
description: THERE are couples who match, and couples who clash. The former are the ones who look more like brother and sister than husband and wife. They marry and have matching children and at Christmas send photographs of themselves that look like pictures from an L.L. Bean catalogue. When you see them you know that somewhere marriage is still a safe harbor, and king-size beds are still sending forth good, solid, gold-pedigreed citizens into a world that is, a little sadly, no longer theirs for the taking.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS ON CARIBBEAN AID PROGRAM
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address Wednesday to the Organization of American States in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Japan's Stand On Chip Sales
description: Japanese electronics producers said today that they would not reduce production of semiconductors or restrict exports to the United States despite criticism there of their large share of the market.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Reuters article in Business Day on Jan. 18 incorrectly reported a domestic oil estimate. The American Petroleum Institute estimated 1981 domestic oil demand at an average of 15.9 million barrels daily, while domestic crude oil production was 8.6 million barrels daily, little changed from 1980.

title: South African Plan On Sharing of Power Divides Ruling Party
description: Twenty-three members of South Africa's ruling National Party rebelled today against Prime Minister P.W. Botha's support of a plan to allow nonwhites a role in government.

title: Interest Rates Move Lower
description: Short- and long-term rates declined yesterday as lower financing costs encouraged traders to increase prices for most outstanding debt securities.

title: Broker Loan Rate Cut
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company said today that it had lowered its broker loan rate to 14 1/2 percent from 15 3/4 percent, effective immediately.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A graph in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly stated the contribution to revenues made by two Dennison Corporation divisions. The company's technical papers division accounted for 14 percent of revenues in 1980 and the industrial systems division for 31 percent.

title: Staten Island Advances
description: Nat Harris, a 5-foot 6-inch guard, was the biggest factor yesterday in Staten Island's 102-84 victory over City College in the quarterfinal round of the City University of New York basketball tournament.

title: IT'S NOT VIETNAM, BUT...
description: ''The decisive battle for Central America is now under way in E l Salvador.'' In that portentious language the Assistant Secretary o f State for Inter-American Affairs, Thomas O. Enders, explained to C ongress the Administration's plans for greatly increased military a id to El Salvador.

title: U.S. Auditors Contend Watt Misused $9,000
description: Almost $9,000 of Government money was misused last year when Interior Secretary James G. Watt and his wife, Leilani. excluded the public from a national historic mansion to entertain guests there, according to the United States Comptroller General.

title: BATTLES SEEM LIKELY OVER CARIBBEAN AID PROPOSAL
description: Representatives of organized labor expressed concern today over the threat of job losses from increased imports if President Reagan's proposals aimed at spurring economic development in the Caribbean Basin are enacted. Labor unions are expected to lobby hard against the Administraton's ''free trade'' package when it gets to Congress.

title: SENATE DEFEATS ANTIBUSING BILL
description: The Senate today rejected legislation that would have prohibited any arm of government, from school boards to the Supreme Court, from authorizing busing as a tool in desegregating public schools.

title: OPERA: WAGNER'S 'FEEN' BOWS IN U.S.
description: FOR its spring-season opening performance last night at the New York State Theater, the New York City Opera mustered the apparent American premiere, in concert form, of the first opera by none other than Richard Wagner. And ''Die Feen,'' composed when Wagner was 20 years old, turned out to be quite remarkable.

title: A RAY OF HOPE GLEAMS IN CONEY ISLAND
description: Reprinted from Wednesday's issue.

title: Oscar S. Stauffer Dies at 95; Founder of Newspaper Chain
description: Oscar S. Stauffer, founder of an 11-state newspaper and broadcast group who was a key backer of Alf Landon's 1936 bid for the Presidency, died Tuesday. He was 95 years old.

title: PROBLEMS OF DISABLED
description: ''The problems of the disabled are unpopular,'' says Itzhak Perlman, who is used to encountering difficulties maneuvering around airports, restaurants, hotels and concert halls all over the world. ''Architects have to become more aware of exactly what is involved in designing barrier-free buildings and homes.''

title: GRETZKY, SCORING 3 GOALS, SETS SEASON RECORD AT 79
description: The first seven times that Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers shot the puck tonight, Don Edwards, the Buffalo Sabres' goalie, blocked it.

title: CITY TAX BREAKS FOR TWO PROJECTS DENIED BY PANEL
description: A city panel that has been accused repeatedly of being overly generous to real-estate developers refused yesterday to grant multimillion-dollar tax breaks to two large commercial projects in Manhattan. A third applicant, facing probable rejection of his request, withdrew from consideration altogether.

title: Bank Reform Needs a Nudge
description: The nation's system of regulating banks and other financial institutions is obsolete. Virtually all would benefit from a looser rein. ... But all have some residual desire to shackle competitors. So they are jostling for legislative advantage and may prevent reform for yet another year.

title: RETIRING CHIEF SPEAKS OUT ON MILITARY COUNCIL
description: Gen. David C. Jones, who will retire as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in June after having served with the Joint Chiefs longer than any other officer, has begun his valedictory by circulating a provocative set of proposals for reforming the nation's senior military council.

title: SCRIPTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: B-Including tax credits of $337,000 for the quarter and $1.2 million for the 9 months

title: BANKER TESTIFIES MRS. VON BULOW HAD $30 MILLION
description: The trust officer who manages Martha von Bulow's financial affairs testified today that she was worth about $30 million at the end of 1980. He also said that her husband, Claus, would inherit $6.5 million outright, plus the income from a $7.5 million trust, on her death.

title: PAXALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JAMES H. PARKER
description: James H. Parker, a former manager of the New York Athletic Club, died of a heart attack Saturday in Boca Raton (Fla.) Hospital.

title: Record Coal Lease Sale Set
description: The largest Federal coal lease sale ever will be held here in April when 17 tracts in the Powder River Basin are offered, Interior Secretary James G. Watt announced today.

title: POP-ROCK: DB'S AT RITZ
description: ON their two independently distributed albums, ''Stands for Decibels'' and ''Repercussion,'' the dB's established themselves last year as the freshest, most promising New York-area pop group. On cursory listening, these records suggest yet another bunch of Beatles imitators, with echoes of many other groups, from the Beach Boys to Television, thrown in.

title: REGIONAL TRUCKERS DEBATE LABOR COSTS
description: Frederick Reed, who has driven trucks for Hemingway Transport Inc. for 23 years, recently got a letter from Richard E. Edwards, the company's president and chief executive officer.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 24 - From the day last March that President Reagan was shot outside the Washington Hilton Hotel, along with his press secretary, a Secret Service agent and a policeman, it has been clear that the man who fired the shots, on national television, was John W. Hinckley Jr.

title: BRITISH EXPERT SAYS M-1 TANK MAY BE HAILED AS INNOVATION
description: The Army's new M-1 tank, a center of controversy in its development and production, has received a qualified endorsement from a former British officer who says he believes that in time the vehicle's engine, a focus of the criticism, ''may well be hailed as a real innovation.'' He added that the tank's speed performance, its combat compartment and its fire control systems were commendable.

title: SOLID STATE SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $138,000 for quarter and $13,000 for the year; C-Including tax credits of $349,000 for quarter and $872,000 for year

title: Italian Layoffs Suspended
description: The Italian Government asked Montedison to suspend moves to lay off about 2,000 workers next month because of excess capacity.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 25, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the peace force in Lebanon at 4 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Wings Seeking Shero?
description: Do the Detroit Red Wings want to hire Fred Shero as their head coach? The answer depends on whom you talk to. Shero, former coach of the Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers, said that he had been offered the job and that his agent was negotiating with the Red Wings over terms.

title: FRANCE TRYING A BALANCING ACT IN MIDEAST
description: The Government of President Francois Mitterrand, which took office hoping to win a balance of good will in the Middle East, has had to settle for a lower order of balance in the form of criticism from all sides.

title: Vietnam Rebuffs U.S.  On Missing G.I.'s
description: A Reagan Administration delegation left Hanoi today after a two-day mission that apparently failed to gain Vietnamese cooperation in the search for 2,500 Americans listed by the Pentagon as missing in action in Indochina.

title: REUSCHEL GETS RAISE
description: Rick Reuschel, the $280,000-a-year pitcher the Yankees acquired from the Chicago Cubs on the eve of the strike last June 12, agreed to a two-year contract extension today, then worked out for the first time this spring.

title: 6 Persian Gulf States Tighten Military Ties
description: Saudi Arabia and five other Persian Gulf oil-producing states, reacting to what they see as threats from Iran, agreed today on closer military ties through a collective security pact.

title: American Can In Merger Pact
description: The American Can Company said it had signed a definitive agreement under which Associated Madison Companies, an accident, health and life insurance company, would become a subsidiary of American Can.

title: DEFICIT CUTS URGED BY VOLCKER
description: Despite the impression of accommodation and harmony left by President Reagan in his endorsement of the Fed's policies at his news conference last week, Mr. Volcker, in his first Capitol Hill appearances since then, made it clear that he still had doubts about whether the President's program can work the way the Administration has promised.

title: An Admiral Returns to His Alma Mater; An Admiral Returns
description: Since it was founded by New York City in 1874, the New York Maritime College in the Bronx, now part of the State University of New York, has made a tradition of turning out engineers and officers for the nation's merchant fleet.

title: Harvester Layoffs
description: The International Harvester Company said it would consolidate production of construction equipment into one United States plant by transferring its tractor and loader assembly operations from Melrose Park, Ill., to Libertyville, Ill. The company said the move would result in the indefinite layoff of about 600 hourly employees and the elimination of more than 200 management and salaried positions at Melrose Park. The Libertyville plant now produces heavy-duty construction machinery.

title: CHOMERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credit of $10,000 for quarter, loss of $1,753,000 from discontinued operations and gain of $45,000 on sale of discontinued operations; C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $560,000 for the quarter and $618,000 for year and tax credits of $80,000 for quarter and $16,000 for year

title: D'Arcy Names New Chairman
description: Alvin Hampel, who has long yearned to move formally from the creative side of the agency world to the business side, is going to be doing it in a big way next Wednesday when he becomes chairman of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York, which bills about $80 million. He will be replacing John Jay deGarmo, who has been chairman since D'Arcy acquired his deGarmo agency, with its $60 million in billings, in January 1980.

title: IN CHILDREN'S BOOKS, FAVORITES ENDURE
description: ON the surface it would seem that children's books have never had it so bad. Many carry adult-size price tags. Libraries, long the major purchasers of children's books, are suffering from significant cutbacks in governmental funding. The popularity of video games has led Stephen Roxburg, editor of children's books at Farrar, Straus & Giroux, to lament, only half-facetiously, that America may become a nation of illiterate space pilots.

title: NUCORP ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,569,000; C-Net income

title: RADIOACTIVE WASTE SAFE IN TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: BERRY INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $68,000 for the quarter and $574,000 for the year

title: FURNITURE FOR THOSE OF CHANGEABLE MIND
description: ITS designer, Vico Magistretti, calls it furniture for ''people who like to change their mind.'' And as he demonstrated the capabilities of a generously proportioned chair from his Sindbad collection at the Salone del Mobile Italiano in Milan last fall, it is also furniture ''done without upholstery.'' Mr. Magistretti thought of the design when he was in London and admired the wool horse blankets used there.

title: NLT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $9.5 million for the quarter and$13 million for the year; C-Including income from discontinued operations of $344,000 for the quarter and $1.9 million for the year

title: Denver Grants Franchise For Cable Television
description: The franchise to wire more than 226,000 homes here for cable television has been awarded by the Denver City Council to Mile Hi Cablevision, one of three concerns that together spent $3 million over the past two years competing for the contract.

title: SCITEX reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago shares outstanding give effect to two equity issues completed during the year and a 2-for-1 stock split, effective Nov 21,1980

title: PACIFIC GOLD & URANIUM INC (LOS ANGELES) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The 1981 results reflect the change in accounting for foreign currency translation

title: LIBERAL PARTY'S CHAIRMAN ASSAILS KOCH
description: The New York State chairman of the Liberal Party has criticized Mayor Koch, jeopardizing the Mayor's chances for a party endorsement of his candidacy for Governor.

title: OBSTETRIC PANEL SAYS CAESAREAN DELIVERY NEEDN'T SET PATTERN
description: An expert committee of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists has concluded that many women who previously gave birth by caesarean section can safely attempt a vaginal delivery in subsequent pregnancies.

title: SMUCKER, J M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Schulman Says No to Knicks
description: Sam Schulman, owner of the Seattle SuperSonics, said tonight the Knicks would not get Paul Westphal this season.

title: Franklin Ave. Shuttle Will Reopen Monday
description: The Franklin Avenue shuttle, closed last month because of a crack in a retaining wall, will reopen Monday, transit officials said yesterday.

title: PEI RESIGNS AT BEAUMONT ARCHITECT
description: The architect I.M. Pei has resigned from the Vivian Beaumont Theater renovation project at Lincoln Center after differences with the acoustician Cyril Harris over the design.

title: Cleaver's New Philosophy Is Booed at Yale; Boos for Cleaver
description: There was a time, back in the 1960's, when Eldridge Cleaver, a founder of the Black Panther Party, advocated armed revolution to overthrow the Government.

title: ROMANCE STILL REIGNS SUPREME
description: To the Editor:

title: Warning On Gas Plan
description: Leading House Democrats introduced a resolution today that warned the Reagan Administration against attempting ''backdoor decontrol'' of natural gas prices.

title: RADIOACTIVE WASTE SAFE IN TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., has elected Charles E. Austin corporate vice president; Joseph J. Garbarino a group vice president, and Albert J. Costello president of Cyanamid's Agricultural division.

title: BELL TREASURER SEES BORROWING CUTBACK
description: Local telephone companies to be divested by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will have to stop long-term borrowing to prevent being overburdened with debt, the company's treasurer said yesterday.

title: Leon Spinks Triumphs
description: Leon Spinks, who has been watching his weight but who still has trouble seeing right hands, made an underpowering but successful debut as a cruiserweight tonight. Carlos DeLeon later defended his World Boxing Council championship in the new 195-pound weight division by stopping Marvin Camel, the former champion, after seven rounds.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including pretax foreign currency translation gains of $866,000 for the quarter and $27,000 for the 6 months; C-Including pretax foreign currency translationgains of $544,000 for the quarter and $934,000 for the 6 months; share earningsreflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Feb 19

title: Bank Offers Loan Bonus
description: The Marine Midland Bank said yesterday that it would pay $200 cash bonuses to customers who finance new car purchases through Marine during March.

title: ILL-TIMED ACQUISITIONS HELPED FORCE LIONEL INTO CHAPTER 11
description: The Lionel Corporation, which has concentrated on toy retailing ever since selling its well-known train business more than 10 years ago, was apparently forced into bankruptcy proceedings last week because of ill-timed acquisitions, marketing mistakes and some poor store locations.

title: FEB. 11-20 AUTO SALES ROSE 1.9%
description: With rebates in effect, the nation's Big Three auto manufacturers today reported their first 10-day sales gain since September - a scant 1.9 percent for mid-February.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: B-Net loss; year-ago results reflect a charge of $4.3 million for the closing of plants and facilities

title: U.S. VOWS TO PRESS LOAN CASE
description: A Labor Department lawyer said today that he would seek full restitution from Morris A. Shenker, a Las Vegas lawyer and hotel owner, for the millions of dollars Mr. Shenker is said to have received from his employees' pension fund and never repaid.

title: NORTH KOREANS' GUERRILLA TRAINING WORRIES SOUTH
description: A dozen deafening drills were turned off at a Seoul subway construction site so that the foreman could make himself heard.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH anyone who first looks inside the headbox at the top of a Venetian blind may be confused by what looks like a complicated assortment of moving parts, these blinds are actually operated by two fairly simple mechanisms.

title: RECITAL: JAN OPALACH, BASS
description: MONDAY night in Alice Tully Hall, Jan Opalach showed us why he won the Naumburg Foundation's 1980 vocal competition. The young bassbaritone seems to have all the qualities necessary to a successful career - a healthy technique featuring delicate control even at the wispiest of pianissimos and then a communicative, flexible personality that moves confidently from mood to mood.

title: Bernice Fitz-Gibbon, 87, Dies; Retail Advertising Specialist
description: Bernice Fitz-Gibbon, a merchandising and retail advertising specialist who was named this year to the Advertising Hall of Fame, died Monday at the Onalaska, Wis., Care Center, a nursing home. She was 87 years old.

title: TRANSPORT LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Year-ago earnings have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split in August 1981

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Feb. 8 describing a new Soviet film about John Reed gave the year of Trotsky's death incorrectly. He was assassinated in 1940.

title: LETTERS
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: After reading the article, I noted that there was no mention of being last on line, and the relief of having someone step up behind you and take over that most undesirable location. THEODORE S. TIGER Evanston, Ill.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt PINBALL. By Jerzy Kosinski. 287 pages. Bantam. Hardcover, $14.95; paperback, $7.95.

title: Canadian Is Honored By U.S. Energy Dept.
description: A Canadian professor and five American scientists were honored today for their research in the field of nuclear energy.

title: DEPOSIT BILL TO BE GIVEN VOTE ON ASSEMBLY FLOOR
description: For the first time in more than a decade of attempts, the bill to place a nickel deposit on bottles and cans sold in New York State will be put to a vote on the Assembly floor, according to its supporters in the Legislature.

title: Mets Sign Leary and Two Other Pitchers
description: Tim Leary, the right-hander who jumped from Class AA to the Mets' staff last spring and then was sent to a Class AAA team, was among three pitchers signed to one-year contracts today.

title: 3 Top Hoover Officers Resign Unexpectedly
description: Three top officers of Hoover Universal Inc., a maker of engineered parts and components, resigned unexpectedly yesterday. The officers were Daniel T. Carroll, 55, president and chief executive officer; Gerald E. Schultz, vice president and chief financial officer, and Shel@don R. Erikson, vice president. All had joined Hoover in 1980.

title: HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Including a gain of $204,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of capital assets; year-ago sales figures have been restated for an accounting change

title: Reprinted from Wednesday's issue.
description: In the 16 years that Martha Badger has lived in an area of Queens called the Crescents, there have been two burglaries near her. The first was several years ago and a few blocks away, but the second was closer in both time and place - it occurred last month, across the street.

title: NEWFOUNDLAND LIGHT & POWER CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Kissinger, 'in Great Spirits,' Leaves Hospital; Kissinger Goes Home
description: Two weeks after undergoing triple-bypass heart surgery for coronary artery disease, Henry A. Kissinger was released yesterday from Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

title: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STAGE: 'THE CARETAKER' REVIVED AT ROUNDABOUT
description: WHAT the director Anthony Page seems to have forgotten in his revival of ''The Caretaker'' is that Harold Pinter doesn't necessarily work in mysterious ways. For all the hidden implications and buried drama in Mr. Pinter's plays, there is a hard core of reality that must be played for keeps. If the characters aren't brought to full life, if the naturalistic dimensions of the action aren't upheld, you lose the bristling, ontological horror that lies below. What emerges instead is a brittle, superficial word game that might just as well have been written by an artsy Pinter imitator.

title: Net Falls for Globe Owner
