description: Affiliated Publications Inc., owner of The Boston Globe, reported today that its fourth quarter net income fell 11.3 percent, to $4.7 million, or 90 cents a share, from $5.3 million, or $1.02 a share.

title: REEF ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Comparable year-ago results are not available because the company went publicin April 1981

title: N.C.A.A. Closes Inquiry
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has closed its investigation into a report that Bobby Lee Hurt, now a freshman basketball player at Alabama, was paid by his high school when he was a prep star after he had threatened to transfer. David Berst, in charge of the N.C.A.A.'s enforcement division, said: ''Whatever occurred in high school, we can find no way to connect it with the University of Alabama.''

title: 'AIR SAFETY TAKES TIME AND COSTS MONEY
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains from the sale of investments of $989,000 for the latest year and $10,010,000 for the previous year

title: Reprinted from Wednesday's issue.; The Talk of Northwest Jersey
description: Not long after the Vernon Valley and Great Gorge ski areas opened about a decade ago, Lois and Wheymer South sold their 30 milking cows and all but five of the 130 acres on their farm.

title: Jesuit Leaders Told To Restrain Liberalism
description: Jesuit leaders summoned to a weeklong meeting here were told today that they must curb a trend toward liberalism and follow the Pope's conservative policies.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Most people don't know where El Salvador is, but the ghost of Vietnam hangs over every instance of military support or action in a foreign country.'' - Representative Bill Alexander, on Reagan aid plan for Latin America. (A16:2.)

title: PRESSURE GROWING ON CAPUTO TO QUIT
description: As pressure grew yesterday for Bruce M. Caputo to quit his race for the United States Senate, he was given until tomorrow to ''straighten out'' accounts about inaccurate claims that he had been a draftee and an Army lieutenant.

title: SENIOR SOVIET EXPERT ON U.S. GRANTED ONLY A LIMITED VISA
description: The State Department, in a gesture of protest against Soviet visa policy, has issued a limited visa to the Soviet Union's leading expert on the United States and Canada.

title: CENTURY FACTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISRAELI PARLIAMENT TAKES UP ISSUE OF 'INTIMIDATION' OF FOREIGN PRESS
description: The Israeli Parliament today took up assertions of intimidation of Western journalists by Palestinian and Syrian terrorists in Beirut and Damascus.

title: AN 'OLD GIRL NETWORK' RENEWS TIES
description: It was a typical group of graduates of Harvard professional schools. They sipped glasses of wine and Perrier and discussed, in the Paine, Webber board room at 140 Broadway, what it was like to work at some of New York's most powerful law offices and corporations.

title: GADGETS FOR PHONES
description: TELEPHONE technology has produced some recently encountered devices that appear to be most useful. One is Buscom's Soft Touch tone dialer (about $40), meant to replace the phone mouthpiece to add tone dialing to a telephone with a rotary dial.

title: U.S. DESTROYER MONITORS ACTIVITY IN AREA OF SALVADOR AND NICARAGUA
description: The United States Navy has for the last two months stationed a destroyer equipped with electronic surveillance devices off the Pacific coast of Nicaragua and El Salvador to gather intelligence, Defense Department officials said today.

title: GREELANDERS VOTE TO LEAVE THE MARKET
description: The people of Greenland voted in a referendum on Wednesday in favor of withdrawing from the European Economic Community. The vote was 12,615 to 11,180.

title: Mrs. Tabb on Sideline
description: Mary Decker Tabb, who has set world indoor bests this winter in the mile (three times), 2,000 meters and 3,000 meters, will not run in the USA/ Mobil indoor track and field championships tomorrow afternoon and night at Madison Square Garden. She has a leg injury. But she will attend the meet to be honored as the winner of the women's indoor Grand Prix.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $64,000 for the quarter and $153,000 for the 6 months

title: Index; International
description: Soviet-Iranian ties improve since storming of Soviet Embassy A2 Accord on starting global talks eludes third world parley A3 State Dept. issues limited visa to the top Soviet expert on U.S. A4 North Koreans' guerrilla training worries the South A6 France seeks balance in Middle East policy A7 Israeli Parliament takes up the foreign-press issue A8 Ugandan guerrillas attack army barracks in Kampala A9 U.S.-Soviet polemics at Madrid parley continue A11 Government/Politics Norman Lear gets Jane Fonda and Barry Goldwater on stage A26 Voice of America told to ''make the truth more attractive'' A29 Prior relationships called a factor in felony cases B6 Bruce Caputo given until tomor- row to clarify stories B10 Washington Talk Briefing B14 Q.&A.: Gen. David C. Jones B14 Quotations from General Jones B14 The State Department's Latin American team B14 General Around the Nation A18 Panel says many women need not continue caesarians A20 Violent robberies prompt citi- zens' patrol of neignborhood B12 Drive opens to end Connecticut tolls B13 Harvard's ''old girl network'' renews ties B13 Obituaries Dr. Edward C. Franklin, immu- nology specialist at N.Y.U. B16 Robert Lowe Kunzig, judge and ex-General Services chief B16 Home Section Home The tile alternative: new design schemes C1

title: FINANCIAL AID FOR STUDENTS: THE STATUS AT WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY
description: To the Editor:

title: A City Swings Sharply After Reagan's Speech
description: Responses from more than 400 households in Columbus, Ohio, indicated that there was a sharp shift of opinion after President Reagan's speech yesterday on the Caribbean Basin.

title: HUMAN-IMMUNOLOGY PIONEER
description: Dr. Edward C. Franklin, professor of medicine at the New York University School of Medicine and an international authority on the human immune system, died Saturday at New York University Medical Center after a long illess. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JEWISH GROUPS PROTEST MET'S DECISION AGAINST ISRAEL SHOW
description: Jewish organizations and individuals throughout New York have reacted strongly to the Metropolitan Museum of Art's decision not to mount a staff-organized exhibition of ancient Jewish, Christian and Islamic artifacts from Israel.

title: Book: Camelot's Failure By John Leonard THE KENNEDY IMPRISONMENT. A MEDITATION ON POWER. By Garry Wills. 310 pages. Atlantic-Little, Brown.  $14.95.
description: NO wonder Garry Wills quotes so often from Norman Mailer and Murray Kempton. Like them, he is a sort of intellectual outlaw. He brings strange books - by Machiavelli, Hume, Clausewitz, Tolstoy and Veblen - to bear on the quotidian. His soul may be full of what John Cheever calls an ''unrequited melancholy,'' but his style, even as it seeks to extol American institutions, has a bandit's flair; it wears a romantic beret.

title: CHRYSLER LOST $66.9 MILLION IN 4th QUARTER
description: The Chrysler Corporation today reported a loss of $66.9 million in the fourth quarter of 1981 and a loss of $475.6 million for the entire year, somewhat less than most analysts had forecast.

title: Bridges and Tunnels To Have Tolls Raised
description: Beginning in mid-April, tolls will rise to $1.25 from $1 at the Triborough, Bronx-Whitestone, Throgs Neck and Verrazano-Narrows Bridges and the Queens-Midtown and Brooklyn- Battery Tunnels.

title: Ballets Canadiens Plans Six Premieres; Ballets Canadiens To Offer Six Premieres
description: Six premieres will highlight a season by Les Grands Ballets Canadiens at City Center from April 7 through April 11. On the opening program, which will be performed again on April 10, the 38-member company will present the American premieres of John Butler's ''Othello,'' a three-character interpretation of the Shakespeare play, and of an as-yet-untitled work by the company's director, Brian MacDonald.

title: PUERTO RICAN CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUPREME COURT BACKS CENSUS BUREAU ON WITHHOLDING ADDRESS LISTS
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the Bureau of the Census need not disclose its master address lists to state and local officials who are challenging the accuracy of the 1980 census.

title: AMISH LOSE APPEAL ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously Tuesday that members of the Old Order Amish Church who operate businesses must pay the Social Security and unemployment taxes required of all employers, despite their religious belief that paying the taxes is a sin.

title: DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INCENTIVE FOR NOT WORKING IS FOUND IN STUDY OF BUDGET
description: Poor people who choose to work would have less disposable income than if they depended entirely on Federal aid under President Reagan's proposed budget for the next fiscal year, according to a new study by the University of Chicago.

title: SOVIET-IRANIAN RELATIONS: 'FRIENDLY' AND 'PROFITABLE'
description: Relations between the Soviet Union and Iran have improved noticeably since the estrangement that followed the storming of the Soviet Embassy in Teheran in December 1980.

title: Nominee to U.S. Rights Post Meets Pennsylvania Senators
description: Senator Arlen Specter met with the Rev. B. Sam Hart today but said afterward that he still had doubts about the nominee's qualifications to be chairman of the Federal Civil Rights Commission.

title: CARIBBEAN PLAN CAUTIOUSLY WELCOMED BY ENVOYS
description: Caribbean governments today cautiously welcomed the Reagan Administration's commitment to the development of the region, but some diplomats expressed concern that the package of trade and aid would face serious problems in Congress.

title: NORPAC EXPLOR SEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a goodwill writeoff of $1.9 million

title: POLICY TUG-OF-WAR
description: The sharpening foreign policy fight in the Reagan Administration is finally bringing underlying arguments, though not policy itself, into better focus.

title: Gas Well Collapses in Gulf
description: A natural gas well that blew out in the Gulf of Mexico collapsed under the surface today, smothering a fire that had burned wildly for 19 hours. Thirteen workers aboard the Texaco Oil Co. drilling rig escaped onto nearby tugboats after the explosion Tuesday.

title: MUSIC: LEVINE LEADS VERDI
description: FREDRIC LEVINE, a young conductor with an operatic bent, surrounded himself with a sumptuous pickup orchestra and some solid singers Sunday at the 92d Street Y and created an evening of Verdi in concert.

title: STRIKE BY TIMES DRIVERS STOPS DELIVERY OF WEDNESDAY PAPERS
description: A walkout by truckdrivers prevented delivery of The New York Times yesterday. The walkout followed a dispute over the refusal by The Times to pay overtime to the chairman of the Times unit of the Newspaper Deliverers Union. Late yesterday the paper filed a complaint before Judge Pierre N. Leval in Federal District Court.

title: SHIFT IN UNDERWRITING RULE ADOPTED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a temporary change in underwriting procedures that some investment bankers have charged will severely undermine their traditional role in bringing new stocks and bonds to market.

title: ADAPTING A HOUSE FOR ITZHAK PERLMAN
description: RITARDANDO, the musical term for slowing down, is painted in big white letters on a wooden sign that hangs from the front porch. ''We thought this was an appropriate name for our house since it is where we come to unwind on weekends,'' says Toby Perlman, wife of the violinist Itzhak Perlman.

title: BECK HURT
description: The Rangers beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 6-4, last night at the Garden and although they lost their captain, Barry Beck, they moved into second place in the Patrick Division. Beck, the big defenseman, went off the ice late in the first period favoring his left shoulder and then went straight to Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including income tax benefit of $169,279 for the quarter and $265,428 for 6 months; the figures for both latest and year-ago quarters and for year-ago 6-month period reflect a change in method of accounting for translation of foreign currencies from NASB Statement 8 to FASB Statement No 52

title: William Schulz, Ex-director Of F.H.A. Office in New York
description: William Adam Schulz, a former regional director of the Federal Housing Administration in New York, died of a heart attack Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 77 years old and lived in Plandome, L.I., and Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: The Atlantic Magazine Changes Its Publisher
description: David Auchincloss, who was named publisher of Newsweek at 34, has now become publisher of The Atlantic at 39, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, chairman and owner, has disclosed.

title: SENATE CHIEFS ASK BUSINESS TO LOBBY REAGAN ON BUDGET
description: Republican and Democratic budget leaders in the Senate today appealed to the business community to give President Reagan the same message it had given members of Congress: His budget is unacceptable because the proposed deficits are too high.

title: CERAMIC TILE SOURCES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Imported ceramic tile prices range from about $2.75 to $4.50 a square foot, and tile installation costs begin at about $3 a square foot. Ceramic tile stores and showrooms in the metropolitan area that carry the Italian as well as domestic and other imported tiles include: Manhattan Outlets Country Floors, 300 East 61st Street, 758-7414.

title: STUDENT ABUSE OF DRUGS REPORTED TO DECLINE
description: Use of illicit drugs by American high school students has dropped sharply since the late 1970's, when it reached its peak, according to a major study made public today.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including income of $167,000 from discontinued operations; C-Net income

title: A TEAM AT STATE IS KEY TO EL SALVADOR POLICY
description: Who is making Administration policy on El Salvador? President Reagan, of course, along with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and numerous officials at the Agency for Intenational Development, the National Security Council and the Central Intelligence Agency. Some Congressional committees and a number of private individuals and study groups also are involved.

title: Transcript of address, page A14.
description: President Reagan proposed a broad plan of trade and investment incentives today designed to improve the economic well-being of the Caribbean area. At the same time, in what seemed a warning to Cuba, he pledged that the United States would do ''whatever is prudent and necessary'' to prevent the overthrow of the governments in the region.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FARR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
BINNEY & SMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $350,000

title: COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Questions for Congressman Richmond
description: Last year Representative Frederick Richmond, the Brooklyn Democrat, helped put a fugitive on the House payroll. Is it too much to ask of Mr. Richmond that he admit or deny knowing that the man was an escaped felon? Aiding a fugitive is a Federal offense, so Mr. Richmond has a right to keep silent. But the public has a right here, too: the right to expect more from government officials than that they are not crooks. ...

title: I.T.T. Net Down 1.2% In Quarter
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter slipped 1.2 percent, while sales fell 5.9 percent.

title: Soviet Corn Purchase
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 200,000 metric tons of American corn, or nearly 7.9 million bushels, for delivery through Sept. 30, the Agriculture Department said today. Officials said the latest sale raised to almost 12.1 million tons the amount of grain -5.9 million wheat and 6.2 million corn - that the Soviet Union has bought for delivery in 1981-82, the sixth year of a grain agreement with the United States.

title: PLANNING FOR THE SUMMER VEGETABLE CROP
description: NOW is the time to complete plans for the summer's vegetable garden. Depending on the weather, planting outdoors can start as soon as April 1.

title: Fake Attorney Loses Own Case
description: A man accused of impersonating an attorney lost his case - after serving as his own attorney.

title: Caribbean Vision, and Nightmare
description: Much that President Reagan said yesterday in outlining a policy for the Caribbean basin was welcome, even admirable.

title: Miller, Kuhn Differ Again
description: Marvin Miller, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, and Commissioner Bowie Kuhn were on opposite sides again today in hearings before the House Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on monopolies and commercial law. The unit is considering legislation to remove baseball's 60-year-old exemption from antitrust laws.

title: FITCHBURG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $139,216, or 20 cents a share, from abatements of real estate taxes

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Canadian National Railway is issuing $150 million in debentures due in 2007, yielding 16 1/4 percent and priced at 99.103 to yield 16.40 percent, to be sold through a Salomon Brothers group.

title: Muskie Prevails in Naming of Jetport in Maine; Muskie Prevails
description: Former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie has been granted his wish. The City Council in Portland, Me., has rescinded its decision to name the local airport after Mr. Muskie, who served for 14 years as a Democratic Senator from Maine.

title: SFN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Brezhnev Again Offers To Curb Atomic Arsenals
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, replying to an open letter addressed to him and President Reagan from an Australian disarmament organization, today repeated his offer to halt the production and stockpiling of nuclear weapons.

title: Advertising; A Test for Public TV
description: TV, Channel 13, has begun a test to see if by increasing the length of sponsor identification before and after programs it can also increase its revenues. It is the the first step down a possible road toward some form of advertising.

title: Mr. Koch Plays With Playboy
description: In the 1976 Presidential campaign, Jimmy Carter gave an interview to Playboy magazine in which, probably searching for the common touch, he insisted that he had ''lusted in his heart'' after women other than his wife. Now, Ed Koch appears in the same magazine, in an interview granted shortly after last November's election, also saying things that have people exercised.

title: Giscard, Planning Comeback, Will Run in a Local Election
description: Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, defeated in the election last spring after seven years of leadership, plans to start a political comeback by running in a local election next month, his office said today.

title: NEW DELHI PARLEY FINDS COMPROMISE
description: The issue of starting global negotiations with the world's industrialized nations nearly capsized the three-day meeting of 44 developing countries that ended here this evening.

title: Mexican Oil Find
description: Mexico's state oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, announced today the discovery of ''potentially fabulous'' deposits of ''super-light'' crude oil near the Sierra de Chiapas mountains in southern Mexico, but did not estimate the quantity of oil in the 23-square-mile exploration zone. Two exploratory wells are being drilled in the area, near Simojovel de Allende.

title: YESTERDAY'S FRONT PAGE
description: President to Ask Rise In Aid to the Caribbean President Reagan plans to announce in his speech on the Caribbean Wednesday that he will ask Congress to increase American and economic military assistance to the region by over 70 percent this fiscal year for a total of more than $1 billion, Administration officials said.

title: COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
Sears and Roper Cited In U.S. Safety Complaint
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission today issued a complaint charging that the Roper Corporation had manufactured and Sears Roebuck & Company had sold a soil-tilling device to 220,000 consumers even though both companies knew the product's poor design could cause serious injuries.

title: FINDING HOUSING
description: A number of organizations around the country and several in Manhattan make it easier for disabled people to find accessible housing.

title: REECE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a charge of $750,000 for quarter from plant closing and consolidation costs and a pretax gain of $433,000 on sale of company's Waltham, Mass manufacturing facility; C-Net income; year-ago results have been restated to reflect adoption of new foreign currency translation standards

title: Citing Big Rents, Officer Quits CBS in New York
description: Here's another complaint to add to all of those you have heard about the cost of housing in the Big Apple. This one comes from Charles S. LaFollette, who has served briefly as chief financial officer of CBS Inc., and is resigning as of Monday - for financial reasons, he said.

title: CECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: At least one star will refuse to walk out if the National Football League Players Association calls a strike next season. Steve Largent, wide receiver for the Seattle Seahawks, said today that he opposed the association's stated objective of obtaining a percentage of the league's gross revenue and that ''as a Christian and a father'' he would refuse to strike.

title: LIFE IMAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRIOR LINKS TO VICTIM CITED IN REDUCING OF FELONIES
description: The case involved a pregnant woman who was beaten and then burned with a hot iron by her former boyfriend. The former boyfriend was arrested on a charge of felony assault, but the Manhattan District Attorney's office reduced the charge to a misdemeanor.

title: Reprinted from Wednesday's issue.
description: In the towns such as this one that line the Connecticut Turnpike, few things are loathed as thoroughly as the tollbooth. On Monday night, a group of the disgruntled met here to plot their legislative assault on their 35-cent foe - a battle they acknowledge may wear on for years - and to vent their collective venom.

title: SIGMA-ALDRICH CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
EVANS & SUTHERLAND COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid in June 1981

title: WOMEN RECONSIDER CHILDBEARING OVER 30
description: FOR women who have postponed childbearing for career building, the past week brought mixed messages: a Time magazine cover story celebrating the joys of motherhood after age 30 and a New England Journal of Medicine report warning that the ability to become pregnant decreases more sharply after 30 than was thought.

title: Rams' Hill Pleads Guilty In Case Involving Minor
description: Drew Hill, the Los Angeles Rams' wide receiver and kick-returner, entered a plea of guilty today to one count of contributing to the delinquency of a minor.

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VOICES NOW AND THEN

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $27,507,000 from discontinued operations; C-After a loss of $1,603,000 from discontinued operations; D-After a loss of $21,192,000 from discontinued operations; year-ago results have been restated

title: MYERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1982; Companies
description: Car sales of the Big Three auto makers rose 1.9 percent in the middle 10-day period of February. It was the first sales gain they had reported since September. Ford's sales rose 4.6 percent and G.M.'s, 3.9 percent, but Chrysler's fell 14.2 percent. (Page D1.) Chrysler lost $66.9 million in the fourth quarter and $475.6 million in all of 1981, somewhat less than had been predicted. (D5.)

title: COMMONWEALTH THEATRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: B-Including a gain of $49,000 from the disposition of property; C-Net income including a gain of $58,000 from the disposition of property

title: Philip Morris Plant
description: Philip Morris Inc. said its board had approved plans for the construction of a $25 million primary tobacco processing addition to its Louisville, Ky., factory.

title: Newspaper Ad Revenue $17.4 Billion in '81
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau reports that its estimate of daily newspaper advertising revenues for 1981 is $17.446 billion, which means that Jack Kauffman, president of the bureau, was right on the button when he predicted $17.4 billion at the beginning of last year.

title: Texas Millionaire Sentenced
description: Rex Cauble, a millionaire rancher whose longtime friend former Gov. John B. Connally testified as a character witness at Mr. Cauble's trial for drug smuggling, was sentenced Monday to five years in prison. Mr. Cauble, 67 years old, was convicted last month of racketeering, conspiracy and fraud. He owns the Cutter Bill Western Wear stores in Dallas and Houston.

title: IMPROVING ACCESS IN HOMES
description: INFORMATION on how to make a home more accessible can be obtained through books, pamphlets, product catalogues and a computer data service. The following is a sampling: 1982-1983 Accent Buyer's Guide. $10 plus 65 cents for shipping. Accent on Living, P.O. Box 700, Bloomington, Ill. 61701, 309-378-2961.

title: UNITED MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Buffalo Lawyer Is Named U.S. Prosecutor; New U.S. Attorney
description: A 41-year-old Buffalo lawyer who specializes in estate work and personal injury cases was named Tuesday by President Reagan as United States Attorney for Western New York. He will succeed Richard J. Arcara.

title: Laker Competitors To File Protests
description: British Airways and British Caledonian Airways announced that they intended to file formal protests with Britain's Civil Aviation Authority against Sir Freddie Laker's plan to transfer the operating licenses for Laker Airways to a new company.

title: LILCO SEEKS A $183 MILLION RISE
description: The Long Island Lighting Company asked today for a $183 million rate increase that would raise its average customer's monthly electric bill 11.73 percent, to $72.09.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Dick Young Backed
description: The Daily News lost a bid yesterday to block the sports columnist Dick Young from writing for The New York Post while it presses a $1.5 million suit for breach of contract against the Post and the writer.

title: THETFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $77,000 from discontinued operations

title: ROMANCE STILL REIGNS SUPREME
description: To the Editor:

title: CARNEGIE HALL NAMES NEW MANAGER
description: Carnegie Hall has appointed Edward H. Michaelsen, a 65-year-old executive active on various arts boards, to be its managing director and chief executive officer as of Nov. 1.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings give effect to the 2-for-1 stock split distributed on Dec 31, 198

title: Three Greek Newsmen Lose 1981 Libel Cases
description: A newspaper publisher and two of his editors were sentenced today to 10 months' imprisonment each on charges of libel against two former ministers.

title: JANNOCK LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After special gain of $1,108,000; C-After special loss of $483,000; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: Market Place; Semiconductor Maker's Goals
description: ANALOG DEVICES INC. stumbled badly in 1981, interrupting a fiveyear history of impressive earnings growth. But the company's fans think it has begun to emerge from the recession while most other semiconductor makers are still in the doldrums.

title: 5 Women Charged In Bank Robberies
description: Five women, ranging in age from 16 to 25, have been arrested in connection with 12 robberies and attempted robberies of banks in Manhattan and Brooklyn since mid-December, the police said yesterday.

title: GOLDWATER AND JANE FONDA LEAD CIVIL LIBERTIES RALLY
description: Norman Lear, the television producer, put Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona and Jane Fonda, the actress who is a liberal activist, on the same stage Monday night in a celebration of American civil liberties aimed indirectly at the nation's religious right.

title: ST. LOUIS SUBURB ENDS 12-YEAR HOUSING FIGHT
description: The City of Black Jack, a suburb of St. Louis, agreed Tuesday in a consent decree to welcome people of all races as residents, ending a 12-year exclusionary zoning case.

title: F.B.I. Seizes Fugitive Indicted in 3 Murders
description: Joseph J. Sullivan, the only prisoner to have escaped from behind the walls of the Attica Correctional Facility and who was under indictment for three murders, was captured Tuesday morning in Rochester by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and New York City police detectives, the F.B.I. said yesterday.

title: GI EXPORT CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $911,200, or 48 cents a share, for thelatest year and $810,000, or 42 cents a share, for the previous year

title: Salvador Communist Says U.S. Will Lose
description: The United States is facing defeat in El Salvador, the leader of the country's Communist Party said in a interview carried today by Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

title: The City; Prosecutor Pushes New Abbott Effort
description: The office of the Manhattan District Attorney began efforts to have Jack Henry Abbott declared a ''persistent violent felon.''

title: BRIDGE DISPUTE SETTLED OUT OF COURT
description: The American Contract Bridge League and two former members, Dr. Richard Katz and Larry Cohen, both of whom resigned in 1977 after being accused of cheating, reached an out-ofcourt settlelement Monday night in a long civil suit that had shaken the loftiest ranks of the nation's contract-bridge players.

title: Frontier Layoffs
description: Frontier Airlines announced that it had laid off or eliminated the jobs of 400 employees because of declining passenger traffic.

title: JARUZELSKI SAYS POLISH TENSION PROLONGS CURBS
description: Addressing the first session of the Communist Central Committee under martial law, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said today that persisting tension was prolonging military rule and that opponents should not ''count on leniency.''

title: SmithKline Head Gets Added Post
description: Henry Wendt, the 48-year-old president of the SmithKline Corporation, a major pharmaceutical and health-related product company, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Robert F. Dee, 57, who continues as chairman of the Philadelphia-based corporation.

title: N.F.L. DISPUTES UNION'S SURVEY ON PAY
description: The Giants averaged $75,738 in salaries and the Jets $78,263 last season, according to a survey prepared by the National Football League Players Association.

title: E.P.A. Administrator
description: A 37-year-old aide to the United States Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works, Jacqueline E. Schafer, was named yesterday as regional administrator for the Federal Environmental Protection Agency for New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

title: UNIMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $181,000 for quarter and 6 months

title: RKO Appeals for Delay On Its Station in Boston
description: RKO General Inc., battling to hold onto its Boston television station, WNAC, asked the Federal Communications Commission Tuesday to allow it to continue to operate the station until the Supreme Court acts on its appeal of a decision to strip the company of its license.

title: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $70,000 for the quarter and $404,000 for the year

title: SCEPTRE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-The company changed its year-end from a fiscal year ended March 31 to a calendar year and, therefore, there are no comparable year-ago results

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE APPROVES LIBERALIZED IRRIGATION LIMITS
description: The House Interior Committee today approved a bill authorizing Western farmers to own or lease up to 960 acres irrigated with cheap water from Federal dams.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $629,000 for quarter and $852,000 for year; C-After gain from discontinued operations of $498,000; D-After loss from discontinued operations of $234,000; the 1980 figures restated for discontinued operations; the 1981 fourth quarter and year figures include loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,315,000

title: Ballet Preliminaries Will Begin Saturday
description: Regional preliminaries for the Second International Ballet Competition in Jackson, Miss., will begin Saturday at the School of Cleveland Ballet.

title: U.S.-SOVIET QUARREL IN MADRID PARLEY AT NEW HIGH
description: With deliberations paralyzed by the East-West quarrel over Poland, the Madrid conference on security and cooperation in Europe today witnessed some of the harshest Soviet-American exchanges since it convened 15 months ago.

title: FRENCH 'TEST TUBE' BABY
description: France's first test tube baby, a 7-pound 12-ounce girl, was born today. The parents, residents of Clarmart, west of Paris, wish to remain anonymous, according to a spokesman for the Antoine Beclere Hospital.

title: WAYNE-GOSSARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $929,601 from discontinued operations; C-After loss of $1.4 million from discontinued operations

title: Dow, Led by Energy Issues, Gains 13.79
description: A brisk demand for oil shares touched off a spirited rally in the stock market yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average sprinted ahead by 13.79 points. The volume of 64.8 million shares, up from Tuesday's 60.1 million, marked the heaviest trading so far in February.

title: MGIC Holders Approve Merger
description: Shareholders of the MGIC Investment Corporation have approved a proposal to merge with the Baldwin-United Corporation, based in Cincinnati, in a transaction that would be valued at $1.2 billion.

title: CONCERT: DEBUSSY AND BARTOK IN A SURPRISE FROM MARLBORO
description: WHEN Marlboro is mentioned in connection with music, Haydn and Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert are the names of composers that automatically come to mind. Debussy and Bartok, never.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
2 More Leave Alsands
description: Two Canadian partners in the Alsands synthetic oil project said today that they were withdrawing their combined 12 percent stake.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Calderon Performances Free at Cultural House
description: Two free performances of Calderon's ''The Great Theater of the World'' will be presented at the Cultural House of Spain, Saturday at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 6:30 P.M. Directed by Angel Gil Orrios, the founder and director of the three-year-old theater, this production includes vocal and piano music, hand-painted canvases that decorate the set and a cast of several actors and actresses and scenes from several works by Calderon, who died 301 years ago.

title: TV: 'MUGGABLE MARY'
description: ''MUGGABLE MARY,'' heroine of tonight's television movie on CBS at 9, is described in a subtitle as a ''street cop.'' That's fudging matters a bit. Mary Glatzle, portrayed with grim and convincing determination by Karen Valentine, is a decoy cop, adept in the kind of subterfuge that has long raised sensitive questions of entrapment. But this entertainment project carefully avoids those questions. The focus is kept firmly on ''personal drama.''

title: RIDICULED SUBURBS IN JEST, KOCH SAYS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was only trying to ''defend New York City'' when he asserted in a published interview that the suburbs were ''sterile'' and that ''it's wasting your life'' to live there.

title: INDEX FUTURES AT THE FIRST BELL
description: Trading in stock index futures got off to a rousing start on the floor of the Kansas City Board of Trade this morning, but much of the enthusiasm evaporated after the first hour.

title: SLAUGHTER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CENTRAL JERSEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After deductions in lieu of federal income taxes

title: Top 3 Derby Prospects Beaten
description: The three top-rated Kentucky Derby prospects had an unusual early-season meeting in the $25,000 Flamingo Prep at Hialeah Park today, but when the race was over, they were all far behind a speedy colt named Distinctive Pro.

title: Sudan Gets I.M.F. Loan
description: The hard-pressed Sudan will be able to draw $225 million more from the International Monetary Fund over the next year, the I.M.F. announced today. The Sudan already owes the fund the equivalent of more than $467 million in hard currency. The fund's announcement noted approvingly the ''sharp reduction in subsidies on key cost-of-living commodities'' in the Sudan.

title: CO-OP CITY HEATING SYSTEM WAS VANDALIZED
description: can bite last graf By PETER KIHSS

title: SUIT SEEKING TO UPGRADE CITY SHELTERS FOR WOMEN
description: A class-action lawsuit was initiated yesterday in an attempt to force the city to upgrade and expand its shelters for homeless women so that they meet the court-approved standards already observed for homeless men.

title: Irvin Fane, Midwest Lawyer Prominent in Jewish Causes
description: Irvin Fane, a Kansas City, Mo., lawyer who was prominent in Jewish causes, died of cancer Tuesday at the City of Hope Hospital in Los Angeles, where he had gone for treatment. He was 77 years old and lived in Kansas City.

title: NEW THREAT TO TIMES OF LONDON
description: Clerical workers from The Times of London and The Sunday Times voted today to ignore 210 dismissals ordered by the publisher Rupert Murdoch, and the union warned that both papers would ''grind to a halt'' if the dismissals were enforced.

title: Technology; Others Follow Apple's Lead
description: A NEW entrant into the personal computer business hopes to challenge Apple by imitating it. The company, the Franklin Computer Corporation of Pennsauken, N.J., introduced a computer yesterday that it says will use all the programs written for the Apple II and can be attached to all the same peripheral devices that attach to the Apple.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $29,320; C-Net loss after a charge of $218,300 froman antitrust settlement

title: BURN'S CANDOR DELIGHTS WEST GERMANS
description: In the space of about 20 minutes, Ambassador Arthur F. Burns told a group of West German reporters that their country suffers from insufficient education in its own history, from economic problems rather more basic than its Government likes to let on and from heeding some silly advice from Jimmy Carter.

title: REBELS IN UGANDA ATTACK BARRACKS
description: Anti-Government guerrillas, said to be supported by Libya, were reported today to have attacked the main army barracks in Kampala, the Ugandan capital.

title: CITY TAX BREAKS FOR RANGERS EXPECTED
description: The city, under increasing pressure from the Madison Square Garden Corporation, is ready to make tax concessions in an effort to keep the Rangers in Manhattan, sources familiar with negotiations between the two sides said yesterday. In addition, the sources said, the city has developed a plan that would enable the Garden to lower its huge electrical costs.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1982
description: International A broad aid plan for the Caribbean calling for trade and investment incentives and technical assistance was proposed by President Reagan. He outlined the six-point economic program in a 40-minute address before the Organization of American States. The President warned Cuba that the United States would do ''whatever is prudent and necessary'' to prevent the overthrow of governments in the region. (Page A1, Column 6.) Caribbean governments welcomed with caution President Reagan's plan to assist the region. But several representatives questioned whether the Reagan Administration's free-enterprise formula was too rigid for an area with mixed economies and major development problems. (A15:1-4.)

title: TRIBUNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: * Alpine Geophysical Corp. said it had acquired Precision Products of North Haven, Conn., for about $3 million, including $2.8 million in cash and debentures and 50,000 shares of Alpine common stock.

title: States News Service Is Sold
description: The financially troubled States News Service, which provides Washington coverage for about 80 newspapers, announced today it had been purchased by a joint venture of the Pulitzer Publishing Company and Indian Head Inc., a New York-based industrial products company. The sale price was not disclosed.

title: TIN MARKET SQUEEZE IS EASING
description: Tin users, who have anxiously watched the metal's price climb steadily in recent months, are breathing a bit more easily. In recent days, the price of tin has fallen sharply, and dealers now say that the squeeze that was expected to wreak havoc in the tin market as early as the end of this week probably will not occur.

title: THEATER: CHAIKIN DIRECTS 'TRESPASSING'
description: DURING his career, Joseph Chaikin has moved back and forth between ensemble activity and more personalized performance pieces, alternatively working as director, author and actor while maintaining his interest in certain recurrent themes. Primary among these is his consideration of death, studied in works as diverse as the Open Theater group collaboration ''Terminal'' and the Chaikin-Sam Shepard monologue ''Tongues.'' ''Trespassing,'' at the La Mama Annex, is his latest, fascinating contemplation of the subject.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Gave Rick Reuschel, pitcher, a two-year extension of his contract.

title: P.L.O., RISK IT
description: If the Palestine Liberation Organization refuses to join the diplomatic game for the West Bank soon, there may be no game to play.

title: Tribune Co.  Net Up 56.3%
description: The Tribune Company, whose operations include The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York, said today that it had record earnings for the fourth quarter and for all of 1981.

title: TYMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
By Sports of The Times; The Genius
description: HE'S known as The Great Gretzky because of the rhythm of the words. But he should be known as The Genius because, as a hockey player, that's what he is. Athletes such as Wayne Gretzky come along in a sport once in a generation, if then. When they do, they always arrive as child prodigies. Most hockey players are content to be considered prospects when they are 21 years old, but when the Edmonton Oilers' slender center turned 21 a month ago, he was pre-eminent.

title: OIL GLUT LEADS TO GASOLINE PRICE CUTS
description: At the Vickers discount gas station on Pecos Street, the sign advertises self-service regular at $1.089 a gallon, and every one of the 12 pumps is humming.

title: Dilemma of Choice
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: No, Ms. Haskell (''Hers,'' Feb. 4), we women do not have to be ''segregated and incarcerated before they can defy the tyranny of glamour and youth.'' All we have to do is stop whining and get our priorities straight.

title: LOWES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a nonrecurring charge of $3,842,000 from discontinued operations of an unconsolidated affiliate

title: JUDGE AND EX-CHIEF OF GENERAL SERVICES
description: Robert Lowe Kunzig, an associate judge of the United States Court of Claims who was the former head of the General Services Administration, died Sunday at Georgetown University Hospital after a short illness. He was 63 years old.

title: Liquor Officials Object To Closing U.S. Office
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to eliminate the agency that helps regulate the liquor industry could lead to watered-down alcohol and infiltration by organized crime, a Senate subcommittee was told Monday.

title: FINAL TESTIMONY HURTS DEFENSE IN ATLANTA TRIAL
description: Wayne B. Williams, his hostility flaring, rested his case at his murder trial today, then saw a parade of prosecution rebuttal witnesses land blow after damaging blow against his defense.

title: ST JUDGE MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
FAN SENTIMENT ON MOVE A MATTER OF GEOGRAPHY
description: The reaction of Ranger fans to the possible move of their hockey team next season to the Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., was split somewhat along geographic lines in a sampling taken at Madison Square Garden last night before the Rangers played the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: Reprinted from Wednesday's issue.
description: Mayor Koch, who vowed he would not get involved in drawing the disputed City Council district lines, has requested that one district be redrawn in a way to protect a Puerto Rican incumbent.

title: Fiery Object Identified As Spent Soviet Rocket
description: A fiery object that lit up the Western sky and broke apart over Idaho in a spectacular display was a falling booster rocket from a Soviet satellite, a United States military spokesman said today.

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: B-After gain on sale of PVO International assets of $423,000; C-After gain on sale of PVO International assets of $4,550,000; D-Net income after gain on sale of PVO International assets of $5,300,000

title: Shell Canada To Sell Units
description: Shell Canada Ltd. said today that it intended to sell more assets, including its agrochemicals business, in order to concentrate on fewer areas.

title: Frederick Poe Graham Dead; Ex-Times Reporter and Editor
description: Frederick Poe Graham, former aviation editor and war correspondent for The New York Times, died Monday in Ripley, W.Va. He was 74 years old.

title: HOOVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; results have been restated to reflect the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding accounting for foreign currency translations

title: Q&A
description: Q. I bought an old house that has plaster walls and ceilings, and in many places the plaster is cracked and crumbling. There are also places where the ceiling plaster is sagging, and in many places the paint is peeling or chipping. What would be the best way to restore and preserve these walls and ceilings? - G.K., Asbury Park, N.J.

title: CALENDAR: GARDEN SERIES AND FOLK ART
description: Urban Gardening, Pratt Manhattan Center, 106 Lexington Avenue (at 30th Street).

title: MUSIC: BABBIT AND WOLPE
description: THERE was an air of brilliant severity emanating from the works by Milton Babbitt and Stefan Wolpe played at the Symphony Space Monday night. The Group for Contemporary Music, by juxtaposing Mr. Babbitt's combinatorial mysticism of recent years with Mr. Wolpe's nonsentimental evocations of displacement, made secular modernity seem almost devotional in its convictions.

title: Irving E. Gershon, Architect; Designed Apartment Houses
description: Irving E. Gershon, an architect who had practiced in Manhattan for 40 years, died Friday at New York Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 earnings reflected a $5 million charge to restructure Lincoln NationalLife's individual life career agency operations

title: GRAMMY FOR YOKO ONO STIRS AWARDS CEREMONY
description: A weeping Yoko Ono and her son, Sean Lennon, received a standing ovation when they accepted a Grammy for ''Double Fantasy,'' the album Miss Ono made with her husband, John Lennon, a few months before his death. The record was voted Album of the Year.

title: PRESIDENT TELLS RADIO AGENCY TO GIVE TRUTH 'ATTRACTIVELY'
description: President Reagan, speaking today at ceremonies marking the 40th anniversary of the Voice of America, said the Government radio network ''remains faithful to those standards of journalism that will not compromise the truth.''

title: REAL AND TREATABLE MENTAL ILLNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: CDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a gain of $200,000 on the divestiture of mechanical construction business segment; year-ago results have been restated to exclude revenues of the divested segment and to reflect a change in accounting in accordance with FASB Statement No 43 regarding unpaid costs of compensated absences

title: No Headline
description: DE PAUL TRUIMPHS OVER FUHRMAN

title: VALERO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics Switched Signals Truth
description: What is ''attractively packaged'' truth? It's the kind of truth that President Reagan described to the staff members of the Voice of America this week, apparently in an effort to indicate how they might embellish the truth to make the United States look good.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt HEADBIRTHS OR THE GERMANS ARE DYING OUT. By Gunter Grass. 136 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95.

title: ANALGO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
CENTRAL AMERICAN STABILITY
description: The Reagan Administration's economic and political strategies are working at cross purposes in Central America.

title: U.S. REIMBURSES DEBT OF RUMANIA TO 2 BANKS
description: In a case similar to that of Poland, the State Department said today that the Federal Government is reimbursing two private American banks $5.8 million because Rumania has failed to meet payments due on Federally guaranteed loans for grain purchases.

title: Cummins Engine To Lay Off 3,000
description: The Cummins Engine Company announced that it would lay off 3,000 workers in its United States and British operations.

title: ALSANDS OIL PROJECT IN CANADA IS LOSING YET ANOTHER PARTNER
description: The troubled $13.1 billion Alsands project to extract crude oil from the vast tar sands of western Canada suffered another serious setback today with the withdrawal of a fifth partner.

title: TO OTIS RUSH, THE GUITAR IS A 2D VOICE FOR THE BLUES
description: BLUES guitarists speak a language all their own. The broad outlines of the language are the same whether the guitarist plays screaming electric lead guitar or carries on an almost private conversation with himself on a battered acoustic instrument. But each guitarist has his own special way of using the language and it identifies him as unmistakably as a fingerprint.

title: BRIEFING
description: Koch's Connection

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $563,800, or 41 cents a share, on the sale of property

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Articles in Metropolitan Report on Jan. 28 and 29 about the suspects in the Brink's holdup, discussing a violent protest at Kennedy Airport, incorrectly described the racial makeup of the Springbok rugby team of South Africa. There was one nonwhite player on the team that toured the United States.

title: Jury Selection to Resume In Public in Corona Case
description: A Superior Court judge today reversed himself and opened to the public the questioning of potential jurors in the retrial of Juan Corona on murder charges.

title: Ogilvy & Mather's Head Receives Another Title
description: Here are two bits of information that Ogilvy & Mather fans should not find hard to take: William E. Phillips, 52-year-old president and chief executive, was additionally elected chairman of Ogilvy & Mather International by the board of directors, which is meeting in Monaco. Already chairman and chief executive of the domestic company, he replaces John Elliott, who has become chairman emeritus.

title: Bridge: It's Strategy That Counts, Not a Tactical Advantage
description: One of the differences between a moderately good bridge player and an expert, like the difference between an Army major and a commanding general, is that he is likely to be obsessed by short-term tactical advantages and to lose sight of long-term strategy.

title: MANHATTAN LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASARCO APPOINTS NEW CHAIRMAN
description: Ralph L. Hennebach, 61 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Asarco Inc., a leading nonferrous metals producer with interests around the world. His appointment will be effective after the annual meeting on April 28.

title: JAPAN AND U.S. SPAR OVER TRADE
description: The Governments of the United States and Japan clashed publicly today for the first time over persistent trade imbalances and what should be done to redress them.

title: SALEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,029,000 for the quarter and $2,230,000 for the year; C-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $761,000; D-After a loss of $1,953,000 from discontinued operations; year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: PANEL PROPOSES END OF AID FOR RENT-CONTROL CITIES
description: A Presidential advisory commission called today for an end to local rent control laws and said that Congress should cut off Federal housing funds to cities that persisted in enforcing controls.

title: U.S. Dismisses Charge It Delays Soviet Talks
description: The Reagan Administration today brushed aside as ''propaganda'' Soviet complaints of needless delay in talks on reduction of strategic arms and said it would not go ahead before it thinks the time is right.

title: UGANDAN GOVERNMENT IN CONTROL AFTER REBEL RAID
description: President Milton Obote of Uganda appeared today to have averted the immediate threat to his Government presented by a prolonged attack on the main army barracks here two days ago, Western diplomats said.

title: POST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 39
JUDGE IS NAMED TO INVESTIGATION POST
description: A 46-year-old judge, appointed to the Criminal Court three years ago by Mayor Koch, was named by the Mayor yesterday to be his Commissioner of Investigation.

title: GULF INTERSTATE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gain of $110,000, or 3 cents a share, on disposition of certain stock held for investment; results for latest year reflect reduction equal to 18 cents a share due to charges against income for research and development costs of company's new technological group, start-up costs in connection with the expansion of company's geophysical company and loss from company's oil and gas operations reported under successful-efforts method of accounting

title: FUGITIVE GUN SMUGGLER APPREHENDED IN MADRID
description: An international arms smuggler who was convicted last year in absentia of attempting to sell 10,000 machine guns to undercover detectives in New York was apprehended in Madrid yesterday, according to the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: People
description: * James B. Hayes named advertising sales director of Money magazine.

title: Minter Leaving Boxing
description: Alan Minter of Britain, the former world middleweight champion, has announced his retirement from boxing. Minter, 30 years old, said he thought of giving up the sport in 1978 after Angelo Jocopucci was fatally injured in the third of Minter's four European title bouts, in Bellaria, Italy.

title: Kansas City Orchestra And Union in Accord
description: The musician's union voted 63-8 yesterday to reinstate its contract with the Kansas City Philharmonic Orchestra. The musicians' actions followed assurances given Tuesday by a philanthropist, who is also a Philharmonic board member, to underwrite the remainder of the orchestra's 1981-82 season.

title: HOP ABOARD FOR A FIFTH AVE. BUS RIDE TO THE PAST
description: New York is one of those cites where things are never what they used to be. Among the things that are most emphatically different is the Fifth Avenue bus, which once was a wonderful and classy doubledecker ride through the parts of town that were, for the most part, the most delightful to look at. But the Fifth Avenue bus as it used to be is, luckily for us, recorded in photographs taken by its proud proprietor, and they are now on view in a gallery of the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street, exactly where the southbound single-deck Central Park West bus stops.

title: Advertising; Benefits Of Network Affiliation
description: AN agency network is an amalgam of shops from various markets that helps the small or medium-sized company compete with the giants. As the words from Longfellow's ''Hiawatha'' go, ''Union gives strength.'' That was the topic yesterday as Harold A. Shoup, president of Carr Liggett Advertising, Cleveland, met with Robert E. Drinkwater, for two years president of the 50-year-old National Advertising Agency Network, which contends it is the largest and oldest of the eight that are listed in Standard Directory of Advertising Agencies.

title: THE RAVES STUNNED HER; The Raves Stunned Her
description: At the National Arts Club, which presented Barbara W. Tuchman with its annual Medal of Honor for Literature, the historian and author was recalling high points in her career. She told about her ''stunned'' reaction to the rave reviews she got for her 1962 book ''The Guns of August.''

title: Criticism of Record on Rights Assailed by Attorney General
description: Attorney General William French Smith today labeled as ''inflammatory and inaccurate'' a report that criticizes the Reagan Administration's civil rights record.

title: EX-CHIEF OF S.B.A. CLEARED IN REPORT
description: M. Michael Cardenas, the former administrator of the Small Business Administration, has been cleared of any improper action in connection with a contract award, according to an internal report made public today.

title: MAXCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After equity losses of $2,803,000 for the quarter and $1,803,000 for the 9 months from earnings of Nucorp Energy Inc

title: A COLLECTOR'S STAINED GLASS GOES ON VIEW AT CLOISTERS
description: IT is difficult to go to the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park on a fine morning toward the end of winter and not feel pleased and uplifted. The sun gives light, if not heat. The air in the central cloister itself is scented ever so slightly by orange trees. The works of art are awesome. Even the staff seems to be having a good time.

title: CENTRAL AMERICANS CALL PARLEY
description: Leaders of five Central American nations called an unexpected meeting within hours of President Reagan's speech on aid to the Caribbean region, Costa Rica's Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Italy-Bahrain Accord
description: A petrochemical company owned by three Persian Gulf Governments announced today that Italy's Snamprogetti S.p.A. had won the contract to build its plant in Bahrain, beating out concerns from Britain, Japan, West Germany and France. The Gulf Petrochemical Industries Company said the contract covered engineering and construction of the complex, which will produce 1,000 metric tons a day of both ammonia and methanol. A spokesman refused to give a value for the contract, but estimates last year of the total plant cost were around $350 million.

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'BOTTOM LINE' FROM FRANCE
description: ''THE BOTTOM LINE,'' which opens today at the Thalia, is a comedy about a Frenchman who makes the leap from cheese to cheesecake overnight. Francois (Pierre Richard) begins the story as a commercial photographer - a cheese layout is the first thing we see him shooting. But he also has ambitions as a film maker. Unfortunately, he soon discovers that a screenplay he has written, entitled ''Mirror of the Soul,'' will be considered bankable only if he turns it into pornography.

title: ART: LOWER MANHATTAN UNFURLED IN FEDERAL HALL
description: THE fact that some New Yorkers carry on as if their city were headquarters for everything is obviously not arrogance but atavism. The place was, after all, the nation's capital for a while, with Federal Hall, at Wall and Broad Streets, the capitol where George Washington, wearing a brown suit made of Connecticut cloth, was sworn in as President 193 years ago come April.

title: U.S. DECISION TO EMBARGO LIBYAN OIL IS REPORTED
description: The Reagan Administration decided today to order an embargo of oil from Libya, Administration officials said. They said the decision was approved by President Reagan at a National Security Council meeting this afternoon and follows months of discussion within the Administration on steps to be taken against the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, which the Administration has accused of supporting world terrorism.

title: STOCKS LOSE STEAM AS DOW SLIPS 0.95
description: The stock market's sharp Wednesday rally centering on energy and other blue-chip issues ran out of momentum yesterday. After climbing about 6 points, the Dow Jones industrial average reversed direction to finish at 825.82, down 0.95. It jumped nearly 14 points Wednesday, as long-depressed oil issues assumed market leadership. Yesterday, most energy stocks showed minimal changes.

title: Police Copter Patrols Over Co-op City Plant
description: City and state agencies monitored the heat and hot water for 60,000 residents of Co-op City yesterday while a police helicopter flew periodic patrol over the Bronx development's power plant. The plant was operated by a contractor's supervisory personnel on the fourth day of a strike by 38 regular engineers.

title: Braniff Cuts Loss in Quarter
description: The Braniff International Corporation, holding company for Braniff Airways, announced yesterday that it had narrowed its loss in the fourth quarter of 1981 to $74.6 million from $76.9 million in the similar 1980 period. Revenues dropped 20.7 percent, to $257.9 million, from $325.2 million.

title: CITY OPERA: WAGNER'S 'DIE FEEN' IN U.S. PREMIERE
description: FOR its spring-season opening performance Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, the New York City Opera mustered the apparent American premiere, in concert form, of the first opera by none other than Richard Wagner. And ''Die Feen,'' composed when Wagner was 20 years old, turned out to be quite remarkable.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SALVADORANS' U.S. CAMPAIGN: SELLING OF REVOLUTION
description: A few minutes before midnight, the two guerrilla leaders from El Salvador and their Mexican host broke off the conversation and switched on the video recorder.

title: Mexico Cuts Its Oil Prices By Up to $2.50
description: The state petroleum monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos, said it would cut its export oil prices by $1.50 to $2.50 a barrel effective March 1 because of the world oversupply of oil and recent price reductions by other major producing nations.

title: UTILITY AND N.R.C. ACCUSED OF MISLEADING ALBANY DURING UPSTATE NUCLEAR ACCIDENT
description: The director of New York State's Radiological Sciences Institute charged today that Federal and utility officials had given the state faulty and incomplete information on the Jan. 25 accident at the Robert E. Ginna nuclear plant near Rochester.

title: AMERICAN SEATING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $572,000 from discontinued operations; the year-ago results have been restated for the retroactive accrual of compensated absences

title: DE FRANCO AND CLARINET COMING BACK
description: WHEN the clarinetist Buddy De Franco was playing with orchestras led by Gene Krupa, Charlie Barnet and Tommy Dorsey in the 1940's, he seemed to be the probable heir to the stardom that Benny Goodman and Artie Shaw had gained in the 30's. But then Mr. De Franco discovered Charlie Parker and be-bop and, after initially emulating Mr. Goodman and Mr. Shaw, became the first be-bop clarinetist.

title: Nominee to Rights Job Defends Ideas on Issues
description: The Rev. B. Sam Hart, nominated by President Reagan to the United States Civil Rights Commission, said today that he supports civil rights for homosexuals although he believes they are guilty of sin.

title: ECKERD, JACK, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1981

title: Restaurants; A Village original and a Paris copy.
description: AMONG the many new restaurants to blossom in Greenwich Village in recent months, the 10th Street Cafe, between Fourth and Bleecker Streets, is one of the more modest and charming. Opened three months ago by Martin Wood, who was one of the original partners in the first Woods restaurant on Madison Avenue, this small and intimate cafe reflects a genuine concern for lightness and originality, with the emphasis on fresh and unusual vegetables.

title: GUARDS CHARGED WITH BRUTALITY IN WESTCHESTER
description: A $52 million damage suit charging brutality by correctional officers in restoring order at the Westchester County Jail last July was filed today by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: Senator D'Amato and the $2,000
description: Sometimes the ethical questions raised in Washington are so subtle that only a scholar would have the patience or imagination to weigh them. Not in this case:

title: ENERGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-The company was incorporated on June 4, 1980 and had no material operations for the quarter ended Jan 31 1981

title: GTS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,027,000

title: IOWA MAINTAINS BIG TEN LEAD
description: With Michael Payne, Bob Hansen and Kenny Arnold scoring a total of 41 points, Iowa kept its one-game Big Ten Conference lead tonight with a 79-55 victory over Wisconsin.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Edward E. Johnson vice president, operations-international.

title: President Begins Steps To Sell Excess Property
description: The Reagan Administration began plans today to sell $2 billion in excess Federal property a year. David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee that Mr. Reagan was signing an order setting up a review board to identify Federal holdings ''that are not being put to highest and best use and to expedite disposal of these properties.''

title: Israeli Aide Ends Egypt Visit Without Accord on Autonomy
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel ended a three-day visit to Egypt today without having persuaded Egyptian officials to agree to a declaration of principles on Palestinian autonomy or set a date for President Hosni Mubarak's promised visit to Israel.

title: A.P.T.A. FIGHTS ETHNIC JOKES
description: They are told everywhere: from the office to the home, from the cocktail party to the business convention. So it ought not come as a surprise when ethnic jokes are recounted on the school bus.

title: LOCAL TELEPHONE SERVICE: THE UNFAIR BARGAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,496,000 for the latest year and $339,000 for the previous year

title: 2 Gunmen Get Jewels In Park Ave. Building
description: Two men armed with pistols forced their way into a woman's apartment in a Park Avenue building yesterday afternoon and made off with $150,000 in jewels, the police said.

title: Tennessee's Victory Over L.S.U. Is Upheld
description: The executive committee of the Southeastern Conference today upheld Tennessee's disputed 54-53 victory over Louisiana State last Saturday.

title: PAY 'N SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MISS VON STADE TO JOIN CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: The American mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade, who will be giving a recital on Feb. 28 in Alice Tully Hall, will become a regular artist-member of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center beginning with the 1982-83 season. She will be the first singer to be a permanent performing member of the Chamber Music Society in its 13-year history.

title: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a net gain of $1 million, or 22 cents a share, on the conversion ofholdings in General Semiconductor into Square D stock; C-Including a pretax gain of $11,665,000 from the sale of Unitrode Corp stock

title: Man Charged in Book Thefts
description: A St. Louis man suspected of stealing $500,000 in rare books from college libraries around the country was indicted by a Federal grand jury Wednesday. James R. Shinn, 45 years old, who was arrested in Allentown, Pa., last Dec. 16, was charged with receiving stolen property and receiving stolen goods.

title: Jesse Jackson Sees Pope About Haitian Refugees
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the American civil rights leader, met with Pope John Paul II for 20 minutes today to discuss the plight of Haitian refugees living in Florida, the Vatican said. It released no details on what it described as a private audience.

title: MET OPERA BALLET IS DANCING UPTOWN
description: Ballet dancers in opera companies get to dance a lot of Walpurgisnachtian orgiasts or waltzing, glass-raising party guests, but often not much else. Tonight through Sunday afternoon, however, New Yorkers will have a chance to see the Metropolitan Opera Ballet in a program of ''real'' dance at City College's well-appointed Aaron Davis Hall, not the first such program the company has performed in its 99-year history, but certainly one of the most varied.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When this bill becomes law, I have failed, but not until then.'' - Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., ending filibuster against antibusing legislation. (A14:1.)

title: WEBB, DEL E, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a nonrecurring net loss of $2,502,000 for the quarter and a nonrecurring net gain of $10,858,000, or $1.14 a share, for the year primarily from major hotel property dispositions offset by a writedown of other assets; C-Including a nonrecurring gain of $8,675,000, or 91 cents a share, primarily from the sale ofcommercial property in Sun City, Ariz and an office complex in Phoenix

title: Leary Is in No Rush To Impress the Mets
description: Tim Leary stood on the practice mound, scowling as he cranked his right arm in slow circles to loosen his shoulder in preparation for the first pitch of the day.

title: Art People; Help wanted at 2 museums.
description: THE directorial saddles are empty again at two prominent institutions: the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Houston Museum of Fine Arts. In Philadelphia, Jean Sutherland Boggs, a Canadian who has been director since July 1978, has resigned to head a corporation that will oversee the siting, design and construction of two museums in Ottawa - a new National Gallery of Canada and an anthropological facility, the National Museum of Man. And in Houston, Bill Agee, director of the museum there for the last eight years, has resigned ''to return to research and writing.'' But thereby hang two tales.

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cobb Expected As Holmes Foe
description: Randy (Tex) Cobb will apparently become the interim opponent for Larry Holmes in early April while Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, waits for Gerry Cooney's injured left shoulder to heal for their fight June 11.

title: A HEADQUARTERS ADDED BY REGAN ON JOCULAR NOTE
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan opened his New York City headquarters yesterday in his bid for the Republican nomination for Governor and called the campaign a two-candidate race between him and Mayor Koch.

title: DESIGN CHANGE CITED IN HYATT DISASTER
description: A change in the design of the walkways over the atrium lobby of the Kansas City Hyatt Regency Hotel was crucial in causing their collapse at a crowded tea dance last July, the National Bureau of Standards said today.

title: Israeli Diplomat Warns Of Move Into Lebanon
description: Israel's new Ambassador to the United States warned today that Israel could be forced to take military action in southern Lebanon, declaring ''I would almost say it's a matter of time.''

title: SCHMIDT AND THE BEAR
description: Why did Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, in his recent interview with my colleague William Safire, so sharply downgrade Western military power in Europe?

title: Rolling Stone Gets A New Publisher
description: Peter A. Bonanni, 49, who in effect has been running Woman's Day, catering mostly to millions of home-oriented women, will start Monday as publisher of Rolling Stone, with a far smaller, younger and hipper audience.

title: AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $1.9 million for the quarterand $9.4 million for the year; C-Including an extraordinary gain of $17.2 million on the redemption of certain Penn Central securities

title: News Analysis
description: After its rapprochement with the United Automobile Workers fell apart last month, the General Motors Corporation chose a familiar route to counter dismal sales. It announced plans to close three plants indefinitely in March, including its Chevrolet and Cadillac plant here, and throw another 7,000 employees out of work.

title: BOB GRAY: PUBLIC RELATIONS MAN TO THE POWERFUL
description: Washington P.R. Wars, Scene One: Nancy Thurmond is sitting in Bob Gray's office. ''I just had a meeting on Project Hope,'' she is saying, referring to her favorite charity ball. ''It was the unanimous feeling of the group that you'd be wonderful to do the publicity.''

title: BUDGET ADVISERS SAY '83 DEFICIT IS MISCALCULATED
description: The Congressional Budget Office, in a ''very grim'' assessment of President Reagan's proposed budget, said today that the White House had underestimated its proposed deficit for the fiscal year 1983 by $29 billion and warned of ''continuing large and growing Federal deficits into the foreseeable future.''

title: SOVIET IS SCOFFING AT CARIBBEAN PLAN
description: The Soviet press agency Tass charged today that ''anti-Communist paranoia'' in Washington was behind the stepped-up program of aid to Caribbean nations that President Reagan announced on Wednesday.

title: Randy Johnson Indicted
description: Randy Johnson, the former professional quarterback, has been indicted on a forgery charge, a felony, and is being sought as a fugitive, Bexar County Court officials said in San Antonio. Johnson, 37, spent 11 years in the National Football League with four teams, including the Giants, and in 1981 was head coach of the Austin Texans in the American Football Association, a summer professional league.

title: SAUDI IS REPORTED TO AGREE TO TERMS ON USE OF AWACS
description: The Defense Minister of Saudi Arabia, Prince Sultan, has privately signed an agreement on conditions for Saudi operation of the Awacs radar planes to be sold to his country, according to State Department, Pentagon and Congressional officials.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Signed Brad Gulden, catcher, to one-year contract.

title: Tobacco Lobby Opens Cigarette Campaign
description: This week, just as the Surgeon General issued especially strong new warnings against cigarette smoking, the Tobacco Institute, the Washington-based lobbying organization of tobacco product manufacturers, began an estimated $6 million defensive magazine advertising campaign.

title: LONGTIME U.S. ENVOY
description: Clare Hayes Timberlake, who was Washington's first Ambassador to the Congo, now Zaire, during that country's violent transition from being a Belgian colony, died Monday in a nursing home in Bethesda, Md., after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Fort Sumner, Md.

title: Earnings Fall at General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter fell 38 percent, to $32.6 million, or 60 cents a share, from $52.6 million, or 96 cents, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Sales rose 4.8 percent, to $1.32 billion, from $1.26 billion.

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BRANIFF INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $8.6 million from the disposition of property and equipment; C-Including a gain of $79.1 million from the sale of property and equipment,a tax credit of $7.1 million and costs of $1.3 million associated with discontinued routes

title: Money Funds Gain in Week
description: Assets of the nation's 172 money market funds rose $1.24 billion, to $186.23 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: U.S.-JAPAN: NEW TENSIONS
description: HISTORICALLY, depressions have grown out of the periods of expansion that followed major wars. The long expansion that followed World War II was notable both for its duration and for the growing worldwide economic integration that nourished it.

title: NEW CLUBS: ROCK, REGGAE AND JUST DANCING
description: Last September, those who nightly make the tour of the New York club circuit were convinced that nothing new loomed on the horizon. They could not think of a new place to wear their pumps, to stay up and drink vodka, to listen to James Brown, The B-52's, Marianne Faithfull or a little reggae. After the halcyon days of Studio 54, was there nothing left to disturb the universe?

title: PARIS AND BONN MOVE TO PATCH THINGS UP
