description: The Polish crisis and the bleak economic effects of high United States interest rates have apparently convinced France and West Germany that it is time to reassert the close partnership of recent years.

title: BOMB LEFT ON DOORSTEP KILLS JERSEY COUPLE AND INJURES 2
description: A couple was killed this morning when a bomb that had been placed in a box at their front door exploded while they were examining the package inside their modest one-story home here.

title: Jerry Sadler, Texas Politician Noted for Fights, Dies at 74
description: Jerry Sadler, a crusty East Texan whose snuff habit and fistfights made him a political legend in the state, died early today. He was 74 years old.

title: STUDENTS ASSERT HIRING IS BIASED AT LAW SCHOOL
description: Concerned over what they said was the small number of women and minority-group members on the faculty of Columbia Law School, eight student organizations asked the Federal Government yesterday to investigate hiring practices at the school.

title: PUBLISHING: THE OKLAHOMA 'NOBEL'
description: AN international jury that convened yesterday at the University of Oklahoma is trying to decide which of 11 authors will be awarded the $25,000 Neustadt international prize for literature, given every two years in recognition of outstanding achievement in poetry, fiction or drama. Candidates for the award, which will be announced today or tomorrow, include Robert Penn Warren, John Hawkes and Laura Riding of the United States, Vladimir Voinovich of the Soviet Union (now a resident of France), Octavio Paz of Mexico and Ted Hughes of Britain. Ba Jin, a novelist and translator, is the first candidate from China in the history of the prize.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: C ULTURE and Studio 54 are not exactly synonymous, but occasionally the twain meet. Culture took over the trendy discotheque Tuesday night at what was billed as a Bal Masque, the first of three fundraisers celebrating the 38th birthday of the New York City Opera.

title: SPLIT WIDENS IN SOUTH AFRICA AS VORSTER BACKS BOTHA FOES
description: The split in the governing National Party deepened today as Prime Minister P.W. Botha's predecessor, John Vorster, emerged from retirement to side with the 22 members of Parliament who voted Wednesday against a motion of confidence in Mr. Botha's leadership.

title: IN 'VENOM,' THE SNAKE STEALS THE SHOW
description: Near the beginning of ''Venom,'' the movie thriller now playing at the Embassy 4 and other theaters, 10-year-old Philip Hopkins drops in at a pet store to buy a harmless African house snake. When he gets home, he taps his fingers happily on the unopened box, already enjoying his new pet.

title: Egyptian Magazine Says 1,000 to Be Indicted
description: Nearly 1,000 Moslem extremists will be indicted shortly on charges of involvement in an abortive coup attempt to set up a fundamentalist regime like that of the Iranian leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, a weekly magazine said today.

title: MEANS SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SECRETARY SCHWEIKER'S FLAWED PLAN TO CURB TEEN-AGE SEX
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Marion Motley's Dream
description: HARRIET TUBMAN is gone, Langston Hughes is gone, Martin Luther King Jr. is gone, but the students at St. Charles Borromeo School did meet a hero of black American history yesterday.

title: EUGENE MEYER, MEDICAL PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Eugene Meyer 3d, professor emeritus of medicine and psychiatry at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, died Wednesday of cancer at his home in Washington. He was 66 years old.

title: UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $217.3 million from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting

title: SHIP IS UNEARTHED AT WATER STREET
description: Buried 15 feet below Water Street on what used to be the Manhattan waterfront, an 18th-century merchant ship has been unearthed. Examination has shown that the ship, which sailed the Caribbean in the early 1700's, was brought to shore some time after 1746 - the date on a ceramic top found below her decks.

title: ANGERED BY PAKISTANI OFFICIAL, INDIA CANCELS ISLAMABAD VISIT
description: Moves to improve relations between India and Pakistan were set back today as the Indian Government said it would not attend talks in the Pakistani capital because of ''objectionable statements'' by a Pakistani diplomat about Kashmir.

title: PRICE INDEX HOLDS STEADY FOR NEW YORK REGION
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey region was unchanged in January on a seasonally adjusted basis, marking the fourth month of overall stability.

title: HOUSE PANEL FINDS WATT IN CONTEMPT
description: In a constitutional confrontation with the Reagan Administration, a House committee voted today to cite Interior Secretary James G. Watt for contempt of Congress for failing to provide subpoenaed documents.

title: State Completes Its Case In the von Bulow Trial
description: The state today rested its case in Claus C. von Bulow's trial on charges of attempted murder. The last prosecution witness, Mr. von Bulow's stepdaughter, testified that her mother had said she was thinking of divorcing the defendant.

title: FOES OF MOVE TO BAN BUSING END THEIR SENATE FILIBUSTER
description: Senate opponents of a stringent measure against busing agreed to end their eight-month filibuster today, and passage of the legislation is now considered virtually assured next week.

title: SCREEN ACTORS PANEL STANDS BY ASNER
description: While 100 members of the Screen Actors Guild picketed outside guild headquarters Wednesday night, the guild's board of directors passed a resolution reaffirming the right of Edward Asner, the guild's president, ''to speak out on political and/or public issues'' as an individual citizen and concluded that he had done nothing ''improper.'' Mr. Asner has been under attack by conservative members of the guild, including its past president, Charlton Heston, because of his public support of the rebels in El Salvador. Mr. Heston has charged that Mr. Asner is politicizing the guild.

title: Interest Rates Are Up Slightly; 3-Month Bill Yields 12.37%
description: Short-term and long-term rates rose slightly yesterday, with the three-month Treasury bill rate rising to 12.37 percent from 12 percent. The yield of 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 13.74 percent from 13.6 percent as its price fell slightly more than a point.

title: FISHER FOODS INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Jan 2
description: B-After extraordinary net losses of $520,000 for the 12 weeks and $8,772,000 for the year; results are for 12 weeks and 52 weeks for the latest periods and 13 and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WESTPHAL ASSURED SALARY FOR WAITING
description: Though he cannot play until he learns whether he belongs to the Knicks or the Seattle SuperSonics, Paul Westphal is assured of $5,000 a game while the issue is being decided. This is in addition to a $150,000 salary for the rest of the season and huge playoff bonuses that could make his total earnings more than half a million dollars between now and June.

title: G.M. SETS CLOSING OF 4 PARTS PLANTS
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would permanently close four automobile parts plants in the next two years. It said it can obtain the parts less expensively elsewhere.

title: WEATHERFORD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fuqua to Sell Theater Unit
description: Fuqua Industries, which abandoned plans last September to take the conglomerate private, said it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its Martin Theaters unit to the Carmike Corporation of Columbus, Ga., for $25 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, the review of Garry Wills's book ''The Kennedy Imprisonment: A Meditation on Power'' yesterday included two incorrect references to the author Veblen. They should have read ''Weber.''

title: SIMKINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VIRGINIA BRUCE, 72, ACTRESS PORTRAYED ZIEGFELD SHOWGIRL
description: Virginia Bruce, who portrayed the quintessential Ziegfeld showgirl in the lavish 1936 musical film ''The Great Ziegfeld'' and was the last wife of John Gilbert, the silent-screen lover, died Wednesday following a long illness. She was 72 years old.

title: OPERAGOERS TO GET A RARE LOOK AT GOETZ'S 'TAMING OF SHREW'
description: New York's smaller opera companies do a good job of keeping the city's opera fans stocked with delectable operatic rarities. But tomorrow evening and Sunday afternoon the John Brownlee Opera Theater of the Manhattan School of Music will be offering an especially appealing bit of exotica from the past - Hermann Goetz's ''The Taming of the Shrew.''

title: Accounts
description: * Town & Country magazine to Geers Gross Advertising.

title: HEROIN ADDICTION: PROBLEM FOR MIDDLE CLASS ALSO
description: Frank, who earns $150,000 a year as a 30-year-old vice president of a Wall Street banking firm, spends his weekday lunch hours receiving doses of methadone at a clinic. He is a heroin addict, and until a year ago he was spending $100 a day to support his habit.

title: FOLK ART MUSEUM IS SHOWING RECENT ACQUISITIONS
description: One of the most important private collections of American painted furniture, weathervanes, paintings and carvings is on view at the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street. The exhibition of 33 examples of naive Americana in ''Folk Art Masterpieces: Recent Accessions from the Howard and Jean Lipman Collection,'' opened yesterday and remains there through Sept. 19.

title: Leak of Chemical Sickens 19
description: The leak of a toxic chemical at an industrial park sent 19 persons to hospitals tonight and forced 200 to 300 more to evacuate the park, said Mike LaCivita, spokesman for the state Office of Emergency and Energy Services.

title: CBS Buys Its First Cable System
description: CBS Inc. disclosed here today that it had purchased its first cable television property, a 35-channel system that covers eight small jurisdictions between Dallas and Fort Worth.

title: AMID DEBATE, U.S. PANEL ASKS WIDER POWERS FOR THRIFT UNITS
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today proposed broad new powers for federally chartered savings and loan associations that would let them compete much more directly with commercial banks and other financial institutions.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions

title: 2 Iranians Said to Escape Assassination Attempts
description: Iran's police chief and a religious leader escaped separate assassination attempts in Teheran, Iran's official press reported today.

title: A WELL-KNOWN BEIRUT HIJACKER STRIKES AGAIN
description: The mufti in the control tower was in for a difficult night; below him, on the tarmac of Beirut International Airport, the well-known Shiite Moslem hijacker ''Hamzeh'' was at work on his seventh plane.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1982
description: International An American-Saudi accord on Awacs has been signed by the Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, according to Reagan Administration and Congressional officials. They said the agreement set forth conditions on Saudi operation of the radar warning planes, but it was not clear whether Prince Sultan had accepted all the conditions that President Reagan had pledged would be set. (Page A1, Column 6.) An embargo on oil from Libya has been approved by President Reagan, Administration officials said. The embargo was described as the second phase of the Administration's anti-Libyan policy. (A1:2-4.)

title: Norway, U.S.S.R. End Ski Race in Dead Heat
description: Norway and the Soviet Union finished in a dead heat in the 40-kilometer cross-country relay at the world Nordic skiing championships today. Both were awarded gold medals, and Finland won the bronze medal in a photo finish with East Germany for third place.

title: AT CENTER OF TAX FIGHT
description: Edward C. Schmults, one of the senior officials who presided over the Administration's shifts in its policy on tax exemptions for private schools, is a Wall Street lawyer who has left his imprimatur on such varied political issues as airline deregulation and New York City's Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: ENERSERV PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New York Air Chief
description: New York Airlines, created by the Texas Air Corporation, said yesterday that it had named Michael E. Levine, the executive vice president of marketing at Continental Air Lines, as its chairman and chief executive officer, succeeding as chairman Frank Lorenzo, who will remain as a director.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC: BEETHOVEN
description: IT is a little bit saddening to hear instrumentalists of the caliber of Vladimir Ashkenazy, Itzhak Perlman and Lynn Harrell play Beethoven trios in a blandly charming manner, without exhibiting a single musical idea worthy of interest, and without treating a single musical line with an attitude more complex than graceful recitation.

title: Koch Ponders Future
description: He loves children and someday may get married and have some, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: ASTRONAUT RUNS AGAIN; Astronaut Runs Again
description: He was defeated when he ran for the Republican nomination for United States Senator in Colorado in 1978, but Jack Swigert, a former Apollo astronaut, said yesterday he was again a candidate for Congress.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $5.2 million for the quarter and year from the sale of certain tax benefits

title: BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $588,000 for the quarter and $823,000 for the 6 months; C-Net income; year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 5% stock dividend issued in December 1980

title: JESUIT OVERSEER PRESENTING THE POPE'S VIEWS
description: For the second full day, the senior priests of the Society of Jesus listened today while the man Pope John Paul II imposed as their acting head discoursed to them on the Pope's views of their achievements and shortcomings.

title: Canada Rig Inquiries Merge
description: Canada and Newfoundland Province anounced today that they had merged their inquiries into the sinking of the oil rig Ocean Ranger with the loss of all 84 people on board. The two governments, which both claim ownership of the offshore Hibernia oil field, had announced separate inquiries into the disaster 10 days ago.

title: PEAVEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 21
On-Court Protest
description: A dispute over the restructuring of the athletic department at Northern Illinois University led to the interruption of a basketball game on Wednesday night.

title: Home Sales in January Off
description: Existing home sales in January, battered by severe weather and high mortgage rates, fell to the lowest level since 1970, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

title: HURDLE DUEL SPICES NATIONAL TITLE MEET
description: The indoor track and field season makes another run through Madison Square Garden tonight with the USA/ Mobil national championships. In a season during which 31 American records or world-best standards have been established, two women hurdlers, Stephanie Hightower and Candy Young, have been among the chief contributors.

title: ON OFF BROADWAY IT'S THE SEASON OF CHARACTER ACTORS
description: THE art of acting is, or should be, immutable, whether one is playing Shakespeare or Sam Shepard: the use of one's self as an instrument is an act of theatrical transformation. Something magical must happen even before the actor walks on stage, and perhaps it is as simple as Pablo Casals's instruction, quoted in Robert Lewis's book ''Advice to the Players'': ''Now that we've learned the notes, please forget them.'' Otherwise, technique will vanquish virtuosity.

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reflect the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding accounting for foreign currency translations

title: ALASKA INTERSTATE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a net charge of $11 million for the redemption fund of Alaska Interstate's Virginia International Co unit special stock; C-After a loss of $13.9 million from discontinued operations and nonrecurring income of $7 million, or 59 cents a share

title: MAKE BOSSES GET RID OF LIE DETECTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Gulden Signs For One Year
description: The Yankees signed Brad Gulden, the catcher, to a one-year contract today.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes gains from currency adjustment of $51,000 for the quarter and $910,000 for the 6 months; C-Including losses from currency adjustment of $2.2 millionfor the quarter and $1.8 millio for the 6 months

title: KEYSTONE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The 1980 share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated for a 5-for-4stock distribution in May 1981

title: BELCO PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $4,919,000 for the quarter and $12,415,000 for the year; C-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,619,000 and a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $8,793,000

title: REAGAN TO WEIGH SOVIET GAS PIPELINE ISSUE TODAY
description: President Reagan is due to meet with his advisers on Friday to resolve a dispute between the State and Defense Departments on trying to block the Europeans from helping construct a pipeline to carry Siberian natural gas to Western Europe, Administration officials said today.

title: TV Weekend; BASH ABOARD 'LOVE BOAT'
description: FLUSHED with the long-running success of its weekly cruises, ABC's ''The Love Boat'' is throwing a party for itself tomorrow at 9 P.M. The occasion is the Pacific Princess's ''first annual cruise show,'' featuring both crew and passengers. As it happens, the passenger list includes Ann Miller, Ethel Merman, Carol Channing, Della Reese, Van Johnson and Cab Calloway.

title: 8 People, 4 Companies Indicted in Cuba Sealift
description: Eight persons and four corporations were indicted by a Federal grand jury late Wednesday on charges of illegally trading with Cuba in the 1980 Mariel sealift.

title: A Town Flees Derailment
description: The derailment of a freight train with a car carrying hazardous liquid phosphorous trichloride forced all 2,985 residents to flee this small eastern Georgia town today, but the danger eased after railroad crews pulled the car upright.

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for latest year reflect quarterly restatement for an accounting change on foreign currency translation, a loss equal to 5 cents a share for a special provision on the phaseout of the company's folder division and a gain equal to 4 cents a share on the sale of land; results for the previous year reflect a gain equal to 6 cents a share on the disposal of two subsidiaries

title: AMERICAN HALTS ORDER AT BOEING
description: Beset by losses, American Airlines announced yesterday that it had taken the unusual step of backing out of its commitment to buy 15 new fuel-efficient 757 jets, worth about $600 million, from the Boeing Company.

title: REAGAN TO NOMINATE 10 BOARD MEMBERS OF LEGAL AID GROUP
description: President Reagan plans to name 10 new board members of the Legal Services Corporation despite his plan to gradually eliminate the federally financed agency that provides lawyers for the poor, the White House announced today.

title: Tax Gasoline
description: General Motors's new mid-size ''A-body'' cars are just what the doctor ordered. They use fuel sparingly and have a clean, high-tech look resembling Japan's best. There is only one hitch: not many people are buying them. G.M.'s older, less efficient mid-size cars in the ''G-body'' line are outselling the A-cars by about 3 to 1.

title: LAND RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; Investing In a Few Stocks
description: THE individual who accepts the conventional wisdom may feel threatened in holding a mere handful of stocks but will do it anyway to make a big profit. That's a conclusion of Thomas E. Conine Jr. and Maurry Tamarkin who seek to explain why many individuals do not diversify but concentrate on two to four stocks.

title: THE HONORABLE BRIDLEGOOSE ROLLS TO JUDGEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: A SPOKESMAN COMMENTS ON HIS JOB
description: John H. Trattner has put in more than a dozen years as a State Department spokesman, and he knows how it feels to try to sell the press a story it doesn't want to buy.

title: Nigerian Heads World Court
description: The 15-member International Court of Justice today elected Taslim Olawale Elias of Nigeria to be its president. Judge Elias, 67 years old, had been acting president and succeeds Sir Humphrey Waldock of Britain, who died in August.

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
LAWYER IN CAPITAL
description: Ralph E. Casey, a former Government lawyer who sharply criticized excessive subsidies to private shipping companies and who later became the chief spokesman for a large segment of that industry, died of cancer Tuesday night at his home in Point Clear, Ala. He was 70 years old.

title: Stadler, On a 66, Is Leader
description: The first round of the Doral-Eastern Open ended today with a mix of little-known players and such familiar ones as Craig Stadler, Jack Nicklaus and Tom Weiskopf among the leaders.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONSUMER PRICE INDEX ROSE 0.3% LAST MONTH, LEAST SINCE JULY '80
description: In a report reflecting fresh progress against inflation, the Government said today that the Consumer Price Index climbed only three-tenths of 1 percent last month, the smallest rise since July 1980.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT PENGUINS
description: Despite their listless play tonight, the Islanders were able to beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 4-2, and extend their home winning streak to 14 games.

title: ABC VIDEO CREATES POSITION OF PRESIDENT
description: After working for more than 25 years in radio and television and serving as vice president in charge of ABC Video Enterprises since it was founded in 1979, Herbert A. Granath, 48, has been promoted to the new office of president of the unit of the American Broadcasting Companies.

title: No Headline
description: LAKERS'S LATE RALLY BEATS SONICS, 104-98

title: RKO LOSES BOSTON STATION
description: The Federal Communications Commission closed its door today to final appeals by RKO General Inc. to retain control of WNAC, its Boston television station, and gave preliminary approval for the station to be taken over by the New England Television Corporation.

title: TOTAL OF YOUTHS IN CITY DECLINED 21% IN DECADE
description: The number of youngsters under the age of 18 in New York City has dropped 21 percent since 1970. Many experts agree that the decline will provide some short-term benefits by relieving the enormous demands on many of the city's social institutions.

title: 'SUPERLUXURY' APARTMENTS GO UP NEAR SUTTON PLACE
description: Despite the current softness in the market for cooperatives and condominiums, local real estate developers, especially those building or converting in Manhattan, remain confident about the strength of residential development here. One reason they cite is the noticeable influx in recent years of investment in very expensive cooperative and condominium apartments from foreign nationals and from individuals who live in other parts of the United States.

title: Tin Prices Fall Sharply
description: Tin prices plunged today to $14,100 a metric ton, the lowest level since last July, leaving dealers on the London Metal Exchange baffled about the cause of the collapse.

title: Broadway; 'Solomon's Child,' Play About Cults, Opens April 8
description: ANTHONY ZERBE will star in ''Solomon's Child,'' which will open at the Little Theater on April 8. Mr. Zerbe, who most recently played Elizabeth Taylor's brother Ben in ''The Little Foxes,'' will play a deprogrammer named Balthazar. He deprograms young people who have been abducted from cults. Everyone connected with ''Solomon's Child,'' however, solemnly agrees that it is not so much about deprogramming as it is about parents, children and a society in which cults flourish. Therefore, they are calling it ''a contemporary mystery.'' Whatever they call it, the play by Tom Dulack was nicely received when it was done at the Long Wharf Theater last season.

title: SAVINGS BANKS LOSE HEAVILY
description: Despite the decline in interest rates at the end of 1981, New York City's leading savings banks continued to lose large amounts of money in the fourth quarter, with the four biggest reporting a combined net operating loss of more than $139 million, savings bank sources said yesterday.

title: ARMY'S TREATMENT OF FILIPINO CIVILIANS CRITICIZED
description: Brig. Gen. Alfredo S. Olano, in jeans and short-sleeved shirt, sat in the lobby bar of the Cuison Hotel drinking Johnny Walker Black Label and soda and holding a microphone that he gladly accepted from a young female singer.

title: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nicholas Wade Joins Times To Write Science Editorials
description: Nicholas Wade, a former editor of Science magazine, has joined the editorial board of The New York Times, Max Frankel, the editorial page editor, announced yesterday.

title: CONCERT: 'MUSIC FROM JAPAN' PERFORMED AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: THE ''Music From Japan'' concert at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night turned out to be a pleasant event. Four works by composers unfamiliar to most New Yorkers were performed in a program put together by Naoyuki Miura, a double-bass player in the American Symphony Orchestra, and played by that ensemble under the direction of Kenneth Schermerhorn. The pieces, neither extreme in idiom nor earthshaking, were amiable and easy to listen to and went together nicely.

title: NARCO SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $427,000 for quarter and $5,040,000 for year; C-After income from discontinued operations of $121,000; the company said that 1981 net was increased by $552,000, or 30 cents a share, from an accounting change for foreign currency translations and 1980 results wereincreased by $265,000 or 14 cents a share

title: ATLANTA MURDER TRIAL TESTIMONY ENDS
description: Testimony in the murder trial of Wayne B. Williams ended today with his mother saying the authorities had ruined her family, ''but they haven't produced any evidence my son is a killer.''

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: Phil Niekro, denying reports that he might miss a month or more of spring training with the Atlanta Braves, said that a hamstring pull would put him out of action for a week to 10 days. The 43-year-old right-hander was hurt while running wind sprints ... A fourth jockey has been indicted in connection with a reported scheme to fix thoroughbred horse races last year at the Meadowlands.

title: E.E.C. PLANS TO CUT SOVIET IMPORTS
description: The Common Market's Executive Commission asked its member governments today to approve a cutback in imports from the Soviet Union of roughly $470 million this year as a protest against the military crackdown in Poland.

title: GIFTS TO AID THE NEEDIEST TOP $1.5 MILLION NEAR DRIVE'S END
description: Contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have exceeded $1.5 million as the 70th annual appeal, which had already set a record, nears its end.

title: QUEBEC FUND HOLDS BIGGEST ALCAN BLOCK
description: Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, the pension fund for the province of Quebec's teachers and civil servants, has become the largest single shareholder in Alcan Aluminium Ltd., Alcan disclosed today.

title: NASSAU TO REVAMP INSURANCE METHOD
description: Francis T. Purcell, the Nassau County Executive, announced today that the county would use a new approach to buying insurance, an approach that he said should avoid any future conflicts of political interest.

title: PENNSYLVANIAN ACCUSED OF JAILING FRIEND UNDERGROUND FOR 45 DAYS
description: The Pennsylvania state police are investigating a bizarre case of a gold coin and a graduate student they freed from chains after 45 days of captivity in an underground tank.

title: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1982; The Economy
description: The Consumer Price Index rose just 0.3 percent in January, the smallest gain since July 1980. Compounded annually, Labor Department officials said, the inflation rate would be 3.5 percent. From January to January, the rate was 8.4 percent, down from 11.7 percent a year earlier. Declines in the prices of gasoline, cars, houses and clothing helped offset a surge in food prices. Economists were optimistic that inflation would remain subdued at least through midyear. (Page A1.) The inflation rate in the New York area was unchanged. (D4.)

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $3.7 million; C-After an extraordinary charge of $8 million

title: Abortion and the Squeal Rule
description: The Reagan Administration issued a rule the other day that requires federally funded family planning clinics to notify the parents of patients under 18 when their children are receiving prescription birth-control devices.

title: Auctions; Five sessions for prints.
description: THE market for European and American 19th- and 20th-century prints continues to be one of the strongest for auction houses both here and abroad. Whether it be the costliest prints selling in six figures or the most modest, bringing prices in three and four figures, the popularity of this material continues unabated.

title: Dick Allen Returns to the Batting Cage
description: Pat Putnam, the Texas Rangers' first baseman, stood in the batting cage along the right-field line and swung at pitch after pitch from Wayne Terwilliger, a Ranger coach.

title: REAGAN'S SALVADOR RIGHTS REPORT: THE BALANCE SHEET
description: Ambassador Deane R. Hinton of the United States told a gathering of Salvadoran business executives recently that there had been ''serious excesses'' in human rights abuses in their country. And a report he sent to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. noted that Government soldiers were responsible for most of the unexplained killings here.

title: At the Movies; No Oscar this year for Miss Jackson.
description: NO matter who wins the Academy Award for best actress of 1981, it won't be Glenda Jackson for ''Stevie.'' Miss Jackson, who came to New York last month to accept the New York Film Critics Circle award (two weeks earlier, she got an award from the National Board of Review) for playing the poet Stevie Smith, is not eligible for an Oscar.

title: Essay; BIN ICH NOCH EIN BERLINER?
description: Ronald Reagan will be visiting West Germany in three months but has not yet decided whether to visit Berlin; that illustrates the striking change that has taken place in our relationship with the Federal Republic in one decade.

title: Columbia Announces 5-Year Drive Director
description: Columbia University has named a vice president for university development and alumni relations.

title: Columbia Pictures In French Venture
description: Columbia Pictures, which has agreed to be acquired by the Coca-Cola Company in a $780 million transaction, has formed a joint venture with Gaumont Films, France's biggest and oldest studio, to distribute and produce movies for specialized markets in the United States.

title: U.N. VOTES TO EXPAND ITS FORCE IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: The Security Council today approved the addition of 1,000 troops to its peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon.

title: NAVY IS CRACKING DOWN AT BIGGEST TRAINING BASE
description: ''The strip,'' blocks of shabby pizza parlors, dimly lit taverns and spartan-looking religious ''drop-in'' centers, has for years drawn thousands of young sailors from the Great Lakes Training Center.

title: INTER-REGIONAL FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated for the merger with Rauscher Pierce RefsnesInc on a pooling of interests basis

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; CAGE AT THE WHITNEY
description: Works by the composer John Cage can be seen but not heard in a survey of his visual achievements at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Cage developed his own systems of musical notation in the 1930's, and the exhibition, celebrating his 70th birthday, offers selections of his hand-drawn music scores, including one that uses stars rather than musical notes as points of reference and another consisting of two lithographs and eight silk-screened plexiglass sheets arranged at random on a wooden base. Also on view is nonmusical graphic work by Cage and a 216-image photographic portrait of the composer by Robert Mahon. Concerts of Cage music are planned March 31-April 2 (admission: $5 for each). Admission to the museum, at Madison and 75th Street, is $2 (free for children, students and the elderly).

title: HOW HARTFORD FEDERAL MANAGED TO HALT ITS RUN
description: Things are nearly normal again these days at the Hartford Federal Savings and Loan Association, although Christopher W. Carriuolo, its chairman, keeps getting a lot of telephone calls from other bankers and savings institutions around the country.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STAGE: GUARE'S 'LYDIE BREEZE'
description: IN the opening shots of John Guare and Louis Malle's remarkable film ''Atlantic City,'' we watch ghostly old beach hotels, the repositories of gilded, early 20th-century American dreams, collapse under the wreckers' ball. ''Lydie Breeze,'' the Guare-Malle theatrical collaboration that opened at the American Place last night, is set in another crumbling beach town of another era - hurricane-gutted Nantucket in 1895 - but it is about the same dreams, the same ghosts, the same kind of metaphorical wreckage.

title: Drifter Indicted in 2 Slayings
description: Robert Dale Henderson, the drifter who the police say has confessed to killing ''10 or 11'' people in a rampage last month, was indicted today for first-degree murder in the Jan. 25 deaths of Dr. Murray Ferderber and Dorothy Wilkinson. The suspect, 36 years old, is also charged with the deaths of three of his in-laws in Ohio and the slayings of a man in Louisiana and a woman in Mississippi.

title: ISRAEL SEALS OFF VILLAGES OF STRIKING DRUSE IN GOLAN
description: Israeli troops today sealed off four Arab Druse villages in the Golan Heights where a general strike has been under way for 12 days over an issue related to Israel's annexation of the area. The military move followed the failure of a political attempt Wednesday night to settle the strike.

title: SCHOOL TAX ISSUE PUT TO HIGH COURT IN SHIFT BY REAGAN
description: The Reagan Administration asked the Supreme Court today to decide whether racially discriminatory private schools are legally entitled to tax exemptions.

title: CABLE COMPANIES VIEW CITY PACT WITH DISMAY
description: Officials of the six companies vying for cable-television franchises in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island have greeted the city's newly drafted contract with varying degrees of dismay and some anger.

title: I.B.M. TO ENTER ROBOT MARKET WITH JAPANESE UNIT
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it would enter the young and rapidly growing market for industrial robots with a low-cost unit made by Sankyo Seiki Manufacturing Company Ltd. of Japan.

title: JONATHAN LOGAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Reflects equity in earnings of affiliated companies of $475,000; C-Net loss; the loss reflects equity in earnings of affiliated companies of $230,000 and after a tax credit of $1,948,000; D-results reflect equity in earnings of affiliated companies of $487,000 and is after a tax credit of $8,453,000; it also reflects previously announced charge of about $17 million after taxes, or $3.29 a share, which resulted from costs related to closing of company's textile manufacturing operations in Spartanburg, SC; E-Net income reflects equity of $491,000

title: Topics; SWITCHED SIGNALS; Basic Baseball
description: Leave it to Japanese ingenuity to come up with electronic improvements on the game of baseball. A Tokyo concern is marketing a baseball glove with a colored plastic webbing to shield its wearer's eyes from the sun, and a helmet with radio receiver that would permit coaches on the bench to advise batters or runners to swing, steal or hit and run.

title: A RED DISSENT IN ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Fraser Board Member Quits
description: Sir Hugh Fraser, ousted last year as chairman of the British trading group House of Fraser, resigned today from the company's board of directors.

title: JAILED VETERAN'S CASE BRINGS POST-VIETNAM PROBLEM INTO FOCUS
description: The fate of a young Vietnam veteran has become the focus of concern in this Deep South stronghold of American patriotism as it seeks to reconcile itself with its Vietnam War veterans after a decade of trying to ignore them and forget the war.

title: FALWELL HIT BY 2 PIES
description: As he addressed the annual convention of the Bible Baptist Fellowship, the Rev. Jerry Falwell, leader of the Moral Majority, was struck by two fruit pies hurled by two women.

title: CADILLAC FAIRVIEW SHIFT AN 'ORDERLY TRANSITION'
description: E. Leo Kolber, 53, who has long been associated with the Bronfman family, which owns 35 percent of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation, has been promoted to chairman and chief executive officer from vice chairman.

title: CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Bolivia Arrests 8, Charging Coup Plot
description: The Government has arrested eight people, including a former congressman, on charges of organizing a ''nationwide subversive apparatus'' to overthrow the military regime, the Interior Ministry announced.

title: STATE WILL MOVE MEDICAID OFFICE FROM NEW YORK
description: New York State is planning to move a privately operated Medicaid billing system and its 675 employees from lower Manhattan to Albany because of a rent dispute with a commercial contractor.

title: GST LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FARE RISES TO EUROPE APPROVED
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today approved new air fares for major North Atlantic routes, allowing carriers in many cases to increase ticket prices sharply. Most new fares would go into effect in April or May, although some increases on the New York-London route could come as early as Monday.

title: Bridge: Leading New York Players To Compete at the Hilton
description: Nearly all the top-ranked players in New York City will be in action today at the New York Hilton Hotel, where the second stage of the Grand National Team Championship is scheduled at 1 P.M. All the players, survivors of club preliminaries, are looking optimistically toward the national playoffs in Albuquerque, N.M., in July.

title: British Ford Layoffs
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had laid off 4,000 workers at its Halewood plant.

title: Nets Beat Trail Blazers on Rally, 110-106
description: There were 35 seconds remaining last night in a game that the Nets would win, 110-106, with what their coach, Larry Brown, called their most dramatic comeback of the season. Brown was standing on the sideline near midcourt, his right hand raised high.

title: ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CREST-FOAM reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AN ECHO OF FAMILY FEELING FOR FORD'S
description: When someone around here says he works for the country's second biggest automobile maker, he does not call it ''the Ford Motor Company'' but simply ''Ford's,'' as in ''Mr. Ford's.''

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-Includng an extraordinary gain of $733,874 on the exchange of mortgate loans for bank notes and interest payable...C-Including a gain of $754,460 on the sales of motor inns

title: GALTACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an unrealized foreign currency translation loss of $231,000...C-Net income including an unrealized foreign currenc translation gain of $110,000 and a gain of $127,000 on the sale of fixed assets

title: BRIEFING
description: Warmup for '84 Race

title: LETTER-WRITING LOVER
description: KAFKA'S OTHER TRIAL. By Elias Canet- ti. 121 pages. Schocken. $11.95 hardcov- er; $5.95 paperback.

title: TOP LAWYER DISSENTS IN BRIEF ON TAX EXEMPTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration made public today a 52-page brief filed with the Supreme Court that provides detailed legal arguments for granting tax exemptions to private schools that discriminate on the basis of race.

title: ARBOR CAPITAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A TALE OF TWO FEDERAL SENTENCES
description: To the Editor:

title: U. of Chicago to Pay $225,00 to 3 Over DES
description: The University of Chicago agreed in an out-ofcourt settlement here today to pay $225,000 to three alumnae who were given the synthetic hormone DES at the university's hospital without their knowledge and to provide free medical care for the children of other women if they develop cancer. The settlement followed a twoweek trial.

title: CITY SAVINGS BANKS LOST $337 MILLION IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: New York City's savings banks lost $337 million in the fourth quarter of 1981, bringing the total loss for the year to $1 billion, the State Banking Department reported yesterday.

title: Heublein Purchase
description: Heublein Inc., the liquor and food products concern, said it had acquired 380,800 shares, or about 3.5 percent, of the outstanding common stock of General Cinema Inc., a theater-chain operator and soft-drink producer.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Lamarr Hoyt, relief pitcher, to a one-year contract.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SPLASH

title: PEACE CORPS, REVIVED, SEEKS NEW CHALLENGES
description: Some months after proposing the Peace Corps in spring 1961, President Kennedy remarked, ''I gave Sarge a lemon and he made lemonade.''

title:
Patents;
Method Developed For Marking Diamonds
description: A method of ''fingerprinting'' diamonds and other crystals has been patented by staff members at the Research and Development Center of the General Electric Company in Schenectady, N.Y. Patent 4,316,385, granted Robert C. DeVries and Roy E. Tuft this week, explains that natural diamonds, synthetic diamonds and cubic boron nitride can be marked without damage to their external appearance.

title: BATTERED WIVES: HOW LAW CAN HELP
description: A study intended to improve New York City's aid to battered wives has concluded that they are much less likely to be repeat victims if they seek help through the legal system.

title: O'Malley Steps In
description: Peter O'Malley, the Dodger owner, says he will fly from the team's training camp at Vero Beach, Fla., to confer with Fernando Valenzuela's advisers in Los Angeles on Sunday. Valenzuela is reported to be asking $1 million a year; the Dodgers have offered less than half that amount. ... The Pittsburgh Pirates are considering a trade that would send Dave Parker and Jason Thompson to the Texas Rangers for Al Oliver, Johnny Grubb and Danny Darwin, according to The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. ... The Seattle Mariners have apparently decided not to sign Jeff Burroughs, the outfielder who played with them last season before becoming a free agent.

title: Some Good News for Baryshnikov
description: The news Mikhail Baryshnikov got from his orthopedist was good enough to make the dancer want to dance for joy. He may not, after all, have to undergo exploratory microsurgery to determine whether he tore a cartilage in his left knee two weeks ago in a performance in Chicago.

title: SEAMAN IS KILLED AS TANKER SINKS INTO EAST RIVER
description: A gasoline tanker exploded, burst into flames and sank in the East River yesterday morning, killing one crew member and injuring three others, moments after it passed under the Williamsburg Bridge.

title: N.F.L. CLOSE TO TV DEAL WORTH UP TO 1.8 BILLION
description: The National Football League and the three major television networks are close to signing a new, five-year contract whose worth is estimated by sources directly involved in the negotiations at up to $1.8 billion.

title: Progress Is Reported In Talks to Sell Rockies
description: A group of investors who want to buy the Colorado Rockies and keep it in Denver met for seven and a half hours today with Peter Gilbert, the current owner of the National Hockey League team. One member of the group, made up of businessman from Denver and St. Louis, said that progress had been made toward reaching a final purchase agreement.

title: U.S. Envoy, in Lebanon, Tries to Shore Up Truce
description: Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, began talks here today aimed at maintaining the shaky cease-fire in southern Lebanon.

title: FIRESTONE: OWNER AS TRAINER
description: The easy winner of Wednesday's fourth race here was a 3-year-old filly named Pure Joy, which is exactly what she brought to Bert Firestone. Her parents, Honest Pleasure and Optimistic Gal, had won numerous stakes in Firestone's colors. He watched Leroy Jolley train them in those races, but on Wednesday it was Firestone who was adjusting the girth on Pure Joy's saddle and giving the jockey a leg up.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.2 BILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply rose $1.2 billion in the reporting period that ended Feb. 17, a change that the credit markets shrugged off as an inconclusive indicator of future changes in interest rates.

title: STUDY REAFFIRMS GENERAL DOUBTS OVER MARIJUANA
description: A long-awaited report released today by the National Academy of Sciences asserts that marijuana smoking has certain undesirable short-term effects on behavior and the body. But it says reliable evidence is so scanty that it is impossible to draw any firm conclusions about potential long-term health hazards.

title: HEALTH DEPT. DISAVOWS CHARGE ON A-PLANT DATA
description: New York State's Health Commissioner yesterday disavowed portions of memorandums written by a state nuclear expert that charged that a utility provided the state with faulty weather information during an accident at the Robert E. Ginna nuclear plant last month.

title: Hunts' Placid Oil Loan Restructured
description: The Placid Oil Company, owned by the Hunt family of Dallas, said yesterday that it has restructured a $1.1 billion loan that helped bail the family out of the 1980 collapse of the silver market.

title: PRESIDENT DROPS NOMINEE FOR POST ON A RIGHTS PANEL
description: President Reagan, yielding to protests from civil rights groups for the second time in two weeks, has lost his choice for a post on the Civil Rights Commission, White House officials said today.

title:
Patents;
Scanning Microscope Aids Chemical Analysis
description: A scanning X-ray microscope patented this week was described by its inventor as useful in the display of chemical reactions. Patent 4,317,036 was awarded Chia Gee Wang, a biophysicist in Millwood, N.Y.

title: Seven Bells Won't Make All Well
description: The 22 local telephone companies that American Telephone and Telegraph intends to cast adrift will apparently not have to row their lifeboats alone. Ma Bell is ditching the operating companies in exchange for permission to enter the lucrative data-processing and equipment markets. It plans now to group the castoffs into seven regional holding companies.

title: Thousands in Florida Seeking Postal Jobs
description: Thousands of people rushed to southern Florida Post Offices today to fill out applications for 700 jobs as letter carriers and postal clerks that will become available over the next few years.

title: Pacific Telephone
description: Shareholders of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company have approved the company's plan to merge into the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. A.T.&T. currently holds 91.5 percent of Pacific Telephone's common stock and 78.2 percent of its preferred shares that have voting rights. A.T.&T. said it wanted the merger to simplify its compliance with a Justice Department settlement that calls for A.T.&T. to divest itself of Pacific Telephone and 21 other local telephone companies.

title: REAGAN BACKS BUDGET BEFORE CONSERVATIVES, CALLS CRITICS SOB SISTERS
description: President Reagan accused critics of his budget tonight of ''sob sister attempts to portray our desire to get Government spending under control as a hard-hearted attack on the poor people of America.''

title: WATER MAIN BREAKS NEAR TIMES SQUARE, DISRUPTING SUBWAYS
description: A large water main burst just below Times Square in midtown Manhattan last night, shutting off subway service for much of the West Side and causing hundreds of buildings to lose water pressure.

title: Letter: On Student Loans Tuition Aid Assures the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia 67, Brown 65
description: A 20-foot jumper by Eric Clarke's of Columbia ended a late Brown bid.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Among 20 senior basketball players selected to play in the Pizza Hut All-Star Game on April 3 in Las Vegas, Nev., were Dan Callandrillo of Seton Hall, Eric Floyd of Georgetown and Corny Thompson of Connecticut. Joe B. Hall of Kentucky will coach the East and Ralph Miller of Oregon State the West. ... Quintin Dailey, a basketball player at the University of San Francisco, pleaded not guilty yesterday to five felony counts in connection with the sexual attack of a female student during the Christmas holidays. Dailey, who is 21, was ordered back to court on Monday for a preliminary hearing.

title: Reagans Going West For Leisure and Talks
description: President Reagan will make speeches in Wyoming and New Mexico next week as he heads west for a four-day vacation at his California ranch, the White House announced today. Mr. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, plan to spend Thursday, their 30th anniversary, at the ranch.

title: PIANIST: BRENDEL IN NEW YORK
description: Each year Alfred Brendel comes to New York, and each year he has something new to tell us. In his piano recital Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, he was without the Beethoven and Schubert that have preoccupied him in the past (though Schubert did surface in his only encore). Thursday it was Mozart and Schumann, Berg and Liszt.

title: No Headline
description: MALONE LEADS ROCKETS

title: CITY FELONIES LAST YEAR ROSE MUCH SLOWER THAN IN 1980
description: Major crimes continued to increase in New York City in 1981, but at a much slower rate than in 1980, according to Police Department figures released yesterday.

title: LOW PRICE IS CRITICIZED
description: The Conservative Government has opened an inquiry into Thursday's sale of a little known state-owned technology company, Amersham International, at what critics called a give-away price: The $130 million paid to the Government was about $38 million less than the prevailing market price of the shares of the company.

title: AIDE TO WATT DEFENDS PARTIES
description: Interior Secretary James B. Watt did not appear today at a Congressional hearing to answer questions about his use of about $9,000 in Government and private funds for two parties.

title: SUSAN SONTAG PROVOKES DEBATE ON COMMUNISM
description: A speech earlier this month by the writer Susan Sontag equating Communism with Fascism has provoked an outburst of discussion among New York intellectuals - a group that is always ready for a duel with words.

title: COLUMBIA CREW LOOKS TO SHUTTLE'S 3D MISSION
description: The astronauts for the space shuttle Columbia's third mission, now less than a month away, today described their plans for the seven-day flight as a ''very ambitious and challenging'' testing of the vehicle's capacity to handle large cargoes, endure extremes of heat and cold and conduct scientific research.

title: VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a gain of $895,000 from excess of proceeds on fire loss

title: THE PROPER PRIORITY OF PRESIDENT REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: A Meeting of 5 Latin Leaders In Costa Rica Is Suspended
description: A meeting scheduled for Saturday of five Central American heads of government has been indefinitely suspended, a Costa Rican Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: BERGDORF BETS ON ONE STORE
description: Bergdorf Goodman, at a time when its competitors are pursuing a strategy of multistore expansion, is going the other way. It is banking on one store, its Fifth Avenue stronghold.

title: BALDWIN & LYONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUPERIOR COURT IN CONNECTICUT WILL ALLOW TV
description: A one-year experiment to open criminal and civil trials in Connecticut's Superior Court to limited coverage by television and still cameras and tape recorders was approved today by the court's judges.

title: AHMANSON, H F, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $218,000 for the qr and $10,191,000 for the yr from the repurchase of bonds and a gain of $34.1 million for the yr from the sale of real estate... C-Net income including gains of $2,618,000 for the qr and $6,245,000 for the yr from the repurchase of bonds

title: STAGE: 'CHEFA,' PORTRAIT OF 50's LOWER EAST SIDE
description: The Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater usually reflects admirably the diversity of the people of the Lower East Side in its plays, written by those who are part of all this and relished by audiences that have shared the experience. ''La Chefa,'' showing there this weekend, is about New York's Puerto Ricans, and if it is fascinating to its local audience, it is surely interesting to others.

title:
Patents;
Steelmaking Process Reduces Need for Coke
description: A Washington engineer who specializes in energy technology says he hopes the process for which he received a patent this week will save money for the steel industry by halving the amount of coke it uses in blast furnaces.

title: CPS CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MISS ASHFORD CAPTURES 60-YARD DASH TITLE AT GARDEN
description: Evelyn Ashford, who can run 60 yards faster than any other woman in the world, took 6.54 seconds to cover that distance last night at the USA/Mobil track and field championships at Madison Square Garden. Then she announced she was going on vacation.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE FEDERAL REPORT ON MARIJUANA
description: Effects on the Nervous System and on Behavior

title: British Caledonian Buys Laker Shops
description: British Caledonian Airways said it had acquired for an undisclosed price Laker Airways' engineering and maintenance facilities at London's Gatwick Airport. The facility comprises 18.9 acres held on a 51-year lease from the British Airports Authority and includes a hangar capable of accommodating two DC-10's, 30,000 square feet of workshop space, 27,000 square feet of offices and 3.5 acres for aircraft parking.

title: CALVIN EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
E-L FINANCIAL CORP LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a special gain of $3,899,000...C-Net loss after a special gain of $2,417,000

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
KANEB SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a gain from discontinued operations of $666,000... C-After gains from discontinued operations of $983,000 for the qr and $3.7 million for the yr...D-After loss from discontinued operations of $6.5 million; the 1980 results restated to reflect discontinued operations; the 1981 net from continuing operations includes a gain of $3.4 million or 15 cents a shr, from the sale of a drilling rig and the 1980 net from continuing operations includes a gain of $19 mill from the sale of Ferguson Oil & Gas Co

title: VOTE ON DEBT CEILING MAY LEAD TO BUDGET CHANGES
description: Republican Congressional leaders are focusing on an unavoidable vote this spring on the national debt limit as a vehicle for forcing a compromise with President Reagan on his 1983 budget, which has met strong opposition in both parties on Capitol Hill.

title: STOCKMAN ENDORSES SHORT-TERM FREEZE IN BENEFITS
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, today raised the possibility of a shortterm freeze in Government benefits as a ''temporary expedient'' in holding down spending. Such benefits are normally adjusted from year to year in accordance with the level of consumer prices.

title: U.S. OPEN-MEETING LAW UPHELD
description: A panel of three judges ruled today that Federal agencies may not hold budget meetings from which the public is excluded.

title: REAGAN AIDES CANCEL PLANS TO CLOSE COAST GUARD BASES
description: The Reagan Administration, under pressure from Congress, reversed itself today and canceled plans to close 15 Coast Guard search-and-rescue stations in 11 states and to reduce operations at 16 other stations for budgetary reasons.

title: U.S. SAID TO FAVOR SALE OF F-16 JETS TO THE JORDANIANS
description: Reagan Administration officials have told members of Congress informally that they are favorably disposed to selling F-16 fighter planes and mobile antia@ircraft missiles to Jordan, but that no decision is likely before next November's Congressional elections.

title:
Patents;
Device Gives Refund On Container Deposit
description: A device that will automatically refund the deposit on a bottle or other container that it recognizes as authentic has been patented for the Coca-Cola Company, Atlanta.

title: WHY I DRIVE A DENTED, RUSTED, PEELING CAR
description: I heard recently that while the average age of cars on American highways used to be three years, it is now seven years. Obviously, car buyers are afflicted with severe ''sticker shock'' and are postponing buying one until their need becomes dire. Many people who automatically bought new cars are buying used cars instead.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 32.

title: Stadler, on 69-135, Leads by 2
description: The winter wind, as much a trademark of the Doral-Eastern Open as the flamingos are at Hialeah, rose today, and so did the scores in the second round of the tournament. Only 39 players beat or matched par 72 on the Blue Monster course of the Doral Country Club compared with 83 players in Thursday's opening round.

title: RANGEL URGES BUSINESSES TO HELP THE 'HARLEMS ALL OVER' THE U.S.
description: Saying that ''nothing can survive in a climate where people are hopeless,'' Representative Charles B. Rangel yesterday appealed to big business to join with smaller neighborhood businesses to help revitalize ''the Harlems all over the country.''

title: The Constitution in Command
description: After promising Lieut. Christopher Cooke total immunity and thus obtaining his confession of passing secrets to the Russians, the Air Force brought the former missile officer to court-martial for espionage last fall. The double-cross was a nagging disgrace to military justice - until the United States Court of Military Appeals ordered a halt this week. Even those who sell out their country are entitled to due process of law, it declared, dismissing the case.

title: ON RADIO CALL
description: To the Editor:

title: WEST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. TRADE GAP WIDER IN JANUARY
description: The United States foreign trade deficit widened in January to a seasonally adjusted $5.13 billion, the thirdhighest total on record, the Commerce Department said today.

title: BENNETT PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $362,000

title: NEW PROPOSAL ON ALIENS WOULD FINE EMPLOYERS
description: The bipartisan bill for immigration law reform to be introduced in Congress next month calls for fines and other penalties for employers of illegal aliens and would provide for a national system to verify the citizenship of employees, one of the bill's proponents said yesterday.

title: U.S. MOVE COULD CUT LIBYA'S INCOME
description: The Reagan Administration's apparent decision to block sales of oil by Libya to the United States could cut sharply into the earnings of the Tripoli Government at a time when Libya's financial position has already been hurt by sluggish oil sales.

title: Maryland Governor Draws the Line on Hospitality
description: A follow-up: Gov. Harry Hughes of Maryland has refused to allow a member of the state's House of Delegates, David Shapiro, to bring a prison inmate as one of his guests at a party in the Governor's Mansion.

title: MESSAGES FOR SALE
description: If you don't like the sound of your own voice or can't think of an imaginative announcement to leave on your answering machine, you can buy a song or a humorous message wherever the machines are sold. Phone Songs and We've Got Your Number sell cassettes with a variety of greetings to choose from.

title: Bridging Transit's Fiscal Gap
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's decision to raise East River bridge and tunnel tolls by 25 percent comes as no surprise. Higher tolls are an essential part of the M.T.A.'s plan to save its lines from disintegration.

title: WHEN 'MICKEYS' WERE THE URBAN BARBACUE
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOS: STUDYING THE JAPANESE
description: Until 1980, James E. Harbour was a little known executive of the Chrysler Corporation, with a gnawing curiosity about Japanese-style manufacturing. Today, he is probably the most-talkedabout auto consultant in Detroit.

title: VERNITRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $87,000 for the qr and a loss of $308,000 for the yr from foreign currency translations... C-After a loss of $17,000 for the qr and a gain of $4,000 for the yr from foreign currency translations

title: PARTY IN POLAND BACKS JARUZELSKI
description: A two-day meeting of Poland's Communist leaders ended Thursday with an unqualified expression of ''full support'' for Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's martial law regime.

title: Long Distance Runner
description: At my shop we repair politicians, so I wasn't too surprised when the mechanic came in and said, ''We've got an interesting problem out here on the hoist and since it's Mayor Koch maybe you ought to have a look at it.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They talked about the trickle down theory, but what we need is the trickle up theory. Small businesses don't want handouts or grants, they want big business to put its arms around their shoulders and to walk down Wall Street with them.'' - Representative Charles B. Rangel. (26:6.)

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Home Products Corp. said its tender offer to acquire up to 14.2 million shares of Brunswick Corp. common stock had drawn 24.5 million shares.

title: POLICE TURNING TO COMPUTERS TO UNTANGLE RECORDS
description: The New York City Police Department, struggling in a morass of confusing paper work, is turning to computers to untangle its arrest records in the hope of unraveling what officials agree has become a chaotic and archaic system.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; France Halts Shipments Of Tanks to Chile

title: G.O.P. AND CONSERVATIVE LEADERS SUSPEND ENDORSEMENT OF CAPUTO
description: Republican and Conservative Party leaders yesterday ''suspended'' their endorsement of Bruce Caputo as a candidate for the United States Senate because statements he had made saying he had served in the armed forces were not true.

title: Price of Tin In Record Fall
description: The price of tin today plunged to its lowest level since last July on the Penang tin market, Maylasia's largest.

title: Ayala, 17-0, Stops King For His 15th Knockout
description: Tony Ayala of San Antonio ran his record to 17-0, including 15 knockouts, with a fourth-round knockout of Nat King in a junior-middleweight bout tonight.

title: Tobias Simon, 52, a Lawyer In Civil Rights Causes in 60's
description: Tobias Simon, a lawyer known for his defense of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights activists in the 1960's, died of cancer Thursday at the age of 52.

title: WHEN 'MICKEYS' WERE THE URBAN BARBACUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Beatrice Considers Buying 2 Bottlers
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said it was currently exploring the possibility of acquiring Coca-Cola bottling companies in San Bernadino and San Diego.

title: BONN MAKES ITS ANNUAL BID TO HAVE A GOOD TIME
description: West Germany's capital hardly runs the risk of being labeled a metropolis of hilarity or gay abandon. People file into the ministries and file out. A man who sticks a colored handkerchief in his breast pocket can pass as a charmer; another who wears a deerstalker's cap to work can assume that he is considered exotic.

title: HINCKLEY SUED FOR $46 MILLION
description: James S. Brady, the Presidential press secretary, filed a $46 million damage suit today against John W. Hinckley Jr. for injuries suffered when he was shot with President Reagan and two others on March 30.

title: McDonald's Plans Pork Sandwich
description: The McDonald's Corporation said it was introducing for test marketing in six United States cities a new pork sandwich called ''McRib,'' which consists of a boneless ground pork patty in barbecue sauce.

title: NEW DIMENSIONS IN ANSWERING MACHINES
description: Originally, telephone answering machines were used almost exclusively by professional and business people who didn't have full-time secretaries. Now, families use them to keep in touch with one another and single people have them to be sure they don't miss any personal calls.

title: Mostek Layoffs
description: The Mostek Corporation, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, said it was laying off 1,250 employees at its plant in Carrollton, Tex., because of the ''continuing recession in the semiconductor industry.''

title: REAGAN PANEL URGES A SHIFT IN MORTGAGE ROLE OF F.H.A.
description: The mission of the Federal Housing Administration should be fundamentally changed and much of its work should be turned over to private mortgage insurance companies, a Presidential commission recommended today.

title: Food Stamps Are Exchanged For TV Sets, House Unit Told
description: Food stamps are accepted for ineligible items by half the food retailers checked by Agriculture Department investigators each year, according to the department's Office of Inspector General.

title: GULF UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $2,000 for the qr and $341,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $2,024,000 for the qr and $6,573,000 for the yr

title: Apology And Applause
description: Mayor Koch has written me a letter with a valid complaint about my last column, in which I discussed some of the potential issues in his forthcoming gubernatorial campaign and suggested that one of them - race -should be buried before the first stump speech is made.

title: Required Reading Smith on Lawyers
description: Attorney General William French Smith, speaking to the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association, in Chicago. Jan. 25, 1982: For the past year, as Attorney General of the United States, I have gained new insight into the role of lawyers in our society, and the public's understanding of that role. The Attorney General, like all lawyers, represents clients and is the advocate for their interests in the courts.

title: 'THE SEDUCTION'
description: ''The Seduction,'' which opened yesterday at theaters all over the city, is an often comically inept, unsuccessfully vicious nonthriller about a beautiful young woman, her live-in lover and the crazy Peeping Tom who pursues the young woman neither wisely nor well.

title: Bolivian Miners Strike
description: The 1,500 workers at the major Catavi tin mine struck for 24 hours today for salary increases, spokesmen for the state-owned mining corpoation said. Workers at other tin mines also threatened to strike if the military Government did not meet their pay demands by April 3, the spokesmen added.

title: U.S. SAID TO EASE SOUTH AFRICA CURB
description: The Reagan Administration, apparently overcoming some second thoughts, has relaxed American export restrictions to allow shipments of various items to South Africa without subjecting them to a strict licensing procedure.

title: WOODS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $7,675,000 or 66 cents a shr on the sale of Wyoming oil and gas properties; revs for the previous yr includes $11,175,000 from the sale of Wyoming properties

title: WILLIAM SMALL RESIGNS AS HEAD OF NBC NEWS
description: William J. Small, president of NBC News, resigned yesterday, citing ''differences in management style.'' Just a month ago, Grant Tinker, chairman of NBC, stated publicly that Mr. Small could remain in his job ''as long as he wanted to.''

title: VIOLENCE AND CYNICISM MAR CAMPAIGN FOR NEXT MONTH'S VOTE IN EL SALVADOR
description: The poster on the front gate of the Christian Democratic Party headquarters downtown says, ''The First Peaceful Revolution in America,'' but the machine gun-bearing guards on either side of it, the tattoo of pockmarks across the green stucco facade and the sharpshooters peering out from behind sandbags on the roof tell a different story.

title: Tribunal Dissolves Injunction Against Police in Washington
description: A Federal appeals court today dissolved an injunction that barred the District of Columbia police from stopping pedestrians to ask for identification or information.

title: BOW VALLEY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a special gain of $18.4 million on public issue of shrs in Bow Valley Resource Service Ltd

title: OREGON STATE BEATS U.C.L.A.
description: Danny Evans scored a personal career high of 26 points tonight as Oregon State defeated U.C.L.A., 72-58, to clinch at least a tie for the Pacific 10 Conference championship.

title: REAGANIZING SCHOLARS
description: As a scholar often in Yugoslavia doing research or attending academic meetings, I have frequently responded to requests from the United States foreign cultural relations agency - now known as the International Communication Agency -to give lectures there on various facets of American life. Although such activity is not very remunerative, it helps, at least partly, defray transportation costs.

title: U.S. WEIGHS PIPELINE STRATEGY
description: President Reagan heard arguments from his chief advisers today on whether to take a hard line with the European allies to prevent construction of a pipeline to carry Siberian natural gas to Western Europe, but he put off a decision, Administration officials said.

title: G.M. to Split Annual Session
description: Shareholders will have little chance to question top executives of General Motors at the May 21 annual meeting.

title: BISHOP GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STATEN ISLAND GAINS FINAL WITH BARUCH
description: The College of Staten Island went ahead just before the half and scored a 69-59 victory over John Jay College last night to reach the final round of the City University of New York postseason tournament at FitzGerald Gym of Queens College.

title: Sullivan Bail Set at $500,000 In Robbery of a Bank in Utica
description: Joseph John Sullivan, surrounded by six United States marshals, was arraigned in Federal Court here today on charges related to the holdup last Dec. 13 of a Utica bank.

title: LIGHT ON BUYING CANDLES
description: O THER than fresh flowers, nothing enhances a table or a room more than the soft flicker of candlelight. Candles are almost as old as civilization itself and even with the convenience of electric light, we don't want to part with their decorative possibilities and pleasant illumination.

title: Westhead Still Puzzled
description: Three months after his sudden dismissal as head coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, Paul Westhead says he still does not understand why he was let go. Westhead, who continues to be paid on a four-year contract that runs through the 1983-84 season, said that he hopes to return to the National Basketball Association as a coach some day.

title: PAPANDREOU, DUE IN CYPRUS TODAY, STARTS DRIVE FOR TURKISH PULLOUT
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou says he has started a diplomatic campaign to gain the withdrawal of Turkish troops from Cyprus and break the deadlock over the island.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1982
description: International No decision on arms for Jordan will be made by the Reagan Administration before the Congressional elections in November, Congressional and Administration sources said, although Administration officials have told members of Congress informally that they are favorably disposed to a sale. The sources said the official reason for the delay in any decision was that Jordan was not expected to make a formal request for either the F-16 fighter planes or the mobile antiaircraft Hawk missiles until later in the year. (Page 1, Column 6.) The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company is going out of business. Its last performances will be given today in London, where the troupe began 106 years ago, with a matinee performance of ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' and a gala in the evening. The company is a victim of rising costs, oldfashioned stagecraft and declining subsidies. (1:2-4.)

title: Illinois Judge Says He Finds Fluoridation Unconstitutional
description: Circuit Judge Ronald Niemann announced today that he had declared unconstitutional the Illinois law requiring fluoridation of municipal drinking water.

title: JURY DELIBERATIONS BEGIN IN WILLIAMS'S MURDER TRIAL
description: The murder case against Wayne B. Williams was placed in the hands of the jury late today after prosecutors, in their final statement, called him a ''mad dog killer'' and likened him to ''Attila the Hun, Adolf Hitler and Idi Amin.''

title: 'MILLIONS FOR PROS, NEXT TO NOTHING FOR KIDS'
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 WOMEN OF TIBET
description: A few months ago, I traveled extensively in Tibet, a country of which I had long dreamed. Several times in recent years, I visited the back areas of China and heard many tales of horror of the Cultural Revolution. But nothing could have prepared me for Tibet. Once it may have been Shangri-La; today, it is a land of desolation.

title:
Patents;
Other Uses For Teller Machines
description: WASHINGTON A VETERAN inventor, with more than 200 patents, proposes that automatic bank teller machines be used to transfer funds to program the operation of postage meters in offices. Luther G. Simjian of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was granted a patent this week for apparatus to issue cards that the meters will accept.

title: BITTER COLD MAKES IT EASIER TO SELL THE SUN TO CANADIANS
description: Eileen Forrow sells the sun. And so does Peter Jenkins, Patrick de Montbrun and Michelle Pinard. Prior Smith sells news about the cold, but his customers are in the sun.

title: Israeli Military Closing Sinai To All Nonresident Civilians
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon ordered all roads into Sinai closed at midnight tonight to prevent militant settlers from moving into the area in large numbers.

title: SOUTHEAST CITES AID BY 2 CITY BANKS
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation of Miami said yesterday that two New York banks had lent it $250 million to help finance its attempt to buy the Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. in a bidding war with Chemical Bank. ,

title: Your Money; Vast Changes For Estates
description: ONCE, before the inflation of the last two decades, estate planning was a subject only for the very wealthy. Now, some people have found that they are accumulating more wealth than they imagined and need to know the complexities and tax consequences of transferring their estates to their survivors.

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1982; The Economy
description: New York City's savings banks lost a record $337 million in the fourth quarter, bringing their loss for the year to $1 billion, the State Banking Department said. The severe losses indicate that a number of major savings banks in the city are in danger of failing. They are expected to exert strong new pressure on Washington to aid the troubled thrift industry. (Page 1.)

title: Conigliaro a Bit Better
description: Tony Conigliaro, the former Boston Red Sox slugger who suffered a massive heart attack on Jan. 9, was reported to have made a ''slight improvement'' yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: EVANS, BOB, FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
BEVIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $105,000 for the qr and $1,246,000 for the yr

title: AUTO-TROL TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONSUMERS WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pilot in Boston Crash Felt Loss of Brakes
description: The crew of a World Airways DC-10 airliner that skidded into Boston Harbor expressed no doubts about a safe landing until the jet was speeding down the icy runway at 138 miles per hour, investigators reported today.

title: PAZ, POET, WINS NEUSTADT LITERATURE PRIZE
description: Octavio Paz, the Mexican poet and essayist, won the 1982 Neustadt Interntational Prize for Literature yesterday. The 67-year-old writer, who teaches one semester a year at Harvard, has written more than 30 books of poetry and prose, of which the best known is ''The Labyrinth of Solitude'' (1950), a collection of essays about Mexico.

title: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRENTON BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAESARS NEW JERSEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Style Page yesterday about new nightclubs in New York incorrectly described Le Club. It is for members only.

title: IT'S BUSINESS AS USUAL, MOSTLY, FOR CAROL BELLAMY
description: Near the end of what could be the most momentous week in her life so far, Carol Bellamy sat in the front seat of her official car and harped on the ''prematurity'' of conjecture about what she would do as Mayor of the City of New York.

title: KOCH PUTS COST OF REAGAN PLAN AT $720 MILLION
