description: President Reagan's latest round of proposed budget cuts would cost New York City $720 million in the next fiscal year, with the impact felt most by the poor, the elderly and the disabled, city budget officials said yesterday.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $672,000 on the early extinguishment of debt

title: VAIL ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Duke Drops Nixon Library
description: Citing a poor economy and an unfavorable political climate, Duke University officials said today they were no longer pursuing negotiations to acquire the Richard M. Nixon Presidential library. It was the first public indication negotiations had stalled, although the faculty Senate rejected the idea last August.

title: AT 106, D'OYLY CARTE FALLS TO THE EXECUTIONER
description: For several months now, the 101 members of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company have felt like Ko-Ko, Pooh-Bah and Pish-Tush, who confide piteously in ''The Mikado'' how unpleasant it is To sit in solemn silence in a dull, dark dock, In a pestilential prison, with a life- long lock, Awaiting the sensation of a short, sharp shock From a cheap and chippy chopper on a big, black block.

title: Lloyd Can Rejoin Giants
description: Dan Lloyd, a linebacker for the New York Giants who had been suffering from cancer of the lymph nodes, has been cleared to resume his football career after missing two seasons. ''He's completely free of the disease, and he's going to give it a try,'' said Dr. Burton Lee of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: A COUNCIL PANEL ON REDISTRICTING BACKS NEW PLAN
description: Some 6,500 Hispanic people from the Bronx would be put in a Manhattan City Council district under a citywide realignment proposed yesterday to create three seats that could be won by racial minorities.

title: OPERA: GOETZ'S 'TAMING OF THE SHREW'
description: The John Brownlee Opera Theater of the Manhattan School of Music is providing a real service with its performances of Hermann Goetz's comic opera ''The Taming of the Shrew.'' The production opened Thursday night and will be repeated tonight and tomorrow afternoon in the school's Borden Auditorium.

title: 2 SCANDALS HAVE ALL MOSCOW ABUZZ
description: The arrest of a flamboyant circus performer known as Boris the Gypsy has set off a major scandal here that has led to the arrest of the country's top circus official. It has also led to the discovery in the official's apartment of diamonds and foreign currency worth 1.2 million rubles, the equivalent of nearly $1.7 million, according to Soviet sources familiar with the case.

title: No Headline
description: FOR THE FIRST TIME in history, two Kentucky Derby winners have been brought together to play the horse breeder's version of spin the bottle.

title: BITTERNESS RUNS DEEP IN CALIFORNIA BATTLE OVER BRINGING MORE WATER SOUTH
description: It would be no more than a big ditch, or, as the state water resources director described it, ''a simple extension of the plumbing system.''

title: CHIC WAY TO ATTACK A TACO
description: Among the most difficult hand-held foods to negotiate gracefully, few require more manual and oral dexterity than the taco. Relatively new to the Eastern eating scene, tacos still present problems for novices.

title: Zungul Held Scoreless
description: Steve Zungul was held without a goal for the first time this season as the Wichita Wings defeated the New York Arrows, 6-3, before a crowd of 6,033 at Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: WILEY, JOHN, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: Penn 65, Dartmouth 56
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Paul Little scored 16 points, and David Lardner added 12 as Ivy League-leading Penn won its 11th straight.

title: 1,000 AT A HEARING ASSAIL PLAN TO MERGE 2 SCHOOLS
description: A proposal by the Board of Education to merge two high schools on the Upper West Side has run into clamorous opposition from the students, teachers and parents of both schools.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Turkish Regime Seizes Lawyers and Journalists

title: DISCORDANT VOICES ON JERSEY DEATH PENALTY BILL
description: Death draws a crowd. On the streets, in the execution chamber and even in the abstract. Here today, to Room 223 of the New Jersey State House, people were drawn again - this time to testify. The Judiciary Committee of the State Senate was conducting a hearing on New Jersey's latest attempt to restore capital punishment. Despite the impassioned pleas of opponents, the committee passed the bill by a vote of 8 to 1. It now goes to the Senate floor.

title: IONA TOPS FORDHAM
description: Rory Grimes scored four free throws, and Tony Hargraves added three in the final 2 minutes 3 seconds to lead Iona to a 45-41 victory over Fordham tonight in a Metro Atlantic Conference game at the Mulcahy Center.

title: Boston Marathon for Sale
description: Marshall Medoff, a Boston attorney and agent for the Boston Athletic Association, is trying to sell the Boston Marathon, one of the world's leading amateur running events, to a commercial, or perhaps professional concern, The Boston Globe reported today.

title: S.E.C. Charges Dirks With Misusing Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed a complaint charging Raymond L. Dirks and several business associates with misusing funds.

title: Sholom Aleichem Festivities
description: The 65th anniversary of the death of the Yiddish writer Sholom Aleichem will be marked March 14 at 3 P.M. with a bilingual program of recitations and dramatizations in the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street. Performers will include the author Bel Kaufman, a granddaughter of Sholom Aleichem, and three actors - Zvee Scooler, Rita Karin-Karpinovitch and David Rogow. Tickets, $5, will be available at the synagogue on March 14 or, in advance, through the Workmen's Circle, 45 East 33d Street, New York 10016.

title: Port Strike in Portugal
description: More than 30 ships were stranded in Portuguese ports today on the second day of a 48-hour strike by harbor pilots in a dispute over pay for weekends and holidays. Airports were disrupted, too, by a 72-hour strike by clerical workers over pay and contract renewal.

title: Dow Declines 1.43; Deficit Worry Cited
description: Stock prices declined slightly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 1.43 points, to 824.39, bringing the total decline in the first two months of 1982 to 51 points.

title: Continental's Auditor Wary
description: Continental Air Lines, which posted a $60 million loss last year, said today that its auditors would qualify their certification of the 1981 financial statement with a clause questioning the company's ability to survive.

title: AEICOR INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $328,000 and extraordinary income of $394,000...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $674,000 extraordinary income of $516,000 and nonrecurring pretax income of $70,000

title: Shirtless 'Lark' Costs a Job
description: After posing for a newspaper with his shirt off, Edward P. Lisiecki Jr. has been dismissed as executive secretary of the Mercer County Park Commission in Trenton.

title: Tanzania Jet Hijacked; 2 Are Reported Killed
description: Hijackers demanding the resignation of President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania seized a Tanzanian jetliner with more than 90 passengers aboard on a domestic flight Friday. They reportedly killed two hostages and forced the pilot to fly to Kenya and Saudi Arabia.

title: Off-Duty Detective Wounded By Youths Trying to Rob Her
description: An off-duty detective with eight commendations was wounded in the chest early yesterday in an exchange of gunfire with two youths who tried to rob her outside her home at 117-31 192d Street in St. Albans, Queens.

title: AZL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $116,000 for the qr and $704,000 for the yr and a loss of $1,932,000 for the qr and yr on the sale of discontinued operations

title: 40-MILLION-YEAR-OLD MUMMY OF INSECT IS REPORTED FOUND
description: A mummified insect has been found with much of its soft tissues apparently intact after 40 million years, scientists at the University of California at Berkeley have reported. The specimen is so well preserved that elements within cells appear to be visible, they said.

title: No Headline
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. She is the youngest woman to win a Rhodes Scholarship. 2. A gas attack was used to rob four Japanese experts in the industrial application of nuclear energy. Some diplomats in Moscow believe the robbery may have overtones of industrial espionage. 3. The Surgeon General advised nonsmokers to ''avoid being in smoke-filled rooms,'' since one of the conclusions of the Report on Smoking that his office issued was that sidestream smoke, the smoke inhaled by nonsmokers who are near smokers, is a ''possible serious public health problem.''

title: Spain Seizes Gunrunner Sought by the U.S.
description: A man convicted of smuggling arms with Frank Terpil, a former Central Intelligence Agency agent, was arrested here Thursday, according to the United States Embassy.

title: ACCURAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sun Belt 'Revenge'
description: Invited to a City Club luncheon yesterday to address New York City businessmen, Mayor Henry G. Cisneros of San Antonio had a warning for his listeners.

title: 3 KEY BONN AIDES BEING INVESTIGATED IN BRIBE CASE
description: A West German prosecutor announced today that two Cabinet members, the ministers of economics and finance, and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's chief aide were under investigation on suspicion of having taken bribes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Dec. 7 on the hunger strike by the Soviet nuclear physicist Andrei D. Sakharov attributed to him the assertion that the United States should maintain armed forces two or three times as powerful as the Soviet Union's.

title: KOLLEK ATTACKS MET ON ISRAEL SHOW
description: Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem has attacked the Metropolitan Museum of Art's decision not to mount a proposed archeological show from Israel because, according to the Met, it would include material from "disputed" territory formerly occupied by Jordan.

title: 1982 PLANS
description: In the last week of the 1981 season, when Charlie Puleo made his first major league start after having been called up from the Mets' Triple A team in Tidewater, about 100 of Puleo's relatives and friends from his hometown of Bloomfield, N.J., called him to ask for tickets.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS UP FOR A SECOND MONTH
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products increased by eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Agriculture Department reported today. It was the second consecutive monthly rise - the first such occurrence in more than a year.

title: BOMB THAT KILLED COUPLE IN JERSEY WAS ADDRESSED TO VICTIM
description: The bomb that killed Andrew and Patricia Puskas, the parents of three young boys, and turned their home into an instant inferno Thursday was addressed to Mr. Puskas, authorities said today. They added that he did not seem unduly alarmed by the device before it exploded.

title: RIGID DEFENDER OF APARTHEID
description: The English-language press has long ridiculed him as ''Dr. No'' because of his inflexible resistance to any easing of the racial code that the world knows as apartheid.

title: Tower Project Proceeds Without Tax Incentive
description: A developer who withdrew his application for a tax abatement because a city panel was prepared to reject his request says he is going ahead with his project without the tax break, which would have amounted to $11.5 million over five years.

title: BOYS IN WEST BANK ARRESTED AT NIGHT FOR WEEKS OF QUESTIONING BY ISRAELIS
description: The Israeli soldiers came about 8:30 P.M. to the concrete home of Isa Abd Rahmen el-Kheldi, a Palestinian refugee. As he tells the story, the smallest of his 13 children were asleep, as was his wife. The oldest were sitting on the cold floor watching television.

title: LEADING DEMOCRATS ENDORSE CHANGES IN NOMINATING RULES
description: Despite warnings of potential opposition from women, big states and state party chairmen, the executive committee of the Democratic National Committee voted today to endorse changes in the Presidential nominating system.

title: WHAT DEREGUALTION OF INTERCITY BUSES WOULD DO TO THE PUBLIC
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Hire Running Instructor
description: Harrison Dillard, the four-time Olympic champion, will join the Yankees Sunday as a running instructor.

title: 4 Winners for Cordero
description: Angel Cordero rode four winners at Aqueduct yesterday, including the heavily favored Viva Sec in the featured Top Round Purse. Viva Sec returned $3.60 for $2 to win at the track after running six furlongs in 1:11. Cordero's other winners were Fabulous Fur, $3.40, in the third race; Jeffery C., $8.40, in the fifth, and Foudroyant, $4.80, in the seventh.

title: Vietnam and the Military Mind
description: As a former marine, who served in Vietnam in 1967-68, I was heartened to see Drew Middleton's article about our military involvement there (''Vietnam and the Military Mind,'' Jan. 10). However, I think Mr. Middleton makes an incorrect assumption regarding military dissatisfaction with United States Government ''direction'' of the war.

title: Basque Hard-Liners Attack
description: The hard-line wing of E.T.A., the Basque guerrilla group, said today that it was responsibile for Friday's grenade attack on the Civil Guard headquarters here. The blast caused no injuries.

title: THE MARSHALL MYSTERY
description: It might be surmised that because the Marshall countergambit in the Ruy Lopez is not frequently seen, someone has discovered a refutation. That isn't so. In the years since Frank Marshall surprised Jose Raul Capablanca with it in the New York tournament of 1918, there has been a perpetual seesaw of tenacious attempts to subdue the raging counterattack and gigantic efforts to justify it. White wins, Black wins, there are hectic draws, but still there is no conclusion.

title: STATE BIDES TIME ON FASTING CONVICT
description: TRENTON DESPITE the transfer of Thomas Clauso to the Adult Diagnostic and Treatment Center in Avenel last week, officials of the state's Department of Corrections are maintaining a wait-and-see attitude toward the prisoner.

title: Record-Tying 300 to Williams
description: Ken Williams of Prospect Heights and Roger Hunter of Thomas Jefferson each turned in a national scholastic indoor-best time of 35 seconds in the 300-meter dash yesterday. But Williams posted his time in the final, so he won the gold medal at the Public Schools Athletic League indoor track and field championships in the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: NEW RELEASES DISPLAY LIST'S RANGE
description: Although he is best known today as a composer for the piano, Liszt was perhaps the most venturesome and diverse composer of the Romantic era. He worked in every possible musical medium and style; there is even an opera composed when he was a teen-ager. The Liszt catalogue contains a bit of everything, and an enormous amount is rarely heard today -except on records. In particular, recently, there have been new releases of his organ music, orchestral music, sacred choral music and songs.

title: Tips for park visitors
description: Regional Parks These are unlike anything in America in that they have been established in inhabited rural areas with roads, farms and towns, and their facilities are not immediately apparent. A visit to park headquarters for information is essential. National Parks They are rather like the national parks in the United States, uninhabited and in rugged country (mostly mountainous) best suited to experienced hikers, skiers and climbers. But they do have peripheral zones with less strenuous trails and interesting villages. Information National parks are under the authority of the Ministry of the Environment in Paris, but it is best to write each park individually:

title: Craig Colhoun to Wed Kathleen O'Shea
description: Dr. and Mrs. William J. O'Shea of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Mary O'Shea, to Craig Scott Colhoun of Wilton, Conn., son of Demaris Deere Wiman Ethridge of New York and Sun Valley, Idaho, and Richard Newbold Colhoun of Boothbay, Me., and Palm Harbor, Fla.

title: India Raising Military Outlay
description: India's military spending will rise 11 percent to $5.65 billion under the budget announced today for the fiscal year beginning April 1.

title: TEAMSTERS GLOOMY ON REOPENED PACT
description: ''If Hoffa was around none of this would have happened,'' Maurice St. Louis said unhappily. ''He knew how to straighten these things out.''

title: STAGE: 'THE GREEKS,' 9 CLASSICS CONDENSED
description: ''The Greeks,'' at the Hartford Stage Company, is a prodigious achievement - nine plays distilled to seven hours' playing time and performed as a trilogy. I saw it at a special one-day marathon, beginning at noon and ending after 11 P.M., with lunch and dinner breaks for actors as well as theatergoers.

title:
GARDENING;
GREEN THUMBS ARE ACQUIRED, NOT BORN
description: SHOULD someone take a vote to determine the most perfect avocation, gardening should win hands down. Through gardening one may beautify one's home both indoors and out, provide food of superior quality and flavor and obtain beneficial exercise. It is doubtful that any other leisure-time activity can make a comparable claim.

title: 26 Establishments Fail Health Code Inspection
description: The New York City Department of Health released the names of 26 restaurants last week that were cited for violations of the city's health code.

title: AUTO-WRECK LOTS TOLD TO HIDE
description: TO Sonny Vecchio, the new ordinance regulating junkyards in the Town of Islip was welcomed as just the muscle needed to clean up the image of the auto-wreck dealers.

title: RETIRING IN FLATBUSH
description: To the Editor:

title: Right Back To You, Supreme Court
description: Civil rights issues, it seems, have lost little of their potential for bitterness - or for surprising turns.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: AMERICAN BLACK DUCK Anas rubripes Size: 21 to 26 inches. Color: Dusky brown body, white underwing linings.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ISSUES REACH HIGH
description: In its latest issues, the United States Postal Service is on a high, but the ones really high are the postal stationery buffs. With the newest issues these collectors cease to be second-class citizens of American philately.

title: TERESA TAAFE ELMS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Alden Elms of Fullerton, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Teresa Taafe Elms, to Robert Demarest Lindsay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Van Cleef Lindsay of New York and Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Jeffrey Schwartz to Wed Nancy Moss
description: Dr. and Mrs. Albert Moss of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Moss, to Jeffrey Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Schwartz of Englishtown, N.J. The wedding is planned for May 23.

title: 'GEORGE M.!' IS STILL HIGH-FLYING SHOW
description: ''GEORGE M.!'' began its Broadway life in April 1968 and ran for 435 performances. The Coachlight subtitled its production, ''A Sentimental Biography,'' a statement that could be ''a sentimentalized biography.'' Despite the statue on Broadway today honoring him, George Michael Cohan was not wildly loved during his own lifetime.

title: 10 YEARS AFTER THE VISIT TO CHINA
description: Exactly 10 years ago, the Shanghai communique capped what I called, in a banquet toast after it was issued, ''the week that changed the world.''

title: SQUEEZING THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: In his incisive article, Mr. Peterson alludes to the way in which the tax deductibility of mortage interest has led to excessive investment in private housing.

title: FOR TWO PAINTERS AND A SCULPTOR, THE SHOW IS THE PRIZE
description: NORTHPORT LAST fall, the Northport Galleries began an unusual project for a private, albeit cooperative, gallery - Expo, an annual juried exhibition. An ambitious but successful undertaking, Expo I was nationwide in scope, attracting more than 100 entries from as far away as California. The top award was a three-person exhibition, and that show, with paintings by George Schulman and Alice Plusch of Huntington and sculpture by Nancy Lindsey, a Wisconsin artist, is on view through March 7.

title: REJOICE! A BONANZA OF GOOD-BAD MOVIES
description: The moviegoing public is in luck. ''Butterfly'' is on hand, for those who like their melodramas tawdry and their heroines even more so. And this is also the season of ''Making Love,'' the story of a boy, a girl, another boy, and their unfailingly well-appointed offices and homes. ''Making Love'' is by far the better and more enjoyable of the two, but that's not to slight ''Butterfly.'' These movies may be bad, but they're terrible treats all the same.

title: AT COOK COLLEGE, RESEARCH CAN BE A PERSONAL PASSION
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE goal of most research at Cook College - to Rutgers alumni of old, it was the College of Agriculture - is keeping New Jersey's food supply adequate and wholesome. But the programs have side benefits as well: They serve as garden plots in which scientists cultivate very personal passions.

title: ENVIRONMENT UNIT ELIMINATED
description: The Department of Transportation has eliminated its Office of Environment in a reorganization that private environmental workers fear may make it more difficult to prevent destructive side effects from new transportation projects.

title: DELBELLO CALLS RESULTS MIXED AFTER MEETING WITH REAGAN
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN reached out to local governments last week, seeking support from the nation's governors and county leaders for his program of redefining responsibilities, or the ''New Federalism.'' The results, according to County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, were mixed.

title: CYPRIOTS GREET PAPANDREOU WARMLY
description: Andreas Papandreou arrived here today on the first visit by a Greek Prime Minister to Cyprus and pledged that his Government would give top priority to promoting ''a fair solution'' to the Cypriot problem.

title: Carolyn Ellis Married to H. Lake Wise
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in New York yesterday, Carolyn T. Ellis, an associate with the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord, was married to H. Lake Wise, an associate with Sullivan & Cromwell, New York lawyers. The Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Morse, Restaurateur Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Reginald G. Morse of Wayland and Woods Hole, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Lesley Morse, to Paul Frederick Richardson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Richardson of Bridgewater and Surf City, N.J.

title: Martin Shafiroff Weds Jean Lutri
description: Jean Lutri, an associate in the corporate finance department of L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, the New York investment banking firm, was married yesterday to Martin D. Shafiroff, a managing director of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre Hotel.

title: SMALL-SCALE POLICE CORRUPTION CITED IN REPORT
description: A report to New York City's Police Commissioner says that while integrity in the Police Department is high, small groups of officers in some units have been able to get away with corruption for periods of time without detection by their superiors.

title: Sarah Conley To Be Bride Of C.J. Kirby
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Conley of Madison, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mr. Conley's daughter, Sarah Gerard Conley, to Charles James Kirby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard N. Kirby of Alexandria, Va.

title: Personal Finance; TOUGH NEW TERMS FOR STUDENT LOANS
description: O F the many Government programs that have come under the Reagan Administration's budget knife, college financial aid programs have been cut especially hard. Funding for some of the Government-backed programs has already been slashed twice during the current fiscal year, and now the White House is proposing further cuts.

title: SUSAN COHEN TO BE BRIDE OF BRUCE E. HIRSCH IN APRIL
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Susan Melinda Cohen to Bruce Elliot Hirsch. An April wedding is planned. Miss Cohen, a second year student at the Cornell University Medical College, where her fiance is in his fourth year, is a daughter of Harriet Newman Cohen of Belle Harbor, Queens, and Philip M. Cohen of Fort Lee, N.J. Mr. Hirsch, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Hirsch of New York.

title: POLITICIANS SHOULD RUN WITH AMATEURS
description: ANEW YORK State Senator, Thomas Bartosiewicz of Brooklyn, has succeeded in getting the State Legislature to authorize the expenditure of $30,000 for the feasibility study of a domed stadium in Brooklyn. So arresting was this development that The New York Times heralded the news on the front page.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CABARET Steve Allen, who is a more familiar sight on the tube than in the flesh, will materialize at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, for two weeks starting Tuesday evening where he will give two shows a night stressing the musical side of his numerous talents.

title: Off and Running In Connecticut
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill has said that nothing would prevent him from facing Connecticut voters in November but his health. Last week, Ernest N. Abate, Speaker of the State House of Representatives, added another potential obstacle: himself.

title: VIETNAM AND THE MILITARY MIND
description: Drew Middleton states, ''The commanders on the scene may have been right in thinking that the Chinese would not intervene'' against ''an American invasion of North Vietnam''in late 1966. Although what would have happened ''if'' can never be proved one way or another, the facts argue against such conjecture.

title: 5 Dead in Texas Crash
description: Five people were killed in the collision of an auto and a tractor-trailer truck here Friday.

title: IN EGYPT, CHILD WORKERS EVERYWHERE
description: The dusty garbage wagon, drawn by three emaciated donkeys, was parked on a main Cairo thoroughfare. It was filled with ashy debris and rags.

title: STATE BUDGETS: THE GOVERNOR PROPOSES, THE ECONOMY IMPOSES
description: Governors write budgets, legislators adjust budgets, but the economy invariably makes or breaks budgets. So it is with Connecticut's $3.2 billion spending plan for the year beginning July 1. Proposed this month by Gov. William A. O'Neill and now the subject of legislative debate, its fate rests not in the Capitol but in corporate boardrooms, on the floors of the stock exchanges, at the Federal Reserve Board and at tens of thousands of cash registers around the state.

title: Deadline for Entries Set In New York Marathon
description: The New York Road Runners Club will begin accepting requests on June 3 for entry forms for the New York Marathon, which will be held on Oct. 24. Fred Lebow, the race director, said that the field will be held to 16,000 runners, as it was last year when more than 40,000 entries were received.

title:
CAMERA;
DAYLIGHT IS DIFFERENT DURING THE WINTER
LESLEY E. BARTH ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Barth of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lesley Elizabeth Barth, to Geoffrey Hugh McKay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh McKay of Maplewood, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Miss Barth is a home economics teacher in Fairfield, Conn. Her fiance is a mechanical engineer with the General Electric Company in Burlington, Vt.

title: Franklin, Hamilton to Meet in Semifinals
description: The boys' basketball confrontation between Benjamin Franklin and Alexander Hamilton High Schools, which had been twice postponed this season, will take place in the semifinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League's championship playoffs next Sunday at St. John's University.

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Fabric Bargains And How to Use Them
description: Stretch and Sew Fabrics in Hartsdale is having a winter fabric clearance with 40 to 70 percent reductions for the next two weeks. The sale items include sweater knits, Irish tweed knits, Qiana crepe knits, challis knits and knit velvets.

title: FILM DIRECTORS WHO HAVE LOST FOCUS IN THE THEATER
description: The current season may not be remembered for many of its plays, though it may be remembered for a few of its more spectacular performances. What it may really be remembered for, however, is the fact that all of a sudden so many celebrated film directors decided it was time to try the stage. Whether this development will eventually be regarded as a godsend or quite a ghastly mistake - or equal portions of both - remains, as they say, to be seen. But Robert Altman (''M*A*S*H,'' ''Nashville'') has already been with us twice, William Friedkin (''The French Connection,'' ''The Exorcist'') has made his local debut, and two more -Louis Malle of ''Atlantic City'' and Karel Reisz of ''The French Lieutenant's Woman'' - are at work as I write. Nothing I say today need apply to the latter two.

title: Censorship And the Press
description: A mixed response was my reaction to the recent article ''Censorship Issue Debated on Suffolk Campus.'' Even as I sympathized with budding college journalists who are resisting mild supervision, I wondered if they weren't undergoing a needed experience.

title: BUILDING N.Y.U.'S SCHOOL OF THE ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: POLITICIANS don't usually head out into the hustings with proposals for new taxes, but that's what State Senator Thom Serrani did last week at a public hearing in which he urged that Connecticut, like every state surrounding it, start taxing out-of-state residents who work here.

title: LAWYER IS FIANCE OF ESTA M. EIGER
description: Mr. and Mrs. David S. Eiger of Minneapolis, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Esta Margaret Eiger to Jamie B.W. Stecher, son of Justice Martin B. Stecher of the New York State Supreme Court, and Mrs. Stecher, of New York. An August wedding is planned in Minneapolis.

title: GILLIAN BARTH TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Allan Barth of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gillian Margaret Barth, to Hugh Grenville Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas William McConnell Davis of Ottawa.

title: SEEING THE FOREST FOR THE TREES
description: he key to understanding landscape design: think very big. ''A collection of choice plants is not a landscape any more than a list of choice words is a poem,'' wrote the late Nan Fairbrother in ''The Nature of Landscape Design'' (Knopf, 1974). ''The merit is in the design, not the materials it is expressed in.''

title: Guide to an old California city Getting There
description: Monterey is on the Monterey Peninsula, about 116 miles south of San Francisco. The drive takes two or two and a half hours, depending on whether you follow the coast road part of the way or go entirely by freeway. Of Interest The capital of Spanish California in 1775, Monterey is an old city by California standards, and has kept or restored many of its late-18th-and 19th-century buildings. A walking tour, ''Paths of History,'' is indicated by red lines painted in the street; it passes 45 old buildings, each marked with a historical plaque. Seven of these - the Robert Louis Stevenson House, the theater, the customs house, the Larkin House, the Casa de Oro (a restored general store), the Casa Soberanes and the Pacific House -- are open to the public (days vary; some have guided tours) under the auspices of the Monterey State Historic Park. Ticketsfor all seven cost 50 cents, available at any of the museums. Maps available, free, from the Monteray Peninsula Chamber of Commerce, 380 Alvarado, or from the Monteray History and Art Association, in the Allen Knight Maritinie Museum, 550 Calle Principal. Other attractions include the Presidio Museum (free; 9-11:30 and 2-4 daily except Tuesday and Wednesday); Colton Hall Museum and Old Monterey Jail (free, 10-12 and 1-5, daily except Monday), and San Carlos Church, the former Presidio chapel, which has an ornate Spanish-colonial facade and has been in continuous use sine 1795.

title: PAIGE WORKING LESS AND WINNING MORE
description: Don Paige has found a delightful formula for success: He is winning more and working out less. On Friday night, in the USA/Mobil indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden, Paige, a 25-year-old Villanova graduate and assistant coach, won his eighth middledistance race this winter - two in Los Angeles, two in the Garden and one each at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Toronto, San Diego and San Francisco.

title: Kathryn Dilworth To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Dilworth of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Elise Dilworth, to Alexis duPont Gahagan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gerli Gahagan of Oyster Bay, L.I. An August wedding is planned in Osterville, Mass.

title: JERSEY TRANSIT AGENCY IS STUDYING CONRAIL COMMUTER LINE TAKEOVER
description: New Jersey Transit Corporation, the state agency that owns or operates hundreds of commuter buses, may soon be operating commuter trains as well, officials said today.

title: TIME OUT FOR THOUGHTS ON THE STATE OF COLLEGE BASKETBALL
description: WITH the college basketball season fast approaching a climax and the championship tournaments just around the corner, a brief review of the key elements (based on recent television of several games, because there were no other sports to watch except Celebrity Arm Wrestling):

title: RADICAL TAX REFORM
description: How can the Federal budget be balanced without slashing social programs and defense spending? ''With mirrors,'' John B. Anderson suggested during his Presidential campaign in 1980. But it can also be done another way: by radically restructuring the tax system. Periodically mentioned by tax reformers and then set aside, creation of a comprehensive tax system is an idea whose time has come.

title: REPORT ON A DEATH FAULTS S.I. MENTAL CENTER
description: A New York State commission that investigates unusual deaths in state mental institutions has released a report finding that the death of a 19-year-old woman at the South Beach Psychiatric Center followed repeated violations of state laws on the restraining and monitoring of patients.

title: Business Conditions; PROFITS IN RAILROADS
description: Despite sagging demand among major freight customers, railroads made money in 1981. ''Last year will go down as either an aberration or a turnaround in railroading,'' said Christopher Naptin, an official with the Association of American Railroads. ''Deregulation and an increase in coal shipments helped a lot last year, and should continue to do so in the future.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
Buying Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: Mailbox; American Abroad
description: To The Sports Editor: One of the most distressing, even shameful sentences appearing on any sports page occurred in Ira Berkow's article ''The Basketball Dream That May Not Come True'' (The New York Times, Feb. 14, 1982). Mr. Berkow makes the statement: ''After nearly four years in college, Howard McNeil is not especially equipped to do much else'' other than to play basketball.

title: THE NUCLEAR DEBATE GOES ON
description: I share Herbert Jaffe's concern about the hemorrhaging of our economy by OPEC. I am also concerned, however, about the awesome consequences of expanding nuclear power.

title: IT'S NEW POLITICS VS. OLD IN VERMONT AS MAYOR STRIVES TO OUST ALDERMAN
description: When the irrepressible Bernard Sanders, a Brooklyn native who describes himself as a radical and socialist, ran as an independent candidate for Mayor of Vermont's largest city a year ago, the incumbent, Gordon Paquette, hardly bothered to campaign. After all, Mr. Paquette, a Democrat in a city where Democrats had been entrenched for years, had never lost a race. Mr. Sanders had never won one.

title: Business Conditions; NO CLOUDS OVER CABLE
description: The financial malaise troubling the television networks has yet to affect cable TV, which continues to enjoy phenomenal growth. Even though statistics tend to overstate the rapid growth of the new industry, nevertheless since 1975 the number of households subscribing to basic cable, a signal-enhancing utility-like service, has increased by more than 200 percent, to 21 million at the start of this year.

title: A Plea for Fairness On New D.E.P. Head
description: Some organized environmentalists are disappointed with the appointment of Robert Hughey as the new Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection. This is not surprising, as these people have expressed similar objections to just about every one of the past Commissioners.

title: Around the Nation; Jury Award to 5 Blacks Hailed as Blow to Klan
description: The jury that awarded $535,000 to five black women in the first civil rights suit filed against the Ku Klux Klan dealt a blow to ''Klansmen and terrorists everywhere,'' the women's lawyer said.

title: LIBRARIANS WARY ON BOOK SELECTIONS
description: QUESTION: What do ''The Hotel New Hampshire'' by John Irving, ''Forever'' by Judy Blume and ''Little Red Riding Hood'' have in common?

title:
Comment;
HOW TO GET OTHER PEOPLE'S MONEY
description: IT'S called O.P.M., or "other people's money" and the search for it takes up a substantial part of most businessmen's time.

title: Michael Marino Will Wed Licia Hahn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Hahn of New York and Shelter Island, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Licia R. Hahn, to Michael F. Marino, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Marino of Philadelphia.

title: Business Conditions; SPORTING GOODS SLUMP
description: Last year was a difficult one for retailers of sporting goods. In spite of isolated pockets of strength, consumers generally put off purchases of sports equipment, shoes and apparel.

title: STATE INCOME TAX WAITS IN THE WINGS
description: FOR a very short time in 1971, Connecticut had a state income tax. Legislators voted for it because they believed it was the only logical way to solve the state's fiscal problems. Taxpayers, on the other hand, were instantly outraged and persuaded legislators to petition for a special session, which repealed the tax before the first dollar was collected.

title: Deborah Hall To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Hall of Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Deborah Ann Hall, to Dr. Robert Charles Sarno, son of Mrs. Alfred N. Sarno of Braintree, Mass., and the late Mr. Sarno. The wedding is planned for May 1.

title: Saints and Sinners
description: To the Business Editor: Gary Sherbell's ''In Stocks, All the Saints and Sinners'' (Feb. 7) assigns Procter & Gamble a ''plus'' for promptly pulling a defective product off the market and Grumman a ''minus'' for the same thing - pulling a defective bus off the streets. As soon as the problem was discovered, we took full responsibility.

title: REAGAN IS NOW THE LEAST OF BUDGET-MAKERS' FEARS
description: Only 12 months ago, Ronald Reagan was preaching that Washington had to learn to live within its means. This year his message is drastically different: Because Government cannot live within its means and still make overdue increases in military spending and carry out the first major tax reduction in two decades, record deficits - which the Administration estimates will reach $91.5 billion in the fiscal year 1983, $82.9 billion in 1984 and $71.9 billion in 1985 -don't matter all that much.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ART NOUVEAU TALKS SET IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK A SERIES of lectures on Art Nouveau will be given at the Newark Museum next month. Each program will begin at 10:30 A.M. On March 10, Alastair Duncan, senior vice president for 19th- and 20th-century decorative arts at Christie's, the international auction house, will speak on ''Art Nouveau Furniture.''

title: A MOST GENEROUS COMPANY
description: MINNEAPOLIS Y OU may have given at the office, but what does the office give? Corporations on the average set aside 1 percent of their pretax profits for philanthropic purposes. Indeed, according to the Council on Financial Education, only a third of some 1.4 million corporations make any charitable contributions at all. Now, with the Reagan Administration's budget cuts in social programs, pressure is building on companies to be a little more generous and take up some of the slack.

title: GENIUSES AND CRANKS
description: SCIENCE OBSERVED Essays Out of My Mind. By Jeremy Bernstein. 376 pp. New York: Basic Books. $16.95.

title: American Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books
description: ANASTASIA AGAIN! By Lois Lowry. Decorations by Diane de Groat. 145 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $7.95. (Ages 8 to 12) By JUDITH ST.GEORGE

title: FROM CANADA TO THE BRONX IS NOT EXACTLY KOCH COUNTRY
description: IN the 165 years since De Witt Clinton became the first Mayor of New York City to be elected governor of the state, nobody else has made the trip from City Hall to Albany. Historic upstate fears of downstate domina tion have played a large part in that.

title: SQUEEZING THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: I am a Federal employee who recently transferred from the private sector. I will have to rely upon a combination of Federal retirement, Social Security and personal funds to maintain a decent income once I retire.

title: 2,000 Rally in Japan To Ask A-Arms Ban
description: About 2,000 people staged a rally today in the port city of Shizuoka calling for a ban on nuclear weapons.

title: NASSAU POST SEEN FOR REILLY
description: ASSEMBLYMAN Joseph M. Reilly of Glen Cove, the senior Republican Assemblyman from Nassau County, is not expected to seek re-election this year, according to Nassau G.O.P. sources.

title: A TROUPE DEVOTED TO THE CLASSICS
description: Instead of carrying the dead Cordelia in his arms at the end of ''King Lear,'' as Shakespeare and tradition dictate, Lear, played by Robert Stattel, will enter dragging her like a broken doll in the production opening today at the Classic Stage Company Repertory theater on East 13th Street.

title: POLAND'S BISHOPS CALL FOR AN END TO MILITARY RULE
description: Poland's Roman Catholic episcopate called today for an end to martial law, freedom for those detained under its provisions and a national covenant in which Solidarity would partcipate.

title: COME, MEET THE FAMILY
description: OLD WORLD, NEW WORLD By Mark Dintenfass. 404 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $14.50.

title: The 256KJAPANESE DILEMMA TOKYO
description: Success has its own problems. Thus, Japan's major semiconductor producers are trying to figure out how fast to push ahead with the next generation of integrated circuit memory - the 256K dynamic random-access-memory chip.

title: Squeezing the Middle Class
description: Peter G. Peterson's ''No More Free Lunch for the Middle Class'' (Jan. 17) is right on, except for the title.

title: Canada-Peking Pact Signed
description: Canada and China signed an agreement today setting up a 1982-83 cultural exchange program, the New China News Agency reported. The program covers the arts, journalism, broadcasting, television, film, publishing, sport, the humanities and social sciences.

title:
GARDENING;
GREEN THUMBS ARE ACQUIRED, NOT BORN
description: SHOULD someone take a vote to determine the most perfect avocation, gardening should win hands down. Through gardening one may beautify one's home both indoors and out, provide food of superior quality and flavor and obtain beneficial exercise. It is doubtful that any other leisure-time activity can make a comparable claim.

title: WHY MODERNIST ARCHITECTURE LOST FACE
description: If any fact can be said to underscore how quickly revolutions age, it is that half a century has passed since the day the Museum of Modern Art put a few photographs and models into its galleries under the title, ''International Exhibition of Modern Architecture.'' Behind that bland and unassuming label was one of the most determined efforts at design proslytizing this or any other museum has ever engaged in. For this exhibition was the celebrated ''International Style'' show, in which the museum presented the stark, white buildings of stucco and glass and metal by Le Corbusier, Walter Gropius, Mies van der Rohe and others that it wanted us to think would pull us out of the stultifying classicism of the 19th century and pave the way to a glorious new world.

title: WHEN JUSTICE AND POLITICS MEET AND MIX
description: To the Editor:

title: Airlines
description: To the Business Editor: The current financial crisis facing America's airlines, as described in ''The Airlines: Stacked Up in Red Ink'' (Feb. 14) should come as a surprise to no one. While being described as ''Neanderthals'' during the debate on deregulation, many wellinformed experts predicted on the record that there could be chaotic financial consequences.

title: 'SLEEPING DOGS,' FROM NEW ZEALAND
description: Smith (Sam Neill) leaves his wife and two small children in the first scene of ''Sleeping Dogs,'' walking out of a suburban house that could be anywhere. Will this be the only side of New Zealand we see, in one of the few films that nation has exported? Not at all. Smith is so unhappy over the marital breakup that he heads for a remote corner of his country, driving across exotic landscapes and arriving at a strange, beautiful island. He asks to rent a house there, and one of the Maori locals offers suddenly - much too suddenly - to trade a dog and a leaky motorboat for Smith's car.

title: Woolgathering
description: A visitor's education in wool will be furthered immensely by staying at one of the many sheep farms that accept paying guests. These farms, concentrated around the town of Cambridge, about 50 miles from Rotorua on North Island, charge a daily rate of about $31 a person, which includes three meals.

title: Around the World; Beirut Car Bomb Kills 8 And Leaves 20 Wounded
description: A car bomb exploded in a Moslem suburb of Beirut today, killing 8 people and wounding 20 others, police sources said.

title: A Creative Force In Animated Cartoons
description: It was a shock to read your Feb. 7 article about the Terrytoons studio (''Mighty Mouse (and Others) on the Way to Save the Day'') and not see the name of one of its most important people, Mannie Davis. It was this man who conceived and developed the concept of combining cartoon characters with live actors on the screen and who is responsible for such wonderful creations as Mighty Mouse and Heckle and Jeckle.

title: No Headline
description: February 28, 1982 NONFICTION CHINABOUND: A Fifty-Year Memoir. By John King Fairbank. 11 ENEMIES OF CHOICE: The Right-to-Life Movement and Its Threat to Abortion.

title: THE 'NEW FEDERALISM' IMPLIES ITS OWN TRICLE-DOWN THEORY
description: AS the nation's governors met in Washington last week to wrestle with the President's 'new federalism' proposals, so did leaders of another level of American government - the 3,041 counties, ranging from Loving County, Texas, serving

title: Catholics and Anglicans Map Path to Reunion
description: A commission of Anglican and Roman Catholic theologians has produced a statement on authority in the church that describes a reunited church under a ''reformed'' papacy.

title: JAPAN'S BIG LEAD IN MEMORY CHIPS
description: Since the age of the transistor dawned at Bell Laboratories in 1947, the United States has dominated what is now the $13 billion global semiconductor industry. In a business where prowess and profits have been measured by the ability to squeeze more and more electronic circuitry into less and less space, companies like Texas Instruments, Intel and Motorola have raced to outdo one another, sometimes trumpeting each new advance well before it was ready for market.

title: Guide to an old California city
description: GETTING THERE

title: BELLS, BELLS, BELLS
description: SANDRA FOUSHEE works in the Denver bureau of The Times. By SANDRA FOUSHEE

title: DEBATE HEATS UP AS DECISION NEARS ON MULTI-TOWN
description: ONE week before the Multi-Town Solid Waste Management Authority awards a contract for construction of a solid waste resource recovery facility to replace Huntington's and Babylon's landfills, criticisms of the size, cost and environmental effect of the project are once again mounting.

title:
ART;
BLACK ARTISTS AT NEWARK MUSEUM
description: NEWARK ON FEB. 6, the Newark Museum, in a tribute to Black History Month, opened an exhibition called ''Black Artists.'' The show, which will remain on view until May 15, is drawn from works in the museum's permanent collection and contains some important and beautiful art.

title: ABOUT MISTRESSES AND SECOND WIVES
description: ''I AM not a mistress any more,'' said Melissa Sands, who was married three years ago on Valentine's Day to a divorced father. ''I am more interested in second wives and their struggles. I think they're an untapped majority, and if they would get together and put their mark on society, there wouldn't be such stigma about divorce, and courts would acknowledge the second wife is as important as the first wife.''

title: PRACTITIONERS OUTSIDE THE PHOTOGRAPHIC TRADITION
description: To the casual New York observer, the contemporary art scene of late has been marked largely by a profusion of so-called Neo-Expressionist painting and by an onslaught of French art in the form of a 16-gallery, mixed-bag showcase called ''Statements.'' There is, however, another notable aspect to this winter season, which is the number of painters, Conceptual artists and unclassifiable others who are using photographs. These are, on the whole, artists who have had little to do with the photographic tradition, and who therefore use photography in ways that frequently are at once radical and naive.

title: L.I.E. NOISE BARRIERS SOUGHT
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS ''PEOPLE in our neighborhood don't need an alarm clock,'' Harold Harris said. ''About 5 A.M., those big over-the-road trailer trucks start booming out on the Long Island Expressway, and that rrr-rrr-rrr sound when they rev up for the little rise in the roadway wakes everybody up.''

title: SUSAN ANN CONNERS FIANCEE OF PETER CERCHIARA JR.
description: Susan Ann Conners, manager of corporate strategic planning for the American Express Company, plans to be married Feb. 6 to Peter F. Cerchiara Jr., manager of benefits for National CSS, a Dun & Bradstreet computer service subsidiary in Wilton, Conn.

title: CO-OP DRIVE A SUCCESS IN BRONX
description: In a reversal of the withdrawal of private investment in housing in the area, nearly 400 tenants at the large Fordham Hill housing complex off Fordham Road in the West Bronx have elected to buy their apartments as cooperatives.

title: A Radio-TV Pioneer Recalled by Grandson
description: ''Focusing on Channel 13 of Old'' (Jan. 10) presented an interesting, albeit truncated, history of commercial television in New Jersey, but it did not mention Frank V. Bremer, the man who pioneered radio and television broadcasting in the state.

title: THE WORKING OF A MIRACLE
description: MIRACLES are pretty hard to come by these days, but on Jan. 26 I witnessed one at Children's Hospital of New Jersey in Newark. In an operating room, I saw skill, dedication and love give an 11-day-old boy the chance to lead a normal and productive life. The story began about 6 o'clock the evening before, when Children's Hospital received a call from the Jersey City Medical Center that an infant there was in cardiac distress. Children's immediately sent a medical van to pick up the child.

title: MISSIONS IMPOSSIBLE
THE SUBJECT WAS SCIENCE
description: I HAVE always liked to tell myself stories, and now that I am past 50 I find myself telling myself stories about my early life. I entered Harvard at the age of 17, in 1947. I had absolutely no idea of what I intended to study. The only thing I was sure of was that it was not going to be science. I had done some journalism in high school, where I had been a mediocre science student, and for a time I thought I might like to become a journalist. This ambition did not last very long, and gradually -under the influence of some great teachers, such as Philipp Frank and Julian Schwinger - I shifted to mathematics and then, in graduate school to theoretical physics. All the while, I was writing - but for nobody in particular. I did not take a single course in creative writing. I never tried to write for the Harvard Crimson or any of the literary magazines that flourished at Harvard. I simply scribbled away at poems, short stories and aphorisms by the dozens, all on sheets of note paper, surrounded by formulae, and, by and large, shown to nobody. If someone had asked me why I was writing, I don't know what I would have said. It was just something I did.

title: Olson Vaults Record 18-10
description: Billy Olson, on his third attempt, cleared an indoor world-best height of 18 feet 10 inches in the pole vault tonight at the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics indoor track and field championships.

title: Globe, $15.40, Rallies And Wins the Grey Lag
description: Globe, in last place by nearly 15 lengths after a quarter of a mile, closed powerfully in the stretch yesterday and won the $84,750 Grey Lag Handicap by a nose at Aqueduct.

title: MUSIC: JUILLIARD PHILHARMONIC
description: The Juilliard Philharmonia offered works by Beethoven, Prokofiev and Debussy on Friday night in Alice Tully Hall under the direction of Ronald Braunstein. The concert marked the first New York appearance by Mr. Braunstein since he won the Herbert von Karajan International Conducting Competition in 1979.

title: THE DANCE: WENDY PERRON
description: Wendy Perron subjected herself to a barrage of words at her Friday night dance concert at Public School 122. Words came tumbling forth in ''A Ststoryry: Impossible to Tell.'' As Miss Perron sat motionless and then got up to move restlessly about, she was deluged with the sound of voices, including voices from a television set and the voices of other dancers. All these voices commented on her emotional state and asked questions, both serious and absurd, about her.

title: Around the Nation; 4 Dead, Many Are Hurt In Southern Snowstorm
description: By The Associated Press A Southern storm smothered a hint of spring yesterday with a foot of snow, sleet and ice that left thousands without power, four dead and many injured from Arkansas to Virginia.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: MUST the owners of the thousands of homes and businesses in New Jersey who had urea formaldehyde insulation installed now remove it - at a cost of up to $20,000? The answer from state environmental health experts is a qualified ''no.''

title: 2 ESCAPE AFTER 4 IN ROBBERY SWITCH COATS WITH HOSTAGES
description: It was a typical hostage situation: a bungled robbery in a Queens supermarket, four heavily armed gunmen trapped inside with 16 employees and customers, a cordon of police firepower outside amid a night-scene clutter of radio cars, flashing lights and blaring loudspeakers.

title: TRAVELING LIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: ANNE MAGGIO IS AFFIANCED TO GABOR CSORDAS, BANKER
description: The engagement of Anne Marie Maggio to Gabor John Csordas has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Edward Vincent Maggio of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, parents of the future bride. her fiancee is the son of the Rev. Gabor Csordas, minister of the Hungarian Reformed Church in New York, and Irene Csordas of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: Stadler, Scrambling to 73-208, Leads Three by Shot at Doral
description: The third round of the Doral-Eastern Open developed into a scramble today, with five players tied for the lead at one juncture. But Craig Stadler pulled a gutsy recovery to reclaim the lead after losing it twice.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Top Guatemala Officer Is Wounded by Rebels

title: ROBERT HABERL TO WED KATE O'BRIEN MAY 15
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack O'Brien have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kate Mary O'Brien, to Robert Joseph Haberl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Haberl of Whiting, N.J. A May 15 wedding is planned at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Giant Slalom to Maria Epple
description: The World Cup women's giant slalom race turned into a family affair for the Epple sisters of West Germany today. Maria Epple, 22 years old, won with a combined time of 2 minutes 13.51 seconds on the icy, 876-meter course. Irene, 24, came in third with a time of 2:14.16.

title: THE LIFE OF A FREELANCE CHOREOGRAPHER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Peter Anastos, whose two latest works - ''The Big Bang'' and ''Don't Wave'' - will be performed at the Dance Theater Workshop this week beginning Thursday, will be off to Los Angeles next week to begin choreographing a new work for American Ballet Theater while it is performing there. By PETER ANASTOS

title: WHAT'S DOING IN STOCKHOLM
description: R. W. APPLE Jr. is the chief of the London bureau of The Times. By R.W.APPLE Jr.

title: DOLE WARNS OF A FREEZE IN SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS
description: Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, today warned the new commission studying Social Security that Congress might take some action on financing the retirement system in the next few months without waiting for further advice.

title: Editor's Choice
description: Irish writer. A BIGAMIST'S DAUGHTER, by Alice McDermott. (Random House, $13.50.) A first novel about a young woman who works for a vanity press.

title: HIJACKED JETLINER ARRIVES IN BRITAIN
description: A hijacked Air Tanzania jet carrying about 90 people arrived from Athens today and was immediately surrounded by the police at Stansted Airport north of London.

title: Disney's New 'World' Is Coming
description: An $800-million ''world of the future'' will be opened at Florida's Walt Disney World on Oct. 1, and special ''keepsake testimonial tickets'' will be available to early birds from now through Aug. 1 on a first-come, first-served basis.

title: DANCE: THE RHYTHMS OF MENTAL ILLNESS
description: Although the dancers of Dancemakers were just fine, their dances were an odd lot. Dancemakers, a Toronto modern-dance troupe, appeared Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church and, under the direction of Carol Anderson and Patricia Fraser, its eight members gave totally committed performances of a program consisting almost entirely of works about derangement and dementia.

title: MUZZLES; Pistol-Packing 101
description: The library science program at Montgomery County Community Col-lege in Pennsylvania does not, in truth, sound like a winner. (At the moment it has nine students.)

title: * To the Editor:$
description: In a Feb. 18 editorial you say that Justice Brandeis's private arrangement to furnish funds to enable Felix Frankfurter to further social and political causes in which both were interested ''violates ethical standards.'' You draw the wrong conclusion.

title: 'Knucklemen' to Open At American Theater
description: ''The Last of the Knucklemen,'' a play by John Powers about a power struggle among a group of men in an Austrailian mining camp, will begin previews Wednesday and open March 13 at the American Theater of Actors, 314 West 54th Street.

title: Rostropovich to Present A Tchaikovsky Festival
description: Mstislav Rostropovich and the National Symphony of Washington will present a four-concert Tchaikovsky Festival in Carnegie Hall April 13-16.

title: VIETNAM AND THE MILITARY MIND
description: It was the gradual erosion of credibility in the military reports and assessments of the war that brought about general disillusionment with the war. These reports, whether from the Pentagon or from the Saigon command, were so continually optimistic over such a long period, and so frequently suggested that the months ahead would bring victory that eventually, I think, they became largely discounted by most of us. ROBERT F. HALSTEAD Bridgewater, Conn. -------

title: Visit to a pair of pyramids
description: Tenayuca Start early enough and you will have time for an interesting stop on the way to Tula and Tepotzotlan. Early does not mean the crack of dawn because Tenayuca is only about four miles north of the circle that marks the intersection of Avenida Insurgentes and the Paseo de la Reforma, the center of Mexico City. At Tenayuca the hours do not seem to be fixed; you may have to wait outside until the caretaker is willing to unlock the gate and accept your 5 pesos. Although much of this modest-sized pyramid and the undulating sculptural frieze of linked serpents representing Quetzalcoatl, the plumed serpent, can be seen from outside the low retaining wall that surrounds the monument, this pyramid is worth climbing and a close look. It is thought to be very similar in style to the great pyramid that once stood in the center of the Aztec capital of Tenochitlan, now Mexico City. But it is only about half the size. The pyramid is fascinating because, like many of the monuments of that era, it was constructed in successive stages, each superimposed on the existing structure. Today, remains of the various levels are clearly marked. Tenayuca was built in seven stages, the last about 1450. By climbing the outer stairway on the facade (which dates from the sixth period; the seventh and final building period was devoted mainly to refinements) one can cross over to the inner, fourth-period structure and view the stairway that remains.

title: CARE SENDING PARTS FOR TRACTORS TO THE POLES
description: Thousands of Polish farmers will get tires and some spare parts for their idled tractors from the American aid agency CARE in time for spring planting, according to the executive director of the organization.

title: 83 HAITIANS IN BROOKLYN STILL FIGHT FOR ASYLUM
description: Sixty-eight Haitian ''boat people'' detained for the last seven months in a former Navy brig in Brooklyn are still engaged in a legal battle for political asylum.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE MARKET IS BEGINNING TO LOOK BETTER
description: Nearly two years have passed since the coin market's dazzling rise gave way to a dizzying fall. The market hasn't yet regained its former momentum - but now analysts are finally seeing signs that things are beginning to move in the right direction once again.

title: Miss Spector Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Stacey Leigh Spector to Richard W. Liebman has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Spector of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Mr. Liebman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Liebman of Rye, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: SPECIAL WORLD OF THE DISABLED'S FAMILIES
description: IF 1981 was the International Year of Disabled Persons, then 1982 should be for the Families of Disabled Persons. They endure a different kind of stress and have a different set of problems than other families.

title: BIG BANDS SWING AGAIN ON NEW DISKS
description: Back in 1969, when George H. Buck Jr. bought the catalogue of World Transcriptions, one of the major radio transcription services of the 1930's and 40's, a Swing Era fan could envision a flood of recordings by most of the big bands of the period that had never before been available to the public. Radio transcriptions were made only for use by radio stations and were not for public sale. But 20 years after there was any reason to have radio transcriptions, that limitation could be overlooked.

title: CABARET: ANDRE DE SHIELDS
description: Andre De Shields, who says that he is ''black by popular demand'' at the Music Room of the Horn of Plenty, Charles Street and Bleeker Street, is putting on what he describes as ''an R & B show.''

title: Australia
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY PLAYOFFS OFFER SOME INTRIGUING POSSIBILITIES
description: Even though there is more than a month left in the National Hockey League season, the points separating the first four clubs in each division make it quite apparent which teams should be facing each other in the playoffs starting April 7.

title: Around the World; Egypt's Envoy Carrying 'Urgent' Notes to U.S.
description: Ashraf Ghorbal, Egypt's Ambassador to the United States, cut short a visit to Egypt and is returning to Washington with ''urgent'' messages for President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., officials said today.

title: RIGHTEST LEADER IN SALVADOR IS WOUNDED IN ATTACK
description: Roberto D'Aubuisson, the principal rightist candidate in El Salvador's elections, was slightly wounded by a gunshot in the back this afternoon as he was leaving the capital for a campaign appearance in a provincial city.

title: PARIS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Brenson is an art critic living in Paris. By MICHAEL BRENSON

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: PORT CHESTER BEFORE coming to the Westchester Opportunities Industrialization Center here, Alan Thompson was, as he tells it, ''cooling out.'' ''I was on the block, hanging out, procrastinating, doing nothing,'' he said. ''I'd shoot pool all day; it was crazy. I had odd jobs off and on, but nothing like I'm into now.''

title: IS THIS ACTION RIDICULOUS OR IS IT BRILLIANT?
description: One of the most bewildering areas for the average player is the bid in the opponent's suit. When made directly over the opening bid, it can have - by agreement - a wide assortment of meanings: the upper unbid suits; the top and bottom unbid suits; two suits of the same color; a big unspecified hand; or even natural, with length and strength in the enemy suit.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Hasty Pudding
description: The Hasty Pudding Club, a 212-year-old institution at Harvard College and the nation's oldest student society, found itself in financial distress last year: it owed $33,000 in back taxes to the City of Cambridge, $18,000 to the university for heating and a variety of other debts amounting to tens of thousands of dollars.

title: 3-Day Seminar Set On the Theater
description: The Foundation for the Extension and Development of the American Professional Theater will sponsor a seminar on ''Producing for the Commercial Theater'' next Friday and Saturday and March 7 at the theater of the Carter Hotel, 250 West 43d Street.

title: PATTI SCHWARTZ ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon O. Schwartz of Fair Lawn, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patti Lynn Schwartz, to Bryan Louis Lakin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Lakin of Highland Park, N.J. The wedding is planned for September. Miss Schwartz is a merchandising coordinator for Seventeen magazine in New York. Mr. Lakin is a documentary examiner in the international letter of credit department of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York.

title: LEGAL DISPUTES SURROUND J.C. PENNEY WAREHOUSE
description: CONNECTICUT'S largest building, the sprawling J.C. Penney distribution warehouse in Manchester, seems well on its way to becoming a symbolic landmark of environmental law in the state, following years of legal disputes that show no sign of letting up.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Soviet Emigre Cellist Offers Pair of Sonatas
description: Boris Pergamenschikow, a Soviet emigre cellist who won first prize in the 1974 Tchaikovsky competition, made his United States debut Thursday evening at the 92d Street Y with a program featuring the sonatas in E minor (Op. 38) of Brahms and in D minor (Op. 40) of Shostakovich - both of which were on the program with which another Russian cellist, Mstislav Rostropovich, made his American debut at Carnegie Hall a quarter-century ago.

title: Getting there
description: The trip to Vonnas down the autoroute from Paris takes about four hours. But the trick is to avoid the autoroute and wander through Burgundy on the way, possibly stopping overnight in Saulieu or Dijon or Beaune.

title: Garrison Keillor
description: HAPPY TO BE HERE By Garrison Keillor. 210 pp. New York: Atheneum. $11.95.

title: Fair Housing In Principle
description: Just because someone hasn't suffered practical consequences of discrimination, the Supreme Court ruled last week, doesn't mean they haven't been injured by it. In a unanimous decision, the Justices said that a fair housing ''tester'' who receives false information about the availability of a house or an apartment can sue under the Fair Housing Act, even if he never intended to complete the purchase or rental.

title: No Headline
description: RUTGERS ENDS WEST VIRGINIA STREAK AT 23 27,318 WATCH SYRACUSE BOW

title: NEEDIEST CASES APPEAL ENDS ON RECORD $1.5 MILLION
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended its 70th annual appeal yesterday with a record total of $1,535,501.54 in contributions from more than 10,350 donors.

title: SHE SHOPS TO CONQUER
description: he's considered the ''customer of the 80's'' in some stores, even the hope of the future. She - and there appear to be many like her - is a shopper who's into fashion with a vengeance. She buys in the departments of stores with catchy names like Expressions (Macy's) or Y.E.S. (Bloomingdale's), and she shops often. In fact, both Macy's and Bloomingdale's report she is accounting for an increasingly large percentage of their business, though she, too, is currently shopping more prudently. She's apt to frequent the trendy hair salons and pick up on the newest cosmetics and accessories. She is not necessarily of any specific age -she can be from late middle age downward - but she is a specific type with a strong personal, if quirky, sense of style. She is the woman the stores refer to as ''the contemporary customer,'' the exact opposite of the woman who builds a wardrobe from season to season and who sometimes sticks to one or just a few designers. ''The contemporary customer wants what's hot right now,'' explains Rick Goldstein, a vice president and fashion director at Macy's. ''This woman mixes up her favorite designer's stuff. She puts a top from one with a skirt from another, and she will keep something from one season to the next only if she can make it work in a new way.''

title: A NEW LOOK AT POLICY
description: Profound changes in America's relations with the world were made as a result of World War II and of a conscious review of goals and challenges when the cold war developed.

title: VALENTINE CHALLENGING CRITICS
description: In six years in the major leagues, Ellis Valentine says, ''there've been days when I wanted to throw my spikes in my locker and go home because I was so tired of people degrading my character.''

title: William Winthrop Burr To Marry Annalisa Cozzi
description: The engagement of Annalisa Cozzi to William Winthrop Burr of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., has been announced by Miss Cozzi's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Luigi Cozzi of Milan, Italy. Mr. Burr is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Page Burr of Matinicus, Me. An early spring wedding is planned in Cold Spring Harbor.

title: Other Business; A SOLAR FACTORY TO MAKE SOLAR CELLS
description: year-old native of Hungary, whose company is already considered the world's largest producer of photovoltaic cells, the type that convert sunlight to electricity.

title: Thais Get 20 U.S. Missiles
description: The United States delivered 20 Redeye antiaircraft guided missiles to Thailand today as part of its accelerated shipments of arms to this country. The portable missile system was sold to Thailand at the special request of Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda when he visited Washington last year.

title: Lacey Isn't in the Middle, Even on Bench
description: The Nets were warming up last Friday night, preparing for the Portland Trail Blazers. Everyone was trying to work up a good sweat before tipoff.

title: CAREY PLAN ON SCHOOLS DRAWS FIRE
description: GOVERNOR CAREY'S latest education-aid proposal continued to draw sharp criticism last week from members in the Westchester County delegation, who believe that the plan spells ''disaster'' for the county's school system and doubt that it will win approval from the State Legislature.

title: Machu Picchu
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NUCLEAR DEBATE GOES ON
description: HERBERT JAFFE'S slapdash analysis of the alternatives to nuclear power (''They Weigh the Alternatives and Choose Nuclear Power,'' Opinion Page, Jan. 31) manages to miss the point entirely, an unsurprising circumstance given his position as a director of a utility stockholders' lobbying organization.

title: The Neediest Give Thanks
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund began its 70th annual appeal three months ago amid dire predictions that the recession might cramp the instincts of charity. With the end of the formal drive today, we are pleased to report the pessimists wrong.

title: HATCHERY CHANGES RULES FOR ANGLERS
description: THE more than 2,000 trout used to stock the public fishing ponds at the Quinebaug Valley Hatchery in Plainfield are usually considered fair game for the state's many fishermen. But officials at the state's Department of Environmental Protection have discovered that its pools are being underutilized.

title: For Transit, It's All Uphill
description: When transit officials launched their $7 billion program to rebuild New York's subways last year, they pledged to improve the system's safety. Last week, one of their first projects was halted for fear it would do just the opposite.

title: POE EXHIBIT IN YONKERS
description: Dr. Burton R. Pollin, professor emeritus of English at the City University of New York and author of several books and articles on Edgar Allan Poe, has lent part of his extensive collection of Poerelated material for an exhibition opening Wednesday in the Sarah Lawrence College library in Yonkers.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 5 4 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 2 2 5 MARCO POLO, IF YOU CAN, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $13.95.) Blackford Oakes's quest for a mole in the C.I.A. takes him to Russia. 3 1 19 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 4 3 15 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 5 9 4 THE DEAN'S DECEMBER, by Saul Bellow. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) During a deathbed vigil in Rumania, a college dean from Chicago realizes some truths about his own land. 6 8 4 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer. (Putnam's, $14.95.) A woman caught between the clashing ambitions of two brothers during the springtime of this century. 7 4 24 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 8 6 16 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A Brief Return ''Television? I don't like it as a medium for an actor,'' said Uta Hagen, who won one of Broadway's Tony awards in 1950 for ''The Country Girl'' and another for ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,'' in 1963. Miss Hagen believes television ''is for directors and cameramen.

title: Where Have the Children Gone?
description: If the future belongs to the young, New York City's may not be what it used to be. Figures from the Census Bureau last week showed that the number of residents under the age of 18 has declined 21 percent since 1970, versus a 10 percent drop in the city's total population during that period.

title: LORD DARNLEY, 16-1, CAPTURES WIDENER
description: Only 16 months ago, Mary L. Russ was among the legion of young women who groom and exercise horses around the track in the mornings. Today, as an apprentice rider, she guided Lord Darnley to a narrow victory in the $172,500 Widener Handicap at Hialeah Park. She was believed to be the first woman to ride the winner of a Grade I stakes race and the winner of the largest purse by a woman jockey.

title: POP: IRISH GUITAR-FIDDLE DUO
description: Folk City, at 130 West Third Street, is the site of an Irish music festival that opened on Thursday with performances by the guitar and fiddle duo of Kevin Burke and Micheal O Domhnaill. On March 13, the Washington-based trio, the Irish Tradition will appear, and the festival will wind up on St. Patrick's night with performances by the traditionalist quartet Touchstone.

title: MARY LEE ARMITAGE WED
description: The marriage of Mary Lee Armitage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Armitage of Rome, N.Y., to Kenneth Irving Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Irving Brown of Fairfield, Conn., took place yesterday at the Zion Episcopal Church in Rome.

title: A CRITIC'S POWER
description: ''Think of all the power you're going to have!'' my friends said when I went to work as a book critic for this paper. I thought of it and didn't believe I would have all that much, but such as it was I resolved to put this power at the service of good writing, remembering at the same time that esthetics was the vaguest course in college.

title: Court in Papua New Guinea Seizes Fishing Ship From U.S.
description: A court confiscated a $13 million American tuna fishing ship today and fined its captain about $800 for infringing on the country's 200-mile economic zone.

title: THE CLIBURN WINNERS - THEIR NEW LIFE AND STYLE
description: Last May 31 the six winners of the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition were announced, and at least one of them - the winner of the first prize, Andre-Michel Schub - went on to instant fame. By coincidence, four of the six will be playing in New York within a 10-day period starting March 5. On that day Christopher O'Reilly, who came in fifth, will be playing the Schumann Concerto in Carnegie Hall with the National Orchestral Association. Then there will be back-toback concerts by Mr. Schub, in Carnegie Hall on March 8, and by Panayis Lyras, the following evening in Tully Hall. Mr. Lyras shared second place with Santiago Rodriguez, who played at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium earlier this season. Finally, on March 15, Jeffrey Kahane, fourth-place winner, will be playing at Tully Hall. That leaves only Zhu Da Ming from China unaccounted for. Mr. Zhu, the sixth-place winner, is currently studying at the Juilliard School and has no immediate plans for a New York debut.

title: SENIOR ALLOTMENT GARDENS ADD NEW DIMENSIONS TO LIFE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard M. Bacon is a horticultural consultant and freelance writer. By RICHARD M. BACON HOLLIS,N.H. So much has been written by and about the individual gardener who probes the soil to find peace of mind that gardening is often seen as a solitary occupation. For the most part it is.

title: Reggie Smith Now a Giant
