description: Reggie Smith, who has hit 296 home runs in a 16-year major league career, signed as a free agent with the San Francisco Giants today.

title: A NEW KIDNEY, A NEW LIFE
description: STONY BROOK ''I FEEL great. My brother plans to jog soon, and I plan to be right there with him.'' As she spoke, Rosita Green was resting comfortably in her glass-enclosed private room, strictly guarded against contamination, at the University Hospital at Stony Brook, five days after undergoing transplantation surgery.

title: POPE WARNS JESUITS BUT MOVES TO END DIRECT RULE
description: Sternly calling the Society of Jesus to strict obedience to his authority, Pope John Paul II nonetheless took the first step today to end his direct rule over the embattled Jesuit order.

title: NEW ERA DAWNS AT MITCHEL FIELD
description: UNIONDALE SINCE the end of World War II, Long Island officials have been struggling with plans to develop Mitchel Field, the former military base in the heart of Nassau County and one of the largest and choicest pieces of undeveloped real estate in the New York area.

title: No Headline
description: Around the Nation; A.&P. Is Reported Set To Close 38 of Its Stores

title: TAIWAN ARMS ISSUE DAMAGING U.S.-CHINESE TIES
description: Ten years ago, when President Richard M. Nixon made his historic visit here, the United States and China endorsed a joint statement in Shanghai that stressed their common concerns and glossed over their considerable differences.

title: Budget Response In a Word: No
description: The public pronouncements of Republican Congressional leaders last week left little reason to doubt a White House spokesman's characterization of their private tone. In an 80-minute meeting with President Reagan on his 1983 budget proposals and its $91.5 billion deficit, there was, David R. Gergen said, ''some plain talk among friends.''

title: Follow-Up on the News; Ferret Finders
description: Last Oct. 29, a black-footed ferret, believed to be the rarest mammal in North America, was captured near its home in a Wyoming prairie dog colony by biologists of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: Muzzles; Liberty and Loyalty
description: Who says that the Stars and Stripes are the exclusive property of the political right? That's what Norman Lear, the television producer, would like to know. He is especially concerned that organizations like the Moral Majority not claim a moral monopoly on patriotism.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Headliners Discordance

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: 12,000 TEST WINGS AT MODEL AIR SHOW
description: WHITE PLAINS ''THEY'LL spend their last dollar on a model, work for 300 hours building it, and then go out and crash it -and then they'll buy another one,'' said Alan Davis, looking out at several hundred men and about 50 boys milling around the County Center. ''They're addicted.''

title: HARVARD, 1
description: PRINCETON PPRINCETON UNIVERSITY students garnered the largest number of Rhodes Scholarships awarded to Americans this year. Of the 32 recipients, five were from Princeton. Yale placed second with three recipients, followed by the Air Force Academy with two. Harvard, which has traditionally dominated the competition, had one.

title: THE CHEF MAKES ALL THE DIFFERENCE
description: IL VILLAGGIO in Roslyn is in a building that, until it was beautifully renovated several years ago, had been an automobile showroom. Actually, Il Villaggio is the third restaurant to inhabit these premises. The large, high-ceilinged space is given a rosy glow from walls of exposed brick and a terra cotta-colored ceiling. Mirrors and chandeliers add dressy but understated glitter, and the tables are formally set.

title: RUMANIA TELLS U.S. DEBT OF $5.8 MILLION FOR GRAIN IS PAID OFF
description: Rumania announced today that it had paid its overdue debt of $5.8 million to the United States for grain that it purchased on credit.

title: LOST GENIUS
description: Russell Baker is really asking for it. How happy are we that Mother Baker gave us Russell? Elated, that's it. ANGELE CROUCH Short Hills. N.J.

title: Sports of the Times; AN ACTOR'S SPRINT IN TWO ERAS
description: FOR 16 weeks of his life, Ben Cross was an athlete. If actors could be transformed into Henri Toulouse-Lautrec and the Hunchback of Notre Dame, Ben Cross could be transformed into an Olympic champion.

title: City Hall Notes; SUCCESSION IS RAISING QUESTIONS
description: Mayor Koch's decision to run for Governor has sent officials at City Hall thumbing through their copies of the City Charter, notably the sections on the line of succession. The provisions seem fairly clear, but not perfectly so, and early signs were that the lack of clarity was sufficient to keep a few lawyers gainfully employed should the Mayor go to Albany.

title: PANEL SAYS LOCAL PHONE BILLS COULD RISE $2 TO $12
description: A state panel investigating the potential effect of the recent antitrust settlement between the Federal Government and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has said that the agreement could increase costs for local service from $2 to $12 a month.

title: By Sports of The Times; Another Chapter for Reed
description: HIS entry into the Basketball Hall of Fame last week was a reminder of what Willis Reed represented when the Knicks symbolized how the game should be played. Among his teammates, he was much more than the center. He was ''the captain.'' And now he's the first of those Knicks to be bronzed in Springfield, Mass., where nearly a century ago Dr. James Naismith nailed a couple of old peach baskets to a gymnasium wall and tossed a soccer ball at them.

title: ISLANDERS IN 5-5 TIE AT HOME
description: Bryan Trottier's goal with 57 seconds to play tonight allowed the Islanders to salvage a 5-5 tie with the Quebec Nordiques. The deadlock, however, ended the Islanders' club record home winning streak at 14 games in Nassau Coliseum.

title:
ANTIQUES;
PAPER, AN AFFORDABLE COLLECTIBLE
description: BROADSIDES, song sheets, theater and circus posters, slave or freedman's papers, old almanacs, early newspapers, political and ''wanted by the sheriff'' notices, stagecoach and ferryboat timetables, are paper memorabilia of life in America before 1850 and are easily affordable antiques today.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: FOR Tarrytown employees of the Union Carbide Corporation in 1979, it was the familiar story of driving to work in their own cars, pooling them in some cases, but still paying skyrocketing gasoline prices.

title: The Week in Business; IN A GLUT OF OIL, PRICES ARE UNDER PRESSURE
description: Oil prices fell under further pressure from world oversupply. Iran cut its price by $2 a barrel, the third reduction in three weeks, to $30.20 a barrel. Mexico's state-owned oil company said it would trim prices by $1.50 to $2.50 a barrel. Britain was rumored to be preparing another cut in North Sea oil prices.

title: MUST WE DOUBT OUR STRENGTH?
description: LAST Dec. 10, Gov. Brendan T. Byrne signed legislation conferring substantial autonomy on the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and renaming it the ''University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.'' The development of this health-professions complex, including this most recent milestone, mirrors the New Jersey character.

title: Military Analysis
description: A battalion of the 82d Airborne Division will be included in the multinational peacekeeping force to be stationed in Sinai after Israel relinquishes control of the last section of the desert region to Egypt on April 25.

title: And Who'll Oppose Tax-Exempt Hate?
description: Switching tactics in the matter of tax exemptions for racist schools, the Reagan Administration has moved from the untenable to the deplorable. After maintaining for seven weeks that the Internal Revenue Service was compelled to bestow the exemptions until Congress made them illegal, it is finally willing to let a test of that proposition come before the Supreme Court. But doggedly, it insists on joining the schools, on the wrong side.

title: DIAMONDS
description: To the Business Editor: The implication in the article that DeBeers created a myth of diamond value using ''slick advertising'' is ridiculous! In the first century A.D., the Roman author Pliny the Elder wrote that the diamond was the most precious of all worldly goods, for a long time ''known to kings only, and to very few of them.'' Diamonds have had mysticalmagical-portentous qualities found in writings of the world's oldest cultures dating back to the Old Testament. And a visit to the Smithsonian, or the Tower of London would allow an illiterate to realize the value placed on diamonds by centuries of royalty.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat'' may not suffice as a full evening's entertainment for adults unaccompanied by children, but it's the ideal family matinee show. As staged by Tony Tanner and written by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice, this Biblical rock pageant flies by on non-stop comic-book gags and clever, tuneful songs.

title:
GARDENING;
GREEN THUMBS ARE ACQUIRED, NOT BORN
description: SHOULD someone take a vote to determine the most perfect avocation, gardening should win hands down. Through gardening one may beautify one's home both indoors and out, provide food of superior quality and flavor and obtain beneficial exercise. It is doubtful that any other leisure-time activity can make a comparable claim.

title: CITY BALLET ENDS ITS SEASON IN TRIUMPH
description: The last night of the New York City Ballet this season at the State Theater was one of the most triumphant in its history. It was hardly the only closing performance at which the audience refused to leave until George Balanchine, the company's artistic director and animating spirit, was called out to take a bow. But it was one of the few such occasions where the entire evening started out on an especially spine-tingling note and never went down.

title: RICHARD CAULEY TO WED MAUREEN E. HEFFERNAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. George C. Heffernan of Belle Mead, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Elizabeth Heffernan, to Richard Franklin Cauley of Princeton, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Cauley Jr., of Broomall, Pa. The wedding is planned in August.

title: NEWARK STARTING DRIVE ON TRUANTS
description: NEWARK POLICE and school officials here are beginning a major offensive to combat truancy and bring errant youngsters back to the classrooms. Starting this week, teams of attendance counselors, accompanied by police officers, will fan out through the city during school hours in search of students playing hookey.

title: LAST OF 'ORIGINAL SEVEN' QUITS ASTRONAUT CORPS
description: A whole generation has come of age since the first American astronauts stepped forward in 1959 as instant heroes, and now the last of the acclaimed Original Seven, Donald K. Slayton, is retiring from the corps.

title: MOTHERS' NEEDS ARE CENTER'S AIMS
description: "It was like the answer to a dream or a prayer. At last the needs of the mother were being fulfilled, not just those of the child, and I, too felt as if I had acomplished something personal."

title: Chinese Culture Over the Airwaves
description: I read with interest the article concerning Chinese culture on Long Island, particularly the part that dealt with the State University at Stony Brook (''Chinese on L.I.: The Years of Change''). We have a very large Chinese population here, both on campus and off, which forms a diverse and interesting segment of the community.

title: ON THE SCENE--AND OFTEN ON THE SPOT -- IN SALVADOR
description: El Playon is a lava field 15 miles outside the capital where death squads used to dump so many bodies that feasting vultures became too fat to fly. Among the many people who have witnessed this scene aghast is a member of the United States Embassy staff here.

title: CARIBBEANS WEIGH NEW OFFER AGAINST EXPERIENCE
description: MEXICO CITY AFTER months of delay and soul-searching, President Reagan last week unveiled his plan to promote economic development and fight Communism in the Caribbean basin. It was new, he said. Instead of the ''good neighbor'' policies of the past, Washington would be ''a true friend and brother'' to the region.

title: T.R. Comer Weds Nancy A. Gumley
description: Nancy Anne Gumley, senior project director in the marketing research department of Combe Inc., a manufacturer of proprietary drugs in White Plains, was married yesterday to Thomas Richard Comer, assistant financial manager at the General Foods Corporation in White Plains.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: NEGLECTED ART The Huastecs, an isolated group of Mexican Indians whose civilization has never received the attention paid the neighboring Mayans, are the subject of an exhibition that opens today at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island. The exhibition, "Neglected Art of the Huastecs, a Pre-Columbian Mexican Culture," includes an extensive collection of ceramic sculpture as well as pieces on loan from other museums. The museum will also conduct a symposium with some of North America's outstanding Meso-American scholars. The reception for the exhibition will be at 1 P.M. and the symposium at 2 P.M.

title: STUDY CONFIRMS TAX PLAN'S EFFECTS
description: Families with the highest incomes will gain the most and the poorest families will lose the most from the package of budget and tax cuts enacted last year, the Congressional Budget Office reported today.

title: ONE SMALLERGIVER
description: MINNEAPOLIS The Jefferson Company, which donates 5 percent of its pretax earnings to charities, operates a bus line and real estate operations in portions of five states: Minnesota, Iowa, Missouri, Arkansas and South Dakota.

title: Speaking Up For a Playwright
description: My first thought upon reading Alvin Klein's lacerating review of the program recently offered by the Contemporary Theater of Syosset (''Triple Bill Has Brevity but Not Wit'') was, ''Poor Mrs. Lieblich'' (whom I don't know).

title: OFFICER CHARGED WITH MURDER IN S.I. BAR SHOOTING
description: An off-duty police officer was charged with murder yesterday after he shot and killed a patron in a Staten Island bar while trying to break up a fight, the police said.

title: An Opening for 'New Federalism'
description: As the nation's governors left Washington last week after a threeday meeting devoted to President Reagan's proposal for transfers of Federal and state responsibilities for welfare, Medicaid and more than 40 other domestic programs, they still sounded wary, but for the most part satisfied. After all, they had lobbied for a greater role for the states for years, and now the Administration had agreed to pay some attention to their views.

title: Mailbox; Recalling Nashua's Derby
description: To the Sports Editor: As a racing writer who witnessed nearly all of Nashua's 31 starts, including most of his 22 victories, I share Leslie Combs's admiration for this remarkable thoroughbred (''Nashua: Class and Character,'' The New York Times, Feb. 21, 1982). I must, however, ask Mr. Combs to jog his memory when, in recalling the 1955 Derby, he writes, ''But he lost the Kentucky Derby, when Swaps sneaked up and beat him.''

title: U.S. PREPARING INDICTMENTS IN MURDER OF JUDGE IN 1979
description: After a 33-month investigation, the Justice Department is preparing to seek indictments against several persons in connection with the slaying of a Federal district judge in San Antonio, Tex., according to department officials.

title: No Headline
description: RANGERS SET BACK BRUINS BY 6-4

title: Elaine Moynihan To Wed May 15
description: Mr. and Mrs. William T. Moynihan of Storrs, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elaine Katherine Moynihan, to John Lisle Jr., son of the Rev. John Lisle of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Dorothy Sayre Lisle. A May 15 wedding is planned in Christ Epsicopal Church in Philadelphia.

title: A DISCONCERTING INTRODUCTION TO LIFE
description: For premature babies these days, intensive care units where they struggle through their early days of life outside the womb mean vastly increased prospects of survival. But some researchers now fear that these near-sterile environments, with their bright lights and the din of medical machinery, may be causing permanent damage to the tiny patients' vision, hearing and motor coordination. New evidence suggests that the so-called heroic measures for infant rescue need to be tempered with more mundane knowledge about soundproofing and environmental engineering, not to mention the age-old comforts of rocking and cooing.

title: FAMILIAR INDIA
description: ZEMINDAR By Valerie Fitzgerald. 799 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95. SHAITAN By Max Ehrlich. 318 pp. New York: Arbor House. $13.95. By PETER ANDREWS

title: AND OTHER AMUSING PEOPLE
description: HUMORISTS are used to being treated as second-class citizens of literature, members of what Frank Sullivan once called ''a cadet branch of beautiful letters.'' Even Woody Allen has said that ''when you do comedy, you're not sitting at the grownups' table.'' But if older humorists remain defensive, there is now a younger generation of comics who offer no apologies for their choice of profession.

title: THE GHOSTS OF GARDENS PAST
description: IT'S seed catalogue time again. I sit at the table near the window that overlooks my plot and open this year's Burpee's for the first time. Since I have no interest in growing flowers, I turn immediately to the section on vegetables. The pictures and descriptions of the luscious edibles I can grow (very easily, according to the catalogue) set my winter-weary heart racing.

title:
DINING OUT;
SUCCESS WHERE OTHERS HAVE FAILED
description: FOR years, Chinese restaurants have attempted to establish themselves in the Arcadian Shopping Center in Ossining, but Hunan Gourmet, the present occupant, appears to have triumphed where others have failed. Open for a year now, the restaurant is a solid addition to county dining places and especially to those in the inadequately served Ossining area. Hunan Gourmet offers some interesting Chinese cooking at moderate prices. To the kitchen's credit, dishes marked hot and spicy on the menu come to the table just that way.
