title: Juvenile Crime First of six articles on the han-dling of delinquents by the schools, the courts and the po-lice, and on some new ap-; proaches to the problems.
description: In school he was a failure - a chronic truant from the time he was in kindergarten, for years unable to read because no one noticed he needed glasses.

title: Visiting antiques row
description: By car If you are driving south on Interstate 95, take the Baltimore Beltway (695) to Interstate 70 west. After 38 miles, there will be a large sign for the New Market turnoff.

title: IN THE SHADOWS OF MADISON AVENUE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Andrew Feinberg writes on advertising in New York. By ANDREW FEINBERG

title: CABARET: DELLA REESE SINGS AT IBIS
description: Della Reese, who is singing at Ibis, 151 East 50th Street, through March 7, has a crisp, precisely enunciated, rhythmic way of delivering her songs that could be simply an exaggerated mannerism were it not colored by the humor and warmth of her personality and the involvement that is generated by her gospel background.

title: Gov. O'Neill Found Fit For Election Campaign
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, who has said that he would seek election this year to a full term if his health permitted, told an audience of Democrats tonight that his doctors had pronounced him fit to run.

title: A LIFE BETWEEN SLEEPING AND WAKING
description: WAKING By Eva Figes. 88 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $7.95.

title: COUNTY REUNION IN FLORIDA
description: Florida reunion.

title: Air Force Held To Its Bargain
description: Just as Air Force attorneys were set to throw the book at Lieut. Christopher Cooke, a Court of Military Appeals ordered them to close it instead.

title: Leslie B. Kersting To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Kersting of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Barbara Kersting, to Steven Edward Mulcahy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Mulcahy of Verona, N.J., and Manchester, Vt. An August wedding is planned in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: PAPERBACKS:NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE WHITE HOTEL, by D.M. Thomas. (Pocket, $3.50.) In Vienna, during the fall of 1919, a woman musician goes to Dr. Sigmund Freud complaining of recurring pains that have no organic cause. The presentation of her case through letters, poetry and extracts from a journal and Freud's analysis of her sexual fanstasies are followed by a narrative account of her life. The Book Review's editors named this novel one of the best books of 1981, observing that ''what it sets out to perform is nothing less than the diagnosis of our epoch through the experience of an individual. It comes close to accomplishing that goal.''

title: The Politics of Missing Soldiers
description: Time does not heal all wounds. Seven years after the last American troops left Vietnam, Washington and Hanoi continue their war of words over the whereabouts of American soldiers killed or captured in the fighting.

title: Children's Books
description: THE ORIGINAL COLORED HOUSE OF DAVID By Martin Quigley. 245 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $8.95. (Ages 12 and Up) By IRA BERKOW

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Rick Mahler and Bob Walk, pitchers.

title: The True Believer, Still
description: Every day, it seems, the President loses another ally in his budget battle with Congress. He alone remains a true believer, unshakable in his faith that a healthy recovery can occur and be sustained for years despite huge and unyielding Federal deficits.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Wilson College
description: Almost three years ago, Wilson College in Chambersburg, Pa., came back from the brink of extinction. The trustees of the liberal arts school for women had planned to close it, citing a depleted endowment and a shrinking enrollment.

title: ARTS PROGRAM PROVIDES ENVIRONMENT FOR GIFTED
description: For more than 45 years the New York City school system has provided a special environment in which gifted youngsters could pursue their talents in art, drama, music and dance.

title: DENT NOT WORRYING ABOUT STARTING JOB
description: Times have changed for Bucky Dent, the Yankees' hero of the 1978 World Series. The shortstop batted .417 with seven runs batted in and 10 hits in six games in that Series. But in last year's World Series, he was injured, and did not play at all. And now the question he is asked most is this:

title: DANCE: NEW SOLO BY BILLY SIEGENFELD
description: Judging from the amiable and unpretentious program that Billy Siegenfeld and Dancers presented Thursday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, Mr. Siegenfeld must thoroughly enjoy putting dances together.

title: A PLAN TO SAVE THE SAVINGS BANKS
description: WASHINGTON F OR 20 years, Representative Fernand J. St. Germain worked steadily to cultivate his political garden but rarely, despite growing seniority, did he find himself a place in the sun.

title: Mailbox; Holzman Should Make His Exit
description: To the Sports Editor: George Vecsey's column on the decline of the Knicks (''It's Not Just the Egg Roll, Sonny,'' The New York Times, Feb. 21, 1982) refers to a journalist - ''who goes back 20 years with Holzman'' - asking Red whether he plans to give up coaching. Although Holzman denied having such intentions, as ''his bleary eyes tightened competitively,'' it seems clear to this observer, who goes back more than 30 years with Holzman, that Red's time in the sport is ended.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: THE POLLS?  WHO RELIES ON THE POLLS?
description: THE statement was about as direct as such statements can be: ''I will not rely on either coupons or polls,'' Mayor Koch said as he pondered the most trumpeted question of New York State's political season. That was a few weeks before he decided to run for governor, and it was similar to his statements over the years whenever the subject of polls has come up. Mr. Koch maintains he is willing to take ''unpopular positions'' irrespective of public opinion.

title:
ART;
NEUBERGER SHOWS OFF PERMANENT WORKS
description: THE Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase now is a feast for the eye. No less than three special exhibitions are there, and all are excellent. One contains wonderful prints, some of which are rarely seen, and another contains one of the most breathtaking pieces of modern sculpture this viewer has encountered in years.

title: WATERFRONT IS A MAGNET IN QUEENS
description: The quiet residential community of Bayside, Queens, long a center of one-family homes, is experiencing a surge in new housing construction. During the next year more than 2,000 new units will be offered for sale, mainly in condominium projects now in various stages of development.

title: LA MERE BLANC: A THREE-STAR REST STOP
description: FRANK J. PRIAL, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times, recently completed two and a half years as a correspondent in the Paris bureau.. By FRANK.J.PRIAL

title: J.B. Lister Weds Mildred F. Boyd
description: Mildred Felten Boyd of Old Westbury, L.I., widow of C.M. Dennis Boyd, was married yesterday to John Beamish Lister of Huntington, L.I., manager of the organization and planning division of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Bruce Rodgers at St. John's Episcopal Church of Lattingtown in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The situation in which the country and nation find themselves bears all the markings of a true moral, social and economic catastrophe.'' - The Roman Catholic bishops of Poland. (1:6.)

title:
Other Business;
HOW THE REAGANS INSPIRE BUSINESS
description: It happened to the Kennedys, the Johnsons, the Nixons, the Fords and the Carters. Now, taking off on the Reagans has become a promising business for publishers and novelty makers.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: SO FAR, NJ Transit has nothing but praise for the 271 new Grumman buses that arrived last fall. The state agency, which placed its order just about the same time that troubles began plaguing similar buses in New York City, demanded a redesigned chassis and much tougher testing.

title: RHONDA MUIR IS MARRIED
description: Ronda Muir, a lawyer with the New York law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, was married yesterday to Richard Joy Sandler, a partner in the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell.

title: Italians Sight Nuclear Sub
description: The Italian Defense Ministry said today that an unidentified nuclear submarine not belonging to NATO forces had been spotted Wednesday by an Italian Navy submarine in the southeastern Gulf of Taranto. Taranto is Italy's most important military port and is often used by vessels of the Western alliance.

title: Readjustments In the Mideast
description: Although the Reagan Administration keeps insisting that its strong support for Israel is unchanged, it did some tinkering last week with its policy toward the Arabs that made Israel and its supporters nervous again.

title: JUDGES REVISE 6 TEXAS CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS
description: A panel of Federal judges today approved 21 of 27 Congressional Districts as redrawn by the Texas Legislature, while ordering changes in four districts in the Dallas area and two in south Texas.

title: A Melange Of Spices
description: The main ingredient The quality of the meat is the thing to be careful about, says the Safeer's owner, Chenni Singh Vohra. Kenya has traditionally had excellent quality lamb and mutton, a legacy of the British colonialists.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Rising Star ''I have become more recognized on the street and in the profession. I have been offered more parts. But the kids at home still treat me as one of the guys and they are very supportive as well, which I am pleased about,'' said Doug McKeon.

title: THEATER: 'PHILISTINES,' GORKY'S FIRST PLAY
description: Maxim Gorky, already a successful author, began writing plays at the suggestion of Anton Chekhov. In 1902, two of his plays were produced. One, ''The Lower Depths,'' went on to become a world classic. The other - actually his first - ''Philistines,'' alternately known as ''The Petty Bourgeois,'' has been largely forgotten.

title: UNCLE SAM SQUEALS
description: The Story: The Reagan Administration has issued a new rule stating that if persons under 18 obtain birth-control devices the Federal Government must send a note home to their parents.

title: CAMPAIGN ON ARMS FREEZE IS ONE-SIDED
description: HERE in Connecticut, a revolutionary event of profound importance could be taking place. Eschewing domestic politics as their prime concern, residents throughout the state have placed the nuclear arms race at the top of their community agendas, and are organizing toward ending the dangerous escalation in nuclear weaponry.

title: WHERE FOOD TO GO IS GOURMET
description: FIVE years ago, the concept of takeout foods was limited in Connecticut to fairly standard fare. But within the last two or three years the number of establishments offering gourmet takeout cuisine has grown in the state.

title: STATE REACHES TENTATIVE PACT WITH CIVIL SERVICE EMPLOYEES
description: Negotiators for New York State and the Civil Service Employees Association reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a new contract that would provide raises of at least 32 percent over a three-year period.

title: JUST WHAT IS 'REASONABLE' IN SEARCHES AND SEIZURES?
description: IT was a victory for the defense. A Federal appeals panel last week upheld a lower court ruling that in the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr., accused of trying to kill President Reagan last year, prosecutors may not use evidence obtained through what the courts considered violations of Mr. Hinckley's constitutional rights. It was also a victory for the so-called exclusionary rule - a doctrine used by the United States Supreme Court to enforce Fourth Amendment strictures against ''unreasonable searches and seizures.''

title: ADVOCATES OF YOUTHS WEIGH BUDGET CUTS
description: MORE than 30 agencies serving children and youths in Westchester have joined together in an effort to monitor budget reductions and inform the public about the effect of cutbacks on social services for the young. The Westchester Committee of the statewide Emergency Campaign for Children and Youths, established last fall to monitor the effect of reductions in the Federal budget, is now turning its attention to the process of budget decisions at the county and state level.

title: STATE RACE IS MARKED BY BATTLES IN 2 PARTIES
description: HARTFORD THE 1982 race for Governor of Connecticut, overshadowed in recent months by the United States Senate campaign, has moved to the forefront. The Democrats were confronted with a contest for the nomination when Ernest N. Abate, the Speaker of the State House of Representatives, announced his candidacy last week with a sharp attack on the party's incumbent, Governor O'Neill.

title: BLOUSTEIN CAUTIONS ON A LOSS OF PROGRESS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE president of Rutgers University has warned that the cuts in student financial aid proposed by President Reagan would mean the loss of ''20 to 30 years of progress in higher education.''

title: CHILD OF TWO CULTURES
description: HUNGER OF MEMORY The Education of Richard Rodriguez. By Richard Rodriguez. 195 pp. Boston, Mass.: David R. Godine. $13.95.

title: Surgeon General Lengthens List of Tobacco Dangers
description: If any doubts remained about the harmfulness of smoking, the Surgeon General's report last week sought forcefully to dispel them. Calling it ''the chief preventable cause of death in our society,'' Dr. C.Everett Koop said cigarette smoking was not only a ''major cause'' of cancers of the lung, larynx and esophagus, but also a ''contributory factor'' to cancers of the bladder, kidney and pancreas.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN HE found himself on vacation in February, alone in the house. It was a good time, he thought, to explore the 30 channels he receives on his television set from Long Island Cablevision.

title: OFF THE BEATEN PATH IN FRANCE
description: JOSEPH L. SAX, a professor of law at the University of Michigan, is the author of ''Mountains Without Handrails: Reflections on the National Parks.'' By JOSEPH L.SAX

title: CURRYING FAVOR IN KENYA
description: PRANAY B. GUPTE is The Times correspondent in Nairobi. By PRANAY B.GUPTE

title: No Headline
description: LENDL AND GERULAITIS IN FINAL

title: Cross-Country Ski Race To Wassberg of Sweden
description: Thomas Wassberg of Sweden won the 50-kilometer cross-country race at the world Nordic ski championships today. Bill Koch of the United States had bronchitis and did not start.

title: MINIATURE FIDDLES: A MARKET RARITY
description: Dancing masters' fiddles are small enough to fit into a jacket pocket and lightweight enough to be carried about that way. They were to 18th-century music lovers what casette-players are for today's enthusiasts of popular music. The difference is that these tiny fiddles were much more carefully crafted and far more interesting to look upon than today's Lilliputian music machines. And, more often than not, they were enjoyed primarily by aristocrats.

title: Second Thoughts On Watt's Plan
description: It seemed almost too good to be true, that announcement last week by Interior Secretary James G. Watt that he wanted to keep miners and drillers out of the Federal Government's wilderness areas. Sure enough, his critics were saying before long, it was.

title: EVENTUALLY, MOST BALLOONS DEFLATE
description: PricesA question that inevitably arises in formulating strategies for financial management in the 1980's is inflation. We are all painfully aware of the prolonged, intense, and some say endemic inflation that has plagued the world economy in recent years.

title: WORKING WONDERS IN WOOL
description: R.V. DENENBERG is a writer who lives in the Hudson Valley. By R.V.DENENBERG

title: CABARET: 'THE STREET SINGER' RETURNS
description: Even to those whose memories can take them back 50 years, the only vestige of Arthur Tracy that they still retain may be ''Marta,'' the broad, open, precisely enunciated song he used as the theme for his radio broadcasts as ''The Street Singer'' in the early 1930's. Little had been heard of Mr. Tracy since then until, in the current movie ''Pennies From Heaven,'' his record of the title song was used as part of a score built on recordings from the 30's.

title: Imaginative Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Mailbox; John Denny Made A Wise Decision
description: To the Sports Editor: One must admire John Denny, a man with the ability to see through an artificial situation. Denny, a 10-6 pitcher with Cleveland last year, chose to stay with his present Indians despite a more lucrative offer from the New York Yankees.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Jazz musicians and some very fine tappers will get together this afternoon at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College for ''1,000 Years of Jazz and Tap,'' a re-creation of the golden age of the roaring 20's. The program title refers to the combined ages of such tap artists as Lon Chaney, Ralph Brown, George Hillman and Jimmy Slyde and the musicians to whose jazz they'll dance.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE LOVING WALLS OF GRANDMA'S CASTLE
description: ONE of my favorite places was my grandparents' apartment in a once all-Italian immigrant neighborhood, Park Hill in Yonkers. Spending the day with Grandma in her castle is a cherished memory.

title: THE PORK CHOP: PLAIN AND (DELICIOUSLY) SIMPLE
description: PORK is an inexpensive meat, mellow and rich without being too heavy. Its subtle flavor goes well with rosemary, caraway seeds, fennel, sage, juniper barries, thyme and even truffles. Vegetables that suit it are sweet and sour red cabbage, little carrots or turnips, leeks, or sauteed green cabbage. The fat is absorbed by starchy vegetables such as potatoes, beans, lentils and dried peas.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Assailed For Salvador Decision
description: A British opposition spokesman on foreign affairs called on the Thatcher Government today to reverse its decision last week to send two observers to the March 28 elections in El Salvador.

title: WHEN JUSTICE AND POLITICS MEET AND MIX
description: To the Editor:

title: Corona's Retrial
description: Fifteen years have passed since Juan Corona was convicted of committing one of the worst mass murders in United States history: 25 farm laborers hacked to death and buried face up on the Sullivan Ranch near Yuba City, Calif. Last week proceedingsbegan to re-try Mr. Corona for those same murders. In 1978 an appeals court overturned his original conviction of 25 consecutive life sentences, ruling that the defense by Mr. Corona's attorney had been inadequate.

title: BEND A ROAD TO SAVE A HOUSE?
description: WHEN Elijah Terry took a job as the first schoolteacher in the hamlet of Farmingville in 1768, he built a modest wood-frame house for his family. The house still stands at 1199 Farm to Market Road, but local historians fear that its historical significance is threatened by a Suffolk County project to widen the road.

title: Anti-Iran Rallies in Germany
description: Demonstrations against repression in Iran were held today in Bonn and West Berlin. About 1,000 people, mostly Iranians, demonstrated in Bonn and about 400 protested in West Berlin.

title: ART GROUP FEATURING SEVEN COMPOSERS
description: ''ALL life is an experiment,'' Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote. ''The more experiments you make, the better.'' That might express the credo of Access, a group for the arts in the county, and the Westlake Gallery in White Plains, which is showcasing the work of seven avantgarde composers at a free concert this afternoon at 4 o'clock.

title: GETTING THE MESSAGE
description: Messages people wrote you used to come in three forms. There was the post card. It showed a bathing beauty or a Ferris wheel on one side and on the other it said, ''Having a swell time see you soon.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1982
description: International Poland's Catholic hierarchy called for and end to martial law, freedom for its detainees and a national covenant in which the Solidarity union would participate. Their appeal was issued after a two-day meeting in Warsaw of all the country's bishops in the strongest statement by the church since martial law was declared Dec. 13. The statement also indicated disagreement with the economic sanctions imposed by the United States and Britain. (Page 1, Column 6.) The U.S. reaffirmed its ties to Peking on the 10th anniversary of the Shanghai Communique that opened the way to formal relations between the two nations. A statement said that despite unresolved problems with China over the Taiwan issue, the United States believed that ''shared global and regional interests'' with Peking far outweighed any of the differences. The State Department said that President Reagan had sent a personal letter to Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang commemorating the anniversary, but that a similar message had not yet been received from the Chinese. (1:5-6.)

title: Diamonds
description: To the Business Editor: ''Selling a Diamond Could Take Forever'' (Feb. 14) was welcome confirmation of a viewpoint I've been expressing since I first started making and marketing my Wellington counterfeit diamonds.

title: LUCAS 3-POINT PLAY TOPS BLAZERS, 107-105
description: A spinning layup by Maurice Lucas with 28 seconds remaining enabled the Knicks to defeat the Portland Trail Blazers, 107-105, in a game that ended in confusion at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Ugandan Rebels Take on the Army
description: When Tanzania recently withdrew the last of its occupation troops from Uganda, President Milton Obote was sorry to see them go. The reason why was apparent last week: 300 anti-Government guerrillas armed with assault rifles, mortars and rocket-propelled grenades reportedly attacked the main army barracks in Kampala.

title: 100 YEARS FROM ANYWHERE
description: MARY Z. GRAY is a writer who lives in Washington. By MARY Z.GRAY

title: Pedroza to Defend Title
description: Rafael Pedroza of Panama, the World Boxing Association junior bantamweight champion, will defend his title against Jiro Watanabe of Japan on April 8. The 15-round fight, which will be held in Osaka, will be Pedroza's first title defense.

title: No Headline
description: A FISTFUL OF FIG NEWTONS By Jean Shepherd. Illustrated. 265 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95.

title: The Week in Business; SUCCESS ON INFLATION
description: An aide at the White House called it ''one of the forgotten stories of our economy.''

title: Misreading The Elements
description: The recriminations that tend to follow nuclear plant accidents usually involve pinpointing blame for some highly technical error, but that was not quite the case in one view of the Jan. 25 mishap at the Robert E. Ginna nuclear plant. The most serious lapse there, a state official said last week, was that plant operators didn't know which way the wind was blowing.

title: Investing; THE SMALL INVESTOR AS VENTURE CAPITALIST
description: M UCH of the the high-risk but high-potential business of investing in new ventures is, for the most part, closed to all but institutions and wealthy individuals who can put up the $500,000 or more to participate in private placements and private venture funds. The latter, all partnerships, have proven lucrative over the long haul, realizing an average compounded growth rate of 20 to 25 percent a year for a 10-year period. Buying into them is costly because the funds are restricted to a maximum of 35 investors to avoid having to report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: No Headline
description: MINNESOTA TOPS IOWA IN THIRD OVERTIME

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: TV Mocks Itself ''We have equal parts in everything we do. When we had our little theater, we would take turns cleaning the bathroom.

title: NOTEBOOK: SELECTION OF THE MARIN JURORS
description: THE administrator for a major division of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was clearly upset. He was being screened as a potential juror in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder case and was insisting, as many others would, that he ''couldn't take six to eight weeks off.''

title: Round-World Fleet Starts Final Leg
description: A fleet of 24 yachts today crossed the starting line off the granite promontory known as Cape Corrientes to begin the last leg of the 27,000-mile Whitbread Round the World Race.

title: AUSTRALIA
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FADING FEAST A Compendium of Disappearing American Regional Foods. By Raymond Sokolov. Illustrated. 276 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title:
FOOD;
HIS BAKERY IS HIS STUDIO - FOR SCULPTURING MARZIPAN
description: BABYLON TOMORROW is the start of National Bakers Week, and to celebrate, Werner Wilhelm, owner of Wilhelm's Bakery, will have assorted baked goods on sale every day - Hungarian strudel, Polish coffeecake or an American version of charlotte russe. But Mr. Wilhelm never marks down his colorful marzipan figures.

title: BEING LEFT: OUT IN THE COLD
description: ''DAD, do you know the etymology of the word 'sinister'?'' my cause-conscious daughter asked. Truthfully, I didn't really know the meaning of ''etymology,'' much less the etymology of the word sinister. So I stalled. Would she repeat the question.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Tram vs. Ferry
description: On two occasions in December 1980, the cable that pulled the Roosevelt Island tramway across the East River to Manhattan fell to the ground, halting service for four months while repairs were made.

title: MAKING MUSIC CLOSE TO HOME HAS ITS PROBLEMS
description: music concerts by community orchestras, of which there are many outstanding ones in Bergen County, need not fear that they will be eclipsed by punk rock, hard rock or any other kind of rock.

title: PUBLIC TV WITHOUT GOVERNMENT FUNDING
EFFICIENT SPEAKERS: BIG SOUND FOR SMALL BUDGETS
description: The perennial quest for better sound for less money has spawned a breed of notably efficient loudspeakers. As most audiophiles know, to say that a speaker is efficient has nothing to do with the way it sounds. In fact, some of the best-sounding speakers used to be notoriously inefficient. This merely means that they need lots of power to reach high volume levels. Conversely, a high-efficiency speaker produces ample volume with far fewer watts. In consequence, such speakers let you use lower-powered and less expensive amplifiers and receivers without skimping on performance.

title: KEAN, FACING BUDGET PROBLEM, MAY APPOINT A 'STOCKMAN'
description: TRENTON IN AN effort to get a handle on the growing problem of trying to find some way to balance his first state budget, Governor Kean is preparing to create an Office of Management and Budget similar to the one run for President Reagan by David T. Stockman.

title: 'SAND MOVES, AND WISE MEN LET IT'
description: WE usually go to the beach in the late afternoon, around 3 or 3:30, when the sun is already low in the sky and the long slanting light gives everything a pale yellowish cast. There are three of us - myself, my wife and our half-breed female golden retriever, Fred.

title: BUSH PRIZES HIS BEHIND-THE-SCENES INFLUENCE
description: After the Reagan Administration decided last month to award tax exemptions to schools that practice racial discrimination, a group of White House officials who felt the decision had been a mistake reached out for help to a key official: Vice President Bush.

title: SPEAKING UP FOR A PLAYWRIGHT
description: While nursing the bloody nose delivered to me with such force by Alvin Klein, I wondered what roused his ire the most: my trying and failing? Or having the chutzpah to reach above my ''station?''

title:
GARDENING;
GREEN THUMBS ARE ACQUIRED, NOT BORN
description: SHOULD someone take a vote to determine the most perfect avocation, gardening should win hands down. Through gardening one may beautify one's home both indoors and out, provide food of superior quality and flavor and obtain beneficial exercise. It is doubtful that any other leisure-time activity can make a comparable claim.

title: Warmer Is Not Always Safer
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission stepped firmly last week where other Federal agencies have yet to tread - into the regulation of formaldehyde and formaldehyde-based products. Voting 4-to-1, commission members banned the sale of urea formaldehyde foam, once a popular home insulation.

title: SOME IN MIDTOWN STILL LACK WATER
description: Residents and businesses scattered through midtown Manhattan were without water yesterday and West Side subway service was disrupted into the morning as work crews began repairing a major water main that burst Friday night south of Times Square.

title:
DINING OUT;
SEAFOOD DOWN BY THE BEAUTIFUL SEA
description: CUT PRICE lobster dinners or ''all you can eat'' seafood buffets are not the mark of a good seafood restaurant. It is the quality and freshness of the seafood, plus the care taken in preparing it. Unfortunately, too many restaurants settle for quantity and low prices, rather than quality, to attract customers,

title: 'Jingle Bells'
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOWERLESS AND THIRSTY, VICTIMS OF BREAK ARE COPING
description: The morning after the water went out, Robert Shapiro found himself rushing two six packs of Perrier water to the apartment building at 137 East 38th Street, where he had spent the night with a friend. ''I have to wash my hair for brunch,'' he explained.

title: HEARNS WINS IN FIRST
description: Thomas Hearns stunned Marcos Geraldo with two right hands and followed with a left to score a first-round knockout in their scheduled 10-round middleweight bout today.

title: LECTURES ON FAITHS
description: Better understanding of five major religions is the theme that will be developed in a lecture series called ''Faiths People Live By,'' to be presented at 8 P.M. every Wednesday in March at St. John's Church, 1986 Post Road, Darien.

title: DAY TRIP INTO MEXICO'S PAST
description: A "lost city" and the dazzle of gold in an almost overwhelmingly decorated church as well as the wealth of arts and crafts in its museum can all be part of a one-day excursion from Mexico City to the ruins at Tula and to the rich glimpses of the heritage of the Toltec and colonial periods of Mexican history. And the itinerary includes a felicitious spot to break for lunch and browsing in a local market, amenities that cannot always be guaranteed in the Mexican countryside.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Susan Rotholz Performs New Beaser Flute Work
description: Rarely is the highlight of a debut program a new work, but it happened Tuesday evening in Carnegie Recital Hall, when Susan Rotholz, flutist, offered the world premiere of Variations by Robert Beaser, a young New York composer who, like Miss Rotholz, did graduate work at Yale. In the piece, which the flutist commissioned through a grant from Meet the Composer and seemed determined to play brilliantly, Mr. Beaser's inventiveness and mastery of materials were immediately apparent, as was his possession of a lyrical gift comparable, in some ways, to that of the late Samuel Barber.

title: Prospects
description: Revising Away Recovery

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Change for Curtin In ''Divorce Wars: A Love Story,'' Jane Curtin, a comedienne bestknown for her improvisational stage work and her television role as the sarcastic reporter on the original ''Saturday Night Live,'' plays the part of the neglected wife of a successful divorce lawyer, portrayed by Tom Selleck. Mr. Selleck is making his first television appearance outside of ''Magnum, P.I.,'' where he plays the dashing private investigator. This new TV film will be broadcast Monday on ABC at 9 P.M.

title: No Headline
description: NO. 1 VIRGINIA BOWS TO MARYLAND, 47-46

title: WHETTING THE APPETITE
description: It amuses us that so many people have an ample supply of dry vermouth in their wine and spirits cabinet while they suffer a shortage of dry white wine.

title: NATO COSTS AND STRATEGY: THE AMERICAN VIEW
description: To the Editor:

title: 927,000 SOUGHT FOR DRAFT ROLLS
description: More than 900,000 young men have still not registered for a possible military draft, according to the Selective Service.

title: School Days
description: After two years of favorable publicity for her success in educating neighborhoold children who were considered ''unteachable'' Marva Collins, director of the Westside Preparatory School in Chicago, was challenged last week by reports charging that students from the school scored poorly on achievement tests, contrary to her claims that they excelled. Mrs. Collins defended both her record and her method, saying that she was an effective teacher, not a ''miracle worker.''

title: FATALISM AND FATALITIES IN THE APPALACHIAN MINES
description: Because coal mining is the riskiest of heavy industrial jobs, it has nutured a pervasive fatalism. Death in the pits is part of the monotonous folk lore of mining coal. To this day, the demonstrable fact that mine safety is both variable and controllable is sometimes under appreciated, as much by coal miners as by mine owners.

title: Drug Use Down - Except Uppers
description: What appeared as a dip in illicit drug use among high school students in 1980 became a downward slide in 1981, according to a University of Michigan survey released last week.

title: JAZZ HAS COME A LONG WAY, BABY
description: WAYNE JAZZ, which sprang from the creative genius of musicians who would be considered largely untutored by today's standards, is making it big in academe these days.

title: THE OPERA'S FIRST SUPERSTAR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Tim Page is classical/new music editor for The Soho News and host of an afternoon music program on WNYC-FM. By TIM PAGE

title: NELLIE BLY SHOW SET TO TRAVEL
description: IN her lifetime (1867-1922), Nellie Bly was best known as the 22-year-old reporter sent by the publisher Joseph Pulitzer to break Phileas Fogg's record by going around the world in less than 80 days.

title: ETCHING A NEW LABEL'S IMAGE
description: Bruce Lundvall was not your average record company president when he was at the helm of CBS records during the middle and late 70's. These days, record company presidents tend to come from legal or accounting backgrounds, but Mr. Lundvall was a jazz lover.

title: SUNSET PARK GAINS IN TIGHT MARKET
description: On a clear day, Leonard Glynn can see all the way across Upper New York Bay to Bayonne, N.J., from the doorstep of his brownstone in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn.

title: IN PURSUIT OF A DREAM
description: The following letter was sent to the New Jersey Weekly by William H. Rundle, 47 years old, who has been in institutions since he was 5 and in the Essex County Hospital for 15 years. Despite severe physical handicaps, he has helped publish a patients' newsletter.

title:
HIKERS' ASSET;
OUTDOORS
description: THE time is not too far off when one will be able to travel throughout the woods of the Northeast without snowshoes or skis. And a new pleasure awaiting those who might be planning to hike the Appalachian Trail in New York State will be using the nearly nine miles of relocated trail in Dutchess County, a project that was completed last fall by the New York/ New Jersey Trail Conference and a host of volunteers.

title: COURT RULING SEEN AS BENEFIT FOR DEAF
description: VALHALLA AUNITED STATES Supreme Court decision last week to permit computerassisted technology into the courtroom for a deaf lawyer who is defending a Westchester school girl's right to have a classroom interpreter ''is a breakthrough for the right of deaf people to be heard,'' according to Janet Acevedo, who trains interpreters at Westchester Community College.

title: A BUSY RADIO SHOW LINKS SINGLES
description: A professor, a nurse, an engineer, a researcher of governmental social programs, a professional musician who is a fulltime cabbie -these are just a sampling of the listeners who call ''Hotline,'' Boston's most popular new call-in show.

title: GEORGETOWN TROUNCES UCONN
description: Pat Ewing scored 22 points to lead Georgetown from a 9-point first-half deficit as the Hoyas beat Connecticut, 60-42, in a Big East game today.

title: CAPTURING THE ESSENCE OF AN AMERICAN POET
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leslie Garisto is a freelance writer with a special interest in television. By LESLIE GARISTO

title: WHAT RUSSIANS READ AND DON'T READ
description: THE gray-haired hitchhiker on the road to Orel took a long draft of white wine from a bottle in his briefcase, settled back and introduced himself. He was a piano tuner; his father had been a coachman; his greatest joys in life were fine pianos, which he tried to buy and restore, and books. ''Books, this is the most criminal deficit,'' he declared with animation. ''Meat - hell, all I need is a bone in the soup, and my wife grows our cucumbers and tomatoes. But how can they deny us books?''

title: CARLSBERG, WHICH IS MOVING INTO CHINA
description: COPENHAGEN D ANES drink a lot of beer - about 32 gallons a year per capita. The Chinese drink very little beer -less than a gallon a year. So the Danish company that owns the Carlsberg and Tuborg labels did some simple arithmetic. It came to an intoxicating conclusion, and in January, the company wrote a contract that could prove the coup of the decade in the beer business.

title: Brooklyn Holdup Victim Shot
description: A man was shot in the chest and seriously wounded by one of five youths who tried to rob him in a Brooklyn housing complex early yesterday, the police said. The victim, who was not immediately identified, was shot about 1 A.M. when the five youths stopped him at 727 Lincoln Avenue in the Linden Plaza complex and demanded his money, the police said. As the man reached into his pocket for his wallet, one of the youths fired a shot from a small-caliber weapon, striking him in the chest.

title: THE NUCLEAR DEBATE GOES ON
description: It used to be that the pronuclear forces would grossly underestimate cost and risk. Nowadays, however, the antinuclear side is succeeding in surpassing its opponents in the field of arrant disregard of the most basic facts. Classical examples of this are two anti-Shoreham-plant letters by Miriam Goodman and Marge Harrison on the Opinion Page on Jan. 17.

title: L.I. 'ANGEL' RETURNS FOR SHAW COMEDY
description: SOME actresses evoke an instant yet distant sense of deja vu. They're recognizable but not identifiable. Passers-by perceive them in terms of a role association and react accordingly.

title: Polish Church Denounces Martial Law
description: The chasm grew wider last week between the institutions that govern in the name of the Polish people and the institution that most commands Polish loyalty and respect.

title: MUST A FITTER PARENT BE A SHE
description: To the Editor:

title: GAYLE V. SIDER TO BE BRIDE OF DAVID J. FREMED IN FALL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome P. Sider of North Woodmere, L.I., and Smallwood, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gayle Victoria Sider, to David Jay Fremed, son of Dr. and Mrs. Monroe Fremed of Wantagh, L.I.

title: The Mail
description: To the Business Editor: Postmaster William F. Bolger's reply ''The Postman'' (Jan. 31) to Stuart N. Brotman's article ''Reagan Should Curb Big Mail, Too'' (Jan. 10) claims the Post Office is still in business and increasing volume. That is reminiscent of Chrysler optimism not many years ago.

title: ART WITH A WARTIME MESSAGE
description: DURING World War II, when nearly everyone joined in the war effort, several of the most influential avant-garde artists were creating propaganda posters for the Allies.

title:
Economic Affairs;
THE BUDGET PROCESS IS TIED IN KNOTS
description: Rudolph G. Penner, Resident Scholar at the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research in Washington, is one of foureconomists who write regularly for the Sunday Business section.

title: RETURN TO CANNERY ROW
description: HERBERT GOLD, who lives in San Francisco, has written a dozen novels; the most recent, ''Family,'' has just been published by Arbor House. By HERBERT GOLD

title: M.N. PAPANICOLAOU FIANCE OF MARGARET V. WHITAKER
description: The Right Rev. O'Kelley Whitaker, Bishop Coadjutor of Central New York, and Mrs. Whitaker of Syracuse, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Victoria, to Michael Nicholas Papanicolaou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Michael Papanicolaou of Lighthouse Point, Fla.

title: RETIRING IN FLATBUSH
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Business; A CHICKEN IN EVERY WOK
description: According to Leslie Watt, president of the Watt Publishing Company in Mount Morris, Ill., the great frontier for special interest magazines is China. So the company has made a foray into the Far East with a magazine that serves a $10 billion-a-year market in this country and an expanding market abroad. The market is poultry, and the magazine is Poultry International.

title: CIVIL MARRIAGES IN GREECE ARE ONE STEP CLOSER
description: In one of its boldest moves to modernize Greece's social legislation, the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou introduced a bill in Parliament last week that would allow civil marriage and end the prosecution of adultery as an offense punishable with imprisonment.

title: By Theodore W. Libbey
description: Music: Debuts in Review Richard Kennedy Gives Program of Tenor Songs

title: OF PIANO TONE AND UMBRELLA TIPS
description: Music occupies an embattled position somewhere between science and mysticism and is always having to defend itself against being overrun from one side or the other. Take the apparently simple concept of a pianist's tone. Scientists contend that there is no measurable difference between a tone produced by human hand and one produced by a mechanical striker - or, in the classic formulation of the argument, by an umbrella tip. Sir James Jeans first propounded this heresy more than 50 years ago and its reverberations have never quite died away. He concluded that the tone of a single piano note depends on nothing more than gradations of weight, ignoring for purposes of his thesis the horizontal relation of one note to the next in melodic lines or to vertically related notes in chordal music.

title: CITY OPERA: 'TRAVIATA' IS OPENER
description: The New York City Opera opened its regular spring season Friday evening with Verdi's ''La Traviata.'' The production is unfailingly pleasant to look at; and indeed if there was one highlight to single out at Friday evening's performance, it was Zack Brown's scenery. Act II's soft, spacious sense of outdoors, Act III's violent reds, and the wispy white of the final scene - all were not only attractive in themselves; they did more to underscore ''La Traviata'''s dramatic undercurrents than most of the acting on stage.

title: AMY WERNER TO BE BRIDE
description: The engagement of Amy Werner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Werner of Syosset, L.I., to Dr. Jeffrey M. Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Berman of Brooklyn, has been announced by Miss Werner's parents. A spring wedding is planned. Miss Werner is a lawyer in Beverly Hills, Calif. Dr. Berman is a senior resident in internal medicine at the New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital.

title: LET JAPANESE HELP RURAL JAVA
description: Fifteen years ago, a village in Java all too often meant a community of ill-fed, raggedly clothed peasants who lived in windowless bamboo huts and slept on straw mats. Gnawing hunger in the dry season was an annual curse. Today, amid new irrigation canals and year-round, scientifically bred rice crops, a village is more likely to mean bright sarongs, brick cottages with tile roofs and glass-paned windows, iron beds with mosquito nets, and the occasional motorcycle or television set. To a new generation zooming down highway with transistors blaring, it all feels like progress.

title: CASINOS IN JERSEY LOOK TO THE SKIES
description: Resorts International has begun providing highstakes gamblers free daily flights from La Guardia Airport in its new $5 million, 48-passenger plane.

title: RUTGERS ENDS WEST VIRGINIA STREAK AT 23 MOUNTAINEERS UPSET, 74-64
description: West Virginia's 23-game winning streak, the longest in major college basketball this season, ended at the Rutgers Athletic Center today. The Mountaineers, making only 35.7 of their shots from the field, were upset, 74-64, by Rutgers, which made 50 percent of its shots.

title: GETTING REVENGE ON IMITATIONS
description: IMITATION, they say, is flattering. It is also a way to make off with someone else's customers. As the vise of recession and inflation squeezes companies' profits, so does the temptation to try to make your new product look like the other fellow's best seller. From books to drugs to toys, the practice is proliferating.

title: SALLIE FOLLANSBEE BRIDE OF RUSSELL K. DUNNING
description: Sallie Crowell Follansbee, director of training with Greater Boston Legal Services, was married yesterday to Russell Kenneth Dunning, a partner in the Boston law firm of Cotter & Dunning. The Rev. Dr. Robert E. Luccock performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College in Massachusetts.

title: MARY ORR FIANCEE OF G.M. SATERSON
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Orr of New York and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Catherine Orr, to George Michael Saterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Saterson of Ridgewood, N.J., and Irving, Texas.

title: MT. SINAI NAMES HEAD OF NEW GERIATRICS UNIT
description: The Mount Sinai Medical Center has appointed Dr. Robert N. Butler, a Pulitzer Prize winner who is director of the National Institute on Aging, to head a new department of geriatrics in its School of Medicine.

title: PRETORIA PREMIER DEFEATS HIS RIVAL
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha overcame a challege to his leadership of the governing National Party by its extreme right wing today and effectively ousted his chief rival from the party hierarchy.

title: IRT TRAIN IS DERAILED BY OBJECT ON TRACKS NEAR EAST 116TH ST.
description: A northbound express train on the East Side IRT subway line derailed yesterday near 116th Street after the wheels of the first car struck a piece of metal on the tracks, a Transit Authority spokesman said.

title: Focusing Attention On Hospice Projects
description: Evelyn Philips's recent article ''Hospice Projects: A Debate on L.I.'' deserves special commendation because of its thoroughness and clarity.

title: REAGAN PLANS RISE IN MATERIALS USED FOR NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The Reagan Administration is planning to expand significantly the production of plutonium for a buildup in the United States' arsenal of nuclear weapons, according to Reagan Administration and Congressional officials.

title: TRAFFIC TALK
description: The message from Metro Traffic Control is ominous: ''A traveler's advisory is in effect.'' To every commuting driver who hears that on his radio, the words mean: ''The police say driving in this weather is dangerous.''

title: SALVADOR OPPOSITION URGES U.S. TO BEGIN TALKS
description: The leader of El Salvador's main opposition coalition said today that the United States should not await the ''failure'' of next month's elections before starting talks that could lead to a negotiated settlement of the civil war.

title: Paperback Talk
description: A lady's secret book. She grew up in rural villages close to the burgeoning English industrial city of Birmingham, where her father owned a paint and varnish factory. She attended the Municipal School and took classes at the Birmingham School of Art. She exhibited some 50 paintings locally, and they were considered quite good. With a sister, who was also an artist, she illustrated several books published by London houses. She made brief visits to Scotland, to Dartmoor and to London and, when she was 40, married a London sculptor. Nine years later, she drowned in the Thames while gathering buds from chestnut trees.

title: PRODUCER PLANS FOR 2 OPENINGS
description: EAST HADDAM THERE are about 115 miles between 52d Street in Manhattan and this town, and for a producer to open shows in both places at once is a formidable task.

title: WILLIAMS GUILTY IN BOTH SLAYINGS IN ATLANTA CASE
description: Wayne B. Williams was found guilty tonight of killing two of Atlanta's 28 murdered young blacks and was sentenced to prison for two consecutive life terms.

title: WHEN AN ELECTRICAL PLUG GOES BAD, HERE'S HOW TO REPLACE IT
description: WHEN a lamp or small appliance fails to work after it is plugged in and turned on, the most common cause is a bad plug - or a bad connection at the plug (where the wires connect to the terminals). This assumes, of course, that the bulb has not blown (if it is a lamp), and that the fuse or circuit breaker has not ''popped.''

title: U.S. MARKS DECADE OF PEKING TIES BUT THE CHINESE MAINTAIN SILENCE
description: The United States said today that despite unresolved problems with China over the Taiwan issue, it believed that ''shared global and regional interests'' with Peking far outweighed any of the differences.

title: KATHLEEN BOVERS, R.F. BITTER WED
description: Kathleen McCabe Bovers, daughter of Mrs. Donald Paul Bovers of New York, and the late Mr. Bovers, was married yesterday to Robert Franco Bitter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Ward Bitter of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: LONG FIGHT SEEN ON DUMPING
description: WHEN local and international members of Greenpeace, the marine conservation organization, steamed away from the New Jersey coast earlier this month on their environmental battleship, Rainbow Warrior, it marked only the beginning of what is expected to be a long confrontation among ecologists, ocean dumpers and the Federal Government over the use of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: PHILHARMONIC: DUTOIT LEADS
description: Charles Dutoit, a Swiss conductor who is music director of the Montreal Symphony, led the New York Philharmonic Friday afternoon in Haydn's C Major Symphony, No. 97, Franck's Symphonic Poem, ''Le Chausseur maudit,'' and Stravinsky's ''Petrushka.''

title: REAGAN EXTENDS A HAND SOUTH OF THE BORDER
description: The Reagan Administration acknowledged last week that guns and helicopters will not suffice to keep the nations of the Caribbean basin in the anti-Communist camp. In a long-awaited address, President Reagan outlined a program of Government assistance and investment incentives to ease the economic misery that has created tinder for leftist revolution.

title: Race Drivers' Rebellion Still Being Felt
description: Last year, the Formula One auto-racing season was threatened by a disagreement between the car builders and the rules makers. The differences were patched up over the season, but now there are problems with the drivers.

title: STATUS SOUGHT FOR YONKERS ENCLAVE
description: RICH Yonkers factory owners and merchants used to live on a hill only a stone's throw above their businesses and the bustling Hudson River docks.

title: SQUEEZING THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: Mr. Peterson attacks income-support programs, such as Social Security and health programs for retired elderly workers, and calls for program-assistance reductions that would force them to reduce consumption. He does not deal, however, with the incomes and consumption of those in the top 20 percent of the family-income distribution, whose average income is eight times that of the average income of families in the lowest one-fifth of the distribution.

title: TRIAL JUDGE FOR ABSCAM CASES IN LINE FOR U.S. APPEALS COURT
description: President Reagan is expected to name George C. Pratt, a district judge who conducted several recent Abscam trials, to the Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

title: Matthew Blank to Wed Susan McGuirk
description: The engagement of Susan Marie McGuirk to Matthew Charles Blank, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Terrence McGuirk of Loundonville, N.Y., the future bride's parents. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Allen Blank of New York and the late Mr. Blank.

title: SOBER TONE TO GERMAN ART OF 60'S
description: NEW HAVEN ANYONE expecting a reprise of Pop and Conceptualism in ''German Drawing of the Sixties,'' at Yale University Art Gallery, is in for a surprise. There are affinities, of course, between these 130 works by 11 artists and their chronological counterparts here. But it appears that Germany's cultural revolution was rather more sober than America's, and for very practical reasons.

title: NEW PLAN OFFERED ON 9-MILE A-PLANT
description: The State Public Service Commission has proposed that the utilities building the multibillion-dollar Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear generating station absorb 20 cents of every dollar in future cost overruns.

title: A SCENARIO FOR A DEPRESSION?
description: Benjamin J. Stein is a writer based in Los Angeles with a special interest in economic affairs. By Benjamin J. Stein

title: CRETE
description: To the Editor:

title: Anthony Tops $1 Million
description: Top-seeded Earl Anthony became the first million-dollar winner in the Professional Bowlers Association today after he overcame a slow start and rolled five straight strikes to win the Toledo Trust-P.B.A. national championship.

title: Lost Genius
description: In a very real sense, Russell Baker opens a Pandora's box of moral dilemmas in his column ''Lost Genius'' (Sunday Observer, Jan. 17). In that gray area between abortion and war lie poverty, malnutrition, prejudice toward minority groups, substance abuse, untapped learning potential, child abuse, pockets of society which lack commitment to our children and young people - all of which may be aborting the intellectual and cultural leaders of the next generation. I, too, would hope that our society is not indifferent to its own fate. JUDITH HUNTER, Pittsford, N.Y.

title: REDUCER OF IGNORANCE
description: CHINABOUND A Fifty-Year Memoir. By John King Fairbank. Illustrated. 480 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book. Harper & Row. $20.

title: CONGRESS SORTS ITS FEELINGS AND OPTIONS
description: Representative John E. Porter was greeting voters at a suburban Chicago train station during the recent Congressional break when he was approached by a commuter who wanted to talk about El Salvador. ''We just don't want our boys going there,'' the man told the Illinois Republican.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: New Directions

title: MISS CHEESEBOROUGH'S NIGHT
description: Carl Lewis and Chandra Cheeseborough were selected as the outstanding athletes at the USA/Mobil indoor track and field championships in Madison Square Garden Friday night, and there was no arguing with the designations.

title: 2 LOCAL COMPANIES AID NUTRITION GROUP
description: THE broad range of information on nutrition that confronts the public will be gathered together and disseminated in a more orderly way if a new nationwide organization, the Network for Better Nutrition, fulfills its aims. Two county companies, General Foods and the Continental Baking Company, have been instrumental in founding the group, which is seeking to increase the awareness of the relationship between nutrution and well-being and to help the public understand some key principles of nutrition.

title: Fluoride and Estrogen Found Aid to Brittle Bone of Elderly
description: An experimental combination of fluoride and estrogen will strengthen the brittle bones of older women and prevent most of the fractures that are a disabling affliction of old age, a study shows.

title: WENDY JOSEPHS IS A BRIDE
description: Wendy Karen Josephs of New York and Eric Steven Colman of Plainview, L. I., were married yesterday at Temple Sholom in Flatbush, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Eli Libenson. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milt Josephs of Sherman, Conn., and New York. Mr. Colman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Colman of Plainview, L. I. The couple are doctors of optometry in New York.

title: WOMEN'S FESTIVAL IS SET FOR SATURDAY
description: NEWARK AN ETHNIC food festival, a photography exhibit, a drama about Susan B. Anthony and a mile-long parade in which more than 1,000 people are expected to march will highlight the International Women's Day festival here next Saturday.

title: INVITING AMBIENCE IN NEW HAVEN
description: NEW HAVEN UNLIKE its namesake in New Orleans, New Haven's Bourbon Street, a restaurant, has a lot going for it. The ambience in the Bourbon Street Cafe is agreeable and inviting. A huge space has been artfully divided into several dining sections, with a long bar and cafe tables on the left. As you enter there are a few tables used at lunch and a larger-than-life painted backdrop of jazz musicians. To the right, a raised area that is separated by hanging plants provides a dining space suggesting seclusion, with comfortable banquettes that wrap around the entire side wall. Soft, taped jazz provides a pleasing background, and there is live music each evening from 9 P.M.

title: R.F. BLUE JR. IS FIANCE OF ELIZABETH G. BENNETT
description: Mrs. Clifton Clement Bennett Jr., of Princeton, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Gant Bennett, to Richard Fownes Blue Jr., of Brooklandville, Md.

title: Atlanta Case Goes to the Jury
description: With prosecutors calling him a ''mad dog'' killer and the defense portraying him as a ''pudgy, fat little boy'' incabable of murder, the case of Wayne B. Williams went to an Atlanta jury Friday after 35 days of elaborate and often contradictory testimony.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: ART ''Dorothy'' emigrated from Russia to America as a child just after the turn-of-the-century, grew up, married, and developed a career as a travelling saleswoman. She died in 1960, and what might have been an unremembered life has now been vividly recalled by '' Dorothy's'' daughter, the artist June Wayne.

title: Crete
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WORK OFTHE FOUNDATIONS
description: There are actually two foundations deriving from the Jacobsen brewing empire, the original Carlsberg and the New Carlsberg, founded by J.C. Jacobsen's son Carl, for whom the beer originally was named.

title: AFTER PAPA AND FAULKNER
description: THE MAN WHO LIVED AT THE RITZ By A.E. Hotchner. 286 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $13.95. SWEET CANE By Bruce McGinnis. 251 pp. New York: The Vanguard Press. $11.95.

title: PANTS SUIT AS PROBLEM SOLVER
description: Amid the riotous colors available in spring and summer clothes, black and white stand out. And despite the proliferation of shapes and lengths of skirts, standard trousers are having a renaissance.

title: SAMPSON ADAPTS ON AND OFF COURT
description: LAST April, when spring arrived at the University of Virginia, thousands of students eagerly became part of an annual rite that Thomas Jefferson, the founder, designer and first rector of The University, did not have in mind. Inspired by the warm weather and fueled by the grain alcohol available in garbage can after garbage can, the students celebrated Easters, a five-day weekend in which Mr. Jefferson's Academical Village happily loses its mind.

title: WEST GERMAN PARTY CALLS FOR A NUCLEAR-FREE ZONE
description: A regional convention of the Free Democratic Party called today for the establishment of a nuclear-free zone in Europe, a position contradicting that of Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the party's national chairman.

title: Mailbox; If N.F.L. Strikes, Fans Will Pay
description: To the Sports Editor: After reading the articles by Ed Garvey and John Donlan (''Views of Sport,'' The New York Times, Feb. 14, 1982), I have come to two conclusions. First of all, there will be a strike by the National Football League Players Association.

title: THE STRUGGLE TO KEEP PHYSICAL PLANT IN REPAIR
description: ACHUNK of concrete falls from a bridge over the Saw Mill River Parkway and hits a passing car. A cement truck rumbles over an old bridge in Yonkers, and the old bridge shakes violently.

title: STUDENT EXCHANGES CREATE EXTENDED FAMILIES
description: CHARLES and Syril deQuillfeldt of Amityville have two sons of their own, but they are also ''mom'' and ''dad'' to 13 young men and women in 13 countries.

title: Zermatt
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Confirms Easing Of South Africa Curbs
description: The State Department confirmed today that the Reagan Administration had decided to ease restrictions on trade with South Africa.

title: NEW REGULATIONS ON CONVERSIONS NEAR
description: In recent years there has been widespread agreement that the processing of plans for the conversion of buildings from rentals to cooperatives or condominiums has taken too long in the office of the State Attorney General. The Legislature itself has mandated that the plans be processed in a specific time period - four to six months - so that sponsors could begin their sales.

title: TAPE CONTRADICTS TESTIMONY OF A MAFIA KILLER
description: An admitted Mafia hit man, Aladema (Jimmy the Weasel) Fratianno, has testified that he and other underworld figures met at the La Costa resort and planned to kill Desi Arnaz, the actor and movie producer, because they were angry at the way he portrayed Italian mobsters.

title: FOR WESTCHESTER METEOROLOGISTS, THE SKY'S THE LIMIT
description: DON'T bother listening to tomorrow's weather forecast. When you wake up, March will be roaring into the county like a lion. Jim Witt is sure of it. When you look out your window, take careful note. Is it snowy? Is it rainy? Is it at least cloudy? If so, then Jim Witt was right.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
CELEBRATING LIFE AFTER 89 YEARS
description: TO BE in my 89th year on this planet is more than a celebration, and on looking back through the pages of time -some bright, some faded - I recall having spent 20 days in the hospital in May 1979.

title: A SENSE OF CHAOS PERVADES UNION CITY
description: UNION CITY FROM the neon-lighted bars of the Transfer Station to the steps of City Hall, chaos is the word that people use most often these days to describe the state of affairs in Union City.

title: MCNAMARA COUNCIL ATTACKS U.S. POLICY ON THIRD WORLD AID
description: The Reagan Administration's response to the needs of the third world was challenged in a report published today by the Overseas Development Council, and by the council's chairman, Robert S. McNamara, former President of the World Bank.

title: POP: T-VENUS AT DANCETERIA
description: Venus is clever, starting with its name. This video/film/avantgarde/ rock band, which made its formal New York debut Thursday night at the new Danceteria, may well be on to something.

title: MEMOS ATJ. WALTER THOMPSON
description: J. Walter Thompson had serious worries about its syndication unit well before discovering what it has called ''fictitious entries'' in the unit's computer. In 1979, Stephen M. Salorio, then Thompson's assistant legal counsel and now general counsel, wrote a long report critical in several ways of the unit's management.

title: Philadelphia Celebrates 300th Birthday
description: On an autumn day in 1682, the good ship Welcome carried William Penn and his band of Quaker followers up the Delaware River to found Philadelphia. To mark the 300th anniversary of that event, the city has begun a yearlong festival, Century IV, that will go into high gear in March.

title: INTERAGENCY FIGHT ON UTILITIES LIKELY
description: TRENTON SHORTLY after Barbara A. Curran was sworn in last week as president of the state's Board of Public Utilities, she disavowed knowledge that, just a few hours earlier, a state legislator had held a news conference at which he announced plans to introduce legislation that could strip the board of considerable decision-making power.

title: Miss Ginsburgh, F.A. Grant-Suttie Engaged to Wed
description: Maj. Gen. Robert Neville Ginsburgh, United States Air Force, retired, and Mrs. Ginsburgh of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Forrest Ginsburgh, to Francis Aeneas Grant-Suttie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ian Grant-Suttie of Sumner, Md., and Woodstock, Vt. The wedding is planned for June 1983.

title: TWO BORDER TOWNS FEEL DEVALUING OF MEXICAN PESO
description: The businesses in this border town of 16,000 and the Mexican shoppers from Nogales, Sonora, a city of 200,000 people across the border, are sharing the pain of the devaluation of the peso last week.

title: Shopping for Clothes
description: Considering Montreal's winter weather, who could blame Claude Charron for wearing an extra jacket - or two? Montreal police, for starters. Mr. Charron, the majority leader of Quebec's Assembly, pleaded guilty last week to charges of stealing a $125 sports jacket from Eaton's department store in Montreal.

title: In the Wake of the Vikings
description: New light is being shed on the the Vikings of old with an exclusive United States showing of ''The Viking World,'' at Chicago's Museum of Science and Industry from now through April 25, and a new series of tours, ''Retracing the Viking Route,'' being offered by Icelandair and Scandinavian Airlines System.

title: FERNAND LEGER: POWERED BY THE AMERICAN EXPERIENCE
description: For one reason or another people have trouble in coming to terms with the broad-shouldered art of Fernand Leger, who was born in 1881 and died in 1955. Isolated paintings here and there never fail of their impact, but as to the continuity, the sustained rationale and the ups and downs - if any - of Leger's long career no general achievement has been reached.

title: AMY LAZARUS FINACEE OF JOHN R. MARCHIONI
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank I. Lazarus of Cincinnati, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Louis Lazarus, to John Robert Marchioni, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gerald Marchioni also of Cincinnati.

title: DOROTHY RACKEMANN TO BE JUNE BRIDE
description: Anne Buffington Banks of Lincoln and Racing Beach, Mass., and William Mandell Rackemann of Bourne, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Mandell Rackemann, to George Stewart Young, son of Jane Stewart Young of Dublin, N.H., and John Dexter Young of Marion, Mass.

title: JANICE LIVERANCE AND JOHN T. GELB TO WED IN MAY
description: The engagement of Janice Eve Liverance to John Thirkield Gelb has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Hill, N.C., parents of the future bride. Mr. Gelb is a son of Lueza Thirkield Gelb and Bruce Stuart Gelb, both of New York. A May wedding is planned in Chapel Hill.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am planning a trip to France in May. Four friends wish to fly to Paris and return from Nice or the other way around. Could you advise how to find the lowest air fares and car rentals? - M.H., Glen Cove, N.Y. Answer:Finding the lowest air fare these days takes diligent research and just plain luck. And with Sir Freddie Laker out of the trans-Atlantic market at this time, Icelandair stands alone with a record of consistently lower-priced fares. If you fly from New York to Paris and return from Nice, the round-trip fare on Icelandair will be $573 if you depart before May 14; it increases to $644 on that date. In either direction the flight includes stops in Reykjavik and Luxembourg. Fare restrictions include a minimum stay of seven days and a maximum of 90; tickets must be purchased 14 days in advance of departure.

title: ARTISTS SEARCH FOR WORK SPACE
description: FOR Judy Corrigan, an artist who works primarily with large canvases, inflation and the housing crunch have caused a professional dilemma - one that is increasingly faced by other Connecticut artists.

title: DEVELOPING COUNTRIES DEVELOP SELF-HELP
description: When Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi called for a three-day meeting of developing nations, the conference became known among Indian reporters as the among Indian reporters as the ''South-South'' talks. The term was as accurate as it was whimsical, for Mrs. Gandhi had made it clear that the meeting, which was held last week, was designed to formulate programs for economic among poor and developing nations.

title: NEED FOR DISCLOSURE
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE THAN AN 'HONEST ARGUMENT' OVER THE VIETNAM WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: LEONA GRAUBARD MARRIED TO MILTON LEVY, EXECUTIVE
description: Leona Graubard, widow of Sidney Graubard, was married yesterday to Milton L. Levy of Newton Centre, Mass., audio-visual manager of the marketing group of Honeywell Information Systems in Waltham, Mass.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: RESIDENTS of Port Washington and Roslyn who have sought to influence the direction of waste-disposal methods in North Hempstead Town are formulating questions to ask at a public meeting on Tuesday at 8 P.M. in the East Hills Village Hall. The questions are about a ''refuse-to-energy'' plant proposed by the Power Authority of the State of New York and the town.

title: Koch Makes His Move and Steps On Some Toes
description: Mayor Koch, who heard the tentative rap of opportunity when Governor Carey announced last month that he would not seek re-election, finally answered last week. But as he opened the door to Albany, he opened himself to a new round of criticism.

title: SOLVING THE CUBE FOR COLLEGE CREDIT
description: NEW HAVEN RUBIK'S CUBE is an obsession with six faces, 12 edges, 27 connected boxes, 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 possible configurations and a three-credit seminar at Yale University.

title: SCOTT C. KRAFT FIANCE OF ELIZABETH W. BROWN
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Waring Brown to Scott Corey Kraft has been announced by Miss Brown's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln Brown 3d of Dallas, formerly of Franklin Lakes, N.J. Mr. Kraft is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin E. Kraft of Wichita, Kan. A May 1 wedding is planned.

title: Greenland Makes Waves
description: Greenland, population 49,000 hardy souls on a huge ice-capped island three times the size of Texas, is a long way from Europe, spiritually as well as physically. Last week, Greenlanders sought to increase that distance, voting to seek withdrawal from the European Common Market.

title: THE ARTISTIC RECIPE FOR 'MY DINNER WITH ANDRE'
description: ''The more I heard about it, the less I wanted to get involved,'' said Louis Malle the other day, recalling a time when ''My Dinner With Andre'' was just another strange idea in Wallace Shawn's head. ''I mean, a movie about two people talking?''

title: THE PROMISE AND RISK OF CHARTERS
description: W hen charters go well they go very, very well. But when something goes wrong, they can be horrid. Of the tens of thousands of Americans who go on package vacations by charter flights each year, most return home satisfied. They know that because a charter operator has hired an entire plane and reserved large blocks of hotel rooms, a vacation may cost several hundred dollars less than if a couple used scheduled flights.

title: DESPITE PROBLEMS, P.A.L. STILL A PAL TO YOUTHS
description: Crime has always been a concern of the Police Athletic League. In the years since its founding in 1914, the league grew from a local precinct captain's desire to deter gangs of young delinquents into a citywide athletic program with more than 100,000 participants.

title: BETSY JOSEPHS IS ENGAGED TO CHRISTOPHER D'ANGELO
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Pearson Josephs of Richmond have announced the engagement of Mr. Josephs' daughter, Betsy Hart Josephs, to Christopher Scott D'Angelo, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. D'Angelo of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
WHEN THE STARS ARE CHILDREN
description: PORT JEFFERSON THE star wears braces. Her leading man is about to become an Eagle Scout. A chorus boy is simply that: a baby-toothless 11-year-old whose 4-foot frame can barely muster the strength to lift his more mature 12-year-old dancing partner. And members of the three-child backstage crew are preoccupied with planning how to introduce their mascot, a rubber chicken, on stage.

title: WHEN COUNTIES CARE FOR THE AGED
description: NOT too many years ago, old-age homes, almshouses and psychiatric hospitals were thought of as shameful places. Hidden in remote rural sites or on the outskirts of cities, they were the refuge of last resort for the poorest of the poor.

title: MEGAN FLANAGAN BETROTHED TO PAUL MICHAEL FRITZ
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Flanagan Jr. of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Megan Flanagan, to Paul Michael Fritz, son of Sally Hale of Sharon, Conn., and H. William Fritz of Bozeman, Mont.

title: HARVESTING MUSICALS AT GOODSPEED
description: Steve Lawson, literary manager of the Williamstown Theater Festival, adapted Bernard Pomerance's ''The Elephant Man'' for television. By Steve Lawson ''We rehearsed 'Annie' at Goodspeed for 18 days,'' recalls the musical's director, Martin Charnin. ''And during the first public preview, a hurricane blew out the generator - and all our lights. The performance ended sometime the next day.'' Unperturbed by sour local reviews (''Goodspeed Has an Orphan,'' ''Two Arfs for 'Annie' ''), the Goodspeed Opera House's executive director, Michael Price, waited until ''Annie'' was whipped into shape, then invited the press back. This time, the critics were enthusiastic and ''Annie'' was launched on its now-legendary way. Since that summer of 1976, Goodspeed's 1 percent of ''Annie'' has taken care of many bills and - with true musical-comedy justice - paid for a new generator.

title: JOINING THE CLUB AT SUGAR ISLAND
description: DAVID BIRD is a reporter for The New York Times. By DAVID BIRD

title: LILCO EXPECTED TO ASK NEW RISES FOR SHOREHAM
description: IN addition to the $183 million rate rise that the Long Island Lighting Company requested last week, it is all but certain that Lilco will ask for another increase to cover costs on its Shoreham nuclear power plant, now scheduled to open next year at a cost of $2.49 billion.

title: Old friends/Memory brushes the same years/ Silently sharing the same fears.  - Paul Simon's ''Old Friends''*
description: ''For a long time, I almost needed Paul to be elsewhere,'' says Art Garfunkel. ''He affected me too much, at a time when I really needed to find my own identity. The wish to work together again evolved organically. It was the absence of stuff in the way - your ego, the need for space. I suppose we'd grown up. Paul said, 'Let's sing' and I said 'It's a deal.' ''

title: A SALUTE TO MENUHIN
description: Yehudi Menuhin, whose concert in New York last Sunday was sold out long in advance, will both play and be honored at Symphony Hall in Newark on Friday, which Governor Kean has proclaimed Yehudi Menuhin Day.

title: DIANA KESSLER FIANCEE OF DOUGLAS E. SINGER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kessler of Butler, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diana Marie Kessler, to Douglas Edwin Singer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Singer of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Around the World; Pakistan Arrests 1,400 On Subversion Charges
description: Authorities in Pakistan's Punjab and Sind Provinces have arrested more than 1,400 people in the last two days in a drive on what was described as subversion, officials said today.

title: INDIAN MIGRANTS TO MIDEAST FACE MANY PITFALLS
description: Thirty-one Indian farmers who said they had been lured to Lebanon by promises of jobs, only to be taken to a guerrilla camp, were rescued last month by the Indian Government, which paid their way home.

title: Sarah Jane Smedley Will Be Married To Peter Spiers, Son of Ambassador
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Smedley of Narberth, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Jane Smedley, to Peter Anselm Spiers, son of Ronald I. Spiers, Ambassador to Pakistan, and Mrs. Spiers of Islamabad, Pakistan; Alexandria, Va., and South Londonderry, Vt.

title: SONIA RYKIEL COMES TO TOWN
description: Sonia Rykiel, the petite, pale-skinned Paris designer, describes herself perfectly as she runs her fingers through her flaming red hair. ''I'm modern,'' she says. ''I'm not in advance. I'm of today.'' Certainly in her 20 years of designing, Sonia Rykiel has proved that she is ''of today'' and has earned her solid standing in the ranks of fashion's superstars.

title: SAVING BABIES BEFORE BIRTH
description: When Andrew Percival was born last Dec. 9, he was an eight-pound bundle of medical history. By all appearances, Andrew was a normal newborn, with the reflexes and level of alertness one expects in a nearly term baby (Andrew had been due to arrive on Christmas Day). But two months earlier, prenatal diagnosis had revealed that Andrew was suffering from a severe and probably life-threatening condition: fetal hydrocephalus, in which the fluid-filled regions of the brain, called the ventricles, expand monstrously and push so hard on the brain itself that nerve cells fail to develop. The result of fetal hydrocephalus is usually profound retardation, blindness, cerebral palsy or death. Andrew was saved from this fate by a team of doctors at Prentice Women's Hospital and Maternity Center in Chicago, who treated him when they hoped they had time to salvage some healthy brain tissue. They operated on Andrew while he was still in the womb. Andrew is one of the world's first travelers to cross the brave new frontier of fetal surgery; he and the handful of others who have had similar treatment represent medical advances that seemed unthinkable even 10 years ago. For doctors are discovering that not only can the fragile and previously inviolable environment of the womb be tapped and sounded to provide vital information about the progress of a pregnancy, but that the fetus itself can tolerate correctivesurgery while inside the uterus.

title: LEBANESE ON ISRAELI WATCH: ALL EYES SOUTH
description: The headquarters on the ''western front'' is a sandbagged basement of a bombed-out house and a nearby tent on a concrete slab. They are on the edge of this ancient port in an alley off a side street of houses flattened during the last round of fighting in southern Lebanon.

title: THE CHANCE WE MISSED
description: KENNEDY, KHRUSHCHEV AND THE TEST BAN By Glenn T. Seaborg. With the Assistance of Benjamin S. Loeb. Foreword by W. Averell Harriman. Illustrated. 320 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $16.95.
